column2: The closest match of the season was played last week at the Brooklyn Whist Club between Earle's team and L. Josephson's team. The former won by one trick, as follows.

LONDON, July 18. -- "Tom" Eck, who trains John S. Johnson, the American cycle "flier," says he has offered to match Johnson for a thousand francs against the winner of the Grand Prix de France, ridden on Sunday last. Johnson will attend the meet of the League of American Wheelmen at Louisville, Ky., on the 18th of August, with the world triplet -- the Jellue brothers and Bronnet.

A novel scene was witnessed at the Hudson Boulevard and the Old Bergen Road, Jersey City, yesterday. Three men were lying prone on the roof of a house. Their heads, shoulders, and arms were visible from the street. Each man was armed with a long pole, to the end of which was affixed, at right angles, a paint brush.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the country is convulsed with its present political campaign, there is a class of humanity for whom we, who are of the disfranchised, would like to make an appeal, asking the voters of this country to exercise the power of the ballot to alleviate some of the existing wrong's by providing a remedy for what is now a crying evil.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 18. -- The third dinner and dance of the season were held at the Kebo Valley Club to-night Everyseat was filled at the long L-shaped table, and the large crowd of society people at the dance, which followed, made the affair a most brilliant one.

From The North American Review. As everybody knows, there exist in Great Britain and America thousands of people who declare the stage to be a most wicked and immoral institution. I have on the subject a rather pleasant reminiscence which illustrates how the Anglo-Saxons can combine the spirit of morality with the spirit of business.

From The Quarterly Review. In Germany, which to-day we regard as the home of the university par excellence, the educational movement, strangely enough, was slow to establish itself. The low state of civilization, the lack of political centralization, the disintegration of civic life, together with the fact that the bulk of the German students, touched by the intellectual revival, was drawn off to Paris or Bologna, told severely against the production of great national studia.

Commissioner Emery of the Brooklyn Health Department urged the Aldermen to pass a resolution giving him the power to transfer the sum of $5,000 in his department in order that he might appoint some Inspectors to look after the dumps in the city.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 18. -- Samuel Brown's Brownie, a new half-rater, built by Walter K. Brown, distinguished herself in her maiden race this afternoon for the Capt. Joseph Elsworth Cup, winning the prize on her allowance against several crack yachts. It was the second race of the season under the auspices of the New-Jersey Athletic Club, sailed on Newark Bay.

DETROIT, Mich., July 18. -- The New-York trotter. Baron Crisp, has broken down, cannot start for the big trotting race here next Tuesday. John Kelly, the Fleetwood trainer, who has him, says the accident occurred while giving Crisp a workout at Grand Rapids just before he was shipped here. The trotter hit a tendon of his front leg, cutting it so badly that he will probably be thrown out of training for the season.

From The Fortnightly Review. In and about the year 1688, thirty-six years after the first landing of Van Riebeek and his handful of men, there arrived at the Cape a body of French Protestant refugees, numbering in all, men, women, and children, somewhat under 200 souls.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 18. -- To-day's game was a pitchers' battle. Five consecutive hits in the fourth inning won the game for New-York. Dexter's work behind the bat was the feature of the contest. Score:

From The Fortnightly Review. There is one modern philosopher who appears to me to have given us a satisfactory formula of the ludicrous. That philosopher is Schopenhauer, unquestionably one of the most profound and penetrating intellects of this century, however we may account of his system as a whole.

From The Nineteenth Century. Look at the case of John Leech, which may be taken as typical. When Leech got into his Dutch house at Kensington, he thought he had settled down to an existence of unalloyed happiness. But the house had one terrible defect, soon to be discovered. It stood where it was encircled by streets and mews infested by organ grinders.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The address of Chairman Hinkley of the Democratic State Committee of New-York, recommending a waiting attitude for the present on the part of the leaders of the organization, is interpreted here by those familiar with the conditions in New-York as a pretty direct hint of a bolt.

NIAGARA FALLS, July 18. -- The delegates to the State Bankers' Convention, spent this morning inspecting the power plants of the Niagara Falls Hydraulic Power and Manufacturing Company and the Niagara Falls Power Company. The third session of the convention met at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon and adopted the following resolutions:

The home of B. F. Fischer, the lawyer, at 220 East Seventy-eighth Street, was robbed by two men about noon a week ago yesterday of $110 in money and jewelry valued at $300, but not until Filday night were two men arrested on suspicion of having committed the theft. In the meantime no information about the robbery was made public.

From Longman's Magazine. We were shown into a large, handsomely furnished room, with a splendid yellow carpet, but without a book, or work, or any sign of life and occupation. The little wife soon appeared, dressed in European dress; in fact it is only in the royal harem that the native costume is kept up.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 18. -- Articles of impeachment were filed with the Board of Aldermen last night by two members of the Board of Councilmen against the members of the Board of Public Safety, Col. R. J. Tilford, D. E. O'Sullivan, and Charles Wilson.

WASHINGTON, July 18. -- The franking privileges enjoyed by the silver Democrats in Congress have turned the scale in favor of this city as the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee. Senator Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the committee, to-day completed arrangements for the occupancy of two floors of an up-town hotel, now vacant, by the committee.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 18. -- Capt. G. W. Loyd is by all odds the most ardent Populist in this village. He has been making preparations for many weeks to attend the St. Louis Convention. It occurred to the Captain, when the silver agitation began in earnest, to have a painting made of Peter Cooper. Capt. Loyd cherishes the memory of Peter Cooper, and often quotes him as an authority on monetary affairs.
A murder was committed in Brooklyn last night at a Democratic meeting.

LONDON, July 18. -- No one can complain of the tone of English press comment on Lord Salisbury's unexpected arbitration speech and on the blue book of diplomatic correspondence on the subject which is publicly summarized to-day. Characteristically enough, Englishmen are more interested in the smart gladiatorial display between Mr. Olney and Lord Salisbury than in the fact that really no definite headway has been made toward a settlement of the question in dispute.

From Macmillan's Magazine. There are few important libraries in Europe that do not possess either Celtic manuscripts or Latin manuscripts glossed with Celtic words. And as every one knows, the Book of Kells, (generally conceded to be the most beautiful book in the world,) though in the Latin language, was penned and illustrated by Gaelic monks, probably before the tenth century of our era.

Workingmen in various occupations were interviewed yesterday as to their views on the question of the unlimited coinage of silver. There were found those who had not yet made up their minds upon the subject and were waiting to hear the arguments of the respective advocates of free silver and of the single gold standard, and there were those who did not seem to understand the question that is agitating the country.

One of the commonest bits of claptrap of the silverites, much resorted to by Mr. BRYAN in his speeches, is the claim or the assumption that gold and silver coined at the ratio of 16 to 1 are "the money of the Constitution." BRYAN in his Kansas City speech called it the "coinage of the Constitution."

From Leslie Stephens in The National Review. Holmes's boyishness appears in his quaint love of athletic sports, more eccentric in America when he wrote than it seems to be at present -- his love of boxing and rowing and walking. We can almost believe the autocra when he says that he was tempted to put on the gloves with the "Benicia Boy," though that hero was of twice his weight and half his age.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 18. -- The office seeker has begun to pour his importunities into Mr. Bryan's ear. The first comer boarded the Bryan train at some point in Nebraska and made his application for a Federal position. It was only a humble place that he wanted. He wore high boots into which his trousers were tucked.
John Renovia made a desperate effort yesterday to kill Vitelle Devito of 329 East One Hundred and Ninth Street, whose wife, Maria, cut him in the throat when he attempted to assault her last Monday.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 18. -- To-day's game was a pitchers' battle. Five consecutive hits in the fourth inning won the game for New-York. Dexter's work behind the bat was the feature of the contest. Score:

Salem (Ill.) Telegram to The St. Louis Globe-Democrat. Coming up from Centralia Mr. Bryan and his escort of newspaper men found themselves on the platform at Odin with an hour and forty minutes to wait for the train to Salem, only six miles away. Mr. Morrison, the magnate of the town, came with a lantern and took Mr. and Mrs. Bryan to his fine house to wait.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 18. -- Lawrence J. McParlin, delegate at large and National Secretary of the People's Party, was interviewed to-night just as he was boarding the train for St. Louis. He said:

BANGOR, Ireland, July 18. -- This was the second day of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club's regatta. The course for the big cutters was the same as that sailed over yesterday from off the battery off Bangor, round the flagboats off Carrickfergus Castle. Blackhead, and the South Briggs, and back to the starting line, three times round.

The violence and disorder in Cleveland with which the police of the city and the militia of Ohio have had to deal during the past week show that striking laborers have failed to learn by experience a most important lesson regarding the rights of others.

From The National Review. "It is a bad road, and no man goes in the desert alone," said they. But I believed less in robbers and more in the immunity of the Briton, especially if mounted on so uncanny a steed as a bicycle. " Is it bad because the sand is deep? " " The sand is deep," said they.

There is on view in London this month a rich and varied collection of recently discovered relics of ancient Egypt. They were all found by the small band of archeologists who carry out investigations with the aid of the Egyptian Exploration Fund. From December to March is the usual period of labor, for then the weather is favorable and the heat not distressing.

William Steinway announced yesterday that, in compliance with a rule he has followed since he was first appointed a Rapid Transit Commissioner in 1891, he will devote to charity the $5,000 awarded to him by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for his services in the last year.

Meagre details were received in Hoboken yesterday of the fate of Mrs. Emma Beuner, a former resident of Hoboken, and her three children. The bodies of all four were found, bound together, in the waters of Galveston Bay, Texas, and an investigation showed that the mother, tired of a long struggle against adversity, had taken this means of ending her troubles, taking her children with her.
If the farmer and the workingman will apply their common sense to this silver policy for a time and then compare notes, neither can be misled by the demagogues who appeal to them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I take the liberty of urging upon you the necessity for a third ticket this year, so far as the Presidential field is concerned. Mr. Bryan will, in my judgment, either defeat Mr. McKinley or come perilously near it if there is not a sound-money Democratic ticket in the field.
Cornelius Vanderbilt, Sr., gained in strength yesterday. The bulletin of the morning was:

Whatever honest-money men may think of a third ticket, of voting for McKINLEY, or of not voting for President, there is one office as to which they can all make their votes effective -- that of Representative in Congress. One has only to realize what the next House may or may not do to make the talk of deserting the polls on election day seem like a sort of treason.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 19. -- The Rev. George Williams, who left here last Monday, failed to return to-day and fill his pulpit. Mr. Williams notified his wife by postal card Friday, after five days' absence, that he would return Saturday.

Frank Whitman Ring. Dr. Frank Whitman Ring of 101 Park Avenue, who died in New-Haven, Conn., Friday, was born in Portland, Me., in 1848, and at the age of thirty was graduated from Bowdoin College. He came to this city and entered the Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital as an assistant to Dr. C.A. Agnew. He subsequently held the position of assistant surgeon, surgeon, and director of the hospital.

The author of this volume presents his work to the public with a modesty that has its charm, although the interest of the expedition he chronicles can well make it stand on its own merits. No extraordinary hardships were encountered, nor were great feats of endurance accomplished; but the fact remains that specimens of vegetation new to scientists were found, and land heretofore untrodden was visited.

Two trolley cars of the Nassau Railroad Company, in Brooklyn, jumped the track yesterday because they were being driven at an excessive rate of speed. In one accident seven persons were injured; in the other only one was seriously hurt.

Daniel Wandell, an old farmer, and lifelong resident of Staten Island, who resides on the old homestead on the Richmond Road at Concord, has found a "pot of gold." The discovery was made accidentally last Friday, when a number of Italians were digging a hole on the road beside the fence for a trolley pole for the Midland Electric Company.

LONDON, July 19. -- The Daily News will to-morow publish an interview with James Bryce, M.P., the well-known author of "The American Commonwealth," on the subject of Anglo-American arbitration. Mr. Bryce's views on the question are optimistic.

Three great life insurance companies whose home offices are in this city have policies in force amounting to more than $2,580,000,000. The similar engagements of the twenty-six principal American life companies exceed $5,881,000,000. The grand total of American life insurance policies in force, those of the assessment companies and orders included, is reported to be $13,048,452,664.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 19. -- Henry C. Payne, Wisconsin's member of the National Republican Committee, who is to have charge of the Chicago headquarters, yesterday, among other things, said:

From The Chicago Inter Ocean. German turners of Chicago have inaugurated a movement looking to the establishment of a National athletic park to be owned by and managed at the direction of Congress. All the great amateur athletic associations of the country shall, as it is planned, hold their meets there, and an annual international contest similar to the Olympic games is to be arranged.

The little census of the opinions or workingmen which we gave yesterday morning is full of meaning and on the whole extremely encouraging. There were 107 addressed in all. Of those who expressed decided opinions regarding the main issue, forty were frankly for the gold standard and thirty-eight for silver.

CANTON, Ohio, July 19. -- Major McKinley will go to Cleveland to-morrow, and it is not probable he will return to Canton before Thursday afternoon. His promise to go to Cleveland to take part in the centennial exercises is of long standing. The occasion is one of dignity and importance, the purpose of it being to observe in a fitting way the one hundredth anniversary of the settlement of the Western Reserve.

We observe a general disposition upon the part of Republican organs, both speakers and newspapers, to have the Democrats drop partisanship this year and join with the Republicans in protecting the safety, honor, and welfare of the country. What we fail to observe is any symptom of a desire on the part of the Republicans to drop partisanship.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 19. -- Mr. and Mrs. Bryan attended services at the First Presbyterian Church this morning and listened to a sarmon by a young minister eulogistic of the Democratic nominee. This is the churh in which Mr. Bryan teaches a Bible class, but he omitted his duties in that connection to-day. There was no unusual number of people present.

Some day this week, possibly Wednesday, Mark A. Hanna, Chairman of the Republican National Committee and manager in chief of McKinley's campaign, is expected to reach this city. When he comes there will be some one in town who knows what sort of a headquarters will be opened here and when business will begin.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 19. -- The will of Mrs. Harriet Beecher Stowe was admitted to probate Saturday afternoon. She leaves all her property to her three children, the Rev. Charles E. Stowe, Miss Harriet Stowe, and Miss Eliza Stowe, the son to have one-third and the remainder to he held in trust for the support of her daughters.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 19. -- When Bryan made his free-silver speech in Congress, in 1893, his friend, E.G. Wilson, of Topeka, wrote him a letter warning him against the Populist Party. Wilson to-day made public Bryan's reply, in which he threatened to bolt the Democratic Party if it should declare for sound money. Bryan said:

WASHINGTON, July 19. -- The change in Japanese Ministers, which has just been made, brings to mind an interesting chapter of diplomatic history which has never been published Mr. Kurino, the retiring Minister, as is well known, maintained the most friendly personal and official relations with Mr. Gresham during that gentleman's tenure of office.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: There is a growing conviction that the coming election will be closely and aggressively contested. The silver men propose to open the campaign in the heart of the gold stronghold, which is New-York City. All sound-money men should follow the example of ex-Secretary Whitney and ex-Gov. Flower, and place themselves on a higher plane than that of following a party.

LONDON, July 19. -- The Daily News will to-morow publish an interview with James Bryce, M.P., the well-known author of "The American Commonwealth," on the subject of Anglo-American arbitration. Mr. Bryce's views on the question are optimistic.

NEW-BRIGHTON, S.I., July 19. -- While John Meagher, a fireman in the Orford Copper Works, was at work last night, he drew the refuse from a furnace and turned the hose on it. The molten matter exploded with great force, knocking him to the ground and inflicting painful injuries. The doctor who attended him said that the injuries would prove serious.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19. -- A curious case of loss of memory was made public yesterday by the identity of the victim being discovered. A well-dressed young man accosted a policeman on the street March 6, and told him that he was lost and had no recollection of who he was or where he came from.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Altgeld, Tillman, and Bryan represent fiatism, repudiation, and anarchy, but not the political principles of Jefferson and Jackson, of Hill and Cleveland.

If any one wanted to have the weather made to order yesterday he probably had his wants satisfied. Extra warm clothing, extra light clothing, and umbrellas were out of order. It was a moderate and a satisfactory day.

At the Eighteenth Street Methodist Episcopal Church last evening a large and fashionable audience asembled to hear the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John W. Campbell, deliver sermon on "Vacations at Home and Abroad." Dr. Campbell is about to take a vacation from his pastoral duties and chose a subject appropriate to the season.
A dispute between two brothers as to which should carry a baseball mask yesterday afternoon ended in the death of the elder at the hands of the younger.

From The Providence Journal. It has often been pointed out that one result of the American system of selecting Presidents has been the choice by the nominating conventions of men of little repute as statesmen or even as active politicians. The Electoral College has, of course, taken an entirely different position than what the makers of the Constitution expected it would take.

We have remarked heretofore that, although the sanitary movement for the suppression of bovine tuberculosis and the purification of the milk supply was checked in this State by the Platt Legislature at its recent session, it has not been checked elsewhere. In Pennsylvania the cities of Pittsburg and Allegheny have taken measures, as we pointed out some time ago, to prevent the sale of milk from tuberculous cows within their boundaries.

The delegates from this city and Brooklyn to the Populist National Convention at St. Louis will start for the convention city, this morning at 10 o'clock, over the Baltimore and Ohio Road. There are twelve delegates from New-York City, and ten from Brooklyn, and they expect that a few from Jersey City will join the party.

More workingmen were interviewed yesterday as to their opinions of the free silver question, and the Anarchist, John Most, who believes in the abolition of all government and of both gold and silver as mediums of exchange, said positively that under the present conditions of society, commerce, and industry gold was the only possible standard.

The McKinley League, through President George E. Matthews and John E. Milholland, Chairman of the Committee on Organization, has issued the first circular of the campaign appealing for funds The claim is made that the league is engaged in an especial fight for sound money, and it asks funds for this purpose.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 20 -- The State Railroad Commission has been notified by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad that it intends to comply with the mileage-book law amendment passed by the last Legislature. The board had some correspondence with the officials of the road, as, under the old law, they had refused to comply with the recommendations of the board, claiming they were complying with the law so far as was necessary.
If Cornelius N. Bliss will accept the position of Treasurer to the National Repubcan Committee, the committee will be glad of his service.

Steps were taken yesterday to unite the principal National banks of this city in a movement to protect the Government gold reserve. Recent large withdrawals of gold from the Sub-Treasury for shipment to Europe, the disposition manifested in certain financial quarters to hoard the yellow metal, and the panicky condition of the stock market have caused some serious discussions among observant and public-spirited financiers within the past few days.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 20 -- Gen. Moses Cleveland of the Connecticut Land Company landed at the mouth of the Cuyahoga, on the shore of Lake Erie, on July 22, 1796, and the people of Cleveland date their history from this event. Great preparations have been made for a fitting celebration of the city's centennial.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 20 -- Arrangements were completed to-day for an open-air performance of "As You Like It" on the lawn of the Casino Friday evening, Aug. 7.

SPOKANE, Washington, July 20 -- The sun is hidden from view at this point by the smoke of forest fires that are raging in the mountains of this vicinity. Miners and prospectors are flocking down into the valleys by hundreds, many of them having lost all they possessed.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Secret Service Division of the Treasury Department has issued a circular, calling attention to the circulation of counterfeit one-dollar and five-dollar bills of the series of 1891. The bills are of poor workmanship and can be easily detected.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 -- George F. Washburn of Massachusetts, one of the members of the Populist Executive Committee, is out in a statement unequivocally declaring for the indorsement of Bryan, in which he says:

The men of Brooklyn who believe in a gold standard are beginning to let themselves be known. Three prominent Democrats yesterday came out in favor of the gold standard. They are Thomas H. McGrath of the Twenty-third Ward, Michael E. Moore of the Twenty-second Ward, and Dr. Harry Eaton, Third Vice President of the Democratic General Committee, a resident of the Sixth Ward.

Among the wild silverites who oppose the "Indorsement" of BRYAN and SEWALL at the coming St. Louis Convention is CHARLES A. TOWNE of Minnesota, and he is himself talked of for Presidential candidate by some of the "middle of the road" Populists. Mr. TOWNE is, like BRYAN, a "brilliant orator" who moves multitudes by the power of his eloquence.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 20 -- When Mr. Bryan entered his library this morning to begin the day's work he was appalled by the formidable array of letters and telegrams lying on his desk. Hard work on the part of Mrs. Bryan and himself and Mr. Schwind, the temporary private secretary, has not made much of a hole in the small mountain of correspondence.
Senator Cannon, of Utah was in this city for a few days last week, on his way to Boston, where he had business.

ST. LOUIS July 20 -- Senator Peffer, while favoring fusion, is disposed to back up Taubeneck's scheme, whereby the Presidential Electors chosen would select the candidates for whom they should vote after the November election. Mr. Peffer has this to say:

If the Populist Convention at St. Louis shall fail to indorse the nomination of BRYAN, it will not be because BRYAN'S views and purposes differ from those the Populists profess. It will be solely because the Populist managers are greedy for spoils and power, and mean to get all they can.

ST. Louis, July 20 -- Thomas M. Patterson of Denver, the Chairman of the Colorado delegation, to the Populist National Convention, arrived here yesterday, and last night issued on address. In which he urges the nomination of Bryan and Sewall.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 -- If there has been any doubt in the minds of conservative Democrats that the Chicago Convention made a declaration of Populist principles and named a Populist for President, the utterances of the leading men in the approaching convention ought t- settle all doubt.

What we are accustomed to call the "Presidential election" is a National election only in the sense that all the States which compose the Nation now vote on the same day for Presidential Electors, but that is wholly a matter of State regulation which has been brought into uniformity as to the time and manner of "appointing" Electors by the independent action of the several States.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 -- So many of the Populist and silver party people as have arrived in St. Louis either to nominate new candidates for President and Vice President or indorse the Chicago nominees are fair representatives of the cause they speak for.

BALTIMORE, July 20 -- Capt. Weise of the steamship America, which arrived to-day from Jamaican ports, brought news of a serious railroad accident on the new Jamaica railroad, in which seventeen persons lost their lives and twenty-two others were severely injured.
BATH, Me., July 20 -- Arthur Sewall, the Democratic candidate for Vice President, speaking of the outlook in this State with respect to the September election, said:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 20 -- The funeral of ex-Gov. William E. Russell to-day was a semi-State, affair. The State and city offices in Boston and Cambridge were closed, and an immense crowd of people participated in the exercises. President Cleveland and many notable people were in attendance.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service has received advices from Sanitary Inspector Caminero, giving the sanitary condition of Santiago de Cuba for the week ended July 4 last.
MANITOU, Col., July 20 -- The committee of bolting Republicans who have been in session here for several days late this afternoon made public the following manifesto:

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The withdrawal to-day from the New-York Sub-Treasury of $3,706,300 in gold has weakened the feeling of confidence expressed Saturday by Treasury officers that the gold reserve was in no immediate danger of being raided. At the close of business this afternoon the reserve stood at $89,761,336,91.

A correspondent who is engaged in the manufacture of mechanics' tools and other hardware asks us to publish the official statement of imports and exports since the enactment of the McKinley tariff, and to show also the course of international trade in cutlery and other finished products of iron and steel.

Tammany proposes to indorse the Bryan and Sewall ticket, despite the advice of some of its most prominent men, and it will probably pave the way to place itself on record this week. A call for a meeting of the Executive Committee, to be held either Thursday or Friday afternoon, will probably be issued to-day.
Two pieces of news that are mutually illuminating appear at the same time. One comes in the form of a Hongkong dispatch to The London Times and the other in a press dispatch from San Francisco.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 20 -- William Sands was arrested here to-day for counterfeiting. He is one of the Jane Doe gang recently arrested in Jersey City, N.J.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 20 -- The weather to-day was all that could be wished for. Bicycle riders and fine turnouts were numerous on the Ocean Drive, and as it was "just right" for bathing, a large number of the hotel guests took advantage of it.

BAIREUTH, July 20 -- The usual large audience assembled this afternoon in the Fests-pielhaus to hear "Die Walkure," the second part of Wagner's tetralogy, "Der Ring des Nibelungen." The performance began at 4 o'clock and was concluded at about 10, with an hour's interval for refreshments after the second act.

The three chess players that the United States has sent to take part in the Nuremberg chess tourney, which began yesterday, will doubtless be able to acquit themselves with credit in their struggle with the European masters.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A number of representatives of railroad companies throughout the United States are expected in this city during the week to have a conference with the Postmaster General on his recent order compelling payment of postage on mail matter exchanged between railroads pertaining to railroad and personal matters.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- Marcus A. Hanna, spent a busy day in Chicago with his fellow-members of the Executive Committee of the Republican Party and prominent Republicans, who wished to confer with the campaign managers.

The house of William H. Van Kleeck of 335 West Forty-fifth Street, who has a banking office at 3 Broad Street, was entered some time on Sunday night by burglars and ransacked from attic to cellar The family Is out of trown.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The announcement is made to-day that, as a result of the conference last week between Mark Hanna, Candidate McKinley, and Chairman Babcock of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, the scope of the work of the committee is to be widened greatly in the coming campaign.

LONG BEACH, N.Y., July 20 -- Commissioner De Witt to-day made the following statement with reference to the work that is being done by the sub-committee which is drafting the Greater New-York charter:

Policeman John J. Bannon of the Mercer Street Police Station was nearly mobbed by a number or indignant-citizens last night at Fourteenth Street and Broadway for assaulting Michael J. Gilder of 777 Second Avenue, whom he had placed under arrest.

As I go about town and listen to the discussion of the silver question which proceeds unceasingly, night and day, men of all sorts contributing to it, I am more and more appreciative of the force of a remark made to me a short time ago by a New-York newspaper man. He said:

On the occasion of its one hundred and eighth celebration of Independence Day the Tammany Society listened in its hall to speeches delivered by Democrats of prominence, all of whom spoke for sound money. Congressman JOSIAH PATTERSON of Tennessee, one of the most earnest and courageous opponents of the 16 to 1 craze, said:
CINCINNATI, July 21 -- The Reds won two good games from the New-York team to-day. In the first game Dwyer's superb work in the box, assisted by errorless support, shut the visitors out.

ST. Louis, July 21 -- About 1,400 Populists will meet in National Convention to-morrow at noon. To predict with positiveness what the convention will do would be rash. None of the leaders, if it is proper to say that there are any leaders, can tell surely, with the convention only twelve hours away. With the incoming of delegates the lack of organization, harmony, and programme becomes more and more apparent.

KEY WEST, Fla., July 21 -- Gen. Roloff arrived in this city to-night on the steamer Mascotte. The entire Cuban population turned out to receive him. The city was gayly decorated with Cuban and American flags.

Policeman Tighe of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station Monday afternoon found a vagrant asleep on the stoop of the house at 56 West Thirty-third Street. Tighe tried to awaken the man, but was only able to do so after employing heroic methods.

LONG BRANCH, July 21 -- Invitations are out for a children's pink dance at the Scarboro Hotel to-morrow night. The children will be required to appear in pink dresses or wear pink decorations of some kind.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- Senator Jones, Gov. Stone of Missouri, and all the Democrats who can be brought here to exert influence upon the Populists to induce them to accept he Chicago platform and candidate, have been at work hard enough, but it does not appear that they have demonstrated any great political ability.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- The National Committee of the National Silver Party met this morning at the Lindell Hotel, but after a brief session a recess was taken until 1 o'clock, when a secret session was held in Dr. Mott's room in the same hotel. George P. Keeney of California presided.

The plan of making public the several "chapters" of the draft of a charter for the Greater New-York as fast as they have been prepared by the sub-committee is an eminently proper one. The success of the work of the commission will depend, upon public approval, and it is desirable that the public should be as promptly and completely informed upon what is proposed as possible in order that opinion may be intelligently shaped.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- The National Convention of the Populist Party elected Senator Marion Butler of North Carolina for temporary Chairman. He is an anti-Bryan man. The committee also attended to other business preliminary to the convention. Chairman Taubeneck presided and about fifty members were present.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- If the Republican managers have any lingering doubts that the money question is to overshadow all others in the campaign, they need only to visit the Treasury to have their minds set right. The mail of several officers of the Treasury has grown steadily to enormous proportions through the desire of men in all parts of the country to acquire information bearing on the silver craze.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Sound-money Democrats should put a third ticket in the field, not only as a protest against the revolutionary methods and programme of the Chicago Convention, and to keep in line the honest Democratic sentiment of the country, but, more important still, to present to the country a definite, rational, and practical programme of currency reform, without which the permanent maintenance of the gold standard is well-nigh impossible.

PITTSBURG, July 21 -- The announcement that Local Assembly No. 300 had withdrawn from the Knights of Labor, taking upward of 6,000 members from that organization, was a fruitful topic of discussion in labor circles to-day.

A meeting of the State Democracy's Reform Committee will be held this evening at 8 o'clock, at the Reform Club. What the committee may do, and particularly what action it may take looking to the nomination of a third ticket, is largely speculative. The committee has not held a meeting since the National Convention, and the members have not had an opportunity to discuss the situation.

BOSTON, July 21 -- The father of Lester H. Monck, the passenger on board the barkentine Herbert Fuller, who is detained at Halifax, is a large real estate owner in this city. The young man is a member of the sophomore class of Harvard University. Owing to ill health he was sent on this voyage to recuperate.

NEWPORT, July 21 -- A reception was given to-day at Heartsease, the Kay Street villa of Mrs. C. Nicholas Beach of Hartford, who entertained in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L.F. Robinson of New-York, the latter her daughter, who were married in Hartford a month ago. As Miss Beach, Mrs. Robinson was a belle in society here, and the occasion to-day practically was a wedding reception for her Newport friends.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- The silver convention will be a small side show, and will last but one day, unless Senator Stewart, who is to address it, should remember that he is not speaking in the Senate. Its mission will have been accomplished when it shall have adopted a platform with one free coinage plank and indorsed the nominations of Bryan and Sewall.
There is a merry war up in Herkimer and Oneida Counties, according to politicians who came to town yesterday.
The Executive Committee of the Brotherhood of Tailors has decided to order a general strike this morning, and between 10,000 and 12,000 men and women are to be idle.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 21 -- The monument which was erected near the grave of John Brown, the noted abolitionist, who was executed at Charlestown, Va., on Dec. 2, 1859, was unveiled here this afternoon in the presence of 1,500 persons, and the Stars and Stripes were unfurled and floated in the breeze from the top of a liberty pole, 100 feet high, which stands near the monument.

Larchmont was like fairyland last night. The grounds around the clubhouse were beautifully illuminated and the yachts in the harbor burned colored fire, flashed their searchlights, and sent up rockets and added much to the splendor of the scene.

We have already remarked, in speaking of the official correspondence upon arbitration, how the legal habits of a lifetime are apt to break through diplomatic reservations and how much more contentious in tone, consequently, Mr. OLNEY'R letters are than the "good, easy" diplomacy of Lord SALISBURY.
ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- George F. Washburn of Massachusetts, Chairman of the Eastern division of the National Committee of the Peopled Party, makes this forecast:

BALTIMORE, July 21 -- The Merchants and Miners' Transportation Company, which operates lines of steamships between this port, Savannah, Boston, and Providence, all of which call at Norfolk and Old Point, Va., to-day met the cut of 33 1-3 per cent. on freight and passenger traffic by the Seaboard Air Line and Southern Railway Company and their steamship allies.

The intrinsic importance of the trial of JAMESON and his raiders is enhanced to the public apprehension by the employment of an unusual mode of investigation -- the "trial at bar." This is stated by the authorities on English criminal procedure as a survival of the universal mode of trial before the writ of "nisi prius" was given by statute.

Earnest and effective work was done by the down-town bankers yesterday in maturing the plan to increase the Treasury gold reserve by turning over several million dollars to the Sub-Treasury in exchange for legal-tender notes.
BAYPORT, L.I., July 21 -- Hiram Weeks dropped dead at his home in this village this morning. He was a retired sea Captain, known far and wide as the hero of many whaling voyages.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Much satisfaction was expressed at the Treasury Department to-day when the news came that the leading banks of New-York had taken steps to add a large amount of gold to the Government reserve. The fact that the withdrawals from the New-York Sub-Treasury for the day amounted to only $164,100 strengthens the feeling here that the action of the banks will have a wholesome effect.
Joseph Wesley Harper, who was, until two years ago, a member of the publishing firm of Harper Brothers, Franklin Square, died yesterday of heart failure at his residence, 562 Fifth Avenue.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 21 -- Mrs. Josephine Hoey, widow of John Hoey, died at Hollywood to-night, after a long and lingering illness, aged seventy-eight years. Three children, Fred and George Hoey and Mrs. C. Russell Hone survive her. The late John Shaw Hoey and William Hoey were Mrs. Hoey's children by her first husband, Mr. Russell.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- Notwithstanding the superabundance of platforms which individual delegates are prepared to unload upon the Committee on Resolutions, it is probable that the Nebraska platform adopted in Omaha July 4, 1892, will form the basis of the committee's recommendations. This was the platform which ex-Gov. St. John of Kansas attempted to force upon the Prohibitionists in Pittsburg last June and which, being rejected, led to the bolt of the free-silver Prohibitionists.

Commodore John Moller, who retired from the business of refining sugar with several million dollars to his credit, and who was last year financially interested with Manager A.M. Palmer in the production of "Little Christopher," at the Garden Theatre, yesterday closed an agreement by which he becomes the manager and financial backer of Edward Harrigan.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 21 -- A high percentage of humidity, with the thermometer at 89 in camp, has made it uncomfortable for the soldiers to-day. The sick list is very small, only two prostrations having been reported this morning. There is also one case in the hospital, but the man's symptoms are not serious.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 -- Sound-money men Everywhere may feel confident that this convention does not represent sane people; that it is a more eflorescence, the symptom of a disturbance: but there is no doubt that it is the indication of a disease that must be reached by the proper application of powerful remedies.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 21 -- The will of Henry Peek De Graaf of Oscawana, Westchester County, was this morning filed for probate in the Westchester County Surrogate's office here. He was one of the well-known firm of De Graaf Taylor, furniture dealers in New-York. His estate is estimated to be worth $1,000,000, though no schedule has been filed.

A young man, about twenty-five years old, well dressed, with smooth face, dark hair and eyes, and soft hands, committed suicide early yesterday morning by taking carbolic acid at 451 West Thirtysixth Street.

There is furious boasting by the Bryan people that they are going to stampede the country as their candidate stampeded the Chicago Convention. There is some unreasoning, uncalculating fear among the believers in the gold standard that this can be done. But the facts show no probability of it.

Michael J. Gilder of 777 Second Avenue, the waiter who is said to have been clubbed Monday night by Policeman John J. Bannon of the Mercer Street Station, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of intoxication and disorderly conduct. None of the people who had witnessed the clubbing was present in court to act as a witness for the prisoner.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 21 -- The Atlanta Evening Journal announces that it will support the Chicago ticket.
CINCINNATI, July 21 -- The Reds won two good games from the New-York team to-day. In the first game Dwyer's superb work in the box, assisted by errorless support, shut the visitors out.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 21 -- Newport defeated New-Haven to-day in a rather ragged game. The score:

CITY ISLAND, July 21 -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Vision, F.H. Benedict; Charlietta, W. H. Hlggins; Helvetia, C. O'D. Islin; Parthenia, Stephen J. Roach; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenburg; Alicia. H.M. Flagler; Dusquesne, T.R. Hostetter; Marietta, Harrison B. Moore; Gladys, A.W. Thompson, and Nereid, Albert J. wise, Schooner Agnes, J. Norton Winslow, and yawl Argo, Dr. Delano Fitzgerald.

KEY WEST, Fla., July 21 -- Gen. Roloff arrived in this city to-night on the steamer Mascotte. The entire Cuban population turned out to receive him. The city was gayly decorated with Cuban and American flags.

Every advocate of the fifty-three-cent-dollar-idea who talks from the platform or writes for the newspapers is a calamity man. Country is going to the dogs; mills are idle; business men are face to face with bankruptcy; laborers are recompensed poorly; people are starving; prosperity has given us a cold shoulder.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- The membership of the Silver Party's National Convention to-day was neither so large nor so picturesque as that of the Populist gathering. It was made up of comparatively harmless monomaniacs instead of all-round lunatics. The delegates were better dressed, less bewhiskered, and generally far more whole-some-appearing than their Populist brethren. there was more unity of purpose, and in consequence less noise.

In response to a call signed by a number of citizens, both Democrats and Republicans, for a non-partisan meeting in favor of sound money and in opposition to the Chicago platform, there was a large assemblage of interested residents of the upper east side at the Old Homestead Hall, Third Avenue and Ninetieth Street, last nignt.

NEWPORT, R,I., July 22 -- The Boston boat Asahi, owned by Bayard Thayer, won the sweepstakes for thirty-footers to-day in a sail through the rain, fog, and mist in turn. The Asahi was manned by "Nat" Watson, and she led from soon after the start, when she passed the Vaquero, which got over the line first, till the finish.
CHICAGO, July 22 -- The Republican National Executive Committee, or that portion of it which has its headquarters at Chicago, is making elaborate preparations for the campaign.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 22 -- The cricket match between, the Germantown team of Philadelphia and the Garrison eleven of this city began on the Garrison grounds at 11 o'clock this morning. The weather was fine, but the ground was well soaked with rain. The Philadelphia team is precisely the same as the one that played the Wanderers on Monday.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 22 -- Among those who are here for the Summer are John M. Rankin, wife, and daughter of Brooklyn. Mr. Rankin is an ex-County Clerk of Kings County, and resides on Rodney Street, Brooklyn. His family consists of his wife and their daughter, Jennie, who is about thirteen years old.

There was a big surprise in store for those 4,000 or more people who went to the Brighton Beach race track yesterday. There were a new track, a new grand stand, new fences, new stables, new managers, and such a general air of newness about the place that none of the crowd saw any resemblance to the old Brighton track, with its more or less savory reputation.

Having pledged themselves to contribute $15,000,000 or $18,000,000 in gold to protect the Treasury reserve, the New-York bankers yesterday solicited the co-operation of the foreign exchange bankers in still further protecting the reserve by keeping gold, in this country.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- The Democrats of the country may as well make up their minds to one thing at once. If they are regarding the convention of the Populists as likely to affect, by its action, their political course in the campaign just begun. The Populists, or a great majority of them, will not ask for favors from the Bryan party that nominated the ticket at Chicago.
DUBUQUE July 22 -- Gen. George Wallace Jones died at his home here to-day.

The Rev. George Williams, pastor of the First Baptist Church of Long Branch, who had been missing from his home since July 13, turned up yesterday safe in this city, but suffering probably from nervous prostration.

CLEVELAND, July 22 -- The celebration of the founding of Cleveland, 100 years ago, was commenced at midnight by a salute of 100 guns reinforced by steam whistles, bells, and fireworks. The National salute was fired at 5:30, and the citizens of Cleveland, as well as 40,000 strangers, gave up all thought of slumber and turned out to celebrate.

No romancer has ever had a more attractive subject for tragic treatment than the weird and monstrous Crime that has been committed on board of the prosaic barkentine Herbert Fuller, prosaically laden with lumber from Boston and prosaically proceding to Buenos Ayres. The tragedy of STEVENSON'S "Wrecker" is scarcely more complicated and by no means more gruesome.

BAIPEUTH, July 22 -- The "Gotterdammerung," the last of the four parts of Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungen," was produced at the Festspielhaus to-day before the usual large audience, which included many Americans. The cast was as follows:

SOUTHAMPTON, July 22 -- Upon the arrival of the American Line steamer St. Louis at this port this afternoon the vessel was boarded by a representative of The United Press, who secured confirmation of the report cabled from New-York shortly after the departure of the St. Louis from that port that the baggage of one of her passengers, a Miss Watson, had been rifled of a quantity of jewels shortly before the vessel sailed.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Of the many arguments on the subject of gold or silver money, some seem good in favor of one side or the other, partly according to the bias of the listener and partly as a matter of fact; but in any case, that arguments are so complicated and impractical as only to leave confusion in the mind of all but the most exprerienced of thinkers.

Gold-standard Democrats of this city were in conference yesterday considering how best to meet the situation, which has suddenly developed by the activity of Western men, who favor an immediate call for another Democratic convention.

ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- The convention, on reassembling at 4:30, appointed a committee of three to invite delegates to the Populist Convention to take seats in the galeries. The rules of the present Congress were adopted, and the Committee on Credentials reported no contests. The Committee on Organization Reported William P. St. John of New-York as permanent President, Representative Towne of Minnesota as vice Presidents, and Robert E. Diffenderfer as secretary.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: There are thousands of sound-money Democrats in this and other States who would not vote for Mr. Bryan for President if they could vote for a sound money man nominated by sound-money Democrats. If another cicket is not placed in nomination, they will either vote for Mr. Bryan or stay at home.
Our Republican neighbor, The New York Tribune, addressed a few remarks yesterday to certain Honest-money Democrats who, The Tribune asserts, are saying:

ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- The convention was called to meet at 12 o'clock, but at that hour but a few delegates were present. Among them were a half dozen swarthy-gowned ladies from Colorado; who sat with their State delegation. Congressmen Newlands of Nevada and Towrne of Minnesota were applauded as they entered the hall, but Banker St. John of New-York, who was slated for permanent Chairman, was not recognized.

GODALMING, England, July 22 -- The Haverford College team of cricketers created consternation in the hearts of the Charterhouse School team here to-day by inflicting a decisive defeat on the famous "Cartusians" by 92 runs. The home team had no expectation of being defeated by the young Americans, and the easy manner in which the visitors gained the victory was the cause of considerable surprise.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Secretary of the Interior has approved the following lists of lands selected by railroads: Northern Pacific Railroad, 128,062 acres in the Helena and Bozeman land districts, Montana, also 12,488 acres to the same road in the Spokane district; Oregon and California Railroad, 17,329 acres in the Roseburg district, Oregon; also 2,037 acres to the same company in the Oregon City district, Oregon.

St. LOUIS, July 22 -- The leading members of the Populist Party are generally agreed that their National platform Shall follow closely the lines of the Omaha platform adopted four years ago, and quoted in these dispatches yesterday. This platform, if agreed to, will be more or less modified, and in this form will be practically as follows:

LONDON, July 22 -- Princess Maud of Wales, youngest daughter of the Prince of Wales, and granddaughter of Queen Victoria, was married to-day to Prince Charles of Denmark, son of the Crown Prince and grandson of King Christian IX. of Denmark. The ceremony took place in the Chapel Royal, Buckingham Palace.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your editorial in Monday's issue, "Drop Partisanship," comes straight home, and is to the point.
ST. LOUIS, July 22 -- The real business of the convention began after Chairman St. John had finished reading his speech.

The Brotherhood of Tailors carried out the plan to strike according to programme yesterday. The committees that had been appointed on Tuesday to call out the men of the contractors' shops assembled early at Walhalla Hall, and before 7 o'clock started out, each member with lists of shops. They went through Ludlow, Essex, Norfolk, Suffolk, Clinton, Hester, and other streets and ordered all hands out.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- A man prominent in financial circles visited the different financial institutions of this city this afternoon in furtherance of a plan to have the local banks exchange gold for legal tender, in the interest of the Government. A number of banks subscribed, and it is understood that near $500,000 was raised in half an hour.

Dr. Adam Cardenas, ex-President of Nicaragua, arrived in New-York yesterday, coming by the steamer Advance from Colon. The doctor is here for the benefit of his health, which has been bad for some time. After staying in this city for several weeks he will go to San Francisco, and thence home.

Regarding the introduction of a secret plan of treatment for alcoholism at Bellevue Hospital, and the use of a public institution for the purpose, as has been asserted, of advertising a private enterprise, without the sanction of or without even consulting with the Medical Board of the hospital, several persons have said to the reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES who has been investigating the matter that an official investigation should be ordered at once.

RAHWAY, N.J., July 22 -- Mrs. Paul Assman, residing on Harrison Street, was awakened by burglars at 2 o'clock this morning. Her husband had been paid Saturday, but was away. Mrs. Assman picked up her husband's double-barreled shotgun and fired two shots, which attracted the attention of the police. The burglars made their escape.

ST. Louis, July 22 -- When the Populists got together in Convention Hall this evening they found themselves in trouble; No provision had Been made for lighting the hall. Neither gas nor electricity gave a ray of light. Candies had been provided by the newspaper correspondents for their own use, but they only served to make the darkness in the other parts of the hall seem more intense.

A clear majority of eighteen in the House of Commons against a measure to which the Ministry is distinctly committed ought, one would be led by precedent to suppose, to work a dissolution of that Ministry. As the British phrase goes, "the Queen's Government cannot be carried on" by Ministers in that predicament.
BOSTON, July 22 -- The July meeting at Mystic Park, postponed yesterday, opened to-day with three good races. In the 2:17 trot Grace Hastings won handily after dropping the first heat.

STATE CAMP, SEA GIRT, N.J., July 22 -- The members of the Second Brigade of the New-Jersey National Guard, who are in camp at this place, are improving in their work in every respect. This is the opinion of Lieut. Rowell of the United States Cavalry, who has been here since Monday watching the progress of the soldiers in camp and giving instructions.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., July 22 -- Senator Elkins was temporary Chairman of the Republican State Convention to-day. He spoke for about an hour. He discussed the tariff and silver questions at length. After showing how the newly developed industries of West Virginia had been depressed since 1892, he produces statistics in favor of protection as the more important issue for the development of the natural resources of the Mountain State.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- The publication of the probable negotiations between President J. J. Hill of the Great Northern Railway and Mr. Masujima of Tokio for a steamship line between Puget Sound and Japan has developed the fact that Chicago men already practically have completed arrangements for such a line of steamers, which it is expected will give them almost complete control of the business between, the United States and the Orient.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- A conference of the leaders of the sound-money Democrats from en States will be held in this city to-morrow night for the purpose of deciding whether to hold another convention. These leaders will represent Illinois, Indiana, Ohio, Michigan, Kentucky, Wisconsin, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri, Texas, Kansas, and Minnesota.

LITTLETON, N.H., July 22 -- Harry Bingham, the Democratic leader of New-Hampshire and a stanch Jeffersonlan Democrat, condemns the Chicago platform as a departure from the traditions of the party. He has not decided yet whether he will support Bryan and Sewall.
PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- The following bulletin has been issued by Chairman Gideon of the League of American Wheelmen:
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The United Press sent out from Washington the following statement, furnished by Secretary Carlisle June 25:

It constantly appears in the ordinary conversation of these days that many intelligent and fairly educated men who believe in maintaining the gold standard, of value have no clear grasp of the elementary principle upon which their faith should rest. It is a common remark with such men that they do not understand the subject or that they do not know much about it, but that they are for sound money.

John Stacom. John Stacom, an old-time Sixth Ward politician, died yesterday morning at his home, 1,279 Union Avenue. For the past six weeks he had been suffering from a complication of diseases. The cause of his death was dropsy.

A correspondent who has read the articles recently published in THE TIMES concerning the effect of exceptionally large crops of corn, potatoes, cotton, hops, and oats upon the prices of these products asks us to say something about hay.
NEWPORT, July 22 -- Miss Leary of New-York arrived to-night at the Paul cottage, Mill Street. She was accompanied by her brother, Charles C. Leary, who will be hef guest for the season.

Leading sound-money Democrats of this city have come to the conclusion that a third candidate for the Presidency, who represents the principles of true Democracy, is the inevitable outcome of the present situation.

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- Lafe Pence, remarking that all the contests had been disposed of, said it was full time to have a permanent organization of the convention, and he moved that a special committee be appointed to wait on the Committee on Permanent Organization and ask it to report its action.

ALLIANCE, Ohio, July 23. -- Major McKinley left Cleveland at 8 o'clock this morning for Alliance to meet an engagement of long standing at Mount Union College. He was met at the station in Alliance by ex-Congressman J.P. Taylor, Congressman Kerr, President Marsh, and other friends of the college.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: At the present time the Mexican silver dollar brings in this country only about 54 cents in exchange for our silver dollar, although it contains a larger quantity of silver than ours does, it is simply taken here at its commercial value, whereas the United States silver dollar goes in Mexico in its purchasing power for two of their dollars.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., July 23. -- Jay Cooke in a statement furnished the press to-day says:

The very striking report that has been published of an interview with BISMARCK on the future of England shows that, however it may be with the aged statesman's political judgment, years have not deprived him of his political imagination. We do not mean that this is an undesirable quality in statesmen.

It is customary in this community to praise the Associated Banks for their patriotism and public spirit as often as they come to the relief of the distressed Federal Treasury. In a like manner the action of the foreign bankers in taking concerted measures to check the outflow of gold is commended.

ST. Louis, July 23. -- Although a resolution was adopted yesterday that all sessions of the National Silver Convention should be opened with prayer, the convention went about its work prayerless to-day. The clergyman selected to invoke the Divine blessing did not appear. In announcing the clergyman's absence, Chairman St. John said: "I trust we are all in the spirit of prayer."

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- The convention of the National Silver Party enjoys the unique distinction of being the only one held this year in which no talk of bolting is heard. The Prohibitionists split at Pittsburg, the Republicans at St. Louis, the Democrats at Chicago, and a large section of the Populists threatens to repudiate the action of its National gathering in this city.

Capt. John H. Grant of the East Sixty-seventh Street Police Station and four detectives are trying to learn how the housekeeper for James P. Kernochan at 824 Fifth Avenue, whose name is unknown to the police at present, but who is sixty years old, came to be found in an unconscious condition in the house last night with a severe wound over the left eye.

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- The Committee on Resolutions of the Silver Convention completed its work this afternoon by adopting the platform and address to the people which had been prepared by the sub-committee. The platform and address are as follows:

She is said to be a university graduate; she must be a believer in dress reform, for she doesn't wear even a stiff waist under her dainty, modish gowns. She can play, sing, and dance; she is the most graceful little lady imaginable, and she is only two feet in height.

DETROIT, Mich., July 23 -- The Detroit Driving Club is having hard luck this year, rain again interfering with the programme, but not until everything except the Chamber of Commerce stake pacing event was cleared up. When the first event was called the track was fast and, in splendid condition, and a crowd of between 5.000 and 6.000 was present.

ORANGE, N.J., July 23 -- A good exhibition of baseball was given at the Orange Oval this afternoon, the Asbury Park nine of college athletes playing the Orange Athletic Club. The Orange nine won by a two-base hit by Westervelt and a single by Gray in the tenth inning.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., July 23 -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Sylvia, Commodore E.M. Brown; Vision, F. H. Benedict; Allegra, C. M. Pratt; Theresa, Gustavus Sldenberg; Ozhestea, G. M. Preston; Free Lance, W. A. Schermerhorn; Lorna, W. L. Stow, Susquehanna, Joseph Stickney; Charlietta, W. B. Higgins, and Toinette, Albert B. Hilton; schooner yacht Vif, R. Floyd Clark.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 23. -- Thomas Ryan, nine years old, was caught in the ropes of a swing to-day, and choken so badly that he died from the effects. His family lives about a half-mile from Harrison.

The speech of Mr. ST. JOHN, as Chairman of the Silver Convention at St. Louis, indicates that a man may be capable of managing the affairs of a bank in ordinary times, when the currency is in a normal condition, and yet have very defective reasoning powers when it comes to dealing with the principles which underlie his own business.

Republican appeals to sound-money Democrats to vote for MCKINLEY are now quite generally sugared over with the admission that the currency, not the tariff, must be the chief issue of the contest. This shows that the sentiment of the leaders and newspaper organs of the Republicans has undergone a change.

NEWARK, July 23 -- The Vim Bicycle Club has accepted the Invitation to enter the parade of the Associated Cycling Clubs of New-Jersey, to be held on Aug. 8 under the auspices of the Tourist Cycle Club of Paterson. The club will take a moonlight run to Bergen Point to-morrow night. The members will meet at the Central Railroad station and take the 6:40 o'clock train for Wayside.

David M. Gilmore, alias Daniel M. Golden, was convicted of robbery yesterday and was remanded until Monday for sentence. The charge against him was that he stole a case of cigarettes valued at $86 from a car of the West Shore Railroad at Weehawken, N.J., on Feb. 7, and sold it in this city.

CHICAGO, July 23. -- The troublesome switching charge has again been the subject of consideration by Eastern roads. When the Joint Traffic Association some months ago declared. that the cost of transferring cars from manufacturing industries over the Belt Line to the various roads must be borne by the shipper, it was thought the matter had been settled.

From The London Telegraph. There was a remarkable scene at a Northumberland Avenue hotel on Thursday. It seems that a party of newly arrived Americans, most of them strangers to each other, were sitting at luncheon, and one of them was with an English friend, who had called to see him.

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- When the convention reassembled, the Committee on Credentials was still unprepared to report, and the services of the band had to be railed into requisition again to fill up the tedious time of waiting.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 23 -- The southern half of Vancouver Island has not seen clear atmosphere for several days, owing to immense bush fires everywhere raging, causing immense damage to property and making travel on country roads extremely dangerous. The worst reports of damage reached this city from Alberni last night.

The news that Secretary Hoke Smith's paper, The Atlanta Journal, has come out for Bryan and Sewall leaves a number of New-York bankers and other business men uncertain whether they have been swindled.

The Brooklyn Democratic Club held a meeting at its rooms, 201 Montague Street, last night, to take action on a resolution prepared by the Executive Committee, relating to the platform of the Chicago Convention. Before the meeting was over it was called upon to act on a resulution favoring a third ticket.

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- Bryan, the Populists' candidate of the Populist Convention at Chicago, will be the candidate of the convention of the Populists at St. Louis. That result was practically accomplished in the prolonged second session of the convention held to-day. Senator Jones, (Dem.,) and Senator Allen, (Pop.,) working together in the cause of Populism, have succeeded in linking the two parties together.

More than $20,000,000 in gold has been pledged to the Sub-Treasury, by the New-York banks, and three-quarters of the amount has been actually turned over to Assistant Treasurer Jordan. These two facts caused President F.D. Tappen of the Gallatin Bank to feel particularly cheerful yesterday.

Much interest is being taken in the coming track and field championship meeting of the Metropolitan Association of the American Amateur Union, which will be held on the grounds of the New-Jersey Athletic Ciub on Saturday, Aug. 1. commencing at 2 P. M. While the entries will not close until July 25, the different clubs, particularly the larger ones, are figuring out the winners.

There are still half a dozen States which hold their State elections in advance of that at which Presidential Electors are chosen in November, and the results will be looked for with peculiar interest this year. This will be especially the case with the two Northern States both of which are in New-England.

We hope no reader of THE TIMES neglected to read carefully that part of the interview with Mr. IVINS, published yesterday, which related to the Brazilian currency. The story is in its main outlines that of any inflated and depreciated currency. We had an experience of our own in that way which nobody who went through it is likely to forget.

President Roosevelt was the trial Commissioner at Police Headquarters yesterday. There were ninety-one cases on the calendar. Among them were twenty conversation complaints, fifteen absent from post charges, two citizens' complaints, and the rest were for minor offenses.

BOSTON, July 23 -- A large crowd saw another good exhibition of trotting at Mystic Park this afternoon. Brennan was the favorite in the 2:17 pace, and took the first heat handily. Then Regina captured the next three easily.

St. Petersburg Letter in The London Chronicle. The great strike among the weavers of St. Petersburg, which lasted for a fortnight and exceeded in extent and severity every previous movement of the kind in Russia, deserves the attention of all students of the workmen's question.
CHICAGO, July 23. -- The conference of sound-money Democrats at the Auditorium to-night decided to call a convention to put a genuine Democratic National ticket in the field.

Dime novels of the wild-West order seem to have brought about the downfall of Leon Halvinne, nineteen years old, who was arrested yesterday near the Morris Park freight yards after he had robbed a house at Van Kest, and shot a man who pursued him after the robbery.

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- The afternoon session developed little of interest. There were present fewer delegates and more ladies than in the morning. Many delegates, unable or unwilling longer to bear the expense of remaining in the city, had already gone home. During the session the desire to get away was manifested frequently, and it was with difficulty that the convention could be kept together until tomorrow.

Mayor Wurster will have to grant a first-class theatrical license to the Surf Athletic Club of Coney Island. He refused, last week to grant such a license, but the persons interested in the club went before Justice Osborne, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, and asked for a mandamus to compel the Mayor to grant a license.

VICTORIA, B.C., July 23 -- The southern half of Vancouver Island has not seen clear atmosphere for several days, owing to immense bush fires everywhere raging, causing immense damage to property and making travel on country roads extremely dangerous. The worst reports of damage reached this city from Alberni last night.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 23 -- Col. Seward, having obtained permission from Adjt. Gen. McAlpin to tender the post commander a review, extended that courtesy to Gen. McAlpin, the post commander, this evening. It was more brilliant than last week's in one way, for today the troops were in full-dress uniform, and the gold iace and nodding plumes, as required by regulation, made a very pretty and imposing spectacle.

Is the opinion of a New-York business man on the silver question worth anything -- a man who is at the head of a large industrial establishment, which gives employment to hundreds of workingmen? I think so. I had an opportunity yesterday to hear a man of this sort express his views on the great question of the day, the proper solution of which is of such vast importance to the American people.

SEAGIRT, N.J., July 23. -- Governor's Day at the State camp was a great success. The troops went through their drills and the review in good form, and the reception to Gov. Griggs this evening was a pleasant affair.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 23. -- Samuel Melville and W.H. Kevan, single-tax speakers, were arrested at Dover last night for speaking on the streets without a permit. They were fined $10 and costs, in default of which they went to jail for thirty days. This makes five speakers now under arrest.

MANCHESTER, N.H., July 23. -- The opening Democratic rally in this city was held in Mechanics' Hall last evening. Dennis O'Connor of the City Committee presided. Addresses were made by J.H. Oberley of Concord, J.J. Doyle of Nashua, and George Fred Williams. Mr. Williams in his speech said:
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- The second day's session of the United States League of Local Building and Loan Associations was devoted almost entirely to the reading of papers.

ST. LOUIS, July 23. -- The sub-committee of the Populists' Committee on Resolutions, appointed this morning by Chairman Weaver to prepare a platform, was in session all the afternoon and until late in the evening. Many of the proposed planks caused considerable discussion and some opposition among those disposed to insist upon a radical declaration of principles.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The last issue of The Demerara Chronicle, that of July 8, which has just reached the Bureau of American Republics, says:

PITTSBURG, July 23 -- Pittsburg and New-York Played two games to-day, and Pittsburg won both. The first game was lost through miserable fielding by the visitors. Sullivan pitched a fine game, and would have won easily had he been given any kind of support. The local men could do absolutely nothing with his delivery, and of the four hits off him. three were lucky scratches.
A strong northwest wind favored the yachts at Larchmont yesterday and sent them over the courses in fine style. It was almost too strong for the small boats, and some of them met with slignt mishaps.
NEWPORT, July 23 -- The entertainers tonight were Mrs. George Henry Warren, Jr., and Mrs. Samuel E. Huntingdon. Mrs. J. J. Mason and Mrs. Warren entertained at luncheon.
LONDON, July 24. -- The House of Commons discussed the Irish Land bill throughout the night and adjourned at 4:40 A.M., after passing the measure through the committee stage.

Moritz Bauer of the Manhattan Investment Company of 150 Nassau Street was in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday in response to a summons issued by Magistrate Brann, at the request of Peter Fasset of 260 East Nineteenth Street.
HALIFAX, N.S., July 24. -- The Magistrate's inquiry into the tragedy on board the barkentine Herbert Fuller began at the City Hall to-day.
While it is conceded by prominent gold-standard Democrats that Tammany will eventually indorse Bryan and Sewall, for various reasons efforts will be made to delay any such action as long as possible.

There is a good deal of Anarchistic sentiment in New-York, and Bryan is getting some benefit from it. It will continue to favor him throughout the campaign, and will make voles for him election day. There is another side to the proposition, though. No matter how much this sentiment shall help the Chicago nominee, it will hurt him many times more.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 24. -- The incapacity for business that has characterized all the former sessions of the convention was displayed again today. From the beginning, at 19 o'clock, right through the session, wrangling between the Chair and the delegates and among the delegates themselves, und constant exhibitions of childishness and crankiness interrupted the course of business and served to prolong the already needlessly long performance.

Mr. CHARLES W. HACKETT, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, is reported to have said yesterday: "If Mr. WHITNEY would say just what he wants, we will try to meet his views." and to have added: "We have no desire to thrust our tariff views down the throats of the Democrats or do anything that will make it difficult for them to vote the Republican ticket."

The tuberculous cows in several dairy herds which had been subjected to the tuberculin test by State officers were slaughtered a few days ago in a certain county of Pennsylvania where such inspections were a novelty. The work was done in the presence of a large number of farmers.

ST. LOUIS, July 24. -- It was noticeable that many of the delegates on their way to the evening session had their gripsacks in hand, as if they had given up their rooms in hotels and lodging houses and intended to take trains for their homes to-night. That was an indication of a hope, or a feeling that the convention would wind up its proceedings and adjourn finally before to-morrow.

Edmund Randolph Robinson. Edmund Randolph Robinson, senior member of the law firm of Robinson, Biddle Ward of 160 Broadway, and a prominent lawyer and civil service reformer, died at 11:25 o'clock yesterday morning at his home, at 23 North Washington Square.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 24. -- The plans of Mr. Bryan for the campaign are gradually shaping into something definite, and when the Committee on Notification shall announce the date of the rally in New-York, at which he will be informed of his selection as the candidate of the Democratic Party, he will prepare a partial programme of his movements.

The preliminary stops were taken last night at an enthusiastic meeting of Democratic business men in the Plaza Hotel for the formation of the Democratic Honest Money league of America. L.J. Callanan presided. The object of the league is to antagonize in every possible way the principles enunciated in the Chicago platform, and to secure the defeat of Bryan and Sewall.
The following open letter to the Chairman of the Republican National Committee has been recieved by THE NEW-YORK TIMES: M.A. Hanna, Cleveland, Ohio:

The People's Party, assembled in National Convention, reaffirms its allegiance to the principles declared by the founders of the Republic, and also to the fundamental principles of just government as enunciated in the platform of the party in 1892.

COLON, July 24. -- Grave fears of serious political troubles exist in Colombia, and 200 troops have been landed at Bocas Cordova to guard against an emergency. The Conservative party has split over the matter of the nomination of a new President of the Republic.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 24. -- Gov. Matthews to-day assumed an attitude of defiance toward the Federal courts by advising the authorities of Hammond to go ahead with the collection of taxes in certain annexed territory regardless of the decision of the Federal Court of Appeals reversing a decision of the lower court, in which a bill for an injunction was denied.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 24. -- Probably the heaviest rainfall ever experienced here fell last night -- two and ninety-six hundredths inches. The streets became rivers, flowing ankle deep from curb to curb, and streetcars ran over tracks that were Several inches under water. Cellars were filled with water, and sewers choked by the unusual demands made upon them.

CHICAGO, July 24. -- The sound-money Democratic conference finished its work to-day. It provided for the selection of a National Committee composed of one person from each State, and that the committee shall meet Aug. 7 at Indianapolis to issue a form-al call for a National Convention to be held not later than Sept. 2.
