We have felt it to be our duty to point out serious objections to two of the principal features of that part of a municipal charter which has lately been submitted to public criticism, namely, the provision for a Municipal Assembly of two chambers and the plan for a federation of boroughs with certain independent local functions.

ATLATIC CITY, N.J., July 30. -- Forty-two persons, at least, were killed and eighty or more injured by the collision of a Reading express train with a West Jersey excursion train, at a crossing just west of this places at 6:30 o'clocK this evening.

A handsome statuesque blonde who said she was Kate Menninger, an actress who, last season, played the role of the heroine in the melodrama " Northern Lights," ran into the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last evening and excitedly asked Sergt. McDermott to send a squad of policemen to Mme. Partello's boarding house at 487 Sixth Avenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. George B. De Forest, who had decided not to take part in the Newport season, expecting to pass the Summer elsewhere, today rented Pinard Cottage No. 1 till October. They will arrive Saturday.

The city was visited yesterday afternoon by another wind and thunder storm, and the Washington Arch and the Jefferson Market Police Court were struck by lightning. A woman and a horse were also struck, but not seriously injured. Several persons were prostrated by the heat which preceded the storm.

The Third Avenue Railroad Company gave an exhibition last night of the operation of the new compressed-air motor cars which it proposes to use first on the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street service, from river to river.

From The Town. Sir James Anderson, who resides at Buttevant Castle, has devoted the whole of his life to scientific pursuits; his extraordinary talents have been mainly directed to the construction of a steam drag or carriage for common roads. Sir James has expended no less a sum than u30,000 in his experiments, and so extraordinary has been his perseverance that he spent a fortune in building twenty-nine unsuccessful carriages to succeed in the thirtieth.

NYACK, N.Y., July 30. -- Maggie Lyons, a domestic in the employ of James S. Haring of Nyack, distinguished herself to-day by putting to flight a negro burglar who had entered Haring's house in the absence of of its owner.

When the Democratic Club communed with itself on Tuesday evening and came to the conclusion that it did not know its own mind it afforded an example of how a Democratic organization of substance and standing ought not to behave in this campaign. Unquestionably a great majority of the membership of the club will refuse to support BRYAN.

Mark Hanna met a number of politicians yesterday morning at the Waldorf, and then went to luncheon at the Lawyers' Club, with Garret A. Hobart, Frank Thomson of the Pennsylvania Railroad, F.S. Witherbee of Port Huron, and F.S. Gibbs of this city.

ROCHESTER, July 31. -- Fourteen of the most prominent business men and Republicans in Second Monroe District to-night were chosen unanimously as deligates and alternates to the State Convention, all of them enthusiastic supporters to George W. Aldridge for Governor.

NEWPORT, July 31. -- Mrs. Potter Palmer of Chicago gave her first social entertainment as a Newport cottager to-night at the Ruthven Pratt villa, Believue Avenue. It was a brilliant dinner company in honor of Miss Julia Grant of New-York, Mrs. Potter's niece.
The races for the Goelet Cups will be sailed next Friday off Newport. The Regatta Committee of the New-York Yacht Club has issued the following instructions for the contests;

BOSTON, July 31. -- The steamship Servin, in which the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company made its trip to and from Europe, was sighted down the harbor at 5:30 A.M. to-day, and by 7 o'clock she was docked and the passengers engaged with the customs officers.

BUFFALO, July 31. -- The Queen City Cycle Works at Idlewood, near this city, were seized last night by Deputy Sheriff Sloan on an attachment for $4,000 issued at the instance of J. Walter Thompson of New-York. The claim is for advertising. The works employed 400 men, all of whom are thrown out of work.

LONG BEACH, L.I., July 31. -- William C. De Witt of the sub-committee of the Greater New-York Commission, gave today for publication Chapter VI, of the draft of the charter for Greater New-York. It is, in substance and in its methods of administration, largely a reproduction, in codified form, of the charter of the City of New-York, made applicable to the large municipality in mind.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 31. -- A vast crowd of excited people -- men, women, and children -- early besieged the West Jersey Railroad station, anxious for more news from the scene of the wreck. Every incoming train was surrounded with persons, and, as the passengers alighted, they were asked all sorts of questions.
Mark Hanna and Thomas C. Platt will meet to-day.

This is the story of the adventures of four men in a boat who went rowing in Flushing Bay Thursday evening in search of fish and fresh air, and who spent the night suspended eight feet above water on the remains of an old dock.

DENVER, Col., July 31. -- Senator Wolcott, whose friends have succeeded in carrying the Republican State Committee in opposition to Senator Teller and the strong pro-silver sentiment in Colorado, to-night issued a statement to the voters of the community, in which be says:

YONKERS, N.Y., July 31. -- George Hadder, five years old, a son of George Hadder, died at 5 o'clock A.M. to-day, after a short illness. He complained of feeling ill Sunday, and his mother gave him some whisky and sugar. Another dose was given to him yesterdady morning. His mother also gave him some coffee. George fell asleep shortly afterward and did not awake.

While the racing was in progress at Brighton Beach yesterday the Stewards of the Jockey Club held a meeting, which was attended by James R. Keene, J.H. Bradford, James Galway, and F.R. Hitchcock. Jockey Anthony Hamilton was before the board, to which the case of his peculiar rides on Hornpipe on Thursday and Saturday of last week had been referred. Hamilton and William Lakeland, the owner of Hornpipe, were both examined at considerable length.
There is a very important question of campaign methods that must be determined by those who are opposed to Mr. Bryan and his platform.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The Populist National Committee has opened here what probably will be its permanent headquarters. Senator Dutler of North Carolina will reach the city soon and arrange plans for the campaign. The Populist National Committee, it is said, will be run entirely independent of the Democratic National Committee.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 31. -- Fifty lives were lost in the wreck, including those of two persons who died this afternoon. The number of seriously injured about equals the number of the dead.

Tammany joined hands with Papalism of the Chicago variety yesterday. Its Executive Committee met and indorsed the Bryan and Sewall ticket. The resolution that turned Tammany over to the "Pops'" ticket absolutely ignored the platform. The Tiger even could not stomach that. He swallowed the ticket without much of a grimace, but even his stout stomach could not take the platform as well.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 31. -- Julius B. Price of Philadelphia tells this story of the accident.

Charles T. Wall, a paperhanger, who lives at 202 East Seventeenth Street, lies at Bellevue Hospital with a bullet wound in his right side as the result of a struggle with a sneak thief at his home yesterday afternoon. After firing the shot the would-be burglar escaped.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 31.--The work of rescuing the living in the wreck and recovering the bodies of the dead, though promptly begun, was slow. Immediately after the trains came together. Thurlow, the block-signal operator, telegraphed the letters of the accident to this city. The fire-bells were rung, and soon the firemen with their apparatus were on their way to the scene.

ALBANY, July 31. -- About 200 of the personal appointees in the Construction Department of the Capitol will be laid off to-morrow. At one of its recent meetings, the Capitol Commission adopted a resolution that no men be placed at work save at a meeting of the commission. This resolution has been violated since the day of its adoption, until the pay roll contains about 890 names.

In the foregoing article, the writer has endeavored briefly to indicate a few of the reasons which seem to him to render the success of the Chicago ticket at least neither impossible nor highly improbable. The average business man of the East is too likely to argue that no programme such as that which has now be adopted by the Democratic Party can possibly receive the indorsement of the office at the polls.

SING SING, N.J., July 31. -- Police Justice M.C. Palmer of this village to-day rendered a decision in a case which created a sensation in town, involving, as it did, a quarrel between the Rev. Henry E. Duers and Village Trustee C.H. Stevens, which resulted in the latter kicking the former out of his place of business and then in the minister having the Trustee arrested on a charge of assault.

Under the Raines excise law hoteir have been springing up in Brooklyn like mushrooms. Localities that could not support a single legitimate hotel under any circumstances now have anywhere from ten to twenty of these hotels, and on Sundays they are all open and doing a thriving business.

" Battle Row," as the neighborhood about Tenth Avenue and Sixty-first and Sixty-second Streets is commonly known, was excited yesterday afternoon by a shooting affray, as the result of which James Cody, eighteen years old, who lives with his parents at 215 West Sixty-second Street, lies probably fatally wounded at the Roosevelt Hospital.
The Free Employment Bureau, which was opened in Cooper Union on July 29, in accordance with an act passed by the last Legislature, has been successful beyond all expectations.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 31. -- It seems marvelous that the list of killed and wounded in last night's wreck is not much longer than it is. Why the whole trainload of excursionist and a part, at least, of the passengers on the Reading's Hier were not killed is hard to understand, and had it not been for that great life saver, the air brake, the total of the dead must have been enormous.

The officials of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge were criticised yesterday morning because nearly 50,000 persons were compelled to walk over the bridge owing to the fact that the cars were not running on regular time.

ALBANY, July 31 -- County Treasurers have no option but to issue a liquor-tax certificate where the application is made according to law. This is the decision contained in an important opinion received by State Excise Commissioner Lyman to-day, which was written by County Judge Longley of Columbia County in certiorari proceedings instituted by James Hartigan against County Treasurer Macy of Columbia County.

The present aspect of American politics gives a particular and timely interest to a retrospect of what has been done by third parties in the past. Of course, there are always third parties composed of convinced persons whose optics are defective insomuch that they distort the comparative importance of things.

ALBANY, July 31. -- The hundreds of so-called social clubs which have been incorporated with the Secretary of State since the Raines liquor tax law has been in force will soon be exposed by an investigation conducted by the State Excise Department.

LAWRENCE, Mass., July 31. -- The announcement of the appointment by the Pope of the Rev. Sebastian Martinelli as Papal Delegate to the United States, as successor to Cardinal Satolli, was received with gratification here, where he is well known.

Mr. William J. Roome has sold for Messrs. Builiran Cromwell, attorneys for the State of William Moir, deceased, the important property at the southwest corner of Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, she 26.5 by 60 feet, and adjoining the dry goods and department store of Messrs. Ehrich Brothers on the south and west. Mr. Roome said with regard to this sale:

ATLANTIC CITY, July 31. -- It developed to-night that last night's ride, which ended in disaster and death, was for Engineer Farr to have terminated in a change of circumstances and a happier life. It was to have been his last ride on the engine, and the second man in the cab, who was also killed, and whose identity has not been fully established, was to have succeeded him in the place.

The members of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Rosary, Jersey City, are greatly exercised just now over a small financial scandal, the principal features of which are a contest for a gold watch and a fraudulent check for $50, for the possession of which there is not likely to be any sort of a contest.

CLEVELAND, July 31. -- Fifteen thousand persons saw Frank Agan win the greatest pacing race of the year to-day at the Glenville track, defeating Robert J. Joe Patchen, and Badge in straight heats. Not only this, but they saw him lower his own record twice, and, incidentally, the pacing record of the track. Agan went one heat in 2:04.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 31. -- Station Master Bodine had a long talk with Engineer Kreiner this morning when he arrived home. The engineer was much shaken up and nervous. After the interview, Mr. Bodine said that from what he was told he did not see how Kreiner could in any way be blamed for the accident.
Ex-Mayor William R. Grace has sent the following letter, bearing on the political situation and a third ticket, to Francis M. Seut, Vice Chairman Executive Committee New-York State Democracy:

BOSTON, July 31. -- The preliminary examination of Thomas Bram, first mate, and Charles Brown, seaman, of the barkentine Herbert Fuller, on the complaint charging them with the murder of the Captain, C.J. Nash: his wife, and A.N. Bramberg, was begun to-day, before United States Commissioner Fisku.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 31. -- Little can be added to the story of the collision as told in these dispatches last night.

I wonder what Mr. Bryan will say about the silver question in his Madison Square Garden speech next month. The report comes from Lincoln that be and Mrs. Bryan are working like beavers on that speech, and with this report is coupled another that the Bryans hope to make that speech the "greatest oratorical effort" of Mr. Bryan's life.

HONOLULU, July 31. -- No final disposition of the boby of Miss Kate Field has been made. Miss Lililan Whiting of New-York has written a request that the casket be forwarded for interment at Mount Auburn, beside Miss Field's mother. Miss Whiting says that George Riddell, the elocutionist, is Miss Field's surviving relative.

The Liberty Cycle Company of 4 Warren Street, whose factories are at Rockaway, N.J., and Bridgeport, Conn., has failed, and yesterday John R. Hardin of Newark, N.J., was appointed receiver by Justice Andrews of the Supreme Court of this district, and also in New-Jersey, on the application of William F. Wilson, Secretary and Treasurer of the company. The receiver's bond was fixed at $40,000 in this State.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 31. -- The Populists expect defeat in the election next Monday. This was made clear at their headquarters in this city to-day. It also was apparent that they meditated wreaking vengeance for defeat by the course of action best suited to that end -- fusion between themselves and the Republicans in November.

The picturesque chimney sweep with his long brush over his shoulder, his sooty, figure, pointed, close-fitting cap, loose blouse, bag, and boy, is a thing of the past even in England, where he was a familiar feature of the streets. As a practical reality we have him still. There is nothing more picturesque about the modern chimney sweep than there is about the plumber.

An incomplete chapter of the tentative draft of a charter for Greater New-York was given out by the sub-committee yesterday. It is in the main an adaptation of the first four titles of Chapter 6 of the present Consolidation act of this city relating to the Finance Department and follows its lines pretty closely.

James Dalton the nine-year-old son of Mrs. Mary Dalton, a widow living on the third floor of the tenement house 466 Eleventh Avenue, had a narrow escape from death early yesterday morning. While asleep he fell through the airshaft into the basement of the house.

HONOLULU, July 31. - The Advertiser publishes the following received here by the Australia, written to Thomas G. Thrum by his son, D.F. Thrum. The Mr. Hammond referred to is the San Francisco agent of the American Bible Society:
LONDON, July 31. -- The Irish Land bill passed the second reading in the House of Lords to-day.

William Fischer, a wheelwright, living at 603 West Forty-third Street, was probably fatally injured, at the works of Conrad Diehl, at 544 West Thirty-fifth Street, yesterday, by the bursting of a grindstone. His skull was fractured, and there is small hope entertained by the physicians of Roosevelt Hospital that he will recover.
Many complaints have been received recently by the Department of Street Cleaning in relation to the incumbered and obstructed condition of the sidewalks surrounding Gansevoort Market.

Long BRANCH, July 31 -- Mrs. A.L. Heyman, who is stopping at the Howland House, put her six-hundred-dollar diamond earrings in an old paper box, which she then threw with seeming carelessness in one corner of the room. Thieves, she thought, would never look there.
NUREMBERG, July 31. -- The eleventh round of the international chessmasters' tournament, played in this city to-day, resulted as follows:

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Senator Pritchard left for his home in North Carolina this evening after a protracted conference with Vice Chairman Apsley of the Congressional Campaign Committee. The Senator is quite satisfied with the situation as he finds it in his Style.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- The latest accessions to our knowledge of ocean currents is set forth in a chart to be published in a few days by the United States Hydrographic Office, mapping the routes followed by ninety-five floating bottles returned to that office in the six months ending June 31.

PROVIDENCE, F.I., July 31. -- Florence Larson, aged thirteen, daughter of Charles Larson of Woodside, L.I., fell from a balustrade six feet high to-night and fractilled her skull. She is dying at the hospital. She came here yesterday to visit her uncle, John Gustavson, at 51 East Transit Street, and the accident happened here.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 31. -- Mr. Bryan this evening completed the itinerary of his journey to New-York.

WASHINGTON, July 31.--The Naval Constructors have completed the work on the plans and specifications for the battleships authorized under the latest Naval Appropriation bill and have furnished the intending bidders with the desired information.

We suppose that scarcely any Western or Southwestern farmer who has been led by the agents of the mine owners and the inflationist demagogues to believe that the price of farm products has been depressed by what they call "the demonetization of silver in 1873" has ever examined the official or semi-official reports which show how enormously the supply of such products in this country has been increased.
MEMEL, Prussia, July 31. -- A dispatch has been received by a newspaper of this place stating that fire started in Libau, Russia, yesterday and is still burning.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Senator J.K. Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is expected to reach the city to-morrow. It is believed he at once will settle the question of, the location of National headquarters and will announce the names of the members of the National Executive Committee.

The fight in the Police Board over the appointment of Inspectors has taken a new turn. Col. Grant, who has heretofore in many things sided with Commissioner parker, but who joined Messrs. Roosevelt and Andrews at Wednesday's meeting in declaring that he would vote for no Inspectors until Brooks and McCullagh were confirmed, came out yesterday with a statement which is regarded as an attack upon Mr. Parker.

PHILADELPHIA, July 31. -- William F. Harrity, ex-Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, has retired from active politics. In answer to inquiries upon the subject, Mr. Harrity made the following statement:

What Mr. STEVENSON would have called the huge welter of competing jurisdictions between SEWALL of Maine and TOM WATSON of Georgia promises to lend an element of relieving humor to the Presidential canvass. The fun of the situation lies in the fact that both of these gentlemen have declared for the middle of the road.

WASHINGTON, July 31. -- Consul Schoepo, at Vera Cruz, in a report to the State Department on a new tax placed by the Vera Cruz Legislature on coffee and tobacco planting, warns Americans against embarking in the coffee-raising industry, and cites figures to show that in these parts of Mexico with which he is familiar the stories of great wealth to be gained by coffee planters does not apply.

There was a small riot at Nostrand and Vernon Avenues, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, in which the motorman of one of the Holy Cross Cemetery cars and four other persons were more or less injured. The riot grew out of the refusal of the conductor of the trolley car to issue transfers to the passengers.

CANTON, Ohio, July 31. -- A delegation of 400-cdd soldiers and citizens of Guernsey County and Cambridge, Ohio, called on Major McKinley at noon to-day. Introductory speeches were made by ex-Congressman J.A. Taylor and the Rev. Dr. McFariane, pastor of the Presbyterian Church in Cambridge, Ohio. Dr. McFariane was Chaplain of the Ninety-eight Ohio Regiment in the war.

The yacht lay on the edge of the fleet. They had just made colors aboard and fired the sunset gun, and were anchored some cable lengths away from another yacht on either side. All the inner harbor, indeed, was gay with the lesser craft, walking for the trial races beginning on the next day.

Every consideration, from the highest to the lowest, should have prompted Tammany to be wise this year. As usual, it has chosen the stupid course. Its Executive Committee declares by resolution that the nomination of BRYAN and SEWALL is a "wise determination of the Democratic National Convention" and pledges to these candidates the loyal and hearty support of Tammany Hall.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 1. -- No more persons have died from injuries received in the railroad accident on the meadows on Thursday evening, when the Reading express train ran into the West Jersey excursion train.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The horse show held at the Driving Park Monday and Tuesday was not, only the event of the week, but was much more of an event than had been anticipated. The social leaders here not only gave their patronage, but entered into the spirit that makes such affairs successful.

Detailing the efforts of the New-York City Consulate to secure an improvement in the streets of the metropolis, Secretary F.M. Frobisher spoke as follows yesterday to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The presentation of Shakespeare's great play of "As You Like It" by an all-star cast, before an audience of 1,000 persons, here tonight, marked the most brilliant histrionic performance ever given on the Jersey coast, and was the even of the season in theatrical circles everywhere.

" It really is a curious case," said one of the piccolo players of a Coney Island band. It struck THE TIMES man that the voice of the story-teller assorted to his instrumeut, it was so sharp, shrill, and staccato.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The work done in the State camp by the Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn was pronounced excellent after the regiment had concluded its last drill this morning. The Separate Companies and the Signal Corps also received congratulations from the State officers for the showing they made.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 1.--The Alabama State campaign closed to-day with speeches in almost every town. Capt. Joseph Johnston, the Democratic nominee for Governor, was in Winston County; Congressman A.T. Goodwyn, the Populist-Republican candidate, was in Limestone County; Congressman Bankhead was in Franklin County, and Gov. William C. Oates was in Henry County.

PLAQUEMINE, La., July 22. -- A very serious river accident occurred this afternoon below here. The steamer Paul Tulane sank in front of the Cora plantation, just below White Castle. The boat has disappeared from sight under the waters of the Mississippi, and will prove a total loss. The officers and passengers are all reported safe at the Cora plantation.

LARCHMONT MANOR, Aug. 1. -- Society turned out in full force, last evening to attend the entertainment and dance in the Casino for the benefit of the Larchmont Athletic Club. The Casino was elaborately decorated. There was a notable assemblage of handsome women beautifully gowned.

A fortunate accident, the discovery of an undergraduate's account book for the year 1882-8, enables us to trace in comparatively minute detail the expenses and in some measure the life of an Oxford student of no great means at the close of the seventeenth century. The undergraduate in question, one James Wilding, seems to have been a servitor of St. Mary's Hall, and afterward became a member of Merton College.

The State Excise Department, the city Police Department, the Vigilance League, and sundry other law-enforcing agencies have been calling upon the Building Department of the city to help them out in the matter of preventing the evasion, real or alleged, of the Raines law on the part of persons who sell liquor on Sunday under the pretense of keeping hotels.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, Aug. 1. -- Bicycling is still the chief recreation here. The merry riders are continually on the go, and they do not need to use lamps at night on their wheels, as the arc lamps light up in avenues. Mrs. Charles Fox, the actress, is a very pretty rider, and Miss May Louth of Hillside is a speedy and graceful rider.

A proper restriction is that the street preacher shall not carry the war into his enemy's camp. The passer-by in the parks is fair game. If he does not like the exhortations addressed to him, he can move away. Probably, indeed, he would not be in that part of the park at all if he did not wish to hear them.

A little water spaniel, in search of a cool place, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning was attracted by the white marble corridor of the Mutual Life Building, and he went in and made himself comfortable on the floor. Immediately the gentleman who gives signals for the elevators to start motioned to the spaniel to depart from the building.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- The week at this resort has been unusually gay and lively. A bicycle race on the South Road brought a large number of persons from Garrisons and the surrounding towns.

LONDON, Aug. 1.--A dispatch from the signal station on the Scilly Islands states that the rowboat Fox passed there at 11 o'clock this morning after a passage of fifty-five days from New-York. The two occupants of the boat were well but somewhat exhausted from the effects of their long row.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1. -- Down in a corner of Wisconsin is a bit of territory which sixty years ago was the lodestone that attracted every adventurer in the country, but is now almost entirely forgotten. It was California, the Comstock lode, and Cripple Creek boiled into one. A place where fortunes were made and lost, where a man lived on champagne one day and drank spring water the next.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1. -- The Clambake Club had a gay time at its rendezvous at Easton's Point to-day. It was its second bake of the season and nearly every member was present. Center Hitchcock, the President, was on hand, he having recently returned from Europe, and took charge of the proceedings.

A bright, forceful little Englishwoman, who arrived in NewYork on the Paris yesterday, was Miss Agnes Slack, who is entitled to write after her name nearly an alphabet of letters, showing that she is Honorary Secretary of both the World's and British Woman's Christian Temperance Unions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The following reports of yellow fever and smallpox in Cuban ports have been received at the Marine Hospital Service.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 1. -- This week has been a lively one. Many new arrivals and dinners, dances, receptions, and yachting parties have almost put to shame the cry that this is an off year for Summer resorts. The Kebo dinner and dance last Saturday night was the largest social event which the season has yet witnessed.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Considerable improvement was shown in the sixth annual championships of the Metropolitan Association this afternoon over the 1895 results. The cinder path of the New-Jersey Athletic Club of Bayonne, four laps to the mile, was in good condition. There was a cool southeast wind prevailing. Only a few hundred spectators attended.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 1. -Mrs. D. O'Dell had an exciting experience this morning with a mass meeting of rattle snakes on the Eagle Valley Road while she was on her way to the village. But for the timely help of William Carpenter the serpents would undoubtedly have enjoyed a morning meal on the contents of her farm wagon.

RUSSIA has throughout the century missed no opportunity, either in time of peace or war, of increasing her own possessions at the expense of Persia, and the larger part or her Transcaucasian Province has been so acquired. She is accustomed, ivylike, to grow fat on decaying organisms.

"I have had a most delightful row. Stuck in the mud for the tenth time this week, and not a man within five miles to help push me off.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 1. -- The general interest in the Fall elections promises to equal that in the State elections this Spring. The breaking up of old party ties, commenced in the Spring, is continuing. The convention of the National Republican faction here Thursday was one of the most respectable in point of numbers and morals held in the State since the war.

According to the present Herald at Arms, "the dignity of Knighthood is now received by the person kneeling before the sovereign, who with a stroke of the sword over the right shoulder, pronounces these words: Sols chevalier, au nom de Dieu, (Rise up Knight, in the name of God,) followed by 'Avance chevalier.'

Gibbon carefully studied for himself the questions at issue in the American war. From Israel Mauduit, the agent of Massachusetts Bay, and from Gov. Hutchinson he gathered material for forming an independent judgment. "I think," he says, "I have sucked them very dry, and if my confidence was equal to my eloquence, and my eloquence to my knowledge, perhaps I might make no very intolerable speaker."

BERLIN, Aug. 1. -- Following close upon the conferences between Chancellor von Hobenlohe and Count Goluchowski, the Austrian Minister of Foreign Affairs, at the former's chateau, at Alt-Aussee, and the summoning to Rome at Count Nigra, the Italian Ambassador to Austria, comes the arrangement for a meeting between the Marquis de Rudini, the Italian Prime Minister, and Count Goluchowski.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, Aug. 1. -- One of the chief events of the past week was the children's musical, given in the music room of the Prospect House last Wednesday evening. The room was crowded with an enthusiastic audience and the little folks charmed everybody with their talent. The programme consisted of songs, piano and violin solos, recitations,

From two big black seeds planted two months ago in the garden of Mr. E.B. Du Val have sprung plants which are blossoming into curios flowers that puzzle those familiar with horticulture . The flower will probably be named the "Du Val lily." as it is a new one in Maryland.

As the late Capt. John G. Bourke, in his "Notes on the Language and Folk-Usage of the Rio Grande Valley," expresses it, the designation, "Arabic" would be misleading if you were to declare that you found traces of that distinct or particular Orientalism among the people of the Rio Grande Valley.

The elevation of sentiment is noble; the style is superb; with all its fervor and force, it retains the calmness, the sobriety, the dignity of truth.

Tommy Atkins is not defending his country, nor fighting for paradise, nor is it religious enthusiasm that sustains him in his struggle on the burning sand against the countless Fuzzy Wuzzies of the Soudan. That he will do all but the impossible, if properly led and fed and adequately backed, we all believe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1.--There appears to be quite a contest after all, over the Quartermaster Generalship, made available by the retirement of Gen. Batchelder. When the date of Batchelder's retirement approached it was agreed on every hand that one or the other of two officers of the corps would secure the prize.

The Camp of Instruction near Peekskill will commence its closing week on Saturday next, and will be known essentially as "artillery week," when all the batteries in the State, with the single exception of the Fifth of Syracuse, will be on duty. The artillery organizations of the State which are to be present at camp comprise the First Battery, Capt. Wendel; Second Battery, Capt. Wilson; Third Battery, Capt. Rasquin, and the Sixth Battery, Capt. Olmstead.

WASHINGTON, Aug 1. -- With the sun hidden behind the clouds, a light breeze blowing, and the shores and clubhouses filled with spectators, the annual Potomac River regatta of 1896 was successfully rowed to-day. All the races, with the exception of the eights, which was one mile straightaway, were one mile and a half, with one turn.

The eighth annual regatta of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, which was sailed yesterday, was, like all previous regattas of the club, a big success. The number of starters fell just one short of fifty, and they were favored with a strong breeze from the south-southwest which at the finish was almost too strong for some of the smaller boats.

In all its long existence Tammany Hall has never before made so stupid and inexcusable a political blunder as the one made on Friday afternoon by its Executive Committee, which then indorsed the Bryan and Sewall ticket, and pledged to it the hearty and loyal support of the organization.

A Denver newspaper (silver, of course,) asks the following questions: "If free coinage would enable the savings banks to pay their $1,350,000,000 of deposits in fifty-three-cent dollars and thereby make a profit of $634,500,000, why is it that the heads of those banks, who are in business to make money, are so bitterly opposed to free coinage?

A radical proposition touching the bonded debt of the City of New-York, after the consolidation for which the new charter is to provide, is put forth by the committee making the preliminary draft, for the apparent purpose of eliciting discussion, since it is presented as an alternative to the present provision of law in regard to refunding city bonds in "consolidated stock."

VINCENNES, Ind., Aug. 1. -- Samuel W. Williams of this city has prepared and forwarded to William J. Bryan a draft of an agreement to be submitted to the Populist and Democratic conference committees which throws light on the inside workings and undertakings of the St. Louis Convention.

MONDAY, AUG. 3. -- By William Kennelly, foreclosure sale. Edward L. Patterson, referee, 483 Manhattan Avenue, west side, 18.5 feet north of One Hundred and Twentieth Street, 15 by 80, three-story stone-front dwelling. Due on judgment, $3,455.

FISHER'S ISLAND, Aug. 1. -- From present indications, this promises to be the gayest season that this place has had in its history as a Summer resort. The weather has been delightful, and all the visitors have enjoyed themselves thoroughly. The favorite amusements this past week were boating, fishing, bicycle riding, and bathing. All the cottages on the island are now occupied, and the hotels are well filled.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 1. -- While a crowd of people were standing on the boardwalk at the foot of Missouri Avenue this afternoon watching efforts being made to revive a man who had been nearly drowned while bathing, the rail of the boardwalk gave way, and about thirty persons were precipitated fifteen feet to the sand below.

A baby boy about eleven months old was carried into the Last One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Police Station about 8 o'clock last night by two weeler, who had taken it from his mother on a station at Second Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street. A cloth tied around its head was wet with blood.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Aug. 1. -- The Haverford College cricketers won a great victory to-day against the Cambridge eleven. At the conclusion of yesterday's play the Cantabs had scored 202 for their first innings, and the Haverfordians had run up the excellent score of 197 for three wickets.
NORWAY, Me., Aug. 1. -- The first frost of the season was seen here this morning. It was slight and the damage was small.

Near the entrance of Calvert Station may be found any pleasant night in July two or more colored crab vendors, who sit in police enforced silence on small boxes, with baskets of their wares on the sidewalk before them. Sometimes the crab vendors are missing, but the baskets are there, and apparently without any guardian other than a sedate and rusty white cat of mature years.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1. -- There have been same departure for Bar Harbor and other seaside resorts this week, as well as some arrivals at cottages and hotels. Miss Cary and Miss Rotch will go to Bar Harbor next week, returning to The Gables for the Autumn season. Mr. Richard Goodman and family, who expected to go to Bar Harbor some weeks ago, have been detained, but will start soon for their annual visit.

It came close to being a record-breaking attendance at the Brighton Beach race track yesterday, the half-holiday people and the Sunday visitors to the Coney Island hotels being out in force and packing the big grand stand to its utmost capacity. All seemed to have a pleasant day's outing of it, and all but the regulars, who will not bet on and have no interest in a steeplechase, remained until the last race was run.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 1. -- During the past week many different events have taken place here, gotten up expressly for the guests, in the way of entertainment. There was a children's carnival at the United States, a german at both the Scarboro and the Howland, the ladies' bicycle race, the proprietor's ball at the West End, and other attractions.

To ascertain with greater precision the shape, size, and density of the earth, the astronomer's base of measures, and thus render the science of surveying more accurate, ten pendulum observations near the unknown extreme of the arc are worth a hundred elsewhere. Observations on magnetism, especially near the magnetic pole, will benefit the thousands of ocean vessels which largely depend for their safety on the precision with which the compass can be interpreted.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Collector of the Port of Perth Amboy Benjamin M. Price and his family have gone to Spring Lake for the Summer. Mrs. M.O. Davis has gone to Romolus, N.Y., on a visit. Miss Maysie Hull is at East Millstone, with friends. Miss Kittie King of Brooklyn is visiting Mrs. William Malller, at the Pines.

There is a prospect of serious trouble in the building world of Boston. Every member of that world knows that buildings are often erected in violation of the building laws, by the simple process of making the plans and specifications to conform to the law, taking out a permit in pusuance of them, and then carrying out the structure without regard to the approved plans, or making such alterations of the law.

Two Brooklyn boys had a wild escapade the other day, departing from the City of Churches to the wilds of Jersey, where, armed with rusty revolvers and sensational literature, they made a number of productive raids on the houses and stores in the neighborhood of their camping-out place. The literature, it was supposed, was to inspire courage and the revolver to keep it up.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- Capt. Murphy, commander of the Laurada, has received the following letter from the Spanish Consul Jose Congosto:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-20 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

It is the old thing over again, "the hair of the dog for the cure of the bite." But when you look into the primal quality of the antitoxines, that really is about what it is, and so we may believe that in former gropings, the "similia similibus curantur" was not so very far out of the way.
LONDON, Aug. 1. -- This was the last day of the International Socialist Trades Congress, and, aside from an academic discussion of social questions, its results, as was expected, have been nil.

Mlle. Couedon, "the Angel Gabriel," as her volaries called her, after going up like a rocket, has come down like a stick. She has not even obtained a gilded retirement, after all her notoriety, for the 2,000 damages she claimed in a recent libel case were reduced to 5, and the three extra postmen who groaned under the weight of mail bags addressed to her have seen withdrawn.
KINUSTON, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- Mrs. Alonzo Van Bramer of 114 Wall Street has asked the police of New-York and Brooklyn to help her investigate the mystery that surrounds her husband's death.

LONDON, Aug. 1. -- It is more than surmised in official quarters here that there has been a sort of palace revolution in Russia and that Prince Lobanoff, if not overthrown has been divested of his unlimited power as Foreign Minister. He has been from the beginning hand in glove with the German Emperor, so much so as amply to justify the original suspicion that his appointment was managed from Berlin.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The United States Consul at Zurich, Switzerland, informs the State Department that the Mexican Consul there is trying to secure bids from Swiss firms on the new electric light installation for the City of Mexico.

The annual convention of the New-Jersey State Dental Society seldom fails to bring that one or more points markedly illustrative of the progressive tendency of modern dentistry. This year's session, the twenty-sixth, which was held at Asbury Park July 29, 30, and 31, formed no exception to the rule.

Springfield, Mass., Aug. 1. -- The Springfield Bicycle Clubs Prize Committee has practically completed its preparatory work and presents the following splendid list, which will doubtless secure the entries of all the best American amateur and professional riders and it is hoped to those of some of the leading foreigners.

A part of the North Atlantic squadron has at last gone to sea to carry out the much-talked-of manoeuvres. Admiral Bunce took out with him his flagship, the New-York, the Newark, the Cincinnati, the Indiana, and the Amphitrite. This fleet will remain at sea for a week or ten days, and then go to Hampton Roads.

The steamship Paris of the American Line arrived at her dock yesterday morning from Southampton, after a rough trip of 6 days 22 hours and 31 minutes. She encountered high seas and head winds throughout.

The market appears to have settled into a normal condition. The fright is out of it. This was shown Wednesday morning, when the machinery was all prepared for a lively smash. After the first drive at prices they steadied and began to recover, because there was not enough long stock shaken out for the short sellers to cover on, and they had to buy back the stocks they had sold.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Miss Sarah Burgess of Philadelphia is visiting his sister, Mrs. Rachel Allen of Park Avenue. Mrs. J.F. Berg and daughter of East Fifth Street have returned from North Branch. Mrs. J.M. Martin and her son, Douglas, of Park Avenue have returned from a visit of a month at Whitehouse.

Without doubt the largest item of natural wealth in the South is in its timber resources. This is especially so of the region bordering on the Gulf of Mexico, back from which for several hundreds of miles extend unbroken forests, meandered by rivers and bayous, and of late years pierced by a steadily growing railway mileage.

BELVIDERE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The residents of Smithfield Tip, a small place near here, are trying to explain the disappearance of two men who appeared to be strangers, as they entered the place driving a spirited horse, and when they left the animal was found dead in the road behind them.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1. -- The receivers of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad and Coal and Iron Companies to-day filed in the United States Circuit Court statements of the obligations, liabilities, assets, , of the companies in accordance with the directions contained in the dual decree of the court of May 1 relating to the sale of the property under the foreclosure of the general mortgage.

The announcement of the death of Nehemiah S. Bean, the venerable manufacturer of Manchester, N.H., is coupled in most of the press notices with a statement that he constructed the first steam fire engine. Probably no man had been more honorably or more prominently associated with the manufacture of steam fire engines than the late Mr. Bean.

The present volume is the third in the series to which it belongs, and Dr. Du Bose defines it as "properly a historical study of the growth and formation of the Catholic doctrine of the person of Jesus Christ -- that is to say, by that personal union of the divine and human in our Lord, which makes Him the supreme object of our spiritual and religious interest."

The appointment of Father MARTINELLI to succeed Archbishop SATOLLI as Papal Delegate to the United States seems now to be completed by the reluctant acceptance of the appointee. The A.P.A. will, of course, see in this fresh proof of the dark and deadly designs of the Pope upon our liberties.

Cruising along the sandy shore, and trailing the flies just where the water suddenly becomes profound, there came to pass a mighty commotion; a great form loomed out of the side of a wave, a broad tail swept around in the brown water, the line tightened bravely, the good greenheart bent in sympathy, and away went the salmon, buzzing off thirty yards of line at a stretch.

A question as to how many of the millions of men in these United States became aware inside of twenty-four hours after action by the two conventions that McKinley or Bryan had been nominated as candidates for the Presidency is one that no human being can answer. But it is not unreasonable to assert that nine-tenths, or even a greater proportion, were informed at some minute in the period indicated who the nominees were.

There was to have been a special meeting of the Business Men's Democratic Association last Wednesday evening for purpose of taking action in relation to the platform adopted at the Chicago Convention and the candidacy of Bryan and Sewall, but the surprise of a great many of the members of the association who were anxious to place the association in the ranks of the sound- money Democrats the notices for the meeting were not issued.
MONTCLAIR, Aug. 1 -- An excursion to Greenwood Lake will be made next Wednesday by the members of the Second Ward Republican Club of Bloomfield.
William H. Park, M.D., Assistant Director of the hospital bacteriological laboratories of the Health Department. Is recovering, at the Presbyterian Hospital, from a mild attack of typhoid fever.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 1. -- The hot wave of a past week has caused choice rooms to demand a premium at the fashionable hotels, and the late-comers to-night were obliged to "double up" or be content with makeshift bed in the hotel parlor. The rivals for the week will number fully love, and Mr. Bradley's unique temperance town is, therefore, comfortably filled with health and pleasure seekers.
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The Peerless Athletic Club will have a moonlight picnic at Verona Lake Monday night.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 1. -- Mrs. S. Eichell is visiting relatives in Boston, Mass. Mrs. S.H. Jacobson has gone to Westport, N.Y., for the Summer. E.E. Moore and family of Euclid Avenue left on Thursday for the Catakills. Mrs. Ernest Koester will spend the month of August at Bradford, Penn. F.R. Smith, General Passenger Agent of the Susqoehanna Railroad, with his wife, is visiting at Warwick, N.Y.

There are in Europe five great powers -- England, France, Germany, Russia, and Austria -- who all hate each other cordially, although they make alliances between themselves whenever expediency suggests agreement.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 1. -- The Atlanta Journal publishes a statement by its business manager. Mr. Cabaniss, in regard to its proposed anti-free-silver movement, in the course of which Mr. Cabaniss says:

One of Frank Corbett's horses while grazing in a field on his farm, north of New-Augustine, yesterday afternoon, was bitten by a large rattlesnake. No one knew of the accident until late in the afternoon, when the animal walked up to the barn with a swollen head, Mr. Corbett made an examination, and discovered the imprints of the fangs of the snake in the horse's nose.

It would be too much to say that the four papers here collected are disappointing, but they are so in the sense that they are not completely reassuring. The penultimate collection was very distinctly disappointing. If we remember aright, it comprised that remarkable performance "The Private Life," in which a mere fantasy, or, rather, a mere quip, was elaborated, documented and fortified with the view of making it conceivable as a reality.
A story of alleged criminal neglect and the death of six persons by suffocation was told yesterday by a young Russian Hebrew, Chaim Silberman, who arrived in this country last January.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- Gen. Powell Clayton of Arkansas, who is a member of the National Republican Executive Committee attached to the New-York headquarters, called at National headquarters to-day, with United States Senator Shoup of Idaho. The Idaho Senator, who refused to bolt, will remain here until Monday, when he will return home to renew his fight for McKinley and the organization of the Republican Party la his State.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 1. -- The pinnacle of the season was reached to-night. Everywhere there is gayety. The visitors have poured into Cape May this week because of the hot weather which the Government forecasters have dealt out to the cities. The New-York colony here has been greatly augmented this week, and in every social function there are a number of them taking prominent parts.

Thomas C. Platt and Mark Hanna shook hands yesterday in the most cordial manner, and they both declared afterward that everything was harmonious mid delightful between the Republican National organization and the Republican State organization.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. Aug. 1. -- The city by the sea is virtually full, and with such an outlook the climax of the season, which always occurs about the middle of the month, will find much crowding at this resort. Last Saturday and Sunday the throng already quartered here was increased by the arrival of 30,000 visitors.
A new method of handling foreign mails went into effect yesterday, by which the forwarding of mail matter destined for points outside NewYork will be greatly expedited.

Any study of Guiana must be from the delta of the Orinoco or along the many streams that interlace the country. The reason is obvious. The country is almost as unknown as many regions in the heart of Africa. There are no means of communication except the rivers, with here and there a few mule paths extending from the right bank of the Lower Orinoco to the mining camps of the interior.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 1. -- A successful fair for the benefit of the Fresh Air and Convalescent Home was held Tuesday afternoon at the home of the Mrs. William B. Smith, in Ridge Road, under the management of the Misses Hodenpyl, Miss Lulu Rubsamen, Miss Jessie Doane, Miss Mabel Smith, and Miss Meta Pollak.

The Hartford College team of cricketers will bring its very successful English tour to a conclusion on Tuesday, and will sail for the Unites States on Wednesday, returning on board the Beigenland, which runs direct from Liverpool to Philadelphia.

The American people doubtless take more liberites with the language of their country than any other nation in the world. When events get too big for the vocabulary as it has been approved up to date, they make such additions or combinations as may be necessary to express their feelings and fit the situation as they regard it.

The death of a well-known literary man a few days ago through morphinomania has called attention to the rapid spread among brain workers of this insidious habit. It was recently calculated that in America there are at least 100,000 persons who use regularly opium in some of its forms. Signs are not wanting that in England more and more are constantly coming under the domination of the drug.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 1. -- Nicholas Ball, the "King of Block Island" for forty years, died to-day at his 0scean View Hotel. He leaves a fortune, the nucleus of which was gathered at "Rattlesnake Bar" on the north fork of the American River, in the years 1849-51. Mr. Ball started out when nine years old to seek his fortune.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. -- The stenographic reports sent out from Chicago July 9 leave no doubt as to the fate of Senator Hill's proposed amendments to the platform reported to the Democratic Convention.

There are several curious underground portions of New-York City which it is not the business of the fewer Commission to explore, nor with which the Public Works Department has a right to interfere, but which are possessed of a unique interest. They are the catacombs, which, in these days of cremation and other modern method of burial, still exist under the city.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 1. -- At the Hotel Ampersand the time seems to pass away all too quickly.

Two stories are told by Neckam of the close of the twelfth century to illustrate the account of the game of chess -- one of Louis le Gros, who, when fleeing from Henry I. of England, killed a soldier who had caught his horse by the reins, saying that the King could never be taken, even in chess.

Mrs. Laura A. Tisdale of this city is the possessor of two genuine copies of Horace Greeley's publications. The Log Cabin and The Extra Log Cabin. The Log Cabin was published simultaneously in New York and Albany, and was a four-pages sheet of twenty columns. The copy in possession of Mrs. Tisdale is dated Sept. 20, 1940, and is the twenty-second number of Volume I., published by H. Greeley Co.

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Aug. 1. -- This has been a most delightful week at the Gap, and, although there is not the same social dissipation that there was a week ago, there is still much life and activity.

RYE, N.Y, Aug. 1. - Henry D. Hotchkiss, one of the sachems of the Tammany Society, who is spending the Summer at the Ostrander cottage, in Grace Church Street, said this evening that the action of the Executive Committee of Tammany Hall in indorsing the Bryan and Sewall ticket was a very great political thunder, because it necessarily indorses the platform, although there is entire silence in the solution about the platform itself.

From The Buffalo Courier.The death of the Rev. John H. Campbell at Lake View recently will be mourned not only by those near to him but by thousands of players throughout the country. It is doubtful if any man out of the player's profession had so wide an acquaintance with the actors and actresses of our time and of those palmy days when Forrest was the greatest American tragedian.

August is a rather conspicuous mouth as far as astronomical phenomena are concerned, and there are various interesting events that will attract our attention. There are two eclipses, one of the sun, on the 8th, that we are not permitted to see in our latitude, a fact much to be regretted, as it is a total eclipse.
BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug.1 -- This city to-day was one of mourning. Business in all the stores was suspended, and everything is at a standstill.

The first duty of an American Ambassador upon his arrival in London is to obtain an interview with the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, and to deliver to him a copy of his letter of credence, says James Walter Smith in The Strand Magazine for August. The Secretary of the Embassy usually notifies the Foreign Secretary of the Ambassador's arrival, and in this way prepares for the interview.

Ever since the bicycle fad developed into large proportions, men of an imaginative turn of mind have been busying themselves trying to find new uses for the wheel or new forms in which it may be made. Not only have water bicycles been proposed, but also machines to navigate the air. In the latter field there is very little hope for success.

This is a very good novel. It is the story of the rehabilitation of a man's character, but, as is usual in such cases, irreparable mischief is done before the light is seen. The hero, Rupert Van Hals, is a Dutch artist, poor, proud, and possessed of undoubted talent, but its true expression is hampered by his weak, selfish, and pleasure-loving disposition.

SHANGHAI, Aug. 1. -- The recent disastrous tidal wave along the coast of Northern Japan has been paralleled by a similar phenomenon on the coast of Haichau, northeast of the Province of Kiangsu, in which Shanghai is situated.

What would be the objections to free coinage of both gold and silver without legal-tender qualifications, the Government simply certifying to weight and flueness? All contracts could provide for gold or silver payment, as the parties might agree. This would be free coinage without fiat mixture.

The pretense of SHEEHAN and the other Tammany leaders that the organization demanded the indorsement of the Chicago nominations and that the Executive Committee had to yield to the pressure would bring a smile to the lips of a graven image. In Tammany Hall the pressure is from above, not from below.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- According to the reports received by the provisional National Executive Committee of the anti-free-silver Democrats, thirty-six States will be represented at the Indianapolis meeting of National Committeemen by persons instructed to sign and join in the issue of a call for a National Nominating Convention.

In a review published recently, Mr. Grant Allen commends a certain author for having had the courage to use in print the colloquial "are supposed to" instead of "are supposed to do," which, according to the critic, is what "a fool would have written." Mr. Allen asserts that in actual speech "no educated man, except, perhaps, a prig," ever uses the longer form.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 1. -- The First and Third Divisions of the First Naval Battalion, comprising fifty men, under command of Lieut. Commander George E. Kent, arrived at Sands Point to-day to join the Second and Fourth Divisions in the camp. The tug E.S. Atwood brought the tars to their destination.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 1. -- The Hotel Brooklyn is notably successful this season. Some of the things contributing to its popularity are the natural attractions of the locality, the perfect hygienic conditions that prevail, the excellence of the hotel itself, pure air and water, the in-suite variety of sports and entertainments offered, and its easy accessibility to New-York.

The trans-Saharian railway is a project worth at least consideration. The East Algerian Railway now reaches Biskra, and might be carried on at any time by Tuggurt to Ouargla; the difficulty of shifting sands engineering enterprise would be equal to, and the French have so increased the water supply that by artesian wells want of water would no longer be a serious obstacle.

Again there were but twelve players at the Compass Whist Match at the Brooklyn Whist Club last week. The highest score North and South was 133, made by A. and L. Josephson. The highest score East and West was 147, made by Tolaz and Elwell. The average North and South was 132; East and West 141.

Within a few days the appraisers of the estate of the late John Stetson, Jr., will have completed their labors and filed their inventory. It will no doubt surprise the general public to know that the property which the deceased theatrical manager, broker, hotel proprietor, real estate holder, , left will probably fall short of $400,000, and in certain contingencies will be much less than that sum.

The people of Japan will soon gaze with wonder at the kissing scene in "The Widow Jones" through the medium of a vitascope. They will be initiated into the mysteries of plumbing, and thereby learn to appreciate the rare wit of American paragraphers. They will also build bicycle factories and inaugurate a bloomer craze among the dark-eyed houris of the Orient.

Sarah Lefalks, thirteen years old, kept the authorities at Snake Hill excited for two hours Friday afternoon, during which time she made two escapes, one of which included a leap from a cliff thirty feet high, while the other ended with a long chase through the Hackensack swamps, in which all the boys in the almshouse took part. Incidentally, a man's leg was broken, and he is now an inmate of the County Hospital.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1. -- According to the reports received by the provisional National Executive Committee of the anti-free-silver Democrats, thirty-six States will be represented at the Indianapolis meeting of National Committeemen by persons instructed to sign and join in the issue of a call for a National Nominating Convention.

A coachman who for many years had been in charge of a large stable of valuable carriage horses gave the writer some curious instances of the nervous illusions of horses. Once only did he find a whole stable in anything like permanent fear. He had taken ten carriage horses to a large house in Norfolk, where they stood in a line in a ten-stalled stable.

The Captain and crew of the German bark Ernst, abandoned in leaking condition and ere this probably sunk in midocean, were brought into port yesterday by the French Line steamship La Bourgogne, from Havre.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 2. -- The local riders who are to compete in the Atalanta Wheelmen races at Waverly Park Saturday, Aug. 22, are practicing for the event. The track work will be begun to-morrow, when the gates of the park will be opened daily for wheelmen, after 5 P.M. Speculation on the result of the team race between the policemen, firemen, and letter carriers is rife, and the race will likely prove a scorcher.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2.--Frederick Ward and Mrs. Sarah Jane Williams were arrested to-day as they came ashore from the steamer Rhynland, which arrived from Liverpool. The couple were arrested on the affidavit of British Consul Clipperton, who charged them with larceny and with having eloped from Tipton, England.

GLASGOW, July 25. -- Meteor continues her career of light weather victories, and at Kingstown has beaten her rivals twice over in Dublin Bay. Meteor's light weather victories have steadily been recording her speed, and in the case of Britannia the record has shown over the steadiest races sailed about ten minutes faster over a fifty-mile course than Britannia.

Newport Harbor is alive with beautiful pleasure craft, gathered these to witness or take part in the annual races. Honoria Hensler has come on board the Neckan, the yacht of her rich Vandowater cousins. She is rich in beauty and all feminine charms, but not in worldly goods, and is engaged to marry Chauncey Parkes, a poor but brilliant college professor.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala. Aug. 2. -- The South has had a great political shaking up this year, particularly in the Gulf States, and for the time being free silver reigns supreme. However, in Mississippi, Louisiana, the Carolinas, Texas, and Alabama the wheels still turn, and there is no telling what may happen in November.

A mad bull caused a scare in Central Park West and Central Park about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. The infuriated animal dashed down the street, tossing his head in the air, and bellowing with rage.
LOS ANGELES, Cal., July 21. -- Two men in a rowboat fought for their lives amid a school of ten whales yesterday off Newport Beach.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- Senator Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, arrived in Washington at noon to-day, and, after a few hours' rest at his residence, went down to the headquarters of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, where he had an hour's talk with Secretary Gardner, who had come to town from his Summer home at Laurel, Md., to meet him.

Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN is right on the main question, but his ideas about methods are rather Quixotic. A third platform without a third candidate would not mend matters much. If, as Mr. COCKRAN proposes, the sound-money Democratic platform, while indorsing the McKinley Electors in the various States, should declare for a tariff for revenue only and denounce "Republican paternalism," Mr. MCKINLEY and his Electors would be compelled to decline the indorsement and repudiate the indorsers.

Another well-known Hoosier Democrat who finds he cannot conscientiously support the Presidential nominee on a free-silver platform is Capt. William Schrodt of Jeffersonville, Ind., who is chief bookkeeper for the firm of Harbison Gathright of this city. Capt. Schrodt has always voted the Democratic ticket previously under all circumstances, but the Populistic dose this time, he says, is entirely too bitter for him to take.

A fishing party consisting of A.D. Neilson, Gustave Neilson, Emil Neilson, and John Neilson, all of 133 Coffey Street, Brooklyn, went from Red Hook Point to Gravesend Bay Saturday night and reached the fishing ground shortly before midnight.

CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 2. -- There has not been a funeral in Camden for years that has attracted public attention to so great a degree as that of Edward W. Farr, engineer of the express train which collided with the excursion train on the Atlantic City meadows Thursday, which occurred this afternoon from the residence of his brother, Charles W. Farr, 730 Mount Vernon Street.

At the general meeting of the Palestine Exploration Fund this year, Lieut. Col. Watson read the annual report, which stated that the excavations at Jerusalem, for which a firman was granted by the Porte, have been carried on by Dr. Bliss with success. An interesting rocks arp has been traced for some distance along this side of an old wall of the city, scum of the present wall, and followed for over 1,000 feet.

A long and varied history has been that of Richmond. Strange is the fate that has come over the royal palace erected there by the seventh Henry. Neither war nor an act of God destroyed it, but the deliberate act of man. Happy were it had this monument of Tudor times, this home of Tudor Kings, been preserved to our day.

One of the things that gives men longest pause when they are told of woman's business faculty and her powers of organization is her acknowledge failure with her own servants.

ALPENA, S.D., Aug. 2. -- Trainmen and tramps engaged in a pitched battle here yesterday afternoon with coupling pins, coal, and stones for weapons. Car windows were broken by the flying missiles, and several of the combatants were injured, but none seriously.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 2. -- This has been the most pleasant Sunday of the season at this place. A cool sea breeze swept over the place all day, and nearly every person who was in possession of a horse and carriage, or a bicycle, was on the avenue.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug. 2. -- To-day was one of funerals in this city. Eleven bodies were interred in different cemeteries. They were those of some of the victims of the railroad disaster on the meadows near Atlantic City, where the Reading express train ran into the West Jersey Red Men's excursion train, killing forty-seven persons.
BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Aug. 2. -- The downpour of rain this afternoon kept the President indoors. After it cleared it was cool in the afternoon and open fires were not uncomfortable.

Modern civilization has not altogether crowded out the picturesque nor have recent inventions completely driven ancient contrivances entirely to the wall. Here and there the searcher after the quaint may find an interesting remnant of bygone times quite worth careful inspection.

To-day London will witness a sight so rare as to be almost unique in her history. A body of foreign soldiery will march through the streets of the capital with drums beating, colors flying, and weapons unsheathed. But, in spite of this martial display, our visitors, who are a detachment of the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston, Mass., come in the friendliest guise.

The people of Chicago have not obtained a supply of wholesome water by extending the main conduit of the city's water system to a point in Lake Michigan four miles from the shore. It will be remembered that this extension followed the great epidemic of typhoid fever which preceded the holding of the World's Fair, an epidemic which suggested The London Lancet's memorable investigation concerning the pollution of the water taken from the lake.

One contributor states that he is a "gentleman" wishing to go abroad on a historical and antiquarian tour through Normandy; the only difficulty being that he has not sufficient means to accomplish his object. He therefore requests my father to send him 12 at once, and he, the writer, will immediately start, and contribute gratuitously, he says, to The Cornhill an account of his journey.

Riots and fights yesterday followed the opening of their shops by the clothing contractors who have broken with the Brotherhood of Tailors and announced that they would take on any men who might apply, union or non-union.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2. -- The paint shop of the Cramp Ship and Engine Building Company was burned last night, causing a loss of about $40,000. The burned structure was of frame, 200 feet long by 90 feet wide.

Those who do not yet see clearly what BRYAN and his followers have set out to do should study that doctrine or tenet of the silver men to which the Bryan party's platform refers when it speaks of the "appreciation of gold."

A Lewiston man -- Uncle Roberts Williams Quimby -- has found what he claims will rid the city of the English sparrows, which he thinks are a pest. Of course, many of us would seriously miss the saucy, good-natured little fellows that chatter around the windows and build nests in eaves and behind signs with the most utter disrespect to the feeling and tastes of the ers.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 2. -- The convict known as Frederick Whitney, who committed suicide in the Maryland Penitentiary yesterday, appears by his own confession to have added murder to his long list of crimes. Whitney sought out Warden Wayler Friday afternoon, and intimated that he meant to end his life.

Webster Gray, who was found dead in his room, at the Grand Union Hotel, on Saturday, having committed suicide by cutting his throat, was a retired merchant tailor of Pittsburg, Penn. He arrived at the hotel on July 23 and gave his address as "862 Trumbull Avenue, Detroit." He had been drinking heavily for several days before his death.

Eight of the eleven men who evaded the Spanish military and naval forces and reached Nassau. N.P., from Cuba in an open boat, July 26, arrived here yesterday on the steamship Antilia of the Bahama Steamship Line.

" There are a great many places in and around New-York that are well worth seeing," said the woman. "I have never been in New-York in the Summer before, and this year my husband and I have been taking ferry trips -- exploring the country. We have a large map and study out the routes. We have no idea of the kind of country we are going to penetrate, and we have some delightful surprises.

A large congregation was attracted to Calvary Baptist Church, in Fifty-seventh Street near Sixth Avenue, last evening, to hear the Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur preach on "Americanism or Anarchism -- Which." All could not be accommodated, as the auditorium of the building could not be lighted, owing to the electric lighting plant not being completed.

Mark Hanna returned to the Waldorf yesterday morning from Englewood, N.J., where he went Saturday to visit his sister, and remained ther until after noon, when he left again, telling the clerk he intended to take the 1:15 train "out of town." He did not state his destination, and it was not known whether he went back to Englewood or to Ophir Farm, or some other place.

NEWPORT, Aug. 2. -- Heavy rains in the morning kept cottagers from church, but the weather this afternoon was bright and cheerful, and there were many out driving. The visiting clergymen to-day included the Rev. E.N. Potter of New-York, at All Saints' Chapel, the fashionable Summer Episcopal church.

We notice that The Press of this city is making a great effort to give the tariff overshadowing prominence as an issue in the campaign. We also notice that while it is using the old arguments which have been addressed by the Republican Party to farmers and others, it shows in the use of them a fine contempt for facts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2. -- The line and staff controversial literature is increasing. The latest contribution is a pamphlet issued in behalf of the staff which may be accepted as a reply to the anonymous brochure which recently appeared from the line organization, and which was spoken of in these dispatches as commendable for the dignity and tolerance with which it discussed a subject usually handled with much fervor and some interchange of abuse.

The death of Gen. Raleigh Edward Colston on July 29 at the Lee Camp, Confederate Soldiers' Home, in Richmond, Va., terminates the earthly career of one of the most interesting figures of the Southern Army. Gen. Colston served with distinction on the Confederate side, and after the close of the civil war entered the service of the Khedive of Egypt.

The political conditions of to-day remind me of a political meeting I attended a good many years ago, when I was a boy. The meeting was held in a New-England city, one ward of which, because almost every man in it was an Irishman, we called "Paddy Ward." The meeting I am speaking of was held in this Irish ward of the city.

The precious Swietenia mahogani does not grow in clumps and groves like our pine and walnut, but each monarch stands alone in solitary state, amid a dense growth of other huge trees, its trunk concealed by a wild tangle of vines, orchids, and underbrush, recurring the closest attention of the inexperienced woodsman to detect it.

-- The unpublished works of Gibbon, which are to be issued in the Autumn, will comprise three large volumes. In the first will be given six autobiographies and in the second and third Gibbon's private letters from 1753 to 1794, addressed to his father, stepmother, Lord Sheffield, and others.

FOSSIL, Oregon, Aug. 2. -- J.M. Smouth, who arrived here Friday from Canyon City, brings news of a desperate battle between sheepmen and cattlemen on the Snow Mountain, southwest of Canyon City, about a week ago. Mr. Kitchen, employed by the Princeville Sheep and Land Company, and two cattlemen were slain.

" One of the serious mistakes of life," says a Down-East stove dealer, "is to get a deaf person offended with you. You never can explain anything to set it right. Somehow, when a person loses his hearing, he is apt to become extra-sensitive and suspicious, and it takes but little to give him offense.

If, as is sometimes held, (though we ourselves are very strongly of the opposite opinion,) the Hottentots and Bushmen of South Africa are not human creatures caught in the very act of developing from lower forms, but are the result of degeneration from some higher type, then the creatures resulting from a cross between the two might revert to the higher type, and be of higher social feeling and intellectual power than either.

Two funeral services were held yesterday afternoon in Elks Hall, Broadway and Twenty-seventh Street, over the body of John J. Tindale, the veteran member of the Building Department, who died Friday at his home, in Mount Vernon.

Charles W. Wall, who was shot in the chest at his lodging house, 202 East Seventeenth Street, Friday afternoon, positively identified yesterday as his assailant George Latham, the railroad conductor who was arrested late Friday night.
FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 2. -- William Finnegan, a hotel keeper, and a well-know resident of Third Street, College Point, is in bed suffering from dog bites received this afternoon.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 2. -- A meeting of leading Republicans of Denver was held this morning in the office of a well-known attorney, and it was resolved to ask Senator E.D. Wolcott to resign his Senatorial office.

Ever since bicycles first came into use efforts have been made to improve the lamp. That a thoroughly satisfactory solution of the problem has not been obtained is demonstrated by the fact that inventors are still hard at work upon it. To this, as a further proof, might be added the fact that riders are so frequently fined for not carrying a proper light.

Four young castaways in a small boat were towed into the Government slip at the Battery Basin yesterday, worn out with long hours of rowing against strong and tortuous currents. They gave their names as "Jack" Harris, ten years old; John O'Brien, fifteen; Enoch Belcher, twelve, and "Jack" Dortan, fourteen.

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 2. -- The pilotboat Glance returned to port this afternoon, having picked up a small boat twenty-five miles out in the Gulf, with Commander Joaquin Delegado, Lieut. Fernando de Velasco, and a Spanish boatman, who left Cuba's shore last Friday night. They fell in Saturday with a Norwegian bark, which took them on board and brought them over.

Apropos of the article in "Gathered About Town," published yesterday in THE NEW-YORK TIMES regarding the politeness of a car conductor in this city, I should like to say something in relation to the utter lack of politeness of the public servants in this country. If there be anything more offensive than to be touched on the shoulder or to have a finger poked into your back I should like to know it.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The eighth annual Summer meeting of the International Order of the King's Daughters and Sons commenced this morning in Ocean Grove. The attendance was very large, being made up of daughters and sons from all parts of the country.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3. -- The Summer residents to-day won their battle in the fight to retain Coggeshall Avenue, which runs through the heart of the cottage colony, as a private way.

A can of benzine exploded in a small dry goods store on the ground floor of 2,295 Eighth Avenue yesterday morning and caused a fire which for a time endangered several buildings and imperiled the lives of twenty or more persons.
