The two new movements of the Salvation Army for the reclaiming of drunken men and fallen women will be in operation some time this month. Commander Booth-Tucker and Brigadier Lewis have been at work for some time on the details of the schemes and their plans will be laid before the staff officers at a meeting to be held at the army's headquarters on Aug. 29.

At the recent Democratic and Populist Conventions there was repeatedly expressed a desire that this country should "go it alone" with respect to trade, currency standards, and everything else. Some persons remarked that Americans did not want to do business with foreign nations or people's.

Much indignation has been aroused in Ireland by a proposal to erect a ring fence inclosing the Giant's Causeway, and to mulct the tourists of a small sum for admission. Orangemen and Nationalists, Catholics and Protestants have combined their forces to resist this attempt to assert "proprietary rights over beautiful points of scenery."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 3. -- The yachts of the New-York Yacht Club assembled in Glen Cove this morning for the annual cruise. Compared with former years the fleet was a small one, but then this is an off year with the New-York Yacht Club, and there is no cup race, with cup defenders to give things a boom. When there is no cup race, racing is dull with this club.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 3. -- It appears at midnight that Johnston has the State by from 30,000 to 40,000 majority. The silver Populists have evidently been allured into support of the silver Democratic ticket.
Chairman Hanna of the Republican National Committee was in conference again yesterday with prominent members of the New-York State Committee.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 3. -- Orlando Smith, President of the Connellsville and Pittsburg Railway, filed a petition in the United States Circuit Court to-day asking that the issue of receivers' certificates to the value of $856,000 be authorized by the courts, the proceeds of the sale of which would be used in making permanent improvements in the line of road.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Ex-National Committeeman Ben T. Cable, one of the leaders of the bolting movement in Illinois, was read out of the Democratic Party this morning at the meeting of the State Central Committee.
The woes of the all-star cast which presented "As You Like It" on Saturday at Asbury Park, under the management of George C. Tyler, were freely aired upon the Rialto yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 3. -- The Esperanza, owned by A. Van Winkle of Bristol, won the cup for 30-footers, given by Mrs. Edwin D. Morgan, to-day. But H.B. Duryea's Vaquero would probably have won had she not grounded. She was then well in the lead and gaining. Mrs. Duryea was assisting her husband in sailing the unfortunate craft.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwaded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
Miss Grace Wilson and Cornelius Vanderbilt, Jr., were married quietly at noon yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard T. Wilson of 511 Fifth Avenue.

The stock market was dull and spiritless to-day. Not more than three or four stocks showed any signs of activity, and the volume of trading in those -- such as Sugar, St. Paul, and Manhattan -- was much smaller than usual. The total sales of all classes on stocks aggregated, for the day, only 96,633, shares, and prices generally manifested a drooping tendency.

Newport harbor is alive with beautiful pleasure and gathered there to witness or take part in the annual races. Honoria Hensler has come on board the Neckon, the yacht of her rich Vunderwater cousins. She is rich in beauty and all feminine charms, but not in worldly goods, and is engaged to marry Chauncey Parkes, a poor but brilliant college professor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3.--Edwin Winter, President of the Northern Pacific Railway Company, accompanied by Edward D. Adams, Chairman of the Reorganization Committee, and a party of prominent New-York and St. Paul Railroad officials, arrived in Seattle, Washington, yesterday from Tacoma, and are the guests of Receiver Burleigh.

The strike which was ordered in the publishing house of Braunworth, Munn Barber, at 16 Nassau Street, Brooklyn, and the bookbindery of Edwin Ives Sons, at 22, 24, and 26 Howard Street, this city, about four weeks ago, threatens to develop into a boycott.

NEWARK, Aug. 3. -- A woman registered at the Park Avenue Hotel six days ago as "Mary Smith, Canada." A.M. Bishop, a New-Haven attorney, came here to see her two or three days afterward and is stopping at the same hotel. A hallboy smelled gas in Miss Smith's room this morning and told the proprietor, Joseph Koelhoefer.
Justice Calvin E. Pratt of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the Second Judicial District, died at Rochester, Mass., yesterday morning.

Despite the fact that Greater New-York's entries in the baseball pennant race are hopelessly out of the hunt, there was considerable interest shown in the meeting between them at Eastern Park yesterday. This was the result, no doubt, of the close contest for local prestige, each club having won four games from the other.

SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Aug. 3. -- The new 800-foot Government lock was informally opened this morning at 10 o'clock, when the Government hosts Hancock and Andy Johnson and the river and harbor tug Antelope entered through the upper gates. The boats were crowded with invited guests, and 2,000 spectators congregated on the side of the big lock to witness the ceremony.
SARATOGA, Aug. 8. -- Three of the leading dental associations of the country are in session here. While distinct each is interested in the deliberations of the others.

Justice O'Dwyer, in City Court, Chambers, heard arguments yesterday on the motion made by Levy Stuart, attorneys for Peter Henderson Co.; to have the Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter of the Baptist Tabernacle punished for contempt of court in failing to obey an order to appear for examination in supplementary proceedings.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 3. -- Major McKinley has had a few days of quiet and its turning over in his mind the points which he thinks of discussing in his letter of acceptance. He will not, however, aim to have his letter ready for publication for three or four weeks.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 3. -- Secretary Herbert was one of the earliest to cast his vote for the straight Democratic State and county ticket.

I propose in this article to apply the free-silver idea to the case of a woman I know. She is a person of humble circumstances -- works for her living as a house servant. Inasmuch as she reads THE NEW-YORK TIMES every night after she has completed her day's work, I will not give her her right name here; instead, I will call her Marie.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 3 -- The State Committee of the National Silver Party held a meeting to-day for the purpose of discussing the matter of a State ticket.

The "striking tailors" have been acting foolishly by making attacks upon shops that ventured to give employment to non-union men, but in so doing they have followed examples of which they must have heard, set by "organized labor" in other strikes. The police have dealt leniently, even gently, with those taking part in the disorders, and perhaps were justified in doing so.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 3. -- About 3,000 persons saw Baid and Sanger race on the new Athletic Park bicycle track to-day.

Chairman JONES of Arkansas has put upon record his disgust with the Populist delegates at St. Louis from the Southern States. He says "they were not a creditable class," and that they admitted while in St. Louis that they "were out for nothing but spoil."

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Four National Committeemen to-day were added to the list of sound-money Democrats who will attend the Indianapolis meeting. W.B. Haideman of the National Executive Committee sent word for Georgia that T.B. Neal, President of the Atlanta Chamber of Commerce, would represent that State.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 3.--In a scuffle over the possession of a cane last night, Frederick Blevins was thrown to the floor by John McMullen and instantly killed, his neck having been broken by the fall.

The War Office is to be congratulated on the progress which has been made in the rearmament of the Royal Horse and Field Artillery. Up to this time the guns for the six batteries of Royal Horse Artillery which it was decided to manufacture at Woolwich have all been issued, while the four remaining batteries to be supplied by the trade will be ready by the middle of next month.
A Chicago newspaper publishes a private letter recently received from Scotland by a resident of that city. We take from it the following:

The twenty-third annual report of the Board of Agriculture of the State of New-Jersey for the year 1895 has just been issued. It will repay attentive examination. Especially will the taxpayers of the State of New-Jersey find it to be to their interest to examine this volume in order that they may determine for themselves whether they wish their money to be expended in printing and disseminating free-silver literature.

The trial of J. Elliott Smith, Superintendent of Telegraph and Electrical Appliances of the Fire Department of the City of NewYork, who is charged with fraud and incompetency in connection with the discharge of his official duties, was resumed yesterday morning at the Fire Department Headquarters, in East Sixty-seventh Street.

Louise Fredericks became a heroine last evening when she jumped into the East River at the foot of Fifty-first Street and brought nine-year-old Henry Reinstein, who was sinking for the third time, safely to the dock on her shoulder.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3. -- Organized labor will not ask for the removal of Henry C. Payne from the National Republican Executive Committee. Agitation in that respect has been dropped by the Chicago Trade and Labor Assembly after a review of the evidence. The Milwaukee trades unions have officially requested a discontinuance of hostility to Mr. Payne.

" Those who expected the Yale crew to win the Grand Challenge Cup, or to beat Leander," writes the sporting authority of The Pall Mall Gazette, "were expecting altogether too much, and have no reason to be proud of their judgment." Continuing, the author of the article says:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 3. -- Senator John B. Gordon of Georgia, whose name has been mentioned for the Vice Presidency on a gold Democratic ticket, says that he would not accept any nomination for any political office. While remaining a sound-money man, he will support the nominees of the Chicago Convention.

Emile Hubert, twenty-five years old, of 211 East Fiftieth Street, was riding his bicycle down Third Avenue at One Hundred and Nineteenth Street alongside of a cable car at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, when, in turning out of the way of an approaching wagon, he ran directly in front of a cable car and fell across the track.

ROME, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- A patriotic celebration was held here this evening. Fort Stanwix Chapter, Daughters of the American Revolution, and Gansevoort-Willett Chapter, Sons of the Revolution, celebrated Fort Stanwix Day at the residence of H.K. While, 121 East Dominick Street, which is on the site of the southeast bastion of the old fort.
One hundred and fifty theatrical managers met in Hoyt's Theatre at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon and formed an organization which will be known as the United Theatrical Managers' Association.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- The Republicans of the Second Assembly District of Westchester County held their convention in Masonic Hall in this village to-day at noon to elect delegates to the State, Congressional, and Judiciary Conventions.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 3. -- The announcement is made that, despite the injunction of Judge Simonton, the Seaboard Air Line does not propose to suspend its warfare on the Southern Railway. It is claimed by the Seaboard officials that the Inter-State Commerce Commission has no jurisdiction over water lines, and the fight will be confined to Chesapeake Bay if the injunction granted by Judge Simonton is made permanent.

BESSEMER, Mich., Aug. 3. -- The Tilden Mine on Saturday closed down both day and night shifts of No. 9 shaft. This completes the shut-down of the Rockefeller mines in this city. Nos. 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10 shafts now employ just enough men to keep the mine clear of water. In a large number of mines the pumps have been taken out and the mines allowed to fill with water.

A report was filed with the Surrogate yesterday by Referee Rastus S. Ransom in a suit instituted by S. Howell Shepard against his mother, Pamele W. Shepard, to compel her to file a report as administratrix and executrix of the will of her husband, John F. Shepard, and to pay to the petitioner a legacy of $50,000 which was left to him in his father's will.

Believers in palmistry are much interested at the present moment in a story circulating in Paris, according to which Mme. de Thebes, the celebrated mistress in the art, predicted his death to the Marquis de Mores a few months before his tragic end. At a dinner party given in Paris last Winter by Dr. Tripler, the well-known electricity doctor, the Marquis and Mme. de Thebes were present, among others.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 3. -- Walter Crafts, aged 85 years, President of the Commercial National Bank of Columbus, Ohio, a guest at the Monongahela House since Saturday evening, was found dead in his room at 9 o'clock to-day.

There were exciting times on the east side yesterday when the association contractors opened their shops for work, this time made better police protection than on Sunday. There were rough and tumble fights between union and non-union men, or with such union men as had got tired of holding out and wanted to earn some money.

ALBANY, Aug. 3. -- A decision which will be of interest to those holding stock in companies which have been consolidated has been rendered by Deputy Attorney General Hasbrouck. The decision will affect certain consolidations of ice companies in New-York City and other cities in the State.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 3. -- William R. Van Dusen of Morristown, who was arrested last week for robbing the residence of Frederick Danbey, at 119 William Street, East Orange, on May 17 last, has confessed to having robbed five other houses in this vicinity.

Anent the third-ticket idea: I wrote a friend in Missouri that I had heard that he was going to vote for McKinley, though I have known him as an unswerving Democrat for nearly thirty years. His reply:

The departed glories of the Hotel Brunswick, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, were brought to mind yesterday, when the entire remaining contents of the wine cellar of the house were sold at auction by Bryan Y. Kennelly of 66 Liberty Street, by order of Joseph H. Baker, the receiver for the Hotel Brunswick Company.

Tammany Hall's hasty action in indorsing the nomination of Bryan and Sewall is still a source of wonder and chagrin to many of its friends. Those who are not friendly to the Wigwam credited it with too much shrewdness to take so rash a step. It has succeeded in disappointing both friends and foes as to its political judgment.

William P. St. John, in the dual role of Treasurer of the National Democratic and the National Silver Committees, opened his headquarters in the Bartholdi Hotel, at Broadway and Twenty-third Street, yesterday morning.
BOSTON, Aug. 3. -- George F. Washburne of this city, Eastern member of the National Executive Committee of the People's Party, to-day issued the following challenge to Bishop John P. Newman:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 3.--The inquest by Coroner McLaughlin into the deaths resulting from the collision between the Reading Railroad express and the Bridgeton excursion train on the West Jersey Railroad, on the meadows, last Thursday evening, began to-day.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 3. -- Nearly 100 men, all of the employes of Van Wagoner Williams, hardware manufacturers, near the Brown Hoist works, inaugurated what promises to be a great sympathetic strike of all the union men in the city by going out to-day.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 2. -- The Grand Circuit meeting opened on the course of the Columbus Driving Association very suspiciously this afternoon. The weather was ideal, the track in fine condition, and the attendance flattering. The feature of the racing was the remarkable time made in the first two heats of the 2:14 pace, the winning horses lowering their records by nearly 6 seconds. The summaries:

HICKSVILLE, L.I., Aug. 3. -- The residents of Syosett, or at least some of them, are greatly agitated over the appointment of John R. De Vine as Postmaster of the village. He is a Democrat, but politics had nothing to do with the objections made to his appointment. He succeeds a Democrat, Charles A. Van Sise.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 3. -- Senator F.E. Warren of Wyoming, in an interview to-day, said:
Of the three sales advertised to be held yesterday at 111 Broadway one was adjourned for a week and two for two weeks.

The Tiffany Glass and Decorating Company has on exhibition at Charles Scribner Co.'s, on Fifth Avenue, a mosaic in glass which will ultimately be placed in the Alexander Memorial Hall at Princeton University.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 4. -- The smashing of two State and one world record made 3,000 persons go wild with enthusiasm at the bicycle races to-day. There was a stiff breeze blowing from the south, but wonderful time was made in spite of it. Bald first went for the third-of-a-mile, flying start, world record of 0:33 3-5, made by W. Hamilton, at Coronado, Cal., on March 2.
NUREMBERG, Aug. 4. -- The fourteenth round of the international chess masters' tournament was played in this city to-day. The results were as follows:

BUTTE, Mon., Aug. 4. -- On invitation of Senator Lee Mantle, Chairman of the State Republican Central Committee representative members of the party to the number of several hundred were in conference here all day and late into the night, discussing the political situation and the advisability of putting McKinley Electors into the field this Fall.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The interest in the morning drills now centres about the north parade grounds, where the cavalry drills are held, and the infantry parade grounds are deserted by visitors. Even the battalions of the regiment that drill there would gladly change places with the separate company battalion which shares the north grounds with the cavalry, for the manoeuvring of a body of horsemen is a fascinating thing to watch.

When the sound-money Democrats were sent to Chicago as delegates they were elected to their mission as to a Democratic Convention. But instead of that they found a convention packed by packed primaries, carrying everything by brute force and violence, and sweeping aside all customary rules and precedents.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- The speculative deal in the stocks of the Diamond Match and NewYork Biscuit Companies has come to an end. The Moore Brothers have failed. The greatest speculation ever known in Chicago has culminated in the failure of the people who were behind the deal.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Tobias Castor, formerly Democratic National Committeeman from Nebraska, and now a worker for McKinley and the gold standard, was a visitor at Republican National Headquarters today. He is engaged in distributing gold literature and traveling through the West.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 4. -- There remains no doubt that the Democratic nominee for Governor has swept Alabama, and that the new State Legislature will be Democratic by large gains over 1894.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 4. -- Prof. R.S. Tarr of Cornell University, who started with Lieut. Peary on an arctic geological expedition in the steamer Hope, has written to his family in this city that they are stuck in the ice.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 4. -- William L. Trenholm, Controller of the Currency in Mr. Cleveland's first Administration, and now President of the American Surety Company, talked to-day about the political situation to the correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, who called on him in his Summer home on the Heights.

The life of a Captain of an excursion steamer is not as pleasant as might appear to the casual observer. To stand in a cool pilothouse and do nothing but turn a wheel, while cool breezes blow and the thermometer registers several degrees lower than in the city, does not seem to be an unpleasant task.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 4. -- The wills of Robert Garrett were made public to-night and both instruments will be probated at Towson to-morrow. One of the documents was executed in Baltimore in 1883 and makes his wife substantially his sole devisee and legatee. The other will was drawn in London in 1886 just after the death of his brother, T. Harrison Garrett.

Chairman Hanna of the Republican National Committee is apparently on good terms with both the Platt organization and the Union League Club. The last-named organization is usually expected to make large contributions to National campaign funds. The former usually spends such portion of it as is devoted to New-York State.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

After a few days comfortable weather, that enabled people to recuperate a little, another scorcher came yesterday with a high thermometer and 90 per cent. humidity. The shady sides of the streets were eagerly sought and crowded by citizens who walked as slowly as their business would permit.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 4. -- Clarence A. Postley's beautiful schooner Colonia sailed into this harbor this afternoon, the first of the racing fleet in the New-York cruise. She was so far in the lead that some of the innocent New-Londoners had an idea that she had no competitor, and had simply sailed over the course with the cruising fleet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The silver-tipped anticipations which the sanguine Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, Senator Faulkner of West Virginia, has been dispensing from Democratic headquarters here for several days were much beclouded to-day by news received from several of the Southern States.

WEST END, LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 4. -- There was a large and enthusiastic gathering at the continuation of the Norwood Park tennis tournament to-day. Larned appeared for the first time since his return from abroad. He was matched against E.P. Fischer, the well-known New-York expert, whom he defeated in straight sets. Larned's game was superb.

The comic literature of every country assures us that to be a mother-in-law is something more than a relation. It is an occupation that may easily rise to the dignity of a profession. Motherhood-in-law is commonly regarded as the vocation of widows in particular, and relates not so much to the wives of sons, except in Japan and other unenlightened and remote parts, as to the husbands of daughters.

NEWPORT, Aug. 4. -- It was a day of much entertaining at the cottages. Mrs. Frederick W. Vanderbilt gave an informal reception in honor of Admiral Pougin de la Maissonneuve and his staff of the French ship Dubourdien. Mrs. William Post and Miss Daisy Post assisted Mrs. Vanderbilt, who served tea and showed her guests of honor about her grounds.

All the artillery organizations of the State, with the exception of the Fifth Battery of Syracuse, which it is expected will shortly be disbanded, will meet in this city to-morrow morning to take up their march to the State Camp, at Peekskill, Brig. Gen. Howard Carroll, Chief of Artillery, has issued orders directing the several batteries to assemble at 9:30 o'clock, as fallows:

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 4. -- Republican politicians from all over the State gathered in Milwaukee to-day, early comers to the State Convention to-morrow. The followers of Scofield, La Follette, Elliott, Baench, Estabrook, and Bashford, all candidates for Governor, all make large claims, and ex-Senator Sawyer is suggested as a compromise candidate by the anti-La Follette faction.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 4. -- The weather was excellent for racing, and the track in excellent condition at the Columbus Driving track to-day, and fast work was predicted generally. In the 2:09 pace, the best racing record for mares, made by Angie D. at Chicago, was broken twice; first by Pearl C., in 2:06 1/2, and later by Lettle Lorain, in the same time.

BOSTON, Aug. 4. -- Manager Edwards of the Boston branch of the Diamond Match Company said to-day: "The failure of Moore Brothers was a surprise to us. We knew nothing of it until we read the news in the paper. It wil not affect our business. Mr. Moore is Vice President of our company.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- Gilbert W. Peck of Canandaigua and Ira A. Deyo of Honeoye, both veterans from Ontario County, have been appointed special agents by Commissioner Lyman. Mr. Peck has been detailed for duty at Poughkeepsie and New-York and Mr. Deyo at Mount Vernon.

An agitation for increasing the efficiency of the Coroners' office, and possibly intended to secure its perpetuation, was inaugurated last night. The Coroners themselves were the originators, and in response to invitations they had sent out some thirty or forty gentlemen met them last night in the Coroners' office, on the third floor of the Criminal Court Building, on Centre Street, for discussion.

COWES, Aug. 4. -- The regatta of the Royal Yacht Squadron, of which the Prince of Wales is Commodore, begun to-day under favorable auspices of wind and weather. This regatta, is the event of the year in the English yachting world, and the large number of boats here yesterday, when the regatta of the Royal London Yacht Club took place, was augmented by many late arrivals last night.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- J.J. Mitchell, President of the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank, says there is little doubt that a pool will be formed to take care of the Diamond Match stock. Mr. Mitchell says:

It looks as though the Democratic victory in Alabama were so decisive that the fusionists could not seriously persist in the cry of "fraud" and "counting out" which they raised before the election with a suspicious "previousness." This victory was evidently due to the fact that the election involved only State issues and was sufficiently separated from the National election to enable the people to act with reference to that fact.
It was with deep interest but comparatively little anxiety that the failure of the Moore Brothers in Chicago was analyzed in Wall Street yesterday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Aug. 4. -- About 200 Democrats of Iowa met here to-day and formally registered their protest against the platform and candidates of the Chicago Convention. Judge John Cliggett of Mason City was named as Chairman. He made a ringing speech, in which he declared the position of the conferrees.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 4. -- The weekly crop report of the Weather Bureau states that, owing to the excessive beat and lack of rainfall over the greater part of the Southern States, the general condition of cotton is not as good as in the previous week.

SARATOGA, Aug. 4. -- The National Association of Dental Examiners continued the consideration of important matters to-day. A large number of dental institutes and colleges made application for membership. Action on all was referred.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 4. -- The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated John Lind, the silver candidate, by acclamation for Governor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- Aside from the confirmation by Federal Judge Hanford at Seattle yesterday of the sale of the Northern Pacific property in this State, sales to the amount of $300,000 for anpatented lands not selected, lying within the Congressional grant, and $1,705,200 for all lands lying within the State of Washington, were made by Special Master Alfred L. Cary, the purchaser of the entire lot being Edwin Winter.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 4. -- Another long-winded game was that of Newark and Wilmington this afternoon. In the eleventh inning, playing to bring darkness, the visitors refused to put a batsman up. The umpire thereupon gave the home team the game by a score of 9 to 0. The score:

The Executive Committee of the Tammany Hall General Committee is beginning to feel the pressure of a public sentiment that it did not take into consideration when at hastily yielded to the wishes of a few ambitious leaders and indorsed the Bryan and Sewall ticket.

The ownership of property, especially of a "home," has been regarded as one of the great conservative forces of modern society. As population increases and occupations multiply in this country a smaller proportion of the people are actual owners of the land and have a direct stake in the community as payers of taxes.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The annual school meeting and election took place in the Town Hall this afternoon. The meeting was one of indescribable confusion and was filled with disgraceful scenes. Though many women were present to vote, men shouted and threatened and made accusations of trickery and fraud against the Board of Education and wildly shook their fists.

The convention at Chicago had hardly been broken up by a separation of all the true Democrats from the half-witted part when the right name of the latter faction was at once invented. It constitutes Popocrat Party, and that is the party of the half-witted. Some people say that "hard words butter no parsnips." Other people say that plain words may be spoken to expose a fraud.

Mr. Henry M. Danton has purchase of Richard Croker the plot of ground, with old buildings, 34 to 38 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, and will erect thereon at once a brick and iron store and office building.

Two alleged policy places on the east side were raided yesterday by Anthony Comstock and Central Office Detectives Tierney and O'Connor. The evidence against the resorts was procured by W.F. Hennessy of Hanse's Detective Agency, who had had several transactions in both.

ALBANY, Aug. 4. -- The civil service rules and regulations are to be revised and a classification of the employes in the State service and in the various civil divisions in the State is to be made at once. This was determined to-day by Gov. Morton. In accordance with his decision be sent a letter to the Civil Service Commission as follows:

MONTPELIER, Vt., Aug. 4. -- Gold Democrats from different sections of the State met to-day to discuss the situation and lay out a plan of campaign. P.M. Meldon was Chairman and W.H. Creamer Secretary. After a discussion of the attitude of Dr. Henry Jackson of Barre, nominee for Governor, it was decided to wait on him and ascertain his position.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 4.--Developments to-day induce the police to believe that the confession made by Hildebrand just before he committed suicide in the Maryland Penitentiary last Saturday was a fabrication of falsehoods, devised and manufactured for the purpose of clearing his old associate, Frank Wilson, who, together with James Farrell, is now awaiting the death sentence in the Altoona (Penn.) Jail, for the murder of Henry Bonnecka.
Entries for the regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which takes place at Saratoga, N.Y., Aug. 12 and 13, are:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 4. -- The testimony brought out at to-day's session of the Coroner's inquest of the meadow railroad collision seems to fix the direct responsibility for the accident upon the dead engineer of the Reading Railroad express, Edward Farr.
The Board of Aldermen met yesterday after an adjournment of two weeks, and Chairman Olcott, for the Finance Committee, reported a resolution to fix the tax rate for the city for this year.

Senator Hill came to this city from Albany yesterday afternoon, and with Chairman Hinkley of the Democratic State Committee went to the Murray Hill Hotel. They were together there for a short time, and then went to Normandle-by-the-Sea.

Senator James K. Jones of Arkansas, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, is expected in this city to-day. His coming will be hailed with delight by Oliver Sumner Teall and the others who are at the Treasurer's headquarters at the Hotel Bartholdi, and arrangements will at once proceed for the notification of Mr. Bryan in Madison Square Garden on the 12th.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4. -- The gold Democratic headquarters received information to-day by telegraph that four more States had chosen representatives to attend the Indianapolis meeting. Joseph Metcalf of Providence will meet with the committee on behalf of Rhode Island. Col. Louis R. Ehrich of Colorado Springs will represent Colorado sound-money Democrats.

FAR ROCKAWAY, Aug. 4. -- Elaborate preparations are being made by the members of the fashionable Summer colony of Far Rockaway, Lawrence, Cedarhurst, and Arverne for a musical and dramatic entertainment to be given at the Waldorf Opera House. Far Rockaway, on Sunday, Aug. 16.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 4. -- A wedding festival in South River, a few miles from this city, Sunday and Monday presented some amusing innovations, that led to the temporary suspension of the festivities by Marshal Applegate, because the celebrators were making more noise than the official thought seemly for an American Sunday night.

CONCORD, N.E., Aug. 4. -- The first State Convention of the National (Prohibition) Party was held here to-day. Only six delegates were present. Charles E. Drury of Bath was elected Chairman and Dr. C.W. Coolidge of Bristol Secretary of the convention. Chairman Drury spoke briefly, saying that his reason for abandoning the Republican Party was because he believed in using stringent legal measures to suppress the illegal liquor traffic.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Aug. 4. -- The Raines or organization forces were in control of the Republican County Convention held to-day. A ticket of State delegates favorable to the nomination of Saxton for Governor received twenty-two out of eighty votes in the convention. The successful ticket is headed by Senator John Raines, and is un-pledged.

Minister TERRELL has responded to some of the criticisms of his course at Constantinople by publishing a long letter written last December to the Rev. H.O. DWIGHT, LL.D. in this he sets forth very fully his belief that the missionaries should withdraw from Turkey on the ground that it is unreasonable, indeed impossible, to expect their protection at the hands of the Turkish Government.

Interest centred to-day in the Moore failure in Chicago, which was announced after midnight, and particulars of which were rather difficult to obtain in this city. The decision of the Governors of the Chicago Exchange to suspend business pending an adjustment of the firm's affairs, while, perhaps, conservative, lent an air of undue importance to the failure.

A strike of the vestmakers was yesterday added to the list of strikes in the clothing industry. These vestmakers are Socialist, but their leaders adopted the same tactics as did those of the Brotherhood tailors to the loosing their contractors know when they intended going out. Even other Socialist clothing makers unions did not know of the strike until it had been under way for three hours.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Aug 4. -- A disastrous freight wreck and powder explosion occurred on the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad at Weldy's Siding, seven miles west of here, at 5 o'clock this morning. Engineer Michael Smock and Conductor Alexander Smith were killed and Fireman Henry Dreisbach was seriously scalded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4. -- The meaning of the result in Alabama is construed differently at the two political headquarters, Vice Chairman Apsley, at Republican headquarters, said to-day that the result in that State was not a disappointment to the Republicans, for the reason that no other result was anticipated.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4.--The main building of the extensive phosphate and fertilizer works of the Baugh Sons Company was destroyed by fire to-day.

I want to ask every reader at THE NEW-YORK TIMES who is a sound-money man what he is doing to contribute to the defeat of Bryan and the miserable doctrines which are involved in his candidacy. To business men, manufacturers, ministers, doctors, lawyers, and workingmen, I ask this question: What are you doing to help the cause of honest money?

PORT DOYER, Ontario, Aug. 4. -- The yacht Canada, which is to compete in the International races with the Chicago yacht Vencedor. In a test race here to-day easily defeated two other forty-footers, the Scorpion and Westwind.

Newport Harbor is alive with beautiful pleasure craft, gathered there to witness or take part in the annual races. Honoria Honsier has come in heard the Neckan, the yacht of her rich Vandervater cousins. She is rich in beauty and all feminine charms, but not in worldly goods, and is engaged to marry Chauncey Parkes, a poor but brilliant college professor.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- Miss Mary Ross died here about six weeks ago. At 2:45 o'clock this morning her brother, James L. Ross, a young business man, died in St. Luke's Hospital At 3 o'clock this morning his mother, the wife of William Ross, died at her home. The mother's health, impaired through grieving over the lost of her daughter, gave way entirely when it was seen her son could not live.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- The feeling in the vicinity of the Chicago Stock Exchange was quiet this morning. The nervousness incident to the first announcement of the Moore failure apparently had given place to a more settled condition. Confidence in the intrinsic value of the securities involved, and of Diamond Match especially, is felt.
Two trolley cars of the Nassau line, in Brooklyn, were in collision shortly after 8 o'clock last night, at Rogers Avenue and Bergen Street.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- The Central News says that at the request of Wilfred Laurier, Edward Blake, member of the British House of Commons for the South Division of County Longford, has been added to the Judiciary Committee of the Privy Council.

New-Jersey has never cast her Electoral votes for a Republican candidate for President since 1872. That continuous record of Democracy will be broken this year. Her people will not choose Bryan and Sewall Electors.
CHICAGO, Aug. 5. -- Mark Hanna will be in Chicago next Monday, according to telegraphic advices received to-day by Committeeman Dawes at Republican National headquarters.

We have almost daily had occasion to commiserate JONES of Arkansas. Contrary to recent appearances, and in spite of his having been severely burrowed into by the silver bacillus, JONES of Arkansas is a reputable Southern Democrat of the old-fashioned kind, and shows none of the symptoms of moral or mental unsoundness that usually accompany the silver craze.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 5. -- Fuller returns do not materially change the estimated results of Monday's election. Joseph E. Johnston has been elected Governor, and both branches of the Legislature are assured to the Democrats by handsome majorities.

Goldwin Smith in The Saturday Review. One of the leading economists and most competent observers in the United States writes to me that he will be glad to be put on record as predicting that this will be the last effort and final failure of the silver craze. He writes from Massachusetts, where the party of sound money, like everything else that is conservative and genuinely American, is strong.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5. -- The Senatorial investigating committee to-day struck a vein that gives promise of yielding some disclosures of interest. During last year a municipal scandal was threatened concerning the manner in which the Mutual Automatic Telephone Company had obtained a valuable franchise from City Councils.

ATHENS, July 18. -- It has been very difficult in the last few days to get any authentic information from Crete, for the telegraph to Canea is directly under the supervision of the Turkish Government, and no cipher telegrams are allowed to be sent except through the Consuls. One thing is certain, that after the renewal of hostilities around Kalibais it will be impossible to get under more concessions out of the Cretan insurrectionists.

After the routine business of the Police Board had been disposed of yesterday there was some talk among some of the Commissioners about the appointment of Inspectors. Commissioner Roosevelt suggested that the question of appointing them be taken up.

Chairman James K. Jones of the Democratic National Committee was in this city yesterday, but, although he was within a stone's throw of the headquarters over which Treasurer William P. St. John presides, he did not gladden them with his presence.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Morris Lodge, I.O.O.F., of this city, held its annual excursion at Rockaway Beach, L.I., last Wednesday. It was in charge of a committee consisting of Mayor Quayle, George W. Bowers, Mancing Youmans, Augustus Paul, and Frank Person. While at the beach these gentlemen met and decided to send the proceeds received from the sale of tickets on the train, which amounted to $460, back to Morristown by express.

OCALA, Fla., Aug. 5. -- The Populist State Convention met here at 2 o'clock this afternoon. While waiting for committees to report, speeches were made by several delegates advocating a "middle-of-the-road" policy. The speakers said the Populists would accept Bryan if he would accept Watson. If not, they favored pulling down Bryan and putting up Watson.

The opening of the campaign in the West and in the East finds the silverite speakers preaching that doctrine to which we referred a few days ago that the dollars we now use and have used for years past are worth too much, that they are really worth two dollars, and that for this reason half their value should be taken away!

The fact that the South Brooklyn Wheelmen has secured the Fall meet of the New-York State Division of the League of American Wheelmen and will give the big event at the Manhattan Beach bicycle truck will be pleasing news to the admirers of the popular sport in the metropolitan district. The announcement was made yesterday.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 5. -- L.W. McAlester, the best all-around ball player in Texas, and D.D. Gear, who has the best pitching record in the Texas League, have been sold by the Fort Worth Club to the Clevelands and will leave for that city this evening. The Clevelands paid $1,000 to Fort Worth for their release.

Mr. Charles A. Berrian sold at auction, at 111 Broadway, in foreclosure, yesterday, 165 West Eighty-seventh Street, a three-story dwelling, lot 20 by 100.8, to Flora Wallack, the plaintiff, for $21,430.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5. -- The racing fleet of the New-York Yacht Club was just three boats bigger than it was yesterday. The Eclipse and Olga hauled down their racing flags, but their places were taken by the schooner Merlin, and the sloops Wayward, Awa, Liris, and Drusilla. All these are old-timers and hardly improved the racing by their presence.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 5. -- Col. John R. Fellows of New-York is to be the principal speaker at the sound-money convention here Aug. 12. The other speaker will be ex-Congressman Sperry of Hartford.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Representative Mercer, Secretary of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee, who returned to-day from Cape May, found sufficient in his mail to justify the jubilant expression he wore during the greater part of the afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 5. -- The thirty-footers had another race to-day for sweepstakes, and it was a royal contest from start to finish. The Vaquero won because she was sailed in a masterly way by her owner, H.B. Duryea, who was assisted by Mrs. Duryea.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- The benevolent mission of Miss Clara Barton and the Red Cross Association, of which she is the American head, is about completed in Armenia, and the return of the expedition is expected shortly. Previous to the Red Cross physicians leaving the stricken cities of Zeitoun and Marash the following letter, signed by a number of Hadjis and other leading Armenians, was addressed to Miss Barton after the scourge had been overcome:
ALBANY, Aug. 5. -- These reports for the quarter ended June 30 have been filed with the State Railroad Commission:
The following letter was sent to J.R. Van Derveer of 503 West End Avenue yesterday by H.S. Beattle, ex-Surveyor of the Port:

NEWPORT, Aug. 5. -- Senator Gray of Delaware, who is the guest of John C. Cadwallader, and Senator Lodge of Massachusetts, who is a visitor at the villa of Senator Calvin S. Brice, had a luncheon given in their honor at noon to-day by Mrs. Brice. Mr. Cadwallader entertained at dinner to-night in honor of Senator Gray.

The presence in this city of the disciples of Father Kneipp, the apostle of water cure, in New-York is made known by a letter to the Park Commissioners, which was made public yesterday, asking that a space in each of the public parks be set apart where persons may walk barefoot on the wet grass each morning.
ATOXA, Indian Territory, Aug. 5.--The national election of the Choctaw Nation was held to-day, and the Dawes commission is anxiously awaiting the result.

NEWARK, N.J., August 5. -- Elijah Beulden Glenn of 135 Elm Street, this city, will be 100 years old on Friday. He is in possession of his faculties and is at present visiting friends near the place where he was born, Carpenter's Point, Md., on Aug. 7, 1796.
" I've chopped my sister's head off with an axe."
Mrs. Florence Gerard Abbey is suing her husband, Henry E. Abbey, the well-known theatrical manager and member of the firm of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, for a limited divorce.

" I do not suppose that once in a hundred times we ever learn the real cause of a railroad accident," said a man who is always well posted on such matters, "when any one of the principals concerned is killed. In individual cases, where a man is lost from a train and his body is found later beside the track, suicide is the first thing suggested; but you can never tell.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 5. -- Mr. Bryan has had a quiet day. He drove down to the railway station this evening and met Gov. and Mrs. Altgeld, who passed through Lincoln on route to Glenwood Springs, Col. Mr. Bryan and Altgeld had a talk over campaign affairs.

Busy folk were in a melting mood yesterday. But for a steady western breeze, refreshing in the shade, but impotent to alleviate the glare and heat in the sun, there would have been much more suffering. As it was there were two deaths from sunstrokes in this city.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 5. -- A banquet was tendered to J. Sterling Morton last night at the Omaha Club, Ostensibly it was merely a gathering of friends of the Secretary of Agriculture to renew old acquaintance, but in reality it was a conference of the prominent Administration Democrats of the State to determine what action Nebraska should take in placing a National Democratic ticket in the field favoring the maintenance of the gold standard.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 5. -- The better portion of the day was spent by the Populist State Convention in listening to speeches by "Stump" Ashby, Melvin Wade, "Cyclone" Davis, and other prominent speakers in the Populist camp.
MADRID, Aug. 5. -- Further riots growing out of the imposition of taxes have taken place throughout the Province of Valencia.

Frank Selber, nine years old, of 5-6 East Twelfth Street, was run over by a truck and killed yesterday in front of 400 East Thirty-first Street. The truck was owned by Noah Chamberlaid of 143 Lewis Avenue, Brooklyn, and was driven by Robert Adams, thirty-three years old, of 343 East Thirty-fifth Street. He was arrested and locked up in the East Thirty-fifth Street Station.

Kings County Charities Commissioners Will Not Deal with Him. The Kings County Commissioners of Charities met yesterday to open bids for coal for the county buildings. The specifications called for 2,500 tons or No. 1 pea coal to be delivered at the almshouse, and 2,500 tons of the same grade to be delivered at the penitentiary. There were seven bids, as follows: Kelsey Loughlin, almshouse and hospital, $3.16 per ton; penitentiary, $3.06.

It is not safe to assume that the future financial policy of our Government depends entirely upon Congress. It is of the utmost importance that we should have a sound-money Congress, not only one that is opposed to the free coinage of silver and to any form of further inflating the currency with depreciated silver, but one that will "do something" for sound money.
The draft of Chapter VII, of the charter for Greater New-York, which pertains to the Law Department, was given out yesterday by the Sub-Committee of the Greater New-York Commission.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Controller Gibson yesterday announced that he had disposed of $100,000 temporary loan bonds at 5 per cent., but to-day he was forced to accept the offer of the Essex National Bank to take the bonds at the current rate of 5 per cent., as the prospective purchaser at 5 per cent. did not materialize.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 5. -- An extremely high temperature prevails in all parts of Connecticut to-day, and is accompanied by an average humidity of about 70 per cent.
" It was a famous victory" in Alabama. The Democrats, it seems, have swept the State by a majority of 40,000 over the Populists.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 5. -- The Democratic County Committee met here to-day for the purpose of fixing caucus dates, choosing Election Inspectors, and adopting resolutions. The members are about evenly divided into two factions, one advocating free silver and the other for sound money.

Chairman Hanna and ex-Senator Platt were in consultation at Republican National Headquarters yesterday afternoon, and during the half hour they were together the details for the opening of the campaign in this State were discussed and, in part, agreed on.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 5. -- The joint committees of the Commercial Club and Board of Trade, appointed for the purpose of assisting to entertain the provisional National Committee of the Sound-Money Democracy and to endeavor to persuade it to hold its September convention in this city, met this afternoon to complete the details of the arrangements.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 5. -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the marriage of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Daly was celebrated here to-night. The Chelsea Avenue mansion was illuminated. Electric lights, with various colored bulbs, lighted the lawn, where a broad platform was built for dancing.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 5. -- A conference of leading sound-money Democrats of Alabama was held here to-day, and it was unanimously decided to bolt the action of the Democratic National Convention.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 5. -- The Republican State Convention is holding a night session, with the prospect that it will not complete the work it began this morning much before daylight. The candidates for Governor are James O'Donnell of Jackson, A.T. Bliss of Saginaw, H.A. Connant of Monroe, D.D. Altken of Flint, A.O. Wheeler of Manistee, and Mayor H.S. Pingree of Detroit.

Mayor Strong has not yet received from the Rev. John Balcoin Shaw an apology for or disavowal of the interview which gave the Mayor such offense. The Mayor seems desirous of reopening the question of T.P. Sinnott's license, if the people who live near the concert garden will make a complaint against the establishment.

SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 5. -- The National Forestry Commission, composed of Prof. Charles S. Sargent of Harvard, Chairman; Prof. Arnold Hague, United States Geographical Survey; Prof, William H. Brewer of Yale; Gen. Henry L. Abbott, retired army engineer; Gifford Pinchot of New-York, and E.H. Shuster of Washington City, Clerk of the board, has arrived in Seattle.

TORONTO, Aug. 5.--Harley Davidson won the Canadian championship race last night, defeating Cecil Elliot, he winning two out of three heats, Davidson won the first, Elliot the second, and the third was so close that many decided it to be a dead heat, but the judges awarded it to Davidson.

A determined attempt was made at 2 o'clock yesterday morning to burn the double tenement, 412 West Fifty-sixth Street. The miscreant who thus imperiled the lives of seventy persons, of whom thirty were children and infants in arms, is at present, unknown, but the police of the Forty-seventh Street Station and the Five Marshal are investigating the affair.

NEWPORT, Aug. 5. -- Two reports were current to-day regarding the wedding of Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, Sr., and Harry P. Whitney. Oue was that it would take place Aug. 25, and another was that they would not be married until late in the Fall.

A controversy as to the true definition of religion appears to have arisen between the ritualistic Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin and the Pro-Cathedral authorities in Stanton Street, the ecclesiastical home of Bishop Potter. The contention seems to be as to whether the good works carried on under the direct authority of Bishop Potter by the Pro-Cathedral constitute pure religion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5. -- Chauncey F. Black and Mr. Kerr, ex-Clerk of the House of Representatives, both of Pennsylvania, were to-day claiming that the Democrats would have at least eight of the Congressional districts in that State after the next election, instead of the two now represented by Democrats in the Fifty-fourth Congress.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 5. -- Franklin Rudolph, who says he is from Pittsburg, is a prisoner in the Second Precinct Police Station, and Mrs. Charles Emmons, wife of Patrolman Emmons of the Fourth Precinct, was warmly congratulated to-day for capturing him, after he had robbed a house close to her residence.

COLUMBUS, Aug 5. -- The unusually hot weather brought generally fast time at the Columbus Driving Park races to-day, but no records were broken. The weather was excellent and the track fast. The average time of the day's races is probably the best ever made in one day since harness racing began as a sport. The attendance was very large.

The Brooklyns defeated the Philadelphians easily yesterday at Eastern Pork, outfielding and out-batting the Quakers. Payne pitched for the home team, and during eight innings the "Phillies" could do nothing better than four scattering hits.
The striking vestmakers held a mass meeting yesterday in Liberty Hall, at 257 East Houston Street, while their Executive Committee met in one of the rooms in that building and there received reports.

BOSTON, Aug. 5. -- Ernest C. Marshall has furnished his poll of the Young Men's Democratic Club of Massachusetts. At its first meeting the Executive Committee of the club voted to repudiate the Chicago ticket, and this action did not meet the approval of certain members, among others Mr. Marshall.

New-York cotton brokers enjoyed a field day yesterday, and there were net gains of 53 to 57 points in prices. Buying orders appeared to be unlimited, a very large proportion of them coming from New-Orleans. The total sales for the day were 442,300 bales, which is an unusually large figure for this period.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 5. -- The publication in THE NEW-YORK TIMES of the fact that the State of New-Jersey had been persuaded to give free circulation to free-silver literature provoked considerable discussion among the State officials to-day, many of whom are Republicans.

LONDON, Aug. 5. -- A dispatch from Madrid to the Central News represents the tax riots in the Province of Valencia as serious Republican uprisings. The leader of the insurrectionists, Bernardo Toledo, was at one time a student of medicine in New-York City, and his brother is now in command of a band of insurgents in Cuba.

ABILENE, Kan., Aug. 5. -- The Populist State Convention to-day appointed a Conference Committee of fourteen members to meet with the committee appointed by the Democratic Convention at Hutchinson yesterday to decide upon a plan for fusion of the two parties.

Quantity, rather than quality, was the rule with the races at the Brighton Beach track yesterday. That applies particularly to the second and the sixth race on the yard, which were both half-mile dashes for maiden two-year-olds, the sort of dashes that will always bring out big fields.

The funeral services for Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Dusinberre Youmans, who were drowned in a lake near Bergen, Norway, July 4, were held yesterday morning in the Church of the Divine Paternity Forty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

The Rapid Transit Commission met yesterday afternoon and adopted resolutions authorizing Chief Engineer Parsons to prepare plans for the proposed Elm Street underground route. Commissioner Starin opposed this action.
It seems an impossibility to get into the minds of some men an appreciation of the silver issue.
The sub-committee on organization, appointed by the General Committee of representatives of the four counties comprised in Greater New-York, will make a somewhat surprising report on Monday.

It is plain enough that the riots in Spain are a symptom of very serious popular discontent with the course of the Government in respect to Cuba. The current uprising in Valencia is the most obstinate and determined revolt thus far, but the disturbances elsewhere have sufficed to show that the feeling so ferociously manifested in Valencia extends through many, if not all, parts of Spain.

ATHENS, July 21. -- The demands of the Cretan Deputies practically are the same as those stated in my previous letter, the only differences being that the Christian Governor appointed by the Porte is also to meet the approval of the powers, and that the payment for the damage done by the imperial troops shall come out of the import duties, and not directly from Constantinople. Some of the Deputies have now left Canea.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6. -- The three days' bicycle meet, held under the auspices of the Press Cycling Club begun here to-day. The interest in to-day's racing centered in the half-mile professional race, in which Bald, Cooper, Zlegler, Butler, and the other cracks of the grand circuit were entered.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 6. -- A public forum will be provided here for the people who want to hear the money question discussed. An old Court House will be opened, and silver and gold speakers will be there at all hours of the day, to enlighten the voters. This plan was made necessary, because the people blockaded the streets in their discussions.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 6. -- A notably impressive funeral ceremony was held at Christ Church this afternoon, when, in the presence of a large assemblage of distinguished people, the last rites of the Episcopal Church were performed over the body of Mrs. Sarah Spencer Morgan, wife of George H. Morgan and daughter of the late Junius S. Morgan of London.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- Secretary Lamont has to-day directed the award of contracts under the proposal received by the War Department for the supply of forgings, gun and mortar carriages, , provided for by the recent appropriation for the armament of fortifications.

WATERVILLE, Me., Aug. 6. -- The Democratic State Convention, held here to-day, nominated Melvin P. Frank of Portland for Governor. He takes the place on the ticket declined by Edward P. Winslow, a sound-money Democrat. Frank was nominated on the first ballot. He had 192 votes, and E.F. Hanson of Belfast had 166. Frank is a free-silver man: Hanson a sound-money advocate.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 6.. . -- Exposition Hall was well Crowded when Chairman Griffin, at 10:15 A.M. to-day, called the Republican State Convention to order. No time was lost in preliminaries,: and the ending speeches for candidates were taken up where they were left off when the convention adjourned last night.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 6. -- A free stage which runs to the water chutes was struck by a trolley car in the middle of the Deal Lake Bridge to-night about 9:30. Both horses which were drawing the stage and a youth were thrown from the bridge into the lake.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 6. -- The Rev. J.C. Hull, a prominent Methodist minister of this city, is locked up in the police station, charged with administering poison to his wife, who is in a very critical condition.
The thermometer marked 89 at 2 o'clock P.M. yesterday, one degree higher than on Wednesday, but there was 87 per cent. of humidity, an increase over the day before of 13 degrees.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Aug. 6. -- Chairman Wright of the Democratic State Committee has received the following letter:

GRANDS RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 6. -- The Republicans of Michigan, in their State Convention to-day, nominated Mayor Hazen S. Pingree of Detroit for Governor on the fourth ballot, which resulted as follows: Pingree, 419; Bliss, 200; O'Donnell, 75; Altken, 17; Conant, 2. Pingree's nomination was made unanimous.
The joyous shouts of 500 little children resounded yesterday from behind the high board fence which incloses the big vacant lot at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The Falkland Islands, on the east coast of Patagonia, were in May the scene of a marine disaster involving the loss of nearly twenty American lives, which still remains wrapt in mystery, as but few details of the disaster have yet been received from the United States Consul at Port Stanley, the capital of the Islands.

The Democratic Honest Money League of America held a meeting last night at its new headquarters, at 15 West Twenty-fourth Street. The rooms are nicely furnished and can comfortably seat about 200 persons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- When Senator Jones of Arkansas, the great adjuster, returns to Washington, where he is expected at headquarters to-morrow, his task of adjustment will be found to have greatly increased in difficulty. It is tacitly admitted around Democratic headquarters here to-day that fusion will not fuse.

WEST END, LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 6. -- The invitation tennis tournament of the Norwood Field Club was continued to-day before a large crowd. During the morning "Bob" Wrenn, the ex-champion, maintained his reputation by taking a well-earned victory form E.P. Fischer, the clever New-York player, following it up later in the day by scoring his match against Talmage of Brooklyn in straight sets.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- The opening of the Stock Exchange is still waiting on the Moore Brothers and the report of the sub-committee of the governing body as to the condition of the Diamond Match property held by the suspended firm.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 6. -- The Athletics had a walk-over this afternoon, the home team playing an all-around poor game. Willington changed pitchers in the fourth inning, but the visitors kept on pounding and running. Score:

SABATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- Owing to the intense heat that has prevailed here for the past two days, the American Dental Association to-day decided to omit to-morrow's session and to adjourn at the close of to-day's business.

B.E. Walker of Toronto, the General Agent of the Canadian Bank of Commerce, the second largest banking institution in Canada was in New-York yesterday. In view of the interest and curiosity aroused by the daily shipments of American gold to Canada, Mr. Walker was induced to make the following statement:
