The Health Department issued yesterday its monthly report as to the deaths and death rate in New-York for the month of July. The report is as follows:

CHICAGO, Aug. 6. -- The political situation and Republican needs were discussed in detail this afternoon at the Republican National headquarters, so far as they relate to South Dakota and Washington. The details of the conference were not considered proper material for the press.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 6. -- Edward Van Sickle, a truck farmer, was arrested to-day on a charge of atrocious assault and battery made by the father of Harry Breece. Mr. Breece alleged that the farmer set a dog on his two sons, and that Harry, who is blind, in trying to escape ran into a barb-wire fence and was impaled on sharp wire points.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- A dispatch has been received by the Department of State from the American Embassy at Paris, from which it appears that important modifications have been made in the regulations for the admission of foreign students to the medical schools of France and for granting their permission to practice their profession.

The most entertaining bit of information at Treasurer St. John's Democratic silver headquarters yesterday came from Dr. J. H. McCallum, a Populist. He was one of the delegates at large from this State to the Populist Convention at St. Louis, and he called at Mr. St. John's rooms yesterday to pay his respects to Oliver Sumner Teall.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 6. -- Thomas B. Reed was renominated for Congress to-day by a unanimous rising vote by the Republicans of the First District, and as soon as the nomination had been made the convention gave three cheers for the candidate.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6. -- The New-York batting order was changed to-day, and Davis covered short field in place of Connaughton. The changes were ineffective, however, and the New- Yorks lost to the home team by the score of 9 to 6. The fielding of both teams was off color, and only 2 of the 15 runs were earned. Glesson was particularly bad.
Mrs. Audede Wilhalmina Wakens Hicks-Lord, now Wakens and widow of Thomas Lord, died Wednesday night in her home, at 32 Washington Square West.

For the month of July the receipts of the Government were $29,029,209 and its expenditures were $42,088,468, so that the deficit was $13,059,259. For July, 1895, the receipts were almost exactly the same, ($29,069,697,) but the expenditures were only $38,548,063, and the expenditures in July, 1894, were less than this sum by nearly $1,000,000.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug 6. -- The harbor to-night' presented a Venetian scene of rare beauty. The much-talked-of fete in honor of the New-York Yacht Club took place, and was enjoyed by the visiting yachtsmen and thousands of others who came from Boston, Providence, Fall River, and Eastern towns.

The police authorities of this city complain that they are unable to enforce the provision of the Raines law forbidding the sale of liquor on Sunday, so far as the "fake hotels" are concerned, because the city Magistrates refuse to hold those charged with the violation of the law and Grand Juries will not find indictments on the evidence presented.
The venerable bullfrog which has made his home in the lily pond in the centre of Union Square for several months post will amuse the loungers in the square no longer.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 6. -- The free-for-all pace, for which Robert J., Frank Agan, and Rubenstein were entered, drew an immense crowd to the Columbus Driving Park this afternoon. The weather and track were such as to lead to the expectation that some record-breaking would be seen. On the whole, the result was all that could be wished.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. -- The first installment of the revised edition of Mr. Bryan's Chicago speech was received at Democratic headquarters to-day, and will soon be circulated over the country. The revised speech bears the evidences of having been gone over carefully by its author, for the alterations in grammatical construction and verbiage number 118.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 6. -- About 150 Democrats attended the meeting called by ex-Gov. Flower, D.G. Griffin, and other prominent Democrats of this city to-night, to protest against the silver plank in the Chicago platform. One hundred well-known names are on the list attached to the call. Ex-County Judge Henry Purcell called the meeting to order.

Many of the free-silver writers have expended their efforts on purely untenable premses, but others have given us serious arguments in support of their doctrines, which seem fair upon their face. They promise prosperity, but fail however, to prove where it is to come from, leaving us to infer that we are to get something for nothing.

PATERSON, Aug. 6. -- The cycle parade in this city previous to the New-Jersey State meet on Saturday promises to be a big success. The following clubs have entered: The Vim Club of Newark, winner of the first prize for New-Jersey clubs at the Long Branch parade; the Hackensack Wheelmen, who expect to have at least 100 members in line, and the Essex Bicycle Club, the oldest organization in the State, will attend in uniform.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 6. -- Mr. Hanna dropped ever here to-day on his way from New-York to Cleveland, and held a consultation with a sub-committee of the Business Men's National Campaign Committee and the campaign. The sub-committee, which met Mr. Hanna was representation of the leading manufacturing and business firms of Philadelphia.

Some personal response seems to be due to the numerous friends who have sought from me an expression of my individual opinion as to the duty in the present political campaign of those who adhere to the principles which hitherto have characterized the Democratic Party.

The cutting of freight rates, especially on grain, by the Western railroads is beginning to affect the values of railway securities, particularly in the New-York and other Eastern stock markets. The Chicago papers print statistics to show that the great reduction in rates have not operated to increase the freight of roads leading out of Chicago to the Atlantic seaboard.

NUREMBERG, Aug. 6. -- Late last night Charousek beat Walbrodt after over 90 moves in a game left unfinished in the fifteenth round of the international chess tournament now in progress in this city. To-day the players met in the sixteenth round, the pairing being as follows: Tschigorin versus Tarrasch, Charousek versus Janowaki, Blackburne versus Walbrodt, Teichmaun versus Porges, Showalter versus Albin, Winawer versus Pillsbury, Schallopp versus Ychiffers, Maroczy versus Lasker, Macro versus Schiechter.

Burglar stories are rife nowadays. There are a hundred experiences told of burglars or would-be burglars for every robbery, and those are numerous. One of these is a true story and of a double tragedy. It is a story of the rash use of firearms. It was a young man who discovered the burglar. He heard first a slight noise outside the house, was sure he heard steps, and, looking out, saw a light.

A dog had his day yesterday. He was a typical street cur, homeless and friendless. Driven mad by the heat and by the difficulty of obtaining water, which is the great deprivation that a homeless dog in the city labors under, he ran the course of one block in Broadway snapping and frothing, and came to a rest in the corner with bullets in his body from the hands of two policemen.
The brigade of United States and New-York State National Guard Artillery, which is to march into the Stale Camp at Peekskill to-morrow, started for its destination yesterday.

It is sometimes asked why, if our silver dollar is intrinsically worth only about 53 cents, it continues to be worth a dollar in exchange and to circulate on a par with the rest of our currency. The fact that it does so is also used as an argument by the free-silverites, as if it were due to the Government fiat or the stamp that makes it lawful money.

THURSDAY -- P.M. The decline in the market to-day was attributed to two things -- the political situation and alleged weakness of Chicago houses arising out of the failure of the Moores. Inquiry of prominent Chicago houses as to the rumor of impending failures in that city brought these replies:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 6. -- The Rhode Island Democratic State Central Committee met here to-day and voted to hold the State Convention for the selection of Presidential Electors in this city Aug. 26 and the district conventions for the nomination of Congressmen Oct. 7.

Frank J. Wakem describing himself as a broker from Chicago, and living at the Hotel Martin, Fortieth Street and Broadway, was a prisoner in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of having violated Section 559 of the Penzi Code by sending a threatening letter to Oliver F. Malcolm, also a broker bale of Chicago and now of 29 Broadway, the city, where he is trading as Comack Co.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Aug. 6. -- Private Perkins of Company B, Fifth Regiment, O.N.G., doing duty at the Brown Works, was shot in the middle of the right thigh some time to-day. Officers and men of the regiment are reticent concerning the shooting, and either decline to talk or profess absolute ignorance of any such occurrence.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 7. -- The National Democratic Party, represented by 900 or more of its chosen delegates, will hold a National Convention in Indianapolis Wednesday, Sept. 2, to adopt a platform of Democratic principles and to nominate Democratic candidates for President and Vice President of the United States. This is the outcome of two short, businesslike sessions of the National Committee, which met here to-day.

The reriot against BRYAN and the Chicago platform is visibly extending. Let any competent judge of political affairs consider the drift of the newspapers from day to day.Let him weigh the incidents and events that favor BRYAN and those that make against him.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- The people of Elmsford, a little farming place midway between this village and Tarrytown, held an indignation meeting last night to stamp their disapproval of the action of the Highway Commissioners of the town of Greenburgh in making alleged ridiculous stipulations in their proposed franchise to the New-York, Elmsford and White Plains Trolley Company to run its line from Elmsford to Tarrytown.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- This fastest and most closely contested bicycle races in the history of the Grand Circuit were witnessed by a large crowd that attended the second day's meet of the Press Cycling Club this afternoon. "Eddie" Bald defeated his old-time racing rivals, Tom Cooper, Tom Butler, Jenny, "Conn" Baker, Ziegler, and the Caliahan brothers in the one-mile open.

Even the raost hardened of American shipbuilder must now be weakening in his position that the way to revive American shipbuilding is to prevent the buying of ships abroad on any terms. This was the lifelong contention of the late JOHN ROACH, and some his successors have seemed disposed to continue It.

The sound-money Democrats of New-Jersey held a conference yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in Taylor's Hotel, Jersey City. Letters had been sent by William J. Curtis of Summit N.J., to about 150 prominent sound-money Democrats throughout that State inviting them to attend the conference.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- If Chairman Jones of the National Democratic Committee received any assurances from Senator Hill to the effect that that Senator intended to support the Chicago ticket, he is keeping it entirely to himself. He was at headuarters this morning. To all callers who made inquiries concerning his recent visit to New-York, the Chairman denied that it had any political significance.
LONG BRANCH, Aug. 7. -- Wheelman and wheelwoman have derived their machines and taken to the water during these hot days. The surf has been about the only cool place for three days.

The Republican County Committee had a special meeting at its headquarters, in Thirty-eighth Street, last night which was as hot as the weather. Three members who are Milholland men passed up their resignations, giving their reasons in a letter, which was not read in full because it was termed "insulting."

Russian coronation cups are beginning to make their appearance in the city. Two large jewelry establishments in the neighborhood of Twenty-second Street, in Broadway have them in their windows. They are the cups distributed among the people at the instance of the Czar as souvenirs at the time of his coronation in May, and in the scramble for which there was such, a terrible loss of life.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 7. -- The champions had a batting matinee to-day and won the third game of the series from New-York by the score of 16 to 1. Donnelly's misplay in the sixth was all that saved the visitors from a shut-out. After a magnificent stop off Van Haltren's bat, he threw wide of first base and allowed the runner to reach third, who scored a moment later on Joyce's infield out.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7. -- Senator Jones, Chairman of the National Democratic Committee, to-night authorized a reporter to deny in toto all the statements made in a dispatch sent out from Chicago to-day to the effect that there had been a rupture between him and Gov. Altgeld of Illinois, and all the other matters set out in the dispatch.

There has been considerable talk of late to the effect that the large investment companies have been considering the advisability of insisting upon a "gold clause" in their New-York City mortgages, but such a movement is generally deprecated by the large money-lending corporations.

BROCKVILLE, Ontario, Aug. 7. -- The weather was all that could be desired for the Canadian Amateur Oarsmen's regatta. It was very warm, and there was quite a breeze blowing, but it was off shore and scarcely caused a ripple on the course. The races, which were well contested throughout, were witnessed by an immense crowd of people from the shore, steamboats, rowboats, and other kind of craft.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., Aug. 7. -- Democratic State Chairman Robert E. Wright has resigned his leadership of the Democratic forces in Pennsylvania. In an open letter to the Secretary of the Democratic State Central Committee he gives his reasons for resigning. The letter is as follows:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 7. -- An explosion from an unknown cause in the packing plant of Swift Co. here last night resulted in the death of one man, the injury of six others, four probably fatally, and in the fire which followed $125,000 in property was destroyed. The killed:

The Republican papers continue to deceive their readers as to the effect of the new tariff. Sometimes they tell the farmer that the price of his potatoes has been cut down by imports, although the imports cf potatoes have fallen to. aImost nothing under the present tariff ad have been very sma in comparison with those reported during the four years of the tariff of McKINLEY.

Thomas Kenney was assaulted while crossing the lonely bridge leading from the station of the Brighton Railroad to the Sheepshead Bay track about 11 o'clock Thursday night. He reported to the police at Sheepshead Bay station that he was going home with a pail of Leer when three colored men met him on the bridge, took the beer away from him, and struck him over the head with a club.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7. -- Senator Julius C. Burrows of Michigan was at National Republican headquarters to-day. He called on his way home to Kalamazoo from a short trip to Yellowstone Park, and announced his willingness to get into the political arena at once. Accordingly, he was assigned to assist in opening the Illinois campaign at Jacksonville Aug. 18. The Senator also will speak at La Grange, Ind., Aug. 15.

NEWPORT, R.I. Aug. 7. -- Count and Countess Castellane probably will pass next season here. C.P. Duval, who was the Count's companion in America, is looking at the Ashurst villa, on Bellevue Avenue, and has taken steps to secure the refusal of it. The house is old-fashioned, but it has large rooms, and is well located on Bellevue Avenue, near Touro Park.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 7. -- The Populist State Convention was at work from 8 o'clock this morning until 11 o'clock to-night, with the exception of a recess for dinner and one for supper, in trying to complete its State ticket. More than 200 speeches were made.
Joseph Holder of 21 West Fourth Street and James McIntyre of 213 West Broadway were each held in $2,000 bail yesterday in the Jefferson Market Police Court for trial on charges of burglary.

That travel has its drawbacks E.N. Tailer of this city can well testify. Mr. Tailer lives at 11 Washington Square North. He is fond of traveling in certain civilised portions of the habitable globe, but he does not care particularly for exploring the hidden beauties of the Yosemito Valley.
The announcement was made at the Bryan and Sewall headquarters, in the Hotel Bartholdi, yesterday, that the A.P.A. in New-England will support Bryan.
BERLIN, Aug. 7. -- The Neueste Nachrichten of Leipzig to-day declares that Chancellor von Hohenlohe has resigned and that he has left Berlin for Cassel.

Though it was decidedly an off day for the races at Brighton Beach yesterday, just one-half the card being made up of dashes for two-year-olds, there was the usual crowd in attendance. They found to their great satisfaction relief from the torrid heat of the city, because of breezes which blew in from the ocean and made it delightfully cool and comfortable.

William Brown, a carpenter and one of the oldest employes in point of service of the New-York and Brooklyn Bridge, was struck by a locomotive yesterday morning while working near the New-York tower, and, after being dragged twenty feet over the ties, was hurled down the well in the centre of the pier.

NUREMBERG, Aug. 7. -- The game between Marco and Schlechter, left unfinished in the sixteenth round of the international chess tournament, now in progress in this city, yesterday evening, was finished late last night, the players drawing after nearly 100 moves. To-day the following results were recorded in the seventeenth round:
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 7. -- Seaborn Augustus Wright was nominated by acclamation for Governor by the Populists this morning. No other name was put up.

" Maurioe Grau of the operatle firm of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, arrived from London yesterday on lte steamnhip Augusta Victoria of the Hamburg-American Line. As soon as the impresari landed he joined his partner, Henry E. Abbey, at the Gilsoy House, an remained in conferences with him for some time.

OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 7. -- Mr. Bryan and his party reached Omaha at 4 o'clock this afternoon. The trip was made without incident, except at Albright and South Omaha, where crowds assembled and cheered Mr. Bryan.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 7. -- No better idea of the strength of the sound-money movement can be obtained than by the expressions of some of the committeemen as to the conditions in their States.

If Policeman Antonio Vachris, one of the guardians of Coney Island, cares to give up his shield and club and accept an offer from some one of the purveyors, of pleasure in that wonderful section of seashore where he new patrols, there is not the least doubt that his picture, with coatskirts uplifted and with contorted body, would soon appear on all the billboards and dead walls of the State.

The stock market was entirely at the mercy of the bears yesterday. There was some resistance, early in the day, to the onslaughts of the raiders; but the disposition to sustain prices was not strong in any quarter, and the whole market experienced a decline akin to disaster.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 7. -- The Coroner's jury that has been inquiring into the meadow wreck returned its verdicts to-day.
A political party always has been defined to be an association of voters to promote the success of political principles held in common.

Franklin Seaman, the youngest son of Samuel H. Seaman, was found in his room at his home, 150 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, last night, with the top of his head blown off. At his side was a repeating rifle of 44 calibre. On the desk near where he was lying was another cartridge.

David Mullen, thirteen years old, came to this city Tuesday from a back county in New-Jersey to seek his fortune, and yesterday he returned to his home without the desired wealth.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 7. -- Hot weary, and dusty, the First, Second, Third, and Sixth Batteries of the State troops and Battery K of the regular army arrived here at 3:15 this afternoon and went into camp at Nelson Park at the lower end of the village. The march had commenced at 6 o'clock this morning at Van Cortlandt Park, in New-York, and the progress had been usually good considering the excessive heat.
PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 7. -- Official notice has been forwarded to the Bering Sea fleet of the stations assigned to the several vessels on the completion of the patrol work.

BOSTON, Aug. 7. -- The Executive Committee of the Business Men's Non-Partisan Club of Boston, which has been formed in the interest of sound money, sent out circulars to-day inviting membership to the organization. The club will make no assignment. The work will be carried on by voluntary subscriptions and personal effort.

HAVANA, Aug. 7. -- The cigar manufacturers here continue to oppose the exportation of Remedios leaf tobacco, which was not included in Capt. Gen. Weyler's recent derive against the exportation of tobacco. Gen. Fitzhugh Lee, the American Consul General, has entered an energetic protest against the delay occasioned by the authorities in the dispatch of 1,000 bales of tobacco belonging to American firms.

It was a sort of red-letter day for the ocean greyhounds yesterday. The American Line steamship St. Louis arrived with 400 cabin and 208 steerage passengers, who had been carried from Southampton to New-York in less time than had ever been made between the two ports in the world's history.

The Democrats of the First Congressional District have done a sagacious thing in nominating Edward W. Staples for Congress. They have put before the people a man, of strict integrity, of pure character, and of great business capacity. He will, we hope, give Mr. Reed a good run, and perhaps outwind him.

WEST END, LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 7. -- Wrenn and Larned are tied for first place as the result of to-day's playing in the Norwood Park tennis tournament. Yesterday Wrenn led the field by one match, having gone through the week without a defeat. This afternoon, however, he met Larned and was beaten after one of the most brilliant matches that has ever taken place on Norwood course.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 7. -- Clarence A. Postley and Nathaniel L. Francis to-day added two handsome pieces of silver to their collection of trophies. Mr. Postley's Colonia won the thousand-dollar cup for shooners, and Mr. Francis's cutter Queen Mab the five-hundred-dollar cup for single-masted vessels, given by Ogden Goelet.

Assuming that the reported interview with Mayor Strong relative to the roof garden of Columbus Avenue and One Hundred and First Street, which appeared in most of yesterday's dailies, was authentic, I feel bound, in the interests of truth and justice, to make a simple statement of the facts in the case to the public.

Surrogate Arnold has signed a citation, returnable Sept. 13, directing John McGee to show cause why letters of administration granted to him on the estate of his brother, Charles A. McGee, should not be revoked.

Senator Stephen B. Elkins of West Virginia was at Republican National headquarters yesterday and made a report to the members of the Executive Committee of the situation in the State. He was convinced, he said, that the Republicans would gain more votes front Democrats on the sound-money issue than the Bryan and Sewall party would gain because of their advocacy of free silver.

In every State there are many honest money Democrats who cannot be induced to voted for MCKINLEY.As Mr. BYNUM said day before yesterday, "they have not lost their unbelief in MCKinleyism." If there were to be no honest-money Democratic ticket,some of thes Democrats might be coaxed or driven" to vote for BRYAN.

Although the mercury did not climb up quite as high yesterday as on Thursday, the combination of high temperature and intense humidity made the day a memorable one. There were showera late in the afternoon, light in the upper part of the city and heavy down town, which were grateful to man and beast.

ALBANY, Aug. 7. -- A fact in connection with the operation of the Raines liquor tax law, which seems to have been overlooked, is the loss the Federal Government will sustain. This comes through the reduced number of drinking places.

ALBANY, Aug. 7 -- Senator Hill arrived at his home in this city this afternoon, where he expects to remain for the next ten days. It can be stated authoritatively that he will not preside at the Bryan and Sewall ratification meeting at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday next, and that all statements appearing in the public prints that Senator Hill is about to declare for the Bryan ticket or against it are without foundation.

It may have been a women's quarrel or it may have been simply a case of shrewdness in the new woman, but whatever was the cause, Lexington Avenue has had the most remarkable case of dispossess proceedings that that quiet thoroughfare has ever known.
Rioting by the striking tailors was rift yesterday, although the contractors whose shops were attacked exaggerated the mischief.

Mrs. Lynn Linton has a paper in the August number of The Bookman on George Henry Lewes and Thornton Hunt, in which she writes strikingly of Lewes's character, his domestic relations, and other matters.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The State Department has received a Consular report on the new rolling steamboat designed by the French marine engineer, Bazin, which is attracting the attention of prominent experts in the shipbuilding line. By this marked innovation in marine architecture, a speed of about sixty miles an hour is promised, which closely approximates that made by the fastest express trains on the Continent.

" Go thou and do likewise," was the whilom advice given to the lawyer who had made a correct answer concerning the example set by the compassionate Samaritan. In the Naval War College at Newport we have before our eyes an instance of what a sound idea, well carried out, can effect.

Gov. Budd is to be shipped on a whaler in a couple of weeks. Besides the Governor, a score of others prominent in politics and business will go to make up the most distinguished whaling crew that ever left this port. Such men as the Governor of California, President Barillos of Guatemala, Captain of Police I.W. Lees, Police Judge Campbell, Capt. John Bruce, and Harbor Commissioners Colnon, Cole, and Chadbourne will make up the party.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- Li Hung Chang, the Chinese statesman, who is now the guest of Great Britain, visited St. Paul's Cathedral this morning and placed a wreath upon the tomb of Gen. Charles George Gordon, who was killed by the Mahdists at Khartoum, in the Southern, in Jan. 26, 1885.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The sixth annual ball was given at the Scarboro Hotel to-night by Proprietor Meares. The affair was in charge of Prof. Lytie, one of Mr. Meares's staff, who spared no time and expense to make it one of the most pleasant events of the season.

Here is the cockney description of a chamois, according to the English tourist in Switzerland: "A sort of wild goat that has a beard and small polished horns, which the natives fasten on the alpenstocks." That old sporting authority, Du Fouillox, for you always have to go back to him, called the chamois the Ysarus or Sarris, and a goat.

So many New-York clubmen are now absent on the annual cruise of the New-York Yacht Club, which began on Monday and will close to-morrow, that it may be said that club topic this week is this cralse of New-York's, and indeed the United States; representative yachting organization

BUFFALO, Aug. 8. -- The third and final day's races under the auspices of the Buffalo Cycling Association to-day ended in a brilliant if not financially successful meeting. There were 5,000 persons present when the first event, the half-mile open for amateurs, was started. After four trial heats, in which the best time was made by T.B. McArthy, Toronto, Ontario, the final was reached with a big field.

People find their counterpart in the East, and the one is at least an offset to the other. In fact the inferior parts of the population of New-York and the other great Eastern cities, as also of certain mining and manufacturing regions, are much worse and more to be feared than the corresponding parts of the Western population.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- England has at last done something in the line of what English-speaking people have been hoping and praying for these fifteen months. She has withdrawn unreservedly from the shadowy concert of Europe and has refused to join others in either forcing the Cretans to submit to the Turk or blockading the island so as to prevent Greek sympathizers from landing arms and supplies for the rebels.
The heat of yesterday was a continuation in intensified form of conditions that prevailed during the earlier part of the week.

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 8. -- The presentation of a solid-silver water pitcher and salver to Commodore J.B. Simpson at the Sagamore this week was a case of genuine surprise to first gentleman. Some time ago, as noted THE TIMES, Commodore Simpson entertained a large party of gentlemen interested in insurance matters.

Under the direction of the South Brooklyn Wheelmen the annual Fall State race meet of the New-York Division, League of American Wheelmen, will undoubtedly attract a large number of people on Labor Day. In selecting the Manhattan Beach track the club secured the best course in the metropolitan district, and the enthusiasts are thus assured of line sport.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 8. -- Hartford won from Newark to-day in a hotly contested game. J. Rothfuss made a home run, sending in two runs ahead of him. Three-baggers by Carroll and Thornton were very timely. Score:

A very favorite last resort of the eighteenth century physician was to send a patient to visit the place of his birth, since it was thought that "natal air" would be likely to prove peculiarly beneficial. This last theory, although somewhat ludicrous when viewed from our modern standpoint, strikes me as being something more than a mere piece of plausible empiricism.

The present hot spell has advanced the price of lemons fully $2 a box. They sold as high as $6.50 a box yesterday at auction at Brown Seccomb's. Some 25,000 boxes, or 7,500,000 lemons, counting 300 lemons to each box, were disposed of.

Woodcraft in all of its many phases is a lifelong study -- in its entirety a most wonderful profession. A few years of application will not permit one to graduate as a bachelor of the craft; rather will he then have completed the freshman term. Constant actual experience, begun in early boyhood, terminated only by old age, makes the student a pair grand master.
The McKinley leaguers are troubled because Chairman Hanna of the Republican National Committee and Mr. Platt, chief of the regular State organization, are on good terms.

BAYONNE N.J., Aug. 8 -- Former Mayor and Mrs. William C. Farr, with their family, are at an Asbury Park hotel for a month's outing. Charles M. Coville of Avenue D is summering with friends in Rockland County, N.Y. Miss Lizzie Cunningham of West Eighth Street and Miss Isabel Snowden Humphreys Avenue are with kinsfulks at Saratoga.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- The work of the Venezuelan Boundary Commission has entered upon a new stage during the last month. Heretofore the efforts of the Commissioners have been directed mainly to securing the evidence upon which the final report is to be based. The work from now on will very largely consist in examining and classifying the information already collected.

GROVE CITY, Fla., July 26. -- Dr. Wilcox caught a shark last week in the Gulf, near this place, which gave him a very interesting and exciting fight before he captured it. The doctor is a great fisherman, and the abundance and great variety of the fish on this part of the coast give him all the amusement needed in that line.

The Union Veterans' Patriotic League yesterday issued an address to the surviving soldiers and sailors who served in the Union Army during the rebellion, calling on them to again come to the rescue of the country.

In spite of the hard times and the unusually hot weather, the theatre managers will begin their work early this year. The Garrick Theatre will be opened a week from to-morrow night with a revival of "Thoroughbred," the little comedy by Ralph Lumley, which, with alterations by Clyde Fitch, was favorably received there in the Spring.

Torpedo boats are designed for a wider service than simply to carry and discharge the frightful weapon from which they take their names. They are to the navy what scouts and skirmishers are to a land army. They form the cavalry of the sea, of which the cruisers are the infantry and the battleships and monitors the artillery arm.
" It's too hot to be good," sighed a small eight-year-old last Thursday, when he was remonstrated with for a succession of peccadilloes, and when you come to think of it, it was.

OCALA, Fla., Aug. 8. -- Shortly after 1 o'clock this morning, when the south-bound Florida Central and Peninsular train was about a mile below here, Henry Greenway, the porter, discovered two men in the Pullman, robbing his sleeping passengers. Greenway closed with the robbers, who drew pistols and shot the porter dead. The robbers then jumped from the train.

Every woman, rich or poor, with the least regard to her character, must be in her house by sundown. Only think of the long, dull Winter afternoons and evenings when no friend can come near them, as all their female friends must be in their own houses, and male friends they cannot have. Even the noon of their own family associate but little with them.

The Babees only pray on formal occasions, like the Christians. A Babee will not roll out his prayer carpet and bow his head in prayer on the deck of a steamer, in the public street, and on the sands of a desert, as will the devout Mussulman. Nor does she Babee admit the doctrine of legal impurity.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- The entries for the Derby and the Oaks of 1898, made in conformity with usage two years before the races come off, are now known. The American entries were never so numerous. Mr. P. Lorillard has six, Mr. W.P. Thompson five, Mr. J.F. Madden four, and Mr. A. Belmont three. Mr. Richard Croker has entered a couple of English-bred cots.

BERLIN, Aug. 8. -- Political interest during the week has centred in the insurrection in Crete and the means to restore tranquillity in that disturbed island, where the Christians are making a desperate attempt to throw off the yoke of Turkish rule, in which they are being aided by Greeks who desire to see Crete part of the Grecian dominions.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 8. -- An enjoyable ice cream festival for the benefit of the Bethel Presbyterian Church was held Wednesday, and Thursday evenings. The young ladies in charge were Miss Elsie Moffett, Miss Alice York, Miss Minnie Silber, Miss Lillie Riker, and Miss Sadie Mills.

Sir Walter Besant's method is so well known as to be hardly worthy of description. Still, it may be indicated as something in this guise: A perfect trotting horse has a measured gait. Legs and feet take an exact action; the stride may be a little faster at times, but you hardly notice it.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 8. -- An alleged land swindle, by which residents of Pittsburg lost $100,000, and perhaps more, has come to light. Requisition papers for the arrest of J.F. Van Smith, one of the principals in the fraudulent transaction, have been issued by Judge Porter. Van Smith was arrested to-day at Alexandria, Va.

Little respect is paid by Americans to the birthplaces of their illustrious dead, and the old snuffmill near Narragansett Pier, in which Gilbert Stuart, in 1755, first saw light, is no exception to the rule. It may safely be said that it would seldom, if ever, be visited were it not a convenient objective point for a drive from the fashionable Summer resort a few miles away.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8. -- Secretary Carlisle started this morning on his trip to visit the President, at Buzzard's Bay, Mass. His party consists of Mrs. Carlisle and his son, W.K. Carlisle and his wife and their two children. They will go to New-York in the lighthouse tender Maple, and then be transferred to the tender Mistletoe. He expects to be absent about two weeks. The Maple left her wharf at 11:30 A.M.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 8. -- The run of the New-York Yacht Club fleet to Vineyard Haven from Newport was spoiled through the wind dying out and leaving the yachts becalmed in Vineyard Sound for hours. The sun was roasting hot, and the yachtsmen had a tough time.

A horse with blind staggers created a good deal of excitement about 1 A.M. yesterday in the vicinity of Lexington Avenue and Sixty-first Street. The animal knocked down and broke a leg of its owner, and then fell through a stairway, wrecking it and fracturing two of its own legs and two ribs.

PORTSMOUTH, Aug. 8. -- The Niagara, Audrey, Isolde, The Saint, and Penitent started to-day from Southsea in the regatta of the Royal Portsmouth Corinthian Yacht Club. A light northwest wind was blowing and rain was falling heavily. The course was twenty-eight miles long, and the prize for the winner was 15.
ASBURY PARK, Aug. 9. -- The first week in August has brought to this ever-popular watering place a sudden influx of excursionists and transient tourists.

This volume contains full-page portraits of twenty-three Judges and innumerable pen-and-ink pictures of the best-known members of the New-York bar. There are also minutes of this court, which so recently want out of existence -- at least in name.

We observe that some of our contemporaries speak of the assemblage of artillery at Peekskill as the most extensive combined drill of that arm that has been seen in the country since the war. This may be so. The simultaneous exhibition and combined drill of five light batteries is at any rate a sight that very few American citizens have had the opportunity of seeing since 1865.
Man's inalienable right to be tried by a jury of his peers was defended by Judge Windes yesterday against an attack by two "new" women, who insisted that a "peeress" was as good as a "peer."

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 8. -- Golf is becoming as popular a sport here as in Lenox, and some very fine players are being developed. Walter Nettleton holds the championship of the club, having made the rounds of the course in forty-three strokes. His previous record was forty-seven, which was beaten by Joseph Choate, Jr., who made a score of forty-six.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 8. -- Senator Donelson Caffery recently has been the subject of much adverse criticism in certain newspapers on account of his opposition to the Chicago ticket and platform. An effort has been made to bring sufficient pressure to bear to cause his resignation of his office of United States Senator.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Ex-Gov. Flower was serenaded by the Watertown City Band last evening, and in responding made some remarks as follows:

For one year and a half there will be no Bourbon whisky distilled in the United States. By agreement, all the distilleries in Kentucky closed on July 31, and they will not resume operations until 1898. They were losing money, many of them being on the verge of bankruptcy, due to an overproduction of the favorite beverage of the Kentucky Colonels.

LONG BRANCH, N.J. Aug. 8. -- Many guests who have been here since the opening of the season have gone to the mountains for the remainder of the season, while those who generally go to the mountains first are arriving here daily, in order that they may have an opportunity to take a dip in the sea before they return to their Winter homes. Bathing was never finer than it has been the past week.

MEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 8 -- Star Pointer (2:04 1/2) and Joe Patchen (2:04) met in a special contest at Combination Park to-day. The 7,000 persons who were present had one of the best day's sport ever witnessed in this section of the country. Besides the star card there were two other special races, which proved to be two of the cleverest exhibitions seen in many days.

This volume is not to be classed with those Lamb describes "as books which are not books." It is, as its title indicates, a catalogue of casts to be found in the Boston Museum of Fine Arts, and there are numbers in it indicating objects from No. 1 to No. 746 but there is a great deal more than that. Mr. Edward Robinson has taken the utmost pains with his text.

The last of four considerable items of real estate news last week was reported yesterday. It consisted in the exchange of the four old houses and plot, 66.3 by 98.9, on Fifth Avenue, east side, 25 feet north of Fortieth Street, at $475,000, by the heirs of C.B. Hart, with E.W. Bliss of Brooklyn, for the Arlington apartment house, in Montague Street, Brooklyn, and $250,000 in cash.

We do not remember any "delegation of property owners" in this city who have exhibited themselves in such an unseemly light as that which visited the Deputy Commissioner of Street Cleaning, who is acting as the head of the department in Col. WARING'S absence, on Friday, to protest against the enforcement of the ordinance requiring the separation of ashes and garbage.

The first steps in what promises to become an interesting legal proceeding were taken yesterday, when Mrs. Jeanie De Quesada obtained a writ of habeas corpus from Justice Stover, in Special Term, Part II., of the Supreme Court, directing Mary Gannon to produce in court to-morrow morning the fifteen-months-old daughter of Mrs. De Quesada.

An ambulance called twice yesterday morning at 84 Division Street for Abraham Abramowitch. The man was insane -- the first time mildly, the next time furiously. He is a tailor, nineteen years old, and lives with two brothers on the upper floor at the above address.

Clark Mills's equestrian statue of Jackson proved the occasion of an architectural revolution in its neighborhood less than half a century ago, the circumstances of which should be made a matter of permanent record. The revolutionary leader was Mme. Montalba, a native of New-Orleans, but a Parisian by residence prior to 1848.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8. -- Although the hour when Mr. Bryan departed from Des Moines was extremely early quite a crowd was at the railway station, which cheered as the train drew out.

Ovid's "Metamorphoses," and in a less degree his "Fasti," are valuable not only as story books and poems, but as documents for the history of ideas. Ovid was a collector of traditions on a vast scale. He had an incomparable knowledge of legends, prejudices, customs, rites, and if he embellished more than the Folklore Society would strictly approve, there is reason to think that he never invented.

The condition of the market may properly be described as one of slow panic. We must be near the end of it, however. Whether the last blow is to be more severe than any yet experienced, or whether the worst has already been felt, it seems incredible that with the majority of securities there can be further serious decline. The Chicago collapse precipitated the liquidation we have had since Tuesday.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 8. -- An excursion to Raritan Beach under the auspices of the Watsessing Methodist Episcopal Church was enjoyed to-day by a large number of persons.

That the conduct of the inmates of Elmira Penitentiary when under surveillance should be accepted as evidence of the success of the institution as an agency for diminishing crime inspires the gravest doubts with regard to any claims made on behalf of the Elmira system itself, and yet it does not appear that there is much better evidence forthcoming.

NUREMBERG, Aug. 8. -- The last but one round in the International Chess Tournament was played in this city to-day, when Lasker, by beating Tarrasch, secured the first prize, valued at $750, and a silver cup and salver, presented by His Royal Highness the Prince Regent of Bavaria. Nothing can be said about the probable winners of the remaining prizes, as there are too many candidates left in the field.

WILLETS, POINT, L.I., Aug. 8. -- Any one unfamiliar with the details of army matters would have ample cause to wonder, in a trip afoot through the wild parts of this country, how the United States troops in time of war overcome the numerous obstructions which appear to block their way in marching across country by routes previously untrodden.
CHICAGO, Aug 8. -- Candidate Bryan arrived in this city at 7:40 o'clock to-night, after a hot, tiresome journey from Des Moines, Iowa, on the Rock Island Railroad.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8. -- Dr. and Mrs. Seward Webb were among the arrivals to-day. They are guests at Vinland of Mrs. Webb's sister, Mrs. Hamilton McKay Twombly, and will stay for all the important events of the remainder of the season.

The use of wood for fuel has depreciated to a great extent within the past few years, and the indications are that the demand for it for such use will continue to grow considerably less for some time to come. Of course the farmer and manufacturer close to wooded lands will continue the use of wood for fire because it is handy to procure and saves transportation charges.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 8 -- The thirty-footers had a very long and unsatisfactory race to-day, which the Hera won because she got the only puffs of wind that were astir just after the yachts started. The triangular course of eighteen miles was sailed. It is from Branton's Cove to and around a stake off Jamestown, to and around Bishop's Buoy, back to the start, and over again.

Greece is, undoubtedly, the most democratic nation in Europe -- perhaps in the world. In Southeastern Europe the rule of the Turk obliterated all social distinctions, and swept away every vestige of feudalism. Roumania alone, which was never so completely under the Turkish yoke, retains an aristocratic class; but Servia, Bulgaria, and Greece are democratic to the core.

A jolly faced, rotund France-German stood on the rolf or Koster Bial's Music Hall, hack of the stage, the other night, and gathered about him was as strange a collection of animals as has ever been taught to amuse the public.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 8. -- The bad weather of the past week has not kept people from coming to Bar Harbor, and this resort has now almost resumed its old-time gayety.

While no great army seems to exist in Switzerland, the whole able-bodied male population of the country can readily be made into an army. The natural defenses of the country have been utilized to the best advantage, and great care has been expended upon numerous defensive works on the frontiers.

Young horses can be led up to a sack lying on the ground and induced to pass it by letting them smell it and find out that it really is a sack, and not the Protean thing, whatever it may be, which illusion conjures up for them. Once the writer saw a very quick and pretty instance of experiment by touch made by a frightened pony.

The Brooklyn police early yesterday morning arrested the man who, they claim, invented the tool that caused the conviction of Bank Burglar Loomis only a short time ago. This instrument, which has been described in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, the police claim, was as fine a burglar's tool as was ever invented, and by its use a combination lock could easily be torn from any safe.

Two blue books relating to education in Scotland have recently been issued. In one of them -- the general report on education in the southern division of Scotland -- Dr. John Kerr, her Majesty's Chief Inspector, states that the attempts to make the school supply equal to the demand in the division had been satisfactorily energetic.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 8. -- A.W.B. Garrison, his wife, and two children, of this village, are spending the heated term in a camp on the opposite side of the harbor at Spring Valley. While lighting the oil stove last evening Mrs. Garrison let the match fall to the ground. It went among some leaves, igniting them.
VANCOUVER, Aug. 8. -- The following Australian cycling advices have been received here:

RIDGEFIELD Conn., Aug. 8. -- The midsummer event in this pleasant Summer resort was the ball in the assembly rooms of the Ridgefield Club this evening. Despite the heat, representatives of nearly every family in the New-York colony were present, and the function was a great success. Mrs. Henry E. Hawley gave a tea on the Country Club grounds a few days ago.

The lobster's legs, all told, are ten is numbers. But only eight of these are largely used for walking. The front pair, or big claws, have been specialized, as in the crab and most others of the higher crustaceans into prehensile organs for catching and crushing the prey. Their use is obvious.
HAVANA, Aug. 8. -- Ricardo Barrio Robado, a prisoner of war, was shot to-day at Matanzas.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 8. -- The body of the Rev. Father Michael M. Murray, assistant pastor of St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, in Brooklyn, who was drowned Tuesday while bathing at Rockaway Park, was recovered at 4:30 o'clock this morning by Robert Carman, a Government life saver, who was making his 4 o'clock tour of the beach.

ATHENS, July 10. -- There is a certain humorously unconventional element about the guerrilla warfare carried on by the Cretan insurgents, which is at times strongly suggestive of light opera. The story I have in mind has been so far bushed up, but it is worth the telling, and its publication by the time this reaches New-York can do no harm.

The now roof garden recently opened by the Hebrew Institute in East Broadway, near Jefferson Street, is one of the greatest blessings that could have been devised to give the overcrowded population on the east side a chance to breathe a little fresher air than they can get in the stifling streets and tenements.

A statement was made yesterday by Charles H. Nicoll, the New-York agent of The Atlanta Journal, of which Secretary Hoke Smith is the principal owner, regarding the "Sound-Money Supplement" to The Journal, for which advertisements and contributions were solicited from leading New-York bankers and business men, but which has not yet appeared.
Bishop Newman of Omaha has on his political fighting clothes. He has lived in Nebraska long enough to know Bryan and his Populistic admirers, and the Bishop is for McKinley and sound money.

ROCKVILLE, Conn., Aug. 8. -- The State firemen's parade was held here to-day and was witnessed by 8,000 people. The parade included the entire fire departments of East Hartford, Burnside, Windsor Locks, Brand Brook, Safford Springs, and Rockville. All business blocks, public buildings, and many residence; were elaborately decorated.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Aug. 8 -- With the beginning of the first week of August, Mount Pocono waters upon its most prosperous month of the season. Here is an altitude of 2,400 feet above the sea level, with always a bracing breeze. Pleasant features here are the beautiful walks and the perfect roads for driving and bicycling.

Mr. Boothby's protagonist may irresistibly remind some of his American readers of Prof. Herrmann, the magician, but the resemblance will serve only to make him more interesting. Dr. Nikola is a wonderful fellow, whose eyes look straight through you, and whose knowledge of occult mysteries is profound.

Edmond de Goncourt, who died recently at the home of his friend, Alphonse Daudet, was the elder of the two famous brothers whose collaboration produced so many original works in the domain of history, romance, and art. Jules de Goncourt died in 1870 and the elder brother remained inconsolable to his dying day.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 8. -- The militia stationed at the Brown Hoist Works charged upon a crowd of citizens who were gathered in front of the home of one of them last night, and two men were bayoneted. Their wounds were not serious. Fifteen men were arrested by the soldiers, charged with disorderly conduct.

The General Committee of the Indian Tea Association (London) refers in its annual report just issued to the special efforts that are being successfully made to develop the market for British-grown tea in the United States. The most noteworthy point since the last annual meeting has been, it observes, the cordial co-operation of Ceylon.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Weelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

The dissolution of the monasteries had greatly increased vagrancy in the sixteenth century. Rich abbeys, like that of Reading, employed large numbers of workmen and servants, who, when their masters had fallen into evil case, were thrown upon a heartless world and took to robbery for a livelihood.

Mental diseases, and especially hysteria, have, from the earliest times to the present; exercised a tremendous influence upon the current metaphysical conception of the universe and upon the whole mental development, and that precisely because they not only occurred sporadically, but, as we shall soon see, attacked the masses in the form of epidemics, and so became of the highest significance and importance for the life of society as a whole.

The appeal for aid for Miss Juliet Corson, the noted writer and lecturer on cookery, has met with prompt and generous responses. Miss Corson, who has been very active all her life, is now suffering from a prostrating ailment, but is courageously fighting it.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 8. -- The plunge of Sphinxetta, by which she won the race, was the feature of the 2:12 pace, which was the last event of the Grand Circuit races, and postponed necessarily from yesterday to to-day. Her owner made several thousand dollars on her. Summary of the race:

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Three men at an early hour this morning broke into the Kearny and Bergen Stone Crushing Mills, on Schuyler Avenue, North Arlington, and began a wholesale raid. They drove to the place, and had placed $500 worth of machinery in the wagon when they were discovered. Henry Bayliss, the son of Mayor George Bayliss of the borough, was awakened by the noise made by the thieves in removing the machinery.

This volume, which Mr. Galton has edited, contains a mass of information derived in a novel way. Persons in England who earn their livings by work -- dressmakers, engravers, bookbinders, bricklayers, agricultural laborers, among the number -- have accounts of their conditions given by one in their own station, some person who, from the place held in some labor organization, seems wholly competent to represent them.

Whether the German Chancellor has actually resigned his office or not, there seems to be no doubt that he has become exceedingly uncomfortable in it. His administration has not been successful. Both domestic and "imperial," or Federal, questions have become more urgent than they were under his predecessor.
FISHER'S ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 8. -- The past week has been the busiest one of the season. Every available room, in the best hotels and cottages is now occupied, and the gay season has begun in earnest.

He consulted a wise man, who told him that a certain spring on his estate had miraculous properties, and if he took a drink from it every morning at 6 o'clock he would find that his fortunes would improve.

Entry blanks are now ready for the National circuit race meet of the Quill Club Wheelmen of America, which will be held at the Manhattan Beach track on Friday and Saturday, Sept. 18 and 19, and can be obtained upon application to the Race Committee of the club, 150 Nassau Street.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 8. -- A report on the condition of the growing crops July 31, together with estimates by its correspondents of the yields of wheat, rye, oats, barley, flax, and hay applied to acreages of each returned by Township Assessors, has been issued by the Kansas State Board of Agriculture.

No patriotic citizen of the United States could regard it as anything but a calamity to have either of the political parties of the country fall under the control of such forces as seized the July convention in Chicago and put forth the platform upon which BRYAN and SEWALL stand as candidates for President and Vice President.

With Aug. 16 comes the opening of the woodcock shooting season. It would not be correct to say that this season is eagerly anticipated by the majority of hunters, as it could not be stated truthfully. This for the reason that but few hunters are successful with woodcock. None of our same birds is so difficult to kill as this king of the wild feathered tribe.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Fishing has the lead, and many other diversions are unheeded. Bluefish in the bay, weakfish, kingfish, porgies, butterfish, eels, , in the North and South Shrewsbury Rivers, all in such quantities that the amateurs can hardly give away their catches. Besides, the commercial fishermen have caught in their fyke nets and pounds great quantities. From docks, bridges, and small rowboats, the hauls have been plentiful.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 8 -- The deposits of the Woonsocket Rubber Company in the Rhode Island Hospital and Trust Company, the Industrial Trust Company, and the Merchants' National Bank of this city were attached this morning by Joseph Banigan to secure payment of a note for $100,000, made by Banigan when he was President of the company, in this own favor.

BRATTLEBOROUGH, Vt., Aug. 8. -- A call was issued to-day for a convention of sound-money Democrats of the State at Bellows Falls Aug. 18, to elect delegates to the Indianapolis Convention and to nominate four Presidential Electors in support of the ticket nominated there.

SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The past week has been notable for the large number of new arrivals at the hotels and the many visitors at the cottages. To-day the hotel proprietors are at their wins end to know how to accommodate the crowd of husbands, brothers, and sweethearts who are here to spend Sunday.

The particular story which gives Mrs. Peattie's volume its title is one of eight, and there is not one of the stories which has not striking merit. Of them all perhaps the "Mountain Woman" and "A Lady of Yesterday" are the vaguest in their conception. Mrs. Brainard, who is born in the mountains, so longs for her grander world that she pines in the flatlands and leaves her husband.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 8. -- The fine weather and the good card presented by the League of American Wheelmen State championship meet drew fully 5,000 spectators to Tourists' Oval this afternoon. Those present saw some excellent racing and close finishes. The two-mile tandem handicap was the feature of the day's sport.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Aug. 8. -- For one whole year the farmers of the inlying towns of Monmouth and Middlesex Counties had been waiting for to-day, which to them was "Salt Water Day," one more generally observed than any of the holidays except Christmas.

The good people of Manhasset, L.I., have for several days believed that a murder by poisoning was committed Aug. 1 at Herrick Village, in the town of North Hempstead. Persons not swayed by prejudice or gossip are convinced that a verdict of suicide will be rendered in the case next Tuesday.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 8. -- The State Populistic Convention adjourned sine die at 5:25 o'clock to-day. It had completed the State ticket by the nomination of J. McMinn for Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and R.V. Bell for Associate Justice, Court of Criminal Appeals, E.O. Call and H.D. Wood, who are fusionists, were named as Electors-at-large, and J.S. Bradley was elected Chairman of the State Executive Committee.

GALWAY, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The Republicans of Saratoga County met to-night and ratified the nomination of McKinley and Hobart. George H. West presided. Among those present were Robert Shaw, James Shaw, George Armer, Frank Tabor, Dr. William V. Balch, Robert Kelly, John M. Clute, George Deckner, S.O. Kemp, John Plerouch, Henry Glenn, Frank L. Smith, Heman Palling, Henry Master, Eli Bailey, Earl Inman.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Pastor Gibbs of the Asbury Methodist Episcopal Church has been spending a few days at Asbury Park. Prof. J.S.C. Wells and family are at Westport, on Lake Champlain. Mayor Cane and family, with Mrs. Graham Vankeuen, are at Point Pleasant. The engagement of William H. Quackenbush and Miss Sophie Kastner is announced.
The outward-bound steamship Etruria of the Cunard Line crashed into and sunk the big self-propelling grain elevator Ceres off Bedlow's Island at 1:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

Edouard Rod writes a story of a provincial Swiss town, Bielle in the Vaudois. To Bielle comes a new Protestant pastor, Henri Trembloz, whose mother is a peasant woman. Mme. Trembloz is made of coarser clay than is her son. She is grasping, sordid, ambitious, gossiping, yet keeps a sharp eye on the main chance.

LONDON, Aug. 8. -- The fact that Lord Salisbury took no part in the debate on the Irish Land bill in the House of Lords has caused a great deal of comment in various quarters. The Prime Minister did not seem to be at all affected by the hostility displayed by his whilom followers, but, on the contrary, assumed an air of unusual gayety, joking on the subject with the Lord High Chancellor.

GENESEO, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Livingston County Republicans hope this year to furnish the Gubernatorial candidate of their party. Their favorite son is James W. Wadsworth, now Congressman from this district, and for years a prominent man in county and State politics.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 8. -- Major McKinley's callers to-day included the members of the Ohio Canal Commission, who are on a tour of inspection of canals in the State. The following was among the Major's telegrams to-day:

There were not enough members of the "compass" whist tournament at the Brooklyn Whist Club last week to make up a game. The whist players at present item to be indulging in retache. It is a much less difficult game to play than whist, and better adapted to warm weather. A very closely contested match was played instead between Segur's team and Henius's team.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., Aug. 8. -- There has been a good deal of playing at the links of the Locustwood Golf Club this week, and some excellent scores were made. Some of the young women are developing into expert golfers. At last week's match Miss Sara Peters was one of the winners. Miss Gretchen Tefft, Miss Helen De Mott, and Miss Ethel Kerner are also often seen on the links.

TAUNTON, Mass., Aug. 8. -- The police arrested Henbert Willis on suspicion of being a noted bicycle thief of Southeastern Massachusetts and Rhode Island and an all-around desperado. He belongs in Taunton and is about twenty-two years old.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 8. -- Mrs. John Silzer and daughter went this week to Castleton, N.Y., where they will remain several weeks.

Announcement has been made that the building of the East Baptist Church, at Madison and Gouverneur Streets, is for sale, and that the remnants of the large congregation which worshipped there years ago have attached themselves to another church of the same denomination in a neighborhood near by.

The very quafutest of all the quaint spots in semi-tropical Southern California is the Indian village of Saboba, nestling in a valley just under the western slope of the San Jacinto spur of the San Bernardino range of mountains. Nowhere else under the flag of the Republic is calm, easy Indian life to be better observed.

William H. Van Tassell, the President of the West Side Architectural Iron Works, at 550 to 560 West Thirty-third Street, went to the West Thirty-seventh Street Police Station in a state of great agitation about 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning and told the Sergeant on duty that one of his offices had been robbed.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The Rev. Dr. Charles F. Aked, the brilliant and distinguished preacher of Liverpool, England, delivered his lecture upon "Political Problems and Progress in Great Britain" here to-day. It was the most sensational lecture of the season. Dr. Aked said in brief:

It is fortunate for the Summer resorts that August is the month of vacations of the year, and consequently insures the liberation from offices and shops of an army of young men, who from force of habit or from very natural choice and desire to obtain a needed change of scene and cooler air, hie themselves to the watering places, where their arrival wonderfully stimulates those resorts.

CENTRE HARBOR, N.H., Aug. 8. -- The New-Hampshire State championship lawn tennis tournament ended here to-day, with a hard match in the challenge round for the championship bowl. J.P. Paret of New-York, who won it last year, met James Terry of Yale, whom he had beaten three straight sets in the finals yesterday. He came within two strokes of winning again to-day, but was finally beaten.

With the temporary revival of royalism in France, facts concerning the Orleans family are once more the order of the day. One of the marked characteristics of the family is that, with few exceptions, its members are gifted with marked literary talent and would be so considered in whatever rank of society the hazard of birth might have thrown them.

Mr. BRYAN remarked some days ago in one of his brief addresses that "poor people" were not in favor of a dollar "increasing in value." The value of a dollar is measured by its purchasing power -- the quantity of food, clothing, , it will buy. Are not "poor people" in favor of a dollar which has large and possibly increasing purchasing power, rather than a dollar of low purchasing power?

The public mind has been occupied not a little during the past ten years in considering the needs of the navy and in observing its steady development to meet the requirements of the country. Notwithstanding the attention given to the subject, it is astonishing to note the prevailing ignorance regarding the service -- ignorance, that is to say, of the purpose for which it was created and the reasons for its maintenance.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- A special regatta of the New-Rochelle Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon. Races had been planned for special thirty-foot class, regular forty-three-foot class, and open catboats of all classes. Though several of the larger boats were on hand, it was decided to have their races postponed because of the almost dead calm that prevailed, and only the catboats were started.

Ocean breezes did not cut much of a figure at the Brighton Beach race track, whither went yesterday a lot of the half-holiday crowd, hoping to find a bit of relief from the torridity and humidity of the city. The regulars found that the game was as hot as the weather for them, as four of the favorites were bowled over without an effort, but two of them, Suisun and Emily Henderson, landing the money.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- Senator T.W. Palmer of Michigan, formerly Minister to Spain and head of the World's Fair Commission, is enjoying life under the Spring House roof, when he is not seeking for a new view on the surrounding hills.

Lord Charles Beresford addressed a crowded and influential meeting held recently under the auspices of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, in the banqueting hall of the Exchange Station Buildings, Liverpool. Mr. F.C. Danson, President of the Chamber, occupied the chair. The subject of Lord Charles's address was "The Manning of the Fleet; Our Dangerous Position."

Surpassingly rich is Rufus Barrington, who is at the head of his own bank in San Francisco, and Rufus is sharp and unscrupulous. He has made his own fortune and all men are his tools. He has two sons. Harry, who is as worldly as is his father, is intent on money grubbing. Dick, the younger, is college bred, and when he comes home has no taste for his father's pursuits.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- The Republicans of the First Assembly District of Westchester County, comprising the towns of Yonkers, Mount Vernon, and East Chester, as it was before annexation, held a district convention this afternoon in Lincoln Hall, which resulted in a complete victory for the Platt faction under the leadership of State Senator J. Irving Burns.
LENOX, Mass., Aug. 8. -- Mr. Richard Goodman and family left this week for Bar Harbor, where they will remain through the month of August.
The Princess Maud, daughter of the Prince of Wales, was well supplied with useful presents on the occasion of her recent marriage with the young Prince of Denmark.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- After their week's stay in the State Camp the Sixty-ninth Regiment left at 2 o'clock this afternoon for New-York City. The work done by the regiment, which is a new one, caused the State officers stationed here to congratulate the officers of the regiment.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- At the Republican First Assembly District Convention of Niagara County, held here this afternoon, great enthusiasm was manifested for Senator Ellsworth for Governor.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 8. -- The event of the week at the Hotel Brooklyn was the East Bay Yacht Club races, which took place this afternoon. The greatest interest was exhibited, and the bay is alive with boats from all South Side clubs. The course was triangular, seven times around, distance ten miles, and was directly opposite the hotel, where a most perfect view was obtained.
