The course was triangular, seven times around, distance ten miles, and was directly opposite the hotel, where a most perfect view was obtained.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 8. -- At the Republican First Assembly District Convention of Niagara County, held here this afternoon, great enthusiasm was manifested for Senator Ellsworth for Governor.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 9. -- The run of the New-York Yacht Squadron from Newport to Vineyard Haven yesterday, which was tame and uninteresting all day, furnished enough excitement at the finish to give the yachtsmen something to talk about to-day. For hours the yachts drifted aimlessly on the Sound, and there was very little prospect of their getting to anchor at all.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Candidate Bryan left Chicago for Pittsburg by the Pennsylvania Road at 11:30 o'clock to-night. Mr. and Mrs. Bryan departed from the Clifton House a few minutes past 11 o'clock, after shaking hands with a large number of people gathered there to say good-bye, and were driven to the Union Station, accompanied by the members of the Chicago Reception Committee.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 9. -- Jules Gueymaud, a storekeeper in St. Charles Parish last Wednesday night was assassinated while standing on his front porch. A Sicilian named Lorenzo Saladino was known to have a grudge against Gueymaud, and he was suspected of the crime. Circumstantial and other evidence caused his arrest Friday.

" May I have the pleasure of a promenade with you at the walk in the morning?" is destined to take the place of the familiar, "May I have the pleasure of a dance with you at the hop this evening?" in the conversation of the Summer youth and the Summer maiden, at the various Summer outing places where they are to be found.
" The little word 'to' once cost me several hundred dollars," said a well-to-do real estate dealer.

In a sermon on "The Coinage Heresy," delivered last night in Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street by the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur, he said that most of the speeches he had read on free silver were made up of equal parts of lungs, lunacy, and larceny.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 9. -- Thomas Kay of Oswego Falls was drowned this afternoon while swimming in Lake Neahtawanta.

The doughty Tammany braves known to fame as the Hickory Club indulged yesterday in their annual outing at Witzel's Grove, College Point. Long will pleasant memories of the occasion linger in the old Fifth Ward.
LONDON, Aug. 9. -- The extensive oil works of Sir W.A. Rose Co., at Rose's Wharf, Millwall, have been destroyed by fire. The loss probably will amount to $500,000.

The Captain and crew of eleven men of the lost Austrian bark Emille, who were picked up in midocean from two boats, in which they escaped from their burning vessel by the British steamship Axminster, from Charleston, arrived here last night on the Clyde Line steamship Seminole.

" I am simply on my way to the great metropolis of the Nation," said Mr. BRYAN in Chicago, "to accept the nomination given me in this city a few weeks ago. I am glad to take them your greetings. I can tell them you are their friends, and that you will help them to save themselves from the domination of European bondage under which they have been suffering."

Such was the great gathering of Methodists in the old historic grove on Sing Sing Heights yesterday, where 2,000 persons worshipped from early morning until night amid the solemn pomp of woodland glades.
John Hughes, twenty-five years old, of 202 East Ninety-eighth Street, fell from the roof of his house early yesterday morning, and was instantly killed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- Gen. Miles has completed a plan for increased coast defense, which he has presented to Secretary Lamont. The project contemplates the establishment of new artillery posts at seven points -- Fort Preble, Me.; Fort Trumbull, Conn.; Fort Hancock, on Sandy Hook, and at Washington, D.C.; Charleston, S.C.; Savannah, Ga., and Lime Point, near San Francisco.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 9. -- The Republican State Committee had a stirring session yesterday. The silver Republicans on the committee carried everything before them, and the McKinleyites bolted. M.M. Patrie, Chairman of the committee, and a majority of the committee held a session last night to consider vacancies, and a plan of campaign. Returns from primaries show that the silver men will have absolute control of the State Convention.
NEWPORT, Aug. 9. -- The heat was oppressive here to-day. Thousands of excursionists came to town and swarmed on the beach and in the parks.
There was no abatement of the heat yesterday until 11 o'clock P.M., when there came a wild westerly gale and a fierce electrical storm, after a dead and trying calm of five hours.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 9. -- The returns of the State election, officially canvassed yesterday, subject to minor changes, show that the Democrats carried 42 counties, and the Populists 26. The Populists, in 1894, carried 38 counties, the Democrats 28. The net Democratic gain is 9 counties. The Democrats carriers 11 Populist counties, and lost 2 Democratic counties.

HONOLULU, Aug. 2. -- P.C. Jones left by the steamship Peru for the United States, where he goes to float the Hawaiian loan of $3,300,000 authorized by the Government after the defeat of the original Refunding bill of Minister Damon, introduced into the last Legislature.

After an endless series of competitive plans, necessarily chaotic, at last the form of the Exposition of 1900 has been determined upon. The final concours has been closed and a judgment rendered, but all we can do at present, is to give some general ideas as to its exterior aspect, with the decorative part, for in this latter lies somewhat the element of success.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 9. -- The Ohio campaign will be opened Saturday at Columbus. The meeting wilt be addressed by Senator John Sherman and Senator-elect J.B. Foraker. Senator Sherman's speech will be looked upon generally as the first step in his campaign for re-election to the United States Senate.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Paterson won from Lancaster to-day after an interesting game of baseball. Both teams batted heavily, but the weather was too hot, and there was little life in the game. Armor did the best batting, getting four hits out of five times at bat. The score follows:

The statement in our London dispatches yesterday morning that the English Government had unreservedly withdrawn from the European concert on the Turkish question may be a very important one. The concert has for a long time been purely a negative one. That is to say, all the powers have tacitly agreed to do nothing to which any one of them refused assent.
" Ah-h-h-h!" exclaimed 70,00O persons on arriving at Coney Island and Manhattan Beach yesterday. They were astonished, delighted, and experienced the sensation one has in plunging into a cold bath.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9. -- Dispatches received from various points throughout the Western country show that no point is exempt from the torrid weather.

The claim has been made hat the rubber tires on a bicycle are a protection to the rider against lightning. The wheel ridden by Walter Scott Thursday evening had rubber tires. He was killed and the tires were not damaged in the least. What became, then, of the bolt of lightning after it accomplished its deadly work?

Photographic copies of an original, it is claimed, are not acceptable as proof before a court, inasmuch as the photographs may easily be changed to suit the wish. Expert picture-makers can take a photograph, and by various processes secure a composite containing several features desired that did not exist in the original.

We hear the suggestion made that BRYAN'S speech at the notification meeting this week will change the course of the campaign. The candidate will make it appear that he is a Democrat, not a Populist. He will disclaim the economic vagaries of the West and appeal by his conservative utterances to the prosy and steady-going East.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 9. -- Registrar Van Dyke of Princeton University has now received nearly all the returns from local examinations for the incoming class, and has announced that steady gains have been made over the past three classes in all quarters. The prospects are that the new class will be the largest since the class of '96 entered, which was the largest class in the history of the institution.

The celebrated altar piece which Raphael painted in 1504-5 for the nuns of Sant' Antonio of Perugia, and which, from its subsequent owners, has been called the "Colonna" or "Ripalda" Raphael, has been purchased from the representatives of the late King of Naples by Mr. Martin Colneghi of the Marlborough Gallery, Pall Pall.

The adoption of the Savage gun for the rearmament of the National Guard at a cost of over $300,000 is to be vigorously opposed by gun inventors and manufacturers who entered the test before the State commission named to select a gun.

Many of our exchanges publish interesting facts concerning the progress of the movement for the purification of the milk supply by killing consumptive cows, and we have been accustomed to direct attention in these columns from time to time to the current reports relating to this sanitary undertaking, the importance of which is more clearly seen every year both in this country and in Europe.
Those politicians who had the energy to discuss anything except the hot weather, as they sat on the hotel plazzas at Manhattan Beach yesterday, turned to the Gubernatorial fight in this State.

It is not to be forgotten that the State campaign in New-York this year is one of more than usual importance. The Republicans have evidently not been united either by the nomination of McKINLEY or by the adoption of a sound-money platform at St. Louis, and their division may make itself felt in the field of State politics.

SALT LAKE, Aug. 9. -- The Cannon family, which for a number of years has regarded Utah as its political and spiritual heritage, is in a bad way. At a time when the Republican Party seemed inclined to pursue such a silver and protection policy as would make Utah Republican for a number of years, the Cannons joined that party.

TEXARKANA, Ark., Aug. 9. -- The race war in Polk County has broken out in earnest, and as a result of the first battle three negroes are dead, eight wounded, and many have been run out of the county by the whites. Several negroes have passed through this place who were forced to leave the county, and they bring news of a pretty bad condition of affairs.

LONDON, Aug. 9. -- Much interest exists in astronomical circles as to the success of the several expeditions sent out to various parts of the world to study the total eclipse of the sun, which occurred to-day.

There is not much free-silver sentiment in New-York. If we could measure Bryan's strength by the strength of the demand for free coinage of silver it would be of insignificant proportions. If the election in New-York State hinged solely on the financial issue it hardly would be worth while for the advocates of sound money to do any campaign work.

Stephen Gardner, who is said to have been the last surviving full-blooded member of the Narragansett tribe of Indians, died on Saturday at the age of sixty-five. He had been employed as a butler for the last five years by a woman living in West Twenty-eighth Street.
Owing to the carelessness of some one an accident occurred at the Brooklyn Navy Yard on Saturday night which caused a damage to Government property of probably over $100,000.

The Webb family of Letcher County, is the wonder of Eastern Kentucky. About the year 1790 Benjamin Webb left his home in Ashe County, N.C., and emigrated to the unbroken wilds of the Eastern Kentucky. He built a home on the beautiful and historic Kentucky River, only a few miles from its source, where the early Kentucky pioneer.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 3. -- Only such work as it was absolutely necessary to perform was done to-day, and every effort was made to make the work as light as possible. The heat wan intense all day, and not a breath of cooling air was felt, not even after sundown. The men and horses suffered greatly, and kept in the shade as much as possible. The work will commence in the morning.

Senator CAFFERY of Louisiana has been asked to resign his seat because he will not support the Populist Chicago platform and candidates. He says that he will do so when he is asked by "such a party as elected" him, but not till then. He remains true to his party. He repudiates the Populists who have seized its machinery.

PORT HURON, Mich., Aug. 9. -- Edward Henkel, aged forty-three, son and successor of Peter Henkel, proprietor of the largest and oldest wholesale grocery and liquor house in Detroit, was killed here to-day on his yacht, the Azalea. He was trying to get out of the way of a big lake liner, and was fending his yacht off the dock, when he was caught between the yacht and timbers and fatally crushed.
The hot wave seemed to have affected the Central Labor Union yesterday, as several of the delegates showed signs of mental irritation.

Miss Jeannette Rose of Randolph, Oregon, seventeen years old, is the heroine of that locality because of her brave encounter with a big black bear Friday afternoon. She was strolling in an unfrequented place in the woods near home, carrying a rifle, with which she was shooting rabbits and birds, when she came upon a bear cub.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 9. -- There was no lessening of the heat here to-day, and many suffered from the scorching sun. The thermometer registered between 90 and 95 all day. Every train and every boat that arrived was loaded to its capacity.

George A. Vaillant, a civil engineer, was found dead in bed at 29 Bank Street, where he boarded, yesterday morning. It was at first thought that he had died from the heat, but a letter was found which Vaillant had written while dying from the effects of a dose of laudanum which he had taken to kill himself.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 9. -- William J. Gilmore, one of the ablest and best-known lawyers at the Ohio bar, died at his residence here this afternoon, aged seventy-three years. He was at one time a Justice of the Supreme Court of the State.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9. -- The heated term that has been almost without precedent in this city continues, and the general impression is that to-day has been beyond all doubt the hottest and most uncomfortable of the season. The churches were comparatively very sparsely attended, the streets almost deserted, and many people left the city in the early morning for river resorts and suburban retreats, in the hope of escaping the torrid temperature of the city.

COLLEGE POINT, L.I., Aug. 9. -- Jennis Friedman of 786 East Ninty-eighth Street and Pauline Landman of East Tenth Street, near Avenue D, New-York City, had a narrow escape from drowning this evening, and late at night they were still in a precarious condition and liable to die from the effects of their accident.

OLD ORCHARD, Me., Aug. 9. -- In two sessions of the Christian Alliance camp meeting at the camp grounds to-day $101,324 was raised for foreign missions, and nearly 100 persons volunteered their services as missionaries to be sent to foreign fields. The Christian Alliance meetings have been in progress two weeks and have been attended by large audiences.

Free-silver men are declaring daily that the scramble for seats at the Bryan meeting in Madison Square Garden Wednesday night in a sure indication of the great strength of the Chicago ticket in this city and State.

Last week was an exciting one in Stock Exchange circles. Monday was a comparatively quiet day, with a small recession in in prices, but on Tuesday stocks broke badly on the announcement of the Moore Brothers' failure, and the consequent indefinite closing of the Chicago Stock Exchange. Liquidation of investment holdings continued throughout the week, and was most pronounced on Friday and Saturday.
Among the companies recently incorporated by the Secretary of State is the "New-York Family Supply Company, to conduct a newspaper in the interest of colored people and to deal in merchandise."

FREEPORT, L.I. Aug. 10. -- Arthur E. Dykman of Brooklyn, who was arrested here yesterday by Officer Dunbar of this place, charged with forging a check for $50, escaped from the officer in New-York today. Dunbar took his prisoner to the city to allow him to obtain bail.

Arthur Sewall, the candidate for Vice President of the Chicago Convention, came to this city yesterday to be officially notified of his nomination at the gathering in Madison Square Garden to-morrow night.

BANGOR, Me., Aug. 10. -- Dr. Wilmer L. Pressey of Bangor was instantly killed by lightning while in the Summer cottage occupied by his family at Islesborough, Sunday. The home was badly splintered and wrecked, but no other person was injured physically. Dr. Pressey was twenty-one years old. He had become betrothed to a young lady, who was sitting by his side when he was killed.

A great multitude of men will attend the meeting at Madison Square Garden to-morrow night. Some will attend as sincere devotees of Populism, Socialism, Bryanism, and 16 to 1. Others will be there from simple curiosity.

ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- The consolidation of seven gas companies of Brooklyn into one corporation, under the name of the Brooklyn Gas Company, was reviewed at a hearing before Attorney General Hancock to-day.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- A lively catboat race was sailed here this afternoon for one of the prizes offered by the Newport Kat Bote Klub. The starters were the Iris, sailed by Robert Livingston Gerry ; the Infanta, sailed by W.T. Davies, and the Victor, sailed by Alfred Vanderbilt.
Seventy-two deaths from the heat and over 170 prostrations were reported yesterday in this city, and many more casualties in Brooklyn and neighboring cities.

The Populists are counting on the Republican vote, both white and black. There was a time when the Republicans would have done all they could to defeat the Democrats, and they would have done it this year if they and the Populists had succeeded in making a fusion ticket, but as the fusion movement failed, there is no particular reason why the Republicans should vote the Populistic ticket.

The novelty of a woman orator drew out a big crowd to hear Mrs. Mary Ellen Lease of Kansas at Cooper Union Hall last night. There were a great many women in the crowd and a number of them were on the stage. Men took off their coats in the hot room and the speakers and audience suffered terribly front the heat.
By its fluctuations and the strong upward movement at the close, the stock market yesterday indicated that a more hopeful feeling is taking root in Wall Street.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 10. -- The Pittsburg Bryan and Sewall Reception Committee, bringing with it Richard P. Bland and wife, arrived in Canton some time before the hour scheduled for Bryan's train to arrive.

We notice that Mrs. MARY ELIZABETH LEASE of Kansas has arrived in this city, and that she is to address public audiences in behalf of Mr. BRYAN and the 53-cent silver standard. One of our contemporaries publishes an interview with her, and a few of her remarks are reported as follows:

CAMDEN, Aug. 10. -- Railroad men are of the opinion that it will require fully $500,000 to pay the damage claims of the relatives of the killed in the Atlantic City railroad accident, and of those who, although injured, survived the disaster. It is expected that a great list of suits will burden the court dockets, but who the defendant company will be is a matter of speculation among attorneys and others.

Mr. J. Woodbury Newcomb had devoted his life to the science of criminology, and at the age of fifty years he was prepared to claim a leading place among experts in that important department of knowledge.
Two impending strikes were rumored by the men out on strike yesterday, but neither of the two came to pass.

Dr. John Craig and William H. McClure, who were arrested Sunday, Charged with having used the United States malls for fraudulent purposes, were arraigned before United States Commissioners Bowe, in Jersey City, yesterday. The prisoners were represented by Counsellor James Furey, inspector J.J Larmour of Chicago said he had six complaints against the prisoners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Navy Department officials have obtained only the most meagre official details of the Brooklyn Navy Yard casualty, yet no doubt exists that some one has been culpably negligent of duty and that the board of inquiry which will at once investigate the occurrence will result in the court-martial of at least one officer high in the service.

There are worse kinds of weather than we are having in New-York now, if a traveler is to be believed, and if extremes of heat and cold together within twenty-four hours are worse than the continued prostrating heat.

DOVER, Del., Aug. 10. -- Chancellor Nicholson delivered his decision to-day in the habeas corpus proceedings brought by the single-tax advocates who are in jail. All the prisoners were present during the reading of the decision, except Samuel Melville, who is sick in jail. Edward Ridgely and Benlah Watson, counsel for the town, were also present.

Since the sliver craze has become the leading topic of discussion, people have been watching to see what effect it would have in the different branches of trade, and it is reported that recently many of the invoices of imported goods have come to the New-York houses marked "payable in gold."
HAVANA, Aug. 10. -- A Government force under command of Gen. Godoy, while convoying a supply train from Minas to Guaymaro, was attacked three times by 2,000 rebels under Avelino Rosas.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- The mercury in the hospital thermometer hovered around the one-hundred-degree mark all day, and the weather was as hot as any one cared w endure. The bathhouse, with its cool showers, proved most attractive, and it had many visitors. Fortunately, no arduous duties were required in the afternoon, or there might have been plenty of work for Post Surgeon Jarrett and his corps of assistants.

NUREMBERG, Aug. 10. -- The International chess tournament practically ended to-day. Altogether 170 games have been played, and only one game, that between Tarrasch and Albin, which was adjourned in to-day's play, lies to be decided. Lasker wins the first prize and Marocay the second. Pillsbury is sure of at least tying with Tarrasch for the third and fourth prizes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The report of the Statistician for the Department of Ariculture for August indicates an improvement in the condition of corn over that reported last month of 4.4 points, or from 92.4 to 96. The average of the principal States are: Ohio, 105; Kentucky, 102; Indiana, 105; Illinois, 106; Iowa, 103; Missouri, 85; Kansas, 109; Nebraska, 108.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10. -- Society is suffering from the heat, which is more intense that Newport has experienced in years.

It will be no cause of regret to the better part of mankind that the Kentucky distillers of Bourbon whisky have decided to suspend operations for eighteen months. The cause is overproduction, or perhaps the distillers regard it as under-consumption. Anyhow, there is a stock of 90,000,000 gallons on hand, and it was still accumulating at the rate of 5,000,000 gallons a year beyond the demand when the shut-down was decided upon.

Aside from the general slaughter of the favorites, Doggett being the only one to win, the sensation of the racing at the Brighton Beach track yesterday was the dead heat between Hazlet and Bessie Abbott to the third race, which was a dash of five furlongs. Hazier was an odds-on favorite for the race, and Bessie Abbott was the rank outsider of the lot, with 30 to 1 against her.
PORT ANGELES, Washington, Aug. 10. -- For the first time in the history of the Pacific squadron of the United States modern naval manoeuvres are to be conducted.

NEWPORT, Aug. 10. -- The yachts had a hard time getting into Vineyard Haven on Saturday night, anti to-day they had a hard time getting out. The harbor start was made at 5:30 o'clock, and then the flagship Sylvia proceeded to the West Chop and made the starting line off the Can Buoy.

It is well known that the average selling price of horses in this country has been declining for some time past. By the intelligent American whose mind is not befogged with silver or tariff delusious the real causes of this decline are clearly seen. We shall speak of them below.
ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- The New-York State Civil Service Commission has appointed Harold N. Saxton from the eligible list as an examiner in its department.

William Toepfer. Jr., a bright little towheaded boy, nine years old, living with his parents at 416 East Eighty-ninth Street, is as bad a boy for his age as can be found, judging from the list of his offenses as detailed by his father, who is janitor of the house.

LAMBERTVILLE, N.J., Aug. 10. -- William Mailay, as he sat down to supper last night, missed his little two-year-old son. Search was made through the house and the premises but he could not be found. Inquiry was made of the neighbors and at least a hundred persons joined in search.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 10. -- Much interest was occasioned along the water front Saturday and yesterday by the presence in the river of a small sloop yacht, which was a novelty, inasmuch as there was no man on board and it was sailed by two women. One of the women was of middle age and the other was twenty-three years of age.

A Macchi, recently appointed Commissioner General of the Foreign Department of the Tennessee Centennial Exposition, arrived in this city yesterday from Montreal, where he has been effecting arrangements for a Canadian exhibit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- If the wishes of the Democratic candidate for the Presidency are complied with, the headquarters of the National Committee will be fixed at Chicago, unless Mr. Bryan is brought to see that better results can be reached by having the campaign conducted from this city.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 10. -- It is hot enough here to broil chickens on the flagstones, but the visiting wheelmen do not mind it a bit, so hospitably are they being entertained by the local cyclist. The latter have been staying up late of nights devising plans for the amusement of their guests, and the schedule as made out for the week is a tempting one.

The General Committee on Legislation, composed of representatives from the four counties of Greater New-York, met in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen yesterday afternoon at 2:45 o'clock. The meeting was called for 2 o'clock, but at that hour only a few members were present, and there was not a quorum even as late as 2:45 o'clock.
NEWPORT, R.J., Aug. 10. -- Secretary of the Navy Herbert addressed the War College to-day on the subject: "The Sea and Sea Power as a Factor in the History of the United States."

We believe that a large majority of the farmers in this country are opposed to the Bryan policy of repudiation, and that they see what would be the effect upon agricultural interests of the election of the silver candidate. We also believe that a majority of the Western farmers are not supporters of this policy.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-20 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10. -- Five persons were drowned in the Delaware River last night, near Bridesburg, a suburb, by the overturning of a rowboat during a gale. The victims are:

The eloquence of the "Boy Orator" does not show to advantage from the rear platform of a railroad train. It seems to be only good for great occasions. It needs to be worked up and to have the accessories of theatrical effect. BRYAN needs time to accumulate rhetorical periods, gather figures of speech, borrow metaphors, and work up to a sacrilegious climax, and then he wants a chance to rehearse and polish up his delivery.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- Senator Shout of Idaho was at Republican headquarters this afternoon and talked very encouragingly of the outlook in the West, especially in his own State.

The final ceremonies over the body of Mohammed Ben Misoud, who arrived here six weeks ago from Egypt, became ill, died, and was buried on July 25, took place yesterday. A tombstone was placed over the last resting place of the departed Turk.

The Commissioners of Accounts, S.S. Terry and R.S. Dennis, sent to Mayor Strong yesterday a report on the irregularities discovered in the accounts of A.J. B. Miller, a former employe in the office of the Public Administrator.

A fire in Mangin Street, near Stanton Street, yesterday afternoon, destroyed a sawmill, brickyard, and lumberyard, disturbed a circus gathering and created general excitement for an hour or so among the thousands of neighboring residents. The loss is estimated at $50,000. The cause of the fire is unknown.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 10. -- Candidate Bryan got very little sleep last night. He left Chicago about 11 o'clock, and the train reached South Chicago at 12:10 o'clock this morning, where Mr. Bryan found a big crowd awaiting him. The cheering was very enthusiastic, and the candidate was hauled down to the station platform by lusty rolling mill men and made to shake hands with the people.
The policy of economy adopted by the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company Directors is being pursued, and in some of its results it will be far-reaching and permanent.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 10. -- As Breuta Hermenneni, who lives on Croton Point, was walking down the tracks early this morning to take a train to New-York, she was passed by a man about half a mile north of the station, who, after passing her, turned and caught her from behind. He tried to take her satchel from her, but she held fast to it.

WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 10. -- Two Walthan men appeared before Judge Luce of the District Court this morning and made the startling assertion that they were seriously assaulted and branded on the body in several places with red-hot irons while being initiated into Victoria Lodge, Sons of St. George, less than a week ago. The hearing was a secret one, and but little could be learned of the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- In Presidential campaigns it is the custom of the organs and managers of the weaker candidate to claim everything and to accept silence as implying assent and support. The organs and the managers of Mr. Bryan's campaign have adopted these familiar tactics. It is easy for them to assert the adherence to their cause of some Democrats who find it difficult to deny their assertions.
The Democratic National Committee will meet at noon to-day at the Fifth Avenue Hotel to outline a plan of campaign in behalf of Bryan and Sewall and attend to various matters of business.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- Miss Mary Proctor of New-York, daughter of the late Prof. Richard A. Proctor, the well-known astronomer, telegraphed to-day from Troudhjem, Norway, that a fine view was had yesterday of the total eclipse of the sun from the deck of the American Line steamer Ohio, which was then off the Island of Stut, Norway.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 10. -- The disaster on the Columbia and Donegal Electric Railway, north of Columbia, at 10:20 o'clock last night, is the worst that has occurred in this county in many years. Up to the present time six persons are dead and sixty-two injured, some of them seriously, and several are expected to die. Following is a list of killed:

The trial of Fire Alarm Superintendent J. Elliott Smith on charges of incompetency preferred against him by the Fire Commissioners was resumed yesterday morning at Fire Headquarters before the full board of Fire Commissioners, Gen. O.H. La Grange presiding. Several fire reports were handed in for identification and marked as exhibits.

Many merchants and manufacturers' agents in New-York City have received from Gustavo Niederlein, the Costa Rican Consul at Philadelphia, a circular issued in pursuance of a desire to stimulate trade between the United States and Costa Rica. The circular, which has aroused much interest among the agents, reads as follows:

NEWPORT, Aug. 10. -- The English-built Rosemarie, Gerald Paget's thirty-footer, which he has brought over to meet some of the fleet, Herreshoff craft, was a badly beaten boat today in the race for the Ralph N. Ellis Cup. was well sailed by her owner and his English skipper, but the Rosemarie has not the speed in her that the Rhode Island built boats have, and at the finish to-day, six Herrshoff craft led her.

SALT LAKE, Aug. 10. -- The body of the wife murderer, Charles H. Thiede, who was hanged here Friday, was interred by his relatives on the afternoon of the execution in the cemetery at Sandy, a small town fifteen miles south of Salt Lake.

The Board of Health has gained another victory in the Supreme Court in its efforts to removed the noxious rear tenements. Justice Stover refused, in the Supreme Court, yesterday to issue a preliminary injunction to Max S. Meyer, the owner of a rear tenement at S2 Columbia Street who wanted the board restrained from declaring the premises vacated prior to taking proceedings in condemnation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10. -- The August returns to the statistician to the Department of Agriculture show a reduction in the condition of cotton during the month of July from 92.5 to 80.1, or 12.4 points. The condition same time last year was 77.9, which was the lowest average for August ever given.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- At Birmingham to-day the Maiden Plate of 105 sovereigns, at five furlongs, for horses of all ages that never won, was won Pierre Lorillard's gelding Glaring, by the Sailor Prince-Flash, two years old. A Bailey's gelding Com Paul, was second, and Col. Forester's filly, by Ayrshire, out of Lady Helen, third.

The New-York baseball club's players made runs enough in one inning -- the seventh -- to defeat the Brooklyn players. The game, which was the last but one of the series between the clubs, was played at Eastern Park in the presence of something like 2,500 people, who blistered sweltered in the hot sun, with no breeze from Jamaica Bay or elsewhere to cool them off.

Distinguished guests at the Hotel Waldorf are Mr. Byron Peters of C.D. Peters Co., London, the largest railroad contractors in the United Kingdom, and his traveling companion. Mr. W.H. Argall, a mining engineer who is associated with vast gold mining interests in New-Zealand.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 10. -- This morning's trains brought many passengers to the city, all bent on seeing Bryan. Nothing was left undone to make the reception, however short it might be, a most enthusiastic one. Large delegations arrived from Zanesville, Akron, and other cities, and assisted the local committees. Two cars loaded with members of the Pittsburg Citizens' Reception Committee came in shortly after noon.

LONDON, Aug. 10. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Madrid saying that the Duke of Tetuan, Minister of Foreign Affairs, recently prepared, with the idea of presenting it to the powers, a memorandum on the condition of affairs in Cuba, and the relations between Spain and the American republics, especially the United States, in connection with Cuba.

St. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 10. -- There is no statement to the frightful heat from which this city and surrounding territory have suffered during the past ten days. According to the Government reports, St. Louis yesterday was the hottest city in the United States, the official temperature being recorded as 99 degrees.

It is easy to detect in the current news from Spain an increasing suspicion that the war in Cuba has gone on about as long as Spain can carry it. Very likely the Spanish riots have been intelligently fomented by Cuban emissaries, but, as we have said before, it would be quite out of the question for Cuban emissaries to create Spanish discontent.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 11. -- The temperature at 3 o'clock this afternoon was 94.2. There were two more deaths from heat reported to-day.

The Legislature created a commission to frame a charter for the Greater New-York and appointed a committee, or a sub-committee of two committees, to keep an eye on the work. Nothing has been heard lately of the Lexow sub-committee, and it may prove not to be overmeddlesome.

The Democratic National Committee met yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel and took action which is construed as taking the management of the campaign pretty effectively out of the hands of Chairman James K. Jones.

What was to have been the feature of the day's racing at the Brighton Beach track yesterday, the match race between the Messrs. Keene's filly Rhodesia and M.F. Dwyer's filly Cleophus, turned out to be a very commonplace sort of a race. Cleophus was made a hot favorite for the event, it being generally believed that, walle Rhodesia was very fast for five furlongs, she would find the extra furlong too much for her.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Baron Fava, the Italian Ambassador, who is at Bar Harbor, has telegraphed the State Department in accordance with the cabled instructions from his Government, asking for official information regarding the lynching of three alleged Italian subjects in Louisiana, reported in the newspapers yesterday.

SARATOGA, Aug. 11. -- Indications point to fair weather for the opening to-morrow of the twenty-fourth annual regatta of the National Amateur Oarsmen on Saratoga Lake. All of the crews and scullers, with the exception of the New-York Athletic Club's eight and the Staten Island Club, have arrived. The hot weather apparently affects the oarsmen but little and practice spins are the order of the day every afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11. -- The thirty-footers raced to-day for the cup offered by Fleet Captain Chester Griswold. Bayard Thayer's Asahi won the prize, and then the cruise of the New-York Yacht Club came to an end, and the squadron disbanded.

Sentiment improved greatly to-day, principally because the market has rallied sharply from the low prices of last week, and shows its ability to maintain the recovery. In fact, the present is the first rally of any consequence in many weeks, and that it has held after the bears have covered a large portion of their short contracts is evidence that substantial interests are once more purchasers or stocks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The Weather Bureau bulletin for the week ended yesterday says:
ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 11. -- The launching of the new Pennsylvania ferryboat Camden was made successfully in the yards of the Nixon Company, in this city, to-day.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11. -- Attorney General Ketcham has made public a letter from Col. Frederick D. Grant of New-York, in reply to a request for information, in which he says:

LONDON, Aug. 11. -- This was a sort of American day at the English race courses. At the Birmingham meeting Pierre Lorillard's gelding Draco, by The Sailor Prince-Draco, won the Doddington Stakes of 150 sovereigns, for two-year-olds, at five furlongs, Mr. Lorillard's colt Sandia, by The Sailor Prince-Saluda, ran second to Sir J. Thursby's colt The Tartar, by Chitabob, for the Saltley Plate.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11. -- Hundreds of horses have succumbed to the intensity of the sun's rays, and many carcasses permitted to lie for hours on street corners as a result of the lack of ambulance facilities.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 11. -- Smith pitched for the Athletics to-day, and he fared worse than Ames did yesterday. Carell hit safely five times, and Thornton and Bottenus each four times. The score:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11. -- Mr. Bryan made no speeches on his trip through Pennsylvania to-day. The only recognition he gave to his admirers at the railway stations was a bow and a shake of the hand to those nearest him.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 11. -- Fine weather and an attractive card drew 2,000 people to the Grand Circuit races at the Fort Wayne Driving Park this afternoon. The track was in good condition, but nothing sensational ensued, the races all going to favorites in straight heats.

A multitude of sound-money Democrats all over the country must have been delighted at the outcome of the Indianapolis conference. It may be hailed as the dawn of the rising and regenerated National Democracy. Not since the war has such a spontaneous and patriotic conference of any political party been held.

Novelties will be a striking feature of the Atalanta Wheelmen's meet at Waverly Park, Newark, on Aug. 22. A race between triplet teams for one mile will be one of the interesting events. The Harlem Wheelmen and Vim Bicycle Club will vie with each other for three-cornered honors. Another club may also be represented. The Kings County Wheelmen's quad will be present for exhibition purposes.
The Board of Aldermen met in the City Hall yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11. -- Sergt. Lorenso Gualiaro, a Cuban, who, for seventeen months, has seen active service in the revolutionary army, arrived to-day in Philadelphia.

Our neighbor The World asserts that "there is a more important, if for the moment less prominent, question than that of silver. This deeper, wider, and more enduring question grows out of the domination in politics, government, and business of the trusts and monopolies."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- Senator Gray of Delaware has been annoyed by recent misrepresentation of his attitude toward the Chicago platform and ticket, and has been constrained to make a statement to a correspondent of a Washington newspaper, which is interesting to those of his friends who have been mystified by utterances attributed to him, and that appear to have been entirely unauthorized.

The Democratic Party Reform Organization will hold a sound-money convention in Saratoga about Aug. 27, and nominate a State ticket. This has been determined upon within the past few days. The ballots of the party will have a ship for an emblem.
The days of death continue. The sun is still unwearied of scourging.
The naked doctrine of repudiation has been avowed and accepted by Mr. BRYAN. In his second speech at Pittsburg on Monday evening he said:

After doing business for twenty-six years under a State charter, the Murray Hill Bank, at Third Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, closed its doors yesterday. In its prosperity it had added $400,000 surplus to its capital of $100,000. It made money by taking long chances with retail merchants. A change to a conservative policy last year diverted that patronage.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 11. -- The intense heat was the only hindrance to fine tennis in the second day's play of the Eastern championship doubles. Many veterans witnessed the match, in addition to the usual Pier throng. The first match of the morning was that between the ex-champion team, Hovey and Hobart, and Slocum and E. Colby. Slocum showed all his old-time prowess, but his game is that of the past.

" I would not have minded John's action on the floor the other day," said a broker to a party of friends yesterday, "if he had not used such a tone of suspicion when he demanded more margin on certain stocks that I had with him in a loan."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- The body of A.H. Pile of San Francisco, Secretary of the National Committee of the Silver Party, who has been missing since last Tuesday, was found floating in the Potomac River yesterday morning. His movements since Tuesday last are unknown, but when last seen he had a large sum of money.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11. -- A morning paper says: "For several years past secret, persistent, and apparently successful efforts have been made throughout the country to unite the friends of silver under one banner to battle for the white metal and to wage war against gold monopoly.

Before the campaign shall be much older the prevailing opinion among intelligent men will be that Bryan is doing excellent work for the cause of sound money and good government. The man will talk himself to certain defeat. He has not said a sensible thing since he left Lincoln. The burden of all his speeches has been talk about English domination in our financial affairs. BALTIMORE, Aug. 11. -- Judge Nathan Goff, in the United States Circuit Court to-day, heard argument upon the petition filed by the Pittsburg and Connellsville Railroad Company, asking that Receivers Cowen and Murray of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad be not authorized to issue $650,000 additional receivers' certificates, the proceeds to be applied to betterments on the leased lines.

ALBANY, Aug. 11. -- William W. Goodrich of Brooklyn has been appointed by Gov. Morton as a Justice of the Supreme Court for the Second Judicial District, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Calvin E. Pratt.

LYONS, N.Y., Aug. 11. -- The inability of Lieut. Gov. Saxton to control the Republican organization of his own county of Wayne has again been demonstrated strikingly. While he will have the support of the Wayne delegates for Governor at Saratoga, its members are men who will do no missionary work for him in other countries, and it is suspected that in their hearts they prefer Aldridge or any other avowed Platt man.

In the interest of a clear understanding of your position, and to allay, if possible, the fear and apprehension which you know to exist, will you answer these questions in your acceptance of the Presidential nomination which you are about to deliver? You must perceive in the preparations for a second Democratic ticket, and in the divisions and distractions among your Populist and Democratic supporters at the South, a growing danger to your cause.

There is one topic, which is upon the whole and has been for a week the most interesting topic before the American people, upon which the Populist candidate for the Presidency has had nothing to say. Perhaps he has been reserving it for his Madison Square speech. Perhaps he has been hoping that it would blow ever and cease to be a living issue before it became necessary for him to discuss it.
An affray that resulted in a homicide occurred early yesterday morning at the Hudson County (N.J.) Almshouse, at Snake Hill, near Jersey City.

The rain that the Weather Bureau promised as a relief from the fatal heat came not yesterday, and the mercury clung to the high figures of the thermometer well into the evening. When the temperature did begin to fall, it grew as weary as the sufferers, the cause of whose woe it recorded in figures, and after descending a few points, stopped charitable work for the night.

The New-Yorks won another game from the Brooklyns yesterday. While they did not make so many hits as the players from over the bridge, they bunched them, and, helped out by errors, ran up the score to 8 runs, while their opponents could only gather 2.

A talk with a small dealer in clothing down near the Battery has convinced me that the silver heresy is not confined to the West, and that good, solid missionary work is needed in the neighborhood of Wall Street itself.

There have just been completed and shown at the studio of the painter, in the Carnegie Building, in this city, five panels destined for the Congressional Library at Washington, where they will be placed shortly, making a notable addition to those already in position, all being part of the admirable and wise selection by the architect of that noteworthy building.

Since the opening of the campaign there has been no more melancholy exhibition than the appearance of Mr. GEORGE FRED WILLIAMS upon the stump in the New-England States, where he is telling the farmers that the prices of their products have fallen on account of the appreciation of gold.
What a pity it is that three or four of Mr. SEVALL'S magnificent clipper ships are not in port just now!

KINGSLAND, N.J., Aug. 11. -- William Jamba, a Polander employed by the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad as a track walker, shot and seriously wounded Otto Gimberka, a flagman on the same road, here this evening about 5:30 o'clock. Jamba then shot and killed himself.

It is intimated in dispatches from London that LI HUNG CHANG would avail himself of an invitation to be the guest of the United States during his brief sojourn therein -- he sails from Vancouver in a month. But it is also declared that he feels much aggrieved on account of the treatment his countrymen have received in this country.

-- It is rarely that the scenery and stage settings for a big spectacular production like "Under the Polar Star," which is to be presented at the Academy of Music on Aug. 20, is completed more than a fortnight before the opening night. Manager Brady has accomplished it, however, and stage rehearsals as well as company rehearsals are going on daily.
TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Aug. 11. -- Ex-Secretary of the Navy Col. R.W. Thompson was prostrated by heat this afternoon.

Mr. J. Woodbury Newcomb, an elderly student of criminology, returning to New-York from a visit to Sing Sing, meets on the train Frank Gleason, Bill Harris, and Jack Pinney, convicts, who have just completed their terms of imprisonment, and who mistake Newcomb for a fellow-convict. To draw them out, he assumes the character, and proceeds to tell them the story of his first crime.

NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 11. -- Not more than forty delegates were in attendance at the ninth annual convention of the New-York State Hotel Men's Association, which opened at 11 o'clock this morning in the International Hotel. The session was called to order by the President, E.M. Tierney of Binghamton, who, after the call, delivered his annual address.

C.B. Bell, who was appointed by Justice Stover of the Supreme Court as referee, heard evidence yesterday in the suit of Mrs. Carlos De Quisada to recover possession of her daughter, fifteen months old.
The bodies of Dr. Eduard Gutmann and Maurice Lowy will be incinerated at the crematory at Fresh Pond, L.I., to-day.

At least three persons perished and twelve were injured through a fire which started yesterday afternoon in the Welch Building, near the fifth-story window Gray Nelsaher. tween Watts and Desbrosses Streets.

The wooden steamer Lizzie Henderson, while lying at her pier at the foot of West Forty-sixth Street, was discovered to be on fire at about 3:30 yesterday morning. Her crew got her steam pump at work, but as her cargo consisted in part of hay and other highly inflammable material, the flames spread with great rapidity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11. -- All the silver men in this city set up a prodigious shout a day or two ago when it was announced that Secretary of the Interior Hoke Smith had decided to support the Bryan ticket, and perhaps would resign his Cabinet office.
William Jennings Bryan, Populist-Democratic candidate for the Presidency, arrived in New-York at 8:30 o'clock last night.
When Charles Miller, the lightkeeper on Liberty Island, got up yesterday morning he saw a large white steer grazing contentedly on the drill grounds on the west side of the island.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12. -- Chairman Midgley of the Western Freight Association, referring to the recent investigation by the Inter-State Commerce Commission, said yesterday that it would be beneficial in readjusting rates on grain from Mississippi and Missouri River points to Chicago, but the original agreement would never be revived.

LONDON, Aug. 12. -- The Irish Land bill was presented in the House of Commons to-day for concurrence in the amendments to the measure made in the House of Lords, a number of which amendments were adopted by the Lords, despite the opposition of the Government.
NEWPORT, Aug. 12. -- The fag end of a cool wave reached Newport to-night and brought great relief to cottagers and hotel guests, who have been sweltering since Saturday.
BELVIDERE, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Charles Cinderbox of Newton, Sussex County, is visiting friends in Phillipsburg. He is 103 years of age and is remarkably bright and active.

The parties interested in the rate controversy in the South between the Seaboard Air Line and the lines in the Southern States Freight Association are looking forward with much interest to the injunction hearing which occurs before Judge Simonton in the United States Court on Saturday. Either the temporary injunction will

Who are the real friends of the laboring man and the poor? What course should a voter take who desires that this Presidential campaign shall result in good to the "common people"? These are important questions. They appeal to a vast number of persons who will participate in the election next November. As these questions shall be answered in the minds that consider them, so will the election turn out.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 12. -- An incendiary fire destroyed the dwelling house and buildings on Spring Hill Farm, in Somerset, this morning and caused a loss of $15,000. The place is 120 acres in extent, and is one of the finest garden truck farms in this section. It is owned by William Perry Hood, the President of the Somerset Foundry. Ten cows, 75 tons of hay, 5 horses, and about 175 chickens were burned.

BOSTON, Aug. 12. -- The Bostons and New-Yorks split even to-day in two exciting games. The visitors succeeded in taking a game from the Bostons for the only time this season. Boston tied in the eighth inning of the first game by fine hitting, but New-York pulled out in the last on Van Haltren's base on balls and Beckley's home run.

It was a very unlucky inspiration for Mr. W.J. BRYAN, the stroke of conceit which led him to choose the City of New-York, "in the enemy's country," as the scene of the notification to him of his nomination as the candidate of repudiation. This was a huge piece of self-conceit on his part. He had undoubtedly "stampeded" the convention to his nomination.
" That old Doc Oldstick simply beats the band," laughed Bridgely to the friends gathered about him on the ferryboat. "The man is reacting quick humilation that picks Doc up for a fool.
Cool breezes last evening ended the hottest Aug. 12 ever known in these latitudes, and, while the death rate was unusually high, relief seems now to be at hand.

There is a house not far from New-York which is run on co-operative principles by the daughters of the family. There are a number of these daughters, all "comely and well favored." The co-operative idea emanates from the masculine head of the house, who has ideas upon matters and things, housework among others.
Kelly Booth, the asphalt contractors, have begun suit against the Public Works Department to compel the Commissioner to open and receive their bid for laying asphalt in Fifth Avenue.

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 12. -- The new Roman Catholic Seminary in the Fifth Ward of this city, not far from the Dunwoodle station on the New-York and Putnam Railroad, was dedicated this morning, the feast of St. Clare the Virgin, with imposing ceremonies.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 12. -- Heavy batting by the home team gave them the third successive victory over Newark to-day. Lloyd pitched for Newark and was touched up for seventeen safe hits in eight innings, when the game was called on account of darkness. Gray, the Paterson pitcher, was also hit hard, and in the eighth inning Cogan relieved him.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 12. -- Prof. Hubert A. Newton of Yale University died at 9:23 o'clock to-night. He had suffered for years with a chronic stomach trouble that caused his death.

Payne's pitching was too much for the Baltimore baseball nine yesterday at Eastern Park, and the Brooklyns shut out the champions. Two hits were all the visitors could make, and both were credited to Jennings. One turned out to be a three-bugger, owing to a bound from the bleachery fence that escaped McCarthy.
This city was the storm centre yesterday of the free-silver movement.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12. -- Bayard Thayer's Asahi won the Duryea Cup for 30-footers to-day. The Boston boat was cleverly handled by "Nat" Watson, and it was her sixteenth victory since she was launched. The English-built Rosemary was not in the race, and it is evident that her owner, Gerald Paget, is disgusted with her showing.
There did not appear to be any change in the degree of heat in Brooklyn yesterday, and people were stricken by the score.

Martin Broderick, a brick mason, who said he came to this city from Chicago on the train with William J. Bryan, yesterday attempted suicide at the home of his brother, James F. Broderick, 103 West Ninety-eighth Street, by shooting himself in the left breast. He was removed to Manhattan Hospital, where his condition was considered critical last night.

The State Department at Washington has forwarded a letter from the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions addressed to her Majesty's Ambassador in Constantinople, in which the board expresses its sincere gratitude to his Excellency for the efforts put forth at many times and in different ways on behalf of the American missionaries resident in Turkey.

The current number of Harper's Weekly has an effective and perfectly fair pictorial exhibition of the Bryan campaign. It gives on one page twelve portraits of "BRYAN and some of his supporters," and on the next twelve portraits of patriotic Democrats who refuse to support him.
The Frank L. Fisher Company have sold for James B. Gillie to a Mr. Alexander the three-story brownstone dwelling 309 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, 17 by 55 by 160.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Postmaster General Wilson has prepared a statement showing the receipts of the thirty largest Post Offices in the United States for the month of July, 1896, as compared with the same month of 1895. The July, 1896, receipts amounted to $2,474,193; for July, 1895, $2,403,401 -- a net increase, of $70,791 New-York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Boston, St. Louis, and Cincinnati lead in receipts.

BOSTON, Aug. 12. -- The Marblehead-Corinthians opened the races of their midsummer series to-day with contests in the twenty-five-foot, twenty-one-foot, twenty-one-foot-cat, and the knockabout classes. The wind was light, from the eastward, and a short courge of about six miles was given all classes to Half-Way Rock and return.

A correspondent writes: "Yesterday a number of Americans who form a band of missionaries which has been sent to this country in order to propagate a knowledge of Theosophy held a private reception to a number of people interested in the movement in London, at the Norfolk Mansions Hotel in Wigmore Street.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 12. -- County Clerk Wrightson of Essex County to-day received a letter from Frederick W.E. Stroetzel, who asked that a copy of his naturalization papers be sent him, as he had lost his original papers.
The National Committee in charge of the Bryan and Sewall campaign met at noon yesterday. It found itself in the midst of troubles.

An appendix to the latest report of the British Consul at Amoy refers to the effect on the tea trade of that port of the Japanese annexation of Formosa. The tea known in the trade as Oolongs is exported from Amoy, and was at one time grown in the district of which it is the outlet, and more recently in Formosa.

Mr. BRYAN is beaten. This prediction may be as well recorded now as at some later day. The candidate himself furnishes the complete assurance of its fulfillment. He has come to the first great test of the campaign and he has wretchedly failed to meet it. His managers had elaborately planned for him a vast spectacular demonstration "in the enemy's country," as he pleasantly put it.

William Jennings Bryan, the candidate of the silver Democrats and the Populists for President, and Arthur Sewall, the candidate of the silver Democrats for Vice President, were formally notified of their nomination at the Madison Square Garden last night. They accepted in formal speeches.
It was stated yesterday that 242 contractors had signed the agreement of the Brotherhood of Tailors up to Tuesday evening. These contractors employ about 2,800 men and 500 women.

Some of our writers have treated the present free-coinage movement as a new experiment, as one never before tried. These writers present most effectively the dangerous character of such a movement, but it may be well to point out in further support of their arguments the fact that there have been many similar experiments tried, and that the results which followed have always been disastrous.

John W. Arctander, who for two months has been sojourning in Europe, returned Tuesday, accompanied by his wife, who has been spending the last year in Paris. Most of Mr. Arctander's time was spent in Christiania, where he mingled with the artists and literary lights of Norway. One of his most interesting experiences was a visit to Bjornstjern Bjornson.

SARATOGA, Aug. 12. -- The opening day of the twenty-fourth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen drew a good attendance to Saratoga Lake, where seven events on the programme were rowed under fairly good weather conditions. The races were not started until 3:18 P.M., but the sun glaring down from a cloudless sky made it intensely hot on the water.

NOGALES, Arizona, Aug. 12. -- The Sonora portion of Nogales was attacked at 3:30 A.M. to-day by a party of sixty Yaqui Indians, religious fanatics. A battle followed, lasting four hours, during which seven Indians were killed, one wounded, and one taken prisoner. Four Mexicans were killed.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 12. -- About 100 of the surviving members of the Twenty-third Ohio Infantry. McKinley's old regiment, marched up to the house of the Republican candidate for the Presidency to-day to assure him of their good-will and support. The veterans stood on the lawn under the trees with uncovered heads, while Major McKinley spoke to them from the veranda. In the course of his address Mr. McKinley said:

L.C. Krauthoff, member for Missouri of the National Democratic Committee, organized by the sound-money Democrats, at Chicago, arrived in this city Tuesday. Mr. Krauthoff, who is a lawyer of Kansas City, when seen at an up-town hotel said that he was here only on private business.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12. -- Representative J.W. Babcock, Chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, returned this morning from his home in Wisconsin, where he has been recuperating for three weeks. He comes back in the best of spirits, and brings advices that utterly repudiate the statements of his friends in the Democratic Committee.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12. -- The following bulletin has been issued by Chairman Gideon of the League of American Wheelmen.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 12. -- The "16-to-1" game that the League of American Wheelmen are getting here is not likely to make them all rabid Bryanites. The Eastern visitors came here with greenbacks, but every time they have bills changed they get nothing but silver in return. Apparently there is little except silver in the ordinary channels of trade in this section. "Cartwheels" predominate.

The main-incident of Li Hung Chang's career since he co-operated with Gordon, over thirty years ago, in the suppression of the Taeping rebellion are probably familiar by this time to the majority of readers, and no one has ever impugned the sincerity of his desire to improve the administration of his State, to introduce industrial reforms, and to maintain peace.

NOGALES, Arizona, Aug. 13. -- Capt. P. Sanchez of the Mexican police and a company of men pursued the Yaqui Indians after they were run out of town yesterday. The party was accompanied by Juan Fernandez, cashier of the Mexican Custom House. They overtook the Indians five miles east of Nogales, near the lake.

The mystery that surrounded the disappearance of Roundsman Michael E. Keating of the King's Bridge Police Station on Wednesday, when two ex-policemen who had been discharged from the force on his evidence for neglect of duty, took his horse to the station house, was partly solved yesterday morning by the finding of his dead body in the woods off Riverdale Avenue.

Even Chaucer, to go back to remoter time, did not dare to make his "Lady Prioresse" seem to learned; her French was only.

It in astonishing to observe the sameness which editors display in the composition of the forms of rejection which accompany the return of one's manuscript. It is perhaps, rather difficult to display any stacking originality in expressing in a few words, and with a decent of courtesy, that your manuscript is unsuitable, that they don't want it, and are accordingly returning it.

One effect of the "tailors'" strike in this city has a very promising look. It is the forming of "co-operative shops," of which about seventy-five have already been set up. It shows that the workmen of this class are gaining the capacity to manage their own labor, instead of farming it out to contractors, which is about as bad a system as there could be.

Brighton Beach's race meeting is rapidly approaching its close, a fact that will be regretted by many thousands who have thoroughly enjoyed the sport that has been had at the track that has been heretofore but one remove from the outcast tracks. W.A. Engeman, with energy and pluck, has pushed the track up into the rank of first-class racing resorts.

A plan to save the Murray Hill Bank was perfected yesterday, and the arrangements were completed to enable the bank to be reopened on a sound basis within a few days, provided no new discoveries of worthless assets are made and the State Superintendent of Banks offers no objection to the plan of reorganization.

In admiring you for the honesty of your course, one seems, at the same time, to see in such conscientiousness a promise that should you, early or late, become convinced of the error of your views, you will retrace your steps with equal straightforwardness.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- According to one report received here, Dr. Nansen's object in leaving the Fram was to push further north than the steamer was able to penetrate the ice. This was in March, 1895. The reports at hand at present are somewhat conflicting.

BOSTON, Aug. 13. -- Capt. Lauretto Prado, a prominent officer of the Cuban Army, was a passenger on the British Steamer Etheired, which arrived here to-day from Port Antonio, Jamaica. His visit to this country is entirely in the interest of the Cuban patriots, and he bears important documents for the Cuban Junta in New-York.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- The owners of the third-footers unexpectedly decided to have a race to-day for sweepstakes, at $10 a boat, and Ralph N. Ellis's Hera took first money; H.B. Duryea's Vaquero, second, and Gerald Paget, who sailed Harry Whitney's Dorothy, saved his stake by coming in a good third. Mr. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor watched the race from the Progresso.

Two fires, four hours apart, cleaned out the upper floors of the five-story brick building running from 190 to 198 Chambers Street, last evening. One gave the Fire Department a long and tiresome fight.

William H. Ten Eyck, Clerk of the Common Council, signs in yesterday's issue of The City Record, the official municipal journal, a list of applications for permission to keep stands for the sale of friut, soda water, newspapers, , within the stoop lines.

Rumors about a band of ferocious dogs having their lair in the shrubs of the Battery Park, attacking and biting passers-by, made the police of the First, Second, and Thirty-sixth Precincts and those of the Park Department active Wednesday night.

The meeting at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday evening was an illustration of she necessity of adopting some systematic method of handling large crowds. The precautions taken by the police were effective so far as concerned their principal object. That is to say, there was no crush at any point which involved or seriously threatened any loss of life.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- It was announced late this afternoon that the Lake Michigan Ferry Company, operating in connection with the "Soo" line, had cut rates 2 cents on first-class and 1 1/2 cents on lower classes of freight. The "Soo" is not a member of the Western Freight Association, and is at present outside the Trans-Continental Association.

Mr. and Mrs. W.J. Bryan will long remember Aug. 13, 1896, as the day of attempted receptions. As if fate had not done its worst in the complete collapse of the stupendous meeting W P. St. John had prepared for Wednesday night, the receptions planned for yesterday only added to the disasters that have followed the invasion of "the enemy's country."

The Brooklyn and Baltimore teams played two games at Eastern Park yesterday, and each team won one. In the first game Daub pitched for the home team, and the visitors could only score two runs, and the Brooklyns won.

The great weakness of the country is in the medium or average intelligence of the West, and this spreads well toward the Alleghenies. A vast body of this thinks that silver be favored as a home products, that if it had the same standing before the law as gold it would win on its merits.

SARATOGA, Aug. 13. -- The second and concluding day of the National regatta of amateur oarsmen furnished some excellent races, which were witnessed by a good-sized crowd from the bluff overlooking the course. The day was an ideal one for aquatics. The torrid rays of the sun were veiled by fleecy clouds, and a gentle breeze from the northeast cooled the atmosphere without being sufficiently strong to interfere with the oarsmen.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 13. -- Members of the Executive Committee of the National Democratic Party are much pleased by the receipt of a dispatch from Senator Caffrey of Louisiana authorizing his signature to the call for the National Convention. They feel that in him they have enlisted one of the strongest men of the South.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- It was so hot to-day that the lecture Prof. Wisner was to deliver at Mrs. Herman Delrichs's was postponed until Saturday. The Professor was to talk about "The Women of the Eighteenth Century and the Women of To-day," the lecture being one of a course in French which is being delivered at the residences of prominent Newporters.

At section, in this Trinity Building Sales-room, yesterday, Mr. D. Phoenix Ingraham Gold, under foreciosure, to the plaintiff, Polka M. Wilkins at $5,000 the four-story brownstone dwelling, 150 East One Hundred and Second Street, south side, 325 feet west of Third Avenue, 15 by 100.11.
Gov. Stone says: "Against English ideas we place American ideas." Yet it is curious that the Chicago platform has two English planks in it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13. -- The Treasury Department has received no information about the allegiant refusal of the Assistant Treasurer at San Francisco to exchange gold for silver Certificates. The is a practice that be has followed for years, and is peculiar alone to the San Francisco Sub-Treasury.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 13. -- Argument was begun before Judge Wales, in the United States Court this morning, on the application of the single-tax prisoners for release from the Dover jail. James J. Haggerty and Arthur H. Stephenson, the petitioners, were in court.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- The third day's racing under the auspices of the Royal Victoria Yacht Club took place at Ryde to-day. The race for large raters was over the long course, from Ryde around a markboat off Cowes, thence to a markboat at Spithead, on to the Nab and back to Ryde; twice around, fifty mile. The contest was for a cup valued at 100, given by C.D. Rose.
RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 13. -- Senator Butler called the Populist State Convention to order at noon to-day. All the counties in the State were represented, and there was only one contest.

In the course of her education the new woman will be instructed in the practical art of tipping the waiter. It is a practice in which, with the tendency of the feminine mind to economy in small things, she has been an acknowledged delinquent. In a down-town city restaurant patronized almost entirely by business men was a very little maiden.

Novelists as a class, already take themselves too seriously. Atlas holding up the word is only a figure symbolic of the novelist's conception of his own place in the scheme of the universe of to-day. To the novelist the novel is identical with modern thought; that is, it is the only adequate vehicle of expression for all the moods, brood-tugs, hopes, aspirations, grapings, philosophies, and what not of modern life.

The Royal Society was incorporated by royal charter in 1662. Five years later the society elected as one of its Fellows, John Ray, the naturalist, whose works were considered by Cuvier as the foundation of modern zoology. It was this John Ray who produced the work entitled "The Wisdom of God Manifested in the Works of Creation."

CLEVELAND, Aug. 13. -- A passenger train on the Lake Shore Railway was wrecked near Otis, Ind., at 4 o'clock this morning by the washing away of a culvert. The engineer and fireman were killed, but the passengers escaped fatal injuries.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Aug. 13. -- Beyond reasonable doubt the Brunswick tug Dauntless is en route to Cuban waters with a filibustering expedition consisting of about 100 men and several hundred cases of small arms.

CHICAGO Aug. 12. -- Eastern leads are conference with the alternative of losing the grain traffic from the West, which heretofore went to New-York and other Eastern supports, or joining the Western roads in making such through rates as will prevent the diversion of the business via New-Orleans, Galveston, and other Southern parts.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 13. -- The Manhanset House, on Shelter Island, opposite this village, was partly destroyed by fire today. The fire department from this village, aided by the streams of water thrown on the flames from the steam yachts and other steam craft in the bay, preserved the newer portion of the hotel and also the annex.

VARDO, Norway, Aug. 13. -- Dr. Fridthof Nansen has arrived here, returning from his attempt to reach the north pole by drifting to it in a steamer. He is accompanied by Lieut. Hansen. They left the steamer Fram, in which Dr. Nansen expected to be carried by the drifting ice to and across the pole, last Autumn.

LONDON, Aug. 13. -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir Matthew White Ridley, Home Secretary, stated in reply to an inquiry by Mr. J. Lawrence Carew, Parnellite member for the College Green Division of Dublin, that, as the result of a medical examination of the prisoners, the Home Office had ordered the release of the dynamiters Daly, Gallagher, Whitehead, and Devany, now-serving life sentences in English prisons.

Representative Charles H. Grosvenor of Ohio, who was second in command in the McKinley campaign before the St. Louis Convention, was at National Republican Headquarters yesterday. He arrived Wednesday night from Europe on the steamship Trave.

BOSTON, Aug. 13. -- The controversy between Bishop Newman of the Methodist Church and George P. Washburn, the Populist National Committeeman, is still in progress. The Bishop in a sermon at Asbury look recently referred to the proceeding of the Populist Convention as anarchistic. Mr. Washburn, who is a member of the Methodist Church, took the Bishop to ask to an open left.

GENEVA, Aug. 13. -- An important meeting of the Central International Committee of the Young Men's Christian Associations of the world closed its sessions in Geneva tonight. It met Monday, Aug. 10, at the country home of M. Ernest Favre, a few miles from the city, and continued in session morning, afternoon, and evening until to-night, the 13th.

Theroigne de Mericourt was a woman singular among the women of the Revolution. Readers of Carlyle will remember his almost gallant salutations of her (a handsome young woman of the streets, who took a passion for the popular cause, and rode on a guncarriage in the famous outing to Versailles) as often as she starts upon the scene.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Joseph Finnegan, sixty years old, of Finnegan Brothers, bakers' supplies of 1 373 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, is dying in the City Hospital here from a fractured skull.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13. -- Three United States Senators, Messrs. Shoup of Idaho, Mitchell of Oregon, and Nelson of Minnesota, spent part of the day at Republican National headquarters and conferred with Chairman Hanna on organization, plans and needs of the party in their respective States. Senator Shoup admitted that there was a big fight before him in his State, but he told Mr. Hanna to count Idaho in the Republican column.

Relief came yesterday to the suffering millions of the metropolitan district. There was no cool wave and the change was gradual, but yesterday afternoon everybody appreciated that the temperature was lower than it had been at the same hour for several preceding days.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 15. -- The yacht races thus far have demonstrated the superiority of the Canadian boats from Lake Ontario over the Lake Erie fleet. Comparison between the yachts of the two countries shows that the American boats are more comfortably fitted out and better adapted to cruising. It is admitted that speed has been sacrificed for comfort.

The funeral of Edward May was held yesterday at Liederkranz Hall, 115 East Fifty-eighth Street. The hall was draped in black. There were present about 300 persons. Among the mourners were Mr. and Mrs. Julius May and their daughter.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 13. -- A violent thunderstorm visited Pittsburg and points within a radius of thirty miles of the city shortly after 8 o'clock this morning, resulting in the death of five persons and the destruction of much property.

There is at all times a good deal of hoarding, especially in parts of the country where savings banks are scarce. Among the inhabitants of such remote districts a favorite method of concealing cash is to put it in a tin box and bury it, either in the cellar or in the ground near the house. Another plan commonly adopted is to put money in the garret under the eaves.

Mr. J. Woodbury Newcomb, an elderly student of Sociology, returned to New-York form a visual Sing Sing Eastern, meets on the train tribe Gleason, P. Harris, and Jack Pinacy, service, who have just completed their terms of imprisonment, and who mistake Newcomb for a fellow convict. To draw them out he assumes the character and proceeds to tell them the story of his first crime.

CANTON, Ohio. Aug. 13. -- Two hundred of the members of the One Hundred and Fourth Ohio Regiment called on Major McKinley shortly before noon to-day. The regiment has been holding a reunion at Massillon.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 18. -- The ex-champions, Hovey and Hobart, won the Eastern tennis championship in doubles this morning. The weather was a trifle cooler, and there was more snap and life to the play. The usual throng of spectators surrounded the courts. Hovey and Hobart showed a strong style of play.
