GREENFIELD, Mass., Aug. 13. -- The annual dinner in aid of Sanderson Academy, Ashfield, to-day served to bring hundreds of persons from the western portion of the State to listen to the eloquence which always follows these dinners. The hall looked attractive, and in the audience were many notables.

The crop reports recently published by the Government and by unofficial authorities of high reputation suggest some remarks about that old law of supply and demand which certain Populists intend to repeal "without the consent or aid of any other nation on earth."

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 13. -- What the authorities of this place believe is a deliberate case of murder and an attempt to keep the body of the victim hidden was discovered this morning by Health Inspector Edwin G. Ross of this village.

A sentiment stalked into Wall Street yesterday morning with the confident mien of a victor and shouted to the timid and depressed souls therein assembled: "There is no danger! Bryan and his cause are harmless!"
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13. -- Yachts sailing today were steamer Lydia, schooner Edith, and sloop Wayward, Mr. Ellsworth.

Plans for the sound-money mass meeting at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday evening are moving rapidly toward completion. W. Bourke Cockran will devote his address to a demonstration of the effects of free silver on the interests of wage earners, and the Democratic Honest Money League, which will organize the meeting, intends that wage earners shall have every possible opportunity to hear him speak.

B.F. Myers Co., wholesale dealers in jewelry and diamonds at 48 and 50 Maiden Lane, failed yesterday, with liabilities of $517,000 and nominal assets of $819,000, and their embarrassment led to an assignment by Henry A. Casperfeld, dealer in jewelry and diamonds at 144 Bowery and $59 Broadway and at Saratoga Springs.

There are about ten women doctors practicing in different parts of Germany. German women may also now attend lectures in most of the German universities, but only as "hospitirende" or "guest students," without being allowed to matriculate, and generally on sufferance of the professors.

Perhaps no one was more surprised than the agent of the White Star Line when the steamship Britannic arrived in port yesterday, the first times she has arrived on Thursday since she was launched, twenty-two years ago .She was classed as a greyhound in early life, twice breaking the record, but leaving Liverpool then as now, on Wednesday, and Queens own on Thursday, she never docked till Friday of the following week in New-York.

GENEVA, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- Geneva is this year the storm centre of Ontario County politics. There are more defections from Bryan here that in any other town in the county, and the Republican Party is more affected by factional disturbances here than in any other locality.
STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 13. -- This has been a day to make glad the heart of the visitor, for there has been scarcely an hour in which there was not soma drill to see that was interesting.
LONDON, Aug. 13. -- Sir John E. Millais died to-day, after a long illness, of cancer of the throat.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 13. -- The grand circuit races were resumed at the driving park this afternoon, with a long and good programme to present and 8,000 people in attendance. A heavy rain in the forenoon threatened another postponement, but a harsh sun put the track in condition for racing by 2 o'clock, which improved with every heat, and was fast in an hour or two.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 13. -- John M. Carman of Luzerne County was elected Chairman of the Democratic State Committee this afternoon, to succeed Robert E. Wright of Allentown, whose resignation was accepted with a vote of thanks for his efficient services in the past and regret that he could not see his way clear to go along with the Chicago ticket and platform.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 13. -- Mrs. Isaac Hendricks horsewhipped Augustus Rolfe at the corner of Abeel and Oliver Streets at noon to-day. Her husband stood by,. and so did two brothers of the man. A crowd gathered and watched the performance. Some persons urged the woman on, while others called on her to stop, but no one interfered.

The Bryans, Mr. and Mrs., left their home in Lincoln with every expectation of stampeding the country into supporting the fifty-three-cent candidate for the Presidency. As I look at it, the country hasn't stampeded worth a cent. Furthermore, it seems to me that these last five days practically have settled the Presidential night and settle it in favor of sound money.

Our news columns yesterday contained the announcement that an important firm of silkmakers in New-Jersey had seen the value of the Mexican dollar as an object lesson and had made use of it. It is a rather costly object lesson to the instructor, as the bullion value of a Mexican dollar is a cent and a fraction more than the bullion value of the dollar which the Populists propose to remonetize.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 14. -- It is understood that Wilfred Laurier has decided to settle the Manitoba school question by the appointment of a special commission to hear arguments in the matter. Representative of the Dominion and Manitoba Governments will be named, and these two will choose a third Commissioner from the bench.
The employes of the Adams Express Company in this city and in Jersey City went our on strike at 1 o'clock this morning.

Only one minute and half an hour now stand between the ocean record and a six days' voyage from Southampton. Only a bank of fog stood between the American Line steamship St. Paul and the glory of a six-day record on the trip completed yesterday.

STATE CAMP, PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The last day of the camp season of 1896 is over, and to-morrow morning at 6:45 o'clock the National salute of twenty-one guns will be fired and the camp will be officially closed, all detailed officers being relieved at that hour. It is expected that the batteries will be out of camp by 7:30 o'clock.
We have received from a correspondent in South Glens Falls a letter in which he asks some questions which we shall try to answer as clearly as we can.

AUBUEN, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- The Republican Convention of the First District of Cayuga County to-day renominated W.C. Sheldon for the Assembly, and in the Second District the Republicans renominated E.B. Rounds for the Assembly. Both gentlemen were named without any opposition.

Ex-Senator Warner Miller some time ago made a remark that he would be at the Republican State Convention to attend to certain matters outside of the routine. It was then thought that Mr. Miller might be a candidate for Governor, and that he might be referring to this.
Three men were locked up in the East Sixty-seventh Street Police Station last night on a charge of cruelty to animals, and the allegation against one of the men reveals an unusual form of brutality.

The heads of the city departments met in the Mayor's office yesterday to hear the report of Presidents Roosevelt of the Police Department and Wilson of the Health Department as to the distribution of free ice Thursday evening. President Wilson reported that ninety-seven tons of ice had been purchased, costing approximately $325, and President Roosevelt said that it had been distributed in a satisfactory manner.

The Board of Rapid Transit, through its President, Alexander E. Orr, has replied to the application of the Manhattan Railway Company for an extension of its routes. The answer was ordered at the last meeting of the Board, and was sent to George J. Gould yesterday. It reads as follows:

" Our opponents have made a special appeal to those who hold fire and life insurance policies, but these policy holders know that, since the total premiums received exceed the total losses paid, a rising standard must be of more benefit to the companies than to the policy holders.

SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 14. -- Those Democrats who have suffered from the perfidy of George Q. Cannon and his Church supporters may now obtain sweet satisfaction by saying "I told you so" to several prominent Republican leaders. The bolt of Senator Frank J. Cannon from the Republican National Convention and his determination to support Bryan simply marks the breaking of another promise.

FRIDAY -- P.M. In striking contrast to the sentiment which prevailed a few days ago is the tone of the general conversation which is heard in brokers' offices since the Bryan meeting in Madison Square Garden. Last week every one seemed alarmed over the possibility of the success of the Chicago ticket, and talked as if they really believed there was solid foundation for their fears.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch from Madrid giving further details regarding the memorandum recently prepared by the Duke of Tetuan, Minister or Foreign Affairs, about the condition of affairs in Cuba and the relations of Spain with the American republics, especially the United States, in connection with Cuba.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Aug. 14. -- John E. Dubignoa, managing owner of the tug Dauntless, says that he is in no wise connected with the filibustering scheme upon which the vessel is said to be engaged, and Coney Parker local agents, state that the Dauntless has gone to Florida waters in tow a barge.

Sister Mary Irene, who for twenty-seven years was at the head of the work of saving the lives of homeless infants in New-York City, is dead. The malady from which she had patiently suffered for forty years, and which ended her life at 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning, was heart disease, but the primary cause of her death was the heat.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14. -- At a Republican mass meeting held in Germantown, suburb. to-night, ex-Postmaster General John Wanamaker made a long speech in favor of the present money standard and against free coinage. In the course of his speech Mr. Wanamaker said:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 14. -- The sound-money Democrats of Maryland are likely to send sixteen delegates to the Indianapolis Convention, notwithstanding the action of the Executive Committee of the Sound-Money League of Maryland in deciding to make no effort in that direction. The opinion is growing that a sound-money Electoral ticket should be nominated in Maryland, and several well-known Democrats were quoted to that effect this afternoon.

The board of naval experts, appointed by the Assistant Secretary of the Navy to inquire into the accidents that happened at the navy yard in Brooklyn Saturday night, when the caisson in the timber dry dock capsized and the torpedo boat Ericsson was badly damaged, convened in Building 7 yesterday afternoon, and two witnesses were examined.

TOKIO, July 31. -- The second insurrection in Formosa is now practically over. It began on the 25th of June in the centre of the southern portion of the island. Finding the Japanese totally unprepared, and, moreover, reinforced by malcontents from the plains, the insurgents achieved considerable success at first, capturing several small towns and driving out the Japanese garrisons.

WEST POINT, Aug. 14. -- Cadets Harry Steele Commager of Ohio and Giles Bishop, Jr., of Connecticut were dismissed from the Military Academy this afternoon in accordance with the finding of a court-martial, approved by President Cleveland.

BUZZARD'S BAY, Mass., Aug. 14 -- Two of the President's Cabinet officers were at Gray Gables this morning. Secretary Carlisle came over from Marion on the steamer Mistletoe in a pouring rainstorm. Mrs. Carlisle and William K. Carlisle and family accompanied him. An early train brought Secretary of War Lamont and Dr. Bryant. Secretary Only, however, was not present.

Franklin M. Edinger, a grocer, at 114 Four-and-a-half Street Southwest, was headed-straight for the realms of matrimonial bliss yesterday afternoon and making record time until he reached the City Hall and applied for a license. There he took a sudden header into an abyss of despair, and eighteen-year-old Lena Jobst was shedding tears last night.

The President of Brown University says that if this country shall retain the gold standard it will be compelled to borrow money every year for the payment of ordinary expenditures. We quote from a letter written by him a few days ago and published yesterday:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The President, in dismissing Cadets Giles Bishop, Jr., and H.S. Commager from the Military Academy at West Point, makes it the opportunity to express in forcible language his contempt for hazing.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Not in years has the Republican Party been engaged in so exciting a local contest as during the past two weeks, anal the County Convention at this village on Monday next is likely to be a record breaker in the amount of factional feeling aroused.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The new five-dollar silver certificates were issued by the Treasury Department to-day. The face of the note is a reproduction of Walter Shirlaw's painting "America." stands upon a globe, her feet touching the man of North America.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The following telegram relating to the movements of the Dauntless was received at the Treasury Department this afternoon from Brunswick, Ga.:

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Congressman Charles Tracey, who attended the recent conference of sound-money Democratic leaders at Indianapolis, said to-day that the convention in this State to select delegates to the Indianapolis sound-money National Democratic Convention probably would be held Aug. 31 at either Syracuse, Rochester, or Niagara Falls.

It is so novel and gratifying for this country to have won a place in the international maritime competition that we are apt to underrate what the fact implies. The truth is that, with a number of warships which in their respective classes are entitled to rank with the best in the world, we have just two modern seagoing merchant steamers of the first class afloat.
W. Bourke Cockran has challenged William J. Bryan to a debate on the issues of the present campaign.

After more than a week of drought and death-dealing heat, rain fell early yesterday morning and again in the afternoon and brought to the suffering millions of the Greater New-York the first relief they have had since the hot wave's arrival.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 14. -- The Third Assembly District Democratic Convention was held in the Common Council Chamber tonight. The Page faction refused to enter the convention and held a separate meeting. The Smith faction elected the following State delegates: Frank Koch, William Ward, Frederick W. Smith; Alternates -- Richard Noonan, Lewis Whalen, Charles Stephany.
Mr. J.R. Jeaffreson of the Jeaffreson-Farnham Arctic Expedition, writing from Cape Thorsten on July 15, says:

Unless something very untoward should happen, there will be no disappointing of expectation in the speech which Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN is to deliver at the great sound-money meeting in Madison Square Garden next Tuesday evening.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The Captain of the Windward has sent a long dispatch from Explorer Jackson to A.C.W. Harmsworth, one of the promoters of the Jackson-Harmsworth expedition. The dispatch says that Mr. Jackson met Dr. Nansen accidentally on June 17 on an ice floe southeast of Cape Flora.

NEWPORT, Aug. 14. -- This noon Secretary Whittlesey, Dr. Dwight, (who is to referee the tournament,) and ex-champion C. Campbell of the National Lawn Tennis Association, met at the Newport Casino and opened the drawings for the National tennis tournament, which opens Tuesday next. The drawings are as follows:

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 14. -- Sociological discussions have been the feature of the week, and the course of lectures delivered by Prof. Francis G. Peabody of Harvard University upon various social problems has been full of interest and practical value. Prof. Peabody delivered the last lecture of the course to-day upon "The Corelation of the Social Questions."

The Futurity Stakes, the richest event of the American turf, will be run at Sheepshead Bay to-day. Eleven two-year-olds are named to start for the much-coveted prize, and there is promise of a good race. It is the opening day of the Coney Island Jockey Club's Fall meeting, and, in addition to the Futurity, five other events will be decided, and in each there will be a good field of starters.

Title to the St. James Hotel property at Broadway and Twenty-sixth Street passed yesterday from the Spofford estate to Pennock Brothers of Philadelphia. The consideration was $1,000,000. The furniture and fittings, which belong to the Spofford estate, will be offered at auction Thursday. The buyers expect to take possession by Sept. 1.

The free silverites are not the first who want a Government to force a debased coin on the people at large. They were preceded in this by the Sultan of Turkey, who had to pay a heavy indemnity in gold to Russia after the war between Turkey and Russia, previous to the Crimean campaign.

The second order for American steel rails for Japanese railroads was placed recently with the Carnegie Company by Kenzo Iwahara, the New-York representative of Mitsul Co. of Japan. It is a special order for 9,000 tons to be delivered by the end of the year, and is for extensions of three railroads, one in Middle Japan, one from Osaka to Maizuru, and one in Klushlu Island, the southernmost of the Japanese archipelago.

Bryan's speech recalls to my mind the story I used to hear about ten times a year while I was a member of a debating society composed of students of Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass. A student named Bass used to tell the story. He was one of the star debaters of the society. Usually he directed the point of the story against a youngster named Babbitt.

Mrs. Fanny Gossett, the venerable mother of ex-Chief Justice Holt, who died at her son's home, at Frankfort, Ky., on Aug. 9, at the advanced age of ninety-three years, was buried at Mount Sterling on Monday. She was in many respects a remarkable woman. Her grandfather was a Lieutenant in the Revolutionary War, and was a prisoned in New-York while the British held that city.

The passengers on the excursion train from Madrid to Aranjuez were a motley, downright Spanish throng, excited enough, as all Spaniards are, at the prospect of an afternoon's bloodshed and terribly afraid the clouds of the morning would thicken and develop rain, which might or might not lead to a prolongation of the life of a dozen or more doomed horses.

Within the last two years British goods have made their way to Montenegro, and a small export trade to Malta and Great Britain has arisen. The area of the principality is about 3,630 square miles, the population about 200,000, the greatest length from north to south about 160 miles, and the greatest breadth about 80 miles.
William J. Bryan will make another speech in this city. This was agreed on by his campaign managers yesterday.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 14. -- There was racing of a sensational character at the second day's sport in the National meet programme at Fountain Ferry track to-day. The city's fashionable element looked on, with distinguished league officials and visiting wheelmen from all sections of the country.

Ex-Congressman William J. Coombs, one of the Government Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad, returned to his home, in Brooklyn, last Thursday night, after a five weeks' trip through the country traversed by that road, particularly west of the Rocky Mountains. Dispatches from Omaba and Chicago have misquoted him regarding the alleged relations of the Vanderbilts with the Union Pacific system.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 14. -- A meeting of prominent Democrats of this city was held this evening in the office of C. H. Ostrander, in Fourth Avenue, and a club called the mount Vernon Sound-Money Democratic Club was organized.

Odd as it may sound to say so, the lobster grows before, not after, he casts his old hard shell -- that is to say, he makes new cells and tissues, which are not at once filled out, but which are intended to plim to their full dimensions as soon as he has got rid of his binding and confining external skeleton.

The tangle in the affairs of the Posocratic managers was not straightened yesterday, and after long consultations Chairman J K. Jones of the National Committee said he could not announce the names of those to form the Executive and Campaign committees.

George Schneider, who was a Sergeant in Company A, Third Maryland Battalion, Veteran Volunteers, in the civil war, was presented with the United States medal for bravery during the battle at Petersburg, Va., July 30, 1861. A letter from Gen. John G. Parks, commanding the Ninth Army Corps, to which the battalion belonged, recommending the awarding of the medal, was recently found in the War Department at Washington.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug. 14. -- Fine weather and an attractive programme drew the largest attendance of the meeting to the circuit races to-day. Five thousand people were present. The temperature was high until 8 o'clock, when a cold wave swept suddenly from the northeast, chilling the crowd and the horses, and having a marked effect on speed.

The fifth quinquennial gathering of the international Homeopathic Congress was opened in London on the 4th inst. The President, Dr. Pope of Grantham, was in the chair, and there was a large attendance of delegates and visitors from all parts of Great Britain and the world.
He had the look of one who has something on his mind.
LONDON, Aug. 14. -- The Queen's speech proroguing Parliament was delivered to the House of Commons at 6:15 o'clock this afternoon. The speech said:

VARDE, Norway, Aug. 14. -- Dr. Nansen, the aretic explorer, says that he expects the Fram will Eventually arrive at Spitzbergen. He says that she drifted with the fee in a westerly direction to 84 degrees. Rocky seas, he says, prevented him from entering the mouth of the Olensk River for the purpose of procuring dogs, and lack of dogs prevented him from reaching the north pole, which he otherwise would have found.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 14. -- It is not at all unlikely that a combination ticket will be put in the field by the Republicans, National Democrats, and Populists in some of the Southern States.

CHATHAM, Aug. 14. -- The sloop yacht Queen Mab, from Vineyard Haven for Bar Harbor, stranded on Chatham Bars to-day. She was boarded by the Chatham life savers and subsequently floated without damage.

In addressing a party of visiting veterans at his Ohio home on Thursday Major McKINLEY said: "Sectionalism has given place to National spirit and patriotism has smoothed the asperities of partyism, while the preservation of the National honor constitutes the great aim and purpose of all patriotic American citizens."

Sr. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Aug. 14. -- May Ellsworth aged twenty, and Alles Varney of Sution, aged sixteen, were struck by a train at 11 o'clock last night in Paddock Village. They were driving, and reached the tract just ahead of a freight train. Their carriege had crossed the track, but the horse suddenly turned and threw the ladies under the moving train.
LONG BRANCH, Aug. 14. -- The Rev. W.L. Freedman of Denver, Col., will conduct the services at the Beth Miram Synagogue tomorrow morning.

Mr. J. Woodbury Newcomb, an elderly student of criminology, returning to New-York from a visit to Sing Sing Prison, meets on the train Frank Glenson, Bill Harris, and Jack Pinney, convicts who have just completed their terms of imprisonment, and who mistake Newcomb for a fellow convict. To draw them out, he assumes the character, and proceeds to tell them the story of his first crime.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14. -- The Times this Afternoon says:

The meeting of the Brighton Reach Racing Association ended yesterday. It has been a very successful one, and but for the weather, the ending would have been in keeping with the other days of the meeting. The storm which was threatening all day, and which finally came during the afternoon kept many away from the track.

LONDON, Aug. 14. -- In the House of Commons to-day Sir William Harcourt, the leader of the Opposition, asked in regard to the Venezuelan situation if the proposal contained in the dispatch sent to the Foreign Office by the United States Government June 12 last had removed the difficulties, and further inquired whether there were any prospects of a speedy submission of the question to arbitration.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 14. -- The second day of the third annual horse show of the Monmouth County Horse Show Association was even a greater success than was the first. The weather, which was so hot yesterday as to render it uncomfortable, was to-day much cooler, and after the scorching days of the last week was decidedly comfortable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Controller of the Treasury has made a decision on the construction of the act of 1885, relating to allowances to be made soldiers for loss of private property, which is of special interest to the army, as the decision reverses a ruling on this act made by the late Controller Mansur.

' LOUISVILLE, Aug. 15. -- The National meet of the League of American Wheelmen for 1806 closed this afternoon with a set of races that left nothing to be desired from the thousands of enthusiasts who looked on at the pretty Fountain Ferry track. There were several surprises, but in each event the finish was exciting.
" Continuous" trains will run from the Battery to Tremont, and vice versa, by the Manhattan Company for a single fare of 5 cents next month.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- A fresh-air excursion for mothers and babes who are sick was enjoyed on Wednesday from this city. It was under the auspices of the Orange Branch of the Guild of St. Barnabas for Nurses, and some eight hundred tickets were issued, several trained nurses and physicians in charge of Dr. Thomas S.P. Fitch accompanying the party.

George J. Tragidis Co., wholesale dealers in butter, cheese, eggs, produce, and poultry at 152 Reade Street, have disappeared from their place of business, leaving a large number of creditors unpaid and no assets that can be reached.

BOSTON, Aug. 15. -- Stivetts was too much for Brooklyn to-day, while Stein was easy for Boston, Harper coming to the rescue in the eighth inning, after the damage had been done. Jonas was spiked by Long over the left eye in the third inning, while stealing second, and a gash an inch long resulted. Hamilton's baze running and batting were the best features. Score:

Prompt and cheerful obedience to lawfully constituted authority is the sure mark of a true manhood. Lord Nelson, who had himself mastered the lesson of obedience, was accustomed to give this counsel to his subordinates: "Obey all orders of your superior officers with an alacrity that will not give you time to inquire into their propriety."

" You can see lots of human astold in a jewelry store," remarked the man who was arranging a tray of gems in the window in as to give them their greatest possilble allurement. "One of the things I have noticed, is that most people dislike to depend on their own judgment. They don't appreciate anything until then know its value in dollars and cents."

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Last Saturday and Sunday were the most crowded days of the present year and for thirteen years past, but the crowds were not here in such great numbers then as they are to-night. At no time since centennial year were so many persons here as are sleeping in this seaside city to-night.

EDGEMERE, L.I., Aug. 15. -- The Edgemere Hotel has been crowded with guests daring the past week, but with the exception of bathing they have done little but talk about the hot weather. The chief event of the week was the entertainment in aid of The Herald Free Ice Fund. The entertainment was a great success, and the hall was crowded in spite of the heat.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. -- Mrs. H. Mortimer Brooks had a reception to-day for her daughter, Miss Josephine Brooks, who was introduced to society. The interior of the villa was a floral bower, roses being used in great profusion. The guests numbered 250. Tea was served in the dining room. The bread piazzas were inclosed, and upon them ices and other delicacies were served, while the Casino orchestra played.

This exceedingly handsome volume, in addition to a most critical text, contains facsimiles of many interesting documents and has a number of maps reproduced in the exact size of the originals, so furnishing the student of cosmography with many precious details. It may be said that in no work have so many important maps relating to early America been brought together in their proper sequence.

The town of Dunmow was crowded yesterday with excursionists, who assembled to see the trials for the Dunmow Flitch. There were three couples claiming the award. A Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Drury were first examined.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- A dispatch received at the Navy Department this afternoon announces the sailing of Admiral Bunce's squadron from Hampton Roads at 2 P. M. to-day for the Southern drill grounds, which lie on the line between Block Island and the Capes of the Chesapeake.

The slow panic, which had been the condition of the market since the Chicago Convention up to last Tuesday, has changed to something like normal conditions. The Street is getting easier. This was shown yesterday when the bank statement came out. It was unfavorable to a degree fully up to the worst anticipations, yet after a momentary shock the market grew stronger and closed steady.

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The weather this week compelled the postponing of all outdoor sports, and all had to content themselves with quiet games in the parlors or under the verandas. Bathing was more popular than usual, and was freely indulged in. The women bathers, however, found fault with the water, it being too warm.

NEWPORT, Aug. 15. -- The warm wave struck Newport with a vengeance this week, and there was a great deal of suffering here that was not altogether confined to the poor, for the wealthy Summer resident could find no place to which he could retreat for comfort. Cottagers have now ceased to arrive, for they are all here.

But good came out of evil, and the women formed for themselves the successful Writers' Club, and the hatchet was finally buried when the men's club invited a Vice President of the women's club to dine with them at the Holborn Restaurant.

The Bourke Cockran meeting is growing into bigger proportions every hour. At the headquarters of the Democratic Honest Money League it was learned yesterday that there is such a demand for tickets that the crowd promises to overflow the Garden. It has already been proposed that the meeting be changed to an open-air gathering, so that all who wish to may have the opportunity of hearing Mr. Cockran.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The season at all the resorts in the Adirondacks is now at its height. Ideal Summer weather has prevailed during the week. The hot wave made it somewhat unpleasant for driving and wheeling, but the cool evenings more than made up for the discomfort endured during the day.

Anyway, looking up, they saw two bright eyes peering down upon them.

LONDON, Aug. 5 -- Twelve years ago, when I was making my first visits to the House of Commons, and familiarizing myself with the appearance of its principal man, I remember that, I was much impressed by the look of one of the men sitting among the rank and file of the Liberals, who were then on the Government side.

Gen. George Clinton, in bronze, 8 feet-high, now lies stretched at full length on the sandy floor of a west side bronze foundry. The brownzeworkers are burnishing up and eradicating rough spots, and in another week the completed statue will be ready for its pedestal in Colden Square, Newburg. A programme of dedicatory exercises is now in course of preparation.

In fact, it was one of the most progressive weeks, so fair as the artillery was concerned, in the history of the camp.

" Saxenhurst" is a story of 200 years ago, and, beginning in Old England, comes to a conclusion in early Colonial days. Lady Belle, daughter of the Earl of Dorsef, has had for schoolmate Donald Duncan, and she loves him. For his part at first it is only a fraternal affection, but in time he sees into the depths of her heart and becomes her devoted husband.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 15. -- This being the last day of the Monmouth County Open Air Horse Show, and a half holiday besides, a large crowd of people arrived here last night and to-day, many of them for the sole purpose of going to the show.

The Norwegian Parliament has just voted the abolition of Greek sad Latin in Norwegian high school. In future the regular course will comprise in the department of languages German, English, French, and Norwegian in all its branches, ancient and modern. The everlasting argument against Latin and Greek, the practical uselessness of the dead languages, is not the principal reason which governed the decision the Norwegian Congress; a moral motive was their pretext.

According to United States Consular Agent Carpenter, at Furth, Bavaria, Germany has recognized the superiority of American goods in many branches of manufacturing. They have stoves made on the American plan, which they call American stoves. American fashion plates in the tailor shops, and many of the toys are made after American samples.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- August Schmidt of 330 Avenue D is the guest of his sister at Pittsburg, Penn. The Rev. Mr. Herbs, recently of Ironton, Ohio, was installed as pastor of St. Paul's German Evangelical (Lutheran) Church last Sunday. Miss Stella Phillips of East Forty-second Street is summering with relatives sat Plainfield, Union County.

There is a good deal of discussion at present as to the utility of what is usually and erroneously called "the Albany lead." It consists of calling for trumps to be led through an honor turned on the original lead. It is done by playing an irregular card, a high one and is intended to show your partner that you have four trumps and an honor superior to the one turned.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, Aug. 15. -- The ever-popular Kaaterskill is more thronged this year, at the present time, than it has been in several seasons past. Guests are constantly arriving, and the hotel is becoming so crowded that there is a strong probability that ere the coming week is ended the accommodations will be found to be inadequate to accommodate them all.

DELAWARE WATER, GAP, Penn., Aug. 15. -- In spite of the midsummer heat, which has been tempered by the pure mountain breezes, out-of-door sports continue the most popular forms of amusement at the Gap. The girls have organized a bicycle club, and are exhibiting considerable enthusiasm over it.

Mr. Clyde Fitch is very clever at trifles, and these stray pieces, collected in a pretty volume, make agreeable Summer reading. The American young woman who moves gracefully in good society is portrayed, through her conversation and her correspondence, by Mr. Fitch with audacity and humor and in the spirit of one who aims to increase the number of bachelors.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Among the delegates who took part in the Second Assembly District Convention of Dutchess County to-day was Edward C. Perrine of Upper Red Hook, at whose residence William Jennings Bryan, the Democratic nominee for President, will spend ten days preparing his letter of acceptance.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, Aug. 15. -- This week has been a rush one in the way of visitors. It was also bathing week. Torrid sunshine compelled people to go in droves to the bathing grounds and spend a good portion of their time in the water. Few ventured from their habitations during the heated hours except for the purpose of the bath.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Albert Miller, the Washington correspondent of the Kansas City Star and a conservative writer on the political situation, has been making a tour of some of the Southern States to ascertain by personal observation the political chances in those States, and he has published the results of his trip in successive number of The Kansas City star since July 31.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Miss Jennie Moore is at Long Brach.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 15. -- C.B. and S.R. Neel, the Western champions, won the all-comers' doubles match. East versus West, to-day in five very exciting sets. The first set Hovey and Hobart won by good work at the net, and the Western pair was unable to dislodge them.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 15. -- A fine concert and Sunday school jubilee were enjoyed on Thursday night in the tent at Valley Road and Portland Place, under the auspices of the Union Baptist Church. The Montclair Circle of the Brotherhood of Union conducted a large and enjoyable excursion to Grand View Park, on Long Island Sound, on Tuesday.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- George Van Vechten and Miss Van Vechten have gone to Chateaugay Lake, New-York, for a few weeks. Mr. E.F. Phelps has gone on a visit to Brooklyn. George D. Stout has gone to Sea Girt. Miss Irene Van Pelt is at Rockaway. R.C. Randolph of New-York is visiting friends here, Mrs. John Long is visiting at Trenton.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The third and last day of the exhibition of the Monmouth County Horse Show Association opened very auspiciously. The grand stand was inadequate to accommodate those present, and all the private boxes were crowded with holders and their friends. Picturesque Hollywood never entertained a larger crowd.
Half a dozen carving knives have been the innocent cause of a lively panic which has occurred in the carriage of a suburban train speeding up to the metropolis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Populist Party campaign handbook for 1896 has just appeared. It is a book of 313 pages, and differs from the handbooks of the older political organizations in that it is devoted to the single subject of money.

The Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor has been an active agent during the dangerous period of hot weather in rendering assistance. The outing parties it gives, three times a week to its homes have been increased from 250, the usual number, to from 500 to 700. The relief thus afforded the poor has been great.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- The Parliamentary tussle over the Irish Land bill closed last night, when Parliament was prorogued to Oct. 31 with a kiss-and-be-friends scene in the House of Commons. The Right Hon. Edward H. Carson, (Conservative,) Member for Dublin University, said he regretted if, in the warmth of debate, he had offended anybody.

One of the great drawbacks to a country residence has been the impossibility of properly lighting the house. To the city-bred person the transition from gas or electric light to coal-oil lamps has been dismal in the extreme, and many an otherwise bright evening has been rendered gloomy on account of it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Baron Fava, the Italian Ambassador, called at the State Department this morning, having come from Bar Harbor for that purpose, and had a long interview with Acting Secretary Rockhill regarding the lynching of the three Italians in Louisiana last Saturday night, which has led to so much excitement in Italy.

After reading this little book by Mr. Wells one finds himself in doubt about the author's purpose. His biological nightmare may be intended as a sort of allegory, but we hasten to say distinctly, for the author's sake, that if that is the case the allegory is very cleverly veiled, and its meaning is not so plain that the purely imaginative quality of the narrative is thereby injured.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 15. -- The rush and excitement at this fashionable resort still continue. The season is fast approaching its height. Many arrivals are expected next week, and by next Saturday night Bar Harbor will be on the crest of the Summer's gayety. Mavroyent Bey, the popular Turkish ex-Minister, gave a large dinner Monday Evening.

WHITESTONE, L.I., Aug. 15. -- Capt. Fitzgerald of the tug Harvey Temple, while passing Riker's Island last night going east, saw a man floating in the water. He had a life preserver about him, and the Captain, putting about, got alongside the man and pulled him on the tug.

LONDON, Aug. 15. -- Li Hung Chang visited Mr. Gladstone to-day at Hawarden Castle, and the two carried on quite a long conversation through the medium of an interpreter. The meeting took place in the drawing-room, in the presence of Mr. Gladstone's family.

The laziest mule in all California is the one on the Furallon Islands that belongs to the lighthouse keepers. He is the successor of the late lamented "Jerry," and is known to his owners as "Patsey." In many ways he is a smart mule, but he devotes most of his talents to devising means to avoid the little work that is required of him.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Aug. 15. -- Nestling among tall and stately trees, the Pocohasset House enjoys unusual advantages, situated over 2,000 feet above tidewater and at a point on the mountains from which the grandest views can be obtained. During the week it has been comparatively pleasant up here, despite the extremely warm weather.

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 15. -- There seems to be more gayety at the Sagamore this Summer than in previous seasons. Crowded in one week were germans, yachting parties, baseball games, tennis tournaments, dove germans, and minstrel entertainments gotten up by young men guests as the hotel. The minstrel performance is said to have been an unqualified success.

FAR ROCKAWAY, L.I., Aug. 15. -- Almost the sole topic of conversation here during the past week has been the intense heat. Fully a dozen horses have died during the week -- an unusual thing here. The temperature has reached the unprecedented figure of 90. Outside of the heat, the principal interest has been the bicycle parade, which has been arranged for next Saturday.

In my last article, says a writer in the London Gentlewoman, I alluded to the bad manners of modern men, an now that the season is practically over, I suggest to my lady readers that before next season comes around they should seriously consider whether they will calmly and patiently go on enduring what I can only call the insulting conduct of the opposite sex, more especially in regard to entertainments.

The business transacted on the floor of "The Baltic," in Threadneedle Street, London, is of a sufficiently varied character. Besides cargoes of grain daily changing hands, a vast quantity of tonnage is annually chartered, and very important transactions in linseed, cottonseed, rapeseed, oils, tallow, , take place. Grain merchants and grain brokers, ship owners and ship brokers, seed merchants and seed brokers, seed crushers and oil refiners, all rub shoulders with one another.

The question of forgeries which disfigure our national collections cannot pass unnoticed. I do not assert that the South Kensington Museum contains more of them than are to be found in similar institutions on the Continent, though it probably does; for with such exquisite and beautiful skill are these objects nowadays forged or "faked" that the most practiced expert may now and again be victimized by them almost without disgrace.

SARATOGA, Aug. 15. -- This being the first season of Saratoga under the new regime, i. e., without gambling or horse racing, a comparison of the Spa now with its record of past Summers is constantly being made.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The week just closed was a great one for Atlantic City, not only great, but the greatest that the city by lhe sea has ever known, and it is conceded on all sides by the business people, the cottagers, the hotel guests, and the permanent residents that more visitors have been here since Saturday last than ever before in the history of the resort.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 15. --The Myopia, second team, of Boston won its opening match to-day, in the polo contests for the Newport cups, open to teams whose aggregate handicaps do not exceed twenty goals. Except during the last period of play the match was tame and quite devoid of interest. It was not till this period had been open same time that the Myopias recovered their handicap of six goals and took the lead.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 15. -- Mrs. Andrew Cox of Liberty Street has returned home from Stelton. Miss McKee of Brooklyn is visiting Mrs. A.J. Leader of Duer Street. Miss Lizzie Sears of West Fifth Street has returned from a visit in Norwich, Conn. Louis Mohring of Park Avenue has returned from his vacation in the country.

The Newburg Wheelmen will have a bicycle meet on the fair grounds on Labor Day, Monday, Sept. 7. The events to be contested are: One-mile novice, one-half mile open, Orange, County championship, two miles; team race, one-mile handicap, one-mile open, and two-mile handicap. In each event handsome prize are offered.

Lord Charles Russell, Lord Chief Justice of England, reached these Welcoming shores yesterday, and was at once taken in hand in a way to make to him feel thoroughly at home. The party that received him took account of the weather, and inflicted upon him no speechmaking or other formality. He remained on the Umbria until she was docked.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- The last week has been the gayest and liveliest one of the season, in spite of the heat. The hotels have been taxed to their utmost capacity to accommodate the crowds that have fled from the hot streets of the city to the cool shores of Shelter Island.

The League umpire assigned to the games was ill, and players had to be chosen for the disagreeable position.

WEST POINT, Aug. 15. -- In spite of the almost unendurable heat that for the past week has baked brown the mountain sides, pleasure and gayety has held full sway and no feature has been omitted from the usual amusements which furnish entertainment for the Summer visitor. In camp it was hot and the cadets suffered considerable.

Rodenbough, Chief of the Election Bureau has issued, under the direction of the Police Board, printed copies of the election law, and also a circular to election officers calling attention to the various changes in the law as enacted by the last Legislature. This is the election calendar for this year:

I venture to suggest a final detail of infinite consequence to real happiness in any rearrangement of society in America. Every school, everywhere, should have competent instructors in the use of the voice; every physician should carry in his pocket a prompt and effectual remedy for our National catarrh. There was a time the rustic Yankee dialect afforded the type for ridicule of our new-world snarl in utterance.

The women of Tennessee may justly be proud of the reputation they have gained through their efforts for the success of the Centennial Exposition to be held at Nashville next year. To their enthusiasm and patriotism belongs the credit of giving the first impetus to the movement.

In art, in literature, the search for violent novelty seems to be tending everywhere toward a return to a sort of rude barbarism. By dint of overrefinement, nothing strikes the exhausted eye but what is rough, or even vulgar. There is a curious instance of this in connection with the latest production of the lively pen of Gyp. "Ohe les Dirigeants!"
GREENVILLE, S.C., Aug. 15. -- There are perhaps more prominent railroad representatives in Greenville to-day than have been congregated in South Carolina in many years.

The power required to keep a bicycle in motion varies within very wide Units. It depends not only upon the weight of the rider and the speed, but also upon the conditions of the road and the steepness of the grade. The wheel itself runs almost without friction -- that is, if it is a first-class machine, with hardened steel bearings.

The agitation begun by some of the uptown wheelmen in favor of the construction of a cycle path on the Seventh Avenue Boulevard from Central Park to One Hundred and Fifty-fifth Street, symptomatic and significant as it is respecting the future of roads, will meet with wide approval from those who ride, and seems likely to find favor also among that lesser portion of the community who are not yet interested in the wheel.

William Jennings Bryan, Populist-Democratic candidate for the Presidency, went into enforced retirement yesterday morning. He would plainly have preferred going on that trip to Boston and Bath, but fate and the campaign leaders would not have it so. Mr. Bryan, therefore, was sent up the Hudson to seclusion and silence.

Macaulay's theory, that with the advance of civilization poetry must inevitably decline, is not quite true; he should have said that it changes its character, but this is because poetry has life for its subject matter. Art is an expression of something, and the greatest art has always given body and shape to the genius of a particular race at a certain point of its development; to this Shakespeare and Racine are not exceptions.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 15. -- Heat of the fiercest kind has sent to this haven of recreation and rest a mighty concourse of sweltering sufferers the past week. But these comers have not been satisfied altogether, for weather is not a purchasable quantity, and moneyed men and wealthy women have perspired and suffered right here on the broad verandas of fashionable hotels.

The largest and finest building ever erected in New-York City for the retail trade is to be opened on Sept. 12, when the new department store of the Siegel-Cooper Company, at Sixth Avenue and Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets, will be ready for customers.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Frederick Mead, a son of ex-Sheriff Mead of this city, was drowned in Cayuga Lake, off Sheldrake, to-day. He was a member of a houseboat party in tow of a steamer, on the way to Glenwood.

I observe with mixed feelings that a gentleman of the resonant name of Samuel Chandos Pole was fined 100 last Monday for writing in a visitors' book at Tamworth. This is a good beginning, and the courage of Mr. Justice Wills and a common jury in chastising our national vice, takes an added lustre quia saevit in ipecs Trojugenas.

LARCHMONT MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Nearly all social functions were suspended this week owing to the extreme heat. Even yachting, ordinarily an unfailing source of delight to Manor residents, languished because the waters of the Sound reposed serene and unruffled by even a breath of air.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The benevolent movement for the benefit of the poor children inaugurated at Zurich, Switzerland, twenty years ago, has grown to such proportions and been emulated by so many European countries that the American Consul at Zurich has sent the State Department an elaborate report on the subject of the vacation colonies, to which school children in need of recuperation are taken in Summer.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 15. -- As usual at this time of year the daily programme is to drive around the luke, and to alternate progressive euchre with concerts during the rest of the time. At a recent euchre party given by Mr. E.M. Earle the prizes were won by Mrs. Conrad, Mrs. Ballard, and Mrs. Spear, Messrs. McCann, Little, and Victor Sutro.
NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The New-Jersey People's Party opened its State Convention in Stetter's Hall, on Broad Street, at noon to-day. Every county in the State was represented.

Berlioz did not find that the artistic temperament; even supplemented by strong mutual attraction, was a sufficient bond of sympathy between husband and wife. The story of his mad love for Henrietta Smithson, the Irish actress whom he saw as Ophelia and Desdemona in Paris, has been told by himself with as much accuracy as is possible to an egoist in treating of his own concerns.

The Vencedor of the Lincoln Park Yacht Club and the Canada of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club at Toronto are to meet in a series of races at Toledo next week. These races are to decide the yachting supremacy of the lakes and will be the most important yacht races of the year.

J.K. Emmet, the actor, son of the late "Fritz" Emmet, appearede in the Harlem Police Court yesterday before Magistrate Mott in answer to a summons obtained by his wife, known on the stage as Emily Lytton. Mrs. J.E. Wright of 363 Manhattan Avenue, where Mr. Emmet makes his home while in the city, was also present in answer to a summons obtained by Mrs. Emmet.

The late Capt. John G. Bourke, in his "Snake Dance of the Moquis," quotes Lubbock, who says that he believes that snake worship "sprang up spontaneously in many places and at many different times. In considering the wide distribution of serpent worship, we must remember that in the case of the serpent, we apply one name to a whole order of animals, and that serpents occur all over the world except in very cold regions.

Slavery is, in truth, a condition so common in the very early stages of social growth, and when it occurs in those stages, is generally so comparatively innoxious that it may almost be regarded as a natural if not quite healthy concomitant of early social development. When the primitive master and his slave live in like huts share like food, and are engaged in like occupations, slavery is slavery in nothing but name.

Eugene Falconer, alias Clarence Talford, was arraigned before Magistrate Mott in the Harlem Police Court yesterday on a charge of abandonment preferred by his wife, Mary, to whom he has been married only six weeks.

Andrew Boyd, engineer, ans James McBride, son of the captain of the schonne Edwin J. Berwin, which is anchored off Redlow's Island, started last night. Both men are said to have been under the influence of liquor, and Boyd fell overbound.

In trying to fix the responsibility for the capsizing of the caisson in Dry Dock No. 2 in the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and the consequent wrecking of the Commandant's barge and damage to the torpedo boat Ericsson, the Naval Board of Inquiry appointed to investigate the affair spent the entire day yesterday, and will probably consume two more days before its labors are finished.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 15. -- Wild and exciting scenes characterized the Herkimer County Republican Convention to-day, when the delegates and shouting partisans crowded the Court House. All was uncertainty, and both Warner Miller and Titus J. Sheard claimed control.

Chapters relating to the Departments of Parks and of Street Cleaning for the Greater New-York charter were added yesterday to the reports of the sub-committee assigned to the preparation of a draft for the commission to consider.

We have received several letters from professors and professoresses of dancing respecting the recent congress of dancing masters in London and expressing the fear that little good will spring from its deliberations. In fact, their views on the future of the profession are gloomy. Mr. S. Bishop thinks, however, that the deplorable leap-hop-and-jump style of dancing so often seen in public ballrooms is not entirely due to the maitre de danse.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Aun Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

BRIELLE, N.J., Aug. 15. -- The season at Brielle is in full swing. Hotel keepers are happy, for the season, has been unparalleled. Major Russell, the proprietor of the Brielle, the largest hotel here, has rented three cottages in the vicinity to accommodate the overflow of guests.

BIGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., Aug. 15. -- An inquest was held at 2 o'clock this afternoon by Coroner Senft of this city in the case of John Mueller, the farmer whose dead body was found sitting in a chair in his home, about a mile from this city, yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- The Chesapeake and Ohio train which left Washington at midnight last night ran into an open switch about twenty miles west of here, derailing all but the two rear cars.

Cloaked and turbaned, they glide bout in slippered feet, the women shod in red, the men in bright yellow. But for their exceedingly substantial build the Moorish women in the street might pass for ghosts, for their costume is, with this one exception, white. A long and heavy blanket of coarse homespun effectually conceals every feature but the eyes, which are touched up with antimony on the lids, and as a rule are sufficiently expressive.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 15. -- The Republican campaign was opened here to-day, with two big meetings, which were addressed by Senator Sherman, ex-Gov. Foraker, and Gen. Stewart L. Woodford. The meetings were held in a tent that seated 10,000 persons. Nearly as many more were unable to gain admittance.

" Chewing gum? Yes, Sir; what kind shall I give you?" said a small shopkeeper yesterday in answer to a request for a cent's worth of that commodity. The inquirer was not an habitual gum chewer, and was not well enough informed to name a preference, and said so.

Not a breath of air, and the vast sea expanse as smooth as a waxed floor. It was an ideal condition for the dance of the waterspout giants, reported by two vessels which came into this port yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 16. -- The followers of Bryan and free silver are not going to have their own way with the Democratic Party in Wisconsin. That fact stands out as hold as a pikestaff in the surroundings of the call for a sound-money Democratic Convention to elect delegates to the convention of the National Democratic Party which will be held in Indianapolis Sept. 2.

Let us conjure up to our imagination the scene of artless jollity -- the old-fashioned country fair. Behold that circle of chubby bumpkins, each with his blowsy, apple-cheeked sweetheart at his side, and note the leathern ellipsoldal ring raised some five feet from the ground and fixed in that position, midmost the village green.

There was no change in the strike of the Adams Express Company's employes yesterday, except that affairs looked brighter and busier at the docks in Jersey City. Agent Temple had thirty-eight men at work instead of eleven, as on Saturday, and fourteen wagons instead of three. The drivers had no helpers but Agent Temple thought they would be able to get along.

The second annual camp meeting at Albertson's Station, on the Oyster Bay branch of the Long Island Railroad, opened yesterday morning with a love feast. These gatherings are on the good old-fashioned Methodist order, with salvation and brotherly love preached on the old lines. The hits at the sinners and backsliders are straight from the shoulder, the preachers believing that a warning is the best way to convince the wayward ones.

OMAHA, Aug. 16 -- Senator Thurston has sent a letter to Senator Stewart in which he discusses the oft-repeated statement that Candidate Bryan since he left Congress has been in the employ of the Bimetallic League, commissioned to preach for silver. Senate Thurston in his letter says:

PARK RIDGE, N.J. Aug. l. -- Mrs. William Maler of this place yesterday afternoon rescued from tramp Grace Broom, the eight-year-old daughter of Davis Broom, who was a attacked by the tramp as she and her sister Ella and their five-year-old brother Willie were picking blackberries in pasture near the house of Mrs. Maler.

One of the queerest reunions in the history of Indiana will take place at Auburn, De Kalb County, on Aug. 20. It is to be composed of the men and women who have been united in marriage by the Rev. W.L. Meese during his ministry there. They form a fair proportion of the population of De Kalb County, besides being represented in every other State in the Union.

This year's Plattdeutsch Volksfest opened auspiciously yesterday, and up to the time that the rain made its appearance in the evening the attendance bid fair to be the largest as yet present at any of these events. The Union Hill (N.J.) Schuetzen Park, the scene of many former festivals of the Low Germans of this section, offered much that was new owing to the fire last Winter, which destroyed some of the main buildings.

Slavery in its legal form was extinguished at Cape Town about the year 1834. The English Government, which had at that time taken over Cape Colony, purchased and liberated all the slaves, at a cost of 1,247,000. Officially slavery passed away; but it left, as always, its indelible marks on the dominant race who had suffered from it.

Thaddeus K. Martin and his wife, Ellen Martin, who lived at 673 Carlton Avenue, Brooklyn, were instantly killed shortly after 9 o'clock last night by a train on the Prospect Park and Coney Island Railroad at King's Highway and Gravesend Avenue, near the old Town Hall.

In a sermon in which the name of William Jennings Bryan was not mentioned, the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur last evening dealt with the Populist-Democratic nominee for President. A congregation which filled Calvary Baptist Church, in West Fifty-seventh Street, evidently approved their pastor's words, Dr. MacArthur's theme was "A Specious Bible Candidate."
A Catboat containing eight men was upset off Robbins Reef in the bay yesterday afternoon about 3:30 o'clock, and two young men were drowned.

The Republican National Committee is not to appoint the ninth member of its Executive Committee, but will allow a vacancy to exist. This comes from men who have been deeply interested in the selection of the ninth man. The members already chosen are Messrs. Henna of Ohio, Manley of Maine, Proctor of Vermont, Quay of Pennsylvania, Payne of Wisconsin, Clayton of Arkansas, Scott of West Virginia, and Leland of Kansas.

CUMBELAND, Ohio, Aug. 16--Major McKinley spent the entire day at National Chairman Hanna's home, in the lake shore. Dir. Hanna arrived from Chicago early this morning, and several hours were spent by the Major and his manager in consultation.

The Hon. HOKE SMITH, Secretary of the Interior in the Cabinet of President CLEVELAND, has gone over to BRYAN. We have expected him to give some reason, if not justifying, at least plausible, for his choice. Apparently, he attempts something of the kind in his letter to the Hon. C. HENRY COHEN of Augusta, which we published yesterday.
NEWPORT, Aug. 16. -- Mrs. William A. Duer gave a charming dinner company at the Casino to-night for Miss Katherine Duer. There were twenty guests.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Washington has recently been visited by several investigating experts, representing foreign Governments, who come to study features of our Government or of our material interests. The latest is Dr. Henri von Laer of Belgium, Director of the Brewing School of Ghent.

Mr. Drudenelle Carter made arrangements with the authories of twenty-five commentary schools in London, with the result that 8,125 children were subjected to simple tests of vision. Of these it turned out that just under 40 per cent, were possessed of normal vision in Loth eye. Between 2,000 and and 3000 of the children with defective vision were subjected to careful medical examination by Mr. carter or by a skillful colleague.
" NO Government by injunction," said the Bryan-Altgeld-Debs combination at Chicago, and labeled it Democratic doctrine.

A tug and a big schooner gave the police of Staten Island an exceedingly lively hour about noon yesterday. The police of two precincts turned out and boats and trolley cars were called into service, but by fast sailing the tug hauled the schooner out of reach and escaped.

Two men who disappeared when the trouble began sat on a bench in the Mall in Central Park Saturday evening, and started an argument on the relative advantages of the silver and gold standards. They became interested in the debate and talked loudly enough to attract a crowd of nearly 100 men, apparently equally interested in the question at issue.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug 16. -- A call has been issued for a State Convention of the sound-money Democrats of Kansas, to be held in this city Tuesday. Aug. 25, at which delegates from this State will be selected to the National Democratic Convention at Indianapolis. The call is signed by Samuel Kimble of Manhattan, Chairman of the Provisional Committee, and Charles J. Lantry of Topeka, Secretary.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 16. -- This has been the pleasantest Sunday of the season. A stiff breeze has been blowing off the ocean all day.

The fireman in charge of one end of the water tower at the Chambers Street fire Thursday night was a humorist. The fire was remarkably persistent, and at the western end of the building blazed again and again after the firemen thought it was out. The last time it appeared through the one window on the top story which the firemen had not smashed in.

One of the most singular phases of the present political crisis is the silence of the religious press. At no time since 1800 have the issues of a Presidential campaign been so distinctively moral, and yet the very journals whose influence it would be natural to suppose would be strongest on the side of honesty and right have, with a few notable exceptions, nothing to say.

One of the most remarkable phases in the experiences of very many people this year has been the multitudinous recognition of spiritual "healers," religious prophets, and other variously named but equally endowed beings, supposed to posses powers superior to those possessed by the rest or mankind. The year 1896 can be said to date the renaissance of the movement.

There is a peculiar strike at Ridgefield Park, Bergen County, N.J. The force on strike consists of one individual, but the results are serious. The whole town is thrown into darkness by the strike, and the tie-up is as complete as though half the place had quit work.

The Rev. Montgomery Hunt Throop of St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church, in Sussex Street, Jersey City, has begun action in the Supreme Court of New-Jersey against his Vestrymen for $300 due on his salary.

For more than 600 years the study of history in England has been pursued under conditions which have marked this island as a "paradise of clerks." The learned industry of monkish chroniclers, of historiographers royal, and of private scholars, has enriched our libraries with a long series of historical masterpieces, unequaled in the literature of any other country.

The facts upon which the subsequent table has been compiled are mainly derived from the Senate report on prices and wages of fifty-two years. This investigation was made by order of the Finance Committee, under the principal direction of Senator N.W. Aldrich and Senator J.G. Carlisle, two most conspicuous representatives of the protective and free-trade theory in the Senate.

Mr. J. Woodbury Newcomb, an elderly student of criminology, returning to New-York from Sing Sing prison, meets on the train Frank Gleason, Bill Harris, and Jack Pinney, convicts, who have just completed their terms of imprisonment, and who mistake Newcomb for a fellow-convict. To draw them out, he assumes the character and proceeds to tell them the story of his first crime.

So far as anything connected with the silver craze is intelligible, it is intelligible why it should have taken hold of the farmers. Leaving morals to one side, it is a taking calculation for the farmer who is behindhand with his interest that if the dollar were made twice as plentiful by being made half as valuable, he could pay twice as much debt with the same quantity of products.

ASHFIELD, Mass., Aug. 12. -- One "of the great memories of Ashfield is that of George William Curtis, who was so deeply interested in the community and whose place at the annual dinner is still vacant. His name is held in honor by the Curtis Club, which to-night paid the first formal and permanent tribute to his connection with the town in the form of a handsome tablet erected in the Town Hall.

Because he could not support his family on $10 a week, Charles Hansworth, thirty-two years old, of 111 Grand Street, Brooklyn, who has been employed for thirteen years by L. Lowenthal Co., manufacturers of children's clothing at 17 Waverley Place, resorted to thievery. He had been getting $15, but his pay was reduced recently.

SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 16. -- The sixty-fifth annual camp meeting of the Methodists, which has been in session here for ten days, closed to-night with the usual "March Around Jerusalem," which consists of the ministers. Trustees, and other officers and the campers generally forming about "the circle," after the evening services are concluded, and marching around through the streets and avenues of the camp, singing a good marching hymn and shaking hands with all.

Some Republicans are expecting that the State Committee will select a new Treasurer shortly after the State Convention in Saratoga next week. Adjt. Gen. E.A. McAlpin now holds that position, and the change, it one is made, will be due to developments at the National Convention of the Republican League of Clubs, to be held in Milwaukee Aug. 27. Gen. McAlpin is President of that organization, and he is a candidate for re-election.

The Rev. Job Bass has been the chaplain of the Kings County Penitentiary for thirty years. During all that time he has devoted himself to bettering the condition of the unfortunate criminals that have been locked up in the institution. He has prayed for them, written their letters, attended to their finances, paid visits to their friends, and has in every way tried to ameliorate their condition.

A lower temperature made yesterday a day of great relief and very material benefit. Though it few cases of heat prostration were reported, the heat was not so great as to make life unbearable in the city, while the conditions were favorable for outings, and the thousands who betook themselves by rail and boat out of town were able to derive genuine enjoyment.

The rule that the whole is equal to the sum of all its parts has a curious exception in a big public audience. When the Amphitheatre is full it undoubtedly contains several thousand bright people, quick to see a joke. Yet, when, as often happens, some speaker gives a touch of humor or witty saying, the audience does not instantly laugh.
Alois Dinkelmann, fifty years old, killed his wife, Adelheid, three years younger, at 145 West Twentieth Street at sunrise yesterday and some time after shot himself.

TABEYTOWN, N.Y. Aug. 10 -- Mr. and Mrs. William J. Bryan. In compnay with Gen. Samuel Thomas, the New York capitalist and prominent Republican, attended divine services this morning at the First Presbyterian Church, in Irvington. O. J. Smith look the nominee driving in the afternoon, Mrs. Bryan, Mrs. Smith, and Mr. Sewall were in the party.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- Unusual economies seem to be exercised now by army and naval officials. Assistant Secretary McAdoo of the navy last week remitted eleven months of the year's imprisonment which was imposed upon Machinist Dunphy of the ram Katahdin, dismissal to follow, on the ground that it was too expensive to keep Dunphy in prison that long.

If the unfortunate social barrier between town and country is to be thrown mean, the initiative must be taken, without doubt from the side of the country. The trading inhabitants of the towns have a great deal too much proper pride to allow of their endeavoring to force intrigue themselves into a society which would not welcome their presents; but they would certainly reciprocate any advances that might be made.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16. -- The State Department has resolved to publish the report of James H. Mulligan, ex-Consul General to Samoa, upon the Government, commerce, products and people of that country, which it has hitherto held as confidential. The report will appear in the August volume of Consular reports now in press.

ALBANY, Aug. 17. -- Superintendent Frederick D. Kilburn of the State Banking Department, has tabulated the reports of the 127 savings bank in the State, showing their financial operations for the year ended June 30, 1896.
There was a little change in the condition of the Adams Express strike yesterday. The strikers gathered as usual at Franklin Hall, Jersey City.

A carriage and south-bound car on the Third Avenue cable road were in collision yesterday afternoon at Fortleth Street, and the occupants of the carriage had a narrow escape from death or serious injury.

An old gentleman whom I rate as a thoroughly conservative man said something to me yesterday which I propose to give here just as he said it. I leave it to the readers of THE NEW-YORK TIMES to put their own estimates on my friend's philosophy. I offer his opinion simply as one man's contribution to the discussion of a momentous question.

"Reception Day" at the Plattdutsche Volksfest was a rare success. Seldom has the Union Hill (N.J.) Schuetzen Park contained such a large assemblage of German societies as yesterday. Very few of the organizations invited were not represented, and most of them were present in large numbers, and marched into the grounds headed by their individual bands.

Another chapter of the proposed charter for Greater New-York was made public yesterday by the sub-committee. It is entitled Chapter IX., and relates to the general powers and duties of the Commissioner of Public Works. The first section, which provides for the appointment by the Commissioner of deputies, was shall have charge of the public works in the different boroughs into which the new city is to be divided, exhibits a remarkable omission.
Mayor Pingree arrived here yesterday from Detroit, Mich., and is lodged at the Murray Hill Hotel.
"Those who are good enough to offer their blood on the altar of their country in time of danger are good enough to trust in the quiet hours of peace." [WILLIAM J. BRYAN at Chicago, Aug. 8.]

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The police of this city, in response to an inquiry by the New-York Department of Police about Harry Mason, colored, who was arrested in New-York City Saturday charged with stealing a bicycle at the Grand Central Station, are investigating the man's record.

NOGALES, Arizona, Aug. 17. -- Capt. Dodge of the infantry company dispatched northward on Friday arrived in Nogales yesterday having in charge three Yaqui Indians captured a few miles east of Tubai. The Indians were traveling toward Tucson, and were heavily armed. They say that they had been on a hunting trip and deny complicity with Friday's raid on Nogales.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17. -- News of an attack in the streets of Valparaiso, on the 16th of last month, by a Chilean mob upon Prince Louis of Savoy, nephew of King Humbert of Italy, and a party of officers and some of the crew of the Italian war ship Cristoforo Colombo, all the facts of which were suppressed by the Government, was received here by the steamer City of Para.

M. HENRI VON LAER, Director of the School of Brewers at Ghent, has just arrived in Washington after a tour of our Western breweries, upon which he is to make an official report. He anticipates this report in some amiable remarks upon American beer. The materials used in its manufacture, he says, are of good quality, and in general the beer is better than the ordinary beer of Belgium.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 17. -- Judge Wales, in the United States Court, this morning, gave decision in the cases of the Single Tax speakers in Dover jail. He decided that the Dover Justice of the Peace had authority to try and to remand James Haggerty, the appellant, to jail for violating a town ordinance by speaking on the street.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17. -- The Casino dance to-night was only moderately attended, owing to some counter-attractions at the cottages. The gowns, though, were unusually handsome.

The funeral of James Olwell, who was for many years prominently connected with the Irish Emigrant Society, the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, and other public and private business, religious, and charitable associations and enterprises in this city, took place yesterday morning in the Church of St. Francis Xavier.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Mrs. Phoebe Wilson, of 22 Pine Street, this village, who was arrested last Thursday on suspicion of having murdered her husband Edward, had a hearing this afternoon before Police Justice Clinton B. Smith in the Town Hall.

But whence the name of "The Baltic"? Like "Lloyd's," it is derived from the name of a coffee house close at hand in Threadneedle Street, which flourished in the seventeenth century. Being frequented originally by Russian merchants chiefly engaged in the Baltic trade, the name of this coffee house was sufficiently appropriate.

There was livelier competition yesterday for the thoroughbred yearlings at the sale of the Silver Brook Stud yearling bred at L.O. Appleby's New-Jersey place than at any sale held this year. The brother to Henry of Navarre was the chief prize, and he was secured after lively competition between William Wallace and James Rowe by the latter for $9,000.

The Rev. Montgomery H. Throop, rector of St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Jersey City, yesterday made an extended statement regarding the suit he has brought against the Vestrymen of his church.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Consul Ashburn D. Taney writes the Department of State from Belfast, Ireland, that the Canadians are making great efforts to introduce household and office furniture in all parts of the "kingdom." One agent of an Orlando firm within a week took orders for about $5,000 worth of furniture in Belfast, and in Dublin for about $10,000 worth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Consul Germain of Zurich, Switzerland, has sent to the State Department statistics regarding the wine production of the world, which show that it is estimated to be 3,671,963,000 gallons annually, having slightly increased during the last few years, in consequence of the decrease of the ravages of the phylloxers, which induced French wine growers to replant their devastated vineyards.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Mrs. Harry S. Henry caused a great sensation early this evening by horsewhipping her husband in the presence of an immense crowd on Kentucky Avenue, near the beach.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- Among the papers contained in the August volume of Consular reports issued by the State Department is one on the "Use of Tectorium in Europe," comprising answers from several Consuls to the department's request for information on the subject.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- The Canty Block, at the corner of Huguenot Street and what is known as the Mechanic Street Extension, southeast of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railway Station, was sold to-day, in foreclosure proceedings, by Arthur L. Clark, for $3,310, to the New-Rochelle Coal and Lumber Company. The buyers also assume a second mortgage on the property for $7,000, making the total price $10,310.
Bourke Cockran will make a speech at the Madison Square Garden to-night in answer to the so-called arguments of Candidate Bryan for free silver on the occasion of his notification Wednesday night.

POPLAR GEOTZ, Ark., Aug. 17. -- Negroes from the Polk and Lowry paraders met here yesterday to play a ball game for a stake of St. William Griffin, the umpire, and an adherent of the Polk side, held the stakes.
