Mr. BRYAN declares that free and unlimited coinage at the present ratio will "create a demand for silver which will keep the price of silver bullion at $1.29 per ounce measured by gold."

UPPER RED HOOK, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Here in this little Dutchess County village, six miles from the nearest station on the New York Central Railroad, nearly two miles from a branch road-of the Philadelphia and Reading, and away from the busy whirl of politics, William J. Bryan has established himself for a week or ten days of quiet to enable him to compose his letter of acceptance.

For the last three months complaints have been made to the police of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station from property owners along the North River front and from Captains of hay barges and excursion barges that gangs of tramps were infesting the property.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 17. -- Major McKinley and Mr. Hanna were in conference at Mr. Hanna's home all day Sunday. Said Mr. Hanna this morning:
Why silver? Why not whisky or cows?
CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- The Executive Committee of the National Democratic Party to-night issued the following address:

Chairman Hanna of the Republican National Committee will be in this city tomorrow. Secretary Osborne received a letter from him yesterday saying that he would reach here in the morning from Cleveland, and would remain a short time.

In Nicaragua the San Juan winds along between banks clothed to the water's edge with feathery palms, tall cacao trees, cedars, bread fruits, ferns, and innumerable other varieties, from the branches of which drop the hanging nests of the crested oriole, or vines with their long tendrils trailing in the stream, and supporting in their turn orchids and other parasites of exquisite color and indescribable forms.

BOSTON, Aug. 17. -- The formal announcement of a date for the assembling of the Honest Money Democratic Convention in Massachusetts marks the culmination of a vigorous and spirited preliminary contest by men who place patriotism above partisanship, and who value honor and honesty more than fealty to a party name.
BELFAST, Aug. 17. -- A large Nationalist demonstration in favor of granting amnesty to all Irish political prisoners took place here to-day, and was the cause of serious rioting.

The chapter of the draft of a charter for the Greater New-York which relates to the Department of Public Works is now made public. Its most important provisions, so far as they differ from those of the present law relating to this city, are those which affect the organization of the department.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Tallsman, J.H. Ballantine; Vision, F.H. Benedict; Parthenia, Stephen J. Roach; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Katrina, Henry F. Noyes; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg; Alicia, H.M. Flagler, and Viking, H.A. Hutchins; Schooner Una, Thomas J. McCahill, Jr.

Recovery in the security market, which began last week, was continued to-day, impelled, apparently, by the same causes in the main which induced the upward turn. All trace has disappeared of the scare that worked the market in advance of the Populist flasco in Madison Square Garden, and political developments since then have converted into prophets for good all whose opinions have weight in forecasting the course of securities.

There is a brutal pastime in vogue among the lumbermen or Maine and New-Hampshire so intimately connected with the tragic story which I am about to relate that I shall begin by describing it. This game, known as "Jack, where be you?" is especially popular during the long Winter evenings, when the gang is assembled in camp after the day's work is finished.

We are convinced that the cause of sound money in this campaign will be benefited and not injured by the nomination of a separate ticket by the National Democratic Party. If we thought it would be in the least endangered, no consideration of party benefit would be allowed to weigh against that, but as a party matter it is not of importance to Democrats alone.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17. -- There is a probability that the Executive Committee of the Populist Party, at its meeting here tomorrow, may imitate the action of the Executive Committee of the Democratic Party and make its headquarters in Chicago, instead of Washington, as at first contemplated.

J7. -- After delibera for several days the Chicago Beat West- ern Railroad Company has decided to meet the percent and in St. Paul road rates in-unsaturated bty the Michigan Car Ferry Company operating in connection with the Soo Lee. This decision was reached late this afternoon and the announcement tomorrow morning through the newspaper will no doubt be a surprise to the other roads handling St. Paul business.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 17. -- Lightning last night struck the carriage house on the Summer place of Collector of the Port of New-York James T. Kilbreth, which is situated here. The building was badly damaged, and a horse owned by the Collector was killed.

Patrick Hartigan, the night watchman for the Beachside Inn and a cluster of cottages surrounding it at Green's Farms, a seaside resort nine miles from Bridgeport Conn., was on the veranda of the hotel at 8 o'clock yesterday morning, when he saw three or four men sitting in a grove about 500 yards from the hotel.

There was a remarkable degree of theatrical activity in New-York last night for the middle of August, but happily the weather was propitious and the indoor performances were all well attended. At the Garrick Theatre "Thoroughbred," the run of which was interrupted by hot weather early in June, was put forward again and will hold the stage for three weeks, when it will give place to Albert Chevalier and a company of English entertainers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- A meeting of the National Executive Committee of the National Democratic Party was held at the Palmer House to-day. Chairman Bynum of Indiana presided, and all the members were present except Charles W. Tracey of New-York, who was detained by party work in his State.

Acting Deputy Chief Cortright, who is the commander of the police force during Chief Conlin's absence, said yesterday that he had made what police arrangements he considered necessary for the big meeting to be held at Madison Square Garden to-night at which Bourke Cockran is to speak in favor of sound money.

NEWARK, Aug. 17. -- Mrs. Paul Wissen, the wife of a dairyman in Clinton Township suburb, was carrying two pails of milk from the barnyard to the house before sun-up this morning. She saw in the weeds a few steps from the path what appeared to be a bundle of clothes or a horse blanket, she could not quite make out which in the twilight.

The New-York baseball team yesterday defeated Washington by a score of 15 to 9 at the Polo Grounds, and, as this made two victories for the New-Yorks to one for Washington on this trip, the local cranks were well pleased.
It seems difficult for the city, under prevailing conditions, to get a fair price for its gold bonds, as was shown yesterday when offers were again examined.

The silicified trees of the Florissant Basin are a marked curiosity of the United States. They are less known that the "stone forest" of Arizona or than the similar mausoleum of the Yellowstone region, but it is only because they have not yet been brought to the attention of the tourist. The trees are at the present time represented only by their stumps.

A journey from Cape Town up country to the region upon which, with about equally mingled rashness and impertinence, an English adventurer has tried to fasten his own now discredited name, substituting Rhodesia for Matabeleland, was never easy to make, and is now harder than ever before.

Considering the vast values in gem pearls obtained from the Eastern fisheries, it is surprising to find that the plain, unromantic mother-of-pearl secured is of even greater worth. Previous to the discovery of the extensive Australian fishing grounds, in 1865, the supply of mother-of-pearl was diminishing, while the demand was increasing.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Aug. 17. -- The mill situation here is a little brighter from the resumption by the Washington Mills of full time in practically all departments to-day. These mills began on forty hours a week last Spring after a busy Winter season. The mills shut down completely June 15 for four weeks. The mills employ 3,500 hands.
HAVANA, Aug. 17. -- The news that Gen. Rolff had landed an expedition at Las Piedras, coast of Moron, and that Garcia had captured the City of Holguin is true.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- Emma Hernberg, six years old, of 378 South Sixth Street, was knocked down by a trolley car near her home this afternoon. She was badly injured about the head. She will recover. The motorman and conductor were arrested.

The Law List for this year discloses the fact that there are over 8,000 gentlemen now living who have been "called to the Bar." Of these, 223 are Queen's Counsel, the rest being ordinary barristers, known variously as "juniors" or "stuffgownsmen." The Queen's Counsel wears a silk gown, somewhat plainly made, with a broad and deep collar.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- At the Genesee County Republican Convention to-day A.D. Sanders of Stafford, R.I. Page of Bethany, Fred B. Parker of Alabama, George M. Gillett of Bergen, and Cortland Crossman of Alexander were elected delegates to the State Convention.

SARATOGA, Aug. 17. -- The State Board of Commissioners for Promoting Uniformity of Legislation in the United States concluded its sixth annual conference to-night. The chief work this year was the reviewing of a draft of a general act on negotiable instruments complied by J.J. Crawford of New-York City.

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 17. -- Several hundred of the most prominent citizens of this city gathered in front of the City Hall tonight in response to a call published in one of the local papers, to express their indignation at the barbarous manner in which Charles Govin of this city, was killed by Spanish soldiers, details of which reached here last Saturday night.

Low records for the year were made at the Stock Exchange yesterday for sterling exchange and for silver. The puncture in the Chicago balloon was a moving cause in each case. Exchange bankers lowered posted rates one-half of a cent at the opening of business. Demand bills declined to $4.87 and sixty-day drafts to $1.86 1/2.
The trial of J. Elliott Smith, Superintendent of the Bureau of Fire Alarm Telegraph, on charges of fraud and incompetency was resumed yesterday before the Board of Fire Commissioners.

CHICAGO, Aug. 17. -- Senator Allison came to National Republican headquarters to-day from the seashore, prepared to take an active part in the campaign in his home State and elsewhere. He said he would not do much campaign work outside Iowa, and added:

Thomas Adams, Jr., son of the millionaire chewing gum manufacturer, who lives at 83 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, is being sued for $100,000 damages for breach of promise of marriage by Miss Myrtle Thurlow, a variety actress. The suit is in the Supreme Court of this city. T.C. O'Sullivan is counsel for Miss Thurlow, while Jerry A. Wernberg is looking out for the interests of Mr. Adams.

The New-York Security and Trust Company, as administrator, has instituted sults in the Supreme Court for constructions of the wills of John H. Howland and of his daughter, Martha H. Hooker. Justice Smyth has granted an order for the service by publication of the summons in the suits upon the heirs of Mr. Howland and all persons in interest.

RIDGEFIELD PARK, N.J., Aug. 17. -- A mass meeting of citizens to consider the strike of the lamplighter, who has left the village in darkness because the Trustees, quarreling among themselves, have not paid him $300 arrearages, was held in the Town Hall to-night.

Oscar J. Taylor, who said he was twenty-eight years old, but refused to give any other information concerning himself, was arrested in Jersey City yesterday charged with being a swindler. Later George Schneider, thirty-nine years old, was arrested as his accomplice. He was equally reticent.

The provisional committee appointed by the sound-money men of New-Jersey met at Taylor's Hotel, Jersey City, yesterday, to complete the organization by the appointment of a State Committee. This duty was delegated to the provisional committee at the meeting of sound-money men held Friday, Aug. 7.

The Englishman who returns to London after a long exile must be struck by the effect of the heat on our traditional reserve. Three years ago we had just such a Lusitanian Summer as that on which Will Waterproof's grandfather's grape grew fat. It made havoc among our customary suits of solemn black.

The social position of the South African halfcaste has been peculiar. He has originated in almost all cases not from the union of average individuals of the two races uniting under average conditions, but as the result of a sexual union between the most helpless and enslaved females of the dark race and the most recklessly dominant males of the white.
SEATTLE, Washington, Aug. 17. -- The steamship Portland, Capt. William Kidston, arrived in port last week from St. Michael's, Unalaska, bringing advices from the latter place up to Aug. 7.

An additional feature, which will add considerably to the general interest, has been added to the programme of events to be run off at the annual Fall championship meet of the New-York State Division, League of American Wheelmen, at Manhattan Beach, on Labor Day. It is a race for District Messenger boys. For the State police championship race there are numerous entries. The events scheduled are:

SAUGUS, Mass., Aug. 17. -- The first day of the August meeting at Franklin Park Race Track was fairly well attended. The track was in good condition in spite of the heavy rains that fell last night. The results:
BARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 17. -- Candidate Bryan and wife to-day came to the home of Mr. E.C. Perrine, at Upper Red Hook, six miles from here. The greater part of the journey was made by boat.
BATII, Me., Aug. 18. -- Arthur Sewall returned from New-York this morning via the Boston boat. He was driven to his residence and passed the day resting. He saw no reporters.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 18. -- The fifteenth annual regatta of the New-Haven Yacht Club was held yesterday. The course was from a buoy at the mouth of the harbor to the mouth of the Housatonic River. The winner in each class was as follows Class 7, Sea Belle, class 11, Oconee; class 12, Monsoon.

In fact, the quotation which the Boy Orator was graping at reads "neither poverty nor riches."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- The long-talked-of ball at Wakehurst, given by James J. Van Alen in honor of his daughter, was an event of this evening. It was a function of great elegance and of lavish detail, and as such was one of the grandest private balls ever given in this country.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 18. -- Mrs. John E. Parsons of Lenox and New-York died at her country place here about 6:30 to-night of inflammation of the brain. She had been out of health for some time, but was not considered in immediate danger until to-day.

Silver touched 66 cents per ounce yesterday for certificates. At this rate the bullion in the dollar that Mr. BRYAN advocates would be worth 51 1-6 cents. This is a fall of about 2 cents since the Populist candidate was put in the field, or a decline of nearly 4 per cent.

Two of the three alleged deserters from the Cuban Army, who were members of the Laurada expedition, and, who were sent to Hoffman Island on the arrival of the steamship Orizaba Monday, were released and came up to the city yesterday. They were James T. Quinn, a locomotive fireman of Boston, and Samuel McNally of Colorado.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 18. -- Chairman Bynum and Secretary Wilson of the National Democratic Executive Committee arrived from Chicago this morning. A telegram from Baltimore to Mr. Bynum states that W. Cabell Bruce, Roger Cull, Joseph Packard, Jr., Isador Rayner, Daniel Miller, Randolph Barton, John M. Nelson, T.K. Worthington, Conway Sams, Pembroke Lee, and Thomas Leigh Bonsal will all support a third ticket and are very desirous of its nomination.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 18. -- The famous letter purporting to have been written by Mrs. J. Fletcher Johnston of this city to Gov. Bradley regarding the appointment of Mrs. Judge Cantrill and Mrs. S.A. Charles as delegates to the Tennessee centennial is developing one of the biggest sensations ever known in Kentucky.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 18. -- The Republican State Executive Committee has decided not to put out a State ticket. It was also decided not to fuse with the Populists, and the individual members of the Republican Party will vote as they please in the State election.

Argument on a motion for alimony and counsel fee made by counsel for Mrs. Henry E. Abbey in her suit for a separation from Henry E. Abbey, a managing Director of Abbey, Schoeffel Grau, Limited, was heard by Justice Smyth in Part I. of the Supreme Court yesterday.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 18. -- Yesterday and to-day were two elegant days at this resort. There were not so many bathers, owing to the coolness of the weather, but the weather was just delightful for bicycle riding and for driving, and a fine display of turnouts was seen on the Ocean Driveway all day long.

" For more than a century no man was ever in doubt as to what constituted Democracy." This is the basis of the statement of the Executive Committee of the National Democratic Party just issued from Chicago. The statement founded upon it is admirably simple and complete. Not only every Democrat, but in all essential regards every sensible and patriotic citizen, can accept it.

Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn yesterday promoted nine Roundsmen to Sergeantcies. The new Sergeants and their assignments are: James F. Allen, Eighth Precinct; E.J. Blaney, Second Precinct; Thomas McCauley, Second Precinct; James McCormick, Tenth Precinct; Patrick Murphy, Third Precinct; John O. Ouchterloney, Twenty-seventh Precinct; George W. Payner, Twenty-first Precinct; W.H. Shaw, Second Precinct, and John Wood, Fourth Precinct.

The scene of the following tragic incident is the wild region about Arctic Falls in Northern Maine; the actors are lumbermen and mill hands of the roughest type. Sally Harden, a big, handsome, uncultured, but sound-hearted girl, daughter of one of the bosses, is the belle of the settlement. Jim Jones and Nick Burdo are her favored suitors, and their rivalry has become bitter and fierce.

There has very seldom been offered in New-York a more pointed and instructive contrast than was furnished in Madison Square Garden a week ago to-night and last night. The contrast was not only in the speeches, but in the audiences and in the arrangements. Last night the arrangements both on the part of the organizers of the meeting and of the police were immeasurably improved from the previous occasion.
Both silver and sterling exchange lowered Monday's records yesterday, the former declining to 66 cents an ounce, and the latter to $4.86 1/4 for demand bills, with a light call even at that figure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15. -- Since the opening of the campaign the Republican Congressional Committee has sent out a little more than 13,000,000 of documents. On Saturday alone 237,000 copies of various speeches were started on their way. So great has been the demands for literature that the committee has been compelled to again enlarge its quarters.

DOLGEVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- Prof. George Gunton of New-York to-night addressed a mass meeting called by the Republican Club of this place. Prof. Gunton is the guest of Mr. Alfred Dolge, who presented him to a large audience assembled at Turn Halle, in these words:

BUCKSPORT, Me., Aug. 18. -- Dispatches from St. Pierre, Miquelon, announce the arrival of the schooners Annie G. Quiner of Bucksport and Frank C. Rich of the Boothbay Grand Banks fishing fleet, homeward bound, with full fares of cod and reporting all vessels of the Bucksport and Boothbay fleets with full fares. The advices state that this has been the most successful season for years.
The Board of Estimate met in the Mayor's office yesterday and voted down the resolution offered by Controller Fitch to issue $603,281.07 of bonds for the purchase of schoolhouse sites.

ELKA PARK, Greene County, N.Y., Aug. 18. -- The charming vlila known as Hammonia was the scene this afternoon and evening of a celebration that was full of pleasant recollections to Sheriff Edward J.H. Tamsen of New-York City and his amiable wife.

Previous to the racing at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday a batch of a dozen thoroughbred yearlings from the Hurricana Stock Farm of Stephen Sanford Sons at Amsterdam. N.Y., were sold at auction for $5.530, an average of very neatly $500 a head, a pretty good average as thoroughbreds are selling this year. Eight head from the Adelbert farm of Williams Radford, Hopkinsville Ky., sold for a total of but $890.

The Republicans held primary elections in all of the election districts of the city last night, to cast delegates to the Assembly District Conventions, which will be held Friday night, for the election of delegates to the State Convention and for delegates to the County Convention, the Assembly District Conventions, for the nomination of Assemblymen, and to the Congressional District Conventions.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 18. -- The Executive Committee of the Revolutionary Society of New-Jersey held a meeting in the office of John Whitehead, Prudential Building, at noon to-day, and contemplated the purchase of the old Wallace House, at Somerville, where Gen. Washington had his headquarters during the Winter and Spring of 1778-9.
Madison Square Garden rang with a burst of patriotic enthusiasm last night.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-20 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- On the Casino courts this morning were again reproduced the familiar scenes of the National tennis tournament. As usual, too, the crowds came late. It was excellent weather for good tennis, the warm sun being thinly veiled by hazy clouds, and only a slight breeze marring the almost perfect conditions for play.

It was the simple notion of our old-fashioned forefathers that the office should seek the man. For something like two generations the politics of this country have, in great degree, been run on exactly the opposite principle, often with results that no sane and honest American could look upon without disgust.

ELKTON, Md., Aug. 18. -- John Boots, engineer of the Diebert dry dock, in Chesapeake City, was yesterday sentenced to be whipped at the post and imprisoned for thirty days for a brutal assault upon his wife.

FLUSHING, L.I., Aug. 18. -- A big crowd gathered this evening to hear the inquest into the Wilson case, but the Corsher ordered the inquest adjourned for one week to allow further investigation. The search of the house, which was begun to-day, was not finished, and it was impossible to have some of the witnesses present.

BOSTON, Aug. 18. -- John Reed, aged twenty-five years, who lives at 615 East Twenty-third Street, New-York City, has been stopping with relatives in this city. While wheeling down the steep grade of Somerset Street this evening he lost control of his bicycle. He plunged down the hill to Howard Street, bringing up against a large plate-glass window.

HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 18. -- In the Vice Admiralty Court to-day Chief Justice Macdonald rendered judgment in the case of the seized Gloucester schooner Frederick Geering, Jr. He declared the vessel confiscated to the Dominion Government for fishing inside the three-mile limit.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18. -- The war on St. Paul rates has just begun. As announced yesterday afternoon, the Great Western decided late in the day to meet the new rates put in force by the Lake Michigan Car Ferry Transportation Company in conjunction with the "Soo" line. Secretary was that announcement made when the Car Ferry Company telegraphed the Inter-State Committee Commission announcing another reduction, in order to preserve the differential claimed under all-rail rates.

BERLIN, Aug. 18. -- The Emperor reviewed the First Guards at Potsdam to-day, and addressed the regiment upon the subject of the battle of Gravelette, of which to-day is the twenty-sixth anniversary, and in which the First Guards took part. His Majesty delivered his usual speech, ending with the words "I expect your absolute obedience to the king."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The Treasury gold reserve to-day declined to $101,834,699. The day's withdrawals were $155,100. At Philadelphia yesterday the Treasury received $15,000 in gold in exchange for the new five-dollar silver certificates. There was deposited at the Assay Office. In Helena, Mon., to-day, $100,000 in gold bullion, which came from the Yukon River mines, in Alaska. It will be coined into Eagles.

Tompkins Square, one of the prettiest of the east side parks, presets a somewhat dilapidated apppearance just now, while it is suffering from the exercise of philanthropy by the Park Commissioners at the close of the recent period of extreme heat, and it is said it will be a year or more before the park has recovered from the damage done by the beneficiaries of the Commissioners' good will.

If statistics of illustrative signs should be taken in New-York it is probable that the one found to predominate would be that showing some kind of a representation of the human tooth. They are to be seen everywhere and in all sizes and conditions. Usually the favorite method of advertising in this way seems to be with a glit tooth in varying degrees of magnitude.

The New-York Times Publishing Company, proprietor of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, has been reorganized. The new organization assumes the ownership to-day. Mr. ADOLPH S. OCHS of Chattanooga, Tenn., in the interest of the new owners, becomes the publisher and general manager. Mr. CHARLES R. MILLER will continue to be the editor.
A fire yesterday morning at 163 West Street caused a loss of about $50,000. One man was badly burned by an explosion, and two firemen were struck by a bursting hose, but were only slightly hurt.

The report of the Superintendent of the Banking Department of this State on the condition of the savings banks for the year ending with June 30 comes as a timely argument in favor of sound money. It shows that the number of depositors is considerably larger than the number of voters in the State.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- The Meadowbrook team won the Westchester cups to-day, administering to their opponents, the Rockaways, the worst defeat they have had in years. The latter failed to score a goal, and lost half of the one they received by handicap. The Rockaway men on the side lines looked on in dismay and dropped a lot of money as well on their favorites.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18. -- The Asahi, owned by Bayard Thayer of Boston, won the gold cup given by Mrs. H.B. Duryea for thirty-footers. It is the finest trophy of the season. The second and third prizes, silver cups, also given by Mrs. Duryea, were won respectively by Mr. Duryea's Vaquero and Ralph N. Ellis's Hera. There was a good breeze and the general conditions were the best of the season.

Henry McLane, twenty-five years old, of 319 West Thirty-sixth Street, a colored porter in the Hotel Savoy, had his spine broken yesterday by falling from the freight elevator in the hotel. He died later in the Flower Hospital. Peter Mulligan of 368 West Twenty-seventh Street, thirty-two years old, the elevator man, had his left foot crushed. The elevator fell from the seventh floor to the basement.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18. -- The reported appointment of Father Martinella as successor to Cardinal Satolli, Papal Delegate to the United States, has been confirmed by Dr. Rooker, Secretary of the Legation, who has just returned from his vacation. He says there will be no official notifical on of the change until the new delegate arrives, and he gives the following as the order of procedure:

The Adams Express strike in Jersey City presented little change yesterday, though, if one may believe the varying statements male, each side had obtained a victory. The company's agents said the strikers were beaten and the strikers claimed they had defeated the company.

LONDON, Aug. 18. -- The races of the Royal Albert Regatta, at Southsea, were interrupted to-day by an accident, which caused the death of Baron von Zedtwitz, the owner of the twenty-rater Isolde, and endangered the lives of the Captain and crew of that vessel, all of whom were knocked overboard.

DOVER, Del. Aug. 18. -- The Democrats State Convention to-day was a long-drawn-out and stubbornly fought contest, an adjournment not being witheld before 7 o'clock this evening. The ticket nominated was:

" I reckon the New-York newspapers have pounded the life out of the silver movement in the East," a friend of mine remarked. "Now, let them pound the life out of the sentiment that prevails largely with workingmen, that Bryan's election would be a good thing for them and all these who are of the people -- a good thing for them on grounds entirely separate from the financial aspect of the case."

Odd Fellows from all over the State gathered at Scottish Rite Hall, Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, yesterday to attend the annual session of the Grand Lodge of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows of the State of New-York, which began there yesterday morning. There are 758 lodges in the State, and over 700 lodges were represented when Grand Master A.A. Guthrie of Albany opened the session with the ceremonies usual on such occasions.

The settlement of the boundary line between Maryland and West Virginia, which affects a cone-shaped strip of land claimed as a part of Garrett County, Md., three-quarters of a mile wide at the base and thirty-seven miles long, tapering to a point, will probably be taken up very early at the next term of the United States Supreme Court, and definitely settled.

There was abundant evidence yesterday that the great patriotic demonstration at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night had given reassurance and a fresh sense of security to the soberminded people of the community. Mr. COCKRAN'S triumph, contrasted with Mr. BRYAN'S failure, furnishes convincing proof of the emphatic declaration of the orator of Tuesday evening that "this soil is not propitious to revolution."
UPPER RED HOOK, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Without expectation or preparation, William J. Bryan made a speech at Rhinebeck to-night.
Chairman Marcus A. Hanna of the Republican National Committee came to this city yesterday morning, and after a brief stay at the Waldorf Hotel went to headquarters, 1 Madison Avenue.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The Firemen's State Convention was called to order this morning at 9:30 o'clock, and much routine business was transacted.

PARIS, Aug. 19. -- In the presence of numerous foreign engineers and a large crowd of onlookers, the so-called roller steamer, the invention of M. Bazin, a well-known marine engineer, was launched to-day of the Call Dock Yards at St. Denis. The vessel will traverse the Seine, cross the English Channel, and go to London.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- The President to-day appointed Col. Charles G. Sawtelle Quartermaster General of the Army, with the rank of Brigadier General. He succeeds Gen. R.N. Balcheider, who retired on the 27th of last month.
Upon sober second thought, it might be a good idea to bury Tom Watson in the Vice Presidency, Vice Presidents these days do very little talking.

One of the features at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday were races for maiden two-year-old horses to be ridden by jockeys that had never ridden a winner. There were two of the races, and they were the first on the card of the day. The first of these was won by Ohio, who was ridden by a lad named Waller, who has ridden frequently as an apprentice.

The Archer Pancoast Company of 18 and 20 West Twenty-fifth Street, which manufactures gas and electric light fixtures at Flushing and Carlton Avenues, Brooklyn, went into the hands of receivers yesterday. Justice Smyth of the Supreme Court appointed Albert C. Hetherington, William S. Fearing, and Peter F. Meyer as receivers, on the application of President Archer V. Pancoast and other Directors of the company.

Mr. PLATT apparently rose to the highest level of sound politics that he is able to reach when he made Mr. MORTON Governor. As matters stood then, this did not show a very high standard, for, beyond doubt, Mr. PLATT believed that Mr. MORTON would be a better "organization man" and a worse Governor than he actually has been.
CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 19. -- Carl Browne, the Lieutenant of Gen. Coxey, spoke for two hours to a crowd of several hundred persons here last night in favor of free silver and the election of Bryan.

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Aug. 19. -- Advices were received here yesterday from the village of San Miguel, this State, that a crowd of twenty bandits had made an attack upon the place and assaulted every woman in the town. All the men were at work on the neighboring haciendas. Three of the bandits were captured, and will be shot.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 19. -- The speech from the throne to-morrow will be of a brief character, containing little of importance beyond what is already known. It is more than probable that his Excellency will refer to the urgency of making provisions for the public service, which necessitated the calling of Parliament at this inconvenient season of the year.

The final arrangements for the reception of Li Hung Chang during his stay in this country were announced yesterday by Major George W. Davis, United States Army, who went to Philadelphia and conferred with ex-Minister to China John Russell Young in reference to the entertainment of the distinguished visitor.

MADRID, Aug. 19. -- The Heraldo asserts that the authorities have discovered the existence of a plot to blow up the castle of La Granja, at San Ildefonso, the residence of the Infanta Isabella, aunt of the King.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- To-day saw the graduation of another great class of students of the Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle. It was the annual recognition, or commencement day, of the circle, and the class of the '96 marched through the grounds and were formally graduated. President Charles Eliot of Harvard University delivered the recognition day address.
TORONTO, Aug. 10. -- William Douglas Balfour, Provincial Secretary in the Ontario Government, died at 6 o'clock this evening from acute hemorrhage of the lungs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- When officials of the Treasury Department prepared Circular No. 123 they were of the opinion that every conceivable question concerning the finance and coinage of the United States had been answered. They find they are mistaken. Hardly a day passes but that questions are asked that Circular No. 123 does not even refer to.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19. -- Mrs. Elisha Dyer gave a unique entertainment to-night. It was a children's ball, from 7 to 10 o'clock. Fifty little ones occupied the ballroom at Wayside, the cotillion being led by Harry Lehr and Miss Swan, daughter of Mrs. Dyer. The favors were silver matchboxes, fancy ribbon trinkets, shepherds' crooks, charms, and stick pins.

The absence of Police Commissioner Parker from the meeting of the Police Board yesterday prevented action on the proposed promotion of Capts. Brooks and McCullagh. As President Roosevelt intends to go West to-morrow to spend three weeks on his ranch at Medora, N.D., it was agreed to hold a special meeting at 10:30 o'clock this morning to settle the question.
PUEBLO, Col., Aug. 19. -- The Democratic State Convention organized at 8 o'clock to-day. Washouts west delayed the arrival of many delegates, and the progress of the convention was slow.

WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 19. -- The most unique case ever tried in the District Court came up this morning before Judge Enos F. Luce, when an alleged expose was made under oath upon the witness stand of the rites and ordeals through which a candidate must pass to become a full-fledged Orangeman.

The Democratic Party in New-Jersey was formally committed to the silver heresy yesterday by the action of its State Committee, and the nominations of Bryan and Sewall were indorsed, but not until after a heated discussion. The vote was 10 to 4.

In the Court of Bankruptcy recently, before Registrar Linklater, a sitting was held for the public examination of Earl Paulett, a debtor, whose accounts showed liabilities 422,293, of which 298,166 is unsecured, and available assets 300. In answer to Mr. Hough, official receiver, the debtor said that up to 1892 he received the rents of the Hinton St. George estates, Somersetshire, and the Grenville Hall estates in Hampshire.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Cool weather, a fair track, and a good programme drew a large attendance at the first lay's meeting of the races at the Buffalo Driving Park to-day. About 4,000 persons were present. The card for to-day was that postponed from yesterday -- the 2:18 class trot, 2:07 class pace, and the 2:25 class trot. Poe's were tall.

Discoveries of odd trading are made from time to time. It is not many years ago that the refuse from housekeeping and the streets of New-York was considered only fit to "make ground" or to be dumped at sea. There came a quick-witted Italian, who knew that the stuff contained wealth. He made a fortune, and now there is a scramble for sorting over rubbish.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 19. -- The Lincoln Club had an auspicious flag-raising to-night, opening the local campaign. It marched to the house of T.B. Reed, on Deering Street, where the band played, and Mr. Reed came out and spoke, as follows:

Gold to the amount of $2,000,000 was engaged in London yesterday for shipment to this city Saturday. In all likelihood other shipments will follow. No estimate of the amount to be imported is yet possible. It will probably be sufficient to avert serious stringency in the money market, that being the purpose in view.

" The committee think that the desideratum in the monetary system is a standard of uniform value. They cannot ascertain that both metals have ever circulated simultaneously, concurrently, and indiscriminately in any country where there are banks or money dealers, and they entertain the conviction that the nearest approach to an invariable standard is its establishment in one metal, which metal shall compose exclusively the currency for large payments."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Isaac N. Stevens of Colorado, Vice Chairman of the Silver National Committee, was at headquarters, in the Corcoran Building, to-day. He expects to remain here until the election. George F. Keeney, organizer of the silver party, will be the Vice Chairman's chief assistant, and Judge C. Hillyer, National Committeeman for the District of Columbia, will also aid the cause.

The announcement that Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN will speak at Chautauqua makes a very interesting suggestion to the managers of that resort. A great many people have assembled there upon different occasions, but a joint debate between Mr. BRYAN and MR. COCKRAN upon the free coinage of silver at the present ratio whatever other effect it might have, would have the effect of breaking the record of attendance at that place.

There was printed in THE TIMES the other day a new exposition of a theme which is not new, the inefficiency of France as a colonizing power. The expounder pointed out that a stationary population, occupying no more ground than will sustain it, has not the reasons that urge to colonial expansion peoples which by increase are pressing harder upon their means of subsistence.

There is an abject apology due through this column. It was not really the fault of the Gatherer, but proper restitution will be made. It was the character of the commuter which was taken away. It was on Saturday last when a story appeared telling the voes of the commuter and his beer.
Bourke Cockran's speech in Madison Square Garden Tuesday night was generally spoken of yesterday as "the opening of the campaign for sound money."

Clara Hendy, a pretty girl, sixteen years old, created a scene in Special Term, Part II., of the Supreme Court yesterday by bitterly denouncing her parents. Mr. and Mrs. George Hendy of One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, near Second Avenue, and exclaiming: "I wen't go to them. I will kill myself."

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19. -- Miss Mattle Overman of Tacoma, Washington, the young lady who gained notoriety through her connection with the disruption of the First Congregational Church of San Francisco, and the disbarment of its pastor, Dr. C.O. Brown, from the fellowship of the churches, has repeated and confessed.

BUTTE, Mon., Aug. 19. -- Foreman Peter Ryan, John Manning, and John Campbell were instantly killed in the St. Lawrence Mine last evening by the failing of a clutch on the hoisting engine to work and permitting the cage to drop to the bottom of the shaft, a distance of 1,250 feet.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 19. -- The second day of the Grand Circuit races drew a small crowd, although the weather was fine. The 2:40 trot and the 2:30 pace were rather uninteresting events, because of the case in which the favorites won. Phenol, the favorite in the 2:12 pace, fell in a preliminary warming up, but nevertheless she captured the first two heats handily.

The Entire Product of S.R. Greene Sons of River Point, R.I., and Also Goods Not Yet Manufactured Sold Close to the Figures Asked at Private Sale -- Many City and Western and Southern Buyers -- The Bidding Spirited.

ALBANY, Aug. 10. -- Gen. Charles Tracey is home from Vermont, where he and Col. John R. Fellows assisted in the organization of Democrats who favor the third-party movement. In speaking of the sentiment in Vermont, Gen. Tracey said:

BATAVIA, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Assemblyman "Archie" D. Sanders is now the recognized leader of the Genesee Republicans. The contest between Sanders and the Tarbox-North-Hamilton combine began when Sanders secured his election as a delegate to the National Convention last Spring, and ended at the Republican County Convention Monday in the complete defeat of the combine.

The White Star steamer Majestic, which arrived at Quarantine at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning, made the fastest passage she has ever made from Daunt's Rock to this port. Her time of passage was 5 days 17 hours 56 minutes, which is twelve minutes better than her, best previous record, made four years ago. She experienced fine weather and smooth seas throughout.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- Judge George S. Batcheller, formerly Presiding Justice of the International Tribunal in Caire, Egypt, and who has a handsome town house here, gave a reception at 9:30 o'clock this evening in honor of the Right Hon. Lord Russell of Killowen, Lord Chief Justice of England, to meet the members of the American Bar Association delegates and legal gentlemen in Saratoga at this time.
GOSHEN, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The trotting races here to-day were witnessed by about 1,500 persons. Summary:

The violent seizure of the name, trademark, and easements of the Democratic Party by the Populists at Chicago has put the Republicans in a vastly confident mood. The bolting and repudiation of the ticket by Democrats makes this one of the years in which they feel that they can elect anybody.

A man was found Tuesday night sitting at the foot of a tree in a vacant lot, near the Bull's Ferry Road, Weehawken. There was a bullet wound in his forehead and in his hand was clutched a revolver. He was still alive and seemed to be trying to fire a shot into his breast. Policeman Dubois, who heard the sound of a shot and ran to the place, seized the pistol.

We do not see any loopholes in Mr. BRYAN'S denial of the charge that he has taken pay of the mine owners or of the bimetallic people for making free-coinage speeches. The charge was made with much positiveness and some specifications that seemed to support it. He not only denies it, and we do not doubt his word, but he offers to make a statement showing in detail all the money he received for speech-making.
There was a decided movement on the part of some of the Platt Republican leaders yesterday to inflate the boom of James W. Wadsworth of Genesco for Governor.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19. -- Senator Thurston, before leaving for New-York to-night, accepted, as conclusive proof of the falsity of the charge, the statement made yesterday by Mr. Bryan that he had never been in the employ of silver mine owners or silver associations.
George M. Pullman in The Atlanta Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- Unless the wishes of Chairman Butler and the members of the Executive Committee are set aside, Mr. Watson, Populist candidate for the Vice Presidency, will not be officially notified of his nomination. Chairman Butler, while declining to make any specific statements on the subject, said that a failure to notify would not be unusual, for the reason that the Populists had never yet notified their candidates.

MOUNT VERMON, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The following persons have resigned from the Democratic City Club of this city: Albert A. Elcht, Dr. H. Eugene Smith, Edwin W. Fiste, Michael F. Carniedy, Fred Drews, Isaac T. Carpenter, William M. Court, F. W. Watts, John H. Cordes, Richard Seder, Mar in Adterman, C.F. MacLaughlin, William J. Marshall, George H. Behrman, J.J. Moore, and S.J. Stilwell. The club has sixty members.

MOUNT VERMON, N.Y., Aug. 19. -- The following persons have resigned from the Democratic City Club of this city: Albert A. Elcht, Dr. H. Eugene Smith, Edwin W. Fiste, Michael F. Carniedy, Fred Drews, Isaac T. Carpenter, William M. Court, F. W. Watts, John H. Cordes, Richard Seder, Mar in Adterman, C.F. MacLaughlin, William J. Marshall, George H. Behrman, J.J. Moore, and S.J. Stilwell. The club has sixty members.

An application was made in the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Smyth by Adolph Bloch on behalf of Josephine Knott for an order awarding her counsel fees and alimony pending the trial of an action that she has brought against her husband, John Knott, a farmer, for separation, on the ground of cruelty and abandonment.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19. -- In addition to his regular weekly bulletin. Chairman Gideon of the Racing Board of the League of American Wheelmen has issued the following special bulletin:

The honest-money Democrats of this State will assemble in convention at Syracuse at noon Monday, Aug. 31, and elect delegates to the convention of the National Democratic Party to be held in Indianapolis Sept. 2.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19. -- The efforts of the silver men of this State to make any headway with the powers in control of the regular Democratic machinery in Connecticut thus far have proved futile and from present indications there is little likelihood that the silver element will make any further progress.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 19. -- Major McKinley worked from 9:30 o'clock this morning till 4 o'clock this afternoon on his letter of acceptance. A large part of the letter is in type, and he spent his time to-day reading proof and making corrections and adding a sentence here and a paragraph there.

A device for registering votes without possibility of fraud has been patented by Albert Snoeck, a Belgian inventor. It is called the Perfected Voting Machine, and is on exhibition at the offices of Logan, Demond Harby, 58 William Street.

Newport, R.I., Aug. 19. -- The marriage to-day of Miss Edith Bishop, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heber R. Bishop, to Moses Taylor, was a quiet affair, as was intended and desired by all concerned, but, nevertheless, society took great interest in it, and nearly as many as were asked to witness the ceremony at noon at Trinity Church were present.
Mr. George A. Bowman has sold, for Cornelia K. Averill, the two four-story brick double this 206 and 208 West Thirty-third Street, 50 by 39.

NOGALES, Arizona, Aug. 19. -- The Indian, Jose Salcedo, who was brought in Sunday, is on the list of the original nineteen rebels and has been identified as one of those engaged in the fight on the morning of the 12th inst. All the prisoners were given a hearing yesterday before United States Court Commissioner Taylor and pleaded not guilty.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19. -- A scheme for continuous mail collection in cities will be put in operation in Washington soon by Second Assistant Postmaster General Neilson. A wagon specially constructed for the purpose is now being built at Hartford, Conn. It will be large enough to accommodate a carrier, independent of the assistant, who will do the driving and take the mail from the street boxes.

LYNN, Mass., Aug. 19. -- William J. Whitten of Haverhill, a non-union laster, was entering the Thomas G. Plant Company's shoe factory this afternoon, when he was set upon by members of a crowd that had gathered at the entrance and quite severely pummeled.

The arrest of Daniel Whalen, the cashier of the old Board of Excise, yesterday afternoon, on a warrant charging him with the larceny of $5,000, came in the nature of a surprise to those who had known him for a number of years as a public official, and by whom he had been regarded as above even the slightest suspicion as to his honesty and integrity.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10. -- Chairman Bynum of the Executive Committee of the National Democratic Party stated to-day that it now can be asserted positively that every State in the Union, except Nevada, Idaho, and Utah, and possibly one Southern State, will send a full delegation to the Indianapolis Convention.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 20. -- A large crowd witnessed the third day's programme of the New Grand Circuit races here to-day. There was some fine racing and in good time. In the 2:25 pace Sherman Clay was the favorite, but Pearl Onward was the steadier after the first two heats, and won with comparative ease. In the 2:15 trot Fred E. won three straight heats, although he had not been counted as a probable winner.

The Rapid Transit Commission has instructed its chief engineer, W.B. Parsons, to make borings along the line of Centre Street in order to ascertain the contour of bed rock along a route for a rapid-transit tunnel which might obviate the necessity of using Broadway between City Hall and Fourteenth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20. -- The new United States cruiser Brooklyn was inspected by the naval examining board to-day. The Inspectors went aboard of the vessel at Cramps' shipyard and spent the entire day in minutely examining every portion of the hull, guns, machinery, They found everything to be up to the requirements, and will submit a report to that effect to the Secretary of the Navy.
American seamen for American ships is a sound and patriotic policy. -- The Sun. Certainly. And American ships for American seamen. They are both sound and patriotic policies.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Aug. 20. -- Responding to numerous inquiries regarding the full scope and effect of the order of the Post Office Department forbidding railroad companies to carry correspondence relating to other than their own business on their trains. Mr. Charles Neilson, Second Assistant Postmaster General, has published the letter of Postmaster General Wilson to E. Prentiss Bailey, editor of The Utica Observer, on the subject.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Edwin C. Garcia, Jr., of Brevoort Park, Rye Neck, when he returns home to-night will find himself without a coachman and poorer than he was when he left home yesterday by the value of an antique gold watch that belonged to his great-grandfather. Michael Coleman, the coachman, ran away yesterday, carrying the watch, a revolver that had been purchased to guard against burglars, and some stable clothes.

The trial of J. Elliott Smith, Superintendent of the Bureau of Fire Alarm, Telegraph, and Electrical Appliances, on charges of fraud and incompetency, was resumed yesterday morning before the Board of Fire Commissioners. All the Commissioners were present. T.J.G. Hall appeared as associate counsel for Mr. Smith.
Thomas Scanlon arrived in New-York from Ireland last Friday, bringing with him $137. His first experience in America cost him just that amount.

HERKIMER, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The Republicans of the Twenty-fifth Congressional District nominated two candidates for Congress to-day after holding one stormy and two harmonious conventions. The stormy one was when the Miller and Platt factions met. The harmonious gatherings were held separately, one by each faction.

The New-York man had been invited to give a short lecture on an interesting subject with which he was familiar, to entertain the guests of a certain charming hotel on the Hudson. He acquiesced, and in the course of his remarks took occasion to compare a great man of whom he spoke with that other great man, Cardinal Wolsey.

The china stores of Ovington Brothers, at 330 Fifth Avenue, this city, and 38 and 40 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, were seized yesterday by the Sheriffs of New-York and Kings Counties, on an attachment for $20,127, in favor of George Borgfeldt Co. of 18 Washington Place, for goods sold and delivered between March 5, 1895, and Aug 13, 1896.

Ex-Gov. St. John of Kansas says that the silver dollar was demonetized in a damnable and treacherous way in 1873, and that from that time to this there have been hard times, and they have been growing harder all the time. Mr. George Fred Williams repeats the statement about hard times.

At Rhinebeck on Wednesday, just after returning from a visit which, in the absence of its owner, he had courteously been allowed to make to Ellerslie, the country home of Gov. MORTON, Mr. BRYAN made the following appeal:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 20. -- Five young women were caught in a rather embarrassing position near Old Bridge yesterday afternoon. They proved equal to the occasion, and the man who embarrassed them wishes he hadn't.

HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 20. -- A fourteen-year-old girl named Marjorie Lewis, who says she went adrift in a rowboat off a watering place on the English Channel and was picked up by the steamer Caledonia and landed at Lunenburg, N.S., has been placed under the care of a benevolent society here.

Among the passengers on the train from this city for Buffalo leaving the Grand Central Station at 7:30 P.M. Saturday, and known as the New-York and Buffalo Special, was a middle-aged man, tall and slight, with light complexion.

Plans were filed with the Building Department yesterday for the fifteen-story hotel which is to be erected by Douglas H. Schneider for Mr. Breslin, at Thirty-sixth Street, Broadway, and Sixth Avenue. The estimated cost is $1,250,000. The framework will be steel skeleton on a rock and concrete foundation. Limestone, brick, and terra cotta will be used for the fronts. Messrs. Hall Turner are the architects, and they will superintend the construction.

The statement which Commissioner PARKER made in the Police Board yesterday was not the explanation which the public had a right to expect of his reasons for "holding up" the promotions of Acting Inspectors BROOKS and MCCULLACH and blocking for months an important part of the work of the board, but an exhibition of intolerable impudence and bravado.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 20. -- Bean Plumb, aged sixty, of 204 Monroe Street, New-York City, was found lying unconscious on Jullen Street here last night, and was removed to the Elizabeth General Hospital.

BUFFALO, Aug. 20. -- Robert J. won again today from his rival, Frank Agan, and while records were not broken, the track record was equaled in the first heat. The second day of the Grand Circuit meeting here brought out a large attendance. The weather was cool and pleasant, and the track was in excellent condition.

The Asylum Baseball Club of Middletown, N.Y., will cross bats with the Oritani Field Club Dine at Hackensack to-morrow afternoon. The Asylums have a great reputation as heavy hitters, and ought to give the Oritanis a close game.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 20. -- The law firm of Dickinson, Thurber Stevenson, which is composed of Don M. Dickinson, Henry T. Thurber, private secretary to President Cleveland, and Elliott G. Stevenson, late Chairman of the Democratic State Central Committee, has dissolved on account of political differences between Messrs. Dickinson and Stevenson.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Commercial Agent Thomas E. Moore reports to the Department of State, from Weimar, that the German life insurance companies in 1895 enjoyed "all around" favorable developments. During the year, 174,754 applications to the value of $158,929,000 were made, against 168,965, valued at $143,603,000, in 1894.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- Chairman Jones, J.G. Johnson of Kansas, and Daniel J. Campau of Michigan, members of the Democratic National Campaign Committee, arrived this morning to begin the campaign work for Bryan and Sewall from the Chicago headquarters, which will be established in the Auditorium Annex.
Major BYRNE said on Tuesday of the "Democratic Honest-Money League of America": "It is the home of all honest Democrats who believe that the party stands for order rather than regularity."

Judge Isaac Lansing of Lincoln, Neb., who spoke last night at the raising of a McKinley and Hobart banner at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Seventh Avenue, opposite the St. Nicholas Republican Club, of the Twenty-first Assembly District, had some interesting things to say about W.J. Bryan.

John C. Sheehan, the executive head of Tammany Hall, declared yesterday that the 105 delegates to the Buffalo Convention to be elected in this city would vote as a unit for the indorsement of the Bryan ticket.

BEDFORD STATION, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- An attempt was made about 12:30 this morning to rob the general country store of Walker B. Adams Son here, in which is the Post Office. This store has several times been entered by burglars, and as a precautionary measure a system of burglar alarms was arranged recently connecting the store with Walker B. Adams's residence, about 300 yards away.

The first theatrical production of the new season has been made with prodigious success. Clay Greene and David Belasco's melodrama called "Under the Polar Star" thrilled and delighted an audience that fairly jammed the big Academy last night. It will make a fortune for its authors and the bold and energetic young impresario, William A. Brady, who has dared to produce it in a splendid manner.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- At the National tennis tournament the attendance was larger than on Wednesday. The weather was excellent. In the matches in the second round, the one between Richard Stevens and Budlong was largely a contest between the back and forward styles of play, one bringing into exhibit the distinctive qualities of the two styles of play.

A departure from the line of established general agencies, and occupying a field sui generis, is that pursued by the firm known as Albert Frank Co., whose principal business is financial and similar advertising. It has never had a competitor which can be considered as such, nor does it, save in the most infrequent of cases, ever come into direct conflict with other houses.

LONDON, Aug. 20. -- Gen. John Wimburn Laurie, M.P., will sail to-morrow in the Allan Line steamer Parisian from Liverpool for Montreal. He is going to Ottawa in connection with the plan for the establishment of a new line of fast mail steamers, and also to discuss the question of extending the naval-reserve system to the colonies.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 20. -- The first woman's train in the world left here to-day for the Thousand Islands over the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad. The train is run by the Woman's Christian Association of this city, who formed themselves into a tourist company for the purpose of running the train and also operating the steamboats on the St. Lawrence River during this personally conducted tour.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- The first of the routine business of the Bar Association was the report of the Committee on Jurisprudence and Law Reform, of which Senator Gray of Delaware is Chairman. He reported progress, and asked further time.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Conqueror, F.W. Vanderbilt; Strangler, Mrs. George Lewis; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg; Clermont, A. Van Sanivcord; Anita, John H. Flagler; Sen Bird, A. Boudonine; Alicea, H.M. Flagler; Orienta, E.R. Ladew; Katrina, Henry F. Noyes; sloop yacht Thistle, J. Howard Ford.

Preparations for the executive work of the Republican State Convention will be begun to-day at Saratoga. Chief Clerk Reuben L. Fox of the State Committee will go to that village to-day with the necessary stationery and a gripsack full of documents, which may be needed before the end of next week.

It behooves C.C. Parks to lower his pitch against Eastern insurance men, for that craft has turned on him for threatening to drive Eastern companies out of Colorado, with the prospect that he will be made ridiculous.

A pathetic interest attaches to the fact that only three days before her death Lady Tennyson, who had only shortly before assisted her son in the correction of proofs of the biographical portion of the life of the late Poet Laureate, expressed satisfaction that she had been enabled to make and finish such corrections.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 20. -- The Maine gold Democrats this afternoon held a mass convention in Congress Hall to choose twelve delegates to the Indianapolis Convention and to nominate six Electors to vote for the candidate for President to be nominated at Indianapolis.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 20. -- Word comes from the Bering Sea fleet that a Lieutenant of the Revenue Cutter Service will be left on the Island of St. Paul, with a detail of seamen, to guard that territory during the coming Winter. The officer selected for duty is said to be Second Lieut. D.F.A. De Otte.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Rumors were circulated this afternoon around, the old Wormley Hotel, which, after many years of prosperity, has fallen into desuetude and is now simply used as headquarters for the Populists, silverites, and the branch Democrats, that there was a bad break in the silver forces in the West.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 20. -- Mrs. George Ostrander and her infant had a narrow escape from being drowned off Eaton's Neck last evening. Ostrander started to sail across the Sound to Connecticut in an open skiff, taking his wife and child with him. A heavy wind from the northwest upset the skiff when two miles from shore.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 20. -- The conference of silver Democrats met this morning. There were about 100 gentlemen present, this city furnishing the greater number of delegates. Litchfield County was not represented, and Tolland County sent but two delegates.

Anson and his Chicago colts were looking for revenge yesterday at the Polo Grounds. They had an idea that the defeat administered by Joyce and his New-York baseball contingent on Wednesday was only a fluke. In the first seven innings of yesterday's game it looked as though the Chicago players would win, but in the eighth the New-York players found the ball easily, and won the game by a score of 9 to 5.

What took place at Saratoga yesterday is, in the proper sense of the word, unprecedented. We have had here before -- thirteen years before -- a Lord Chief Justice of England. Nobody who heard it and nobody who read it is likely to have forgotten the eloquent speech that was made by Lord COLERIDGE on the occasion of his reception by the Bar Association of New-York.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 20. -- The Sound-Money Democratic Convention, held in Music Hall this afternoon, was attended by nearly every leading Democrat in the State. The convention was made up of 877 delegates. Ex-Lieut. Gov. James R. Hindman was elected temporary Chairman, and then there was a loud demand for ex-Congressman W.C.P. Breckinridge, who sat on the stage with his wife.

Gen. TRACEY has just returned from the Green Mountain State, where he picked up a good deal of information about the general feeling toward BRYAN and Bryanism. He says that while the Democrats of Vermont are somewhat unsettled and disorganized, most of them will either vote for the sound-money candidate of the National Democracy or for MCKINLEY.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- All the cottagers gathered at Rockburst to-night for the ball given by Mrs. H. Mortliner Brooks in honor of Miss Brooks, who is one of the buds of the season. Mrs. Brooks, elegantly gowned in blue silk, received, assisted by Miss Brooks, who wore white, and Mrs. Charles H. Baldwin.

UPPER RED HOOK, Aug. 20. -- William J. Bryan threw down the gauntlet to-day to Major McKinley. It was a dignified challenge, for in it he refused to discuss the issues of the campaign with any person except the one that stands his equal in office-seeking ambition. He was asked if he intended to answer Mr. Cockran, and said in answer that he was receiving many invitations from prominent men to debate the silver question.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 20. -- The first session of the Eighth Parliament of the Dominion of Canada met at 3 o'clock this afternoon. His Excellency the Governor General proceeded to the Senate Chamber and, taking his seat upon the throne, the members of the House of Commons being present, declared Parliament in session in the following speech:
WHITESTONE, L.I., Aug. 20. -- Four places were entered by burglars in this place last night. Not much was secured, and it is believed the same gang committed all the burglaries.

ST. PETERSBURG, Aug. 20. -- The St. Petersburg astronomical expedition which was sent to Tornea, Finland, to observe the recent total eclipse of the sun, has been very successful. Members of the expedition have telegraphed here that they were enabled to get ten excellent photographs of the corona.

The Free Employment Bureau established by the State at 331 East Fourteenth Street on July 1 has resulted very satisfactorily thus far. Superintendent Bealin is kept busy receiving applications for labor and help, and up to date has 10,000 applications on his books. He has secured 200 positions.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- No greater ovation was ever given to any speaker in Saratoga than that accorded Lord Russell, Chief Justice of England, when he entered Convention Hall at 10:25 o'clock this morning to address the American Bar Association in their nineteenth annual convention.

The public is singing "America" a good deal these days. Do you know what that means? It means hope for those who believe in sound money, good government, unsullied National honor. The more America the less Bryan.
CHRISTIANA, Norway, Aug. 20. -- Dr. Nansen's arctic exploring steamer Fram has arrived safely at Skjervoe, a fishing post on the bay, near the North Cape.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 20. -- The Republicans of Plymouth opened the political campaign this evening, in Standish Guards Armory, with a large crowd present. E.B. Atwood presided, and the Rev. Frank W. Gunsaulus, President of Armour Institute, Chicago, made the principal address.

Chairman Marcus A. Hanna of the Republican National Committee divided his time yesterday between the headquarters, a Madison Avenue, and the business/district. Cornelius N. Bliss, who is Treasurer of the National organization, acted as Mr. Hanna's escort on his down-town trip.

HAVANA, Aug. 20. -- The case of Gen. Jose Lorenzo Cepero, an American citizen, who was arrested in January last on board a steamer running between Clenfuegos and Batabano, has been transferred from the military to the civil authorities, and he will be tried by the High Criminal Court of Santa Clara.
The commandment, "Thou shalt not steal," thundered from Sinai and reiterated in the legislation of all nations, is no respecter of persons. [Mr. BRYAN at Madison Square Garden.]

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- At the convention of the Montgomery County Democracy at Fonda this afternoon the following delegates were chosen to the State Convention: F.J. Perkins, William J. Roser, Clinton Lampman. Alternates -- John G. Landon, T.C. Pegnim, Peter F. Mellis. The Congressional delegates were chosen as follows: E.J. Maxwell, A.A. McLaughlin, Alonzo Schuyler, Elias J. Eillthorpe, Robert Wemple.
The Tweed Ring stole fifty millions from the city, and it took Tammany seventeen years to live down the odium of its felonies and come again into possession of the great offices.

It is two generations ago since FANNY KEMBLE recorded her meeting in the United States with an English actor, of whom she naturally inquired how he liked the country, and who answered that he liked it pretty well, "except the confounded custom, mem, of perpendicular drinking."

A number of well-known New-York wholesale liquor dealers met in the office of P.W. Engs Sons, at 268 West Broadway, at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon for the purpose of taking steps toward the organization of an association for putting a stop to the overproduction of liquor in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20. -- Acting Secretary McAdoo of the Navy Department to-day detailed a board composed of the commander in chief of the North Atlantic Station, the chiefs of the Bureaus of Navigation and Ordnance, the President of the War College, and the Chief Intelligence Officer, to consider and revise the plans for the defense of the coast prepared at the Naval War College.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- The second Myopia team of Boston won the Newport Cups to-day, beating the second Meadowbrooks in a struggle that was not interesting till the last period, during which it was lively polo from start to finish. It was the finals in the tournament for teams whose aggregate handicap did not exceed twenty goals.

After a fairly firm opening the market drifted into dullness, with the tendency to lower prices. The foreign exchange market was decidedly firm, the demand rate being $4.35 3/4, against $4.85 yesterday. At to-day's rate the importation of gold without loss became impossible. There was no improvement in the money market.
Police Commissioner Parker was absent from the meeting of the board Wednesday, and in consequence a special session was held yesterday to settle the Inspectorship question.

-- The crew of the bark William Geake, which was wrecked at Biron's Island, in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, Aug. 2, have arrived at Halifax, N.S. The Geake encountered a gale July 31, was dismasted, and rendered helpless. She struck the rocks, and the crew took to the boats. The bark went to pieces, and nothing was saved. She had a full cargo of molasses from Barbados for Montreal, where the vessel was owned.

HAMILTON, Mass., Aug. 20. -- Entire absence from ostentation characterized the funeral of Miss Mary Abigail Dodge, (Gail Hamilton,) which was held from her home on this town at 8 o'clock this afternoon. Many message of sympathy from men and women of prominence have been received since her death, but few of them were able to come to the funeral.

Surrogate Arnold yesterday confirmed the report of ex-Surrogate Rastus S. Ransom, as referee, deciding that Mrs. Pamela Shepard Hovey is responsible for the loss of over $84,000 of the estate of her first husband, John F. Shepard, which was bequeathed to her son, Spencer Howard Shepard.

CHICAGO, Aug. 20. -- In the war on St. Paul rates, the Michigan Car Ferry Company has met the cut made last evening by the Lake Michigan and Lake Superior Transportation Company, thus doing away with all differentials heretofore allowed the latter line on account of being compelled to break bulk and absorb marine insurance.

A motion for an injunction was argued in the Supreme Court, before Justice Pryor, yesterday in an action brought by Dr. Cyrus Edson, formerly of the Health Department, against the Ammonol Chemical Company of New-Jersey and Dr. Allen E. Still and F.W. Stemmler.

Prof. Gregoire Tocilesco of the University of Bucharest and Chief Director of the National Museum, has recently visited Western Europe on a mission for the Rumanian Government to the principal scientific and archaeological societies. At the recent congress of the Royal Archaeological Institute at Canterbury, the professor gave an account of his researches in the Debrudshe and of the extensive excavation which he has carried out during several years.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 21. -- Much satisfaction was expressed at the National Democratic Party Headquarters to-day over the fact that the President's Cabinet will be represented at the Indianapolis Convention.
BELAIR, Md., Aug. 21. -- D.C. Wharton-Smith of Harford County and Franklin. Stokes of Philadelphia have been appointed receivers for the Susquehanna Water Power and Paper Company of Harford County.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 21. -- The stock yards branch of the American National Bank, which is situated on the second floor of the Live Stock Exchange, was robbed of $2,000 in cash this morning.

FORT WORTH, Aug. 21. -- A report has gained currency here that A.W. Terrell, United States Minister to Turkey, either had resigned, or would tender his resignation soon. Capt. J. Terrell, the Minister's brother, says that he does not believe the rumor. If his brother has resigned, or intended to resign, he has not been informed.

Prof. Peellmann of Bonn, with the characteristic industry of his nation, has been reducing the Rougon-Macquart problem to a matter of statistics. He declares that he has traced the posterity of an alcoholic ancestress from the date of her death, early in the century, to the present day. Her descendants number 834, out of whom he has been able to get the life record of 709.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Aug. 21. -- News was received here to-day that S. Tomioka, who was in San Diego a few weeks ago as private secretary to President Asano of the Toyo Kisen Kaisha Steamship Company of Japan, has been in the City of Mexico for a week, seeking information as to the running of steamers along the Mexican coast as far south as San Benito.

LONDON, Aug. 21. -- A cablegram received from Santa Catharina, Brazil, says the American ship Willie Rosenfeld, commanded by Capt. Dunphy, which sailed from New-York April 23 for San Francisco has foundered 400 miles off the coast. Part of the crew were saved and landed there, but two boats containing fourteen persons are missing.

Patrolman John J. Bannon of the Mercer Street Precinct was placed on trial before Commissioner Andrews yesterday on charges of clubbing Michael J. Gildea, a waiter, in front of the Dairy Kitchen in Fourteenth Street, on the night of July 20. The case was brought to the attention of the Commissioners by citizens.

Having tried in vain since early Spring to induce the railroad companies to readjust rates on grain to the seaboard, so that shippers from New-York may stand on a level with those from other ports, the Produce Exchange, through its Grain Committee, has applied to the Inter-State Commerce Commission for relief.

The queer plank about reciprocity in the St. Louis platform, it has now become quite plain, was not inserted unadvisedly or lightly. The queerness of the plank is extreme, especially in the statement with which it begins that "protection and reciprocity are twin measures of Republican policy."

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- The thirty-footers raced to-day for the cup given by Gerald Paget, owner of the English yacht Rosemary, and the Vaquero won. To-day she was again sailed by her owner, H.B. Duryea. Mrs. Duryea sailed on the Rosemary with the donor of the trophy. Mrs. W. Butler Duncan, Jr., sailed on the Wawa with James Stillman. The wind was blowing freshly from the southwest, and the sea was choppy.

ALBANY, Aug. 21. -- The reception to Candidate Bryan on the occasion of his visit to this city on Tuesday next promises to be as frosty as any in his experience, from a Democratic standpoint. Fearful of this result, the Bryan followers have decided not to consider the event of any political effect whatever, and urge the citizens generally to aid in the demonstration.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- In the new edition of the pamphlet issued by the Democratic Congressional Committee, entitled "Money of the Constitution," will be found the following extract, which shows conclusively, as the committee believes, that President Grant had no knowledge of the demonetization of silver up to the time of his sending his message to Congress, which was in January, 1875.

The routine of the Republican State Convention, which will be held in Saratoga next week, has been nearly settled. According to the present plans Frank S. Black of Troy will be chosen the temporary, and Gen. Stewart L. Woodford of Brooklyn the permanent, Chairman. They are the favorites of the organization Republicans, who will be so thoroughly in control that it is not thought by the antis worth while to make a contest.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Ex-Gov. Flower was elected President of the Sound-Money Democratic Club at its meeting tonight. The organization has over 150 members. In his speech of acceptance, Mr. Flower said:

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- Commodore and Mrs. Gerry nearly played havoc with the Casino dance to-night with their sailing party on the Electra. Still, there was a fair-sized company present, and an enjoyable dance resulted.

There were nearly 700 cabin passengers on the big Cunard steamship Lucania, which arrived at her pier yesterday afternoon. Besides the influx of returning American tourists there were a great many prominent Europeans aboard. The Lucania made a fine run, though not a record-breaking trip, and her passengers enjoyed a fine-weather voyage throughout.
All the leading cycle clubs of the metropolitan district have scheduled runs for to-morrow, as follows:

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 21. -- This was a very delightful day, the coolness bringing nearly every one out. The bicycles to-day upon Ocean Driveway were so numerous as to give the impression that they were monopolizing the whole avenue.

The Indian Harbor Yacht Club will have a special regatta on Saturday, Sept. 12, off Greenwich, Conn. There will be races for the 34, 21, and 15 foot classes, all cabin catboats, all open catboats, and all yawis. Commodore Charles T. Wills has offered a prize for the cabin cats, Rear Commodore George G. Tyson a prize for the twenty-one-footers, and William Stewart Tod a prize for the open cats.

Robert Hilliard, the actor, who was arrested Thursday night at Thirty-fourth Street and Broadway by Policeman Urquhart, on the complaint of James McDonald, of 761 Seventh Avenue, a conductor of a Broadway cable car, for refusing to pay a fare, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct, and after a hearing was discharged.
The Republican Assembly District Conventions for the election of delegates to the Saratoga Convention were held in the thirty-five Assembly Districts of the city last night.

AUBURN, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The Republican campaign in Cayuga is now under way, all the nominations having been made and the county organization perfected. Democratic conventions are never a matter of much moment in Cayuga, since only a tidal wave can give a Democrat an office. This year will be no exception to the rule.
OMAHA, Neb., Aug. 21. -- The gold Democrats of Nebraska named a delegation to the Indianapolis Convention last night.
BOSTON, Aug. 21. -- The Boston Commercial Bulletin will say to-morrow regarding Western Union and Bell Telephone:
