CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- Managers of the Western roads held a conference in Commissioner Midgley's office yesterday to brace up rates on packing house products from the Missouri River, but no action grew out of the meeting. Yesterday the Santa Fe Road put in a rate on provisions to the Atlantic seaboard of 5 cents per. hundred pounds, Missouri River to Chicago, on export business only.

In his annual address as President of the American Bar Association Mr. MOORFIELD STOREY devoted his attention chiefly to an evil which has grown to enormous proportions in this country in the reorganization of insolvent railroad corporations. This process presents the anomaly of receiverships in the interest of debtors instead of creditors, and the rehabilitation of the property for the benefit of those who very often are responsible for bringing it to wreck.

The Bryan headquarters in this city have been open several weeks, and not one representative New-York Democrat has been seen about the place. "JIMMY" O'BRIEN goes there, and sometimes SULZER. But compare the short list of the daily visitors with the list of well-known Democrats who were in Madison Square Garden when BOURKE COCKRAN spoke for sound money.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 21. -- The home team took a spurt to-day, and by good playing, defeated Hartford. Nops was effective in the box, and Mertes of the Philadelphia League, and Fuiler, late of the Athletics, of the same city, rendered valuable assistance at left and first, respectively. Score:

BALTIMORE, Aug. 21. -- "It is very curious and interesting," said a leading Democrat to the correspondent of THE NEW-YORK TIMES to-day, "how the papers and the people of the country fail to understand the perplexity of Senator Gorman in the money fight. It is known that he is personally for sound money, but politically he is pretending to help the silverites.

Henry B. Sire had a petition in the Supreme Court, before Justice Pryor, yesterday, in which he sought to have a judgment entered against him on July 12, 1893, set aside on the ground that he had never been served with the summons and complaint in the action. It was also alleged by his attorney that the cause of action shown was such a simple one that no sane man would have defaulted.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Mrs. Wilson Terry of Stillwater was missed from her home early this morning. A domestic found two of the children, girls, aged six and four years, asleep in a crib, but the youngest child, two months old, had been drowned by being plunged head first, into a slop jar.

She was young -- of course she was pretty -- and she was gayly attired, but she stepped on the Broadway smoking car the other day without attracting more than ordinary attention. The women themselves have demonstrated the fact and the officials of the road have acquiesced to a foregone conclusion that women may ride wherever they can and will.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 21. -- Assistant District Attorney John F. McIntyre of New-York, who is stopping at the Columbia with his family, has become involved in an altercation with a local Chinese laundryman. Mr. McIntyre called at the laundry to get some collars that he claimed the Chinaman had overlooked.
The Tammany Executive Committee will be called to meet at the Wigwam Thursday afternoon to make the final arrangements for the Buffalo Convention.

The actor who submitted to be arrested on Friday night rather than to submit to pay what he regarded as an unjust demand for an additional car fare has performed a public service. What HERBERT SPENCER called the criminal good nature of the American people is illustrated by the fact that there are few of us who will take a dollar's worth of trouble in order to resist an extortion of a nickel.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- This was the last day of the Orange County circuit trotting races. Fully 1,000 persons saw the different events run off. Summaries:

UPPER RED HOOK, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The Bryan and Sewall campaign will be opened in earnest to-morrow at Tivoli, in this county, by Mr. Bryan. With the exception of his Madison Square address, the speech he will deliver, it is said, will be the most important of his utterances since his nomination.

FRIDAY -- P.M. To-day's market was in control of professional operators, and as they are all bears just now, naturally prices declined. There was practically no commission-house business. Much interest was shown in the condition of the banks. The statement to be issued to-morrow is looked forward to with much interest, but it seems probable that the showing to be made will not be so bad as at one time expected.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 21. -- A threatening sky interfered with the attendance at the new Grand Circuit races to-day. The track was in a fine condition, notwithstanding the rain of the morning, and there were some good races. Surpal, a three-year-old stallion, was the star performer, giving Exploit a hard fight. Emma Offut was an easy winner in the second race.

The union and non-union Chinese laundrymen of the city have been at odds for several weeks. The union men declare that the non-union men are ruining the industry and lowering the prices, while the non-union men complain that their accuser's have formed a close corporation, in which only well-to-do Chinamen can become members.

A correspondent of The London Times who was at Vadso, No way, on Aug. 9 gives a graphic description of the sun's eclipse as seen from that point. The earliest contact of the moon with the sun, he says, was timed to take place at 43 seconds after 4 A.M. Shortly before this a gradual breaking of the clouds was welcomed, and occasional peeps of sunlight illumined different parts of the extensive landscape.

FAR ROCKAWAY, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- A small yellow cur, with bloodshot eyes, made its appearance on Central Avenue here about 3 o'clock this afternoon and caused considerable excitement. While on its way through the thoroughfare it bit at everything within its reach.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The sound-money Democrats of the Town of Rye met last evening at the Lyceum and formed an organization to maintain the principles of true Democracy during the campaign.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- The social side of the annual convention of the American Bar Association found a most auspicious close in the nineteenth annual banquet, held this evening in the ballroom of the Grand Union Hotel, and which was attended by 260 members of the legal fraternity.

Allusion has been made in some of the reviews of Lord Chief Justice Russell's address at Saratoga to the similarity of his invocation of public opinion, as a practical factor regulating the conduct of nations, to a like passage in one of Daniel Webster's speeches. The similarity is the more interesting for being apparently quite unconscious on the part of Lord Russell.
SAUGUS, Mass., Aug. 21. -- To-day was the fourth day of the August meeting at Franklin Park, and the conditions at the track could not have been better.
CHICAGO, Aug. 21. -- The usual confusion incident to "moving in" was observable at Democratic National headquarters in the Auditorium annex this afternoon.

Edward F.C. Young, as receiver of the National Cordage Company, has begun suit in the United States Circuit Court against James M. Waterbury, Caleb P. Marsh, Chauncey Marshall, Frank T. Wall, Elisha M. Fulton, and Willard P. Whitlock, alleging breach of trust and misconduct on the part of the defendants as officers and Directors of the company, and asking that they be made to account for their management of its affairs.

A sharp advance in the rate for call loans and a decline in sterling exchange comprised the most interesting features in the financial districts yesterday. Each bate closely on the money slination, for the tendency of each is to draw gold from Europe.

BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 21. -- The Democrats and Populists have agreed upon a basis of fusion. The nominations will be distributed as follows: To the Democrats, Presidential Electors, Supreme Court Justices, Governor, Attorney General, Treasurer, Mine Inspector. To the Populists, the Legislature, Senate, Congressman, Lieutenant Governor, Secretary of State, State Auditor, Superintendent of Public Instruction.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21. -- While the Republican State Convention will not meet till Tuesday next, the advance guard reached here to-day, and it is expected that there will be a very heavy arrival to-morrow. The first to reach here this morning were the boomers of Congressman F.S. Black of Troy.

QUEBEC, Aug. 21. -- A dispatch from Rimouski received here to-day states that the steamship Labrador, from Liverpool for Montreal, which passed that point to-day, signaled that Sir David MacPherson of Toronto, a member of the Dominon Senate and one of the best-known men in Canada, who was a passenger on board the Labrador, died last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- Further inquiry into the damage of the Brooklyn dry dock will be made before the findings of the court of inquiry are made public and orders fixing the responsibility for the accident are issued. Acting Secretary McAdoo, who has charge of the matter, made the following statement to-day:
John A. Magee died at the Hudson Street Hospital on Aug. 11 from insolation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- The Agricultural Department has published Circular No. 1, called forth by numerous inquiries, giving the acreage, production, and value of the principal farm crops, with other data, in the United States, from 1866 to 1895, inclusive. A few of the articles and average price per bushel are given:

Guy Sickels received a handful of red pepper in his eyes yesterday from a man who, it is said, sought to rob a drug store at 68 East Broadway. His scalp was also wounded, but he was able to continue at work after receiving medical attention.

BEDFORD STATION, N.Y., Aug. 21. -- Walker B. Adams, the senior partner of Adams Son, who was shot in the forehead by one of the burglars during the encounter on Thursday morning, after lying just twenty-four hours insensible in his home, died, at 1 o'clock this morning.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 21. -- The funeral of Mrs. John E. Parsons was held to-day from Trinity Episcopal Church at 2 P.M. after a short service at Stonover, Mr. Parsons's country seat. The services at the church were conducted by the Rev. Harold Arrowsmith, rector of the parish, and the Rev. William M. Grosvenor, rector of the Church of the Incarnation, New-York.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21. -- The American Bar Association met at 10:30 o'clock this morning for the concluding day's session. The first business was the election of officers for the ensuing year, as follows:

Hoarding of pig iron is an industry not commonly known, but its development of late has kept pace with the hoarding of gold, and those who are engaged count on returns less uncertain and probably larger than the collectors of the yellow metal can hope to realize.

BUFFALO, Aug. 21. -- Despite threatening weather, the attendance was good at the third day's Grand Circuit races here to-day, the card being an attractive one, containing, as it did, the unfinished 2:10 pace from yesterday, the 2:14 trot, the free-for-all trot, and the 2:11 class trot. A stiff wind up the track prevented any fast time from being made.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21. -- United States Senator Augustus Octavius Bacon of Georgia, who has been traveling through the Western States as far as San Francisco, and who is an ardent free-silver advocate, dropped some rather cold comfort at the branch Democratic headquarters here to-day, just before his departure for his home in Georgia.
The General Committee of the Democratic Party of Kings County held an enthusiastic sound-money meeting at the Criterion Theatre, Brooklyn, last night.

CHERBOURG, Aug. 21. -- A decision was rendered to-day by the Commercial Maritime Court in the matter of the collision, Feb. 29 last, between the General Transatlantic Line steamer La Bourgogne and the Allan Line steamer Allsa, which resulted in the sinking of the latter vessel. The court holds that the Captain of La Bourgogne was not to blame for the collision, which was entirely a "peril of the sea."
" You say you want to get at the capitalists and make them smart a little, and that is why you propose to vote for Bryan?"
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

Senator Quay is expected at Republican National Headquarters in a few days. He is now in the South on a vacation. Secretary Osborne of the National Committee received a telegram from him yesterday, in which the Senator said he should come North in a few days, and his arrival is looked for before Sept. 1.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21. -- The beautiful weather continued to-day. As the National tennis tournament progresses and the lists narrow toward the finals the interest increases, and this morning's attendance was the largest since the opening day.

" Jack" Clark is a stout boy of fourteen years, living at Sherman, Me. He goes out after the cows every night and drives them home to the tie-up, always in the greatest safety, but the other night he had an adventure which has led to the substitution of his older brother in the gathering of the kine o'nights.

" Why should not women smoke?" asks a woman with a phliosophic turn of mind. "Except for the feeling of horror some people have about it -- the feeling that a woman who smokes has lost every trace of womanliness -- I can really see no harm in it. It might even become a dainty and pretty practice with a graceful woman.

Those of us who have had some acquaintance with the navy and merchant service, as well as the great trading ports, view with some alarm the considerable risks the country incurs by the employment of aliens in the very maritime service we wish to protect from the foreigner. The anomaly of the position can only be appreciated by those who know to what extent foreigners are employed.

One of the results of the hard times is the total extermination for the time being, around this neighborhood at least, of the industry of building steam pleasure yachts and the pleasure of sailing them. Among the yachts now offered for sale here are the Idler, Azalea, Argo, and Wayward. The Idler is the property of Senator McMillan.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 22. -- The social functions have this week far exceeded those of last week, and to-night the round of gayety has culminated in two grand balls. The subscription ball at the Stockton and the invitation ball at the Lafayette last night were the biggest hops of the season. All over the place there have been bowling parties, dinners and private dances.

After the days of excessive heat, when it was only safe to stay at home under some shelter from the overpowering sun, it is pleasant to have cool, breezy hours that make it a pleasure to go about again. Those of you who are in the city will like to take a trip to the tomb of Gen. Grant, which is now well worth seeing.

The Jannisaries are unique in the history of the world. Nothing like them has ever been known in the Constitution of any State. We think of them somehow in association with the Mamelukes of Egypt, but though there were some points in common between them, they differed widely in their character and aim.
MONTCLAIR, Aug. 22. -- An enjoyable smoker and watermelon cut were held Tuesday night by the William S. Pierson Camp of the Sons of Veterans in Grand Army Hall, Bloomfield.

A parody must necessarily be sportive, or it would not belong to the great family of the ludicrous; but the laughter, or the smile, which it excites need not be at the expense of the composition imitated. Pope speaks of his imitation of one of the satires of Horace as a parody; but the laugh which he raises does not fall upon Horace.

CENTRE MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 22. -- The ball of the East Bay Yacht Club was one of the greatest social successes of the season. The yacht club is one of the favorite organizations of this section and its social affairs are always looked forward to with pleasure.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the American Line Steamship Paris were the wife and daughter of Samuel L. Clemens, (Mark Twain,) whose eldest daughter, Olivia Susan Clemens, died on Tuesday night last, at the home in Hartford, Conn.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 22. -- The most notable political demonstration of the campaign occurred here at noon to-day when 1,200 voters from New-Castle, Ellwood, and other points in Lawrence County, Penn., arrived on two special trains and, enlivened by the music of two bands, a drum corps, a calliope, and a brass howitzer, marched up to the McKinley residence to call on the Republican candidate for the Presidency.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug 22. -- Miss Katharine Donovan or Lackawack, N.Y., is being entertained by her cousin, Miss Nora Walsh of Avenue D. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Eddy and family of Avenue C and West Thirty-sixth Street, are rusticating at High View, Sullivan County, N.Y. James Seymour, eldest son of Mayor Egbert Seymour, is rapidly convalescing at his home on Avenue C from a serious illness.

SATURDAY -- P.M. Speculation to-day waited upon the bank statement. It was published earlier than usual and made a showing by no means so gloomy as had been expected. It is true that the banks lost $2,400,000 in cash, but legal requirements were minimized by a loss in deposits of over $9,000,000.

WOODSTOCK, Conn., Aug. 22. -- At the flag raising to-day under the auspices of the Woodstock McKinley and Hobart Campaign Club, of which Dr. George Austin Bowen, Surgeon General of Connecticut, is President, there was a large attendance and enthusiastic speeches were made. Among the letters read was the following from Major McKinley:
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Mrs. Caroline C. Hussey entertained the inmates of the House of the Good Shepherd at her home, 142 Arlington Avenue, East Orange, Wednesday afternoon.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 22. -- County conventions to select delegates to Democratic Congressional Conventions were held in every county in Alabama to-day. So far as could be ascertained from reports received to-night the result would seem to be as follows:

The Democratic Honest-Money League has accepted the challenge issued by the Central New-York Chautauqua for a debate on the money question. It will take place on the grounds of the assembly at Tully Luke on Aug. 27 and 28.

" There is no new thing under the sun," says Ecclesiastes. "That which hath been done is that which shall be done; and that which hath been is that which shall be. Is there a thing whereof men say: See, this is new? It hath been already in the ages which were before us."

DELAWARE WATER GAP, Penn., Aug. 22. -- The hop at the Kittatinny last Saturday evening was the most brilliant affair of the season. The much-talked-of aquatic event, which was to have taken place on the river opposite the bathing bench on Tuesday afternoon, has been postponed until next Saturday on account of the extremely cool weather.

The rain caused a postponement of the Atalanta Wheelmen's race meet at Waverly Park yesterday afternoon. Fully fifty racing men, unable to ascertain beforehand that the meet would not be held, gathered about the entrance to the park shortly before 1 o'clock and patiently waited in the drizzle for the gates to open. The club had no representative present, and after a wait of over an hour an indignation meeting was held.

FORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 22. -- Work has commenced in connection with the erecting of batteries on Puget Sound. So they parties are at present in the field, a large party being engaged in the vicinity of Morristowne Point and Admiralty Head. Under the last fortification appropriation $50,000 was made immediately available for the defense of Puget Sound.

It is popularly supposed that a person never gets something for nothing, but the axiom does not seem to apply to the employes of certain large corporations in this city. Wealthy companies which are generally supposed to grind their dependents to dust have been found dispensing favors of various kinds, so that bank clerks and other employes have begun to believe themselves in clover.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 22. -- Marblehead the quaint and picturesque, Marblehead the rock-bound, sea-girl old fishing port, has long been the delight of the New-England poet, of artist and story teller, of yachtsman and Summer tourist. But Marblehead has made history, and the memorials in the town connected with her names of National fame alone are worth a vacation journey to see and consider.

ALBANY, Aug. 22. -- The Albany Mihollandites, under the lead of John F. Montagnani, to-day went through the farce of sending delegates and alternates to Saratoga, to contest the seats of the regularly elected Republican delegates. The conven tion was held in the City Hall, and thirty-three delegates were present. No roll was called, and it was taken for granted that these thirty-three represented themselves and some others.

The international yacht races between the Canada of the Royal Canadian Yacht Club and the Vincedor of the Lincoln Park Yacht Club of Chicago will begin to-morrow at Toledo, and will be the most interesting yachting event on the lakes this year.

Considerable interest is displayed at Paris in the engagement of the Duc d'Orleans to the Archduchess Maria Dorothea, the political results of such an alliance being even the subject of some speculation. As an instance of this, says a Paris dispatch to The London Telegraph, a very curious story which has been put into circulation may be mentioned.

WATKINS, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The Schuyler County Democratic Convention, held here this afternoon, elected Frank L. Moran, John G. Reynolds, and M.T. Fish Delegates to the State Convention. They were instructed for John B. Stanchfield for Governor. George W. McMemer was nominated for the Assembly.

SHELTER ISLAND, Aug. 22. -- Among the many yachts which have been in the harbor this week were the Stranger, Clermont, Lagonda, Dimon, Emerald, Idlewild, Rialto, and Nixie. The weekly handicap tournament at the Shelter Golf Club court is being played this afternoon.

Morris Spigel, twelve years old, who unintentionally ran away from his home at Germantown Junction, near Philadelphia, yesterday, had an experience that will probably lead him to stay at home when he again finds himself under the paternal roof, but that will not be for a month at least.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Mrs. Lew Wah has filed in the Chancery Court a petition for divorce from her husband. Lew Wah, who conducts a Chinese laundry at 284 Mulberry Street. The petitioner was formerly Lizzie Fenerstein, who lived with her widowed mother, Mrs. Kate Fenerstein, at 161 Walnut Street.

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 22. -- There were some notable germans on the lake this week, at the Lake House, Marion House, and the Sagamore. The one at the Lake House was probably the most artistic affair ever given here. The large parlor was handsomely decorated with evergreens, vines, sweet peas and other flowers.

Marcus A. Hanna, tired out with several days' hard work in this city, took the 6 o'clock train for Boston last evening, and will spend to-day with his brother-in-law, J.F. Rhodes, at Marblehead, Mass. His lieutenants say he will be back to-morrow.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Frederick Gardner, the General Secretary of the Orange Valley Young Men's Christian Association, is the originator of another novel plan to provide work and shelter for the poor of this vicinity. He is accepting offers of the use of woodland properly in the mountains and vicinity from property owners who wish the land cleared.

Mr. Pritchard has his liking for bric-a-brac, and as you began "Without Sin" you remember Balzac's "Cousin Pons." Ephraim Levinge's Art Gallery in old Bond Street is cluttered with Sheraton's chef d'oeuvres, and there are Van Eycks and Limoges and Dresden and Sevres, and all those magnificences "which one blazed in the imperial apartments of the Pekin palace."
A life went out like a candle yesterday morning under the sidewalk of Fifth Avenue, just below Thirty-fifth Street, and one of the minor tragedies of life in a great city came to its end.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- A freight train on one of the east-bound tracks of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railway was partially wrecked just below the passenger station at 3 o'clock this morning. The train broke apart, and the engineer backed the engine and the cars that remained attached to it up the track to meet the section of the train that had been left behind.

Have you ever tasted of paprika? It is Hungarian pepper-pungent, sweet, and same color. Maurus Jokal flavors his "Black Diamonds" with this special condiment. Now, one of the peculiarities of this seasoning is that for its perfect enjoyment or appreciation that can only be had where it is produced.

At music halls the songs, or those with the best chances of being popular, are written chiefly by only two or three writers; and to this fact sometimes is attributed what must be called their painful monotony, or, at the least unhappy paucity, of theme. You have the mother-in-law, and the mother-in-law, of course, is a nuisance and an obstacle.

Great interest naturally centred in the bank statement, about which some very gloomy ideas had been entertained, which correspondingly affected the market on Friday. When the statement appeared yesterday, showing only a nominal decrease in the surplus reserve, the small traders bought back the stocks they had sold and the market closed with a fractional, improvement.

Henry Richardson is under arrest in Brooklyn on a charge trying to purchase from P.W. Taylor Co., jewelers, $500 worth of goods with a note for that amount purporting to have been drawn by J.H. Baker Co. of 14 South Street, this city. This note, it is claimed, is a forgery.

Twenty-five years ago Nantucket was asleep. Fire and war had long since destroyed her industry; and not yet had her fame as a Summer resort gone forth. There was an air of unreality about the town, consonant with the soft mirage which off a uplifted her gaunt windmill and quaint gambrel roofs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- Hoke Smith, Secretary of the Interior, will retire from the Cabinet Sept. 1. His resignation was sent to the President a few hours after the action of the Chicago Convention became known to the country.

The family of the late Shah Nussir-ed-din was a large one. He had three legitimate or Akhal wives and some fifty concubines. Many of these latter were merely wives in name, for a lady who has once entered the royal anderun, or harem, only leaves it at death, or when the Shah, us a special mark of favor, gives her in marriage to a subject.

Although he receives but casual attention from hundreds of thousands of the inhabitants of this great metropolis, the local expressman is almost as necessary an adjunct to almost every business interest as the postman or the electric spark. Upon it's reliability and promptness, often requiring dexterous skill and wide diversity of information, depend, to a wonderful extent, the success of millions of invested capital.

After he had frankly stated him objection, his Superior meditated for a while and then told him mildly:

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 22 -- It is believed here that A.W. Terrell, United States Minister to Turkey, either has resigned or soon will place his resignation in the hands of the President, and within two months will return to this country. This information is said to come direct from Mrs. Terrell, who gave it out, it is said, not expecting it would be made public.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 22. -- It has been a weekof triumph for Mrs. R.W. Taller, as both the benefits arranged by her have been great social and financial successes. Tuesday evening, at the Boys' Club tableaus, the audience included nearly all of the world here known as fashionable, and the actors were mostly from the Spring House and Earlington guests.

The desirability of smooth pavements was never better shown to cyclists than on the occasion of a recent visit to Dayton, Ohio, by a party of New-York wheelmen. They were returning from the National Meet at Louisville, and stopped off for a day to look over a city of which they had heard much.

In the English translation of the work of the lamented and lamentable Friedrich Nietzsche Vol. III follows with appropriate lack of logic after Vol. XI., while Vols. X., IX., and VI, will issue from the presses in the order named. Logical sequence would be entirely out of place in an edition of this inspired German lunatic, who threw logic to the winds in all his writings.

Count Gruloff, an alleged magnate from St. Petersburg, but in reality a common-place Frenchman named Gerard, has been arrested, together with a woman called Marie Despres, who passed as his wife, for heartless swindling. They not only defrauded tradesmen of goods, but obtained considerable sums of money from two old Flemish dames who believed them to be wealthy and influential members of the old Muscovite nobility, and who are now in Paris almost destitute.

The "Monomotapa," which forms the subject of Mr. A. Wilmot's new book, is the modern Rhodesia. The work to which Mr. Rider Haggard contributes a short introduction, has nothing to do with the Chartered Company. It ends with 1830, when the last Dominican monk left Monomotapa, and is entirely concerned with the identification of the land with the "Ophir" of Solomon and the ancient Phoenicians.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 22 -- The English Lutheran Church society of this city will lay the cornerstone of its new edifice, in Bridge Street, between Seventh and Eight Avenues, to-morrow at 8 o'clock P.M. It will be the twenty-second church building in Mount Vernon.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Albert George Whitehead, the Irish-American dynamiter who, with Dr. Gallagher, also an American, was sentenced in June, 1883, to life imprisonment, was released from Portland Prison at 7 o'clock this morning, and immediately started for Weymouth, where he took a train for London.

Henry Siegel of the Siegel-Cooper Company has been interviewed by a reporter for The Dry Goods Chronicle on the prospects of success in the new dry goods store which his firm has erected on Sixth Avenue between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets. In the course of his interview he says:

Women are just emerging from the egg of suppression; it is natural that, like newly hatched chickens, they should chirp a little just at first. "There are so few of us who have distinguished ourselves; why should we not the ourselves serious and responsible airs?" Women are terribly self-conscious; directly one of them attains to celebrity she feels the eyes of all the world upon her, and she at once ceases to be natural.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- "Tom" Butler, the hero of the National meet, failed to win a first prize in the cycle races held here this afternoon. He qualified in the quarter and one mile open events, but failed in the finals to get a portion of the money. "Tom" Cooper was also beaten out for the big prizes. Ray Macdonald of New-York got second place in the final heat of the quarter.

BEDFORD STATION, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Coroner Charles E. Birch of White Plains held his inquest into the death of Walker B. Adams this afternoon in the hall over Adams's grocery store near the railroad station. A large crowd collected about the rooms and doors.
Gordon McKay, with whom shoe manufacturers were once better acquainted than now, was recently honored with the degree of Master of Arts by Harvard College.

TUESDAY, Aug. 25. -- By William Kennelly, foreclosure sale, Charles D. Olendorf, referee, Bainbridge Avenue, north side, 100 feet west of Suburban Street, 76 by 122.8 by 75 by 112.9, two-story frame dwelling; also lot 36 by 100 at southwest corner of Suburban Street and Briggs Avenue. Due on judgment, $1,185.

The coming election in this city will be held under the provisions of Chapter 909 of the Laws of 1896, known as the Election law, which differs in a number of respects from the law under which the last general election was held.

" Patsy" in life had first place in the affections of Miss Alice Howard of 79 East Tenth Street. Had "Patsy" lived, a suit against Miss Howard to recover $125 would not, in all likelihood, have been instituted.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- Because of the talk of lynching the Adams assailants, Sheriff Johnson of Westchester County got a little anxious last night about the safety of the prisoners, and, with Deputies Breese, Atkinson, and Underhill, drove up from White Plains and staid here all night. They were reinforced by deputies who had been sworn in yesterday afternoon by Justice Crane, and so everything remained quiet during the night.

In the eighteenth century the editor of The Daily Courant was deliciously amusing when he wrote: "I will give no comments of my own in this paper, as I assume that other people have sense enough to make reflections for themselves!" Henry Bate, the editor of The Morning Post, never picked his words with care.

WEST POINT, Aug. 22. -- Light overcoats have become fashionable during the past week, and robes and wraps are in constant demand. The sudden drop in temperature, while not agreeable to most people, gives delight to the hotel proprietors, as the mountain and seaside resorts are colder than the "Highlands," and visitors flock to this place in large numbers.

At this time, when the State Department is making an effort to improve the Consular Service of the United States, an executive essay, dealing with the reform of the imperial Consular Service of Germany, which has been forwarded by the Rhineland and Westphalian Union for the protection of the empire's industrial interests, is apropos.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The third weekly handicap for the cup given by Theodore A. Havemeyer, President of the National Golf Association, was won to-day by his son, Harry O. Havemeyer, Jr. He had the best gross score. The scores were as follows:

The Gypsum Empress is one of a fleet of Nova Scotlan schooners which bring gypsum from Windsor, N.S., to New-York. She's a stanch tern of 780 tons, Another of the fleet is the Gypsums King, and there are other gypsums, but this story has to do with the Empress.

HILLSDALE, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Mme. Eglantine Gaudin, the reputed heiress of 17,000,000, who had probably received more proposals of marriage than any other woman in America, was married this afternoon to Bernardo Malizia, a widower, in her home at this place.

The Lord Chief Justice of England, Lord Russell of Killowen, delivered an address to the American Bar Association upon a topic chosen by himself, namely, international arbitration. The fact that Lord Russell selected this as his subject is tangible evidence of the genuine vitality of the movement for world-wide peace.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 22. -- Harry Payne Whitney and his charming bride are expected to reach Adirondack Lodge, about seven miles from Lenox Village, on the top of October Mountain, next Wednesday. They will remain here for an indefinite time. For the first two weeks they will live in a very romantic way in a canvass tent built by professional guides from Paul Smith's, in the Adirondacks.

What is a carbon? This is, perhaps, a difficult question to answer. Of one thing we are certain, namely, that in may respects it is similar to the reindeer of northern Europe; not only in appearance, but in characteristics, migratory nature, and speed as well. It has some of the characteristics of our American deer, and many of the moose.

There is promise of a civilized system of disposing of the household refuse of the city, and there ought to be a general co-operation of citizens and authorities to give it success. The barbarous plan of dumping a foul mixture of ashes, garbage, and street sweepings into the very gateway of the harbor should be abandoned as speedily as possible.

During the New-York camp season at Peekskill this year, which came to an end on Aug. 15, there has been a total of 6,512 officers and men on duty, which is a little more than half the aggregate strength of the force. The attendance, it is believed, was the largest in the history of the camp. In the percentage of attendance of regiments.

James F. McGovern, seven years old, of 1,844 Park Avenue, was found dead near the tracks of the New-York Central Railroad at One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Park Avenue at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
Andrew Freedman, as receiver of the Manhattan Athletic Club, by order of Justice Martin L. Stover, made his report to Referee Isaac Fromme last Wednesday.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Ninety-four years ago to-day John Insley Blair saw the light of the world on a farm two miles below Belvidere, in this State. Friends begun to call on him before 10 o'clock this morning, and congratulations were pressed upon him in person and by messenger and post until after nightfall.

At one period in the history of racing-say thirty to forty years ago -- there where class of rich men ("plungers" they were called) who lost and won immense sums. Sir Joseph Hawley was one of the most famous and successful; the Marquis of Hastings had the most riotous and tragic career; the late Sir Robert Peel was one of the most recent survivors.
After a long and useful life the old steamship Dessoug has gone to the marine graveyard at Cow Bay, Long Island, where she will be broken up, and whatever metal or other parts of value sold.

Mammy may be sixty-five, as black as the ace of spades, and with the whitest of souls. She is as broad as she is long, but with the hand and foot of a Princess of the blood, and if Mammy has a weakness, it is in regard to these physical distinctions.
FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- The past week was a red-letter one at this resort. Rooms were in demand at a premium.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- The polo game to-day was a special match for special cups arranged for a wind-up of the coaching parade. An effort was made to get together a team strong enough to cope with the Meadowbrooks, but it failed. The only feature was the attendance, which was the largest seen on the grounds in years.

Catherine Hayes, of 212 East Sixty-fifth Street, who was arrested on Friday night on a charge of waywardness, was paroled by Magistrate Kudlich, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday, for a week, in the custody of her mother, Mrs. Mary Hayes.

BARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- William J. Bryan opened the political campaign in earnest to-day at Madalin, a town in Dutchess County. He delivered his first actual campaign speech since his nomination, and showed an earnestness in delivery closely resembling that which brought about the demonstration in his honor at Chicago the day before he was selected as the Democratic standard bearer.
According to tradition, the true Mahdi will be preceded by sixty forerunners -- John Baptists or Eliases -- called Babs, (Bab means the door, through which enters Messiah.)

When Louis Becke's first book, "By Reef and Palm," made its appearance, all the critics decided that the stories about the South Sea Islands which it contained were good ones, while a few, more enthusiastic, declared that the tales were altogether out of the common, and with difficulty refrained from linking at once the name of their author with that of Stevenson.

Suppose some of our agitators should take the trouble to study Lord RUSSELL as a possible and actual, if not a representative, English product. We hear a good deal of talk these days of the danger to this country of following the lead of England, of being under "English domination," and of having the springs of our National life defiled by English infiltration.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 22. -- The rate war between the Bay Line and the York River Line broke out afresh to-day, when the latter announced that it would meet the cut in passenger rates put into effect by the Bay Line July 17, and would go under the latter's cut in freight rates on Norfolk business.

LI HUNG CHANG has actually left Europe, and is on his way to this country. That a Chinaman of the highest rank and position should have undertaken such a voyage of exploration as that of which the present is the last or the penultimate stage is a fact which, it is to be hoped, will appear hereafter more significant than it does now.

Gen. Wilson's volume comprises in the main letters of the well-known heroes and heroines -- Abolard and Heloise, Anne Boleyn, Queen Elizabeth, Mme. de Sevigne, Richard Steele, Lady Mary Wortley Montagu, Sterne, Mrs. Thrale, Goethe, Scott, Keats, and many others. The introductions which he has written outline the circumstances in which the letters were produced, and here and there give other information.

We should be pleased to see the religious press give generous expression to their sympathy with the suffering Cretans. It is not much of an island for missionaries, but the inhabitants of Crete are human beings. They suffer as acutely under Turkish misrule and massacre as our friends the Armenians.

The annual regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club was sailed yesterday off Larchmont, and was one of the best races for small boats of the year. Thirty-seven yachts started and made races in fourteen classes. It was not a good day for a yacht race, but the weather rather favored the yachtsmen.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- At Nottingham to-day the Robin Hood Plate of 150 sovereigns, for two-year-olds, maidens at the time of entry, the second to receive 10 sovereigns out of the plate; five furlongs, straight, was won by Mr. C.S. Newton's ch.c. Sybarite, by Satiety, out of Satire. M.R. Lebaudy's ch.f. Dalken, by Kendal, out of Raker, was second, and Mr. W.R. Marshall's ch.f. Dovey, by Whitehall, out of Apia, third.

" No, argue as you choose," the girl in the hammock was saying, "the ideal way of spending one's Summer is camping out. I don't mean as the fashionables do, with guides and servants and a solid roof over one's head, but really and truly camping, in its primitive sense."

HOLLYWOOD, N.J., Aug. 22. -- In spite of the feverish activity of the Summer visitors to this place, the season is rapidly drawing to a close. Only a couple of weeks of it remain, for when Sept. 1 shall have dawned, the bulk of the transient population will fold up its tents, like the Arabs, and noiselessly move away.
To us the notices and advertisements relating to schools in England have a strange reading. Here is one:

Mr. BRYAN, in a number of his speeches since taking up his march into "the enemy's country," has spoken with a curious mingling of alarm and resentment of the newspapers. He began it before he reached Chicago, and he has kept it up at intervals since. Two ideas seem to be in his mind. One is that the newspapers are all against him.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Interest in the Anglo-Egyptian expedition to the Soudan, which waned somewhat during the period the troops were awaiting the rise in the Nile, has been revived by the receipt of intelligence that the preparations for the resumption of the advance have been completed, and that the troops will go forward from Kosheh within a fortnight.
Clearing House certificates will probably be issued this week, to enable the banks to relieve the money situation.

ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, N.J., Aug. 22. -The leading event of the past week has been the St. Agnes Church festival, which was held at M.E. Curtis's cottage. The leading people in the management were Mrs. John Williamson, Mrs. Harry Macarthy, and Mrs. Joseph Barre, Summer residents, and in their attendance at their pretty tables at the fair they were assisted by Miss Anna Williamson and Miss Mary Dallas, all from the greater city.

The record of the season seems to be a discussion of the effect of alternate hot and cool if not cold waves upon the doings of the people who constitute that indefinite world known as society at the watering places. Last Sunday the record was rather a gloomy one, treating, as it was obliged to do, of a week made dull of tropical deadly heat and a gloomy business outlook.

The French Republic, thanks to the new alliance between the Phrygian cap and the knout, has done its best to make its soil insecure for those who fled from the tyranny of Czardom. Among Russian exiles living at Zurich, Geneva, and Lausanne spies have latterly been introduced, even in the guise of alleged lady students of the same nationality.

From time immemorial the rainbow has excited the curiosity of man, and in the days of old was looked upon by even the most enlightened as a sign of one kind or another, and, if the truth must be told, it is to regarded at the present time by the great majority of the inhabitants of the world.

An interesting table showing the coal production of the world for the past twenty-eight years has been prepared by Statistician Edward W. Parker of the United States Geological Survey. This bulletin shows a steady advance on the part of the United States. In 1868, when the total output of the world was about 225,000,000 tons, the United States yielded but 14 per cent.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Li Hung Chang, Special Ambassador of the Emperor of China, with his suite, left Waterloo Station at 9 o'clock this morning for Southampton, where he embarked on board the American Dine steamer St. Louis for New-York.

The compressed air motors designed for running street cars by the Metropolitan Traction Company of New-York City, and upon which experts have been at work at the plant of the American Wheelock Engine Company at South Worcester for several months, have passed the experimental stages and are now working most satisfactorily.

LAKE KUSHAQUA, Aug. 22. -- Here in the picturesque wilds of Franklin County, and on the edge of one of the most beautiful little lakes yet discovered, is a charming Adirondack lodge, lighted by electricity. It is the only hotel in the mountains whose guests enjoy the advantages of electric lights, and it is one of the few Summer resorts that fully meet the alluring promises of their names.

LONDON, Aug. 22. -- Lord Chief Justice Russell's address at Saratoga and the fervent reception which, from all accounts, it received are regarded here as forming by far the most noteworthy episode of the week. It surprised nobody that Lord Russell should have made a great speech, because his power to rise to the full possibilities of any occasion has come to be an article of faith in England.

BUFFALO, Aug. 22. -- This was the last day of the Grand Circuit meeting at the Buffalo Driving Park. Although the weather was sultry, the track was in perfect condition, and the attendance numbered about 7,000. Three additional heats were required to determine the winner of yesterday's unfinished 2:11 trot.

MOUNT POCONO, Penn., Aug. 22. -- In all the romantic regions of the Pocono Mountains there is no resort more attractive for those in quest of health and pleasure than Mount Pocono. The weather during the past week has been delightfully cool and pleasant, and many drives and excursions to the numerous attractive points were taken.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22. -- The President has commuted to imprisonment for life the death sentence imposed on Robert E. Boutwell, convicted of murder in Texas and sentenced to be hanged on Sept. 4 next. The President says:

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 22. -- The younger members of the New-York Summer colony are actively rehearsing for the amateur theatricals to be given next Saturday evening in the assembly room of the Ridgefield Club. The first number will be the original comedietta, "A Morning Call," by Miss Huntington and Mr. Nicholas, to be followed by a short drama, "A Fair Encounter," by Miss Crafts and Miss Ingersool. Miss Hailenburg of Kentucky will sing.
LI Hung Chang is coming all the way from Peking to see Chinatown, and all Chinatown is going to see LI Hung Chang.

LONG BRANCH, Aug. 22. -- A heavy rainstorm set in here early this morning which had the appearance of being a lasting one. It rained at intervals until noon; after that time the weather was pleasant overhead but very disagreeable under foot. When the guests at the hotels arose this morning nearly everything looked like disappointment to them for the day.

LARCHMONT MANOR, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Bicycling has been the all-absorbing source of amusement this week. The cool weather was favorable and the roads were in superb condition. The result was that all the Manor was a-wheel as long as daylight lasted, and time could not be found for much else.

The tumults and disorders in some of the Republican primaries and Assembly District Conventions in this city and the charges of fraud and irregularity in local management which have been rife in the organization for the last year indicate that the present law for the regulation of such party proceedings is quite ineffectual.

The fishermen and their families whose homes are on the coast of Labrador are suffering again for want of the necessaries of life. Their misery has been described during the last two weeks in dispatches which excite the pity and sympathy of the philanthropic. They are starving, it is reported by trustworthy observers.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 22. -- Mrs. H.M. Brooks gave a dinner and small dance at Rockhurst to-night, in honor of Miss Sybil Sherman, who has just reached her twenty-first birthday. Mrs. Calvin S. Brice, Mrs. Clement Cleveland, Mrs. J.S. Bryce, Mrs. G.M. Hutton, Mrs. John C. Gray, Mrs. J.J. Mason, and Mrs. Stanley Mortimer also entertained this evening.

CHICAGO, Aug. 22. -- Shortly after midnight last night this city was visited by a heavy rainstorm, accompanied by a series of electrical storms, which did great damage to property, especially in the southern part of the city. Electric cars, telegraph and telephone lines in all parts of the city were affected.

There has been a marked improvement among the whist players of Brooklyn, as evidenced by the matches and games at the Brooklyn Whist Club. Players who a year ago hardly knew the leads now play a good game of whist and are able to criticise the play intelligently. The closeness of the play in most of the matches is really remarkable.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 22. -- The Plant system of Railways has established a hospital and relief department, membership in which will be a requisite to employment in any department of the system after Jan. 1, 1897. About 3,500 of 5,500 employes of the system have already become members of the department. A stated amount is set apart from wages for its maintenance.

It looks as present as if the depths of the business depression had been sounded. There is apparently a dimunition of the anxiety and feeling of discouragement which precipitated such a vast shrinkage of values last month, when a concentration was affected of all the forces antagonistic to a sound currency and the strict execution of all the laws at the land.

It is M. Paul Bourget's preface, in the cuise of a letter to his translator, which has its peculiarities. The Anglo-Saxon, he says, has "misconceptions" in regard to "a work written in and for a Latin country," when it is transplanted. But these surely can be no "misconception" about anything nasty either in French or in English.

Lyman Andrews, private secretary to Andrew H. Green of the Greater New-York Commission, was arrested in his office in the Western Union Building yesterday by a detective from Yonkers, N.Y., on a warrant sworn out by Mrs. Andrews, who charges him with desertion and non-support.

It was extremely unfortunate for people who love racing for the sport there is in it that yesterday was such a gloomy day, with such miserable weather. Rain itself had converted all the tracks into marshy runways. Prospects of a still further rainfall kept people at their homes, and so the chance to see a grand racehorse, Requital, run in true racehorse style was lost to thousands who would have thoroughly enjoyed the sport.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 22. -- Dr. Wendell A. Anderson, Consul General at Montreal, the veteran Wisconsin campaignen, has decided to support Bryan. In reply to a letter from a man in this city he writes as follows:

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 22. -- The harvest hall and lawn party given at the Prospect House last night was the event of the week here. Extensive preparations had been made for the event. The hotel, cottages, and grounds were illuminated. The big hotel ballroom was a scene of gayety until a late hour.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 22. -- The Kebo Valley Club never gave a more successful entertainment in the way of a dinner-dance than that on Saturday evening last. The dining hall presented a very pretty scene with its seventy guests moving, chatting, and laughing. Jewels sparkled, and many candles threw a soft light over the picture.

BERLIN, Aug. 22. -- The resignation of Gen. Brohsart von Schellendorf from the office of Minister of War continues to occupy the attention of the press and the public, and this has especially been the case since the Reichsanzeiger, the official journal, published the announcement of the Minister's retirement from office, coupled with the declaration that the impairment of his health was the main cause of his withdrawal.

SAYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 22. -- Henry Steinert, a New-York boy, who is here with his parents for the Summer, last night had occasion to go to the telegraph office to send a message. He rode his wheel on the sidewalk, and went so close to Richard Weeks, the eighty-year-old resident at this place, who is familiarly known as "Uncle Dick," that Mr. Weeks tried to chastise him.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 22. -- Peter L. Conklin is at Oqauko Lake, N.Y. Mr. and Mrs. Christie Romaine are visiting at Warwick, N.Y. Henry S. Ferdon and family are at Far Hills, N.J. Mr. and Mrs. H.L. Bartow are enjoying a vacation visit up the Hudson. W.J. Tice and family of Union Street have gone to White Lake, N.Y.
SEA GIRT, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The meeting of the New-Jersey State Rifle Association, to be held here, beginning Aug. 31, promises to be the largest for military competitions ever held in this country.

To make more effective war on cats Peter Fisher, seventeen years old, borrowed a parlor rifle from a neighbor. He was in the kitchen of his home at 410 East Seventy-eighth Street, yesterday afternoon, tossing the rifle about as carelessly as if it had not been loaded.

The statement of Mr. MCANENY, Secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association, which will be found in another column, is one that Superintendent ALDRIDGE cannot afford to ignore. There are certain parts of it that he will not deny, because they are perfectly well known and officially recorded.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The baseball game between Newark and Lancaster before 8,000 persons this afternoon was particularly lively at its close. In the last half of the ninth inning Lancaster had scored 5 runs, making the score 14 to 15, and there was a man on third and another on first and one out. Newark left the field, claiming it was too dark to see the ball.

There is no more cheap and vulgar form of demagogism than that exhibited in Mr. BRYAN'S continual references to the "common people" and the "toiling masses." What does he mean by the "common people"? It has been the boast of this country that it is the land of equality, not of capacity and of achievement, but of rights and opportunities.

Strolling along Stanton Street, at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, Policeman Webb and Harris of the Eleventh Precinct, who were on special duty and in citizen garb, were alert because, when they reached Eldridge Street, they heard a noise as of breaking of woodwork.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The Wanderers is the name of a newly organized and already prosperous cycling organization in East Orange. The officers are: President -- Asa Booth; Vice President -- Charles Wadsworth; Secretary and Treasurer -- Harry Greening; Captain -- Charles P. Whitman; Lieutenant -- Joseph Ward.

The Civil Service Reform Association if satisfied that Superintendent Aldridge in his administration of the State Department of Public Works has violated the civil service section of the Constitution in a gross and flagrant manner.
Three alarms were sent out shortly after 2 o'clock yesterday morning for a fire which kept the firemen, under the direction of Deputy Chief Reilly, busy for four hours.
PORTLAND, Oregon, Aug. 23. -- The sound-money Democrats of Oregon held a convention in this city yesterday at which eighty-nine delegates were present, the majority of whom were Federal officials.

Investigations recently made by the bacteriologists of the Baltimore Health Department show that tuberculosis or consumption is not the only disease which may be communicated to man through the agency of milk from infected cows. It became known that eighty cows on a dairy farm near Ellicott City, from which milk was shipped to Baltimore, were suffering from a disease the nature of which could not be clearly ascertained.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23. -- It being settled that Hoke Smith is to leave the Cabinet, the gossips now are busy with the question of his successor.

DES MOINES, Aug. 23. -- L.M. Martin, National Committeeman for Iowa in the Sound Money Democratic Organization, is in receipt of a letter from J. Sterling Morton, which Iowa sound-money Democrats are disposed to take as a declaration that Mr. Morton is willing to be nominated for President by the Indianapolis Convention.

The Republican State Convention appears this year to be more completely than ever before PLATT'S convention. It seems to be admitted that, of 738 delegates, about 660 are ready to do his bidding but he has an unusual task on his hands. PLATT always counts upon party loyalty for the support of candidates after they have been nominated, but he counts carefully upon the forces that are to be handled in determining nominations.

Florence Diginet, a Frenchwoman twenty-three years old, of 155 West Thirty-third Street, and her husband, Edward, were arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday by Policeman Rosenberg of the West Thirtieth Street Precinct.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23. -- Dispatches from points in Indiana and Ohio report severe storms last night, accompanied by much destruction of property by lightning and some fatalities. Telegraphic communication is much impaired.
Permit me, if you will, a few words upon one feature of the American Bar Association banquet to Lord Chief Justice Russell at Saratoga.

BEDFORD STATION, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- The funeral of Walker B. Adams, who was shot and killed last Wednesday night by the burglars who entered his store here, took place this afternoon. It was the largest funeral ever held in the town of Bedford.
" There's that spook trotting on the roof again," said Policeman Cronin of the Oak Street Police Station, as he rushed to the Sergeant's desk on Saturday evening.

Among those who waited on the Netherlands-American Line pier, in Hoboken, yesterday afternoon, for incoming passengers on the steamship Spaarndam, from Rotterdam and Boulogne, was H.M. Stephenson of Boston. He awaited his wife and son, who had been spending the Summer in Europe, Mrs. Stephenson having gone abroad for her health.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23. -- The free silver tide in Wisconsin is on the ebb. Proofs of this fact are being received every day. The strongest array of evidence comes from sources other than political, and this to a practiced observer makes it the stronger. But it is all of one piece, that the capitivating glamour of "16 to 1" has gone glimmoring down the wind so far as the people of this State are concerned.

Having finished their Summer engagements in Michigan, Ohio, and Indiana, the stars of the light-harness brigade are now on their way to the Atlantic coast. The Grand Circuit is all but over, the six meetings in the West to be followed by one more week that will be spent in the metropolis after the horses return from Boston, where they are to open the new track at Readville on Tuesday.
" Like the silent tread of a cat," is the characterization by Senator Daniel of the manner in which the Demonetization act of 1873 went through Congress.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Henry Stimpson and William Nolan, waiters in the pavilion at Glen Island, were arrested yesterday by order of Capt. Timmons of the New-Rochelle police to make a test case against the management of Glen Island for the purpose of determining whether the hotel license that has been obtained for the Island is sufficient to cover all the places on the island where liquors are sold.

BOSTON, Aug. 23. -- The new cruiser Brooklyn, which will have her official Government trial off the New-England coast on Wednesday, arrived off Boston from Philadelphia at 6:15 o'clock to-night and anchored about eight miles out from the city.

George Herdling, son of the proprietor of the United States Hotel, at Fulton and Pearl Streets, this city, was robbed last evening, in the Raines' law hotel, at 23 Chatham Square, which has the name "P. Cunningham," over the door. Then the robbers kicked him out into the street.

Certain Republican politicians, including Senators LODGE and THURSTON and Congressmen GROSVENOR and BARTHOLDT, appear to have been indulging, through the medium of a Cincinnati newspaper, in a discussion of what the Republican Party will "do for silver" hereafter in the way of promoting international bimetallism.

The Armenian Relief Association has sent out an appeal to the business men of the United States. From one of its correspondents the association says it has received a report showing the condition of affairs in Armenia. The following from this report is quoted in the appeal:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23. -- It is said that within the next month, Gen. Estrada Palma, the Minister Plenipotentiary of the Cuban Republic to the United States, and Gonzales Quesada, the Secretary of Legation, with other prominent supporters of the revolutionary cause, will go to Cuba to consult with President Cisnerosa as to the future conduct of the battle for freedom.

Mr. HOKE SMITH is learning that in politics, as in business, it is very risky to sign checks in blank. His friends explain his present plight, when he is supporting the policy which a few weeks since he declared was full of danger, by saying that in his debate with Mr. CRISP he promised to support the Chicago candidate, whatever the convention did.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 23. -- Chairman Bynum of the National Democratic Executive Committee to-day said:

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 23. -- There was all kinds of Summer weather witnessed here to-day. Early in the morning a fog made its appearance, later in the forenoon it became very cloudy, and at noon a few drops of rain fell, followed by sunshine, with a very heavy humidity the whole day. The thermometer registered from 80 to 85, and nearly every person was complaining of the heat.

Henry Jacob Winser died yesterday at 201 Washington Avenue, Newark, N.J. He was born Nov. 23, 1833, on the Island of Bermuda, and was the son of an officer in the British Navy. He studied at the Springfield Academy, in Bermuda, and came to New-York in 1851, where he became a proofreader in a printing office.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. Almeric Hugh Paget gave a dinner company to-night in honor of Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt and Harry P. Whitney, Mrs. Paget's brother. The ushers and bridesmaids of the coming wedding were among the guests. Saturday evening Miss Vanderbilt had a dinner company at "The Breakers," in honor of her bridesmaids, Miss Emily Vanderbilt Sloane, Miss Shepard, Miss Angelica Gerry, and Miss Taylor.

A man stopped at a book cart in Ann Street Saturday to look over the cheap paper editions that it contained. He picked up a copy of Les Miserables. As he did so a tramp touched him on the shoulder and said:

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 23. -- The Princeton football season will open three weeks from tomorrow, and the 'Varsity field at Princeton is now being put in condition for the players. Trainer McMaster has returned from his Summer vacation and is busily engaged in preparing the turf of the 'Varsity gridiron for the opening of the season.
SARATOGA, Aug. 23. -- Talk of the nomination of Thomas C. Platt for Governor has made a sensation here to-day among those who are on hand for the Republican State Convention.

SARANAK LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Every one is getting ready for the musical and from this entertainment to be given this week for the benefit of the Sanitarium. The musical part of the programme will be given by Mrs. Rockwood, soprano; Mr. Moretar, baritone; Mrs. Winkler, piano; Messrs. Clarence Townsend and J. Howard Meltoarest, banjos, and the house orchestra.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 23. -- Major McKinley expects to be uncommonly busy this week. He will make two speeches on Monday, one to a delegation of farmers from Knox County, Ohio, and the other to a deputation of potters and other citizens of East Liverpool.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 23. -- Bush fires are raging with unabated fury in the mainland of British Columbia. New-Westminster is surrounded, and, as firemen cannot be at all places at once, it is feared some part of the city will be destroyed by the oncoming flames, in spite of them.

BUFFALO, Aug. 23. -- Frederick Gordon Rew, the Cornell student who disappeared on Oct. 2, 1804, and was supposed to have met with foul play, has been heard from. His father, Esbon P. Rew of this city, received a letter from him yesterday, dated in India, stating that he was in good health and bound for home.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 22. -- John F. Chamberlin, the hotel man of Washington, died at the Grand Union Hotel here at 11:25 o'clock to-night, of Bright's disease.

Four boys, half starved and with throats so parched by thirst that they could hardly speak, were found in a box freight car at the Central Railroad yards, in Jersey City, at 7 o'clock yesterday morning. The train of which the car formed part had just arrived from Philadelphia. The discovery and release of the boys was accidental.

RUTLAND, Vt., Aug. 23. -- The arbitrators filed in the County Clerk's office Saturday a decision in the famous suit for libel of Urban A. Woodbury, Governor of Vermont, against the Herald and Globe Association of this city, of which one Robert A. Perkins is the editorial writer. The case by mutual agreement was submitted for arbitration to Chief Justice Ross and Justices Rowell and Tyler of the Supreme Court of the State.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 23. -- Ansel E. Wright, the canal statistician in this city, last evening gave out some figures which show the enormous increase in canal business since the incumbency of George W. Aldridge as Superintendent of Public Works over that of 1894 and previous years. Mr. Wright says:

The safe return of Dr. NANSEN has now been followed by the arrival of his ship at a Norwegian port near the point from which it started three years ago, and the history of the voyage suggests some remarks about what the explorer has accomplished and the theory which he set out to verify.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 23. -- A severe windstorm visited the States of Illinois, Missouri, Arkansas, Texas, and Oklahoma Territory last night. Several lives were lost and much property destroyed. Electrical discharges and heavy rain accompanied the storm of wind.

The Bryans propose to put their Crown of Thorns and Cross of Gold Combination on the road again next week. The company will visit Albany, Syracuse, Rochester, Buffalo, and other points in Western New-York, to say nothing of Erie, Penn.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 24. -- In the face of the tremendous efforts by the machine silver Democrats to stifle the sound-money movement in Alabama by abuse and vituperation, meetings were held this evening in almost every town of any size in Alabama for the election of delegates to the Sound-Money State Convention to be held at Montgomery next Thursday.

Fishing has been unusually good at Hemlock Lake, and fishermen from Rochester Honeoye Falls, Dansville, and other places have been attracted to its waters to indulge in the sport. One of these men is a prominent banker of Honeoye Falls. This knight of the rod and reel has not been as favored by fortune as the other men who ply the waters for their hour's pastime.

There will doubtless be a good deal of tinkering with the Raines law done at the next session of the Legislature. It is to be hoped that among the amendments will be one that will require a more genuine examination of the respectability and orderliness of the places to which "hotel licenses" are issued than has thus far been the case.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Over 3,000 persons saw Earl Bovee of this city break the world's amateur competitive record for two-thirds of a mile at the National Circuit races at the Binghamton Athletic Association grounds here to-day. Bovee's times of 1:25 breaks the record of 1:25 1-5, made by F.A. McFarland of San Jose Cal., last October, and ties the professional record, held by "Tom" Cooper.

-- The first of the suits was filed yesterday which old soldiers intend to bring against the City of Hartford, Conn., to cover alleged town bounty due since the war. George Jones brought suit in the City Court to recover $800 in 1862. The suit is returnable in the City Court of Hartford. About twenty-five others will follow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The announcement to-night by the President of the appointment of ex-Gov. Francis of Missouri as the successor to Hoke Smith, Secretary of the Interior, has caused no surprise in the limited circle in which it is known.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- There are plenty of signs to be found in this town that the silver leaders are becoming worried over the outlook in States which, a month ago, they were claiming for the Chicago candidates. While they still talk in the most encouraging way for publication, their private utterances indicate the anxiety which they feel.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded is that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

SARATOGA, Aug. 24. -- There never was better convention weather than that in Saratoga to-day. If it holds out the delegates, their friends and followers will have a chance to enjoy Saratoga at her best. There were several driving parties to the lake this afternoon, and the convention comers generally enjoyed themselves.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Capt. Hooper, commander of the American patrol fleet in Bering Sea, reports from Unalaska, under date of July 22. His fleet consists of 6 vessels, 60 officers, and 300 men. He states that so far there are 45 sealing vessels in the sea, of which 7 are American and 38 British, with an aggregate crew of 1,298 men, of which 837 are Indian and 456 white.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, L.I., Aug. 24. -- Burglars entered the Seaside Station of the Long Island Railroad between Sunday midnight and 6 o'clock this morning. The safe was blown open and $400 in cash and some railroad tickets were stolen. The money belonged to the Long Island Railroad and the Western Union Telegraph Company.

ALBANY, Aug. 21. -- The business interests of the capital city are almost solid for the gold standard, and consequently the silver men and the Chicago ticket are receiving but little support and encouragement by most Democrats.

Mr. Alfred Austin, a salaried official of the English Government, is evidently a man of influence. At all events, he has had influence enough to secure the publication in The London Times -- at the head of a column, too, and next to reading matter -- of the following lines. They are entitled "John Everett Millais."

Michael F. Wynn, President of the New York Roofing Company of 437 East Twenty-third Street, and his family, consisting of his wife and his seven children live at 314 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street. They have been passing the Summer at Far Rockaway.

HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 24. -- Counsel for the New-England Railway Company filed in the Superior Court to-day an amended complaint, against the Central Railway and Electric Company of New-Britain, the New ington Tramway Company, and the Hartford Street Railway Company, in its suit to restrain those companies from building a trolley road between this city and New-Britain.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- John Jenkins, alias "Reddy" Jenkins, alias John Byrnes, one of the Bedford Station burglars, who was shot last Wednesday night by William Adams at the time his father, Walker B. Adams, was killed, died this morning a few minutes after 8 o'clock in the building known as "the hall," the building which adjoins the lock-up, and to which he was moved yesterday afternoon.

BRIDGEPORT, Aug. 24. -- Mrs. Ida Porter of Fairfield is trying to recover her four-year-old daughter, who was adopted by Mrs. Ashabel Penny of Black Rock three years ago. Mrs. Porter's husband was at that time poor, and went West. Now Mrs. Porter is able to care for the child and wants it.

The question as to whether the Sheriff or the receiver, Louis Clark, Jr., has the right to the possession of the stock of S.F. Myers Co., wholesale jewelers at 48 and 50 Maiden Lane, was before Justice Pryor, in the Supreme Court yesterday, and was productive of a long and peculiar argument, in which two and one-half minutes played an important part.

TOLEDO, O., Aug. 24. -- The attempt to sail the first international race between the Canada and Vencedor for the Inter-Lake yachting championship on Lake Erie, off Toledo to-day, resulted in a failure on account of the lack of wind, as the regatta committee declared the race off at 3 o'clock this afternoon, after the yachts had drifted about for four hours.

The Salvation Army last night held a meeting, with the aid of the stereopticon, on the City Hall steps. Commander Booth-Tucker had previously had a talk with Mayor Strong about the various departments of philanthropic work which the army desires to introduce in New-York this Winter. The Mayor approved Commander Booth-Tucker's ideas and gave him a permit to hold his meeting on the City Hall steps.

The officers of the New-York, Ontario and Western Railway Company have under consideration a plan for the establishment of a uniform passenger rate of 2 cents a mile between all points on its lines, and the consequent abolition of mileage books, trip tickets, and excursion rates.
SARATOGA, Aug. 24. -- If Mr. Platt takes the Gubernatorial nomination, as it seems probable to-night he will, who is to be the candidate for Lieutenant Governor?

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 24. -- The House of Commons resumed its sittings to-day, when Mr. McInnes, Vancouver, B.C., who is one of the youngest members of the House, moved the adoption of the address in reply to the Governor General's speech from the Throne, opening Parliament. He made a vigorous speech, in which he attacked strongly the policy of the late Tupper Government.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Unable to meet its obligations in the Clearing House Saturday, the Haymarket Produce Bank early this morning made an assignment to Charles L. Boyd. According to the assignee the liabilities are about $160,000, and the assets about the same.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 24. -- The messages which continue to come to Mayor McKinley in increasing members announcing the organization of clubs indicate to the Republicans here that there is unusual activity in this direction throughout the country. The total number of these messages last week exceeded 350.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 24. -- George Slater, thirty-eight years old, of New-York, who has been in charge of the golf links for the Norwood Field Club this Summer, narrowly escaped being murdered at this place early this morning. Slater was out spending the evening with some friends along the shore, and about 1 o'clock came down Ocean Avenue, until he reached Pavilion Avenue, which leads to the New-York and Long Branch Railroad main station.

LONDON, Aug. 24. -- It is learned by The United Associated Presses, upon official authority, that Dr. Gallagher, the Irish-American who, with Daly, Whitehead, and others convicted as dynamiters, has been confined in Portland Prison, will be released in the course of the next ten days and will sail for the United States without delay.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The State Department has received from Consul Jastramenski, at Callao, Peru, a report regarding the rumored loss of an exploring party in the Inamburi River region, led by an American named Cooper. Learning of the rumor, which has been cabled to the country, the Consul called on Consular Agent Meier, at Hollenda, to transmit all the information he could secure.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Alfred Hunter, the colored man whom Mrs. Warner thought she saw in the store of John T. Henke, a short time before he was found murdered, on Saturday night, was taken into custody while attending a colored camp meeting at Buckto last night.
Chairman Mark A. Hanna did not return to Republican Headquarters yesterday. He remained at Marblehead, Mass., with his brother-in-law, J.F. Rhodes.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 24.-- The Navy Department has invited shipbuilders on Puget Sound to bid for the construction of one or more torpedo boats, for which provision was made by Congress last Spring. The firms having the invitation under advisement are the Puget Sound Engineering Works of this place, Moran Brothers' Company of Seattle, and the Everett Steel Barge Company of Everett, Washington. Bids will be opened in Washington City early in September.
The strike of employe of the Adams Express Company appears to be a complete failure, as was to be expected, and it shows once more how slow workingmen are to profit by the lessons of experience.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Wrenn and Larned met in the final match in the All Comers' tennis series to-day . Larned's chief fault seemed to be driving into the net, and many balls found their way there. Several times also he made double faults, and more than once showed a carelessness that amounted almost to weakness. Wrenn meantime was playing with his head as well as with his racquet.

Garrett Storms was a large owner of real estate in New-York fifty-years ago. He was descended from an old Knickerbocker family, and was connected by marriage with the Livingstons. He owned all the land lying between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-sixth Streets and Broadway and Sixth Avenue.
CHICAGO, Aug. 24. -- Gen. E.A. McAlpin of New-York, the President of the National League of Republican Clubs, who is on his way to the National Convention of the league at Milwaukee, said to-day:

PITTSBURG, Aug. 24. -- The through express train from Chicago on the Pittsburg and Western Railroad, which was due in this city at 12:35 P.M., was wrecked at Valencia, a small station twenty miles west of here, at 11:30 o'clock to-day, and more than a score of passengers were injured, four of whom may die.

The meeting of the Hide and Leather Sound Money Association, held yesterday afternoon at the office of Faverweather Ladew, 28 and 30 Spruce Street, was well attended. It was announced that 90 per cent. of the trade had already joined the association.

A motion was made in the Supreme Court yesterday before Justice Pryor, on behalf of Francis R.
