Pemberton and William McAdoo, of the banking firm of Pemberton McAdoo, for an injunction to restrain the Mechanics and Traders' Bank from selling certain securities alleged to have been given as collateral security on a note of the firm of the bank, of $22,000, which was discounted July 31 by the bank.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- In the preliminary or practice trial to-day the cruiser Brooklyn developed an average speed closely approximating 21 knots. There were, of course, no official figures which could have any impartial or valuable hearing. Watches were held by all the officers aboard, and also by those members of the Government Trial Board, and close calculations were made from buoy to buoy in the run of 83 knots.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 24. -- The platform of the National Democratic party is in course of formation.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- All is ready for the great wedding of to-morrow, and all who are to be present at the breakfast are here to-night. The florists began their labors at the Breakers this morning, and will hardly conclude before it is time for the wedding march.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 24. -- Delegates and visitors to the Republican National League Convention which will begin here at noon to-morrow have been streaming into the city since early morning. Most of the Eastern State delegations are present in full force. The indications are that there will be over 1,000 delegates in attendance.

Charles W. Brooke, counsel for Mary Alice Almont Livingston Fleming, recently acquitted of the charge of poisoning her mother, Mrs. Evalina M. Bliss, says that he has not yet been paid the fee agreed on for his services. There is a strong probability that he will have to resort to a suit to establish his claim.

KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 24. -- The following affidavit, which will be transmitted to Secretary of State Olney, has been made in regard to the recent murder by the Spaniards of Charles Govin, an American citizen:

The New-York and Louisville ball teams played two games at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon. In the first game Seymour and Hill, the two pitchers, got badly rattled in the second and third innings, and the New-York team had the better luck and finally won the game. The second game was called at the end of the sixth inning when each side had scored four runs.

Admiral Bunce's fleet, at anchor off Tompkinsville, was increased to nine vessels yesterday by the arrival from the navy yard of the double-turreted monitor Terror. There were few visitors, though thousands of Staten Islanders and passengers on the ferry and the rapid transit and trolley roads viewed the magnificent spectacle with great interest and very apparent admiration.

FREDERICK, Md., Aug. 24. -- One hundred and twenty persons had a fearful ride down the Catoctin Mountain grade in a trolley car, which was beyond the motorman's control, last night. At Mercer's curve, the car jumped the track and went down art embankment, turning over on its side with a crash and finally coming to a stop against a fence.

The Law Enforcement Society of Brooklyn is actively engaged in procuring evidence against persons who have secured liquor-tax certificates on false sworn statements. Some of the cases already discovered have been brought to the attention of the public through legal proceedings, and several more are in course of preparation.

The-Times-Democrat gave some time ago an account of the great drought, extending over a large part of North Louisiana and portions of Arkansas and Texas, but it has grown even worse than it was when we then wrote of it. It is, in fact, the most widely extended and severe drought which has ever visited this country, causing the greatest loss to crops, and consequently the most widespread suffering.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Orders were issued to-day by the War Department for four troops of the Sixth Cavalry, stationed at Fort Myer, Va., near Washington, to proceed to New-York on Wednesday.

The trial of J. Elliott Smith, Superintendent of Fire Alarm, Telegraph and Electrical Appliances of the Fire Department, on charges of fraud and incompetency was resumed yesterday before the Board of Fire Commissioner. All the commissioners were present.

The Fall regattas of the yacht clubs on the Sound will begin this week, and owners of racing yachts are now having their vessels put in shape for these races. Three events are scheduled for next Saturday. They are under the auspices of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian, Huguenot, and Huntington Yacht Clubs.

ALBANY, Aug. 24. -- Gov. Morton is in the Adirondecks, where he proposes to remain until after the convention. He is removed from telegraphic communication, and it is intimated here that he purposely got away so as to avoid the passing of telegrams to and from him during the convention.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- Mark Hanna. Chairman of the National Republican Executive Committee, visited Young's Hotel this morning, and received a large amount of correspondence which had been awaiting his arrival.

Frank O'Neill of 532 West Forty-ninth Street, Joseph Ferindi of 190 Hester Street, Samuel Margenlander of 232 Stanton Street, and Charles Cohn of 118 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street, newsboys, whose ages range between thirteen and sixteen years, were arrested last night while picking up pennies at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street which had been thrown to the street by people on the balconies of the Casino.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- The season at this place has closed. The season of 1896 has been a great success, when the general financial depression of the country is taken into consideration. The receipts have exceeded all expectations, and are within about 2 per cent. of last year, or about $55,000, the total amount received from all sources.

That is a curious report which comes to us by way of Philadelphia that the Cuban leaders have determined upon a more drastic policy than they have heretofore been pursuing. It is curious because to ordinary observers it seems that, considering the disparity of the Spaniards and the Cubans in numbers and resources, the insurgents have been pursuing quite as active a policy as could reasonably be expected.

The following letter seems to show that if women should to any extent take up the practice of smoking, a certain style of dress reform would have to follow, and every woman have her own pockets for carrying her necessary belongings

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24. -- The bolting Democrats from the Chicago Convention will meet here in State Convention tomorrow to elect delegates to the Indianapolis Convention, end to form a new party organization in this State.

Mr. William Rosenzweig has exchanged for J.L. Buttenwieser the two six-story brick flats, 239 and 211 West Fifteenth Street, 48 by 93 by 103.3, at about $90,000, with G.D. Hyman, for the five-story brick tenement, 156, Attorney Street, 25 by 70 by 100, at $28,000, and other consideration.

BOSTON, Aug. 24. -- At the Boston Museum to-night, Roland Reed presented for the first time on any stage a new comedy, "The Wrong Mr. Wright," written by George H. Broadhurst. It was well received by a large audience. Mr. Reed and his associates, including Isadore Rush, acted well in their respective roles.

SARATOGA, Aug. 24. -- No matter what the outcome of this convention of 1896 may be, it will enjoy the distinction of having been the largest attended of any Republican State Convention in recent years.

BIG INDIAN, N.Y., Aug. 24. -- Winnisook Lodge, high up in the Catskill Mountains, ten miles from a telegraph station, and as perfect in isolation as it is beautiful in situation, shelters Williams Jennings Bryan and his wife to-night.

Terry, the Chicago pitcher, and Kennedy, who occupies a similar position on the Brooklyn team, had a battle royal in the game at Eastern Park yesterday. Kennedy and the home team won the game, scoring one run in the seventh inning. "Papa" Anson's colts failed to score.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 24. -- Charles B. Foster, who is said to be a member of the Brooklyn police force, was arrested in West Orange yesterday and fined for insulting Michael Buckley and John Bolmer, young men of Orange. The case was one of mistaken identity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- Mr. Stevens, Vice Chairman of the Silver National Committee, has returned from New-York, and reports the outlook there more favorable than he anticipated. He says the work of organizing silver clubs is progressing rapidly, especial headway being made in the country districts.

Entertaining a Czar and his wife is a rather vexatious task for the President of the French Republic. There are plenty of palaces in which they can be lodged, and though French cooking is not what it was in the great days of the monarchy, the visitors will have enough to eat and drink. The real trouble is in the streets.

Option among the opponents of Populism has greatly changed during the last month as to the need of a third ticket and how it would work. When the offensive and dangerous Chicago flatform was adopted, and when a candidate who filled its worst features was placed upon it, the first impulse of indignant citizens was to declare that votes for McKINLEY were the best things with which to defeat BRYAN and Bryanism.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 24. -- The following letter from Edward J. Phelps, ex-Minister to England, to G.G. Benedict was made public to-day:
HAVANA, Aug. 2. -- The decree which, it is stated, Capt. Gen. Wayler will shortly issue, prohibiting the grinding of the coming sugar crop, will also forbid the gathering of the coffee crap.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24. -- Mrs. Calvin S. Brice again delighted cottagers to-day with her reception. May Irwin sang "Bully Boy" and "I Want You, Ma Honey," having to repeat the latter five times. Gordon McKenzie and Mlle. Alice Verlet, of the Opera Comique of Paris, also sang, the latter from "Romeo and Juliet." There were two hundred society people present.
SARATOGA, Aug. 24. -- The Republican leaders have put the crown upon the brow of Thomas C. Platt.

A Republican newspaper or Mount Vernon died the other day. It had been edited by Dr. E.F. Brash, a well-known trod well-to-do citizen, who has been trying for some time to oppose the regular Republican machine in Mount Vernon. He established The Sentinel to aid his endeavor to attain his political ambitions.

The first convention of Jewish women ever held in this country will assemble in this city on Nov. 15, and continue until Nov. 20. On this occasion the first biennial convention of the National Council of Jewish Women will take place in the Tuxedo, at Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

The Street and Water Board of Jersey City held a special meeting yesterday for the purpose of receiving bids for a new water supply. Three proposals were handed in, but one, to furnish water by filtration, was informal. It was submitted by the United States Filtering and Purifying Company. The other bids were from the East Jersey Water Company and the Rockaway and Hudson Company.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24. -- The cause of sound money has received a decided impetus by reason of the hesitation of contractors to bid on Government work.

Temporarily Eclipsed by Hanna, He Is Again Entitled to be Called the Most Powerful Politician Not in Office -- The Candidates Who Are Willing to Take the Governorship If Platt Will Not Have It -- Nearly All for the Machine.

The Detroit Tribune, (silver Republican,) one of the few newspapers east of the Rocky Mountains which support the Bryan policy, tells the farmers of Michigan that the substitution of the fifty-three-cent dollar for the one-hundred-cent dollar now in use would help them by reducing their taxes.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- The Committee on Credentials met on the platform of Convention Hall during recess. Chairman Van Alen presided. All contests from Albany County were withdrawn. Onondaga and Herkimer Counties were passed and the Third Oneida District was taken up. C.K. Davis presented the case for the contestants, who were headed by Judge I.J. Evans.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- The Miller contest had no sooner been disposed of than William Barnes, Jr., Chairman of the Committee on Permanent Organization, reported the name of Stewart L. Woodford of Brooklyn for permanent Chairman.

These records in the blotter of Engine Company No. 14, which is commanded by Foreman Charles H. Shay, son of ex-Chief Charles Oscar Shay, were entered in sorrow, as they chronicled the end of two favorite Grimalkins.

The Pilot Commissioners met yesterday. Pilot Jacob Erickson, who was in charge of the Etruria Aug. 3 when she ran down the floating grain elevator Ceres off Liberty Island, made a report of the accident. He said that the elevator had the right of way, and he therefore had the steamship's engines stopped and steered to go astern.

BOSTON, Aug. 25. --The Messrs. Cramp have decided to have the official trial of the cruiser Brooklyn on Thursday instead of Wednesday. This change is made for the purpose of giving the men on board a complete rest, and to have everything put in condition for the official test.
OLD ORCHARD, Me., Aug. 25. - The feature of the great Republican mass meeting here this afternoon was the address of Thomas B. Reed, who spoke, in part, as follows:
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 25. - Thomas P. Penlon, Chairman of the Sound Money Democratic Convention which met here to-day, to-night sent the following telegram to President Cleveland:
SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- Much disorder attended the taking of the first ballot for Governor. The vote by counties was announced as follows:
The American Legion of Honor, fraternal benefit order that has 10,000 members in New-York City, is in trouble owing to the increase in assessments, caused by an unusually heavy death rate.
SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- Chairman Woodford, on finishing his speech, called for the report of the Committee on Resolutions. Lemuel E. Quigg of New-York read the platform, as follows:

It seems to have been a very pretty wedding at Newport yesterday, and it derived a pathetic interest from being the first appearance of the bride's father since his illness. This sign of his convalescence will rejoice not only everybody who knows Mr. VANDERBILT, but everybody who knows of him.

The Executive Committee of the striking knee pants makers completed the new union agreement yesterday, and about ten of the contractors signed it and got back their men, after giving bonds for the faithful observance of the agreement. These strikers, however, are not as well organized as are the tailors, and do not seem to have any leaders that are capable of managing the men.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- The Breakers, the villa here of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, is the grandest Summer residence in the world. It replaced a villa, which Mr. Vanderbilt bought from Pierre Lorillard several years ago, and which was destroyed by fire. It is taxed for a million, and undoubtedly is worth twice that sum.
SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- The following committees were announced by Temporary Chairman Black at the Republican Convention:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- Capt. W.T. Sampson, Naval Chief of Ordinance, has completed the list of merchant ships which may be depended upon in time of war to form an auxiliary navy. These ships comprise the pick of the vessels engaged in oceanic commerce and passenger transportation, and will materially increase the efficiency of our offensive and defensive qualities afloat.

RICHMOND, VA., Aug. 25. -- The Virginia sound-money Democrats are making a determined fight against the Populistic declarations of the Chicago Convention and the nominees of that body. Meetings were held yesterday in all parts of this State to elect delegates to the convention which meets here Thursday to send representatives to the National body.
The Captain and crew of the British tramp steamship Moldava were brought into this port yesterday by the Anchor Line steamship Circassia, from Glasgow, which had picked them up at sea.

The convention of the Republicans at Saratoga has its comic as well as its serious aspect. Fourteen candidates actually balloted for, of whom ten have been formally presented, constitute an unusual and excessive supply for a mere State Convention. The certainty of Republican success may have multiplied the number of aspirants, but it is more likely that the conditions of the balloting last night were the result of a prearranged scattering of forces.
Chairman Hanna was at the Republican headquarters early yesterday. He returned from Boston after midnight.
SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- The Platt boom went to sleep last night a glant. It did not awake this morning, and there was confusion in the house of the machine which had nourished it.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- Two ballots were taken for a Gubernatorial candidate in the Republican State Convention to-night, which revealed the most thoroughly mixed-up situation which has been seen of late years. They indicated nothing with certainty, except that there are some dark horses who may develop sufficient running qualities to reach the wire ahead of all those that have been so long in training.

BOSTON, Aug. 25. -- The State Convention of honest-money Democrats held here to-day, for a highly respectable and somewhat solemn gathering indulged liberally in the exuberance and enthusiam which characterize popular political assemblages composed of men who have something to hope for beyond the mere assertion of a principle.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- William J. Bryan, as the candidate of a great party, was accorded a reception by Albany this afternoon and evening such as has seldom been accorded a visitor within her gates. It is estimated that 10,000 persons attended the meeting in City Hall Square, composed of Albanians and residents of places within a radius of fifty miles of the Capital.

Mr. Bryan, in his speech at Madalin on the 22d inst., says: "They refuse to apply to the silver that is produced in the world the law of supply and demand. We say increase the demand for silver by legislation, and that new demand 'will raise the value of silver bullion to $1.20.'"

Developments in the financial district yesterday were interesting, and in some respects hopeful. Sterling exchange declined to $4.85 3/4, and engagements of $1,750,000 in gold resulted. No bank asked the Loan Committee of the Clearing House for accommodation.

The pavement of Third Avenue, from Harlem to Ninth Street, has attracted attention of late, and there have been criticism both as to its laying while the Third Avenue horse railroad was being change into a cable road and of the recent relaying.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- The great event of the season, in which all Newport was interested, though comparatively few of its people were present, the wedding of Henry Payne Whitney, son of the Hon. William C. Whitney, ex-Secretary of the Navy, and Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt, daughter and Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt, took place to-day.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The National Circuit bicycle meet, held at Woodlawn Oval yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Saratoga Good Roads Association, was, both in point of attendance and spirited racing, an unqualified success. The entries, while not us large as expected, included several of the cracks of the professional and amateur classes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- The War Department proper will take no further action regarding the military ceremonies attending the arrival and stay of Li Hung Chang in this country. The entire programme has been intrusted to Gen. Ruger, who commands the Department of the East, and who by vesture of this command is authorized to order troops to parade and assign officers to such duties as he pleases.

The trial of Superintendent Smith, of the Department of Fire Alarms and Telegraph in the Fire Department, went on before the Fire Board yesterday, and testimony was given by John A. Seely, of the firm of Belden Seely, contractors. The witness thought there was nothing in the New-York Fire Department specifications to prevent a contractor from bidding intelligently on the work.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 25. -- The Chicago yacht Vencedor was unmercifully beaten by the Canada in the first of the series of yacht races for the international yachting championship of the lakes, on Lake Erie, off Toledo, to-day.

LONDON, Aug, 25. -- Miss Clara Barton President of the American Red Cross Society, accompanied by her staff of aides, arrived in London to-day on her way to New-York, and in an interview with a representative of The United Associated Presses expressed herself as greatly pleased with the results of her mission to Turkey, which was undertaken a number of months ago for the purpose of distributing relief to the suffering Armenians in Anatoila.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- "Tom" Watson of Georgia, the unanimously nominated candidate of the People's Party at St. Louis for the Vice Presidency, is encountering some difficulty in arranging with the National Committee of his party his campaign assignments. Mr. Watson desires to be heard.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25. -- The thirty-footers raced to-day for three cups given by citizens, valued, respectively, at $100, $50, and $25. H.B. Duryea's Vaquero won the first, Bayard Thayer's Asahi the second, and H.P. Whitney's Dorothy the third.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. -- It was hardly to be expected that the gossips would permit the appointment of ex-Gov. Francis as Secretary of the Interior to pass without dwelling upon the alleged danger of the Senate refusing to confirm him. Already one hears the statement that the silver Senators may combine to defeat him.

LONDON, Aug. 25. -- The Royal Torbay Yacht Club's regatta was continued at Torbay to-day. The race for large raters over a, forty-four-mile course was won by the Caress on time allowance from the Ailsa, the only other starter. The Satanita was expected to start, but did not do so. The race for small raters was won by the Audrey, which beat the Penitent. Niagara, and Samphire in the order named.

No Democrat of New-England has a higher claim to the respect of his party than Mr. E.J. PHELPS of Vermont. His great ability, his strong and high character, the firmness and force with which he has upheld the cause of the party where it was continually in a hopeless minority, the distinction that he conferred upon his party and his country when Minister to England -- these are titles to confidence that none will deny.
Many gourmands have stood in rapt contemplation after reading this announcement in the show windows of a store in Third Avenue:

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- The Village mariners who sailed away last Friday night for New-Haven returned safe last night. They had a good time, but they say they will never begin another cruise on Friday.

Arrangements have been made to enable American manufacturers to exhibit machinery and mechanical appliances in Pekin University, Calna, without being obliged to pay duty, and it is believed that the scheme will affect the development of our export trade to China. The President of the Pekin University is H.H. Lowry, D.D., Superintendent of the Methodist Mission in China, and its Vice President and Secretary is Minister Denby.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 25. -- The State Democratic Sound Money Convention was called to order in Musical Fund Hall this afternoon by William M. Singerly, publisher of The Philadelphia Record. The auditorium was filled.

At auction, in the Trinity Building Sales room yesterday, Mr. D. Phoenix Ingraham sold, under foreclosure, to the plaintiff, Alfred B. Price, at $67,450, the six-story brick flat 133 and 135 West Eleventh Street, north side, 375 feet west of Sixth Avenue, 50 by 103.3. He also sold under foreclosure, to Thomas Stokes, at $23,600, the four-story brick dwelling 472 West End Avenue, east side, 60.815 feet south of Eighty-eighth Street, 20 by 100.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- During recess there was a lot of talk and strong efforts to get together and select a ticket, bat the booms held together and resisted all efforts at fasten. Mr. Platt's cottage was the scene of a continuous performance, so far as conferences went, but the time for the convention to reassemble arrived with everybody at sea as to the ultimate result.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- The convention gave Warner Miller a respectful hearing only on a personal appeal from Mr. Platt, and after that Mr. Miller walked out of the convention while the motion to adopt the report of the Credentials Committee, which excluded him as a delegate, was being carried. Just before that there had been one of the most interesting incidents of the day.

Mr. BRYAN was talking to farmers. The remarks which we have quoted above set forth clearly the chief cause of the decline of the prices of agricultural products here during the last twenty-five years. But Mr. BRYAN and all the other silverites tell the farmers that these prices have fallen because of the "appreciation of gold" and the "demonetization of silver"!

CHICAGO, Aug. 25. -- The State Convention of the National Democratic Party was called to order by Chairman Ewing of the State Executive Committee at 12:30 o'clock. The galleries had been crowded long before.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- Benjamin B. Odell, Chairman of the State Executive Committee, called the convention to order in the absence of Chairman Hackett of the State Committee at 12:30 P.M. He presented the name of Frank S. Black as the selection of the State Committee for temporary Chairman.
NEWARK, N.J. Aug. 25. -- The prevalence of glanders among horses in the Broome Street section of this city made necessary the killing to-day of five horses afflicted with the disease.

TUESDAY -- P.M. Business to-day was extremely dull, the total transactions amounting to only 95,710 shares. Fluctuations were narrow, and net charges were with few exceptions only fractional. The general list at the close was lower than yesterday. There was no news of an influential character.

From day to day I read of the various plans for the entertainment of Viceroy Li Hung Chang. He is to be feted, taken to West point, and then under and on the Brooklyn Bridge, Wouldn't he be surprised if he should enter a private residence in this town and find a chronological collection of the pottery and porcelain of his native land such as he could not see elsewhere in the world!

The immediate future of this country now rests upon the decision of the ten grain-growing States of the Upper Mississippi Valley -- Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, and Missouri. The centre of power now lies in this section.
F.B. Thurber of this city has sent the following open letter to William Jennings Bryan the candidate of the Chicago Convention for President of the United States:

Are the honest-money men looking to the nominations for the House of Representatives? Are they looking to these sharply and with a clear idea of how much depends upon right nominations and how these are to be brought about? We hope that they are, but we are by no means sure.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 25. -- On the morning of the first session of the ninth annual convention of Republican League Clubs, the reported effort of delegates from the Western States to capture the convention for free silver seems to have entirely disappeared. Not many delegates are present from those States, and those who are here declare themselves to be for the St. Louis platform.

SARATOGA, Aug. 25. -- Senator Myer Nussbaum of Albany made a record to-day. He made the speech placing Capt. John Palmer in nomination for Governor, and he did it without once saying. "The man who." The "man whoing" business was begun in the next speech by A. Sloat Fassett, and after that the words were used about a thousand times.

PLATT has for a good many years bristled with uses for the moralist, the publicist, and the political philosopher. He has been an excellent text for reproof and for edification But he hag not, until just now, appealed to the psychologist. That is to say, there was never any doubt or mystery about his motives.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

LARCHMONT MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 25. -- Burglars attempted to force an entrance into the ticket office of the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railway station here last evening, but were frightened away by Albert Banta, the night ticket agent and watchman.
The Matabeles have been whipped. Their chiefs have surrendered to the British and there is peace around Bulawayo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- In explanation of the fact that no arrangements have been made for official courtesies to Li Hung Chang by the heads of the Government departments on his brief visit to the National Capital, it is said at the War Department that the reception by the President in New-York and the other functions there will complete the proposes official entertainments as far as the United States Government is concerned.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The following were chosen as members of the new State Committee by the Republican Convention:

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 26. -- Husky of voice and tired of body after a hard day of campaigning, William Jennings Bryan found himself confronted on his arrival in Erie to-night with a programme calling for three more speeches before he could rest from the weariness that this day of railroad traveling and speechmaking had brought to him.

William Galway, nineteen years old, employed by Jackson Brothers, truckmen, of Gouverneur Slip, as a driver, was arrested at his home, 342 Madison Street, yesterday by detectives of the Leonard Street Station.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 26. -- People were gathered all along the streets of Syracuse, through which the train passed on its way to the New-York Central station, to see the Democratic nominee. Mr. Bryan stood on the rear plaform of his car, and bowed in response to the applause which marked the progress of his train.
" I have not been so near death since the war," said Senator Quay yesterday, "as I was last week, after catching that 203-pound tarpon off the Florida coast."
ATHENS, Aug. 26. -- A body of Turks yesterday made an attack upon the Cretans at Malevyzi, but were repulsed, losing forty of their number killed and twenty wounded.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- Newport's open-air house show was opened here to-day, and it was a success socially and professionally. All the boxes were filled with gayly-gowned cottagers, while the rows of reserved seats were crowded. Mrs. William Astor not in one of the boxes, with A. le Ghait, the Belgian Minister, as her escort.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The committee of the Jeffersonian Club of this city appointed to draft resolutions indorsing Bryan and Sewall and the Chicago platform, which was composed of ex-Congressman Dr. Thomas Dunn English, Jeremiah O'Rourke, Joseph A. Beccher, Gladstone K. Rogers, and Henry F. Phillips, has reported as follows:

SARATOGA, Aug. 26. -- Timothy Lester Woodruff, Park Commissioner of Brooklyn, is one of the youngest politicians in that city. He has been an active Platt man, and broke away from the anti-Platt crowd shortly after Mayor Wurster appointed him Park Commissioner.

Oscar Hammerstein, the proprietor of the Olympia, the Harlem Opera House, and the Columbia Theatre, made known yesterday the particulars of a theatrical venture he has under way, and of another to be launched later.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 26. -- The gold Democrats held a State Convention here to-day to select delegates to represent them at the National Convention to be held at Indianapolis Sept. 2. Arnold Greene presided. The following delegates and alternates were chosen:

As the study of genealogy increases among us, so do the typographical merits of the printed books improve. Some of the early ventures in this line were indifferent examples of the printer's art; many were poor specimens of local printing, when in most cases means that they came from country presses, type, ink, paper, and binding being of the least attractive kinds.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 26. -- Recent information received by Consul Niederieln of Costa Rica shows that on Aug. 12 the Government of Cost Rica abolished its tobacco monopoly, allowing free cultivation of tobacco in the entire area of the Republic. This open a new market to Americans manufacturers for agricultural implements and tobacco machinery, and a new field for American enterprise in tobacco growing.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 26. -- The locked-out men of the Brown Hoisting and Conveying Company's works have voted to return to work, and the famous strike, productive of several battles and riots, is broken.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- Major McKinley gave cut his letter of acceptance this afternoon, having finished his last reading and revision of it at 12:30 o'clock. The letter touches upon all of the important pranks in the Republican National platform, but the first half of it is devoted to an incisive discussion of the money question. The letter is as follows:

HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The first game of the championship series between Oritani and Orange resulted in a tie after ten innings of the hardest kind of play. Mackey, the Oritani pitcher, allowed Orange only three hits, one of which was a scratch bunt, Stephens was almost as effective for Orange. The score:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- The report telegraphed from San Francisco, that the Monocacy was lost at some time previous to Aug. 3, is set down by naval officials as a sailor's yarn related to the marines. On Aug. 15, two weeks after the alleged loss, the department received a cablegram from Admiral McNair, announcing that Commander Reisinger of the Monocacy had been invalided home.

" Dad" Clarke pitched for the New-York team against the St. Louis players at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The visitors made twelve safe hits, but owing to the sharp fielding of the home team could only score 4 runs. Donohue pitched for the visitors, and 11 runs were netted by the New-Yorks.

The financial centre was calm yesterday, while, with the prospect of gold shipments estimated at $4,000,000 within ten days and $20,000,000 to $25,000,000 within two months, there was an undercurrent of buoyancy.
SARATOGA, Aug. 26. -- The Republican State Convention finished its work in one session to-day. It was slow in assembling, and it was nearly noon when Chairman Woodford rapped for order.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The old Summer residence of George Hanneman, a wealthy naval contractor, on Clark Street, was destroyed by fire yesterday. The house was a large one, but it had been unoccupied for a long time. Its location made it a tempting resort for tramps, but it is said that no member of the wandering fraternity ever slept there a second night, and the regular rounders gave it a wide berth.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- After an exciting contest, the Canada won her second race from the Vencedor to-day by the narrow margin of 26 seconds, corrected time, and with it captured the beautiful Toledo Challenge Cup, the international yachting championship of the lakes, and 60 per cent, of the fifteen-hundred-dollar purse offered by the citizens of Toledo.

SARATOGA, Aug. 26. -- Candidate Black, who started for the Executive Chamber to-day, was the man who headed a delegation to that chamber when Gov. Flower was there, and asked for special Executive action in prosecuting the "Pat" Shea case. Gov. Flower would not listen to him, and essentially he was shown out.

There are several lawyers and others in Brooklyn who are looking for Frank L. Barnard, who for years was Deputy County Clerk in Brooklyn. He is a lawyer, a son of the late Daniel P. Barnard, and a nephew of Justice Barnard of the Supreme Court.

Mr. MacGregor, British Vice Consul at Barranquilla, has published a report in regard to the trade of Colombia, which will be found to contain a great deal of information interesting and valuable to all doing business with that country, or in any way connected with its interests.

The American Marine Merchant Association, of which Arthur Sewall, Vice Presidential nominee of the Bryan Democrats, is the President, is trying to get the Republican campaign speakers to advocate the policy of high protection for the benefit of American shipping. These Republican orators are asked to do this "in the interest of protection."

PORT ANGELES, Washington, Aug. 26. -The War Department has directed Brig. Gen. E. Otis, commanding the Department of the Columbia, to clear all settlers off military reservations on Puget Sound. The order is preliminary to the early fortifying of important strategic points along the Northwestern frontier.

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The sound-money convention held to-day in the Opera House here was a success, notwithstanding the early fears of the men who managed it. The gold Democrats throughout the State expressed their sympathy, but offered no assistance because they were timid and dislike the notoriety that an affiliation with an independent political movement secures.

General financial conditions explain the results of recently protected bond issues by the city. No class of securities rank higher than municipal bonds, and New-York City bonds are regarded by investors here as the bust in that class.

Rear Admiral Richard W. Meade (retired) has been brought forward by Lafayette Post, No. 140, G.A.R., of this city as a candidate for Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, to be voted for at the National Eucampment at St. Paul Sept. 2, 3, and 4, as the successor of the present Commander in Chief, Gen. Ivan N. Walker.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- The Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad Company put into effect to-day a flat freight tariff on grain from Kansas points to Chicago based on local rates. This places the rates on the same basis as those mode by any other line quoting proportional rates. The new tariff gives all shippers the same advantage.

BOSTON, Aug. 26. -- Affairs were extremely quiet on board the cruiser Brooklyn to-day. The workmen strolled or sprawled about the ship, getting, for the first time since leaving Philadelphia, the rest that is needed by them before entering into the hard work necessary in tomorrow's official test of the big cruiser's capabilities.
Gen. Benjamin Harrison reached the city last night a little after 10 o'clock. He was due at 9:40, but the train was late. He was accompanied by his wife and his private secretary, E.F. Tibbott.

Lord Salisbury's installation as Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports and Constble of Dover Castle was marked by all the ancient ceremonies. His predecessors in the office during the Queen's reign have been Lord Palmerston, the Duke of Wellington, Earl Granville, Mr. W.H. Smith, and the Marquis of Dufferin.
ERIE, Penn., Aug. 26. -- The eighth annual General Assembly of the Democratic Societies of Pennsylvania was opened this morning at 11 o'clock in the Park Opera House.
Mr. Hobart returned to Republican headquarters yesterday from his hurried visit to Canton, Ohio. He was in Canton only one day.

NEWPORT R.I., Aug. 26. -- Two thousand cards went out to-day to various parts of the world announcing the marriage of Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt. They are in heavy script lettering on thick pebbled paper. They are simple and neat, and directed in a neat feminine hand. They read:

At some time in a remote past the factories of Fall River must have earned fully as much as anybody suspected, and it is probable that the sum total was considerably larger than it was generally assumed to be. At all events, most of the companies were fortunate enough to accumulate surplus accounts which have not petered out as yet, and it is no secret that managers have drawn on them heavily.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 26. -- Major McKinley hardly had a breathing spell to-day. A number of messages commending his speech to the farmers came from people, in the West this morning. Among the callers at the McKinley residence were the surviving members of the Second Ohio Battery.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26. -- At the office of Moore Brothers, agents of the Diamond Match Company, it was stated this morning that the losses sustained at Ontonagon, Mich., by that company are fully covered by insurance. The logs belonging to the company in that locality are in the river, three miles from the place where the fire occurred.

The nomination of Mr. FRANK S. BLACK of Troy for the office of Governor by the Republican Convention at Saratoga was a party nomination in the strictest sense, but it was an altogether reputable party nomination. It was not dictated by a "boss," and if Mr. BLACK becomes subservient to a "boss" as a candidate or as a Governor it will be his own fault.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 26. -- About three hundred sound-money Democrats, anxious to show their hearty accord with "honest money" partisans in other States in their fight against freo silver, met at Rennert's Hotel to-night and selected sixteen delegates to represent Maryland at the Indianapolis Convention.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 26. -- The National Convention of the League of Republican Clubs concluded its business at the session to-day, and will meet at Detroit the second Tuesday of July next. The session was attended with some excitement, arising over the contest for the Presidency. This was confined to Charles U. Gordon of Illinois and D.D. Woodmansee of Ohio, the latter an old league man, the former a recent worker in the ranks.

ONTONAGON, Mich., Aug. 26. -- Twelve dwelling houses situated in the extreme eastern part of the village are all that remains to-day of Ontonagon, which twenty-four hours before was a prosperous community of 2,000 people, comfortably housed. The fire which swept through the village yesterday afternoon left these people homeless and dependent upon public charity for food and shelter.

BELMONT, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Allegany County to-day presents a political situation more interesting, because more doubtful, than any other county of Western New-York. It is the scene of a revolt against Platt and his local lieutenants more determined than elsewhere can be found, and it is also the locality where Populism and free silver have taken the firmest hold on the convictions of farmers of all parties.
Ex-Judge Henry Hilton's effort to continue the dry goods business, out of which Alexander T. Stewart drew a fortune every season, came to an end yesterday in failure.

Bryan has "struck his old gall again." He has quit "making believe" he is a statesmen, and once more is before the people in his accustomed role of demagogue, talking rubbish about the oppression of the poor by the rich, the cruel sufferings inflicted on the tolling masses by the heartless millionaires, and the miserable condition of the laboring classes growing out of their subjection to the goldbugs.

LARCHMONT MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 26 -The annual parade and inspection of the Larchmont Fire Department took place this evening. It was witnessed by all the villagers and many persons from New-Rochelle and Mamaroneck.

The annual regatta of the Middle States Association will be held this year on Labor Day, Monday, Sept. 7. This is a little later than it is usually held. So much interest is being taken this year in rowing, and Labor Day being a holiday, it is expected by the Regatta Committee that this will be the biggest regatta of its kind this season, and, in fact, the biggest in several seasons.

PORT TOWNSEND, Washington, Aug. 26. -- Telegraphic orders have been received by the senior revenue cutter officer on Puget Sound, Capt. D.F. Tozier, to put the new steam revenue cutters Guard and Scout into service. Crews are now being shipped, and the two vessels have been commissioned, respectively, under the commands of Lieuts. H.B. West and G.L. Carden.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26. -- Secretary Carlisle to-day addressed the following ratio to a correspondent in Ohio, in regard to the unit of value, and authorized its publication as an answer to many other similar inquiries which are constantly being addressed to him:

SARATOGA, Aug. 26. -- Charges of broken promises were flung around in plenty after the convention adjourned to-day. They came largely from the Aldridge people, who were very mad, although their chief made the best of the situation.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 26. -- Ex-Gov. David R. Francis of Missouri passed through Cincinnati last evening on his way home. To a reporter he said:

SARATOGA, Aug. 26. -- It was plain to be seen when all the delegates had assembled in the convention hall to-day that there was to be no "show business" about to-day's proceedings. It was all right enough for the machine to allow delegates to vote as they saw fit on the two ballots of last night, just to mask the batteries of the machine, but that wouldn't do for to-day.

Some very interesting racing atoned slightly for the poor judgment displayed by Atlanta Wheelman in starting their postponed meet at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. There was a big, good-natured crowd on hand at Waverly Park, N.J., to witness the sport, but nobody relished leaving the track at 7 o'clock, and many departed before the final event.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- The failure of the usually vigorous vocal organs of the young Democratic nominee for the Presidency to perform with their accustomed strength disappointed the multitude that assembled in Brown's Square this afternoon to hear Mr. Bryan deliver a speech.
Primaries for the election of delegates to the State Convention of the Democratic Party Reform Organization will be held in this city to-morrow night.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 26. -- Mr. Bryan arrived here at 7 o'clock, after a journey of two hours and a half from Buffalo, made in a special train furnished by his supporters to this city. A committee of five from Erie consisting of Otto Germer, W.A. Minz John S. Rilling, W.C. Crosby, and L. met him at the Buffalo station and asserted him to the special.
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Superintendent George W. Aldridge made the following statement after the convention:

There was no change in the general charter of the stock market to-day. The volume of business was small, the transactions amounting to only 101,962 shares. Prices sagged during the morning, improved slightly in the afternoon, and closed generally lower than yesterday. There were exceptional declines in Baltimore and Ohio of 2 3/4 points, in Illinois Steel of 5 points, and in Pittsburg.

A queer story comes from Na-au-say Township, in Kendall County, Ill. Mrs. Platt has been very sick for over a year -- so ill that her life has been at times despaired of. A few weeks ago the family completed building a new house, about three -- quarters of a mile south of the old one, and, loading patient into a large surrey on an improvised cot, they started for the new home.

The papers are enthusiastic about the victory of persimmon, or rather of the Prince of Wales, at the Derby. Nothing succeeds like success, and the Prince is popular, so that even we who for local reasons wished "Tueful" (as we call him) to win, take our beating philosophically. But why should the Stock Exchange burst cut into singing "God bless the Prince of Wales?"

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Alderman Henry E. Walters of this city has received a telegram from Mayor P.J. Gleason of Long Island City accepting the invitation to umpire the baseball game between the Alderman of Yonkers and Mount Vernon. The ball game is to be played in North Broadway, Yonkers, Labor Day, and the proceeds are to be devoted to the Exempt Firemen's Association of Yonkers.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 26. -- It was thought a couple of weeks ago that there would be no contest whatever at the National Democratic Party Convention for the Presidential nomination, but since then things have taken on a somewhat different aspect. Among those prominently mentioned to head the ticket are Senator Vilas and Gen. Bragg of Wisconsin, Henry Watterson of Kentucky, Senator Palmer of Illinois, Secretary Morton of Nebraska, and Senator Gray of Delaware.

SIASCONSET, Mass., Aug. 26. -- Out on the far side of Nantucket Island, built on a bluff, between which and the Old World is nothing but a narrow strip of while sand and 4,000 or 5,000 miles of deep blue. sea, is Siasconset, which everybody Who knows the place calls Sconset. It is a Sconner town.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 26. -- Charles E. Green, Jr., a young lawyer of Trenton, whose father is a millionaire, occupies a cottage at Anon, just south of this place. He was awakened this morning about 2:30 o'clock by a noise in his bedroom. Raising up, he saw a man in front of the bureau examining the jewelry and trinkets by the light of a dark lantern.
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 26. -- The Republican Convention for the selection of Presidential Electors will be held here to-morrow.

The quaint and time-honored ceremonial which is associated with the presentation of a flitch of bacon to each married couple who can prove that "for a twelve-month and a day" they have lived without domestic strife and have not wished themselves unmarried, was performed at Dunmow on the 8d inst., and, as heretofore, attracted the whole countryside, not to speak of many hundreds of London visitors, to the little Essex town.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Aug. 26. -- The following League of American Wheelmen weekly bulletin was issued to-day by Chairman Gideon of the Racing Board:

Louisville's ball players met the Brooklyn team twice yesterday, and were beaten in each game. Harper pitched for the home team, and hold the visitors down to five hits, which resulted in two runs. Hill pitched for the Louisvilles, and nine runs were scored by the home team. The Louisvilles started off well. scoring in the first inning, but they were unable to keep up the pace.

Those who have seen fire horses dashing from their stalls to an exact spot where the suspended harness may be dropped upon them and with a few deft manipulations, fastened ready for a start have little idea of the patient and persistent effort required to train the animals promptly and unfailingly to do their part in securing the one great point of dispatch.

LYONS, N.Y., Aug. 26. -- Assemblyman George S. Horton of Wolcott two weeks ago considered himself sure of a renomination for a fourth term. Nearly all of the delegates to the nominating convention were chosen when delegates were elected to the convention which named the Wayne representatives to the State Convention.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 26. -- Mr. and Mrs. Bryan, who spent the night in Bagg's Hotel, Utica, were to have left there at 5 A.M. to-day, but were persuaded to take the 7:10 train instead. They walked from the hotel to the station. A few persons were on the platform and they sent the candidate off with a cheer.

The Democratic General Committee of Brooklyn, the McLaughlin organization, met Tuesday night and indorsed the nomination of Bryan and Sewall and the Chicago platform. Over 600 members of the committee were present in the Atheueum, Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, and of them all, Edmund R. Terry of the First Ward was the only one who spoke against the resolution of indorsement and in favor of sound money.

Messrs. James Kyle Sons have sold for the estate of Marion Osborne to Mandelbaum Lewine the three-story frame building 146 East Forty-fourth Street, 25 by 100 A five-story flat will be built on the lot. The Messrs. Nyle have also sold for Henry Folk the five-story brick tenement 326 East Thirty-ninth Street, 25 by 05 by 100.

A French engineer proposed last year to the Directors of live International exposition to be given in the French capital in the year 1900 the digging of a hole to the depth of one mile. The ides was favor ably received, but on investigation the magnitude of the undertaking became so apparent that the idea has been dropped.

The sub-committee on draft of the Greater New-York Commission yesterday made public Chapters 12, 13, 14, and 15 of the charter, providing for the Departments of Buildings, Public Charities, Correction, and the Fire Department. Chapter 12, relating to the Department of Buildings, contains a complete codification of the laws governing the erection of buildings in New-York City, and covers seventy-seven pages.

At Glastonbury, England, in 3892, the discovery was made of lake dwellings near a small pool, which poll in the long past must have been a fairly large expanse of water. To-day it is hardly more than a wet meadow. Certain mounds were opened by local archaeologists, and far beneath were found the dwellings of the original lake dwellers.

The ferryhouse of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company in Jersey City took on a warlike appearance yesterday afternoon upon the arrival from Fort Myer, Va., of a detachment of the Sixth United States Cavalry, which is to act as escort to Li Hung Chang, the Chinese Viceroy, during his stay in the city.

SARATOGA, Aug. 26. -- Candidate Black said, after his nomination, that he would not begin campaign work until he had taken a short vacation. In a day or two he would go with his family to his old home in Maine. He could not say what part he would take in the campaign until he had conferred with the committee in charge.

The length of time consumed by the Royal Commission on Vaccination in dealing with questions as to which all the materials necessary for arriving at sound conclusions had for many years been available to all who wished to use them has been little short of a public scandal, and has been indirectly the cause of a smallpox mortality which both could have and caught to have been avoided.
Is THE TIMES quite fair in its criticism of Major McKinley's letter of acceptance?

The condition of affairs along the river front in Brooklyn -- the absence of vessels at the docks and of freight to handle -- has made the longshoremen thoughtful about the outcome of this Fall's election.
Ex-Congressman William J. Coombs, President of the Manufacturers' Trust Company of Brooklyn, a sound-money Democrat, in discussing the recent failures of business houses, yesterday said:

CONCORD, N.H., Aug. 27. -- The down express on the Concord Division of the Boston and Maine Railroad due here at 2:28 P.M. left the rails on account of a defective switch near Ferry Street, throwing several cars from the track and injuring several passengers. An ambulance with a corps of physicians has gone to the scene of the wreck.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- A special dispatch from Constantinople says that yesterday afternoon a party of forty men, armed with revolvers and bombs, forced their way into the Quenian Bank, killing the gendarmes into were guarding the doors of the institution. The clerks employed in the bank and look refuge in the office of the Regie, which is next door to the bank.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- The specially interesting event in society to-night was the young people's dance which Mrs. George Hoffman gave in honor of Miss Hoffman. There was general dancing untill midnight, when supper was served on the in-closed piazzas, and then followed the cotillion, led by Maurice Duval and Miss Hoffman.

LONDON, Aug. 27. -- The Foreign Office has received dispatches from Zanzibar, stating that the usurping Sultan, Said Khalid, having refused to surrender this morning in accordance with the terms of the British Consul's ultimatum, the palace was bombarded by the warships in the harbor, and, after the bombardment, was captured by the British sailors and marines, who had been landed by the war vessels.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- Two hundred delegates were in attendance at the State Convention of the sound-money Democrats here to-day. Congressman Outhwaite presided. Among the prominent Democrats in the convention were V.P. Kline of Cleveland, W.W. Medary of this city, Col. S.K. Donavin, Henry Apthorp, Julius Dexter of Cincinnati, and E.L. Hinman of Columbus.
SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 27. -- Former General Master Workman of the Knights of Labor Terence V. Powderly, when asked to-day who he thought would be elected the next President, said:
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.
Harry Hill died at Flushing, L.I., last night. Death was caused by chills and fever. He had been ill but one week.

After making all reasonable allowance for the disappointment of unsuccessful writers, after admitting that no honest editor can expect to be popular among contributors, the plain fact remains that the casual contributor does not understand his true position. His demands are frequently unreasonable, and there need be little hesitation in saying that he receives far more consideration than he deserves.

Mr. MCKINLEY'S assertion that the tariff is of "supreme importance" and his announcement that it will be the "first duty" of the Republican Party to enter upon a campaign of tariff agitation must have disheartened those of his Republican friends who are wise enough to perceive the danger he incurs in obstinately sticking to this narrow and worn-out creed of his party.

Gold news yesterday was of a kind to strengthen predictions that the import movement now begun is for long account, and will bring a great amount of that metal here in the next few weeks. Shipments and engagements reach $9,550,00, distributed among the following banking houses and banks:

The resignation of Gen. Bronsart von Schelieudorf still monopolizes the attention of the German press. The organs of almost all parties agree in regretting the occurrence, and even the comment of the Socialist Vorwarts is devoid of that bitterly scornful tone which usually characterizes its utterances.

Ex-President Benjamin Harrison was the principal speaker at a meeting in Carnegie Music Hall last night, designed as the formal opening of the Republican campaign by the National and State Organizations.

Joyce's New-York ball players are now tied for seventh place with the Brooklyn team in the championship race. The New-Yorks won two games from the St. Louis team yesterday at the Polo Grounds and broke a record. This is the first time this season that they have won two games in one afternoon.

A destructive fire broke out at 4 o'clock this morning (Aug. 18) at the Industrial Exhibition of Montpellier. The book department was in a few minutes burned to embers. It contained a gallery of rare pictures of men and scenes connected with Montpellier, throughout the history of that old and famous university city.

What nonsense it is to say that Bryan is fighting for the "common people"; to speak of him as if he was the champion of a certain class of American citizens oppressed and made miserable by a certain other class. Whenever Bryan makes a speech he grows eloquent as he talks about the alleged sufferings of the "tolling" masses, the bondage of the "common people," and the cruel wrongs of the wage earners.

VIENNA, Aug. 27. -- The Emperor and Empress of Russia arrived here this morning. Their Majesties were met at the station and welcomed by Emperor Francis Joseph, Empress Elizabeth, and a number of Archdukes and Archduchesses. A large crowd of people assembled near the station, and cheered the imperial visitors with great enthusiasm.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- Further reductions in freight rates between Chicago and St. Paul were made yesterday. Early in the morning information was received by the railroad companies that the Lake Superior Steamboat Line had put in effect the following new tariff from Chicago to St. Paul:

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- Superintendent George W. Aldridge of the State Department of Public Works to-day opened the bids for the first piece of work under the nine-million-dollar scheme for the improvement of the canals. The bids were for lengthening Locks 21 and 22, Erie Canal, and for other incidental work.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- A rumor was current today that the Moore brothers, who have been prominent in connection with the bull movement collapse in Diamond Match stock and the closing of the Stock Exchange, would be asked to resign their positions; J.H. Moore as First Vice President and W.H. Moore as Second Vice President, to make room for P.D. Armour and George M. Pullman, the largest individual holders of Diamond Match stock.

Night bicycle riding was continued at the Olympia track, One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street and Lenox Avenue, last evening. The track has been improved, and additional lights have been provided, so that the riders were easily seen from all parts of the grounds. Some of the best riders of the district were entered, and excellent time was made.

The long statement of the Armenian Relief Association appealing to the business men of America, the bankers and merchants, for the creation of an adequate relief and rescue fund of $1,000,000 to relieve the persecuted and distressed Armenians does not meet with the full approval of the National Armenian Relief Committee.

M. Berthelot, now happily returned from the opportunism of politics to the opportunities of science, transcended the occasion of the moment in his Presidential address at the Sorbonne to the second International Congress of Applied Chemistry. His words should reach beyond the delegates, although these had come from Peru and Russia, from Mauritius and from the United States, and strike the attentive ears of the whole civilized world.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- The thirty-footers had a fine race to-day for a cup given by Edwin D. Morgan, ex-Commodore of the New-York Yacht Club. The wind was southwest, and it blew strongly and steadily all the afternoon. The course was from Brenton's Cove to and around Dyer's Island Buoy and return, a distance of sixteen miles.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 27. -- One of the principal topics of conversation among the cottagers and hotel guests here to-day was the enforcement of the bicycle law, by the police authorities of this place, which has been the means of catching a number of the guests, and the cottagers, and some of their families in the trap.

READVILLE, Mass., Aug. 27. -- The third day of the New-England Breeders' Association races drew another immense crowd, the grand stand and grounds being taxed to their utmost. The unfinished 2:16 pace of yesterday was finished to-day. The fourth and fifth heats were won by Lantana, who thus captured the race, with Kentucky Star second, and Robert R. third.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 27. -- Sound-money Democrats appear to be thoroughly satisfied with their State Convention, held in this city to-day. The attendance was about what the leaders anticipated, and the enthusiasm was manifested in many ways. The convention was the result of a conference between Joseph Bryan of The Times and other influential sound-money men.

PARIS, Aug. 27. -- Advices from Rio de Janeiro say rumor is in circulation there that Dr. Carlos Augusto de Carvallo, Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Dr. Antonio Goncalves Ferrelva, Minister of Justice, have resigned their portfolios in consequence of the trouble between Italy and Brazil.

Policeman John H. Jones of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station went out on patrol duty in uniform at midnight of Wednesday, and was to be on post until 6 o'clock yesterday morning. His post was in One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, from Lexington Avenue to the East River.
It was quiet at Republican headquarters yesterday. Mr. Hanna got to work at 10 o'clock in the morning, and he and the entire force of secretaries and clerks were busy all day.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The children's Idle held to-day in Purdy's Grove was so novel and was conducted on so large a scale that many visitors came from all around to watch the antics of the youngsters.

One need not be very far along in life to have seen the whole of the decline and fall of the great house of A.T. STEWART. It is but twenty years since the founder died, and he died the first of merchant princes. His house had reached its highest prosperity within the two or three years before.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- Passed East -- Steam yachts Repose, B.B. McGrezur; Nada; Forget-Me-Not, W.H. and G.P. Butler; Thelma, J.A. Mollenhauer; Trophy, E.H. Bennett; Ncoya, E.N. Dickerson; Theresa, Gustavus Sidenberg; Parthenia, Stephen J. Reach; Orienta, E.R. Lalew; Alicia, H.M. Flagler, and Lorna, W.L. Stow; schooner yacht Neaera, Henry K. McHarg, and cutter yachts Infanta, John D. Mills, and Xara, Pullip T. Dodge.

As he turned his back upon the "enemy's country" and retreated toward a more congenial clime Mr. BRYAN recovered his recklessness of speech. He scattered on his way from Albany to Erie such a picturesque variety of false statements that we can believe in his honesty only at the expense of his intelligence.

Mr. E.R. Henry, Inspector General of Police at Bengal, has published an exceedingly interesting report on the results of the working of the anthropometric system for the identification of old offenders during the past year. It seems that the measure of success in tracing the antecedents of criminals the local police fail to identify is steadily growing.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 27. -- At the Sound-Money Democratic Convention, at Montgomery to-day, the enthusiasm that marked the proceedings was a shock to the supporters of Bryan and Sewall. Forty-one counties out of sixty-six were represented by delegations in spite of the short notice given.

The police force in and around the hall numbered 350 men, commanded by Acting Inspector Harley of the Fourth District. There was also a corps of Central Office detectives inside on the lookout for pickpockets. Perfect order was maintained.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 27. -- The division of the Maryland Democrats has raised a question about the election judges and clerks. By the law there are two judges from the majority party and one from the minority. At present the Republicans are in the majority, and all the Election Boards have a majority of Republicans. The Democratic Supervisors, as a rule, belong to the section of the party opposed to Gorman and the machine.

Mrs. Lucia O. Case, who was recently nominated for the office of Attorney General on the National Party ticket, has written to Dr. Newton or Ottawa, Chairman of the State Committee, declining the honor. Mrs. Case was not informed of any intention to place her name in nomination until she read The Capital's report of the proceedings of the convention, and her name was placed on the ticket without her consent.

Li Hung Chang will not, if he arrives before late in the afternoon to-day, be taken from the steamship St. Louis of the American Line to the Dolphin and spirited away. If he were taken off by the Dolphin, many people would be deprived of the pleasure of seeing him.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- The total estimated liabilities of Hilton, Hughes Co. of New-York to Boston shoe dealers is over $50,000. It is also reported that she manufacturers throughout New-England are creditors to a consideraoble extent. The firm's accounts in Boston are scattered among several houses, and in most cases the amounts will not exceed $2,000.
PANAMA, Colombia, Aug. 27. -- The Star and Herald says:

HAVANA, Aug. 27. -- The report of an engagement between insurgents and Spanish troops near Manzanillo has been received here. The Spanish force, which was commanded by Capt. Gomela and consisted of 125 men, was largely outnumbered by the rebels. At the first fire Capt. Gomela fell. The troops immediately formed a square and repulsed the charge made by the cavalry of the enemy, and reinforcements arriving, the rebels were dispersed.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Aug. 27. -- Commodore E.C. Berriman of the Lincoln Park Club, the owner of the Vencedor, challenged the Royal Canadian Yacht Club of Toronto to race next year. The challenge reads as follows: ...

In many of the English counties, dairy farming was conducted on a large scale. Cheshire then, as now, was celebrated for its cheese, though much of the so-called Cheshire cheese was made in Staffordshire and Lancashire. "Such quantities are made of it that London alone is said to take annually 14,000 tons; vast quantities are also sent to Bristol, York, Scotland, Ireland, "

Arthur B. Hagen, fifty-two years old, of 17 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, a tall, good-looking, well-dressed and intelligent man, who gave his occupation as dry goods clerk, was committed by Magistrate Kudlich, in Yorkville Court yesterday, to answer a charge of fraudulently obtaining money.

ALBANY, Aug. 27. -- The work of organizing the third party movement in the Counties of Renssolaer, Saratoga, Washington, and Columbia is about completed. Gen. Charles Tracy says he has been in correspondence with Democrats who refuse to support the Chicago ticket in these counties, and that he was surprised to find the work of local organization well under way before he, as National Committeeman, began his search for some one to come out.
The following letter was sent to Mayor Strong yesterday by Wahle Stone, attorneys:
The trial of J. Elliott Smith, Superintendent of Fire Alarm and Telegraph for the Fire Department, was continued yesterday before the Board of Fire Commissioners.

Cleophus turned the tables on Chic in the opening race at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday, which was a run over the Faurity course with a field of ten starters. When the pair met last Tuesday Sims held Chic too cheaply, and allowed the Littlefield ally to get such a lead in the early stages of the race that Cleophus was not able to catch her.

A party of fifty or more bicycle riders, male and female, headed by a pretty figure on a racing wheel, dressed in light knickerbockers, brown stockings, a blazer jacket, and white cap, passed up the Riverside Drive Wednesday night at the rate of twelve or fifteen miles an hour.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- James S. Clarkson of Iowa was heard from to-day at Republican National headquarters for the first time since the campaign opened. He has been recovering his health at Spring Lake, N.J., and from that place wrote to headquarters as follows:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 27. -- At the second day's session of the Sound-Money Democratic State Convention, the following delegates at large to the Indianapolis Convention were chosen: John Cosgrove of Cooper, R.E. Anderson of Marion, W. Shelton of Dunklin, and C.C. Williams of Vernon.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27. -- The attendance at the horse show to-day was much larger than yesterday. Every reserved seat was taken and the public stands were crowded.

It was a good speech that ex-President HARRISON made at Carnegie Hall last night, a very good speech; so strong and convincing that the tribunes of the Democratic Party would find it hard to answer were they not already half in agreement with him as to much that he has to say and altogether in accord with his defense of sound money.

There is no good reason to doubt the news that the Sultan has granted to Crete a Christian Governor and a sufficient amount of autonomy to make her practically independent. Such action was inevitable when England refused to join hands with Germany in enforcing a blockade of the island.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 27. -- It now can be positively stated that Senator Caffery of Louisiana will be the permanent Chairman of the coming National Democratic Party Convention. Ex-Gov. Flower of New-York is slated for temporary Chairman.

As near as is the mountain from which this city takes its name, the largest deposit of nickel in the world is said to exist. There are thousands of tons in sight, and the assays show the ore to be of the highest quality. The mine is owned by Tacomans and was found by accident.

BUFFALO, Aug. 27. -- No public man ever received a heartier reception in Buffalo during a political campaign than that given William J. Bryan to-night. It was, in fact, continuous from the time Mr. Bryan reached the Lake Shore station at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon, after a journey of two hours and a half from Erie, marked by an incidents of interest, until he escaped from the crowd just before midnight and went to bed.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 27. -- About 3 o'clock this morning there was a lively time at the St. Rosalie Hotel, the guests, about twenty-five in number, flying to save their lives. The St. Rosalie, a hotel situated near the Mansion House and the United States Hotel, had a laundry that did a large business with the Summer hotel guests and cottagers.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 27. -- Lancaster took a big lead in the first inning to-day, but was able to score only one run thereafter, while Paterson, by lucky kitting, aided by bases on balls in the eighth inning, tied the score and won out in the ninth. Score:

YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 27. -- The case of Lyman Andrews of New-York, who was accused by his wife of non-support, was before Acting City Judge Reilly here this morning. There was a preliminary hearing last Saturday. When the case was called to-day, Alfred Beglow, counsel for Mr. Andrew's, asked that the case be dismissed.

Two trots were decided on the half-mile track of the Parkway Driving Club yesterday. They were for the 2:24 and 2:50 classes. A fair-sized gathering of Brooklyn horesmen was present, and enjoyed the sport very much. For a while it looked as though the racing would be rather tame, but the 2:24 class turned out to be a horse race, after all.
