The story of a quarrel in which Thomas O'Rourke, George Dixon's manager, and Edward J. Shipley, who is in business at 41 Water Street, figured, came out before Commissioner Andrews yesterday, in the trial of the charges against Patrolmen James O'Brien, Edward Sullivan, and Frederick J. Grecke of the Mercer Street Station.

" Farmer" Little came to town. He had been to the St. Louis and Chicago Conventions, and was on his way to Saratoga -- he attends all the conventions. "Farmer" Little loves a game, but, as he says, "the limit mus'nt be too high, 'Cause why' Crops is poor, income is limited, and expenses is regular."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- The report of the Governor of Louisiana regarding the Italian lynchings did not reach the State Department this morning, much to the disappointment of Baron Fava, the Italian Ambassador, who makes no concealment of his regret at the delay of this Government in rendering redress for what his own Government is disposed to look upon as an international affront.

In an article reproduced in this paper recently the musical critic of The Saturday Review vehemently attacked Baireuth as a place where the widow and son of Wagner were now coining into money the dead composer's fame, and that in return they give operas badly sang and badly acted, with scenery badly painted, though admirably managed.

Our specialists in history, whether on the Teutonic or the Celtic side, may allow too little influence to the Roman factor in the making of England, and of the English people; but in France, and especially in Southern France, there can be no temptation of that kind, for Latin is to be read almost as clearly in the race as in the language.

The parents of Beverly Tucker built expressly for him a pretty and modern house on the outskirts of White Plains, N.Y., only a year ago. It is a house of mourning to-day, the body of the young man for whom it was built having been found out in the road yesterday morning.

A young actor, who, well nurtured, well educated, and well liked had already mormed the lower rungs of the theatrical ladder came by his death on the stage of the Novelty Theatre early yesterday morning.

TABOR, N.J., Aug. 27. -- The particular of an alleged assault which occurred at this place on Monday night last became known here last night, and only the timely arrival of a posse of constables prevented the lynching of David Williams, a Negro. He is now locked up in the Morris County Jail awaiting a hearing.

Senator QUAY apologizes to Mr. DAVID MARTIN of Philadelphia, for some years past the Republican "boss" of that city, for something which he said in the Senate a year and a half ago. "In January, 1895," the Senator now remarks, "in the Senate I made a public statement indicating that Mr. MARTIN had been influenced in his action in a then recent political transaction by corrupt considerations.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 27. -- Gov. Altgeld to-night gave to the press his answer to the open letter recently published by William S. Forman, attacking his administration and charging him with converting State money to his own use. Among other things, he says:

SARATOGA, Aug. 27. -- To-day's session of the Grand Lodge of Good Templars of the State of New-York was confined to the adoption of reports and resolutions. The Committee on Political Action submitted a very long document, which caused considerable debate, but was finally adopted. The document cited first that the unvarying policy is and has been total adstinence from intoxication for individuals, and absolute prohibition of the liquor traffic by the State.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- The new cruiser Brooklyn to-day proved herself to be the greatest naval vessel of her class in the world by covering a distance of 83 knots in a continuous run at an average speed of 21 92-100 knots per hour. She still further showed that she is capable of greater speed than 21 92-100 by maintaining an average of 22 9-10 knots during a portion of the run.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27. -- Republican, Populist, Democratic, and Silver headquarters here were all running to-day under a full head of steam. Wagons bearing the sign, "United States Senate and House of Representatives" were before all the headquarters, unloading canvas bags bulging with literature on the financial question.

BOSTON, Aug. 27. -- The midair kite photographs of Boston taken by William A. Eddy of Bayonne, N.J., were developed at 2 P.M. to-day. Of the first twelve films seven were successful, giving distinct views at a great height of the Common, Beacon Street, Commonwealth Avenue, Charles River, and the outlying suburbs.

There was no particular change yesterday in the condition of affairs at the dry goods store of Hilton, Hughes Co. The curtails at the big show windows were drawn, as on the previous day, the doors were belted, and there was no outward sign of activity about the place.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 27. -- The State Convention of sound-money Democrats to-day was called to order by C.J. Deveraux. After a brief statement of the object of the convention he requested E.U. Farrar to act as temporary Chairman. Mr. Farrar, on taking the stand, delivered an address, in which he said, he always had been a stickler for strict party discipline as one of the necessary conditions of party success.

Acting Fire Chief Goodeson has notified the Fire Marshal that a fire was discovered in the four-story brick house at 205 East One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street about 11 o'clock last night, which should be investigated.

MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 27. -- At an early hour this morning fire destroyed the clothing store of A.G. Peterson Co., at 1,203 Washington Avenue South, and Lundeen's lodging house, adjoining. After the fire was extinguished the bodies of F.A. and G. Anderson and John Schroff, lodgers in the Lundeen building, were found in the ruins.
I want to thank you for the article on the temporary Chairman of the Saratoga Convention. It is right to the point, entirely applicable to the situation, and thoroughly deserved.

In virtue of a judgment of the Civil Tribunal, of Paris, the Due d'Albuefura and Mme. da Vai de Donneville his sister, have been chiged to sell the chateau and estate of Malmalseu. The sale took place on the 12th last. The amount realized was 200,000. The land was sold in lots, the purchases being the Countess de Barl and the nuns of the adjoining orphanage.

Certain questions recently put to the Lord Advocate in the House of Commons, with reference to the legality of an attempt now making by Glasgow tradesmen to boycott co-operative societies, have attracted much attention in England, owing to the fact that these questions gave the most Englishmen their first proof of how rapidly co-operative principles and practices have been spreading in Scotland.

BIRMINGHAM, Mich., Aug. 27. --Three burglars entered the feed store of Volney Nixon early this morning. They were discovered and pursued by Mr. Nixon and two companions, who overtook the thieves on the outskirts of the village. Nixon called on the thieves to surrender, and when they refused the three pursuers fired at them.

CHICAGO, Aug. 27. -- The announcement of the appointment of an Advisory Committee of six men outside the regular Democratic Party by Chairman Jones of the National Committee may be expected this week. The Senator said to-day: ...

TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 27. -- Franklin Murphy, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, called the convention of his party for the selection of Presidential Electors to order at 12:10 o'clock at Taylor's Opera House in this city to-day. The hall, which was packed, was decorated with flags and bunting, and pictures of McKinley and Hobart ornamented the stage.

The office of The United Press Local News whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

For about a unit dozen of the lot competition was lively, but as a rule the bidding was slow, and half the offerings went for $100 or less, several selling for $25 each. " I am going fishing," said "Trayfull" Ivins to his friend, "for a most peculiar kind of fish, of which I have just heard. It is a species of horned pout, which suckles its young."
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 28. -- Articles of incorporation of the United States Guide and Information Company have been filed with the Secretary of State. The authorized capital stock is $1,000,000.

When Thomas Nugent, twenty-nine years old, no home; was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday by Park Policeman Moore of Union Square, the complainant, William Sidel, a lame boy, told a story of how he had beer terrorized for three months by the prisoner and forced by him to beg.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The reference to Senator Tillman by ex-President Harrison in his speech in New-York last night has induced the South Carolinian to send him a challenge to meet him on the stump somewhere in the North. Mr. Tillman arrived in Washington this morning, and after reading Mr. Harrison's speech, sent him this dispatch:
SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 28. -- An enthusiastic meeting in behalf of the persecuted Armenians was held in Convention Hall this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28. -- Following is the Pennsylvania Railroad Company's statement of comparison of earnings and expenses for the month of July and seven months of 1896, with the same periods of 1895:
ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The genuine Cuban Giants came out to the Orange Oval this afternoon and defeated the Orange Athletic Club in a baseball game which was very raggedly played by Orange.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- The thirty-footers sailed today for one of the Duryea Cups. It was the second prize of the three that Mrs. H.B. Duryea, offered a week ago, and was then won by Mr. Duryea's, Vaquero. He put it up again, and won it himself once more, and to-day he again offered it, and in order that he should not win it, he kept out the race with the Vaquero.

Senator HILL IS at the present moment one of the most interesting political figures in the country. Men are curious to know whether he will ultimately declare for BRYAN and make speeches in his support.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 28. -- Major C. J. Moore, provisional committeeman of the National Committee for Arkansas yesterday made public a call for a meeting of the sound-money men of Arkansas, to be held in Little Rock Aug. 31.

Augustin Daly was a passenger aboard the St. Louis yesterday, returning from a successful season in England. He brought his yearly budget of theatrical plans, plays, and ideas for the approaching season.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28. -- The Lake Superior Steamboat Line yesterday announced a rate of 15 cents first-class and 6 cents for all the lettered carload classes from Chicago to St. Paul. The Lake Michigan Car Ferry Line responded with a rate of 5 cents per 100 pounds on all classes of freight lower than fourth from Chicago to St. Paul.

George F. Averill, who claims that he holds a contract with the city that will make him worth millions of dollars within the next twenty-five years, was a prisoner in Jefferson Market Court yesterday on a charge of larceny preferred by Mrs. Margaret A. Diamond of 384 West Thirty-second Street.

The St. Louis ball players defeated the New-Yorks at the Polo Grounds yesterday. Brelfenstein pitched for the visitors, and held the home team down to seven hits. Doheny started in to pitch for the home team, but gave way to Seymour after the fourth inning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The President has pardoned "Billy" Wilson, alias D.L. Anderson, of New-Mexico, who was covicted of passing counterfeit money about fifteen years ago and escaped from jail pending an appeal. The President writes:

M.C.D. Borden's new steam yacht Sovereign yesterday morning had a race up the bay with the Jersey Central Railroad steamer Monmouth. The Sovereign won, but she had hard work to lower the colors of the crack steamboat.

In his opening speech before the Saratoga Convention Mr. FRANK S. BLACK of Troy, now Republican candidate for Governor of this State, exasperated and repelled the Democrats who are asked to contribute to a Republican victory with the following language:

MONTREAL, Aug. 28. -- The Chinamen of Montreal have decided to invite Li Hung Chang to visit them here and have commissioned George Foster, advocate, to go to New-York for the purpose of conveying their invitation to him.
At the trial of J. Elliott Smith, Superintendent of Fire Alarm and Telegraph for the Fire Department, before the Board of Fire Commissioners yesterday, the first witness was Michael Vail.

MOUNT KISCO, Aug. 28. -- Coroner Charles E. Birch of White Plains held an inquest this afternoon on the burglar John Jenkins, who died here, where he was brought after being shot while attempting to enter the store of W.B. Adams Son, at Bedford Station.

Gross earnings of the Southern Railway Company for the fiscal year ended June 30, as shown in the second annual report, mailed yesterday to stockholders, were $19,082,247, an increase of $1,967,456 over those of the preceding year. Net earnings reached $5,630,799, an increase of $578,862. Surplus, after paying interest an rentals, amounted to $556,478, against $805,744 for the preceding year.

Gen. Queralta, a veteran of the last previous Cuban revolt, was talking yesterday with a group of Cubans and American sympathizers about the prospects of the patriots in the present struggle for independence. He felt very sanguine, and said that this time the Cubans would certainly succeed in throwing off the hated Spanish yoke.

" I notice one of the opponents of free coinage said the other day that if the farmer had suffered from falling prices when he went to sell, he had gained in falling prices of what he went to buy. That may all be well enough for some one who is not a farmer to tell a man who is a farmer. [Applause.]

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- Newport's open-air horse show was closed to-day. It has been a success far beyond all expectations. The attendance was very large. Warwick, owned Mrs. J. De Forest Danielson of Boston, and ridden by Mrs. Belle Beach, took the prize for champion saddle horses. Blue Ridge Bella owned by J. Holloway of Chevvy Chase, Maryland was a close competitor, and was reserved by the judges.

It is given out that Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN'S visit to this country, which he has already announced as purely private, has yet political significance. It is even said that he has come empowered to conclude with Mr. OLNEY the arbitration treaty and the Venezuelan dispute. This would be a strange mission for a Foreign Secretary to intrust to a Colonial Secretary and for a Tory Premier to intrust to a Liberal-Unionist subordinate.
BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 28. -- The Republican State Convention made the following nomination:

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The report of Gov. Foster of Louisiana upon the lynching of three Sicilians charged with murder and confined in the parish jail at Hahnville, St. Charles Parish, just below New-Orleans, in respect to which Baron Fava, the Italian Ambassador, in the name of his Government, has asked reparation from the United States, has just been received at the State Department.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 28. -- Christian Slack, twelve years of age, died at his home, at 33 Oriental Terrace, last night as the result of a bicycle accident which occurred yesterday afternoon. The boy was a novice on the bicycle, but had taken his brother's wheel out for practice. His brother had warned him to remain on the asphalt pavement while practicing.
The trip of the St. Louis with Li Hung Chang's suite aboard was one which will be long and pleasantly remembered by all of the fellow-voyagers. There was the full complement of passengers.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 28. -- At noon to-day the family of Charles W. Green, Traveling Passenger Agent of the Big Four Railway, consisting of Mrs. Green and three children, a boy aged fifteen, a girl aged nine, and a girl of six, were found dead in their home, 519 West Thirty-fourth Street.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 28. -- The Southern Express Company has brought action against the Seaboard Air Line in order to fight the decision of the Asheville Magistrate that no express matter save perishable articles can be transported in North Carolina on trains on Sunday. The Seaboard Air Line and Southern Railway have both issued notices to the Southern Express Company that orders had been issued forbidding the carrying of such express matter.
F.G. I.N. Van Vilet, maltsters at 402 Produce Exchange Buildings, made an assignment yesterday without preference to Lucas L. Van Allen. The partners are Frederick G. and Isaac N. Van Vilet.

Laura Forman, nineteen years old, who was sent to the House of Mercy, an Episcopal institution at Inwood, N.Y., by her father, was before Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, on a writ of habeas corpus obtained by George H. Lefferson. After hearing the statement of the case from her counsel and the girl's assertion that she was detained in the institute against her will, Justice Beach signed an order directing her discharge.
Employes of the Mauser Manufacturing Company of 14 East Fifteenth Street are at work during odd hours on a loving cup of solid silver, finished in gold, which they will present to Major McKinley.

However satisfactory Gov. McKinley's letter of acceptance may be to his fellowRepublicans, it does not commend itself to Democratic advocates of the gold standard, who were intending to vote for him because they considered him to be sound on the currency question, although they knew that he was nominated because he is a representative of protection.

The Democratic Party Reform Organization held primaries in each Assembly District of the city last night for the purpose of electing delegates to the State Convention of Sound-Money Democratic to be held at Syracuse Monday.
Justice Beach of the Supreme Court granted an order yesterday to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed for the Murray Hill Bank.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 28. -- Among the officials who were in the Ottoman Bank when it was attacked by a mob on Wednesday was Sir Edgar Vincent, the Governor of the institution, but he was among the number who succeeded in making their escape.

ALBANY, Aug. 28. -- The State Canal Board, which is composed of the elective State officers, met this afternoon and adopted plans and specifications prepared by State Engineer Adams for work on the canal under the $9,000,000 canal improvement appropriation, to the amount of $3,126,301.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 28. -- T. Dumas, W.H. Renaud, E.C. Fenner, and Julius Keiffer, all Directors of the American National Bank, were arrested to-day by the United States Marshal charged with signing false statements of the bank's condition. These showed the bank to be all right just prior to its collapse to weeks ago.

The movement for a consolidation of the two combinations which have for some time controlled the window-glass industry and some remarks recently made by our Republican friends concerning "the change in the tariff" as affecting imports and the domestic manufacture of glass induce us to publish the following official figures, which show how large the imports have been during the last six years:

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 28. -- The National Circuit races under the auspices of the Bridgeport Wheel Club took place at the Pleasure Beach track to-day. Arthur Gardner lowered the world's record for a single mile, paced, to 1:57 2-5. He was paced by Wells Stevens, Clark Mertens also broke the track and State record in the one-mile open professional, being paced by W.W. Hamilton.

The will of De Witt C. Weeks, who died Aug. 3, was offered for probate in the office of the Surrogate yesterday. It directs, first, that the homestead in Mott Avenue, between One Hundred and Sixty-second and One Hundred and Sixty-fourth Streets, be divided into two equal portions, one portion to go to his son, Francis M. Weeks, absolutely, and the other portion to his daughter, Elizabeth B. Ball.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 28. -- The Rev. A.H. Chase was a prisoner before Police Justice De Meza to-day charged with disorderly conduct. The minister halls from Whitewater, Wis., and has been conducting a camp meeting near Netherwood.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28. -- Charles M. Oelrich made a wager several weeks ago with a person whose name is not given that he could, while swimming in the water, successfully hold out against all efforts of a single person to bring him in with an ordinary fishing rod and line, the latter to be securely fastened to his belt.

BRYAN'S speeches through this State from the time he left his seclusion at Upper Red Hook bristle with appeals to what he calls the "common people" against the capitalists of the country. At Barrytown Aug. 22 he said:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28. -- With a yellow flag displayed from her foretopmast, the Earn Line steamship Earnwell, from Santiago de Cuba, arrived at Delaware Breakwater yesterday with part of her crew down with smallpox. Those sick are Chief Officer Flowers and four others.

Two conspicuous men in American cycle trade affairs arrived from Europe on the St. Louis yesterday. They have been abroad on business and pleasure. R. Lindsay Coleman, who is President of the Western Wheel Works, as well as of the National Cycle Board of Trade, critically observed the foreign trade conditions, and was chock full of interesting information.

Li Hung Chang, the Chinese Viceroy, the greatest foreigner and the most powerful ruler that has ever visited the United States, arrived in New-York by the steamship St. Louis yesterday at 2 o'clock P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28. -- The President has decided to send a warship to Constantinople, and the little cadet practice ship Bancroft has been selected, as the first American National vessel since the ratification of the treaty of Berlin to pass the Bosphorus and anchor in the Golden Horn, opposite the gardens of the Seraglio.

Viewed with the outward eye, the reception of LI HUNG CHANG by New-York was somewhat disappointing. The white squadron, indeed, which was drawn up to receive him, fulfilled all expectations as a demonstration of our new naval power. But the naval reception was marred, through mischance or maladroitness, so that the St. Louis did not pass between the lines of warships, but upon one side of them.

Miss Katherine Ettienne was riding her bicycle down Macdougal Street yesterday when she was knocked down by a horse and wagon at the corner of West Houston Street, and received severe bruises about the body. She was carried to her home at 44 Thompson Street, and the driver of the wagon, Thomas Faley, fifty-six years old, of 12 Chatham Square, was arrested.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Aug. 28. -- Premier Laurier presented to Parliament to-day the correspondence between Sir Charles Tupper and Lord Aberdeen in respect to the resignation of the late Ministry. The correspondence begins with a memorandum from Lord Aberdeen to Sir Charles Tupper and his Ministers.

The riot at Constantinople should be an object lesson to the European Governments of the absolute incapacity of the Sultan's Government; not so much its weakness as its incapacity. For more than a year the city has been in a condition of disorder bordering on anarchy. There has been no security for life or property.

In this morning's issue you call attention to Mr. Bryan's reckless and disingenouos statements regarding the free-coinage issue. There is, however, one argument which he uses repeatedly, and which he must know is disingenuous to the point of dishonesty. I refer to his persistent charge that those of his opponents who believe in bimetallistic as statements regarding the free-coinage issue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28. -- Henry R. Lemaire, one of the cross-continent relay bicycle couriers, rode into Battle Mountain, Nev., yesterday afternoon at 1:20, bringing the news that his trailer, Cyril Miles, had been overcome by fatigue on the desert ten miles away. A fast team was at once dispatched to render assistance to the disabled man.

LONDON, Aug. 28. -- At Hurst Park to-day the Malden Plate of 103 sovereigns, for two-year-olds that had never won up to the time of starting, five furlongs, straight, was won by Mr. E. Melly's br. f. Bewitchment. Mr. F. Grant's b. c. Magnate was second, and Lord Cowley's Specula filly third. Mr. P. Lorillard's ch. c. Quibble II. was one of the starters, but was not placed.

Gold news yesterday was quite cheering and not unexpected. The first lot ordered in Europe since exchange touched the importing point arrived. It amounted to $2,000,000 in United States coin and $250,000 in bars.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 28. -- The next directs news from the Peary arctic expedition received in this city came this evening in a long letter to Mrs. Tarr, wife of Prof. Ralph S. Tarr of the Cornell scientific party, who is with Lieut. Peary on the steamer Hope, which sailed July 15 from Sidney, C.B.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 28. -- L.C. Kranthon of Missouri member of the National Executive Committee, arrived in Indianapolis to-day and will henceforth assist to the preparations for the convention. In regard to the statement of a Pennsylvania gentleman "that Mark Hauna be called to the Indianapolis Convention and be offered the support of the Sound-Money Democrats for McKinley, provided the tariff plank in the Republican platform be tempere.

Chinatown was ablaze last evening. The streets and sidewalks were practically given up to the white barbarians to see how Chinamen could illuminate and decorate their dwelling places on special occasions to honor members of their imperial family or their representatives.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Aug. 29. -- This has been the best season Williamstown has had in some years, nearly all the cottages being occupied. The town is looking its loveliest, as the Village Improvement Society has taken active measures toward keeping the streets and walks in the best of condition. Mr. Proctor's stately Ivory Villa is closed this Summer, although men are kept at work about the grounds to keep them in good condition.

Timothy L. Woodruff, the Republican nominee for Lieutenant Governor, was serenaded by his friends in Brooklyn last night. The Republican voters of the Third, Eighth, Ninth, Eleventh, Twentieth, and Twenty-second Wards marched through the various streets of their wards and then combined in a big parade and marched to the residence of Mr. Woodruff, at Eighth Avenue and President Street.

At that time bullion, as now, was piled high in the Bank of England, and the rate of interest was very low. Home railways, which had proved a profitable investment, became the arena of frantic speculation. Much nonsense was written as to their dividend-yielding capacity. They were infallibly to become "the permanent deposit of all the surplus wealth of the country." Credulous people believed the fiction.

Lettuce, according to Twentieth Century Cookery, forms a much better soup ingredient than the average American housewife imagines. It also makes an excellent vegetable, especially the large headed and coarse-leaved varieties, which are now both plentiful and cheap.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- The Ministers are resting from their labors, and their works will not follow them till the recess campaign begins. Mr. A.J. Balfour seems rated to be the first member of the Cabinet to open the campaign, by appearing before his Manchester constituents. Prior thereto he will visit Mr. Gladstone at Hawarden.

The ceremonies of the President's reception of Viceroy Li Hung Chang began Friday night, with the coming of Secretary of State Olney. Mr. Olney arrived late and took a room close to Earl Li's apartments, so that the Chinese statesman would not have much trouble in paying him the necessary formal call yesterday morning.

RICHFIELD SPRINGS, Aug. 29. -- The baseball season here came to a close this week with great success. Four victories were witnessed by four crowds, composed largely of ladies and admirers of the snappy game of the college boys. Wednesday and Thursday the opponents were the strong professional team from Hornellsville, and they played two good games, but could do nothing with the pitching of either Fishel or Summersgill.

A larger crowd than usual was at the Sheepshead Bay track yesterday, owing in great part to the fact that the winner and the second horses in the Futurity were to meet over a course of seven furlongs in the Flatbush Stakes. It was the thirteenth running of the stakes, which has never yet been won by a bad horse, with the single exception of the year when Senator Grady won it.

Will you decide a controversy by informing us in your next Sunday's issue if there is a law requiring the Secretary of the Treasury to sell bonds when required to keep the one-hundred-million-dollar gold reserve in the Treasury?

The spacious auditorium of the Grand Opera House was crowded in every part last night when the season began, auspiciously as it seemed, with the first performance in New-York of "The Cotton Spinner," a play by Scott Marbie, which tells a tale of the rough course of true love in North Carolina, and is full of exciting incidents.

It is poor Jean Valjean of "Les Miserables," squatting "in the north corner of the courtyard," choked with tears, "while the bolt of his iron collar was being riveted with heavy hammer blows."

FISHER'S ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The past week was a jolly one at this resort. The weather was fine and gave people an opportunity of enjoying themselves out of doors. Fishing is a favorite recreation with a great number of the Summer visitors here. The following party went on a fishing expedition last Tuesday.

Julius Isaacs, who is not yet fifteen years old, the son of a retired merchant, attempted suicide yesterday in the vestibule of his home, at 123 East Seventy-third Street, by shooting himself in the right breast. He was removed to the Presbyterian Hospital, and the doctors say that he will probably die.

SHELTER ISLAND HEIGHTS, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- There are no perceptible signs yet of the season drawing to a close at Shelter Island. There are as many people here now as at any time during the season, and the life and gayety have not diminished in the least. By far the most popular amusement of the week has been sailing, and the weather could not have been more favorable for this delightful pastime.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- Two State professional records were broken this afternoon at the fifth annual tournament of the Quaker City Bicycle Club, on the grounds of the Tioga Cricket Club. The Australian crack Parsons and the American flier John S. Johnson performed the fests, they respectively making a mile in 1:52 and a half mile in 0:54.

The finest display of bicycles and wheelmen ever witnessed in Jersey City took place yesterday on the occasion of the formal opening of Hudson County's great driveway and bicycle road, the Hudson Boulevard. All the clubs in the county took part, and there were visiting delegations from all over the State, and also from New-York and Brooklyn.

Edgar Schramm, United States Consul at Montevideo, has some very interesting information to give concerning the lumber trade of the United States with Uruguay and the Argentine Republic. Mr. Schramm says that this trade presents incongruities which cannot but be harmful to the lumber interests of the United States.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 29. -- Troops have arrived here from Adrianople and reinforced the soldiers and police who are patroling the streets. The city has become quiet, and the shops at Galata are being reopened and business is being resumed.

The first annual carnival of sports of the Bay Ridge Athletic Club was held at Ambrose Park, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. The grounds will eventually make an ideal athletic field, although their newness militates against good performances.

Love of animals is strong in the hearts of the American people, and this country will soon possess the finest zoological gardens in the world. The National Zoo at Washington, now but an infant of seven years, already surpasses in numerous ways the famous gardens in Europe. In a few more years it will, its managers predict, eclipse anything of the kind in existence.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29. -- The scene of gay life in Newport now changes from the Casino, where the lawn tennis tournament has been in order, and from Freebody Park, where all the cottagers gathered daily for the horse show, and, indeed, from the beautiful Breakers, where that most interesting of weddings took place, to the golf links, upon which some matches are to be contested next week.
The residents of Brooklyn are complaining, and have been for several weeks, over the bad condition of the water which they are compelled to drink, and which seems to be getting worse day by day.

I am tickled to know that Wagner was an exact and expensive dresser, and that Beethoven was a sloven, with an old coat and slippers trodden down at the heels. It interests me to hear that Paganini always carried a shirt in his fiddle case, because he sweated, so profusely over his solos that he had to change between the parts if he played twice.

Arrangements are in progress in London for establishing some memorial of the late Thomas Hughes at his old school, Rugby. This fact gives special interest to a biographical sketch by his old friend and fellow-worker, J.M. Ludlow, in the new number of the quarterly periodical, The Economic Review, wherein are set forth facts in the early life of Hughes.

Li Hung Chang, the Chinese Viceroy, was received by President Cleveland at the home of ex-Secretary Whitney yesterday morning, and in the evening he was the guest of former members of the United States Diplomatic and Consular Service in China.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 29. -- This week, the last of Atlantic City's most successful Summer season, contrary to the usual rule, gave the City by the Sea an impetus which so gradually let the Summer glide into the Fall that the change of seasons is hardly perceptible. To-day and to-morrow will prove about the last great Saturday and Sunday of this season.

Hilton, Hughes Co.'s big store building, at Broadway, Fourth Avenue, and Ninth and Tenth Streets, passed formally into the hands of ex-Judge Henry Hilton early last week. The deed was passed before the announcement of the failure, but was not recorded until immediately after.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The American Vice Consul at Dublin, reporting to the State Department on bicycles imported from the United States, says that, though the present year has been the busiest yet known in everything pertaining to the cycle trade, the general opinion is that the coming year will far exceed it in business done.

The Quill Club Wheelmen, whose race meet takes place at the Manhattan Beach track on Sept. 18 and 19, have come out with a feature race that will far exceed in originality, interest, and prominence any long-distance race ever given. It will be an hour competition race, with J.F. Starbuck representing America and J.W. Parsons representing Australia.

The memory of his (HARRISON'S) Administration and the beneficent conditions which prevailed during its continuance relieves the distress in which the country bus since been plunged, and is full of hope and promise for the future. -- Mr. DEPEW at Carnegie Hall Aug. 27.
The annual athletic games of the New-York Caledonian Club will be held on Sept. 7, Labor Day, at Ambrose Park, South Brooklyn. These games were started forty years ago.

According to reports from Chicago, the fight for business between lines running west out of Chicago and lines running north from Gulf Mexico ports developed a new feature yesterday, and one that is causing Chicago traffic officials anxiety.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20. -- The polo tournament for special cups was closed here this afternoon with a match between the Meadowbrooks Second and Newport teams. The former gained a victory that came very easy after a time, though the play in the first and second periods was very close.

STOCKBRIDGE, Conn., Aug. 29. -- Wednesday was the Laurel Hill Association's day in Stockbridge. The business meeting for election of officers and reports of committees was held in the morning. Some interesting facts were given about the revolutionary soldier furnished by the town, which have been hunted up by the combined efforts of the association and the town authorities.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 29. -- The Commercial Travelers' McKinley Club of Chicago arrived on a special train at 7 A.M. The Commercial Travelers' Club of Canton and the Dueber Escort Club, 400 strong, met the Chicago men at the station. The delegation marched to Major McKinley's residence.

OXFORD, Penn., Aug. 29. -- Of all the significant expressions issuing from the Revolutionary struggle, not one has been handed down that conveys so much meaning as "Remember Paoli!" The one hundred and nineteenth anniversary of the massacre at Paoli will be celebrated on Sept. 19, as the correct date of the anniversary falls this year on Sunday, Sept. 20.

During the past eight or nine years the import and export trade of Honduras has been injuriously affected by the series of revolutions through which that country has passed. The value of exports from the United States, although larger than from any other country, has declined during that period over 20 per cent., while that of Germany has increased 10 per cent.

Mr. Gladstone in his old age, since his retirement from a public career of unusual hope, appears to have set himself the extraordinary task of rehabilitating the theology of the beginning of the eighteenth century in defiance of all progress in knowledge and thought since that time. For this purpose he has taken the "works" of Bishop Butler, but chiefly his "Analogy" of Religion.

-- Lightning struck in nearly a dozen places in Houghton County, Mich., Friday afternoon, Joseph Ruppa was killed in the Finnish Church at Hancock. Mrs. Weber was dangerously injured at Quincy; a blacksmith named Johnson at the same place was knocked senseless by a bolt; James Kane of Hancock was prostrated by a shock, and various other casualties were recorded.

LONDON, Aug. 29. -- Nicholas II. has made his first appearance in the West, and has retreated again, leaving Europe more uncertain about the immediate future than before. For some reason Vienna expected great things of his visit. Even the official papers were inspired to say that political questions of the highest importance would probably be settled while the Czar and his advisers were in the Austrian capital.

Much interest is being manifested in the State Division meet, which takes place at the Manhattan Beach track on Labor Day, Sept. 7, under the auspices of the South Brooklyn Wheelmen. Entries for the different events, which are as follows, close to-morrow with N.R. Macdonald, Secretary, Room 1,426, 150 Nasau Street, this city:

It looks as if England were at last going to have an opportunity to settle the Zanzibar question. For years it has been a thorn in her side, moral if not political. The slave trade, which under the prorectorate was forbidden, could not be entirely suppressed, and the anomaly was presented of the great anti-slavery Government of the world practically allowing it.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Miss Nora Williams and the Misses Needham of North Plainfield have returned from a visit at Bedminster. Mrs. Drisler of Brooklyn is visiting Miss Currie of Arlington Avenue. Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Green of East Front Street returned home yesterday from the White Mountains. Miss Carrie Frazer of West Front Street is visiting friends in Westfield.

Again the banks have maintained their reserve by reducing loans, as they did a week ago. Yesterday's statement had been expected to show a heavy reduction in the surplus reserve. Instead, it showed little over half a million loss, and the surplus is still about $9,000,000. Loans were cut down another $3,000,000; deposits decreased over $6,000,000.

The official applications for space, rules, regulations, and diagram of the third Eastern National exhibition of cycles and accessories were mailed on Saturday last to all signers of the agreement to exhibit at sanctioned cycle exhibitions only.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- The Navy Department has selected most of the officers for the Turkish cruise of the Bancroft, and their orders have been sent directing them to report on board the vessel as soon as possible. The officers are:

Twenty-seven yachts sailed a very good race over the ten and three-quarter and fifteen mile triangular courses of the Huguenot Yacht Club off New-Rochelle yesterday, it being the club's second annual regatta.

WASHINGTON , Aug. 29. -- Unless accorded an especial permission by the Secretary of State and the Librarian, who is the custodian of the State documents, none of the visitors to the State Department has the privilege of seeing the valuable historical papers which are preserved by the Chief of the Bureau of Rolls and the Library.

It is in the air that the day of the chain is drawing to a close and that its place will be taken by the bevel gear. During the past few days this has been the chief topic for conversation among the cycle trade people. The chainless bicycle, it is charmed will make the long-expected break in the safety line.

A yacht race for which nearly every contesting boat has been especially built will take place near New-York Sept. 13. It will be the most interesting event of its kind this year, and particularly memorable in the anuals of the yacht club, because it will be the first regatta in which the members have ever participated.

Another long meeting of the Stewards of The Jockey Club was held at the Coney Island track yesterday. More meetings are to be held next week, at which the mystery of the alleged combination of owners, trainers, jockeys, and bookmakers is to be still further investigated. What has already been done is kept a profound secret by those who have been "on the grill," and what may be done is a still deeper secret.

In the American report of the Commissioner of Education for 1892-3, published at Washington last year, there is a most thoroughgoing report on "Child Study," or, as it is sometimes called, "Paidology." A bibliography of about seven pages, in books and articles, shows how much attention has been bestowed on the subject in the United States.

Marcus A. Hanna had a long talk yesterday with Thomas C. Plati, at the Republican National Headquarters, 1 Madison Avenue. It is understood that the leaders talked about two things -- ways and means to supply the campaign fund and the details of campaign management in this State.
The oyster season is close at hand, and on Tuesday, the 1st of September, the month with the letter "r" in it, the favorite bivalve will be declare free from spawn, plump, and luscious.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 29. -- A grand barbecue in aid of the new Church of the Sacred Heart, in Rosindale, was given at Apollo Garden to-day. An immense crowd was present. A number of sports of various kinds were on the programme, and able addresses were delivered by ex-Lieut. Gov. Sheehan of New-York State and Senator Jacob A. Cantor of New-York.

As a visit of pure ceremony the Chinese Viceroy's call upon the President of the United States yesterday might have been expected to produce nothing beyond the conventional assurances of amity appropriate to such occasions. Two things were said, however, which are of real international importance.
At a meeting of the National Beagle Club of America recently a resolution was passed concerning the death of St. Nicholas Rowe, who was a member of the club.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Harry Hodgett, a farmer near Pluckemin, was hitching up in his barnyard after breakfast to-day, intending to drive into the village. Elmer Clawson, a youth eighteen years old, who had been a hand on the farm for a few months prior to a year ago, rode up on a wheel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Mr. H.E. Difenderfer, Secretary of the National Silver Party, speaking of the statement that Chief Arthur of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers had declared for McKinley and sound money, said to-day: "If the published statement be true, I would like to ask Chief Arthur how he reconciles such action with his course in signing the following paper, published in Senate Miscellaneous Document No. 94, Fifty-third Congress, Third Session:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Irving S. Upton, registrar of Rutgers College, this week arrived home from Europe, where he has been traveling for some months. Miss Margaret Parent is visiting in New-York. H.D. Voorhees, Rutgers Professor of Agriculture, is touring in Maine. Mrs. Frances Wilber has returned from her outing in Vermont, Miss Maggie Clark is visiting E. Bayonne.
The National Democratic Party, whose name is three weeks old and principles are 100 years old, will hold a National Convention at Indianapolis Wednesday, Sept. 2.

Mr. D. is an extensive real estate owner in one of the suburbs of New-York. He is also an insurance agent and a general adviser on matters of law and equity, and, in addition to all this, he is the proud father of a three-weeks-old baby. The other day Mrs. D. took the little treasure into the parlor, and, after a half hour's cooing, lulled it to sleep.

Saratog, still gossips over its enjoyment of Lord Russell's visit. The entire party made a most agreeable impression. Lady Russell is a fine-looking woman, whose face shows her character and intelligence. She dresses plainly, but not without distinction.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

All the leading racing men are either in Springfield or en route to that famed mecca of wheelmen. Once more the giants of the cinder path are gathering for the supreme tests of the year, and in Springfield, as usual, the culmination in rivalry, speed, and interest of this season's entire series of cycling events may be looked for.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Aug. 29. -- A start at Bloomfield, under the auspices of the Active Wheelmen's Association, Thursday night, was greatly enjoyed. Charles Blanchard was floor manager, and Allen Cook assistant floor manager.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- John Hughes, the night ticket agent at the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railway station, was obliged to use his revolver last night in order to protect himself from the attack of thieves, who, it is supposed, were after a bag of money belonging to the railway company, which Hughes had in his possession.

The tailor's trade was only permitted so far as it was necessary for clothing, but so far as it or any other trade ministered to luxury, pride, and arrogance it was abjured as "rootless work." Thus, they could not be goldsmiths, silversmiths, or jewelers. Nor would they make any weapon of war.

LAKE GEORGE, Aug. 29. -- With the passing of August, the temperature of society, as marked by functions, rises to boiling mark. If it is not a german it is a musicale; if not a musicale it is a baseball game, with the ladies as shouters; if not a baseball game there are a hundred or so other affairs on the tapis, such as swimming parties, yachting, tennis, concerts, dances, mountain climbing, or alfresco picnics.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- This week has been one of crowds -- crowds in the dining rooms, parlors, and offices, crowds on the verandas, lawns, and tennis courts, crowds on the mountain drives and island-dotted lakes, crowds everywhere. It is safe to say that this week is the climax of the Summer season of 1896, and the greatest one in point of prosperity.

We have already taken occasion to commend Major McKINLEY'S sensible and patriotic declaration about the wiping out of sectional lines in our politics. "The era of reconciliation," he wrote in his letter of acceptance, "has come, happily, and the feeling of distrust and hostility between the sections is everywhere vanishing, let us hope never to return."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- Army officers are greatly interested in a new utilization of the shelter tent, which is carried by the soldier in the field. At present this shelter tent is made of very unsatisfactory material and is by no means water-proof. It is of no other use than as a shelter tent, and beyond that is an incumbrance to the soldier, adding to his burdens on the march by about three pounds.

BAR HARBOR, Aug. 29. -- The week just closing has marked the climax and the beginning of the decline of the season's gayety. The 1st of September is almost here, and with it, unless the season turns out to be a late one, will come the departure of many guests.

A bright woman, when applauded recently for her goodness, begged her friend to let the matter drop. "For," she said, whimsically, "though I do try to be good from some really high motives, yet I have one reason for trying which I am afraid is a low one." "What do you mean? "inquired her laughing friend.

In making comparative estimates of the merits of the French and German Army organizations, one improtant factor must be taken into consideration -- the relaxation of discipline in the French Army of late years. This relaxation has been commented upon outside of army circles and has been looked upon with alarm by patriotic Frenchmen, who, not being blinded by chauvinism, have become aware of the superior discipline of the Germans.

ALBANY, Aug. 29. -- There were 303 men dropped from the force employed on the construction of the Capitol to-day. This action, coming close on the heels of the Saratoga Convention, has given rise to the rumor and belief that Superintendent Aldridge and Lieut. Gov. Saxton are responsible for the lay-off.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- State Chairman James W. Hinkley returned from Winnisock Lodge to-day.

HORNELLSVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 20. -- Before a gigantic gathering at Maple City Park, near Hornellsville, this afternoon William J. Bryan severely criticised the third ticket movement and those who are taking part in it.

ATHENS, Aug. 12. -- On Sunday last, Aug. 9, a little affair happened which has been the talk of the town over since. The Government, which is doing all it can to prevent the sending of war material to the Cretan insurgents, got wind that there was ammunition on board the steamer Mina at Laurium.
There was a big crowd at the Polo Grounds yesterday to see the games between the New-Yorks and Clevelands. Each team won a game, darkness shortening the second to six innings.

Mr. BRYAN and his followers complain because the people of this country can buy more with a dollar now than they could twenty years ago. This is the complaint from which the silver movement, as it is manifested in our politics to-day, receives its impulse; it is the burden of all the speeches by which the silver candidate and those who assist him are appealing now to the people, and especially to the farmers.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Albany has been a centre of the agitation in favor of a pronounced stand against the free-silver issue promulgated by the National Convention of the Democratic Party at Chicago ever since Gen. Charles Tracey left his seat among the New-York delegates of the convention when the free-silver platform was adopted.

The dueling hero of the first years of the century in France was the Marquis Merle de Sainte-Marie, whose encounters were almost incessant. One of his "affairs of honor" was so silly that it helped to set in motion the current of ridicule which has made dueling a pastime so much less honorable than it once was.

By the corn law of 1773 importation of wheat was prohibited until the price touched 48s. per quarter, when a nominal duty of 6d. was imposed. In the year 1787 the average price of wheat was 12s. 5d. But so abundant was the supply of corn that large quantities were exported to less favored countries abroad.

Possibly the queerest banquet that has ever been given in New-York was enjoyed at the Waldorf last night. The hosts were former members of the American Diplomatic and Consular Service in China, and their guest was the Prime Minister of that country.

When I met Tommy first, his only asset was in serious danger, for his five underfed and underbred ponies were about to be seized for overdue taxes. I could not help Tommy with money, but I tried to with advice. "Strike old Sam Ashby for a couple of hundred dollars," I suggested. Sam Ashby was one of the rich men of Helena, Mon., at that period, and ran a small savings bank.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- The vote to incorporate that part of the town north of the railroad tracks into a village, to be called North Pelham, was carried this afternoon by a plurality of 2 votes out of 132 cast. The election was warmly contested. The village will elect President, Trustees, Treasurer, and a Collector the latter part of September.

It is quite plain that the resources of our mints are by no means equal to the production of such a volume of currency as is required by the Populistic notion of the laws of trade. The Bland law required the mints to coin a minimum of two millions a month, but they never succeeded in doing it for year together.

Adam Smith long ago pointed out that in every voluntary exchange both parties profited. So the average man, when he buys a book or a coat, comes home with a feeling of satisfaction in his purchase, If the book is dull or if the coat does not fit, he forms a resolution to deal no more with the authors.

The inhabitants of Denby Dale, a hamlet in the Township of Denby, near Barnsley, who for over a century have baked large pies in commemoration of remarkable events in the history of the country, have recently celebrated the jubilee of the repeal of the corn laws, by means of another large pie.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29. -- The thirty-footers sailed to-day for a cup given by Bayard Thayer of Boston, owner of the Asahi. He offered the trophy a week ago, but then won it himself, and to-day he put it up again, but kept the Asahi out of the race that the cup should go to another. His skipper, Nat Watson, however, sailed the Wawa, and won the race with her.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29. -- "What is the situation of Harpoot indemnity? Also of Marash indemnity?"

Charles Hulle once said to me: "Fanny Kemble was the most difficult person I ever had to deal with. I remember one day at Manchester, she was to read A Midsummer Night's Dream with Mendelssohn's music. Well, something in the lighting, or the desk, or the music, or the chair, did not quite suit her, but at that late hour nothing could be altered.

Piercing screams for help from the fourth floor of 583 West Twenty-sixth Street Friday night attracted the attention of Policeman Robinson, who was passing. He saw the window on that floor hurriedly pushed up, and a woman pushed through the window. She clung to the sill and screamed loudly.

I am seated before a blazing are in the library of a man I see at a glance is a book-loving as well as book-owning man. Near me, by the centre table, Jay Gould is seated in a low chair. The shaded lamp throws a flood of light on a book he holds, and also shows in relief against the background of shadow his clear-cut features.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 20. -- Saturday, Sept. 5, will be a day not to be forgotten by the wheelmen and all the people in this part of the State, for on that day they will witness the largest and most elaborate bicycle parade that has been held in this part of the country. It will be the occasion of Plainfield's great daylight bicycle carnival, which will begin at 3:30 o'clock in the afternoon.

Military men in New-York and other States will be very much interested in the annual meeting of the New-Jersey State Rifle Association, at its fine range at Sea Girt, which commences to-morrow, and continues until Saturday, Sept. 5. This meeting will bring together the best marksmen in the country, both as to individual shots and teams.

Every New-Yorker should pause and bend reverently at the intersection of Nassau and Ann Streets. It was one of the corners of these two thoroughfares, in what was known as the New Franklin Building, now demolished, and forgotten by the present generation, that George P. Morris, Theodore S. Fay, and Nathaniel P. Willis published and edited The New-York Mirror.

LAHKI, Province of Kidonia, Crete, Aug. 2. -- For four days I have been almost constantly on my feet, crossing the mountain chain called the "White Mountains," in going from the southern coast of Crete to within a short distance of the northern coast. We are now in full view of the Turkish lines.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Aug. 29. -- Dennis W. Collins of the livery firm of Collins Boyd of Amsterdam has received a letter announcing that the body of his brother, John Collins, has been found in the North wood, fifteen miles beyond Lake Piseco. The young man left Amsterdam for Piseco to work in the lumber camp with his brother, and on Oct. 28 last disappeared.

The Saints, it seems, began their war against storied urn and animated bust. "They left," we are told, in Chichester Cathedral, "not so much as a cushion for the pulpit nor a chalice for the Blessed Sacrament." The commanders having in person executed the covetous part of sacrilege, they left the destruction and spoiling part to be finished by the common soldiers.

ST. PAUL, Aug. 29. -- St. Paul is ready for the veterans, although they will not be here in full force till the first of the week. Bunting and flags are in evidence everywhere, in the residence portions as well as in the business centre, and already a good many visitors are here in anticipation of the encampment.

Physicians could tell strange and startling tales were it not for the seal of silence which is seldom broken by the honorable practitioner. Now and then the medical papers refer to interesting cases without names, but none more interesting than a tale told by a prominent doctor of this city to a few intimate friends the other day has ever been made public.

ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 29. -- Judge George A. Stearns and wife of Long Island are the guests of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J.G. Pugin of South Orange. William V. King of Chestnut Street, East Orange, is at Lake Placid, Miss M.E. Gage of East Orange is in Nyack, N.Y. The Misses Dean and Ollie Dean of South Orange are at Perth Amboy.

Police Commissioner Welles of Brooklyn has been taken to task for the loose manner in which the police of that city have been conducting themselves of late, especially at Coney Island. It has been said that Coney Island is worse now than it ever was under the administration of John Y. McKane.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29. -- Cottagers gathered at Halley's Beach again this morning to witness another human angling match; these are quite the thing just now, Samuel Powell, Jr., was assisted in his fishing by Robert Ralston and Theodore A. Havemeyer, who is an expert has fisherman.

SARATOGA, Aug. 29. -- That Saratoga is the best place in the State for political conventions was again demonstrated this week, when the big crowd that came to the Republican Convention here was handled with the greatest ease by the hotel keepers and the greatest comfort to themselves.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29. -- The cruiser Brooklyn, returning from her successful trial trip, reached Cramps' shipyard at 4 o'clock this afternoon. Her passage up the Delaware River to-day was one of which her builders may well feel proud. Philadelphians have in the past several years become accustomed to the return of naval vessels after successful trials in other waters, but the return of the Brooklyn, for some reason, had, it seemed, attracted unprecedented attention.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29. -- Foxhall Keene went over to the golf club to-day, not expecting to go into the competition for the third Havemeyer Cup, but he was induced to enter, and won the trophy. It was eighteen holes, medal play. The scores were as follows:

Commodore H.C. Rouse of the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club offered a five-hundred-dollar cup for schooners to race for, and Rear Commodore J. Kennedy Tod offered a two-hundred-and-fifty-dollar cup for the thirty-footers. These races were scheduled for yesterday and it was expected that yacht owners would show their appreciation of the generosity of those two yachtsmen by entering their yacht liberally.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 29. -- October Mountain will probably be hereafter known as Mount Whitney. Carriages conveying those who have Summer places here, also many people from towns roundabout, have been seen daily going to this mountain top, to see what sort of a place young Harry Payne Whitney and his bride have in which to spend their honeymoon.

The 1896 apple crop, barring unforeseen contingencies, will be the largest ever raised in this country. The trees are literally loaded down with the fruit, and it threatens to be not a case of profits, but of how to dispose of the stuff. Early apples are now bringing but 50 to 75 cents per barrel, and dealers are cautious how they load up even at those prices.

LONDON, Aug. 30. -- The Daily Telegraph to-morrow will publish a Kieff dispatch saying that Prince Lobanoff-Rostovsky, the Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs, who accompanied the Czar and Czarina on their recently begun foreign tour, died suddenly to-day while on his way from Vienna to Kieff.

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., Aug. 30. -- William Obergfell, son of a prominent business man, was run over and severely hurt by a wheelman this afternoon. Ferdinand Bergtold, an aged resident, was also run down by a wheelman, and his right arm was badly fractured.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30. -- A cool wave reached Newport to-day, and grate fires are burning to-night in the cottages and hotels.

ORANGE, Mass., Aug. 30. -- Engineer William Clements, aged about thirty-five years was instantly killed shortly after 5 o'clock this morning in a collision on the Fitchburg Railroad, half a mile east of this place. George Fowler, the fireman, was fatally injured, and W.S. Sexton, a brakeman, received a bad cut on the head, and was unconscious for several hours.

The Democratic Convention which meets at Syracuse to-morrow is the logical and necessary outcome of the honorable course pursued by the Democratic delegates from the State of New-York at Chicago. When the majority of that body adopted its platform the New-York delegates promptly refused to take any further part in the proceedings of the convention.

The Viceroy was tired when he was disrobed in the Cluny bedroom, at the Waldorf, Saturday night, and because of this the start for Gen. Grant's tomb was arranged for 3 o'clock in the afternoon. The plans were made by Gen. Ruger, his staff officers, Major Davis and Capt. Mills; Col. Grant, and Gen. Horace Porter, President of the Grant Memorial Association.

GOV. GRIGCS of New-Jersey the other day told the Republican Convention that the Chicago candidate and his supporters were "hysterically opposed to every sentiment heretofore distinctly Democratic." That is a cold fact which every man who is "a Democrat but not a revolutionist" ought to be able to see -- and act upon.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Bryan attended service at the First Presbyterian Church, in Jamestown, this morning and heard the Rev. G.M. Colville, the pastor, preach a sermon from the text beginning "He saw a great multitude." This war construed into a reference to the vast audience which Mr. Bryan addressed at Celoron, on Lake Chautauqua, last night, one of the greatest gatherings that has ever heard him speak.
Viceroy Li Hung Chang visited the tomb of Gen. Ulysses S. Grant yesterday, and by him the riveted iron coffin was "crowned with bays."

The four boys, ranging in age from fifteen to eighteen years, who escaped from the Queens County Jail Saturday evening between 8 and 9 o'clock, adopted a plan to secure their freedom which the majority of their superiors both in age and strength would have shrunk from even to save their lives. There was another boy in the party, but he lacked the courage of his companions and remained behind.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 30. -- This was the last day of the season for some of the hotels, though others will be open until October.

Edward Atkinson of Boston read a paper on money before Section 1, of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, in Buffalo, on Friday of last week. In his conclusion, after a review of the history of money, he said:

SYRACUSE, Aug. 30. -- William A. Beach, who has had charge of all arrangements for quartering the delegates while in Syracuse, and who is consequently well informed as to the possible number of those who will attend the convention Monday, said to-night that he thought almost every county would be represented.

WATERLOO, Iowa, Aug. 30. -- A large crowd gathered in the East Side Park, in this city, last evening, to listen to ex-Gov. Horace Boles open the campaign in behalf of the Democratic Party. F. E. Pollands, candidate for County Attorney, presided, and after making a short speech, presented the ex-Governor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- The defeat of Mr. Sewall and the impossibility of the election of a full Democratic ticket of any character seems to have been settled by recent State Conventions. The plan of fusion which is being carried out between Chicago Democrats, free-silver Republicans, and Populists makes it impossible that Mr. Sewall can be elected Vice President by the Electoral College, even though Mr. Bryan may be chosen President.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30. -- Consul General Mills, at Honolulu, supplementing a former report calling attention to the diversion of Hawaiian trade from San Francisco to New-York, writes to the department under date of Aug. 13, that, during the six months ended June 30, the total exports from Honolulu to the United States were valued at $8,748,526.40, against $4,499,916.27 for the corresponding period last year, an increase of nearly $4,000,000.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 30 -- One of the earliest arrivals from the Eastern States is W.J. Curtis of New-Jersey. He reached the city in advance of the delegates from his State, that he might attend a meeting of the Executive Committee to-morrow.

The chief argument of the advocates of the free coinage of silver is that it would increase prices and relieve debtors. That necessarily implies that it would debase the standard of value, whatever may be said of the conflicting statements that silver would rise to the gold level and that gold would sink to the silver level, or that they would meet somewhere between.

A stylishly dressed young man, describing himself as Joseph, Baron von Rabeneck, of Philadelphia, was arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of snatching a woman's pocketbook.

An unusual number of sailing craft arrived in port yesterday. There were three ships and seven barks. The ships were the big American clipper Roanoke, which brought a cargo of sugar from Honolulu; the American ship Tam o' Shanter, with feas, mattings, , from Hongkong, and the German ship Wilheim, with china clay from Fowey, England.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 30. -- The representatives of the sound-money Democrats of the State will meet in convention at noon to-morrow in the Alhambra in this city.

Annie Quinn and Annie Tucker, aged respectively four and six years, both of whom live at 427 East Fourteenth Street, fell from the third-story fire escape, in the rear of their home last evening, the former receiving injuries which may prove fatal, and the latter sustaining a compound dislocation of the wrist.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 30. -- The delegations from New-York and Kings Counties reached Syracuse by special train at 7:15 o'clock to-night. They immediately went to their quarters at the Yates House. Both delegations are fully represented, and they have taken possession of the hotel. Their headquarters are in Room 55, and the Kings County men went into conference as soon as they had eaten dinner.

There is to be another great international cricket contest hereabout this year, for the negotiations between the New-Jersey Athletic Club and the Australians have been concluded satisfactorily, and the famous antipodean willow wielders will be seen at Bayonne Wednesday and Thursday, Sept. 23 and 24.
What success would lawyers have serves the courts if they cited authorities after the fashion of the present-day silver advocates?

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 30. -- The city to-day has been quiet, and no reports of further disturbances have been received. It is officially announced that the Government has decided to leave it to the choice of the residents whether or not the city shall be illuminated to-morrow evening upon the occasion of the twentieth anniversary of the accession to the throne of the Sultan.

John Bradley, alias "Chinee" Bradley, a well-known negro thief, about twenty-five years of age, was shot and killed by a policeman yesterday afternoon while trying to rob the laundry of Sam Lee, at 388 Third Avenue. Patrolman William J. Miller of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station shot the negro while resisting arrest, the bullet entering the thief's right eye.
I should like to correct a statement in too day's paper that "Harry Hill died in Flushing after a week's illness from chills and fever."

The Rev. Dr. R.S. MacArthur preached last evening at the Calvary Baptist Church at Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue; on "The Political Caves of the Adullamites." The preacher took his text from First Samuel, xxii., 1-2, "David fled for refuge to the caves of Adullam." Dr. MacArthur said that David was in trouble at this time, and was something of a freebooter.

GOSPORT, England, Aug. 22. -- The Isolde disaster has paralyzed yacht racing in the English Channel. The Prince of Wales has ordered Britannia to Cowes to get the damage done by Isolde's bowsprit and bows repaired, after which the cutter is to stop racing for the season. Alisa and Satanita, it is reported, are also to haul down their racing flags for the season.

PASSAIC, N.J., Aug. 30. -- Henry Darten, a farmer considered well to do, whose place, is near Nigh Mountain, came here on Friday and preferred a charge of assault and battery against George Lavey, who is by this time the son-in-law of his accuser, and it was while Darten was trying to prevent the elopement of his daughter with Lavery that the alleged assault was committed.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 30. -- The first production of H. Grattan Donnelly's new play, "The Woman in Black," was given at the Grand Opera House to-night. It was received with much favor, the audience becoming very enthusiastic over the election parade at Madison Square. The play is built up on melodramatic lines, but its most conspicuous characters are faithful reproductions of types familiar to every New-Yorker.

ASTORIA, Oregon, Aug. 30. -- Forest fires are still raging in the vicinity of Oakpoint, Washington, but a change in the wind has deflected the flames northward, and Oakpoint City, as well as several large canneries on the Columbia River, which were threatened, are now out of danger.

The Apostolic Christian Congregation, which believes that the second advent of Christ will take place Wednesday, is holding a series of revival meetings at 154 East Fifty-fourth Street. An audience of about 300 believers and skeptics was addressed yesterday afternoon in German and English by the Rev. F. Stutzke and his assistant, William Redwood, a recent convert.
PORT CHESTER, Aug. 30. -- The Rev. Dr. F.P. Tower preached to-day the first sermon of his pastorate in the Methodist Church of this place.

CORONA, L.I., Aug. 30. -- Funeral services were held here this afternoon over the body of Harry Hill, at the hotel and residence of his son on Jackson Avenue. There was a crowd of about 500 persons about the house while the services were in progress, but most of them were residents of this place and had congregated out of idle curiosity rather than out of respect for the memory of the dead man.
We are permitted to publish the following extracts from the letters of a New-York woman spending the Summer in Virginia. Her bright observations cannot fall to be both interesting and encouraging:

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 31. -- Tomlinson Hall, in which the convention is to be held, is about ready for occupancy by the National Democratic delegates. The carpenters are still at work, but the decorators, the electricians, and the telegraphers have kept at work with them, and the workmen will finish together.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 31. -- The preliminary work of the convention was rapidly and thoroughly done this morning before the delegates assembled in the Alhambra. When the convention was called to order it was evident that its session would be short, as reports were ready to be submitted and the different county delegations knew what they were going to suggest and know pretty well what would be suggested by others.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- The delegates and Electors at Large named by the Syracuse Sound-Money Democratic Convention in the Alhambra here to-day are as follows:

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 31. -- A special judicial committee began sessions in this city to-day for the purpose of trying 400 Moslems and Armenians who are accused of having participated in the recent rioting in and around Constantinople.
No respect for the august person of Li Hung Chang, the distinguished Chinese guest of the United States, was shown by the elements yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 31. -- Fire today consumed the Stockbridge House, known lately as the Red Lion Inn, and removes one of the oldest hotels in Massachusetts. The house had 165 guests, some of whom were domiciled in outside cottages.

Mr. DANIEL G. GRIFFIN -- a veteran Democrat, whose character and ability have long been known to his party in this State -- was the temporary Chairman of the convention at Syracuse yesterday. In the course of his speech he said:
LEWISTON, Me., Aug. 31. -- Mr. Bateman, the Populist candidate for Governor of Maine, has received the following letter from Senator Allen:

SYRACUSE, Aug. 31. -- The second session of the National Democratic State Convention was called to order at 2:45 by Temporary Chairman Griffin. He stated that while the convention was awaiting the reports of the committees, Dr. William Everett of Qaincy, Mass., would address the delegates. Dr. Everett, who had served his party in Congress, when introduced said that Massachusetts stood shoulder to shoulder with New-York for honest money, honest politics, and a united Union.

RIPLEY, N.Y., Aug. 31. -- Mr. Bryan arrived here at 1:30 P.M., after a rather uninteresting drive across country from Mayville. Many houses in the town here are decorated with banners bearing the names of Bryan and Sewall, while not a few have McKinley lithographs.

A recent meeting oarthe United Soldiers and Sailors' Mutual League of Indianapolis adopted the address given below, which had been reported by a committee composed of Gen. John Coburn, ex-Lieut. Gov. Thomas Hanna, the Rev. D.R. Lucas George C. Webster, and O.H. Woodworth. The address was received in this city yesterday, and will be circulated as a campaign document by the Republican National Committee.

There seems to be no doubt about the authenticity of the statement that the Spanish Government has approved of Gen. WEYLER'S decree prohibiting the gathering of the sugar and coffee crops in Cuba this season, and his orders prohibiting both the people of the island and foreigners resident there from holding intercourse with foreigners outside.

Our opponents have said that the soldiers who are receiving pensions must be protected against the free coinage of silver. They would have us believe that these financiers who are insisting upon a sold standard are insisting upon it for fear the soldiers drawing a pension may suffer by the abandonment of the gold standard.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 31. -- Hugh C. Wallace of Tacoma, who was a member of the Democratic National Committee and one of the delegates to the Chicago Convention, came to this city to-night, prepared to launch a boom for President Cleveland as the candidate. Mr. Wallace is one of the delegates at large to this convention.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 31. -- Ellis B. Usher of Wisconsin, a member of the Executive Committee of the National Democratic Party, arrived this morning. He said the delegation from Wisconsin would be here tomorrow morning, and while it was not under positive instructions to support Gen. Bragg for the Presidential nomination, the Wisconsin Convention had passed a resolution of indorsement which would be construed as an instruction.

As Mr. McKINLEY is talking quite freely about the tariff, we suggest that he should say something about the work of the combinations in the iron and steel industry. We announced in our news columns on the 14th ult. that the Carnegie Steel Company had recently sold 9,000 tons of steel rails to Japan.

The New-York Herald has made a canvass of representative election districts in New-York, New-Jersey, and Connecticut. It sent out 4,500 cards. The card requested to know whom the voter voted for in 1892 and how he intends to vote this year. The total vote of the selected districts in 1892 was as follows:
