MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 5. -- William J. Bryan reached the Northwestern Station here at 11:10 this morning and was met by ex-Gov. Peck and Willis C. Silverthorn, the Democratic candidate for Governor of Wisconsin.

Mr. Pike is not an unfamiliar traveler to those who read the best books of travel. His volume on "The Barren Grounds of Canada." published a few years ago. will be remembered for the testimony it gave to hardihood in travel and intelligence in recording the results of it. His present work will disappoint none of the expectations which that volume may have raised.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Sept. 5. -- A complete panic was caused here yesterday by the falling of an Armenian from a window to the street below. The people who saw the man fall believed that he had been thrown out of the window, and a rumor spread like wildfire that rioting had been renewed.

The Republican headquarters were unusually quiet yesterday. M.S. Quay was not at the rooms, but remained at the Waldorf, where he had several callers. He had intended going to Maine Friday night, but could not get away.
The long-standing troubles in the Peekamoose Club resulted in stirring incidents on Saturday, Aug. 29, which first became public yesterday.

Paris Dispatch to The London Standard. In the Rue Laghoust, an individual, named Delafond, planted himself yesterday straight in front of a sergent de ville, and shouted, " Vive Ravachol!" He was of course, immediately conducted to the Police Commissary's office, where, after saying that his object in indulging in the seditious cry was simply to get arrested and secure himself against dying from starvation, he related a strange story.

From The London News. The transactions of the Bale Congress on Alcoholism afford copious and interesting materials for the history of the rise and fall of drunkenness in our times. This congress, held on the borders of France, has passed unheeded by the French public, although the French Government was represented by M. Buisson, Director of Public Instruction.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 5. -- The International cricket match between the United States and Canada, which was commenced here on Friday, was interrupted by rain to-day, which allowed of no play after luncheon, and an adjournment had to be taken until Monday morning.

"I hear that 'Augy' Belmont is to be back some time this month, and that then the question will be settled as to whether be will make, a campaign in England next season." remarked The Traveler, as he came in and settled himself in his favorite corner, to enjoy the chatter of the sporting crowd.
CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 5. -- Decorated with clusters of goldenrod, emblematic of the money they favor, 5,000 Pennsylvanians visited Major McKinley to-day to cheer him and to listen to his speeches.

On Tuesday, Sept. 8, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the First Department will sit to hear arguments in appeals from orders. The Justices assigned to hold the term are VAN BRUNT, P. J.; RUMSEY, WILLIAMS, and O'BRIEN. A session for the same purpose was held late last July, at which Mr. Justice BARRETT presided, with Justices RUMSEY, PATTERSON, and INGRAHAM as his associates.

The deposits of imported gold in the Sub-Treasury yesterday were the largest of any single day since the flow of gold from Europe began. The steamship Campania, which arrived in port last Friday, alone brought twelve consignments of gold, and the St. Paul three. Nearly all of this gold was taken to the Sub-Treasury yesterday, and the clerks in that institution were kept busy the greater part of the day counting and packing it away.

BOSTON, Sept. 5 -- The stock market was inactive. The copper shares were quiet, with the exception of Montana and Old Dominion. The former gained 1 1/8, to 79 1/4, and the latter 1/2, to 16 1/8. Calumet and Hecla was steady at 301, ex dividend. The gold-mining shares were steady. Money at the Clearing House was easier at 6 per cent.

NEWPORT, Sept. 5.-- Sweet Charity is having her turn here. Nearly everybody went to the Travers villa Tuesday evening for the benefit of the Lisa Day Nursery of New-York, and doubtless next Wednesday afternoon the lawn of the Beaulieu, which the Calvin S. Brices are occupying, will be well covered with cottagers, who are to make a great effort to aid the financial condition of St. Mary's Hospital for Children of New-York.

Looking at the market movement for the week we percaive that McKinley is already elected. His election may be reversed by the vote of Arkansas to-morrow, but that has not come off yet. In the meantime, the professionals turned in with a will, and on the returns from Vermont put prices up with as much vigor as they fell on the bad days in August.

"In my Summer jaunting about," says a woman who has just returned to town. "I have been impressed with the growth of the village improvement association movement. My itinerary has taken me into email towns and hamlets in the interior of this and one or two adjacent States, and I have not been in a place where one of these organisations did not exist in a more or less flourishing condition.

A locomotive attached to a Brighton Beach Railroad train, bound from Coney Island to Brooklyn, struck a patrol wagon of the Twenty-fourth Precinct, Brooklyn, at 11:30 o'clock last night, at Emmons Avenue and Shore Road, and threw it into Coney Island Creek. Doorman Daniel Bayley was killed and Policeman John P. Morgan was seriously injured.
ALBANY, Sept. 4 -- Attorney General Hancock has been asked to advise concerning the rights of Indians to lands in the Tonawanda Reservation. In a written opinion the Attorney General says:

THIRTY-SIX years ago the Democratic Party was divided as it is divided now. The effect of the former rupture was to exclude it from the control of the Executive Government for twenty-three years, and during most of that period not only from the control of either house of Congress, but from establishing in either an effective or formidable opposition.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5. -- With a view of correcting erroneous statements, the Treasury Department to-day issued the following official memorandum of Treasury deficits and receipts and of the public debt paid by the last two preceding Administrations, which statement is also accompanied by a comparison of the customs receipts under the McKinley and Wilson laws.

BERLIN, Sept. 5 -- The diplomats who are assembled at Breslau around Prince Hohenlohe, the German Imperial Chancellor, include Prince Radolin, the German Ambassador at St. Petersburg; Count von Osten-Sacken, the Russian Ambassador at Berlin; Baron Marschall von Bieberstein, German Minister of Foreign Affairs; Count von Pourtales of the German Foreign Office, and Geheimrath Gunther of the German Imperial Chancellorie.

The New-York Whist Club expects lively times the coming Fall and Winter in defending the American Whist League trophy, which it won at the last congress. The club has some able players. They are not only good short-suit players, but play the long-suit game. In short, they are first-class all-around players. It will not be easy to wrest the trophy from them.

Sterilized milk as a good food for babies deprived of their natural nourishment has been noticed in a previous article. The milk is easily sterilized by boiling it in bottles. The bottles themselves must be kept scrupulously clean, being washed every time they are used with hot water, containing a saltspoonful of washing soda, in each quart bottle.
Alluding to an article from THE TIMES, (which it kindly describes as " one of our best dailies,") The Christian Work thus defines its position on the political issues now before the country:

Notwithstanding considerable realizing today, the market continued to show strength. The Grangers closed with fractional advances, and the active industrials were higher, notably General Electric and Tennessee Coal and Iron. Some of the international stocks scored small losses, but the general list was firm.
The September number of The North American Review contains the following announcement:

The day's trading in grain was chiefly in a scalping way, with prices lower with the West, and on expected freer receipts next week. Provisions were steadier and quiet, with offerings more reserved. Cotton was fairly active and closed higher after an early decline. Coffee was lower on free offerings, with a light demand.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 5. -- When Major McKinley was informed this afternoon that a rumor was current in Chicago that he was about to take the stump in Illinois at the request of the National Committee he declared emphatically that he had no intention of making speeches outside of Canton.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 5. -- Woodbury Kane, who sailed on the Defender in her races with Valkyrie last Fall, offered a cup for thirty-footers, which was sailed for to-day, and won by the Boston boat Asahi, owned by Bayard Thayer. It was a fast and interesting contest, and was followed by scores of cottagers and others in steam yachts.

BUFFALO, Sept. 5 -- William C. Cornwell, President of the City Bank, Buffalo, addressed the School of Finance here tonight on the money question. Mr. Cornwell used partly the arguments from his pamphlet on "Greenbacks: the Silver Trouble and Its Causes," which has been called the hit of the campaign.

This will be a comparatively dull week after the rush and bustle that have lately prevailed in the theatrical world. "Rosemary," "An Enemy to the King." "Marty Malone," and "The Caliph," which is a fair specimen of contemporary comic opera, handsomely dressed and mounted, at the Broadway Theatre, and performed with extraordinary nimbleness on the part of the star, Jefferson De Angelis, are now all launched on careers that promise to be successful.

On the day that Dr. Jameson and his officers were found guilty of infringing the Foreign Enlistment act and sent to Holloway Prison, Mr, John Hays Hammond, the American engineer, who was a most active member or the Reform Committee in Johannesburg at the time of the raid, was staying in London at the Savoy Hotel.

The Atlantic Yacht Club members were surprised yesterday by being served with an injunction restraining the club from racing for a cup offered by Vice Commodore Fred T. Adams for a race for sloops. The injunction was granted by Justice Smyth on the application of J. Montgomery Strong, the owner of the sloop Choctaw.

NEW-YORK, Sept. 5. BEEVES -- Receipts were 39 cars, or 468 head, all consigned direct to slaughterers, with the exception of 1 carload. No trading; feeling steady. City-dressed native sides firm for good to choice quality; weak for common and medium grades; quotations are 6 1/2@8c for decent to choice; inferior quality sells as low as 6c. Range beef lower at 5 3/4@6 3/4c per Ib.

BAYONNE, N. J., Sept. 5. -- The Bayonne Rowing Association's nineteenth annual regatta scheduled for this afternoon on Upper New-York Bay had to be postponed owing to very unfavorable conditions. In this usually quiet water, protected by Constable Hook and the Packard Canal Basin, which acts as a breakwater, shells and barges could not be launched owing to rough water, and wind which blew a gale for some time.

From all indications the members of the Knickerbocker Club will find their clubhouse at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-second Street, which has been in the hands of the carpenters, plasterers, and painters all Summer, very much improved in every war when they begin to return from their Summer outings this week.
A private letter from a member of the traveling party, which also included Mr. and Mrs. Youmans, gives an account of the sad fatality which cost them their lives in Norway in early July.

Antitoxine serum was first administered for tetanus in the public hospitals in this country on Thursday evening, when Earnest Neidecker of One Hundred and Seventy-fourth Street and St. Nicholas Avenue was taken to the Fordham Hospital, suffering from lockjaw. He is fifteen years old and is a driver for a lumber dealer.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- Sir Philip W. Currie, the British Ambassador to Turkey, who left London on his return to Constantinople on Monday last, was directed before his departure to obtain an early audience with the Sultan, and to deliver to his Majesty a message from Queen Victoria protesting against the massacres which have taken place, and demanding that stringent measures be taken to prevent further outrages.

LONDON, Sept. 5 -- It is a long time since any sudden death has excited Europe so much as that of Prince Lobanoff. The confused statecraft of the past eighteen months had put so many strings into his hands that his wholly unlocked for dropping out affected every diplomatic interest in the Old World.

It is a doubtful and complex outlook that our London dispatches reveal this morning. The one question that haunts the thoughts and troubles the dreams of the great diplomats -- the question of how long the carving of Turkey can be deferred -- does not become less perplexing with time.

Observers in the bicycle trade are unanimous in the opinion that the time is not far distant when manufacturers will provide for a brake on every wheel turned out, barring, of course, racing machines, on which the attachment would be superfluous. A year ago the sentiment in the ranks of the riders, owing largely to the antagonistic attitude of leaders who were expert cyclists, was apparently against the brake, but now this is changed.

The recent death on the Island of Melos of M. Henri Brest, says The London Standard, recalls the fact that his name many years ago was a celebrated one on account of its connection with the statue of Venus, now one of the great treasures in the Louvre Museum, and brings to mind some interesting souvenirs connected with that statue.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 5. -- New-Jersey Athletic Club yachtsmen this afternoon held a regatta on Newark Bay and raced for fleet pennants offered by Former Commodore Howard M. Cook. They sailed three times around a triangular course, starting off the boathouse and running three times around to cover ten miles. East by southeast wind prevailed, and was puffy, notwithstanding the rain.
SAVANNAH, Sept. 5. -- Spirits of turpentine firm at 22c; sales, 1,463 bbls. Resin firm at $1.40.

The Commercial Travelers' Sound Money League headquarters, on the southeast corner of Broadway and Prince Street, will be opened Wednesday next at noon by Garret A. Hobart, Republican candidate for Vice President, and Chauncey M. Depew.
Saturday, Sept. 5. GRAND BOULEVARD, e s, 28.1 ft n of 105th St, 27.1x10.6x25x6; Frank L. Smith, and wife to F. M. Jencks .............. $1

On my way from the Leipziger Strasse to the exhibition, while sitting on the top of a tram car, a young lady of some seventeen Summers, with a fine, intelligent, and unmistakably Jewish face, came on and sat herself beside me.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 5. -- The game between the Athletics and Patersons here to-day was called in the sixth inning on account of rain with the score 2 to 0 in Paterson's favor. Wagner knocked a home run in the second inning. Smith pitched a good game for Paterson, striking out seven men in six innings. The score:

Among the many new plays of the week "An Enemy to the King." which Mr. Daniel Frohman and Mr. Sothern have produced at the Lyceum Theatre in a manner which satisfies the imagination and stirs the feeling for romance that lies dormant in the breast of the most prosaic practical folk, is first in importance.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 -- Carl Schurz discussed the silver question this evening before an audience that completely filled the Central Music Hall. Every seat was taken and many who desired admission were unable to get into the hall. The meeting was under the direction of the American Honest-Money League.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5 -- Drizzling wet weather affected the programme for Li Hung Changes last day of entertainment in the United States quite as much is the Viceroy's own comfort has demolished arrangements from time to time since his arrival in New-York.

The State Board of Pardons yesterday recommended to the Governor a full pardon for NUMA DUDOUSSAT, late Alderman of the City of New-Orleans, convicted of having received a bribe. There seems little doubt that CAUFIELD and HALEY, bribe-taking and bribe-demanding Aldermen of this city, but now in the penitentiary, will soon be pardoned out.

Now it is Dr. HANS RICHTER who has come to the defense of SIEGFRIED WAGNER. He writes to The London Times: "The growing influence of RICHARD WAGNER's son, Herr SIEGFRIED WAGNER, in the management of the festival performances at Baireuth has been animadverted upon in a tone which is very severe for the promising young man and unjust toward the able and conscientious managers of the Festspiele.

OXFORD, Penn., Sept. 5. -- East of Oxford, five miles away, there is a quiet village. New-London, which was known a century ago as New-London Cross Roads. The name came from the proprietors of the territory, the London Company. Few hamlets in this old Commonwealth have such history of general interest as New-London.

From The Detroit Free Press. (Dem.) Rising prices without rising wages mean serious injury to the workingmen and to everybody in the receipt of a fixed salary. Even when wages are advanced to correspond with the rise in prices -- if that period ever comes, which is by no means certain -- they will be no better off than they are now.

Col. James J. Mooney, Chief Inspector in the Department of Street Improvements of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards, caused the arrest yesterday morning of Michael Kennedy, an employe of Isaac Hopper, the contractor, who is building the new bridge over the Harlem River at Third Avenue.

Renting of houses and apartments occupies the attention of real estate firms just now, as usually happens at this time of year. Conditions in the general market do not differ materially from those of last year. Landlords demand the same rents as before, and they get them when figures are moderate.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 6 -- The most impressive services ever held in a Catholic church in this section took place to-day in St. Mary's Church, of which parish the Rev. Richard Lalor Burtsell is pastor. The church, being free from debt, was consecrated by Archbishop Corrigan, assisted by the Rev. P.J. Canon of Buffalo and by a dozen priests, at 7 o'clock, the service lasting two hours.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 6. -- One of the biggest State scandals since the days of reconstruction in South Carolina was discovered last night by Gov. Evans. If his statement is correct, the dispensary system has been as good as a gold mine to those in charge of it.

SING SING, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The officials at the State prison here to-day absolutely denied the rumors circulated recently that John Y. McKane was accorded privileges in the prison which are denied to the other prisoners. Warden Sage is absent on his vacation, but Secretary Hickey, speaking for the Warden, said there was no truth in the statements that had been made by discharged convicts.

To some it appeared churlish that Jupiter Pluvius should quench the ardor of those who believe in the efficacy of the Kneipp, or dew, cure for human ills, but this was the effect of the rain in New-York yesterday morning.

BRESLAU, Sept. 6. -- The festivities in connection with the visit of the Czar and Czarina were continued to-day, but, it being Sunday, the popular enthusiasm was not as demonstrative as it was yesterday. Emperor William and Empress Augusta Victoria attended a luncheon given to-day by their imperial Majesties of Russia.

City Magistrate Cornell was about to leave the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday when he was told that there was another prisoner, a young woman, still locked up in the pen. The Magistrate inquired what she was charged with, and who the policeman was that brought her to court.

Dr. George Brown Goode. Dr. George Brown Goode, Assistant Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, and in charge of the National Muspum, in Washington, died of pneumonia shortly before 9 o'clock last evening, at his residence, at Lanier Heights, a suburb of Washington.

Ex-Congressman Perry Belmont yesterday made public the letter to Chairman Hinkley of the Democrate State Committee, in which he resigns from the State Committee because of his inability to support Bryan and Sewall. The letter is as follows:
The storm of Saturday and yesterday extended over a wide area, and the rainfall was above the average.

Foreign exchange was higher early in the week, but became easier. The posted rates for sterling were $4.83 for sixty-day bills and $4.85 for demand. Actual business was done on Saturday at $4.82 1/2@$4.82 3/4 for sixty-day bills, $4.84@ $4.84 1/4 for demand, $4.84 1/2@$4.84 3/4 for cable transfers, and $4.81 1/2 for commercial.
"Look out, there's a tramp in the house!" This cry of warning was uttered by an inmate of the tenement house 804 Eleventh Avenue shortly after 6 o'clock A.M. yesterday.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 6. -- There was a serious riot at the Polish Catholic Church, on the south side of this city, just after the 10:30 o'clock mass this morning, in which eight or ten members were severely beaten and two or three police officers were battered.

Coroner Coombs of Brooklyn purposes to inquire searchingly into the cause of the accident on Saturday night when a patrol wagon of the Coney Island Police Station was smashed by an engine of the Brooklyn and Brighton Beach Railroad Company and Doorman Daniel Bailey was killed.

MONDAY -- A.M. Business on the Stock Exchange has increased in volume and prices have advanced without important reaction. Sentiment, which had been slowly improving since the import movement of gold began, received increased stimulus from the splendid result of the Vermont election, and it was further aided in no small degree by the unequivocal success of the sound-money convention in Indianapolis.
Dr. Thomas Gallagher had not slept a wink since Saturday morning, when his breakfast of toast and tea was yesterday taken to his room in the Savoy Hotel.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Sept. 6. -- The three-masted schooners Hattie H. Barbour, Capt. Erskine, of and from Bangor for Bridgeport, Conn., with a cargo of ice; Electa Bailey, Capt Thurston, of and from Bangor for Philadelphia, with a cargo of laths, and Charley Bucki of Jonesport, Me., from Two Rivers, N.S., for New-York, with a cargo of laths, all ran ashore north of Hedge Fence Shoal.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 6. -- Mr. Bryan spent a quiet day at the residence of E.C. Wall, Democratic National Committeeman from Wisconsin. He attended service in the morning, with Mrs. Wall, at Emanuel Presbyterian Church. He will leave Milwaukee at 7:15 o'clock to-morrow morning, and will reach Chicago at 9:30 o'clock.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- Li Hung Chang and party arrived in this city at 11:45 o'clock this morning, accompanied by the United States Army officers who are escorting the party about the country. They came directly from Washington in a handsomely appointed Pullman vestibuled train of seven coaches.
The Rev. Robert S. MacArthur delivered a sermon last evening at Calvary Baptist Church on "Religious Lessons from the Political Events of Last Week."
-- The future of American politics is explained for the benefit of The London Times by Mr. THOMAS G. SHEARMAN as follows:

The apparently successful application of lockjaw antitoxine to a patient in the Fordham Hospital was reported in our columns yesterday. This antitoxine is produced by the method used in the manufacture of antitoxine for diphtheria. Lockjaw is an infectious disease and has its characteristic bacillus, the Introduction of which into an open wound causes the malady.

-- The death of M. Josaph Thome, formerly a stonemason, and later a millionaire, is announced from Paris. He is the man who, under the inspiration of Napoleon III. and the guidance of Baron Haussmann, carried out the vast building schemes which changed old Paris to the new one, and had vast political as well as aesthetic influence upon the city.

For some years, and up to a comparatively recent date, Mr. WILLIAM J. BRYAN vigorously opposed in and out of Congress the protectionist tariff policy, mainly upon the ground that it increased the prices of the necessaries of life and other commodities. Those prices, he contended, ought not thus to be increased.

Two inquiries are constantly being made by Democrats who have not yet made up their minds to vote against BRYAN, and both relate to the election of McKINLEY, which they rightly regard as the only probable alternative to the election of BRYAN. One is: "How can we, sincere believers in a tariff for revenue only, help in the election of the most narrow and obstinate of high protectionists?"

Among the many notable performances of the harness horses this year the battle of the pacers at Fleetwood Park last Wednesday furnished what is likely to stand as the most sensational feat of the season. As the annual visit of the crack campaigners to the metropolis brought the Grand Trotting Circuit of 1896 to a close, the contest takes precedence of anything that happened during the Summer tour which began nearly two months ago.

Two charming young Southern women have ensconced themselves in a cozy den on Forty-fourth Street West. They are both of a literary turn, and came to New-York two weeks ago from Dixie, to seek fame and fortune on the troubled sea of journalism. Their pocketbooks are still unexhausted, and they are supremely happy.

UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The bicycle relay riders who are bringing a message from The San Francisco Examiner to The Journal in New-York reached this city at 9:20 P.M. Rain, has delayed the riders, though good work has been done over heavy roads. With the roads in a bad state, the packet bearing the message will not be delivered in New-York till early to-morrow evening.

A correspondent inquires as to the sources of information on which we based an estimate of the amount of American securities returned from abroad since 1890, in an article of the 25th ult. The estimate was based on reports of a number of banking houses engaged in this line of business. They are necessarily approximate only.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 6. -- Mrs. Robert Curry of 20 Frederick Street is in doubt as to whether she is still a wife or a widow. Her husband disappeared on Aug. 3, and it was believed he had gone to another city to look for work. On Aug. 10 an insane man, half nude, was captured by the Elizabeth police and sent to the Morris Plains Asylum.

OLEAN, N.Y., Sept. 6. -- The Democratic Convention for the First Assembly District of Cattaraugus County, held at Franklinville yesterday, nominated E.M. Bedford of Portville for Assemblyman and elected M.B. Jewell, P.T. Button, and John Hunt delegates to the State Convention. The Chicago ticket and platform were indorsed.
The Rev. Horace Porter, assistant pastor, preached in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, yesterday on "The Problem of the Poor in Greater New-York," taking for his text, "Remember the poor." Gal. ii., 10.

BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Sept. 6. -- Yore's Opera House and adjoining buildings were burned early this morning, causing the death of eleven firemen and injury to a number of others and entailing a loss of about $65,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 6. -- Reports which have been coming in from the West the last few days indicate that the ticket nominated at Indianapolis is to prove an important factor in the campaign. It will draw a great many votes away from Bryan in all the Central Western States, especially in Illinois, Indiana, and Kentucky, where such votes are likely to count.

LITTLE ROCK, Sept. 6. -- The Arkansas State election, to be held to-morrow, has awakened far more interest than any election here since the war. While all indications point to the success of the Democratic ticket, it is predicted that it will fall far short of its boasted majority of 50,000.

GLENCOE, Mina., Sept. 6. -- Charles Cingmars and Dorman Musgrove, who murdered Sheriff Rogers in June, were hanged at 1:20 o'clock this morning to the railroad bridge, less than a quarter of a mile out of town. One of the men was hanged from the north side of the bridge and the other from the south side.

Dr. Charles A. Eastman, a Sioux Indian, delivered yesterday afternoon an address before a meeting of men at the Harlem Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. His subject was "The Foundation and Development of Young Men's Christian Association Work Among the Indians of North America."
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 6. -- Mrs. William Grosvenor entertained at dinner to-night in honor of Mr. and Mrs. J.B.M. Grosvenor of New-York.

A handsome young woman, who said her name was Annie Kumpf and that she lived in Brooklyn, but declined to say on what street or avenue, was taken to the Yorkville Court yesterday morning, attiped in a natty bicycle costume of light stuff, and was remanded toy Magistrate Flammer on a charge of picking pockets.

BERLIN, Sept. 6. -- The conferences which have taken place between the Czar and the Emperor and their accompanying Russian and German diplomats, which at first were alleged to be devoid of anything more important than mere ceremonial conversations, are now reported to have taken the character of initiating a new concert of the powers, winch is to have a bearing of the utmost importance upon the future events in Turkey.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 6. -- In the Eighth Congressional District yesterday the National Democrats nominated W.W. Callahan of Decatur for Congress and J.C. Lester of Sheffield for District Elector. The Indianapolis nominees and platform were indorsed. Other sound-money nominations will be made in every district.
The London Saturday Review asserts that the war in Cuba is rapidly degenerating into pure barbarism, and makes the following interesting suggestion:

Gustav Salvini, the younger son of the lamented tragedian, is now in Naples for a short theatrical season. A correspondent of The London News says of him: "Salvini is following in the steps of his father, and fairly promises to attain the same artistic rank. He is a tall, handsome man, with a fine brow and a pleasant expression.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 7 -- The dedication of the new Public School No. 1, acknowledged to be the largest and finest building of its kind in the State of New-Jersey, took place at 3 o'clock this afternoon. The building is on East Jersey Street, near the corner of Third Street, and will accommodate 1,200 pupils.

Alfred B. Darling, senior member of the firm of Hitchcock, Darling Co., proprietors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel, died Sunday at Richfield Springs. He was born in Burke, Vt., in 1821, and lived on a farm until of age, when he went to Boston and was employed by Paran Stevens at the Revere House.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In opening this series of letters I used the word "half-witted" to describe the "Popocrat" Party. I did this with the intention of challenging attention and making people read what I had to say. It has worked well -- they do read. Anonymous, threatening, and abusive letters and newspapers pour in.

BAYONNE, N.J., Sept. 7 -- The Bayonne Rowing Association's nineteenth annual regatta, postponed from last Saturday, was decided this morning under favorable conditions. The course was along the Bayonne shore of New-York Bay, and the water was perfect, with no wind to interfere. Several hundred spectators witnessed the regatta, which was well managed and interesting throughout.

A heavy deficit confronts the party which has reduced the tariff and is anxious to prevent a necessary readjustment of duties. * * * Let us meet this question, Democratic friends, in the same spirit of devotion to public welfare which is shown in rejecting the Populist nomination at Chicago. [New-York Tribune, Sept. 7.]

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 7 -- Society observed the holiday very quietly, most people going over to the Country Club for luncheon and for the afternoon, as the weather was most auspicious for such an outing. There were many dinners at the cottages, the most charming being those of Mrs. Robert M. Cushing, Mrs. John Thompson Specner, Mrs. James Hude Beekman, and Mrs. R.H.I. Goddard.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Sept. 7 -- A primary was held in this place to-night for the purpose of electing delegates to the Democratic State Convention, which meets at Trenton Wednesday, Sept. 9.

Yet another example of the blind, unreasoning ferocity of naval courts-martial. A boy named Kavanagh of Her Majesty's ship Blenheim was ordered by Commander Currey to receive twelve strokes with a birch, and very probably with good cause; but on receiving his sentence, Kavanagh straightaway went for the commander and struck the sacred person of that officer.

The annual Fall regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club was sailed yesterday on the Sound. It was rather a fluky race. The wind, which had been blowing freshly all the morning, died out just after they crossed the line, and they drifted about on the Sound all the afternoon, making poor headway.
LONDON, Sept. 7 -- Sir Joseph Archer Crowe, the noted English journalist, war correspondent, diplomatist, and author, is dead.

The Rev. C.A. Wooddy is the tallest minister on the Pacific coast. He is also the preacher and journalist whose utterances are backed by the greatest weight. Mr. Wooddy is the coast Secretary of the American Baptist Home Mission Society, editor of The Pacific Baptist, the official organ of the Baptist denomination on the coast, and a powerful preacher.

Silver is inferior to gold as a standard for measuring value, and it has become in the last twenty years much less fitted for the purpose than it was before on account of a decrease in the cost of producing it and a corresponding increase in the amount produced, with consequent fluctuations in its value which have constantly tended downward.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 7 -- Major McKinley had something of a holiday to-day. He read letters and newspapers most of the morning, and viewed the Labor Day bicycle parade from his porch. He was cheered by those in the parade, and so was the handsome new flag which was unfurled in honor of the occasion.

Mr. BLAINE'S friends were accustomed to say during the canvass of 1884 that the withdrawal of the Mugwumps had greatly benefited the Republican Party. They were a lot of milksops at best, overeducated, inclined to make too much fuss about the methods approved by practical politicians, a nuisance in council, and of small aid in the field.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Sept. 7 -- Herbert Felders, a New-York broker, had three fingers dislocated by being thrown from his bicycle in Sayville, L.I., to-day. He was riding with friends. Opposite the residence of W.K. Vanderbilt he struck the root of a tree. He was pitched head first from his wheel, and to protect his head thrust out his left hand.

The Birmingham (Ala.) News, which carries the names of BRYAN and SEWALL at the head of its columns, takes no stock in one of the arguments most used by Mr. BRYAN himself. It says: "One hears every now and then the assertion that the increase of failures in this country this Summer as compared with last Summer is due to the single gold standard.
"Poolrooms, roulette, faro, , in full swing at Weehawken. N.J."

While Albert Chevalier was beginning his second engagement in New-York, last night, at the Garrick Theatre, with a brand-new background of red cloth, Cissy Fitzgerald was audaciously dancing at Koster Bial's, before the very background of red cloth that the famous coster singer had used last Winter.

It was made very apparent among the local golf clubs during the past week that the vacation season was over. Many golfers, who had been away, were seen again in their old familiar places, while even those who had remained at home put a little more snap and vigor into their play, as though more was expected of them, now that the Fall season had fairly opened.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Sept. 7 -- The city celebrated the semi-centennial of its existence as a city in a royal manner. A feature was the magnificent parade of military and civic bodies, the procession being five miles long, with nearly 10,000 men in line.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Clark Howell of Atlanta has taken the place of Congressman Richardson as the representative here of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. Howell received a number of callers during the day, and examined the contents of a large pile of mail. He said the situation in Georgia was such as to indicate a tremendous majority for Bryan.

Dr. Thomas Gallagher was particularly violent yesterday and Sunday night in his room in the Hotel Savoy, frequently striking and kicking any one who came within his reach. He became so ungovernable Sunday night and his nurses were so badly frightened that a hotel boy was sent out for a straightjacket and straps.

The story of the Uitlanders in the Transvaal, as told from their statements by Mr. RICHARD HARDING DAVIS in the supplement to Sunday's TIMES, has some points of novelty. It is the first presentation of their case that the Reform Committee of Johannesburg have permitted to be made, because it could not have been made before without putting in jeopardy the chances of Dr. JAMESON and his companions before a British court of justice.
The First Regiment of the Irish Volunteers celebrated Labor Day with games in Sulzer's Park, at One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Second Avenue.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 -- The celebration of Labor Day by Chicago's workingmen centred mainly in the meeting addressed by William J. Bryan, at Sharpshooter's Park, a pleasure ground situated at an inconvenient distance from the city. The street railway service was not of the best, and many persons were unable to reach the park.
NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7 -- The Waverly faif opened this morning under the auspices of the New-Jersey State Agricultural Society.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- Although Labor Day has been a day of rest with the Republican Congressional Committee so far as the actual work of distribution of documents is concerned, it has been fruitful in good reports. Chairman Babcock has received information from all quarters of the most encouraging character.

YONKERS, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- Everybody turned out here to-day to witness the game of baseball between the Aldermen of Yonkers and the Aldermen of Mount Vernon, and they wanted to see Mayor Patrick Jerome Gleason of Long Island City, who had been selected to umpire the game.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 7 -- The dead body of an unknown woman, apparently about thirty-five years old, was found in Aden's Woods, in the northeast part of this village, to-day by Walter Beaaton and two other young men while hunting. They notified the police and Coroner Banning of Mount Vernon.
Erie ferryboat John G. McCullough ran into the Slip at the foot of Pavonia Avenue, Jersey city, yesterday, and crushed the bridge between the dock and the bow of the boat.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 7 -- Indications are that the Democrats, who have complete control of the election machinery of the State, in the State election to-day have secured a majority for their ticket fully equal to what they predicted it would receive.

LONDON, Sept. 7-- The great single scull race for the world's championship and a stake of L500 between Jacob Gaudaur, the Canadian oarsman, and James Stanbury of Victoria, Australia, who won the championship by defeating Charles R. ("Wag") Harding of Putney on July 13 last, was rowed to-day and resulted in a victory for the Canadian, who won with the greatest ease.

A perfect day, a large crowd of spectators, hotly contested events, and great enthusiasm made the seventh annual regatta of the Middle States Regatta Association on Harlem River yesterday one of the most successful ever held.

Never in the history of New-York has the feast of Rosh Hashona, the Jewish New Year, been as widely observed, both the Orthodox and Liberal Jews uniting to make a great celebration of this feast, the gladdest in the Jewish calendar.

No one who followed the course of Mr. MANNING while Secretary of the Treasury even casually would be likely to believe that he "paid, or threatened to pay, any part of the coin obligations of the United States in silver when the holders of such obligations demanded gold."

We do not see the wisdom of evading or belittling the lesson of the Arkansas election, as some of the Northern and Eastern papers are inclined to. In its way it has as much meaning as the Vermont election, and it is unfortunately to a marked extent an offset to that. Both are agricultural States.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 8. -- It looks as though the Democratic majority in the State election would run up to 65,000. There seems to be no doubt that the Democrats have made large use of their control of the election machinery.

LANCASTER, Sept. 8 -- Lancaster administered a defeat to Newark to-day, and the latter's chance for the pennant is thus considerably lessened. Both clubs put up a good fielding game, but Setly was hit hard in the last two innings. Score:
EDINBURGH, Sept. 8 -- The second day's sitting of the Trades Union Congress opened this morning with a full attendance of delegates.

KIEL, Sept. 8 -- The Czar and Czarina arrived here to-day. Their Majesties were received at the station by Prince Henry of Prussia and his wife. Princess Irene. The imperial visitors entered carriages and were driven to the Jensen Bridge, where they embarked on board a steam launch and were conveyed to the Schloss.

Accountants in the Sub-Treasury were kept busy on Labor Day figuring up the recent deposits of imported gold, and according to their figures yesterday the total amount of the Government gold reserve considerably exceeds $107,000,000.

-- A curious tribute to a strong personality is described by The Savannah News: "The Hon. William Elliott of the First South Carolina District, whose seat in the present Congress was stolen by the Republican majority and bestowed upon a negro, has been unanimously renominated for the position.

-- Ex-Congressman FORMAN of Illinois, who is usually a man careful in his statements, reiterates his serious 'charges against Gov. ALTGELD, which The Chicago Chronicle declares ALTGELD has not denied:

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 8. -- The second home-coming of William Jennings Bryan since his nomination by the Chicago Convention was made the occasion of an enthusiastic outburst on the part of his fellowtownsmen, that differed from his first reception here as a Presidential candidate in that it was strictly partisan.
Ex-Gov. P.B.S. Pinchback of Louisiana was in this city yesterday. He has been invited by the Republican National Committee to make several campaign speeches.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 8. -- The National Silver Party, through its regularly appointed committee, to-night formally notified William Jennings Bryan of his nomination by its convention at St. Louis. The ceremonies attending the notification were in strong contrast to those at the meeting at Madison Square garden last month, when Mr. Bryan and Mr. Sewall were officially informed that they were the choice of the Chicago Convention.

PACIFIC JUNCTION, Iowa, Sept. 8. -- After a night of that uncertain rest which a sleeping-ear berth affords, Mr. Bryan arose early this morning to greet a crowd of people gathered on the covered platform at Malvern. The crowd there numbered 200, and Mr. Bryan shook hands with nearly everybody in it.

Col. Pattie Watkins of the headquarters division of Ballington Booth's Army of American Volunteers, and her stenographer, Capt. Fred A. Lindsay, Staff Captain in the corps of field officers of the Volunteers, were united in marriage at Carnegie Hall last night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- Senator Butler, Chairman of the Populist National Committee, believes that Candidate Tom Watson is the victim of misrepresentation by the press in the report of his speech of yesterday.

The farmers have suffered in their export trade. The total wheat, rye, barley, oats, and corn crops for 1895 amounted to 3,556,900,000 bushels. The total of this product exported was 132,304,000 bushels, or a little less than 4 per cent, of the total product annually, and more than 96 per cent, was consumed at home.

Policeman O'Neil was standing on the Bowery Monday night about 10:30 o'clock, when a cable car conductor went up to him and handed him a bag, saying it had been left on his car. Before the policeman could examine the bag, the conductor jumped on his car and left.

OAKLAND, Cal., Sept. 8 -- W.A. Richards, the Republican Governor of Wyoming, is in this city on a visit, accompanied by his wife. Gov. Richards fully believes that Wyoming will elect three Republican Electors.

It is known to the elderly New-Yorker that there was once a time when the journals of this city delighted to wallow, at intervals, in personal controversies with each other. In the course of one of these controversies the editor of one of them adverted to a rumor, invented by himself, that another was edited by a malignant lunatic who was making some noise at the time.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 8 -- A large body of Ohio Republican editors, who are here attending their annual State Convention, called on Major McKinley to-day. John Hopley, the oldest editor in the State, was their spokesman. Replying, Major McKinley said:

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 8 -- The open tennis tournament of the Sleepy Hollow Tennis Club was continued here to-day, and a number of interesting matches were played. Most of yesterday's delinquents have put in an appearance, and the tournament is now in full swing. R.H. Carleton of Harvard played one of the best matches of the day against E.H. Thayer of Tarrytown.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 8 -- Outside of the Democratic State Committee there are not over fifty Democrats here to-night, and it is the smallest advance guard that has ever been in advance of a State Convention.

The New-York ball players defeated the Pittsburg team yesterday afternoon at the Polo Grounds. Hastings pitched for the visitors, and for six innings did very well. In the seventh the local players found Hastings very easy, and scored five runs. During the inning Lyons protested so vigorously against Umpire Emslie's decision in declaring Joyce safe at third that he was fined, and put out of the game.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8. -- Chairman Babcock of the Republican Congressional Committee, here, speaking of the Arkansas election, said:

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 8. -- A mass meeting was held in front of the State Capitol Building this afternoon. A parade composed of Bryan flambeau clubs and free-silver clubs, and including floats bearing free-silver devices and several hundred men on horseback from neighboring localities, formed at City Hall Square and escorted Mr. Bryan to the State House.
OMAHA, Sept. 8. -- From the steps of the car on which he was to make the journey from this city to Lincoln, Mr. Bryan made a speech to a crowd of about 1,200 persons. He said:

SAUGUS, Mass., Sept. 8 -- At Franklin Park this afternoon the first event was the 2:24 trot left over from yesterday, in which Phantom had taken one heat. She had little or no trouble in winning the race to-day in straight heats.

HELENA, Mon., Sept. 8. -- Senator Carter's statement regarding the course of conduct he pursued as a delegate to the St. Louis Convention is published to-day in the form of an open letter to the members of the Republican State Convention of Montana, which the Senator says he will be unable to attend.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 -- The following address to "Every American Patriot" has been issued from the headquarters of the National People's Party:

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Sept. 9 -- The Union National Bank, which was founded in 1839 and one of the oldest banks in the city, closed its doors to-day. It had always been a prosperous and paying institution until some time ago it became known in business circles that it was not thoroughly sound.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- William R. Dawes, a business man of Lincoln, Neb., has sent to Republican National Headquarters the result of a non-partisan and extensive canvass of the country towns and surrounding rural region of Nebraska, omitting Douglas and Lancaster Counties, where Omaha and Lincoln are situated.

There is a basis of cowardice in the talk of the Bryanites about the "independence" of this country in matters of finance. Mr. BRYAN himself shows it, but not so plainly as some of his followers. For instance, here is a gentleman by the name of JOHN F. BIBLE of Michigan, from whom a letter is published in The Constitution-Democrat of Keokuk, Iowa.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9 -- Working up against a fearful off-shore breeze, a terrific sea has developed to-night. This morning the fishing schooners anchored off Seaconnet tugged hard at their cables, and at least two of them parted, their ground tackle and were blown to sea.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 -- Two colored men have been arrested and lodged in the Towson Jail, charged with poisoning 3,000 English pheasants and 300 domestic fowls, including ducks, geese, chickens, and turkeys, the property of the Bowley's Quarter Ducking Club, at Bengies, Md. The monetary loss is placed at $5,000.

EDINBURGH, Sept. 9 -- The Trades Union Congress resumed its sittings this forenoon. The President announced the expulsion from the sittings of the congress of all reporters representing newspapers which employ nonunion compositors, which, although ordered by resolution yesterday, had not been in the meantime enforced.

Mr. BRYAN seems to have a curious and mistaken notion as to the newspapers of the East. When he came to New-York to make his notification speech and when he wrote his formal letter of acceptance his notion apparently was that these were about all of his utterances that would reach the readers of the papers in this part of the country --" the enemy's country."

Henry Hildebrand, nineteen years old, who is employed as confidential messenger by George Ringler Co., brewers, was attacked by two men shortly after noon yesterday and was robbed of $1,989 in cash and $3,000 in checks. One of the robbers is in custody, but the other escaped.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 9 -- Major McKinley has been engaged all day in the not-unfamiliar work of writing speeches. He is to be visited by ten delegations the latter part of this week, and it seems likely that he will have to make a separate address to each of them. The arrival of the delegation of Vermonters at 0 o'clock Friday morning is looked forward to with uncommon interest.

The readers of BRYANS speeches include the entire reading population of the United States. The great majority of readers continue to peruse both the formal and the casual speeches of the Populistic candidate With as much avidity as they read the speech by which he stampeded the Chicago Convention to his nomination, or the speech by which he stampeded his audience at Madison Square Garden out of the place.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 -- The Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston, which recently visited England, will come to Baltimore on Oct. 6, and there will be several days of unusual jollification.

Roland L. Smith of 544 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday in Greenport, L.I., for forgery and was taken to Brooklyn, where in the afternoon he was arraigned in the Lee Avenue Police Court, before Justice Goetting, who held him for trial.

The suit of W.H.A. Brown, administrator of the estate of W.H. Brown, who died last October, to recover $2,000,000 and interest from October, 1853, from the estate of Commodore Vanderbilt, was brought to an end yesterday by a decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court upholding Justice Pryor ruling that Brown is not entitled to examine the business aucounts of the late Commodore Vanderbilt.

CHICAGO, Sept. 9 -- Gen. John C. Black has written a letter formally declining the nomination of the State Gold Democratic Convention of Illinois for Governor. After saying that he was out of the State at the time of his nomination, and giving as a reason for the delay in answering the notification that he needed time to ascertain the reasons for his nomination, he says:

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 9 -- Mr. Bryan today gave out a corrected itinerary of his Southern and Eastern trip as far as arranged. He will leave Lincoln Friday, Sept. 11, at 9:15 o'clock by the Missouri Pacific Road, arrive in Kansas City at 7 o'clock the next morning, and leave there about 9 o'clock over the Wabash for St. Louis. He will not speak in Kansas City.

John B. Stanchfield of Elmira, N.T., the Democratic leader of the last Assembly, has practically declared himself out of the race for the nomination for Governor, although it has been evident all along that if he wanted the nomination from the machine at Buffalo he would be almost certain to get it.
BANGOR, Me., Sept. 9. -- Ex-Gov. Roswell P. Flower of New-York addressed a big meeting in the City Hall to-night, under the auspices of the Sound-Honey Democratic Club. Mr. Flower said:

The Illustrated American has done an excellent thing in printing a pageful of portraits of men whom the capture of the Chicago Convention by the Populists and Anarchists left politically homeless. They comprise nine lifelong Democrats of eminence, and they might have comprised nine times nine without lowering the standard of eminence.
BOSTON, Sept. 9 -- The annual convention of the Massachusetts Prohibition Party was held in the Young Men's Christian Association Hall to-day, beginning shortly after 10:30 o'clock.

BABYLON, L.I., Sept. 9 -- The Suffolk County Second Assembly District Democratic Convention named Willard P. Reid, Ebenezer Bryant, and Isaac F. Terry delegates to the State Convention at Buffalo Sept. 16.

Major Anthony S. Diller of Taylor's Hotel, Jersey City, a lawyer, ex-member of Congress from Virginia, and a veteran of the Confederate Army, was in the First Precinct Police Court of Jersey City yesterday on the charge of assaulting Ernest A. Marschall, a young lawyer, who has a desk in the office of ex-Judge William P. Hoffman.
LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 9 -- Mr. Bryan today made public the following letter accepting the Democratic nomination:

NEWPORT, R.I , Sept. 9 -- Newport has been in the throes of a great storm all day and few cottagers went out of doors. The rain fell in torrents nearly all of the time, and the wind blew a gale from the northwest, devastating the foliage and lawns and leaving the ground strewn with flowers, leaves, and tree branches.

COFFEVILLE, Miss., Sept. 9. -- W.B. Johnson and John Wilbourn, two prominent farmers, fought a duel with rifles at fifty yards near here to-day which resulted in Johnson's death from four wounds.
ERIE, Penn., Sept. 9 -- A glorious day greeted the Republican League Clubs of Pennsylvania. The convention was called to order in the Park Opera House by Major Everett Warren of Scranton.

In this particuiar case the geisha is Miss Dorothy Morion, while the geisha are the young (and middie aged) ladies of the chorus.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 9 -- Ex-United States Senator Henry B. Payne, ninety years old, who had been regarded for many years as the Democratic patriarch of Ohio, died at his home at 9 o'clock this morning. He was smitten with a stroke of paralysis last Wednesday, and, except at intervals, was unconscious until his death.
The body of a man about forty years old, 5 feet 6 inches in height, and weighing about 150 pounds was taken from the North River at the foot of Charlton Street yesterday and removed to the Morgue.

PARIS, Sept. 10 -- Traffic in the streets was stopped for two hours by a severe wind and rain storm that passed over this city. this afternoon. The wind blew with hurricane force, and the downpour of rain was heavy. Much damage was done, and several persons were injured by being struck by flying debris.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- It is reported that a private dispatch arrived here to-night from Constantinople confirming the rumors recently current that the powers are seriously considering the question of deposing the Sultan.
RALEIGH, N.C., Sept. 10 -- The Populist and Republican State Committees this afternoon, aftert many hours' conference and work through sub-committees, adopted the following plan of co-operation:
In the course of an article by Mr. THOMAS H. WATSON, in this week's Independent, the following plain statement is made:

HARRISBTJRG, Penn., Sept. 10 -- The Democratic State Convention, which was reconvened to-day for the purpose of filling vacancies on the State ticket that have occurred since the Chicago Convention, through resignations or sound-money men, and also for the primary purpose of nullifying the gold platform adopted by the original State Convention, held at Allentown April 20, was characterized by great turmoil.

LONDON, Sept. 10 -- The Directors of the Bank of England have advanced the bank's rate of discount from 2 per cent, to 2 1/2 per cent. This is the first time that the bank has increased its discount rate since Feb. 22, 1894.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 10 -- The Democratic State Committee which was hurriedly called to Indianapolis to accept the resignation of Chairman Holt, whose gold leanings brought about a breach between him and Gov. Matthews that finally forced his retirement, met at the Grand Hotel at 11, o'clock this morning.

The annual championship games of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, which take place Saturday at Manhattan Field, promise to surpass any given by the union, not excepting those of 1890, at Washington, when records were the order of the day. Rarely have there been seen fields of such high class, and with one or two exceptions every event ought to be fought right up to the tape.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 10 -- The steamer City of Worcester was disabled by the breaking of her shaft west of Bartlett's Reef Light last night, while on her passage to New-York, and is to-night on her way to New-York in tow of the steamer City of Lowell.
