CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- The final test of the airship Albatross was made yesterday afternoon by William Paul, the inventor, and proved a failure. The party of experimenters had been waiting for two weeks at Dane Park, Ind., for a favorable wind with which to test the invention, and the opportunity came yesterday.

All the recent indications give promise of the election of a majority of sound-money Representatives in the Fifty-fifth Congress. The majority may not be so large as it is in the Fifty-fourth Congress, and it may be larger. If larger, the majority beyond that now held by the Republicans probably will be made up of sound-money Democrats, who will be ready to talk and vote on financial propositions along parallel lines with the sound-money Republicans.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 -- The financial statement of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company, filed by Messrs, John K. Cowen and Oscar G. Murray yesterday in the United States Circuit Court, as a part of its answer to the demand of the Johns Hopkins University and other holders of preferred stock for the payment of the usual preferred stock dividend, shows a total deficit in the financial operations of the company for the six.

When Mr. CONSTABLE took charge of the Building Department he incurred the hostility of a large number of builders by the delay in passing their plans, against which they made a public clamor. It turned out, however, that the delay was made necessary if the examination of plans was to be a real examination, as required by law, and not a sham, as it had frequently been in practice.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- The football season at Yale has been formally opened. The demand for new material from the incoming class this year is larger than ever, 1893 not excepted. Of the last year's team the following men will return to the team: Capt. Murphy, Bass, Hinkey, and Finke.
An inquiry into the collapse of the building 1,078 Madison Avenue, whereby Robert J. Crane, a bricklayer, was killed, and ten other workmen hurt, was made by the Building Department yesterday.

It was a striking table which appeared in our news columns yesterday showing the falling off in travel by the elevated roads and the increase on the surface roads during the past three years in this city.
Two more tales of the storms that have been raging at sea were brought into port yesterday, illustrated by the battered condition of the craft that brought them.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 27 -- Differences have arisen in the Populist camp which threaten to throw the greater part of the strength of that party to the McKinley Electoral ticket. The Populists already have indorsed W.F. Aldrich, the Republican Congressional nominee in the Fourth District, and the Republicans have indorsed A.T. Goodwyn, the Populist nominee in the Fifth District.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 27 -- W. Bourke Cockran, the brilliant New-York ex-Congressman, last night presented the sound-money case to Maryland Democrats at Music Hall. His remarks were listened to by an immense crowd, whose enthusiastic cheering far surpassed that which had been called forth by the Palmer-Buckner meeting in the same place Friday night.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Sept. 27 -- The main building of Mount Holyoke College and the gymnasium building adjoining were destroyed by fire this evening. The loss probably will amount to $200,000. The fire started under the gymnasium, probably in the drying room connected with the laundry, and spread rapidly to the rest of the building.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your correspondent employs this opportunity to express through your valuable paper his satisfaction and indorsement of the admirable editorial which was published in your paper of yesterday, "Is Bryan Crazy?"

There was once a builder in this town named BUDDENSIEK, whose name became a synonym for bad building. It was BUDDENSIEK'S business as well as his pleasure to evade and defeat the efforts of the Building Department and the Health Department to enforce the laws, and his practice to put up buildings which directly threatened the lives of those who inhabited them, and even of those who were engaged in constructing them.

Senator James K. Jones, Chairman of the Popocratic National Committee, reached the Fifth Avenue Hotel from Chicago just before 7 o'clock last evening. A few moments before Senator Arthur P. Gorman of Maryland arrived at the hotel, registered, and went to his room. Earlier in the day Senator Charles J. Faulkner of West Virginia also arrived at the Fifth Avenue.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 28 -- A delegation of veterans from Lisbon and other towns in Columbia County, Ohio, arrived at noon to-day, and called on Major McKinley. Congressman R.W. Taylor was the spokesman. He called attention to the fact that Columbia County in 1876 threw its vote in the Congressional Convention to McKinley, giving him the nomination, thus starting him on his upward career.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 28 -- Candidate Bryan began his day's work at Lynn, Mass., and began it early in the morning. At 5:30 o'clock he was turned out of his warm berth in the sleeping car that had brought him from Bath, Me.

Mr. William C. Whitney will be married at noon to-day to Mrs. Edith S. Randolph. The ceremony will take place in St. Sauveur's Episcopal Church, at Bar Harbor, and will be private. Less than a dozen invitations have been issued.
ALBANY, Sept. 28 -- D.M.S. Fero of Glens Fall, Chairman of the State Committee of the People's Party, has called the Populists' representatives to reconvene at Syracuse Oct. 1.

PATERSON, N.J., Sept. 28 -- Mr. Bryan spoke to-night to a crowd of 15,000 assembled about a stand that had been erected on Coates's Hill. The crowd extended into the side streets, swarmed on near-by rooftops, and even the trees and telegraph poles in the vicinity were dotted with men anxious to hear the Chicago candidate.
L.P. Labonte, Manchester, N.H.; Miss J. Linen, hosiery and underwear; Miss Longwell, trimmings and fancy goods; Mr. Guyon, domestics, linens, and cottons; B.J. Conlon, dress goods; St. Denis Hotel.

The labor unions of this State are perturbed over the decision of the Supreme Court at Buffalo holding unconstitutional the law of 1894 which prohibits the employment upon public works of any but citizens of the United States, and are anxious to secure another adjudication of the question, the time having gone by for an appeal in this case before they were aware of its full significance.

BAYSIDE, L.I., Sept. 28 -- Mrs. E. August Neresheimer, the wife of a diamond dealer of 20 Maiden Lane, New-York, was noticed by a neighbor, early one morning, walking barefooted in the fields. She lives in a beautiful house, is young, attractive, and popular.

Candidate BRYAN spoke in Worcester, Mass., last Friday. It was reported at the time that his admirers were very indignant because immediately opposite to the stand from which BRYAN spoke the knitting goods manufactory of W.H. BURNS Co. displayed a United States flag bearing a portrait of McKINLEY and a blood-red flag supporting a portrait of BRYAN.

One of the interesting features of the present political situation in Europe is the appearance of Montenegro as an appreciable element. It is a long time since the sturdy men of the Black Mountain have come into public notice. The past twenty years since their plucky fight with Turkey have, however, been employed very industriously and very effectively in internal improvements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Although this town is outside the centre of political activity there can be no doubt that the exact situation is better understood here than elsewhere. The reason for this is plain. Washington is the Mecca of all politicians. They go to New-York or to Chicago to take their orders or to consult with the leaders of the different parties.

The sixty-fifth exhibition, or fair, of the American Institute was opened last night in Madison Square Garden. Although some of the arrangements were not completed, the display was of uncommon interest. One hundred firms and individuals had space for exhibits. Many others have made application for privileges.

It is not at all wonderful that the Czar's visit to England should be "viewed with apprehension and alarm" in France. In the first place, an agreement between England and Russia upon the points in dispute between them would make it a matter of indifference to both powers whether France concurred in the settlement.

The forcible speech on Armenian atrocities and the necessity of English intervention, made by Mr. Gladstone at Liverpool Sept. 24, has been cabled to The Independent, and will be published in full in the issue of Oct. 1.

The third panel of the Sheriff's Jury, which goes out of office Oct. 1, met in the County Court House yesterday. The meeting was the one at which Peter F. Meyer, the foreman of panel, was to make his farewell address and, incidentally, a few interesting remarks about Sheriff Tamsen. Mr. Meyer made his address, but Sheriff Tamsen was not present.
The Hilton, Hughes Co. store, which has been in the hands of an assignee since Aug. 26, has been sold to the firm of John Wanamaker Co. of Philadelphia.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Sept. 28 -- Candidate Bryan spoke to a crowd of 3,000 persons at noon. He talked for an hour. He began with a tribute to the late Lyman Trumbull, who was born in New-London, and under whom the Popocratic candidate studied law. Mr. Bryan devoted himself to a discussion of the money standard.

From The Philadelphia Record. An eminent alienist writes to THE NEW-YORK TIMES confirming the frequently expressed opinion of others who have read and heard Mr. Bryan's speeches that he is not of sound mind. The proposition is startling, but the rambling, illogical, and contradictory speeches which Mr. Bryan is making and which grow more wildly erroneous as his campaign proceeds, furnish the strongest proof of mental disorder.
The Democratic State Committee met last night at the Hotel Bartholdi and nominated Wilbur F. Porter for Governor and Frederick C. Schraub for lieutenant Governor.

An eminent expert on nervous diseases, over the signature "Alienist," wrote to THE NEW-YORK TIMES calling attention to the mental condition of William J. Bryan, the Populist-Democratic candidate for the Presidency. The letter was published on Sunday. It cites incidents of Mr. Bryan's errabund tendencies and argues that his utterances prove him to be of unsound mind; it classes him as a political "mattoid."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Sept. 28 -- During the Summer months William Fink, a city missionary here, has been holding open-air services on what are known as the Chancellor Docks, at the foot of Livingston Street. As a rule, he has given away tracts, but yesterday, owing to its being the last openair meeting of the season, he changed the order of things by distributing apples among the throng.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 28 -- It was 8:15 o'clock when the train bearing Mr. Bryan and his party arrived in this city. Crowds surged about the place and cheered the candidate when he alighted, Mr. Bryan and party were driven to Caledonia Park, in the western end of the city.

The Republican candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor, Frank S. Black and Timothy L. Woodruff, were welcomed by their first New-York audience last night. They opened their campaign in this city at a mass meeting in Carnegie Hall, under the management of the New-York County Committee.

The officers of the reorganized Norfolk and Western Railroad Company will take possession of all the property belonging to the system immediately after 12 o'clock tomorrow night. Mr. Henry Fink, the new President, and. Mr. F.J. Kimball, as Chairman of the Board of Directors, will succeed themselves in official control of the Norfolk and Western lines.
William J. Bryan, the Popocratic candidate for President, was the guest of the Tammany braves at their Wigwam last night.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Assertions by Chicago papers that the Democratic National Committee is hopelessly involved in debt has brought out a vigorous denial from those in charge.
Charles Grip, who was a participant in an assault on Annie Luff at the Sunken Meadow, Randall's Island, last Thursday evening, was shot by a policeman while endeavoring to escape arrest yesterday.

-- BONNIN Pasha, the chief of the Sultan's private police, is a plump, thick-set, square-headed Frenchman, hailing from Rouffiac, in the Charente. At the age of thirty-five he left the army to become an Inspector at the Prefecture in Paris, and eight years later, in 1884, was put at the disposition of M. DE MONTEBELLO, then French Ambassador at the Sublime Porte.
HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The Democratic County Convention to-day nominated Charles Davis of Valatie for member of Assembly.

We do not suppose that any intelligent Democrat in the State Of New-York has the least doubt that the McKinley Electors and the Republican candidates for State officers will be elected by an overwhelming plurality. Therefore, no Democrat who retains a preference for his own party principles has any reason for voting either the National or State Republican ticket in this State this year.
At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday afternoon the provisional estimate for the expenses of the Building Department was read.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 29 -- Three of the five delegations scheduled to arrive here today postponed their coming, and the two remaining ones did not go to Major McKinley's house on account of the rain, but met him in the Tabernacle. A delegation of 500 Union veterans from the Ohio Soldiers and Sailors' Home at Sandusky, with a hundred citizens of that town, came at noon.
HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The Democratic County Convention to-day nominated Charles Davis of Valatie for member of Assembly.

The romantic story of the engagement of Miss Henrietta Markstein, the well-known Harlem music teacher, who resides, at 123 East One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, to M.C. McAllister of Mercersburg, Penn., lacks confirmation by the lady. As the story runs, Miss Markstein was a nurse during the war of the rebellion, and in that capacity attended to a man named McAllister in the field hospital at Gettysburg.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 29 -- John W. Foster, ex-Secretary of State, slipped quietly into Canton this morning, and had an hour's talk with Major McKinley. He said, before leaving, that Indiana would give a very substantial plurality for McKinley, and that he would get the votes of most of the gold Democrats.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 29 -- W.W. Crane, counsel for Mrs. Stella Barr Macready, today appeared before Judge Kirkpatrick in the Orphans' Court for the appointment of a commissioner to take testimony in Minneapolis, Minn., with a view to proving that Mrs. Ida Macready was not only divorced from the late James Macready, proprietor of the Hilton Hotel, but that she married again.

In another column will be found the "suggestions" with which Col. FRANCIS V. GREENE closes a singularly compact and valuable article in the latest number of Scribner's Magazine on "The Government of Greater New-York." These "suggestions" are advanced by the writer with modesty as not being "out of place for consideration in the wide discussion which will take place and which it is desirable should take place before a new charter is adopted."
Senator Raines has sent forth a statement to the residents and taxpayers of his city concerning the working of the law that bears his name. He says:
A furious wind, accompanied by heavy rain, swept this city last night, and it is likely to continue with, unabated force for some hours to-day.

AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 29 -- During the meeting addressed by Senator Teller last evening, a letter was read by Gen. E.B. Finley of Bucyrus, which had been written by Major MeKinley to E.S. Perkins of Weymouth, Medina County, in the Fall of 1890. Mr. Perkins was at that time a representative in the Ohio Legislature.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Although I have been only a short time in this State, (North Dakota,) I have been long enough to see very clearly that here, as indeed elsewhere, Bryan's much-harped-on division into the higher classes and the common people is, as all the rest of his appeals to the passions and prejudices of his audiences, an attempt to deceive.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 29 -- It was decided to-day by the free-silver Democratic State Central Committee to ask for a Division of time between Secretary John G. Carlisle and Senator J.C.S. Blackburn in the four meetings in Kentucky the Secretary of the Treasury is to address.
Col. Francis V. Greene, in Scribner's Magazine for October, concludes an article on "The Government of the Greater New-York," as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 24th inst., on the editorial page, you have an item which, implies that the twentieth century commences on the 1st of January, 1901. You say: "It is not a debatable question." It is a mathematical question, and I think your answer to it is in error.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Following is the text of the letter addressed by Mr. Howard Gould, the owner of the yacht Niagara, to the Council of the Yacht Racing Association, in regard to the action of the association's committee last Summer in making an examination of the yacht in Mr. Gould's absence and without his having been notified of the committee's intention:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The West Indian tornado, which struck Washington between 11 o'clock P.M. and midnight last night, respected neither official nor diplomatic proprieties.
CHARLESTON, West Va., Sept. 30 -- The Republican State Committee announces that ex-President Harrison will speak here Tuesday or Wednesday next.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 30 -- Thomas E. Watson will return to Kansas in about ten days and make ten speeches against the Bryan and Sewall Electoral ticket. Fusion leaders fear this will divide their forces, and have demanded that the National Democratic Committee send Bryan to follow him.

"We here, in America, are passing through a civic crisis which involves as its essential characteristic the single question whether, at this period of the world's history, any single people may hope successfully to divorce itself from all the past -- from other and older civilizations -- and be a law and a life to itself.
MILWAUKEE, Wis., Sept. 30 -- The barge Sumatra foundered off the Government pier this morning, and four of the crew were drowned. The dead are all from West Bay City, Mich. They are:

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 30 -- The football season was opened at Yale this afternoon, with Amherst as a visiting attraction. The Massachusetts team gave Yale a hard argument, allowing the blue only two touch-downs in the first and none in the second half, the final score being Yale, 12; Amherst, 0.

-- A letter from MR. GEORGE H. PUTNAM, of this city, dated June 18, was read at the banquet given by the Cobden Club of London, in celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the repeal of the corn laws, in which he spoke of the condition of tariff reform in this country after the enactment of the Wilson bill.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Before wheat trading began to-day, cablegrams from Liverpool told the Street that every reasonable offer yesterday had been accepted, and that wheat was still in firm, demand.

William Radcliff Thompson, a tall, fine- looking man was arraigned in the Central Street Police Court yesterday, charged with bigamy. Mrs. May Irving Pierson a stylishly dressed woman of thirty five years, who claims to be the fifth wife and the sixth victim of Mr. Thompson, was his accuser.

The German-American Reform union has decided by resolution not to indorse as a body any of the Presidential or Gubernatorial candidates. It also decided to have a committee of three appointed to wait on the Mayor and the Board of Education to urge an increase in the school facilities of the city.

Dr. CARLOS F. MACDONALD has resigned the office of President of the State Lunacy Commission to take charge of a private asylum at Pleasantville and is to be succeeded by Dr. PETER M. WISE, who has been Superintendent of the St. Lawrence State Hospital for the Insane ever since it was established.

DOVER, Del., Sept. 30 -- The Republican State Committee of Delaware, representing the anti-Addicks Republicans, met here today. As a result of the meeting William C Spruance and Manlove Hayes, candidates for Presidential Electors, announced late to-night through the committee their withdrawal from the field.

In discussing the suggestion recently made by The St. James's Gazette, that England and the United States, with possible aid from Italy, might safely and effectively intervene in Turkey and save the Sultan's Christian subjects from extermination and even from persecution. The London Chronicle prints the following somewhat remarkable editorial statement:
With a heavy track, a card that was commonplace in the extreme, and with but few people at the track, the racing at the Brooklyn track yesterday was far from exciting or interesting.

NEWARK, Sept. 30 -- There was a fusillade of bullets at the corner of Ferry and Bowery Streets this morning. In which the members of a band of gypsies and two police officers took part, but fortunately nobody was hurt and there were no arrests made.

There appears to be good reasons for believing that the Popocratic National Committee is not as poor as is pretended. True, Chairman Jones has authorized the statement that his committee "is broke, and that he is glad of it," but this is probably said to serve as a blind.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Sept. 30 -- The State Convention of the Republicans was held in this city this afternoon and named a complete ticket. The First Congressional District Convention this morning named T.R. Hoffmeyer of La Junta.

Julia Beringer, a widow, who lives at 150 West Thirty-sixth Street, was held in $1,000 ball yesterday afternoon in Essex Market Court on the charge of larceny on July 28 of deeds for property in Brooklyn valued at $200,000, belonging to Jacob Elias, a real estate owner, seventy-six years old, of 647 Sixth Avenue.

Senator RAINES puts forth a statement for the vindication of the liquor-tax law, so far as its effect upon this city is concerned. We do not think it is true, as he says, that it was contended that the high tax would not reduce the number of places selling liquor, while it would reduce the city's revenue from the traffic.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Sept. 30 -- The city has not recovered from the alarms of the furious storm that swept this coast last night. Accurate news has not come from the flooded sea islands yet. Eleven fatalities have been reported here, and a long list of minor accidents.

CANTON, Ohio, Sept. 30 -- Major McKinley had a call to-day from 400 citizens of Centre County, Penn. They got to Canton at 8 o'clock this morning after an all-night ride in the cars. The spokesman of the delegation told Mr. McKinley Pennsylvania would give him a majority of 300,000. In his speech to the Pennsylvanians Mr. McKinley said:
HOLLIDAYSBURG, Penn., Sept. 30 -- At the Three Mile Dam the river is choked with pumpkins and other farm products.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Representative Hainer of Nebraska was at Republican headquarters to-day.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- A poll of the employes of mills, factories, and railroad shops in Illinois, outside of Chicago, has been taken by correspondents of The Chicago Tribune, under instructions to be absolutely unbiased and thoroughly accurate.

GRAFTON, West Va., Sept. 30 -- Candidate Bryan was due here to-night at 8 o'clock, but it was 11:10 when he reached here. A broken bridge on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was the cause of the delay. Mr. Bryan began speaking this morning at Harper's Ferry. From that point he proceeded to Cumberland.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 30 -- The bridge over the Susquehanna River at Columbia, Lancaster County, which was a mile and a quarter in length, was blown into the river by the heavy windstorm this morning.

-- Balmoral, Queen VICTORIA'S palace in the Highlands, has a tower which relieves the exterior from absolute tameness, and pulls together the disjointed buildings which have been patched on from time to time, but the interior is plain to ugliness. The corridors are hung with that abomination of early Victorian days, imitation marble paper, are lighted with oil lamps, such as one sees in the engine-room of a steamship.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- At Newmarket to-day the flye-furlong race, known as the Hopeful Stakes, of 25 sovereigns each, with 200 sovereigns added, for two-year-olds, the second to receive 100 sovereigns out of the stakes, was won by Lord Durham's chestnut celt Hellebore, by Peter Flower, out of Satanella. P. Lorillard's chestnut colt Berzak, by Sensation, out of Belphoebe, was second.
FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 30 -- At the R.P. Pepper sale to-day, the famous trotting stallion Onward was sold to Peter Duryea of New-York for $7,250.

NEW-ROCHELLE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The storm did considerable damage to the pleasure craft at anchor hi Echo Bay. The fifty-five-foot sloop Nellie, owned by Harry Hathaway of Mount Vernon, broke away from her moorings, drifted on to the rocks near the bathhouse, and stove a large hole in her port side.

TROY, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- A warrant was obtained this afternoon by the Finance Committee of the Board of Supervisors of Rensselaer County for the arrest of County Treasurer George II. Morrison on the charge of felony.

CLARKSBURG, West Va., Oct. 1 -- Candidate Bryan began his speechmaking to-day at this place. He said a few words in front of the hotel where he had breakfast, and later spoke at the fair grounds. In his first talk he said:
SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 1 -- Reports from the coast are meagre. The sea islands along the coast of Georgia and South Carolina had almost a repetition of the storm of 1893.

Exports of 50,000 tons of rails this year at prices far below those current here, and 25,000 tons pig to England at $8.93 at Manchester, freight being at least $3.15, indicate unloading a surplus abroad to prevent weakening the markets here. [DUN Co.'s weekly review.]

"It is not a popular statement just now, but it is none the less true," said Mr. George M. Coffin, Acting Controller of the Currency, to a Star reporter to-day, "that the sudden addition of a large amount of money to the volume of circulation is not a good thing, and this is true whether the addition represents the best money or the worst."

It may be difficult to get much public attention for the Greater New-York charter until after the election, but when that is over, the public mind will be ready to take a keen interest in the subject, and the commission ought to be prepared then to present something definite for its consideration.

PASSAIC, N.J., Oct. 1 -- Fifty day hands and fifty night hands went on strike to-day at Gould's Continental Match Factory in connection, with the order issued some time ago compelling the employes to have their teeth filled or be discharged. The order required the teeth of all employes to be examined and passed upon by a dentist selected by the company.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 1 -- A special from Jacksonville, Fla., to The Constitution says the West Indian hurricane which entered Florida at Cedar Keys Tuesday morning and swept across the State in a northeasterly direction left death and destruction in its path.

The report on the recent epidemic of smallpox at Gloucester, just issued by the special committee appointed by the Board of Guardians during the outbreak, contains evidence of the most striking character upon every aspect of the vaccination question. The statistics alone are worth volumes of argument.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Mr. K.F. Mc- Elroy, a chemist employed in the Agricultural Department, when seen to-day concerning the reported attempted suicide in Vienna of a Mrs. Constance McElroy, who was supposed to be his wife, said that he had received an answer to his cablegram of yesterday, which stated that his wife was very low.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Oct. 1 -- Vice President Stevenson, Gov. Drake, and a number of others were injured to-day by the collapse of a stand from which they were reviewing a civic parade in honor of the semi-centennial of Iowa's Statehood. Neither Vice President Stevenson nor Gov. Drake is seriously injured.

WHEELING, West Va., Oct. 1 -- Mr. Bryan had a big meeting here to-night. Ohio joined with West Virginia in swelling his audience. From Steubenville came many excursionists, including the members of two free-silver clubs. Pittsburg, Penn., sent 1,500 persons.

Probably very few persons in last night's large audience at the Garden Theatre remembered the first performance of Rice's "Evangeline" at Niblo's more than twenty years ago, when Ione Burke and Fannie Hayward were Evangeline and Gabriel, Louis Mestayer Catharine; the veteran of "palmy days," J.W. Thoman, the Lone Fisherman, and W.H. Crane Le Blanc, with his inevitable song of "The Old Sexton" and a breakdown between the stanzas.

Joseph Ullman, the greatest bookmaker in the United States; Alexander Ullman, his brother, who is a plunger at the race tracks; Archibald C. Chandler, a sheet writer, and Frederick Fisher, his assistant, were arrested yesterday afternoon at 19 West Twenty-sixth Street in a room in which was found a great amount of evidence that convinces Anthony Comstock, the complainant, that he can easily prove a violation of the law against gambling.

Etheric lighting has long been the "philosopher's stone" of the electrician. The possibility of doing away with the inconvenience of the present electric-light system and the expensive gas tip has fascinated every electrical scientist in the world for many years.

Edward Vroom the tragedian, made a big hit last night, but it was not as an actor, but as a spell-binder. He addressed a large mass meeting under the auspices of the Republican County Committee at Urback's Hall, One Hundred and Seventieth Street and Third Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Navy Department has received the following from the Commandant of the Naval Station at Port Royal, S.C., dated Sept 30, 1896, regarding the storm:

The wedding of Miss Martha Gilbert Colt and C. Stevens Houghton took place at the First Congregational Church, Pittsfield, at 11:30 A.M. yesterday. The ceremony was followed by a wedding breakfast and reception at the home of the bride's parent, Mrs. James D. Colt, on Housatonic Street.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 1 -- Six deaths have been reported as a result of Tuesday night's hurricane in Maryland. Five of the deaths occurred in Montgomery County, and the other in Baltimore County.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- The following telegrams have passed between Mark Hanna Chairman of the Republican National Committee, and Rudolph Blanenburg, Chairman of the Business Men's Executive Committee:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- One death is charged to the tornado which swept over the city Tuesday night, and it is believed more will be added to the list when the wreckage is cleared up.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The betting in this town, which, is conservative even in sporting matters, is 2 to 1 on McKinley. Several bets with these odds have been entered at one of the leading sporting resorts. The amounts thus far wagered are not large.

Walter Harris of 329 East Fifty-seventh Street, while on his way to school on his bicycle yesterday morning, was run over by an express wagon at Lexington Avenue and Forty-fourth Street and received injuries which resulted in his death two hours later.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 1 -- It took three special trains to bring the Portage County (Ohio) delegation to Canton to-day. The delegation numbered more than 1,600 persons. There were McKinley and Hobart clubs from all the towns in the county, and three marching clubs composed entirely of women.

The author of the letter printed in last Sunday's NEW-YORK TIMES, signed "Alienist," which declared, that the mental condition of William J. Bryan was unsound, and classed the candidate as a mattold, has made answer to some of the criticisms of his position which have appeared.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- The National Convention of Democratic Clubs will meet here Saturday. W.S. MoKean opened headquarters a week ago, and has presided in dignified state in practically empty rooms ever since. To-day "Tom" Wand, a Democratic statesman of local renown and an undertaker by profession, called at the headquarters.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The wheat market, which was so strong yesterday, was stronger still to-day. December, which closed Wednesday at 63 1/8 to 68 1/4 cents, opened this morning at 68 3/4 cents and 69 cents, and in little over an hour it went as high as 70 cents, being 1 1/2 cents above the highest it sold at yesterday.

"I want you to remember that in this campaign those who advocate the free coinage of silver are the only ones who have a system of finance that they are willing to lay before the American people." -- W.J. BRYAN at Harper's Ferry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Bryan finally has turned westward, and the East will see him no more in this campaign unless he shall take it into his head to make a fresh effort to capture New-York and New-England. He has had his own way thus far, so that it is not safe to predict he will follow the plan presented by the Popocratic National Committee.

That was an interesting announcement that Dr. PARKHURST made in yesterday's TIMES, that he "expected to see Mr. BLACK, the Republican candidate for Governor, and have a talk with him some day," and that it was possible that the impressions he derived from the interview "might be conveyed to others."

Attorney General HARMON lays down sound doctrine in his letter to United States Attorney LASSITER of Virginia. Mr. LASSITER has been acting as Chairman of a campaign committee and tak- ing an active part in politics. Complaints were made, and he has resigned. In accepting his resignation, Mr. HARMON shows that it is for the good of the service.

The United States revenue officers in Brooklyn yesterday raided an illicit liquor distillery at 5 New-Lots Road, in the Twenty-sixth Ward, and arrested two men and a woman, who were found in the place. Five children were also present.
There has been trouble at the Republican National Headquarters ever since Senator Matthew Stanley Quay took charge and attempted to conduct the campaign in a practical, methodical way.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- A court proceeding at Syracuse to-morrow Will determine the validity of the security taken by brewers in the nature of powers of attorney for moneys advanced to saloon keepers by them for liquor-tax certificates.

That is a very depressing announcement which is made by Mr. HOKE SMITH'S paper in Atlanta that Mr. TOM WATSON is about to withdraw from the Populistic nomination for Vice President. One naturally suspects a report put abroad by a man who has a personal interest in desiring that it should be believed and should be true, and Mr. HOKE SMITH has such an interest in desiring that TOM should retire.

ITHACA, N.Y. Oct. 2. -- Prof. A.D. White, former President of Cornell University, in an open letter, deals with the much-discussed message of Prince Bismarck to Gov. Culberson of Texas in reference to the policy of bimetallism. The letter follows:

They assume that he is either incapable of understanding the very question which they say is the great issue of the campaign or does not care to understand it, and can be incited to political action under the influence of passion.

That was a significant dispatch from Madrid published in the newspapers of yesterday which stated that the Spanish Government was taking energetic measures to prevent the emigration of families containing young men liable to military service.

CANTON, Oct. 2 -- Among Major McKinley's callers to-day were Senator Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts. Theodore Roosevelt, President of the New-York Police Board; Congressman Dalzell of Pennsylvania, and Congressman Dingley, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. This is how they sum up the situation:

NEWARK, Oct. 2. -- A young man looked over George A. Scheller's stock of jewelry at 296 Market Street, this afternoon, bought nothing, and went out. The jeweler was alone. Two men entered in a few minutes and asked to see a clock in the display window. The jeweler, while he was in the act of getting the clock, looked over his shoulder.
PAOLA, Kan., Oct. 2. -- The ascension of George P. Anderson, an aeronaut, twentytwo years old, believed to come from Galena, Kan., was a feature of the Miami County Fair yesterday.

Dr. Charles L. Browne, formerly Commodore of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, and at present Vice Commodore of the Corinthian fleet, owner of the sloop yacht Tempus, and a well-known clubman, is in trouble with his wife. Their relations have been strained for some years, but few, even of his most intimate personal friends, knew of the serious extent of the disagreement between them.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Another word regarding the twentieth century. Of course the matter is wholly undebatable, and the explicit statement of Webster's International Dictionary, quoted by one of your correspondents, ought to be sufficient; however, as the question does actually puzzle very many, permit this addition to my recent paragraph upon the subject, still following the same line of thought.

Of course the matter is wholly undebatable, and the explicit statement of Webster's International Dictionary, quoted by one of your correspondents, ought to be sufficient; however, as the question does actually puzzle very many, permit this addition to my recent paragraph upon the subject, still following the same line of thought.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2. -- The weather forecast for October on the North Atlantic, issued by the Naval Hydrographic Office tonight, says frequent gales are likely to be encountered between the New-England coast and the British Isles, and as far south as the fortieth parallel. Cyclones or hurricanes will probably be experienced west of 60 degrees west.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: Of all the silly controversies in this age of silliness, it seems to me that the one over the beginning and ending of the century bears off the palm.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 2. -- It is probable that hundreds at lives were lost in the Florida Keys during Tuesday's storm. The town of Cedar Keys is a total wreck. But few houses were left standing, and most of the 1,500 inhabitants of the town were killed or injured.

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch received by a news agency from Berlin, saying it is stated that Germany notified Great Britain some days ago of her intention to transfer Said Khalid to German East Africa.

The coal-trade situation is absorbing the keenest interest of the dealers as well as of the producers just now. The month of September has developed about the condition that might have been expected, in View of the unsettled state of business. Slight sales have been made in some quarters not any, and no sales are heard of on the basis of the twenty-five-cent advance announced in the circular for Sept 1.

Lieut. Robert E. Peary, the arctic explorer, returning from a cruise in northern latitudes, arrived in the city yesterday. He sailed on the cruise from Sidney, Cape Breton, July 16, in the steamship Hope. The object of his voyage this time was not one of exploration, but to secure ethnological specimens of the northern Eskimos for the American Museum of Natural History in this city.

BALTIMORE Oct. 2. -- For the first time since the formation of the National Association of Democratic Clubs, Baltimore will not be represented at its convention, which will meet in St. Louis to-morrow. The absence of representation is pointed out as being striking because the National Association was organized in this city eight years ago.

HUNTINGTON, West Va., Oct. 2. -- Mr. Bryan made a speech here this afternoon to about 10,000 persons, representing the three States of Ohio, Kentucky, and West Virginia. He previously had spoken at Charleston and one or two other places on the road from Wheeling.

HAVANA, Oct. 2. -- Gen. Melguiza reports that the combined Spanish columns commanded by Cols. Hernandez, Frances, and Romero met several rebel parties under Maceo near Tombas de Torino and dis- lodged them from their positions. The rebels retired and the Spanish columns continued their march.

The Fifty-fifth Congress promises to be a constant reminder to the Democrats of this country, in a humiliating way, and to the opponents of Bryanism, to their great satisfaction, of the criminal foolishness of the policy that was adopted at Chicago in July.

That Tammany has made some sort of an alliance with the so-called organized labor vote was made clear last night, when its County Convention was held in the Wigwam and Jacob E. Bausch was nominated for Coroner, the only place on the county ticket this year.

ALBANY, Oct. 2. -- A certificate was filed with the Secretary of State to-day setting forth an agreement of consolidation between the Central Tunnel Company, the New-York and New-Jersey Tunnel Railroad Company, and the Terminal Underground Railroad Company of New-York, forming the Underground Railroad Company of the City of New-York.

In his speech at Clarksburg, West Va., on Thursday, Mr. BRYAN quoted from, two speeches of Mr. McKINLEY, one on the Allison-Bland bill of 1878 and one on the Sherman bill of 1890. Mr. BRYAN'S object was to show that his rival for the Presidency now holds a position as to silver different from that he held as late as six years ago, and opposed to it.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: Of all the silly controversies in this age of silliness, it seems to me that the one over the beginning and ending of the century bears off the palm.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 2. -- "Tom" Watson will neither affirm nor deny the report that he contemplates retiring from the Populist ticket. He said to-day that he had no comment to make on the published reports further than to state that his retirement would defeat Bryan, because the "Middle of the Road" Populists would vote for McKinley before they would for Sewall.
WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 2. -- Senator George F. Hoar arrived in this city last evening from Europe. He will take an active part in the campaign. Discussing the outlook, he said:

LONDON, Oct. 2. -- The Standard will tomorrow publish a dispatch received by a news agency from Berlin, saying it is stated that Germany notified Great Britain some days ago of her intention to transfer Said Khalid to German East Africa.
MADRID, Oct. 2. -- The Supreme Court has remitted the case of Julio Sanguily to Havana for retrial on the ground that there was a lack of proof to warrant his conviction.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. -- A story came here to-day from Jacksonville, Fla., which, if true, may still further complicate the relations between this country and Spain.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I dropped my newspaper in the parlor of my hotel yesterday evening to listen to the conversation of some ladies, carried on in such a tone that it was evident that they had no secrets to divulge.

With October comes a sharp thrill in the air which tells us to prepare for possible cold snaps. It is true we may have some warm weather outside the harvest season in November, when one expects a temporary return of Summer heat, but the system, in anticipation of cold, begins to crave the heavier dishes and a variety of rich desserts.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3. -- Never was there such a frostbitten gathering as that which assembled this morning under the name of the Second Quadrennial Convention of the National Association of Democratic Clubs.
Republican National Headquarters seemed to be infused with new life yesterday due, it is said, to the fact that Chairman Hanna had determined to carry the war into the South.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3. -- At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Democratic State Central Committee here to-day, it was decided that Chairman William J. Mills shall call the convention to order, and ex-Gov. Thomas M. Waller of New-London will be temporary Chairman. A meeting of the State Central Committee will be held in Hartford Tuesday night, Oct. 6, when final preparations for the convention will be made.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 3. -- William J. Bryan to-day gave out his letter accepting the Populist nomination. It reads as follows:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 3. -- Harvard defeated Williams on Soldiers' Field this afternoon in a football game by the score of 6 to 0. It was the first game of the season, and was attended by some 2,000 persons.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 3. -- Fifteen thousand men who came from the mills, furnaces, farms, colleges, workshops, mines, and counting rooms of New-York, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Ohio, and Indiana marched up the Market Street hill in Canton to-day to greet and to hear Major McKinley, and then marched down again with the flush of enthusiasm in their faces, and the promise of victory in their ringing cheers.

More than 1,000 men stood in William and Beaver Streets, near the Cotton Exchange Building, yesterday noon and sang "The Star-Spangled Banner" while the sound-money cotton brokers' big flag floated out upon the breezes. The occasion was one of unsual enthusiasm.

With the arrest of David J. Morse, alias David J. Wilson, in this city, the last of a gang of firebugs who have been operating in the West, principally in Detroit and Chicago, has come to grief. Morse was arrested in this city Thursday morning by Detective Sergeant Hugh Kane of Detroit, Mich., assisted by Detective Sergeant Evanhoe of this city.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 3. -- The football season opened here to-day. The Tigers defeated Rutgers by a score of 44 to 0.

Treasurer St. John of the Popocratic National Committee denied last night that Vice Presidential Candidate Arthur Sewall had contributed $20,000 to the campaign fund during his recent stay in this city. Mr. St. John said that he had received no contribution from Mr. Sewall since early in the campaign, when he received a check for a considerable amount.
CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 3. -- In speaking to the delegation of miners. Major McKinley said:

From The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times. With reference to Bryan's stock sneer at all who do anything, or propose doing anything but manual toil, a writer in THE NEW-YORK TIMES says: "Bryan himself is a college man. He does not belong to the 'tolling masses' -- his mouth may, but he does not."

A week of fine Autumn weather, varied only by a couch of the cyclone which so avaged the Southern Atlantic seaboard, has brought the Autumn, or suburban, season almost to its height, and the lovers of outdoor sports have enjoyed to the utmost since Sunday last the bright sunshine and cool airs which have enabled them to pursue golfing, bicycling, riding, driving, and walking under the best of conditions.

Georgia Cayvan will begin her engagement at Palmer's Theatre to-morrow night in a play by W.R. Walkes called "Mary Pennington, Spinster." Mary Pennington, the heroine, is a college-bred woman, who has fallen heir to a large mill property, which has been in her family for generations.
Adolph Schoensiegel is a thrifty German butcher. He has a frugal wife and a goodly family of children.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 3. -- The talent was more fortunate at the closing day of the Fall meeting of the Pimlico Driving Club. The favorites captured three of the four events contested.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- The Czar and Czarina, accompanied by the members of their suites, left Balmoral Castle at 10 o'clock this evening en route for Portsmouth, where they will go on board the Russian imperial yacht Standart to cross the Channel to Cherbourg, where, according to advices received here, great preparations have been made to receive them.
LONDON, Oct. 3. -- William Morris, the poet, died at 11 o'clock this forenoon.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. -- Merriweather H. Griffith, who was arrested in Baltimore last night for embezzling $10,000 belonging to the estate of the late Frederick A. Tilton, an old Boston merchant, who died in 1856, is a prominent member of the Somerset Club, and has moved in some of the most select social circles of this city and Nahant.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- This was Frank S. Black's day in Rochester. Besides being honored by a big parade this afternoon and a mass meeting directly afterward in the Driving Park, he was given a dinner later as the guest of George W. Aldridge at the latter's home.

Illuminated advertising is one of the many useful applications of electricity which has been recently perfected. Electrical advertising signs -- that is, on a large scale -- date back about four years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3. -- The Government is to begin dredging the Chicago River to a depth of seventeen feet Nov. 15, and Major Marshall, the engineer in charge, has sent out a warning to dock owners that many of the docks may be ruined. He says:

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 3. -- Mr. Bryan spoke here to-night to a large audience in the Auditorium. The crowd was the greater because of the National Association of Democratic Clubs, which is meeting here. Mr. Bryan's speech aroused the first enthusiasm of the meeting. The Auditorium was packed, and the police were unable to keep the crowd in order.

The Tammany leaders were busy yesterday trying to adjust the differences in various Congressional Districts, so that the siate could be made ready for to-morrow night, which is the time set for the conventions in all the districts of the city.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 3. -- A daring robbery was perpetrated this evening on Freight Train No, 79 of the West Shore Railroad, which reached this city at 7:25 o'clock, by which two drovers named Hilton of Saratoga were robbed of over $150, and their gold watches and other valuables were taken.

The multicycle handicap was a decided novelty on the programme of the Westchester Cycling League's fourth annual race meet, held yesterday afternoon at White Plains, as the closing attraction of the county fair. While not a glittering success as a contest, the multicycle race was interesting as being the first of the kind ever held in this country.

ALBANY, Oct. 3. -- The tabulation by the State Board of Health of the vital statistics of the State for July shows that the reported mortality for the month, 12,659, exceeds that of the month preceding by 3,300 and is nearly 1,000 in excess of that of the corresponding month of last year, as well as that of the past ten years.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3. -- The ticket, State and National, of the sound-money Democrats, was placed upon the Australian ballot by the Secretary of State to-day, upon a petition, signed by 15,000 voters -- nearly twice the number required by law. There will be seven tickets on the ballot, as follows: Republican, Democratic, National Democratic, Prohibition, Populist, Socialist-Labor, and Nationalist.

Charles R. Flint's steam yacht, a description of which was printed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, will be one of the attractions of next year's yachting season. The new boat, which will be 122 feet in length, will be fitted with engines capable of driving her through the water at the rate of thirty-eight miles an hour.

J.M. Barrie, the Scotch author, who has become well known through his books, "A Window in Thrums," "My Lady Nicotine," "The Little Minister," and others, arrived on the Campania from Liverpool yesterday. With Mr. Barrie was his wife. It is their first trip to this country.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- Since the Czar's accession to the throne there have been many reports of the change in his disposition, he having become grave and taciturn, as though he felt the burden of the responsibilities resting heavily upon him. Reports from Balmoral, where he and the Czarina are now visiting the Queen, confirm these statements.

"Under no circumstances will I vote for Bryan and Sewall, nor will I do anything to aid in their election. On the contrary, I propose to do all that is in my power to aid in their defeat."

Gen. Thomas L. James returned on the City of Rome last night. He has been on an extended tour through England and Scotland, with the view of getting rid of a bad attack of hay fever. When questioned he had this to say:

The annual meeting of the Brooklyn Chess Club, which it was supposed would be a stormy one, and might tend to disrupt the club, turned out to be a love feast. Some of the members became angry at the publication of an article about the club last Summer, and called for the resignation from the club of the alleged author of the article.

The alleged sandbagging of William J.A. McKim, at Fifth Avenue and Seventeenth Street, early Friday morning, has been investigated by Capt. Chapman of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station. He says that Special Policemen Welsh and Caddell have secured sufficient evidence to disprove the statement made by Mr. McKim that he was sandbagged.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3. -- At the afternoon session of the National Association of Democratic Clubs the permanent officers of the convention were selected as follows:

Mgr. Sebastiano Martinelli, Archbishop of Ephesus, recently appointed Apostolic Delegate from the Pope to the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, in succession to Cardinal Satolli, arrived in this city yesterday morning on the Cunard steamship Campania, which reached her dock at 8:40 o'clock.

Ex-Postmaster General Don M. Dickinson of Michigan is at the Hoffman House. He was asked last night by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES to give his opinion of the political situation, especially with reference to his own State. He said:

BERLIN, Oct. 3. -- The Emperor left Rominton this morning, and will join the Empress to-morrow at Hubertusstock, where he will continue his hunting. While at Rominton the Emperor shot an enormous stag, which had twenty antlers. His Majesty could not suppress his joy, and the woods re-echoed with his thrice-shouted hurrahs.

LONDON, Oct. 3. -- In spite of a more generous flow than usual of Court news from Balmoral, due, it is said, to the personal interposition of the Queen in favor of the barred-out journalists, the only matters the world cares to know about in connection with the Czar's visit are kept fairly secret.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 3. -- There are more Barons, Counts, Princes, and other titled dignitaries here now than ever before in the history of Lenox. The cottagers are doing everything to entertain these foreigners, and many young women who count their worldly possessions by millions are looking their prettiest these days, and are at dances and other entertainments where they are sure to meet these men of rank and title.

There are intimations thrown out already in regard to what Mr. PLATT proposes to do the corning Winter in the matter of charter legislation for the Greater New-York. Among other things it is said that he will not consent to a single-headed Police Department.

Mayor Patrick J. Gleason of Long Island City was in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, when the application of the New-York and Queens County Railway Company for a temporary injunction to stop police interference with the relaying of its rails in Long Island City came up before Justice Goodrich.

When Archbishop SATOLLI was appointed Papal Delegate to this country, there was raised on the part of certain papers and in certain communities a cry of warning. The delegation has been strengthened and made a permanent establishment. Its head has been elevated to the Cardinalate, and now he is succeeded by another and no one takes any other or different notice of the change than when one Ambassador replaces another at Washington.

STOCKBRIDGE, Oct. 3. -- At the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Wilson Doane and Charles Stuart Wilson, which will take place at St. Paul's Saturday Oct. 10, Miss Margaret Rood, Miss Helen Rood, Miss Armstrong, and Miss Roelker will be bridesmaids, and Miss Vipont Doane, sister of the bride, maid of honor.

Mrs. Caroline Hagan, widow of the former State Senator, Edward Hagan of the Ninth Senatorial District, in this city, was arrested at Saratoga late Friday night, on a warrant charging her with contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. -- As indicative of the intensity of the bitter feeling prevailing between the Carlisle and Blackburn forces in Kentucky, correspondence and interviews published in the local papers here possess interest.

IRVING remarked, in submitting himself to a newspaper interview lately, that he found a proof of the strong hold the stage, has in England, in the fact that the excessive publication of "chatter" about actors has not drowned public interest in the drama. Sir HENRY was scarcely ingenuous in this remark.

The Merchant Tailors' Sound Money League yesterday erected a McKinley and Hobart banner, with proper ceremonies, at their headquarters, 241 Fifth Avenue. The orators were Messrs. C.C. Shayne and Andrew Patterson. They had a large audience.

Allan L. McDermott, who was nominated for Congress by the Bryan and Sewall Democrats of the Seventh District of New-Jersey, declined to appear before the Notification Committee Thursday. When he was asked to appear before the County Committee Friday night, he failed to comply with that request also.

William S. Wright, the oldest contractor and builder in Brooklyn, was run down at the corner of Myrtle Avenue and Adelphi Street, about 6:30 P.M. yesterday, by a runaway horse attached to an express wagon. He received injuries from which he died two hours later, in the Homeopathic Hospital.

Among the wildly absurd statements in BRYAN'S Tammany Hall speech was one to the effect that stock gamblers, by sending gold out of the country, "run stocks down and reap a rich profit," and then, by bringing it back, run stocks up and reap a rich profit. "Our financial system," he said, "has been turned over to the stock gamblers."

William Zoeber, a meek-talking, mild-mannered little tailor, about fifty years old, lives on the first floor of 97 Attorney Street. Assisted by his five daughters, who range in age from fourteen to twenty-two years, he conducts his business, and the family is liked generally.

The trouble is that we have had our markets filled with foreign goods which we might have made at home, and also the great uncertainty that is felt by business men while our currency is being juggled with. What remedies do we propose? To put a new President in the White House, one sound on money and protection.

Mr. William D. Foulke of Richmond, Ind., who has been making addresses in Indiana for some time in the interest of sound money, is in this city. He came here to attend a meeting of the Executive Committee of the National Civil Service Reform Club. He was seen by a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES and asked to give his views on the outlook in Indiana.

The public has only lately become aware that thousands of children are without school accommodations. But for a long time in the crowded neighborhoods there have been hundreds of children found upon the streets at all hours of the day whose proper place was in a school of some kind.

The big Republican managers of the National campaign met yesterday and discussed questions relating to the make-up of the next United States Senate. They want to make sure that as many sound-money legislators as possible are chosen in States which have a Senator to elect this Winter.

Chairman William D. Bynum of the National Democracy's Executive Committee arrived in this city last night. He will meet members of the New-York State Committee and National Committeeman Tracey to-day for a discussion of the campaign in this State. Mr. Bynum will then begin a series of campaign speeches, leaving the executive work of the committee in the hands of Vice Chairman Hopkins of Illinois.

The funeral of John Y. Savage, Sr., who was an old and well-known politician of this city, took place at the home of his son, George W. Savage, 1,670 Second Avenue, at 2 o'clock yesterday. His death, which resulted from fracture of the skull received while alighting from a Third Avenue cable car last Thursday, was in Bellevue Hospital on Friday.

An investigation recently made by Health Commissioner KERR of Chicago adds another milk epidemic of typhoid fever to the long list of those heretofore reported. The typhoid death rate in Chicago has been very high during the past year, owing to the notorious pollution of the water drawn from the adjoining lake.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 4. -- This week in Canton will be one of the most interesting of the whole campaign. It will begin Monday with the call of a large delegation of farmers from Northern Missouri. Many of the Missouri farmers will travel 800 miles to reach Canton. An excursion of Republicans from Central New-York will occupy a conspicuous place among visiting delegations Tuesday.

Columbia College begins this morning her one hundred and forty-second year. This will be a memorable one, for it is planned to open the new buildings on Riverside Heights in the Fall of 1897. It is also expected that during the year exercises will be held as a sort of farewell to the old college grounds, occupied by Columbia since 1857.
BUDA-PESTH, Oct. 4. -- The Hungarian Millennium Chess Congress opened this afternoon with an address of welcome from the President of the congress.

The committee of women of the Medico-Legal Society, Psychological Section, consisting of such well-known women as Caroline J. Taylor, M. Louise Thomas, C. Van D. Chenoweth, Rosalia Dailey. Countess Bettini di Moise. Sophia McClelland, Sara W. M. Lee, Ida Trafford Bell, Rosalie Loew, Laura A.C. Miller, the Rev. Phoebe A. Hanaford, and Florence Dangerfield Potter, has recently made a report to the officers of the Psychological Section.

PORTSMOUTH, Oct. 4. -- The special train from Ballater, Scotland, bearing the Czar and Czarina and the members of their suites, arrived here at 5:30 o'clock this afternoon. Their Majesties appeared none the worse for their long journey from the Highlands, where they had been the guests of the Queen at Balmoral.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4. -- Hides have advanced from 20 to 47 1/2 per cent, within a month. Leather is slowly but surely following in the same direction, and the wearer of boots and shoes will undoubtedly have to pay a dollar or two a pair more next Summer in order to be sure that he is wearing the quality to which he has been accustomed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- Bishop John J. Keane, Rector of the Catholic University of America, in this city, has resigned, at the request of Pope Leo XIII. The news, which became public here to-day in an unauthorized and somewhat inaccurate form, was entirely unexpected, and caused much comment in Catholic circles.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Controller of the Currency Eckels to-day issued the following statement, exhibiting the summary of an investigation made by him of the amount of money held by the banks of the country, and the kinds thereof:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4. -- In relinquishing the office of Apostolic Delegate to the United States, Cardinal Satolli to-day addressed the following letter to Cardinal Rampolla, Secretary:

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 4. -- The arrangements for the meeting and the entertainment of ex-President Harrison, who is to speak here Monday night, are causing some stir among the colored politicians. That race furnishes 80 per cent, of the Republican vote in this State. In selecting the Committee of Arrangements and those who are to occupy places on the stand, the negroes have been ignored.

Indications appear of an approaching factional fight over the affairs of the Third Avenue surface railway. Stockholders are being urged to give proxies on their shares, to be voted in a contest against the administration of Millionaire Henry Hart. Mr. Hart is an old man as well as a rich man -- a combination ordinarily supposed to provide conservatism and hesitancy.

We well remember how this same extract was used by the Greenbackers in 1877.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5. -- The final meeting of the National Circuit bicycle races was held this afternoon at International Athletic Park under the management of the White Flier Club. The weather was cloudy, the track fast, and the attendance large.

It was a bitterly cold day at the Aqueduct track yesterday; yet a couple of thousand persons went to the track to attend the races of the Queens County Jockey Club. There were six races to bet on, but none that had any element of sport in them, the horses being such a poor lot that even Billali. Golden Badge, and Contractor were able to win.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 5. -- Entries for the Orange County Horse Show indicate an interesting exhibition. Among the prominent exhibitors are S.S. Howland of Mount Morris, who has entered several horses, including the famous Lady Bird; George B. Hulme of New-York, who will exhibit Cracksman, Greystone, Fanny Fern, and his high jumper, Senator, and Archibald Russell of Tuxedo, who has entered his ponies Nina and Pinta.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6. -- Miss Jennie Stanford Catherwood of San Francisco and Dr. Morton Grinnell of New-York were married at 10:30 o'clock this morning at the Presidio. The bride is a granddaughter of the late Judge Hastings of California and a daughter of Mrs. Clara L. Catherwood, who herself was married here a year ago to Major John A. Darling of the Fifth United States Artillery.
No doubt the existing Anti-Trust law can be enforced by a President and vigorous Attorney General in sympathy with it. [Telegram from Senator JOHN SHERMAN to The World.]

BALTIMORE, Oct. 5. -- The chances for the Temple Cup resting in Baltimore this Winter are very bright. To-day the third game of the series with the Cleveland team, and the last one to be played in Baltimore, went to the home team by the score of 6 to 2. The champions need but one more game to capture the elusive flagon.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 5. -- Mr. Bryan, in his speech here to-day, seemed to indicate that he really expects to be elected and that he hopes to be able to carry out his free-coinage theories. He made an urgent plea for the election of a silver House of Representatives.

At the meeting of the Commercial Travelers' Sound Money League, Prince and Broadway, yesterday, there was a big gathering to hear Congressman W.D. Bynum of Indiana, the Chairman of the National Committee of the National Democratic Party.

Justice Charles F. Brown of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the Second Judicial Department, whose term is almost expired, and who was nominated to succeed himself by the Judicial conventions of both the regular and reform Democrats in Brooklyn, was in Europe when the nominations were made, and his wishes were not consulted.

Columbia College opened her one hundred and forty-second academic year yesterday morning with no other formalities than an address of welcome by President Seth Low at the conclusion of the chapel service. This year will be the last spent on the Madison Avenue site, for it is planned to have a sufficient number of the buildings ready on Morningside Heights next Fall to enable the college authorities to begin to hold recitations.

-- Two things will tend to decrease the vote cast at the State election in Florida to-day, these being the required prepayment of a poll tax and an educational qualification, now for the first time demanded of voters. The Jacksonville Times-Union believes that these will cut off four-fifths of the negro vote.

We are not prepared to assent to the rather fanciful notion of Col. W.L. TRENHOLM that the South favors free silver because of a sense of gratitude to the free-silver Republicans. The voters in the South who want free-silver coinage know nothing about Mr. RANDALL'S alliance with the Western silverites to seat Democratic Congressmen, and not one in ten has any knowledge of a similar combination under the Harrison Administration to defeat the Force bill.

Tammany nominated its candidates in all of the Congressional districts that are wholly within the city last night. In the Seventh District, part of which is in Richmond County. J.H.G. Vehslage was named on Saturday, and in the Sixteenth, part of which is in Westchester, E.B. Travis was named on the same day. The following owere nominated last night:

When Georgia Cay van appeared on the tage at Palmer's Theatre last evening she wore a close-fitting gown of tan-colored watered bengaline, and she entered a room in old English homestead which had been redecorated in the Empire style, but from which the old-fashioned blue-tiled mantelpiece and fire place had not been removed.

PORTSMOUTH, Oct. 5. -- High winds prevailed throughout the night, kicking up a rough sea in the channel, and rendering things altogether disagreeable, but this morning the wind subsided, and the air was cold and the sky clearing. Gradually the clouds rolled away, and the sun contributed its share toward making it a brilliant morning.
