There are a few Democrats of prominence in this country who have openly avowed their purpose of supporting the ticket nominated at Chicago, although they do not accept the platform there adopted and believe that the free and unlimited coinage of silver at the old ratio which that platform demands would be disastrous.

LONDON, Oct. 5. -- Sir William Vernon-Harcourt, the leader of the Opposition in the House of Commons, to-night attended an anti-Sultan meeting at Ebb Vale, Monmouthshire. A resolution was submitted and adopted calling upon the Government to do everything possible to protect the Armenians.

The single taxers are divided into two camps, and the sound-money faction repudiates the position taken by those who have indorsed Bryan. They propose to issue a declaration setting forth their own views, and have it signed as numerously as possible by their friends throughout the country.

As a pageant, the turning over of the Czar and the Czarina to their new national host seems to have been spoiled by the weather. An escorting squadron of thirty-odd British men-of-war speeding the parting guest while an escorting squadron of twenty-odd French men-ofwar welcomed the coming guest ought to have been an impressive and memorable spectacle.

There was no performance at the Broadway Theatre last night. After an uneventful run of five and one-half weeks, "The Caliph" was suddenly withdrawn, much to the surprise of Manager A.A. McCormick, who was not notified of the withdrawal of the piece until shortly before 7 o'clock.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5. -- George F. Parker, United States Consul at Birmingham, has written a sharp letter in reply to one of Treasurer Campau's begging circulars. In the course of his letter, Mr. Parker says:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5. -- The cricketers of Philadelphia won a great and merited victory over the Australians by defeating them this afternoon in an innings and 60 runs in the concluding day's play of the third and last match of the series.

BUDA-PESTH, Oct. 5. -- Play at the hail of the International Chess Congress was delayed nearly an hour this morning to enable a second drawing of numbers and a new pairing, made necessary by the entirely unexpected withdrawal of Alapin, who yesterday afternoon accepted the drawing and all the rules of the tournament.

PARIS, Oct. 5. -- The boulevards this evening presented a remarkable sight. It had been stormy early in the day, and this caused the greatest discomfort to the thousands of visitors, who had been unable to secure lodgings in the city or vicinity. The museums and other places were thronged with people, who went to them not to see what was to be seen, but to escape from the falling rain.

CHERBOURG, Oct. 5. -- The Czar and Czarina arrived here from Portsmouth. England, at 2 o'clock this afternoon, and received an ovation from the immense crowds that had assembled near the Basin du Commerce, the Avant Port, and the quays in that vicinity.

On the Thirty-fourth Street branch of the Manhattan Railway system the motor, designed by the Electric Storage Battery Company, which has had numerous private tests on the elevated lines within the last few months, had a practical trial yesterday.

Charles Dewey Hilles of Lancaster, Ohio, was married about a week ago and decided, to come to this city on a honeymoon trip. He and his bride, escaped from Lancaster without the usual parting salute of old shoes and rice, but they did not know then what was in store for them when they reached Jersey City.

The twenty-third annual convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of the State of New-York was begun yesterday morning in the Emmanuel Baptist Church, Lafayette Avenue and St. James's Place, Brooklyn, Mrs. Mary Towne Burt presided. Five hundred delegates were present, representing all the counties in the State but two.
BUDA-PESTH, Oct. 6. -- The second round of the Hungarian chess tournament was played to-day, and attracted a large number of spectators, who gave close attention to the battles in progress.

No doubt Corporation Counsel SCOTT is right in his opinion that the Commissioner of Public Works has no power to restrict or regulate traffic on any public street. If he means to imply, as has been hastily inferred, that the Board of Aldermen has no authority to restrict the use of certain streets by trucks or any particular class of vehicles because these streets are public highways, the position he takes is of doubtful soundness.

CLINTON, Iowa, Oct. 6. -- W.H. Harvey, author of "Coin," at a meeting here last night, referred to Generals Sickles, Alger, Howard, and the others in the celebrated car of veterans which arrives here to-night, as "old wrecks of the rebellion who have lost all their honor and patriotism, and are tools of political Shylocks."

CHARLESTON, West Va., Oct. 6. -- Ex-President Harrison was greeted this afternoon by the largest crowd ever seen here at a political meeting. He arrived at 1:13 P.M., from Richmond, and spoke at 2 o'clock to an audience variously estimated at from 10,000 to 15,000. His appearance was greeted with tumultuous applause.

CEDAR KIYS, Fla., Oct. 6. -- The ruin and devastation caused by the recent hurricane have assumed such proportions that the citizens of Cedar Keys find themselves unable to cope with the conditions confronting them, and they are forced to ask aid from more fortunate sections to relieve some of the suffering and distress existing among them, that will certainly become greater as the scanty stores now on hand become exhausted.

Chairman Marcus A. Hanna of the Republican National Committee started for Chicago yesterday afternoon. He will remain there until the end of the campaign, and the work at the headquarters in this city will be in charge of the other members of the Executive Committee.

PARIS, Oct. 6. -- Along the boulevards and principal streets vari-colored lanterns were swung to-night in festoons upon the trees, producing a most beautiful effect amid the foliage. The Place de la Concorde was one blaze of light, and all the chief buildings from the Church of Notre Dame on the Ile de la Cite to the Palace of the Trocadero were outlined in flame.

The elaborate paper by Judge W.J. GAYNOR, which THE TIMES published yesterday, is probably the best statement of the strongest argument that can be made on the Bryan side in this canvass by any person who wishes to be reasonable. It is for the most part dignified in manner and bears all the marks of entire sincerity.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Oct. 6. -- The ladies of the United States who are credited with playing the most graceful and skillful games of golf held full sway over the picturesque links of the Morristown Golf Club to-day. It was the most interesting golfing day in the history of the club, and the spectators, as well as the players, were nerved up to the most intense excitement.

It would have been a pity if the bad weather that spoiled the naval parade in the Channel on Monday had spoiled the street parades in Paris yesterday. The French have no rivals, unless it be the South Germans, in the effectiveness of such "demonstrations" as Paris had arranged in honor of the Czar and of what the French papers, having for years called the "entente," now make bold to call the "alliance."

Whether under the election law the anti-Bryan, or sound-money, Democrats of this State are entitled to have the name "National Democratic Party" over their ticket on the official ballot depends upon the purpose of the provision of the law in that regard and the effect upon that purpose of the use of the name.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Not only because it is a matter of the greatest personal pride to me, but also because the public should know the spirit of loyalty, of fidelity, and of hopefulness that pervades the whole working force of the Department of Street Cleaning, I ask atention to the exhibition of that spirit which was the chief feature of the recent annual "outing."

No doubt Corporation Counsel SCOTT is right in his opinion that the Commissioner of Public Works has no power to restrict or regulate traffic on any public street. If he means to imply, as has been hastily inferred, that the Board of Aldermen has no authority to restrict the use of certain streets by trucks or any particular class of vehicles because these streets are public highways, the position he takes is of doubtful soundness.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- Through the filing of an inventory in the estate of Susie C. Ashley in the Probate Court a life's story which reads like a romance was disclosed.
JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., Oct. 6. -- Candidate Bryan began in this city this morning his Indiana campaign. He spoke for fifteen minutes to an audience of 2,500 persons.

An Interview with Mr. HENRY W. OLIVER of Pittsburg concerning the tariff is published by our neighbor, The Commercial Advertiser. Mr. OLIVER was a member of the Tariff Commission of 1882. He represented the Pittsburg manufacturers before the McKinley Ways and Means Committee in 1890, and reported, if our memory serves us, that in the McKinley Tariff act they obtained all that they asked for.
The old Pavonia ferry house, at the foot of Chambers Street, was partially destroyed by fire last night.

We are afraid Eastern Democrats are not fully awake to the importance of the National Democracy's campaign. They are not yet aware of the great service the nomination of PALMER and BUCKNER has done to the cause of sound money. Even row one occasionally hears the foolish question whether the third ticket will not draw more votes from McKINLEY than from BRYAN.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6. -- The bull fever in wheat raged again for about an hour today, and then gradually abated in intensity, but had oft-repeated spasms, and was far from having been entirely relieved up to the close of the session. It rose 1 cent per bushel in one jump at the opening, gained another cent, and then dropped to a point which left it still 1 1/4, cents higher than it closed yesterday.

HAVANA, Oct. 3, Via Tampa, Fla., Oct. 6. -- Stories are told here to the effect that every night, at the Police Headquarters, some prisoners are taken out and put on the books as released. These individuals are guarded by one "celador" (police delegates) and two policemen, and taken between 1 and 3 o'clock A.M. to a landing place at the entrance of the harbor, two blocks from the Police Headquarters.
CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 6. -- A delegation of enthusiastic Republicans from East Brady, in the Democratic County of Clarion, Penn., came in the rain to call on Major McKinley this morning.

NEW-ALBANY, Ind., Oct. 6. -- Mr. Bryan made a speech here this morning to about 1,000 persons. The only noteworthy incident connected with his visit here was the presentation to him of fifteen white roses representing the fifteen Electoral votes of Indiana. The donors were the "lady clerks of New-Albany Post Office."

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 6. -- Mr. Bryan was greatly pleased by his reception in this city. He arrived here about 10 o'clock from Louisville, having made ten of a dozen speeches along the way. He spoke here four times to large and enthusiastic audiences.

The Seattle (Washington) Times remarks: "The silver is going to other nations to be used in replenishing the silver coin already permitted, and would do so just the same if free coinage prevailed. The exportations of silver this year have reached $30,000,000, in spite of the efforts of the American goldbug press to dishonor it.
BATH, Me., Oct. 6. -- The following is the letter of acceptance of Arthur Sewall, Democratic nominee for Vice President of the United States:
ALBANY, Oct. 6. -- Mark Hanna, it is reported, has requested Warner Miller to withdraw his candidate for Congress in the Oneida-Herkimer District.

The letter of Commissioner WARING to THE TIMES yesterday very plainly shows two things of the highest interest. One is that a great city department run on strictly business principles can rely on loyal and efficient work from those employed such as never was and never can be got under the spoils system.

The meeting of representatives of anthracite coal-carrying roads, which was to have been held in this city yesterday, was postponed indefinitely. The purpose for which the meeting was called was to discuss the advisability of reducing the freight rates on hard coal. Philadelphia interests favored a reduction, but the New-York interests, which opposed the reduction, apparently were the strongest, consequently the meeting adjourned without taking action.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 7. -- Everett P. Wheeler of New-York City delivered an address to-day before the Convention of the American Board of Foreign Missions on "The Duty of the United States to American Citizens in Turkey." It contained many references to State papers and decisions on international law.

In terms the letters of Judge BROWN and Judge CLEMENT rebuke the Democratic Party for the mad and immoral courses it entered upon at Chicago. In spirit and implication they constitute a public censure of the Republicans of the Second Judicial District for their dull and greedy partisanship.

Weather for Thursday: FAIR, COLDER. Call money -- 5@8 per cent. Wheat, 75 1/2c; corn, 28 1/4c; cotton, 8c. Representatives of arms companies urged Gov. Morton yesterday to reject the Savage rifle for the State troops.

-- The Manchester (N.H.) Union prints a letter to a friend from the Hon. LUTHER F. McKINLEY, United States Minister to the United States of Colombia, in which he says that if the Democratic Party in New-Hampshire confirms the candidacy of Mr. BRYAN and the Chicago platform, that is not the kind of a Democratic Party he belongs to.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 7. -- The New registration throughout the city and State closed to-day. It is much more full than was expected. There are about 240,000 registered voters in the State, and this year's registration probably will come within 15,000 of that number. It was thought the Democrats would not get out their men, but in spite of the lack of money and the apathy of the managers, the Democrats are well registered.

The question what a hard-headed Maine man of business like Mr. ARTHUR SEWALL "was doing in that galley" has been an obvious question ever since he embarked in the free-silver campaign. It has since been repeated, upon every convenient occasion, by Mr. TOM WATSON of Georgia with great force and fluency.

Commissioner Slump of the Immigration Bureau sailed for Europe yesterday on the American Line steamship Paris. He is to visit Rome for the purpose of conferring with the Italian Government officials in reference to the immigration laws.

The largest catalogue of black silks ever Offered at auction in the United States was placed on sale yesterday morning at the auction rooms of Townsend Montant, 87 and 89 Leonard Street. Over seven thousand pieces were offered. More than three hundred buyers, among them many women, who represented dressmaking establishments, were present.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 7. -- Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Carnegie are passengers on the St. Louis, which left Southampton on Saturday. They are returning earlier than usual on account of prospective changes in the management of the Carnegie Steel Company.

A report was received here yesterday that a destructive fire was raging in Guayaquil, Ecuador, in which fifteen squares of the town had been destroyed, including the most important and valuable buildings.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 7. -- The first large and fashionable wedding of the Autumn here was solemnized to-night in Christ Episcopal Church, East Orange, at 7:30 o'clock, when Miss Eleanor Ailing Palmer, daughter of the late Albert Palmer and granddaughter of the late Stephen B. Ailing of Newark, and Ernest J. Morgan of London, England were married by the Rev. Mr. Crittenton, assistant rector of the church.

GALESBURG, Ills., Oct. 7. -- Knox College honored the memory of Lincoln and Dougas by the unveiling to-day of a bronze tablet, commemorating the thirty-eighth anniversary of the great Lincoln-Douglas joint debate.

The coming National Cycle Show in the Grand Central Palace was the main subject for discussion by the National Cycle Board of Trade Tuesday. The allotment of spaces was satisfactorily attended to, and a vote of thanks extended to R. Lindsay Coleman, President of the board, for his clear-sighted policy in the direction of arrangements for the exhibition.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 7. -- Major McKinley had 3,600 visitors to-day and made four speeches. His visitors included 2,500 from Geauga County, Ohio; 400 from Ashland County, 600 from Parkersburg, and other points in West Virginia, and 100 from Indiana.

PARIS, Oct. 7. -- A cold, drizzling rain fell throughout the forenoon, but, despite the discomfort of being out of doors, thousands of people assembled in the vicinity of the Russian Embassy, hoping to catch a glimpse of the imperial visitors.

We wish the Ancient and Honorable Artillery Company of Boston much joy of their brief visit to Baltimore, but we scarcely dare venture to hope that they have had it. They comprise without doubt the most dining-out part of the population of Boston. Long experience at YOUNG'S and the Boston Tavern has lubricated their tongues, cultivated their tastes, and rounded their outlines to shapes more suggestive of convivial relaxation than of military service.
Gen. Fraaz Sigel has sent out the following communication from the Union Veterans' Patriotic League headquarters, 1 East Ninth Street:

Daniel G. Griffin and Frederic W. Hinrichs, the candidates of the National Democratic Party for Governor and Lieutenant Governor, were formally notified of their nomination last night. They accepted the honor in speeches which declared their allegiance to the old-time principles of Democracy, and were filled with arguments in opposition to the doctrines laid down in the Chicago platform, and indorsed by Mr. Bryan.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- H.E. Wagoner, President of the Monarch Rubber Company, St. Louis, writes to Chairman Babcock:
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- H.E. Wagoner, President of the Monarch Rubber Company, St. Louis, writes to Chairman Babcock:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- The suit for divorce brought by Mrs. Louis J. Knoop against her husband was calfed this afternoon before Judge Dykman in the Westchester County Court. Mrs. Knoop in her suit named Sarah Noddle as co-respondent. Her husband has instituted a counter suit, in which he names Leo Diedrichstein as co-respondent.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 7. -- It is expected that the convention of the State League of Republican Clubs, which will meet here tomorrow, will conclude its labors in one session. The election of officers may cause some strife. Much interest is manifested in the outcome of the canvass for President. Mayor Green has held this office for four successive years, and says, that he will not accept a renomination.

There was an uncommonly animated scene in the receiving portion of the Grand Central Station yesterday morning, when the last of the eight trains? bearing the Rome, Watertown, and Ogdensburg Railroad excursionists unloaded its joyous freight. Several hundred families from the interior of the State came to town for their annual outing.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The fire which occurred in the office of the Corporation Counsel of the City of New-York last evening, destroying some valuable papers therein, prompts me to call your attention to the want of security of the papers and valuable documents in the Register's office in the City and County of New-York.
Among the passengers on the train which left the Erie Station, in Jersey City, at 7:45 Tuesday evening, was a man named Julius Collis of Youngstown, Ohio. He occupied a berth in a sleeping car.

-- Senator ARTHUR PUE GORMAN of Maryland delivered his first speech of the campaign in Laurel, that State, on Tuesday evening, before his neighbors and friends. They cheered for "the man who defeated the Force bill," and he said that he was glad to be numbered as one of the people, and that he was "with his party."

The debate arranged by the Committee on Political Education of the New-York Retail Grocers' Union on the political issues the campaign was held last night at the union's bail, in East Fifty-seventh Street. about 150 members and their friends were present. The committee consisted of Lawrence J. Callinan, Chairman; George H. Tiemeyer, Henry Stureke, H.F. Neumann, H. Mudeudorf, Hermann Rohrs, President of the union; H.F. Meyer, and F. Luddir.

The Rev. Dr. Theodore L. Cuyler of Brooklyn last evening delivered a strong address on the issues of the present campaign before the Union Republican Club of the Twentieth Ward, at 104 South Oxford Street. The clubrooms were filled. President George F. Kenneth presided, and the first speaker was George F. Elliott.

LONDON, Oct. 7. -- The Central News is authority for the statement that Lord Rosebery has written a letter to Mr. Thomas Edward Ellis, member of Parliament for Merionethshire and first whip of the Liberals, resigning the leadership of the party. The reason given for his lordship's resignation is that he disagrees with Mr. Gladstone and other leading Liberals regarding the proper policy to be adopted on the Eastern question.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7. -- It has been an open secret for some time that all is far from well in the affairs of the Illinois Steel Company. A fortnight ago the Street was startled with rumors of internal dissensions in the big corporation.

The sound-money marine parade and pyrotechnic display, for which arrangements are being made by the General Committee of the Shipping and Industrial Sound-Money Association, promise to develop into a more imposing demonstration than even its enthusiastic projectors dreamed of.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- Bishop Keane, late rector of the Catholic University, will to-morrow night be the occasion for a gathering of his many admirers in Washington at the Carroll Institute, when it is expected that many warm testimonials of his worth as a priest, a man, and an educator will be heard from men of different denominations of Christians.

BOSTON, Oct. 7. -- At the Republican ratification meeting to-niglit, at which Speaker Reed, Acting Governor Wolcott, and Senator Lodge were the chief speakers, Mr. Lodge amused his audience with a little sarcasm at the expense of George Fred Williams.

The Democratic members of the Aldermanic Greater New-York Committee of this county absented themselves from the meeting of the Aldermanic Supervisory Greater New-York Committee yesterday, and the result was that John Guilfoyle of Kings County was elected Chairman of the body by a vote of 8 to 5.

The report that the Sultan has refused permission to the Government of the United States to pass the Bancroft as a guardship through the Dardanelles may be premature. But if the Sultan rests his decision on the strict construction of the treaties relating to these straits, it is sure to be against such permission.
A man with a bullet wound in his head and clothes covered with, mud walked into McFadden's durg store, at Hackensack, Tuesday evening and asked for a doctor. He then fainted and fell to the floor.
ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 7. -- Georgia goes Democratic, and the Populist candidate for Governor is defeated by a majority roughly estimated at 30,000.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8. -- The semifinals in the tennis tournament for the new intercollegiate championship were played this morning. Whitman of Harvard defeated Dodge of Yale in the first match, the scores standing 6 -- 3 and 6 -- 2. The second match was between Driscoll of Georgetown University and Ware of Harvard.

Weather for Friday: FAIR, SLIGHTLY WARMER. Call Money -- 1@7 per cent. Wheat, 76 1/2c.; corn, 28 1/2c.; cotton, 7 15-16c. John Warga of Newark, N.J., in a drunken frenzy dashed out the brains of his child.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 8. -- Three hundred members of the United Italian Republican Clubs of Pittsburg, Penn., called on Major McKinley to-day. Their spokesman was Luigi Beggino. He said to Major McKinley:

Lieut. H.D. Wise, United States Army, stationed at Governor's Island, has been experimenting for some time with kites for use by the Signal Corps of the Army. He has observed a rigid silence regarding his work, but the sight of the kites has frequently attracted the attention of boatmen, ferryboat passengers, and persons along the Battery.

The new home of the Bar Association, in Forty-fourth and Forty-third Streets, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, was thrown open to the members of the association and their friends last night. The opportunity to visit the house was taken advantage of by nearly every lawyer of prominence in this city, Brooklyn, and Jersey City.

ERIE, Penn., Oct. 8. -- There are grave apprehensions here that the steamer Sanalac of Bay City was lost in the gale which prevailed on Lake Erie Tuesday and Wednesday. The Sanalac left Buffalo with the barge Oneonta in tow Monday night for Midland, Ontario. The gale increased in energy, and the steamer and her barge, being light, were terribly tossed.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I have been reading Judge Gaynor's letter on silver, in which he says: "And it should be borne in mind that the question is one which cannot be decided by the people, or by the President they elect, but only by the Congress, enlightened, it is to be hoped, by the Nation's best thought."

During the past year American property has been destroyed in the cities of Harput and Marash, in the interior of Turkey, and in Constantinople. American citizens have been fired upon in Harput, Marash, and Erzrum, and an American citizen has been arrested, deported from his home to the coast, and, so far as the Turkish Government is concerned, exiled, without the form of trial and in defiance of the most positive pledges.

Having engaged the exclusive use of sixty halls in Chicago from the 10th inst. until the end of the campaign, ostensibly to serve the convenience of Bryanite speakers, but really, we suppose, to promote the inconvenience of their opponents, Gov. ALTGELD has promised that he will address a mass meeting in this city a week from next Saturday.

The fire at Guayaquil, Ecuador, on Tuesday and Wednesday, which almost entirely destroyed the city, is said to have beer, of incendiary origin. This is strongly favored by the fact that the fire started in the Government and municipal buildings and entirely destroyed the business portion of the city.

There was published yesterday in The World of this city a fac simile of a warrant on the Treasury of Montana, signed by the Treasurer and Auditor, which had been sent to a firm in New-York in payment of a debt of the State, and when presented in the ordinary course of business had been returned with the Treasurer's indorsement in pencil: "Cannot say when they will be paid."

HAVANA, Oct. 8. -- Gen. Bernal, whose troops were recently in battle with Maceo's forces, has arrived here. He is ill. He gives further details of the engagement at Ceja del Negro. After the rebels were dislodged from their first position, the troops encamped on their ground. Later the rebels, 2,000 strong, tried to surround the troops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Neither the Department of State nor the Navy Department could be induced to-day to make any reply to the demand made at Toledo by Everett P. Wheeler of New-York, in his speech before the American Board of Foreign Missions, that the United States Government support its demands upon the Turkish Government by "an adequqate armed force."

Lord ROSEBERY should have retired before. Indeed, there was never any reason why he should have been the leader of the Liberal Party, excepting his personal ambition. If the story that has been so often told is true, that in his boyhood he expressed his purpose of winning the Derby and becoming Prime Minister, he might with propriety have retired from politics, if not from the turf, after he had performed those feats.

The State Convention of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union continued its sessions yesterday in the Emanuel Baptist Church, in Brooklyn. It was well known that the Comstock controversy, which had precipitated a heated discussion in the sessions of the two preceding days, was not settled.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- Gen. Palmer and Gen. Buckner to-night made their first appearance before a Chicago audience since their nomination for the Presidency and Vice Presidency by the Indianapolis Convention. The meeting was held in the Auditorium. Both candidates made speeches.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 8. -- Baltimore won the Temple Cup by taking to-day's game from Cleveland. The score:

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The most unique character in Cayuga County died to-day when Anthony Shimer reluctantly paid the debt of nature. Plentifully possessed of this world's goods, he yet preferred to live the life of a man of all work.

UTICA, Oct. 8. -- Ex-Gov. Roswell P. Flower will leave Watertown for Indianapolis Monday to speak for Palmer and Buckner in Indiana and Illinois. With John R. Wilson of Indianapolis, he will speak in Anderson Oct. 14, in Marion Oct. 15, in Logansport Oct. 16, and in Fort Wayne Oct. 17.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- The Post Office authorities have issued a notice to the public that the land wires to the west of England and Ireland are prostrated by the heavy gales which have prevailed during the last twenty-four hours. Two of the crew of a Lowestoft trawler were carried overboard by the gale and drowned.
The State Committee of the National Democratic Party yesterday received reports from several parts of the State in which nominations of local tickets have been made.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: In Judge Gaynor's letter, so well answered in your editorial this morning, he assumes that gold has risen in value since 1873, an assumption entirely unwarranted by the facts. Value in commodities being the result of labor judiciously employed, labor must be the ultimate measure of true value.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 8. -- The convention of the State League of Republican Clubs met here to-day, elected a set of officers, received a letter from Mr. McKinley, and indorsed the latter's candidacy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Minister Andrade of Venezuela distinctly refuses to discuss in any manner the action of the British Gulanian Colonial Government in granting a concession along the Kaituma River to the Barima gold fields within the disputed territory, beyond expressing his surprise at the news.

ALBANY, Oct. 8. -- The hearing on the protest of Chairman Elliot Danforth, of the Democratic State Committee, against the filing with the Secretary of State of the State ticket of the National Democratic Party, thus giving it a column on the official ballot, was had before Secretary of State Palmer this afternoon.

-- The Galveston (Texas) News tells a queer little story about Gov. CULBERSON'S now famous letter to BISMARCK. It seems that last July he wrote to the Prince, asking his views on the financial question. Then he placed a two-cent stamp on the envelope and dropped it into a convenient mail box.

-- Alais, a town in the centre of the mulberry and silkworm district of France, has been commemorating by a series of fetes the services rendered by PASTEUR to sericulture. The silk industry now covers an enormous area, and its extension is owing to the studies conducted by PASTEUR at Alais in 1865 and the following years into the diseases of silkworms and the method of eliminating them.

From The London Standard. Iceland has recently been visited by a series of earthquake shocks, the most serious, with regard to the damage that has been done, that have occurred in this century. On the evening of the 26th of August the first shock occurred, and it was followed by another, somewhat less severe, the next morning.

The National Democratic candidate for Governor in this State has clearer ideas on the money question than any candidate for any important office has yet announced. He is not content with condemning free silver coinage. He probes the theory of bimetallism by international agreement and finds nothing in it that is practicable and honest.

President Roosevelt's invitation to countrymen up the State to make application for appointment on the local police force has met with a generous response. More than 3,000 letters have been received by the Police Civil Service Board asking information and requesting that application blanks be forwarded.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 8. -- The somewhat sensational divorce suit of Mrs. Josephine Knoop against tier husband, Louis J. Knoop, begun in the Supreme Court, yesterday, before Justice J.O. Dykman, ended to-day. Mrs. Knoop was given the divorce, and the jury also found there was not enough evidence to support the allegations made by Knoop in his counter suit.

We remark with surprise that a delegate to the convention in Brooklyn of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union is opposing "the insidious inroads of root beer into Christian families." We had always supposed that there was no objection to the drinking of root beer by anybody who liked it.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 8. -- As a wind-up to the convention of Republican clubs, a mass meeting was held to-night. Francis S. Black, Republican candidate for Governor, made the principal speech. Mr. Black said:

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- At Leicester to-day the mile plate of 103 sovereigns, for horses that had never won a race of a mile or upward before the time of entry, (selling races excepted,) one mile on the round course, was won by Mr. P. Lorillard's bay gelding Dolabra, by Emperor, out of Dolinka, four years old.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Oct. 8. -- Candidate Bryan spoke here this morning to a large crowd of Iowans. Prior to the speech-making there was a parade of mounted and unmounted organizations. A number of women on horseback were in the line. After peaking from the principal stand, in Crapo Park. Mr. Bryan made a number of short talks in other parts of the park.

The orders from the Navy Department to have the double-turreted monitor Puritan ready to go into commission on Nov. 1 are putting to its best energies Constructor Bowles's force of men at the New-York Navy Yard. The force includes a great variety of workers under the immediate direction of Assistant Constructor Frank W. Hibbs, who has had supervision of the work for a year past.

The returns from the State elections in Florida and Georgia this week are not sufficiently accurate and complete to make them the basis of any close calculation, but the result of those elections has no such bearing on the condition of popular sentiment in the States as that of the elections in Vermont and Maine.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8. -- John S. Johnson this afternoon lowered the world's two-mile paced record by 5 seconds at the new Garfield Park cement track, riding the distance in 3:38.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 8. -- This was the first day for registration in Canton, and among the first men in his precinct to inscribe his name on the lists was William McKinley. He was No. 38 on the roll, and registered at 9 o'clock.

Jamison -- Suydam. Miss Margaret Simeanina Suydam of Roseville, N.J., and Mr. Daniel Jamison of Philadelphia were married at 5 o'clock yesterday, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Suydam, parents of the bride, 177 Roseville Street, Roseville, by the Rev. Mr. Stephen H. Granberry of St. Barnabas's Church, assisted by the Rev. Mr. Van Horne.

LONDON, Oct. 8. -- In the political clubs it was net expected that Lord Rosebery would resign the leadership of his party at present, despite the agitation against him. The advanced Liberals desire a more progressive and aggressive policy, though a large section of the party approves Lord Rosebery's coolness in a time of feverish excitement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8. -- Carroll Institute Hall was crowded to the doors to-night with an audience that came to listen to speeches expressive of the regret of this community in the departure of Bishop John J. Keane, late Rector of the Catholic University of America. The meeting was non-sectarian.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 8. -- The Republican County Convention was held here to-day. Contesting delegates came from the towns of Harrison, Rye, and White Plains. The Rye delegates finally withdrew their contest and settled their difference among themselves. The Harrison delegation headed by George T. Burling was declared regular.

MORRISTOWN, N.j., Oct. 8. -- Stroke by stroke the hard-fought contest for the ladies' golf championship of the United States is drawing to a close. The finishing strokes will be made to-morrow, and there is now no question that the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club of Southampton, L.I., will be the possessor of the magnificent one-thousand-dollar silver trophy.

The Democratic and Republican members of the Brooklyn Board of Elections yesterday afternoon decided that candidates of the National Democratic Party are not entitled to a place on the official ballot, because the party name is an infringement on the name of the Democratic Party.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 8. -- To-day there was another and entirely unexpected development in the South Carolina dispensary situation. When it was discovered some time ago that Liquor Commissioner F.M. Mixson's sons had received commissions on the sale of liquors to the State Dispensary Mixson offered to resign, but later refused to do so, and it was ascertained that he could only be removed by impeachment, as he was elected by the Legislature.

DALLAS, Texas, Oct. 8. -- The committee appointed by the Republicans to harmonize the differences in the party caused by the "Cuney" and "Grant" factions, each nominating Electors at Large, has completed its work. P.B. Hunt of the "Grant" faction and George C. Clifford of the "Cuney" faction have been selected as Presidential Electors at Large.
President Cleveland passed through this city yesterday. He was on his way from Greenwich, Conn., to Washington, where he goes to prepare for the last Winter of his term as President.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. -- The National capital is one of the poorest points of observation of the campaign that can be used to convey to the rest of the country a correct impression of what the election is to bring forth. There are here, to be sure, the headquarters of the Republican and Bryanite Congressional Committees, employed chiefly in sending out Congressional literaure under frank.

Mr. BRYAN'S committee in Chicago has been sending out another estimate of the Electoral votes he will receive. It is a good deal lower than the last, which footed up 383. This one stops modestly at 300. It includes Illinois 24, Indiana 15, Iowa 13, Michigan 14, Minnesota 9, New-Jersey 10, Ohio 23, 108 votes altogether, every one of which to any sane observer is, to say the least, doubtful.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- Freight Traffic Managers of Western roads were in session all of yesterday considering the problem of restoration of rates to a normal basis. Not much progress was made at the last session, for the two matters under discussion present probably the knottiest questions that can arise.

DETROIT, Oct. 9. -- In reply to a letter from Chairman Daniel J. Campau, asking for aid in the Democratic campaign, Edwin F. Uhl, ex-Assistant Secretary of State of the United States, and now Ambassador to Germany, writes in refusing the request:

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The clubs here tonight were filled with members, who eagerly awaited a report of Lord Rosebery's speech at Edinburgh. The Central News was alive to the importance of the occasion, and caused a column of the speech to be put on the "tickers," concurrent with its delivery.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 9. -- An interesting delegation of 500 came from Knoxville and East Tennessee. In the party were the donors of the large hickory stump which Major McKinley received some time ago from Knox County, Tenn. The Major today made use of the stump for the first time in addressing the Tennesseeans.

"Unless all the signs by which we have undertaken to forecast events are misleading, if every Democrat who will not vote for Bryan will vote for Palmer and Buckner, Bryan will then be beaten in this State by 300,000 votes."
A project for widening East Fifty-ninth Street, from Third Avenue to Fifth Avenue, was placed, before the Board of Street Openings at its meeting, in the Mayor's Office, yesterday.

The American Line twin-screw steamship Paris, which left here at 10 o'clock Wednesday morning for Southampton, broke her starboard tube shaft at 8:40 o'clock Thursday morning, when 320 miles east of Sandy Hook.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9. -- The final instalment of the assessment on the first, second, and third preference bonds, the deferred income bonds, and the stock of the Philadelphia, and Reading Railroad was payable to-day. The underwriting syndicate has also been asked to pay in 20 per cent of its subscriptions.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The clubs here tonight were filled with members, who eagerly awaited a report of Lord Rosebery's speech at Edinburgh. The Central News was alive to the importance of the occasion, and caused a column of the speech to be put on the "tickers," concurrent with its delivery.

The Park Board seems at last to have come to terms with the contractor for the completion of the first section of the Harlem River Speedway and the remedy of the defects in the work already done, for which it seems to be conceded that the contractor was not responsible.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 9. -- More than 1,000 Southern veterans who had worn the Confederate gray and fought under Stonewall Jackson visited this place to-day and paid their respects to Major McKinley. They constituted about one-half of a party which came here in three special trains from the Valley of the Shenandoah.

Four years ago the people of this country determined to change that [tariff] policy, and they did change it. What has been the result? We have had for the greater part of that time a deficiency in the Treasury, and labor has never been so ill employed. Your spokesman tells us that in your own county thirty-one blast furnaces have been stopped.

The correspondent of The London Times at Havana has sent that journal some interesting and apparently impartial information about the condition of Cuba. It is plain that the situation of Spain is absolutely desperate and that there is no longer any hope even in the chapter of accidents.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 9. -- The Horse Show Association of Orange County has had an ideal Autumn day for the opening of its second annual horse show at the Driving Park here. People from all parts of the county, to the number at least of 3,000, were at the track, and the Tuxedo Park, contingent, resplendent in Autumnal finery, was well represented.

Yesterday was the first day for the registration in New-York, and the returns show a material increase in almost every Assembly district of the city. The total for the city, with four election districts missing, was 136,015.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9. -- The big flag floated over the White House this morning for the first time since June 30, and announced to the 20,000 Government officials and clerks hurrying to the various departments that the Chief Executive had returned from his Summer vacation at Gray Gables, on Buzzard's Bay, Massachusetts.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- The Chicago Record, an independent newspaper, is taking a ballot by postal cards, which have been sent to every voter in this city, and to the voters throughout this and other States. Judges from all parties are counting the ballots as they come in. The result in ten wards in this city to date shows that McKinley has three votes to Bryan's one.
Mr. Edmund S. Mills hag sold, for Mrs. E.M. Lockwood, to Mrs. William R. Graves of Bennington, Vt., at about $40,000, the private dwelling 250 West Seventy-third Street.

How can Brooklyn procure in the near future a supply of water which shall be both wholesome and sufficient? Recent investigations concerning the source and character of the contamination which made the city's water repulsive during the Summer have led to the preparation of a report which deals not only with the results of these inquiries, but also with the broader question as to the enlargement of the supply.

-- The following is an extract from a letter of a prominent woman residing in Virginia, in the heart of the rural districts, and shows the cause for much of the strength of free silver: "I see revolution menacing, no matter how the election goes, and I think Mr. MOODY'S suggestion of a day of fasting and prayer, that class hatreds and sectional bitterness may be calmed, is a very timely one.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I am a friend of Judge Terrell, our Minister to Turkey. I read with much interest your editorial of this morning on our rights and duties in Turkey, and the dispatch on the American Turkish policy, from Washington. I was in Constantinople in March last. I had excellent opportunities while there of looking into the Armenian question.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9. -- The twenty-fifth anniversary of the Chicago fire was celebrated to-day by a parade, in which more than 75,000 persons took part. The original idea of the celebration was entirely lost sight of and the occasion was turned to the account of sound money. Democrats and Republicans alike took part in a parade, the greatest ever seen here, with the exception of that by which the World's Fair was dedicated.

It has not yet been shown satisfactorily why the Hovas of Madagascar, who had shown themselves a warlike race, allowed the French column to march unopposed from the coast to the capital. What seemed their pusillanimity may very possibly have been the result of domestic politics and an opposition to the Queen.

LONDON, Oct. 9. -- The United States Embassy here is making every possible effort to ameliorate the position of the Americans, Walter Michael Castle and his wife, Ella Castle, who were arrested on Wednesday on the complaint of several furriers, charging them with stealing valuaole sable and chinchilla skins, and upon arraignment in the police court remanded for a week without bail.
WELLS, Minn., Oct. 9. -- John D. Sair, who, it is supposed, directed the robbing of the bank at Sherburne, this State, Wednesday afternoon, killed himself this morning while being pursued by a posse.

EDINBURGH, Oct. 9. -- Lord Rosebery, the ex-Prime Minister, to-night discussed the remedies that had been suggested for the settlement of the Turkish question. He gave reasons against nearly every one of the remedies.

The annual report of President B.A. Kimball of the Concord and Montreal Railroad for the year ended June 30 is very brief. It recites that prior to the lease of the road to the Boston and Maine Company the Directors had under consideration plans for enlarging, increasing, and improving the terminal and station facilities at Manchester.

John J. Carroll, the night receiving clerk at the Eighty-sixth Street station of the New-York Central Railroad, probably owes his life to the sagacity of his Maltese cat Jim. He lives at 135 East One Hundred and Eighth Street.

Considering the questions that have been raised as to the right of the sound-money Democrats of this State to have a party column on the official ballot under the name of "The National Democratic Party," it was proper enough for the Brooklyn Board of Elections to make a pro forma decision against them in order to bring the matter to a prompt adjudication.

A banner raising and mass meeting were held yesterday afternoon at the corner of Broome and Mercer Streets. After a McKinley and Hobart flag, bearing the inscription "A Sound Dollar and a Chance to Earn It" had been unfurled, a number of addresses were delivered from, a platform erected on the northeast corner of the crossing.

Justice Clement, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, will hand down a decision on the right of the Democratic Party Reform Organization in Brooklyn to use the name National Democratic Party on the official ballots this year, to-morrow morning. He heard arguments in the matter yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 10. -- The list of junior appointments at Yale, including the general scholarship averages of the present junior class, '98, for the first two years of their course, were announced this morning. The total number of members who secured Phi Beta Kappa stand is 53, 3 less than the number of the record-breaking class of '97.

Yesterday was the second day of registration in this city for the coming election. The work of registering was much more lively during the early hours yesterday than had been expected, and gave promise that the total would far exceed the second day's registration of preceding years, but the promise was not carried out.

A pathetic scene was witnessed in the Chancery Court at Jersey City yesterday. The characters in it were Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Stagg of Paterson and their three small children. Mr. and Mrs. Stagg separated four years ago. The children were then in the care of the latter. Some time ago she began suit for divorce on the ground of ill treatment.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 10. -- Mr. and Mrs. William C. Whitney arrived Thursday afternoon at their beautiful new country home on the top of Washington Mountain, better known, as October Mountain. They came from Bar Harbor. Mr. Whitney is in excellent health, his rheumatism having almost disappeared.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- To-night, at Fitzhugh Hall, was held a business man's political mass meeting. There were about 2,000 prominent business men and citizens present, while on the platform sat several hundred of the leading mercantile lights of the city. The meeting was under the auspices of the Young Man's Republican Down-Town Club.

Walton Storm, who was an Assistant District Attorney until the end of last month, and who has been prominent as an office holder and man about town, was a prisoner at the Tombs Police Court yesterday.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Wilson Doane and Charles Stuart Wilson, Lieutenant in the Royal Engineers of the English Army, took place at high noon to-day at St. Paul's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Arthur Lawrence, rector of the church, and the Rev. Theodore Sedgwick were the officiating clergymen.

The raising of a campaign banner by the employes of Harper Brothers' publishing house was the occasion of a notable political demonstration yesterday at the noon hour. The banner was purchased entirely with money raised by subscription among the employes, the members of the firm being entirely lost sight of in this transaction.

There is a chance at last that the marital troubles between Joseph K. Emmett and his wife may terminate in a divorce. Mr. Emmett served papers on his wife Sept. 18, and the time to answer expired Oct. 8. Mrs. Emmett, it is said, failed to make answer to the charges contained in the complaint, and judgment by default will be demanded to-morrow.

LONDON, Oct. 10. -- Earl Russell yesterday afternoon obtained a warrant for the arrest of his mother-in-law, Lady Tina Scott, upon a charge of criminal libel, and the lady was arrested last evening at a hotel in the Strand, and spent the night in a cell at the Bow Street Police Station. Lady Scott was arraigned in the Bow Street Police Court this morning.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 10. -- Thomas B. Reed addressed an audience of more than 2,000 persons in the Auditorium this evening, and as many more were turned away, the building being crowded to the doors. He was warmly received, and there was much enthusiasm.

The men of the navy who have served under Capt Belknap, now commanding the United States steamship Bancroft, which is lying at the entrance to the Dardanelles, prohibited from entering by the Sublime Porte, predict that the vessel will reach her destination and accomplish her mission if she has to pass through the fire of a score of batteries to do it.

The former pilot boat Joseph F. Loubat, which was to have sailed yesterday for Terra del Fuego, with a party of gold seekers, did not sail. She had not completed the work of taking on provisions and the mechanical appliances which are to be used in getting out the gold in that Land of Fire.
The scholars of St. Vincent de Paul's Academy, on North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, must not wear motto, buttons. Such are the orders issued by Father Ludeke, who has charge of the academy.
An encouraging letter, of interest to bicycle manufacturers and wheelmen, generally, has been written by United States Commercial Agent Henry C. Carpenter, at Furth, Bavaria. He says:

TRENTON, Oct. 10. -- Although the situation is favorable for an unprecented Republican plurality in New-Jersey, there are places in the State where the Republicans have serious troubles, and in other localities they are too sanguine about the gold Democrats voting for McKinley and Hobart Electors.

The school systems of Prussia and of New-England were the subjects of a lecture by Prof. E.J. Goodwin at the meeting of the Schoolmasters' Association of NewYork and Vicinity at Columbia College yesterday. Prof. Goodwin is Principal of the high school of Newton, Mass.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- Senator William P. Frye of Maine addressed an audience of 5,000, many of whom were women, in Caledonian Park Hall to-night. The combined Republican clubs of the city completely filled the hall, side stages, and balconies.

ALBANY, Oct. 10. -- Secretary of State Palmer to-day decided that the National Democratic Party is entitled to a column on the official ballot under the emblem of the ship, adopted by it in State Convention.
NEWPORT, Oct. 10. -- More than half of the cottages are now closed. Still it will be more than a month yet before all society is gone and the Newport season may really be said to have closed.
BUDA-PESTH, Oct. 10. -- With the fifth round to-day the first week's play in the Hungarian chess tournament was completed.

A young woman, giving her name as Minnie Clark, was engaged as a servant Wednesday morning by Mrs. Ferdinand Maeder of 1,033 Park Avenue, Hoboken. The girl gave satisfaction until 11 o'clock yesterday morning, and Mrs. Maeder was congratulating herself that she had settled the vexing question of domestics for a time.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10. -- The beautiful Autumn weather augured happiness for the high contracting parties of the wedding which took place this morning in the little country church at Jenkintown, when Miss Emily Ewing Borie became Mrs. George William Beals of Boston.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10. -- After weeks of correspondence between the "seconds" of the respective parties, which finally assumed the similitude of a Corbett-Fitzsimmons wordy war, the aid of intermediaries has been dispensed with, and Stilson Hutchins, the newspaper proprietor, and Henry E. Davis, a prominent lawyer of this city, have decided to give the Washington public the advantage of hearing a joint debate on the money question.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The football team of the Elizabeth Athletic Club met and vanquished the strong eleven of Rutgers College here to-day, by a score of 28 to 0. Theh home team played a snappy game from start to finish, their interference and tackling being excellent. Langford of the Elizabeths made a superb run of nearly the entire field and scored a touchdown.

Happy and contented, the two young polar bears brought by Lieut. Peary from the far North are living in a five by ten wooden crate at the northeast entrance of the American Museum of Natural History, in this city. That they are happy and contented is attested by their keeper, Matthew Henson, a colored man, who has made two trips to the North with Lieut. Peary and who brought the bears to this city.
ST. PAUL, Oct. 10. -- Four fairly long speeches constituted William J. Bryan's tribute to-night to the fight for free silver that is being waged in Minnesota.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The Horse Show Association of Orange County ended its second annual horse show here to-day. The attendance was nearly 5,000, and so great was the interest aroused by the exhibition classes, as well as the racing, that the association officials are now assured that the affair will be of annual occurrence.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 10. -- Delegations began to arrive in Canton at 4:30 o'clock this morning. The echoing tread of the departing Confederate veterans had hardly died away before the shouts of fresh arrivals were heard. The first comers before day-break were from Lebanon, Penn. They were followed a few hours later by large delegations from other towns in Pennsylvania, Kentucky, New-York, and Indiana.

The Evening Recorder appeared for the last time yesterday afternoon. The suspension, of the paper had been expected for some time. It was the short-lived successor of the morning Recorder, which had been in difficulties for several years, and had been losing money with a magnificent lavishness that portended early disaster.

Storm signals were flying all along the Atlantic coast yesterday, from Florida to Massachusetts. Mariners in the Southern waters had no need of the warning, for a hurricane already prevailed in that section.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Oct. 10. -- Pittsburg was invaded between 8 and 9 o'clock this morning by a regiment of Confederate veterans from the historic Shenandoah Valley. The old soldiers and citizens of Allegheny County vied in hearty welcome.

"Every one does not know that any citizen may make an arrest," said a man speaking of the work of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and the people who take active measures to prevent the abuse of horses. "The law reads," he continued, "that 'A private person may arrest another for a crime committed within his presence.'

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Your issue of Oct. 6, which contained an account of the visit and the address of Mr. W.J. Bryan, reached this city to-day. Your correspondent, in his dispatch, either through being misled or not being observant, stated that the "merchants closed their doors, and even the banks suspended for the day," or words to this effect.

Oscar Hammerstein and Albert Bial of Koster Bial's have been skirmishing against each other ever since that famous quarrel in 1894, when Mr. Hammerstein left the firm in West Thirty-fourth Street and planned to make himself a prince of entertainment in Longacre Square.
BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 10. -- The corporate membership of the American Board of Foreign Missions has been increased by the election of the following members:

BOSTON, Oct. 10. -- Harvard defeated the Newton Athletic Association this afternoon on Soldiers' Field by a score of 18 to 0. The game from the Harvard men's point of view was decidedly unsatisfactory. The visitors were palpably weak. The fumbles in off-side play were responsible for Harvard's gains, rather than strong playing on the part of the latter.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The Third Democratic Congressional District Convention to-day nominated the Rev. John A. Wells of Liberty Corner, Somerset County, for Congress. He is for silver. The convention adopted the Chicago platform.

AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The mystery of the missing convict, Lewis Sarles, who sawed out of his cell in Auburn Prison Thursday night, was cleared up late this afternoon. He was found in a cupboard in the office of Keeper Johnson.
MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The first day's registration in the six election districts having polling places in Malone village show a slight falling off from last year of about fifty.
BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The foursomes for the club cup at the links of the Essex Country Club were begun this afternoon, when the following scores were made:

FARGO; N. Dak., Oct. 10. -- Everything went awry with Bryan last night. In the first place, it was after 1 o'clock when he reached Aberdeen, S. Dak., three hours late. His expectant audience had been held for all that time by word from Mr. Bryan that he would speak when he got there, and the candidate found not one only, but three gatherings to hear him.
MALONE, N.Y., Oct. 10. -- The first day's registration in the six election districts having polling places in Malone village show a slight falling off from last year of about fifty.

The mishaps of a horsecar of the Dry Dock, East Broadway and Battery Line in Park Row early yesterday morning, comprised a series of collisions and consequent damages that kept Conductor Max Frank up very late last night making out a detailed report to the company in writing.
CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 10. -- Packers here are very angry over the order of the German Government by which American canned meats will hereafter be inspected.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 10. -- The Third Democratic Congressional District Convention to-day nominated the Rev. John A. Wells of Liberty Corner, Somerset County, for Congress. He is for silver. The convention adopted the Chicago platform.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Oct. 11. -- At the present time, were the vote taken, the Republicans would carry the State by from 5,000 to 8,000. This statement is based upon an accurate poll. The majority is likely to increase between now and November.

We have taken occasion heretofore to discuss the exceeding importance of making proper provision in the Greater New-York charter for a municipal legislative body, with adequate powers, and have considered in a general way the question of constituting it of one chamber or of two.
Fifteen hundred miles in diameter, and central off the Virginia coast, well out to sea, the predicted storm gave evidence yesterday of its increasing influence hereabout.

Mr. McKINLEY struck the note of high patriotism in his speech to the Confederate veterans on Friday. What made that reunion of former foes significant was not merely the proof it gave that the passions of the civil war are stilled. That has been abundantly shown in other ways and in past years.

We find in a Chicago newspaper an interesting interview with Mr. FRANK JAMES of Missouri, "the reformed bandit," who is connected with a theatre and a race track and is said to be "one of the most persistent silver advocates in the State." Mr. JAMES retains, it appears, his old hatred of banks and capitalists.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 11. -- The schooner Alsatian of and from Bath, lumber laden, for Boston, capsized off Baker Island this afternoon, and is a total loss. According to Capt. Oliver, the Alsatian left Bath Saturday morning with a moderate wind, but with indications of an approaching storm.

It is noticeable that in recent epidemics of Asiatic cholera the mortality percentage has been unusually large. In the year 1895 there were in Japan 53,999 cases and 38,500 deaths. A mortality of 71.30 per cent, is here disclosed. Up to Aug. 21 there had been, this year, in Egypt 18,544 cases, of which 15,393 were fatal.

The protest of Mr. HOWARD GOULD against the treatment to which he had been subjected by the British Yacht Racing Association has produced some curious revelations. When Lord DUNRAVEN brought charges of cheating against the managing owner of the Defender, which he neither could substantiate nor would retract after they had been overwhelmingly disproved, nobody accused British yachtsmen in general of being accurately represented by him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- John R. Procter of Kentucky, President of the Civil Service Commission, has been looking over The Congressional Record in order to determine the ground the Democratic Party has held in times past with reference to the gold standard. Speaking to-day of his researches, Mr. Procter said:

Senator William M. Stewart of Nevada took his farewell of the East last night after conceding this part of the country to "the enemy." The Senator held forth to a crowd in the corridor of the Hoffman nearly all of yesterday afternoon. He did not -- as strange as it may seem -- once mention the "crime of 1873."
ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 11. -- Mr. Bryan was up bright and early this morning to meet Mrs. Bryan on her arrival here from Lincoln, and at 11 o'clock they went to the Central Presbyterian Church.

The State Committee of the National Democratic Party yesterday made public a statement of the campaign plans of the organization in this State. It was in the form of an interview with John De Witt Warner, the Chairman of the Campaign Committee, who has been brought into close relations with the party workers, and in the brief time since the new party was organized has made rapid progress.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11. -- The Supreme Court of the United States will meet to-morrow and open the term for 1896-7. All of the Justices have returned to the city, and are expected to be present at the opening session, although Judge Field's health is such as to make it probable he will not be able to join his associates on the bench regulariy.

LONDON, Oct. 11. -- The Archbishop of Canterbury, Primate of AM England and Metropolitan; the Right Hon. and Most Rev. Edward White Benson, D.D., and Privy Councilor, died suddenly to-day while attending divine service in the church at Hawarden.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- A meeting of the Yacht Racing Association was held this afternoon, at which was drafted the following reply to the letter addressed to the council of the association by Mr. Howard Gould, owner of the yacht Niagara, protesting against the action of the committee of the association in boarding and examining the Niagara in May last in the absence of Mr. Gould and without giving him previous notice of their intention:

HAVANA, Oct. 12. -- Gen. Echague reports that on Oct. 8 his command had a serious encounter with the rebel forces, who held strong positions on the heights of Guayabitos. After a fight lasting three hours, the rebels were finally dislodged, despite their tenacious defense under the raking fire of the Spanish artillery and a brilliant bayonet charge by the Spaniards.

The report of the Consul General of the United States at St. Petersburg concerning the wheat output of the world this year shows what has been the cause of the recent increase of price here and abroad. His estimate is that the world's crop in 1896 falls short of the crop of 1895 by 183,000,000 bushels.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 12. -- A letter from Ambassador Bayard to a friend in this city is published here to-day, in which Mr. Bayard suggests that Democrats should refuse to support Bryan and Sewall, and says they should vote for Palmer and Buckner.

When E.R. Chapman of Moore Schley learned through Senator Brice yesterday some facts about the political situation in the Middle Western States he said he would bet $500,000, or any part of it, that the Democrats would not carry a State east of the Mississippi River or north of the Ohio.

There are very few men in this country whose public utterances command more attention or exert more influence than those of the Archbishop of St. Paul. Among prelates of his own Church his position is almost unique, being shared only by Cardinal GIBBONS. That is to say, he is recognized both within and without the communion of the Catholic Church as an American Catholic.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 12. -- Twelve employes of Crawford's department store, who were discharged last Saturday because they championed the free coinage of silver, held a meeting to-day. They decided to stand together and fight the case. Later the discharged employes went to the State Democratic Headquarters, where they related the circumstances of their dismissal from the firm's employ.
CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 12. -- Major McKinley received but two delegations to-day -- both from Pennsylvania. They came from the Monongahela Valley.

The opening of the recently completed navigable channel through the Iron Gates of the Danube is an event not merely of commercial and industrial importance, but of great political significance. It marks the close of the Hungarian millennial celebrations, which for six months have been demonstrating to the world the marvelous development of the Magyars.

The New-York Association for the Protection of Game and the marketmen who sell it are likely to come to an understanding by which the game laws will be amended and both sportsmen and dealers work in harmony.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 12. -- The bark Henry A. Litchfield, bound from Brunswick, Ga., for New-York, went ashore on Pleasure House Beach, inside the Capes, about 5 o'clock this morning. None of the crew was lost, and the cargo of lumber is safe, but it is thought the vessel cannot be floated.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12. -- Mr. Bryan made four speeches here to-night.
FREEPORT, Oct. 12. -- E.A. Dorlon's yacht Rambler was wrecked, and the Prospect Gun Club's yacht Moslem was blown ashore by the storm at this place. The tide is five feet higher than usual.

Nobody can dispute the right of THOMAS F. BAYARD of Delaware, now our Ambassador in London, to speak for the Democratic Party of this country. For a generation he has been one of the ablest, most consistent, upright, and earnest representatives of its principles. Nobody understands better the policy upon which that party was founded and for which it has stood through the vicissitudes of nearly a century of political history.

We suggested about two months ago that the workingmen of the United States should make an inquiry in Mexico, through the agency of representatives chosen by themselves, concerning the condition of labor in that country and the influence of the silver standard there upon wage earners.

In Carnegie Hall last night, Mayor Strong presided at the final meeting of the Zion Grand Centennial Jubilee, which for the past twelve days has been held in celebration of the one-hundredth anniversary of the founding of the Zion African Methodist Episcopal Church.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- Archbishop Ireland's political declaration in favor of sound money has caused more pleasure at Republican National Headquarters than any event since the Maine election. The official commentary on it was given out by Perry Heath, Chief of the Literary Bureau. Mr. Heath said:

The mystery surrounding the disappearance of Miss Grace Dickerson from her home, 1,341 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, Sept. 22, has been partially solved by the finding of her body yesterday in Wykoff Swamp, near Canarsie, L.I., by John Vaught, a bayman, and L. Remsen Schenck, a carpenter, who were hunting.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dear Sir: In an article published in The Brooklyn Citizen of Oct. 11, commenting on the flagraising at D. Appleton Co.'s factory, the following occurs: "A subscription list was sent around * * * several employes signed it, believing that was better than looking for a new position at this season of the year."

-- Stories apparently true about women who are actually fighting for Cuba continue to come from that island. A correspondent of The New-Orleans Times-Democrat says that on Oct. 3 a band of Amazonian warriors, headed by Senorita MARTINA HERNANDEZ PEREZ, attacked the village of Vueltas, in the Remedies district.
Tremendous damage was wrought all along the coast from Cape May to Boston by the northeast gaie, which continued yesterday with unabated fury.
FREEPORT, Oct. 12. -- E.A. Dorlon's yacht Rambler was wrecked, and the Prospect Gun Club's yacht Moslem was blown ashore by the storm at this place. The tide is five feet higher than usual.

LONDON, Oct. 12. -- Lady Tina Scott, the moher of Countess Russell, who was arrested on Friday and arraigned on Saturday at the instance of her son-in-law, Earl Russell, who charged her with criminal libel, was again arraigned in the Bow Street Police Court to-day. The courtroom was crowded with spectators, many of whom move in the highest circles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12. -- Chairman Washburn of the Chicago Headquarters of the Populist National Committee said to-day regarding the probable object of the National Executive Committee meeting called by Chairman Butler to-morrow in Chicago:

There is much evidence that the attitude of many thousands of Western men toward the dominant question of this campaign has teen changed in the last six weeks. We refer to those who were at one time inclined to vote for BRYAN, or had decided to do so, and who have come over to PALMER or MCKINLEY.

The wind and rain storm which has been raging off the coast for two days abated somewhat yesterday and vessels which were obliged to turn back were able to enter port. Other ships which feared to venture to sea in the face of the hurricane passed outside.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 13. -- A delegation of about 300 voters from the Lehigh Valley district of Pennsylvania arrived here this morning to pay their respects to Major McKinley. Ex-Congressman Charles N. Brumm of Pottsville, Penn., acted as spokesman for the visitors. In his remarks to the candidate he predicted that Pennsylvania would send a solid Republican delegation to the next Congress, besides giving McKinley a majority of 750,000 votes.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 13. -- John F. Barrett, Vice President of the Chicago Board of Trade, has wagered $1,500 to $750 that Gov. Altgeld would be defeated in Illinois, Col. M.C. Wetmore taking the short end. Mr. Barrett has $30,000 more to place on the Republican side of the question. Bryan money is exceedingly scarce here, his supporters doing more talking than betting.

Coincident with another increase in the price of wheat of 1 1/8 cents per bushel, commercial bar silver declined yesterday to 64 1/2 cents an ounce, the lowest figure touched in three years. With pure bar silver at 64 1/2 cents and ounce the actual value of a silver silver at 64 1/2 cents an ounce, the actual dollar is only 49.88 cents.

It is reported that a meeting will be held to-day at the residence of Archbishop Corrigan, at which Cardinal Satolli, Bishop Keane, and many other dignitaries will be present, to consider the question of dividing the Archdiocese of New-York.

Bishop Potter will consecrate the chapel of the new St. Luke's Hospital, on Morningside Heights, next Saturday morning, this being the day before St. Luke's Day. After the services attending the consecration of the chapel, the Bishop will visit each ward of the hospital separately and will dedicate each to its humane purposes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13. -- The announcement by Cardinal Gibbons that the Directors of the Catholic University at their meeting in this city on the 21st inst. will consider at length the question of a successor to Bishop Keane as rector of the Catholic University of the United States is understood to mean a contest for the position.

For some years many newspapers, serious, comic, and serio-comic, have been opposing with bitterness the feminine fashion of wearing large, umbrageous, and opaque hats in the theatre. Our esteemed contemporary The Herald has gone so far in this opposition as to abandon its usual judicial attitude in politics, and, if we understand it aright, to oppose ex-President HARRISON on account of the size of his hat.
