WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Senator Faulkner, Chairman of the Democratic Congressional Committee, said this morning:
CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Reports from New-York of a rise in the tea market are borne out in the Chicago field. When asked about the matter yesterday, A.P. Upham, tea buyer for Sprague, Warnei Co., said:

D.M. HYMAN, an owner of mines in Colorado, tells one of our contemporaries that the mine workmen in that State have contributed to the Bryan campaign fund "by allowing their employers to withhold a certain percentage from their pay rolls." That is to say, they are giving a part of their wages to support a currency policy the adoption of which would cause their wages to be reduced.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- Damp, cool all and leaden skies greeted the pilgrims who came to Canton to-day. but neither chill Autumn winds nor threatening clouds are potent enough to check the flow of incoming delegations or repress the ardor of Major McKinley's visitors. Five delegations came to-day, Kansas, Pennsylvania, and Indiana bringing Major McKinley assurances of support and promises of victory.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The treatment of Secretary Carlisle at Covington last night was the subject of earnest talk among politicians of both parties in this city this morning. Democratic leaders denounce and disavow the actions of those who assaulted the Secretary, and Republicans, while condemning the acts committed, profess the belief that the insult will help the cause of sound money in that State and elsewhere.

Unless countermanding orders are issued this morning, the Department of Street-Cleaning will suspend operations. Not a wagon or an employe will be seen on the streets. Garbage and refuse may pile mountain high, and it will not be removed. The streets may revert to their ancient condition without one protesting broom or shovel.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- Dr. Tanner, who gained notoriety some years ago by fasting for various numbers of days, was burned to death Wednesday when the Whitmore-Robinson Company's pottery was destroyed by fire. His body is still in the ruins.

BUDA-PESTH, Oct. 24 -- As the outcome of the international chess tournament here, which ended on Wednesday, was a tie at the score of 8 1/2 wins each for Tschigorin and Charousek, a match to determine which player should have first prize and which second prize of the tournament, was begun to-day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24. -- Some time ago our Consul at Geneva sent to the State Department a drawing of a bicycle invented at Geneva by Charles Challand, for exhibition at the Paris National Exposition. The saddle of this bicycle is developed into a seat, and it is dropped back almost immediately over the centre of the rear wheel, the steering bar being lengthened to enable the driver to control the wheel without bending forward.

With all of the fierceness that attended the can rush between the sophomores and the freshmen of Columbia University on Thursday last, but with additional brutality, the classes of 99 and 1000 in the Columbia School of Mines fought for the possession of a stick at Columbia Oval, William's Bridge, yesterday morning.

Gen. William McKinley Osborne got back to his office in the Republican National Committee's rooms from a trip to Canton a few days ago. Gen. Osborne talked about his visit yesterday without disclosing the urgency of the business which took him West. That the Secretary of the National Committee could be spared for a week's absence indicates that Mr. Hanna considers' the fight already won in the East and further caution needless.

ST. LOUIS. Mo., Oct. 24. -- State Chairman Roselle of the People's Party charges that four times since the nomination of the Populistic ticket he has been offered money from Republican sources to use his influence toward keeping a full third-party ticket in the field. In an interview to-day Mr, Roselle said:

A fleet that glowed under thousands of colored lights, red, white and blue, paraded the waters of this port last night, and half circled the city with its patriotic fires, as a novel demonstration in the cause of sound money.
From The San Francisco Call. Attorney George Levinsky of the Stockton legal firm of Levinsky Young was the vic 1/4 tim recently of as strange an accident as ever befell a member of the bar.

To-morrow night the old Academy of Music will be ablaze with the glory of 200 additional incandescent lamps and many new arc lights. The old grand circle, with its dark-red background, will be recalled to life as Robin Luron recalled Pompeil in the Sardou-Offenbach fantasy. The veteran of many musical campaigns, James Henry Mapleson, will be at his post again.
LOUISVILLE, Oct. 24 -- Joshua Levering, Prohibition candidate for President, returned from his Southern trip yesterday, and was accorded a hearty welcome to Louisville.

The Stevens Preparatory School of Hoboken played a tie game with the Pingry School of Elizabeth for the New-Jersey Interscholastic Football League championship at the grounds of the latter, at Elizabeth, yesterday afternoon. But one touch-down was made by either side, and neither team succeeded in kicking the goal. The final score was: Stevens, 4; Pingry, 4.

Good golf, close games, and a breeze that would have forced yachtsmen to take a double reef in their sails were the most characteristic features at the Westchester Country Club yesterday. The big three-day open golf tournament was brought to a close in an eminently fitting manner, and every visiting golfer has gone home with fond recollections of the royal manner with which the Westchester people treat their guests and manage their tournaments.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Chairman Mark Hanna has sent The Chronicle the following letter, in which he gives his views of the situation:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 24 -- The greatest speech ever delivered in this city was that of Bourke Cockran, the noted Tammany orator, here to-night to an audience composed of the choicest citizens of Central Kentucky. The Opera House was packed on every floor, and hundreds were turned away, not finding standing room.

LENOX, Mass., Oct. 24 -- Mr. and Mrs. William D. Sloane, Miss Emily Sloane, and Miss Leila Sloane, who went to Scarborough-on-the-Hudson to attend the Shepard-Fabbrl wedding, returned on Thursday and have quite a large house party. Mr. and Mrs. James Abercrombie Burden, Jr., will remain for some time longer.

The streets of New-York were not cleaned yesterday, and Commissioner Waring, in a statement issued in the afternoon, declared practically that the business of his department would not be resumed until private contractors are assured of their pay by Controller Fitch and the Colonel is relieved of responsibility for payment of money on contracts.

You say, with a sense of disappointment, "After all this is only diplomacy these are only diplomatic methods, soft methods, wheedling methods. Oh! for something manly and downright. Oh! for an hour of CROMWELL and his action." [Cheers.] I knew the name of CROMWELL would elicit a cheer.

Tammany Hall is claiming that it will elect twenty-six out of the thirty-live Assemblymen from this city, but expert politicians are claiming that if Tammany succeeds in electing from sixteen to twenty Assemblymen in a year like this it will be doing very well.
George H. Stover of 46 West Eighty-seventh. Street was yesterday arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court on a charge of having violated the hotel law.

One hundred Catholic pilgrims will sail on the North German Lloyd steamer Werra Jan. 16, 1897, for an extended tour through Palestine and the Holy Land. The party will sail direct to Gibraltar, and from there will go to Egypt, calling at Pisa, Leghorn, Naples, and other points en route to Alexandria, which will be reached on Feb. 7.
PETERSBURG, Va., Oct. 24 -- The closing days of the Virginia campaign promise to be characterized by even more bitterness than the memorable one of 1883, which witnessed the downfall of Mahone.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24. -- August Schrader, known to fame as the "Divine Healer," arrived in this city from the West last evening, charged with the special mission of curing the bodily afflicted. His coming was unheralded, and very few besides his landlady were aware of his presence here.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: You will remember that about three weeks ago I sent you a letter calling attention to certain significant things in the action and speech of Mr. Bryan. It seemed at that time, looking at the matter in a broad, unblased, and objective way, that striking evidences of defective mental balance were being exhibited.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- The "Faneuil Hall" Democracy, the Boston contingent that has long and bitterly fought the attempted dictation of the newly arisen boss, George Fred Williams, hoisted the white flag to-day, and will negotiate for peace. After a session of two hours the Democratic State Executive Committee, hitherto anti-Williams, named a committee of four to patch up a truce.

Controller FITCH has issued a statement regarding the sale of city bonds for which bids are now invited by advertisement, a significant part of which is an explanation of the security which the city offers to its creditors. This issue of bonds will be the largest in the history of the city, amounting to $16,046,590.70, of which $7,000,000 are to be used for the redemption of 7 per cent, bonds maturing Dec. 1.

From The London Truth. The President stood between Nicholas and Alexandra as they descended from the palace on wheels at Passy Railway to drive through Paris. The excellent President is pompous, portly, scrupulously attentive to externals, self-satisfied, likes to be thought a Lord Bountiful, and has lots of "side."
PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 24. -- Carl Schurz this evening, when asked about the Bismarck letter to Gov. Culbertson of Texas, which has been represented as favoring the Bryan cause, said:

From The London Standard. Winchilsea House, Longacre, was inaugurated yesterday afternoon at the Central Depot of the British Produce Supply Association, by a luncheon given by the Earl of Winchilsea rind Nottingham and the Directors of the association. The object of the association is to supply London, through the Central Depot, with all kinds of farm produce as direct as possible from the producer.

LONDON Oct. 24 -- Last Winter, when everybody in England surrendered himself to blind rage against the German Emperor, and the memorable step of mobilizing a special service squadron was taken, the people who feel a special interest in strengthening the British Navy took advantage of the popular feeling to arrange that hereafter Trafalgar Day should be celebrated as a national patriotic anniversary.

From The London Chronicle. From private information we learn some interesting details about the bombardment of Zanzibar. The steamer Glasgow, which defied the British arms, was manned by natives who were evidently unacquainted with the gunnery of a British warship. They opened fire with the saluting guns, with which the Glasgow was in the habit of hailing the coming or speeding the parting guest.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- In to-day's football game with Cornell, Harvard came off victorious by the score of 13 to 4. The game was very closely contested, and Harvard had to put her best foot forward to win. A lucky goal from the field in the first half dampened the ardor of the Cornali team, but they played a plucky up-hill game.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Sir: Not since the great coalition of William of Orange to suppress the aggressions of Louis XIV. -- not since that of Austria, Russia, France, Saxony, Sweden, and the Electorates to crush Frederick of Prussia -- have the European States been confronted by so unsolvable a problem as that of the Turkish Sultan at Constantinople.
Edwin Willits. Edwin Willits, formerly Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, whose sudden death has been announced, was born in 1832, and his early years were spent in Michigan upon a farm.

These are busy days for Timothy J. Campbell, who, having represented the Ninth Congressional District once on a Republican and once on a Democratic platform, is running for the third time as the candidate of a combination party made up of Republicans, Independent Democrats, National Democrats, and members of the German Reform Union, on a platform of honest money.

QUINCY, Ill., Oct. 24 -- This was a lazy, meandering day of campaigning for William J. Bryan. It is true that he traveled 300 miles through his native State, and spoke more than a dozen times, but his activity did not compare with his recent work.

The resignation of Col. Dowd of the Twelfth Regiment has been forwarded, and is now in the Adjutant General's office. It is likely that Adjt. Gen. McAlpin, appreciating the services of Col. Dowd, will place him on the supernumerary list, thus retaining a valuable officer, that can be called upon in an emergency, and one that can be relied upon.

Sir Walter's victory in the race for the Municipal Handicap, at a mile and three-quarters, was the crowning feature of a very fair day's sport at the Morris Park track yesterday afternoon. The track was heavy with mud that was sticky and holding. There was a decided touch of wintry weather, too, that made the wearers of heavy wraps satisfied with themselves for having provided for that sort of thing.

From The New-York World. The Sunday World's exposure of the plot to nullify the provision of the new Constitution requiring that the Adirondack preserve owned by the State "shall be forever kept as wild forest laud "met with instant and favorable response throughout the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- In the presence of 13,000 people Lafayette lowered the pride of Pennsylvania this afternoon by thrashing the Quakers at football by the score of 6 to 4. The defeat came with crushing humility to Pennsylvania from its total unexpectedness, and that, too, at the hands of a college that is not considered in the same class athletically as the big Philadelphia University.

HAVANA, Oct. 24 -- The Government has suppressed The Discusion, an independent daily newspaper of this city, because of its publication of a leading article commenting on an editorial which appeared in The New-York Herald on Saturday last, advocating that the United States and Mexico should act in concert to bring about a peaceful settlement of the Cuban trouble.

Byron Douglass, an actor, thirty years old, was arrested yesterday while rehearsing the leading role in Wilton Lackaye's new play, "Dr. Belgraf," which is to be produced in Chicago on Monday night. The complainant was the actor's wife, Mrs. Marie Douglass, who got a warrant upon allegations of abandonment and non-support for four years.

Yale's football players walked off Manhattan Field yesterday with the scalps of the Carlisle Indians dangling from their belts, hey won the football game, according to the official score, but there was very little glory in the victory for the Yale boys, and if W.O. Hickok, the referee, had not made a wrong decision, the score would have been a tie.

We reprint elsewhere an article from The Evening Post of this city discussing the "duty of a newspaper at a crisis like this to print freely the views of both sides." The Post holds that this is not a duty, and that the practice may be carried to a point where it becomes "irrational and immoral."

TRENTON, Oct. 24. -- The agitation for the ringing of the curfew at night to clear the streets of children has extended all over the State. The question is being considered by the people of twenty towns. The agitation began in the Mercer County branch of the State Charity Aid, and now it has extended to the Women's Christian Temperance Union and the New-Jersey Home Societies, which have branches all over the State.

NEWPORT, Oct. 24 -- The Clambake Club talks of changing its quarters, and at its next annual meeting in New-York in January, the matter will be considered. The club has now 100 members, and there are many applicants. The present clubhouse on Easton's Point, while it is most charmingly located, with a fine sea view from its piazzas, is very far from what it should be, architecturally.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Fine weather, a veritable foretaste of Indian Summer, has prevailed this week, and guests and cottagers have made the most of it.

The football teams of the four big coleges -- Yale, Princeton, Harvard, and Pennsylvania -- are rapidly getting into shape for the games that will be played next month. Princeton and Harvard will meet at Cambridge on Nov. 7. Harvard and Pennsylvania will play at Philadelphia, and Yale and Princeton at Manhattan Field on Saturday, Nov. 21.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an interview had with me by your reporter in relation to the New-York and Northern litigation, he makes me use in your to-day's issue the following words: "It is clear that there was fraud and collusion in this case, and it was through the action of the New-York Central that prevented the New-York and Northern from obtaining business, and forced the default."
Of the present Senate, fifty-nine members will hold over after March 4, 1897. Twenty-nine of these favor free coinage and thirty are opposed to it.

Daniel P. Reynolds, a printer and inventor, who lives with Patrick Doherty, a brother of ex-Police Captain Michael Doherty of this city, at 253 Washington Street, Brooklyn, while drunk last evening ran amuck in the barroom of the Hotel Brooklyn, corner of Washington and Concord Streets, and shot two men and then himself.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 25. -- Little was done to-day toward clearing up the mystery that surrounds the tragic death here last Wednesday of Hamlin Andrus, Secretary of the Chemical Works. The boy Louis McLeod was taken to the works by Coroner Miles, and together they took a walk through the cellar of the factory.

From The London Times. The largest quantity of champagne ever put up to auction without reserve was sold at the London Commercial Salesrooms on Wednesday afternoon by Messrs. Molly, Kelly, Graham Co. The sale was on account of an eminent firm of New-York bankers, which had ordered the wine to toe reshipped from New-York, where it was imported in the early part of 1894.

The Consul of the United States at Ghent, Mr. MORRIS, has some curious ideas about the effect of the proposed free coinage of silver. He remarks, in a report of which we published a part yesterday, that many of the working men in Belgium are idle and that "free silver would bring them hurrying to America."

TOKIO, Oct. 10. -- The publication of the new Japanese civil code renders it clear that the complaints made by Europeans and Americans about the tenure of land under the revised treaties are business. Although the privilege of owning land is withheld, foreigners will be able to secure land for and number of years in the capacity of superficiaries.

The striking statement by Rear Admiral ROE which we published yesterday morning presents a solution of the Turkish problem that has long been hinted at in the press of the Continent and openly discussed by a portion of the English press. But no such complete and convincing account has appeared of the military elements involved in that problem.
AMERICUS, Ga., Oct. 25. -- The remains of ex-Speaker Charles F. Crisp were interred in Oak Grove Cemetery, in Americus, at twilight to-night.

LONDON, Oct. 25. -- The Right Hon. and Right Rev. Frederick Temple, D.D., Bishop of London, Provincial Dean of Canterbury and Dean of the Chapels Royal, has been appointed Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of all England in room of the Right Hon. and Most Rev. Edward White Benson, who died suddenly at Hawarden Oct. 11.

From The Chicago Record. OSAWATOMIE, Kan., Oct. 22. -- People in Osawatomie date events from the falling of the aerolite. They say the Mayor vetoed the dog license two years before the aerolite fell or that Mrs. Dusenberry's twins must be eight months old because they were born about three years after the aerolite fell.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 25. -- Bernard McMeeney, employed by Thomas Manning, a sub-contractor, was engaged with two others in digging a trench in Oraton Street, near the corner of Chester Avenue. It was intended to connect the main sewer at this point with the sink leading from a tenement house situated at the corner of these streets.

The Consul of the United States at Ghent, Mr. MORRIS, has some curious ideas about the effect of the proposed free coinage of silver. He remarks, in a report of which we published a part yesterday, that many of the working men in Belgium are idle and that "free silver would bring them hurrying to America."

An urban policeman, even if he call himself a detective, sometimes presents a singular spectacle when he possesses himself of a "theory." Sometimes he is indiscreet enough to frame his theory before the evidence is in, and when the evidence upsets it his struggles to maintain it are most ludicrous to view.

From The Pall Mall Gazette. As the military forces of Russia on a war footing contain upwards of three millions of combatants, it would appear that something more than "coercion that does not of itself mean war" would be required to enable any nation of Western Europe to settle the Eastern question without first consulting the Czar.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Emulating the example of the Covington free-silver mob, a number of West Side hoodlums last evening made use of eggs to emphasize the expression of their political faith.

We have heretofore spoken of the greed of the Nail Pool or Trust and of the effect of this Pool's exactions upon the farmers in this country. Beginning in May of last year, the combination increased the price of both cut and wire nails, making a large addition every month, until the entire increase was more than 200 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 25. -- A head-end collision occurred on the St. Louis and San Francisco Railway, near Mesamec Highlands, at 10 o'clock this morning, by which nine people were killed and a score injured:

From The London Times. Some statistics have just been published relating to the census of occupations taken in Berlin in the middle of last year. A peculiar feature presented in the general result is that the number of persons actually engaged in professions, trades, or productive industry has increased by more than the total addition to the population since 1882.

In discussing the difference between "slaughter thirst" and "blood thirst," a writer in The Spectator says that the so-called "bloodthirsty" Prince is usually only a perfectly callous person who wishes to be finally rid of his enemies in the quickest and easiest way, or who believes that terror is the strongest instrument of government.
JACKSONVILLE, III., Oct. 25. -- Mr. and Mrs. Bryan have passed their Sunday here and most of the day have been at the residence of Dr. Hiram K. Jones.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 25. -- The Third Unitarian Church was afire this morning, and people were within. A man said from the pulpit cool words, dismissing his hearers swiftly through the back door. They went out in order, but in haste. One minute afterward the edifice was aflame from floor to roof.

That many Single Taxers are not supporting William Jennings Bryan in the present Presidential campaign is attested by the names of many prominent men attached to a printed circular, in which is shown undoubtedly the sentiment of a large number of followers of Henry George. The list of signatures includes a large number of those who have been prominent in the single-tax movement.

COVINGTON, Ky., Oct. 25. -- A subscription was started by the Newport Commercial Club yesterday to secure the services of detectives and attorneys for the purpose of ferreting out and bringing to punishment the perpetrators of the insult to Secretary Carlisle.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25. -- Emulating the example of the Covington free-silver mob, a number of West Side hoodlums last evening made use of eggs to emphasize the expression of their political faith.

Engineer PARSONS of the Rapid Transit Commission has been prevented from submitting the report of his plans and estimates for the underground railroad on the Elm Street route, the main features of which we gave some time ago, by the failure of the Commissioners to get a full meeting since it was ready.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25. -- The Joint Select Committee, created at the last session of Congress, to investigate and report upon the question of the use of alcohol free of tax in the manufactures and arts, has prepared a series of interrogatories, which will be distributed throughout the country to such parties as are thought to be interested in the question.

This county will roll up a big vote for JOHN H. KETCHAM, since we are deeply interested in the preservation of our present protective duty on hydraulic cement. At Rosendale and elsewhere in this county, there are 2,000 men employed in thirteen cement factories. We have to meet the competition of the Portland cement dealers of England; of those at Stettin, in Germany, and those at Alp Nauch, in Switzerland.

From The Chronicle. Yesterday at the office of the Queen's Remembrancer at the Royal Courts of Justice an ancient ceremony was observed in respect of two very quaint quit rents for certain lands in the Counties of Salop and Middlesex, of which the Corporation are tenants in capite to the Crown.
A corporation has been formed to construct a tunnel between this city and Brooklyn, under the name of the New-York and Brooklyn Railroad Company. The Board of Directors is composed of the following:

In his very full and interesting statement of the working of his department and of the difficulties he has to meet, which we published on Saturday, Mr. CONSTABLE, the Superintendent of Buildings, declares that "many of the men who pass the civil service examiners are neither mentally nor morally fit to serve as Inspectors."

Thomas Murphy, fifty-one years old, employed at the Morris Park race track and giving his address as 638 Lexington Avenue, was accused in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday of robbing an unknown woman of an unknown amount of money on an unknown date.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 26. -- While a sound-money meeting was in progress to-night at Pulaski Hall, on Eighteenth Street, a band of hoodlums entered the hall and began to shout for Bryan and Altgeld, interrupting the speakers. Many of the intruders were drunk, and soon began to fight among thmeselves.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Will you allow me to express in your columns my appreciation of your to-day's editorial apropos of The Evening Post's attitude toward the proposition that a newspaper should give more space to its opponents' views than The Post has been in the habit of giving?

JACKSONVILLE, Ill., Oct. 26. -- Candidate Bryan made a speech here to-day to the students of the Illinois State College, in which be received a portion of his education. Some who heard Mr. Bryan's speech considered it a plea for charitable judgment.

LONDON, Oct. 26. -- The Mark Lane Express, in its review of the grain market, says: "The rise in the price of wheat is justified by the situation. It is not a speculative advance; on the contrary, a speculative effort to bear the market is on foot. The English wheat crop did not exceed 7,250,000 quarters, though it is stated that it reached 9,000,000 quarters.
It is understood that another contract for steel rails for Japan has been taken, 10,000 tons being the size named for the order. -- [Engineering and Mining Journal, Oct. 24.]

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Oct. 26. -- Chairman Roselle of the Populist State Committee is preparing evidence to present to the Grand Jury, which he believes will prove several prominent Republicans guilty of ante-election bribery. Mr. Roselle says that as Chairman of his party's State Committee he was offered $10,000 as a campaign fund if fusion with Democrats on the Electoral ticket in Missouri were prevented.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- Prominent politicians are paying more attention to candidates for the Legislature this fall than usual, and the reason is to be found in the fact that the next Assembly will choose a successor to Senator John M. Palmer.

A mass meeting to welcome the Armenian refugees was held in Carnegie Music Hall last night under the auspices of the Salvation Army and the Woman's Christian Temperance Union. The hall was well filled, 500 seats being sold at 25 cents each for the benefit of the Armenian immigrants on Ellis Island.

The only distinctively Tammany campaign document that we know of is a placard posted upon the stations of the elevated railroads, showing the city tax rate, the city debt, and the valuation of taxable property under what it calls "Democratic administration" in 1894, and under what it calls "Republican administration" in 1896.

YONKERS, Oct. 26. -- A statement which may have some important bearing on the Hamlin J. Andrus case was made this afternoon by Charles Mallinson, an expert electrician. He declared that he made an examination of the wiring and other mechanism that was found in the cellar of the office building, and declared that all the wiring was done by the same person.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- Mr. Buchanan, United States Minister to the Argentine Republic, in a report to the Department of State on money and prices in foreign countries, says:

Between eighty and ninety young women assembled yesterday morning at the preliminary session of the Women's Law Class of the New-York University, in the university building, on Washington Square. Several of them wore mortar boards and gowns, and before many days all will be so attired.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The public health report issued by the Marine Hospital Service brings to the attention of the authorities the danger of importing yellow fever from Cuba through a new and hitherto unknown agency. Dr. D.M. Burgess, Sanitary Inspector at Havana, writes to Surgeon General Wyman, under date of Oct. 17:
The Rev. Thomas Drumm. The Rev. Thomas Drumm, M.A., M.D., former Chaplain of the Port of New-York, died of nephritis, after a three months' illness at St. Luke's Hospital, yesterday morning.
The distinguishing feature of the opening of the last week of the Presidential campaign in this city is its dullness.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- The plan for a State university, housed in the most coherent and handsome group of educational edifices in the world, is now near realization. The announcement was made at a Board of Regents' meeting that $4,000,000 had been promised by private citizens as soon as the State gave $500,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- The Republican National Committee to-day issued a bulletin claiming thirty-three of the forty-five States for McKinley. Only twelve States are conceded as likely to go for Bryan, and in five of these the Republicans say they have a good fighting chance.

CHICAGO, Ill., Oct. 26. -- All negotiations which were being conducted by Western Chairman Washburn of the Populist Nationalist Committee, representing Candidate Watson and Chairman Jones of the Democratic National Committee for the purpose of solidifying the "Middle of the Road" Populist vote for Bryan, were officially declared at an end to-day by Mr. Washburn in an interview.

There was, as might have been foreseen, a great reunion at the Academy last night of the laudators of past time and the lovers of "bel canto." The audience, which was packed to the gallery, and formed three deep against the walls of the lower auditorium, was distinguishable at a glance from an audience of the Metropolitan, mainly by reason of the larger proportion in it of the more than middle-aged.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26. -- A letter from Spiridion C. Zavitziano, United States Sanitary Inspector at Constantinople, addressed to Surgeon General Wyman of the Marine Hospital Service, gives a striking idea of the extent of the recent massacres in that city. He writes:

It is rather a good thing that the insolence of Prussian officers should have been carried to so flagrant an extent as to arouse the indignation of Prussian civilians. The punishment of Lieut. BRUSEWITZ, recorded in our columns yesterday, was absurdly inadequate for his crime, which was willful murder.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 26. -- Garret A. Hobart began his tour of New-Jersey by speaking here this evening. He was given a great reception. No man was ever before so honored as he by a Camden crowd. Temple Theatre, where the meeting was held, was crowded and hundreds were turned away.

Clinton Street did honor to ex-Sheriff James O'Brien last night. From three houses three dozen Chinese lanterns were strung to a common centre on Apollo Hall, a band "discoursed" popular airs, and about 100 boys marched behind a banner with the name of the "Young Democracy, Regular Organization, of the Twelfth Assembly District."

The Palmer and Buckner National Committee is now denoting special attention to the Southern States. An attempt will be made to bring out a full National Democratic vote in all the States, and especially in the doubtful ones, like North Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia. Maryland, West Virginia, and Kentucky are reported as practically safe for McKinley.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26. -- In less than an hour at noon to-day fire destroyed $1,200,000 worth of property on the North Branch of the Chicago River, in a dilapidated locality known as Goose Island. The Pacific Grain Elevators A and B, owned by the Chicago and Pacific Elevator Company, were completely destroyed, and several frame dwelling's adjoining were swept away in the avalanche of flame.

Whatever may be the merits of the contention between those who desire to maintain the present Constitutional protection of the Adirondack forest preserve and those who favor the leasing of small tracts of the State land for camp and cottage purposes, we have no doubt that the pending amendment should be defeated by an emphatic vote.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 26. -- The following open letter was sent by Col. E. C. Stahl of Trenton, Department Commander of the Grand Army of the Republic and a well-known Democrat, in answer to an inquiry from a personal friend concerning his reasons for taking the stump for sound money:

HALIFAX, N.S., Oct. 26. -- The evening papers print a sensational story in which it is charged that William O'Connor, a British, subject, who went to New-York from Halifax, in 1892, was for four years confined in an insane institution on Ward's Island, though he claims to have been perfectly sane all the time.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26. -- The steamer Coptic, which arrived in this city yesterday from Hongkong and Yokohama, brings additional details of the rebellion in the Philippines.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 26. -- The most interesting event at Canton to-day was the reception by Major McKinley of a large delegation from New-Jersey, composed for the most part of citizens of Newark and Trenton. The delegation included the Frolinghuysen Lancers, the best drilled and most handsomely uniformed body that has come to Canton since the campaign opened.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Oct. 27. -- Mr. Bryan began his speechmaking to-day a little after midnight, when he was called out of his car at Carlinville by the persistent and vociferous demands of a crowd of 500 persons. He spoke at Lincoln at 7 o'clock. In this city he addressed an audience of about 10,000.

The week before the election brings renewed assurances of the election of the Republican candidate for the Presidency. In this State he is certain of a phenomenal majority. In this Democratic city MCKINLEY will poll more votes than BRYAN. There will be a Republican Governor and a Republican Assembly.

-- Members of Congress can have anything that has appeared in The Congressional Record reprinted at the Government Printing Office in any quantity they choose by paying simply the cost to the Government of paper, ink, and labor, and yet almost invariably they find it cheaper to get the work done by outside printers, who have rent to pay and who do not enjoy the privilege of using the original plates.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I took the liberty last April of expressing in your columns, as a citizen of the State of New-York, my deep appreciation of the inestimable services rendered to the people of this Commonwealth by the press of the city and State in exposing and defeating the Brackett-Eldridge bills relating to the Adirondack watershed.

Mayor WURSTER of Brooklyn on Monday secured the passage of a resolution by the Bridge Trustees for the employment of three engineers to report, in connection with Mr. MARTIN, on the feasibility of running the surface and elevated railways continuously across the bridge.

The experiments that are being made and are about to be made with the compressed-air motor in this city give promise of a new power to be applied to the traction of street cars which may displace all other, and if it prove successful is pretty sure to finish the use of the horse in that capacity.
Chauncey M. Depew talked last night to 10,000 persons, 7,000 of whom were in Durland's Riding Academy in the Circle and the others in Lenox Lyceum.

RICHMOND Va., Oct. 27. -- The Republicans and the sound-money Democrats are making tremendous efforts to swing this State into line for McKinley. Not only are these two elements straining every nerve to secure the Electoral vote, but they are perfecting the most carefully digested plans for electing Judge Lewis to Congress in this (Richmond) district.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Weighing the confidence of the Republicans with the claims of the Democrats, and giving some attention to the comments of men who are acquainted with the conditions in the States and who are not naturally disposed to misrepresent, the outlook is that the Republican, majority in the Fifty-fifth Congress, in the House of Representatives, will be not far from 100.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 27. -- The delegations were late in reaching Canton to-day. The first to arrive was a large one from the mountain counties of West Virginia and Maryland on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. There were 600 farmers and a number of business and professional men. About seventy-five ladies from Martin's Ferry arrived with the delegation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27. -- Reports on money and wages from United States diplomatic and consular officials abroad continue to pour into the Department of State in response to Secretary Olney's July circular asking to know the experience of foreign nations with the currency problem.

It is unfortunate that the reports procured by the State Department concerning currency systems abroad as related to wages and prices, published three or four days ago, could not have been laid before the people at an earlier date, because they contain so much valuable and instructive information affecting the dominant issue of the campaign.

Daniel G. Griffin, the National Democratic nominee for Governor, called at the party headquarters, in Twenty-third Street, yesterday. He is taking an active part in his own and in tne National campaign. He will speak at Saratoga to-morrow night, and at Mount Vernon Friday night. In speaking of the progress of the campaign, as observed by him, Mr. Griffin said:

LONDON, Oct. 27. -- At the Newmarket Houghton meeting to-day the race for the Criterion Stakes was won by the Prince of Wales's bay colt Oakdene, by Donovan, out of Poetry. Leopold de Rothschild's bay filly Goletta, by Galopin, out of Biserta, was second, and the Duke of Westminster's bay colt Rust, by Bluegreen, out of Ruth, was third.

YONKERS, Oct. 27. -- Coroner Miles has been forced at length to make a statement on the Hamlin J. Andrus case. Some hints thrown out by him have implicated certain members of the Andrus family, and public sentiment demanded a plain statement ot any facts in the possession of the Coroner.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 27. -- E.R. Lynch, Secretary of the People's Party State Committee, makes the following statement:
CHICAGO, Oct. 27. -- The Republican National Committee to-day gave out the following:

KEYPORT, N.J., Oct. 27. -- Dr. W.W. Palmer, a prominent physician of Keansburg, and his fifteen-year-old granddaughter were killed and William Hauran, a friend, probably fatally injured on a grade crossing of the Atlantic Highlands Division of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey at Keansburg this morning.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- Eddie Jacques, alias Peter James, one of the Bedford burglars, escaped from the county jail here to-night.

PLATTSBURG, N.Y., Oct. 27. -- At a meeting in the interest of sound money tonight the principal speaker was Smith M. Weed, for years one of the most prominent Democrats of the State. There was a large crowd present, Republicans and sound-money Democrats uniting in the organization of the meeting.

It is reported from Albany that the "Platt machine Republicans" of that city are displaying bad temper at the decision of the Court of Appeals which holds the Partisan Police act of last Winter unconstitutional, and that they threaten to "cut" the vote of Judge VANN as much as possible at the coming election because he concurs in the decision.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 27. -- The Chairman of the Republican State Committee, H.G. McMillan, claims that McKinley will have 75,193 plurality in Iowa, or 63,193 majority. He estimates the vote as follows: McKinley, 251,113; Bryan, 175,920; Palmer, 9,000; Prohibition, 4,000. Total vote, 439,033.

I read in the papers that in various institutions of learning they are nearly all against me. My friends, if I should read in the paper that there was not a college professor, not a business man, not a man prominent in society who believed in what I am teaching, while I would believe in it I would still teach it.

BUDA-PESTH, Oct. 27. -- The third game of the match between Tschigorin and Charousek, to decid the tie for first honors in the International Chess Tournament, was played to-day. Charousek won. At the end of play the following bulletin was posted:

SEATTLE, Washington, Oct. 27. -- An afternoon paper has complied information showing that the farmers of Eastern Washington have, since the recent rise in wheat, sold 15,000,000 bushels at an average price of 60 cents, the crop netting about $3,500,000 more than last year. This season the farmers were enabled to borrow money on warehouse receipts which enabled them to hold their wheat until the rise.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 28. -- The consummation of the deal for the transfer of the control of the Seaboard Air Line has been postponed until after election day. Options on the stock held by the Pooling Committee, composed of Messrs. Moncure Robinson of Philadelphia, L.M. Watts of Portsmouth, Va., and Louis McLane of this city, practically place about 8,000 shares of stock in the syndicate's control.
CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 28. -- All Canton was divided into two parts this evening -- those who marched to Major McKinley's, and those who viewed and cheered the marching throngs.

MADRID, Oct. 28. -- An official cablegram received from Manila, the captial of the Philippine Islands, to-day, says that a conspiracy against the Government has been discovered in the Sooloo Islands. Eight Spanish soldiers were shot in a conflict with the revolutionists at Sooloo, the capital of the Sooloo Archipelago, and troops have been sent there by the Governor of the Philippines, who has also armed a local force at Sooloo.

Lieut. Col. Henry C. Stanley, M. Inst. C. E., Chief Engineer of Railways for Queensland, Australia, is in America, making a semi-official study of methods of railway construction and operation in the interests of the Colonial Government. He is the second Ambassador from the other side of the world who has visited this country on the same errand within a month.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At no time have the varied labors of the University Settlement Society given better results and better promise for the future than during the past Summer. The number of residents is greater than ever before. Seven men are now in residence, and another is expected within a week.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Oct. 28. -- Vice Presidential Candidate Garret A. Hobart and Gov. John Griggs were given a rousing reception here this evening. This is Hobart's county, as he was born here, and Monmouth still claims him as a son, although he has long been a resident of Passaic County.

From Forest and Stream. The end sought to be gained by this amendment is wholly and purely private, personal, and selfish in character, and contrary to the rights of the public in the public's own possessions. The intention is to open the way to hand over the choice locations of the Adirondacks for camp and cottage purposes.
BOSTON, Oct. 28. -- The free-silver parade, under the auspices of the Bryan-Sewall-Williams Club, has been abandoned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Secretary Herbert this morning announced that the unnamed ships now under construction will be named as follows: Battleships -- Alabama, Illinois, and Wisconsin; Gunboats -- Annapolis, Marietta, Newport, Princeton, Vicksburg, and Wheeling.

Patrick O'Connor, twenty-seven years old, of 345 West Thirty-eighth Street, was arraigned in Yorkville Police Court yesterday by Detectives Wade and Savage of the Central Office on the charge of being a suspicious person. The detectives would say but little about him, except that he had stolen goods in his possession and refused to explain where he got them.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- The second day of Mr. Bryan's canvass of Cook County began at 10 A.M. by an address in the Polish district, to an audience of women -- Polish, Danish, Swedish, German, and women of other nationalities. They gathered in St. Stanislaus Hall, at Bradley and Noble Streets, and cheered him.
William D. Bynum, Chairman of the National Committee of the National Democratic Party, has written an encouraging letter to the headquarters of the party here. He says:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- Chief Constructor Hichborn's annual report shows a total of 110 vessels in the navy, of which 30 are armored, including 8 battleships, 2 cruisers, 1 ram, 6 double-turreted monitors, all of which are in active service prepared for offensive or defensive operations, and 13 single-turreted monitors which might be utilized in the harbors in which they now lie.

Few of the changes made in the election law at the last session of the Legislature affect in any way the task of the voter in preparing his ballot, but as most persons are apt to be forgetful in such matters it will be well to remind them of just what they have to do when they reach the polling place on election day.

-- In a recent issue of The True Reform, a Prohibition paper the editor made what seemed to be a serious offer to bet $10,000 against $2,000 that, in case of BRYAN'S election, four months after his inauguration, two-thirds of the mills, shops, stores, and banks in the United States will be closed.

ALBANY, Oct. 28. -- The second Westchester County Assembly contest was argued before the Court of Appeals to-day. Joseph Ennis was nominated by the Robertson Republicans and Richard E. Emmett, Jr., by the Platt Republicans. The County Clerk placed Emmett's name on the ballot.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Oct. 28. -- Dr. Grenfell, Superintendent of the British Mission to the Deep Sea Fishermen, now operating in Labrador, sends appalling accounts of the destitution which prevails on that coast.

Operagoers were surprised last night to meet the announcement on the doors of the Academy of Music that, the Alfredo of "La Traviata" being ill, "Aida" would be repeated. Those of them who were not at the opera on Monday night had certainly no right to be disappointed, nor, indeed, had those who were, for not performance of the earlier opera could be so good as the production of the latter.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 28. -- Secretary of the Treasury John G. Carlisle spoke tonight in Louisville, the stronghold of the Gold Democrats of Kentucky. He spoke in the Auditorium, the largest building in the city, and the audience, which listened to the distinguished Kentuckian was even greater than that which assembled to do honor to Palmer and Buckner when they were notified of their nominations last month.
LONDON Oct. 28. -- The Admiralty authorizes an explicit denial of the statement that orders have been issued to double the strength of the British fleet in American waters.

DENVER, Col., Oct. 28. -- Politics has made strange bedfellows in Colorado this year, and at the close of the campaign the situation is complicated and the result of the domestic battle, except on Congressmen and the Governor, is in doubt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The completion of the British case in the Venezuelan boundary dispute, according to the under standing of the Venezuelan Commission was signalized at the meeting of that body to-day by the receipt from Secretary Olney of an important publication "printed by the authority or his Excellency the Governor of British Guiana" in the colony.

It does not seem to us that either those who are just now extremely nervous or those who are extremely sanguine as to what will happen after Tuesday next are showing the best judgment. That on that day BRYAN and Bryanism will be overwhelmed and crushed we have no doubt.

Mrs. Edgar S. Werner, or Mrs. Titus Werner, as she is known among lawyers, is a member of the Society of Friends. She was recently appointed a receiver by Justice MacLcan at the same time as a couple of sisters in the legal profession. All three are naturally proud of their appoinments, as they are the first women to be selected to such an office in this State.

From The San Francisco Call, Oct. 20. By a decision of the Court of Appeals yesterday the Oregon and California Railroad secured the right and title to over 200,000 acres of land lying in and adjacent to the City of Portland. The victory means a clear gain of several million dollars to the corporation and a corresponding loss on the part of the Government.

This is an unprecedented campaign in One very noteworthy respect, and that is that the American flag has been appropriated by one of the contesting parties as its own emblem. The appropriation is recognized, even by those who pretend not to recognize it, as an appropriateness. Nothing of American tradition or American instinct went to the framing by ALTGELD and TILLMAN of the platform upon which BRYAN stands.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Republican managers at National, State, and county headquarters were kept busy to-day answering the question:

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 28. -- Sheriff Johnson's Deputy Sheriffs and special Deputy Sheriffs scoured the county in all directions to-day in their search for Edward Jacques, alias Peter James, the Bedford Station burglar, who escaped from the county jail here last evening, in order to instill more interest into the search Sheriff Johnson today offered a reward of $250 for the arrest of the fugitive.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28. -- Two boys, Chauncey M. Foster and Lewis Hanchett, were arrested this noon for throwing eggs at Mr. Bryan. while he was proceeding yersterday from the train to Battery D. They admit their guilt. Foster is seventeen years old, and the son of a retired merchant; Hanchett is of the same age.

Madison C. Peters, in the Bloomingdale Reformed Church, corner of Sixty-eighth Street and Boulevard, last night talked on "The Perils of the Republic." He denounced trusts, advocated the income tax, favored restricted immigration, scored the free-silver proposition, and criticised both political parties.

ALBANY, Oct. 28. -- At noon to-day, at All Saints' Cathedral, Miss Harriet Weld Corning, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Erastus Corning, was married to Mr. Rufus Wheeler Peckham, Jr., second son of Justice Peckham of the United States Supreme Court, the Right Rev. Bishop William Croswell Doane officiating, assisted by Dean Wilford L. Robbins.

The sound-money mass meeting in the interest of the candidacy of John Murray Mitchell, in the Eighth Congressional District, last night, was one ou the largest held in Cooper Union during the present campaign. The hit of the evening was made by Capt. Jack Crawford, "the poet scout." A notable feature was the reading of this telegram from Major McKinley:

Mr. BRYAN is clearly disquieted by the prevailing opinion that continual talking in his own behalf is unworthy of a candidate for the Presidency. He has lately apologized for his course by the statement -- which is true -- that he has very few newspapers to support his claims to election.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28. -- The Popocrats are greatly disturbed over the reports, which, they try to deny, that the Republicans of North Carolina have stolen a march upon them and will carry the State.

The Fire Commissioners yesterday dismissed the charges of fraud and incon petency under which J. Elliott Smith, Superintendent of Fire Alarm and Telegraph in the department, was recently tried, and reinstated him in the position, from which he was suspended when the charges were first made.
HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 28. -- Dartmouth played her first home football same this afternoon, with Bowdoin. and won in a hard-fought contest, 26 to 10. The line-up follows:
LONDON Oct. 28. -- The Admiralty authorizes an explicit denial of the statement that orders have been issued to double the strength of the British fleet in American waters.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I was disgusted by an editorial in The Tribune this morning ridiculing the Palmer Democrats and employing against them sophistries of the Bryan stamp. The main one of these was that a big vote for McKinley would mean the annihilation of the silver danger and a great triumph for sound money.

BOSTON, Oct. 29. -- To George Fred Williams has been refused the use of another hall in Boston. This time it is Jacob Sleeper Hall, at Boston University. It is, however, under somewhat different circumstances than those connected with Music Hall, for the request did not come from the Bryan-Sewall-Williams Club, but from the club formed by the students of the university whose politics has a silver gleam.

-- "There is absolutely no doubt that BRYAN will be elected." So says GEORGE FRED WILLIAMS by long-distance telephone to his Boston manager. GEORGE FRED might have gone even further and said there is not even a suspicion of it.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- A dispatch from Ardrossan, Scotland, says the British steamer Memnon. Capt. Bales, which sailed from Montreal Oct. 14. via Quebec, for Bristol, came in collision with the barkentine Ciba off Corsewall Point, Scotland, to-day. The Ciba's headgear was carried away, and she is leaking a little. The Memnon proceeded to her destination.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29. -- The result of the competition for the Stinnecke Prize, the largest prize which can be won by a Princeton student, was announced by the faculty to-day. Richard Webster of the class of '99 is the successful competitor. By winning this prize, Mr. Webster will receive a total of $1,500, $500 being awarded each year for three years.
CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 29. -- At present the interest of all Harvard students is almost wholly engrossed by the political activity which surrounds them, and of which they feel themselves a part.
Treasurer William P. St. John of the Democratic National Committee is very confident.

LONDON, Oct. 29. -- A dispatch from Ardrossan, Scotland, says the British steamer Memnon. Capt. Bales, which sailed from Montreal Oct. 14. via Quebec, for Bristol, came in collision with the barkentine Ciba off Corsewall Point, Scotland, to-day. The Ciba's headgear was carried away, and she is leaking a little. The Memnon proceeded to her destination.

The observations of Dr. THEODORE BARTH on the canvass, which we published yesterday morning, are valuable. He is a political leader, being a member of the German Reichstag, elected by universal suffrage. He is a trained and successful journalist, the editor of Die Nation, which is an authority on questions of finance and economics.

Within the past three days THE TIMES has contained reports of interviews about American railroads with Mr. POLLITT, the chief engineer of an important English line, and with Col. STANLEY, the chief engineer of railways for Queensland, Australia, where the roads are under the control of the Government.
If you take the purchasing power of a single dollar, it will be less. -- [Mr. BRYAN to The New-York Journal, Oct. 28.]

The case of the explosion by which Mr. ANDRUS lost his life at Yonkers illustrates the serious defects of our system of dealing with sudden death and suspected crime. Proceedings have been dragging along for a week or two and nobody knows yet whether Mr. ANDRUS'S death was a matter of accident or of homicide, because the Coroner and the Chief of Police have been at loggerheads over it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- Secretary Kdgerton of the National Populist Committee to-day gave out his first formal interview, his subject being the claims made by the Republican committees in regard to the election of McKinley, which he characterized as "preposterous," and "made with the idea of fraud in all the doubtful States.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- The following was issued to-night from Democratic Headquarters:

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 29. -- Mrs. Annie Meyers, thirty-two years old, was this afternoon attacked by two men while she was in her apartments. She was chloroformed, gagged, bound, and thrown on a bed. Then her assailants searched the flat and obtained $95 in cash.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Final reports by letter from the Chairmen of the Republican State Committees have been coming to Headquarters here for the last week. Tonight, after a council of the National Committee, it was decided to give to the press these reports as fast as they were received, following the action of Campaign Chairman Campau of the Democratic National Committee.
CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Chairman James K. Jones and others connected with the National Democratic headquarters are fearful that Bryan will collapse before the campaign ends.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 29. -- The delegations were small to-day, but sufficiently numerous and by no means lacking in enthusiasm. The approach of the election seems at last to have an effect upon the size of the delegations. There was a good deal of variety, too, about the visitors to the Republican candidate to-day.

Col. Robert G. Ingersoll entertained an immense audience at Carnegie Hall last night with a political speech. For nearly two hours he held up as a target before the applauding crowd Bryan and his doctrines, while he kept twanging the bowstring of his wit, and making "bull's eyes" every time.

The National Democracy is making a brisk canvass, not only in New-York, but throughout the entire country. Reports from a number of Southern States are not anly interesting, but indicative of flattering results.

Marion J. Verdery, whose interview in THE NEW-YORK TIMES on Bryan's "crown of thorns" and "cross of gold" has been republished all over the country, is having an amusing experience as a result of its wide dissemination. Many men who read Mr. Verdery's sentiments did not agree with them, and are not hesitating to let him know it.

MADRID, Oct. 29. -- The Imparcial has opened a fund for the benefit of the wounded soldiers who are returning to Spain from Cuba. Queen Regent Christina heads the list of subscribers to the fund with the sum of 10,000 pesetas.

To the Editor of The New-York Times The Tribune is an excellent newspaper. I read it every morning, always making due allowance for its inconsistencies. Lately it manifested a proper indignation at the depletion of our forests, while advocating the preservation of Canadian trees and the cutting down of our own.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29. -- Missouri continued to be the State most talked about and reported on at Republican headquarters today. The campaign managers, from Chairman Hanna down, are now settled in their conviction that there is an even chance in that State for the Republican Presidential ticket.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29. -- From Bryan headquarters a programme is being prepared for an official Senatorial inquiry next Winter into the charges of discrimination in passenher rates against Democrats in all parts of the United Spates. The charge is being formulated that railroads have systematically refused to make reductions to Democrats, and that they have transported the Republicans in great numbers and bodies in all parts of the country at rates that are ridiculously low.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I was disgusted by an editorial in The Tribune this morning ridiculing the Palmer Democrats and employing against them sophistries of the Bryan stamp. The main one of these was that a big vote for McKinley would mean the annihilation of the silver danger and a great triumph for sound money.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 29. -- The State Attorney this afternoon nolled the case against the Rev. H.H. Hayden, which has been on the Superior Court docket since 1879. The clergyman was charged with the murder of Mary Stannard of Guilford, and the trial attracted the attention of the whole country at the time.

W. Bourke Cockran spoke last night in the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, to an audience of 4,000 persons. It was an audience of men engaged in the production of the wealth of the community, manufacturers and laborers, and his address was framed along lines that were of especial interest to those who listened to him.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I have read with pleasure year recent editorial article in opposition to the proposed Constitutional amendment regarding the Adirondack Forest Reserve. As one who has long been interested in the question of forest preservation, both in this State and in the country at large, I desire to emphasize the importance of voting "no" on the proposed amendment.

Within the last few days Mr. BRYAN has said to his audiences (at Bloomington, Ill., and elsewhere) and over his signature (in a dispatch to The New-York Journal) that his party's purpose is to reduce the purchasing power of the dollar.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30. -- Samuel J. Roberts, Chairman of the Kentucky Republican Committee, gives out the following:
ROME, Oct. 30. -- Cardinal Prince Gustave von Hohenlohe-Schillingfurst, brother of Prince von Hohenlohe-Schillingfurst, the imperial Chancellor of Germany, died here this morning.

JACOB WORTH has been appointed County Clerk of Kings County to serve until Jan. 1 and until his successor is appointed. He was appointed by Gov. MORTON on the recommendation of Mr. BLACK, the candidate of the Republican Party for Governor, and to all intents the Governor-elect.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 30. -- In the sound-money parade in this city to-day, which was one of the greatest demonstrations ever witnessed in Rensselaer County, Joseph King of Lansingburg, aged 105 years, who always has been a Democrat, but who has declared intentions of voting for McKinley was to the line in a carriage.

CANTON, Oct. 30. -- A direct long-distance telephone connection has been established between Major McKinley's house and Buffalo, N.Y. The line was used for the purpose of transmitting a message from Major McKinley to the meeting in Buffalo tonight, under the direction of the commercial travelers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- The following final statement from the Populist side as to election day probabilities and expectations throughout the country was given out tonight by Chairman Washburn of the Chicago Headquarters:
LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Following are reports of to-day's wheat markets on the Continent:

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 30. -- Chauncey M. Depew arrived in Canton at 1:3O o'clock this afternoon, and was met at the staion by Major McKinley and the Citizens' Reception Committee. He was driven at ince to the McKinley residence. Mr. Depew said:

MADISON, Wis., Got. 30. -- The usual throng of enthusiastic silverites did not greet William J. Bryan on his arrival in Madison to-night. A couple of hundred people only were at the Northwestern Railroad station when his train came in and the brass bands and marching clubs did not get there until after Mr. Bryan had started for the big building where his first speech was made.

There were more evidences of petty hoarding of gold at the Sub-Treasury yesterday than on any day during the last fortnight. In the gold room there were at all times a score of men and women in line and often twice as many.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Nothing out of the ordinary was noted at the opening of the wheat market to-day. Prices were lower by 3/8 to 3/4 of a cent, but this depreciation was recovered in the course of ten minutes without any unusual animation. The Liverpool market was lower, which tended to restrain bull enthusiasm.

LONDON, Oct. 30. -- Edward J. Ivory, alias Bell, the alleged Irish-American dynamiter who was arrested in Glasgow Sept. 12, was again arraigned in the Bow Street Court today and remanded for another week.

There was a patriotic demonstration in Carnegie Hall last evening in the interest of McKinley and sound money, when the Union Veterans' Patriotic League held its last meeting previous to election. The big hall was filled with an enthusiastic gathering of ladies and gentlemen. In fact, the boxes in the gallery took on something of the appearance of a first night at the opera.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- Manager Hanna addressed the Commercial Democratic McKinley Club to-day.

There has been evidence for some time of a growing disposition among sound-money Democrats in the South to join with the Republicans in support of McKinley and Hobart Electors. Considering the political conditions in those States, we think that it is the wisest thing for them to do, and they ought also to use every effort to secure an honest election and an honest return of the results in every State.

The crowd which packed Cooper Union last night was a typical Bryan gathering. It was extremely boisterous and exhibited a strong desire to do the talking instead of the orators. The names of the leading Democrats of the country were hissed, and those of the most respected citizens, such as ex-Mayor Abraham S. Hewitt, William Steinway, and William C. Whitney, were loudly hooted.

From The Baltimore Sun, Oct. 26. A coincidence in theatrical circles in Baltimore this week will be the presence here of three sisters who are all well known to the stage -- Miss Ada Rehan, who will be at the Academy; Mrs. Oliver Byron, who will play with her husband at Holliday Street Theatre, and Mrs. Hattie Russell, who is expected to come to Baltimore to pay a visit to Mrs. Byron.

From The Chicago Times-Herald. Assistant City Engineer Roemheld lifted the Clark Street Bridge Sunday and put new wheels under it. He did it about as easily as an ordinary man would lift a bedpost and put new castors in it. He began early in the morning and finished the work at sunset.
CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- The Saratoga Hotel, in Dearborn Street, is a stronghold of freesilver men, and here the-sound-money men congregate in search of ventures, on the result.

From The San Francisco Examiner. A unique character is Col. J.H. Burns, who, with $1,000,000 in his charge, made a trip from Chicago to New-York. He was in charge of a Wells-Fargo Express car, in which $1,000,000 in gold and a trifle of $45,000 in silver was packed to transfer from the Sub-Treasury in San Francisco to the Sub-Treasury in New-York.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 30. -- Mr. Bryan made he following statement to-night:

The Cunard Line steamship Campania, from Liverpool and Queenstown, landed her passengers last night. Among them was Mme. Melba. Awaiting friends hurried her into a carriage and took her away, while two maids remained behind to look after her baggage.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30. -- The Republican National Committee received more reports today from State Committee Chairmen, in response to the call sent out by Chairman Hanna for the latest and most conservative estimates of the result. Presidential, State, and Congressional. Following are extracts from these reports:

The people of this city have had two striking examples of Gen. Horace Porter's unsurpassed powers of organization. The first happened a few years ago, when he took up the almost dormant Grant Monument j Fund and increased it within four months from less than $150,000 to the required $500,000.

In the preliminary battle of the people against the plutocracy, the people have already won. In spite of an expenditure of money so large that the civilized world stands appalled at its magnitude, to-day a large majority of the people of the United States are in open revolt against the merciless gold standard.

BOSTON, Oct. 30. -- Between almost interminable lines of hurrahing people, their way lighted with the incessant glare of red fire and rockets, while the heavens were rent with the blare of myriads of tin horns and megaphones and cheers, marched the parade of college students to-night.

The aspect of the business quarter of New-York yesterday was quite without precedent. It is safe to say that nobody has ever before seen so many American flags at once as might have been seen in Lower Broadway. From Madison Square to the Battery, Broadway has been signalized for some weeks by the display of great ensigns hung across the street.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 30. -- Gen. Harrison began his second speaking tour through Indiana to-day. He left Indianapolis at 8 o'clock this morning on a special train. A crowd of enthusiastic admirers compelled him to make a few remarks before he left the Indianapolis station. Stops were made at Greenfleld, Knightstown, Anderson, Muncie, and other points, at all of which Gen. Harrison spoke.

One of the most interesting of the many road races to be decided on election day will be the annual fifteen-mile handicap for the cycling members of the New-York Athletic Club. The event will take place on the Merrick Road, the start and finish being at Freeport. The course will have only one turn in it, and that will be at Smith's Hotel, just seven and one-half miles from Freeport.

The crowds that lined Fifth Avenue, north of the reviewing stand, had an exciting afternoon. Men and women of all ages seemed at times to lose control of their senses, and in their wild attempts to give vent to their feeling, smashed hats and ruined personal property.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 31. -- Flag Day was generally observed by the patriotic citizens of Pittsburg and Allegheny City. There have been parades in Pittsburg and Allegheny City in years gone by that were immense in size and in the amount of enthusiasm put on exhibition. In future years all events of this character will probably date from today's display, given by the Republicans this afternoon as a grand finale of the campaign of 1896.

The members of the Westbrook Golf Club of Islip, L.I., were treated to one of the finest golfing days yesterday that have been enjoyed this season. It was the last day of the club's open tournament. Golfers actually seemed to swarm over the links.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- The Harvard's scalp will not adorn the Carlisle Indians' wigwam to-night, for by the pluckiest sort of resistance they prevented them getting a single point, and when time was called had beaten the visitors by a touchdown. Score -- 4 to 0.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 31. -- If the election in Virginia shall pass off without bloodshed it will be fortunate.
-- Coquelin will shortly act Don Caesar de Bazan in the Dennery play at the Porte St. Martin for the first time in Paris.

Miss Anna Layton, a teacher in the primary department of Grammar School No. 5. One Hundred and Forty-first Street and Edgecombe Avenue, was summoned before Magistrate Deuel, in the Harlem Court, yesterday morning, to answer a complaint of Frederick Jacobson, eleven years old, of 2,574 Eighth Avenue, who is one of her pupils, and who charges her with assaulting him in the class room Thursday morning, breaking both of the bones in his left forearm.

The Sunny Hour Barefoot Mission needs help! No one who knows the history of Tello J. D'Apery, the "philanthropical boy journalist," could wish to see his labors for barefooted children come to an end. He commenced his mission as a child of ten giving to poor children such shoes and stockings as he could collect.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31. -- On her trial trip up from Monterey the battleship Oregon yesterday morning experienced her severest test. After leaving Monterey a stiff breeze sprung up and the swell became quite heavy, causing the vessel to roll considerably. Capt. Howlson remained on the bridge throughout the night, anxiously watching the ship's behavior.

TO be taken back twenty years and more is a grateful gift to Persons of a certain age, and Col. Mapleson came very near to bestowing it upon a great part of the audience which packed the old Academy, in Fourteenth Street, on Monday night to hear and see the revival of " Aida."

Agent Wilson of the Gerry Society yesterday appeared before Magistrate Kudlich in the Morrisania Court, having in his custody George Choate, fourteen years old, of Careyville, Mass., who was deserted in this city by Elijah Stone, also of Careyville, who the boy says brought him to this city on the pretense of getting him work as an office boy.

John C. Sheehan, the executive head of Tammany Hall, issued his final statement on the campaign in this city last night. It reads in part as follows: "All the other organizations have already closed up their headquarters, but Tammany's headquarters are never closed. Our work does not cease until the vote is canvassed and the result announced.
-- Young Bronislaw Hubermann, the violinist, will take part in forty concerts in this country. His tour begins Nov. 21 at Carnegie Music Hall.

The fitful, dwindling days and the crimson hectic of the leaves warn us that November is here, which is but too well confirmed by the pale lustre of the sun and the land of clouds that at this season are often so leaden, drear, and dismal. The sharp winds blowing through the trees and whirling away the falling leaves seem to be calling Winter as they rush by us.

THUS the itinerant bard, O'Heerin, in his rhyming topographical survey of Ireland, wrote five hundred years ago. Like so many of his fellows, the O'Dalys, the O'Dugans, and less famous wandering chroniclers and poets whose pictures of contemporary life survive in the Irish manuscripts of the Middle Ages, he had a wealth of blarneying adjectives at the tip of his goose quill.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 31. -- There is seemingly no question as to the stand of the City and County of Worcester in the pending campaign. The banner Republican city and county of the State are thoroughly in favor of sound money. That was shown by the unprecedented demonstration made here to-day.

The brokers and bankers of Wall Street devoted much of their time to patriotism, but in the enthusiasm of it all the Stock Exchange did a bigger business than has been transacted in any recent Saturday's half-day session. Martial music, huzzahing thousands on parade, the very air heavy with the fervor of Americanism, gave impetus to business.
Work on the old Naval Hospital in the navy yard enclosure at Washington and Flushing Avenues, Brooklyn, is to be resumed to-morrow after a delay of nearly six months.

Much excitement was caused among Brooklyn politicians and office holders yesterday by a report that the October Grand Jury had voted Friday evening to indict Harry H. Adams, former County Treasurer, who left office Jan. 1, 1895, with a deficit of $89,000 on his books.

Clement A. Griscom, Jr., of the American Line of Steamships, was seen Thursday about sidewalk obstructions. The American Line uses Pier 14 North River, in the heart of the squatting district. Mr. Griscom said that New-York City is far behind European cities in regard to street and sidewalk obstructions.

Naturally most of the talk in the sporting corners of the clubs just now is of football, even the devotees of golf admitting that there is a passing interest taken in the sport, and that it has really been made a National sport by the adoption of the Walter Camp game by nearly all the colleges and preparatory schools of the country.

BALTIMORE, Md., Oct. 31. -- In no year heretofore have there been so many political meetings held in Maryland. The nomination of a Maryland man for the Presidency by the Prohibition Party had the effect of adding an additional stimulus to the campaign in this State. It will not, however, have much, if any, effect on the election next Tuesday.

Long before 9 o'clock crowds of paraders and spectators assembled in Lower Broadway. Broadway, Wall Street, Broad Street, Nassau Street, John Street, and, for that matter, every down-town street, was a symphony in red, white, and blue, and Stars and Stripes. It was a sight to stir the heart of every citizen.

IT is perhaps a significant note in the many discussions relating to the theatre hat that at a class of parliamentary practice the other day, no one could be found who would or could take the negative side of the motion that women should lay aside their hats at theatres and other places of public amusement where the audience was seated.

Frederic W. Hinrichs has just replied to a correspondent who asked him for his opinion on the gold and silver question. This correspondent is both a wage earner and a real property owner, having been long employed as a station agent in the Long Inland Railroad, and also owning a farm, on the mortgage of which he has long been paying interest.

It was after the play, and numerous theatre parties were strolling into the gorgeous and flower-scented restaurant. The lights were softened by silken shades of crimson and orange, and sweet melodies from a Judiciously restrained orchestra enhanced the animation of the scene.
MR. BENSON was taking his usual after - lunch, or "after-dinner nap," one should say, for "the Benson," being only "dining-room floor lodgers for a permanency."

WEDNESDAY, Nov. 4. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, John H. Rogan, referee, 13 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street, north side, 225 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 19 by 100.11, five-story brick flat. Due on judgment, $17,025.

Dr. Johnson in his old age remarked that solecisms in the use of the English language were by no means as common as when he was younger. "Everybody composes pretty well." This may be said a century later of piano playing. Everybody plays the piano pretty well. Certainly it may be said of Miss Rachel Hoffmann, who made her American debut at last week's Damrosch Sunday concert.

Grammar School No. 6, situated on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street, was opened on May 1, 1894. The building, which is one of the most commodious structures in the city, was erected by the Trustees of the Nineteenth Ward on plans furnished by C.B.J. Snyder, the Superintendent of School Buildings.
All day long it was a city of gold. Yellow was the comman wear.

LENOX, Oct. 31. -- Nearly all the men here will go to New-York to vote next week. It is rare to find a silver man among those who have Summer places here; in fact, nine-tenths of the men will vote for McKinley. Several of the cottagers are planning to close their houses soon after or just before election, and most of the people will be away by the end of next week.
