PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- At 2 o'clock the special trains from Philadelphia and New-York arrived bearing their addition to the crowd already in Princeton on the occasion of the Princeton-Cornell football game. The game was warm for good football.

The game of golf has found its way among the colleges. The first evidence of what college students can do in golf will be seen next Saturday at the Ardsley Casino, on the Hudson, near Dobbs Ferry. That club has arranged for an intercollegiate golf meeting, and has offered a handsome silver cup to the winning college team.

The weekly statement of the New-York City banks, issued Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $2,502,325. The banks now hold $17,463,225 in excess of the legal requirement. The following table shows the condition of the New-York City banks this week as compared with last week:

The delegation of sound-money Democrats that held meetings throughout North Carolina last week returned to New-York yesterday morning. Their experiences in North Carolina will never be forgotten. From one place to another they were hooted and jeered, and in several instances they were threatened with personal violence.

A number of enthusiasts among the elderly business men were so interested in the parade that they overtaxed their strength. They evidently relied on their enthusiasm to carry them through the fatigue of the long and heating march. Age was forgotten, and they entered upon the tramp of three and a half miles like veterans of a half dozen wars.

A number of Italians employed in the quarries at Cliffside, just beyond Hudson Heights, quarreled Thursday night. One of them obtained a warrant for Giuseppe Kabanni, on a charge of assault. Fabanni said he would shoot any one who attempted to arrest him. He had in his shanty a double-barreled shotgun, which he loaded with shot and slugs.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- The market for local stocks was largely confined to Bay State Gas stock and bonds. The former was very strong, advancing 1 5/8, to 7 3/8, and closing at 7. The first 5s were up 6, to 78, and the seconds 7, to 62, with 66 bid at the close. The rumored elimination of the Addicks interest from the company was taken as a bull point, and caused the advance.
"You don't write to me as you used to," she said to her husband, who had returned from a business journey out of the city.

Frank Freeman, supposed to be a burglar, was captured in Coroner Fitzpatrick's residence at 258 Henry Street at 3 o'clock yesterday morning by Policeman Collins of the Madison Street Police Station, and was found to have two bullet wounds in the body, received in a way which has not yet been explained.

Now that Hallowe'en is over, the next thing to look forwad to in the way of a fete day is Thanksgiving. In a few days the President will issue his annual proclamation. There is a little form to be observed about this.

Presumably nobody now living ever saw Balfe's "Bohemian Girl" produced with any sort of regard to historical accuracy in the scenery and dresses, or with even an intelligent attempt to make the meaning of the story clear. In the latest revival of that tuneful work by The Bostonians, the abduction of the child was as devoid of illusion as ever.
-- The Hudson County Board of Elections yesterday issued certificates of registration to 153 persons who were unable to register on the days designated for that purpose.

HURON, S.D., Oct. 31. -- The heaviest snowstorm experienced in October since 1880 prevailed here and over the entire State yesterday and last night, with ten inches of snow on the ground. Fortunately the weather is not cold, but should it become severe, cattle on the ranges will seriously suffer. Railroading and telegraphing are somewhat interrupted.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- The Presidential campaign in Pennsylvania has not been a particularly active one. Mr. Bryan has made speeches at Phildelphia and at Pittsburg, and also at some of the smaller towns in the Western part of the State. Senator Tillman, in the earlier part of the campaign, addressed a number of meetings in the Eastern part of the State, and Senator Stewart addressed a mass meeting at Philadelphia.

WILMINGTON, Del., Oct. 31. -- In addition to Presidential Electors, Delaware will vote for a Governor, a Congressman, (the State being entitled to but one Representative,) members of Constitutional Convention, and State Senators and Representatives.
The parade of yesterday recalls some of the political, industrial, and patriotic demonstrations that have made New-York famous for its processions.

A number of kites were floated over the route of the parade, and general views of the procession as seen from aloft were recorded by a camera lifted high over Broadway by a string of four kites sent up from the northwest corner of the roof of the Mutual Reserve Life Building. Pictures were taken at intervals of fifteen minutes during the greater part of the afternoon.

Women will have the privilege of voting for President this year in three Western States. These are in the Rocky Mountain region, and adjoin one another. They are Colorado, Wyoming, and Utah.

A ratification meeting of the Tammany Central Association was held last night in Cooper Union Hall. Henry D. Purroy made a speech denouncing the John C. Sheehan contingent and was loudly cheered. He said in part:

-- One of the most experienced librarians in the vicinity of New-York is Miss Emma Toedteberg of the Brooklyn Historical Society Library. Miss Toedteberg inherits a taste for books from her father, who was a connoisseur and collector. She selects and purchases all the books for the library, and has done so for more years than it would seem possible, considering her comparatively youthful appearance.
BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- The Addicks people in the Bay State Gas Company have all resigned and the Standard Oil interest, beaded by William Rockefeller, J.G. Moore, and H.H. Rogers, will control.

NEWPORT, Oct. 31. -- Miss Natalie Dresser, who is the guest of her cousin, Mrs. Louis B. MacCagg, is to sail for Europe at the close of next week to rejoin her sisters, who are making their horns in Paris.

WHEN a man tells you in conversation, or writes for publication, that the contemporary stage lacks cultivation, refinement, originality, and decency, and intimates that there was a time he knows of when things theatrical were much better, he is either old and very tired or young and lacking in knowledge of the subject upon which he expresses his opinion so bluntly.

Mrs. Johnson -- Now, Johnny, when the rector comes to call this afternoon he will ask you your name, and you must say, "John Johnson, Sir." And when he asks how old you are you must say, "Five years, Sir." Then when he asks if you know what will happen to you if you are not a good boy, you must say, "I'll go to the bad place, Sir." Now don't forget, Johnny.
LONDON, Oct. 31. -- The progress of the negotiations for the holding of a conference on the Turkish question, proposed to the powers by Prime Minister Salisbury, is favorable.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

CLUBMEN are still talking of the reception and dinner given at the University Club a few nights ago in honor of the distinguished foreign scholars and educators who recently came over to attend the sesqui-centennial anniversary of Princeton College, now Princeton University.

Almost every evening on Washington Street, near Clark, may be seen a group of young men busily engaged in discussing politics. They often grow quite excited, but always preserve good order and create no disturbance. They generally put in their appearance about 5 o'clock and continue to discuss politics until it grows so dark that they can no longer see to talk.

While witnessing the parade from the north end of the grand stand in Madison Square, Peter A. Sullivan of Portland, Me., was accidentally pushed off the stand to the sidewalk, a distance of 15 feet. He struck on his head and sustained a fracture of the skull. Ha was taken to Bellevue Hospital in an unconscious condition.

BOSTON, Oct. 31. -- "Old Glory" was hoisted to the top of the staff on the State House this morning just as the sunrise gun at Fort Warren boomed over the bay. It is not a new feature to have the Stars and Stripes float over the State House, but on this occasion, by order of Gov. Wolcott, a large new flag was thrown to the breeze in special significance of today.

ONSIEUR BONNAT'S wellearned reputation as a portrait painter rests on his success in catching at once the salient and the subtle characteristics of his sitter. The portrait of Mr. Hewitt, which we give this morning, is a reproduction of one by M. Bonnat.
"The Geisha" is still filling Daly's Theatre. -- "A Florida Enchantment" persists at Hoyt's.
Mrs. Wardman -- Your husband's canvass for the nomination was unsuccessful, I believe, dear?
The story of the parade would be incomplete without the impressions of paraders.

The competition of the parade and the holiday and the wonderfully fine weather had its effect upon the audience yesterday at the Academy of Music, but no visible effect upon the performance, which was very good indeed. It would have been perhaps more in the color of his enterprise if Col. Mapleson had put forward the "Trovatore" as the first work of his season.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 31. -- N.L. Miller, Secretary of the State Democratic Campaign Committee, gives the following as the campaign managers' estimate of the result of Tuesday next: Bryan and Sewall, 150,000; McKinley, 50,000; Bryan and Watson, 25,000; Palmer and Buckner, 5,000. Levering and Johnson insignificant.
The business men's parade, in behalf of sound money, in this city yesterday, broke the world's record as a civic demonstration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The report reaches Washington that the Democratic Committee, in Chicago, is to-day distributing a silver trust fund of about $1,000,000, to influence the floating vote in Illinois, Indiana, Kentucky, and Michigan. Arrangements are said to have been completed for the placing of this vast sum where it will do the most god.

CONCORD, N.H., Oct. 31. -- The political campaign in this State has been the quietest ever known in a Presidential year. By far the greater activity has been manifested by the Republicans. The disaffection among the Democratic leaders over the financial plank of the Chicago platform disheartened the rank and file, and in many places they did not keep up their organization.
The National Brotherhood of Surface Railroad Employes before adjourning their tenth annual convention held in this city last week, adopted a resolution pledging their support to McKinley and Hobart.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Chairman Babcock of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee to-day made public a final statement of the work of the campaign and its probable results. In the course of it he said that his committee had sent out to the different Congressional districts more than 25,000,000 copies of authentic documents to elucidate the pending questions of the campaign.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 31. -- Outdoor pleasure has continued throughout another week of fine weather. The chief incidents were the annual meeting of the Golf Club and the first run of the Ocean County Hounds. The meeting of the Lakewood Golf Club for the election of officers was held Monday evening at the residence of Jasper Lynch.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 31. -- Word was received in this city to-day of a series of outrages perpetrated by Bryan adherents at Lancaster, thirty miles south. The Republicans, in anticipation of flag day, had handsomely decorated their houses with lithographs of McKinley. About 10 o'clock last night a party of hoodlums started out on a mission of destruction.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 31. -- The campaigners in New-Jersey are at sea, and the result is more doubtful than it was a week ago. The silverites are now claiming the State, which is the campaign "bluff" of Col. E. Livingston Price, who is Chairman of the Popocrat Committee.

Richard Mansfield and his company will begin a four weeks' engagement at the Garden Theatre Nov. 23, the same night selected for the beginning of the regular season at Daly's and the Lyceum Theatres. If Mr. Mansfield wants a large representation of "first nighters" at his opening performance, his selection of a date is unfortunate.

Joseph Jacobs, B.A., of London, a distinguished Jewish scholar and writer, arrived yesterday on the steamer St. Louis. He is probably best known as an authority on folklore and anthropology. For a number of years he was the President of the British Folklore Association and editor of the journal of the association. He has published four volumes of fairy tales, edited a score of literary classics, and written several volumes of essays.

Of the many cotton presses which were in operation in New-Orleans sixty years ago, the two principal ones were the Levee Cotton Press and the Orleans Cotton Press. They were large and massive buildings, each occupying, like most of the others, a square of ground. The Levee Cotton Press was built in 1832 by a company bearing the same name at a cost of $500,000, and was two stories high.

August Falk, who worked on a Long Island farm during the Summer, visited Hoboken on Friday in search of employment. He met Peter Kruse, who invited him to drink, and afterward offered him a temporary home at 304 Park Avenue. He was given a bed on a sofa. Falk said he had $105 in a belt about his waist and $14 in one of his pockets.

The Presidential campaign really began in St. Louis, in the second week in June, in the strenuous and gallant struggle to plant the Republican Party and its candidate fairly on the maintenance of the gold standard. There were anxious hours in that brief and hot contest, when not merely the fortunes of the party, but the honor of the country, seemed to be trembling in the balance.

The adoption of the Australian "blanket" ballot has made it expedient, in the eyes of party managers, to open schools for the instruction of voters. At first blush, this would not seem necessary; but a glance at the ballot itself shows how complicated it is, and how easily it might be misunderstood in the hurry and confusion of voting.

TOPEKA, Kan., Oct. 31. -- The three headquarters of Democrats, Populists, and Republicans were practically closed to-night. The Democrats and Populists, who have fused on State, Electoral, and Congressional tickets, claim the State by not less than 20,000. The Republican managers issued a statement to-night in which the Electoral vote of Kansas is claimed for McKinley by 10,000 majority.

The head of the parade, with Assistant Chief of Police Cortright in the lead, turned from Waverley Place into Fifth Avenue at Washington Place, at 10:30 o'clock. A stand had been erected at this point by the Park Department, and each occupant was furnished with a small flag, and as the various platoons made the circuit into Fifth Avenue, they were greeted with cheers and waving of banners.

Yale's football team has again shown that it is nothing like as strong as the teams of former years, and that it will have to do some hard work to be any match for Princeton's team on the 21st. In the game at New-Haven against the Elizabeth Athletic Club team Yale had to play hard to avoid a defeat, and even then could not prevent the Elizabeth men from scoring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Col. Heywood, commanding the United States Marine Corps, has brought that essential arm of the force afloat to a high state of efficiency in spite of statutory limitations which dishearten good officers by the stagnation in promotion. According to Col. Hey wood's annual report to Secretary Herbert, Captains of marines do not reach the grade of Major until the average of sixty and after forty years of service.

Howard Gould, the owner of the racing yacht Niagara, arrived yesterday morning on the steamship St. Louis. The Niagara has been racing during the Summer in the British regattas, and, considering that she is now two years old, has made a remarkable record this year against the new boats, and has more than held her own.

Besides casting their ballots for thirty-six Presidential Electors, the voters of this city will on Tuesday also vote for a Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals, a Congressman in every Congressional district, a Coroner, which is the only county office to be filled, and an Assemblyman in each of the thirty-five Assembly districts of the city.

Louis J. Morrison of 44 Broadway has issued the circular in regard to Central Pacific Railroad interests which has been noticed in THE NEW-YORK TIMES. In addition to the statements already published, Mr. Morrison says to the stockholders, whom he advised to secure the foreclosure of the road by the Government:

OVER in Brooklyn for the past six months has been going on a most profitable work of destruction. All through the Summer and early Autumn workmen have been busy tearing down the Brooklyn factory of a watch company which has decided to do all its work hereafter at its other factory, in Sag Harbor, L.I.

OSCEOLA, Iowa, Oct. 31. -- When Mr. Bryan to-day saw the table published in the morning papers as the estimate of Chairman Hanna of the Republican National Committee, and was asked if he had anything to say as to its correctness, he made this answer:

Yachting rules are still the chief topic of conversation in the yacht clubs and until they are finally passed there will be little done in the way of ordering new boats. Yachtsmen want to fully understand the rules and restrictions before they give orders to build new boats.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 31. -- The bitterest political campaign ever waged in Kentucky closed to-night with excitement at wholesale.

It appears that sooner or later the patriotic societies may be called upon to place themselves on record with regard to the use of the devices of heraldry. There are members of the societies who think that armorial bearings have no proper place in a society which is supposed to keep alive the flame that typifies the spirit of '76.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- Out of the West there came to-day a newspaper correspondent who has served a prominent Western paper here with much care and who has acquired a well-earned reputation for sound judgment of political tendencies in various contests. He made calculations about the delegates to the Republican and Democratic Conventions of this year that were closer and earlier than those published by the managers of those parties.

Ex-Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn returned from Europe Friday evening, and yesterday he told some impressions of his travels and what he learned regarding European opinion of the coming election in this country.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Chairman Troup of the Democratic State Committee said to-day that, based on the figures submitted by the members of the State Committee at yesterday's meeting, McKinley had an apparent majority of 8,000 in the State.

VERY likely the world at large has forgotten that John Lockhart wrote verse, does not know that he wrote novels, dimly recalls that he was editor of a magazine, but can never forget that he was son-in-law to Sir Walter Scott and wrote a great biography.
He is a phlegmatic man who in the financial world has not this week been enthusiastic. Extraordinary conditions have had extraordinary sequels.

It would be a public misfortune and a disgrace to the city and the State if FRANKLIN BARTLETT should fail of election in the Seventh Congressional District, including Staten Island and Lower New-York. He is a candidate for whom Democrats and Republicans alike can vote with unmixed satisfaction.

CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 31. -- With many a ringing cheer and many a stirring air from two-score bands, the last great day of the campaign at the home of the Republican candidate came to an end. Senator-elect Foraker contributed to the brilliant ending.

It was admitted on all sides that much of the success of the parade was due to the very complete and comprehensive arrangements made by Chief Conlin for giving the procession a clear passage through the streets and preserving order along the route, and the admirable manner in which his orders were obeyed.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 31. -- Never in the history of a political campaign in this city was there so much enthusiasm as to-day. Flags were flying from at least 3,000 buildings, public and private, and Republicans and sound-money Democrats vied with each other as to which should make the best displays.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Oct. 31. -- The campaign in Wyoming has been a rather quiet one. The Democrats have not been very aggressive, for two reasons. They have considered the State would naturally be for free silver, and they have had a limited amount of money for campaign purposes.

Harry Furness, the noted English artist, was the guest of honor last night at a smoker of the Illustrators' Club, 95 Fifth Avenue. The guest of the evening arrived late, and explained to the members of the club that he had been waiting at his room in the Holland House to see the end of the longest parade on earth go by.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 31. -- The soundmoney non-partisan parade this afternoon was the largest political procession ever held in this city, exceeding by thousands any public demonstration ever held here since Battle Flag Day, Sept. 17, 1879, when Connecticut's war flags found a final resting place in the Capitol.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The Executive Board of the Southwestern Traffic Association convened in St. Louis yesterday at the association rooms in the Union Trust Building. The Mexican lines were represented during the discussion of Mexican matters.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Chairman Tyler of the McKinley forces, an old campaigner, claims that the State will give a plurality for McKinley of nearly 40,000, and 25,000 to 30,000 for the State ticket, headed by Lieut. Gov. Cooke. He also claims a solid Senate, 24 members, and 200 of the 252 members of the House of Representatives.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

GENEVA, Ind., Oct. 31. -- The Empire magazine, situated half a mile west and north of this city, exploded at 3:45 A.M. to-day. Seven hundred quarts of nitro-glycerine, which were stored there, tore the magazine to atoms and wrecked scores of houses in this city.

The parade dismissed, there was a dash for refreshment and sustenance, but in the neighborhood of Forty-second Street the first comers had disposed of nearly everything that was salable and every saloon keeper and druggist had blessed the demonstration.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 31. -- Fully 5,000 people witnessed the West Point-Yale football game this afternoon, the largest crowd that ever attended a similar game here. Every town and city on both sides of the Hudson River furnished its quota. Special trains were run from NewYork City and Newburg. The day was a veritable Summer one, and was a great delight to the hundreds of ladies in attendance.

The returns made to President John A. McCall by the correspondents of the New-York Life Insurance Company in all the States were tabulated yesterday. They show the estimates of 52,693 persons, indicating the correspondents' opinions as to, the Electoral result in the States in which they are situated.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31. -- Good time and distance were made in all of Yale's track games this afternoon. R.M. Graff, a freshman from Pittsburg, Penn., with two yards' handicap, made the best time of the day, covering the 100 yards in 0:9 4-5. The relay race, won by the seniors, was the most fiercely contested of any of the events of the day.

LONDON, Oct. 31. -- Nothing could more forcibly illustrate the anxious and even frightened state the nations of Europe are in than the prodigious fuss which has been made this week and is still making over Bismarck's disclosure that from 1884 to 1890 he was dealing with Russia behind the back of his partners in the Triple Alliance.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 31. -- At Mount Sterling this afternoon there was rioting between the advocates of gold and silver. Negro drummer boys were knocked senseless and their instruments smashed. James Biggers, a Bryan man, was stabbed several times in the back and side, dying to-night.

Despite the fact that the Court of Appeals handed down a decision that John F. Fallon was to be reinstated Warden of the Tombs, and as a result was placed in charge of that institution last Friday afternoon upon the order of Commissioner Robert Wright of the Department of Correction, Warden John E. Van De Carr, Commissioner Wright's personal friend and appointee, is again practically in charge of the prison.
Mr. W.L. Bull of Edward Sweet Co. and ex-President of the New-York Stock Exchange, said yesterday, in talking of the outlook for the stock market:
Broadway, Exchange Place, and New Street, for a twelve-story brick and stone office building, by William Waldorf Astor of 21 West Twenty-sixth Street, owner; cost not yet estimated.
In spite of the counter attractions of the great parade in the city and sports of all kinds in progress near to town, there was a good crowd at the Morris Park track yesterday to enjoy the racing.
The money market was quiet. Call loans were made at 10 per cent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- Chairman Hanna gave out his final estimate of the Electoral vote this afternoon. He claims McKinley will have not less than 311 Electoral votes. He bases his estimate on reports received from State Committeemen and from careful polls just completed. The vote by States will be as follows, according to Hanna's information:

The gap between gold and silver will be closed, and therefore a silver dollar and a gold dollar will be of the same value, whether melted or coined here or anywhere in the world. -- [Mr. BRYAN, Oct. 30.]
Gold amounting to $2,037,950 came into this port yesterday. This makes the imports since Jan. 1 last about $75,000,000. The exports were about $51,000,000.

The banking, brokerage, and mercantile district was in a whirl of enthusiasm and patriotic excitement yesterday. The hurly-burly incident to preparations for the big parade began almost at dawn, and did not end until late in the afternoon.
No safer barometer of the general trade conditions of the country can be had than the outlook in the wholesale dry goods markets.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. -- The War Department to-day made public the sentence of the court-martial in the case of Capt. Charles G. Ayres, Tenth Cavalry, and the action of the President in the matter.

For several months past experiments have been conducted at the American Wheelock Engine Company's works in South Worcester upon an air motor adapted to use upon hackney carriages, heavy wagons, and private vehicles. These experiments and the work upon the motors have been carried on entirely independently of that on the compressed-air street-car motors now building there for the Metropolitan Traction Company of New-York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31. -- The abandonment by both parties of the parades which were to have been held here this evening is a subject of general congratulation, for in the present state of political feeling in Chicago, rival processions marching over almost the same routes would surely have provoked a riot.

The effect of BISMARCK'S disclosure of the secret treaty between Russia and Germany has been that which might have been expected and which its author no doubt intended it to produce. It is not necessary to attribute to him on this occasion a cynical or a mischievous intention.

Suggestions for a new TIMES motto or phrase continue to pour into the publication office of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. Enough suggestions have been received up to date to fill several newspapers, but the winner of the one-hundred-dollar prize has not yet been selected.

It was exactly 10:55 o'clock when Gen. Porter, preceded by the mounted police escort, reached the reviewing stand. Gen. Porter saluted the Governor gallantly, and passed on, followed by his aides on their prancing steeds.

MAMARONECK, Oct. 31. -- Dr. A.J. Mixsell, one of the Coroners of Westchester County and a candidate for re-election on the National Democratic ticket, was killed by a train on the New-Haven Railroad at Mamaroneck this morning. The Coroner attempted to cross the tracks to catch a train for New-York City, where he intended to do some business and to see the sound-money parade, when, he was struck by the Naugatuck express.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31. -- Local stocks were strong and prices advanced all around. The feature of the session was Pennsylvania Steel stocks, the common advancing from 30 to 35, and the preferred from 58 1/2 to 62 1/2. There was very little doing in the traction stocks, and the close was at advances of 1/4 per cent, generally.

To-morrow night what has been the Music Hall of Olympia wall become the Auditorium. Edward E. Rice will there present his "Evangeline-Up-to-Date." All the puns of 1874 have been eliminated. The aerial ballet has been amalgamated with the burlesque. The principal performers will be Henry Dixey, Theresa Vaughn, Violet Potter, Cheridah Simpson, George K. Fortescue, Frederick Solomon, Charles Bigelow, and Yvonne La Guerre.

The rainfall in this locality thus far, during the year 1896, has been excessive, and when it is remembered how near to the verge of actual exhaustion of its water supply this city came in 1895, a rainy season can be better appreciated. If each of the succeeding years in the next decade could be guaranteed to furnish as much rainfall, there would be less reason for anxiety as to the water supply.

It was not only on Broadway and Fifth Avenue and along the line of the big parade that New-York blazed with color yesterday. Chairman Mark A. Hanna's genial and diplomatic invitation to celebrate the day as Flag Day was almost universally accented, and every street had its own display.

Patrons of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have this year contributed more generously to its great collection than at any other time during its history. Their gifts have wrought a great change in the picture galleries, which are now crowded with works of the great masters, while other departments of the museum have also received many contributions.

From The Lewiston (Me.) Journal. Thursday night Dr. Foster of Lisbon sent for Dr. Alonzo Garcelon of Lewiston to assist him in a consultation at Bowdoin Corner. After the consultation, Dr. Garcelon started to drive home, fifteen miles, by way of Webster Corner, as he had gone by way of "Dead Man's Road," as it is called, and had found that it was muddy.
The Rev. Dr. James M. King, at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, said in the course of his sermon:
To-morrow will be Election Day. The polls in all the election districts will be open for voting from 6 o'clock in the morning until 5 o'clock in the afternoon.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 1. -- Jacob J. Johnson died at his home in this city last night. For sixteen years he had been unable to walk, on account of a spinal injury received in the war.

From The Little Rock (Ark.) Gazette. The Hot Springs News contains the draft of a bill prepared by Senator Kimbell, which will be introduced by that gentleman in the next Legislature, providing a State banking law. As The News remarks, "A safe and equitable banking law would not only foster and encourage legitimate banking in the State, but would afford legitimate protection to the patrons of these institutions.
Adolph Ketchum, a well-known Brooklyn clothing merchant, died yesterday, at his home, 892 Union Street, of paralysis and injuries sustained by being run over by a trolley car.

Minnie Geagles, twenty-seven years old, who claimed to live at Sixth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, was in Yorkville Court yesterday on a charge of grand larceny, preferred by Charles Leinesch of 740 Ninth Avenue.

From The Washington Star. It is announced that the District is enabled to complete the Stevens School, left unfinished by the contractor, because the contract price was $6,000 below the appropriation. The moral to be drawn from this fact is striking. The default of the contractor was probably due in large measure to his undertaking to do the work at too low a price.

BERLIN, Nov. 1. -- The conference which Chancellor Prince Hohenlohe had with the Emperor yesterday is understood to have had reference to a projected conference of the European powers with the object of revising the treaties of Berlin and Paris, and also a settlement of the customs dispute which has for some time existed between Russia and Germany.
There will be an election in every State to-morrow, all voting for Presidential Electors and Congressmen. Nearly all will vote for Governor or minor State officers.

-- Many Harvard students assert that they were insulted and ridiculed by some of the registration officials when they went to put their names on the list of voters, and that this treatment was prompted not only by a prejudice which has always been shown by Cambridge people against Harvard students, but also by a political prejudice based upon the fact that Harvard College is overwhelmingly for sound money and McKINLEY.
There is one sure and safe guide for every voter to-morrow: Vote for no man who will not support sound money or who is afraid to say that he will.

From The London News. Why the wisdom of America calls old stories "chestnuts" is a disputed problem, which we cannot pretend to solve. Meanwhile a writer in The Atlantic Monthly remarks that, practically, all stories are old stories. He knew a cosmopolitan barber, a Podolian, or Volhynian Jew, from the officina gentium in Eastern Europe, and this man was famous for his narratives.

From The London Daily News. Dr. Wynn Westcott, Coroner, held an inquiry at the Shoreditch Coroner's Court yesterday respecting the death of Jessie Shirley, aged nine months, who died suddenly at 12 Turner's Place, Hoxton. Louisa Mercer said that she had had charge of the deceased for thirteen weeks.

From The Rochester Herald. Mayor Warner having signed the new contract with the Myers Ballot Machine Company, no further legal impediment remains to the use of the voting machines in this city next Tuesday.
The following table shows the changes in the principal stocks for the week, the comparison being with the final prices of Saturday, Oct. 24:

In thirty-four conspicuous stocks there were net changes last week of 1 per cent. and over. Of these thirty-Four changes three were declines. Thirty-one were advances. The three that fell were industrial stocks, dealt in but slightly. Every active industrial went up. In the railway share list not a single important stock declined.

The constitutional amendment which will be voted upon to-morrow has for its object the despoiling of the Adirondack forests. The proposed amendment is meeting with almost condemnation from the press and public throughout the State. It is denounced as a plot, engineered by a few men to gain valuable concessions from the State and at the same time rob the public of the beautiful and healthful forests in the Adirondack Mountains.

The Sultan is apparently getting ready for another massacre and one on a greater scale than any he has yet attempted. This is the conviction of the foreign Ambassadors, as is manifest in a note of rather unusual severity, and it accords with all the information from Constantinople.
The Rev. Morgan Dix, rector of Trinity Church, for the first time in very many years, yesterday referred to politics in his pulpit He said:

HAVANA, Nov. 1. -- Consul General Lee sailed to-day for New-York on board the Ward Line steamer Vigilancia. Captain General Weyler sent an Adjutant aboard the steamer to bid him adieu. A number of Gen. Lee's personal friends also went on board the steamer to see him off.

To divert attention from Tammany Hall, agents in various trades and labor unions who have tried to induce the members to vote for Mr. Bryan, the assertion has been made that employes had been coerced into marching in the great parade of Saturday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- Silverites armed with rifles, clubs, canes, and carrying cobble-stones, bricks, and bags containing pepper and lampblack, terrorized residents and pedestrians of aristocratic Ashland Boulevard from Adams to Congress Streets, last night.

There was little betting yesterday. The places where politicians usually gather were practically deserted. It was commonly remarked that it was the dullest Sunday previous to a National election. John Mathews was around with money to bet on Bryan, if he found odds of 4 to 1. He found many at 3 to 1, taut would not take it.

From The Evening Post. Under the present Constitution there can be no alienation of any part of these lands. That is what the people wanted when they put the forest clause in the Constitution. That is what they want now and ought to insist upon. If any desirable lands inside the preserve belonging to private owners are offered for sale at reasonable prices, the State ought to acquire them and pay good money for them.

LONDON, Nov. 1. -- The Standard will to-morrow publish a dispatch from Madrid saying that the loan to be made to the Government by Spanish bankers, announcement of which was made to the Cabinet on Thursday last, amounts to 40O,000,000 pesetas, (about $80,000,000,) nominal, redeemable in eight years, and bearing 5 per cent, interest.

From The London Shipping World. The European press, and among them we are sorry to see many English papers, have affected to laugh at the idea of American warships forcing the Dardanelles. Ignoring for the moment the political aspect of the question, we would ask: Have not those who scoff lost sight of the fact that the American Navy is daily becoming a greater power than they care to acknowledge?

Competitors for the prize of $100, offered by THE NEW-YORK TIMES for a new motto, multiply as the date of the award draws near. Many of the suggestions apply to special as well as general characteristics of THE TIMES. Others paraphrase the present popular motto, "All the news that's fit to print," which nightly attracts the multitudes who pass under the great illuminated sign of THE TIMES Madison Square.

From The Boston Republic. We published in last week's Republic an able and interesting letter which Mr. J. D. O'Connell of the statistical department of the United States Treasury wrote to President Eliot of Harvard College, touching some errors and omissions which that gentleman made in a recent paper contributed to the October Atlantic Monthly.

CANTON, Nov. 1. -- Major McKinley is serene and confident to-night- The expectation of victory proves a wonderful tonic and restorative. The last week of the campaign was in some ways the hardest of his many weeks of arduous work.

PANAMA, Oct. 25. -- M. Belin, the new local representative of the canal company in the Isthmus, arrived by the French steamer St. Laurent, to occupy the position of Director General of the administration of the new canal company. M. Belin is well known in the Isthmus, having held for several years an important position in the former administration of the old canal company, and rendered it very important services.

Richard W. Bier, a noted miniature and tapestry artist, died at Flower Hospital last Friday night, the result of an accident. Mr. Bier left his home, 114 West One Hundred and Second Street, on Friday morning, at 8 o'clock, for a spin on his bicycle, his wonted custom. When he reached Madison Avenue, at Forty-sixth Street, he turned to one side to avoid a man who had alighted from a car.
The Rev. Dr. William Lioyd, pastor of the Central Congregational Church, in the course of his sermon, said:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: As this contest progresses it becomes painfully apparent that those who send in mottoes are blinded by the $100, and are not giving thoughtful attention to the conditions to be met.

The Rev. Thomas Dixon, Jr., when he reached this city from Virginia yesterday morning, learned, that he was accused of registering as a voter from the Ashland House, where he has not occupied or rented a room for more than a year.

A fourteen-year-old girl found intoxicated on the streets and a sixteen-year-old boy whose father complained that he was a habitual drunkard were among the prisoners arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday.

From The Toronto Monetary Times. A Year Book of Mining is to be compiled for the Province of British Columbia. Owing to the increasing attention being directed to British Columbia, and the rapidly growing interest in its mineral and other resources, there is likely to be much demand for such a volume.

One of the grounds on which the decision of the Court of Appeals in the Albany Police Board case was based was a violation by the act providing for the appointment of the Commissioners of "the principle of local self-government," which Judge O'BRIEN said in his opinion "has always been regarded as fundamental in our political institutions, and to be the very essence of every republican form of government."

CHICAGO, Nov. 1. -- The following warning, addressed "To the Voters of the United States," was issued to-day by George F. Washburn, Chairman of the Chicago branch People's Party National Execcutive Committee:
The appeal to the Democrats of the State of New-York in behalf of the cause represented by Palmer and Buckner and Griffin and Hinrichs is, in full, as follows:
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 1. -- Cardinal Gibbons touched upon the political situation in his sermon at the Cathedral this morning.

A Chinese educational institute was informally opened under the auspices of the American Chinese Association, by the President of that society. Mrs. E.B.H. St. John, at 35 West One Hundred and Twentyfifth Street, yesterday afternoon. The object of the institute is the propagation of education and Christianity among the Chinese of this city, among whom Mrs. St. John has long been an enthusiastic mission worker.

Nearly 2,000 persons crowded into the Murray Hill Lyceum last evening to hear the Rev. Henry Frank talk about "Drifting Toward Monarchy." Last week Sunday he spoke at Worth's Theatre and attacked the clergy for the part they are taking in the interest of sound money.
Silver bullion certificates quoted on the Stock Exchange at 65 1/4 @65 1/2. Sales of 146,000 ounces made during the week at 65@ 65 3/4, with the last sale at 65 1/2, a decline of 1/8.
Prof. Felix Adler yesterday morning, in Carnegie Hall, discussed political and kindred problems before a large audience.

Augustus Schrader, the so-called "divine healer," gave his first public exhibition at Sailer's Park, Bayonne, yesterday afternoon, and applied his "divine" treatment to the lame, the halt, and the blind. Not one of the persons treated gave any indication of having been cured, but several said they felt better.

PARIS, Nov. 1. -- The Seine has been rising for some days, and has now reached a point that is causing much alarm. Low-lying structures along its banks have been flooded, and much damage has been done above and below the city. The river is so full of floating debris that traffic upon it has been stopped.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, showed an increase in reserve of $2,502,325. The banks now hold $17,463,225 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show a decrease in loans of $3,869,100, an increase in specie of $2,545,800, a decrease in legal tender of $552,700, a decrease in deposits of $2,036,900, and a decrease in circulation of $14,800.

PROVIDENCE, Oct. 31. -- The local market continues extremely dull. There is some inquiry for the better class of investments, but those who have these securities for sale are inclined to await the result of the election before talking trade. There is little doing in the local money market.
From The Philadelphia Ledger. The law of Pennsylvania forbids political parades in the ten days before election.

Murphy yesterday, who complains that Capt. O'Brien is persecuting him on account of his past record. Murphy was arrested by Central Office Detective Rataone, who charged him with being a suspicious person.

From The Little Rock (Ark.) Gazette. What can Mr. McKinley do for the relief of the country? Nothing. What does he propose to do? Nothing. Mr. McKinley's election means simply a repetition of the business horrors of the Cleveland Administration. That and nothing more.
Cyclists wishing to Join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

Edward H. Sothern, the actor, and Virginia Harned, who is temporarily playing the leading woman's part in "An Enemy to the King" at the Lyceum Theatre, are to be married early next Summer. Their engagement, Mr. Sothern says, has lasted several years.
A rhyming mania has seized the freesliver advocates out West. One newspaper printed a page of these rhymes, some of which are very funny.

PITTSBURG, Oct. 31, -- The last week has been given up mainly to political campaigning, a large number of brokers and active business men being members of clubs, which have been doing active work for sound money. Hence the stock market has been neglected. It is noticeable, however, that despite the dullness, nearly everything on the usually active list is higher than at any time this month.

There is an institution in Paris unique in its functions, the Observatoire de Montsouris, the Municipal Hygienic Observatory of Paris. This institution is so little known outside of France, or, one might say, of Paris, and it is of such great practical importance that a little account of its work will certainly interest a wide circle of readers.

"Bother your silver arguments, and don't talk gold to me," said John Franz, the other day, as he rushed to the desk of his hotel in Fourth Avenue and took from a secret drawer a musty purse, with which he returned to half a dozen friends who were sitting in the Summer garden.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 1. -- The Silverites have made pretentious claims of carrying the State, and the distinguished Mr. Henry George went to the trouble to tell the Eastern people that Bryan would have 30,000 majority here. Among his reckless statements was one to the effect that there was a Bryan club in Council Bluffs numbering 500, all of whom were formerly Republicans.

The five silver States -- Colorado, Nevada, Idaho, Montana, and Utah-have as much power in the Senate as the five greatest States in the Union -- New-York, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Illinois -- and they are going to use it to bring about the restoration of free silver. -- [The Salt Lake (Utah) Herald.]

Dwight Braman, who was on Oct. 16 appointed by Judge Wales of the United States Circuit Court for the District of Delaware one of the temporary receivers for the Bay State Gas Company, arrived in this city from Wilmington, Del., last evening. He is at the Cambridge, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, where he made the following statement:

Our opponents have, even gone into religion and have appealed to missionary societies and to church boards, and told them that the free coinage of silver would lessen the value of their investments. -- [Mr. BRYAN at Ottumwa, Iowa, Oct. 31.]

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 1. -- Joseph P. Smith, one of Major McKinley's secretaries during the campaign, has compiled the following table of estimated pluralities of the popular vote for President. These estimates, furnished by prominent Republicans in the several States, are as follows:

All the postal clerks and carriers of the Jersey City Post Office were working at high-pressure speed yesterday in getting off the 70,000 pieces of election mail matter deposited at the office on Thursday last.

Gen. Horace Porter received a number of congratulatory messages yesterday upon the success of Saturday's great sound-money parade. Gen. Porter says that he believes that there were fully 125,000 men in line, and that for the first two hours they marched at the rate of 16,000 per hour. A large number of the older men who started to march, the General said, became tired of the delay and dropped out before reaching the reviewing stand.

The Rev. Dr. William N. Dunnell, in a robe of white, his head crowned with the line dignity of silvery locks, and his face expressing a happy thankfulness, was a striking figure as he faced his parishioners yesterday in all All Saint's Church and acknowledged their remembrance of the twenty-fifth anniversary of his rectorship.

When one sees the programme of an opera concert that begins with the overture to "Semiramide" he knows what to expect. He would have been a very ungrateful hearer who did not admit at the first opera concert of the Mapleson troupe last night that his reasonable expectations were more than fulfilled.

The Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company of Brooklyn is trying to encircle the City Hall with a trolley track following the lines of the pavement around from Fulton to Court Streets, and all day yesterday and the night before, a gang of workmen was at the work.
The Republican Party does not believe in the saving grace of low prices. -- [Congressman LEMUEL ELY QUIGG'S letter to his constituents.]
Ex-Gov. R.P. Flower will be in Wall Street again on Wednesday, back from campaigning in the West, and ready for business activity.

George Wilson, the Secretary of the Chamber of Commerce, is occasionally reminiscent. The other day he was recalling, in the company of a few friends, some of the peculiar business signs that he had seen in this town. Somebody mentioned the familiar old signs: "Ketchum Kissam," "Adam Happy, Tailor," and "Slamm, Bang Co.," whereupon Mr. Wilson said:

To the Editor of The New-York Times: It is wonderful how slow Bryanites are in comprehending that the introduction of the proposed 16 ts 1 free-coinage silver dollar, without our Government guaranteeing the stamped value thereon, will result in loss to every one, and especially to savings bank depositors.
Messrs. Tilghman, Rowland Co. say regarding the outlook:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 1. -- Joseph Kline of First Avenue and East Thirty-second Street, John Crosby of 352 East Thirty-second Street, Michael Murphy of 340 East Thirty-fourth Street, and Daniel Sullivan of 305 East Thirty-second Street, all of New-York, are held at the Harrison Police Station awaiting the arrival of their parents.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst preached yesterday morning to a congregation that completely taxed the capacity of the Madison Square Presbyterian Church. The sermon was on the duty of citizens tomorrow.
In a fight between two Italians, at 102 Mott Street last night, Gilastrini Guari was stabbed in the neck by Oti Cardinale, with whom he has boarded for the last five years.

Dora Clark, who was arrested two weeks ago as a disorderly person, because, she says, the Nineteenth Precinct Police persecute her, and had as her witness Stephen Crane, the novelist, was in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning, charged with disorderly conduct. With her, on the same charge, was a woman who said she was May Kane.

A shooting and stabbing affray yesterday afternoon in a Raines law hotel at 663 First Avenue, kept by Thomas Kilgannon, was the result of John Larkin's failure to get into the Kip Bay Club in the hotel. Larkin is a laborer, and lives at 217 East Thirty-eighth Street. The Kip Bays are a jolly, social lot, and didn't like Larkin's presence, and told him so plainly, when he knocked at the door at 12:30 o'clock.

Miss Julia Jay, daughter of Col. William Jay, who was brought home in a special coach on Friday from the Garden City Hotel, suffering with typhoid fever, is still in a precarious condition at her home, 22 East Seventy-second Street.

In formation was received yesterday at the headquarters of the National Democrats from some Southern and Southwestern States, that is of a highly encouraging character. The best reports were from Maryland, West Virginia, North Carolina, and Missouri.

The Constitution says: "The Congress shall have power * * * to coin money, regulate the value thereof, and of foreign coin, and fix the standard of weights and measures." Also, "No State shall * * * coin money, emit bills of credit, make anything but gold or silver coin a tender for payment of debts."
Mrs. Clara Foltz of 533 Temple Court ap- peared in Centre Street Police Court yes- terday before Magistrate Simms as attor- ney for Thomas O'Connor, who is wanted by the New-Jersey authorities.

Alfred Henry Mason, Secretary of the New-York College of Pharmacy, died at his residence, 749 West End Avenue, yesterday. He was fifty-three years old and a native of England. After serving an apprenticeship to a pharmacist in England he went to Canada in 1884. Soon after he was appointed chief analyist of the Dominion of Canada.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The meteorological forecasters are most uncertain about the conditions which will prevail in the doubtful States of the Middle West to-morrow. Recognizing the great importance upon the elections' result of a snowstorm, sunshine, and good roads, special efforts have been made by the Weather Bureau to foretell accurately the conditions.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

ALBANY, Nov. 2. -- In the matter of the petition of John C. Lester to the Attorney General to institute proceedings to annul the charters of the Willlamsburg Gaslight Company, Fulton Municipal Gas Company, Nassau Gaslight Company, People's Gaslight Company, Metropolitan Gaslight Company, Citizens' Gas Company, the Brooklyn Gaslight Company, and the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, the Attorney General has granted permission for actions to be brought against the first seven named companies.

Sorosis held her second regular monthly meeting of the season yesterday. As usual she lunched sumptuously, was introduced in a body to her distinguished guests, and then settled down for an hour of music before the work of the day.
The authorities on the Jersey shore have taken many precautions against fraudulent voting to-day, and they declare that the election will be as free from fraud as possible.

Six members of the Building Departmen were engaged most of the day yesterday in superintending the tearing down of a new unfinished building at 508 and 510 Broome Street, that had become dangerously out of plumb. The east wall leaned twelve inches.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 2. -- The Harvard eleven was so battered up again in the game with the Indians that in its present condition it is almost a certainty that Princeton will get Saturday's game in Soldiers' Field.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 2. -- John Krause and Joseph Daniel were lodged in jail to-day charged with atrocious assault and battery, with intent to kill, upon John Terhune, cashier of the First National Bank of Long Branch. The cashier was shot by the two men, whom he caught poaching yesterday afternoon, and his thick overcoat saved him from being fatally injured.

President Eames's gavel fell and the gong clanged at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, closing business at the Stock Exchange until to-morrow. There was silence for just one instant, then a roar of jubilation from 500 stock brokers and as many spectators, who, for half an hour, bad packed the galleries.

George Foster Peabody, the New-York member of the National Committee of the National Democrats, and who has had charge of the campaign in the Western States, last night issued a review of the situation, in which he said:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The President will receive news on election night at the White House, through the dispatches of The United Associated Presses and the Western Union Telegraph Company, supplemented by private advices from friends.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Nothing important materialized in the wheat market during the morning. Scalpers evened up considerably, and some buying to hold over election was noted. The strength continued throughout, prices moving upward gradually, but sagging a little when the visible supply announcement of 1,395,000 bushels increase was made. The reaction was but temporary, prices subsequently regaining all they had lost.

We insist upon the maintenance of the gold standard and of the parity therewith of every dollar issued by the Government, and are firmly opposed to the free and unlimited coinage of silver and to the compulsory purchase of silver bullion. But we denounce also the further maintenance of the present costly patchwork system of National paper currency as a constant source of injury and peril.

Chief Conlin and Acting Inspector Brooks yesterday arranged the police details for today. Every member of the force who is not on sick leave will be on duty, as it will require 2,784 men to police the polling places, the law requiring that there shall be two policemen at each place.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Eighty thousand dollars was to-day withdrawn from the SubTreasury on legal tenders of the 1890 and later issues and on gold certificates. The withdrawals were in amounts ranging from $50 to $1,000, and were solely for hoarding. People stood in line throughout the day, but many had currency of issues not redeemable at this branch.

The petition of John C. Lester set forth that the combination or absorption of the seven companies was not by bona fide purchase and sale, but was a scheme to evade the laws enacted against illegal combinations and monopolies and to advance the price of gas.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- Chairman Hanna went, to Cleveland to-night. He will vote in that city to-morow morning, and then take a train for Canton, where he will spend several hours with Major McKinley. Returning to Cleveland at 7 o'clock, he will take up his headquarters in the Union Club, where he will receive returns from the election.

The preliminary contest for the Lazarus Scholarship was begun yesterday, in the Studio Building, 51 West Tenth Street. The scholarship is open to any unmarried male citizen of the United States, and its income is $3,000 for three years, payable in quar- terly installments by the Treasurer of the Metropolitan Mueseum of Art.
TORONTO, Ontario, Nov. 2. -- A vault in the office of the Toronto University was entered by burglars Saturday night, and $3,000 in cash and checks stolen.

A driver yesterday morning backed his wagon diagonally across the sidewalk to a warehouse platform near the corner of Leonard Street and West Broadway. It did not take him long to finish his business, but he was in no hurry. Resting himself comfortably on a box, he entered into a discussion with the employes of the ware- house concerning the sound-money parade.
The polls will be open to-day from 6 A.M. until 5 P.M.

Robert Hilliard introduced to a New-York audience at the Garden Theatre last night "The Mummy," which is described as "a new and original farce." There was a fairly large audience, which gave to the company every advantage that patient attention and liberal applause can give. Considering the handicap Mr. Hilliard labored under of an unsuccessful production of the play in London, he should be satisfied with his reception, which was flattering enough.

It looks as if there might be a law suit between Daniel Frohman and E.H. Sotharn. At least, if Mr. Sothern does not make reparation something is going to happen, Mr. Frohman says. It is a remark- able case of a star running away with his own pictures. They are rather remarkable pictures, however, which is some excuse.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The President to-day pardoned Emil C. Knappe, convicted of embezzling the funds of the Chicopee National Bank of Springfield, Mass., and sentenced in 1894 to five years' imprisonment.

BRYAN himself and the Chicago platform have been the only forces of visible influence and effect at work on the freesilver side in the campaign. The managers and committeemen have simply wasted their time and funds. "We are not sure that they have driven away votes, but certainly they have gained none.

-- Nobody who read with any care the "last addresses" issued by the big and little Populo-Anarchistic managers could have failed to see that every one of these documents was simply a whining complaint that all the forces of intelligence, honesty, and success were united against the representatives of stupidity, disorder, and failure.

A boy, twenty-two months old, bearing the name of Anastasius Havemeyer Aldrich Lucas Langdon Bishop Nicholas died Nov. 1 in the Children's Hospital on Randall's Island of pneumonia. The following death notice was printed in the newspapers Monday morning:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- British Guiana newspapers, which reached the State Department to-day, disagree with the London Press over the Kaituma Railway episode, and advocate compliance with the Venezuelan remonstrance about the violation of the status quo.

There were the usual day-before-election scenes at Tammany Hall yesterday. The leaders of the various Assembly Districts drove up in carriages and obtained from Superintendent Robert Kelly the usual election equipment for each Assembly District. This includes specimen tickets, paraphernalia for booths to be elected within proper legal limits of the polling places, signs, banners, and so forth.

The laying of water pipes through Jersey City to Bayonne by the New-York and New-Jersey Water Company gave rise to two battles yesterday. The first was in the Chancery Court, when Chancellor McGill heard the application of Patrick Murray for an injunction forbidding the company to cross lands owned by him.
In the activity and buoyancy marking the close of the stock market on the eve of the election large influence has been exerted by great banking firms having intimate relations with Europe.

The new extravaganza with which the "regular" Winter season at the Casino began last night was by no means an instant success, for the first of its three divisions had nearly ended before any laughter or applause not obviously perfunctory was excited, but after that the audience took heart and began to treat the piece with a cordiality that soon approached moderately near to enthusiasm.

First of all, every citizen whose name is on the voting list should consider it a patriotic duty to cast his vote. Indifference or neglect at such an election as this are without excuse, and should be regarded as disgraceful. It matters not how sure one may feel about the result, every vote will tell in giving emphasis to the verdict and making it forever irreversible.

The meeting of the Executive Committee of the Good Roads Association of Brooklyn at 1,187 Bedford Avenue last evening gave additional evidence of the organization's prosperity. Nearly 200 new names were added to the list of members, 10O being from the Brooklyn Bicycle Club. By the end of next season President Angell said he felt confident the association would have 5,000 members.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 2. -- By gold and silver Democrats and Republicans Connecticut is conceded to McKinley. Chairman O.R. Fyler of the Republican State Central Committee to-night made his final claim before the election. It is: "McKinley will have about 34,000 majority, and Lorin A. Cooke, Republican, will have about the same majority for Governor.
Election returns will be displayed tonight upon THE TIMES'S great bulletin screens at Twenty-third Street and Fifth Avenue and upon the Printing House Square facade of THE TIMES Building.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 2. -- Notwithstanding that Chairman Blake of the Bryan and Sewall Committee, is claiming the State by 150,000 plurality over McKinley, silver leaders here say it will not exceed 25,000.
Bernard J. York, Chairman of the Democratic Campaign Committee of Kings County, declared yesterday that the county would give Mr. Bryan a plurality of 5,000.

A new operetta by Reginald De Koven and Harry B. Smith, called "The Mandarin," was produced in a showy manner at the Herald Square Theatre last evening. It was rapturously received by some part of a specially selected audience. A bulletin sent out late at night from the theatre announced that sixty members of the NewYork Athletic Club and twenty-five members of the Knickerbocker Club occupied orchestra, chairs.
PERTH AMBOY. N.J., Nov. 2. -- Major James T. Robertson, a Wall Street stock broker, was arrested yesterday by Game Warden James L. Tooker of this city.

This is the last day of the racing season this year in this State, and seven races will be run at Morris Park, including a steeplechase. Sport will begin at 1:30 o'clock, a half hour earlier than usual. Following are the entries for the day's sport:

LONDON, NOV. 2. -- The Clerkenwell Sessions, to which court the trial of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Castle of San Francisco upon a charge of shoplifting was assigned by Magistrate Newton of the Great Marlborough Street Police Court, opened to-day. The hearing of the case of the Castles was set down for Friday, Nov. 6.

The number of suggestions for a motto to be used in THE NEW-YORK TIMES'S electric sign on Madison Square was increased sev- eral hundred yesterday. Since the an- nouncement that the contest would close on Nov. 7, the postal cards bearing sugges- tions have been received in greater num- bers than ever.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2. -- The Weather Bureau has issued the following special bulletin for Tuesday: "Generally fair weather will prevail in the States of the Missouri Valley and in Colorado, Wyoming, and Kansas. Rain or snow will fall in Minnesota and Montana. In Iowa and Missouri rain will be followed by fair weather in central and west portions Tuesday.

There will be plenty of election day sports. The golf men have several tournaments on hand. At the St. Andrew's Club, at Yonkers, there will be a tournament for the club championship, the winner of which will receive the John Reid gold medal. There will be a tournament for the Governor's Cup at the Essex Country Club, at Orange.
The annual meeting of the Council of the New-York University was held yesterday afternoon, with President Charles Butler, a member of the council since 1836, in the chair.

"Both miners and operators of the Pitts- burg district," says The Coal Trade Jour- nal, in discussing the anthracite coal trade, "agree that the present condition of affairs cannot last long, and that some movement that will raise the price of mining and the selling price of coal is absolutely imperative to save the trade from complete demoraliza- tion.

LONDON, Nov. 2. -- In Mark Lane to-day wheat was quiet. The price of English wheat has not changed since Friday. Holders are firmer, however. Foreign wheat has advanced 6d., but corn is 6d. cheaper, the large new crop of that cereal in America having had a decided effect upon the opinions of traders.
The last pieces of the delayed mail of the Republican County Committee, held since last Thursday at the Jersey City Post Office, were delivered yesterday morning.
Monday's stock market active and buoyant. Election anticipations ruled. Steep money rates -- opening at 25 and rising to 96 per cent, before falling to 6 -- exerted slight influence.

Anna Arnstetn's anxiety to secure a husband made her complainant against Oscar Arnstein of 159 East Forty-ninth Street, who was arraigned in the Yorkville Court yesterday on a charge of larceny. When the woman, who was employed by Arnstein as a domestic, made known her desires, he said he could arrange matters to her satisfaction.

-- Dr. SLAUGHTER, the Single Tax candidate for Governor in Delaware, claims that his followers certainly hold the balance of power in that State, and just possibly are numerous enough to elect him, unless the two old parties have formed a secret coalition.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 2. -- Chairman Caren of the National Democratic State Committee and Chairman McConville of the Democratic State Committee will give no estimate of the election result in the State. Chairman. Kurtz of the Republican Committee lets his statement of Saturday night, in which he claimed the State for McKinley by 65,000 to 100,000, stand unamended.

OMAHA, Nov. 2. -- The last day of Mr. Bryan's campaign was one of the most exciting he has experienced. He started from his home early this morning and concluded his tour with three speeches in this city, the last one at midnight.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov.-2. -- The Rev. S. S. Yenovkian, an Armenian resident of this city, naturalized, with a wife and four minor children in Turkey, has received the following from Secretary Olney in answer to an inquiry which affected him:

We see no reason for questioning the accuracy of the account published in a London paper of the manner in which the new Spanish loan is to be expended. After hawking a new loan all over Europe in vain, the Spanish Government was compelled to fall back upon the Spanish banks, and from them it has managed to obtain an advance nominally of $80,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2. -- The Treasury official comparative statement of the receipts and expenditures for the fiscal year to date, and for October, was issued today. It shows the deficit for the first third of the current fiscal year to have been $32,885,000, or at the rate of $98,000,000 for the current year.

An exhibition of the Kindergarten work done during the Summer by the children in the vacation schools under the care of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor was opened yesterday in the rooms of the association in the United Charities Building, Twenty-second Street and Fourth Avenue.
