BALTIMORE, Nov. 2. -- The rumor that Bishop Keane is to be made coadjutor Archbishop of Baltimore with a right to succession is being widely circulated in Catholic circles, and is believed by many. It is certain that Cardinal Gibbons has practically taken charge of the Bishop's future.

The centre of the betting last night was the Hoffman House, and the crowd there was so dense that passage through it was the work of several quarters of an hour. Still, when the lights began to go out and the throng to disperse, "Joe" Ullman, the bookmaker, declared, wearily:

Henry Ayres, thirty years old, said to have been the son of wealthy parents, committed suicide yesterday morning in his room at 48 Clinton Place. Ayres first drank a dose of laudanum, but, the poison failing to take effect as soon as he desired, he severed an artery in his right wrist with a razor and bled to death.

EGG HARBOR CITY, N.J., Nov. 2. -- This section, which has so often within the last few years been swept by forest fires, was the scene of another fierce one to-day. The fire broke out about noontime, and is supposed to have resulted from the carelessness of workmen who were burning brush and allowed the fire which they were using to clear a piece of land to get away from them.

National Democrats who have been affiliated with the Honest Money League are earnestly combating the efforts of some of the officers of the organization in supporting L.E. Quigg for Congress in the Fourteenth District. The fallowing letter was sent yes- terday to a number of the voters in the dis- trict:

BOSTON, Nov. 2. -- The annual Harvard 'Varsity Fall handicap track games were held this afternoon on Holmes Field. The weather conditions were not of the best, and the track was pretty heavy. No specially good records were made except in the 120-yard high hurdle, which was won by G.G. Hubbard, 1900, who, owing 13 yards, beat out E.H. Clark, L.S., by a yard.

BATH, Me., Nov. 2. -- Arthur Sewall, Democratic candidate for Vice President, says he is as sure that William Jennings Bryan and himself will be elected at to-morrow's election as he is that the sun will rise. Like his meteoric associate on the ticket, he does not form that opinion from canvasses or the reports of the Campaign Committee Chairmen.

The Twenty-second Regiment, N.G.N. Y., is disturbed over the prospect that a part of the rank and file may go to Ludlow Street Jail. Major Richard Thurston, who has been for the past week adjudicating the matter of back dues, said last night that such would be the fate of delinquents who failed to pay according to agreement.

An air of cheerfulness pervaded the headquarters of the National Democrats yesterday. Encouraging reports from all the debatable States were received. In the afternoon there was a meeting of the Executive Committee, which was presided over by John De Witt Warner. After the business of the campaign was cleared up, reports from every county of the State were read which indicated a vote of 156,000 for the National and State ticket.
The money market was active. Call loans were made at 6@96 per cent. The last loan was made at 51 per cent.

An appropriate entertainment for election week is James A. Herne's drama of stalwart American character, "Shore Acres," which is now on view at the Harlem Opera House, with the author in his skillful and telling impersonation of Nathaniel Berry, the Maine farmer. The performance is as effective as ever, each pictorial detail being carefully ordered, in Mr. Herne's accustomed way.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 3. -- The State has in all probability gone Republican. It was given out at 9 o'clock to-night that Gov. Stone, who is a member of the Democratic National Committee, conceded the election of MeKinley. He was also reported to have conceded the State Republican, and to have acknowledged the election of eleven of the fifteen Republican candidates for Congress.

The St. Andrews Golf Club had one of the finest golfing days in its history yesterday. There has been no finer golf played on the links than in yesterday's club championship tournament. This is the most important St. Andrew's event of the year, and it is the ambition of every club member to hold the club championship at least once.

We expect to carry every single State in this Union. * * * Why, this man, [McKinley,] who used to boast that he looked like Napoleon, that man shudders to-day when he thinks that he was nominated on the anniversary of the battle of Waterloo. Not only that, but as he listens he can hear with ever-increasing distinctness the sound of the waves as they beat upon the lonely shores of St. Helena.

For the past thirty years there has been a party of inflation in the United States. Yesterday for the first time the people had a chance to vote Yes or No on the question: Will you have money worth less than its face in gold? Their answer, by a heavier vote, a larger number of States, a more overwhelming majority than have ever before been known in the history of the Republic, is No.

The vast assemblage that surged about the terminal of the Third Avenue elevated station adjoining the Court House in City Hall Park completely blocked the Park Rew thoroughfare at that point. Many persons who endeavored to force a passage through the dense gathering which had come to it standstill at that place, in order to get a better view of the bulletins, were repeatedly forced back and thrown against the "L" posts or steps.

PARIS, Nov. 3. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, M. Denys, Deputy for Cochin China, interpellated the Government, demanding to know what action France would take in defense of the Armenians. Continuing his remarks, he asked what the powers had done since 1880 in defense of a race whose sufferings were without a parallel in history.

From The San Francisco Chronicle. China has thrown down the gauntlet to the big coal miners of the Pacific coast, and to those of the United States, for that matter. The American bark Colorado, which arrived in port Aug. 27, brought a mixed sample cargo of anthracite and manufactured coal, mined and made in the Tonquin district.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 3. -- Chairman McMillan of the Republican State Committee claims Iowa for McKinley by $3,000 plurality and says it may go higher. He also claims the election of every Republican Congressman by from 3,500 plurality for Curtis in the Second District to 14,000 for Dolliver in the Tenth.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 3. -- McKinley has carried Kentucky by at least 20,000 votes, all of which come from the sound-money Democrats, and to whom alone credit for the victory is due.

TIMES OFFICE, Nov. 4. -- 4 A.M. William McKinley and Garret A. Hobart, the Republican candidates for President and Vice President of the United States, have been elected by a tremendous majority in the Electoral College and by an enormous plurality of the popular vote.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Rochester used the Myers ballot machines in the election to-day for the first time. Difficulty was experienced in many election districts from the catching of the knob on the exit doors, which delayed the voters from five to fiftyfive minutes. The vote of the city, however, was very heavy, and the voters had practically completed their work fully an hour before the close of the polls.

If applied to last night's celebration in the Tenderloin district, the word carnival would be inadequate to convey the least idea of its gayety. It was an open-air thanksgiving of thousands upon thousands of citizens welcoming a new era of prosperity.

The weather yesterday in the vicinity of Moristown, N.J., seemed to be particularly well adapted to golf, for seldom has a larger or more enthusiastic turnout of golfers been seen on the links of the Morris County Golf Club.

The Niantic Wheelmen's Club of Jersey City held a race meet on the Bayonne Boulevard, near Willow Haven Casino, yesterday afternoon. H.C. Rohlfs, the club's crack rider, won the majority of the events.

Madison Square was the concentrating point for an exulting, yelling, screaching, screaming mass of humanity long before 8 o'clock, intent on seeing the bulletins of THE NEW-YORK TIMES. It began to gather by 6 o'clock, coming from uptown, down-town, and the cross streets. At first it crowded the sidewalks in front of the Fifth Avenue Hotel and the borders of the park.

There was, of course, interest in the casting of ballots by many notables. Mayor William L. Strong and his son were saluted by all when they went to the polling place at 980 Sixth Avenue, of the Eighth Election District of the Twenty-ninth Assembly District, to vote. They were expeditious, and the Mayor facetiously charged one of the election officers with "coercion" when he asked him if he had done his duty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3. -- While forest flames circulated around the President's suburban residence at Woodley to-night, taxing the resources of the City Fire Department to an unusual extent, the President and his personal and Cabinet family sat in the private apartments at the White House and received the news of the election.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- Major McKinley voted at 9 o'clock. He was accompanied to the polling place by his brother, Abner. They walked from the Major's home to Precinct B, in the First Ward, and the candidate's vote was registered as No. 230. Quite a number of voters were around the polling place when Major McKinley entered the booth.

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- As an illustration of the great interest displayed hero in the Presidential election in the United States the fact may be cited that a large number of Americans and others gathered this evening at Effingham House. Arundel Street, Strand, where are situated the London offices of The United Associated Presses, for the purpose of obtaining the earliest possible information regarding the result.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 3. -- This evening a Bryan negro was being crowded by McKinley negroes, when Jake Craig, another Bryan negro, went to his relief. Another negro drew a knife and Craig drew his pistol, and a thousand men rushed in, and for two minutes a riot was imminent. Officials quelled the disturbance.

The following table shows the pluralities in the several counties of New-York of the Republican and Democratic candidates for Governor. The figures in the last column give votes cast for the National Democratic candidate:

A man who wished to make sure that an ailing child in a bed in an adjoining room kept covered through the night, and who before he went to sleep himself made a mental memorandum to the effect that he must not sleep without waking more than an hour or two, really fell into a very sound slumber.

From The Philadelphia Record. Street railway men, who are Inclined to ascribe all the ills from which they suffer to the introduction of electricity as a motive power on the car lines, have discovered new grounds for complaint about the hardships of the lives they lead. A conductor of the Columbia Avenue line put the case in a nutshell the other night, when he said: "Railroadin' ain't the softes' Job there is in the world.

The Irving Club football eleven of Brooklyn defeated the Rutgers College team on the Eastern Park fotball field yesterday afternoon by the score of 26 to 0. More than a thousand persons were in attendance and filling the east grand stand and both side lines. Among the spectators was a large Rutgers contingent, who cheered continually for the Jerseyites.
ST. PAUL. Minn., Nov. 3. -- Minnesota has given McKinley for President 40,000 plurality at least, and probably 50,000. He has a clear majority over all candidates.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

From The Milwaukee (Wis.) Sentinel. Among the 16,000 estates that have been acted upon by the Milwaukee County Court, perhaps there has net been one more singular than the will in which the testator unconsciously chronicled a "bull." After leaving the bulk of his property sensibly enough, he separated a piece of real estate from the rest with the expressed object of paying a political debt with it.

The Republicans have elected a sufficient number of Legislatures or parts of Legislatures that must choose Senators of the United States to assure them the power to reorganize that body on a political basis, and to utterly prevent, for the two years following March 3, 1897, the passage by the Senate of any financial measure not approved as sound or in agreement with the policy of the party.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 3. -- The State has gone for Bryan by 30,000 majority. Sound-money Democrats throughout the State voted for silver's champion. Democrats early in the evening claimed the State by 60,000. The figures were reduced little by little until but half that number was reached.

Mr. TILLMAN at Chicago appealed to the South and West to combine against the East. After the war that reunited the country there was no North and no South. In yesterday's election the coun- try repudiated TILLMAN's counsel of sec- tionalism, and now there is no North, no South, no East, no West, and the broad sun shines upon a Nation one in senti- ment and indivisible.

A great deal of attention was attracted in the down town district yesterday by a series of kites, which William A. Eddy, the Bayonne kite expert, sent up from the Postal Telegraph Building. The kites were five in number of varied colors, and supported a small camera, suspended below the kites.

Yesterday was the tenth and last day of the Westchester Racine Association's meeting and also the last day of the legitimate racing season in this State. A good card of seven races included the White Plains Handicap for two-year-olds, and the Morris Paris Handicap for three-year-olds was given. The weather was fine and a large crowd was in attendance.
TIMES OFFICE, Nov. 4. -- 4 A.M. McKinley carried New-York State by a plurality that broke all previous records. It is about 270,000.
It was cripple day at Bayonne, N.J., yesterday with August Schrader, the " divine healer."

LONDON, Nov. 3. -- The Right Rev. Frederick Richards Wynne, Protestant Bishop of Killaloe, dropped dead in the street in Dublin to-day. A dispatch from Dublin to the Central News says that Mrs. Wynne, the wife of the Bishop, was found dead in her bed an hour after her husband's death.

Mrs. Margaret Dorsey, wife of John W. Dorsey, Baltimore and Ohio foreman at Okonoko, West Va., twenty-six miles east of Cumberland, was killed in a singular way Sunday. She was walking along the track toward a moving west-bound freight train, and when directly opposite the engine the fireman threw off a lump of slate coal, which struck her on top of the head, crushing her skull.
BOSTON, Nov. 3 -- 11 P.M. -- The plurality for McKinley in Massachusetts is now estimated at 165,000. Bryan will probably get about 95,000 votes.

The members of the Country Club of Westchester opened the pigeon-shooting season with a series of shoots that lasted from early in the morning until dusk. Altogether nineteen events were decided, some were handicaps, some miss and out, and some at a given number of birds. The birds were a fast lot, and the shooting very good.

While the election closed all American markets, American securities were dealt in abroad as usual; and it has been a long time since such attention was given in "New-York to quotations at London. All the international banking houses had frequent cables, and the news that they gave was sought anxiously by every man having Wall Street interests.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- The indications are that Ohio has gone overwhelmingly Republican. From scattering returns received early it is thought that Major McKinley will carry the State by nearly as large a plurality as was given Gov. Bushnell last year. National Committeeman H.C. Payne estimates at a late hour that Ohio has gone Republican by at least 80,000.

A monster sea turtle, weighing 362 pounds was the most interesting object to be found on the water front yesterday. Turtles are very rarely found in Northern waters, and how this one managed to stray so far away from home is a mystery.
The Republicans have secured control of both branches of the Fifty-fifth Congress.

John Cashdollar, Joseph Bennett, Moses De Graft, William Anderson, Bernard Longner. and George Sterrett, all of whom are inmates of the Home for Destitute Blind, at Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Fourth Street, were arraigned before Magistrate Deuel in Harlem Court yesterday morning on the charge of illegal registration.

Although Mr. McKINLEY was nomi- nated as the foremost representative of high protective tariff legislation, and not because he had been a consistent and courageous advocate of honest mon- ey, our Republican friends must see that his election and the events imme- diately preceding it have laid what is known as McKinleyism on the shelf.

By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, John H. Rogan, referee, 13 East One Hundred and Twelfth Street, north side, 225 feet east of Fifth Avenue, 19 by 100.11, five-story brick flat. Due on judgment, $17,025.

This is the first prophecy by Mr. McKinley's friends of those must likely to compose his Cabinet officers. From now until March 4 speculation will be rife, and slates will, of course, repeatedly be made and broken, but until that time it will be impossible for any one to definitely know who will comprise the President-elect's political household.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 3. -- McKinley has carried Indiana, but the size of his plurality is not known yet. Returns are coming in slowly, and everywhere there are big Republican gains. The plurality for the Republican candidate will not be less than 20,000. This city will give between 9,000 and 10,000 for McKinley.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Nov. 3. -- The regular Republicans distinguished themselves today by knifing the Republican candidates in order to show their displeasure at the assumption of authority by the white Republicans. The city is carried for Democracy by 8,000 or 10,000 despite the fact that many Democrats voted for Republican Congressmen.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 3. -- As William J. Bryan sat in the public dining room of the Paxton House, Omaha, this morning, eating his breakfast in company with Mrs. Bryan, he did not look like a man with an anxious mind. He slept well last night after the fatigues of his final day of campaigning, and was up at 7 o'clock.

The Circuit Court in Columbus decided a case on Saturday involving the constitutionality of the collateral inheritance law and held that measure constitutional. This is directly contrary to the decision of the Supreme Court some months ago, declaring the direct inheritance law unconstitutional. The case was instituted by attorneys for the estate of the late Henry C. Noble, a brother of ex-Secretary of the Interior Noble.

From the London Times. Dr. G. Harris Morris, consulting chemist to the Country Brewers' Society, gave evidence at the second day's sitting of the Departmental Committee appointed by the Treasury to inquire into the subject of beer materials. He stated that, speaking generally, he knew of no brewing materials in use by brewers which he considered to be deleterious.

Returns from New-Jersey were complete enough at midnight to show that in the Legislature the Republican majority on joint ballot would be 43. Six out of eight Republican candidates for Congress were certainly elected. There was doubt in the Fourth District, between Pitney, (Rep.,) ind Cutler, (Dem.,) and in the Seventh, between McEwan, (Rep.,) and Young, (Dem.) Pitney's election is probable.

-- A missionary stationed at Mersine, Asia Minor, writes to The Augusta (Ga.) Herald a letter warmly eulogizing the late THOMAS R. GIBSON, for several years Amer- ican Consul at Beyroot. The writer declares that Mr. GIBSON'S honesty and courage were in marked and brilliant contrast with the qualities too often displayed by this country's minor representatives abroad.

-- Bostonian "Old Subscribers" are wor- ried because in that city both fire alarm and mail boxes are painted red. This con- fuses the Boston intellect, it seems, and people there are constantly calling out the fire engines when they only intend to mail an order for the latest treatise on "The Immorality of Greek Sculpture."

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 3. -- Arrangements were to-day perfected between the William Johnson Co., Limited, Steamship Company of Liverpool and the South Carolina and Georgia Railway Company, to establish a line of steamers between Charleston, Liverpool, and other foreign ports. The first ship of the line will arrive in Charleston Dec. 1, and within a few days thereafter will be cleared for Liverpool with cotton and a general cargo.
Frank S. Black, the Republican candidate, has been elected Governor by a plurality greater than was ever before given to a candidate for that office in New-York State.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 3 -- Returns received from all parts of the State at the office of The Times indicate a result in this State that has completely dazzled all the political prophets and prognosticators.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 3. -- The Democrats give up the fight. Chairman Peck of the Democratic State Committee said at midnight that the Republicans had the State by from 50,000 to 75,000. Chairman Coe of the Republican State Committee said that the Republicans had carried the State for McKinley by over 100,000 and elected ten Congressmen.

In his six hundred speeches Mr. BRYAN laid before the people many curious propositions and assumed that all of these would be received with favor and commendation by a great majority of the voters in the United States. He professed to believe that their commendation would be expressed at the polls.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 3. -- A fierce football struggle was witnessed on the Orange Oval this morning between the rival teams of the Orange and Elizabeth Athletic Clubs. Neither side scored, although two hard-fought halves of 30 minutes and 25 minutes were played. The visitors had the ball in Orange territory the first half and used the tandem wedge with a little effect, although the rushline of the home team was hard to break.

In forty-five States and at 68,194 poll- ing places 13,000,000 voters yesterday recorded their choice for President of the Republic and determined the policy of the Nation upon the most momentous question that has come before the peo- ple for decision since the war of the rebellion.
Kings County fell in line with New-York in giving McKinley a majority, claimed by the Republicans to be about 30,000. The vote for the Presidential Electors in all the wards was uncommonly large.
BALTIMORE, Md., Nov. 3. -- Maryland swung into the Republican column to-day with no uncertain movement. For the first time Maryland goes Republican in a National election.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 3. -- Major McKinley received returns in various parts of the house. Early in the evening he sat in his study, where he heard the news of his election. After dinner he moved into the dining room and sat in an armchair near the head of the table, which had been converted into a desk for the filing of returns.

Superficially considered, nothing could be more admirable than the working of the blanket ballot under the revised elec- tion law in this city. The process of vot- ing was easy and rapid to a degree never before known. There was an unusual disposition to get to the polls early, but there was no long waiting or standing in line, and few intelligent voters re- quired more than a minute to prepare their ballots.

It was a marvel of a day for ballot-casting. Dawn ushered in weather that was ideal. The air was benign, neither too warm nor too cool for agreeable walking or ear-riding; there was enough of a breeze to exhilarate. No better natural auxiliary to the full exercise of the franchise in pleasant circumstances could have been wished.

May Irwin's genius for singing darky songs was not inherited, it was not even acquired -- it came to her, and seems to be almost a part of herself, so she says. People have thought that she must be a Southern mowan, but she comes from the antipodes of the South, and she had not even sung there before she took up this special line of work.

DEDHAM, Mass., Nov. 3. -- George Fred Williams cast his ballot just before 9 o'clock this morning. He was questioned by reporters present, and expressed his faith as strong that Bryan would sweep the country.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 3. -- Fewer than onefifth of the voting precincts of the State are reported, and indications are that Bryan has carried his home State.

There was great joy last night at the headquarters of the Republican National Committee, in the Metropolitan Life Insurance Building, Madison Square. From the very first returns received the indications were most favorable. By 7 o'clock reports were received by long-distance telephone from Chicago, indicating that McKinley and Hobart would carry that city by 50,000 plurality, insuring the Electoral vote of Illinois.
CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 3. -- William McKinley has carried Illinois by about 100,000 plurality, and John R. Tanner, for Governor, has buried Altgeld and his hosts by a vote almost as large.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 3. -- Indications are that Kansas has given her Electoral vote to McKinley, though Chairman Briedenthal of the Fusionists is still claiming the State. The probabilities are, however, that McKinley will have a big plurality.

Early yesterday morning Detective Gargan of the Leonard Street Station saw Michael Shannon, a man whom he knew to be a river thief, rowing up the North River in an empty boat. Later Gargan saw Shannon row to the foot of Franklin Street with his boat loaded down with rope. As the detective drew near, he saw Shannon had in his boat the largest rope he had ever seen.

The Republican State Headquarters, at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, were thoroughly equipped for receiving the news. Parlor D.R. was well supplied with telegraphic paraphernalia, there being seven different wires. From early in the evening the room was packed with people anxious to get the first news of the election.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- A rec- ord-breaking vote was cast in this city today. Voters got out early, and did but little splitting. The weather was pleasant, and the day passed off quietly, except that Democrats made charges that the Republicans were using a big corruption fund, and in three instances Republicans were arrested charged with buying voters in the First District of the First Ward.

A float of the Erie Railroad Company, carrying fourteen loaded freight cars, sank yesterday at 7:30 o'clock A.M., in the East River, opposite the Long Island City slip of the Long Island Railroad ferry. The float had left Pier 8 East River about a half-hour before the accident occurred, in tow of the tug Jamestown.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3. -- Democratic candidate for Vice President Sewall acknowledges his defeat. He says in a telegram: "We are in for four years of government by injunction."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3. -- McKinley's plurality in Pennsylvania is estimated at 300,000. Grow and Davenport, for Congressmen at Large, follow the National ticket throughout the State. Indications point to the election by the Republicans of all but four of the Congressional delegation.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 3. -- A very heavy vote was polled throughout the State. The weather here was fair, and voters visited the polls early. Nearly the full list registered voted, It is unquestionable that many Democrats voted for the McKinley Electors.

The first Tuesday in November is the day for the declaration of dividends by most of the banks of this city, but, being a holiday, nearly all of them acted Monday. The list of the dividends we present below in comparison with the last previous dividend of each bank, together with the amount of capital and the total of dividends paid out of each bank:

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 3. -- Binghamton is celebrating the splendid victory of McKinley. Never before was any candidate or any cause better supported than were McKinley and sound money. The Democrats were utterly without organization.

While driving across the tracks of the Midland Electric Railroad at Stapleton, S.I., yesterday morning, John Bausch, driver for Bechtel's Brewery, and Joseph Kiengle, his assistant, were struck by a trolley car and bady injured. The men were talking together and did not see the rapidly approaching car until too late.

David Brennan, fourteen years old, of 507 West Forty-sixth Street, was shot last night in the arm by an Italian who keeps a fruit stand on the northwest corner of Forty-sixth Street and Eleventh Avenue. The only name that the Italian is known by is "Tony."

Patriotic Japanese of this city celebrated yesterday the forty-fourth anniversary of the birth of Mutsu Hito, Emperor of Japan. The present Emperor, who has witnessed the peaceful revolution by which his country freed itself from feudalism and became modern and free, was born in 1852, and has been on the throne for twenty-nine years.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 4. -- Official returns are coming in slowly. Sixteen counties show a net gain for the Democrats of 5,000 over the Gubernatorial vote in 1892. If this gain continues, Taylor (Dem.) is elected Governor by over 20,000. The best advices to The Chattanooga Times from all over the State indicate that Bryan and Taylor have fully 20,000 majority in Tennessee.

While the total vote of the city on Tuesday bore about the usual relation to the registration, it was not so large as it ought to have been, considering the importance of the election. It shows that about 25,000 registered electors failed to vote. Some of these doubtless were Democrats who concluded that they would neither vote for BRYAN nor against the regular candidates of their party.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-20 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

There was a meeting yesterday of the committee of ladies who have in hand the arrangements for the fair to be given at Sherry's on Dec. 11 -- afternoon and evening -- in aid of the Children's Surgical Hospital. The committee met at the house of Mrs. Theodore Sutro, 20 Fifth Avenue.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 4. -- Returns are sufficiently complete for Minnesota this evening to indicate clearly how the State has gone. McKinley has a plurality of perhaps a little more than 30,000, having carried St. Paul by 4,400 and Minneapolis by 6,360
The sales at auction set down for to-day at 111 Broadway are as follows: ...
All the Commissioners were present at a Board of Education meeting yesterday, and many other persons interested in matters to be considered by the board.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Complete returns are not yet in from all the Senatorial districts, but those received show that the new Illinois Legislature, which meets at Springfield the first week in January, will be overwhelmingly Republican. A Republican will be elected United States Senator to succeed John M. Palmer.

"It is plain that no system of taxation that could be endured by the people of this country Can be resorted to to maintain the gold standard. Consequently an unlimited bonded debt must be forced upon the taxpayers of this country if they are to maintain permanently the single-gold standard under the present conditions."

It is a pity to see so intelligent an English friend of America as the author of "The American Commonwealth" going wrong on an important point connected with our election, the more a pity, because Mr. BRYCE'S expressions on American affairs command and deserve respect in England.
The Rev. Dr. Charles A. Parkhurst, in speaking of the result of the election, said:

John C. Shechan, the executive head of Tammany Hall, received a dispatch from Chairman Jones of the Popocratic National Committee last night. Mr. Jones was still claiming the election of Bryan thriugh the Southern and far Western States, and he was also claiming Indiana.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 4. -- Maryland has again been struck by a political cyclone, the second being of even greater magnitude than that of last year, when the Governorship and the State and city machinery were all wrested from the Democrats.

LIVERPOOL, Nov. 4. -- The wheat market opened stronger and 2d. higher to-day upon the strength of the election of McKinley to the Presidency of the United States, and advancing under a good demand, reached a 3d. rise almost immediately. The market varied, selling and buying orders predominating alternately, and subsequently lost 1d.

John De Witt Warner, the Chairman of the Campaign Committee of the National Democrats, said the result was practically as he had predicted it would be. "I am a little surprised," he said." at the strenght displayed by Tammany Hall. As much as I dislike the purposes and methods of that organization, I must say that the management it has shown in holding the rank and file was superb.
The result of the election has been more than satisfactory to the various firms in the dry goods district.

PARIS, Nov. 4. -- There is general jubilation in the American colony over the election of McKinley. Bryanites virtually have no existence in Paris. Although the triumph of McKinley was generally expected in the American colony here, there were still persons among them deriving their incomes from home who feel greatly relieved.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 4. -- The total vote in this State for President yesterday was 174,133. McKinley's plurality is 53,838. The total vote for Governor was 173,590. Cooke's majority over all is 44,344. His plurality over Sargent, the Silver Democratic candidate, is 52,397.

W. Bourke Cockran had not recovered from the enthusiasm of Tuesday night when a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES saw him in his office yesterday. "I was so enthusiastic last night," said Mr. Cockran, "that I walked up Broadway blowing a tin horn."
CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Mr. Washburn, at the People's Party headquarters to-night, gave out a statement, in which, among other things, he says:

George Foster Peabody of the Executive Committee of the National Democratic Party, at the New-York headquarters, said: "The extent of the overthrow of Populism and Popocracy is not yet entirely clear, but I am particularly impressed with the response which the South has made by its sound-money vote to the attack on the country's credit and honor.

A man whose garb indicated that he belonged to those whom Mr. Bryan called "the masses," did not wait long to pay an election bet, and he and the winner caused a blockade and a great deal of fun in Broadway yesterday afternoon.
Among the passengers on the steamship Trave, which arrived yesterday, was Carl Halir, the noted violinist and director of the Royal High School, Berlin.

-- Newest of London's periodicals is The Automotor and Horseless Vehicle Journal, a sixpenny monthly paper, which, in its own words, "anticipates the field which will doubtless soon exist for its operations." Its originators are convinced that in the near future the auto-car industry must become an important one in England and other countries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 4. -- The President has issued the following Thanksgiving proclamation:

It is not likely that any future adventurer will imitate the rash enterprise of Col. Mapleson in undertaking to re-establish grand opera in Fourteenth Street. It is really impossible to assign any reason for the comparative lack of fashionable or of popular interest in his proceedings, except that people will no longer resort to the old Academy for opera.
The course of free lectures to the people under the auspices of the Board of Education will open in twenty-three places tonight at 8 o'clock.
-- More than 60 per cent, of the first consolidated mortgage bonds of the Ogdensburg and Lake Champlain Railroad have been deposited under the plan of reorganization.

The stock market all buoyancy. Everything advanced. Many advances were large. Money ruled practically all day at 6 per cent., just touching 10, till at the close it was offered in superabundance at 3.

Bradley's election over Campbell in the Ninth Congressional District marks the only change since yesterday in the returns for Congress in this city. The Democrats now have five out of nine places in the city delegation. Latest figures compiled for the Ninth District are as follows:

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- Returns from the State are coming in slowly, but bear out the early estimates of a majority exceeding 100,000 for McKinley, with Tanner for Governor running well up. In Chicago Tanner polled 30,000 votes less than the head of the ticket, but he ran ahead in many country districts, and it is believed will not be very far behind McKinley when the returns are completed.
The Iron Age will say to-day in reviewing the iron and metal trades:

The "precious metals" were in contempt yesterday. Silver declined nearly 3 cents an ounce. As to gold, the premium disappeared, and no one wanted to handle it. The standard of value was, for the nonce, a drug on the market.

There were many rumors yesterday morning in the Ninth Congressional District to the effect that "Tim" Campbell, the Republican candidate, would contest the election of Bradley, the Tammany-PopocraticSteckler candidate. The rumors grew out of a general mix-up of things, an alleged gross violation of the election law by one Board of Registry, and the erroneous reports sent out early in the morning, which gave Campbell a small plurality.

A man may change his bumps. That is the encouraging conclusion of the phrenologists. Miss Jessie Fowler of the College of Phrenology says she has seen a man's head change and vary from an inch to an inch and a half in the course of several years. This was owing to his change of and interest in things calling for the play of different characteristics.

Careful analysis of the vote cast in this city will show interesting results. The latest returns give 153,950 for McKinley, 134,287 for Bryan, 5,615 for Palmer, and 7,304 for Matchett, the Socialist-Labor candidate.

BERLIN, Nov. 4. -- The leading bankers and Boerse operators here Declared to-day that they were very well satisfied with the result of yesterday's election for President in the United States. Exporters say that they will now execute large orders, which were placed upon the condition of McKinley's election.

From The San Francisco Examiner. The five whalers who deseried their ships in Winter quarters at Herschel Island succeeded in reaching the gold mines of the Yukon. They staggered into Circle City after having tramped nearly a month over the mountains and trackless, snowy wastes of the arctic.
To the Editor of The New-York Times: I am not in business, have nothing to advertise, am not needing influence, nor seeking notoriety. I do not want anything.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 4. -- Many full and more partial returns from Indiana this afternoon indicate that the Republicans have been claiming the State by a larger plurality than they will get. Many of the counties in the Southern part of the State began to report during the afternoon, and some of them showed unexpected Democratic gains.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 4. -- Latest returns indicate that Kansas has declared for Bryan by 12,000 plurality and for the entire fusion State ticket by 7,000.
New-Jersey, the home State or Garret A. Hobart, Vice President-elect, did nobly in the ranks of the sound-money States.
Everybody cheered, everybody sang, everybody made and answered inquiries as to the condition of some one else. The answer invariably was "He's all right!"

Henry H. Adams, ex-County Treasurer of Kings County, was arrested yesterday for misappropriating a trust fund amounting to $2,967,22, which was deposited in his care in October, 1892, while he was in office. He had been indicted by the Grand Jury last week.

Henry B. Hyde, President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, said: "It gives me a feeling of comfort and of confidence in the stability of the Republic to think that the people have risen for the right and so overwhelmingly defeated the ideas embodied in the platform upon which Bryan stood and asked for their votes."
No one took a keener interest in the result of the Presidential campaign than J. Edward Simmons, President of the Fourth National Bank. Mr. Simmons, who is a sound-money Democrat, yesterday said:
Francis Lynde Stetson, the well known lawyer, and the law partner of Grover Cleveland just previous to his second election to the Presidency, said:

William Whalen of 3 Minetta Street was stabbed in the abdomen and killed about 11 o'clock last night in the backyard of his residence, where he had been drinking with a crowd. His slayer, John Murphy, twenty-seven years old, of 38 Laight Street, was arrested and locked up in the Mercer Street Police Station.

Visitors who went to the galleries of the Stock Exchange yesterday morning expected wild juiblation and pranks when it opened. The floor was so thronged that few of the members could have been absent. Nearly all who were there to resume business from Monday looked keen and anxious. They had not come to demonstrate their joy over the defeat of Bryan, but to attend strictly to business in the boom that was certain.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 4. -- The World-Herald, the paper of which William J. Bryan for a time was political editor, to-night sent the following dispatch to THE NEW-YORK TIMES:

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 4. -- To the surprise of even the Republicans, California will cast her Electoral vote for McKinley, end five of the seven Congressmen elected are Republicans. The Slate Legislature will also be safely Republican in both branches, all of which has completely upset the calculations of the most astute politicians of either side.

The National Democrats propose to take a hand in the politics of this State in the future. The State Committee which was organized soon after the Indianapolis Convention adjourned has been one of the liveliest political bodies in the State in the recent campaign, and extended the new party into all the counties.

The recent visit to this city by Gov. Evans of South Carolina was due to business relating to the purchase by the Thomas-Ryan syndicate of the Port Royal and Western Carolina and the Port Royal and Augusta Railways.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 4. -- There was not much sleep in the McKinley household last night. It was nearly 5 o'clock this morning when Major McKinley got to bed, and the noise on the streets increased rather than diminished in volume as the darkness fled.
The members of the Produce Exchange decided yesterday to celebrate the election of McKinley and Hobart, and carried out their plan zealously and successfully.

Government bonds were very strong. The 4s of 1925 advanced 1 1/2, the 4s of 1907, registered, 1, and the 5s, 1/2 and 7/8, respectively, for the registered and coupon. The sales were $46,700 4s, 1925, coupon, at 119 1/2 @ 120 3/8; $70,000 5s, registered, at 111 1/2@111 1/4, and $12,000 do., coupon, at 112@111 1/2. The following were the closing quotations:
CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 4. -- In an editorial article signed by Senator Chandler in The Monitor to-night occurs the following:

Mrs. Rose Hawthorne Lathrop, daughter of Nathaniel Hawthorne, and the wife at George Parsons Lathrop, the well-known writer, lies seriously ill at her self-chosen home in a tenement house at 1 Scammel Street. She took up her abode at this address months ago with the avowed purpose of devoting her life to the care of persons suffering from cancer and unable to pay for treatment at a hospital.
On the eve of election a prominent banker in this city received the following from a correspondent in Illinois:

The returns from back districts in NewYork State do not materially alter the majorities of either Major McKinley or Mr. Black, although they bring the plurality of the former above 270,000, and that of the latter within reach of 220,000. They demonstrated, however, that the Bryan men were greatly deluded when they imagined the farming people of New-York sympathized with their cause.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department, of THE NEW-YORK TIMES.

LONDON, Nov. 4. -- As the result of the elections in the United States at the opening of the Stock Exchange this morning American railroad stocks were very strong, and became still more so under the pressure of a tremendous business. It was a difficult matter to get jobbers to make prices. The leading stocks were 5 to 6 points up, and the lower class of stocks 2 to 3 points up.

In Kings County the head of the Republican ticket received the largest plurality ever given to a Republican by the county; the entire judiciary was elected by majorities of 25,000 and more; five Republican Congressmen were re-elected by majorities larger than they had ever commanded before; and thirteen Assembly districts were won.

The returns from the various Congressional and Assembly districts of the city did not please the Tammany men, although it was plain that in several of the election districts Tammany had succeeded in pulling its chestnuts out of the fire. This was especially so in the case of Vehslage, the Tammany candidate for Congress in the Seventh Congressional District.

The competition for the prize of $100, offered by THE NEW-YORK TIMES for the best motto to take the place of "All the News That's Fit to Print," continues to excite the utmost inerest. Every mail brings hundreds of postal cards containing suggestions. Many of them are exceptionally good examples of vigorous, terse, or original expression.

From The Washington Star. "The best oyster experts that I know of," said the Captain of an oyster boat, "judge an oyster by the smell, instead of by the taste. There is something about the smell of any oyster that indicates its condition to me much plainer than does the taste. People buy them and eat them probably on account of their taste.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4. -- W.D. Bynum, Chairman of the National Committee, admitted this morning that no further efforts would be made to organize the National Democratic Party or to keep it alive. It failed to poll 2 per cent. of the total vote in Illinois, and, therefore, has no existence as a party organisation in the State.

One of the peculiar outgrowths of the election was the activity among some of the brokers and bankers in the Wall Street district in regard to arbitrage business. Arbitrage trading is almost as old as the Atlantic cable, but it has been almost exclusively confined heretofore to foreign houses with branches or representatives in this city.

Several men of prominence will disappear from the Senate chamber after March 3, 1897. It is certain that Senator Don Cameron of Pennsylvania will retire, and it is predicted by Pennsylvanians that Gov. Hastings will succeed him. Senator Voorhees of Indiana, who has been in poor health for several years, will be succeeded, probably, by Gen. Fairbanks, a Republican.

The various committees of the Drug, Paint, Oil, and Chemical Trades Sound Money Campaign Club met yesterday at noon in their headquarters, 59 Maiden Lane, to file reports and adjourn indefinitely and congratulate each other on the result of the election.

IPSWICH, Mass., Nov. 4. -- The great McKinley and Hobart flag that waved in Depot Square was last night cut down, badly torn, and trampled in the dirt of the street by some miscreants, supposed to be members of a local Democratic club who were disappointed in the result of the election.
J. Edward Simmons, President of the Fourth National Bank, sent the following telegrams yesterday:

The latest returns on the Presidential election change the aspect given by the earlier returns, although they give McKinley a majority in the Electoral College. A few States are still in doubt, notably in the West and South.

The Government that was elected on Tuesday will control the Executive and both houses of Congress. It will be its duty to make the country perfectly safe, not only from the recurrence of such a revolutionary movement as has now been crushed, but from the difficulties and dangers of the financial system that made that movement possible.

The delightful JONES was "still hopeful" in yesterday's afternoon papers. JONES is undoubtedly an able claimant after as well as before his claims have been put to the proof. Why he should think it necessary to keep it up is more than we can see, unless there is an unexpended balance of appropriation for his headquarters.

The Republican candidates for the judiciary in the Second District were elected by handsome pluralities. The ticket carried every one of the nine counties in the district except Richmond, which was lost by a small vote on account of a split ticket and the canvass of a Local independent candidate.

HAVANA, Nov. 5. -- Gen. Gonzalez Munoz reports that his command had an engagement with the rebels under Perico Delgado and Perico Diaz, at Manuelito, near Cabanas, Province of Pinar del Rio. The rebels held strong positions in the hills, but were dislodged after several combats, in which Gen. Inclan assisted Gen. Munoz.
Electoral State. McKINLEY. Votes. California 9 Connecticut 6 Delaware 3 Illinois 24 Indiana 15 Iowa 13

-- Any New-Yorker who feels that his exaltation over the result of the election is approaching the danger point can easily calm himself down by glancing over the list of Congressmen elected from this city. It is an exhibit of which even Schoharie County would be ashamed -- if it had brains enough to be ashamed of anything.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 5. -- The first information that Senator Jones had conceded the election of McKinley was given to Mr. Bryan at 8 o'clock this evening.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 5. -- Major McKinley, yielding to the pressure of friends and physician, has at last decided to absent himself from Canton for a time, and will, with Mrs. McKinley, leave for Cleveland within a few days. Mrs. McKinley has been suffering from a severe cold for more than a week, and is now convalescent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Chairman Washburn of the People's Party National Committee will go to Washington in about ten days to confer with Senators Jones and Butler in regard to the future policy of the allied silver forces. In this connection Mr. Washburn said in an interview to-day:

An unassailable column of 260 electoral votes has been secured for McKinley and Hobart. This column may be increased by the addition of the votes of the States of Kentucky, South Dakota, Tennessee, and Wyoming, which are still in doubt and claimed for both McKinley and Bryan.

HONOLULU, Oct. 29, via San Francisco, Nov. 5, per steamer Australia. -- At the meeting on the 23d of October, of President Dole and the Council of State, it was voted unanimously to extend a full pardon to ex-Queen Liliuokalani.

Benet-Laidlaw. The marriage of Miss Edith Elizabeth Laidlaw and Dr. Imlay L. Benet occurred yesterday afternoon at St. Agnes's Chapel, West Ninety-second Street, the Rev. Dr. Bradley, vicar of the church, officiating. Miss Alice Laidlaw was maid of honor, and the bridesmaids were the Misses Edith Edson, Lillian Benet, Edith Benet, Jessie Laidlaw, Agnes Laidlaw, and Bracher.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 5. -- The incendiary speech of Senator "Joe" Blackburn here last night accomplished, its perfect work, for he had hardly finished his sulphurous tirade before the silver ward workers began a reign of terror that did not cease until to-night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5. -- Chairman Faulkner of the Democratic Congressional Committee to-night gave out the following:
CHICAGO, Nov. 5. -- Gov. Altgeld gave the following statement to the press yesterday:

Some disappointment has been felt that the victory of Tuesday does not appear so overwhelming as the first reports gave reason for believing it to be. But this feeling comes from laying too much stress upon a large majority of the Electoral votes and giving too little attention to the popular vote of those States which had the deciding voice.

John. Hamilton Inman, the well-known cotton merchant of this city, died yesterday morning at 9 o'clock at his country seat in Berkshire, Mass. Mr. Inman had been absent from his city home for three months. He had been traveling in the Adirondack region and through the Berkshire Hills.

The Government's revenue is not sufficient to meet Us expenditures. Everybody knows that. The expenses were increased by extravagant legislation at the recent pension of Congress, but even if they had not thus been enlarged the revenue would still be inadequate. For the first four months, of the current fiscal year -- July, August. September, and October -- the expenditures exceeded the receipts by nearly 33,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While greatly rejoicing over the victory which we sound-money advocates have gained, and fully appreciating the beneficent influences which will follow, I cannot but view with a feeling of regret and apprehension how many States have favored by a majority of their voters repudiation and the establishment of a dishonest monetary system.

"I beg to tender my services" were the closing words of the telegram of congratulation which ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt sent to Major McKinley day before yesterday. The telegram was published in this city yesterday.

The auction sale of Washington Heights lots belonging to the estate of Susan Barclay Ward, which is announced for Nov. 19 by D. Phoenix Ingrraham Co., under the direction of Abraham Van Santvoord, referee, is already attracting attention from investors and builders. The property is situated between the King's Bridge Road and the Hudson River, in the neighborhood of One Hundred and Seventieth Street, and embraces nearly two hundred lots.

"Four strikes and he's out, and I am in it," said Jeremiah Sullivan, the ex-baseball umpire, yesterday. He was the Republican candidate in the Tenth Assembly District against Otto Kempner, Tammany. The police election returns showed that Sullivan had carried the district by a plurality of four. Later he claimed that his plurality was seven.

LONDON, Nov. 5. -- Advices received here show that earthquakes were renewed in the southwestern part of Iceland on Oct. 4. One hundred and fitfy farms were ruined, a large number of cattle killed, and quantities of stored foods destroyed. There is much misery among the people, who are camping out under improvise 1 shelters.

When Gen. Fitz-Hugh Lee, Consul General from the United States to Cuba, landed from the Ward Line steamship Vigilancia yesterday morning, he was welcomed at the wharf by a delegation of Cubans and Spanish sympathizers with the Cuban insurgents, some of whom he had succeeded in having liberated from Morro Castle, where they had been imprisoned by Gen. Weyler for political offenses.
The following telegram was received by Mark A. Hanna from Major McKinley last night:

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 5. -- The Republicans and the gold Democrats in Virginia will unite in a determined fight for fair elections. The issue is to be made in the Legislative and Gubernatorial contest of next year. This issue is to overshadow every other.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Nov. 5. -- Indiana's fifteen Electoral voles will be cast for McKinley and Hobart. The Republican plurality on Electors will not be far from 20,000, the figures named by the THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent Tuesday night. Unofficial returns from all counties show it to be 20.237.

The sound-money men, either of Kentucky or of the country, have nothing to regret in the defeat of the notorious BRECKINKIDGE, from the fact that the offensive qualities that made him notorious were the cause of his defeat. It required no small amount of hardihood for him to present himself to the people of his district and ask their votes.

From The Poughkeepsie News Press, (Chairman J.W. Hinkley's Paper.) The election on Tuesday demonstrated in an emphatic way the safety of a Government like ours from the influences which Altgeld and Tillman insisted upon defending and seeking to introduce as factors in American politics.

BERLIN, Nov. 5. -- Herr Bleichsroder, the great German banker, in an interview on the result of the American Presidential election, expressed the opinion that the election of McKinley had made a most excellent impression in Germany, but added that he was unable to foretell whether untoward circumstances would arise later to undo the good that has already been done.
A political party must have principles, organization, and the confidence of the people. It can gain no following without the first, no standing without the second, and no victories without the third.

Yesterday the Board of Education of this city adopted a resolution authorizing the Superintendent of Schools to transfer children from one school to another for the purpose of making room for the admission of a larger number to the present schoolhouses, and directing him to make the transfers in such a way that the children shall attend schools in the vicinity of their homes, so far as possible.

The announcement of BRYAN'S defeat flashed over the wires and was read in the papers throughout the land on Wednesday morning. Within thirty-six hours the following cases of industries starting up or increasing their force were reported:

Hotel men are looking forward to Horse Show week with fear and joy. As far as the hotels in the city are concerned, it will be a period of prosperity. All the leading hotels on Broadway have received advance orders for rooms to such an extent that many of the bonifaces are perpiexed regarding accommodations.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 6. -- Major P.P. Johnston, Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee, in an interview tonight, said:

It must be at once conceded that the seventh annual exhibition of the New-York Water Color Club, which was shown to inivted members of the press at the gallery of the Fine Arts Society yesterday. Is superior to any of the club's recent exhibitions. The collection numbers three hundred pictures in pastel and water colors, and includes fewer examples of eccentricity than marked the club's exhibition last year.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6. -- The statement was made to-day on very high authority that representatives of Bryant May, who have heretofore enjoyed the monopoly of the match industry in Great Britain, were in this country negotiating for a controlling interest in the stock of the Diamond Match Company at $200 a share.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 6. -- The result of the election in this State on the National ticket seems to be that the majority for Bryan is 20,000.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 6. -- Major P.P. Johnston, Chairman of the Democratic State Executive Committee, in an interview tonight, said:

-- It would be interesting to know how many of the people who drew small amounts of gold from the Sub-Treasury in the campaign's closing day were really alarmed for the safety of their savings, and how many of them had in mind the possibility of making a snug profit in case gold went to a premium for a while.

RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 6. -- The fight for Senator to succeed Jeter C. Pritchard is on. The complexion of the Legislature is Republicans, 65; Populists, 55; Democrats, 50, so that either two of the three parties, by fusion, can elect a Senator.
Marion Mills Miller, who ran for Congress on the Populist and Single Tax ticket in the Twelfth District, delivered a lecture last night at the Manhattan Liberal Club on "The Coming Democracy."
The wisest words President-elect McKINLEY has ever spoken are these from his telegram to Mr. HANNA:

-- The present sent by Emperor WILLIAM, through Gen. VON HAHNKE, to Queen WILHELMINA of Holland on the occasion of her confirmation, is a cross made of seven chrysolites, surrounded by brilliants, and modeled after an ancient Netherlands cross in the Berlin Museum.

Much may be pardoned to a man suffering under the chagrin of defeat. This should be kept in mind in reading Mr. BRYAN'S manifesto to the "bimetallists." Only some fifteen men all told have known what it is to miss the Presidency of the United States when they had confidently expected to win it.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Nov. 6. -- The steamer Tiber, commanded by Capt. Delisle, bound for Sydney, which left here at 7 o'clock tonight, when just beyond the entrance to the harbor, collided with the schooner Maggie, bound from Bonavista Bay for St. John's, with a cargo of fish and lumber. The schooner was sunk, and of her crew of nine and fourteen passengers thirteen were drowned.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Nov. 6. -- Elkwood Park, owned by Philip Daly, which is but two miles from this place, and almost next door to the Monmouth Park race track, is to have the finest shooting grounds in America. There will be a clubhouse and pavilion, with three sets of traps and all the latest European equipments, located on fifteen acres of ground.
CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 6. -- Major McKinley replied to the congratulatory dispatch that Mr. Bryan had sent by this telegram:
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 6. -- William J. Bryan this afternoon gave out the following statement to the bimetallists of the United States:

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 6. -- The counting up of the returns for this county was finished by the men on the adding machines at 7:30 o'clock this evening. No disorder occurred after 3 o'clock this morning.

Fifteen years ago Senator PLATT resigned his seat in the Senate and returned to New-York in confidence that his course would be "vindicated" by a re-election. He resigned for no public reason whatever. No measure of his party, no policy of the Administration, then recently inaugurated, had compelled him to assume an independent position, or to seek a renewal of the commission he had received.

BRICK CHURCH, N.J., Nov. 6. -- The third night of the horse show at the Riding and Driving Club brought out a crowd of fashionable folks this evening, who seemed greatly pleased with the exhibition of combination saddle and harness horses, single harness horses, saddle horses, and hunters and jumpers in the championship and other classes, that were judged.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 6. -- Wheat went on another moderate boom to-day. It closed last night at 74 1/8, a sharp decline from the closing price of Wednesday. To-day it rose under a steady demand till it ruled strong at 78 1/8, when the bell tapped.

The gunners who took advantage of the fine weather on election day and tried the quail and duck shooting on Long Island found excellent hunting, but few birds. Some good bags were, however, made, but the greater part of the crowd that filled the Long Island Railroad trains came back with comparatively small returns.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 7. -- Thomas Lloyd, the editor of The London Statist, deseants upon the result of Tuesday's election in a cablegram to his paper as follows:

TUXEDO, Nov. 7. -- Tuxedo is now enjoying the most successful season since the opening of the park. The clubhouse and all the cottages are full, and the brilliant ball of Oct. 30 has been followed by a round of gayety.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 7. -- The suit of the Commissioners of Public Works for the removal of Frederic Shonnard of Yonkers and James W. Boyle of New-York, as Commissioners of Appraisal, appointed March 7, 1894, with Martin J. Keogh, to appraise land required by the City of New-York at Katonah, Westchester County, came before Justice J. O. Dykman, holding a special Term of the Supreme Court here this morning.
The Third Avenue Railroad Company has not put up its $250,000 in cash required by law for the proposed extension of the company's tracks from One Hundred and Sixtysecond Street to Spuyten Duyvil.

Mrs. Sisieretta K. Jones, known as the Black Patti, was examined yesterday before Justice Schuchman in supplementary proceedings touching her financial ability to pay Job E. Hedges a judgment of $236 for legal services.

The multitudinous ferry and boat landings in the neighborhood of the Battery, to say nothing of elevated and surface railroad termini, are a source of perplexity to strangers. A United States infantryman, somewhat under the weather, and seeking out the way to Fort Wadsworth, drifted into the ship news office yesterday.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 7. -- President Mendenhall yesterday presented to half the divisions of the Worcester Polytechnic Institute a paper for the signature of the students to the effect that the signer had no part in the McKinley bonfire Wednesday, for promoting which two boys were expelled Thursday, and that he promised to obey the orders of the Faculty.

NEWPORT, Nov. 7. -- Cornelius Vanderbilt's new greenhouses are attracting great attention from cottagers and professional florists. The houses, which were constructed several weeks ago, are stocked with rare specimens, and among the many beautiful greenhouses connected with Newport's magnificent Summer residences, easily take the lead.

Every one recognizes without difficulty that the times have for more than three years been "bad," and every one since Wednesday morning has been able to see the signs that times are suddenly becoming "good." So striking a change showing itself over night gives a good chance to see exactly what the difference is.

HARVARD, Ill., Nov. 7. -- Charles Fisher, a wandering piano tuner who a short time ago induced Miss May O'Connor, the daughter of a wealthy resident, to elope with him, was brought back from Chicago after a few hours' absence, by the Sheriff of this county, to-day.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 7. -- The admirers of football got their money's worth here this afternoon, in a game between the cadets arid the Wesleyan College team. The contest was an unusually exciting one, and honors were about even. It was a hard and rough battle, several men on both sides being badly injured.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7. -- Pennsylvania shook off the lethargy to-day that has paralyzed her football playing this season, and took the scalp of the Carlisle Indians by a score of 21 to 0.

HAVANA, Nov. 7. -- Gen. Munoz reports from his camp, at Manuelito, that the Spanish forces continue to advance into the interior of the hills. They have destroyed a number of rebel huts and taken some prisoners. Maceo is retreating further into the hills.

BERLIN, Nov. 7. -- The Reichstag, which will resume business on Monday, will have a short session, but it will nevertheless have an extremely exciting one, in the discussion of promised Interpellations by various political leaders upon the question of the right of Prince Bismarck, or, for that matter, any ex-Chancellor or Minister, to disclose State secrets.

LAKE WOOD, N.J., Nov. 7. -- The election was the all-absorbing interest here this week. The McKinley and Hobart Sound Money Club secured an excellent service for election returns, and Tuesday night the clubroom was crowded with enthusiastic voters who applauded the returns indicating Republican success as read from dispatches.

From The San Francisco Call. A peculiar case of death from blood poisoning, caused by the sting of a small blue fly, is at present occupying the attention and interest of the medical profession of this city.
BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- The expected has happened. Princeton won the big football game with Harvard.

Adolph Weiss ot 538 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, and Henry Schwergert of One Hundred and Eighteenth Street and First Avenue, while fishing in Long Island Sound, off Riker's Island, yesterday morning, found an overturned flatbottomed skiff floating on the water. They towed it to the foot of East One Hundred and Tenth Street.

Anthony Comstock, Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, returned from Albany last evening, after having secured the arrest of one of the leading booksellers of that city and one of his clerks on the charge of having sent obscene matter through the mails.
Louis Boas died suddenly at his home, 128 West Seventy-fourth Street, early yesterday afternoon.
Henry E. Parker. Henry E. Parker, Professor Emeritus at Dartmouth College, died yesterday at the home, in Boston, of his son-in-law, Dr. Benjamin Tenney, after a lingering illness of four years.

The opinion that Cornelius N. Bliss of this city will be named for Secretary of the Treasury by Mr. McKinley is entertained generally by local Republicans, despite the fact that Section 243 of the Revised Statutes of the United States apparently bars from the office of Secretary of the Treasury any one interested directly in the importing or banking business.

BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- President Francis A. Walker of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology addressed the Massachusetts Schoolmaster Association, at the hotel Brunswick, upon "international Bimetallism," by invitation. The speaker, who met with a very cordial reception, presented with much detail the various arguments for or against bimetaillism, and summed up as follows:

In declining the dinner invitation of the Commercial Club of Cincinnati Major McKINLEY announced that, although he had been much urged to visit the City of Chicago, and he understood he was about to be invited to New-York by some of his most influential supporters, he nevertheless had resolved that with the exception of a brief visit to Cleveland, he would remain in Canton until he went to Washington.

CHICAGO, NOV. 7. -- The wheat market was in the main very strong to-day, but had quite a few periods of considerable heaviness. December ranged from 77 1/4 to 79 3/8 cents, and closed at 78 1/8 cents. Corn closed at a slight decline, and oats at a trifling advance. Pork, lard, and ribs each closed at a slight gain on yesterday's final prices after a dull and uninteresting day's business.

LONDON, Nov. 7. -- The everlasting Irish question is coining up in an acute form, through the old and too familiar occurrence of an Irish famine. The Bishop of Raphoe, in a recent appeal for subscriptions in aid of the Irish Party Fund, spoke of the bleak prospects before the agricultural population as operating against the fund.
NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 7. -- The official canvass of the vote on Presidential Electors in the State of New-Jersey was made, today. The plurality for McKinley is 87,102.

There was a large and enthusiastic gathering of college golfers on the links of the Ardsley Casino, near Dobbs Ferry, yesterday afternoon. The best golfers from Yale University were there, and Columbia also tent her best representatives. The latter showed that they had much to learn about the game before they could hope to play on favorable terms the blue golfers from New-Haven.

The best commentary upon the issues fought out in the election of Tuesday is the immediate and decided improvement in all business. It was a campaign of trade against stagnation, of a sound basis for traffic as against a fluctuating currency and an unstable market. Business, having won, is exultant, and is confident of the present and of the future.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7. -- Preliminary steps were taken to-day toward the formation of a Credit Men's Association for Chicago, on lines similar to those of kindred associations recently formed in a score of American cities. The Chicago association will be affiliated with the National Association of Credit Men.

The dinner given by Chairman Mark A. Hanna of the Republican National Committee to the newspaper men at the Waldorf last night was attended by about 100 members of the press of this city and Chicago, who were on duty at the two branches of Republican headquarters during the recent campaign.

The invitation that the Harvard Athletic Committee has extended to Mr. Lehmann, the English coach, will probably result in more or less radical change in rowing methods in Cambridge, but more than that, it may be considered as a distinct victory for the undergraduates in their effort to recover the control of their rowing interests, which was taken from them by the committee two years ago.

The invitation that the Harvard Athletic Committee has extended to Mr. Lehmann, the English coach, will probably result in more or less radical change in rowing methods in Cambridge, but more than that, it may be considered as a distinct victory for the undergraduates in their effort to recover the control of their rowing interests, which was taken from them by the committee two years ago.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 7. -- Yale gunners beat those at Harvard and Princeton here to-day in the interscholastic school. The Harvard butts are on low ground and wind and tide so backed up the Charles River that the last men who were at the targets had to stand in four inches of water and shoot out to sea.

The statement that there are 100,000 men in New-York, and that 50,000 more idle and hungry men would be added to this number in the next thirty days, is not credited by the various charity organizations in this city. They denounce the statement as unnecessarily alarming and as being without foundation.

BOSTON, Nov. 7. -- Capt. Edgar N. Wrightington, '97, of Brookline, left half back, was Captain of the Longwood team before he entered college. He has played football almost ever since he has been at school. He played on the 'Varsity and freshman elevens in his first year at Harvard. He has been behind the line on the 'Varsity team ever since then.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES printed yesterday morning a story to the effect that the Manhattan Elevated Railroad Company and the Metropolitan Traction Company had resumed negotiations with the object of consolidation. The Directors of the Traction Company met at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon and remained in session until nearly 6 o'clock.

The New-York City Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution held its first meeting of the season in Sherry's ballroom yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Donald McLean, Regent, presided. It was an informal social meeting. There were about 300 persons present, most of them members.

David Blakely, manager of Sousa's Band, died suddenly yesterday afternoon in the Carnegie Building, Fity-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, from an attack of apoplexy. Mr. Blakely was in the best of health until stricken. At about 4 o'clock his typewriter went out on an errand. When she returned, she found Mr. Blakely lying on his face on the floor of his office.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 7. -- Trinity outclased the New-York University football team here to-day, and won by a score of 40 to 0. Trinity played straight football and tried no tricks. At the start Trinity had three substitutes, and before the end of the game had practically her second eleven Trinity made two touch-downs which were not allowed because of holding.

D.L. Moody, the evangelist, for the first time since he became famous through his revival conducted here twenty years ago in the old Hippodrome, where Madison Square Garden now stands, has come again to begin a revival. He held his opening meeting in Carnegie Music Hall yesterday afternoon.

The following letter explains itself: To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Nov. 3, under the heading "For Fornes; Against Quigg," you publish an anonymous letter attacking the Hon. Lemuel E. Quigg, and slurring this organization.
George Fisher, five years old, of 231 West Twenty-seventh Street, was run over by a crosstown car on Twenty-eighth Street at noon yesterday, and died at 10 o'clock last night.

Bishop John P. Newman of Nebraska, whose utterances on political topics during the campaign brought criticism from some of Mr. Bryan's supporters, was at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. So pleased he was when he spoke of McKinley's election that his face beamed with smiles, and he said "magnificent," "splendid!"

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8. -- Germany's forty-two life insurance companies have enjoyed unprecedented prosperity during the last few years, according to United States Consul Monoghan at Chemnitz, in a report to the State Department. He says they are favored by the ever-increasing active interest of the people and not less by the Government's policy of exempting premiums to a certain figure from taxation.

Information which comes from a source apparently authentic is that President-elect McKinley hopes to prevail upon Senator John Sherman to head his Cabinet. There are many reasons for believing that he will accept the Secretaryship of State.

Cannot the American caricaturist invent a new type to represent his peculiar notion of the American farmer? It would be a great relief and it would tend to peace and National good feeling. The farmers are the only class designated by their occupation in this Republic for the ridicule of the comic artist.

In the seven weeks ending on Oct. 17 the number of deaths caused by typhoid fever in Chicago was 141. The mortality tables published by the Marine Hospital Bureau at Washington show that Chicago's typhoid rate is higher now than that of any other large city in this country.

Bertha Graff, fourteen years old, who lives at 156 Essex Street, had started to go down to the cellar of the house on an errand for her parents yesterday afternoon, when a man sprang from behind a partition and called to her to stop. The girl, though frightened, tried to step by him and run up the stairs, when he placed himself in front of her and pointed a revolver at her head.

The members of the Public Hack Owners' Association who met last evening at McGarry's Hall, at Thirty-second Street and Lexington Avenue, suspended all business and talked of the Horse Show. Several of them who had good horses have entered them in the show, and at the meeting it was decided that the members should make a reduction of fares during the continuance of the show.

The Rev. William Justin Harsha, at the Second Collegiate Reformed Church, One Hundred and Twenty-third Street and Lenox Avenue, preached yesterday morning upon the theme, "Shall we have a Republic fifty years hence?"

We ask the workingmen and all other persons who voted for BRYAN, but especially the workingmen, to think a little about the meaning of the great revival of industry which is now taking place. The newspapers publish every day columns of dispatches showing that in all parts of the land men who have been idle are going to work.

The opinions of several prominent Republicans as to the action which may be or should be taken with respect to the tariff and the revenue have been published during the last two or three days. Senator SHERMAN, it is reported, thinks that his party should try to pass the Dingley bill, which was sent to the Senate by the House at the last session of Congress.

Senator MORGAN of Alabama says that the National Democrats will quarrel with the Republicans and be back with those who supported BRYAN within two years. BUTLER of South Carolina says that the Republican Bryanites were scared by the name Democrat, and four years hence there will be a free-coinage party.
All of the arrangements for the funeral of Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt, with the exception of selecting the pall bearers, have been completed. The pall bearers will be chosen to-day.
CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 9. -- The following are among the congratulatory messages received to-day by Major McKinley:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Duke of Tetuan, Minister of Foreign Affairs at Madrid, cabled Senor Dupuy de Lome this afternoon that Gen.
