Weyler had left Havana to take immediate personal command in the field of the comprehensive operations against the insurgents which has been in preparation for some months, and for which large reinforcements have been made available.

Naturally the public curiosity about the performance of "Faust" at the Academy of Music last night centred in the first appearance in her own country of an American Margherita in the person of Miss Susan Strong of Brooklyn. The curiosity was extensive enough to fill the auditorium with the largest house that has assembled there since the production of "Aida" on the first night of the season.
LONDON, Nov. 9. -- When Lord Salisbury arose to reply to the toast, "Our Ministers," he received an ovation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9. -- The Duke of Tetuan, Minister of Foreign Affairs at Madrid, cabled Senor Dupuy de Lome this afternoon that Gen. Weyler had left Havana to take immediate personal command in the field of the comprehensive operations against the insurgents which has been in preparation for some months, and for which large reinforcements have been made available.

There is less than the usual amount of post-election talk about the "army of office seekers" and the coming "distribution of patronage," but there is enough of it to show that the old spoilsseeking spirit is still alive. Statements are made here and there about the promises and pledges that are to be kept or the expectations that have been raised.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 9. -- Alfred L. Hartridge, a broker, has been arrested, charged with forgery by raising South western Railroad stock scrip. The amount involved is between $20,000 and $30,000. The Germania Bank, the National Bank of Savannah, and the Savannah Bank and Trust Company hold the scrip in various amounts.

The Armenian question was the occasion of a special meeting in Chickering Hall last night under the auspices of the Armenian Relief Committee. The large hall was filled almost to overflowing. In the parquet and side aisles there was not a seat to be had long before 8 o'clock, the time for meeting.

The Prisoners' Hope demonstration, held at Carnegie Hall last night, under the auspices of the American Volunteers, attracted an audience that nearly filled floor, boxes, balconies, and platform. It was an audience that evinced by its responsiveness and enthusiasm a keen interest in the work in behalf of convicts, their families, and ex-convicts which Mrs. Bailington Booth has undertaken, and a disposition to lend substantial aid.

An effort to set aside the will of the late John B. Haskin, who, during his lifetime, was known to the members of Tammany Hall and to city politicians generally as "Tuscarora," was begun yesterday before Surrogate Arnold.

LONDON. Nov. 9. -- The United Associated Presses is informed that Mrs. Ella Castle of San Francisco, sentenced a few days ago to three months imprisonment for shoplifting, will be released to-morrow. She is at present in the hospital of Wormwood Scrubbs Prison.

"Die trojanische Frage ist gelost" -- with these words Prof. Wilhelm Dorpfeld, the distinguished German archaeologist, closed the first of his series of lectures in German at Columbia College yesterday afternoon.

"The Sign of the Cross," acted at the Knickerbocker Theatre last night by a company imported from England by Charles Frohman and Frank Sanger, is a four-act drama the scene of which is laid in Rome at the time of the persecution of the Christians under Nero. The theme is the conversion of a Roman libertine, Marcus Superbus, by a girl martyr named Mercia, and his sacrifice of life for her sake.

Mr. BRYAN had the support at the polls of a great many honest Americans who were not attracted by his policy with respect to the currency. Indeed, we have reason to believe that votes were cast for him by a considerable number of men who either were in doubt as to the expediency of that policy or had come to think that the adoption of it might or would affect the Nation injuriously.

AUGUSTA, Me., Nov. 9. -- The Republicans of this city and Maine to-night ratified the results of the election by a big open-air demonstration. Joseph H. Manley was the principal speaker. In the course of his remarks he said:

"New-York has not a few Republican sons who would worthily speak and act for her in the United States Senate," A highminded, accomplished statesman whose Senatorial career would recall the best days of that body, and hence make every public-spirited citizen prouder than ever of being a New-Yorker -- that's the type of man whose election is demanded by the fitness of things -- Rochester Post-Express.

The senile spitefulness of BISMARCK is more to be deplored on account of his own fame than on account of its effect upon European politics. His name is a great name. Five years ago it was one of the national possessions of the German people. It was one of the things indeed that made Germany a nation in fact as well as in name.

LONDON, Nov. 9. -- At the banquet given this evening to celebrate the installation into office of George Faudel Philips, the new Lord Mayor of London, Lord Salisbury made the statement that in his belief the controversy between England and the United States with reference to Venezuela was at an end.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 9. -- The steam dumper Cinderella, the first vessel of her kind ever launched, was sent down the ways at Nixon's ship yards here shortly before noon to-day. There was a big crowd to witness the launching. There were many engineers, contractors, and others who are interested in the success of such a craft present.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9. -- Bullish sentiment and bullish endeavor were in control of the wheat market this morning, and the price reached its highest point. The trade was brisk and heavy, tout resistance was offered to advancing prices by a number of holders, who, feeling that their profits were ample, for the present, threw a large amount of property on the market.

The City Vigilance League held it's annual meeting last night in the assembly room of the United Charities Building, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-second Street. Besides the speakers, Gen. Charles H.T. Collis, Theodore Sutro, the Rev. Dr. Hoffman, Police Commissioner Andrews, and other prominent men were on the stage.

ALBANY, Nov. 9. -- Court of Appeals Judge Irving G. Vann, who was re-elected last week, to-day filed with the Secretary of State his certificate of election expenses, which aggregated $3,555. Of this amount $2,500 was contributed to the Republican State Committee, and $1,000 to the Onondaga County Committee.
The largest bond sale ever attempted by the City of New-York has met with success.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Wheat had another of those strong days, such as have been recently emphasizing the growth of opinion favorable to much higher prices. The news was all bullish, and the absence of any short sellers of any account to be panicstricken by it alone accounts for the careful testing of the soundness of every step of advance before another is ventured upon which the market is permitted to exercise.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- The Treasury, for the first time in several years, is receiving gold in considerable quantities for customs duties, from this reason and from the further fact previously mentioned in these dispatches, that gold is being withdrawn from hoarding places and deposited in the various Sub-Treasuries, the gold balance at the close of business to-day had increased to $122,234,315.

At the annual meeting of the Vigilance League on Monday night "Dr. PARKHURST issued a declaration of renewed hostilities against the power of Tammany in this city and gave warning that in the contest for the control of the City Government there must be no alliance with Republicans as Republicans or with Democrats as Democrats.
In only a slight degree, and that at evening, was the social atmosphere of the Horse Show yesterday more lively and gay than that of Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The returns to the Department of Agriculture for the month of November as to the rates of yield make the average of corn 27.3 bushels, which is above the yield indicated by the condition figures in October. Last year the preliminary estimate of yield was 26.2 bushels.

Mark A. Hanna was the chief guest of honor at the Republican Club last night. The occasion was the first of the series of monthly dinners which will be given this season by the club. The dinner last night was in the nature of a celebration of the election of McKinley and Hobart.

These are the words in which Lord SALISBURY on Monday evening referred to the Venezuelan controversy. He added that the only serious difficulty -- the definition of the settled districts -- had been solved by a suggestion from the United States Government. The spirit in which Lord SALISBURY spoke was very friendly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Americans who have followed the Venezuela case, and who are impatient to hear from their own Government the latest developments of the effort to bring about arbitration of the boundary dispute, are doubtless wishing tonight that a banquet could be provided at which Secretary Olney might add to the welcome information last night volunteered by Lord Salisbury at the Lord Mayor's dinner in London.

An understanding has been reached by a number of the leading Republicans who will sit in the Legislature next year for a radical change in the civil service law of the State of New-York. Its real, though of course not its avowed, purpose is practically to "beat" the law, to make its evasion practicable.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10. -- Two letters which were exchanged between the United States and Great Britain regarding Venezuela since the presentation of Mr. Olney's counter proposition of June 12, were given to the press at the State Department this afternoon, and help materially to clear up the situation.

For several weeks Surrogate John H. V. Arnold has had before him the legal dispute over the will of Henry B. Brandt. Brandt was a young man when he died, but he had managed to run through quite a lot of property, which he received from his father. Some had been left, however, and as it was not left to his widow absolutely, the will was contested by her.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- R.S. Taylor, in the Supreme Court of the United States, to-day continued the opening argument for the Government in the suit to cancel the Berliner microphone patent, owned by the Bell Company.

Well, a wicked and adulterous generation did but a tariff on tinplate. And what was the result? Why, the coutrary stuff actually refused to increase in price. Political economy, theology, seismology, and hypnotism all demonstrated beyond a shadow or a doubt that the price must go up.

Well, a wicked and adulterous generation did but a tariff on tinplate. And what was the result? Why, the coutrary stuff actually refused to increase in price. Political economy, theology, seismology, and hypnotism all demonstrated beyond a shadow or a doubt that the price must go up.

ALBANY, Nov. 10 -- The much-discussed question, of employing the prisoners in the penal institutions of the State so that the product of their labor will not come in competition with outside labor is being carefully considered by the State Prison Commission.

John T. McDonough, Commissioner of the State Bureau of Labor Statistics, has examined some fifteen factory employes as to what their wages have been for the last five years, the difference in wages paid to men and women, and the extent to which women workers have displaced men in factories.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Complaints are frequently made by traveling American bicycle riders touring through Germany of obstacles and delays caused by the vary rigorous laws governing the use of bicycles on the public roads in that country. For the benefit of such tourists, United States Consul Sawter at Glauchu cites a few of the stricter rules which cyclers are called upon to observe throughout the empire.

LONDON, Nov. 10. -- The announcement made by Lord Salisbury in his speech at the Guildhall last night, of the practical settlement of the Venezuelan trouble, has been receives with expressions of satisfaction by this afternoon's newspapers. The Pall Mall Gazette, in its comments, says that additional enthusiasm was given to the satisfaction with which the Premier's declaration was receives by the presence of Mr. Bayard, United States Ambassador, at the banquet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- There appears to be more anxiety in Washington than in Canton about the composition of Mr. McKinley's Cabinet, and prodigious industry will be developed soon to make up the body of the advisers of the next President. Already there is speculation enough to fill the Cabinet over several times, and of course every ambitious Republican is "mentioning" his favorite as frequently and as advantageously as possible.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: A friend put Into my band yesterday a column of your Sunday paper headed "Funeral of Mr. Intnan," in which it was stated that I "asked that the soul of the dead might be received within the holy gates."

Mr. DINGLEY, Chairman of the House Committee on Ways and Means, expresses the opinion that "there is not the slightest ground for hope of the passage" of the Dingley tariff bill "by the Senate at the approaching short session." Senator SHERSLAJT says: "We shall make an effort to pass the bill.

The Department of Public Works has started a movement which is of great importance to the property holders, builders, and architects of the city. It will come in the nature of a revolution to certain portions of the business district, particularly along Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth, Twenty-third, Thirty-fourth, and Forty-second Streets.

TROY, N.Y., Nov. 10. -- In the Supreme Court, in this city, this afternoon, ex-County Treasurer George H. Morrison pleaded guilty to two indictments for misappropriating county funds, and was sentenced to ten years and five months' imprisonment in Clinton Prison. His decision to plead guilty was determined upon shortly after the reconvening of court for the afternoon session.

PATERSON, N.J., Nov. 10. -- Miss Fannie Parke Emerson, the only daughter of the late Dr. Amos Emerson, and Mr. Halsey Terrell, Jr., son of the ex-Alderman and present Chairman of the Ninth District Committee of this city, were married today at the home of the bride, 967 Madison Avenue.

The price of wheat will not be affected by newspaper articles or the opinions of any one not directly concerned in buying or selling that interesting commodity. At the same time, it is worth pointing out that a considerable number of active but conservative financiers hold the view that it is quite possible for wheat to advance so fast and so far that embarrassment and even mischief may follow.
ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- Gov. Morton to-day issued the following Thanksgiving proclamation:

CHICAGO, Nov. 11. -- Wheat took a sudden drop this morning on 'Change. It was difficult to understand the weakness in the leading speculative market. Wheat was sick in all markets from the start. In this market it showed a straight drop from the Tuesday's closing of 2 cents. Without waiting for any definite bear news the trade appeared to be in a disposition to sell everything in sight for a turn.

The compromise that is being arranged between the Lottimer heirs through the signing of an order by Judge Lawrence of the Supreme Court permitting Frederick W. Jones to obtain an agreement of settlement as guardian for Edythe P. Jones. The suit, which was brought before Judge Lawrence, was in the name of Mrs. Eliza G. Jones and her four children.

Although the Knights of Labor and the American Federation, of Labor have had prepared and published a memorial to the Commissioners of Jurors, declaring that in the selection of Grand Jurors there is discrimination against laboring men, and asking that representatives whom they name be included in the next jury list, the Commissioners, Recorder Goff said yesterday to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES, have not received the memorial.

It will be recalled that the "Lexow sub-committee" of the two Committees on Cities which had charge of the Greater New-York bill at the last session of the Legislature was continued, to be in some way subsidiary or auxiliary to the commission intrusted with the framing of a charter.
A day of clouds and winds, rain, and fog, fortunately followed soon after nightfall by clearing skies and cool winds from the west, made the third day of the Horse Show one of contrasts and changes.

Jordan -- Storm. A fashionable out-of-town wedding last night was that of Miss Adelaide Rowley Storm, who was married at 6:30 o'clock, at the residence of her uncle, A. Edward Faber, 38 Rockview Avenue, Plainfield, N. J., to Mr. Gilbert Everson Jordan of Hudson, N.Y.

The official canvass of the vote cast at the last election was begun yesterday morning at 10 o'clock by the Aldermen, acting as a Board of Canvassers. Each Alderman is required to read the returns for his own district.

A dinner given last night by the Union League Club of Brooklyn to Timothy L. Woodruff, Lieutenant Governor-elect, and to the other successful candidates from Brooklyn, was attended by the local Republican politicians and other prominent guests, over 500 in number. William Berri presided.

That is a somewhat painful controversy, if it may be called a controversy, between Mr. COUDERT, President of the Manhattan Club, and Col. BROWN, one of its most inveterate members, of which THE TIMES gave the documents yesterday morning. One cannot help entertaining a certain sympathy with Col. BROWN.

We perform a plain duty in calling attention to the proposed wasteful and extravagant use of the public funds in advertising in six daily newspapers of this city the official statement by the Board of County Canvassers of the vote cast at the election of Nov. 3 in the County of New-York.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 11. -- President Gilman of Johns Hopkins University, and one of the members of the Venezuelan Commission, was asked to-day for his opinion as to whether the effect of the published decision was to make the Monroe doctrine international law or to establish a virtual protectorate on the part of this country over Venezuela.

Major John Byrne, President of the Democratic Honest Money League, in order to clear away the general impression that he had not accorded fair treatment to Mr. Charles V. Fornes, the honest-money candidate for Congress in the Fourteenth District, wrote a letter to THE NEW-YORK TIMES, in which he reflected on the good faith of Mr. Fornes.

The action decided on by the Department of Public Works with reference to the authority of the city over the sidewalks and the legal limit covered by that term is a matter of very great importance. THE TIMES has set forth clearly and in detail the legal ground on which Commissioner COLLIS is proceeding.

Expert book buyers attended in force again yesterday the third day's sale of the library of the late Henry F. Sewall, in the auction rooms of Bangs Co., 93 Fifth Avenue. Two more days will be required to sell the first one-third of the library, and the interest increases to the collector of rare books as the sale goes on.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 11. -- It appears to be the purpose of General Master Sovereign of the Knights of Labor to put the organization of which he is the head into politics and to give the support of that organization to the free-silver cause. On the assembling of the Knights of Labor to-day Mr. Sovereign delivered the annual address, saying:

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 11. -- Chauncey Goodrich Parker was married this afternoon in Trinity Church to Miss Dora Mason Wright, daughter of Col. Edward H. Wright. Mr. Parker is the son of Cortlandt Parker. The ushers were Edward H. Wright, Jr., brother of the bride; Archibald J. Barklie, Cortlandt Parker, Jr., brother of the groom; Charles G. Beekman of NewYork, Edward C. Hammond of Boston, and Frederick Frelinghuysen.

ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- James J. Belden, the successful Congressional candidate in the Onondaga-Madison district, to-day filed with the Secretary of State a statement of his campaign expenses which aggregated $13,180. He gave $10,180 to C.H. Duell, Chairman of the McKinley League County and Congressional Committees; $500 to D.W. Peck, Chairman of the Onondaga Democratic County Committee, and $2,500 to Secretary E.M. Belden for campaign expenses.
ALBANY, Nov. 11. -- It has been generally talked about the Capitol for the past month that the next United States Senator from New-York would be Thomas C. Platt, should he care to accept the place.
Chairman Marcus A. Hanna has gone to Ohio. He closed his work at Republican National Headquarters yesterday afternoon, and, accompanied by his family, departed at 6 o'clock.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 11. -- The annual flower show of the New-Jersey Horticultural Society opened last night in the large tennis building of the Orange Athletic Club. The number of entries is unusually large, and they include some choice varieties of orchids, chrysanthemums, and foliage plants.

The Prison Commission of this State held a meeting at Albany on Tuesday to consider a plan for giving employment to the inmates of the penal institutions after the present year, and expects to take final action on the subject at another meeting to be held on the 1st of December.

To the Editor of The New- York Times: We generally hear those who oppose vivisection spoken of as "sentimental" and "hysterical," but may we not take heart to say a few words against a practice which was condemned by a man like Lord Chief Justice Coleridge, as follows?

Gov.-elect Frank S. Black came to this city yesterday and stopped at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. It was his first visit since election. He said he was well over the fatigue of the campaign. He wore a short coat, an Alpine hat, and a black tie, having discarded the white lawn which he used to wear on all occasions.
The completion of the organization of the Greater New-York German Orphan Dowry Society will mark the establishment of a unique charity based on novel lines.

Politicians, legislators, and newspapers are talking about the Dingley Tariff bill, which was sent to the Senate by the House at the last session of Congress. There seems to be some misunderstanding about the provisions of this bill and as to the probable effect of the enactment of them.

The Brooklyn Democratic Club, an organization with which Edward M. Shepard at one time was affiliated, last night refused to adopt resolutions looking toward an amalgamation with the regulars. The fear was generally expressed by the speakers that the regulars would swallow them and that they would lose their identity in politics.

LEADVILLE, Col., Nov. 12. -- The bitter hatred which for some time existed between the striking union miners and the imported non-union men from the lead mines of Missouri brought about a second riot at 2 o'clock this morning, which resulted in the death of Steven Frankowitz, the fatal wounding of Jerry Dormandy, and serious injuries to half a dozen others, all strikers.

It is not wonderful that Seuor CANOVAS DEL CASTILLO should be kept busy denying rumors about Cuba. As in business "rumors" are not apt to originate and gain currency except about a shaky concern, so in international politics they are generated by a losing and declining nation.

It is possible that SOVEREIGN, the "General Master Workman" of the Knights of Labor, is sufficiently passionate and fanatical in his advocacy of what he conceives to be the interests of workingmen to believe the statements which he made in his address to the General Assembly, at Rochester, but if so he is so deluded as to be a dangerous leader.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- President Cleve- land will consider it a bit of good fortune if he may be able, on Dec. 7 or 8, to announce the agreement of the United States and Great Britain to a treaty of arbitration of the Venezuela-Guiana boundary.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12. -- Wheat closed to-day with a gain of 1 3/4 cents a bushel, thus recovering all but 1/8 of a cent of yesterday's decline. Strong as was the market here, it was beaten in that respect by nearly every prominent outside trading centre.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 12. -- John S. Lenz (Silver Dem.) was to-day officially declared to be elected to Congress from the Twelfth District, comprising the counties of Franklin and Fairfield, and was given a certificate.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 12. -- Justice Dykman handed down his decision this morning on the application of New-York City for the removal of Frederic Shannavd and James W. Boyle, Commissioners to appraise land taken in connection with the water supply. The city charged unnecessary and unwarranted delay by the Commissioners.

LONDON, Nov. 12. -- Mr. Bernard Abrahams of counsel for the defense in the case of Mrs. Walter M. Castle of San Francisco, who pleaded guilty last week to charges of shoplifting, was sentenced to three months' imprisonment and subsequently pardoned, has sent to the offices of The United Associated Presses the following communication:
Commissioner John T. McDonough of the State Bureau of Labor Statistics has examined several servants and typewriters in regard to the exactions of the private intelligence offices.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- " Scare " stories about an imminent war with Spain on account of Cuba were printed here this morning, but until dispatches from "Wall Street, making anxious inquiries about the warning information were received here by stock brokers' representatives, the stories were regarded as no more worthy of serious concern than the recent preposterous sensations promising that the little Bancroft was about to undertake the forcible passage of the Dardanelles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12. -- Nothing short of party caucuses of Senators will clear? away doubt about the possibility of the passage by the Senate of the Dingley Tariff bill. The efforts to poll Senators have not been satisfactory to remove doubt.

The speech of Senator SHERMAN to the Brooklyn Republicans was a happy one. He feels cheerful as to the future, kindly as to the present, and apologetic as to the past. He recognizes how much the honest-money Democrats did to win the great victory; he sees how sectional lines have beer wiped out; he knows how business is reviving, and he faces the problems of currency and revenue with a light heart.

Yesterday a year ago was what has passed into history as "Marlborough Day" at the Horse Show, when the public, curious to see the young Duke and his bride, poured into the Madison Square Garden in such numbers as to break the record of attendance at the show.

History has not long delayed her verdict of justification upon President CLEVELAND'S Venezuelan message of Dec. 17. It has come within his term of office, within the twelvemonth, while the facts of the controversy and the principles asserted on both sides are yet fresh in the minds of the people.
ALBANY, Nov. 12. -- Daniel S. Griffin, the sound-money candidate for Governor, filed with the Secretary of State to-day a certificate stating that he expended $60.

BERLIN, Nov. 12. -- The Emperor performed the ceremony of swearing in the troops in the Lustgarten at 2:30 o'clock this afternoon in the presence of the Empress. Grand Duke Vladimir of Russia, who wore the uniform of the Hussar Regiment; the Siamese Field Marshal, and the Imperial Princes, who occupied the balcony of the palace facing the field altar, before which the ceremony took place.

YORKVILLE, S.C., Nov. 12. -- The verdict in the case of the State against Mrs. Ellen Anderson, Daniel Luckie, and M.R. Reese was rendered this afternoon, and a few minutes afterward Reese was shot down while attempting to escape from an officer.
A municipal hotel for the waifs and strays of humanity who have not elsewhere to lay their heads will be opened about Nov. 20 at Twenty-third Street and First Avenue.

The London Chronicle of Nov. 2, 3, and 4 prints Nansen's own detailed account of his arctic voyage. It is a graphic narrative, highly embellished by pictures of a different and better sort than usually accompany stories of travel in the high North. For his forthcoming book, Nansen is to receive u10,000, and he will probably take half as much more from other writings.

YONKERS, Nov. 13 -- The inquest into the death of Hamlin J. Andrus, which was occasioned by the explosion of a bomb in his office Oct. 21, was held by Coroner C. A. Miles in the City Court room to-day.

Miss Kathrine Regan, a dressmaker, of 4 West Thirty-seventh Street, is about to begin a suit for $10,000 against Muxlow Co., the proprietors of the Guarantee Storage Company, in Forty-first Street, near Eighth Avenue. Her complaint is that the storage company removed her goods without authority, and refused to rerurn them until she paid $9,70.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- A new high record for wheat for the year was made here to-day. Wheat was strong on the curb before the opening because the early cable news was very bullish. The unofficial price on the curb touched 81 7/8c.

From The Boston Advertiser. THE NEW-YORK TIMES has offered a prize for an improvement on its motto, "All the news that's fit to print." If truth rather than terseness is wanted, that motto can easily be improved by inserting the word "suitable" before the word "news."

There is a newspaper car on all the Third Avenue Elevated trains running up town in the early part of each afternoon. The car next the engine, which is least patronized by the general public, is the one taken for this purpose and it is well filled with men, boys, and a ton or more of afternoon papers which are being taken to different destinations up town.

From The Toronto Mail and Empire. The work of St. George's Church, New-York, should be of special interest to Canadians, not only because its rector, the Rev. William S. Rainsford, D.D., is so well known in Canada, but because it enrolls in its membership and active workers a number of Canadians.
Gov. Oates of Alabama says in his annual message to the legislature of that State:

The police are rapidly closing in on the gang of swindlers of which John L. Bough was the ringleader and whose dishonest practices were exposed by the confession of William Valentine, now under indictment for forgery in Brooklyn. C.H. McLaughlin, one of the leaders of the gang, was arrested in Hoboken, N.J., Thursday night, with a young woman named Daisy Hampton, nineteen years old, who posed as his wife.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 -- A report telegraphed from New-York last night to the effect that Cardinal Gibbons, as well as Archbishop Ireland, had been attacked by Cardinal Satolli in his report to the Holy Father on American affairs, and that Cardinal Gibbons had become persona non grata at the Vatican is scoffed at by representative Catholics of this city.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The big battleship Iowa returned here this evening from her builder's trial trip off the Delaware Capes. The trial was essentially an engineer's trial, to give the ship's builders an idea of the power of the engines and the way in which they worked, and the speed developed was a secondary consideration of the trip.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 13 -- For the twenty-third time in the history of the organization, the Woman's Christian Temperance Union met in annual canvention this morning. The delegates to the number of nearly 500 assembled in Schuyler Memorial House at 8 o'clock and attended devotional exercises led by Miss Elizabeth Greenwood of New-York.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court handed down a decision yesterday which is important as regards the law which makes void all charitable bequests made in a will within two months of the made in the testator.
By far the largest, the gayest, and the joliest crowd of the week was at the Horse Show yesterday for both the afternoon and evening sessions.

One of the first acts of the Republican Congress, elected last Tuesday, ought to be the passage of a vigorous Anti-Trust law. The time has come for putting a check upon the aggressions of combined capital.

A reception was given to Col. Waring, Commissioner of the Street Cleaning Department, by the Juvenile Street Cleaning League of the Children's Aid Society Industrial School, at 249 East Forty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon. The league numbers 250 children.
Spanish war fables dominated the stock market. Short interest extended. Few long stocks sold. Money on call, highest at 4 per cent., down to 3 1/2.

To the Editor of The New-York Times. In your number of Oct. 10 you publish a most interesting letter from Mr. John E. Parsons. I entirely agree with Mr. Parsons in his opinon as to the necessity of and Government's moving with great caution in Turkish affairs at present, and I feel quite certain that in seeking to protect our citizens the only course is to cultivate friendly relations with the Turkish Government.

Secretary of the Navy Herbert was the guest of honor last night at the dinner, given at Delmonico's, marking the close of the annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers. President Griscom presided, and introduced Mr. Herbert, whose address was received with prolonged applause.

Mr. Moody's 10 o'clock meeting in Cooper Union yesterday morning was attended by a larger crowd than usually goes to the forenoon services. There were as many lined up, waiting for the doors to open, as turn out in the afternoons, and the hall was just as full five minutes after the doors were opened as it has been at any time during this revival.

Members of the old families of New-York will be much interested in a project which has been started by the Van Cortlandt heirs, at Croton-on-Hudson, in setting apart about ten acres of the old Van Cortlandt manor land for the establishment of a cemetery.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Capt. Seccombe, who was in charge of the Cunarder Cephalonia when she went ashore off Holyhead on Dec. 31, 1895, and lost his command because of the accident, is now in the employ of B.P. Cheney, in the express business. His salary is $3,000, whereas he received but $1,800 as Captain of the Cephalonia.

Dr. E.R.L. GOULD of Johns Hopkins University says that "of all the model tenement houses in cities of 100,000 and over in this country and the Old World 88 per cent. are on a paying basis. That means at least 4 per cent. abroad and 5 per cent. or 6 per cent. here."

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- The Chronicle will to-morrow publish what it claims to be a complete summary of the agreement regarding the Venezuelan question. The article is entitled "Heads of a Proposed Agreement Between Venezuela and Great Britain for the settlement of the Venezuelan Boundary Question as Agreed upon Between Great Britain and the United States of America."

The decision of Judge WHEELER of the Connecticut Superior Court, by which a temporary injunction forbidding the completion of a trolley road between the cities of Hartford and New-Britain is made permanent, is one that will tend to check the growth of suburban trolley lines in that State.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 13 - -It is said here to-night that Governor Bradley will be advised not to call an extra session of the Legislature this Winter, as has been contemplated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- To a Senator who called upon him to-day to inquire in respect to the war rumors in regard to Cuba, President Cleveland replied that the position of this Government was, as stated in his last annual message to Congress -- one of traditional sympathy with a people struggling for autonomy and freedom.

The suit of the United States against La Compagnie Francaise des Cables Telegraphiques, the United States and Haiti Telegraph and Cable Company, and the United States and Haiti Cable Company came up before Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court yesterday afternoon on a motion for an injunction to restrain the defendant companies from establishing sub-marine cable termini upon the shores of this country.

The first convention of Jewish women, to be held in this country, will meet at 3 o'clock to-morrow afternoon in the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street. The delegates compose the National Council of Jewish Women. The sesslons will continue until Friday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- It is said on good authority that Secretary Olney is much put out by the publication of the situation in the Venezuelan matter.

Of the newest school of Italian operatic composers America's practical acquaintance may be said to be limited to two representatives -- Mascagni and Leoncavallo. Smareglia, the Dalmatian, and Franchetti are already rather among back numbers. From time to time, more or less prejudiced statements come to us of what others among "Italy's bright young men" -- Puccini, Tasca, Cilea, and Giordano in especial -- are achieving to make themselves topics of local critical enthusiasm.

Richard V.D. Wood, who has been acting as assistant cashier of the Metropolitan National Bank, now in liquidation, is missing, and it is said that he took and disposed of $60,000 worth of the securities of the bank for his individual purpose.

It is said that a strong corporation is soon to be formed to conduct a transportation business upon the waterway between this city and Buffalo. The plan is to have a fleet of steam canalboats, each with a complement of consorts, and facilities for elevating and storage at both ends of the line, and to utilize electric power so far as practicable by an arrangement with the Cataract General Electric Company.

TACOMA, Washington, Nov. 13 -- The result of the election in Washington has caused such an interest among bankers, dealers in securities, and mercantile houses of New-York and Philadelphia that many letters are being received here inquiring as to the true state of political affairs in this State.

John Y. Foster. John Y. Foster, Secretary of the New-Jersey State Republican Committee, and one of the editors of Frank Leslie's Weekly, died at his home in Newark yesterday after an illness of nine days. The cause of his death was pneumonia, contracted while performing the duties of his position in the State Committee.

Oscar Hammerstein received a memorandum last night from William Brinkerhoff informing him that Camille D'Arville was ready to fulfill her contract with him up to May 1, 1897, provided he fulfilled all obligations required of him by the agreement. "This notice virtually means." said Miss D'Arville's lawyer," that if Mr. Hammerstein pays my client the sum of $825 due her she is quite willing to resume her role in 'Santa Maria' and fulfill her contract.

CONNEAUT, Ohio, Nov. 13 -- The steamer Wallula, ore-laden, from Ashland, Wis., went ashore while trying to make this port in the storm this forenoon. When it appeared as though she was going to miss her pier, the crew scuttled her, hoping to make her right up. The effort was a failure, and she went upon the rocks.

The bankers of various cities from Minnesota to Maryland are expressing themselves in a more or less formal manner in favor of getting the Government "out of the banking business." The feeling is strong everywhere among all business men that this ought surely to be done, and to be done as promptly as possible.
LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Edward J. Ivory, the alleged dynamite conspirator, was committed for trial to-day by the Bow Street Police Magistrate.

The Republicans of the Thirty-third Election District of the Nineteenth Assembly District gave a dinner in the Hotel Majestic, Seventy-second Street and Eighth Avenue, last night in celebration of the victory of the party, and as the hosts said, "in commemoration of good government." This district was almost equally divided between the two great parties in politics.

Policemen and citizens of the Twenty-seventh Precinct had a hot chase after a burglar yesterday afternoon, and he assaulted a citizen with a jimmy and tried to shoot two policemen with a revolver before he was finally disarmed and captured.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Prospect Hill was the scene here to-day of a Winter contest of a most unusual kind. Arrayed against each other on the cricket field were two elevens of young athletic maidens; one from Mrs. Hazen's boarding school, Pelham Hall, and the other from Rosemary Hall, a similar institution at Wallingford, Conn.

Two more firemen's names were inscribed yesterday on the honor rolls of the department. The name of one was inscribed with those who, forgetful of their own lives, have in the midst of awful peril saved others. The second was honored for having made the most efficient fire company in the department.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 14. -- Walter I. McCoy won the first and Robert S. Sinclair the second prize in the medal handicap tournament played on the golf links at the South Orange Field Club this afternoon. The scores made in the tournament were as follows:

Edgar S. Schiefflin of East Chester, a part of whose estate is a piece of forest known as Schiefflin's Wood, was a complainant in the Harlem Police Court before Magistrate Brann yesterday against three Polish women, whom he charged with cutting the trees in the wood.

BOSTON, Nov. 14. -- Harvard received another crushing defeat this afternoon in its last game on Soldiers' Field, scoring only six points to eight by the Boston Athletic Association team. The game was witnessed by 1,000 enthusiasts, who were willing to sit in snow and be buffeted by the bleak north wind in order to see these leading local teams struggle after the pigskin through slush and mud.

Richard V.D. Wood, the assistant cashier of the Metropolitan National Bank, who, it is alleged, absconded with $60,000 of the bank's securities, is still at large, and the Federal officials who are trying to capture him think that he is in Canada.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- The annual report of the Commissioner General of Immigration, made public to-day, shows that the total arrivals during the fiscal year aggregated 343,267, an increase of 84,708 over the preceding year. Of this total 340,468 were landed and 2,799 were debarred and deported at the expense of the various steamship lines by which they came to this country.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 14. -- The football game with the New-Jersey Athletic Association to-day may be taken as an indication of what Tale may be expected to do in the game with Princeton. The first part of the playing served to develop the coaching the team has had during the past few days.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14. -- Pennsylvania team easily beat State College (Pennsylvania) this afternoon by the score of 27 to 0. State was very weak, and Pennsylvania scored its points by plain straight football of a rather indifferent kind.

The official canvass of the vote for Presidential Electors and Representatives on Nov. 3 has not yet been completed in all the States. In some of them it will be a week or ten days before the final and exact result can be known.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14. -- The Princeton football season entered upon its final stage this week. With the championship Harvard game off their hands, the coachers are now directing their attention toward the other great game of the Princeton season, the contest with Yale, which, if won, will bring back the championship to Old Nassau.

As Mr. CLEVELAND'S term draws to a close -- he will send his last annual message to Congress two weeks hence -- the public mind naturally turns to the main features of his remarkable career, and the more closely these are studied the more sincere and strong will be the feeling of honor and gratitude in the hearts of the American people.

Col. Stuart Weatherley, Chief of Artillery on the staff of Gen. Maximo Gomez, is in New-York, after a year of adventurous campaigning with the Cuban Army. He is silent as to his mission in the United States, but gave to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday many facts concerning the military situation in the island that have not heretofore been published.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Notwithstandins the Horse Show in town, which took many of the cottagers away this week, including Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gould, Miss Turnbull, and Mr. and Mrs. Dwight M. Harris, the week has been far from a dull one. Monday evening, Jasper Lynch, James Converse, and Robert BagS Kerr went to dine with Mr. Gould, and to occupy his box.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14. -- Four weeks from to-morrow Congress will meet to resume the work that it dropped early in the Summer, and the members of the House and Senate who are doomed to retirement will appreciate the sensation of a leave-taking of the capital that will be trying only for the period of three months.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 14. -- Mrs. W.E. D. Stokes of New-York, who has been investing in Kentucky blue grass land and trotters, sustained a heavy loss last night in the burning of one of her barns, together with nine head of the choicest stock on her farm.

Miss Marie Halton and Oscar Hammerstein severed connections last night. Miss Halton, who was next to Miss D'Arville in the cast of "Santa Maria," stated that her reason for leaving the Olympia was the fact that the manager had failed to recognize her when Miss D'Arville resigned.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 14. -- There were some close contests in the second day's play for the pair of prizes offered in the handicap foursome tournament at the links of the Essex County Country Club this afternoon. The final play in this tournament will be on the last Saturday in December, and the winners will be the two players who have made the lowest net score in the tournament.

Rudolph Quensell, an insurance broker at 1 Third Avenue, who lived at 1,800 Lexington Avenue, escaped last Wednesday from the sanitarium at Chester Hill, in Mount Vernon. His body was found yesterday morning in a pool made by the overflow of the Bronx River, in a Mount Vernon lane.

The three Russian adventurers who, after an experience with the Cuban insurgents in the field, surrendered to the Spanish authorities and were ordered to leave the Island of Cuba, and who were detained at Quarantine when they arrived last Monday on the steamship Yumuri, were taken to Ellis Island yesterday.
Commissioner Parker yesterday sent a letted to Mayor Strong in which he praised Chief Conlin for his good work in connection with the Police Department. The following is the letter in full:

Dr. Thomas H. Burchard. Dr. Thomas Herring Burchard, one of the best-known surgeons in the city, died suddenly yesterday afternoon at his residence, 53 West Fifty-second Street. He had had trouble with his heart for over two years, but was confined to his bed only two days before his death.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 14. -- A band of cutthroats and bandits have brought about a condition of terror among the Post Office officials and stage drivers of New-Mexico and Arizona, the like of which has not existed since the days of "Black Bart," thirty years ago.

The Orange Atheltic Club and the Elizabeth Athletic Culb football elevens played one of the best exhibition games witnessed in this vicinity this season at the Manhattan Field yesterday afternoon. It resulted in a tie score of 6 to 6. It was the second tie game of the season played to decide the football championship of New-Jersey, barring Princeton University, and was stubbornly contested from start to finish.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 14. -- The Sultan gave an audience last evening to Signor Panza, the Italian Ambassador, who insisted that the proposed reforms should be executed immediately. The Sultan promised that they should be enforced, but Signor Panza said that they were not being enforced.

When the Grand Jury of Queens County filed into the courtroom at Long Island City yesterday, they had a batch of indictments to hand up, and expected they would be discharged with the usual commendation.
William Jay Schieffelin, the newly appointed Civil Service Commissioner, to succeed Thomas Sturgis, was sworn into office yesterday morning by Mayor Strong at the City Hall.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 14 The Military Fair will be opened in the armory of Gatling Gun Company A in East Orange Tuesday night. Major Gen. Joseph W. Piume, commander of the National Guard of New-Jersey, will be present with his staff and will make an address.

Claudius E. Harrell, a dealer in furniture and bric-a-brac at 306 Fifth Avenue, was arrested by Deputy Sheriff Walgering yesterday and lodged in the Ludlow Street Jail in default of $12,000 bail. The arrest was made on an order signed by Justice Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, in a suit brought by Gesundheit Blairman of Manchester and Scarborough, England, to recover $15,000 for goods alleged to have been wrongfully converted by Harrell.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Nov. 14. -- The Sultan gave an audience last evening to Signor Panza, the Italian Ambassador, who insisted that the proposed reforms should be executed immediately. The Sultan promised that they should be enforced, but Signor Panza said that they were not being enforced.

TRENTON, Nov. 14 -- A delegation of twenty-four Jerseymen, representing veterans, officials, and Legislators, will go to Chickamsuga next Saturday and dedicate a monument erected in the National Military Park to the memory of the New-Jersey heroes.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 14. -- What is expected to prove one of the society events of the season in the Oranges will be the Carnival of Authors, to be held in Music Hall. Thanksgiving night, for the benefit of the House of the Good Shepherd. It will be given by the Young Ladies' Auxiliary.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 14 -- Earl Moore, a young man of about twenty-two years, convicted Thursday by a jury of prizefighting, was to-day sentenced to one year in the penitentiary by Judge Miller. The sentence would have been made heavier but for a petition from the jury for clemency.

We take a gratifying view of the result of the Presidential election when we consider that MCKINLEY received 272 Electoral votes to 175 for BRYAN, and that his popular plurality was about 1,000,000 votes, in spite of certain disadvantages in the Electoral system. Our complacency increases as we study the large majorities in the States of the East and in the most populous and advanced of the Commonwealths of the Central West.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW-YORK TIMES has very ably urged upon the incoming Administration the advisability of refraining from disturbing the business of the country by tariff tinkering. But will they refrain from so doing? Is it probable that any consideration of their debt to honest money but anti-tariff agitation Democrats will prevent such tinkering?

The vogue of the horse is ended. Society ended its first week of Winter gayety with the close of the jumping contests at the Garden last night. One day of rest is to follow, and then "all the world" will devote itself to the opera for several weeks to come with all the energy with which it has given itself over to the horses for the last six days.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 14. -- Under the auspices of the Lincoln Bimetallic Club, the local Traveling Men's Bryan Club, and what was known during the campaign as the "Bryan Home Guards," William J. Bryan to-night delivered his first formal address since the election.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 14 -- Andover grave Exeter a sound thrashing this afternoon, defeating her old rival by a score of 28 to 0. Andover was far superior to her opponent in defensive and offensive play. Exeter was weak on the ends and Andover made long gains at those points. At centre Pierson was too strong for Kasson, and the latter was knocked out several times.

The members of Good Government Club C will hold their next monthly dinner next Saturday evening, at the City Club, when the subject of "The Municipal Campaign of 1897" will be taken up. Members of Good Government Club C have found the monthly dinners most interesting. Questions relating to municipal reform are discussed at each.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 14. -- An immense crowd gathered at League Park this afternoon to witness the game of football between the Indian team from the Carlisle (Penn.) Indian School and the University of Cincinnati eleven. The occasion was made a grand social affair, the boxes being occupied by the Mayor, Capt. Winthrop of Ft. Thomas, and leaders of Cincinnati society.

It seems to be generally agreed that this year's Horse Show as a "social function" is less successful than any of its recent predecessors. That is to say, there were fewer well-known people in the boxes, and fewer brilliant and especial "confections" worn by them, and fewer people came to stare at them.

ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 14 -- At the opening of the Navy vs Lehigh football game today, play began with the ball in the hands of Lehign, who punted well up toward the goal of the Navy. The ball declined to stick in the hands of the Navy's full back, Woods, and as it bounded off, Gass of the Lehigh picked it up and made a touchdown for the visitors in a trice.

LONDON, Nov. 14. -- Notwithstanding the fact that the Sultan has promised to execute sweeping reforms throughout his dominions, his promises are still looked at askance by those here who have had experience of his artfulness and lack of good intention, and this in spite of the fact that orders have already been given for the putting into effect of some of the reforms promised.

The "servant-girl question" has been cited by misogynists as a proof of the Inaptitude for affairs of the female sex. It is pointed out that this question has been wholly in charge of women, with the result that within a generation the wages of domestic service have been multiplied by three, without any increase in the average quantity or quality of service, and that the servant-girl question remains the most perplexing of domestic problems.

H.K. Van Meter, a son of the Rev. W.C. Van Meter, for a long time a missionary in Armenia, has prepared a brief review of the records of Armenian outrages. These records have been carefully prepared by Mr. Van Meter, and are full of interest.

The committee appointed by the Board of Education to revise the manual for the public schools has made its report, and it is now in the hands of each Commissioner and being considered, so that when the report is taken up the board may be fully conversant with the provisions.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- The football game yesterday between Yale and the New-Jersey Athletic Association team served a double purpose. It showed the effect of the coaching the Yale team had received during the week, and also showed how the team could play in the absence of Hinkey. The work of coaches has relieved Capt. Murphy of much responsibility for training the team, and his playing has improved materially.
It is all very well to tell Congress what to do, but the worst part is that Congress generally won't do it.

First Assistant District Attorney Miles of Kings County, who was charged yesterday by a morning newspaper with certifying to the honesty of James G. Wilson, otherwise known as Abner W. Coverly, an ex-convict, and by whom, through Miles's introduction, John G. Crane of 648 1/2 Sussex Avenue, Newark, N.J., is said to have lost $1,000, indignantly denied last night the truth of the story.

James W. Foster, a law student, was found by a policeman lying on the sidewalk at 4:15 o'clock yesterday morning near the side door leading to P.M. Brady's hotel, Forty-ninth Street and Eighth Avenue, suffering from what the physicians at Roosevelt Hospital think a fracture of the base of the skull, and very serious.

Mrs. Emma Scrobiss, a seamstress, living at 611 East Sixth Street, was called upon, by Jacob Deubert, agent for the Gerry society, yesterday, who said he had authority to take charge of her daughter, Alfreda, fifteen years old. Mrs. Scrobiss became so violent that Deubert called in two policemen, and a patrol wagon had to be summoned to take the woman to the Union Market Station.

The weekly statement of the New-York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, shows an increase in reserve of $8,693,525. The banks now hold $23,503,925 more than the legal requirements. The changes in the averages show an increase in loans of $3,228,900, an increase in specie of $8,266,300, an increase in legal tenders of $4,407,200, an increase in deposits of $15,919,900, and a decrease in circulation of $17,200.

Two of the "Moral Dangers of Life in a Great City" were described yesterday before the Society for Ethical Culture, at Carnegie Music Hall by Prof. Felix Adler. They were: "The difficulty of bringing up children in metropolitan environment" and "The perversion of the 'play instinct' among the adults."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The views of a number of prominent members of Congress have been obtained as to the probability of tariff legislation in the next session of Congress. Among these views are the following:

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday on the Ward Line steamship Santiago, from Nassau, were Capt. Michelson and six of the crew of the schooner Bessie E. Crane of Parrsboro, N.S., which was wrecked on Ragged Island, Bahamas, Nov. 2.

At Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon an audience that filled the auditorium to overflowing greeted Mr. Moody and his fellowworker, Ira D. Sankey. This crowd, estimated at between 4,000 and 5,000, did not comprise one-half of the number that endeavored to gain admittance and was turned away.

ROME, Ga., Nov. 15 -- The officials of this place are puzzled over a new sort of degenerate. Her name is Martha White, and she is now in jail here, charged with having instigated the killing of William Mason, a young man of this place, last week.

The Rev. Dr. William Justin Harsha, pastor of the Second Collegiate Reformed Church, in Harlem, preached last night on "The Revival Now in Progress in New-York" Dr. Harsha is Secretary of the committee of pastors under whose auspices the Evangelistic campaign now going on under the leadership of Dwight L. Moody was started.

The Arion concerts are social as well as musical events, but as musical events they are always among the most interesting of the season, and it was to be expected that the ample hall of the clubhouse would be crowded, as last night it was, for the first concert of the Winter. It was the first concert of the second season of the society under the direction of Herr Lorenz.
The Stock Exchange has long placidly looked on without doing anything out of the ordinary to add to its prestige, to defend its rights and good name, indeed.

The managers of Mr. BRYAN'S canvass sought, during the last weeks of the campaign, to account for the advance in the price of wheat in several ways. Their favorite explanation for some time was that Mr. HANNA and the Republican Committee had obtained control of the wheat markets of the world by the expenditure of an immense sum of money and were "putting up" the price for political effect in the agricultural districts.

Col. Mapleson's new Imperial Opera Company, Limited, gave another successful concert last night at the Academy of Music. Most of the principal artists and the full orchestra presenting an agreeable programme to a large audience. With the exception of two Wagner numbers and Liszt's "Rhapsodle Hongroise," by the orchestra, the programme was mainly a popular one.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- The strong tone to local securities which prevailed last week was continued throughout the present week. Sales of both local stocks and bonds were made at advanced prices. The largest gain was in Municipal Gas of Albany, which sold at 162, a gain of 12 points. Hudson River Telephone stock rose 2 and Celluloid 3 points.
"The Place of Woman in Modern Civilization" was the subject of the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman's discourse yesterday morning in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street. He said, in part:

At his own request, Mr. Frederick Saunders, for nearly forty years connected with the Astor Library, has been retired as chief librarian by the Trustees of that institution. His increasing years and the additional burden which would be placed upon him on the consolidation of the Astor with the Lenox and Tilden Libraries, induced him to present his application for retirement at the last meeting of the Board of Trustees, a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 15 -- Despite the fact that there is no probability of either this Congress or the next passing a free-ship bill, E.T. Chamberlain, the Commissioner of Navigation, in his annual report given to the press to-night, refers prominently to the subject, and urges the necessity for the passage of such a measure.

The presence in the city yesterday of a number of leaders from up the State gave rise to considerable political gossip about the corridors of the Fifth Avenue Hotel. How well founded it is will be seen when certain legislative appointments are made.
The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached in All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday morning on "The Moral Aspects of Corporation."
The Executive Committee of the Irish Political Prisoners' Fund Association held a meeting in Tecumseh Hall, in West Forty-second Street, yesterday afternoon, at which Chairman J.R. Kennedy presided.

"Bulls" are not all of Irish origin, or at least they do not all originate in Ireland. A dispatch from Constantinople printed by The London Telegraph contains his radiant specimen of the locution named. It runs thus: "Whether the powers will avail themselves of the opportunity to prevent the inevitable catastrophe that is impending remains to be seen."
BUFFALO, Nov. 15 -- The Cornell-Williams football game at the Buffalo Athletic Field yesterday resulted in a tie.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The alleged adulteration of lager beer is to be brought to the attention of the coming State Legislature. At the meeting of the State Board of Health on Thursday last, Dr. S. Case Jones of Rochester, Chairman of this committee, submitted a report, saying: "In the meaning of the law, beer is classed as food, and largely concerns the public health.
Money on call was easy, with rates at 3@5 per cent., with the average of loans about 4 per cent.
The first convention of the National Council of Jewish Women was opened last evening in the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, and will be continued until Friday.
I believe that we have made great progress. My friends, the cause was stronger the day after election than it was at any day during the campaign. -- [Mr. BRYAN at Lincoln, Neb., Nov. 14.]

They were shopping in one of the big up-town department'stores. By dint of much patience and adroit elbowing they reached a bargain counter upon which clocks and a miscellaneous assortment of mantel and table ornaments were displayed. "Oh, look at those lovely thermometers on golden standards, marked down to $4.90 from $15," exclaimed a feminine voice.

BERLIN, Nov. 15. -- Public interest has been greatly excited over the promised intetrpellation of the Centrist leaders in the Reichstag to-morrow, demanding that the Government disclose the nature of the Russo-German neutrality treaty, the existence of which, from 1884 to 1890, was revealed in Prince Bismarck's recent articles in his personal organ, the Hamburger Nachrichten, and an explanation why the agreement was allowed to lapse.

Thirty years ago, at the first International Convention of the Young Men's Christian Associations, an International Committee was formed, consisting of a number of men closely identified with the work, mostly resident in this city. The idea was to furnish some means by which the energies of the associations should be directed along useful lines.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Nearly $1,000,000 capital already has been subscribed, and plans are being matured for the formation in Chicago within two weeks of a gigantic commercial company, which is to enter the field of Chinese trade before the end of the month, as the rival of the American Trading Company, and eventually to obtain control of American trade in China.

The Republican Congressmen of Indiana have agreed to submit the selection of Postmasters in their several districts to a vote of the Republican patrons of each office. In the districts of the Democratic Congressmen the Postmasters are to be "accorded" to the Republican Senator.

A few years ago there was proposed a clearing house of cards for the use of society. It is true that pasteboard has played an increasing part in carrying on social relations, and that a fashionable woman, in the course of an afternoon's visiting, if she have adult males in her family, disperses nearly as many cards as if she were a sporting gentleman engaged in dealing a game.

An unusual prevalence of diphtheria in many small towns, with a high death rate, has been reported by press dispatches during the last few weeks. For example, in the town of New-Providence, N.J., where there are less than seventy school children, there were eight deaths from this disease last week, and it is probable that the number of fatal cases will be increased.

Enthusiasm is warranted over the weekly bank statement submitted at the close of last Saturday's Wall Street business. The overwhelming return of funds to normal channels gives good ground for anticipations of vastly better business.

CANTON, Nov. 15 -- A friend of Major McKinley said to-night that the President-elect was desirous that Congress should pass the Dingley bill this Winter, his feeling being against an extra session of Congress.

The firm of Joseph Wechsler's Sons, the dry goods dealers at Bedford Avenue and Fulton Street, Brooklyn, closed their doors at 10 o'clock last Saturday night on an order of Justice Gaynor, acting as trustee of the estate of Joseph Wechsler, who died three weeks ago, leaving an estate valued at $2,000,000.

PITTSBURG, Nov. 14 -- The market here has displayed a broadening tendency during the past week, although the actual business is still below expectations. The Westinghouse group displayed considrable strength, Union Switch and Signal common advancing to 20 1/2, the highest price of the year. Westinghouse Air Brake has sold in a small way at 175, with limited offerings at 180.

The remarkable sprinting of Bernard J. Wefers, the record holder, in the 100-yard dash at the Thirteenth Regiment Athletic Association's an- nual games, held Saturday evening in the armory, Sumner and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn, was a feature that was loudly applauded. The great runner's time -- 10 seconds -- beats the best previous board floor record by two-fifths of a second.

Yesterday afternoon was begun the fifth season of the delightful and unique concerts of chamber music arranged and directed by Mr. Sam Franko, at the Aschenbroedel Verein. The music-lovers who are so fortunate as to attend these concerts have the assurance, not only that everything will be well played, but that they will have opportunities of hearing music not elsewhere presented.

Mme. Hariclee Darclee, a prima donna of the New Imperial Opera Company (Limited) and Signor de Marchi, a tenor of the company, have severed connection with the organization and propose to go back to Europe.
Silver bullion certificates quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 3/4 @65 1/4. Sales of 116,000 ounces made during the week at 65 1/4 @ 64 5/8, with the last sale at 64 7/8, a decline of 7/8.

THE TIMES reminds us that the Dingley bill would increase many duties unjustly and restore the tax on raw materials, the abolition of which has given great aid to our manufacturers and needed relief to consumers.

Charles Frohman has at last definitely decided on his plans for the season of the Empire Theatre stock company. John Drew will continue at the Empire until after Christmas, presenting "Rosemary," and the regular company will open New Year's week, producing for the first time here "Under the Red Robe," a dramatization of Stanley Weyman's novel by Edward Rose, the adapter of "The Prisoner of Zenda."

Surely the Germans have a great nose for diseases. They have found them in our beef, in our pork, in our canned goods, and lately in our apples. Not only in these articles have the officials of the Fatherland discovered noxious germs, but they have found them also in some of our life insurance companies.

MADRID, Nov. 15 -- The newspapers unanimously express the opinion that the loan will result in an imposing demonstration of national enthusiasm, and that all classes will co-operate to cover the amount of the loan, which is nominally 250,000,000 pesetas. The bonds will be guaranteed by the customs revenue.

CANTON, Nov. 15 -- Major McKinley displays great interest in the speculations of the Cabinet makers of the country, but says nothing in reply to suggestions as to the make-up of his Cabinet. It is evident the President-elect has not made up his mind as to the formation of his Cabinet, nor even decided upon the geographical allotment of places.

The Church of the Pilgrims, Brooklyn, will commemorate during this week the fiftieth anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. Richard Salter Storrs, D.D., LL.D., and the jubilee services in honor of the event began yesterday morning. The church is one of the oldest in Brooklyn, and Dr. Storrs is the only pastor it has ever had.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- It is officially stated that King Humbert has received a telegram from Menelik, Emperor of Abyssinia, stating that a treaty of peace between Abyssinia and Italy was signed on Oct. 26.

A weary-appearing man, with a handbag, like its owner looking much the worse for wear, dropped in upon the cashier of a Wall Street institution one day last week. He had some business to transact, he said. The banker didn't know whether he had on his hands a professional humorist or a mere crank with a bomb.

When William Frienberg of 128 East One Hundred and Eighth Street, a butcher's delivery boy, with a big basket, tried to mount a rapidly moving Third Avenue cable car at One Hundred and Eighth Street yesterday afternoon, his basket was caught by an elevated railroad pillar, and he was thrown to the ground.
It was a delicately tinted audience that filled the big horse shoe, so soft in color tones that even diamond tiaras, sunbursts, and stars flashed with a subdued effect.

MALONE, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Dr. E.F. Osbaldiston, a masseur, and Mrs. Louisa Metzgar, nee Weisse, who have been spending recent Summers in Malone, were arrested in Montreal Friday night, charged with grand larceny for taking goods from the store of G.W. F.W. Fay of this village. When arrested, Mrs. Metzgar had on a cloak which F.W. Fay identified.

The package and information room of the Grand Central Station is a box-like structure, 20 by 8 feet, built of wood. It is in the extreme southeast corner of the station, and is lighted by windows in the heavy walls of the main building, on the Forty-second Street side. These windows are directly under the platform of the Forty-second Street branch of the Third Avenue elevated railroad.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- The Rev. H.W. Thomas, for seventeen years pastor of the People's Church of this city, has taken an associate in his ministerial work, and, beginning with next Sunday, will, in a large measure, step down and out of the pulpit which he erected and which he has made famous.

BUFFALO, Nov. 16 -- The trial of Senator Michael J. Coffey, accused of libel by ex-Assemblyman Charles Schoepflin, will begin in the Supreme Court here to-morrow. Several New-York politicians and newspaper men directly interested in the case arrived to-day. Among the witnesses are Senator George A. Owens and a number of NewYork and Buffalo newspaper men.

Aldace F. Walker, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company, who has just returned from Chicago, where he was busy with matters connected with the Kansas raid on the road, gave a history of the Granger endeavor yesterday.

Congressman-elect Thomas J. Bradley, who defeated Timothy J. Campbell, in the Ninth District, distinguished himself yesterday afternoon by rescuing from under the wheels of a Grand Street car eleven-year-old Abraham Rosenberg of 42 Essex Street.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 16 -- Richard Owens, the hotel keeper of this city who for five days had suffered from hiccoughs, died this afternoon. The hiccoughs resulted from an attack of erysipelas. Five days ago Owens had a severe and protracted fit of vomiting. When this subsided, the hiccoughs began, and did not give the sick man a single minute's rest afterward.
DENVER, Col., Nov. 16 -- Ex-Senator John J. Ingalls in an interview to-day on the late election in Kansas, said:

American shares were a fraction lower in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Canadian Pacific, 3/8, to 60; Declined -- St. Paul, 1/2, to 80; Louisville and Nashville, 1/2, to 53 1/8; New-York Central, 3/8, to 98 1/2; Atchison, 1/4, to 16 1/4, and Illinois Central, 1/8, to 99. Erie sold at 17 3/8, do first preferred at 38 1/2, Pennsylvania at 54 5/8, and Reading at 15 3/4.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The famous appeal of John Brown from the judgment of the District Court for the Western District of Arkansas was decided to-day by the United States Supreme Court, and Brown will be given a fourth trial on the charge of murdering Josiah Poorboy and Thomas Whitehead, United States officers in the Cherokee Nation, Dec. 8, 1891.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The correspondent of a Chicago newspaper who is well acquainted with a firm of stock brokers doing business in New-York and maintaining a Washington office on F Street has sent his paper a report accounting for the origin of the recent Cuban war scare, which is almost as interesting as the "scare" itself, and which does not fully explain to all who have heard it.

Policeman Cron of the East Twenty-second Street Station, who has made several high-handed arrests of women in Third Avenue, was yesterday reprimanded by Magistrate Cornell, in the Yorkville Police Court. He had arraigned Michael Creegan and James Hogan, workmen in Canary's livery stable, in East Nineteenth Street, early yesterday morning, and charged them with drinking beer in the street, acting boisterously, and insulting passers-by.

At a recent meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of Chattanooga, Tenn., the following committee report and resolution of compliment to the publisher of THE NEW-YORK TIMES were unanimously adopted: To the Chamber of Commerce of Chattanooga, Tenn.:

John W. Alexander, the well-known American artist, who arrived here on the steamer La Touraine last Saturday, is now in Washington, supervising the placing of his decorations in the Congressional Library. Mr. Alexander came directly from his Paris studio for this purpose, bringing with him the five panels that he was commissioned to execute.

Ten days ago Mayor Strong wrote a public letter requesting that the churches come to the aid of the city in furnishing temporary school accommodations for children who cannot now secure places in the overcrowded public schools.

It is not to be supposed that the action of Italy in the case of Abyssinia has been determined by the appeal made by King MENELEK to the Pope. The Italian acknowledgment of the complete independence of Abyssinia is none the less an acknowledgment of the complete defeat of Italy.
Stocks under bear attack, but concessions chiefly fractional. Call money, 3 to o per cent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- There were no orders to-day, and the few stocks offering found no buyers except at marked concessions in prices. The Cables, Diamond Match, and New-York Biscuit were 1/2 @ 3/4 lower. The closing was at a very slight recovery.

HAVANA, Nov. 16. -- No definite news regarding the movements of Gen. Weyler, operating against the rebels under Maceo in Pinar del Rio, has been received. The last reports stated that he was penetrating the Rubi Hills under a harassing fire from the insurgents, but since then nothing has been heard from him, and there is considerable anxiety among the loyalists here.

The Metropolitan Opera House was opened last evening for its thirteenth Winter season. It was a "first night" which, from the social standpoint, easily eclipsed in brilliancy and life all the "first nights" in the history of the famous house, brilliant and beautiful as many of these have been.
Vice President Frank S. Bond of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad said yesterday in discussing the outlook for Western business and the prospects of a trade revival throughout the county:

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16 -- To-day's football practice did not tend to strengthen the belief in the Tigers' ability to "down the blue." Hundreds of students were on the side lines, and they came away after the game with bowed heads. The team gave one of the most wretched exhibitions of playing seen here this season.
Messrs. Bernard Smyth Sons have sold to William H. Picken six lots on the south side of West Ninety-eighth Street, comprising the entire street frontage between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 16 -- Two thousand enthusiastic Princeton students and alumni crowded into the gymnasium tonight to cheer on the Princeton football team to victory over Yale next Saturday in the great game of the year. Alumni were present from the leading cities, and delivered stirring addresses.

At the last session of Congress I made the suggestion, in debating the question of an increase of revenue, that we should levy a duty of about 35 per cent, on tea, coffee, spices, cocoa, and matting, all of which articles are now on the free list, and the duties on them at the rate named -- 35 per cent. -- would produce about $40,000,000 per annum.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- December wheat to-day closed with a net loss of 3/4 of a cent from Saturday's prices. The option lost nearly 2 cents during the morning, and up to midday showed little power of recovery. Bull news appeared to have little effect. The market acted as if it was breaking under some powerful influence, regardless of the news.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 16 -- The coaches put the Yale team through the hardest practice of the season to-day. Two halves of fifty and thirty minutes were played. Fincke was taken back to quarter and Chauncey played full back. Benjamin and Mills were half backs. On the second scrub team, Sanford of "92" team played centre, Heffelfinger was at right guard, and "Brink" Thorne played full back for a short time.

A message of appeal addressed to the Latin-American Republics has been issued by Salvator Cisneros and Rafael Portuondo y Tamayo, the President and the Secretary of Foreign Affairs of the Cuban Republic. Copies of this message have already been received in Washington and this city.

We recently pointed out some of the conditions which had made Bryanism the professed creed of the Democratic organization. Among these conditions were blind partisanship and the worship of "regularity," the cowardice and demagogy of political leaders, ignorance as to what good money is, and the discontent of a large class who feel that the rich enjoy an undue share of the benefits of our present laws.

It is not in New-York alone that the tide of hoarded funds is returning to normal channels. Bank statements all over the country show the same thing. At Chicago it is especially encouraging. Says The Chicago Sunday Times-Herald:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
