The first effect of the appeal by the Cuban revolutionists to the Latin American republics must be to dispel the impression which Spain has sought to create of the character of the insurgents. They have been represented to comprise only the dregs of the population of the island, to include numerically a large part of the population, but not to include any of the character, intelligence, or substance of Cuba.

John Wanamaker has come to New-York. That does not mean that he is to become a resident of this city; in fact his admirers in Pennsylvania hope and expect that he will soon become a resident of Washington as the successor of Senator Cameron in Congress.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 16 -- Judge McCormick was asked to-day to release Miss Edith Behr, the young woman who was sentenced to three months' imprisonment by him on Saturday, on being convicted of assaulting the Bloy brothers. The lawyer told the Court that the young woman had been sufficiently punished, and that the men whom she was accused of assaulting were nearly twice her size and should be ashamed of prosecuting her.

President Robert Maclay of the Knickerbocker Trust Company was seen yesterday by a representative of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, and asked his opinion on the financial outlook and the general prospect for business improvement. Mr. Maclay said:

The interest in the first night of the opera is so much lucre social, or, if you prefer, human, than it is musical or dramatic, that the success of it depends more upon other considerations than it does upon the excellence of the performance. It is conceivable that the performance might have been as faulty as it was perfect last night, and still the occasion, as an occasion, been almost as memorable.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Members of the Bondholders' Committee of the Chicago and Northern Pacific Railroad made a tour of inspection of the property to-day, preparatory to bidding it in at the foreclosure sale to-morrow. The committee will offer $10,000,000 for the road, including assets of every kind, and also assume the preferential mortgages, one of which runs to the City of Chicago, and conveys the site of the Grand Central Passenger Station.

LA PORTE, Ind., Nov. 15 -- An epidemic of diphtheria is threatened in a number of localities in Northern Indiana. The entire Tomlinson family, six in number, living near New-Carlisle, has been wiped out by the malady. Four children in one family at Auburn have died, and general alarm prevails in the stricken district.
The money market was easy. Call loans at 3@5 per cent. The last loan was made at 4 per cent.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 -- The seventieth annual meeting of the stockholders of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was held today. The annual report of President Cowen was read and adopted, and the following Directors were elected: William F. Frick, James L. McLane, George C. Jenkins, Alexander Shaw, George A. Von Lingen, Maurice Gregg, and William H. Blackford of Boston; Louis Fitzgerald, Eugene Delano, Edward R. Bacon, William A. Read, and Howland Davis of New-York.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- Local stocks were very quiet, and finished at fractional declines from Saturday's closing prices. The feature of the session was Welsbach Commercial preferred, which declined 4 1/4 per cent, to 65 1/4, without any apparent reason, excepting that orders to sell came in at a time when the market was bare of support.

The effect of the recent election in Kansas upon the financial interests of the State is already perceived by those who have been engaged in lending money and in procuring capital elsewhere for the use of the inhabitants of that unfortunate Commonwealth. A correspondent of The United States Investor, writing from Abilene, said last week:

The Harlem business men are anxious to have a portion of the ocean traffic diverted from the lower bay to the upper end of the island. To this end a party of those interested yesterday inspected the Bronx kills around the north end of Randall's Island to see what would be necessary to open an oceanway to Harlem through the Sound.
Cooper Union was crowded from doors to platform yesterday afternoon with an audience eager to take part in the revival services now being conducted by Dwight L. Moody and his brother evangelists.
Thirteen seamen, including Capt. Nelson and his crew, of the British steamship Coila which foundered off the coast of Cuba Nov. 4, arrived here yesterday on the Ward Line steamship Yucatan.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 -- With the change in ownership of the Seaboard Air Line, which is expected to be consummated tomorrow by the transfer of a controlling interest to the syndicate headed by Mr. Thomas F. Ryan, one of the first effects will be a restoration of rates by all lines involved in the recent rate war.

The transmission of electric power from Niagara Falls to Buffalo, a distance of twenty two miles, which was successfully accomplished between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning, is the result of the enterprise, patience, and financial power of New-York capitalists.
PITTSBURG, Nov. 16 -- The Consolidated Steel and Wire Company, at Braddock, has started its works in full, employing 800 men.
-- The Lehigh Valley Railroad Company is gradually retiring the old four-wheeled coal cars of six tons capacity, and replacing them by eight-wheel cars of thirty tons capacity.

-- Even Chicago is puzzled by the fact that in his Thanksgiving proclamation Gov. ALTGELD, in referring to Providence, uses the pronoun "her." The Governor has found the course of events very discouraging of late, and perhaps he regarded it as so mysterious that he was unconsciously reminded of feminine ways of doing things.

Dr. Dorpfeld lectured yesterday, at the Academy of Medicine on "The Recent Excavations in Greece." He reviewed, and illustrated by pictures on the stereopticon screen, the work accomplished by the excavators of Germany, France, England, Italy, and America. These excavations had comprised the sites of ancient temples, cities, and theatres, the central points of earlier civilizations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- The Chicago syndicate controlling the celebrated Ronquillo estate expects soon to begin the argument in the district court, and to have a speedy decision, settling one of the greatest land-grant cases in the country, and involving title to 1,500,000 acres on the Mexican border of Presidio and Jeff Davis Counties, Texas.

The Fifth Artillery, which is stationed at Forts Hamilton and Wadsworth, made a satisfactory test of four of the five eight-inch breech-loading rifles at Fort Wadsworth yesterday. This was the first time a modern piece of ordnance had been turned on the water leading to the Narrows.

The first of the so-called Horse Show sales was held at the Madison Square Garden yesterday morning, afternoon, and evening under the management of W.D. Grand. There were a number of horses that had been entered for the show that were listed to be sold, but none of them managed to get away with many blue ribbons.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- There was a fair degree of activity in local stocks during the morning, but toward afternoon the market became dull and fell off all around. The dealings in mining shares constituted the bulk of the market, under the lead of Montana. That stock, declined 1 1/8, to 95, closing at the lowest point.

DENVER, Col., Nov. 16 -- On Sunday, Oct. 25, Andrew J. Spute, a prosperous grocer of this city, went boat riding on Smith's Lake, a suburban resort, with his wife and five children. The boat by some means was upset, and all except the husband were drowned.

Silvio Lenguciri, who shot his wife and fired a bullet into his head back of the ear, and Joseph Butler, who was shot in the arm by a patrolman, were taken from the prison ward of Bellevue Hospital yesterday to the "X-Ray Studio" of Drs. O'Connor and Hawkes in Fifty-third Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.

A ten-year-old woebegone-looking little girl, with disheveled hair enough drooping about her face and ears to suggest a hairy child of Borneo, answered in a piping tone of voice, when the name of "Stein, tenant," was called by Judge McKean in the Seventh District Court yesterday morning. She said her "Mamma just got her a little sister," her papa wouldn't be paid until Saturday night, and they wanted a few days to move.

An elevator car, containing thirteen person, fell from the tenth floor to the cellar, a distance of 150 feet, in the building of the American Tract Society, at Nassau and Spruce Streets, yesterday afternoon.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Mrs. Alma Merritt, wife of George William Merritt of New-York, died in this city Saturday night under circumstances that at first led to the belief that she had committed suicide.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 -- The Philadelphia Wool Merchants' Association met this afternoon to take action on the Dingley bill.

When Miss Felicia A. Griffin, the Principal of Grammar School No. 47, in East Twelfth Street, told the teachers and pupils in the Grammar Department that she had been slated for transfer to the charge of Grammar School No. 50, in East Twentieth Street, they cried.
-- The effective melodrama called "Shaft No 2" is this week's play at the Grand Opera House. Frank Losee is the sturdy hero.
Public interest, quite outside of Wall Street, will attach to the following statement issued yesterday by the financial news agency of Dow, Jones Co.:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 16 -- William Jennings Bryan was in Kansas City a short while this morning, leaving for a two weeks' hunting and fishing trip in the Ozarks, in Taney County, Missouri. He will join a party consisting of Gov. William J. Stone, Senator James K. Jones of Arkansas, Daniel J. Campau of Michigan, and others.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 16 -- It is denied here to-night on high naval authority that Admiral Bunce's fleet is going to the West Indies. Navy Department officials scout the idea, and say the fleet is in no condition to go, even if there was cause for its moving.

The steamship Orinoco, which arrived here yesterday from Bermuda, brought word of the safe arrival there, on Nov. 4. of the boat sent off by the disabled steamship Strathisla Oct. 17, with orders to look out for a passing steamship or to make Bermuda and secure assistance.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Encouraged by the result in Albany County, which gave a plurality of 4,426 for McKinley and 2,692 for Black, State Committeeman and Leader William Barnes, Jr., seems to be reaching out for nearly everything in sight. This is the first Presidential campaign since 1872 in which the Republican nominee has been given a plurality in Albany County.

The Boston Herald says: "So firm is the belief in good times, however, that professional traders are liable to grow weary waiting for sellers, and become buyers themselves. The market may become dull, but it does not act like breaking very badly. To-day's New-York bank statement is calculated to encourage the long side of the market.

A crude play, performed as a whole with more zeal than dramatic intelligence, was nevertheless enjoyed by the large audience at Palmer's last evening. "Roaring Dick Co." does not lack vitality; it contains one or two strongly dramatic situations, and its big show scene, the children's festival, cannot help but attract spectators for a time.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 16 -- The Macon and Birmingham Railroad filed a mortgage here to-day for $500,000 to the Old Colony Trust Company of Boston, Mass., bonds to that amount having been issued to protect the mortgagee.

POUKHKEEPSIE, Nov. 16 -- Frederick W. Pugsley, an elderly lawyer with a large practice, greatly surprised his lawyer friends a few days ago. While on the witness stand he was asked, as a matter of form, "Are you married?"

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 16 -- A local paper here to-day reproduces a column of criticisms of the people of Kansas because the State cast its Electoral vote for Bryan. These comments are taken from Chicago and New-York metropolitan newspapers. The local paper says:

The celebration in honor of Dr. Richard S. Storrs's fiftieth anniversary as pastor of the Church of the Pilgrims. Brooklyn, was continued last night with a dinner and the presentation of a loving cup by the Manhattan Association of Congregational Ministers. The dinner and presentation ceremony took place in the lecture room and parlor of the Clinton Avenue Congregational Church.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 16. -- E.W. Curry, Chairman of the Democratic State Committee, is dying of blood poisoning here.

Prof. William M. Sloane of Prince ton was yesterday appointed, by the Trustees, to be the first occupant of the Seth Low Professorship of History, recently established at Columbia University, in recognition of President Low's million-dollar library gift. Herbert L. Osgood, Ph.D., and William A. Dunning, Ph.D., Adjunct Professor of History, will be promoted to the position of associates with Dr. Slcane.

The annual meeting of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States was held at the Astor House yesterday. The old officers were re-elected. The proposed plan to register athletes was referred to a committee, with instructions to report by Jan. 1. An alliance was entered into with the National Interscholastic Amateur Athletic Association of the United States.

At the meeting of the Police Board yesterday, President Roosevelt read a voluminous report in reply to the criticism that Commissioner Parker had made on the methods of examining applicants for the force. The report was, in part, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- After litigation extending over a period of five or six years, the California statute locally known as the Wright Irrigation Law, has been pronounced to be constitutional and valid by the Supreme Court of the United States, and the validity of the $16,000,000 of bonds issued thereunder is affirmed.

President Alexander E. Orr sat at the centre of the guests' table. To his right were Postmaster General William L. Wilson, Gov. John W. Griggs of New-Jersey, Whitelaw Reid, Mayor William L. Strong, Seth Low, Samuel D. Babcock, Charles S. Smith, Gen. Nelson A. Miles, and the Rev. David H. Greer, D.D.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 -- The much-talked-about Seaboard Air Line deal received a knock-out blow this afternoon when the committee, which has some 8,000 shares of the stock pooled, refused to turn it over to the syndicate headed by Thomas F. Ryan of New-York. The decision was a great surprise to every one, excepting President Hoffman and a few of his associates.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: Mr. Turnure's letter on this subject is so candid and thoughtful that it deserves careful consideration. Mr. Turnure does not overstate, the danger to which our citizens are exposed, not only in Constantinople, but everywhere in Turkey. The practical question is, What are we going to do about it?

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 -- Steinitz claimed an off day in the championship chess match to-day.

Miss Felicia A. Griffin, Principal of Grammar School No. 47, in East Twelfth Street, talked plainly yesterday of the attempt that, she asserts, was made to coerce her into accepting a transfer to Grammar School No. 50, in East Twentieth Street, as planned by Superintendent Jasper. She is still very indignant at the treatment she received in the matter.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- The Right Rev. William Croswell Doane, the Episcopal Bishop of Albany, in his annual address, delivered to-day before the twenty-eighth annual convention of the Diocese of Albany, said:

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 17 -- The day's news, taken altogether, was most favorable to the bulls in wheat; but, like the bruised and maimed players in a football match, in which skill and science have to give way to brute force, the party referred to got nothing but hard knocks, and the worst of it in the end.
Considerable interest attaches to the question as to whether, in the general improvement in all lines of business, there will be any revival in mining stocks.
President Orr then announced: "The last toast upon our list is 'The Navy.' It will be responded to by Commodore Sicard."

Prof. Dorpfeld reached yesterday the most interesting topic in his series of lectures "The Acropolis of Athens." This is one of the sites of ancient architectural splendor that is comparatively familiar to all. The Parthenon has been for several centuries the most interesting as well as the best known ruin in the world.
Another unique club is on the tapis. It will be called "The Canvas-buck Club," and its members will consist of the best-known American sportsmen.
When Commodore Sicard sat down Mr. Orr announced: "We have now exhausted our list of speakers. What is the further pleasure of the meeting?"

A snake season productive of many complications and much literature closed on the 31st ult. But our latest mail advices from Dingman's Ferry and the Knob Pond come freighted with bear stories of great power. Two opera companies singing in three languages are at work in this city.

There has been a break in the ranks of the strikers on the St. Paul Building, at Ann Street and Broadway. The marble carvers, who went out on strike on Saturday, returned to work yesterday, and so did the elevator constiuctors, who had gone out three weeks ago, when the strike was first ordered.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 17 -- In the United States Court here this morning Judge Jenkins entered an order discharging Frank C. Bigelow and Edwin H. McHenry as receivers for the Northern Pacific Railroad in the consolidated action. The order, however, does not terminate the receivers, there being nothing in the order which affects the receivership and appointments of the recivers under the supplemental bills of complaints filed last May.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 17 -- The members of the chorus of the Watson Sisters' Burlesque Company, which began a week's engagement at the Front Street Opera House to-day, appeared in long skirts instead of tights at both the afternoon and evening performances to-day. Early in the day Manager Pierce of the company was notified that a complaint would be entered against him if he allowed the girls to appear in tights.

As a result of a recent reference in THE NEW-YORK TIMES to the method, by which the City of Edinburgh is lighted, a Suggestion has been received that the water in the Croton Aqueduct, as it flows down toward New-York, be used to turn a turbine wheel which shall furnish the power for 3,500 electric street lights.

At its meeting to-day the Board of Education may learn whom the Mayor has chosen to fill seven of its places, and the new bylaws relative to teachers, the transfer of principals, and the grading of teachers on a time and merit system may come up, but, in any event, the board will learn that the women teachers have formally and the men informally approved the proposed new salary arrangement.
At the conclusion of Gen. Miles's speech Mr. Orr introduced Senator Hawley to respond to "The Country and the Flag." Mr. Hawley said:

-- While little Queen WILHELMINA was in England recently, it is said that, to an inquiry from the Prince of WALES as to how she liked the English people, she replied: "I am astonished to find them so nice and amiable. I never should have thought it from the specimens I see in Holland."

Gold to the amount of $29,500 came to this port yesterday. By the steamship Yucatan $4,000 arrived from Mexico, for the Guggenheim Smelting Company. On the steamship Grenada, from Port of Spain, was $20,000 for the Colonial Bank, and $5,500 for J.H. Arthur Co.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Annual report of the Board of Ordnance and Fortifications, composed of Gen. Nelson A. Miles, Col. Royal T. Frank. First Artillery; Col. Peter C. Hains, Corps of Engineers; Major F.H. Phipps, Ordnance Department; Capt. J.C. Ayres, and ex-Representative J.H. Outhwaite, was made public to-day.
In an interview published yesterday morning in The Tribune Mr. LLOYD, the editor of The London Statist, remarked:

Joseph Jacobs, M.A., of London, delivered his first lecture in a course on "Fables and Fairy Tales" before the department of philology at the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Admiral Selfridge cabled the Navy Department to-day from Smyrna that he had transferred his flag from the Minneapolis to the San Francisco. Both vessels are provided with Admiral's quarters, and it is left to Admiral Selfridge's discretion which one he uses.

The Atlantic Transport Line Steamship Mobile, from London, which arrived yesterday, brought word that the Anchor Line steamship Anchoria had broken her shaft, and was anchored east of Nantucket, a day's steaming from New-York, pending repairs. The Mobile also brought Purser Matheson of the Anchoria, from whom the particulars of the accident were learned.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- A marked effort was made in this market to depress prices, and it met with same success, the stock brought out, however, was readily taken, and at the end of the session orders to buy wore plenty. Scarcely any stock, was offered and these orders for the greater part went over until to-morrow.
The Loomis Sanitarium, for the treatment of cases of incipient tuberculosis, will be dedicated Friday. Bishop Potter will conduct the exercises.
"Is Governor-elect Black making a show of independence in refusing to accept orders from the Republican State organization in the matter of appointments?"

Capt. Nelson and crew of the British steamship Coila, who when wrecked off the Cuban coast were subjected to ill treatment by the Spanish soldiers, who suspected that they were Americans, were released yesterday from Hoffman Island. They went to the British Consul's office on reaching the city, and arrangements were made for sending them to their homes.
Aqueduct Avenue, northwest corner of Hampden Street, for a two-story and attic frame dwelling, by William D. Peck of 314 West One Hundred and Fourth Street, owner; cost, $6,000.

The Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers, completed the count of the votes cast at the last election at noon yesterday. Chairman Oakley, who presided over the deliberations of the canvassers, was congratulated yesterday upon the fact that his board had broken the record, and completed the count , in five and one-half days.

It is reported that the "Republican managers" propose to press upon Congress at the coming session the contention that South Carolina is entitled to only three Representatives in the House instead of seven because the educational qualification for the suffrage in the new Constitution of the State "practically" restricts the right to vote to the whites.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-20 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
Among the European passengers who arrived yesterday were the following:

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 17 -- The storm which has swept Northwestern Washington and British Columbia for the past forty-eight ohurs is the most severe in the history of the country. It is estimated that the damage to railroads alone in Western Washington will exceed $500,000, and the Loss to private property will be fully as great.

The Manhattan Trust Company is delivering the new junior securities of the Green Bay and Western Railway Company, the successor company of the old Green Bay, Winona and St. Paul Railroad, which was sold under foreclosure May 12, 1896, and the committee of the consolidated bondholders will now announce that the stock given in exchange for the old consolidated mortgage bonds is ready for delivery.

Gen. T.M. Logan, who is well known in New-York as being closely in touch with the industries and enterprises of the South, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW-YORK TIMES, in discussing the outlook for improvement and a revival of business throughout that section of the country:
President Orr next introduced Gov. Griggs of New-Jersey, who responded to the toast of "Social Discontent," and who said, in part:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Washington Post a few days after the election told its readers how "Bryan Might Easily Have Won." Eager and sad sympathizers with The Post in the cause of the Silver Boy Orator have grabbed at the explanation offered to show how, with a change of 25,393 votes in nine States, McKinley might have been beaten.

E.W. Pettus, who has been nominated for the United States Senate for Alabama to succeed Senator Pugh, is a native of Alabama, and belongs to that class known as the "Southern gentlemen." He is a strict party Democrat and a silverite. Although seventy-four years old, he is still hale and hearty and a hard fighter for his party.

TRENTON, Nov. 17 -- The coming session of the Legislature will be of considerable importance if all the subjects that are scheduled are considered. There is talk of trying to make it the shortest session on record, but this will be impossible if any consideration whatever is given the important things that are suggested.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- The Philadelphia branch of the National League of Business Men has adopted resolutions extolling the character and business experience of John Wanamaker, ex-Postmaster. General of the United States, and expressing the desire of the league that he should become a candidate for United States Senator, to succeed J. Donald Cameron, whose term will expire March 4 next.

In introducing Mayor Strong, Mr. Orr said: "The next toast, a familiar one, will be responded to by one who holds a very dear place in all of our hearts -- 'The City of New-York.' The Mayor will respond.

Christopher R. Robert of Oakdale, L.I., bought the property 41 and 43 Wall Street, extending through to Exchange Place, of W.K. Aston, for $1,826,000. Mr. Robert gave in part payment his Oakdale residence, containing about 850 acres, at a valuation of $500,000. It adjoins the properties of W.K. Vanderbilt and the South Side Sportsmen's Club.

WHITE PLAINS, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Very little interest was manifested to-day in the investigation into the management of the Westchester Temporary Home for Destitute Children, which was resumed before Referee Daniel W. Guernsey. Superintendent Pierce was again on the stand, and in detail denied the charges of witnesses at former hearings.

The coming games of the Seventh Regiment Athletic Association on Dec. 5 are attracting considerable attention from the members and their friends. It is expected that the armory will be taxed to its utmost on that night to see the thirty-two events run off with the promptness and dispatch so characteristic of this crack organization.

The Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Traction Company, at a meeting yesterday at 621 Broadway, passed a resolution to divide the stocks in the company's treasury among the stockholders, and also to divide the certificates of indebtedness of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company now held in the treasury in the form of interest-bearing scrip, redeemable at par within three years.

Plans were filed at the Department of Buildings by the Trustees of the Columbia University yesterday for a seven-story building on their grounds at Morningside Heights, a general description of which was published in THE NEW-YORK TIMES on Aug. 2. A peculiarity of the structure is that three of the seven stories will be below the surface.

The plan of Prof. Walter B. Gunnison, President of the Brooklyn Teachers' Association and Principal of Erasmus Hail High School at Flatbush, to bring the parents of school children and the teachers in the Brooklyn schools to concerted action for the benefit of public-school education, culminated yesterday in twenty-one largely attended meetings.

The proposed ordinance introduced in the Board of Aldermen by Mr. Olcott keeping trucks and business wagons off Fifth Avenue between Twenty-fifth and Fifty-ninth Streets, except for the receipt and delivery of goods, between the hours of 3 and 7 P. M. from Oct. 1 to June 1 is in great danger of being defeated.
The "Jimmie" O'Brien Democracy last night made public a series of resolutions in which the organization pledges itself to support Mr. Bryan and Bryanism for an indefinite period.
Charles P. Pressly. United States Vice Consul at Marseilles, France, is at the Marlborough Hotel, Mr. Pressly is from Augusta, Ga. He was appointed first to Grenoble, France.
-- The receivership of Edwin H. McHenry and Frank G. Bigelow of the Northern Pacific Railroad has been terminated by Judge Jenkins of Wisconsin.

Marie Barbella, whose second trial for murder has been begun, has been very nervous and melancholy within the last few days, spending the greater part of her time in tears when alone. To quiet her, Matron Smith of the Tombs has kept her as much as possible with her in her office, a large room at the entrance to the female prison.

To the merchants and their guests at the Chamber of Commerce dinner held at Delmonico's last evening President Cleveland sent the following letter, which was received with marked demonstrations of approval:

This is a very good programme for a piano recital, and fairly covers the development of composition for the instrument, historically and aesthetically. It would have been completed by some Schumann, which Mr. Rosenthal promises -- the "Carnaval" -- for the next recital to-morrow. But it contains nothing of mere bravura, except the final piece.

After Mr. Orr had read the President's letter he said: "As we have many speakers on our programme to-night, I will confine myself simply to announcing the name of the guest, and the toast to which he is to respond. The first toast is Free Governnent on Trial,' and it will be responded to by the Hon. William L. Wilson, Postmaster General.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Governor's Day brought a throng of politicians to the State House. The organisation of the Legislature, so far as its personnel is concerned, is the matter of their chief anxiety and regard just now.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 17 -- Never before in the history of Yale football has there been such uncertainty so close to a game about the final make-up of the team as at present. Practice this afternoon consisted of two halves of thirty-five and sixty minutes. The latter half was played in secret, and was devoted to practicing signals and tricks.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Considerable mystery attaches to a report concerning Mr. James Martin White, a Liberal who represents Forfarshire in the House of Commons. The Dundee Advertiser announced on Saturday last that Mr. White had accepted the stewardship of the Chiltern Hundred, in other words had retired from Parliament.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- The market for local stocks was rather quiet, with Bay State Gas, Montana, and Erie Telephone the features. While there were few changes in quotations, the undertone was somewhat weak, with the recent favorites suffering the most. Montana fell oft 1, to 94, recovering 1/4, later; Bay State Gas dropped 1/4, to 5 3/4, but toward close advanced to 6 1/4.

The brewers of this city are not at all concerned at the threatened investigation of the methods of manufacturing lager beer, nor at the report received by the State Board of Health recommending that it favor a law fixing a Government standard for the manufacture of good and wholesome beer.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- The new company, successor to the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, was organized to-day at the Reading's general offices. A new President and six Directors were chosen, as follows: President -- Joseph S. Harris; Directors -- George F. Boer, Charles H. Coster, Thomas McKean, Francis Lynde Stetson, George C. Thomas, and John Lowber Welsh.

Ann McCormack, whose suit for damages against the Nassau Railroad Company was brought up for trial Monday before Judge Hurd, was awarded yesterday morning $12,000 by a jury. Mrs. McCormack sued to recover damages for the death of her husband, John McCormack, who was killed last June while driving an ice wagon.

It is a clutter of bric-a-brac, the one known as the Mrs. Richard Mansfield collection, which is to be disposed of to the highest bidder by Thomas E. Kirby, and on exhibition at the American Art Galleries, Madison Square, until to-morrow, when the sale takes place. There are jewel boxes, Japanese, with many kinds of Oriental wares, and some fine teapots, There are Chinese, Japanese, with a Wedgwood.

Cashier Isaac Howland of the New-York National Exchange Bank when asked yesterday by a representative of THE NEW-YORK TIMES for his opinion on the financial outlook and general prospects for business improvements, made the following statement:

A feature of the morning evangelistic service at Cooper Union yesterday was the presence of a large number of young persons. Another was the pronouncement of Mr. Moody against "mission churches" and his attack on the women who had been "showing off" at the recent Horse Show. Mr. Sankey opened the service with singing, having returned from Philadelphia, where he had inaugurated a revival on Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A dispatch from Canton yesterday which carried a Cabinet list omitted the name of H.C. Payne of Wisconsin, who, according to Washington reports, is on the roll for Postmaster General. The Canton slate named Samuel H. Hastings of Pennsylvania for that office.

Mrs. Sisieretta Jones, known on the playbills as "the Black Patti," was again examined yesterday in supplementary proceedings in an effort by Mayor Strong's private secretary. Job E. Hedges, to collect a bill of $236 for professional services rendered when Mrs. Jones was suing Major J.B. Pond for back salary claimed to be due her.
Stock market feverish under continued bear attacks by traders who are short below current prices. Money on call plentiful at from 3 to 4 per cent.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- An investigation of the administration and operation of the State civil service laws is contemplated at the next session of the Legislature. Assemblyman Henry E. Abell of Brooklyn intends to introduce a resolution calling for an investigation by an Assembly committee.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, United States Navy, was to-day placed on the retired list at his own request, after forty years' active service, in accordance with law. The announcement was received at the Navy Department with astonishment, as Capt. Mahan would have been promoted to the rank of Commodore in a few months, and could then have retired with increased pay.

The New-York State Association of Railway Surgeons held its sixth annual meeting yesterday at the Academy of Medicine, 17 West Forty-third Street, and gave a reception and banquet at the St. Cloud Hotel in honor of the guests of the society. A number of papers were read and discussed at the day session.

The American Tobacco Company added another chapter to the history of its fight for legal existence yesterday in arguing the demurrer to the indictment against the officers and Directors of the company for violating the anti-trust law, before Judge Fitzgerald, in General Sessions. Joseph H. Choate and W.W. Fuller appeared for the defendants.

The thirteenth annual report of the State Bureau of Statistics of Labor has just been printed, it is got up in two volumes this year, instead of one, and has 641 pages. It starts out with long statistical tables giving the rates of wages and hours of labor of members of labor organizations during the second part of 1894 and down to July, 1895.

The Belgian Government is making every preparation possible to insure the success and importance of the International Exposition to be held at Brussels, April 24 to Oct. 31. 1897, and it is desired that the industries of the United States be well represented on that occasion. The United States Commissioners appointed by Secretary Olney are Prof. J.H. Gore of Columbian University, Washington, D.C., and Thomas Wilson of the National Museum.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 17 -- William J. Bryan is preparing to publish a book about the first of next year, which will embody an exhaustive treatment of the silver question and bimetallism, emphasizing its importance as an issue in 1900.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17. -- Consul General Fitzhugh Lee saw the President this afternoon for the first time since he returned to this city Saturday. He only spent a few moments with the President, who had an engagement to go driving with Mrs. Cleveland at 4 o'clock, just about the time Gen. Lee called.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- The General Assembly of the Knights of Labor elected officers to-day. J.R. Sovereign was re-elected General Master Workman, with no opposition, and General Secretary Treasurer Hayes, was re-elected, with no opposition. To the office of General Worthy Foreman Thomas Maguire of Amsterdam, N.Y., was elected.

Abraham Gruber spoke at the Lincoln League, Grand and Forsyth Streets, last night. The Lincoln League is the social part of the Republican organization in the Eighth Assembly District -- practically the same old 'Ate District of the days of John J. O'Brien and his followers.

The Republican politicians were discussing Col. John Hay of Washington yesterday as the successor of Ambassador Thomas F. Bayard. An Ohio politician was responsible for bringing his name into the field.

The special dry goods sale of Ehrich Brothers, Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, which was begun Monday with the opening of an addition to their store 25 by 10O feet in Sixth Avenue, is attracting a rush of customers to the bargain counters in every department.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 17 -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union Convention to-day adopted the following resolution:
President Orr opened the speechmaking as follows:
In a careful review of business conditions, as especially denoted by the Western situation, the financial editor of The Chicago Tribune writes:

The Rev. Dr. Richard Salter Storrs, pastor of the Church of the Pilgrims, Henry and Remsen Streets, Brooklyn, last night was the guest of the Hamilton Club of that city at a reception in commemoration of his fifty years' pastorate of that church. Over 160 of the clubmen were present.
So many inquiries were made of Chief of Police Conlin regarding the rumor that he intended to retire from the force that yesterday afternoon he made the following statement:

CHICAGO, Nov. 17. -- Lillian Russell is confined to her room at the Auditorium Annex with a malady which may end her professional career, and life as well. Already she has undergone three operations, and while she has secured temporary relief, each of them has weakened her to a marked degree.

The market is decidedly steady, with many buyers in evidence. These are purchasing quite generally, though the detail of the store trade at first hands shows that single purchases are not bulky. In staple cottons, trading has been modestly carried on, in conservative fashion, in bleached and brown goods.

"The real genuine, all-round cranks make this place a headquarters, I believe," said a waiter in a down-town restaurant the other day. " If you want to see some of them you just sit around a little while."

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- State Treasurer Addison B. Colvin, President of the State League of Republican Clubs, has announced that the league has decided upon a banquet to be given to the Republican United States Senator-elect on the evening of the day on which the election shall take place by joint ballot of both houses of the Legislature.

Amateur billiard players are now busily preparing for the Winter tournaments. Several of the clubs, among them the New-York Athletic, the Knickerbocker, the Lie- derkranz of this city, the Oxford and Montauk Clubs of Brooklyn, Kings County, and Long Island Wheelmen will have these tournaments.

The convention of the National Council Jewish Women began its third day's session in the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday morning, with a tendency on the part of several of the members to disagree with some of the addresses and reports of Monday.

George C. Austin, to whom was referred by Surrogate Fitzgerald the question of the allowance to be made to Eula H. Costerlitz for the maintenance and support of her daughter, Dorothea Edgardita Grouse, filed a report some weeks ago, in which he recommended a yearly allowance of $7,500.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- King Oscar II. of Sweden, who has just been agreed upon as the designator of a fifth member of the Venezuelan Arbitration Commission in case the other members fail to make a choice, has clone a gracious act to the memory of two Americans, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Youmans of New-York City, who were killed while driving along a mountain read near Bergen, Norway, on July 4 last.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The extremity of fabrication so notable for the past week in "Spanish war scares" was reached last night in the roundabout misinformation purporting to come from Madrid through a Marine Corps officer in New-York, and securing publicity through an alleged brother officer on the Newark at Norfolk, announcing that Minister Hannis Taylor had been given his passports and compelled to leave Spain.

The National Academy of Sciences began its annual meeting yesterday at the School of Mines building, Columbia College. Gen. Francis A. Walker, President of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, presided, in the absence of Wolcott Gibbs, the President.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -- By an opinion handed down by the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday, the British steamer Coquitlan, with 6,190 seal skins, which was seized by the revenue steamer Corwin, in June, 1892, and ordered forfeited to the Government by the District Court of Alaska, was released.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 17 -- After the enthusiastic mass meeting in the interests of the football team held last evening, every one expected to-day to see the 'Varsity do good work. The side lines were thronged with spectators, who cheered the players as often as fine playing was exhibited.

The entire country has for months been deeply interested in a financial issue of the greatest importance, and it is not surprising that immediately after the election the highly objectionable features of last Winter's Dingley tariff bill were not clearly recalled by some who reasonably desired that the revenue should be increased without unnecessary delay.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: The recent campaign has demonstrated, among many other things, that there is perhaps nothing to which the term "crazy quilt" could be more appropriately applied than to the election law of this State. This institution has been under the patronage of the Platt politicians for the last two years, and to them we owe all that we have gained (?) in the way of reform.

For reasons which are well known to those who are familiar with the history of tariff legislation during the last nine years, the opinions of Senator ALDRICH as to what the Fifty-fourth Congress can do at the coming session, so far as tariff duties and the revenue may be affected fay its action, and what the Fifty-fifth Congress ought to do, deserve careful consideration.

Leon La Roche, a "circus actor," late with Barnum's, did not fly to San Francisco yesterday. His "flying machine" has no wings, and is standing to-day in a stable yard in Hoboken, eyed by the Schneiders and the O'Malleys, who live next door. La Roche knew he couldn't fly, but this fact did not lead him to correct the spreading impression that he had solved a great problem, and would soar away to the westward.
CAPE MAY, N. J., Nov. 17 -- There is to be built shortly a steam packet to ply between this place and Philadelphia, which will cost $175,000 and have a speed of twenty-five miles an hour.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- Dullness was the only feature to the local market, and prices were slightly irregular. In the traction stocks, Metropolitan advanced 1 per cent., to 108 1/2, while declines extended to 1 per cent. in Indianapolis, 3/4 in Philadelphia, and 3/4 in Electric and People's 4s. The unlisted specialties were without feature.

The Board of Health has ordered that unless certain retorms are carried out in the Ladies' Deborah Nursery and Child's Protectory, at Eagle Avenue and One Hundred and Sixty-first Street, within five days, it will order the institution vacated.

The Association of the Silver Cross Day Nursery, 242 East One Hundred and Twentieth Street, opened its three days' fair yesterday at 3 P.M. in the Harlem Casino, One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue. Eleven booths, prettily decorated, Empire style, in red and white, were presided over by the members of the association.

Our friends of The Tribune show a praiseworthy anxiety for the "maintenance of a sound currency." That paper has, during the past six months especially, done excellent service in combating the false notions on the currency question advocated by Mr. BRYAN and the few speakers who were willing to join him in the campaign.

A report was circulated yesterday alleging that there was a threatening storm brewing in the surpliced choir of the St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, at Seventy-first Street and Madison Avenue, over the discharge of the entire choir by the new organist, Walter Hall, and that the congregation had taken sides, some for and some against Mr. Hall.
LEWISTON, Me., Nov. 17 -- Every indication is that the alliance which existed between the Populist and Democratic Parties during the recent national campaign can no longer exist.

WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 17 -- Referee H.R. Barrett this morning sold the Consolidated Gas and Electric Light Works at Port Chester and Rye, at the Court House, here, and they were bid in by Charles Perry of Wesley, R.I., for the bondholders, for $190,200.
The Apawamis Golf Club of Rye has recently purchased thirteen acres of land, and leased sixty acres more, and a tine nine-hole golf course is to be laid out at once.

BERLIN, Nov. 17 -- To-day's proceedings in the Reichstag were of quite as much interest as those of yesterday, and in many respects, a great deal more exciting. As announced last week, the Radical interpellation on the recent murder of Herr Siebemann at Carlsruhe by Lieut. Baron von Brusewitz and other military outrages and scandals, and also upon the question of dueling, was introduced to-day in the presence of a full house and packed galleries.

Apropos of the assertion frequently made by free silverites that the money power of England has always tried to coax or bribe our own and other nations into adopting the gold standard, Mr. D. Ochs. who is in close touch with European financial matters, writes:

Patrick McGuire, one of the three contractors charged with defrauding the Government on a contract for a boundary wall at the navy yard, was arrested in Passaic, N.J., yesterday and brought before United States Commissioner Benedict in the Federal Building, Brooklyn, who committed him for trial.

Through the permission of the Right Rev. Henry Y. Satterlee, D.D., Bishop of Washington, and formerly rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, this city, the facts concerning a mission of peculiar moment with which he was intrusted during the course of the past Summer are now for the first time made public.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The Coroner's jury which held an inquest this afternoon over the body of Mrs. Alma Merritt, wife of George W. Merritt of New-York, who died at the Hotel Cecil Saturday night under peculiar circumstances, returned a verdict that the lady committed suicide while temporarily insane.

People who have visited Coney Island during the past warm days say that it is delightful beyond anything that can be said of it during the regular season. Tuesday the great expanse of water was like a sheet of glass, the air was soft and balmy, and the silence, broken only by the ripple of the water as it washed up on to the beach, was inexpressively restful.

Says a Chicago authority: "Soft coal, such as is used by manufacturers for steam making and other purposes, has advanced 5 to 15 cents a ton within the last three days, and the demands on the owners of the same are fully up to their present capacity of supply.

EL PASO, Texas, Nov. 18 -- "Dan" Stuart has succeeded in securing a spot where he may "pull off" prizefights without fear of police interference. That place is on the Mexican side of the river, near Paso del Norte.

The Gas Commission met in the Mayor's office yesterday, and, on motion of Controller Fitch, it was decided that the lighting contract for the annexed district by the Northern Gaslight Company be left as it has been except along Sedgwick Avenue, where, from King's Bridge Road to Van Cortlandt Avenue, it is proposed to put in 100 new electric lights.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Nov. 18 -- Mark Hanna said to-day: "I was only enabled to have a hurried conference with President-elect McKinley Tuesday. While a good many questions were considered, still they were only touched upon, as we had too many things to talk about, with a limited time to do it in."

The Dingley bill is in no sense a radical tariff measure, and there is no reason why any member of the present Congress should fall to vote for it. That bill ought to be made a law before the holiday recess of Congress. -- [Cleveland, Ohio, Leader, Nov. 13.]

The Anchor Line steamer Anchoria arrived at her dock, at West Twenty-fourth Street, about 8 o'clock last night, having been delayed two days by the breaking of her thrust shaft. The accident occurred last Sunday evening while Capt. Wilson and the passengers were at dinner.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 18 -- Miss Lenora Dean, a pretty young maiden, has succeeded in breaking a sale of property made by her mother, a widow, to her lover under circumstances of peculiar interest. Mrs. Lola Marshall Dean, the mother of the young woman, was a woman of great beauty and decided literary ability.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Maryland next year will elect a Legislature that will, in 1898, choose a successor to Arthur Pue Gorman as a Senator of the United States. Soon after its organization, in January last, the present Legislature, having a Republican majority on joint ballot of forty-seven, chose Representative G.L. Wellington to take the place of Senator Gibson, whose term will expire March 3, 1897.

AUSTIN, Texas, Nov. 18 -- The Secretary of State will not open the election returns until forty days after the election to make his official count for President, Congressmen, and all State officers, except the vote for Governor and Lieutenant Governor, which the law requires to be counted exclusively by the Legislature, meeting in January.

Mr. Bryan and others are telling us how to save the Democratic Party and down the Republicans in 1900. One man's opinion is as good as another's in this regard, and we are entitled to express ours, which is to this effort: The Democrats of this country will have to learn as truths these things before they can ever again hope to control the Government of this Republic:

John R. Procter of the Civil Service Commission delivered a lecture yesterday afternoon at the Berkeley Lyceum, before the Women's Auxiliary of the Civil Service Reform Association and League for Political Education. His subject was "The Federal Service," and his lecture was one of a series being given under the auspices of the societies mentioned.

The Directors of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company met yesterday in the Mills Building and declared a semi-annual dividend of 1 per cent, and authorized President Collis P. Huntington and Secretary William H. Lane to plan for the building of a twin-screw steamship for the China trade of the company.

The Good Roads Association held its fifth annual meeting Tuesday at the Johnston Building, Brooklyn. About 700 members were present. The following officers were elected to serve during the coming year:

Since the new child labor provisions of the mercantile and factory laws went into effect a few weeks ago the Board of Health has had no end of trouble by the failure of school teachers to co-operate heartily.

Mr. J.W. Doane of Chicago, who is closely in touch with the Western business situation, and who is interested in many of the important enterprises of the West, said yesterday, regarding the bettered conditions and the outlook for business improvement:

The delegates who began Sunday as representatives of the National Council of Jewish Women to hold their first convention in the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, have now become representatives of the Council of Jewish Women. The national distinction was dropped at the suggestion of the women of Canada and with the knowledge that Jewish women in Europe desire to affiliate with their American sisters.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Tariff discussion at the short session of Congress will be antagonized by two powerful and pos- sibly commanding influences.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Charles Ayer Whippie of New-York is completing a portrait of Secretary Herbert for the Navy Department.
William E. Valentine was arraigned for trial yesterday morning in the County Court, Brooklyn, before Judge Hurd, on five indictments comprising forgery, larceny, felony, assault, and abduction.

A young American militiaman, a Pinkerton spy, a Cuban patriot, and some nondescript marines, whose only ambition had been the pay of the Junta, made up a theatrical cast of witnesses in the trial yesterday of Col. Emelio Nunez and Capt. Charles B. Dickman before the United States Criminal Court on a charge of having engaged in a Cuban filibustering expedition that left these waters in May last.

At the recent election in Colorado a proposition that the Constitution of the State should be amended so as to provide for the creation of a bonded indebtedness of $1,200,000, in order that certain outstanding warrants might be paid or funded, was overwhelmingly defeated.
-- The new Western Freight Association is to have a Rate Committee of officials of the rank of Assistant General Freight Agent and higher, with its executive and administrative boards.

When Mayor STRONG had the untrammeled power of removal at the beginning of his term of office he did not realize the importance of reconstituting the Board of Education, and even when he made his appointments to that board a year ago he was not fully impressed with the need of thoroughgoing reform in the administration of our school system.

CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 18 -- A morning newspaper to-day printed a telegram sent out by Edwin Gould, in which he refers to the failure of the Diamond Match Company Investigating Committee to state in what shape the notes for $790,000 were. He asks President Webster if he knows that the notes have not been offered to him (Gould.)

The Hon. H.E. ABELL, of Kings County, a member of the Assembly, intends to have, the working of the civil service law "investigated." We hope that he will carry out his intention and that he will make the investigation searching. The reported reasons for this move on his part are not definite or satisfactory, but the friends of the reform do not care for that. All they wish is light, and plenty of it.

The trouble between Miss Felicia A. Griffin, Principal of Grammar School No. 47, in East Twelfth Street, and City Superintendent Jasper, growing out of what she declared on Tuesday was an attempt to coerce her into accepting a transfer to Grammar School No. 50, in East Twentieth Street, is at an end.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 18 -- While the market for local stocks generally was dull and inclined to weakness, the copper shares were fairly active and quite strong. During the early morning Montana declined fully a point, to 93 1/4, on a few sales, but later rapidly advanced to 95 1/2, and closed at 95.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day President Brisson gave the floor to Gen. Billot, Minister of War, when the proposed interpellation of M. Castelin, Republican Revisionist, in regard to the conviction of Capt. Dreyfus, the French military officer who was degraded and sentenced to life imprisonment for betraying military secrets to Germany, was called in its order.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The British steamer Memphis, Capt. Williams, which sailed from Montreal Nov. 4 for Bristol, was wrecked in Dunlough Bay, near Mizen Head, on the south coast of Ireland, last night, and ten of those on board of her lost their lives.

United States Commissioner of Navigation Chamberlain has made public a synopsis of his annual report, in which he attacks the discriminating duty policy as outlined in the bill introduced in Congress by Senator Elkins of West Virginina. This bill proposes to tax imports in foreign ships 10 per cent, ad valorem more than such imports in American ships are taxed, so as to give the carrying to American ships.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- Major Winfield D. Osgood of the Cuban insurgent artillery with Gen. Maceo, a Boston boy, and not long ago a famous half back on the Pennsylvania football eleven, has at last been heard from, and the report of his death at the hands of the Spanish forces is proved false.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Republicans who have talked with Major McKinley since the election and who obtained impressions of the plans of the President-elect for tariff legislation come to Washington with the almost uniform opinion that there will be no tariff legislation until the meeting of the Fifty-fifth Congress in extra session.

It must be owned that "Die Meister-singer" loses a great deal when it becomes "I Maestri "Canton." There may be German export fun as there is German export bier, but it does not appear to advantage in Italian. The fun of Beckmesser, though Beckmesser is already a claim in its way, is to all but German-speaking people an acquired taste, and those who have acquired it do not dissociate it from the German words.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Rabbi Machol of the Scoville Avenue Temple protests against that portion of President Cleveland's Thanksgiving proclamation in which there is a recognition of Christ as a mediator between man and God.

Notwithstanding all the reports that are circulated about the interest of politicians in the work of the commission which is framing a charter for the Greater New-York and about their designs upon it when the report of the commission reaches the Legislature, we see no reason for apprehending that any great harm is likely to come from that source.
-- Katharine Grey is seriously ill at her residence, the Hotel San Remo. Miss Grey is suffering from peritonitis.

The Trustees of the Roosevelt Hospital opened yesterday, for the inspection of all who are interested in hospital work, the new addition to be known as the Private Patients' Pavilion. It was kept open for such examination from 2 to 6 in the afternoon, and a large number of persons availed themselves of the opportunity to look through the hails and rooms intended for private patients.

Many persons in working attire attended the afternoon meeting of the revivalists in Cooper Union yesterday, and the hall was more than taxed to accommodate the throng which came to bear the preaching and singing. As on the preceding day, an overflow gathering was arranged for, but yet numbers preferred to remain without seats than to go to this additional meeting.

The Dwight Alumni Association has arranged for a course of lectures upon important legal topics by lawyers of high standing, to be delivered in the Carnegie Chamber Music Hall on Saturday evenings. The first lecture of the course will be delivered next Saturday evening by Charles E. Hughes, on the subject of "Trial Practice."

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Le Journal publishes a report of an interview with Senor Canovas del Castillo, Prime Minister of Spain, in which he says that the relations between Spain and the United States are excellent.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- In the elevator controversy which was resumed before Judge Tuley to-day. Attorney Henry S. Robbins, representing the Board of Trade interests, advanced a novel and startling proposition. The evidence which will form the basis of his argument was presented to-day. It consists of tables compiled from the reports of the Warehouse Commission and covering the period from 1873 to 1896.

The late Prof. Henry E. Parker of Dartmouth College was Chaplain of the Second New-Hampshire Volunteer Regiment in the war of the rebellion. An incident of his service is thus described by a correspondent of The Springfield (Mass.) Republican:
Further bear aggressiveness, but no declines of consequence. Money on call abundant at from 2 1/2 to 4 per cent.
Messrs. Frederick Southack Co. have old for Jefferson M. Levy, at about $110,000, the property at 300 Broadway.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 18 -- The majority of the 'Varsity men rested this afternoon. McFarland played centre instead of Chamberlin, and Drummond went to guard in place of Murray. Alport was seen in Capt. Murphy's position at tackle; Hazen took Bass's place at end, and Chancey played at full back. Hinkey's position.

SEATTLE, Washington, Nov. 18 -- Residents of Seattle and vicinity who, by reason of the floods and snow have been virtually prisoners in the fastnesses of the Cascade Mountains since Friday last, are coming in, some on gravel trains, some afoot, and others by boat. They tell harrowing tales of suffering, devastation, and destruction.

Wilbur F. Wakeman, General Secretary of the American Protective Tariff League, returned from a trip "West" yesterday. One of the Western cities which he visited was Canton, Ohio, and so far as records indicate he was the first New-York Republican to pay his respects to the President-elect, at the latter's home, since the election.

A peremptory trade sale of nearly 12,000 dozen silk handkerchiefs and mufflers was held by Field, Chapman Fenner, 80 and 82 Leonard Street, yesterday. The sale was by order of the Phoenix Silk Manufacturing Company, Graef Co., agents, and consisted of the widely assorted output of the Paterson Mills.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- During the past week Justice of the Peace Carpenter of Highland, a near-by village, has had in his court a somewhat peculiar case.

When Gov. GRIGGS of New-Jersey spoke of the banquet of the Chamber of Commerce as a "Thanksgiving Day" occasion, he was nearer the truth than perhaps he meant to be. The utterances on Tuesday evening expressed not only the profound gratitude for blessings accorded, but the searching of the conscience that marks Thanksgiving in the communities of New-England with whom it had its beginning.

The members of the Catholic Club had their second monthly dinner last night at the clubhouse, in Fifty-ninth Street, and over 200 sat down to table. This was the occasion of the first visit of Bourke Cockran to the club since the organization went into its present quarters, and Mr. Cockran was the principal speaker to address his brother members.

The earnings of the Grand Trunk system having much improved, there is wonder abroad as to how much of this betterment is due to the fact that the management is now in the hands of a railway man -- C.M. Hays -- trained, in the United States. The following is from The London Railway News:

-- Dr. CYRUS HAMLIN, ex-President of Robert College, when questioned by a Boston reporter about the statements in Mr. F. HOPKINSON SMITH'S latest contribution to the Armenian controversy, did not hesitate to declare that many of the inaccuracies In Mr. SMITH'S letter deserved a very much stronger as well as shorter name.

When Samuel Sobel was called as a juror before Justice Bookstaver, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, he asked to be excused on the ground that he had been subpoenaed to appear in the Court of General Sessions. Mr. Sobel was excused. He went down to the Criminal Court Building, and was called to plead before Judge Newburger to an indictment for grand larceny.

At an executive meeting of the Harlem Board of Commerce held Tuesday evening at its rooms, 50 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, the following committees were appointed by the Board of Directors:

Townsend Montant of 87 and 89 Leonard Street sold at peremptory sale yesterday a stock of novelty dress goods, imported by Franz Merz through C.A. Auffmordt Co., and also a special line of black and colored dress goods. The sale was important as comprising many lines of goods not generally seen in auction rooms.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 18 -- The Santa Fe trouble figured in two Kansas courts to-day. At Oskaloosa District, Judge Meyers appointed ex-Senator John Martin to be receiver of the railroad, in place of Charles F. Johnson, who refused to qualify.

In discussing the Dingley bill Judge LAWRENCE is reported as saying that "he would rather wait till McKINLEY comes in and calls a special wool growers' session of Congress." "Would not a special wool wearers' session of Congress be more to the purpose?
The Railway Age addresses itself in this vigorous way to the recent Populist attack on the Atchison:

The plan recently set on foot in some of the public schools of Brooklyn for regular and systematic conferences between the teachers and the parents of their pupils is excellent in purpose, and the first of the series of such conferences is reported to have proved interesting and promising.
CHICAGO, Ill., Nov. 18, 1896 -- The market was dull and irregular. Diamond Match and New-York Biscuit were weak, the former closing 3 1/2 and the latter 1 1/8 per cent, lower.

The sale of trotting horses at Madison Square Garden yesterday was devoted to a disposal of the stock of the Cloverdel! Farm of A.H. Moore of Colmar, Penn. In all, seventy-six head were disposed of for a total of $26,425, an average of a bit over $360. The stock was from some of the best strains in the country, and mostly the get of Director.

Funeral services were held yesterday morning at 10 o'clock at the late residence of Joseph Seidenberg, who died last Sunday. Prof. Felix Adler of the Society for Ethical Culture conducted the services, which were very simple. Dr. Adler spoke of some of the events in the life of Mr. Seidenberg, and referred especially to his energy of character, his humanity, and his charity.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Nov. 18 -- A report finds it way into print here that many Southern gold-standard Democrats will seek appointments under President McKinley, and it is said Chairman Hanna promised assistance, in several instances, to Southern men who would help to bring about Bryan's defeat.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- The long, hard season of football practice on Soldiers' Field closed this afternoon, and from now until the Pennsylvania game on Saturday the Harvard squad will take a rest. The practice to-day, which again was secret, was very long, but on the whole quite encouraging. Capt. Wrightington and "Beef" Wheeler were in the line-up, and Cabot played for a short time.
Thomas F. Ryan yesterday made the following statement regarding the Seaboard Air Line situation:

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- The heaviness which has been the chief feature in the grain trade for two days past culminated at the opening to-day. There was a drop in prices in all markets on first trades. Wheat touched 76, December wheat became the leader, with a bull market, and prices were lifted nearly 2 cents in two hours.

WALLACE, Idaho, Nov. 18 -- Down mountain gorges floods have been raging since Sunday morning, creating havoc everywhere. Of six railroads running into Wallace, but one can run trains, while the best residence portion of Wallace is a scene of desolation. Buildings have been swept away and their places occupied by driftwood, while two blocks have the soil washed off to bedrock, covered with gravel, or lying bare.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Nov. 18 -- John Wanamaker having formally consented to stand as a candidate for United States Senator, the Philadelphia branch of the National League of Business Men will immediately start upon a campaign in his interest, conducted along lines which have been laid down by National Chairman Hanna.
Friends of Mrs. Lucius E, Reynolds, whose husband died here two days after their marriage, are interested in the legal complications which may arise as to the possession of the dead man's property.

Nicola Barili, who died last Monday, was the last member of the family of Mme. Patti in American. Signer Barili was a half-brother of the famous songstress, his mother having taken for her second husband, Patti's father.
A man without sympathy for his kind may be tolerated, but a woman without human sympathy is a monstrosity. There never was one? Perhaps not.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- John S. Patterson was arrested to-day on a warrant from New-York charging him with grand larceny in the first degree.

Albert M. Palmer relinquished control of his theatre to the owner, Theodore Moss, last Monday. Mr. Palmer telegraphed the fact of his withdrawal to Mr. Moss, who took absolute charge of the house. He refused to either deny or affirm the story to a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES last night.
Curtis Romaine write: "We have never seen any profits taken in selling Sugar only two weeks before the time for the dividend.

A gang of burglars has been arrested in this city the members of which have lately been committing burglaries in Connecticut and New-Jersey. Detectives Doran and Krauch of Capt. O'Brien's staff saw Max Lowenstein, seventeen years old, come out of a Bowery pawnshop Wednesday and join a woman.

It was reported late yesterday afternoon that Lawrence B. Lynch, a lumber dealer of 46 Tenth Avenue, through his lawyer. John Henry Murphy, had secured an attachment against the Imperial Opera Company and the Academy of Music for $505 for lumber furnished and carpenter work done.

If the people who go to the Irving Place Theatre had not been rather spoiled by the frequency with which plays of merit in one way or another have been offered for their amusement or edification, they would have expressed their approval of the comedy presented there last night even more demonstratively than they did.
There are more real Anarchists in Wall Street than in the wilds of Oklahoma.

William K. Vanderbilt is rapidly recovering the use of his right hand and arm, upon which a painful surgical operation was performed about two weeks ago. He now spends considerable time at his office, in the Grand Central Station, and he is giving an unusual amount of attention to business matters in consequence of his brother Cornelius's illness.

At the third day's session of the trial of Col. Emilio Nunez and Capt. Charles R. Dickman for breaking the laws of this country by sending a filibustering expedition to Cuba in the steamship Laurada, it was developed that somebody in Philadelphia is paying a regular weekly stipend to two of the chief witnesses for the Government.

MADRID, Nov. 19. -- A dispatch to the Imparcial from Havana says that Capt. Gen. Weyler has reached the town of San Cristobal, about fourteen leagues northeast of the city of Pinar del Rio and about midway between that city and Havana.

BERLIN, Nov. 19. -- The debate on the Radical motion in regard to the practice of dueling in the army and the case of Lieut. Baron von Brusewitz, who recently murdered Herr Siebemann in a cafe in Carlsruhe, was resumed in the Reichstag to-day. Herr Heller, a Bavarian Deputy and a lawyer, defended the procedure of the military courts, which, he admitted, might be amended.

The long-talked-of I.B. Potter claim against the League of American "Wheelmen was settled yesterday. By the decision of the committee appointed to close the case Mr. Potter, who is now the Chief Consul of the New-York State Division, will receive $4,277.50 from the league, which is the amount of the principal and interest combined.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- A report re- ceived at the Department of State from Consul General Crittenden on the cultivation and exportation of tobacco by Mexico, shows that the Mexicans have made enormous strides in this industry since 1889. In the year 1889-90 the tobacco exports amounted to $948,332, and in the year 1894-95 they were increased to $1,460,133.

The Dock Board at its meeting yesterday received a letter from Nathan Straus asking permission to erect coal bins and ticket houses on the piers at the foot of East Third Street and at the foot of West Fifty-second Street for the distribution of coal to the poor, as has been his practice for several Winters past.

We are not ready to believe that the remarks of Speaker REED before the members of the Duluth Board of Trade on Wednesday are correctly reported in the dispatches relating to his reception in that city. The speech was an informal and brief one, addressed to the brokers whose attention had been diverted temporarily from the buying and selling of grain by the appearance of Mr. REED in the market place.

The jubilee services in honor of Dr. Richard Salter Storrs's fiftieth anniversary as pastor of the Church of the Pilgrims, Brooklyn, were continued yesterday, with a reception, speeches, music, and a present of $5,000 to Dr. Storrs from his parishioners. The reception took place in the afternoon in the church parlors.

LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The body of Mrs. Alma Merritt, wife of George W. Merritt of New-York, who committed suicide in the Hotel Cecil Saturday night while temporarily insane, was taken last night to St. Martin's Church, where funeral services were held, and to-day it was cremated at Woking.

A cold wave, on its way to the ocean, slightly warmed by its long journey from British Terirtory, struck the city yesterday and reduced the temperature to near the freezing point. If the promises made by the Weather Bureau be fulfilled it will soon be time to lock up bicycles and sharpen skates.
ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 19. -- "Tom" Watson, in his paper to-day, published his answer to Senator Butler. Watson says, in part:

A corps of Salvation Army soldiers under Commander Booth-Tucker took possession of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, last evening. The commander spoke of the work being done by the army in this country. He said in part:

Tammany Hall had a jubilation yesterday afternoon over the fact that it succeeded in polling about 135,000 votes in this county for the Chicago ticket, which was not enough however, to prevent the county from going Republican for the first time in its history at a Presidential election.

The proposition to have an extended series of lectures and addresses on the subject of municipal government among the people in this city, Brooklyn, Long Island City, and other parts of the domain to be included in the metropolis after consolidation has been effected, promises to serve a most important purpose.

The Treasury notes of 1890 (the Sherman notes) are a curious element in our currency. In some respects they are the most undesirable and therefore are the point at which an essential and lasting reform could best be begun. Like the United States notes, (greenbacks,) they are a legal tender for all debts, public and private, unless otherwise specified in the contract.

An important sale of dress goods was held yesterday at the auction rooms of Wilmerding, Morris Mitchell, 64 White Street. The goods consisted of 60 cases of the make of the Westbrook Manufacturing Company. The sale attracted considerable attention from the fact that most of the goods were exceedingly desirable for use in the South, and nearly all the lines were of such a character as to be useful for Spring trade.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 10. -- Gen. Miles was the guest of honor at a banquet given by the Commercial Club to-night. Said Gen. Miles, in response to the toast "Our Country":

The Aldermen seem to be in danger of doing a very stupid thing in refusing to consent to the proposed restriction of Fifth Avenue, during certain hours of the day and certain months of the year, to pleasure vehicles. The "exquisite reason" of the Aldermen who oppose the restriction is that all citizens have equal rights in the public streets.
Mr. Henry Feuchtwanger of the Stock Exchange house of Feuchtwanger Co. said yesterday in discussing the stock market and the outlook for prices:

Police Commissioner Roosevelt was present at a meeting of the Federation of the East Side, at 339 East Fourth Street, yesterday, and learned a few things regarding charitable work on the east side. He also told his audience some facts about the police.

A story illustrative of the economies being practiced by the new Reading management comes by way of Philadelphia and tells of a wholesale slashing of the rentals for several of Reading's leased lines.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- There were many calculations upset on Change this morning. There was plenty of action in the leading market, but it was a sort of undoing of the work of yesterday. There was so much doubt about holding prices in other markets that the bulls in wheat had to draw in their horns. There was a lively trade, and only a part of the splendid gain of yesterday was wiped out.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 19. -- Bound by ironclad restraining orders from both the State and Federal courts, both sides to the controversy in the Santa Fe receivership matter are now powerless to move, and it is thought there will not be any new developments until the case shall come up for hearing before Judge Foster in the Federal Court here next Monday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- Business on the Stock Exchange here is confined mainly to purchases for investment account, with bonds in particular demand. Diamond Match continue the speculative feature.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19. -- Dullness was the prevailing feature of the local market, changes were slight in nearly all stocks except Metropolitan Traction and Welsbach. In the traction group, Metropolitan shows a net decline of 2 1/2 per cent., while Electric, Philadelphia, and Union were practically unchanged.

A most attractive collection of housefurnishing novelties is that now displayed by Joseph P. McHugh Co. of 3 West Forty-second Street. Mr. McHugh, who stands nigh as an authority on correct furnishings, purchased the bulk of this stock during his recent trip abroad, and has obtained hundreds of the latest novelties in odd bits of furniture. The collection is most appropriately arranged throughout the various rooms of the store.

BOSTON, Nov. 19. -- Local stocks were dull and heavy. Butte, Montana, and Bay State Gas were the only noteworthy features. There was considerable trading on the firstnamed stock, but the price differed only fractionally all day, and the closing, 5 3/8, was the same as last night's. Bay State Gas declined to 5 1/8, closing at 5 5-16; Montana dropped 1, to 94, but recovered 1/4 later.
LONDON, Nov. 19. -- The personal estate of the late George Du Maurier, the celebrated artist and author, is ascertained to be u47,380.

We have referred to a proposed investigation of the civil service system of the State advocated by Mr. ABELL, of Kings. That gentleman has published the points of a bill based on the investigations already made by his committee. They are, some of them, we think, covered by the present law.

-- A Yale Alumni Association has been formed at Portland, Oregon, with ROBERT T. PLATT as President, HENRY F. CONNOR as Secretary, and an Executive Committee composed of the two men mentioned and Dr. J.W. HILL. The association is open to any resident of Oregon, or that part of Washington contiguous to the Columbia River, who studied for a full year in any department of Yale University.
