PITTSBURG, Nov. 19. -- Patrick Cronin, aged twenty-five, now a prisoner in the Western Penitentiary, made a desperate attempt this morning while en route from Erie to Pittsburg to escape from a fast moving train. His unsuccessful attempt cost the life of Thomas McCrea, Warden of the Erie County Jail.
Prof. Wilhelm Dorpfeld reserved yesterday as subjects for his last lecture, under the auspices of Columbia University, the Cyclopean ruins of Tiryns and Mycenae.

Mary Frances Siddons, whose death in London is announced, was born some time in the early forties, in India, where her father, William Young Siddons, a grandson of Sarah Siddons, the "Tragic Muse," was stationed with his regiment. Her mother was a daughter of Col. Earl. At the age of sixteen years Mary Frances went to England to complete her education.
Stocks still under bear attack, fluctuations small; short interest conspicuous. Money on call from 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 per cent.

The office of The United Press Local News, whoso service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.
-- Very soon the entire passenger equipment of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad will be of the "Royal Blue" color, which has made the Washington and New-York trains of the line so distinctive.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 19. -- Capts. Japhet and Clinton Townsend, two seamen well known in this vicinity, are cruising in Townsend's Inlet and along the shores of Seven-Mile Beach in a small two-masted schooner in search of wrecks that are known to contain valuable cargoes. They have located the ship Merrimac, which was sunk near the north bar of Townsend's Inlet thirty years ago.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 19. -- There is little doubt that the Varsity lined up to-day just as it will appear against Princeton in the football game Saturday. In the line Bass and Connor were on the ends, Murphy and Rodgers were the tacklers, Murray and Chadwick the guards, Chamberlain centre, Fincke quarter, Benjamin and Hine half backs, and Hinkey full back.
-- As the result of the discontinuance of the Missouri Military Academy, First Lieut. George W. Goode, First Cavalry, is relieved from further duty at that institution and will join his troop.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19. -- A thrilling story is told by Peter Mauner of Bath, Me., one of the survivors of the wreck of the Nicaraguan bark Charles R. Flint, which, while petroleum laden from New-York to Japan, caught fire off the coast of Brazil. Mauner arrived here to-day from Liverpool, as Consulman, on board the American Line steamship Indiana.

The financial and social troubles of T.B. Musgrave, a former well-known member of the New-York Stock Exchange, were once more aired and ventilated in the courts, as told in THE NEW-YORK TIMES yesterday, through the medium of a suit brought by him against his own son in the Superior Court at Boston, Mass., to recover $125 alleged to have been paid for the tuition of the son for one quarter at the Harvard Medical School.
Wall Street was much in evidence at Madison Square Garden last night, when John R. Gentry, the fastest harness horse in the world, with a record of 2:00 1/2, was sold at auction.

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 19. -- The Populist leaders of Kansas propose to pass a law through the Kansas Legislature this Winter making Mexican silver dollars legal tender. They do not hold that the coin could be made legal tender for obligations existing prior to the passage of the act, but profess to believe that they could make it a legal tender as to future debts and contracts.

It is in all probability a compliment to Evangelist D.L. Moody and his singing co-worker. Ira D. Sankey, that a good portion of the audience which filled Cooper Union yesterday afternoon consisted, of persons, male and female, who have been daily attendants at the revival meetings there. The congregation showed a great spirit of eagerness to participate heartily in the services and suffer the inconvenience of crowding in some cases.
LANCASTER, Penn., Nov. 19. -- While gunning near Petersburg this morning. Jacob M. Landis, a farmer, was accidentally shot and instantly killed by Adam E. Zerphy.
Mounted Policeman Sweet yesterday found a diminutive "wild boy" in a vacant lot in Jerome Avenue, near One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Street.

Opposition to the Reorganization Committee of the Louisville, New-Albany and Chicago Railroad Company, known as the Olcott Committee, by bondholders represented by W.D. Barbour Co. and Pomroy Brothers, has ended.

Chester H. McLaughlin, alias Charles H. McLaughlin, and Daisy Hampton, who were extradited from New-Jersey Wednesday, were taken before Judge Newburger, in Part I., General Sessions, yesterday to plead to the indictments against them.

Under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, a conference was held yesterday afternoon in the Art Building on "The Training of Students for Citizenship." The audience was comprised principally of teachers and others directly interested in educational work. The conference was presided over by William A. McAdam, Principal of the Pratt Institute.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19. -- It is believed that an elopement club exists among the girls of the High School in Hyde Park. Four girls have eloped within eighteen months, marrying the men. In all cases the departure of the girls has been received by their comrades in the most matter-of-fact way, and it is asserted that an organization has been formed among them, the members of which are to elope within two years after joining.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The Navy Department, in order to deter officers from overcharging their traveling expenses, has permitted to leak out a few details of some small scandal that might have led to a serious court-martial.
The first convention of the Council of Jewish Women was brought to an end yesterday with the election of officers at the Tuxedo and a brilliant reception and series of addresses at Sherry's.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 19. -- There were no callers of political importance at the McKinley residence to-day. Gen. Horace Porter of New-York was expected to spend the night here, but did not come. He will visit Canton a few days later on his return from St. Louis. He is talked of in connection with the position of Secretary of War.

MADRID, Nov. 19. -- According to advices received by the Government from Manila, the capital of the Philippine Islands, battles have been fought at Santa Cruz and Angrat between Government troops and insurgents. The reports state that the Spanish were victorious in both engagements? Their losses was said to be slight, while that of the rebels was nearly 500.

The Harlem Philharmonic Society musicale, in the hall of the Harlem Young Men's Christian Association, was largely attended yesterday morning. The programme, of a miscellaneous character, was rendered by Olive Mead,' violinist, and the Mendelssohn Quartet Club, comprising William Dennison, Charles Herbert Clarke, James A. Metcalf, and Charles B. Hawley.

Perhaps no measures ever suggested by a committee of the Board of Education of this city have aroused such determined opposition from the Principals and teachers as those sections of the new by-laws which relate to the examination and licensing of teachers, their assignment to duty, their tenure of office, and the grading of the salaries on the basis of a time and merit system.

The steamship Bermuda, long deprived of registry because of her Cuban filibustering enterprises, has at last secured a provisional register, and her new master, Capt. William K. Scott, formerly of the steamship Flamborough, took out clearance papers yesterday at the Custom House, naming Halifax as his destination.

Mr. BOURKE COCKRAN made a striking and suggestive speech, at the Catholic Club on Wednesday evening about the civic significance of that body and what it represents. He took occasion, in defending the Catholic Church in this country, to defend also the "foreigners" of whom the membership of the Church in this country is so largely composed.

ROME, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- Negotiations are nearly completed for the establishment in this city of the first beet-sugar factory in the State of New-York, The "First New-York Beet-Sugar Company," with a capital of $300,000, has been incorporated for the purpose, and the capital is practically all placed.

The locality in the neighborhood of Eleventh Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street has the name-of Hell's Kitchen. The nature of the locality and its people has been illustrated in a trial which has been going on before Judge Freedman and a jury, during the present week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- Notwithstanding the rigid Chinese Exclusion act, the report of the supervising special agent of the Treasury shows that 3,510 Chinese were admitted and 415 rejected. One hundred and ninety-eight were arrested for violating the law, and 120 were deported.

The women students in the Law School of the New-York University are now considering the question: "In time of war should women come to the front and carry arms?" Daniel Webster Blumenthal, editor of The University Item, and a member of the senior class, has offered a gold medal for the best essay on this subject.

Lieut. Col. McCoskry Butt was elected at the armory, Sixty-second Street and Columbus Avenue, Colonel of the Twelfth Regiment last night. He succeeds Col. Heman Dowd, who resigned two weeks ago. Col. Daniel Appleton of the Seventh Regiment presided.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19. -- The receipt of the returns of the late election in South Dakota makes it possible to complete the list of members of the House of Representatives of the Fifty-fifth Congress.

From all quarters comes the news of improvement in the iron and steel trades, and of prospects of a steady revival in business. A good indication of the general feeling is the current trade review of The Iron Age, which says:

Hazen S. Pingree, the Governor-elect of Michigan and Mayor of Detroit, arrived in the city the other day, and is a guest at the Murray Hill Hotel. In private life, Mayor Pingree is the head and front of the shoe manufacturing firm of Pingree Smith, in Detroit.

The Republican leaders in Virginia who have been claiming that there were outrageous frauds at the recent election in that State present evidence which certainly makes out a prima facie case. Their present claim is that but for these frauds there would have been a plurality of at least 15,000 for McKINLEY instead of 20,000 for BRYAN.
ALBANY, Nov. 19. -- Senator Raines's special committee which was appointed by the last Senate to investigate the operation of the Raines liquor tax law will meet here next Monday afternoon.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 19. -- The Knights of Labor voted this afternoon not to put the free coinage of silver plank into their preamble, but adopted the plank as a principle. The idea of putting the plank into the preamble originated with General Master Workman J.R. Sovereign, but the Knights thought that by its being put into the preamble it would bar from the organization all who were not free silverites.

ABERDEEN, S.D., Nov. 19. -- The official returns are now in from all the counties in this State. They show the election by the fusionists of Congressmen, Electors, Governor, Lieutenant Governor. Attorney General, Auditor, and Railway Commissioners by pluralities running from 107 to over 800. The plurality on Electors is 191.

In spite of a telegram said to have been sent by A.M. Palmer yesterday morning, requesting his representatives here to deny the statement that he had given up Palmer's Theatre, Theodore Moss remains in possession and personally manages the house. Mr. Moss contends that his assumption of the management is virtually a dispossession of Mr. Palmer, and he intends to hold the theatre until he has made other arrangements.

It was announced yesterday by Frederick B. Esler, counsel for the New-York and Brooklyn Railroad Company, which proposes to build a tunnel under the East River, that the work will be pushed with all speed, and that the tunnel will probably be completed within the next eight months.

The Police Department is investigating what may turn out to be a case of assault or poisoning and robbery. So strong are the indications of foul play that after an autopsy the stomach and other internal organs of the victim were ordered by Coroner Tuthill to be submitted to expert chemical analysis.

Over 1,000 persons assembled in the Real Estate Salesroom, 111 Broadway, yesterday to participate in the sale of the Ward estate by D. Phoenix Ingraham. The property offered is located between One Hundred and Sixty-ninth and One Hundred and Sevnty-second Streets, on King's Bridge Road, Port Washington and Haven Avenues, and Boulevard Lafayette.

George Lockhart Rives and Woodbury Langdon were elected members of the Board of Rapid-Transit Commissioners yesterday afternoon, to fill the vacancies caused by the resignation of Seth Low and the death of John H. Inman.
Chicago, Burlington and Quincy sells ex dividend to-day. In this stock a particularly sharp contest goes on between the bull and bear speculators. The Wall Street News remarks:

The Salvation Army proposes to give a Thanksgiving Day turkey dinner to at least 1,000 persons from 11 o'clock in the morning till 6 o'clock at night, at Memorial Hall, 120-124 West Fourteenth Street. In order to satisfactorily carry put the proposed plan, Major W.W. Winchell, commander at headquarters, sent out an appeal yesterday for gifts of food and money.

The police have been able to trace the whereabcuts of Frank P. Arbuckle on Wednesday night until about 10:30 o'clock. After that they say all is a blank until he was found at 3 o'clock Thursday morning at One Hundred and Fifty-third Street and Eighth Avenue, unconscious and dying. They have also arrested four men whom they suspect of having something to do with a plot that resulted in Mr. Arbuckle's death.

We are not surprised that our neighbor The Sun dissents from our conclusion that "the continued and malignant abuse of Mr. CLEVELAND during the past twelve years" has contributed in a large measure to the downfall and disintegration of the Democratic Party. The Sun's view of the career and public services of Mr. CLEVELAND is somewhat different from our own.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The Daily News will to-morrow say that in response to the demand of Sir Philip Currie, the British Ambassador at Constantinople, for an explanation from the Porte regarding the arrest of the Rev. Mr. MacCallum, a British clergyman, the Porte has ordered that he be immediately released.

The announcement made the other day that the Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst had become a member of the Leagae of American can Wheelmen was the best intimation many of his friends had that he was directly interested in bicycling. As a matter of fact. Dr. Parkhurst has been a cyclist for the last two seasons.

Henri Labouchere in Truth. The Daily Mall, with its enormous sale must have cut into the circulation of some of the London penny morning papers. But it is not likely that any of them will meet this by reducing their price to a halfpenny. With the amount of paper which they give, this, indeed, would be impossible.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 20. -- The Rev. Dr. Conaty is much pleased by his appointment as rector of the Washington University. He said to-night:

The statement is made on what seems trustworthy authority that it is the intention of Mr. BLACK, when he becomes Governor of the State of New-York, to appoint to the office of Superintendent of the Insurance Department one Louis F. PAYN, more commonly known as "LOU" PAYN.

In Philadelphia, on Wednesday last, at the second annual convention of the National Hardware Association, the members of which represent an invested capital of about $150,000,000, the association's Executive Committee submitted a report in which Trusts and similar combinations were emphatically denounced.

The New-York Society of Keramic Arts is holding a most successful exhibition in the Waldorf banquet hall and state apartments. The rooms, the corridor, and the elevators were crowded with visitors yesterday. There were so many of them that it was an effort to see the beautiful display of china which was the occasion of the gathering.

HAVANA, Nov. 20. -- Operations in the Province of Pinar del Rio are apparently at a standstill. No serious encounter has been reported since the engagement with the rebels under Munoz. No information is vouchsafed regarding the movements of Gen. Weyler, and the impression grows that the authorities here know nothing about him.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Nov. 20. -- Premier Laurier gave out to-day the terms of the settlement of the educational questions which have been so long in dispute in the Province of Manitoba, as agreed upon between the Dominion and Manitoba Governments.

LONDON, Nov. 20. -- The Daily News will to-morrow say that in response to the demand of Sir Philip Currie, the British Ambassador at Constantinople, for an explanation from the Porte regarding the arrest of the Rev. Mr. MacCallum, a British clergyman, the Porte has ordered that he be immediately released.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 -- Chairman Hanna of the Republican National Committee had a conference here to-day with Ferdinand W. Peck of Chicago, in which he said:

TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 20 -- Attorneys Keeler and Hite were to-day served with notices that certain depositions in the Santa Fe stock-jobbing scheme would be taken outside of Kansas, and informing them of the names, dates, and places.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20. -- At the meeting of the Board of Directors of the Catholic University at Washington last month, Cardinal Gibbons, President of the board, was requested to prepare a letter expressive of the sentiments of the members for the late rector, Bishop Keane.

In Philadelphia, on Wednesday last, at the second annual convention of the National Hardware Association, the members of which represent an invested capital of about $150,000,000, the association's Executive Committee submitted a report in which Trusts and similar combinations were emphatically denounced.

R.G. Rolston, President of the Farmers Lean and Trust Company; Henry Amy, and Henry K McHarg sign as a committee, at which Mr. Ralston is Chairman, an address to the holders of first mortgage bonds, consolidated mortgage bonds, preferred stock, and common stock of the Oregon Improvement Company.
WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 20. -- The Rev. Dr. Conaty is much pleased by his appointment as rector of the Washington University. He said to-night:

The Consolidated Traction Company, which now owns nearly 200 miles of street railroads in and about Newark and Jersey City, is reaching out in all directions from those cities, and if its plans are carried out will soon connect all the larger places in that section of New-Jersey by means of its trolley roads.

PRINCETON, Nov. 20 -- The Princeton undergraduates fully expect the Tigers will defeat Yale in the football game to-morrow. About all of them will see the contest, leaving Princeton at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning in a special train. They will be heard in song on Manhattan Field. Probably they will open by singing:

Two detachments of football players arrived in town yesterday afternoon. They will do battle to-day on Manhattan Field for the honor of being called champions of the game. They came from Princeton and Yale Universities, and both reached New-York about the same time. The Princeton players arrived from Princeton by the Pennsylvania Railroad a few minutes before 6 o'clock.

ALBANY, Nov. 20. -- It has been known to fishermen along the Hudson River for several years past that salmon do exist in the river, and recently it became known that the fish has a spawning bed or beds in the fresh water section of the stream. The fact has been disputed and has been a matter of discussion in fishing circles official and otherwise for several years.

The Society of New-England Women is doing a useful and pleasant thing in its revival of old-time feasts and merrymakings. Last season its New-England dinner and minuet afterward were a brilliant social as well as historically accurate and picturesque affair, and its husking bee at the Waldorf on Friday evening was equally important and interesting.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- It may seem very early to be getting ready for the inauguration of President McKinley, but the preparations are on foot, and the records show that it has been customary to set about planning the ceremonies for March 4 quite as early as this middle date of November preceding the inauguration day. It might be supposed that the frequent recurrence of the function would diminish local interest in it.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Nov. 21 -- The celebration will take place in this city Sunday, Nov. 22, of the one hundredth anniversary of the founding of Methodism in Poughkeepsie by the Rev. Freeborn Garrettson. In 1796 he preached in the Old Reformed Dutch Chufch, on the north side of Main Street, just east of the Poughkeepsie Hotel.

There has been some talk of consolidation by members of the Manhattan and Democratic Clubs. No definite action has been taken by either club. About 120 members of the Democratic Club are now members of the Manhattan, while the total membership of the former is about 600.
TUESDAY, Nov. 24 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., executor's sale, 32 West Thirty-first Street, south side, 450 feet west of Fifth Avenue, 25 by 98.9, four-story and basement brownstoae dwelling:

From Our Own Correspondent. GLASGOW, Nov 11 -- The Varuna steam yacht built for Eugene Higgins of New-York by A. J. Inglis of Pointhouse Partick, Glasgow, of 1,500 tons, has been launched for some time, and the cabin and internal arrangements are about completed. None of our Scottish nobility and even England cannot boast of a nobleman who owns any similar yacht, whether as regards external appearance or internal appointments.

The audience at Rosenthal's second recital Thursday afternoon was much larger than that of Tuesday, almost completely filling Carnegie Hall. It was also much more enthusiastic, and, indeed, there was more to excite enthusiasm. The first movement of the Beethoven sonata was given with breadth and dignity, but the adagio was somewhat dull.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 21. -- Passengers who arrived from Havana to-night report that it is generally admitted in Havana that Weyler has failed in his campaign against Maceo.

The hierarchy or repudiation and mob law is not of one mind about the penalties of heresy and schism. Senator HARRIS with bell, book, and candle solemnly reads out of the party all the soundmoney Democratic Senators. "They will not be permitted," he says, "to participate in any purely Democratic caucuses hereafter."

Managers of the steamship lines with headquarters at this port are not pleased with the system under which the Dock Department is conducted. They assert that the only apparent object of the commission is an increased revenue to the city, and that the interests of the commerce of the port are ignored.
TUESDAY, Nov. 24 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., executor's sale, 32 West Thirty-first Street, south side, 450 feet west of Fifth Avenue, 25 by 98.9, four-story and basement brownstoae dwelling:

The Aldermen did a very good thing yesterday. They rescinded their action by which the statement of the canvass of the County of New-York was to be printed in full in six papers, limited the statement to one of the actual determinations, and limited the cost of publication in each paper to $1,500.

The official declaration of the vote cast at the last election, with the exception of the vote for Assemblyman in the Tenth Assembly District, was made yesterday by the Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers.

H. Beerbohm Tree and his company from Her Majesty's Theatre, London, arrived by the St. Louis yesterday. Mr. Tree is accompanied by Gilbert Parker, who has dramatized his novel, "The Seats of the Mighty," especially for the actor and his company. This play will be seen at the Knickerbocker Theatre, where Mr. Tree commences his engagement, Nov. 30.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21. -- Chicago's wheat trade was upset early by some surprising buying for a local operator. This was followed by just as surprising selling, and a decided break in prices to the lowest point of the week. For the first hour December wheat sold at 76 1/4 cents and 74 1/4 cents; May at 80 cents and 78 cents.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- Amid a freezing rain 500 people saw the Harvard freshmen defeat the freshmen team from Pennsylvania on Soldiers' Field, Cambridge, 26 to 0 this afternoon. It was the worst day of the season for a football game, but the crowd was drawn to the field also for the purpose of seeing the progress of the Varsity game at Philadelphia, reproduced on the score board at one end of the field.

ALBANY, Nov. 21. -- Congressman George N. Southwick believes that it is altogether unlikely that the coming session of the present Congress will do anything so far as revenue, tariff, or financial legislation is concerned. "There will be about fifty legislative days to the session, and they will be almost monopolized by regular appropriation bills," he says.

Is mendacity an essential trait of press agents? It often seems so from the number of untrue theatrical and other yarns that have been promulgated lately. probably press agents were ever to delusions given. Some were born with them, other's have let them grow upon them until they are quite unable to distinguish fact from fiction.
It is said "authoritatively" that Governor-elect Frank S. Black intends to appoint Louis P. Payn of Columbia County to be Superintendent of Insurance.

In truth, to excogitate a descriptive epigram for THE TIMES has been no easy task. Its perfomance was attempted by all sorts and conditions of men and minds, by the prominent and obscure, the grave and the frivolous, by experienced men of letters and by young women unpracticed in the art of composition.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- Under Chapter 743 of the laws of last Winter the Mayor of the City of Albany, together with four persons residents of the State, was directed to be appointed by the Governor a commission for the purpose of conducting, managing, and directing the celebration in the City of Albany, Jan. 3, 1897, of the one hundredth anniversary of the selection of this city as the State capital.

WEDNESDAY, Nov. 25 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Daniel W. Patterson, referee, 165 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, north side, 150 feet east of Seventh Avenue, 25 by 99.11, five-story brick flat. Due on judgment, $20,625.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Nov. 21. -- The annual meeting of the Vassar Students' Aid Society was held at Vassar College this afternoon. Sixty ladies from New-York and Brooklyn came up in a special car to attend it, and there was a good representation from other places.

WEDNESDAY, Nov. 25 -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Daniel W. Patterson, referee, 165 West One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, north side, 150 feet east of Seventh Avenue, 25 by 99.11, five-story brick flat. Due on judgment, $20,625.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- If the expectations of the Egyptian cotton crop held in September are justified, the cotton market must feel the effects of an Egyptian supply from a vastly extended acreage and a yield favored by suitable weather and freedom from, the ravages of a worm that caused great concern last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- The President and all the members of his Cabinet will be at home on Thanksgiving Day, and will observe the festival with good cheer and hospitality to chosen friends.

Fitz Greene Halleck, for a score of years a noted character in the Adirondack region, and Superintendent of Dr. W. Seward Webb's Ne-ha-sa-ne Park ever since it was established, has been compelled to retire from active pursuits in consequence of ill health. For many years Mr. Halleck was a State forester.
A large amount of stolen property, valued at several thousand dollars, was recovered by detectives of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station yesterday.
Senator William E. Chandler of New-Hampshire is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. He will go to Washington to-morrow to attend to some eliminary work before the opening of Congress.

It was simply a case of push. Princeton's football eleven were the hardest pushers, and so they gave the boys from Tale the worst "licking" they have ever had. With a score of 24 to 6 against them, the Yale football players left Manhattan Field yesterday broken-hearted. They had found, for once at least, that the boasted "Yale pluck and Yale luck" had proved myths.

This week an unusually interesting programme of theatrical entertainment is offered. Ada Rehan will return, after a long absence, and will act Rosalind at Daly's Theatre to-morrow night in a handsome reproduction of "As You Like It," with Charles Riehman as Orlando, George Clarke as Jaques.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21. -- For the third successive year, Pennsylvania this afternoon, on Franklin Field, defeated Harvard at football. Pennsylvania won by a score of 3 to 6, the smallest and closest score rolled up by the Red and Blue in its victories over the Crimson.

Are numerous, but of the latter none is more ridiculous than the promiscuous and random use of laxative rills and other drastic cathartics. These wrench, convulse, and weaken both the stomach and the bowels. If Hostetter's Stomach Bitters be used instead of these no-remedies, the result is accomplished without pain and with great benefit to the bowels, the stomach, and the liver.

It has been rather an eventful week in the world of New-York society. The opera season opened on Monday with unusual brilliancy and promise, and, while there have not been, with the exception of Mrs. Astor's dinner for Prince Louis of Savoy on Tuesday night, any large private entertainments, there have been numerous informal luncheons and small dinners.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Nov. 21. -- Thanksgiving Day will find Lakewood well prepared for the first holiday of the present season. The hotel managers are ready to welcome the usual crowd of guests. In addition, many more are expected to attend the opening of the golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21. -- In an extended talk with a reporter, printed in The Star, Senator Morgan says that he does not look for the passage of the Dingley bill, expresses the opinion that it was offered as a bribe to the Northwestern wool growers to vote against silver, and says he is willing to stand aside and let the Senate pass it, possibly with the help of some Democrats.

When one reviews the causes and influences which have raised Mr. McKiNLEY to the Presidency, what a curious play of opposing forces is disclosed, and how much at variance with an ideally just apportionment of rewards for exceptional ability and the effective advocacy of measures for the public good appears to have been his elevation to this high office!

Prof. Daniel G. Elliott, curator of Zooology in the Field Columbian Museum, Chicago, and a member of the Faculty of the Chicago University, arrived yesterday on the American Line steamship St. Louis from a six months exploration of the jungles of Eastern Africa, where he went to collect zoological specimens.

When the Aldermen, acting as a Board of County Canvassers, met in the Council Chamber of the City Hall yesterday to make the official declaration of the vote cast at the last election they clearly demonstrated that they did not sanction the unnecessary expenditure of public money in extravagant advertisement of the results of the canvas.

Robert Lee, a colored man, who peddles ice in the eastern part of town, had his mare, named Kate, stolen last April from stables at 22 Cannon Street. Lee had become attached to the animal, and since has visited many horse sales trying to find her. He was at Delancey and Willett Streets Friday when Max Busander came along driving a horse attached to one of Thomas Fletcher's yeast wagons.

The New-York and Pennsylvania Railroad, recently completed, was opened for traffic a few days ago between Oswayo, Penn., and Canisteo, this State, where it connects with the Erie Railway. This new line is forty-two miles long, and was built for the purpose of bringing into closer relations the prolific lumber districts of Northern Pennsylvania and the agricultural and manufacturing region of Western NewYork.

Richard Croker arrived from Europe yesterday on the steamship St. Louis of the American Line, which was delayed several hours by bad weather, and did not reach her dock until 1:30 o'clock this afternoon. Mr. Croker came alone. His voung son Herbert was left at school in England. The other member? of his family ere all in this city.

In addition to the individual efforts of D. O. Mills, Mrs. J. Pierpont Morgan, and some members of the Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church to institute practical tenement-house reform in this city, a number of capitalists have undertaken to accomplish the same end on a business basis and upon a large scale.

-- The St. Paul Railroad is richer than it was by the price just received by its General Baggage Agent for an Egyptian mummy that has been lying unclaimed in the Milwaukee station for more than a year. Who it was that traveled with this curious bit of baggage has not been discovered, and whether he simply forgot his grim friend or had tired of a companion so taciturn will probably never be known.

The Brooklyn Institute is a great enterprise in co-operative education. Like other great enterprises in other lines of business, its success, which is remarkable, and we believe unprecedented, depends on the skillful application of two principles. One is the principle of organization by which interest, power, and responsibility go together.

William Ayers Haupt, better known as Will A. Mestayer, actor and playwright, died Saturday night at 337 West Twenty-third Street from Bright's disease, after a lingering illness of many months. Two years ago he was told by a physician that unless he submitted to an operation he had no chance of recovery.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Nov. 22. -- The Southern Pacific Railroad's steamer San Benito, which left Tacoma for San Francisco last Thursday, with a coal cargo of 5,000 tons and a crew of 43 men, was driven ashore early this morning two miles north of Point Arena in a heavy gale.

Superintendent Dennett of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, with the assistance of several policemen of Inspector Harley's staff, arrested on Saturday night two men and two lads who, he declares, are blackmailers against whom many complaints have been made to his society. In the Jefferson Market Court, yesterday, when the prisoners were arraigned before Magistrate Simms, Mr. Dennett asked that they be remanded until to-day.

The anniversary of the Feast of St. Cecilia was celebrated yesterday at St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. The sermon was preached by the Rev. Dr. Z.K. Rooker, Secretary of the Apostolic Delegation, Washington.

The story of the operations and downfall of the Sullivan County (N.H.) Savings Bank should be read by every man in the West who is still ignorantly denouncing what the Populists call the "money power" of the East, and who still holds that those who have loaned money to Western farmers are oppressors and robbers whose mortgages should be deprived of half their value by legislation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Ryan is unjust to himself and the Pooling Committee, if correctly quoted in THE NEW-YORK TIMES, when he complains of the limitations contained in the agreement under which the committee acted and says he was not informed of them.

There are certain parts of the country in which the growth of trolley systems, urban, suburban, and interurban, has been exceptionally rapid, and where the character of the competition between such systems and the steam roads and the causes of the popularity of the new lines have been clearly disclosed.

The largest and handsomest building yet erected for the exclusive use of the Young Men's Christian Association in this, city will be publicly opened next Tuesday evening. It is situated about 200 feet west of Eighth Avenue and faces both Fifty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets, its main front being on the last named street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22. -- "Sleepy" Burke, the well-known criminal, is alleged to have made a confession, which is now in the hands of Secretary Easeley of the Civic Federation, in which he implicates several prominent police officials, politicians, and other citizens in a conspiracy which resulted in the robbery of over $50,000 worth of bonds from an old miser named Schrage.

-- Marks left in a pumpkin pie by a Pittsburg burglar's teeth have just led to the man's arrest, and are almost certain to land him in prison for a considerable period. Though bearing the honored name of WASHINGTON -- preceded, however, by FRANK, not GEORGE -- an evil impulse led this unfortunate person to enter the house of a police surgeon, Dr. R.L. TAYLOR.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Nov. 22. -- George W. G. Ferris, the inventor and builder of the Ferris Wheel, died to-day at Mercy Hospital, where he had been treated for typhoid fever for a week. The disease is said to have been brought on through worry over numerous business matters. He leaves a wife in this city, and friends in mechanical and building circles all over the country.
Lee Jung of 16 Mott Street was before Magistrate Kudlich, i the Centre Street Court, yesterday morning, charged with having attempted to bribe a policeman.

HAVANA, Nov. 22. -- After a somewhat lengthy silence Capt. Gen. Weyler has at last been heard from, and in an interview he expressed himself as being confident of soon putting an end to the insurrection.

In a recent interview published in The New-York Sun Mr. J.H. WALKER of Massachusetts, Chairman of the Committee on Banking and Currency of the House of Representatives, discussed the currency situation at some length.

Many visiting football enthusiasts remained in town yesterday, from the crowd which flocked to see the game of the year Saturday, and consequently considerable talk was heard on the Tigers' victory and Yale's defeat. A majority of the members of the New-Haven team left for home on an afternoon train.

The Rev. Dr. Minot J. Savage was installed as minister of the Church of the Messiah, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street, last night. The church was crowded to the doors. The pulpit was surrounded with plants and flowers. All the Unitarian churches of the city and vicinity were represented by clergy and laymen.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22. -- In his fourth annual report, the Secretary of Agriculture shows that with $280,000, which may be saved from the appropriations for the current fiscal year, there will have been covered back into the Treasury since March 7, 1893, over $2,000,000. That this great economy was effected without any loss of efficiency he attributes in a large degree to the improvement in the personnel of the force under civil service rules.

BAY CITY, Mich., Nov. 22. -- St. Stanislaus Parish, which has at various intervals for two years been the scene of incipient riots over the disposition of its favorite priest, was the battleground at intervals, for seven hours to-day, of two factions, into which the parishioners had divided. When trouble ceased this evening it was ascertained that one policeman and about twelve of the church members had been injured, but none seriously.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 23. -- Complete official returns from Illinois give McKinley 605.124 Bryan, 464,109; Palmer. 6.299; Levering, 9,808. McKinley's majority, 124,908.

Some important changes in the theatrical programme commanded the attention of habitual playgoers last night. Miss Rehan and her accustomed associates returned to the stage of Daly's Theatre in "As You Like It," performances of which will be alternated this week with "The Geisha." Richard Mansfield began his yearly engagement in New-York at the Garden Theatre, acting Richard III. for the first time in nearly seven years.

The First Signal Corps of the National Guard made a teat last night at Washington Heights of a new torch for signaling. The test was under the direction of Lieut. Lambke, and H. G. Opdeyke represented the company who manufactured the torch.
CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 23. -- Col. Fred D, Grant arrived here this afternoon. His coining was unannounced. He took a cab and drove at once to Major McKlnley's residence.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23. -- The grain trade was a guess and a scalp early in the local market. Wheat was forced down to 75 1/8 cents, December, and 78 7/8 cents. May, then had an unexpected upturn to 76 1/2 cents and 80 1/4 cents, 5/8 cent over Saturday.

Gen. WEYLER'S cheerful confidence in the result of his expedition against the insurgents is not justified by experience. Now that he has in effect been ordered from Madrid not to return to Havana except as victor, it is, perhaps, necessary for him to-talk boastfully, but it is imprudent for him to tell in detail why he brags.

BAYONNE, N.J., Nov. 23 -- A fight between two rival gangs of laborers and a general riot were narrowly averted here to-day. Had it occured, Mayor Seymour, the police, and the engineers and workmen of the New-York and New-Jersey Water Company would have been arrayed on one side, and six of the Aldermen, the volunteer firemen, and the city workmen on the other.

William T. Gibson. The Rev. Dr. William T. Gibson died at Utica, N.Y., yesterday. He was in his seventy-fifth year. For many years Dr. Gibson had been a prominent figure in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the State. Years ago he surrendered his pastorate and grave his attention to Church literature.

Mr. MORTON, the Commissioner of Agriculture, never talks without saying something. His official reports are apt to be as readable and suggestive as his unofficial speeches and interviews. This is conspicuously true of his fourth annual report, of which a tolerably full abstract was printed in yesterday's TIMES.

There seems to be much justice in the contention of the representatives of steamship companies and of other large commercial interests that the water-front property of the city should be managed with reference to the encouragement of commerce rather than for the direct profit of the municipality.

Richard Croker, while declaring yesterday that he was out of politics, said that he was keenly interested in the success of Tammany, and that he proposed to do all that he could in his individual capacity to aid the organization.
PARMA, Nov. 23. -- Italo Campanini, the famous tenor, died to-day at his villa, near this city.

Madison Square Garden is this week given up to cattle, sheep, swine, and a few ponies. It is the second annual Live Stock Show, and is given under the auspices of the National Association of Exhibitors of Live Stock.

The Rev. Dr. Richard S. Storrs was the guest last evening of the Congregational Club of Brooklyn at its November meeting, in the Johnston Building, Nevins Street, near Flatbush Avenue. Over 200 members of the club and invited guests were present.

ALBANY, Nov. 23. -- "There are between 4,000 and 6,000 places within a radius of ten miles of the New-York City Hall that are selling liquor without a State license, in violation of the State liquor-tax law, presumably under police or some other protection."

CORNING, N.Y., Nov. 23. -- S. Spicer Berry, a retired business man and a large real estate Owner, was the victim of the old-time swindle or the tin box and three card trick to-day. For several days a well-dressed man has been here trying to arrange for the purchase of one of Berry's farms, which are situated at Caton, a few miles from this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23. -- The President to-day appointed Charles C. Nott of NewYork, now Judge of the Court of Claims, to be Chief Justice of the Court of Claims, and Charles B. Howry of Mississippi, now an Assistant Attorney General, to be a Judge of the Court of Claims.

-- The California papers refuse to get excited over the transmission of electricity from Niagara Falls to Buffalo. They say that over two years ago electrical energy was thus transferred from Folsom to Sacramento, a considerably longer distance, and that it has been in successful use on a large scale ever since.

Camille d'Arville and Oscar Hammerstein met yesterday afternoon at the Barrett House and talked over their past difficulties. The meeting was arranged by Julius Steger, who has been striving for some time to induce Mr. Hammerstein to procure an artist to take the leading role in "Santa Maria."

The Congregational Club had its monthly dinner last night at the St. Denis Hotel. About 100 members and guests, including many women, were present. John H. Washburn presided. The topic announced for discussion was "The Permanent Lessons of the Campaign." James L. Blair, Police Commissioner of St. Louis, and Everett P. Wheeler made the set speeches.

Discussion of election frauds and of restrictions upon the suffrage has become more general in the Southern States since the recent election than ever before. There are not only charges of fraud in Virginia, Tennessee, Alabama, and other States, but there are admissions of fraud by newspapers of the party in whose favor they were perpetrated.

The performance of "Romeo et Juliette" at the Metropolitan Opera. House last night attracted an audience of uncommon size and lustre of aspect. Perhaps the recent gentle request of the management that pretty heads might be uncovered had something to do with the appearance of the house, but, at any rate, it is quite certain that the auditorium never presented a more picturesque appearance except on an opening night.
At the recent session of the Farmers National Congress, in Indianapolis, ex-President HARRISON made an address, in the course of which he said:

Ex-President Andrew D. White of Cornell University, a member of the Venezuelan Boundary Commission, was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Some have brought his name into politics as a suitable man to be the next Secretary of State. He is not seeking the appointment, and said, when a reporter for THE NEW-YORK TIMES asked him if there was anything to be said on the subject:

A new play written by Henry V. Esmond, a young English actor, who is also a budding playwright, and was described by a London critic recently as "a dramatist to be reckoned with," served last evening to open the,tenth Fall and Winter term of Daniel Frohman's management of the Lyceum Theatre.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- A meeting of the Cobden Club was held at the rooms of the National Liberal Club to-day. Among the speakers was Lord Farrer of Abinger, formerly Sir Thomas Henry Farrer, the author of "Free Trade versus Fair Trade" and other economic works. Lord Farrer expressed his satisfaction that Mr. Chamberlain's proposals for an imperial zollverein had fallen flat, both at home and in the colonies.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- Sir Edward Clarke, M. P., formerly Solicitor General, delivered a speech at Accrington to-night, in the course of which he took occasion to refer to the Venezuelan matter. He congratulated Lord Salisbury upon having the courage to abandon the preposterous claims that Great Britain had made for years regarding a definite boundary between British Guiana and Venezuela.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- State Excise Commissioner Lyman, in discussing to-day the published statements regarding State excise law violations of members of the Senate Special Excise Committee, which is investigating the operations of the Raines liquor-tax law, said:

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 24. -- Helena Hasselback of 339 East Eighty-fifth Street, New-York, came here this afternoon and positively identified the girl found dead on the outskirts of the city Sunday morning as her sister Minnie.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 24. -- The exaggerated and sensational statements that appeared in a couple of morning papers that brutal hazing has been revived at Princeton were read here to-day with surprise and disgust. An investigation has brought to light the exact facts, which show that the statements of these journals are so exaggerated as to answer to falsehood.

Ex-Gov. Roswell P. Flower was entertained at dinner at the Democratic Club, at 617 Fifth Avenue, last night, by several of the club members, who took this means of showing their appreciation of the services rendered by him to the cause of sound money in the last campaign. About eighty contributors and guests sat down at 7 o'clock, in the parlors, which were very elaborately decorated.

For three hours yesterday afternoon the Committee on By-laws of the Board of Education listened to the representatives of the different teachers' associations, who appeared to protest against certain sections of the proposed new manual. Commissioner Ketchum was absent.

Jerseys, Guernseys, and Holstein-Friesians divided honors at the Live Stock Show at Madison Square Garden yesterday, and with the exception of a few sheep, occupied the attention of the judges all day. The animals in the different classes seem to be very evenly matched, as it takes the judges a. long time to select the prize winners.

HAVANA, Nov. 24. -- Every effort has been made to learn the true reasons for the return last night to Havana of Capt. Gen. Weyler from the Province of Pinar del Rio, but nothing definite has transpired. All that is known is that he came here on the gunboat Legazpi from Mariel, accompanied by only one Adjutant.

Senator RAINES left no doubt as to what he meant by the statement that between 4,000 and 5,000 places within ten miles of the New-York City Hall were "selling liquor without a State license, in violation of the State liquor-tax law, presumably under police or some other protection."
ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- Senator John Raines gave out a carefully prepared typewritten interview with himself to-night. He says:

The ten days' jubilee in honor of the fif- tieth anniversary of Dr. R. S. Storrs's Brooklyn pastorate ended last night with a citizens' reception in the Academy of Music. The house was crowded with enthusiastic admirers of the distinguished pastor. The interior was decorated with flags, evergreens, and flowers, interwoven with incandescent lights.

HAVANA, Nov. 24. -- Every effort has been made to learn the true reasons for the return last night to Havana of Capt. Gen. Weyler from the Province of Pinar del Rio, but nothing definite has transpired. All that is known is that he came here on the gunboat Legazpi from Mariel, accompanied by only one Adjutant.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Nov. 24. -- A report from Fort Duchesne, Utah, says that an explosion occurred there in the St. Louis Gilsonite Asphaitum Company's mine, by which two or three men were killed, and several others seriously injured.

Adee -- Fitzgerald. Miss Geraldine Fitzgerald, daughter of Gen. and Mrs. Louis Fitzgerald, was married to Ernest Adee at the Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church in Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, at noon yesterday, by Bishop Satterlee of Washington, D. C., formerly rector of Calvary Church, assisted by the Rev. Mr. Parks.

LONDON, Nov. 24. -- The trial of Lady Scott and the other defendants, Cockerton, Kast, and Aylott, charged with having criminally libeled Earl Russell, was resumed in the Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey, this morning.

ALBANY, Nov. 24. -- Since May 1 last there have been 3,360 so-called Raines clubs incorporated by the Secretary of State, while for the entire year preceding the 1st of last May there were only 843 incorporated.
-- The Presbyterian ministers of Toronto have decided that "The Mind of the Master," Mr. "WATSON'S last book, is not orthodox. Well?

It is reported that the Senate Finance Committee is to take possession of a large room now occupied by the Regents of the University for the State Library. It is in the southwestern corner of the second floor of the Capitol, and is one of a suite extending along the western side from the south to the north.
Richard Croker's declaration that Tammany had given to New-York City a much better government than the present administration called out a few remarks from Mayor Strong yesterday.
The New-York Tribune published on Sunday last, in the cable letter of its representative in London, the following remarks about the Consular offices and the Civil Service rules:

Richard Croker said emphatically yesterday that he did not intend to resume the personal direction of the affairs of Tammany Hall. Soon after the holidays he purposes to return to England to look after his racing stable there. The date of his coming back is uncertain, but it is believed that he will be here again some time in September of next year.

LONDON, Nov. 25. -- The Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey, was crowded this morning, when the trial of Lady Tina Scott, John Cockerton, Frederick Kast, and William Aylott, for criminally libeling Earl Russell, was resumed Lady Scott wore a black dress with white gloves and carried a bouquet of violets.

TOKIO, Japan, Nov. 17. -- It is positively stated that immediately before the departure of the Russian representative, Count Cassine, from Pekin, Sept. 30, he succeeded in concluding with the Chinese Government a convention of great importance.

Gov. MORTON is about to close his term of service with an act of far-reaching and permanent benefit to the State, to which he can always look back with legitimate pride and for which he will deserve the gratitude of the people of the State. At his request the State Civil Service Commission has prepared a careful and thorough revision of the civil service rules.

Evangelist Moody's power over the audiences which daily listen to his preaching in Cooper Union was never more noticeable than at the afternoon meeting yesterday. He moved the congregation to laughter and to sympathetic tears at his will. If the offering had been taken up after instead of before the sermon the purse-strings of many might have been further loosened.
DENVER, Col., Nov. 25. -- It was very late last night before Mr. Bryan began speaking at the banquet in the Brown Palace Hotel. It was after 2 o'clock when he finished his speech.

The Chamber of Commerce has had for some time two committees at work investigating the situation of New-York City with reference both to foreign and domestic trade. One of them is considering the conditions imposed particularly by the railway lines affecting the current of transportation to and from the city.

The series of addresses on "Civil Service Reform" being given under the auspices of the Women's Auxiliary of the Civil Service Reform Association and the League for Political Education, was continued yesterday at the Berkeley Lyceum by a short talk by Theodore Roosevelt. Mr. Roosevelt's subject was "An Object Lesson in Civil Service Reform."

-- A.S. CLAY, the newly elected Senator from Georgia, seems to have won, not only a seat in the upper house of the National Legislature, but complete control of the State Democratic machine. The group of politicians of which Gov. ATKINSON is the head, has lost much, or all, of its power, and the weight of influence has been transferred from the up-country to the coast counties.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The annual freshman-sophomore cane spree was fought late last night and early this morning, and resulted in a victory for the freshmen, who won two canes to one for the sophomores.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 25. -- The Southern express on the Pennsylvania Railroad, east bound, this morning ran into the wreckage of a freight train near this place.

-- "The Pons Via" is the inscription which the builder of a fine new business block at Springfield, Mass., has placed on the corner of his structure. After considerable study of this curious phrase, the man's neighbors decided that it was an attempt to put "Bridge Street" into Latin, but they have not yet decided, or at least have not revealed, whether he displayed ignorance or humor in making the translation.

when reports began trickling east-ward out of Chicago that certain Joint Traffic Association railroads were cutting rates in deliberate violation of the terms of the year-old agreement, Chauncey M. Depew was asked whether he thought the Joint Traffic Association was in danger. He promptly replied that he did not, and furthermore that he did not believe the reports that there were any intentional violations of the agreement on the part of joint traffic lines.

John E. Redmond, the Irish leader and Member of Parliament for Waterford, arrived last night on the White Star steamship Teutonic. He comes to this country to deliver a series of lectures on the subject, "Fifteen Tears in the British Parliament."

BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- James W. Langley, better known to the police of the United States as "Doc" Langley, was arrested at Hartford. Conn., to-night, at the request of Chief Watts of the Bureau of Criminal Investigation.

There may be such a thing as carrying harmony too far. In one way it is the exclusive business of the Democratic Club whom it invites, even to such of its celebrations as take the form of public functions, the dinner to Gov. FLOWER on Tuesday evening, for instance. No man better deserved such a compliment at the hands of the sound-money Democrats, and, for that matter, of sound-money men of any party.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: To-day, for the first time in seven years, Thanksgiving finds the Tenement House Chapter of the King's Daughters and Sons without money to make the day a glad one for the children of our neighborhood. We have 74 cents in our treasury and nearly $500 of bills to meet.

The Ward Line steamship City of Washington, which arrived yesterday from Havana, brought some interesting news of the engagement which occurred recently near Mount Rubia between the Spanish troops and the insurgent forces, headed by Gen. Maceo.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- There was another of those speculative explosions in the leading grain market this morning. For several days Liverpool has been acting the part of the balky horse. This morning that market made a lunge. This relieved the obstruction to the bull market here, and prices got a very sudden spurt.

ALBANY, Nov. 25. -- One of the largest appropriations which the incoming Legislature will be called upon to make will be $150,000 for the completion of the grand western staircase and eastern approach of the Capitol. The last Legislature appropriated $310,000 for this work, to be done by day's labor. This was on the estimate made by Capitol Commissioner Perry that such sum would be ample for the work specified.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- The President of the United States and nearly all his official advisers will pass Thanksgiving Day in this city in a quiet way. The President and Mrs. Cleveland will attend church in the morning, and eat their Thanksgiving meal in the Executive mansion, in company with their three little girls.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25. -- Private advices from the American colony at Matlatoynca, State of Pueblo, Mexico, received in this city to-day, tell of four atrocious murders by peons, the victim in each case being a member of the colony.

In his carefully prepared reiteration of the charge that "somewhere in the neighborhood of 4,000 places are selling liquor illegally within ten miles of the City Hall, Senator RAINES shatters the apology for his first statement which Commissioner LYMAN considerately made by showing that he did not intend to include Brooklyn, Long Island City, or Hoboken, and that he did not even refer to "fake" clubs or hotels, or to any places that hold certificates.

The first of a series of meetings in the interest of Hampton Institute, the Virginia industrial school for Indians and negroes, was held last night in the Phillips Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street and Madison Avenue. The Rev. H.B. Frissell, D.D., President of the institute, was at the meeting.

The swine had an inning at the lave Stock Show, at Madison Square Garden, yesterday, and occupied the attention of the judges for a long time during the morning. Two boars and a boar and a pig tried to settle the question of superiority without the aid of the judges, and furnished an entertainment not on the programme.

Emmet -- Garland. One of the prettiest house weddings of the season was that of Miss Louise Garland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Garland, to Robert Emmet, son of Dr. Thomas Addis Emmet, which was celebrated at noon yesterday, at the residence of the bride's parents, 259 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25. -- Assistant Secretry Curtis has been in New-York two days, but will be at his desk Friday. No information is vouchsafed at the department as the cause for his visit to New-York, but it is believed that it has had some connection with the proposed renewal of the issuance of gold certificates.

MADRID, Nov. 25. -- Several of the leading newspapers of Madrid are very bitter in their criticisms of the return of Gen. Weyler to Havana, and declare him to be morally ruined. All of these papers demand that Gen. Azcarraga, the present Minister of War, be sent to Cuba at once to supersede Gen. Weyler.

Edward Lauterbach's plea for the aid of the sound-money Democrats in the Republican campaigns of the next four years, made at the dinner to Gov. Flower at the Democratic Club on Tuesday night, excited great comment among politicians of all sorts yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The market to-day was in the hands of the beats from the start. The attack was principally on the Yerkes stocks, which declined from 8 to 7 per cent., the latter in North Chicago Street Railroad. The balance of the list showed declines of from 1/2 to 1 1/2 per cent. The setback to the market has discouraged traders and there is a disposition to hold off, awaiting further developments.

E.A. Ford, General Passenger Agent of the Pennsylvania and Vandalia Lines, possesses, for a railroad man, an uncommonly well-developed poetical tendency and an almost enthusiastic fondness for epigrams. In a recent address to men of his own cloth on "The Tribulations of a General Passenger Agent," he frankly avowed that it vas his desire to say and do something that would be beneficial to his fellowcraftsmen.

The days of "Paddy's Market" appear to be numbered. In fact, the market has already become a sort of remembrance, and with new ordinances, police interference, and competition on the upper west side, it seems that the market will soon be no more of a market than any other street ill which business is done by peddlers from wagons on Saturday nights and on the eve of holidays.

At a meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday, eighty-eight new patrolmen were appointed on probation. Michael E. Morgan, one of the candidates slated for appointment, was objected to by President Roosevelt, who said that he had learned that Morgan, who was a bartender, had been once arrested for excise violation, and that his case was to come before the Grand Jury in a few days.
United States Consul Germain, at Zurich, Switzerland, decries the lack of system in connection with the development of our foreign trade, and says:

COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 25. -- When the State Board of Canvassers met here yesterday they were unprepared for a protest from Electoral candidates, and as a consequence it was somewhat of a surprise when a protest was received from B. O'Dell Duncan in behalf of the Presidential Electors of his (the Lily-white Republican) ticket.

The natural inference from the return of Gen. WEYLER to Havana is that his expedition has been unsuccessful. That would be the inference in any case when a commander had "taken the field in person" with so much pomp and pretension. It is strengthened in this case by the report, which seemed to be authentic and was intrinsically probable, that WEYLER had orders not to return to Havana until he had won a signal victory.

BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- The market for local stocks was very dull, relieved only by speculations as to the result of the West End Street Railway election. That stock was heavy, declining 1 1/4, to 67 1/4. Bay State Gas was quiet, and varied but 1-16, closing at 5 1/4. Dominion Coal was dull, but 1/4 stronger, at 10.

The annual Fall games of the Twenty-second Regiment Athletic Association were held at the armory, Sixty-seventh Street and the Boulevard, last night. About a thousand persons were present. The prizes given to the winners consisted of medals, watches, scarf pins, cuff buttons, and silver cups.

BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- In the office of President Little of the West End Street Railway Company this afternoon, the vote taken at the annual meeting of the stockholders of that corporation yesterday was announced, and the Directors indorsed by the Morgan-Kidder-Peabody interest were declared elected.

The State Central Committee and the Executive Committee of what during the recent campaign was the regular Democratic organization in Kentucky have decided that the "campaign for silver" should be "kept up without intermission" and that none but silver Democrats should be "recognized" in future primaries and conventions.

There is much comment on the reported injury to Victor Herbert's famous violoncello. It was not learned yesterday to what extent the instrument had been damaged, and the professor's admirers are hoping for the best.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25. -- A correspondent of The North China News, in speaking of the situation in the Philippine Islands, says:

MASPETH, L.I., Nov. 25. -- In the ninth round of the twenty-round battle between the welter-weights, "Mysterious" "Billy" Smith of Boston and "Tommy" Ryan of Syracuse, at the Empire Athletic Club to-night. Referee "Tim" Hurst disqualified Smith for repeated fouling, and gave Ryan the decision.

CANTON, Ohio, Nov. 25. -- Major McKinley listened this evening to a committee of the National Grange, which, urged the appointment of J.H. Brigham of Ohio as Secretary of Agriculture. The committee consisted of O.H. Hale of New-York, George B. Horton of Michigan, W.W. Miller, Secretary of the Ohio State Board of Agriculture, and Aaron Jones of Indiana, who acted as spokesman.

BOSTON, Nov. 25. -- The jubilee banquet and celebration of the Home Market Club in honor of the election of William McKinley was held at Mechanics' Hall last evening. Governor-elect Wolcott, Gen. Alger, and Senator Hoar made speeches Senator Hoar, in the course of his remarks said:

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- The new agreement relating to the issue of passes during 1897, which was adopted by the Western Passenger Association at its recent meeting in St. Louis, makes a more radical change in the present agreement than was believed at the time of the meeting. The details were made the subject of a circular to-day for general railroad information.

The New-York Society of the Sons of the Revolution, 200 strong, celebrated the one hundred and thirteenth anniversary of Evacuation Day last night by a dinner at Delmonico's. Although there were six set toasts and an elaborate menu, the affair was informal.
Messrs. Hiram Rinaldo Brother have leased for the estate of Maurice O'Brien, for five years, to Louis Minsky, at $6,500 yearly, the Grand Museum Building, 345 and 347 Grand Street.

Extensive preparations have been made for the proper observance of Thanksgiving Day. Nearly all the public institutions and asylums and those of semi-public character have made elaborate arrangements for dinner giving. Incoming trains have brought to the city markets tons of turkeys and other succulent dainties from the farmyard, and outgoing trains have taken thousands of New-Yorkers, of New-England descent especially, to spend the day with their families.

Thomas P. Fowler, President or the NewYork, Ontario and Western Railroad, who went to Europe last month to look into European securities, was a passenger with the Misses Fowler on the Teutonic, which arrived last night. When the cable announced the election of Major McKinley, Mr. Fowler was in Paris.

"'Trilby' has given people a wrong impression of studio life," says the wife of a New-York artist, who makes her home, with her husband and children, in studio apartments. "Life in a studio is as regular as in a private house. People who make their homes in studios live as other people do who try to solve the problem of fliving in New-York by doing light housekeeping.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25. -- The last football game of the season of 1896 between the teams of the big Eastern colleges will be played to-morrow by Cornell and Pennsylvania on Franklin Field. The Cornell team arrived here this evening.
"I am tired of masquerading as a tariff reformer. I will never again be found before the public as a tariff reformer."

CHICAGO, Nov. 25. -- Patrolmen Miland and Sheehan of the Hyde Park Police Station to-day arrested Henry Hunt on a charge of being accessory to forgery, and are hunting for Frederick J. Lee, for whom they have a warrant on a similar charge. It is thought Lee is now in Milwaukee.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 26.-- Attorney Harold R. Durant of Waterbury, who coached the Southwestern University football team at Jackson, Tenn., last season, has arranged to have a Yale eleven make a trip through the South during the Christmas vacation. Georgre Foster Sanford, centre rush on the Yale team of 1891, will captain the eleven.

The twenty-five mile handicap road race over the five-mile course at Jamaica, L. I., yesterday, was a spirited contest, resulting in a victory for an old-time long-distance rider, John Rud of Newark. The race was a lively one.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 26. -- An exciting game of football was played here this afternoon between sailors of the battleship Indiana and the post team composed of enlisted men. It was a hard fought battle, in which the soldiers came off victorious by a score of 18 to 4.
KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 26. -- It is now positively known in Havana that Gen. Weyler and his army have been defeated by Maceo and his forces in the province of Pinar del Rio.

A Thanksgiving fishing excursion was abruptly terminated and 150 lives were placed in jeopardy yesterday, when the old side-wheel steamboat John E. Moore, attempting to navigate in a fog which placed an embargo on all shipping, lost her way in the Swash Channel while bound for the fishing banks, and struck a snag on Romer Shoal, which made a hole in her bottom and caused her to sink.

Richard Croker's indorsement of John C. Sheehan's management of Tammany,fall was regarded yesterday as indicating mainly that there would be no important change in the conduct of Tammany for the next year. Mr. Sheehan is to continue as the executive head and Mr. Croker as the adviser.

Gladwin, Willis A. Seward's prize Berkshire boar, furnished some more fun yesterday at the Live Stock Show at Madison Square Garden. It was during the parade of swine, which of itself caused lots of merriment, Gladwin started in peaceably enough, but when half way around the ring caught sight of " Charley " Chamberlain, the undefatigable press agent.

-- Mr. H.C. EVANS of Nashville has been mentioned as likely to be appointed Attorney General by Mr. McKINLEY. The Nashville American derides the rumor, declaring that "EVANS is a shrewd politician, a successful manufacturer, but no one has yet accused him of being a prominent lawyer."

Evidence of economy in administration meets the eye at once on opening the annual report of the Secretary of War. For salaries and the contingent expenses of the War Office the expenditure of the fiscal year ended June 30 last was $1,436,795, a saving of 8582,750 as compared with the expenditure four years ago.

What can the Government do for the farmers? That is a question directly raised by the extent to which Bryanism drew the support of this class. It is not a simple question. In some ways the Government can do much. In other ways, and to these, unfortunately, the "discontented" farmers give a good deal of importance, the Government can do nothing.

Considerable golf activity was seen on the links of the Knollwood Country Club, near White Plains, yesterday. Mrs. Jules Reynal presented two handsome silver cups, and the contest for them called out some clever golfing. The cup for the ladies was for a 36-hole putting match, and was won by Mrs. Gibert Thebaud, with a score of 99.

It was not Col. ABRAHAM GRUBER whom, but a kangaroo which, the late Artemus Ward described as "an amoozin but onprinsipled little kuss." "We will not apply the characterization to Col. ABE in its entirety, though we believe that he is not of towering stature, and we are sure that he is amusing.

A pamphlet lately issued under the title of "Spanish Perfidy" by a Cuban journalist, Don JOSE DE ARMAS-CARDENAS, sheds much light upon the policy of Madrid in respect to Cuba. In the capacity of diplomatic agent of the Cuban provisional Government the author visited Madrid and was admitted to two interviews with the Spanish Premier.

From the day to night they struggled; Brown men, red men, all together; And the sly, elusive Brown men Didn't do a single thing then To The red men of the forest, On the field that's called Manhattan On the Island of Manhattan.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26. -- Pennsylvania this afternoon defeated Cornell at football by a score of 32 to 10, but the plucky boys from Ithaca succeeded in twice crossing the Quakers' goal line. Pennsylvania scored six touch-downs for a total of thirty, and compelied Cornell to make a safety touch-down.

BOURKE COCKRAN'S remark at the dinner to Major BYRNE that he was a free trader, and would never again "masquerade" as a revenue reformer, yet, while he regarded protection with abhorrence, "we are bound to sustain this Administration and even the adoption of its party policies," was only a manifestation from the Democratic side of the spirit abundantly manifested on the Republican side during the campaign.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26. -- When the Senate shall resume its sitting it will find on its calendar a number of bills which have been the subject of much popular consideration in the past.

The games of football in Brooklyn yesterday brought one of the tragedies which critics of the game say are bound to come from its rough tactics. Walter L. Rhue, sixteen years old of 720 Carroll Street, Brooklyn: was killed.

-- Apparently the lot of superannuated Methodist ministers in Indiana is not a happy one, if they are obliged, that is, to depend for even the barest necessities of life upon the allowance made them by the State Conference. For two years, now, contributions for this purpose have fallen short of the amount nominally appropriated by $10,000, and no claimant has received more than $70.

ORANGE, N. J, Nov. 26. -- The " Carnival of Authors," held in Music Hall to-night, was attended by a large and fashionable company. The programme opened with a grand entree and the dancing of the Louis XIV. minuet.
-- Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Gould gave an informal dance and party to a number of the young friends of their little daughter Edith last evening at their residence, 5 Washington Square North.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 27. -- The storm which has been raging throughout the Northwest for the past forty-eight hours is the greatest that has visited this section since the blizzard of Jan. 12, 1888, in which 107 lives were lost.
The first open public golf tournament that has ever been held in this country will take place today at Van Cortlandt Park, beginning at 11 o' clock.
Abram S. Hewltt. ex-Mayor of New-York City and ex-Representative in Congress, said:

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 27. -- Details of the shortage of Postmaster R.B. Armour came out to-day. The exact amount of the deficit was $12,233.88, which was paid over to Assistant Postmaster Harris Nov. 18.

Bluebells had his picture taken yesterday. Bluebells is the colt of one of the Shetland ponies at the Live Stock Exhibition in Madison Square Garden. This exhibition has afforded a great opportunity to the young art students of NewYork to make sketches from life. Bluebell's picture was taken by three pretty girls wearing Alpine hats, and with extra pencils tucked in their belts and sketchbooks in their hands.

The authorized report of an interview with Gen. WEYLER is in very striking contrast with the report of Capt. REYES of the Cuban Army, who has arrived wounded in Florida. The Captain General reports that he is "entirely satisfied" with the results of his military operations, that MACEO was able to offer but a feeble resistance to the Spanish attacks, and that only "a few hours' fighting" was needed to dislodge him.

The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club last Fall challenged for the Seawanhaka Cup, which was won by the Glencairn, and the races for the trophy are to be sailed next season. Beyond knowing that the boats to race for and defend this cup are to be 20 feet racing length, yachtsmen are ignorant of the dimensions of the boats and the rules that are to govern the races.

An autopsy was held at Seney Hospital yesterday afternoon on the body of Walter S. Rhue, the sixteen-year-old boy who was killed Thanksgiving Day in a football game at Prospect Park, Brooklyn. The conclusions reached were embodied in a letter to Coroner Coombs, which was mailed to him at 4 P.M.

We told a few days ago the story of the failure of the Sullivan County Savings Bank, in New-Hampshire, and of the deplorable effect of the loss of a greater part of the money which many people of very moderate means in Claremont and neighboring towns had deposited in that institution.

Our neighbor, The Tribune, publishes an editorial article of considerable length concerning the operations of the Nail Trust, a combination which, it says, was "designed to prevent intense competition and destructive depression of price." The Tribune is profoundly impressed now by the severity of this competition, but has scarcely anything to say about the combination's outrageous exactions.
-- Coupons of the Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad Company's consolidated first mortgage bonds maturing Dec. 1 will be paid at the Union Trust Company.
The coming curling season promises to be one of more than usual interest.

The reputation of the American duello has been distinctly lowered by the conduct of Mr. J.A. HUTCHINSON, who has been, so to speak, fighting with the Marquis DB MONTMORT in the neighborhood of Paris. For the affair was simply the common and harmless French duel, in anticipation of which no accident insurance company would dream of raising its premiums.

From The Boston Herald. We have no record of just how the Puritans' Thanksgiving tables were set, but from contemporaneous pictures we can judge judge that there few, if any, forks, each guest being supplied with a knife; they sat on benches and chests, ate from pewter platters, and the table was in most cases literally a board placed on wooden horses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27. -- The Spanish Legation has no intelligence confirming the report that the Spanish gunboat Baraous has captured three boats laden with insurgents and arms off the Province of Santiago de Cuba.

The laurels of Galveston and NewOrleans have disturbed the sleep of Charleston. We have recently called attention to the remarkable increase in the exports from the further Southern ports, as shown by the reports of the Bureau of Statistics for Nov. 1. In connection with an analysis of these returns The Manufacturers' Record of Baltimore says:
