BERLIN, Dec. 5. -- Commenting upon the proclamation of the President of the United States restoring tonnage dues upon German vessels, the National Zeitung says that the tonnage dues at Hamburg, Bremen, and other German ports will surely be increased, but solely for the purpose of improving the harbors for the general benefit of shipping, and not for State purposes, as in America.

The revision of the new drill regulations is being eagerly looked forward to by National Guardsmen, and, from the latest information, the War Department should have the work ready for issue in about a month. There are many radical changes, some of which are as follows:
The Rev. John Watson, "Ian Maclaren," was the guest of the Lotos Club last night.

ALBANY, Dec. 5. -- Mr. Matthew Hale, in the presentation ceremonies, in turning over the new Court House here, whose purchase was made necessary by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court sitting in Albany, made the historical address. It was a carefully prepared and finely delivered elfort.

TUESDAY, Dec. 8. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Edward Browne, referee, 412 West Fortieth Street, south side, 156.8 feet west of Ninth Avenue, 18.4 by 98.9, four-story and basement brick dwelling. Due on judgment, $3,760,06.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- The members of the Joint Congressional Commission appointed to investigate and report upon the matter of internal revenue regulations, with a view to permitting the use of free alcohol in the arts, manufactures, and composition of medicinal compounds, returned to-day from New York.

NANSEN is not yet turned of forty -- indeed, he is about five years short of it -- but here we have a life of him from his birth down to his departure for the polar regions, from which he has recently returned with so much acclaim.
A score of important New York Stock Exchange houses submitted the following inquiry yesterday to correspondents throughout the country:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 5. -- The Baltimore Reorganization Committee of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company is not satisfied with the report of Stephen W. Little on the financial condition of the property between the dates of Sept. 30, 1889, and Nov. 30, 1895, the period of the Mayer management, and will probably make an independent examination of the books and accounts of the corporation.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 5. -- The series of members' handicap tournaments was commenced to-day on the Golf Club links, and the excellent turnout of players augurs well for the interest in Winter golf this coming season. A handsome silver cup has been presented to the club by The Lakewood Times and Journal, and it is to be played for every Saturday, rain or shine, during this month and January, making nine contests in all.

ALTHOUGH Grammar School No. 55 is one of the older schools in this city and cannot boast of a building with those modern appliances which conduce so much to the comfort and pleasure of both teachers and pupils, yet it has the reputation of having an excellent staff of teachers and of turning out well-equipped scholars from the graduating classes.

Kate Leary, widow of the notorious "Red" Leary, the bank burglar and all-around thief, died Friday night at the Red Light, a shanty hotel on the Coney Island Bowery, of a complication of diseases and alcohol. She was about fifty years old, and not many years ago was considered one of the cleverest shoplifters and pickpockets in this vicinity.

AN event of more than ordinary importance to a large section of the club was the laying, a a few days ago, of the cornerstone of the new home of the New York Athletic Club. The plans for the building depict what will undoubtedly be the finest house of its kind in the world, embodying as it will so many things essential to that life.
District Attorney John R. Fellows was still alive at midnight last night, although his physicians had given up all hope of his recovery, and said that his death was only a question of hours.

The greatest peril to the negroes of the South when freedom came to them from the war for the Union was the fact that for generations labor, in the minds of the dominant race, and therefore in their own minds, had been disgraceful. It was inevitable that when they were freed from slavery their first feeling should be that they were freed from the obligation to work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Secretary Herbert in his annual report asks Congress at the coming session to authorize three light-draught battleships and twelve torpedo boats. He recommends that these ships be planned for an extreme deep load draught of not more than 23 feet, and suggests that considerations of strategy upon our Atlantic and Gulf coasts render this an essential to the success of naval campaigns.

Commodore George J. Gould, Vice Commodore Fred T. Adams, and Rear Commodore John H. Hanan will again be the flag officers of the Atlantic Yacht Glub next year. They have been renominated, and each has accepted the nomination. There will be no opposition to their election, because the members of the Atlantic Club appreciate the services these gentlemen have rendered, the club in the past.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5. -- Mark Hanna's arrival in Washingtin imparts a tone of animation to capital gossip, but Mr. Hanna's conversation, which is free enough to all callers, conveys no information about the Cabinet of the incoming Preseident, nothing definite about his policy, and only guarded-particulars about the arrangements for the inauguration.

It is generally the case that false money is worthless money, but the Treasury Department of the United States is experiencing trouble with silver dollars which in value come nearer being genuine dollars than the coins struck off at the Federal mints. This is due to the fact that the silver in the standard dollar is worth only about 50 cents, which leaves a tempting margin of profit for counterfeiters.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 6 -- The Union National Bank, which suspended business on Sept. 9, owing to the defalcation of $612.000 by Individual Bookkeepers Colom and Leefe, who operated through outside confederates, will resume business on Monday. The bank will start with a capital of $300,000. S.V. Fornaris will be President and S.E. Worms First Vice President.

John Fink of 322 Kossuth Street, West Hoboken, and Frederick Schick, a neighbor, were in a saloon in West Hoboken at 2 A. M. yesterday. Fink was telling Schick that he had not seen his eldest son for fifteen years, the boy having gone away twelve years ago.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The rate of discount during the past week for three months' bills was 3 per cent., and for thirty-day bills 2 1/2 per cent. Some gold was shipped to Russia. Silver was unchanged. At the Stock Exchange the depression in mining securities dampened other shares. No revival is expected until the new year.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 5. -- The local market continued to improve in tone, and higher prices were again recorded. Trading was very light, and there was very little increase in the offerings. Hudson River Telephone was 1 point higher for bid price, and no stock was offered under 60. Celluloid stock advanced 1 per cent, on the-declaration of the usual dividend.

District Attorney John R. Fellows was no better at midnight last night. His condition changed little during the day, and both Dr. Fleming and Dr. Rodenstein gave it as their opinion that if the Colonel's vitality will only remain good, he may live through the night and possibly to-day.

BERLIN, Dec. 6. -- Apart from the trial of the five editors and the scandals attached thereto, the chief topic of discussion, in Berlin social circles grows out of the circumstances of the production of Wildenbruch's "Kaiser Heinrich," at the Berliner Theater, on Tuesday last) and Gerhard Hauptmann's "Sunken Bell," at the Deutsche Theater, on Wednesday.

To the Editor of The New York Times No lover of freedom and humanity can help having sympathy with the Cuban patriots in their struggle for independence. I spent some time in the beautiful and miserable island a few years ago, and became acquainted with the horrors of Spanish misrule.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

RIVER EDGE, N.J., Dec. 6. -- An old man with gray whiskers, fairly well dressed and a good talker, has been perpetrating petty swindles on the keepers of boarding houses in North Bergen County. His mode of procedure is simple, but has never, so far as known, failed to work. He visits the boarding house about midday and asks if the house can accommodate four men for from two to six weeks.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 6. -- The movement of the business interests of the country toward National currency reform upon wholly non-partisan lines, which has resulted in a call by the commercial organizations of the Central West for a convention in this city in January, promises to become one of the notable things in the history of the country.

It is not probable that at the second and last session of the Fifty-fourth. Congress the National revenue will be increased by tariff legislation of any kind. It appears to be settled that there will be a special session of the Fifty-fifth Congress, beginning on or about March 15, called by President MCKINLEY in order that the tariff laws may be revised by his party.

Five cents will buy a surprising amount of transportation on an east side street car, especially in the case of an obstinate woman who pretends that she does not understand English very well. The other day a small Italian woman boarded a Second Avenue car at Twenty-sixth Street and said that she wanted to get off at Second Street.

In the present situation in the United States Senate it is plainly a good thing that no action, by that body is needed to carry out the proposed settlement of the Anglo-Venezuelan question. But it is a still better thing that the proposed settlement does not involve positive action, by the American Government at all, but is to be carried out by the two Government directly interested.
All immediate interest in the financial world hangs on to-day's meeting of Congress and the President's message.

We have no doubt that the City of New York will take its full share of the work to be done to make the Indianapolis Convention of Business Men on Jan. 12 a success. There is no city in the Union with interests so great, direct and indirect, in the purposes of the convention.

The Board of Education has been stirred up to inquiring into the delays which have heretofore prevailed in acquiring sites and constructing buildings for the public schools, and it has also taken action in regard to renting various premises for the use of schools until proper buildings shall be provided.

His wife's dissipation caused the death, at the Flower Hospital, yesterday, of Theodore Leon, forty-nine years old, of 1,115 Second Avenue. Under the name of Sarah Archer, a woman was arraigned in Yorkville. Police Court on Tuesday on a change of intoxication. She was fair looking, and wept so bitterly that Magistrate Crane discharged her.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6. -- It is not likely that anything will be done in either house of Congress to-morrow except to exchange congratulations and condolences over the results of the election, and to listen to the President's message.

A special service was held at St. Andrew's Protestant Episcopal Church, One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, under the auspices of the Association for Promoting the interests of Church Schools, Colleges, and Seminaries.

LONDON, Dec. 6. -- The Hon. Thomas F. Bayard, the American Ambassador, has written a letter to The Daily Telegraph anent that journal's proposal to take up a public subscription for the purpose of purchasing him a National Christmas gift as a token of the esteem of the British people. The letter, which is dated Dec. 5, says in part: ...

More than 1,000 persons failed last night to get into the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, to hear the Rev. Dr. John Watson, (Ian Maclaren) preach, and, although the sermon lasted, fully forty-five minutes, the crowd thronged hopefully around the many entrances until the services ended.

The underground trolley is to furnish the motive power for the cars on the Fourth and Madison, the Sixth and the Eighth Avenue street car lines. This is the decision reached individually by the Directors of the Metropolitan Traction Company. They will hold a meeting Tuesday afternoon, and give formal expression to their determination.

In a small library desk belonging to Brian G. Hughes of 49 East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street was discovered a few days ago. a couple of secret drawers which, upon examination, were found to contain some jevelry and securities and deeds to thousands of acres of land.
Thousands of admirers of a contest in which endurance and physical power must tell gathered in the Madison Square Garden last night to witness the start of the six days' international bicycle race.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The probable assent of Venezuela to the proposed treaty of arbitration of the British Guiana boundary dispute through the good offices of the United States and the practical conclusion of a general arbitration convention between Great Britain and the United States, it is stated, will form two of the most important diplomatic announcements in the President's message to Congress tomorrow.

BAYONNE, N.J., Dec. 6. -- William A. Eddy, Dr. William B. Mitchell, and Henry L. Alien sent the first kite telephone and telegraphic message over a midair wire, sustained by three large kites, last night. Morse sounder telegraph signals were also sent by means of a battery.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 7. -- The impression seems to prevail that there is a contract in existence which requires a quadrangular race between Cornell, Harvard, Pennsylvania, and Columbia, to be rowed over the Poughkeepsie course next June. Such is not the case. No action has been taken here in respect to any future college regatta, and none will be taken until overtures are made from one or more of the colleges interested.

G.H. Duggan and Secretary Hamilton of the Royal St. Lawrence Yacht Club and C.W. Wetmore, Walter C. Kerr, C.A. Sherman. W.P. Stephens, C.H. Crane, and Frank Bowne Jones, representing the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club, have had two conferences and have agreed on the conditions that are to govern the races for the Seawanhaka Cup next Summer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- Conditions were against holders in all speculative markets at the opening here for the day and week. The cables were soft. There was enlargement of receipts and indifference on the part of outsiders. There appeared to be selling of an important character by professionals in leading grain markets.

Evangelist Moody gave his first sermon on "The Return of Our Lord" yesterday morning in Cooper Union before a well-filled house. He will preach this morning on the same subject. The Rev. Dr. Harsha led the meeting in prayer and the choir sang several hymns.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 7. -- Arrangements are about complete for the big fair for the benefit of the Orange Orphan Home, which will be held in Berkeley Hall on Wednesday and Thursday. The decorations are to be handsome and elaborate, and the society people of this vicinity will turn out in large numbers to help along this charity, which has not had the benefit of a public fair for twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Senators were loath to discuss the President's message to-night, and this reticence was especially noticeable among members of the Committee on Foreign Relations. Of this committee. Senators Sherman, Davis, Cameron, Lodge, Gray, Turpie. Daniel, and Mills refused to discuss the message.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The General Pension Appropriation bill for the year ending June 30, 1898, which was reported to-day to the House from the Appropriations Committee, carries a total of $141,203,880. This is $65,000 less than the appropriation for the current fiscal year, and the same amount under the estimates submitted by the Commissioner of Pensions.

TRENTON, Dec. 7. -- According to the report of State Dairy Commissioner McGuire there are in New Jersey 200,347 milk cows, and their value is $6,887,930. This is an increase of 7,706 cows over the number reported in 1895, showing that the dairy business in the State is increasing rapidly, and many people are going into the milk-producing business.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 7. -- Five negroes, it is reported, were killed and a number of others injured by a volley of bullets fired at them from ambush as they were at work on the Cotton Belt Railroad, in a jungle, near Malvern, last Tuesday.

BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 7 -- Consul General Murguiondo of Uruguay affirms the statement he made through The United Associated Presses last Friday to the effect that the reported revolution in Uruguay was of little account. The Consul General was at that time in receipt of a cablegram from Montevideo, the Uruguayan capital, saying that the revolt was unimportant.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 -- The engagement of Miss Isabel Perkins, who has a larger fortune in her own right than any other young woman of the Summer Newport cottage set to Lars Anderson has been announced. Miss Perkins is the only child of Capt. and Mrs. Perkins of Boston. Some years ago she was left $17,000,000 by her grandfather, Mr. Weld of Boston.
Stock market dull and rather weak. Money on call, 1 to 2 1/2 per cent.

NEWARK, N.J. Dec. 7. -- A man, heavily bearded and of burly build, was captured this morning in the old copper mine at North Arlington by Mayor George Baylis of Arlington, his son, George Baylis, Jr., and Policeman Smith of Kearny. There have been a number of petty robberies in the vicinity of the Mayor's house of late, and Mr. Baylis feels satisfied that the mysterious mine dweller knows all about them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- An interesting and important litigation respecting street railroad franchises in Cincinnati was ended to-day by the refusal of the Supreme Court of the United States to bring up the decree of the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals for review. The particular line involved is that locally famous as "Route No. 8," over the granting of the franchise for which there was much criticism of the municipal authorities.

Mozart's "Don Giovanni" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. There was an audience of respectable size and a tolerable amount of enthusiasm. It cannot be said that the evening was one of glad surprises, for those parts of the performance which deserved much commendation had been made familiar in previous seasons, while those which were new to the audience did not call for special praise.

When the ordinary citizen finds himself confronted by a public or private nuisance he generally moves away from it or suffers in silence. He has had, perhaps, in the past the agreeable sensation of seeing his carefully drawn complaint to some department ignored entirely or else dismissed forever with a curt "The matter will be submitted to the proper authorities."
The heads of the City Magistrates seem to be impenetrable to the meaning of the wonderful "Raines law." At the Yorkville Court on Sunday Magistrate CRANE is quoted as saying:
Louis F. Payn will be the next State Superintendent of Insurance. Governor-elect Black has been saying he would point him if he wanted the place. Mr. Payn has decided to take it.

For the first time in eighteen years a Republican Board of Freeholders yesterday took charge of the affairs of Hudson County. Yet the Republicans did not succeed in organizing the board. Nominally the board consists of fifteen Republicans and twelve Democrats. Actually it consisted of fourteen Republicans and Democrats, and thirteen Republicans.

Transactions on the Chicago Exchange were confined in the main to purchases of bonds for investment account. There is little or no trading by speculators, and as a consequence the variations in prices are hardly worth noticing. The demand for bonds shows no abatement, and a heavy business is being done outside the Exchange over the counters of dealers in this class of securities.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 7. -- In the Federal Court to-day the Santa Fe lost its point of contention, and the case was remanded back to the court of Jefferson County, and will be heard by Judge Myers. The decision was rendered by Judge Foster, and concurred in by Judge Mayer of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 7. -- Henry L. Goodwill of East Hartford, a stockholder of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, has written a letter to State Treasurer Hodge claiming that an error has been made in computing the tax due the State from the company, and that the error makes the tax appear to be about $50,000 less than it actually is.

The length of the President's message and the lateness of the hour at which it was published yesterday afternoon prevented many persons from being prepared to express an opinion upon it last night. This was the statement of many, among prominent lawyers, bankers, and business men whose opinion was sought.

Not since the great auction of the Morgenthan syndicate's property, in the Washington Heights section of the Twelfth Ward, in May, 1891, have as many New York lots been sold in a single day under the hammer as were disposed of by George R. Read in the Real Estate Exchange yesterday.
Indoor cycling records are at a discount in Madison Square Garden. The contestants in the six-day race are toppling them over every hour in a game struggle to achieve glory and fortune.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- Senators and Representatives were chary in their comments on the President's message this afternoon. Some few of the opinions expressed follow:

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 7. -- James Gray, a hostler in Dietrich's stables, 116 Main Street, was found on the sidewalk in front of the stable by Martin Keating this morning, dead. On retiring last night to his room over the stable, he moved his bed close to the window. In his sleep he probably rolled out of bed and fell to the ground out of the window, which was open.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Congress reassembled to-day under "most favored nation" conditions, with bright sunshine, a gently bracing air, a temperature running from 40 to 55 degrees, and both halls of assembly renovated and purified and ventilated in a manner more nearly conforming to hygienic requirements than has ever before been attempted.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7. -- The local market was firm and very dull, until the last hour, when it weakened somewhat and became more active. The Traction stocks were featureless all day, and closed at about 1/8 difference from Saturday. In the specialties there was good buying of Pennsylvania Heat common, which gained 1/2, and the preferred was in good demand, at 21.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The Senate was called to order by Vice President Stevenson and prayer was offered by the blind Chaplain, the Rev. Mr. Milburn. A special blessing was asked for the senior Senator from Iowa, (Mr. Allison, Rep.,) that he might be restored to perfect health and be brought speedily to his seat.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7. -- The first session of the conference of social reformers and charity workers took place this afternoon at Chicago Commons. Prof. Graham Taylor presided, and told how great was the need of interest in, and discussion of, the problems which confront society. Prof. C.R. Henderson of the University of Chicago spoke on "Social Reconstruction; a Growth of Human Life."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 7. -- John Suydam, a farmer living near Franklin Park, reported to the authorities this morning an encounter he had had, and turned over to them a burglar's kit which he obtained as the spoils of his experience. He said that he drove to this city behind a spirited colt.

BOSTON, Dec. 7. -- The market for local stocks was narrow and uninteresting, with no particular feature. The tone on the whole was fairly strong, and fluctuations even in the stocks most traded in were narrow. Butte was the most active stock on the list, selling down 5/8, to 6 1/2. Montana was very dull, and down 1/4, to 92 1/2.

Some time between 10 o'clock Sunday night and 7 o'clock yesterday morning one of the plate glass windows of Ehrich's dry good store was broken and opera glasses and bric-a-brac to the value of $250 were stolen. . Although there are six watchmen on duty within the store, they failed to discover that the window had been broken until 7 o'clock yesterday morning.

LONDON, Dec. 7. -- Commenting upon President Cleveland's message to Congress, The Standard will to-morrow say it is dignified and able and is marked throughout with sterling common sense. It deserves and will doubtless obtain the serious study of the European peoples. The Standard is of the opinion that the message will excite bitterness in Spain, which country, nevertheless, must make up her mind to listen to friendly counsel.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 7 -- The principal topic of discussion politically in Utah is the action of the Mormon Church authorities taken recently in depriving Moses Thatcher of his ecclesiastical offices, refusing him admission to the Mormon Temple, and attempting to prevent the Legislature, which will meet in January, from electing him to the United States Senate.

Jewelry and household bric-a-brac, held on unredeemed pledges by the Provident Loan-Society of New York, were placed on sale yesterday at the auction room of William B. Norman, 238 Fifth Avenue. It was the third lot sold by the society since it began business under a special charter of the Legislature as an aid to the destitute.

Mr. Mansfield and his company gave a brisk and effective performance at the Garden Theatre last night of George Bernard Shaw's remarkably clever satirical play, in three acts, called "Arms and the Man," which, quite contrary to general expectation, has secured a permanent place in their repertory.

The trial of a suit brought by J. Hirsch-field against all the stockholders of the Madison Square Bank and the receivers of the bank, Miles M. O'Brien and James G. Cannon, to compel the stockholders to pay a deficiency of 50 per cent, on their stock was begun yesterday before Justice Stover in Special Term, Part V., of the Supreme Court.

The aquarium in old Castle Garden will be opened to the public on Thursday, Dec. 10. Work on it is almost completed, and painters were yesterday putting the finishing touches on pools and tanks, in some of which fish have been living for two years, awaiting the speculative curiosity of the public or the studious observation of scholars.

The King's Bridge Road, franchise controversy had another airing, before Judge Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday. A temporary injunction had been obtained in Part II., restraining the Third Avenue Company from going on with the line until the question could be determined by Judge Truax.

This is a time for the discussion of municipal problems and for education on the subject of civic duty and responsibility. Every contribution to the subject should receive attention and be submitted to scrutiny. A leading point in a lecture delivered before the "League for Political Education" at the Berkeley Lyceum on Saturday by Mr. J.A. TAILOR was that the city should exploit its franchises largely for revenue.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 7. -- Harold Payne Whitney, son of ex-Secretary Whitney, has bought the John Knower place, on Bellevue Avenue and the Cliffs, and has presented it to his wife, who was formerly Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt. He paid a quarter of a million for the estate, and is to have the house remodeled and turned into a palatial Summer residence, for which plans are now being prepared.

Whether or not the Supreme Court of the United States shall decide that the Inter-State Commerce Commission has power to fix the rates and charges of the trunk-line railroads from the West to the Atlantic ports and to establish "such rules and regulations in regard thereto as are lawful and just," in accordance with the Produce Exchange petition, the subject is one upon which the commission should make a thorough inquiry.

In view of the testimony given recently before the Senate committee investigating the Raines liquor tax law the question has again come to the fore as to what constitutes a meal. A number of persons were asked to give their opinions, and the answers for the most part declared it impossible to accurately fix on any certain amount of food as a standard.
Sorosis came yesterday to the educational platform in the annual round of topics which she follows from year to year. The meeting was held in the ballroom of the Waldorf.
Republican primaries will be held through-out the city to-night for the election of delegates to the Assembly District Conventions. These will elect members of the County Committee.
From THE NEW YORK TIMES, Nov. 14. LONDON, Nov. 13. -- The Chronicle win tomorrow publish what it claims to be a complete summary of the agreement regarding the Venezuelan question.

The suit of the Westchester Water Works and Moses R. Crow, a contractor, to restrain Mrs. Maria H. Hotchkiss, widow of the firearms manufacturer, and Joseph Richardson from selling or otherwise disposing of bonds and stock of the Westchester Company, the Upper New York Water Company, and the New York District Water Company, to the amount of over $4,000,000, came up for argument in the Supreme Court, before Justice Truax, to-day.
New York clergymen discussed "The Ideal Newspaper" yesterday morning at the conference of Ministerial Associations in the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Col. John R. Fellows died at 1:06 yesterday afternoon at his home, 610 West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street, where he had been confined to his bed since last Tuesday, suffering from a cancerous growth of the stomach. The end came peacefully.

The Grand Jury for the December term was sworn in yesterday by Recorder Goff in Part I., General Sessions. In his charge the Recorder made reference to the memorial of the labor organizations that representatives of the workingmen be appointed on Grand Juries. The memorial could not affect the present Grand Jury, for the reason that it was selected a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7. -- The report of the Secretary of State, to which President Cleveland referred in his message to Congress, states that "the relations of the United States with foreign powers continue upon that footing of harmony and friendliness which has been their fortunate characteristic for so many years."

The Spanish-American Light and Power Company, whose office is at 113 Wall Street and plant in Havana and Matanzas, Cuba, is having a hard time on account of the war in Cuba. It is a New York State corporation, incorporated in 1883 with a capital stock of $2,000,000, which has since been increased to $4,000,000, and represents a consolidation of five gas and electric light companies in Cuba.

BERLIN, Dec. 7. -- The trial of the five editors, Baron von Luetzow and Herren Ploetz, Berger, Foellmar, and Leckert, for libeling Baron Marschall von Bieberstein, Count August von Euienburg, and Prince Alexander von Hohenlohe, was resumed this morning. The courtroom was crowded with privileged persons, expectant that additional sensations were imminent, and in this expectation they were not disappointed.

Wallack's they again call the house that has so long been Palmer's, and the change of name is appropriately coincident with the production of a good new play and the reappearance of a well-liked and able actor. Mr. Willard was welcomed last night without fuss, but with heartfelt cordiality, by a large audience.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal news-papers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

BOSTON, Dec. 8. -- The plans of the Boston Terminal Company, which is constructing the new Union Station, contemplate a new departure in railroading. These plans provide for the joint handling of electric and steam traffic.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Congress devoted itself to business to-day. Little was accomplished in the slow-going Senate, but the House managed to dispose of the General Pension bill.
Stock market dull and featureless. Money on call, 1 1/2 to 2 per cent.

ALBANY, Dec. 8. -- Gov. Morton to-day reduced to forty years, subject to commutation for good behavior, the sentence of William West of New York City, a life prisoner in Sing Sing. This will release West in September, 1898, when he will have served twenty-four years.
SING SING, Dec. 8. -- The Rev. T. De Witt Talmage is about to marry again. The engagement of Miss Susie Mangam of this village to the well-known preacher was formally announced to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- Politicians here are taking a lively interest in the Pennsylvania Senatorial fight; not that they care much as to the identity of the man who shall succeed Cameron; that is immaterial. But they are deeply interested in knowing whether Senator Quay shall continue to be the dictator of Republican policy in the Keystone State.
The Republican Senatorial caucus unanimously adopted yesterday the following resolution, offered by Senator WOLCOTT:

A complete set of the Grolier Club publications was the attraction which brought a roomful of bidders to the sale of the Richard Riker library at the auction rooms of Bangs Co., 93 Fifth Avenue, yesterday. The bidding for these works was done through agents, who acted in most case's for younger members of the Grolier Club who do not own the earlier publications issued in its name.

BOSTON, Dec. 8. -- Elections were held today in fifteen Massachusetts cities. As is usual in this commonwealth, the contests were generally of a, non-partisan character, the label "Republican" or "Democrat" being seldom what it seemed. In, several cities the American Protective Association joined in the strife, but was successful in none.

The Dingley Tariff bill is dead. For some time past we have expressed the opinion that the Republican leaders would be compelled to give up all hope of passing it. The proceedings in the caucus of the Republican Senators yesterday indicate that the bill will be dropped.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8. -- The bears were in control of the Chicago Stock Exchange, and prices were heavy in consequence. The principal attack was on Diamond Match and North Chicago stocks, the former declining to 118 and the latter to 205 1/2 Diamond Match closed stronger at 120 bid. North Chicago was also bid up some two or three points at the close, without bringing out any stock.

LONDON, Dec. 8. -- The Secretaries of the County Cricket Clubs held their annual meeting in London to-day. Among other business transacted, a schedule of the games to be played by the Philadelphia cricket team was drawn up. The first game of the Philadelphians will be played against the Oxford University eleven, at Oxford, on June 7, and the series will close in London, July 29, with a match against the Surrey team.

Ira Shafer, whose death has been announced, was for years a noted figure among the lawyers of this State. He at one time did much in the criminal branches of the courts, and always showed a friendly feeling for young and inexperienced lawyers, offering his assistance to them, when the perceived that they were uncertain as to the method of presenting a case.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Charles Melville of 953 Amsterdam Avenue, New York City, it is said, deserted his wife Nov. 17 last and ran away with Genevieve Brown, twentytwo years of age. Mrs. Melville, learning that her husband and Miss Brown were in Chicago, came here last Sunday with Miss Theresa Brown, a sister of Genevieve.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 8. -- The Atlanta Chamber of Commerce this morning adopted a resolution providing for the appointment of a committee from the chamber to attend the commercial convention to be held at Indianapolis Jan. 12 for the purpose of considering the money question and urging upon Congress the adoption of some remedial plan.

HAVANA, Dec. 8. -- There is great rejoicing among the Loyalists in Havana over the report that Antonio Maceo, second in command of the Cuban forces, was killed in a battle in the vicinity of Punta Brava. The report may be true, or, like previous reports of Maceo's death, it may be false.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The case of the United States vs. the Trans-Missouri Freight Association came up in the Supreme Court of the United States this afternoon, and argument was begun by Attorney General Harmon, in behalf of the Government. He was followed by Mr. John F. Dillon of New York, for the Union Pacific Railway Company and allied corporations.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 8. -- A band of tramps made what appeared to be an organized raid on this town last night, causing the greatest excitement among the inhabitants.
Miss Maude Augusta Balston and Walter Eugene Ragsdale were married at 8 o'clock last evening at the home of the bride's parents, 103 Decatur Street, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- "I intend to quit politics for good," said Congressman William Lorimer to-day. "I shall remain in Congress long enough to vote for Reed for Speaker of the Fifty-fifth Congress, as I hear that there may be a fight against him. I shall also wait for the passage of the Tariff bill; I want to vote for it.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8. -- The local market was dull beyond description. In fact, a number of stocks were not traded in at all, and in no case did the closing price vary more than 1/4 to 1/2 per cent, from yesterday. Choctaw new preferred stock was brought out to-day for the first time, and sales of it (full paid $25 per share) were recorded at 23.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- The Republican National Committee having decided to establish permanent headquarters at Washington, Messrs. Hanna and Osborne, the Chairman and Secretary, respectively, of the National Committee, accompanied by Mr. Payne. the National Committeemon from Wisconsin; Mr. Myron M. Parker, the District member of the committee, and Gen. Horace Porter of New-York to-day began in inspection of several buildings that have been offered to them for headquarters.

As readers of THE TIMES already know, Monday's session of the conference of ministerial associations was devoted to the subject of " The Ideal Newspaper." There could be no topic more suitable for a meeting of ministers or of any other persons professionally or unprofessionally devoted to the welfare of mankind.

-- Miss Laura Duane Ireland made her debut in society at a large dinner and dance given by her mother, Mrs. John B. Ireland, of 15 East Forty-seventh Street, at 8 o'clock last evening. The debutante was gowned in white satin, with white velvet trimmings, and carried a bouquet of pink roses and orchids.

It has become a matter of pressing importance that Congress should provide for a readjustment of the relation of the Government to the subsidy debt of the Pacific railroads. On the 1st of January bonds issued to the Union Pacific will come to maturity amounting to over $13,000,000, and those issued to the Central Pacific to the amount of over $6,000,000 will also mature.

The women revivalists, it would seem have determined that the supremacy of numbers must be with them for the rest of the Cooper Union meeting's. Their attendance at the afternoon services of the present week was much better than at any of the meetings held last week, and yesterday they numbered 60 per cent, of the audience.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- There ware yesterday a few explosive criticisms of the President's message touching the Cuban situation, but the impression given to most persons was that the disposition to grant belligerent rights to the combatants was less conspicuous than it was a year ago.

A meeting of the Tree Planting Association of New York City was held yesterday in the parlors of the Wool Club, in the Wool Exchange Building, to elect officers for the ensuing year. Mayor Strong presided.

Mrs. Sarah B. How, who is one of the lecturers employed by the Brooklyn Institute, began yesterday morning at the "Woman's Exchange, 12 East Thirtieth Street, a course of six lectures on "The Ancient and Honorable Art of Housewifery." Yesterday's lecture was on "The Housewife of the past."

A reception was held at the Hotel Waldorf last night by a number of women of Washington, D.C., who are interested in the National Congress of Mothers, which will meet in that city Feb. 16, 1897. The visitors are Mrs. Adlai E. Stevenson, Mrs. William L. Wilson, Miss Morton, Mrs. A.A. Birney, Mrs. T.W. Birney, Mrs. Kincaid, Miss Janet E. Richards. Mrs. H.W. Fuller, and Mrs. Phoebe Hearst.

BOSTON, Dec. 8. -- There was considerably more doing among local stocks than for a number of days past, but the activity was largely confined to a few specialties, and those among the mining shares. There was a wide range of fluctuations in both Butte and Montana, the former rising rapidly on the opening from 6 1/2 to 7, and then declining to 6 3/4.

OMAHA, Dec. 8. -- Two years ago the Legislature appropriated $150,000 in aid of the drought-stricken settlers on the Western frontier, a region which prospered when devoted exclusively to stock grazing, and can only be tilled when irrigated.
The City Vigilance League gave its fourth annual dinner at the Hotel St. Denis last night. One hundred and thirty members and guests sat down to the banquet at 7:30.

The decision of the Metropolitan Traction Company to employ the underground trolley on the Fourth and Madison Avenue, the Sixth Avenue, and the Eighth Avenue lines gives a somewhat new aspect to the question of rapid transit. Of course it does not solve that question.

Daniel Osborn Ketcham died Monday night at the home of his son Edwin Ketcham, 273 Skillman Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Ketcham was born in 1814 at Mount Hope, Orange County, N.Y., where his family was prominent. He settled in Brooklyn when a boy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- A Republican Senatorial caucus was held this morning.

"The Girl from Paris," a two-act musical farce, or burletta, that has long been popular in London under the title of "The Gay Parisienne," was produced at the Herald Square Theatre last night under the able direction of Edward E. Rice, and was received with a vociferous expression, of approval.

PARIS, Dec. 8. -- Sir Edmund John Monson, who was recently appointed British Ambassador to France in succession to Lord Dufferin, visited the Palace of the Elysee to-day for the purpose of presenting his credentials to President Faure. He was received with the usual honors. The salon where President Faure received him was filled with State officials and military and other officers.

At autcion in the Trinity Building Salesroom yesterday Mr. Peter F. Meyer Co. sold, under foreclosure, 412 West Fortieth Street, three-story trick dwelling; 18.4 by 98.9. to Samuel Werner, for $8,700. for $8,700.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8. -- The Board of Trade has adopted a series of resolutions expressing feelings of relief and satisfaction over the recent victory for sound money and, "realizing the necessity for the correction of the evils that have led to the harmful financial agitation of the past few years," favoring a change in the currency system of the Government.

All the arrangements for the funeral of the late District Attorney, John R. Fellows, were completed yesterday. Acting District Attorney Vernon M. Davis, who is in charge of them, announced that the funeral would take place this afternoon at 3 o'clock at the Church of the Intercession, One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street and Eleventh Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8. -- James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, submitted his annual report to Congress to-day. The report contained many recommendations and suggestions, besides a large amount of statistical information. The report covered the period to Oct. 31, 1896.

A big meeting of real estate dealers and owners, lawyers, and business men, was held yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock, in the Real Estate Exchange and Salesroom, 50 Liberty Street, for the purpose of directing attention to the necessity for a fireproof Hall of Record. This public meeting was held in response to a call issued by the association that was organized a few weeks ago for securing this new building.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Postmaster General Wilson, in his annual report, reviews the growth of the Postal Service of the United States.

Argument was heard in the Supreme Court yesterday on an aplication made by William F. Sheehan, representing the North New York Traction Company, for an njunction to restrain the People's Traction Company from building the trans-Harlem Street Railroad, from the Bronx to the Harlem River, and for an order setting aside the grant of the franchise by the Controller to the People's Company for 100 per cent, of the gross receipts of the road.

Wheels are still a-spinning in Madison Square Garden and interest in the great six-day bicycle race is growing. Last night the attendance was larger even than on Sunday night, when the twenty-eight riders started on the long journey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Carroll D. Wright, Commissioner of Labor, to-day transmitted to Congress his report upon a plan for a permanent census service, in accordance with the joint resolution of March 19, I896. His bill provides for the establishment of a permanent organization, independent of any department, the duties of which shall be the taking of the twelfth census and succeeding censuses, and the collection of other information provided for.

The close of the third auction sale of unredeemed pledges by the Provident Loan Association of 279 Fourth Avenue, yesterday, will give a basis for the second annual report, to be made in January. This report, the officers believe, will show the experiment has been a success.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8. -- Cardinal Gibbons is in receipt of the official letter from the Pope informing his Eminence of the appointment of the Rev. Dr. Thomas J. Conaty of Worcester, Mass., Rector of the Catholic University at Washington, D.C. The letter is as follows:

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

It was gas day in the Board of Aldermen yesterday. The board took action on two gas matters. One was the granting of a franchise to the Consumers' Fuel Gas, Heat and Power Company to lay mains in the streets of this city.

BOSTON, Dec. 9. -- Plans are already being prepared for the legislative contest that is now impending with reference to the elevated railroad charter and franchise. J. Otis Wardwell has been selected as legislative counsel for the Pierpont Morgan-West End interests, and it is understood that a rough draft of the bill which will be asked for has been made.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- Col. Alexander K. McClure, the veteran editor of The Philadelphia Times, to-day rounded out fifty years of journalism, and his friends "tonight commemorated the golden anniversary of his editorial work by tendering him a dinner at the Hotel Walton. About 300 guests were present, representing not only Mr. McClure's associates in the newspaper fraternity, but men representative of every walk of life.
ALBANY, Dec. 9. -- Gov. Norton this afternoon approved a re-classification of several thousand positions in the State service which had been submitted to him by the State Civil Service Commission.

The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange decided last evening to suspend J. Kirkner of 24 New Street from membership for one year as a contumacious witness in the case of E.B. Cuthbert Co. Mr. Kirkner will, it is understood, appeal from the decision.

BERLIN, Dec. 9. -- Miss Lucy Follett Uhl, laughter of United States Ambassador Uhl, was married to-day to Guy V. Thompson of Tale University. The civil service was performed before the Register at 11:30 o'clock this morning. The religious ceremony was held at the residence of Ambassador Uhl at 7 o'clock this evening.

CHICAGO, Ill., Dec. 9. -- The market was very quiet, but the tone was steadier. There were renewed efforts by the bear traders to again depress prices, but their attacks met with more resistance, and the stocks offered were easily absorbed.

Henry Piepgras, as shipbuilder, was the first witness before the court of inquiry yesterday in the trial of inspector Fairchild. He testified that he had advised Mr. Woertz to purchase the Havana, believing the vessel fit to carry passengers to the fishing banks. He had repaired the Havana, and denied the allegations of Government witnesses about imperfect work and corrupt practices.

The Aquarium at Battery Park was opened yesterday to those who had invitations from the Park Board. To-day the building will be opened to the public, and hereafter the building will be open from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., except on Sundays and Mondays.

Greater New York was the subject of discussion last night at the dinner of the Committee of the Reform Club on Municipal Administration. The banquet hall of the club was filled with members and their guests. Among those present were:

From present indications it appears that an organized crusade will soon be begun against the city for violating the law as to sidewalks. For many years it has been the custom of the city to rent the privilege of using the sidewalks in the vicinity of the public markets to small dealers. This is especially true as to Washington Market.

We take as fairly credible the announcement, first made in a cable dispatch to yesterday's Sun and in part confirmed by the afternoon dispatches, that an effective pressure is at last to be put upon the Sultan. The announcement is that the pressure is to be brought to bear by a combination of England, France, and Russia, with the acquiescence of the other signers of the Berlin treaty, Germany, Austria, and Italy.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9. -- The local market was dull and closed at fractional concessions. Reading was the only active feature, but the trading was largely for the account of room traders, whose dealings are without significance. The annual meeting of the Union Traction was held to-day, but no new developments were brought out, there being perfect harmony, and the present management remains in control.

The Board of Education met yesterday to consider and discuss the new manual and by-laws drafted by the committee appointed three months ago to do that work. It was expected that the sections relating to the promotions and salaries and transfers of teachers and Principals would occasion considerable argument, and many teachers were present when the meeting began.

To the Editor of The New-York Times: I read with interest your editorial Nov. 29 regarding filtered water supplies. About Aug. 1 last there were completed at Louisville, Ky., experiments, some of which extended over nearly a year, which were undertaken with the view of determining the best means of purifying the water supplied to that city, which is taken from the Ohio River.
Mr. J. Craig Havemeyer of Wood Have-meyer said yesterday concerning the present condition of the market for outside securities:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- In May last Senator Elkins of West Virginia introduced a bill as follows:
The crop of bicycle records being harvested in Madison Square Garden is the most remarkable in the history of long-distance racing indoors. Unquestionably this sixday race will be the best ever held.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- A conference of the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee will be held to-morrow night, probably at the rooms of Mr. Dingley, the Chairman, to decide what action shall be taken with reference to the preparation of a tariff bill. The consideration of this question also involves the necessity of an extra session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Populist Senator Allen disturbed the serenity of the Senate to-day by his unexpected motion to take up the Dingley bill without having consulted the Populists of the Senate before making his motion.

At a meeting of the Police Commissioners yesterday, Col. Grant called attention to the bad condition of several station houses. He said that the Thirtieth Street Station was too small to accommodate the number of men attached to it. He said the building was overcrowded and in an unhealthy state.
The funeral of Col. John R. Fellows took place at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Intercession, One Hundred and Fifty-eighth Street and Western Boulevard.

It could not have been zeal for the public interests which induced the Board of Aldermen by a vote of 26 to 4 on Tuesday to grant to a newly organized corporation for furnishing fuel gas a franchise to tear up the streets of the city to lay its pipes practically without compensation.

Funeral services were held yesterday morning in old Trinity Church for Gordon Winslow, late Captain in the United States Army, who died in Florence, Italy, on Oct. 22 last. The body arrived on Monday by the steamer California. The Rev. Joseph W. Hill, curate of the church, officiated. The body was taken to Greenwood Cemetery and interred in the Hyer family vault.
The annual meeting of the Women's National Indian Association began yesterday morning in Calvary Baptist Church. About seventy-five delegates were present.

Mr. Moody's audience in Cooper Union yesterday morning was very large. He gave the first of the two sermons which he had announced to preach on "The Ten Commandments,'' and he had something to say about Sunday newspapers.
The women who are in this city, to arouse interest in the Congress of Mothers, to be organized soon, held a reception last night at the Waldorf Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Finance now engaged in an investigation of the bond sales held a brief session to-day, and agreed to maks a partial report to the full committee and ask for instructions.

Market narrow and irregular. Money on call, 1 1/2 to 2 per cent. Little that was now appeared in yesterday's stock market. Quotations were generally almost at a standstill. Three or four stocks only fluctuated as much as a whole point.

The Wednesday matinee at the Metropolitan Opera, House was not attended by so large an audience as the performance deserved. "Tannhauser" was the opera, and, while it was not given with stars in all the parts, it was, nevertheless, presented in a creditable and generally enjoyable manner. There certainly was no reason to believe that the afternoon's entertainment was not as good as people have any right to expect at half prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- In the absence of Vice President Stevenson the Senate was presided over to-day by Mr. Frye, (Rep., Me.,) the President pro tempore. In the Chaplain's opening prayer the late ex-Speaker Crisp was referred to as "a man faithful and loyal in all his relations, an admirable presiding officer, and an earnest and faithful servant of the people."

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 9. -- For several days circulars have been distributed here announcing a forthcoming book, entitled "Crimes and Criminals of Dartmouth Medical College." It is supposed that the author of these circulars is Robert Langdon MacDermott, of New York City. To-night Dr. S.J. Bartlett of the college gave out the following statement:

The fifty-third annual report of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor, just issued, is interesting and instructive, especially to those who contribute to the great charities of New York, and those who are interested in the study of sociological subjects.
Gov. Morton came to this city from Albany yesterday. Before he returns it is expected he will decide whom he will appoint to succeed John R. Fellows as District Attorney.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency at its meeting to-day decided that some steps should be taken by them "to correct the evils in our banking and currency system."

MADRID, Dec. 9. -- The Government has received official confirmation of the deaths of the Cuban insurgent leader Antonio Maceo and young Gomez, son of the rebel leader, Maximo Gomez, the dispatch adding that Gomez committed suicide upon seeing Maceo dead.

Russian Sable heads the list of valuable furs and has been for generations the favored fur of the crowned heads of Europe. C.C. Shayns Co., importers and manufacturers of reliable and elegant furs, West 42d St., near 6th Av., make a specialty of Russian Sables and have an immense stock to select from.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- President Cleveland appears to have been advised correctly when he was told a day or two ago that the determination in the Senate to adopt some expression favorable to active assistance to the Cuban insurrection was almost "irresistible." The inclination to accord belligerency has not been so conspicuous as it was a year ago until to-day, but inquiries made by Senators justified the information carried to the President.

BUFFALO, Dec. 9. -- Senator John Raines, author of the Raines law, arrived here this afternoon. His investigating committee will probably hold its first session to-morrow morning. The other members of the committee arrived to-night.

SING SING, Dec. 9. -- The story published this morning to the effect that the Rev. Dr. T. De Witt Talmago of Washington was about to marry Miss Susie Mangam, the second daughter of Paniel D. Mangam, who lives in this village, was denied to-day.

Without doubt the Tree-Planting Association of New York has undertaken a most beneficent work. So far as it proves to be practicable it will contribute as much as any other scheme that could, be projected for the embellishment of the city. The incorporators are to a considerable extent the same as the incorporators of the Botanic Garden -- men well known for public spirit and intelligence.

There may be a round-up of Raines law hotel keepers next Sunday if it is found that the Building act is being violated. Chief Conlin will issue his instructions during the week and the Police Captains will investigate the hotels in their precincts to make a thorough examination of the premises.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- Ricardo Dias Albertini, Second Secretary of the unrecognized Cuban Legation here, was seen this morning regarding the alleged killing of Gen. Antonio Maceo in battle. He had no official information, but said the story was obviously untrue, and that this was about the twentieth time that Maceo had been Killed, according to Spanish advices.

The report of the Controller of the Currency is so important and valuable that it cannot properly be discussed in any one article. It is, indeed, bound to furnish material of a nearly unique sort for all the careful, varied, and prolonged discussion that must still precede any adequate settlement of the problem of our National currency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9. -- A conference report was submitted by Mr. Poole, (Rep., N.Y.,) recommending that the House agree to the Senate amendment to the bill granting a pension to Mary Gould Carr, widow of Brig. Gen. and Brevet Major Gen. J.B. Carr, formerly Secretary of State of New York, fixing the monthly payment at $75 a month instead of $50, as the House had voted.

The action of the Board of Aldermen Tuesday, in granting a franchise to the Consumers' Gas Fuel, Heat, and Power Company to lay its pipes and mains in the streets of this city, came in for much discussion yesterday. The vote in favor of granting the franchise was 26 for and 4 against, the latter being President Jeroloman and Aldermen Hall, Ware, and Olcott.

The peddler who goes from door to floor selling his goods has a hard time. It is only by an accident that he can get into a private house, and in a public building he is equally debarred. In many of the business buildings there is a sign at the entrance forbidding peddlers the premises. It is an unwritten law in all buildings, and the men know it very well.

The Washington Times is now agitating for the change of the name of the Congressional Library to the National Library. That library is so good, it argues, that it should be nationalized, so that people generally may feel that they have a personal ownership in it and to arouse National pride in its behalf.

WESTERLY, R.I., Dec. 9. -- Mrs. Ellen Foley was burned to death in her home this morning. The house was destroyed, and Mrs. Foley's bones were found in the cellar. Mrs. Foley drew $600 from the bank yesterday, and some persons suspect she was murdered and the house burned to hide the crime.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- C.J. Boatner, (Dem., La.,) elected from the Fifth Louisiana District to fill the vacancy caused by his being unseated at the last session of Congress, appeared at the bar of the House and was sworn in by Speaker Reed.

Mayor Strong refused yesterday to say what action he will take in regard to the franchise granted by the Board of Aldermen to the Consumers' Fuel Gas Company. He intimated, however, that his action will take the form of an emphatic veto. "I will not say anything About it now," he declared, "because I intend to say something publicly in a few days."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Republicans are not sanguine now of their ability to put a tariff bill through the next Senate with strictly Republican votes. If all the places in the Senate are filled there will be ninety members, and to pass a bill forty-six votes will be required. With forty-five and the vote of the Vice President deciding the Republicans could win, but that accident is one not expected to happen often.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 10. -- Eight tramps engaged in a desperate fight on the tracks of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad half a mile south of this city to-night, and one of them is now in Vassar Hospital, with wounds from a bullet which passed through his hand, and spent itself against his breast.

Henry D. McCord, President of the Produce Exchange, and Frank Brainard, Vice President and Chairman of the Committee on Custom House Site, have addressed a letter to Congressman Seth L. Milliken, Chairman of the Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds, strongly opposing a favorable report of the committee to the House on the Quigg bill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- In the Senate to-day, Mr. Cullom of Illinois, speaking in support of a resolution declaring that Spain's rule over Cuba should be brought to an end, said:
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10. -- Ex-Queen Liliuokalani of Hawaii arrived from Honolulu this morning on the Steamer China.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Secretary of War sent to the House to-day reports from the Chief Engineer of the Army as follows:
An electric wire caused a fire in the Mills Building, in Broad Street, last evening at 8:15, when the down-town district was deserted.

The one explanation and excuse given by members of the Board of Aldermen for voting with such impatient haste to grant to the Consumers' Company the franchise for supplying fuel gas in this city is that "the people want cheap gas" or that they obeyed the wishes of their constituents, who, as one of them said, "want cheap fuel gas."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- On motion of Mr. Aldrich, (Rep., R.I.,) it was agreed that when the Senate adjourns to-day, it be until Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10. -- The Executive Committee of the Philadelphia Branch of the National League of Business Men this evening made the following reply to Senator Quay's criticisms of the organization:

James C. Hart, thirty-nine years old, of Trenton, was arrested yesterday on the charge of having appropriated $10,000 worth of diamonds from Mrs. Elizabeth M. Delabarre eighteen months ago. In this case Mrs. Delabarre had an option on the jewels, which were owned by a society woman, and took them to Hart for the purpose of raising money.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 10. -- The Executive Committee of the National Democratic Party held its first meeting since the election this afternoon, and in the evening had Henry Watterson as the guest of honor at a little supper.

That is a startling statement which Superintendent CONSTABLE made to the Mayor on Wednesday, that there were 3,200 unsafe buildings in New York. And yet, when we come to consider how inefficient the administration of the department has been in the past and how inefficient it still is, by the confession, though not at all, we believe, by the fault, of Mr. CONSTABLE, the statement will not seem incredible or even excessive.
PARIS, Dec. 10. -- M. Andre Theurlet, the French litterateur, was to-day elected a member of the French Academy, receiving eighteen votes to four cast for M. Emile Zola.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- Representative Gibson (Rep., Penn.,) introduced a bill today designed to prevent and punish frauds in the election of representatives and dele-gates to Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10. -- The Committee on Ways and Means will go to work at once to prepare a tariff bill.
-- A single order for 1,000,000 pounds of smoking tobacco was a new record in that line of business recently achieved by a Virginia tobacco manufacturing firm.

The third irregular dinner of the Society of Pointed Beards was held last night at the restaurant of Leon Flouret, Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. The society was organized about eighteen months ago and holds dinners at irregular intervals. The object of the society is for the encouragement of the growth and training of pointed beards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Chaplain Colden, in his opening prayer to-day, caused a buzz of excitement by his reference to the bill passed yesterday prohibiting the sale of liquor in the Capitol Building. He said: "Especially do we thank Thee that this House is no longer responsible for the liquor traffic within the walls of this, our Capitol.

BOSTON, Dec. 11. -- J.R. Kendrick, Vice President of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, died this afternoon on the way from the station in this city to his home in Newbury Street. He died in a carriage, of rheumatism of the heart.

It may be that ANTONIO MACEO is dead, hut whether he is or not, the continued and continually revised story of his taking off will remain a monument of the Spanish capacity for adding a new interest to death in the manner of reporting it. They are said to have held the news that the most formidable leader of the insurrection was dead for twentyfour hours in Havana before giving it out.

The plans for the botanical garden in Bronx Park have been presented by the Plans Commission of the garden to the Board of Managers. The present condition of the enterprise warrants the expectation that this noble addition to the treasures of the city will in time become not only a municipal but a National possession, and will be a not unworthy rival to Kew Gardens, or to any other collection of like scope and purport.

BUFFALO, Dec. 11, -- James H. Dormer of the Charity Organization Society, while testifying to-day before the special Senate committee inquiring into the workings of the liquor-tax law. complained that the brewers were chiefly the bondsmen for saloon keepers, and that companies had been formed to deal in such bonds.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 11. -- Foreclosure of the mortgage and sale of the Quincy, Omaha and Kansas City Railroad was ordered by United States Circuit Judge Thayer, in Chambers, this afternoon.

WAREHAM, Mass., Dec. 11. -- Before many years have passed, Cape Cod will be threaded from Provincetown to Wood's Holl by an electric trolley line, starting on its southern shore and connecting the extremity of the cape with Chatham, Harwich, Dennisport, Hyannis, Yarmouth, and Falmouth. Then the contemplated line runs north to Buzzard's Bay, connecting with the trolley road to New Bedford, via Matapoisett and Marion.

The Universalist Woman's Alliance of the metropolitan district held its second monthly meeting in the Church of Our Father, Grand Avenue and Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, at 11 A.M. yesterday. The attendance was large, 250 ladies being present. They were delegates from the eleven Universalist churches in the district.

Balow will be found an index to the advertisements of publishers and booksellers which appear in to-day's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Both in the number of houses represented and in the space filled these advertisements make a much larger showing than has been made in THE TIMES on any other single day since the paper was started, 45 years ago.

Theatrical managers and playwriters in this city said yesterday that they had greater cause for congratulation over the action of Congress on Thursday than over any other single act of that body for years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- "A moderate measure" is the characterization which leading Republicans of the House give to the new tariff bill which it is purposed to frame this Winter in anticipaton of an extra session of Congress.

From The Jewish Chronicle. Compulsory religious education in Prussia has led to a curious result with, regard to the children of non-conformists. According to the socialistic organ, the Vorwarts, some parents have hit upon a rather peculiar expedient to relieve themselves of their difficulty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Issue of to-day there appears an article associating my name with the distribution of some circulars announcing a book entitled "Crimes and Criminals of Dartmouth Medical College." You will oblige me by stating that I have had no connection whatever with the distribution of the circulars referred to, nor the publishing of the book.

MOUNT VERNON, Dec. 11. -- The friends of Miss Naomi Voise, aged eighteen, granddaughter of the late millionaire Alfred Duncomb, were surprised to-day when they learned that she had been secretly married to Charles Hollister, aged nineteen, a young civil engineer of this city.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 11. -- Three million dollars' worth of property is involved in the case of J.S. Dowdell, executor of Mrs. Annie Dowdell, vs. The Elyton Company and others, wherein the complainant filed in the City Court of Birmingham to-day an application for the appointment of a receiver for the defendant company.

The war between the Columbia sophomores and the incoming classes in the college and the School of Applied Science was renewed with vigor yesterday, and resulted in several pitched battles, in which both sides claim a victory.

At the weekly meeting of the Manhattan liberal Club last evening George W. Foote, President of the National Secular Society of Great Britain, spoke on "The Irreligion of Shakespeare." Previous to the lecture Secretary Edward Dobson read a reply to a letter previously published and sent by the club to Dwight L. Moody, challenging the Evangelist to a debate on the merits of Christianity before the club.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Dec. 11. -- By the steamer Pacheco, which arrived from Lower California yesterday, news was received of the murder of Major Tomas Alvarado of the Twelfth Infantry, stationed at Torin. His slayer is Capt. Vicente Cota, a descendant of a famous family in Mexico.

-- The Professor of English at Vanderbilt University, Nashville, Tenn., has issued a grammar based on the very sound principle that from custom there is no appeal, and that in language whatever is, is right. It is apparent, however, that Nashville, Tenn., has customs in the use of words that are all its own, for the professor commends such sentences as "Who did you see?" "It was him," and "These sort of books."

After about a week, of deliberation, the Directors of the Volunteers of America have succeeded in framing a Constitution, which, in their estimation meets the requirements of the new movement started by Ballington Booth about nine months ago.

CHICAiGO, Dec. 11. -- The claim of Mary Dawson McCaffery of Virginia that she is the legal widow of John McCaffery, is now before Judge Dunns on appeal. A jury was secured yesterday and the trial commenced to-day.

Mrs. Caroline, Siefke, the wife of Henry Siefke of 307 West Twenty-sixth Street, has called upon the police of the Sixteenth Precinct to clear up the mystery of an asault and robbery which occurred at the Siefke residence shortly before 7 o'clock Thursday night. The statement made to Police Captain Walsh by Mrs. Siefke is as follows:

To-night will see the end of the biggest six-day contect ever held in Madi on Square Garden, and, barring accidents, "Ted y" Race will carry off the largest bag of gold. When the filth day ended last hight at mid-night he was in better condition physically than any of his rivals.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11. -- Mrs. Sarah B. Cooper and her daughter, Hattie, were found dead in bed at their home this morning, having been asphyxiated.

The sum of $6,300 was realized from the benefit performance tendered to Rose Coghlan at the Broadway Theatre yesterday. Although the benefit was artistically and financially a great success, it was a keen disappointment to all of Miss Coghlan's friends that the programme was too long to permit of the presentation of "Nance Oldlfield," in which she was to have appeared.

From The Christian Advocate. Crime is a word of terrible significance. It has a hard, merciless sound, unlike the monosyllables, sin, and vice, which, though words of similar, import, are softened to the ear by sibilants. Crime-how harsh it sounds, harsher than, death, even. It is fairly driven from the lips with an expulsive force which suggests the moral detestation with which men regard it.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- "The Lord saves -- He has saved me -- of all sinners the lowest."

There was a large gathering of cricketers last night at the Murray Hill Lyceum to witness the presentation of the cricket trophies won this year. The affair was given by the Metropolitan District Cricket League and the New York Cricket Association. During the evening refreshments were served and there was some singing and recitations.

HAVANA, Dec. 11. -- Gen. Weyler arrived here this evening. He rode into the city on horseback, accompanied by two squadrons of cavalry. His coming had been announced to the public, and large crowds gathered to welcome him. He was given a popular ovation from the time he reached the city limits until he arrived at the palace.

The report comes from Washington that the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee, in preparing the tariff bill which their party Slopes to pass at an extra session next Spring, trill retain large parts of the present tariff law because they are "satisfactory" as they stand.

The testimony for the Government, in rebuttal in the suit of The United States vs. The Bell Telephone Company and ALEXANDER GRAHAM BELL, commonly called the "Bell Telephone Case," Is almost concluded. -- [Annual report of the Department of Justice, published Dec. 10.]

The bicycle race which is to be finished to-night at Madison Square Garden is by far the most interesting and by far the most successful test that has been furnished of combined speed and endurance on wheels. Five or six of the men in the present race have beaten all records, while at 1,400 miles the leader in this race was well over a hundred miles in advance of it.

HAVANA, Dec. 11. -- Dr. Maximo Zertucha, formerly the physician of Antonio Maceo, who, after the death of Maceo, surrendered to Gen. Tort, at San Felipe, has been interviewed by a reporter of La Lucha, one of the leading newspaper of this city.

A dinner was given by the Get Together Club at the Cafe Hungaria, on Union Square last night to welcome M. Francois de Carbonnel back from a four months' tour of the United States and to bid him bon voyage on his journey home to France. Covers were served for forty members and guests. Dr. W.H. Tolman of the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor presided.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 11. -- Joseph Huckins, who owns a poultry farm out in Piscataway township, was in this city this morning selling poultry, and told with much gusto a story of how a tramp was routed on his farm yesterday toy turkeys.

A well-dressed young man who was hurrying to the Liberty Street Terry last evening was arrested and taken to the Oak Street Police Station. He carried a satchel, on which was the name of J.W. Johnson, Dunellen, N.J. He affected surprise and indignation at his arrest until confronted at the station house by Louis H. Hobby, Superintendent of the drug firm of Schieffelin Co., of 170 William Street, who charges him with theft.
CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 11. -- A large delegation of friends of James A. Gary of Baltimore came to Canton to-day to ask the President-elect to consider Mr. Gary as a Cabinet possibility.

An exhibition of the bookbinders' art will begin to-day in the art rooms of E.F. Bonaventure, Broadway and Thirty-first Street, and will continue until Dec. 19. Many of the books are interesting, not only for their fine bindings, but because of their own rarity. The bindings are almost all the work of celebrated artists, many af whom are dead.

The dealers in Washington Market and its vicinity have discussed with much earnestness the action of the Board of Trade and Transportation at its Wednesday meeting, when the board unanimously passed a resolution whereby Controller Fitch will be called upon to abate the outside-stand nuisance of Washington Market.

From The Chicago Standard. Patience in well doing arises from a true view of life in its deeper meanings. The man who has never learned to rejoice in the present, to be content with work simply for its own sake, because he is accomplishing what he was created for, can not know tho meaning of patience.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11. -- The big German, club Germania had planned a foxhunt for to-morrow. All the junkers were to mount and chase a real fox. With the Germania were to follow the Chicago, Garfield, Centaur, and Lincoln Park Equestrian Clubs, and the start was to be from Ravenswood, wood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11. -- Mr. Boatner (Dem., La.,) offered in the House to-day a bill increasing to $10,000 per year the salary of the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and to $7,500 per year the salaries of Senators and Representatives, to go into effect March 4, 1897.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 11. -- A desperate battle occurred in the woods at Esopus, ten miles from this city, before daylight this morning, between a posse of officers and four crooks

For a second time a portion of Fifth Avenue has been flooded, and again residents of the block on the west side of the avenue have been aroused at night by water pouring into their cellars and basements.

After a most remarkable exhibition of pluck and endurance, the fifteen riders remaining on the track throughout the great six-day race in Madison Square Garden stopped pedaling at 9:58 o'clock last evening to the presence of one of the largest crowds ever seen in the vast amphitheatre.

The evening classes of Russian immigrants assembled last evening in the Educational Alliance Building, at East Broadway and Jefferson Street, to compete for prizes offered by the Patria Club. The club was represented by the Rev. Dr. Chapin, the Rev. Dr. J.W. Hageman, and Miss Myra B. Martin.

Golfers will be interested in the announcement by W.A.
