MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 30 -- The stockholders of the Mobile and Ohio Railroad met here to-day and authorized the issuance of $4,000,00 bonds for the construction of what is known as the Montgomery extension, from Columbus, Miss., to Montgomery, Ala., via Tuscaloosa.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 30 -- The city's plight, caused by the burning of the dynamo room of the Newark Electric Light, Heat, and Power Company's plant, was somewhat relieved to-night, when, by connecting with small plants in the city and suburbs, some of the principal streets were lighted. No attempt has been made to light the incandescent lamps.
MONTREAL, Dec. 30 -- Archbishop Fabre, the head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Montreal, died to-night of cancer of the liver.
SPRINGFIELD, 111., Dec. 30 -- Miss Cora Edith, English, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Turney English of this city, was married today to John Riley Tanner of Louisville, 111., Governor-elect of Illinois.

A large and interested crowd stood in Sixth Avenue yesterday morning watching a couple of painters cover half the side of a building above the first story with a big advertisement. It looked, when finished, to be white letters painted on a black background. As the work was done it was a black background painted around white letters.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 30 -- Following is a summary of the racing to-day at Ingleside:

William Lichenberg, twenty-two months old, and his brother Jacob were found dead in bed yesterday morning at One Hundred and Fortieth Street and Locust Avenue. Their mother, with whom they were sleepng, was found unconscious, as also the father, John Lichenberg, who was in an adjoining room.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 30 -- About 500 leading Northern and Western manufacturers and railroad officials, including Presidents Cowen of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad and Ingalls of the Chesapeake and Ohio; Vice Presidents Finley of the Southern Railway and St. John of the Seaboard Air Line; President Gates of the Ilinois Steel Company, Abram S. Hewitt, and others contribute to this week's issue of The Manufacturers' Record their views upon the business outlook for 1897.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The recent reports that the Spanish Government was endeavoring to secure the co-operation of the great European powers to prevent, by force if necessary, the intervention of the United States in the Cuban insurrection have no better authority than many other startling rumors that have been industriously circulated during the past few months.

BALTIMORE, Dec., 30 -- Ex-Secretary of the Treasury Charles S. Fairchild opened the morning session of the third day of the annual meeting of the American Economic Association. "What is the Present Direction of Acquisitive Investment? What is the Relation of the Deposits in Savings Banks to the General Business of the Country?" was the subject of his address.
Mr. Joseph E. Heimerdinger, of the Stock Exchange house of H.P. Goldschmidt Co., said yesterday, regarding the market for investment securities:
ALBANY, Dec. 31. -- Adjt. Gen. McAlpin to-day made public his annual report for the past year.

Taken altogether, the year 1896 has been an active one in the money market. The year has shown a good demand for money and good rates. The banks and financial institutions have, I think, all made fair profits. From the first of the year until the election in November there was a gradual tightening in money, and the average rate was a profitable one to lenders.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- Gov. Morton this afternoon took summary action, and removed Frederick C. McLewee, Inspector General on his staff, from office, and at the same time appointed Capt. Hoffman of Elmira in his place. Capt. Hoffman has already been selected to serve as Inspector General on Gov. Black's staff.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 31. -- Brilliant balls at the Laurel-in-the-Pines and the Lakewood Hotel welcomed the New Year at Lakewood. In the crowd of people here for the holidays there are many who are well known in social, financial, and political affairs in near-by cities.

Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, denied a motion made by George Putnam Smith, acting for Mortimer Hendricks, a bondholder, to restrain the Directors of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company from paying out the quarterly dividend of 1 1/2 per cent., due and payable to-morrow.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31. -- The closing session of the ninth annual meeting of the American Economic Association was held to-day in Levering Hall. A paper on "The Day Labor and Contract Systems of Municipal Works," by Prof. J.R. Commons of Syracuse University, brought out general discussion.

The following review is by the Hon. Abraham S. Hewitt, ex-Mayor of New York ex-Representative in Congress, and for many years as a member of the firm of Cooper, Hewitt Co., a large employer of labor in manufacturing industries:

Railway construction in 1896 has disappointed the hopes and expectations that were so general at the year's beginning. When the totals for 1895 were cast up and the miles of new roadway built during the year computed at 1,803, the number appeared ridiculously small and insignificant, but illustrative of the financial and business depression that had been the feature of the year's history.

Gov. MORTON has taken a very emphatic way of showing the resentment of the criticisms of the National Guard conveyed in the report, published yesterday, of the Inspector General He has removed Gen McLEWEE from the inspectorship, which he holds during the Governor's pleasure, some twenty-four hours or less before the Governor's own time expires.

The two important points in the National finances of the past year were the gold reserve and the excess of expenditures. Of these the former was far the more important. The following table (prepared in the office of the Treasurer of the United States) shows the net gold in the Treasury, coin and bullion, for each month in the year. The figures for December are those given out by the Treasury on the 30th:

The city budget as finally adopted by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment aggregates $49,486,297.17, but after the general fund has been deducted the amount to be raised by taxation is $45,686,297.17, or only $1,689,725.86 more than last year. The increase in the amount required for the redemption of bonds and for the expenses of the Police Department much more than accounts for the difference.
The fight in Tammany between John C. Sheehan and County Clerk Henry D. Purroy was marked yesterday by another broadside from Mr. Purroy. When Mr. Sheehan read it in the afternoon newspapers he said:

Obadiah L. Sypher, doing business as Sypher Co., dealer in antique furniture, at 246 Fifth Avenue, corner of Twenty-eighth Street, and at 400 Fifth Avenue, filed a confession of judgment yesterday for $83,404, in favor of Henry Lesinsky, for money which the latter had loaned to him at various times in the last six years. Execution was issued to the Sheriff, and Deputy Mulvaney took charge of both stores.

The investigations of the Grand Jury into the methods of certain lawyers of the Court of General Sessions did not result in indictments, as was expected. The Grand Jury, in its presentment to Recorder Golf yesterday, contented itself with recommendations for certain reforms both in the court and in the relations of counsel and prisoners.
What were the pre-eminently memorable deeds and events of the year 1896? We should make up the list in this way:

The following review is by the Hon. J. Edward Simmons, President of the New York Clearing House Association:

The financial budget for 1897 was adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment, and afterward Mayor Strong issued a statement in the nature of a criticism of Controller Fitch, and said it was unfortunate that the Controller "should have been so careless and inexact in his preliminary estimates."
The following review is by the Hon. Charles Stewart Smith, ex-President of the Chamber of Commerce:

The State Board of Arbitration and Mediation, at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday, made an investigation into the causes of the strike of the drivers of the New York Cab Company. Delegate Mahr of the Liberty Dawn Association of Coachmen and Drivers, and about fifteen strikers and other Knights of Labor appeared, and the cab company was represented by Col. William Jay, the President, Allen Lexow, the Treasurer, and James Heffernan, the General Manager.

The new year was ushered in at midnight last night by the bells of old Trinity in the presence, or within the hearing, of one of the greatest throngs of men, women, and children that have ever gathered bout the old church on a like occasion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The President to-day issued a proclamation promulgating the action of Congress providing regulations for preventing collisions at sea and setting July 1, 1897, as the day upon which they shall take effect.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday provisionally agreed on a route and plan for an underground system, running from the Battery to King's Bridge, on the west side, while the eastern route will go as far as Bronx Park. The estimated cost is $35,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- The two industries, woods and manufactures of wood and pulp, papers, and books, were the subjects of the hearing to-day by the Committee on Ways and Means. The hearing was opened on behalf of the lumber interests by Mr. C. D. Goodyear of Buffalo, who had been designated for the purpose by the Cincinnati Lumber Convention, and who was accompanied by twenty-four other representatives of that industry.

For the second annual Hungarian peasant ball, the Grand Central Palace last night was transformed into a Hungarian village. There haughty Magyars in all the wealth of furs and lace promenaded the decorated hall or danced the Csardas at breakneck speed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Embarrassing complications are anticipated if the steamer Dauntless sails for Cuban ports carrying a cargo of firearms unless special permission is given her to do so by the Spanish Consul at the port of clearance. Several of the great European powers have stringent laws on this subject, and the importation of arms is strictly prohibited, except where special permission has previously been received.
The final sessions of the American Historical Association were held yesterday, and the meeting adjourned, after deciding to meet the same date a year hence in Cleveland, Ohio.

MADRID, Dec. 31. -- The Imparcial and The Heraldo to-day published articles condemning the military administration in Cuba and pointing out that despite his oft-repeated promises Capt. Gen. Weyler has practically accomplished very little in the direction of suppressing the rebellion. Both papers demanded that Gen. Weyler be recalled and that Gen. Azcarraga, Minister of War, be appointed in his place.

Business failures for 1896 in the United States, according to Bradstreet, number 15,112, with total liabilities of $247,000,000 and actual assets of $148,200,000. These figures refer only to business embarrassments in which total liabilities are in excess of actual assets, except in the cases of banks, when the suspension of payment during business hours, no matter for how short a time, is accounted a failure.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Dec. 31. -- E. A. Van Valkenburg, who was arrested at Harrisburg last evening on a charge of attempting to bribe Representative Weiss of Northampton County to vote for Wanamaker for United States Senator, had a hearing before Squire Kuebler to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 31. -- Joseph B. McCullagh, editor of The Globe-Democrat, was found dead on the pavement in the rear of his residence, 3,837 West Pine Boulevard, at 6:30 o'clock this morning. He had evidently jumped from the window of his bedroom, on the third floor of the house, sometime between midnight and daybreak, and dashed his brains out on the stone flagging of the yard.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Dec. 31, -- Henry L. Dawes has just returned to his home in this city after an extended visit to Indian Territory with the Indian Commission, of which he is the Chairman. He was accompanied by his daughter, Miss Anna Laurens Dawes, who is greatly interested in the work among the Indians.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Dec. 31. -- Rain and mud marked the last day of the year here and only mudlarks prevailed at the race course, but as the large crowd present named four favorites, the public made money on the day.
Charles Buermann Co. have sold, for Charles Bardes, to William Koster, Jr., at $23,000, the five-story front and four-story rear double tenement, 101 Avenue D, 24.4 by 115.

Readers of THE TIMES will receive with this morning's issue a Financial Supplement. We consider it a very useful publication and intend to make it an annual feature of the New Year's issue of THE TIMES.

ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 31. -- The inauguration of Governor-elect Black to-morrow has brought a large number of Republicans, prominent and otherwise, to Albany. The hotels are crowded to-night. Many members of the Legislature are here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31. -- Twenty-four months from this date the rapidly growing Japanese Navy will be increased by the addition of two swift cruisers of American build. The contracts were signed to-day at the Japanese Legation by Minister Hoshi, representing the Japanese Government, and by Messrs. Henry Scott of San Francisco and Charles H. Cramp of Philadelphia representing the Union Iron Works and the Cramps ship yard, respectively.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31. -- Little was expected in the way of action in wheat for the closing day of the year. The action of the officials in voting to close the session at 12 o'clock had a tendency to restrict operations.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 31. -- In the Superior Court to-day Judge Frederick B. Hall issued a writ of habeas corpus to Otto Kelsey of Genesee, N.Y., the New York guardian of Clarence Ward, the thirteen-year-old son of Ferninand Ward of Grant Ward fame, calling upon Frederick D. Green of Thompson to produce the body of young Ward before the court Jan. 12, and show cause why he should not be surrendered from his custody.

The attack made by Edward M. Shepard on Controller Palmer of Brooklyn, in a public statement Thursday, has borne fruit, Mr. Shepard, in speaking of the civil service law, in connection with Justice Keogh's recent decision, said the Controller is "a chief offender against the law," and "the [Controller's] office has been subjected to as extraordinary a piece of political looting as has been known for many years."
The following review is by Mr. M.L. Muhleman, Deputy Assistant Treasurer of the United States at the Sub-Treasury in New York:

Judged superficially, 1896 has been a year of discouragement. It is easier to remember the embarrassments, the distresses, and the disasters than it is to keep in view the year's inspiriting accomplishments.
The Committee on Draft of the Greater New York Commission gave out yesterday five additional chapters of the Greater New York charter.

Herbert Beerbohm 'Tree acted Hamlet at the Knickerbocker Theatre last night, and his portrayal of tha[ fascinating rDle, first made known here in February, 1S95, was seen again with pleasure by many habitual tneatre-goers. {r. Tree's Prince of Denmark is blonde, handsome, and unmistakably Scandinavian.
The following review is from the Hon. Aldace F. Walker, recognized as an authority in every department of railway business:

Brooklyn's bicycle riders comprising the Cycle Club will celebrate the opening of their indoor riding season in the Armory Building, Flatbush Avenue and Hanson Place, to-morrow evening. A programme not unlike those arranged last season will be offered. A number of novelties have been planned for the coming meetings. There will be music at each session.

Commissioner Waring has made a statement regarding the removal of snow from the streets, as an explanation to such persons as are now wondering why a large part of the city is in what he calls "its present horrible condition."

Recent misstatements concerning Yale's attitude in the matter of the proposed aquatic meeting with Harvard next season have caused every friend of the New Haven college to indignantly deny them without seeking to ascertain their origin.

-- So many tollgates have been destroyed in Kentucky since the present campaign against those often picturesque but always absurd structures began, that if any are still left, the original number must have been great indeed. Of course the very existence of a tollgate is clear proof either of stupidity on the part of the people living along the highway it commands, or of malfeasance on the part of their official representatives.

RALEIGH, N.C., Dec. 31. -- News reached here to-day of a lynching a mile from Gibson's Station, Richmond County. The man lynched was Jim Green, (colored,) who was employed in a cottonseed oil mill. Nothing was known of him except that he was of bad reputation and had served time in the penitentiary.

The members of the Ancient and Honor able Artillery Company of Boston promise that if Faneuil Hall is made fire-proof they will add their own valued souvenirs to the city's collection of "relies of four wars," and make it the most interesting in the country.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 1. -- New Year's Day at this resort was marked by two notable social affairs at the Country Club. Mrs. George J. Gould this afternoon gave a reception from 4 until 7 o'clock, and tonight Mr. and Mrs. James Converse and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bage Kerr gave a dance.

The Poultry Show proved such an attracion ysterday that all the expenses entailed in running the exhibition are now paid, and the receipts to-day will all go into the treasury of the Poultry and Pigeon Association.

It was a notable contribution to the public opinion of the business world that was made by the various gentlemen of "light and leading" in our Financial Supplement yesterday. J. EDWARD SIMMONS, CHARLES STEWART SMITH, ABRAM S. HEWITT, Controller of the Currency ECKELS, and Messrs. FROTHINGHAM and WALKER, with Mr. MUHLEMAN, (whose article appeared on the main sheet,) are men whose experience, ability, and training give authority to their views.

When years bring to a man what to many they deny -- the ability to question as well as to assert, the recognition of many points of view, the wide and humane vision that can see the single end to many roads -- and when to this catholicity is joined the love of honesty and purity, the result is a noble foundation upon which to build literary monuments.

Miss Harriet Monroe's "Life of John Wellborn Root," just published by Messrs. Houghton, Mifflin Co., is a very interesting record of a man whose importance is generally recognized in his own profession of architecture, and in his own city of Chicago. To those who knew him his personal charm was more noteworthy even than his public achievements.

A meeting was held in the Music Hall, Edinburgh, about two weeks ago in behalf of the proposed memorial to the late Robert Louis Stevenson. Lord Rosebery presided. Mr. A.J. Balfour, in a letter of regret, spoke of Stevenson as the most distinguished man of letters Edinburgh had produced since Scott. Sir Henry Irving wrote that all who loved good and noble work would feel honored in being able to aid in such an object.

A collection of quaint interest to art has just been received by the British Museum from excavations made at Ekomi, near Salamis, in the Island of Cyprus, where work has been carried out under the supervision of the museum. The collection is composed of 464 objects, of which 155 are diadems and mouth plates of pure gold, some plain, others beautifully ornamented.

Our books of to-day, those which we love to look at, which we caress, which we dress in morocco, relieved with mosaics, which we enrich with autographs, with original drawings, with charming water colors, and margins, and to which these marks of intimate ownership serve as their proudest ex libris -- our well-beloved books of this latter end of the nineteenth century, what is to become of these?

Paul D. Cravath, who has been one of the pronounced advocates of the candidacy of Joseph H. Choate for the Senatorship, has written a letter to the Republican Club in reference to the club's action Monday night. He says:

PARIS, Jan. 1. -- Mr. Eustis, the American Ambassador, held a New Year reception to-day, which was very largely attended by the members of the American colony. Miss Eustis, daughter of the Ambassador, acted as Hostess. She was assisted by Mrs. George Eustis, Mrs. Alan Eustis, and Mrs. Vignaud, wife of the Secretary of the Embassy.

ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- Frank S. Black to-day was inaugurated Governor of New York, and Gov. Levi P. Morton became again a private citizen. The transfer of the authority of the Chief Executive of the State was simplicity itself -- dignified, to fit the importance of the office, but unostentatious, to meet the wishes of the new Governor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- The annual New Year's observance at the White House took place to-day according to custom. It constitutes an ordeal for the President and the mistress of the White House, for they must shake hands with thousands of their fellow-citizens and a large number of distinguished foreigners.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1. -- W.A. Bisbee, owner of the Dauntless, received a telegram to-day from Miami saying that the men from the Three Friends expedition are no No Name Key, and that two are dead from exposure. The Dauntless will bring them to this port, and then clear with an expedition for Cuba.

The trend of thought to-day among our Christian brethren of any culture and enlightenment is against bigotry and hatred for the greater glory of God. They are realizing that humanity is larger than any special creed, and they hail the growth of justice, not toleration, the spread of peace and kindly co-operation for the welfare of mankind.

When the Recorder charged the Grand Jury to investigate the practices of the "shysters," THE TIMES suggested that in many cases it would probably be safer to proceed by disbarment than by indictment. A lawyer may be guilty of unprofessional and disgraceful conduct and yet keep himself clear of the Penal Code.

The change which has come over our old friend (or enemy) The London Saturday Review in recent years has been remarked by all its readers. It is no longer the puissant journal it was in the days when Freeman belabored Froude, and many others were belabored in its whacking columns. That old Roman profile and that sternness of feature have indeed been lost.

It is pleasant to learn that the memory of Charles Keene, who was one of the leading Punch artists, is to be preserved. A medallion portrait has been placed in the Public Library, in Uxbridge Road, Shepherd's Bush, London. Leigh Hunt lived near Shepherd's Bush.

BOSTON, Jan. 1. -- The Boston Commercial Bulletin, whose figures are accepted as the standard by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers and by the United States Government, will say tomorrow in its review of the year:
The Rev. Dr. Maurice H. Harris of the Temple Israel, at Fifth Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, delivered a lecture last evening on "Providence."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Rear Admiral Joseph S. Skerrett, United States Navy, retired, died at his residence, in this city, at midnight last night, aged 63 years.

Fright and loss of presence of mind by several persons last evening probably allowed a woman to be fatally burned. Mrs. Ellen J. Rawlings, who keeps two connecting boarding houses at 61 and 63 West Twelfth Street, while striking a match to light a lamp in a room at No. 63, accidentally set fire to the table covering, which was of inflammable stuff, and her dress also caught fire.

ALBANY, Jan. 1. -- Many Republican members of the Legislature have been here to-day to witness the inauguration of Gov. Black. They have the programme for the organization of the Legislature next week fully out lined. Assemblyman James M.E. O'Grady of Rochester, who is to be the Speaker, and Assemblyman Fred E. Nixon of Chautauqua, who is to be the Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, have attended to these details.
HAVANA, Jan. 1. -- A reporter of The Diario de la Marina has had an interview with Capt. Gen. Weyler in the Mata Toro camp.

The annual midnight race of bicycle riders from this city to Yonkers and Tarrytown, beginning when the old year was on its last legs, was an exciting adventure. Twenty nervy racing men undertook to win the first contest of the new year, but snow and ice made the roads anything but desirable for bicycle riding, and more than half of the competitors were forced to retire along the route with punctured tires or damaged wheels.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- After twenty-one years' honorable service on the bench as a Supreme Court Justice Jackson O. Dykman to-day retired, having reached the age limit of seventy years. Justice Dykman has won the respect and esteem of the bar of the State.

The Week of Prayer which is observed by most of the Protestant churches in the country will begin to-morrow. The subjects for each service are arranged by the Evangelical Alliance for the United States.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- Gypsy, the bad man-killing elephant, is not to be killed by electricity. She has been reprieved and may be sent to Cuba to trample down the ranks of the Spaniards.

The preacher was making clear the thought that wherever a man's home might be, his spiritual birthplace was in Zion. Said he:

Whatever may be the justice or injustice of the rebuke for too free expression of opinion administered by Gov. Moirton to Inspector General McLewee, it has had the effect, for the time being at least, of silencing criticism from National Guard sources. A reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday visited five National Guard officers of commanding rank, but none of them would discuss the matter.

Gov. MORTON'S dismissal of his Inspector General a few hours before the terms of both expired was perhaps a natural mode of showing resentment for the indiscreet and irregular conduct of that official. But obviously it was not responsive to the criticisms contained in Gen. McLEWEE'S report.

MADRID, Jan. 1. -- The semi-official newspapers defend the action of the Government in seizing the issues of the Heraldo and Impartial upon the ground that the articles published by those papers denouncing the policy of Capt. Gen. Weyler in Cuba had a tendency to create discontent among the troops in Cuba, and to encourage American filibusters.

Of course, the offer by Spain of a measure of autonomy to Puerto Rico is intended to point a moral at the expense of the Cuban insurgents. By making the offer the Spanish Government in effect declares to Europe and America that this is the handsome manner in which it would have treated Cuba if Cuba had behaved herself.

The London Times announces among the most recent acquisitions of the National Gallery what it calls "a portrait of Gilbert Stewart, the American painter, by himself." Gilbert Charles Stuart (not Stewart) was the painter's name. Somehow English writers on art sometimes will have it that Stuart was an Englishman, whereas Narragansett, R.I., was the place of his nativity.

From old and new readers have lately come many letters laden with praise of THE TIMES. They bear gratifying testimony of the appreciation with which the efforts of its conductors to produce a newspaper acceptable to intelligent men and women have been rewarded.

Maurice Jokai's "The Green Room," has been translated and will be published shortly. The book is a historical romance, with a picture of Russia in the first quarter of the present century. Pushkin is the hero.

Mr. Barrie's tender and beautiful tribute to his mother, the Margaret Ogilvy of his recent volume, has been widely read and generally admired; but there has sprung up in private circles (and the sentiment is creeping into the newspapers of England and America) the criticism that the publication suffers from indelicacy.

The chapter of the Greater New York charter relating to the Department of Education, as it comes from the Committee on Draft, appears to be a compromise with the demands of the Brooklyn Board of Education, and yet it does not satisfy the Brooklyn members of the commission, who seem to be possessed with the idea that there is something superior in the present Brooklyn system which that borough should be allowed to retain.

Geologists are anxious to have borings made with the diamond drill, which will show the actual conditions of the rocks at the utmost depth which can be attained. Such an exploration, carried on with the modern skill in labor of this kind, would probably give us test-tubes having a depth of 100,000 feet or say thrice the depth of the deepest of our mines.

Under the title, "The Yoke of Empire; Sketches of the Queen's Prime Minister," Reginald B. Brett has just published in London (Macmillan) an interesting volume. Some of the sketches will be found below:

Walter Savage Landor's rupture with his wife, in 1835, took place in consequence of words spoken by her in the presence of his children. He left Florence, never, he thought, to return. He wrote as though the only creature he loved on earth had been rent from him. Yet this extraordinary man was not in the least inconsolable. His friends did their best to get at least the two elder children intrusted to his care.

Senator Edward O. Wolcott of Colorado arrived in New York from Washington yesterday, and will sail for Europe to-day. He is the envoy of the Republican Senatorial Caucus Committee to the bimetallists of Europe. He called on President-elect McKinley at Canton last week, and talked with him on the financial policy of the incoming Administration.

It would appear that there would be no great reason for surprise if we should read any morning in the newspapers that a silent and determined crowd of spectral figures disguised as Indians had broken overnight into the Boston Public Library under cover of electric light, dragged the Macmonies "Bacchante" from its refuge, carried it in procession to the end of India Wharf, and intrusted it to the seclusion of the harbor.

The shores of the river are admirably adapted for wharves, and, did the Government but allow it, arriving ships might unload their cargoes directly into railway trucks on shore.

" Count Bismarck's study, as he called it in English, was a room of no great size nor furnished with any splendor. It was comfortable, nothing more. There was a rug on the varnished floor of the usual hard wood. A large writing desk, littered with papers, stood in the right hand corner on the further side. There were few books. A print or two hung on the walls.

The quietness of the main thoroughfares of this city yesterday was suggestive of exhaustion caused by the turbulent outburst of New Year enthusiasm which made the preceding midnight a wakeful period. To "the stranger within our gates" there was comparatively little in yesterday's doings to awaken an interest in the holiday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1. -- Cloudy, warm weather and a track deep in mud marked New Year's Day at the race course. A big crowd of 6,000 people was present. Scribe won the one-thousand-dollar New Year's handicap.

Every month sees more Japanese arrive and a larger percentage of them are common laborers who enter the hop-yards, orchards, and sugar-beet fields of California. In fruit packing they have crowded out white men and women.
KEY WEST, Jan. 1. -- The rumor of the death of Gen. Rius Rivera cannot be verified in any way, and it is believed to be a Spanish canard.

The year just closed has furnished an alarming array of prominent men who have died of Bright's disease of the kidneys. The number includes Prof. Austin Abbott, the great jurist and author of law books; M.B. Brady, the famous photographer; Col. Thomas W. Knox, the author of the "Boy Travelers"; Mark M. Pomeroy, the well-known editor; Mr. Edwin Pardridge, the prominent Chicago merchant, and ex-Gov. Greenhalge of Massachusetts.

Each baby is fed every two hours, and the number of squeals which I heard during the half-day that I spent with Dr. Lion and his rosy children showed me that babies, like bigger mortals, have an unerring idea of dinner hours. The clever nurses had evidently hit upon the excellent plan of feeding the children at different times, in order that they might wake up in rotation.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 2. -- Judge W. K. Townsend, in the United States Circuit Court, has appointed William F. Fuller of this city receiver of the Iowa Mortgage Company, in which Mr. Fuller is a Director. This action was taken on petition of Harry C. Ryan and Julius Lischer of Davenport, Iowa, creditors of the company.
The chapter on education of the Greater New York charter, which was given out Thursday, will undoubtedly be the subject of much discussion during the public hearings on the character.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Secretary Morton has made a reply to Samuel W. Allerton's criticism of the Agricultural Department which is pronounced masterly by prominent persons here. Mr. Allerton alleged in letters to the Secretary and in newspaper articles that the exportation of cattle from the port of Boston was operating injuriously to stock raisers in the United States.

The report that Dr. Antonin Dvorak will shortly return to America and resume his position as Director of the National Conservatory of Music in this city was verified by Mrs. Jeanette M. Thurber, President and founder of the Conservatory, last evening. To a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES Mrs. Thurber said:

-- The Syracuse Post has given to each of the fifty-two carrier boys in its employ a curious Christmas gift -- a full, paid-up membership in the Syracuse Young Men's Christian Association. The membership admits them to every department of the association, including its gymnasium privileges and educational classes.

TRENTON, Jan. 2. -- The politicians in New Jersey understand that United States Senator Sewell will have a good deal to say about the distribution of Federal patronage in New Jersey the next four years. He already has heard from a number of men who are desirous of securing places of honor and emolument.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The comparative statement of the receipts and expenditures of the United States for the month of December, 1896, and for the first six months of the fiscal year ending June 30, 1897, shows that retrenchment has been practiced all along the line.

The attorneys of the American Female Guardian Society and the Prison Association are endeavoring to solve the mystery of the disappearance of $15,000 or $20,000, which should have been paid jointly to them, by the city under the operation of an old law. The whereabouts of the money is now unknown, although it is believed to have been turned into some city fund in small amounts, during the period from 1873 to 1882.
There were two important matches shot by the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club last night at the armory. They were the Covell Trophy competition and the team of five match.

The closing week of the old year, with its limit of four business days, was productive of little in the real estate line that might distinguish it from the dullest of its predecessors during the twelve months of 1896.

THE oft-repeated assertion that "there is nothing half so sweet in life as love's young dream" must give way now to a material alteration. The truth is that there is nothing half so sweet in life as a press agent's young dream.

President Cleveland, having signed the bill appropriating $130,000 for the erection of a suitable building for the display of the United States Government at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition, all arrangements for the carrying out of the plans of the committee are now perfected, and there is joy throughout Tennessee.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Jan. 2. -- A very pretty romance developed here recently, the characters in which are a battle-scarred veteran of the Soldiers' Home in this city, his sister, and his sweetheart, neither of whom he had seen for a quarter of a century until to-day.

"Tin pounds of lamb chops! Fer the three of yez! Ye'd never ate them, mum!" Those exaggerated speaking tubes, the baseme/lt st.qJrs, become terribly effectlTe vhen one is such a favored visitor as to be taken into the lounging room at the back Instead of into the stiff and stately parlor.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- By contrast with the boiling excitement of last New Year's, due to the Jameson raid, the Venezuela scare, the German imbroglio, and the menacing Levantine situation, 1897 opens in almost lamblike fashion. It is true that pending the increases in the Old World's armaments the fighting forces are of a magnitude never before dreamed of.
In the closing address on civil service reform before the Women's Auxiliary Association and the League for Political Education last Wednesday Mrs. CHARLES R. LOWELL made this sweeping statement:

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2. -- Capt. Slocum, the American skipper who is voyaging around the world alone in a small yawl, tells of his visit to Robinson Crusoe Island, Juan Fernandez, off the coast of Chile, on his way across the Pacific. At Valparaiso he had heard the reports that the island had disappeared, but he found it all right.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 2. -- There are two companies organizing to compete for the control of the Richmond Gas Works. The capitalists behind this movement include some prominent New York, Richmond, and Boston men. The gas plants are owned and operated by the City of Richmond, but complaint is now made that the municipal government is not being economically administered.

One might infer from the number of lynchings in the South reported during the month of December that the tendency to substitute mob violence for the orderly execution of legal sentences is growing in this country. Fortunately, such an inference would not be warranted by the facts.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 2. -- About 500 men attended the mass meeting in Music Hall to-night in the interest of Joseph H. Choate for United States Senator. The meeting was called to order by Charles Daniels, and Judge Frank Brundage presided. The speakers were Judge Brundage, W.D. Guthrie of New York, Sherman S. Rogers, Arthur W. Hickman, and E. Charles Rohlfs.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 2. -- The Omaha Savings Bank failed to open for business this morning. Ex-Senator Manderson is President of the bank and J.E. Wilbur is cashier. The bank was established in 1882. Six months ago its deposits were about a million and a half dollars, but withdrawals have reduced them to less than $800,000.

The complaints of the people in the valley of the Illinois River about Chicago's sewage canal, are of more than local interest, because they will stimulate exertion in support of the project for a ship canal from Chicago to the Mississippi. The construction of this canal would involve a perceptible lowering of the surface level of the great lakes and a readjustment of transportation routes to the seaboard.

The year begins with much less business disturbance than the average forecaster predicted. So far as New York as a financial centre is involved, the record is distinctly favorable. And even elsewhere, where there have been bank collapses, with consequent commercial troubles, it now seems as if it would be but a brief time before normal steadiness and strength are re-established.

FTER the United States Government had determined to name one of its new cruisers Brooklyn, many of the prominent men of the City of Brooklyn, following the eXample of men of other cities after which war vessels had been named, determined to present the vessel with a silver service.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The outlook for farmers in this country is decidedly favorable, Secretary Morton thinks. The Secretary, in a bulletin over his signature, issued to-day, said:

DENVER, Col., Jan. 2. -- On Jan. 11 the Democratic Party will have assumed control of the executive and legislative departments of the State of Colorado for the first time in its history. The transfer of the latter department will take place on that day at noon, when the Eleventh General Assembly will be called to order.

BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 2. -- Members of the Idaho Legislature are now nearly all assembled, and the preliminary moves are in progress looking to the election of a United States Senator. Fred T. Dubois, silver Republican, the retiring Senator, is leaving no stone unturned to secure his re-election, but he has a strong Democratic-Populist combination against him.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- Trading for 1897 began with considerable force. Every market on 'Change showed higher prices at the opening, following the holiday. Wheat showed the greatest activity with 3/4c gain the first hour. Coarse grains were up from 1/4c to 1/2c. Even provisions, which were stagnant all through December, made a fair start for better prices.
CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- W.A. Hammond, Second Vice President of the National Bank of Illinois, which failed recently, drowned himself some time last night in Lake Michigan. His body was recovered at noon.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 2. -- Many members of the Legislature arrived to-day and the political atmosphere is clearing somewhat. Those who have been regarded as doubtful are now announcing their preference on the Senatorship, and the lines are more distinctly drawn. At the Penrose headquarters the claim is made that the Wanamaker people will have less than 65 votes, but the managers of the ex-Postmaster General's campaign declare such a statement to be absurd.

ADA REHAN'S impersonation of Shakespeare's Beatrice may lack something of the radiant beauty and charm of a few of her earlier impersonations in the poetic and classical drama -- it is a far cry, for instance, from her well-remembered and deliciously irresponsible Peggy Thrift to this work, while her Katharine and her rather hoydenish but always delightful Rosalind were simpler, more buoyant, and more easily appreciated performances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- To-day was the fifth day of the tariff hearings before the House Committee on Ways and Means, the subject under discussion being flax, hemp, and their manufactures. There was a large attendance of persons interested in these industries.

It is reported that Dr. GACCARELLI of Rome has discovered the characteristic germ of yellow fever and that he hopes to utilize his discovery for the prevention or amelioration of the disease. We understand that this physician recovered not long ago from an attack of yellow fever while residing temporarily in one of the South American countries.
had spent some years in the colonies, doctoring diggers and the like rough and ready folks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The special board appointed by Secretary Herbert to examine a number of defective structural steel plates delivered by the Carnegie Steel Company at Newport News for the battleships Kentucky and Kearsarge has submitted its report to the Navy Department. The board made extensive tests of material at the ship yards and arrived at the following conclusions:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 2. -- The statement of operations of the West Jersey and Seashore Railroad Company for November, 1596, shows gross earnings of $145,902, a decrease of $9,303, compared with November', 189~; operating expenses, $132~618, a decrease of $9,948; net earnings, $7,2S4, a decrease of $645.

Mr. HENRY OLIVER, Jr., the Pittsburg manufacturer, who was a member of the Tariff Commission in 1882, and who is associated with the Carnegie interests in the steel industry, advises that the tariff should be revised by "making a horizontal reduction of from 25 to 33 per cent. on the McKinley rates."

The part that may have been taken by the incoming Administration in Senator Wolcott's bimetallic enterprise in Europe was the subject of general speculation yesterday after the publication of the Senator's interview in THE NEW YORK TIMES. The opinions of business men vary widely as to the scope of Major McKinley's intentions, as expressed by Senator Wolcott, when he said that the President-elect fully approved his project to promote international bimetallism.

A score of young men in sleeveless woolen shirts, knee breeches, long black stockings, and slippers stood in orderly lines before an instructor in the big gymnasium of the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association. Each hand grasped a two-pound dumbbell, and each eye was fixed on the erect, muscular form of the instructor.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 2. -- Cubans here now feel that it never rains but it pours. This afternoon word was received from New Smyrna, 100 miles south of here, that the tug Commodore, that went out of here Thursday night with a cargo for Cuba, sunk at sea twenty miles off shore.

"How you women hate each other!" said a man to the woman who was objecting to having the feminine half of the world put off always in a corner and marked, "This corner of the world reserved for women."
"I know exactly the kind of a man I shall marry, mamma," said Felicia.
The Democratic League of Brooklyn will take a hand in the fight for cheaper gas in Greater New York, if the plans of its leaders do not miscarry.

For the third time in the history of cricket, the invasion of Great Britain by a representative American team has been decided upon. All the preliminary arrangements have been made, and on May 26, fourteen of the foremost exponents of the game in this country will set sail to do or die on British soil.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 2. -- Attorney General Hancock has not yet announced his opinion regarding the inquiry of District Attorney Olcott of New York City as to whether the subordinate positions in the District Attorney's office should only be made from the competitive civil service list.
LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 2. -- The holiday season just past will make a brilliant chapter in the history of this resort.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- It is regarded as certain by many State officers that Capitol Commissioner Isaac G. Perry will soon be succeeded by a new man. His position is worth $7,500 a year, and the incumbent holds office during the term of the Governor who appoints him.

There were three interesting musical entertainments in this town yesterday. Two of them took place at the Metropolitan Opera House, one in the afternoon and the other in the evening, and those may be dismissed without very extended comment. In the afternoon the second performance of "Siegfried" was given before a numerous and highly demonstrative audience.

GLASGOW, Dec. 19. -- Ogden Goelet's twenty-rater Samphire is to go to the Mediterranean regattas once more. Being a fin and bulb cutter, these can be removed and the cutter's hull shipped aboard a steamer. Mr. Paget, Mr. Goelet's partner in the cutter, is named as the responsible owner in the Riviera trip, but it must occasion surprise that any owner would take the trouble of getting the Samphire under a racing flag again.
Mr. F.K. Sturgis, ex-President of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES in discussing the outlook for the stock market of 1897:

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- The case of alleged taking of a deposit of $154 from Frank Kennedy, a saloon keeper, by the banking firm of E.S. Dreyer Co., when the owners of the bank knew they were insolvent, was called by Justice of the Peace Hall this afternoon. Robert Berger, one of the defendants, was in court, with Charles H. Wacker, the bondsman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- President and Mrs. Cleveland held the last New Year's reception for the present Administration on Friday, and only the expert observers could have told in what respect it differed from the three New Year's receptions under this Administration. The weather favored it in that there was no rain, but a southeast wind blew a damp and penetrating suggestion of storm up from the Potomac River.

The pigeons and poultry closed their annual reception at the Madison Square Garden last night. During the day the show was well patronized, and the association, after paying all expenses, has been enabled to add a small sum to its treasury. Charles M. Griffing. Treasurer, had a busy day. He paid all the prize winners the money due them.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2. -- Rosenthal, the pianist, is again suffering a replapse. The facts of the case have been withheld from the public, for the alleged reason that facts published are telegraphed abroad and cause alarm to Rosenthal's relatives, who have been all along depressed by premonitions.

Attorney General Hancock yesterday dismissed the application of Mortimer Hendricks, asking him to bring an action in the name of the State against the Manhattan Railway Directors, to prohibit the latter from declaring the next dividend, and compelling them to refund certain moneys heretofore paid as dividends.

BERLIN, Jan. 2. -- The New Year's reception given by the Emperor to the diplomatic body yesterday was a brilliant event. The reception was held in the Marble Hall of the Schloss, and was very largely attended, nearly all of the Ambassadors and Ministers accredited to the German Court being present.

The first business day of the new year brought with it a decidedly strong tone to the speculative market. The day's transactions were small in number, but the advances were general and, in many cases, significant. A special feature of the market was the small supply of stocks. Offerings were few -- more so than for some time.
AIKEN, S.C., Jan. 2. -- John D. Crimmins and Richard Croker, with a party, arrived here Wednesday.

Although the thoroughbred racing season is nearly four months away, a vast amount of preliminary work necessary to it has been done during the past six weeks. The outlook for the year is promising, unless there shall be some unwise attempts made at Albany to tinker with the existing racing law.

THE explorers of our time are not alone the men who penetrate to lands whereon the feet of civilized races have never trodden before. Not alone does Stanley traverse the Great Forest of Africa and navigate the headwaters of the Nile and the Congo.

Almost every reader of New York or Brooklyn newspapers is familiar with the complaints of foul water, scarcity of water, or failing pressure of water that have emanated from Brooklyn consumers well-nigh constantly during the last three years, and more particularly during the Summers and Autumns of 1894 and 1896.

M. Leon Herrmann, nephew of Alexander Herrmann, the famous magician, who recently died, arrived in New York yesterday, on the American Line steamer St. Louis. Leon is destined to succeed his uncle, and will make his first appearance here next Sunday night, probably, at Hoyt's Theatre, when he will give a performance for the press and invited guests.

Some, if not adequate, relief for elevated railroad passengers, whose home stations are between West One Hundred and Sixteenth and West Sixty-sixth Streets, is promised. It may come by the middle of this month. Fault has been found with the existing condition of affairs since the road started.

THAT Frank S. Black was to be the successor of Levi P. Morton as Governor of New York was settled a few minutes before 11 o'clock on Thursday, Aug. 26. Two hours before that time he was simply the "favorite son" of his Congressional district, which had in the State Convention a total of 23 votes.

THE handsome clubhouse of the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club of Lakewood has become a wonderfully popular rendezvous for both permanent and temporary residents of that fashionable Winter locality. The club has sometimes been called George Gould's club on account of the deep interest which he has shown toward making it a success.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 2. -- C. Oliver Iselin of Defender fame is apparently negotiating with the Herreshoffs for some sort of a yacht, but just what it is, neither the Herreshoffs nor Mr. Iselin will say. Mr. Iselin has been at Bristol several times during the past few days.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 2. -- The Rev. Henry Clay Morrison, the Methodist evangelist and sanctificationist and coeditor of The Methodist, a holiness newspaper, promises to be the cause of a war in the Southern Methodist Episcopal Church which may rend it in twain. The Quarterly Conference sitting as a jury here has expelled him from the church.

HAVANA, Jan. 2. -- Gen. Weyler has issued from his camp at Bayete two edicts, bearing date of yesterday. One of them prohibits the storage or sale of hardware, saddlery, clothing, provisions, or medicines in unfortified towns. It also absolutely prohibits the removal of such goods from the towns in the Provinces of Pinar del Rio, Havana, and Matanzas without a military permit.

Aside from the two National cycle shows the event during the Winter season that appeals most strongly to the wheeling enthusiasts is the annual meeting of the League of American Wheelmen. The questions that will come up and the twenty-and-one things that are liable to happen are eagerly discussed weeks before the meeting takes place.

CUBA, TWENTY-THREE MILES WEST OF HAVANA, Dec. 15, 1896. -- I have accomplished that for which I have been trying for over three weeks, and at last I am among the insurgents, but I do not know how or when I shall get back to Havana. I am writing by the light from a burning stick, which the Cubans call a candle.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 2. -- The Rev. Henry Clay Morrison, the Methodist evangelist and sanctificationist and coeditor of The Methodist, a holiness newspaper, promises to be the cause of a war in the Southern Methodist Episcopal Church which may rend it in twain. The Quarterly Conference sitting as a jury here has expelled him from the church.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 2. -- C. Oliver Iselin of Defender fame is apparently negotiating with the Herreshoffs for some sort of a yacht, but just what it is, neither the Herreshoffs nor Mr. Iselin will say. Mr. Iselin has been at Bristol several times during the past few days.

MADRID, Jan. 3. -- Queen Regent Christina and the Government have sent messages to Gen. Polavieja, Captain General of the Philippine Islands, congratulating him upon his great victory over the insurgents on the heights of Cacaron, Province of Bulacan.

Officers in the Salvation Army are expecting to see important results during 1897. A great deal of new work has been scheduled for the year. Ideas which have never been tried in this country will be put in force. Some of them will be extremely novel, and the officers feel that they will accomplish a vast amount of good.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Among the interesting cases on the call of the Supreme Court of the United States this week is that of Frederick W. Vanderbilt's yacht Conqueror. The question is whether the vessel is subject to the payment of customs duties. The case has been on the court docket twice, but in the first the merits of the case were not involved.

During a quarrel at their home, 2,428 First Avenue, yesterday morning, Belle Davis Smith, a colored woman, thirty-two years old, fatally stabbed her husband, Jesse, in the throat with a pair of scissors.

One Hundred converted Jews of this city have signed a protest, to be presented to the New York Presbytery, in relation to Hermann Warszawiak, whom that body refused to ordain. The protest will be presented at the next meeting of the Presbytery by the Rev. Dr. John Hall.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 3. -- The destructive conflagration which visited this city last night at 11:15 o'clock was not well under control before 3 A.M. The fire, by far, was more disastrous in its results than was indicated in last night's dispatches. A series of unfortunate conditions handicapped the Fire Department in its work, and a very strong wind playing from the south made matters much worse.

The first of the Sunday evangelistic meetings, which are to be continued until the end of this month in Carnegie Hall took place yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock. Mr. Moody preached his New Year's sermon to an audience that occupied the entire hall. The Rev. Drs. Theodore L. Cuyler and A.C. Dixon of Brooklyn were among those who sat on the platform.

The letter carriers of this city who belong to Branch 36 of the National Letter Carriers' Association held their annual meeting and installation of officers yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Palace, Lexington Avenue and Forty-third Street.

The independent voters of the State of New York are a tremendous but undisciplined force. When they are thoroughly aroused by indignation at a public wrong they are irresistible. Indeed, they sometimes overdo their work, showing too little merciful discrimination, so that the innocent with the guilty are trampled down by them and in one red burial blent.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3. -- A few days before Christmas two boys, giving the names of James Hagen and Edward Burns of New York, were arrested here for picking pockets. Hagen was identified as a boy who had served time on Blackwell's Island for picking pockets in New York, but nothing was learned of the Burns boy. Both boys were convicted and sentenced to two years' imprisonment in the Huntingdon Reformatory.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- The spectacle of the dead body of a child which had rolled from a splintered coffin into the gutter, near Ninetieth Street and the tracks of the Calumet Electric Railway, was witnessed this morning at 9 o'clock. The accident was the result of a collision between a trolley car and the buggy of an undertaker, in which the coffin with its little corpse reposed.

The Aquarium was opened for the first time on Sunday yesterday, and, though it had not been positively announced in advance, 2,900 persons, as counted by the policeman at the door, passed in during the open hours, between 10 A.M. and 4 P.M.

On the last day of the old year some interesting testimony concerning the manufacture of paper was given before the Ways and Means Committee in Washington. We refer to such paper as is used by the daily press. Mr. JOHN NORRIS, publisher of The New York World, asserted that a combination of the manufacturers had recently been formed. We quote the following from a published report of his remarks:

MADRID, Jan. 3. -- The Hon. Hannis Taylor, the American Minister, had a long conference to-day with the Duke of Tetuan, Minister of Foreign Affairs. The subject of the conference has not been divulged.

One thing is plain from the comments of business men on the errand that has taken Senator WOLCOTT of Colorado across the sea. It is that, no matter what he may learn there, the American people have their own currency to attend to, and that the Government would make a great mistake and be guilty of a great fault if it allowed our business to wait on the decision of foreign Governments.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- The organization of the Legislature, which will meet here Wednesday, will be a quiet affair. The organization of the State Senate will not be changed materially from last year, and all that will be necessary to complete the organization of the Legislature this year will be the election of officers in the Assembly.

It is so desirable that ex-Fire Commissioner PURROY and ex-Police Commissioner SHEEHAN should fall out and take to exposing each other that their quarrel is instructive and should be valuable. What the controversy is ostensibly about does not much matter. What it is really about is, of course, the leadership of Tammany Hall.

The dinner of the Reform Club Saturday evening, at the clubhouse, 233 Fifth Avenue, was made the occasion for an interesting discussion of the tenement-house problem. The speakers were Jacob A. Riis, Dr. E.R.L. Gould, Roger Foster, and Richard Watson Gilder.

Two young men, who had just looted the country residence at Riverdale-on-the-Hudson of Samuel D. Babcock of 636 Fifth Avenue, came to New York by the 9 o'clock Croton local train Saturday evening. They carried the result of their expedition with them in the shape of two large and apparently very heavy bundles, a yellow valise, and a medium sized package, secured by two shawl straps.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 3. -- It was stated today that Major McKinley hoped to dispose of the principal posts in his Cabinet in a fortnight or three weeks, but that the Cabinet, as a whole, would not be completed till March 1.

The regular exercises of the Society for Ethical Culture were held yesterday morning at 11:15 at Carnegie Music Hall and were largely attended. Prof. Felix Adler occupied the platform and delivered a New Year's address, in the course of which he said:

The joint committee of the Twenty-third and Twenty-fourth Wards has issued an address and argument which it will present to the Greater New York Commission Jan. 13, recommending a plan for the local administration of public works and improvements applicable to all the boroughs of the new city.

PARIS, Jan. 3. -- Elections, which were held to-day in various parts of France for one-third of the members of the Senate, resulted in the defeat of the Radicals, who failed in their attempts to oust Moderate Republican candidates wherever the latter contested the districts. Even Siene-et-Marne, M. Bourgeois's own department, and the Department du Nord re-elected the retiring Moderate Republican candidates.

Among the actors and productions that closed engagements Saturday night were Richard Mansfield, who presented a composite bill of acts from his favorite plays at the Garden Theatre; W.H. Crane in "A Fool of Fortune" at the Fifth Avenue Theatre, H. Beerbohm Tree in "Hamlet" at the Knickerbocker Theatre, "Brian Boru" at the Broadway Theatre, and "My Friend from India" at Hoyt's Theatre.

BERLIN, Jan. 3. -- The members of the Berlin Produce Exchange began business yesterday under the new Boerse law, which went into effect on Jan. 1, as a free association instead of a close organization as formerly, but very little business was done. The Berlin association exchanged communications with the free associations (formerly the Boerses) of Halle, Stettin, Brunswick, and other centres, and some future transactions were recorded.

Mr. Jules S. Bache of J.S. Bache Co., who has just returned from a six weeks' trip through the West, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES in discussing Western business and financial conditions:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- When the Senate meets Tuesday morning after the holiday recess it is quite likely that the debate on matters pertaining to foreign relations and the position assumed by Secretary Olney for the Executive in respect to Cuba will begin to take shape. Whether Mr. Cameron will call up the Cuban resolution the opening day of the session is not yet known.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 3. -- The following dispatch, giving an account of the sinking of the filibuster steamer Commodore, was received from Datona at 11 o'clock to-night:

The first hearing upon the provisions of the Greater New York charter is to be given before the commission in the Council Chamber, at the City Hall, today, at 1 o'clock, and will relate wholly to the Police Department. It is a subject of very great importance, and one upon which the draft of the charter is in one point radically wrong.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- The Allan Line steamer Carthaginian, Capt. French, from Philadelphia, which ran aground in the Clyde, was compelled to discharge part of her cargo in order to get afloat. She sustained considerable damage. She will discharge the cargo yet on board of her, and will then go in dock to repair.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 4. -- Richard D. Cornelius, one of the oldest and best-known bank cashiers of this city, committed suicide to-day. His body was found in the duck pond in Druid Hill Park this afternoon, a few hours after a shortage of $60,000 had been discovered in his accounts at the National Farmers and Planters' Bank.

HAVANA, Jan. 4. -- Four hundred rebel cavalrymen, commanded by Maximo Gomez, the insurgent Commander in Chief, made attacks at Santa Teresa and other places upon a Government convoy. The Spanish forces comprised artillery and the charges of the rebels were met with volleys of grapeshot, which caused havoc in their ranks.

On Aug. 22, 1891, Thomas Ray, then fifteen years old, a stable lad employed by Albert Cooper, trainer for James R. and Foxhall Keene, was thrown by a vicious colt and so badly injured that one of his legs had to be amputated. Two years later guardians for Ray brought suit against Cooper to recover damages, on the ground that Ray had sustained his hurts through the negligence of the trainer.

The owners of iron-ore mines in the Lake Superior mining district will ask the Ways and Means Committee next Saturday for a higher tariff duty. The present duty is 40 cents per ton. "Congressman STEPHENSON of Michigan," says The Cleveland Leader, "proposes to ask for a tariff of $1.50 a ton.

Honorable merchandising is a duty. It is commendable and commands the respect of the community. When the article of merchandise handled is such that the buyer must rely upon the integrity of the house rather than his own judgment, the increasing business of an establishment is an evidence of honorable dealing.
ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Open competitive civil service examinations for places in the courts in the City and County of New York will be held in that city during the week beginning Jan. 25.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Tobacco and manufactures thereof, being Schedule F of the existing tariff law, was the subject of the hearing before the Committee on Ways and Means this morning. The National Association of Cigar Manufacturers of the United States was represented by a number of gentlemen.

Considering that the offer of autonomy by Spain to Puerto Rico was obviously and almost avowedly intended mainly to conciliate Cuba, the sequel of it is particularly instructive. On the face of it this was an offer to divide the government between representatives of the people concerned and representatives of the Crown, the casting vote being reserved for the Viceroy, who was necessarily a representative of Spanish against colonial feeling.

Mr. John Hare received a cordial greeting from an audience of exceptional quality when he began his second engagement in New York at the Knickerbocker Theatre. His play was "The Hobby Horse," a three-act comedy of Pinero's "second period " -- for it is becoming fashionable to treat Pinero's career like Shakespeare's, and classify it.
Charles N. Chadwick read a paper before the Froebel Society in Brooklyn yesterday on the educational chapter of the Greater New York charter.

The Legislature of this State meets in regular session at Albany to-morrow, but there is no sign of a contest in that quarter. The organization of the Senate as effected last Winter will continue undisputed. Though the Assembly is newly elected, and a Speaker is to be chosen, there has been a complete absence of the customary rivalry for the honor of presiding over the lower chamber.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 4. -- Reports from different sections of Michigan show that much damage has been done by heavy rains. The town of Ashley is nearly under water. Sidewalks are afloat and the railroad track is in some places a foot under water. Great damage is being done to crops and property.

While commenting a few days ago upon Secretary MORTON'S first reply to the attack made upon him by SAMUEL W. ALLERTON of Chicago -- who hopes to be Secretary of Agriculture in Mr. McKINLEY'S Cabinet -- we remarked that Mr. ALLERTON should be urged to write in one of his letters his reminiscences concerning the work of what was called the Association of Eveners.

It was a brilliant night at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, yet the opera was "Faust," a work worn threadbare by long usage, yet always a source of indescribable delight when sung as it was last night. The house was packed to its utmost capacity, and the audience, thanks to the Astor ball, was as brilliant as it was numerous.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The improvement of Cuba in wealth and economic development under Spanish rule was set forth today in a rather forcible manner by Senator Hale of Maine in a talk with the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which the Senator stated some of his reasons for opposing the Cameron resolutions, recognizing the independence of the Cuban Republic.

It is old news that Japan has sent a man-of-war to the Philippines, presumably to observe and report upon the progress of the insurrection and to see whether there is "anything in it" for Japan. The possession of the Philippines would be quite as important as the possession of Formosa to the execution of the programme of expansion which it is quite evident that Japan has adopted.

It is announced that the once famous collection of pictures, statuary, and art objects owned by Marshall O. Roberts, and which at his death in 1880, he left to his widow, who is now Mrs. Col. Ralph Vivian of London, will be sold at auction.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- Senator Raines, who is Chairman of the special committee investigating the operation of the Raines liquor-tax law, to-day talked with Gov. Black with reference to the Governor's treatment of the Raines law in the annual message.

The hearings before the Consolidation Commission are to be so crowded one upon the heels of another that no adequate consideration can be given to the important matters that are to come up on successive days of this week and next. But the two most important subjects are that of police administration, which came up yesterday, and that of the constitution and powers of the Municipal Assembly, which is to be considered to-day.

The annual message of Mayor Wurster of Brooklyn was transmitted and read to the Board of Aldermen of that city at the first meeting of the year, yesterday afternoon. The message is significant, in that it will probably be the last to be issued by a Mayor of Brooklyn. It naturally treats of many things in connection with the greater city.

Otto A. Krauss, a member of several German clubs and societies, and well known in the wine trade in this city, left home on Nov. 17 last, ostensibly on a business trip to Mexico. He has not been heard from since.

Superintendent Constable of the Building Department recently asked Corporation Counsel Scott for an opinion as to the construction to be placed on the opening sentence of Section 480 of the Consolidation act as amended by Section 16, Chapter 275, of the Laws of 1892, in so far as it relates to buildings altered to be occupied by hotels.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn., Jan. 4. -- Mrs. Mary Cole of 77 North Street, an employe at the European House, was missing since Friday night. There was no sign of life around her house, so the police broke a window this morning and entered the building. They found Mrs. Cole sitting on the edge of her bed, unconscious, and with a deep gash 3 inches long over her left ear.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- General Order No. 1 was issued to-day by Gov. Black, as Commander in Chief of the State Militia. Besides officially announcing the appointment of The Governor's staff, the order says:

Arthur F. Dennett, the Superintendent of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, is mentally and physically ill. He has been acting so strangely for several days that his friends became uneasy at his condition. The Directors of the society yesterday granted him a two weeks' leave of absence for rest and recuperation, with the understanding that the leave would be extended if necessary.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 4. -- W.R. Townsend, the special agent recently dispatched to Japan by the San Francisco Bureau of Foreign Commerce, for the purpose of collecting data with reference to matters affecting the interests of American manufacturers, has submitted his first report.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 4. -- The Germania, the Allemania, and the West Side Banks, all doing business as State banks, to-day closed their doors, each one of them being literally pulled down by its depositors.

Wide differences of opinion as to the Police Chapter of the Greater New York charter as prepared by the Draft Committee were manifest at the first of the series of public hearings before the Greater New York Commission, held yesterday, in the Aldermanic Council Chamber in the City Hall.

William S. Matthews, Superintendent of Insurance for the State of Ohio, and Seldon R. Hopkins and Walter S. Fogg, Special Examiners from that department, have been engaged for the past week in an examination of the books and affairs of the Globe Fire Insurance Company, which has offices at 80 William Street, this city.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 4. -- While the Southern Railway train from Atlanta was entering Rome, Ga., at an early hour this morning a passenger clad only in his night clothes took a flying leap from the platform of the sleeping coach, and lay in an unconscious heap beside the track until picked up by the crew.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

There is now a chance for a meeting in the ring between Robert Fitzsimmons and James Corbett. Fitzsimmons yesterday signed the articles of agreement calling for a contest to a finish on March 17, to which Corbett some time ago affixed his signature.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- "The committee is packed in the interest of the people who control the Pacific roads, and it is useless to hope for a favorable report on my resolution."

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 5. -- The Senatorial fight has begun. It starts out with a contest for the Speakership of the House. It is agreed by the Republicans that the Populists shall have that position. So the Populists' caucus must settle the matter. There are two candidates -- Hileman, who favors Pritchard for Senator, and who is backed by Congressman Skinner, and Shulken, who is supported by Senator Butler, and who is an anti-Pritchard man.

JACKSONSVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5. -- A special dispatch from Key West says that it is reported there on good authority that the Dauntless landed the men and arms taken from Noname Key, upon the coast of Cuba Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Five general officers of the army and three of the navy will retire, on reaching the age limit, during the present year. The first of these, Brig. Gen. Michael R. Morgan, the Commissary General of Subsistence, goes off the active list on the 18th of the present month, when he will, without doubt, be succeeded by Col. Thomas C. Sullivan, his assistant and next in rank.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5. -- Bright, clear weather drew out 3,000 people to-day. The track was slow and lumpy, but four favorites won, and the bookmakers got the worst of the play. A feature of the day was the good running of Jockeys F. Morris and Hirsch on Chugnut and Grafton, respectively.

Frank Ellison, formerly a well-known clubman, was released rom Sing Sing Prison yesterday morning, and arrived in this city on the afternoon train from Sing Sing. Ellison did not complete his five-year sentence for assaulting the aged broker, William Henriques, in this city in July, 1893. As he was an obedient prisoner, the law allowed him over a year commutation.
Funeral services for Mrs. Dorothy Scribner Harris, who died on Monday at the home of her daughter, Mrs. Andrew McFeeters, 457 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, took place at the residence last evening.

The House of Representatives reassembled after the holiday recess with an attendance of only about half its members. The galleries were well filled, and the occupants for a time remained in their seats listening to the debate upon the Loud bill to amend the postal laws with respect to the transmission of second-class matter, which had been made the special order for the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- A favorable opportunity to enlarge the American market abroad will be afforded by the opening of the Central American Exposition at the City of Guatemala on the 15th of March next. The Guatemalan Minister, Mr. Lazo Arriaga, states that all the foreign Governments in Europe and America have been asked to send exhibits, but he cannot state how far the invitations have been accepted.

MADRID, Jan. 5. -- The Imparcial publishes a report of an interview had by the correspondent of that paper in Havana with Capt. Gen. Weyler yesterday. Gen. Weyler is quoted as saying that he is greatly surprised at the course taken by certain Madrid newspapers in charging that gross corruption exists in the military administration in Cuba. Doubtless, he says, there have been some abuses, but these have been remedied whenever they have become known.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- The Republican Assemblymen, with a majority greater than has ever before been seen in this State, organized to-night.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 5. -- The Pennsylvania Legislature was organized to-day. H.K. Boyer (Rep.) of Philadelphia was chosen Speaker of the House. Gov. Hastings's message was read in both houses. An interesting portion of the Governor's message refers to the Pennsylvania Election laws.

HAVANA, Jan. 5. -- Col. Baquero reports having met a force of rebels holding a position on the heights of Boqueron, near Guantanamo, in the Santiago de Cuba Province, dispersing the enemy with the loss of eight men killed and many wounded. Yesterday Col. Baquero had another sharp engagement with a band of rebels at Altos Sorpresa, in which the Spanish loss was two guerrillas killed and one captain and twenty-two privates wounded.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 5. -- It turns out that the sale of the final sixty shares of the Woolson Spice Company stock, sold by Spence T. Acklin for $100,000, was not to the American Sugar Refinery people after all, as even Mr. Acklin supposed. It was simply a grand coup of the Arbuckles to get on the inside of the Sugar people's affairs.

A long line of little girls, scholars from a near-by school, passed up Lexington Avenue yesterday afternoon with a teacher. They were, it would seem at first sight, children such as might come from any school. There were sounds of laughter and of voices, though one could not distinguish anything that was said.
The bill to be introduced in the Legislature by resolution of the Gas Committee of the Board of Aldermen has been prepared by Chairman Benjamin E. Hall, and will be submitted to the committee to-day.

The somewhat amusing declaration of Gov. Black in his inaugural address, that "no intolerant clamor or irresponsible assault will force or prevent a single Executive act," reminds me of a tradition long current in this city in regard to one of the Governor's predecessors.

Somebody has taken the trouble to telegraph from Washington a preposterous tale, to the effect that France will "within the next ten days" send a force of troops to Martinique for the purpose of assisting the Spanish Army in Cuba. The assistance is to be rendered as soon as our Government interferes. In the first place, French statesmen have learned not to take too seriously the remarks of American Senators.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- The most careful canvass that the Republican machine leaders have been able to make on the Senatorial question shows that 126 members are for ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt.

Pincus Lowenfeld and William Prager have bought from Sarah B. Anderson a vacant lot on the south side of One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, 140 feet west of Park Avenue, 35 by 100.11, for improvement.

The death of Gen. WALKER justifies the usually trite remark that it is untimely.
