It is unpleasant to think of a man of his intellectual vitality, his personal energy and love of work, his varied and trained powers, his talent for instruction, and his high standard of professional achievement, dying of apoplexy at the age of fifty-six.
Mr. Henry W. Poor of the Stock Exchange house of Poor Greenough said yesterday to a NEW YORK TIMES representative in discussing the financial outlook:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The reassembling of the Senate this morning, after its fortnight's holiday, was unmarked by any noticeable incident.

We infer from what was said during the tariff hearing concerning sugar and from other indications that in the Ways and Means Committee's new bill the present ad valorem rates will be displaced by specific duties and that the sugar taxes will be increased. The two questions in which the people are especially interested are these:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The Secretary of the Navy to-day sent in his report to Congress on the subject of armor plate. Under the act making appropriations for the naval service for the year ending June 30, 1897, Congress directed the Secretary to examine into the actual cost of armor plate and the price for the same which should be equitably paid.

An animated discussion regarding the constitutional meaning and effect of the New Jersey ballot law has been started in that State in consequence of a ruling made by Judge Depue, sitting in the Supreme Court circuit, in a contested election case in Newark a few days ago.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Superintendent of Insurance James F. Pierce, in response to an inquiry of a correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said he had read in THE TIMES this morning the published report of the examination of the Ohio Insurance Department of the Globe Fire Insurance Company of New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- Lincoln Park Policeman Max Krueger adopted rather a remarkable method yesterday to prevent a suicide on the north shore. Bernard Kraus, a tailor, living at 142 Cornelius Street, had become despondent through inability to obtain employment and jumped into Lake Michigan with the intention of committing suicide.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5. -- The trial of John A. Hanley, formerly General Traffic Manager of the Santa Fe Railroad, and J.W. Rinehart of the same line, indicted in the Federal Courts for violating the Inter-State Commerce laws, was begun this morning before Judge Grosscup.

A story that a steamship was loading with grain -- No. 2 old corn -- at the Erie grain elevator, in Jersey City, was read with interest at the Produce Exchange yesterday. If it had been true, it would have been accepted as an indication that the grain-elevator interests of this port had voluntarily cut down port charges.

The largest transfer of school teachers that ever took place in this city was announced to the teachers concerned on Monday, and is to go into effect immediately. The transfer involves the promotion of about 800 teachers, the permanent appointment of about 100 teachers from among the substitutes, and the degrading of three teachers.

The petitions that are going to Washington for the Torrey Bankruptcy bill are only the latest of a stream of them that has been flowing in that direction for years. We do not recall a single measure of a purely business character since the civil war that has commanded the approval of so large a body of the interests directly and indirectly affected by it or one that has so richly deserved such approval.

BOSTON, Jan. 5. -- Those three famous evangelists, Dwight L. Moody, Francis Murphy, and "Sam" Jones, began revival meetings from the same platform yesterday. The meetings took place in Tremont Temple, and immense audiences were present both day and evening. The revival will last two months at least, and in that time Boston's evil side will get a thorough cleaning out.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- There is little doubt that Major McKinley to-morrow will offer the Treasury portfolio to Senator Allison, and urge him to accept it.
The Board of Superintendents of Schools held a meeting yesterday afternoon at which the chapter on education of the Greater New York charter was read and discussed.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 5. -- The strangest event in the history of this port has just occurred. Some days ago the schooner Robert I. Carter grounded on Alden's Rock, and it was supposed that she must be a complete wreck. Her sails were taken off, she was stripped of everything movable, and then abandoned, as far as her cargo was concerned.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 5. -- The seven Union Republican (Addicks) candidates for the House of Representatives in Kent County, who were declared not elected by the Board of Canvassers, and the seven Union Republicans who were defeated in Sussex County, met in the State Library this morning and decided to form a "rump" House, to meet at the Hotel Richardson.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The efforts of counsel to secure a judgment from the Supreme Court of the United States upon the constitutionality of the law for the suppression of lottery traffic through the National and Inter-State Commerce act, in the prosecution of Albert L. France and others, indicted for conspiracy to violate the act by trafficking in lottery slips and drawings between Cincinnati and Covington, Ky., have come to naught.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate in response to the resolution offered by Mr. Call the correspondence in the case of Charles Govin, an American correspondent, alleged to have been captured by the Spanish troops near Jaruco and put to death.

There was a novel entertainment in connection with the annual meeting of St. John's Guild at the Plaza Hotel last night. A large audience was present. Before the business meeting the Mendelssohn Quartet rendered some delightful music.

There is trouble in Coaching Club circles, and several of the members who have been prominent in club affairs for many years and have held office have been retired and new officers elected. Then, too, T. Suffern Tailer, who was proposed for membership, has been blackballed. All this occurred at a meeting of the club which was held at the Knickerbocker Clubhouse last Saturday night.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 5. -- Maurice Auerbach, President of the Union Bank, was to-day appointed receiver of the Allemania Bank, under bond of $200,000. The Board of Directors of the Germania Bank held a special meeting, and appointed a committee of seven stockholders to take measures for the speedy reorganization of the bank. Charles

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The annual report to the President of John J. Brice, Commissioner of Fish and Fisheries, indicates how important the work of his office has become. No less than 48,000,000 shad eggs were collected, and from these 93,000,000 fry were planted in streams emptying into the Atlantic ocean and the Gulf of Mexico last year.
ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- A canvass for a bit of Federal patronage was carried on here to-day at the Speakership headquarters of Mr. O'Grady.

Letters sent to Syrian (residents in this city say that the officials in the Yildiz Palace in Constantinople were greatly disturbed recently by a telegram announcing the arrest of a prominent young Turk in Beyroot, Syria, on charges of making treasonable utterances against the Sultan.

Cable car No. 291 ran away on Lexington Avenue last evening, between Eighty-first and Ninety-sixth Streets, smashed into two other cars, and injured six persons. The runaway was caused by the grip of the car catching a broken strand of the cable. The injured were:

RIVERTON, N.J., Jan. 5. -- George Work and Julian Davies shot a match at 100 birds to-day. Work won by four birds, in a score of 82 to 78. The stakes were $100 a side, the loser to pay for the birds. Each man shot from the thirty-yard line.
HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 5. -- The great fight for Senator Cameron's seat is over. Senator Boies Penrose of Philadelphia has won.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The Ways and Means Committee to-day considered the agricultural schedule of the tariff law.
Seven truant officers of the Brooklyn Board of Education and six policemen in citizens' clothes yesterday afternoon arrested fourteen schoolboys, who ran away from school to go to the theatre.

The Republican Club gave a banquet last night in honor of Cornelius N. Bliss, its retiring President. Mr. Bliss presided, and several prominent guests sat on either side of him. Among the guests of honor were Mayor W.L. Strong and Representative Mahlon Pitney of New Jersey. Mayor F.W. Wurster of Brooklyn was also on this list, and was expected to speak, but did not come.

President E C. Jameson of the Globe Fire Insurance Company, which has been the subject of a report by special examiners in the employ of William S. Matthews, Superintendent of Insurance for the State of Ohio, was seen yesterday by a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES. Mr. Jameson had this to say of the allegations contained in the report, published in THE TIMES yesterday morning:

It is many a long day since New York has had anything so artistic in the form of light opera as "Shamus O'Brien." If this delightful work does not attract general and continued attention from the public, the public will be the loser. "Shamus O'Brien" was produced last night at the Broadway Theatre. The house was well

BOSTON, Jan. 5. -- Gen. Francis A. Walker, President of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and widely known, died this morning. His death was unexpected. He had enjoyed good health up to the time of retiring last evening. Just before midnight he was stricken with apoplexy. Mrs. Walker was awakened by the General's hard breathing.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- The following, on a printed slip, was circulated about the Capitol to-day among the members of the Legislature:

A correspondent inquires how we make up the "debt budget" for Greater New York, outside of the municipal debts of New York and Brooklyn, at "nearly $30,000,000," as stated in our editorial columns last Sunday. It was a general deduction from a statement prepared by SILAS B. DUTCHER, a member of the Greater New York Commission, and presumably authentic, of the debts of the different "civil divisions" in question on the 30th of June last.

BAY CITY, Mich., Jan. 5. -- The troubles of St. Stanislaus's Polish Church, which have been agitating the communicants for more than a year, broke out afresh to-day, and a riot resulted in which one man was shot and severely injured and several others badly hurt by being beaten with clubs:

The electric plant ordered by John Jacob Astor from a Poughkeepsie firm is for the new hotel in course of construction at Thirty-fourth Street and Fifth Avenue, adjoining the Waldorf. The new building has been leased to Charles C. Boldt, who conducts the Waldorf, for a term of twenty years, and the two hotels will be run on the same lines.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 5. -- There was loss of life in the blizzard of Sunday and Monday. A telegram from Barnesville came to Representative McGrath this afternoon, saying his brother, John McGrath, was lost in the storm, and perished before he could reach shelter. A dispatch from Fargo says two children of John Pettit of Hunter were frozen to death in Sunday's storm.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 5. -- There is a lively contest going on to acquire the Richmond City Gas Works, either by purchase outright or by lease. Competing propositions were last night submitted to the City Council. The first was by the Richmond Gas Company, an organization of which Mr. Miller of New York is President, and the other was from a syndicate which is represented by Judge Henry W. Flournoy and Col. Marshall of Portsmouth.
The Mining Exchange of New York, at 38 and 40 New Street, was auspiciously opened yesterday.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5. -- It seems to be settled that the seven men missing from the crew of the foundered steamer Commodore have been drowned.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- There were not more than a dozen Senators in the chamber to-day when the Chaplain offered his opening prayer, and the galleries were almost deserted.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The following bills were introduced in the Assembly to-day: Mr. Sanger -- Providing for a reclassification of the civil service; also, providing for tabulation in New York and Kings County of election canvasses; also, authorizing the State Engineer to co-operate further with the United States Government in continuing the geological and topographical survey; also, prohibiting the killing of deer with the aid of jacklights.

HAVANA, Jan. 6. -- Another edict has been issued by Gen. Weyler under which all owners, managers, and overseers of estates and farms in the Provinces of Pinar del Rio, Havana, and Matanzas shall, within eight days from the date of the edict appear before the Mayors of the fortified towns earest to their homes, and prove their ownership of estates or the capacity in which they are employed thereon.
RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 6. -- The latest method of disposing of a case of a would-be duelist seems to have been hit upon by Squire Vincent of this (Henrico) county.

Vigorous opposition to the creation of the Municipal Assembly, as proposed in the Greater New York Charter, developed yesterday at the hearing before the commission in the Council Chamber of the City Hall.

Many American readers must have been puzzled by the fragmentary dispatches relating to the agitation in Ireland upon the subject of taxation. Irish Unionists have been found expressing agreement with Irish home rulers. The landlord and the dynamiter have stood together on platforms and given voice to the grievance of Ireland.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- The ordinance passed Monday evening by the City Council, aimed at the high-hat nuisance in the theatres, has been declared invalid by a number of the best authorities in the city, who found many faulty points in its construction.

Gentlemen: One Summer morning at Athens I stood upon the Acropolis. Before me were the temple of her religion, the seats of her famed Court of Justice, and the field where her popular Assembly deliberated and enacted laws. Memory swiftly reviewed the inspiring past. Names which have survived the centuries and made immortal Grecian art, letters, eloquence, and arms were materialized by the imagination.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Jan. 6. -- Burglars entered the Raritan Dime Savings Bank, at Raritan, this morning, and blew off the outer door of the safe. They escaped, taking nothing but 50 cents, which they found in an outside drawer.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- A nolle prosequi was entered to-day in the case of Joseph W. Reinhart, ex-President of the Santa Fe Railroad Company, charged with giving rebates on freight rates. Judge Grosscup ordered him discharged from the case at once. The Government failed to prove that Mr. Reinhart knew anything of the alleged transactions.

Speaker O'GRADY, on taking the chair in the Assembly, felt it his duty to call attention to "a matter the correction of which will save a great deal of time and much expense to the State." He referred to the introduction of a flood of bills, many of which are "carelessly introduced and afterward found to be needless and improper" and others of which "are introduced with no intention of passing them.

SILVER SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- One hundred and sixty cars loaded with 5,450,000 pounds of salt left here to-day, consigned to New England firms. The train was the Worcester Salt Special, bearing a consignment of orders to New England, which had been given contingent upon President McKinley's election.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Gov. Black this morning appointed George W. Aldridge of Rochester to be Superintendent of Public Works. The Senate promptly confirmed the appointment by a unanimous vote and without a roll call.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 6. -- The rise in the Mississippi River continues at the rate of nearly an inch per hour. So far over 125,000 feet of wharves have been washed away and considerable damage has been done to cotton and other goods stored along the levee. Rivermen predict that the flood will go as high as twenty-seven feet, and it is feared an immense loss to property will result.

A large part of the space of the morning papers yesterday was given up to reports of legislative caucuses, in one of which a candidate for Senator was named, and in the others the proceedings were of interest because of their effect on Senatorial nominations. The reports were not cheerful reading for those who care for the repute or usefulness of the United States Senate.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 6. -- The fortieth General Assembly convened at noon to-day, and the new officers of the Legislature chosen at last night's Republican caucus were sworn in.

TORONTO, Jan. 6. -- The Globe to-day publishes a circular which it says has been sent to Protestant clergymen and leading citizens throughout Ontario. The circular is dated Toronto, Dec. 29, 1896, is headed "Patriotic Vigilance Committee," marked "Confidential," and begins as follows:

ALBYNY, Jan. 6. -- The Senate session of 1897 was called to order at 11:20 o'clock to-day by Lieut. Gov. Woodruff. The Lieutenant Governor was the recipient of some beautiful floral tributes, one of them being basket of fragrant flowers from M.J. Dady of Brooklyn. Mrs. Woodruff and a party of friends had seats in the gallery at the right.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Superintendent F.D. Kilburn of the State Banking Department to-day gave out the following summary, showing the aggregate of resources and liabilities of the 212 State Banks at the close of business on Dec. 9, as exhibited by their reports to his department:
WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 6. -- The House Committee on Judiciary has been discussing Senator Hill's bill "to prevent government by injunction," and will be ready to report to the House in a few days.

Within the past few months there has been an inordinate deal of report and rumor upon Papal politics as they affected this country. Some of the reports have been promptly discredited by explicit denials from those who were in a position to know about the subject matter.

Visitors to the Salvation Army Headquarters last night saw the "devil" dismembered and dissected by Major Winchell, and also saw him burned to a crisp, from his cloven hoof to his horn-topped head. Incidentally they also heard the Major's physiological lecture on the several parts of the "devil's" anatomy.
The United States Realty Company has sold to Charles W. Fernald, at $58,900, the four-story brownstone private dwelling 244 Central Park West, 22 by 55 by 100.

BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 6. -- The unexpected breaking up of the Democratic-Populist fusion in the Legislature and the coalition between the Democrats and Silver Republicans, by which the former were enabled to organize both houses, have given a new turn to the Senatorial contest, and seems to indicate that the Populists, instead of securing the Senatorship, as they expected to do by the aid of the Democrats, will be left out in the cold.

The gift of a drinking cup to President ]/icCosh of Princeton was .one of the first cases that attracted atenti6n, for usually this form of present was confined to the convivial and eslJe-cialIy favored amo.ng clubmen and actors. But Dr. Storrs of Brooklyn received one recently, and now the staid old First Church in I-Iartford has presented a loving cup to the Rev. Dr. George.

The trouble between the Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter of the Baptist Tabernacle and the Baptist City Mission Society, did not abate yesterday. There were during the day several episodes which, without having serious consequences or changing materially the situation, kept the community around the disputed house, at Second Avenue and Tenth Street, in a state of anxiety.

YUMA, Arizona, Jan. 6. -- Timely discovery alone prevented the carrying out of a carefully planned plot to escape from the Territorial Penitentiary at this place. A tunnel had been dug from beneath the onyx shop to the north wall of the prison inclosure, and was almost completed when discovered. The tunneling required to reach freedom was through thirty feet of hard cement formation and eight feet of stone wall.

Unless the legal authority who has profered his services to former Inspector General McLewee is wrong in his law, former Adjt. Gen. McAlpin has possibly not heard the last of the squabbles that culminated in Gov. Morton's removal of the former Inspector General.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 6. -- A divorce obtained in Oklahoma was to-day practically declared invalid by Judge Van Valen, in the case of Anna Marsh against A.L. Marsh. Marsh is an expert stenographer and telegraph operator. For long time he was in ex-Gov. Flower's private office in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- There is information of an apparently reliable sort that the Union Pacific Reorganization Committee is prepared to enter into an agreement to pay the Government between $30,000,000 and $40,000,000 for the Union Pacific properties under foreclosure proceedings to be instituted by the Government in the event of the funding bills failing to pass the House.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6. -- The going on the track to-day was lumpy, but faster than for several days. Rossman, the favorite, won the $1,000 Live Oak Handicap very cleverly. Only one other first choice won during the day.

Mr. DEPEW'S centennial address at Albany was very properly devoted to a celebration of the State of New York. The two advantages which the orator selected as accounting for the development of the Commonwealth to the first place in population and wealth are the same upon which HORATIO SEYMOUR delighted to dwell in public addresses and treated with great fullness of knowledge and power of luminous exposition.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6. -- It has been found that the pillars at the rear of the Speaker's desk in the Assembly Chamber, in the State House, are not, as was supposed, and as the specifications are supposed to have called for, marble. They are simply pine timbers cut to represent pillars and then covered with plaster. The bases are of marble.

In accordance with the annual custom of the New York City Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, the anniversary of Gen. Washington's wedding to Martha Custis was celebrated by a reception at Sherry's yesterday afternoon from 4 to 7 o'clock.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 6. -- Eight newspaper men appeared before the United States District Attorney this morning in response to subpoenas issued on Tuesday, but they were not called upon to go before Grand Jury to testify in filibustering cases, as was anticipated. After all had reported, they were excused until Friday morning, when they will have to tell what they know about the last expedition of the steamer Three Friends.

Dispatches from London indicate that the report of the Pacific Cable Commission will favor the laying of a cable which will bring all Greater Britain into immediate communication with the metropolis of the empire. South Africa and India are already provided for in this respect. Australia and New Zealand remain to be included by the line it is proposed to lay from Vancouver to Australia, touching none but British possessions.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The opening of the Senate to-day was enlivened by a protest by Senator McCarren of Brooklyn against the further leadership of Jacob A. Cantor, who for several years has been the Democratic spokesman on the floor of the Senate.

Stephen Miller, a prepossessing boy of fourteen, is locked up in the workhouse in Brooklyn, for the theft of $1,200 in diamonds and jewelry, and $90 in cash, the property of Samuel Neill and his wife, whose home is at 358 Snedeker Avenue.

Police Judge Steers, in the Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, played the part of a Good Samaritan yesterday, and not only suspended sentence against a man who was charged with stealing, but gave him $10 because he said he had stolen because he was starving.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The tariff hearings before the Ways and Means Committee were continued to-day, "raw wool" being the schedule under consideration.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The members of the Assembly were on hand early this morning. Previous to the opening of the session at 11 o'clock, Secretary of State Palmer appeared in the well of the chamber and swore in the members. Floral offerings were on the Speaker's rostrum for the newly elected Speaker, Assemblyman 0'Grady of Rochester, and on the desks of Assemblymen Austin and Andrews of New York, and Abell of Brooklyn.

Jacob A. Riis, agent of the Confederated Good Government Clubs, presented a report to the clubs Tuesday evening, at 722 Lexington Avenue, on the subject of providing accommodations for boys' clubs in this city. Mr. Riis asked the meeting to have the report submitted to the Board of Education, asking them to allow the use of the school rooms for these clubs when they were not demanded for other purposes.

The Brazilian Minister of Finance recently asked the Banco da Republica to provide cedulas (bonus) to the aggregate of 4,000,000 to pay the Companhio Metropolitana the indemnity agreed upon for the redemption of its contract for introducing immigrants.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- At the dinner of the Article Club, given at the Hotel Cecil this evening, the Hon. Thomas F. Bayard, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, responding to the toast, "The American People," referred incidentally to Canada, in the growth of which, he declared, where was nothing that ought not to awaken the sympathy, pride, and pleasure of the citizens of the United States.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 6. -- State Bank Commissioner John W. Breidenthal predicts that the number of Kansas banking institutions will decrease materially within the next two years. He says there are too many banks in Kansas now for the amount of business transacted, and is advising consolidation in every place where it is feasible.

Selden R. Hopkins, as Special Examiner for the Insurance Department of the State of Ohio, has written a letter to James F. Pierce, Superintendent of Insurance, at Albany, concerning the examination of and report upon the affairs of the Globe Fire Insurance Company made recently.
Cyclists wishing to join the League of American Wheelmen will be furnished with application blanks and necessary information by addressing Cycling Department of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Two days have passed without effort in the Senate to take up the Cameron resolution on Cuba, and some of the eager friends of Cuba have come to the conclusion that the members of the Senate who determined that there should be intervention of some sort by the United States have jumped to the conclusion that the Pennsylvania Senator has weakened in his enthusiasm, and that the resolution has been abandoned.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan 6. -- The General Assembly of 1897 was organized to-day, and Lorin A. Cooke of Winsted was inaugurated Governor. The interesting feature of the day at the Capitol was the address made by Joseph L. Barbour in assuming the duties of the Speakership in the House. In the course of his remarks he said:

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- Two boys, James Potter and Adolph Cornell, one fourteen and the other sixteen years of age, had an experience with a wildcat a night or two ago that they will remember probably as long as they live. Both of the young lads reside near the little village of Woodstock, in the Catskill Mountains, distant about twelve miles from this city.

Chief Conlin thinks the proposed parade with music to escort Troop F, Third United States Cavalry, from the Grand Central Railroad Station to its quarters next Sunday is a violation of the Sunday law. The point was brought to his attention by W.W. Atterbury, Secretary of the Sabbath Committee.

In a small pamphlet entitled "Anniversaries,'' a reprint from the American Historical Register of February, 1895; and published by Isaac Myer, is a treatise on the subject of anniversaries in general, and an investigation concerning the anniversary of Washington's Birthday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Secretary Herbert's report fixing a fair price for armor plate, and criticising the Carnegie and Bethlehem companies, is understood to cover substantially the ground and position taken by the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- Rising to a question of personal privilege, Mr. Grosvenor (Rep., Ohio,) offered resolutions calling upon the heads of departments to explain why they had not responded to a resolution introduced by himself in the House on the 20th of May last, and adopted June 5, asking certain information regarding the operation of the civil service law.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Bills providing for cheaper gas in New York City are showing themselves in such numbers as to be confusing. Two were introduced to-day in the Assembly, and if the order of introduction of bills had been reached in the Senate, there would have been two or three in that body.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- Gen. Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, transmitted to the State Prison Commission a letter bearing on the prison-labor problem.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 6. -- Major McKinley left Cleveland at 7:10 this morning in the private car of Vice President King of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad for Canton. Breakfast was served en route, and the President-elect reached Canton a few moments before 10.

A grand mounted military tournament was held last night at Durland's Academy, Eighth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, by Troop C, assisted by pupils of the academy, for the benefit of a National Guardsmen's hospital.

Some interesting facts are likely to be laid before the American Paper Manufacturers' Association at its annual meeting, which has been called for Feb. 23, in this city. There have been changes in the paper trade situation within the past few months, and questions of lessening the cost of production, regulating prices, and the introduction of novelties in the paper manufacturing business will doubtless receive consideration.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- The ideas expressed by Gov. Black upon the operation and administration of the civil service are to be embodied in a bill to be drafted by Assemblyman Henry E. Abell of Brooklyn, and introduced at an early date.

Massenet's lugubrious opera, "Werther," Which has not been given here for two years, was brought forward last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Its previous performance took place on April 19, 1894.

Perhaps the oddest natural curiosity of the Christmas was a wagonload of white redwood from Sonoma County. Mr. Orr, who is interested in that part of California, sent large quantities of redwood saplings to town for Christmas trees, and by way of variety included some "everwhites." The bark and wood are not different from the common redwood, but one distinct dissimilarity marking the freakish tree.

-- Gas was first used as an illuminant just 100 years ago. The people of this and a good many other cities seem to be meditating a most sensible celebration of the anniversary, for they have practically decided that a century of exploitation by corporations is quite enough for one of the necessities of life to undergo.

The Trustees of the Atlantic Yacht Club held a special meeting at the office of J. Rogers Maxwell yesterday afternoon to consider the advisability of moving the clubhouse from Bay Ridge to Sea Gate, the new name for the western end of Corey Island. The Trustees had invited the flag officers and Col. David E. Austen, Newberry D. Lawton, Gen. Thomas L. Watson, and Henry B. Howells to be present.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 6. -- The third of the series of torpedo boats to be built at the Columbian Iron Works for the United States Government was launched this morning. The first was launched about three months ago, and the second, about six weeks ago. The trio have not been named, but are known, respectively, as Torpedo Boats No. 3, No. 4, and No. 5. Their contract price was $97,500 each.
ROBERVAL, Quebec, Jan. 6 -- Seven nuns were suffocated this morning by the burning of the Convent of Our Lady of Lake St. John. They were:

WASHINGTON, D. C., Jan. 6. -- Word has been received here that the Russian Government has appointed W. E. D. Stokes of New York City the Imperial Russian Government's correspondent for horses and horse breeding in America, with rank, uniform, and official entree, and with permission to wear this uniform in America on official occasions.
CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- New and startling complications are growing out of the failure of the National Bank of Illinois.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- Attorney General Hancock to-day made public his opinion, written at the request of District Attorney Olcott of New York City, asking whether the employes in the District Attorney's office below the Assistant District Attorneys come within the civil service.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- Senator Brush has introduced a bill which is designed to allow a citizen to compel his recognition at a party primary by a mandamus.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 6. -- Presidents of eleven Western universities are holding a meeting here to-day, called by President Adams of Wisconsin University, to discuss various matters relating to those institutions, one important feature being their relations to preparatory schools, with a view to securing uniformity in the standard of requirements for admission to a university.
The message of the Governor is a Constitutional requirement, and the facts and recommendations herein submitted are in compliance therewith.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- In the Woodlawn Police Station of this city are five young members of a gang of bank swindlers and forgers who have operated for years. A score of Chicago citizens and several banks here, as well as in St. Louis, Pittsburg, Cincinnati, and Burlington, Iowa, have lost about $100,000 in the last year.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Jan. 6. -- Information of the most mysterious lynching that has occurred in this State since the death of the notorious "Leon Lyncher" reached here from Orangeburg Court House tonight.

As the principal reason given by the Consolidation Commission's Committee on Draft for providing in the Greater New York Charter for a Police Board of four members is the absolutely false one that the Constitution requires a board charged with police duties in connection with elections "to be composed of equal representation of the two dominant political parties," it is worth while to point out that the committee has not provided for any such board.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 6. -- A report sent out from Albany, N.Y., on Friday to the effect that a receiver had been appointed for the Milburn Wagon Company of this city was wholly without foundation. F.D. Suydam, Secretary of the company, said to-day that the facts in the matter were that the firm had some difficulty with J.D. Leeson Co. of Albany, in which concern the Milburn Company had an interest.

Dr. Rudolph T. Knoll of Vienna, African explorer and scientist, is staying in this city for a short time, preparatory to his departure for Sarawak, in the Island of Borneo, whither he goes in the interest of several European geographical societies to conduct a series of investigations into the lower strata of animal life peculiar to those regions.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- The centennial of the establishment of the State capital at Albany was appropriately celebrated to-day.

The Board of Managers of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company met yesterday to pass on the rate of dividend for 1897. Those present were James Roosevelt, Robert M. Olyphant, William H. Tillinghast, Alfred Van Santvoord, James A. Roosevelt, Alexander E. Orr, James W. Alexander, James R. Taylor. Benjamin Brewster, and Horace G. Young. The absentees were Cornelius Vanderbilt, Chauncey M. Depew, and John A. Stewart.

A committee of the New York Yacht Club appointed at the recent special meeting is considering the advisability of the club's taking the initiative in the formation of a yacht racing league. The advocates of the league have brought the matter before the New York Yacht Club because that is the oldest and best-known yachting organization in the country.

There are on exhibition at the Avery Art Galleries, 268 Fifth Avenue, two of the largest and most important examples, and probably the most important example, respectively, of those great masters of the Barbizon school, Rousseau and Diaz, which have ever been seen in this country.

BOSTON, Jan. 7. -- Gov. Roger Wolcott's address to the Legislature, after his inauguration to-day, is a document of a non-committal character throughout, and more devoted to a recital of incidents of the past than to recommendations for the future.

SUMTER, S.C., Jan. 7. -- Simon Cooper, a negro, murdered five persons at Lynchburg this morning. He is the same man who, at a colored emancipation celebration at Magnolia, Jan. 1, killed a colored man, and when a party of negroes attempted to arrest him, shot and severly wounded five of the party, and then made his escape.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Several memorials were presented by Mr. Cullom (Rep., Ill.,) in favor of the recognition of Cuban independence, and one, from the Commercial Club of Chicago, indorsing the policy of the Administration regarding Cuba.

The Rev. James L. Barton of Boston, a former missionary to Turkey, and the present secretary of the American Board of Foreign Missions, spoke last night at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, in West Forty-eighth Street, on mission work in Turkey. The meeting was under the auspices of the Evangelical Alliance. Dr. Barton, in the course of his remarks, made substantially this statement:

The German Liederkranz of New York celebrated its fiftieth anniversary last night at Carnegie Music Hall with a festival concert, under the direction of Heinrich Zoellner, in which the male chorus of the Liederkranz, the Metropolitan Permanent Orchestra, Miss Lillian Blauvelt, soprano; Miss Helene Bartenwerffer, soprano, and, Mr. Rafael Joseffy, pianist, took part.

-- BERNARD SHAW, whose other name is Irreverence, says that IRVING as Richard III, wooes Lady Anne "as if he were a Hounsditch salesman cheating a factory girl over a pair of second-hand stockings." This is certainly an illustration that illustrates, but perhaps there is a little doubt whether it throws light on IRVING'S acting or on Mr. SHAW'S unending effort to live up to his "Anything to give pain."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The debate upon the proposition to refund the indebteaness of the Pacific railroad companies to the Government was begun in the House to-day under an order adopted last month which set apart the rest of this week for that purpose.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- Speaker Reed gives no intimation when he will fill the Democratic vacancy on the Ways and Means Committee caused by the death of ex-Speaker Crisp of Georgia. The two principal aspirants for the appointment have been Mr. Newlands (Silverite) of Nevada and Mr. Swanson (Democrat) of Virginia.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- Col. William Cary Banger of Oneida County introduced in the Assembly on its opening day two bills proposing changes in the fish and game law. One relates to the killing of deer in all parts of the State except Long Island; the other proposes a change in the open season for partridge and squirrels.

At the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday the chief topic of interest was found in the resolutions which advised making haste slowly in the preparation of the Greater New York charter. A long and earnest debate resulted in the adoption of the resolutions, which advocate adoption of the resolutions which advocate a referendum.

But suppose the charter to be simply a charter providing the form of a city government, with its departments and officers and their general powers, the analogy to a Constitution and the method of dealing therewith would still fail. It has to be the work of the Legislature, and it would be subject to amendment or change at the will of that body.

Gen Russell A. Alger of Michigan is in this city on a business visit. He came East to look after a monument now being made in honor of Gov. Blair, the war Governor of Michigan, and to secure speakers for the celebration of Washington's Birthday. He will go in search of the speakers to Washington, leaving this city to-night.

It may safely be assumed that in the new Tariff bill which the Republican Party in Congress is making, there will be duties on wool. The imposition of these duties upon the manufacturers' raw material will require the tariff revisers to increase largely the duties on woolen goods.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The wool manufacturers were well represented before the Ways and Means Committee to-day.
Mr. Thomas Denny, Jr., of the Stock Exchange house of T. Denny Co. said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in discussing the bond market:

Our readers will have observed that the home of Mrs. LEASE, at Wichita, Kan., was sold under foreclosure the other day. They may remember that we called attention during the campaign to the fact that the oratrix had defaulted on her interest and inquired whether her animosity against Eastern capitalists proceeded from a special spite against the goldbug who had made her this heartless loan.

In consequence of the unwise restriction put into the State Constitution by the convention on 1894, the State Prison Commission and the Superintendent of State Prisons are at their wits' end for means of keeping convicts employed to the extent necessary for their health and good discipline, to say nothing of the cost of their maintenance and the reformatory effect of industrial habits.

The Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners gave a hearing yesterday afternoon to property owners, or representatives, along the proposed route of the underground road from the City Hall to the Battery. At a meeting of the board last week a plan for an underground rapid transit route was provisionally agreed upon, which contemplated an extension from the City Hall to South Ferry, with a loop around Whitehall and State Streets.

PARIS, Jan. 7. -- The marriage of Miss Edith Lyman Collins of New York to Rechid Bey, (Count Czaykowski,) an attache of the Turkish Embassy at Rome, took place in this city at 1 o'clock this afternoon in the Church of St. Germain l'Auxerrois, near the Louvre.

GOV. BLACK has raised a point as to the civil service clause of the Constitution which he will find great trouble in sustaining. The Governor's office compels us to treat his suggestions with a certain degree of seriousness, though they are in themselves worthless or mischievous, and are expressed in a style at once flippant, impertinent, and vulgar.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- A favorable report was made to-day by the House Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds on the bill to erect a new Custom House in New York City.
CHICAGO, Jan, 7. -- William J. Bryan was the guest of honor and the principal speaker at the Jackson Day banquet of the Bryan Club to-night.

ALBANY, Jan. 7. -- In order to carry out the new order of things whereby the public institutions of the State are to purchase their supplies, so far as possible, of the State prisons, the Secretary of the State Prison Commission has been directed to have printed blank requisitions for such supplies to be forwarded to twenty different State institutions on Jan. 10.

J.H. Johnston Co., dealers in diamonds, jewelry, and silverware at 17 Union Square, made an assignment yesterday for the benefit of their creditors. The assignees are Arthur H. Masten of the law firm of Masten Nichols, in Wall Street, and John R. Keim, jeweler at 1,128 Broadway.
AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 7. -- Gov. Powers was inaugurated in due form this morning in joint convention of the Legislature, and delivered his address.

The Loud bill for the reform of abuses in the use of the mails for second-class matter goes to the Senate with the force of a good majority behind it, obtained after a pretty thorough debate. It ought to pass the Senate, and will do so if the interests of the whole public, and not those of special classes and enterprising citizens, be considered.

The bad feeling that has existed between Capt. Washington Willcocks of Company G, Ninth Regiment, and ex-Lieut. George D. Barnard of the same company culminated in a wordy row the other evening that some members of the Guard think may end in an affair of honor.

Senator JOHN SHERMAN does "not sympathize with the movement proposed to retire United States notes from circulation. I believe," he says, "it is easy to maintain a limited amount of these in circulation, without danger or difficulty."

The trial room at Police Headquarters was filled with a motly crowd yesterday afternoon. The fashionable man about town and the man who goes to court to keep warm were there. Most of the persons were drawn by curiosity, but a number were there in obedience to subpoenas.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 7. -- In the Supreme Court to-day, held in the Court House in this city, Judge Edwards presiding, the jury in the case of Homer Burger against John Quincy Adams Ward and Elmer F. Van Wagenen found a verdict for $300 damages in favor of the plaintiff.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 7. -- A dispatch from Key West says that Gen. Gomez has begun the work of reprisal against the Spaniards. In an attack upon the central trocha near Moron, he captured the Spanish garrison of Jago Avile, with 114 men.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 7. -- Although the steam tug Dauntless is in custody of an officer of the revenue cutter Boutwell, as a result of her last trip, from which she returned Monday night, her owner, W.A. Bisbee, this morning applied for clearance papers for the steamer to go to Nuevitas, Cuba, with a cargo of arms and ammunition.

Henry D. Purroy sent a letter to the Tammany Executive Committee yesterday declining to attend its meeting, which was held in the afternoon in the Wigwam. It was received by Chairman James J. Martin, to whom it was handed by ex-Assemblyman Marvin, one of Mr. Purroy's friends, but it was not read to the committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- "I am too old to go into the Cabinet." Such was the summary way the venerable Senator Sherman disposed of the report in the dispatches last night that he was to be Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7. -- The State Department has secured from its diplomatic officers at the European capitals and from the Minister at Honolulu the qualifications necessary for American dentists to practice in those countries. In Austria-Hungary there is only one so-called American dentist practicing, and he received a special permit from the Emperor after renouncing his American citizenship and becoming naturalized in Austria.

The domestic manufacturers of tin plate will ask the Ways and Means Committee, it is announced, for an increase of the present duty, which is 51.86 per cent., and we hear that the majority members of the committee are disposed to make a considerable addition. Several of our Republican contemporaries are saying that the duty ought to be higher.

On Saturday evening next there will be enacted in the chapel of one of our Harlem churches a strange scene. It will recall to some minds that day in the history of Notre Dame de Paris when a ballet dancer was set up in the sanctuary to be worshipped as the goddess of beauty.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 7. -- The first annual message of Gov. Pingree was presented to the Legislature to-day. The Governor suggests that the reforms which he proposes to exploit should begin with reform of primary elections. He believes that conventions of political parties should be abolished, and suggests a system whereby a direct vote of the ballot holder for party candidates should be permitted.

The committee from the National Guard who have charge of next week's military tournament in Madison Square Garden held a meeting yesterday in the Second Battery Armory, Thirty-fourth Street and Park Avenue.

It is a common belief in these days that some of the great moneyed corporations of this city contribute large sums every year, directly or indirectly, to influence the action of the Legislature. It is said that in former times some of them employed agents in the lobbies of the Capitol to "look after their interests "; that is, to promote legislation for their benefit or protection, and to prevent that which would injure them.

Frederick Soulhack Co. have sold for Samuel A. Wood the old five-story business structure 598 Broadway, running through 10 Crosby Street, 27.6 by 200 feet, at $175,000, to Henry Corn, who purposes erecting a modern twelve-story mercantile building on the site.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 7. -- Frederick Bauman, alias Wilson, a prisoner confined in the county jail, charged with forgery and obtaining goods by false pretenses, says he was concerned in the death of Frank P. Arbuckle of Denver in New York Nov. 19, and that Arbuckle was murdered. He gives no reason for confessing the crime further than that he wants to make known his part in it.

August Belmont will ship by the Atlantic Transport Line steamship Manitoba to England Saturday seven race horses. It is not his intention to make an invasion upon the English tracks, but to enter them in favorable races, provided they attain good condition after their arrival and under the training of John Watson, who has handled some of Mr. Belmont's horses in England before.

The Greater New York Commission heard arguments yesterday in the Aldermanic Chamber on that portion of the charter which relates to the powers of the Mayor, and the question of municipal civil service. On the latter subject no discussion took place, Carl Schurz of the Civil Service Reform Association anouncing himself as prepared to defend the work of the Draft Committee in case any one came there to attack it.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 7. -- Senator Vest undoubtedly will be renominated by the Democrats in joint caucus to-morrow night. No opposition has developed. A nomination will be equivalent to an election.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 7. -- Fair weather and track nearly again dry marked to-day's sport. The attendance was larger, and the racing spirited, with four favorites winning. In the last race Trixie nearly fell to her knees and unseated her jockey, but no harm was done.

It may safely be said that no trade journal has ever made a more complete, instructive, and helpful review of the industries in its chosen field at the close of a year than is set before its readers by The Tradesman, of Chattanooga, in its eighteenth "Annual," published on the 1st inst. And The Tradesman's field is a broad one, including all the prominent Southern industries.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter of the Tabernacle Baptist Church emerged victorious yesterday from the troubles that have embarrassed him since Saturday, when the Baptist City Mission Society surrounded his domicile with sentinels with the purpose of compelling him to vacate.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 7. -- Major McKinley removed to-day from M.A. Hanna's suburban residence to the home of another friend, Myron T. Herrick, who lives in the heart of the residence portion of the city. Major and Mrs. McKinley will remain at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Herrick till Monday morning, when they will return to Canton to stay till March 1, when they expect to leave for Washington.

The Republican leaders of Kings County are still at sea over the selection of a Chairman for the General Committee. The withdrawal if Silas B. Dutcher has caused more trouble than the leaders thought possible. The decided declination of Gen. Stewart L. Woodford has further complicated the situation.

I was particularly interested in your article in the Saturday Review of Books and Art of Jan. 2, on the works of Gilbert Stuart in Europe. You said that "while visiting Paris and Dublin Stuart undoubtedly painted portraits, and to find them to-day would be well worth while." One of them, at least, may be seen at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in your city.

We have seldom seen a more beautiful modern book than the one adorned by Will Bradley's cover, and printed by John Lane of the Bodley Head. And in some respects the text is harmonious with the cover and paper and typography; but not in all. We had almost forgotten Mr. Nordau, and were lapsing into the easy belief that recent literature was pretty decent stuff.

Railroad circles have of late been agitated by rumors of war against the Baltimore and Ohio Road on charges of rate cutting. There has been a great deal of talk regarding the matter, and it has been freely declared that the new management of the Baltimore and Ohio is ignoring established rate schedules in its efforts to get increased soft-coal tonnage.

From "Margaret Oglivie," J.M. Barrie. "But you should have heard my mother on clubs. Often have I heard her on them. 'Thirty pounds is what he will have to pay the first year, and 10 a year after that.' 'But the difficulty is in becoming a member; they are very particular about whom they elect, and I dare say I shall not get in.'

Of late years boys have been heard to say that Washington was "no good," and they didn't care to hear about him; and in this irreverent age they said this thing and lived. Now, the trouble is not that they had heard too much about Washington, but that they had heard about him in the wrong way. The inevitable reaction that keeps the balance in literature as in everything else has at last set in.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Ways and Means Committee to-day listened to statements by representatives of the earthenware, glassware, marble and stone industries.

The effort to "place" Walt Whitman in his proper relation to English literature is continued with unabated zeal, but with no present prospect of a satisfactory solution of the problems that must be solved before the exact standing of Whitman as a poet can be decided upon. The two latest contributions to the already large and bewildering library of Whitman books are both interesting and relatively important.

Berlin Dispatch to The London Standard. One of the most valuable and imperishable of the late Gustav Freytag's works is his "Bilder aus der Deutschen Vergangenheit," (Pictures from Germany's Past.) In writing it he gradually gathered a unique collection of works bearing on the history of civilization in the Fatherland, and he kept adding to this collection to the last.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Upon request of Mr. Turner (Dem., Ga.,) a resolution was agreed to instructing the Attorney General to add to his last annual report full copies of all correspondence and telegrams between the department and public officers and all persons relative to the railroad strike in Chicago in 1894 and the action of the Government in suppressing the same.

He made very few comments upon the stirring events which were crowding so closely upon one another until the reports came in regarding the prisoners. When the large numbers captured were announced, he said, with the first trace of animation he had shown, "That's the kind of news I like to hear. I had hoped that a bold dash at daylight would secure a large number of prisoners. Hancock is doing well."

When with all that solemnity which supposably accompanies a royal proclamation, her Majesty, Queen Victoria, admonished her subjects that her displeasure would be incurred did they not respect the Federal blockade, certain English people paid not the least respect to the admonition.

Kent's Cavern, near Torquay, was a famous haunt of Palaeolithic man and extinct animals. It has been thoroughly explored. It was at one time occupied by hyenas, lions, bears, and the formidable sabre-toothed tiger, (machairadus.) A certain deposit here known as the "black band" marks the place where man used to light his fires and cook his food.

Another notable book sale will take place, beginning Jan. 18 and concluding on the 22d, when Messrs. Bangs Co. will dispose of the remainder of the library of the late Henry F. Sewall. There are about 1,300 items in the catalogue, and many are of exceeding rarity. The collection is remarkably rich in old English literature and rare editions of the dramatists, poets, and essayists.

The book trade was recently surprised to hear that on Dec. 22 the body of Oscar M. Dunham, for many years the manager of the American branch of Cassell Co. of London, and later President of the Cassell Publishing Company of this city, had been brought here from the West and buried in Greenwood.
MAYFIELD, Penn., Jan. 8. -- One man was killed, two fatally and five seriously injured during a general fight with knives at a Hungarian christening last night. The victims were:

RUTLAND, Ill., Jan. 8. -- The strike at the Hakes mine here has assumed an ugly phase. Soldiers are on guard, and for the first time in a number of years active service in January has fallen to the lot of the Illinois National Guard. The guard is composed of sixteen men of Company C, Third Infantry, Lieut. Harden commanding, under the direction of the Sheriff.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- A mortgage for $1,500,000 given by the Terminal Railroad Company and the Michigan Central Railroad to Edward B. Wesley and William Emlen Roosevelt was filed to-day with Receiving Clerk Cochrane of the Recorder's office. The money was borrowed by the Michigan Central, which uses the tracks of the Terminal Road, to complete the construction of a new branch of the Terminal.

SUMTER, S.C., Jan. 8. -- Simon Cooper, the negro desperado, was shot dead by a posse of deputies this morning. Cooper, on Wednesday and Thursday, killed six persons and wounded as many more with his rifle, creating a veritable reign of terror in the neighborhood.

"With coal," Jevons writes, "any feat is possible or easy; without it, we are thrown back into the laborious poverty of early times." Dwelling on the mineral fuel in common use and the idea that the time may come in the future when there may be a deficiency of coal, the want of it will not be so severely felt to-morrow as it would have been yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- The Michigan Central is now the only Vanderbilt road in the Central Passenger Committee territory which is not a party to the interchangeable five-thousand-mile-ticket agreement. This road fears that by selling such tickets it could be forced by the State authorities of Michigan to sell all tickets at 2 cents a mile.

One of the probable outcomes of the strike of the drivers of the New York Cab Company will be that the company will gradually do away with horses and have horseless carriages, propelled by compressed air. An inventor has received a contract to build several such carriages for the company, and they will be ready by the 1st of April.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- It is only necessary to look at a page of The Congressional Record on any day to discover that the opponents of the Loud bill, which has just passed the House, are preparing to make a strong fight against it in the Senate.

Roger Sherman's ancestry was English, and the family belonged to Dedham of Essex County. As trade in middle-class England gave the names, the Shermans were clothiers, or what we call to-day woolen manufacturers. William M. Evarts, who had the Sherman blood in his veins, found out that there was some of the Sherman stock in Lord Rosebery.

The bills introduced by Assemblyman SANGER to prohibit the killing of deer by hounding and "jacking" and to protect other game are commendable and worthy to be enacted. We are glad to see this evidence of an intelligent regard for the preservation of one of the chief among the few remaining natural features of the Adirondack forest that make it still interesting to those who love the wilderness.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

The dinner of the Fine Arts Federation on Thursday evening was a very noteworthy and a very auspicious event. Very seldom, if ever, has there been an assemblage that has so fully represented and indeed has come so near to completely embodying the artistic interests of New York.

Britons, as has been before observed, do not know when they are whipped. The evangelical Briton dies particularly hard. After the Queen had chosen an essayist and reviewer to be Archbishop of Canterbury there was really nothing for the protestants to do except to leave the Church and go to chapel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Admiral Bunce's squadron of evolution will blockade Charleston early in February. The Admiral had a long conference with Secretary Herbert and other naval officials to-day, and as a result his plans for drills and manoeuvres, of which the rigid military blockade of Charleston, S.C., is to be the chief feature, were thoroughly approved, and all necessary arrangements for carrying out the proposed operations will at once be inaugurated.

In this present art season, which up to this time has been unusually barren of art sales, the collector or buyer of pictures who purchases for his or her own taste and not so much on account of names or schools, has found little of the opportunity which the average Winter generally affords for adding to his or her art treasures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The January of annual report of the statistician of the Agricultural Department will be out in a week or ten days. It will contain final estimates of the wheat, corn, and oat crops.

It is now practically settled that the railway fare from New York to San Francisco during the National Convention of the United Societies of Christian Endeavor, which meets in the latter city in July of this year, is to be $75. The passenger agents have been consulting for the past week, but could come to no definite conclusion owing to the non-action of the Western passenger agents.

"Napoleon met an obstinate opponent to some of his pretensions in Pope Plus VII. The Emperor, accordingly, had the Pontiff brought from Rome to Fontainebleau, and in the chateau at that place occurred the interview vivified by the poetic art of Alfred de Vigny. We are told that during that historic meeting Napoleon raged and stormed as he paced the polished floor, while Pius VII, sat in a large eagle-studded chair, attentive and calm.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 8. -- The banks of St. Paul and Minneapolis are recovering much more rapidly than was expected from the shock of the past two weeks. The assets of the Germania Bank of St. Paul have been found in excellent shape and the reorganization will be pushed with all possible speed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- There was a large sprinkling of Georgians before the House Elections Committee No. 1 this morning to hear the argument in the contested election case of Watson vs. Black, from the Tenth Georgia District. Mr. Watson was the Populist candidate for the Vice Presidency. Black has been for many years a member of the House.
SAN DIEGO, Cal., Jan. 8. -- Details of the burning to death of thirteen men in the Santa Gertrudia Mine, at Pachuca, State of Hidalgo, Mexico, Dec. 31, have been received here.

Various new suggestions were made to the Greater New York Commission at yesterday's hearing in the Aldermanic Council Chamber. The provisions of the proposed charter in regard to the heads of departments and their terms of office were under discussion. There was a large attendance of the general public. Advocates of longer official tenure, additional power for the Mayor over the police, and favoring an entirely new name for the greater city were heard.

The monthly meeting of the Universalist Woman's Alliance of the Metropolitan District, in the Church of the Divine Paternity, yesterday, was devoted to "Church Extension as Applied to Universalism." Mrs. Edwin C. Bolles, President of the alliance, opened the meeting, and Mrs. Charles H. Eaton presided during the discussion.

Biographies and sketches of Queen Victoria have been published without number, but the first volume dealing with her life apart from her office (since Divine right went the way it prepared for itself, are not Kings and Queens mere office holders for life?) is one just published in London by Sarah A. Tooley. Some of the anecdotes in it make interesting reading, as the following will show:

The most prosaic, the most bourgeois of all eminent French statesmen and historians, the late M. Adolphe Thiers, fought a duel when a young man with the irate father of a pretty girl whom Thiers, while anxious to marry, did not wed, because he was too poor to support her. Shots were exchanged without result, and the combatants embraced.

Dioli Giuseppa reached New York from the West yesterday morning with $2,300 and before nightfall had lost all of it but the price of a ticket to Europe. Giuseppa left his wife and six children in Italy four years ago to come to America and make his fortune. By hard work at mining and ranching in California, he got together $2,300.

A handsomely dressed woman walked up Broadway yesterday, stopping to speak to every policeman she met. She looked like a woman of wealth, and no one who noticed her could believe that she needed to ask each officer she met for directions around the city. She was not a stranger. She was making New Year's calls on members of the police force.

There can hardly be any doubt in the mind of a rational property owner or business man on or near Broadway below the Post Office as to the desirability of having the proposed underground rapid-transit line extend down that thoroughfare from the City Hall Park, if it is to run from the City Hall Park through Elm Street and Fourth Avenue up town.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 8. -- A letter written by one of the crew of the cruiser Philadelphia has been received, and tells of a disastrous fire in the cruiser's bunkers on the morning of her arrival at Callao, Peru.

Mr. Chatfield-Taylor knows his Spain. His point of view is widely removed from that of the average tourist, or, indeed, from that of any tourist whatever. He has made the country his own, its history, ancient and modern, its cities and provincial towns, above all its people, from its nobles and statesmen down -- or up -- to its peasants, whom he thinks "the redeeming feature of Spanish society."
DAKOTA CITY, Iowa, Jan. 8. -- The Supervisors of Humboldt County met to-day, and after investigation found County Treasurer J.W.S. Lindley $20,000 short in his accounts.

The January number of The Art Amateur opens for the coming year with two colored plates, "The Old Mill," by Bruce Crane, and "Violets," by Maud Stumm. For frontispiece there is an excellent print of Sir Thomas Lawrence's "Countess of Grosvenor." There are many examples of Gainsborough, Beechey, and others. In treating of china painting, the house, and pyrography, the illustrations are numerous.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- Many distinguished persons attended the funeral of Gen. Francis A. Walker at Trinity Church to-day. Although in deference to the wishes of the family there was no suggestion of a military funeral, 1,200 students of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology escorted the remains from the residence, at 237 Beacon Street, to the church.

"Saratoga," a comedy by Bronson Howard, was presented by amateurs last night, at the Central Opera House, for the benefit of the Organization Fund of the United Councils, Catholic Women's Benevolent Legion.

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- The final determination of Gov. Black to appoint George Curtis Treadwell, son of George H. Treadwell of this city, to be his military secretary was arrived at yesterday, it is said. Over this appointment there has been a fight between Mr. William Barnes, Jr., State Committeeman from this district, and Senator Myer Nussbaum.

Accurate knowledge of the characters and ideals of men is not so often to be obtained from their autobiographies and morbidly analytical "confessions" as from the unintentional and unconscious self-revelations which they sometimes make in the performance of a task in which no direct personal reference is to be found.

Longfellow's famous words, "Look not mournfully into the past, it cometh not again," can be followed with pleasure by the visitor to the art galleries, and, indeed, the rooms of the Marshall O. Roberts house, at Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street, whose pictures and sculptures, with the furnishings of the house, are to be sold during the week beginning the 18th, as was exclusively announced in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Tuesday last.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Twelve persons -- men, women, and children -- were taken violently ill Wednesday from eating fresh pork and sausage. Physicians have been in constant attendance upon the stricken persons, and have managed to save the lives of at least one-half of the number and have hopes of seeing all but two of their patients recover.

The Bureau of Incumbrances made its eighth raid since last July on the Astor House sidewalk signs yesterday, and left the walls on the Vesey Street side of the hotel bare of every sign and railing. For two hours and a half employes of the bureau were engaged in tearing down the signs and taking them to the corporation yard in Twenty-fourth Street.

Gov. David M. Clough of Minnesota in his inaugural address urged the need of a thorough revision of the general tax laws of the State, and recommended the creation of a Tax Commission or the appointment of a joint committee of the two houses to report to the next Legislature.

TOKIO, Dec. 22. -- In connection with the fears recently entertained in America lest Japan should become a serious industrial competitor of the United States, it is interesting to observe that the old problem of capital and labor is already beginning to harass Japan's manufacturing career.

LYNN, Mass., Jan. 8. -- The meaning of the experiments with explosives for the past few days along the Maine and New Hampshire coasts has been explained by the electrician who had charge of the work. He returned to Lynn this morning and said he had received good pay for his services.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- The Right Hon. and Most Rev. Frederick Temple, D.D., the recently appointed Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England, was enthroned in the cathedral at Canterbury to-day in the presence of 12 Bishops, 350 clergymen, and a large gathering of the laity.

-- A London paper announces that the Examiner of Plays has ordered the managers of theatres where pantomimes are given to permit no references of any kind to the Sultan of Turkey or to happenings in the country over which he pretends to rule. This, if true, is certainly amazing, and can well inspire Englishmen to ask whether they live in Great Britain or Russia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Public men here are, gratified at the Treasury report for December, which shows a great reduction in the volume of legal tender notes presented for redemption in gold.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The House Commerce Committee to-day reported favorably on the following bills:

The discussion in Congress of the bill for refunding the debt of the Pacific railroads to the Government on account of the maturing subsidy bonds brings out a great deal of talk about past legislation and adjudication and the management of the roads in times gone by, but this has only an incidental bearing upon the question to be decided now.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- The dead body of William Speidel, aged twenty-one years, son of Martin Speidel, a well-known conductor employed on the Erie Railroad, was found this morning in the yards of the Erie Railroad. The body was frozen stiff and bore evidence of foul play. A white handkerchief was stuffed in the mouth.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- The Lake Lines have completed the organization of their new pool and arranged to act in complete harmony with the Joint Traffic Association, subject to its direction or approval.

The January concerts of the Philharmonic Society will probably dwell long in the memories of local music lovers, because of the beauty of the programme and the enthusiasm with which it was performed. The afternoon concert took place yesterday, and was attended by an audience which quite filled Carnegie Hall.
Many Changes in the Present Civil and Criminal Courts in the Greater New York Territory -- Lawyers Only to be Appointed to the Bench in Certain Courts.

Look into "your uncle's" on the Bowery and you may often see a medal, or a decoration, or a clasp, which once on a time belonged to some brave man. These badges of honor come from all parts of the world, and are stranded in a New York pawnbroker's window. There are, however, collectors in New York, and some times prizes are found in strange places.
SING SING, N.Y., Jan. 8. -- The law against contract labor in the prisons of the State, which went into effect Jan. 1, has had the effect already of driving one convict to attempt suicide.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The Jackson Democratic Association of the district held its annual banquet this evening in Masonic Temple. The Administration was criticised for its so-called "traitorous participation" in the last campaign.
KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 8. -- Reports from the Pinar del Rio section of Cuba contradict Gen. Weyler's statements that all is calm and peaceful.

The discovery of another lost classic is announced. A papyrus manuscript has recently been acquired by the British Museum the contents of which have been found from internal evidence to be the poems of Bacchylides, the contemporary and rival of Pindar, which have hitherto been known only in fragments.

M. Henri Rochefort is positive that the Millet in the Louvre, the one whose authenticity has been questioned, is not a Millet at all. The subject represents a countrywoman (une campagnarde) nursing her child, and it is dated 1841. M. Rochefort says:

Mr. Zangwill has ready another volume on Jewish life, with the title "Dreamers of the Ghetto." Mr. Abraham Cahn's "Yekl: A Tale of the New York Ghetto," is another volume on the same topic, only it is somewhat new to learn that there is a ghetto in New York. Mr. Heinemann of London is to publish the two romances.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Members of the National Democratic Party from the ten Middle and Western States who fought under the banner of Palmer and Buckner, assembled 300 strong to-night in the banquet hall of the Auditorium Hotel to celebrate the birthday of Andrew Jackson, the victory over Bryan and free silver, and renew pledges of adherence to the Indianapolis platform.

The London Academy gives an account of Robert Louis Stevenson when he was at Saranac Lake, in the Adirondacks, during 1887-8. He was living there with Dr. E.L. Trudeau, who was both friend and physician. To Dr. Trudeau he gave a copy of all his books, and on them wrote impromptu verses in amusing doggerel.

David M. Talmage, once a prominent resident of Brooklyn and formerly United States Minister to Venezuela, according to a dispatch received here yesterday from Wahpeton is suing his wife for divorce on the ground that she deserted him in 1883.

The testimony of the second day in the trial, at Police Headquarters, of Capt. Chapman, charged with unlawfully interrupting the Seeley dinner at Sherry's, Dec. 19, was listened to by a crowd that filled the room to its capacity.

The fact that Senator WOLCOTT of Colorado has just been sent abroad by the President-elect as an ambassador most extraordinary to bring Europe to bimetallism is evidence that the gold standard is still concealing its blessings from the American people. If the gold standard is the standard of civilization, why should we risk a return to barbarism by chasing after international bimetallism?

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Little by little the real history of the National Bank of Illinois failure is coming to light. It becomes more and more evident that the real Mephistopheles in the long-drawn-out drama was not William A. Hammond, who committed suicide.
Mayor Wurster of Brooklyn Receives the Report of the Atlantic Avenue Improvement Commission -- Long Island Railroad Will Co-operate.

With two editions of Byron about to make their appearance -- editions in the sense that they contain new matter and have had important editorial handling -it would seem clear enough that a revival of interest in Byron is upon us. There can be no question that interest in this poet has declined in marked degree within the past quarter of a century.
Mr. Jesse C. Bennett has sold for Joseph Lawrence, to an investor, the five-story brick flat 88 West One Hundred and Third Street, 20 by 87 by 102.

WILLIAM C. WHITNEY, having in his possession the fairy wand of the present day -- active, energetic, progressive brains -- has transformed a mountain top. He did it in a few short weeks, that his son, Harry Payne Whitney, and his son's young bride, formerly Miss Gertrude Vanderbilt, might have a charming place in which to spend their honeymoon.

AT the time of the dedication, St. Thomas's Day, of the memorial given to St. Thomas's Church in memory of the late Rev. William Ferdinand Morgan, D.D., THE TIMES was enabled to give a description of the work, but was unable, owing to the extensive Christmas decorations in the building, to obtain a good photograph from which to make a half-tone illustration.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- The battle between the Trustees of the village of New Brighton and the State Island Electric Railroad Company, came before Justice Barnard, at Special Term, to-day, on the hearing of a preliminary injunction.

A week that began well with the first large ball at a private house of the season, did not keep up its promise, and notwithstanding three crowded opera nights and one or two subscription dances, with a few dinners and weddings, it closed last night without having made a red-letter mark upon the social calendar of the season.

Property owners on One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street, between Third and Vanderbilt Avenues, are up in arms against the city authorities. The trouble is over the widening and changing of grade of the street. First, the fences and stoops which remained within the prescribed line, five feet being taken off the property on either side of the street, were sold, and many stoops and fences disappeared.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Sherman for Secretary of State, Goff for Attorney General, Bliss for Secretary of the Navy, and Payne for Postmaster General, are the men talked about to-night as likely to fill some of the places in President McKinley's Cabinet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- A most extraordinary condition of things existed in the House to-day. Under a resolution passed at the Friday night session, when the lack of a quorum led the majority of members present to order the arrest of delinquents and their production on Tuesday next before the bar of the House, 242 members were to-day presumably in contempt and subject to arrest by the Sergeant at Arms.

The feeling aroused against the Board of Education for having selected a school site in Fifth Avenue, between One Hundred and Tweny-ninth and One Hundred and Thirtieth Streets, was expressed at a mass meeting of citizens and property owners, held last evening in the basement of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, One Hundred and Twenty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue. There were fully 500 persons present.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 9. -- Gen. Simon B. Buckner presided over a conference of the leaders of the National Democratic Party in attendance at last night's banquet, which was called to order this afternoon in the Auditorium Hotel by Franklin MacVeagh of Chicago. A call of States brought responses from seventy-five representatives from Missouri, Nebraska, Wisconsin, Iowa, Illinois, Minnesota, and Michigan.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 9. -- Gov.
