Griggs's message, which will be submitted to the Legislature Tuesday, promises to be an interesting one, because he will discuss a number of important subjects with characteristic frankness. This will be his first annual message to the Legislature, and the first document from him discussing State matters.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Within three weeks Cecil Rhodes will land in England, and it is already apparent that his arrival will mark the beginning of another period of deep popular concern about the South African problem. When he was last here the public was too confused concerning the merits of the recent disturbance to know just how to treat Rhodes.

ARTHUR SCHOPENHAUER did Wagner some harm, it must be admitted; for it is to the influence of his philosophy upon the master's mind that we owe the long passage of metaphysical hairsplitting in the great love duet of "Tristan und Isolde." But, on the other hand, Schopenhauer gave to Wagner one of his noblest conceptions of the scope of his art.

Among the "gas bills" to be introduced in the Legislature this week is one in the hands of Assemblyman ABELL of Brooklyn establishing a State Gas Commission, which, Mr. ABELL says, "shall have over the gas companies of the State the same jurisdiction as is exercised now by the Railroad Commission over the railroads."

To the woman who loves beautiful jewels as well as beautiful gowns, "The American Beauty" will be a joy forever. The play gives an opportunity for an unlimited display of jewels, and as the American Beauty Miss Russell wears many of hers, and they are beautiful.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 9. -- A comparatively quiet week has followed the holiday gayety at this resort. The snow is gone, so that impatient golfers and wheelmen may enjoy their favorite pastimes. Golf devotees did not wait for the snow to entirely disappear, and a number went over to the Country Club links last Friday to play for the cup presented by James Converse.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The hearing to-day before the Ways and Means Committee was devoted to iron and lead ores, metals, and manufactures thereof.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 9. -- The San Juan County Bank of Aztec, N.M., has been closed by the officers of that institution, owing to poor business. Depositors will be paid through the Smelter City Bank of Durango, Col.

At the hearing on the charter before the Greater New York Commission yesterday, Seth Low presided in the absence of Gen. Tracy. There were present Commissioners Gilroy, Pinney, Gleason, De Witt, Dutcher, Strong, and Moore. The principal addresses were by Erastus Wiman, Edward M. Grout, Alfred B. Cruikshank, and Albert E. Henschel.

After several weeks of unwonted activity, there will be a lull in theatrical affairs this week. Only one new play will be acted to-morrow night, instead of five or six, as has been the case Mondays hitherto. The new play is "Heartsease." It is a romantic drama in four acts, written by Joseph I.C. Clarke and Charles Klein.

A handicap fencing tournament took place last night in the Fencers Club, 37 West Twenty-second Street, for the purpose of making up the teams to represent the club in league competitions. Many ladies were among the spectators present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Thirty-five years ago last month this Nation was in the throes of a great excitment. The election of Abraham Lincoln had taken place, he was soon to be inaugurated, and the South, fearing that the new Administration would prove prejudicial to the slaveholding interests, was working up to the secession movement.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- The announcement that President George B. Roberts of the Pennsylvania Railroad would decline a re-election was denied to-day at the offices of the company.

GLASGOW, Dec. 30. -- The American millionaires who have been getting floating palaces built on the Clyde, it is rumored, have not been an unmixed blessing. Some very sensational stories are afloat as to the many thousands of pounds Clyde shipbuilders have lost through their contracts to build the floating palaces already launched for American owners.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- A wholesale poisoning of dogs has occurred here. The latest report gives the number dead at 105. Nearly every house has lost pet. The poisoners began at the north end of the village Thursday night. They succeeded in distributing large quantities of poisoned meat.

A queer war is going on in Hoboken between Mayor Fagan and Anthony J. Volk, formerly one of the Mayor's friends and supporters. They were recently associated in the publication of a daily newspaper, but Mr. Volk drew out. He is a Republican and the Mayor a Democrat. Recently Mr. Volk announced his intention of starting a weekly newspaper to fight Mayor Fagan in his efforts to secure a renomination for Mayor.

In a year of small trade a nearer approach is made to the essential features of that trade. At high water the profile of the shore is covered, and many of the notable characteristics are concealed from view. With the receding of the tide more definite outlines are seen, and the foundations of the banks become exposed.

Living has become a high art, it might be called a science, in America. The feasts of Lucullus were entertainments in themselves. The eccentricities, rare substances, and curious combinations of viands were placed before the guests to tempt as much the eye and understanding as the palate.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 9. -- Judge Prentice of the Superior Court handed down a decision to-day dismissing the injunction suit instituted several months ago by Tax Collector Mooney restraining the Common Council from indorsing the agreement reached by the city's committee and the consolidated road for the elimination of grade crossings through this city.

The Schoolmasters' Association of New York and Vicinity met yesterday morning, in Hamilton Hall, Columbia College, with A.H. Cutler, President of the association, in the chair. The principal address was by Dr. Caskie Harrison, on "Some of Our Present Discontents."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- A bill was passed in the House confirming the erection of a bridge over the Red River at Fulton, Ark., by the Texarkana and Northern Railroad Company, and now operated by the Texarkana and Fort Smith Company.

The new gymnasium of the Pratt Institute, in Brooklyn, will be opened Tuesday evening at 8 o'clock. An address of welcome will be made by F.B. Pratt, and the pupils will give exhibitions in gymnastics. Members of the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn will assist in this feature of the entertainment. Girls of the senior class of the Pratt High School will give a Spanish dance.

We do not know what views the present Park Commissioners hold concerning the proposed extension of Riverside Drive northward by means of a viaduct across the Manhattanville hollow, and thence on to a connection with the drives and boulevards leading to Yonkers. Last Winter the approval of the Park Board was given, we believe, to the southern section of this proposed extension, as far as the Trinity Church Cemetery.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 9. -- A scheme, having for its direct object the development and untilization of machinery to be adapted to the varying needs of a coal mine, and for its ultimate object the discouragement of strikes as a means of bettering conditions, took definite shape to-day. A prominent Hocking Valley operator secured from the Secretary of State the blank forms and instructions necessary to the formation of a corporation for profit.

LONDON, Jan. 8. -- Persistent rumors have been in circulation for some time that it is the intention of Don Carlos, the pretender to the throne of Spain, to abdicate his claim in favor of his son, Don Jaime. This action is said to be due to the scandal arising from the recent elopement of Princess Elvira, Don Carlos's daughter, with a married artist.

INSURGENTS' CAMP, NEAR HAVANA, CUBA, Dec. 16, 1896. -- At dawn this morning we broke camp and have marched hard all day, only stopping two hours at noon to refresh ourselves and rest our horses. Courteous treatment has been received from all the pacificos whom we have chanced to meet, and all seemed anxious to render us every service in their power.

Dreams of territorial extension and great commercial advancement have for many a year been beckoning the public spirit of Newark to arouse itself and reclaim the adjacent marsh lands. This subject has been discussed a great many times, and from various standpoints, until a strong sentiment has been aroused in favor of the adoption of some practical plan to build up and utilize the waste acres.
Salome stood on the bridge which spanned the foaming stream, and gazed dreamily at the mountains beyond, and then at the meadows.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- The Dime Savings Bank, which has 4,000 depositors, and is the oldest exclusive savings bank in Chicago, will be sold or will go out of existence before the expiration of the ninety days notice which has been required of depositors since the suspension of the Atlas National Bank.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9. -- A morning paper says: "Negotiations for the formation of a powder combine are again very active. It is understood that an agreement has been reached by the Judson, California, and Giant Companies to advance the price of powder in Colorado and Montana 2 cents a pound, and not to enter into any new contracts on this coast for thirty days.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- A mortgage for $20,000,000, given by the Commercial Cable Company of New York to the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New York, was filed with Receiving Clerk Cochrane of the County Recorder's office this afternoon. The company, under the mortgage, issues coupon bonds, payable in gold and bearing 4 per cent. interest.

The record made by sales at private contract during the past week is a flattering one. The reported transactions show an increase of one-fourth over those of the first unbroken business week of 1896, and the aggregate consideration is considerably more than double the amount invested through the purchases of the same six days.

It is not a matter of immediate importance, but it is interesting to know the estimate put on the relative strength of the Spanish and American Navies by a competent authority. The Saturday Review of London is generally recognized as unusually well informed and careful on such points.

The first business week of the new year has made plain little that is new. On the Stock Exchange there is virtual stagnation. And Wall Street apathy seems closely to reflect the situation and disposition of the business world generally. The public is waiting.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9. -- Mrs. Charles Bouchzin of 47 Clark Street was attacked by two highwaymen at Kinzie and West Water Streets last night, assaulted and dragged from the cab in which she was riding and robbed.

The annual banquet of the Lotos Club was given last night in honor of Gen. Horace Porter. At the guest table with Gen. Porter were Gens. Benjamin F. Tracy, Thomas H. Ruger, D.E. Sickles, Stewart L. Woodford, Martin T. McMahon, Thomas L. James, and Anson G. McCook, and Elihu Root, Abram S. Hewitt, Charles Emory Smith, A.R. Lawrence, Walter C. Gilson, Dr. D.B. St. J. Roosa, Chester S. Lord, and the Rev. Dr. Henry Vandyke.

Mme. Melba has a record. She has been "indisposed" six times in the course of the current season. It is generally believed that this score has not been beaten by any colorature soprano of the present generation. She was invisible again yesterday afternoon, when she was to have sung Violetta, in "La Traviata," for the second time.
" I have more parcels to be sent," said a customer in one of the big department stores; "I suppose you will want to get them all together into one package."

Inspector Thompson signalized the opening of the third day of the Chapman hearing by excluding from the trial room all those not having business in the room. Commissioner Grant did not arrive until nearly 10:30 o'clock, although he had suggested the night before he wished to have 9 o'clock set for the hearing.

The golfers at Lakewood are in their element again, for the snow has gone and the links can be used without the troublesome necessity of digging golf balls out of several inches of snow. The regular weekly handicaps at the Ocean County Hunt and Country Club are now being played on their regular days, and add considerable extra life to the club.
Major R. Augustine Smith, one of the best-known men in the paper trade, and well known also as a clubman, died last night at his home, 4 East Sixteenth Street, of uraemic convulsions.

A large painted sign was hung on the front wall of the Tabernacle Baptist Church, at Tenth Street and Second Avenue, yesterday morning, announcing that a service will be held this morning at the Welsh Congregational Church, 206 East Eleventh Street. The Tabernacle congregation has been denied the use of the Tabernacle since the mortgage on the edifice was foreclosed, Dec. 19, by the Baptist City Mission Society.

AMONG the illustrated books of the recent holiday season have been none more interesting than those devoted to historic lands and cities. Has not Stratford, in that charming volume of Mr. and Mrs. Ward, been shown to us as never before?
The graduation exercises of the fifth class, Baron de Hirsch Trade Schools, were held last evening in the presence of a large audience, at the school building, 225 and 227 East Ninth Street.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- The return of a number of prominent politicians to London from the various places where they spent the Christmas holidays, and the renewed activity at the several political clubs, indicate the opening of the Parliamentary session.

BERLIN, Jan. 9. -- The reassembling of the Prussian Unterhaus yesterday, after the Christmas recess, excited very little attention in any quarter. The attendance of members was small and the sitting was brief. Some little surprise was expressed, however, at the fact that so few members were present in view of the presentation of the Budget by Dr. Miquel, the Prussian Minister of Finance.

It is not yet settled who is to succeed Judge Monson as the next President of the Knickerbocker Club. The annual election will very shortly take place, and there is a strong probability of a contest over the nomination. Mr. Johnston Livingston, the present Vice President, who has served the club very acceptably for several years, is considered by many members to be the proper successor to Judge Monson.

-- Investigation of the boarding houses and restaurants in which the students of the various Boston schools get their meals has revealed that many of them are dark, unventilated, and uncleanly places, in which wretchedly prepared and badly chosen food is served at prices which, though apparently small, are really large, when considered in relation to the amount of proper nutriment that is supplied.

ALL kinds of stories are told about Jean de Reszke's age. Certain envious singers and scurrilous journals have been fond of saying that he is now fifty-six years of age. If that be true, he is a human marvel. According to Grove's Dictionary of Music and M. de Reszke himself, he was born in Warsaw on Jan. 14, 1850.

WILKES-BARRE, Penn., Jan. 9. -- An empty passenger car attached to a freight train on the Wilkes-Barre and Northern Railroad broke its coupling this afternoon near Dallas, and dashed down a heavy grade for several miles. When nearing Luzerne Borough at a crossing, and at a frightful rate of speed, it came into collision with a trolley car.
KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 9. -- News was received here to-day from the Pinar del Rio country to the effect that the Lone Star Company of Texas Rangers in the Cuban Army had again distinguished themselves.

There are two different sides to a policeman's nature, but the public sees only one. That is as it appears on the street, that of a pompous individual, more or less kindly and benevolent. As the policeman appears at Headquarters, particularly to the head of the municipal department, he is a different being -- he a very bl schoolboy before his schoolmaster, humble and submissive, and receiving a reprimand or sharp word with meekness.

As the report of ex-Inspector General McLewee, it is understood, will never be officially issued, those portions of his remarks given verbatim in this column last Sunday were eagerly read and will be of especial value. Other extracts here given, and to be given, will be found of equal value and interest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- It became necessary, a day or two ago, for the Chairman of the Committee of Arrangements for the inauguration of the next President to call at the White House and secure from President Cleveland permission to enter his front yard and construct a stand from which President McKinley will review the inaugural parade.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 9. -- To-day's Official Gazette contains a notice that the Manitoba and Pacific Railway will apply to Parliament at its coming session for a charter to build a road through the Crow Nest Pass, in British Columbia, to the Pacific coast. The Winnipeg, Duluth and Hudson Bay Railroad has applied for a charter to construct a railway from the south boundary line of Manitoba to Winnipeg, and thence to Hudson Bay.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 9. -- Major McKinley had many callers from many parts of the country to-day, and conferred with a number of prominent Republicans.

Sorosis, at her regular monthly meeting last Monday, talked of the home life. One of her speakers was Dr. Catherine G. Townsend. Dr. Townsend sounded several notes of warning against dangers threatening the home life, and one of these was against the use of narcotics.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- Nearly 100 offices are to be filled by appointment before the two branches of the Legislature will be thoroughly organized and ready for business. They are the positions of assistants to the clerks, the minor clerkships and deputies, clerks to committees, messengers, and the like.

Several cities in Connecticut which discharge their sewage into rivers have been warned by recent decisions of the courts that they must dispose of their waste in some other way. One of them has applied to the Legislature for permission to construct a sewer, thirty miles long, to Long Island Sound.

Assemblyman Henry A. Abell of Kings County announced yesterday that he would introduce a bill soon providing for the creation of a State gas commission. The provisions of the bill are of such a nature as to indicate that its purpose is to checkmate the efforts of the Gas Committee of the Board of Aldermen to secure legislative authority to investigate the New York gas companies.

HIGHLAND, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- The outlook for a peach crop in the Southern Ulster fruit belt for the coming year is much improved as compared with the record of twelve months ago. At that time it was predicted by the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES that there would not be over a dozen baskets of peaches harvested during the year 1896 in the Southern Ulster fruit belt.

BOSTON, Jan. 10. -- George F. Washburn, who was Chairman of the Chicago branch of the Populist Executive Committee in the Presidential campaign, has issued an appeal to the Populists of the country. He wants the People's Party in the future to act as an independent party. He believes if the Populists remain mere camp followers of another party, their own party will be disintegrated. In the course of his appeal, he says further:
Prof. Felix Adler delivered an address before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Hall yesterday upon the subject of "The New Place of Woman in Modern Society."

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 10. -- Nebraska's eight Presidential Electors, elected on the Bryan and Sewall-Watson fusion ticket, met yesterday at the State Capitol, and organized by electing a Chairman and Secretary.

HALIFAX, Jan. 10. -- An unknown ocean steamer has been sending up signals of distress off White Head, 100 miles east of Halifax. When first observed, darkness was coming on, and she was about seven miles distant, showing a flag calling for assistance, and seemed to be running in a westerly course, keeping off shore. After dark she discharged a number of sky rockets.

The service of the Tabernacle Baptist Church Society was held at the little Welsh Church at 206 East Eleventh Street yesterday morning. There was a good-sized congregation, composed mainly of members of the Tabernacle Church, with the young people predominating.

If this week in any way duplicates the transactions of last week. Wall Street will have to confine its current interest to about half a dozen stocks. More than that number of shares last week changed quotations, but few more were in any sense even fairly active.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The Presidential, Electors of this State will meet to-morrow, under the requirement of a Federal law of Feb. 3, 1887, and cast their votes for President and Vice President of the United States. The Senate last week authorized the use of the chamber in which it sits for the purpose.

ALBANY, Jan. 10. -- The Republican machine leaders are making a struggle to secure the support of every one of their vast majority in the two houses for ex-Senator Thomas C. Platt for the next United States Senator. With an overwhelming majority of the 150 "regulars" pledged to Mr. Platt, there is an evident attempt to make the vote for him unanimous.

The decision of the District Attorney that all the offices within his department except those of the assistants whose relations to him are intimately confidential shall be filled by competitive examination is highly creditable to him. We understand that he has taken this course because his study of the Constitution and its interpretation by the courts, including the Court of Appeals, has convinced him that it is his duty to take it.

In a review of the financial prospects with which the new year begins, The London Statist (just received here) admits, but with an ill grace, that at last there are signs of industrial and business revival in the United States. Judging from the tone of British comment of the past few years, any commendation of America's financial prospects, however reluctantly given, is a decided change.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 10. -- Major McKinley will leave for Canton to-morrow, and expects to remain there till the 1st of March.

Troop F, Third United States Cavalry, arrived at the Grand Central Station yesterday morning shortly before 9 o'clock. The troopers, who came from Fort Ethan Allen, were accompanied by the Twenty-first Infantry Band from Plattsburg, N.Y. A crowd of over 2,000 citizens met them, including the members of the Executive Committee of the military tournament, to be held this week in Madison Square Garden.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 10. -- Gov. Drake must commission John R. Prime as Brigadier in command of the First Brigade of the Iowa National Guard or answer for contempt of court. In case he is brought up for contempt, the Governor's attorney has stated that he will pardon himself, and the interesting spectacle will be presented of the executive and judicial departments in direct conflict with each other.
Gov. Ramsdell of New Hampshire recommended in his inaugural address that Fast Day be abolished as an annual holiday. It has become too much of a sporting day.
MADRID, Jan. 10. -- The popular impatience with the Government because of the failure to suppress the rebellions in Cuba and the Philippine Islands is daily increasing.

PARK RIDGE, N.J., Jan. 10. -- Justice William B. Smith's office in this place was crowded last night with citizens who were anxious to get a glimpse of the noted Rawson twins, Albert and Alpheus, who were arrested by Constable Charles Duryea charged with crimes enough to send them to State prison for more than twenty years.
It is refreshing to find an avowed bear above cheap tricks -- and, apropos, here is a paragraph from The Boston Commercial Bulletin's financial review:

It is plainly intimated from Washington that if the bill for refunding the debt of the Pacific railroads on account of the Government subsidy bonds should pass the House it will be "talked to death" in the Senate. There is nothing surprising in this. The Senate has largely ceased to be a legislative body.

The ice was too soft on the lake in Van Cortlandt Park yesterday for skating, and thousands who had walked and wheeled up or ridden up on trains were disappointed. There was a constant stream going and coming all day long. Some of the skaters made the best of things and took a pleasant Winter walk away up to the northern end of the park to see the new herd of bison.
The Jerry McAuley Cremorne Mission celebrated yesterday the fifteenth anniversary of the establishment of the mission in its rooms, 104 West Thirty-second Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- An exclusive phalanx of 300 has been formed within Chicago's society, and into this charmed circle none may enter without the approval of the patriarchs, at the head of which is Robert Todd Lincoln. The new regime of social dictation and an absolute code was instituted at the ball given at Kinsley's on Friday evening, guised under the harmless name of an assembly.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 10. -- Fire broke out in the Richmond Block at 6 o'clock this evening and damaged the building and contents to the extent of $150,000. The building is a five-story structure at the corner of Seneca and Ellicott Streets. It is occupied by the clothing firm of Altman Co. The retail department is on the first floor, and the other four floors are used to store surplus stock.
The Central Labor Union, at its meeting yesterday, adopted resolutions favoring the appointment of a commission to inquire into the sanity of Police Magistrate Mott.

It is gratifying to learn that the annual statements of fire insurance companies indicate that they have had an unusually prosperous year. There has been such a general complaint for some years before of an unfavorable condition in the business of insuring against losses by fire and of the straits to which many companies were reduced that this comes as an agreeable change.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The legislators who hail from the "hop country," particularly the Counties of Oneida, Otsego, Schoharie, Chenango, Madison, Onondaga, and Cortland, wish to secure legislation which they believe would result in a better quality of beer in this State. The hop growers are interested in extending the home market for their product, and they have taken the initiative.
The various department reports of the New York Athletic Club have been made, and show that the organization has had a lively year.

BERLIN, Jan. 10, -- The export of German raw sugar to the United States has assumed enormous proportions in the past year. From January to November last the totals were 2,397,191 double (or meter) hundredweight, as against 473,154 in 1895, and 675,057 in 1894. The raw sugar exports to England during these periods has largely fallen off.
The following sales are set for to-day at 111 Broadway:

At the annual meeting of the patrons and members of the Hebrew Technical Institute in the Tuxedo, Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, yesterday morning, the reports of the past year's work were read and disclosed some interesting facts to friends of the institute.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Voting upon the Pacific Railroad Funding bill and amendments will occupy the House to-morrow. For the remainder of the week appropriation bills probably will have the right of way.

" All honor to Capt. Chapman," said the Rev. Dr. Carlos F. Martyn of Chicago, in his speech on "Municipal Problems," at the meeting of the American Temperance Union yesterday afternoon, in Chickering Hall.

Carnegie Hall hal the usual gathering of revivalists at the afternoon service yesterday, and every seat in the house was occupied. _Mr. MOody returned to ' the clty on Saturday from Boston, where he has been conducting .eYangelistic Work during the past week.

Gen. BUCKNER gave sensible advice to the National Democrats at their Chicago conference when he urged a thorough organization of the party and a campaign of education to gain the confidence of the people. All this will be useful. But it will not reunite the Democratic Party. That will come by occasion and opportunity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Republican leaders in the House are of the opinion to-night that the Pacific Railroad Funding bill will be defeated to-morrow.

One of the chief bull arguments of the present time, and one that is constantly being referred to in current market reviews, is the bed-rock position of stock-market prices. It is pointed out that the average quotations at the beginning of the year were very nearly the same as at the beginning of 1896.

-- London Truth says that since the Liberal Party lost its one leader with a commanding personality -- Mr. GLADSTONE, that is -- it has surpassed all Conservative precedents in hopeless, helpless imbecility. This somewhat sweeping statement is followed by the prophecy that "until we realize what utter fools we are, we shall remain in the quagmire into which our folly has precipitated us, and deservedly remain there.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10. -- Mrs. E.W. Wilson, the aged sister of C.P. Holden, one of Chicago's oldest citizens, was abducted from 26 Aberdeen Street, Tuesday, Dec. 29, and a secret search by the police ever since has failed to reveal her whereabouts. Mrs. Etta May Truesdell and Hal E. McNeil, alias Earle M. Truesdell, took her away at night, and it is alleged have since kept in hiding from the police and relatives.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 11. -- There is just a little feeling among the delegates to the monetary conference who have already arrived concerning the outcome of the meeting, whether it should result in the appointment of a National commission selected by the conference, a National commission selected by Congress, or a committee to be chosen by the body in session here this week, to act as advisers of Congress on financial matters.

The resignation of Mr. WILLIAM BROOKFIELD from the district association of the Republican organization in this city, of which he has long been a member, is said to be the prelude to a movement for a new "independent Republican organization" in opposition to the present "machine,"

ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- The Electoral College met at noon in the Senate-Chamber and was called to order by Secretary of State Palmer. Before being called to order, the Electors were photographed in a group, in front of the Lieutenant Governor's desk. The galleries were well filled with ladies.

The associated owners of the Western iron-ore mines ask Congress to restore the McKinley duty on ore, which was 75 cents per ton, the present duty being 40 cents. But under the reduced duty the imports have fallen off, the annual average for the two years of the present tariff having been $800,147, as against an annual average of $1,663,534 for the four years of higher duty under the McKinley tariff.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The tariff hearings before the Ways and Means Committee were concluded to-day, the schedules containing "sundries" and the "free list" being considered.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11. -- Two years ago the United States Government and the Premier of Canada, on behalf of the British Dominion intrusted a joint commission with the task of making exhaustive investigations to establish the practicability or impracticability of a deep waterway between the great lakes and the seaboard for ocean commerce.

Our dispatches have informed us that "an exclusive phalanx" of three hundred is now forming by natural or artificial selection out of the general mass of the population of Chicago, and that when formed it would constitute "society" in the esoteric sense. It was in this sense that the late WARD MCALLISTER said there were only four hundred New Yorkers "in society."

Sheriff Buttling said yesterday that Jesse D. Frost of the Twenty-second Ward will be chosen Chairman of the Republican General Committee of Kings County, which meets to-night. This selection caused surprise to the Republicans of Brooklyn. Sheriff Buttling said last night that Mr. Frost had held several offices of importance in the ward organization.
Riker Son have sold to H.B. Anderson, at about $38,000, the four-story brownstone dwelling 11 East Fifty-seventh Street, 20 by 100.

Taxpayers were at liberty yesterday to exercise their annual privilege of criticising the work of the Tax Commissioners in placing a valuation on such of their taxable property as is within the limits of this city. Since the first Monday in September about twenty Deputy Commissioners have been busy with their appraisals of the real property, while a separate corps have devoted their attention to placing valuations on personal property.

-- It is getting wearisome to record the vagaries of the Populistic mind as developed in Kansas. Hitherto a tendency toward the repudiation of honest debts has been the most notable characteristic of the party in that State, but now that it has attained to power the effort seems to be toward making the name of Kansas ridiculous.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- Severe and indignant criticism has been heard to-day at the Capitol and State Department upon the publication of a letter written by Senator-elect Money, now a Representative from the State of Mississippi, relating his recent experiences in Cuba, and giving to the public a message said to have been sent from Havana by Consul General Lee to Secretary of State Olney, and obviously intended only for Mr. Olney's ear.

OMAHA, Jan. 11. -- E. Ellery Anderson, one of the receivers of the Union Pacific system, in discussing the defeat of the Powers bill this afternoon, said: "Personally, I was not favorably impressed with the Powers bill. As a Washington paper termed it, the bill proposed to increase the security of the Government by increasing the amount of the prior liens against the property.

John H. Levine, known also as John Mosler, was arrested yesterday and arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court on a charge of having attempted to make a "book" on the races in the Federal Building.

The hop growers of this State are said to be desirous of having a bill passed by the Legislature to improve the quality of beer. Of course their purpose is to have hops more largely used instead of cheap substitutes, but the object is a good one apart from the benefit to the hop business.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 11. -- Considerable interest has been aroused lately over the carrying of bituminous coal to the East, and the railroad companies which handle this traffic have been somewhat agitated by the publication of articles in the various newspapers indicating that there was trouble to be anticipated, and that there would probably ensue a rate war.
Yale and Harvard may meet in athletic and aquatic contests this year.
Thomas F. Conkling, Superintendent of the Pinkerton Detective Agency in Kansas City, an account of whose alleged suicide was published yesterday morning, was well known in this city.
LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Commenting upon the signing of the arbitration treaty between Great Britain and the United States, The Daily News will to-morrow say:

Nearly every physician, every scientist, and every sufferer has been asking this great question: What is the Grip? Some have asserted that it is a dangerous microbe which comes into the system, breeds several millions every second, and soon overruns the body with disease. Others have said that we are passing through a region of star-dust, and that the minute particles are drawn into the body with every breath.
ALBANY, Jan. 11. -- An attempt was made to-day to secure the indorsement of the Electoral College of the candidacy of Mr. Platt for the United States Senatorship.

Whatever its shortcomings may appear on examination and discussion to be, the draft of a chapter on the public art of Greater New York, submitted yesterday on behalf of the Fine Arts Federation, has one substantial and striking merit. It embodies a distinct recognition of the truth that the aspect of a city is a subject proper for municipal care and municipal regulation.

The ardor of the friends of Joseph H. Choate was not chilled yesterday by reports from Albany that in the Republican caucus Mr. Choate would have only one vote, while Thomas C. Platt would receive 150.

A brilliant dance and dinner was given by Mrs. Henry Sloane in her new house, 9 East Seventy-second Street, last evening. The house was profusely decorated with palms, crushed baskets of American Beauty roses, growing plants, and lilies and orchids.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- A dispatch from Bonny, on the coast of Upper Guinea, reports the massacre of all the members of a peaceable British expedition which left the coast about Jan. 11, intending to proceed to Benin City, on the Benin River, by way of Sapele.

HAVANA, Jan. 11. -- Gen. Bosch reports that on Jan. 9 the columns of Spanish troops under command of Gens. Ferrer and Rey engaged in two encounters with the rebels at Jacobaina and Manzanille, in which the troops lost one man killed and thirty-four wounded, including a Major, Gen. Rey's Adjutant.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 11. -- Gov. Tanner will make a public declaration in favor of the candidacy of Alderman Martin B. Madden for United States Senator to-morrow, or Wednesday at the latest. The Governor is going to do this without solicitation on the part of the Cook County machine and as a measure of defiance to the forces that are endeavoring to drive him to oppose the machine candidate.

Henry Miller is again a "star" actor. The term means less nowadays than it used to, when most of the available histrionic talent was concentrated in stock companies; but it means a percentage of the receipts, and that, in this commercial era, is enough to lend a "star" actor distinction, if the receipts are large.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The Chronicle, which has vigorously and persistently advocated the conclusion of an arbitration treaty by Great Britain and the United-States, will to-morrow publish the text of the treaty that has been signed at Washington.

The two factions of Baptists who are at odds over the property of the Tabernacle Corporation, at Second Avenue and Tenth Street, were well represented in court yesterday. Two suits came up for trial, in each of which the Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter, pastor of the Tabernacle Church, was the central figure.

David J. Dean, First Assistant to the Counsel of the Corporation of the City of New York, died Sunday night in San Antonio, Texas, while on the way to Arizona, where, on the advice of his physicians, he purposed spending the Winter. He had been suffering for more than five years with consumption and diabetes, and had twice sought relief at the Carlsbad baths.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 11. -- Charles Demarest died at the hospital this morning. Death was due to a fracture of the skull at the base of the brain. It was supposed until last night that there was no question of how he was injured. On Wednesday morning about 1 o'clock the young man was returning from a party.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 11. -- The first positive step in the direction of the general taxation of those properties of Yale College asserted not to be used for educational purposes was taken Saturday by the New Haven Assessors by the preparation of a list which includes about thirty pieces of property owned by Yale in this city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The President sent the following message to the Senate this afternoon, transmitting the Anglo-American general arbitration treaty:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The Anglo-American General Arbitration Treaty was signed in the Diplomatic Parlor of the State Department at 12:20 o'clock to-day by Secretary Olney and Sir Julian Pauncefote. The latter was accompanied by Lord Gough, Secretary of Embassy. The American witnesses were Chief of the Diplomatic Bureau Cridler and Private Secretary Blandford.

One of the most novel entertainments ever offered to New Yorkers is that which opened for a week's run in Madison Square Garden last evening. It appeals directly to the martial spirit, being a military tournament something like those held annually in London and the leading continental cities. This is the first time that anything of a like nature has been held here.

After Jacob Seabold, the Purroy leader of the Thirty-fourth Assembly District, left the Tammany organization, Thomas Lloyd and a number of members of the District General Committee remained with the organization, and it became an issue whether the "old-regulars" or the men who have been fighting for six months to oust Mr. Seabold should control the new General Committee, which is to be elected at the primary Friday night.

Referring to a recent article in THE TIMES, "Why They Want It" -- "it" meaning an additional duty on iron ores -- is it not "the dog in the manger" disposition -- is it not asking that a more favored district of the United States be protected to the injury of other portions? The Western iron-ore men certainly need no protection.

The Fire Marshal, assisted by the police, is investigating two fires of supposed incendiary origin which occurred in the cellars of two big north side tenement houses early yesterday morning. The lives of many families were imperiled, and two children were rescued, nearly suffocated, from one of the buildings.
A meeting of the New York Presbytery was held yesterday afternoon in the lecture hall of the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Chambers, Moderator, presided.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 11. -- There are many chagrined young men among the corps of cadets at the Military Academy to-night. The result of the January mental examinations was made known this afternoon, and thirty of the number were found deficient. To-night they were discharged from the academy, and a number of them immediately started for their homes.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10. -- Much interest is being manifested in the National Congress of Mothers which will assemble in this city Feb. 17.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- The general treaty of arbitration between this Government and that of Great Britain reached the Senate this afternoon, while Senator Mills was making his speech on Cuba. It was not laid before the Senate until the doors had been closed for an executive session.

The Aldermanic Council Chamber presented a livelier appearance at the hearing given by the Greater New York Commission yesterday than since the subject of police was under discussion on the Monday before. The commission heard a number of speakers on the Departments of Parks, Health, and Education. Commissioner Seth Low presided in the absence at Albany of Gen. B.F. Tracy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- A full attendance of members was evidence of the interest taken in the Pacific Railroad Funding bill, which was debated last week and upon which, under the special order, a vote was to be taken to-day immediately after the reading of the Journal.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11. -- During the routine morning business Mr. Perkins (Rep., Cal.) presented the joint resolution of the California Legislature declaring unalterable opposition to any extension of the debt of the Pacific Railroad Companies, favoring immediate collection of the debt, and asking for a hearing before the Pacific Railroad Committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- Judge Brentano this evening, upon the application of Attorney Thomas S. Hogan, issued an injunction against Leslie Carter, restraining him from taking his son, Leslie Dudley Carter, out of the State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- After the transaction of some routine business in the morning the Senate at 12:15, on motion of Mr. Sherman, (Rep., Ohio,) proceeded to the consideration of executive business.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- Secretary Carlisle has abolished the charge of S cents per package on dutiable merchandise transported in bond from one port of the United Sta,tes lo another. This charge has been made since 1575, and has been a source of many protests and. much annoyance to the department.
Prof. Harold E. Lippincott, who represents the Gas Reform Association, said yesterday that the association will take measures to aid the movement for cheaper gas at Albany.

Several members of the Westminster Kennel Club made a trip to the club grounds, at Babylon, yesterday morning to witness the pigeon match between George Work and G.S. McAlpin. It proved to be by far the best match of the season, despite the fact that a bitterly cold northwest wind swept over the traps and made it uncomfortable for spectators, and particularly hard for the shooters.
Mr. A. Littery has sold for Hagenauer Wesslau, to C. Schlosser, at $32,000, the five-story triple flat 303 West One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, 27 by 100.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 12. -- The Committee on Permanent Organization recommended the name of C. Stuart Patterson of Pennsylvania for President, and a Vice President from each State represented.
SING SING, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- James Mahoney, a prisoner in Sing Sing Prison, tried to burn himself to death in his cell at an early hour this morning.

A leading Boston banker, in conversation to-day, recognized prevailing dullness in the money market, but expressed hope that the abundance of funds and the improvement in general business, which he expected to see ere long, would supply uses for money. The stock market of New York holds out no promise of activity for the moment.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- At the tenth annual convention of the State branch of the American Federation of Labor, William F. Butts of Brooklyn submitted for the approval of the federation a bill to prevent the prisoners in the penal institutions of the State from being employed to do the printing for the State Departments and for municipal and county offices as is contemplated by the State Prison Commission.

A more than ordinarily good collection of 148 canvases, the property of Mr. Bernard Franck and other collectors, and composed for the most part of examples of modern French brushes, is now on exhibition at the Fifth Avenue Auction Rooms, 238 Fifth Avenue, where it will be sold to-morrow and Friday evenings, Jan. 14 and 15.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12. -- Within less than six weeks the new social regime in Chicago will commence its reign. The second ball of the Assembly, to be held on Feb. 19, is to decide the personnel of the new "Three Hundred." The persons who have access to the Assembly's select function, and they alone, will have the right to consider themselves members of the new Patriarchal set.

Funeral services were held yesterday morning in Grace Church for Major Augustine Smith, who died suddenly Saturday in the seventy-sixth year of his age. The Rev. Dr. W.R. Huntington, rector of the church, officiated. He was assisted by the Rev. Dr. G.F. Nelson, formerly rector of the church and now secretary to Bishop Potter.
Police Captain Chapman and Little Egypt, the dancer, were put on the stand yesterday in the investigation into the raid on the Seeley dinner at Sherry's Dec. 19.

Paul Shearer, the Brooklyn artist, arrested on Saturday for selling to Simon Joel, a self-appointed agent of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, two clam shells, upon which he had painted improper pictures, was arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday, and, on his own statement that the charge against him was true, was held in $200 bail.
The annual meeting of the American Geographical Society was held last night at Chickering Hall, Fifth Avenue and Eighteenth Street. Charles P. Daly, President of the society, presided.

Alexander P.V. Kinnan one of the members and a Dricetor of the Sullivan County Club, applied to Judge Lawrence Monday for an order restraining the club from enforcing one of its by-laws prohibiting certain members from voting for Directors and officers at the annual meeting of the stockholders held Monday afternoon.

The Draft Committee of the Greater New York Commission met yesterday in Mayor Strong's private office, and, after a long discussion, decided to revive the Board of Assessors and the Board for the Revision and Correction of Assessments. Neither of these boards was provided for in the charter, and some of their present power was vested in the Municipal Assembly.

The representations of Hernando De Soto Money, member of Congress and Senator-elect from Mississippi, as to the state of affairs in Cuba, are pronounced to be incorrect in many particulars by J.A. Wood, the architect, of 153 Broadway, who was in Cuba at the time of Mr. Money's visit, and has personally investigated the situation there.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 12. -- Seldom or never has been seen a finer-looking deliberative body than the monetary conference, which assembled to-day in Tomlinson Hall.

The Pilot Commissioners met yesterday afternoon and discussed the proposed improvements for harbor lighting suggested by the shipping agents of the port. The suggestions, with the Commissioners' report, will be forwarded to the Lighthouse Board in Washington some time next week. The Commissioners disagree with the recommendations in many essential respects.

Lilli Lehmann, the great dramatic soprano, made her first appearance in four years in this city at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, when she gave a recital of songs. When she left us, it seemed as if we were destined never again to hear the majestic peal of her organ-like voice, never again to throb under the intense emotional force of her delivery.

It would be well if in this country and in England there could be a formal and general celebration of the great event so quietly consummated in Washington on the 11th of January. Nothing in the history of the relations of the two countries in this generation is more memorable than that event is likely to be, and few things in the history of either are more characteristic of the genius of the two nations.

Approval of the treaty providing for a general arbitration of disputes between this country and Great Britain was expressed with a cordiality akin to enthusiasm by a large number of representative New Yorkers yesterday. It is seldom that an important public measure has received such prompt and unanimous commendation.
There is a row of considerable dimensions among the members of the Union League Club as a result of the club's indorsement of Joseph H. Choate for United States Senator.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 12. -- The problem of successfully casting steel after many years of experimenting and testing on the part of many men has been successfully solved by Elmer and "Burt" Whitely of Muncie, Ind., together with their father, Amos Whitely, of this city. The latter is a manufacturer and a brother of William N. Whitely, known as "the reaper king."

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 12. -- Gov. Leedy, (Pop.,) in his annual message to the Legislature to-day, touched upon the adverse criticisms of Kansas made in the East, and compared the prosperity in his State with that of the States whose people indulged in the criticisms of Kansas. He said:

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- Dispatches received at the Foreign Office this morning confirm the previous reports of the massacre by wild tribesmen in the territory of the King of Benin, of the members of a British expedition which left the coast of Upper Guinea on Jan. 1, intending to proceed to Benin, in the Niger Coast Protectorate.
One of the most brilliant subscription balls of the season was the first of the series of two Tuesday Evening Cotillions which was given in Sherry's large ballroom last evening.

The Consolidated Canal and Lake Company will not take the lease of the pier at the foot of West Fifty-fourth Street unless the Dock Board grants also the bulkhead property on the Harlem River which the company desires for the erection of free storage warehouses for flour.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 12. -- To the representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES a number of delegates to the conference expressed their opinions on the means to be adopted to secure a reform of the currency system, the recognized need for which furnished the reason for the present gathering.

A London financial newspaper predicting increasing earnings and a probable surplus for an American railroad company is a curiosity. The London Statist, however, presents such a noteworthy example. In referring to the St. Paul property, The Statist says:

Company F, Seventh Regiment, had a very entertaining and prosperous evening last night. It not only broke records in shooting for trophies, but received a handsome silver loving cup from Edward Kemp, in commemoration of his joining the company in 1858.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- One of the most interesting topics treated of in the fourth volume of the "Official Records of the Union and Confederate Navies in the War of the Rebellion," soon to be issued, is the enforced removal of the Naval Academy from Annapolis, Md., to Newport, R.I.

LONDON, Jan. 12. -- The Chronicle's Washington correspondent telegraphs that Russia has been most keenly anxious to obtain knowledge regarding the treaty of arbitration just signed by the representatives of Great Britain and the United States. He says that during the negotiations the Russian Minister to the United States asked Secretary of State Olney whether it was a treaty of offense and defense, and whether it committed the two countries to an alliance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- An excess of exports of $102,882,264 was the gratifying exhibit made by the records of the fiscal year 1895-96. A recent tabulation for the calendar year, in part official and estimated for the months of November and December, made it plain that the excess of exports would be much greater for the fiscal year 1896-97, if the tendencies shown during the calendar year were not changed.
The following letter has been addressed to a member of Congress opposing the Loud Postal Reform bill by a business man of standing:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The Republicans of the Senate held a caucus this morning for the purpose of considering the bimetallic resolution reported to it by the caucus committee, of which Mr. Wolcott of Colorado is Chairman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The House Committee on Rules to-day gave an audience to a number of Representatives and Senators, principally from the Pacific slope, who are interested in the Nicaragua Canal bill.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- The ice was in good condition for ice-yacht racing at Orange Lake to-day, but the wind blew a gale from the northwest. The boats had to race under reefed sails.

Complying with the provisions of the National Banking law, the stockholders of all National banks held their annual meetings yesterday and elected Directors for the ensuing year. Elections were also held in many State banks. There were very few changes in the Boards of Directors in this city, and none of much importance, although one was not without significance.

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- Two of Mr. Platt's lieutenants, bringing orders from headquarters for the forces which will nominate a United States Senator to succeed David B. Hill, came to this city to-night -- ex-Postmaster Cornelius Van Cott and ex-Police Justice Clarence W. Meade of New York.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- The successful transmission of electric power from Niagara Falls to Buffalo was celebrated to-night by a banquet at the Ellicott Club, which was attended by about 400 invited guests. The menu cards were elaborately gotten up, the covers being made of aluminium manufactured at Niagara Falls with the electricity developed there, and with the name of each guest engraved thereon.

There was no election yesterday of a Chairman of the Finance Committee by the Aldermen, because neither the Tammany men nor the Republicans have yet secured the necessary sixteen votes. Tammany has decided upon John T. Oakley for the place, but has only fifteen votes. Alderman Dwyer, one of the two O'Brien Democrats in the board, still refuses to vote with either side, and President Jeroloman has declined to vote with Tammany.
Mr. William L. Bull of Edward Sweet Co., ex-President of the New York Stock Exchange, in talking of stock market prospects yesterday, said to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES:
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 12. -- The evening session was called to order by Chairman Patterson at 8:20 o'clock.

GOSHEN, N.Y., Jan. 12. -- Charles Backman of Stony Ford Stock Farm has sold to A.A. Bonner of New York his entire lot of Alcantara colts, among them the four-year-old colt Camelot, out of the dam of Eloise, record 2:15, and Stevie, 2:19, by Hambletonian; and the bay filly by Alcantara, dam by Leland, sire of Geneva, 2:111/2; second dam, Integrity, the dam of Instant, 2:141/4, and Prosperity, 2:221/2 by Belmont.

It will be especially gratifying to advocates of international arbitration to find that the agreement includes "all questions in difference" between the two powers "which they may fail to adjust by diplomatic negotiation." There is no reservation, as had been reported, of matters involving territorial claims or "national honor."
BOSTON, Jan. 12. -- Revivalist Moody paid his respects to-day to the city pastors who Sunday charged him with "lowering the pulpit."

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 12. -- Commonwealth's Attorney Farrell, who went to England with Sheriff Gross to bring back Arthur Platt, murderer of Jesse Tyree in the Eastern Kentucky Lunatic Asylum here eleven years ago, to-day cabled for the deposition of Michael McGlade, Platt having refused to return without being compelled to do so by law.
ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- State Controller Roberts to-day at noon opened bids at his office for a loan of $4,000,000 in canal improvement 3 per cent. gold bonds. The following proposals were received:

ALBANY, Jan. 12. -- Louis F. Payn had a long conference with Gov. Black at the Executive Chamber to-day. It is believed here that Mr. Payn will be appointed Superintendent of Insurance, and his repeated visits to the Executive Chamber are construed to mean that he is one of the advisers on behalf of the Republican machine.
Cincinnati is an important distributing and Clearing House point. There is, consequently, interest in the following from an authority in that city:

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 12. -- At 9:15 o'clock this morning the tankhouse of the Columbia Powder Company, situated in a hollow one-half mile back from the Ohio River and midway between the boroughs of Shousetown and Shanopin, blew up. Five minutes later the storage room, in which was stored a large quantity of explosive material, was also shattered by a terrific explosion.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 12. --A tremendous crowd marked the first ladies' day of the meeting, the attendance being variously estimated at between $8,000 and 10,000 persons. Only one favorite won, and the public lost money.

The suit of the Baptist Tabernacle against John D. Rockefeller was continued yesterday before Justice Pryor in the Supreme Court. Dr. Potter, pastor of the church, testified that Mr. Rockefeller had given money to the church, securing himself by mortgages, and the church had accepted the money, believing that the mortgages would not be foreclosed.

-- Now that the ruler of Benin has allowed his subjects to murder a party of Englishmen in that little-known portion of the Niger Protectorate, he is likely soon to acquire a large amount of familiarity with England's method of instructing "natives" in the methods and habits of civilization. The Sultan of Zanzibar had a lesson of this sort not long ago, and the King of Comassie a little while before.

The American Line steamship Paris, which sails to-day for Southampton, will make the voyage with one screw, owing to the disablement of the port propeller. It was thought that the trouble was one that could be easily remedied, but an examination by the divers showed that the outboard sleeve in which the tail end of the propeller shaft rests was cracked, and a piece of it was gone.

Mayor Strong yesterday submitted his annual report to the Board of Aldermen regarding the finances of the city for the last year as furnished by the Controller. Instead of presenting a general resume of the various departments, the Mayor refers to the Corporation Counsel's office only, reserving for future messages facts concerning the other departments.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 12. -- The National Monetary Conference was called to order at 2:35 o'clock by Hugh H. Hanna, Chairman of the Executive Committee, under whose management the arrangements for the convention were made and who originated the movement culminating in the meeting to-day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12. -- The hope of those members of the House who are anxious to secure some legislation with reference to the Pacific Railroads at this session was quenched to-day by a decision of Speaker Reed.

The Hotel Association of New York City gave its eighteenth annual banquet at Delmonico's last night. It drew together nearly all the hotel men, and a large number of the Judges, politicians, and other prominent citizens, besides several well-known hotel managers of other cities.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 12. -- By a decision of the Supreme Court handed down to-day, Nathan M. Markwell, a shirt manufacturer of New York City, will regain possession of his little daughter, Fanny, for whom he has been fighting for years.

The short time that will be given by the Charter Commission to the discussion of the provisions of the charter relating to local charities at the hearing to-morrow has disappointed some of those interested in the administration of the Department of Charities.

Dr. R.W. Finley of 219 West One Hundred and Twenty-second Street received a hurry call at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and went to Quinn's livery stable, on One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, and ordered his horse and buggy. The hostler in his hurry put the wrong bridle on the doctor's horse.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The following standing committees of the Assembly for the present session were to-night appointed by speaker O'Grady:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13. -- The Board of Directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad yesterday approved the report of the operations of the company for the fiscal year ending Nov. 30, 1896. It will be presented to the stockholders at their annual meeting on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Senate today spent two hours in executive session on the motion of Mr. Sherman, Chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee. It was ordered that a vote be taken on the House Free Homestead bill at 4 o'clock to-morrow.

Much interest was manifested in yesterday's discussion, before the Greater New York Commission, of the work of the Draft Committee in regard to the subjects of boroughs, borough officers, local boards, and local improvements. Orators in plenty appeared to criticise the provisions of the charter, and the attendance was larger than at any previous hearing.

Testimony in the Chapman case was concluded yesterday. The question of whether or not the Police Captain exceeded his authority in interrupting the Seeley dinner at Sherry's, Dec. 19, now rests with the Board of Police Commissioners.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 13. -- A message received here from Washington to-night makes it reasonably certain that Senator Sherman's present intention is to accept the position of Secretary of State in Major McKinley's Cabinet.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Senator White will introduce the General Charter for cities of the second class, which was introduced last year, upon a report from a commission which drew the charter. It applies to the Cities of Rochester, Syracuse, Albany, and Troy.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 13. -Miss Cassie Haggerty, twenty-two years old, of 231 East Thirtieth Street, New York, who had been employed as a domestic by Mrs. H.S. Whiting of this village, was found dead in her cell in the village jail this morning. She was arrested by Constable Burnett last night, and a physician here said she was suffering from alcoholism.
CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- The stockholders of the North Chicago Street Railroad Company met in annual session yesterday and elected Directors for the ensuing year.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The committee announcements in the Assembly to-night contained a few surprises. The one which is most noticeable is on Gas, Electricity, and Water Supply, which attracts unusual attention because of the flood of bills for cheaper gas in New York City which will be in its hands this year. Only one New York City man is on this committee, and he is one of the minority members -- Mr. Corrigan.

It is a curious thing that the man who wrote the admirable libretti of Verdi's "Otello" and "Falstaff" should have written "Mefistofele." The two opera books which Arrigo Boito made from Shakespearean plays are notable for their compactness and symmetry, for their dramatic continuity and lucidity. "Mefistofele," on the other hand, is disjointed and episodic.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., Jan. 13. -- The Legislature met in joint session to-day and cast the formal ballot electing George C. Perkins United States Senator.

An article published in the supplement of THE TIMES a few Sundays ago relating to the thirteen historic Hamilton trees was in error in one respect. The article stated that the thirteen trees were a part of a forest, and these thirteen trees were separated and simply made to represent the thirteen States, and not planted originally by Gen. Hamilton for that purpose.

There are rumors of opposition to the ratification of the treaty of general arbitration in the Senate. We do not believe that there will be any serious opposition, first, because there is nothing to base it on, and, second, because there is nothing politically to be made by it.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 13. -- The real work of the Monetary Conference to-day began at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, when the Committee on Resolutions made its report. The morning session was taken up with the presentations of schemes for currency reform, which were sent to the Committee on Resolutions, and with five-minute speeches. In the afternoon the delegates inspected the State House.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for W.W. and T.M. Hall to a Mr. Blum the five and a half story American basement limestone front dwelling 11 East Seventy-sixth Street, 22 by 70 by 102.2. This leaves but one remaining out of a row of six.

Richard Croker attended the monthly meeting of the Tammany Central Club, on East Thirty-second Street, last night and made a speech. Almost every man at the club's meeting was an old friend of Mr. Croker's, and when he entered the room with Andrew Freedman and Jefferson M. Levy he received a most hearty greeting.
ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- The first regular night session of the Assembly was called to order by Speaker O'Grady at 8:35 o'clock.

The vote for a United States Senator to succeed Mr. HILL must be taken in the two houses of the Legislature at Albany next Tuesday, and the result must be declared in joint convention the next day. It has been the custom heretofore for the members belonging to each political party to hold a caucus on the evening before the vote and agree upon their candidate.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 13. -- The Monetary Conference has completed the work for which it assembled and has adjourned.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Union League Club members who are urging Joseph H. Choate for United States Senator have been here all day presenting Mr. Choate's claims to such Legislators as they could find. They do not claim to have made any converts, and they expect Mr. Choate will receive at most not more than five or six votes in the caucus, which will be held to-morrow night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The wheat crop of Australasia for the coming harvest is so short, according to estimates reported to the State Department by Consul Bell, at Sydney, that it will reduce that country from her position as sixth wheat-exporting nation of the globe to about the eleventh wheat-importing country.

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- The St. James's Gazette says that, although it has been the fashion in England to scoff at Secretary Olney as an amateur diplomat, he seems likely to leave a mark upon the international system of the civilized world.

Commissioner Charles Bulkley Hubbell was elected President of the Board of Education yesterday, to succeed Commissioner Robert Maclay. On Nov. 19 last, the day after Mayor Strong appointed Messrs. Speyer, Eustis, Anderson, and Greenough to succeed Commissioners Strauss, Beneville, Holt, and Meirowitz, THE TIMES announced that the progressive minority of the board had at last achieved a majority, and that Commissioner Hubbell would be its next President.
VINELAND, N.J., Jan. 13. -- Mrs. John Thompson, who for the last ten years has supposed herself a widow, learned yesterday that she had a husband living.
Mr. Thomas H. Bolmer of the Stock Exchange house of Prince Whitely said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES in discussing market conditions:

LONDON, Jan. 13. -- After the conclusion of the Cabinet meeting which was held today, Lord Salisbury received United States Ambassador Bayard, and his Lordship and Mr. Bayard congratulated one another upon the signing of the general arbitration treaty between the United States and Great Britain.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- The Senate joint resolution was adopted providing for expediting the erection of the Government Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 13. -- The New York delegates are very well pleased at the result of the conference. These are some of the expressions of approval given to-night to THE NEW YORK TIMES representative:

Andrew M. Seguine of 164 West Forty-seventh Street; a driver for the New York Cab Company; was assaulted by striking cabmen about midnight Tuesday night at the Morningside Restaurant, 306 Boulevard. He is at present confined to his home from the effects of the injuries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- In the Senate to-day, Mr. Gear introduced a new Pacific railroad bill, which provides that the Secretary of the Treasury, the Secretary of the Interior, and the Attorney General be appointed as a commission, with full power to settle the indebtedness of the bond-aided Pacific railroads upon such terms and in such manner as may be agreed upon by a majority of them and the owners of the roads.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13. -- From advices received by the Japanese Minister to-day in regard to the death of the Empress Dowager of Japan on the 11th inst., it is learned that the Empress Dowager died of lung disease after an illness of only a few days. She was the widow of Emperor Osakito, who died in 1865.

The convention of business men at Indianapolis consists of 300 delegates from all parts of the Union, but there is among them no sectional feeling and not a sign of political division. They are very solidly agreed as to the objects to be attained; what difference exists is as to the specific means for attaining it.
The foreign policy of President Cleveland was discussed at length last night at the meeting of the Nineteenth Century Club, at Sherry's.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13. -- A general message was sent out to the police to-day by Sergt. De Long of Central Headquarters instructing the officers in all parts of the city to look out for Benjamin A. Buxton, a Minneapolis man, who disappeared in this city last Saturday night. The man is a brother-in-law of Dr. E.F. Rush of Room 1,520 Masonic Temple, and was in Chicago on business.

Detectives camped in the basement office of the Broadway Insurance Company, 63 William Street, Tuesday night. Their presence was due to the litigation between one set of the company's Directors and stockholders and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company. They were there in the Hartford company's interest and to prevent the annual election in the office of Directors by the Magnus or Frelinghuysen faction.

INSURGENTS' CAMP, NEAR HAVANA, Cuba, Dec. 20. -- I have not written in my diary for several days because the Spaniards have pushed us so closely that we have had scarcely time to eat or sleep. It is one continual forced march through the day and at night we are obliged to smother our camp-fires, so one does not find much opportunity for writing.

At the annual meeting of the Board of Directors of the Mechanics and Traders' Bank, yesterday, President Ignatz Boskowitz declined a re-election, and Cashier Fernando Baltes was chosen in his stead, Mr. Baltes has been connected with the bank for thirty-two years.

Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles, United States Army, was one of the most interested of the spectators at the military tournament in Madison Square Garden last evening. He occupied a central arena box with Col. Albert A. Pope of Boston and several others. The bicycle races amused him, and he took pride in Troop F and Light Battery D, which were the only two detachments of the regular service seen in the arena.

ALBANY, Jan. 13. -- Senator McNulty to-night introduced three bills, carrying out the ideas of Edward M. Grout of Brooklyn, as expressed at a hearing before the Greater New York Commission, regarding municipal ownership and disposal of public franchises. The first bill provides:
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 13. -- The report of the Committee on Resolutions called forth an extended debate.

The subject of the general arbitration treaty between this country and Great Britain takes on an additional interest from the fact that to-day is the one hundred and thirteenth anniversary of the final ratification and promulgation of the first treaty of peace between this Republic and Great Britain.

In expressing his disapproval of the adjournment of the Legislature of Illinois to escape a farewell address from the retiring Governor, Mr. BRYAN has merely marked again his dissent from the great majority of his fellow-citizens. It was quite certain beforehand that ALTGELD was prepared to make an exhibition of malignity not only toward the Republican Party, but toward the decent people of Illinois.

While it is probable that in the new Connecticut Legislature the friends of the trolley roads now in use and of the many projected trolley lines will control a considerable majority in the House and may be able to overcome opposition in the Senate, there are indications that they will not undertake to repeal the excellent statute which forbids the joint use of a crossing at grade by trolley and steam companies.

The Tammany primaries will be held to-day. The big contest will be in the Thirty-third Assembly District, where Nicholas J. Hayes, Louis Davidson, and their friends are seeking to wrest the leadership from ex-Police Justice Burke and Civil Justice Fallon and their friends. There was almost as much excitement in the district last night as there would be on the eve of an election.

William G. Wood was a witness yesterday in the examination as to his mental condition by a commission in lunacy. He said he had from time to time disposed of all the property left to him by his father, with the exception of that held by his wife. He began to sign his wife's name to notes in 1885. He thought he had a right to do this.

Dr. Alvah H. Doty, Health Officer, of the port, returned home yesterday on the Lahn. He visited Naples, Rome, Genoa, and Egypt. He looked into the method of shipping rags from Egypt, to satisfy himself as to the efficiency of the disinfecting system there. He examined also the details of passenger detention at Naples and Genoa.

BOMBAY, Jan. 14. -- It is estimated that over 500,000 persons, comprising more than half the population of the city, have fled to the country to escape the plague. The streets are practically deserted, shops and bazaars are closed, and business is at a standstill. The doctors are beginning to fear treating plague patients lest they contract the disease, and many of the native doctors lave fled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The President to-day returned to the House without his approval a bill "to constitute a new division of the Eastern Judicial District of Texas and to provide for the holding of terms of court at Beaumont, Texas, and for the appointment of a clerk for said court."

Brooklyn is to have a public library at last. The Brooklyn Library Association, chartered under the University Law of the State of New York to promote the establishment of public libraries and reading rooms in the city of Brooklyn, will see that this is accomplished, and to give the movement further stimulus arranged for a reception which was given Andrew Carnegie at the Academy of Music last night.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 14. -- Martin B. Madden, the machine candidate of the Republicans for Senator, to-night withdrew in favor of ex-Congressman William E. Mason.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The Senate has given an indication of its ill feeling toward the Secretary of State that augurs ill for the chances of the general arbitration treaty, when treaties of extradition with the Orange Free State and the Argentine Republic were under consideration.

The magnificent gift of $1,000,000 to the New York Lying-in Hospital, by J. Pierpont Morgan, announced exclusively in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday, has caused the liveliest sentiment of gratitude among all those interested in the hospital and its work.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14. -- Charles L. Fair has started his crusade against Mrs. Nettie Craven and the persons connected with the production and establishment of the alleged forged deeds to property belonging to the estate.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- A number of private pension and other minor bills were passed.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Mr. Cockrell (Dem., Mo.,) occupied the chair.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- During the first reading of bills Speaker O'Grady interrupted the Clerk, and cautioned the Sergeant at Arms that he would hold him responsible for the presence on the floor of any persons not authorized to be there.

Gen. Carlos Roloff, Secretary of War of the Republic of Cuba, who was arrested Wednesday evening and lodged in Ludlow Street Jail on a warrant charging him with violation of the neutrality law, was arraigned before Commissioner Shields yesterday, in the United States Circuit Court. He gave $2,500 cash bail to appear for examination to-morrow, as did Dr. Joseph J. Luis, a Cuban, arrested and arraigned on a like charge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The newspaper rivalry that is producing a new sensation about Cuba every morning is responsible for the reproduction to-day of the agreement made in 1878 between the Cuban insurgents and Spain for the discontinuance of the former revolution, and a long chapture of conjecture is added to the revival of the old greement to give it an air of plausibility.

Capt. Dodd's Troop F, United States Cavalry, a gymnastic drill by the Thirteenth Infantry, United States Army, Lieut. E.L. Butts in command, and a drill by Light Battery D, Fifth Artillery, United States Army, Capt. Thorp, furnished the military part of the tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- Albert N. Voris, bigamist, traveling man, and letter writer, made a complete surrender in Judge Tuley's court this morning. Confronted by over fifty letters which he had written to his first wife, who lives in Cincinnati, the man saw that conviction was inevitable.
A meeting of the Brooklyn Yacht Club, in which the two factions of the club, the yacht owners and non-yacht owners, took part, was held at 5 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The Chief of the Bureau of Statistics reports that the total values of the exports of merchandise from the United States during the month of December, 1896, and during the twelve months ended Dec. 31, 1896, as compared with similar exports during the corresponding periods of the preceding year, were as follows:
