Emma Cummings, daughter of William H. Cummings, a dealer in scrap rubber at 200 Washington Street, this city, and Margaret H. Williams, a niece of William Hall Williams, rector of the Church of the Good Shepherd, in Boston, were found by Patrolman Bowden in the waiting room of the elevated railroad station at Third Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street at 3:30 yesterday morning.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Thomas Collier Platt to-night was made the Republican candidate for the United States Senate to succeed David B. Hill. He received 142 votes on the first ballot at a joint caucus at which 149 Republicans were present.

Four United States prisoners confined in Ludlow Street Jail escaped from that institution yesterday afternoon by sawing their way through iron-barred windows, jumping or climbing to the roof of a tenement house, and then descending to the street.

The election of Mr. HUBBELL as President of the Board of Education rather than the re-election of Mr. MACLAY was the only logical and rational course for the board to take. Nobody questions Mr. MACLAY'S ability or integrity. His motives may have been quite honest in opposing reform in the school system and in favoring the retention of Superintendent JASPER, and no doubt he would endeavor conscientiously to do his duty under the new law.

RICHARD CROKER, the retired "boss" of Tammany, in the character of a sage giving advice to the rising generation of "boys," is an impressive spectacle. He appeared in that character at a Tammany club the other night, and the talk he gave to the admiring assemblage would have done credit to any Dutch uncle of them all. First of all, he kindly but firmly assured the "boys" that he was out of politics "for keeps."

Numerous as great American fortunes have become and public spirited as the owners of many of them have shown themselves to be, Mr. PIERPONT MORGAN'S gift of a million dollars to the New York Lying-in Hospital is still rather startling. In amount it has not often been exceeded or even equaled as the benefaction of a living man to a single institution.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- The only breeze in the Senate to-day was afforded by an objection to the reference of Senator Guy's bill prohibiting discrimination by railroads in rates to New York State ports.

I think it high time that the taxpayers of New York took stock, to see where or how much the Greater New York will leave them. After all the agitation that has been had on the subject during the last three or four years, the really important point of the whole matter seems to be only now receiving discussion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Late this afternoon information reached the capital that the Union Pacific proposition is formally before the President, who has given it favorable consideration, and will direct ex-Gov. Hoadly, special Government counsel in the Pacific Railroad case, to enter an appearance on behalf of the Government by filing cross bills in the pending foreclosure, commenced in Missouri, Iowa, Nebraska, and other Western States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- The appearance of the stamp of the so-called Cuban Republic in the United States mails has caused much comment here, and was the source of some discussion at the Post Office Department to-day, as to whether such stamps could be recognized as proper for the transmission of mails into the United States, as this Government has not recognized Cuba as a free and independent country.

BOSTON, Jan. 14. -- There is every prospect that New England is on the verge of another mill curtailment, although not to as large an extent probably as occurred during last Summer. T. Jefferson Coolidge, Treasurer of the Amoskeag Mills, says:

PIERRE, S.D., Jan. 14. -- The Senatorial fight has narrowed down still further to a contest between Kyle and Loucks, with chances apparently about even. It is thought Kyle has lost ground. It was estimated at the start that his adherents numbered more than fifty. None of his friends now estimates his strength above thirty votes. The Republican caucus last night selected Congressman Pickler as the Republican candidate for United States Senator.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 14. -- The steamship Delaware of the Clyde's Boston, Wilmington, Charleston, and Jacksonville Line came into port this morning, having on board Lieut. Sutherland of the United States dispatch boat Dolphin. The presence of the Lieutenant on board the steamer is accounted for by the fact that she was taken for a filibuster when she appeared off the bar.

All parts of Kansas do not seem to partake of the "simple blessings" which the Populistic Governor declares to abound in the Commonwealth generally. It is the home of Mrs. LEASE of Wichita which has just been allowed to go to the Eastern oppressor under foreclosure under circumstances which indicate that the market price is less than the mortgage.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 14. -- President-elect McKinley is posing for a life-size oil painting, which is being executed by The bauld Chartran.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 14. -- State Treasurer Colvin, who is President of the State League of Republican Clubs, under whose auspices the banquet is to be given in this city Jan. 26, in honor of the United States Senator-elect, announces that the following, who were members of the United States Senate with Thomas C. Platt during the latter's former term, have been invited to the banquet as special guests:

HAVANA, Jan. 14. -- At 12:30 P.M. to-day the sentence was read in the case of Luis Someillan, the naturalized American citizen who has been found guilty of conspiring against the Spanish Government. The sentence of the tribunal before which he was tried is that he be imprisoned for life in chains. Someillan's lawyer will appeal to the Supreme Court at Madrid against the decision of the Havana tribunal.
ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- The following Cuban resolution was introduced in the Assembly to-day by Assemblyman Whritner, (Rep., Rockland,) and was made a special order for Monday night.

So large a number of New York men participated in the deliberations of the Monetary Conference, just closed in Indianapolis, that its outcome possesses a special interest for the bankers and business men of this city. There was a general discussion in financial circles here yesterday of the proposition to establish a monetary commission, and the idea met with much favor.
INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 14. -- Congressman J.H. Walker of Massachusetts, Chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, is as strongly against the Monetary Convention's work as ever.
The members of the Council of the University Athletic Club met Tuesday evening at the clubhouse and received the report of the Football Committee.

The Business Men's Convention at Indianapolis proposes two things, that Congress shall provide for a currency commission; failing that, that a commission be selected by the Executive Committee of the convention. In either case the principles to be applied to the currency are clearly defined and agreed upon by the convention, and an organized movement to secure the support of the country for these principles will be begun at once and vigorously and continually pressed.
ALBANY, N.T., Jan. 14. -- Assemblyman Horton to-day introduced a bill providing for the purchase by the State of text books for use in the schools.

Mme. Teresa Carreno gave her first piano recital yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf. Her audience was a large one, and there were numerous demonstrations of delight. Her programme was built on the familiar lines, sanctified by custom the world over, beginning with some serious music by Bach and ending with some superficial glitter by Liszt.

The thirteenth annual ball of the Bachelors' Circle of the German Liederkranz was held last night at the clubhouse, on East Fifty-eighth Street, near Park Avenue. The ball marked the close of the gayety attending the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the society.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- The caucus was held in the Assembly Chamber. The spacious room and galleries were crowded. Among those in the front row of the ladies' gallery were a few of the committee of fifty of the Union League Club of New York City, including William D. Guthrie and Edward Mitchell.

We have seen no evidence in the published reports of the tariff hearings at Washington that the majority members of the Ways and Means Committee fully realize the vast difference between the conditions prevailing in 1890 and those with which they must deal this year, or the difference between the construction of a tariff designed to decrease revenue and the making of one which will largely increase the Government's income.
Iron and steel companies are reported large borrowers of money in Eastern markets. -- Boston Herald.
ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee is expected to prepare a bill which will carry out the civil service reform ideas expressed by Gov. Black in his first message.
City Magistrate Joseph M. Deuel has addressed a letter to Senator John Raines at Albany on the subject of excise legislation.

A dejected, half-starved-looking individual, who gave his name as Jacob Nelson, was arraigned in the Harlem Police Court yesterday on a charge of burglary. The Rev. R.F. Wagner, pastor of the German Baptist Church in One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, was the complainant.

The Greater New York Commission heard arguments in the Aldermanic Council Chamber yesterday afternoon on taxes and assessments, buildings and charities. Gen. Tracy presided, Mayor Gleason, State Engineer Adams, Messrs. Pinney, Moore, Gilroy, Dutcher, Woodford, and De Witt were present.

The third of the series of dances given by the Up-Town Waldorf Dancing Class, organized by Mrs. D Phoenix Ingraham, was held at the Waldorf last evening. It was attended by a large gathering of young men and women.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- It is reported that an agreement has been reached between the Reorganization Committee of the Atlantic and Pactfic Railroad and the Santa Fe Company whereby the former road will go into the control of the latter. This would secure the Santa Fe its present route from Albuquerque to California.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 15. -- In the racing to-day three favorites won, and the public divided the spoils with the bookmakers. Joseph F. Morris, on account of the interference of his father with his mounts, has been suspended.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Senator Ford of New York City said to-day that if an extension of time for hearings in the Greater New York charter were needed, he believed it would be wise to postpone consideration of the charter at the regular session and attend to it at a special session.

The appearance of Mr. SAMUEL W. ALLERTON of Chicago as a candidate for the Senatorship of Illinois must excite some surprise, even if the candidacy is not to be considered very serious. Secretary MORTON has been asking Mr. ALLERTON some questions about his connection with the "eveners" of twenty years ago, which Mr. ALLERTON has not thus far found it convenient to answer.

Sheriff Tamsen began an investigation yesterday of the escape of the four Federal prisoners from Ludlow Street Jail Thursday. He read Warden Roe's report and questioned Keepers Rumpf and Finkelstein, and the plumbers who have been at work in the prison for some weeks. Peter Masso, the one of the escaping four who was recaptured, and Policeman Barnitz, who arrested him, were questioned closely.

In some houses the little children who go to bed early put out their shoes and stockings, and find them crammed with presents in the morning. Others have to play a game of hide-and-seek for their presents, which the father and mother have hidden in the most mysterious manner and in out-of-the-way places.

Passages from this new volume of letters written by von Moltke are at hand in English papers. The Times says the collection will deepen the impression produced by the earlier volumes of his correspondence, and it is mainly on account of their revelations of the character and the home life of the man that the letters deserve to be widely read.

"A penitent was occupied in confessing. I approached at last and knelt down in a niche which was just vacated. I had to kneel there ten minutes waiting. At last a little door inside the grating opened, and I saw the priest leaning his ear toward me, I was obliged to begin, and yet I did not know a word of the formula.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The trial of the action brought by Douglas J. Neame to obtain a divorce from his wife, Leila Olyve Neame of New York, naming Frank Ellison of New York as co-respondent, was concluded in the Divorce Division of the High Court of Justice to-day, the court granting Neame a decree nisi. Ellison, as co-respondent with Mrs. Neame, was not represented in court.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Messrs. Charlton and Farrer, Liberal members of the Canadian Parliament, are here in an unofficial capacity sounding Congressmen on the subject of closer trade relations between the United States and the Dominion. They have received little encouragement.

The figures of our foreign trade for the year 1896 are published by the Bureau of Statistics. The totals will be subject to some slight correction, but are wholly trustworthy for general inferences. When we have the details as to the character of the various elements of our export trade, an analysis and comparison with previous years will be of great interest.

There seems to be no sound reason for an English criticism like this: "The American's desire for culture, laudable as it is, often leads him on to out-art the standard set up by the European classics, rather than more wisely to conform to it." If it is laudable, then it must be good. Conforming to certain standards may not to-day be necessary.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 15. -- President-elect McKinley has made his wants known relative to his trip to Washington. His mother, wife, brother, and nieces will accompany him. On account of the age of his mother, Mr. McKinley has made a special request of the Pennsylvania Company, that the train bearing the Presidential party to Washington be run on a slow schedule, in order not to have too great a strain on the old lady.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Mr. Allen (Rep., Utah,) started business in the House to-day by presenting a resolution calling on the Secretary of the Interior for information as to why patents had not been issued for lands secured by bona-fide purchasers from the Union Pacific Railroad Company, the lands having been given the company under Government grants. The resolution was agreed to.

Beautiful and touching are Max Muller's recollections of Charles Kingsley in Cosmopolis. Some of us may remember Kingsley when he lectured in the United States. Strong may have been his Northumbrian view, a trifle awkward might have been his gestures, but after Thackeray he was by far the best of all the English lecturers.

The New York Hockey Club beat the Montclair team last night at the New York Ice palace, One Hundred and Seventh Street and Lexington Avenue, by one goal to nothing. It was a hard-fought game, and at times a little rough, but was thoroughly enjoyed by the spectators on account of the excellent work of the players. The line-up was:
Stock market active and strong. Advances general. Call money, 1 1/2 to 2 per cent.

Max Muller's literary recollections, as reprinted in these columns a month ago from Cosmopolis, related to German men of letters whom he had known in his youth. They were of uncommon interest, since they were concerned with his father, who was a poet, with Uhland, Heine, and others.

Vassili Verestchagin has come to grief in Paris -- not artistically, but in a literary way. It is well for the picture alone to declare itself. The advantages of long written descriptions of what it means are rarely necessary. An oratorio never was more musically impressive because of the pamphlet which tells what every chord or trill of note may mean.
It is not politics that Senator Henry Cabot Lodge writes about in the February Scribner's, 'but an article on ''The Rehabilitation of the Character of Richard III."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- The Republican Senatorial caucus this morning decided to leave the text of the resolution providing for an international monetary conference as previously submitted to the conference. It will be reported to the Senate Monday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 15. -- Payment has been stopped by the State of Illinois on nearly everything except legislative expenses, because the State Treasury is empty and there is no money on hand with which to redeem the Auditor's warrants.

A considerable part of the milk supply of this city and Brooklyn comes from dairy farms in the adjoining States of New Jersey and Connecticut. No milk taken from tuberculous cows should be sold or received in either of these cities. The sale of such milk here can be prevented, however, only by the elimination of diseased animals from the dairy herds.

Is fine bookbinding now in general demand in the United States? At once the distinction must be made between what is fine bookbinding and artistic binding In the latter is to be included the chef d'oeuvres of elegance and of admirable handicraft. This highest development of the bookbinder's art is a luxury which demands a great deal of money and in which a majority of book owners do not indulge.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- On account of the filthy drinking water supplied by the city, the Board of Health ordered the Board of Education to put in filters.

There can be no doubt whatever that a great many persons regarded the revival of Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde," at the Metropolitan Opera House this season, as hazardous experiment. There were some doubts whether it would be attempted. However, the music-drama was given last night, and an audience of good size listened to it attentively, and applauded it enthusiastically.

The first report of the State Excise Commissioner shows that the difficulties of enforcing the Raines liquor tax law all hang upon the provision for Sunday prohibition, which was retained from the old excise law.

Mention may be made of a new process of lithography, said to have been discovered in Germany and in practical use. Thin plates of aluminum take the place of lithographic stones. The new process is called "algraphie."

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 15. -- A United States revenue cutter is at Newport News looking for the coal barge J. Ward of Philadelphia, which is supposed to have on board, in addition to her other cargo, arms and ammunition for the Cuban insurgents. The Ward has not shown up yet.

The official list of English books published in 1896 has just appeared. Like the lists for the two preceding years, it shows an increase -- the number was 60 greater than for 1895. The respective totals were 6,573 and 6,513, the new editions of old books for 1896 being 1,339, (which are included in the total of 6,573.)

LONDON, Jan. 15. -- A dispatch to the Central News from Madrid says that at a Cabinet council over which the Queen Regent presided, it was decided immediately to introduce reforms in Cuba, and a decree putting the reforms into effect will be published on the King's fete day.

The bravest men are always the most modest, and Field Marshal Lord Roberts of Kandahar, that fine type of English pluck and gallantry, in telling the story of his services in the English Army, which he calls "a plain, unvarnished tale of Indian life and adventure," begs the reader to remember that "the writer is a soldier, not a man of letters, and therefore forgive all faults of style and language."

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Senator Lexow offered a resolution for an investigation of the existence of monopolies and trusts, and asked that it be made a special order for next Tuesday. He said he believed that the Republican Party should take hold of this important question, which was now agitating the public.

In the contest over the will of William Campbell, the millionaire wall paper manufacturer, who left nearly $1,000,000 to his housekeeper, Mrs. Lillian Ash, and only $75,000 to his daughter, Estelle, before Surrogate Fitzgerald yesterday, Richard Martin, the lawyer, testified that Mr. Campbell endeavored to get Mr. Ash to secure a divorce from Mrs. Ash so the former could marry her. He said Mr. Campbell expected a contest of the will.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- There was filed in the office of the Secretary of State to-day, a certificate of the lease of the Saranac and Lake Placid Railroad Company to the Chateaugay Railroad Company and the Chateaugay Ore and Iron Company, jointly, for a period of seventeen years.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 15. -- Entries for the remaining stakes of the Spring meeting of the Louisville Jockey Club closed to-day. The Louisville Futurity, worth $10,000; the Kentucky Derby, worth, $6,000; the Clark Stakes, worth $4,000, and the Kentucky Oaks, worth $3,500, are included. The final payment of the Futurity was made to-day.
ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- State Excise Commissioner Lyman to-day submitted his first annual report to the Legislature, showing the operation of the Raines liquor tax law.

Many citizens still follow the custom of paying men to remove ashes and other refuse matter from their premises. The Street Cleaning Department does this work gratuitously and thoroughly, but it has no objections to offer in cases where citizens prefer to give the employment to private individuals.

If every preacher in the land to-morrow should state the true character of the general arbitration treaty and point the way of duty to the Senate of the United States, it would be a useful and righteous exercise of his functions. That noble agreement appeals not only to the followers of CHRIST, but to every religious society, and indeed to all men of humane hearts and just minds.

The primary and apparently the most prolific cause of our present political instability is believed to reside in our too frequently recurring Presidential elections. Longer continued periods of uninterrupted business tranquillity are extremely desirable, and, indeed, indispensable, for the safe development of a diversified industrial progress.

It may not be out of place to suggest that if there is any American poet who deserves the statue of a man of action -- not the seated or half-recumbent effigy of the thinker or philosopher, but the figure in bronze standing in the attitude of intellectual combat with the world -- that poet is Whittier.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 15. -- The case of Wallace vs. the City of Richmond, decided in the Supreme Court of Appeals yesterday, was a rather unique and interesting one. The night the City of Richmond was evacuated by the Confederate forces, the City Council ordered all the liquor stored in the wholesale houses here to be poured into the streets.

One of our contemporaries yesterday contained a very unjust sneer at the Bar Association, in which that body was accused of never having effected anything. The sneer was very unjust. If Senator HILL were called upon to name the agency which did most to defeat his purpose of foisting Judge MAYNARD upon the Court of Appeals, without doubt he would name the Bar Association.

For the elucidation tip of isthmian canal projects Mr. Keasbey has worked through an enormous amount of material, scattered through old archives, Government documents, general histories, books of travel, monographs, and pamphlets without end. To comprehend the geographical part of the subject has required much study.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 15. -- Mr. Austin's bill, providing for a new Hall of Records in New York, was ordered to a third reading, and recommended to the Committee on Cities, retaining its regular place in the order of third reading.

The Tammany primary elections were held in all of the Assembly districts of the city last night, for the election of delegates to the General Committee and the district committees. There were only three real contests, one in the Thirty-third, another in the Twenty-first Assembly District, and another in the Twenty-third District.

The nomination of Mr. PLATT, which was made unanimous in the Republican caucus at Albany Thursday evening, may be taken as equivalent to his election to the United States Senate next week with the support of all the representatives of his party in the Legislature, who include more than two-thirds of the members of each house.

The life of a book depends on its usage. The primer is thumbed out of existence; hence the rarity of old schoolbooks. If our hands have been educated to fondle books, we are tender with them. A child ought always to be told not to lay an open book down on its printed pages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Charles Emory Smith's chances for the Cabinet were smashed to-day by an intimation from Senator Quay that Smith was not the man for a Cabinet place. It can be asserted with much positiveness that no Pennsylvanian whom Quay opposes will go into the Cabinet.
CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 15. -- Senator Sherman this afternoon authorized the positive announcement that he had accepted the portfolio of State in President McKinley's Cabinet.
The Ohio Coal Traffic Association's Executive Committee is to meet at Chicago next Tuesday, when an opportunity will be given for the making and investigation of complaints of rate cutting.

From "Hopkins's Pond," by Robert T. Morris. The tables are creaking with solid sections of brown, juicy, steaming roasts and piles of mealy potatoes enveloped in hot fog, and long, white platters of whole salmon, through whose tender torn skin the pink flakes and streaks of white fat look all ready for the limpid golden butter sauce which stands in the brimming full dishes near-by.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- The work of reorganizing the Alley "L" Company was completed yesterday by the filing of articles of incorporation of a new company to manage the South Side Elevated Road. The name of the road is changed in the articles of incorporation from the South Side Rapid Transit Company to the South Side Elevated Railroad Company.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- "There is good reason for thinking that the Government will be able through foreclosure to get every cent due it from the Pacific roads."

The joint committee of the Brooklyn Aldermen and the Queens County Supervisors met yesterday in the City Hall, Brooklyn, and decided to report favorably on the plans of Engineer John McLaughlin for the new Newtown Creek Bridge.

Twenty-two Protestant denominations of the United States and Canada were represented at the interdenominational mass meeting in Carnegie Hall last night. There was not a great crowd in the hall, and the seats on the stage were not all filled, but probably 2,000 persons were present. Women composed the larger part of the audience.

There are efforts being made in Paris toward the union of the various artistic Salons. But what Parisian journal calls "le snobism" seems to prevent an alliance. Champs Elysee and Champs de Mars differ as to what is the dignity of associes and societaires. Meanwhile another question has arisen.

HONOLULU, Jan. 7. -- Mrs. W.W. Dimond, wife of the eldest son of the late Gen. W.H. Dimond and grandson of the late John Thomas Waterhouse of Honolulu, sailed for San Francisco last Friday. Her friend, Charles D. Wilson, a bookkeeper for the Hobron Drug Company, was a passenger on the same steamer.

Some of those who appeared before the Charter Commission yesterday, at the hearing on the chapter relating to taxes and assessments, reverted to the old arguments against consolidation. That question was settled more than two years ago, and the existence of the commission rests upon the assumption that it is settled finally.
ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- When Mr. Lexow had presented his resolution for an investigation of alleged trusts in the Senate to-day, he was asked what he was aiming at.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15. -- An application for a receiver for the Harrison International Telephone Company by the Fort Smith (Ark.) stockholders, who sold the stock of their company in exchange for Harrison stock, was heard by Judge Grosscup, in the Federal Court to-day. The occasion was taken advantage of by the Court to sharply rebuke the petitioners and say some plain things about the Harrison Company.

M. Mucha's art work in L'Illustration is one of the curiosities of to-day. For fancy, with a great deal which is incomprehensible, M. Mucha is to be considered a master. Take the cover of L'Illustration as an example. The colors are admirable, for, despite the excellence of our own American mechanical work, we cannot exactly blend or register as do the French.

-- Investigation conducted by a naturalist sent to Africa by the Royal Society of England has confirmed the belief that at no remote period, geologically speaking, Lake Tanganyika was a part of, or connected with, the sea. Some years ago jellyfish much like those in the neighboring ocean were found in its waters.

The activity of Superintendent of the Bureau of Incumbrances William Henkel has made Vesey Street sidewalk obstructors apprehensive. He has informed all merchants on Vesey Street whose sidewalk displays for years have encroached upon the public thoroughfare that they must cease these violations of the law.

Sheriff TAMSEN has been particularly unfortunate. The escape of three mail robbers from Ludlow Street Jail, shortly after the beginning of his term, was noteworthy because the men were daring and dangerous criminals. It was even more noteworthy on account of what one of STEVENSON'S characters called the "stupefying impudence of their proceedings."

Mrs. Delia Quinn, widow of Thomas Quinn, who conducted a real estate, business in Main Street, Brooklyn, is about to bring suit to recover her dower right on 600 parcels of property situated in this city, Brooklyn, and Queens County, worth $200,000. She has already served notice on the owners of the properties, to whom Quinn transferred them as a supposed single man.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 15. -- An action for damages may be begun by the Louisville '96 Meet Club against the manager of the press bureau that has been booming Isaac D. Potter for President of the League of American Wheelmen during the assembly at Baltimore.
HONOLULU, Jan. 7. -- United States Minister Albert S. Willis died yesterday morning at 8 o'clock, after several months' illness.

Every sympathetic heart will be touched by the grief of Mr. PLATT at CORNELIUS N. BLISS'S refusal of a Cabinet office. "It will be a matter of sincere regret to Republicans of this State," said Mr. PLATT, "that Mr. BLISS did not see his way clear to accept a Cabinet appointment."
The Frank L. Fisher Company has sold for Walker Lawson the five story single flat 203 West Eighty-fourth Street, 19 by 90 by 102.

If the impressionists must go, after having done more harm than good, because no end of lazy persons thought they might be impressionists, must what are called "tonists" jump into their places? If the word "tone" be taken from music, its application to a picture is singularly indefinite.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 15. -- The sale of Col. James E. Pepper's stud of thoroughbreds took place at Meadow Thorpe to-day. There was but little competition, and Mrs. Pepper bought in the entire fifty-six head for $1,279, an average of $23 per head.

The international art exhibition to be held at Dresden this year will show a thousand pictures selected from the best creations of the present day. The other objects of art, as sculptures, , will be very large in number. Advantage is to be taken from experience acquired in other exhibitions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The details of the agreement between Russia and China regarding the construction of a Chinese eastern railway has been reported to the State Department by Consul General Karel of St. Petersburg.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency gave hearings to-day to B.A. Lancaster, a banker and broker of Richmond, Vt.; Gamaliel Bradford of Boston, and R.B. Ferris, Vice President of the Bank of New York, all of whom had suggestions to make concerning the solution of the currency problem.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 16. -- William E. Mason and Congressman Lorimer of Chicago are the leading candidates for United States Senator. Mason claimed to-day that he had a majority of the Republican votes, but his lieutenants fear that before the party caucus Monday night the machine and Lorimer, its new favorite, will have won over enough members to prevent Meson's nomination in caucus.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The House today, in accordance with an order entered some weeks ago, turned aside from the consideration of public business and listened to eulogies upon the life and services of the late ex-Speaker Charles F. Crisp of Georgia. The occasion was marked by all unusually large attendance of members, while the galleries were filled by auditors who listened with interest to the obituary eloquence.

WALTON, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Sylvanus Cash and his two sons, Robert, aged twenty, and John, aged about eighteen years, recently arrested by Detective Frank Esquirrel of the United States Secret Service, on the charge of making and passing counterfeit money, made use of an extremely simple mechanism in the manufacture of the bogus coin.

THE life of the people of this city before the railroad and commerce had raised the place to eminence as a real metropolis has received much attention since phenomenal growth set in after the war closed. With Mrs. Lamb's history for the most notable example of this interest, we have had other volumes from Mr. Mines, Mr. Janvier, and Mr. Haswell.

The racing associations, in preparing their stake races and other turf contests this year, have paid more attention than usual to the amateurs, and have shown a desire to give the gentlemen riders more of a chance. Especially has the Westchester Racing Association moved in that direction, and among the new races prepared for the coming season the amateurs have several races to try for.

MAY IRWIN'S sway is undisputed. She has the sceptre and the tiara and the laurel and all those things. Her merit is that she makes people laugh, and this is the quality that attests her title to the crown of Momus and the throne of Euphrosyne. The cry of the multitude is for "heart-easing mirth," and Miss Irwin has an unfailing supply of it ever on tap.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The Annual Register of officers of the United States Navy is out earlier than usual, and, as usual, very much ahead of the Army Register. It shows some changes that are generally interesting, but are of particular interest to the few officers who have passed from one grade to a higher.

HAVANA, Jan. 16. -- A summary of the military operations of the last twenty-four hours, according to official reports issued to-day, shows that the troops are continuing their skirmishing tactics in the Provinces of Pinar del Rio, Havana, Matanzas, and Santa Clara. The aggregate losses of the rebels cannot be ascertained, but they left fifty-two of their dead on the several fields of battle.

WEST POINT, Jan. 16. -- Few of the hundreds of tourists who have climbed the rugged sides of Cro' Nest ever noticed near the top a ledge rich in soil and free from the stunted brush that covers the mountain. The spot contains fully half an acre of excellent land, level as a pine floor, and sheltered from wind and storm by the overhanging rocks.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Jan. 16. -- "I can tell you a little incident that happened on the historic island of Put-in-Bay in Lake Erie some years ago, and as the narrative leads up to a sensational and tragic climax and has never appeared in print, it would perhaps make interesting reading," remarked Mr. John J. Rice, a traveling man for a New York house, to-day.

The brokers were either more energetic or unusually fortunate last week, and the result of their efforts was an increase of about 50 per cent. in the number of sales negotiated at private contract. Among them were seven with considerations ranging between $100,000 and $375,000. The bulk of the business transacted, however, was due to sales and deals involving minor properties.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 16. -- Edward Percy of Adrian, Mich., nineteen years old, committed suicide in Brady's Hotel, at the corner of Academy and Halsey Streets, this evening. He took a rubber hose from the gas stove, and, placing one end of it in his mouth, attached the other end to the gas jet, which he turned on, and when he was found he was unconscious.

J.W. Kjelgaard, Superintendent of the Cooper Union Labor Bureau, spoke yesterday morning before the League for Political Education, at the Berkeley Lyceum, on the subject of "Help by Work and Sympathy." There was a large attendance.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 16. -- The City of Boston will receive no taxes from the First Spiritual Temple. The appointment of the Common Council's special committee was, it seems, all for naught. The Board of Assessors has voted to abate the tax upon the property at the corner of Exeter and Newbury Streets.

ALBANY, Jan. 16. -- Chairman S. Fred Nixon of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee has been in conference much of the time to-day with Gov. Black and the heads of the departments, trying to fix a policy and determine a basis for making the appropriations this year.

The history of the mortgage on the house of Mrs. LEASE, in Wichita, Kan., as published in the West, shows, as we had surmised, that the heartless oppressor who loaned her the money lost the greater part of it. And this oppressor was not one of the "money sharks" and "goldbugs" of the East whom Mrs. LEASE is fond of denouncing in picturesque language on the platform, but one J. MARCH of Kansas City.

"Of course it is all nonsense, wholly inexcusable, without rhyme or reason, and anything else you may like to say about it, and I should know better and act more rationally. But I'll be hanged if I am not as nervous as a Vassar 'freshie' on the day before her first exam." The Oarsman felt a bit relieved after having thus freed his mind.

The stock market becomes active. It is strong. Both activity and strength promise further development. Even something like enthusiasm is developing. The Wall Street week has closed with a show of what -- contrasted with recent experiences -- is outright buoyancy.

The proposition to make the City Hall Park the southern terminus of the system of rapid transit is probably not very seriously made. It is put forward mainly as a measure of coercion against the owners of property below this line who have shown opposition to the continuance of a tunnel down Broadway.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 16. -- California has lost many valuable trotting stallions in the past ten years, and now is about to lose Guy Wilkes. The sire of Fred Moody, Hazel Wilkes, Sable Wilkes, Muta Wilkes, and many other Grand Circuit performers is to be shipped East in the course of a few days, to be sold at public auction.
Toasted Crumpets and Devonshire Junket -- English Plum Pudding and Mince Pies -- A Little Breakfast for Ten.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16. -- At a dinner given at Kinsley's to-night by the Bankers' Club of Chicago in honor of James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, that gentleman made an extended address, in which he discussed banking and other topics and paid a high tribute to the Administration of Grover Cleveland. Mr. Eckels was frequently interrupted by applause.

It is not probable that Western Europe will ever again suffer from an epidemic of the deadly fever called plague, although the European victims of this malady in the past have been numbered by millions. Nor should the prevalence of plague in the Orient cause any alarm in the United States.

ONE of the most popular schools on the west side of the city, in the Harlem district, is Grammar School No. 10, of which Dr. Ernest R. Birkins is the Principal. It is situated in a very favorable position, at the intersection of St. Nicholas Avenue and West One Hundred and Seventeenth Street.

The cold weather recently has cheered the hearts of young men who are to race for the championship honors of the Amateur Athletic Union, and they have hopes that the ice will be in good condition next Wednesday, when the first event of a three days' meeting will be contested. In many seasons the races have been postponed from date to date, owing to sudden thaws or snowstorms.

THE docks of the City of New York on the North River front from Barclay Street to Thirty-fourth Street, so far as they are built, are floated on a mass of mud from 80 feet to 200 feet in depth. Whatever docks shall be built in the future within this range of some three miles must be floated in the same way.

-- Two policeman at Cambridge, Mass., have made so many arrests lately that citizens living on the beats patrolled by them have appealed for protection to the Board of Aldermen. The complainants charge that there is rivalry between the two men, and that each is trying to make more arrests than the other, without any question as to whether the arrests are necessary or not.

Announcement was made yesterday that Frank Farrell of 315 East Thirty-seventh Street was arrested Friday night and lodged in the Tombs, charged with the murder of Mamie Cunningham of the same address, the thirteen-year-old girl who was found strangled to death at her home on Decoration Day last.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 16. -- Count Cassell, Private Chamberlain to the Pope, the announcement of whose death has been received here from Rome, at one time figured as defendant in one of the most prolonged and sensational lawsuits ever tried in Colorado.

GLASGOW, Jan. 6. -- Queen Victoria is to have a new steam yacht built to replace the old Victoria and Albert paddle yacht, which was built fifty years ago, and was many more years older in design and equipment. She was without exception the ugliest steam yacht afloat, and lying at her moorings in Cowes Road must have been an eyesore to the yachtsmen who admired a good-looking craft.

Charles Rothchild, a cloak manufacturer, plunged head foremost from the eighth floor to the bottom of the light shaft in the Cable Building, at Broadway and Houston Street, at 10:30 yesterday morning.

THE First Battalion, Naval Reserve Artillery of the State of New York, the outcome of a popular sentiment that was created in the late eighties, was made possible by the act to establish a State Naval Militia that was passed at Albany in 1889.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- The agreement between the Secretary of Agriculture and the Canadian Minister of Agriculture relating to quarantine of animals, between the United States and Canada provides that:

The really amusing feature of slang, says a writer in The Illustrated American, is not the expression itself so much as the delicate and fanciful application of it made by skillful hands. "Dontcher know" has been established so extensively and generally that the listener's ear takes no more notice of it than of a punctuation mark.

An impressive funeral service was held yesterday at Calvary Baptist Church over the body of David J. Dean, who died at San Antonio, Texas, Jan. 10. The personal and professional friends of the deceased attended in large numbers, and four clergymen who had been his pastors during his long membership of St. James Church eulogized his life and character.

Old shoes are not lost by any means. In this country they are dissected and subjected to a course of manipulations by which they are converted into a kind of artificial leather, which is made to look very fine, and may be elegantly ornamented. In France they go through a less elaborate transformation.

Yachtsmen have been busy during the week. Some clubs have elected officers for the coming season, others have made nominations, and the elections will be held soon. By far the most important action, though, is that of the Regatta Committee of the Atlantic Yacht Club, in settling the dispute as to the ownership of a cup given last year by Vice Commodore Frederick T. Adams.

The Ohio Society of New York held its eleventh annual banquet at Delmonico's last night. It was an occasion of special interest to the society in view of the fact that an Ohio man is soon to take the Presidential chair at Washington, and the speakers were selected and the subjects assigned with special reference to the responsibilities that will be transferred from Mr. Cleveland to Major McKinley in March.

LONDON, Jan. 16. -- England this week has been moved by fears and alarms from distant causes, though in one case the danger came perilously near these shores. The newspapers have startled sober Englishmen with their announcements, in giant type, of cholera, plague, famine, massacre, and war.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 16. -- Mark A. Hanna is an avowed candidate for Senator from this State, to succeed John Sherman. He has announced his candidacy in an informal manner, and has defied Senator Foraker. It has been decided that Mr. Hanna shall formally and publicly make an announcement of his candidacy at a banquet of the retiring members of the Ohio Legislature at Columbus Feb. 22.

George Ohnet's new play, "Le Colonel Roquebrune," at the Porte St. Martin, in Paris, is described with enthusiasm by the correspondents. It takes up an episode of the Napoleonic legend which preceded the Emperor's return from the Island of Elba. Roquebrune himself is a fictitious personage, drawn from that group of "lions" which included Marbet and Oudinot, who served the Corsican faithfully and gayly.

TRENTON JUNCTION, N. J., Jan. 16. -- A local train that left Philadelphia at 6:10 o'clock this evening and the Royal Blue Line Flier of the Baltimore and Ohio came into collision at 7:10 o'clock three miles north of Skillman, a station eighteen miles east of here. Four railroad men were severely hurt. Two or three of them are probably fatally hurt. Those most severely injured were:

The United Trades and Labor Council of Erie County has prepared a bill regulating the manufacture and sale of beer, ale, and porter in this State, which it is proposed to introduce at the present session of the Legislature.

January of the present year of grace will probably from the gayeties it has already brought, and those which it promises to bring, be a red letter month in the annals of New York society for some years to come. The dullness, so far as society entertaining and entertainment were concerned, of the Christmastide holidays has been followed by a somewhat unexpected and unusual amount of gayety.

"Speaking of misjudging people," remarked The-Young-Man-Who-Has-Money and can take pleasure trips whenever he feels like it, "I had a peculiar experience when I took the steamer trip up the lakes. I was a little late in applying for a berth, and the clerk informed me that every stateroom was occupied, and he would have to give me a berth in the same stateroom with another person.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Jan. 16. -- To-day's issue of The Official Gazette contains a notice that the British Pacific Railway Company will apply to Parliament at its coming session for incorporation. The company proposes to construct a road from Victoria, B.C., through the Northwest Territories, to Winnipeg, Manitoba, with a branch to Hudson Bay.
Senator SHERMAN, coming from a conference with the President-elect at Canton, Ohio, on Friday, said: "I have accepted the State portfolio."

The imps, demons, wraiths, and genii indigenous to Chinatown had a hard time of it last night around Mott and Pell Streets. So far as could be seen by an outsider, the cohorts of the evil one were routed foot, horse, and dragoons.

It is proposed to explore the island or rock of Rockall, which is situated in the open Atlantic, in 57 degrees 36 minutes north latitude, about 200 miles west of the Hebrides, with no other land nearer. It is about 230 feet in circumference at the base and 60 feet at the top, and looks at a distance like a ship under sail, being whitened by the guano that has been deposited upon it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Senator Sherman reached Washington this morning after his brief visit to the President-elect. He confirmed the press dispatches that he had agreed to accept the Secretaryship of State, and said the information had been given out in Canton authoritatively.

RALEIGH, N.C., Jan. 16. -- The Tribune to-morrow will print an interview with Col. Harry Skinner, Representative in Congress, who is here supporting the candidacy of Senator Pritchard, in which Col. Skinner asserts it as his judgment that Pritchard will be elected on the first ballot next Tuesday. He declares that the Pritchard Populists are stronger than they were yesterday, and that there is absolutely no defection in the Republican ranks.

THE fame of Benjamin Franklin as a newspaper editor and publisher has been eclipsed by his notable public services and his career as a patriot during the dark days of this country, when independence was more a name than a reality.

P.I. Bonebrake, President of the Central National Bank of Topeka, Kan., has written a letter to Gov. Woodbury of Vermont in defense of the good name of his State. Mr. Bonebrake is one of the most prominent citizens of Topeka, and a steadfast Republican. He has been Auditor of the State, and is thoroughly acquainted with conditions in Kansas.

The military, bicycle, and athletic tournament was brought to an end last night. Madison Square Garden was well filled twice yesterday. In the afternoon a special matinee was arranged, and was very successful. Capt. Dodd's cavalry, Lieut. Butts's infantry in heavy marching order, four companies of the American Guard of Public School No. 77, First Brigade Cadet Corps, and Company D of the American Guard furnished the entertainment.

ANDERSON, Ind., Jan. 16. -- An embargo is threatened on Indiana whiskerettes by Jim Reeves, an Anderson barber, who has prepared a bill and is endeavoring to get some Representative or Senator in the present Assembly to father it. Reeves is quite in earnest about it, and gives as his ground for its presentation that it would restore prosperity to barbers and would at the same time be a means of decreasing the public debt.

BOISE CITY, Idaho, Jan. 16. -- The ballot for Senator to-day resulted: Dubois, 25; Texas Angel, (Pop.,) 24; T.J. Nelson, (Pop.,) 16; others scattering. The Populists all went to Angel, while the Democrats centred their strength on Nelson.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Nearly 1,000 persons witnessed a most exciting horse race on Lower Saranac Lake to-day. The horses entered were Miss May Bee, owned by Wallace Murray of this place, and Roscoe C., owned by Paul Cotey of Luzerne. The purse of $100 was won by Miss May Bee in three straight heats, Time -- 2:25, 2:23 1/4 2:22 1/4.

There are several interesting projects now pending in this city for the consolidation of clubs. The fact of this pendency does not necessarily denote that the founding of clubs has been overdone in New York, but it does prove that to the establishment of a successful club there goes much of skill or of good fortune, or of both.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 16. -- Another installment of the old-fashioned Winter that has favored Lakewood this season made its appearance this week. The light snow has not brought about any postponement of the golf schedule at the Golf Club or the Country Club. The roads have been in fine condition for wheeling, and rough ice has not hindered the skaters, who have hunted the few smooth places.

The Tammany primary elections were declared yesterday by friends of both John C. Sheehan and Henry D. Purroy to be entirely satisfactory to them. Mr. Purroy having held his own primaries In the Thirty-fourth and Thirty-fifth Assembly Districts, proposes on form an anti-Sheehan organization on Jan. 26, the same night on which the Tammany General Committee will organize for business.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 16. -- Two men tussling to get possession of a pretty and fashionably attired woman drew a large crowd on Market Street, near Broad, shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon. "I've got you now," said one of the men, "and I'm going to hold on to you. You and Dave thought to give me the slip, but I was on to you, you see."

Adolph Meyer, a tailor, thirty-nine years old, who lives with his wife and family on the second floor of a big tenement at 108 East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, was caught by a neighbor, starting a kerosene fire at the bottom of a dumbwaiter shaft in the cellar of his home at 9 o'clock last night.

In a recent lecture on "Public Architecture," delivered under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, Prof. Warren Powers Laird of the University of Pennsylvania pointed out the deficiencies of the architecture in this country as compared with that of Europe.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 16, -- The Connecticut Historical Society, in this city, has come into possession of one of the noted Pitcairn Bibles, which were brought to this country from Pitcairn Island by Levi Hayden of the American whaling ship Cyrus of Nantucket in 1840. There were two of these Bibles.

MILLVILLE, N.J., Jan. 16. -- While working on an old building on the Hayes property, two miles from Port Elizabeth, yesterday, Somers Cole, a carpenter of the latter place, found a fortune secreted in the eaves of the structure. The fortune was found in a long box and was in the shape of bonds, mortgages, gold and silver coin, and large rolls of paper money, and amounted to nearly $25,000.

The last of the hearings given by the Greater New York Commission in reference to the provisions of the draft charter took place yesterday afternoon in the Aldermanic Council Chamber. This was the time fixed for hearing the representatives of the Chamber of Commerce and other bodies, and there was a large attendance, including Charles Stewart Smith, Abram S. Hewitt, George Wilson, Gustav H. Schwab, John E. Parsons, Wheeler H. Peckham, and L.J. Callanan.

Charles Harcourt of 227 West Forty-sixth Street recently became insane over the study of music. He got the impression that he was a grand opera singer, and made life unbearable for his family and neighbors by his singing. Friday he was induced to visit the office of a physician, who was represented as an operatic manager.

A number of he older stall holders in Washington Market have taken a decided stand against the vendors who have been granted licenses to do business on the sidewalks. Not only do they want the sidewalk merchants removed, but they want more stringent rules governing the dealers who have stands inside the building.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 16. -- Mlle. Antoine Trebelli, daughter of the world-famous Trebelli Bettini, arrived from Australia on the Monowai. She inherits her mother's gift of song, but, unlike her, has a soprano voice. She has just completed a tour of Cape Colony, Natal, the Transvaal, Tasmania, South Australia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- Senator Allen has offered to the people, through the medium of a Senate document, an explanation of the Republican victory in November. He attempted to get this document into The Congressional Record, so that he could have it sent out as a campaign contribution, but Senator Hill was doubtful about the propriety of so printing it, and Allen was obliged to be satisfied with printing it as a Senate document.
DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 16. -- Sixteen children lost their lives and nine were injured, three probably fatally, by the burning of the Buckner Orphans' Home, near here, this morning.

We gave yesterday the striking and pleasing figures of the balance of trade and of exports especially for the entire country. To-day we compile from the bulletin of the Bureau of Statistics (reported Jan. 9) the figures of the principal articles of domestic exports, with the amount sent out from each of the principal ports of the country.

CANDID Americans are obliged to confess that the Cuban question is to us a source of almost hopeless perplexity. It creates an international situation from which it is impossible for us to emerge with entire satisfaction, so sharp is the conflict between our sense of duty and our sense of justice. The cause of our embarrassment is to be sought in the dual nature of Spain.

One last resonant note from the marvelous throat of De Reske, a stirring choral climax, the final crash of the cymbals, descending curtain, and the opera is over. The singers hurriedly depart from the stage, the musicians in the orchestra gather up their instruments and dive into subterranean depths, while, with comfortable deliberation, the audience resumes its street habiliments and gradually melts away.

An able writer who has for many years writhed under the tormenting consciousness of his own inability to prostrate the English people in the dust and put a stop to the insolent successes of GROVER CLEVELAND has discovered a large African settlement in the arbitration woodpile.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 16. -- A well-dressed man, about thirty years old, who registered at the Germania Hotel, on Market Street, last night, as Jules Tetaine of Danbury, Conn., was found unconscious in his room at 4 o'clock this afternoon. It was owing to his non-appearance that the hotel people decided to break in the door of his room.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- A sub-committee of the Senate Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads had an interesting hearing this morning on the Loud Postal bill, which, among other things, raises materially the rate of postage on serial publications. A delegation from Maine, opposing the bill, under a misunderstanding that the committee would not meet to-day, left the city, but will be heard at another time.

The finals in the championship races of the Interscholastic Athletic Association were skated last evening at the St. Nicholas Rink, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street, but they did not decide which school is entitled to the championship banner, Berkeley and De La Salle being tied the number of points won.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Charles Courtney, who coaches the boat crews at Cornell University, is out with his annual announcement that the '98 freshmen who offered themselves as crew candidates contain "some of the finest material that ever stepped into the crew room."
BALTIMORE, Jan. 16. -- The fight for the control of the Seaboard Air Line has been renewed, and the case promises to occupy the attention of the courts for some time.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Dec. 23. -- The fall in sugar, which is well known the world over to be the principal, and, indeed, practically the only, industry of the West Indies, appears to have touched bottom this year. At any rate, the last most urgent appeal from the colonists has proved very much more effective than any of its forerunners -- and their name was legion.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Jan. 16. -- Gen. George S. Batcheller, who arrived here from Washington last night for a few days' sojourn, was seen by a United Associated Presses reporter this morning relative to the dispatches from Washington yesterday to the effect that he was being discussed for Secretary of the Treasury.

PERCY, Ill., Jan. 16. -- Monroe Skidmore, a widower, aged seventy-eight, and Mrs. Kelly, a widow, aged sixty-five, residing near Ruma, this county, were engaged to be married, the wedding day being set for Christmas. At that date a large number of guests gathered at the home of the prospective bride, but the bridegroom failed to appear.

There is a corner of the Maritime Exchange partitioned off from the main floor which is always in a state of activity. It is one of the first places visited by a sea Captain upon coming ashore, and one of the last places visited before he goes to sea. It is the headquarters of the New York branch of the Hydrographic Office.

A young Hollander named Van der Ver excited the admiration of Tolstoi last Summer by refusing to perform military duty. The eccentric Russian at first supposed that the refusal was based on religious scruples, and wrote an article in which he exulted over what he declared was a notable exhibition of true Christian courage.

A wheelwoman has been seen here and there along the streets this past week in spite of the cold and unpleasant weather. In a month or so it will be time to think of buying new wheels. The Gentlewoman has recently given a few hints upon this important business for the benefit of English women and girls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16. -- In the disturbed condition of affairs in the Southern States which followed the war a commission sent out by President Johnson to investigate matters (and of which Gen. J.E. Fullerton of the Chickamauga Park Commission is now almost the only survivor) found in every Southern hotel they visited Gen. Robert E. Lee's portrait displayed in the post of honor in the office.

The members of the National Guard have hopes that the present administration will bring about the much-needed reform regarding the reorganization of the force on a more satisfactory military footing, and the Governor, both in his message and in General Order No. 1, gives evidence that he believes in reform, and that he intends to improve the efficiency of the Guard.

BOSTON, Jan. 17. -- Carl B. Christenson, who says he was a profesor in Waterloo College, Waterloo City, Iowa, was arrested to-day charged with stealing about sixty-three books of various kinds from the public library. Christenson, who is a Dane, was found at 55 B Street, where he has been stopping since last September. Sergt. Maynes found in his room about twenty-five books, which came from the Hartford public library.

The Rev. Dr. I.K. Funk, President of the Brooklyn Prohibition League, which has been agitating the subject of the alleged Raines law violations in Brooklyn, made a reply yesterday to the presentment made by the Kings County Grand Jury for December. The reply, which was in the form of a statement, was read at the meeting of the American Temperance Union at Chickering Hall yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast has under consideration the bill which proposes to create the rank of Major General in the National Guard and make important changes in the Military Code. It was drawn by Col. Samuel M. Welch, Jr., of the Sixty-fifth Regiment, Buffalo, an officer of the National Guard Association of the State.

The conference in Mr. Platt's apartments at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last evening brought together an unusually large number of the politicians who have come to be regarded as composing the inner circle. They were on hand early, and the consultation lasted for over three hours.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- The condition of the Rev. Thomas C. Hall, who has been ill at his residence, 408 North State Street, for the last two weeks, was reported practically unchanged to-day from what it has been for two or three days. The physicians in attendance -- Dr. R.D. McArthur and Dr. R.R. Campbell -- say he is seriously ill, but they have confidence in his ultimate recovery.

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- Under instructions from the Foreign Office, Baron Saurma von Jeltsch, German Ambassador to the Porte, has given persistent support to M. Nelidoff, the Russian Ambassador, throughout the series of ambassadorial conferences held in Constantinople, which are now about to terminate, but in the discussion of the financial and administrative reforms proposed by M. Nelidoff, Baron Saurma has taken no prominent part.

The season of indoor riding is now in full blast, owing to inclement weather outside. The riding schools have of late had a remarkable increase of attendance, such as to necessitate additions to the stables and the employment of more riding instructors. The bridle paths of Central Park, covered as they are with snow, and stiff from the cold and frost, are dangerous.
Over one hundred members of the Exempt Firemen's Association met in Jefferson Market Building yesterday afternoon to nominate officers to be balloted for at the quarterly meeting to-morrow evening.

Shall we permit the failure of the treaty of arbitration for fear that its ratification would add to the prestige of Great Britain? Amazing as it seems, this question is seriously raised by the opponents of the treaty, and, ridiculous as it really is, the argument implied is the most plausible that side can show.
The effort being made before the House Ways and Means Committee, at Washington, to have the tariff on books increased has aroused the interest of publishers and literary people generally.

Some of those who always opposed consolidation and who keep up their opposition by objecting to all manner of things in the Greater New York charter, and would find things in it to object to if it were the most perfect instrument of government ever devised, are pretending to fear that the debt of the city may be doubled through the action of county authorities.

Fresh from the scene of his second week of revivalistic work in the City of Boston, Evangelist D.L. Moody appeared yesterday afternoon before one of those immense throngs which it is his customary experience to address every Sunday in Carnegie Hall. The multitudes still come to hear him, and the decision to continue these meetings until March shows that the promoters of this movement feel as sanguine as ever that the throngs will be continued.

A locomotive of the Ninth Avenue elevated road jumped a switch at South Ferry yesterday afternoon. Then it left the track and parted from its train. The passengers who filled the four cars constituting the train received a shaking up and a fright they may not soon forget.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 17. -- It was reported here to-day that ex-Mayor Frank Magowan and Mrs. Barnes, wife of his former Superintendent, with whom Barnes recently compromised a suit brought by him for the alienation of Mrs. Barnes's affections, had ben married in Philadelphia by the Rev. W.A. Hunsberger, and that they would to-morrow come to Trenton and occupy Magowan's palatial residence.

-- "Why do so many papers," gravely asks one published in Boston, "speak of the Secretary of State as 'the Premier?'" Then it enters into an elaborate, accurate, and conclusive demonstration of the fact that the Secretary is not a Premier, but gives no space at all to revealing what journals, except in fun, ever were guilty of the mistake.

According to Health Officer Doty, there is little cause to fear that the bubonic plague may reach New York. The doctor, who has just returned from a visit to Egypt, says that he is satisfied from the quarantine supervision maintained by English officials at Suez that there is little danger of the disease passing that point.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- State Factory Inspector O'Leary has completed his report for the year 1896. The report shows that 27,425 inspections were made in 1896 -- 6,240 more than in 1895. The establishments inspected included manufactories, bakeshops, mines, and mining plants. In the establishments visited there were employed 537,702 persons, 159,226 of whom were women, including 53,997 under twenty-one years of age.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Senator Platt's special committee charged with the investigation of the question of the rebate of the internal revenue tax on alcohol used in the arts has had the subject under consideration for several weeks and has taken a very large amount of testimony. Some important information bearing upon the subject has just come to the attention of the committee.

The great and growing cost of the attempts in Massachusetts to exterminate the gypsy moth shows how serious may be the consequences of a disturbance of "the balance of nature" by the introduction of foreign insects or animals. A few of these moths were imported some years ago by an entomologist residing near Boston.

A fine programme was given last night at the Metropolitan Opera House concert, with Master Huberman, the boy violinist; Mme. Litvinne, M. Salignac, Signor Campanari, and M. Plancon as soloists. Anton Seidl conducted the orchestra.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 17. -- The three railroad men most severely hurt in the collision Saturday night between a Philadelphia and Reading local train and the Royal Blue express of the Baltimore and Ohio Road were in very critical condition to-night in the Muhlenberg Hospital here.

It was said yesterday that the indictments found by the Grand Jury Friday, about which so much mystery was made in the District Attorney's office, were for five men who were prominently interested in the Britannica Publishing Company, which failed July 11, 1893. The indicted persons will, it is expected, surrender themselves some time to-day, and give bail for their appearance when wanted.
The following sales are down for to-day at 111-Broadway:

Gov. Asa S. Bushnell of Ohio and his staff, who came to New York last Friday to attend the Ohio dinner, will leave for their homes to-day. During his stay in the city the Governor has succeeded in stirring up considerable talk concerning the probable successor to Senator Sherman when the latter takes his place in President McKinley's Cabinet.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton, at All Souls' Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, yesterday morning addressed his congregation on "Humanity's Interest in Our Arbitration Treaty."
The leaders in the agitation for gas reform in this city read yesterday the list of new Assembly committeemen on electricity, gas, and water supply with a feeling much resembling consternation.

RACINE, Wis., Jan. 17. -- The Belle City Street Railway Company, of which Jackson I. Case is President, has been placed in the hands of Hiram J. Smith as receiver. Case, who is the principal owner of the company, has expended $400,000 on the road.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 17. -- Now that Senator Sherman has accepted the portfolio of State, the rest of the Cabinet seems to centre on a Secretary of the Treasury. Charles Emory Smith has been mentioned frequently in connection with this post, and to-day another name has been suggested, which may receive consideration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- Appropriation bills will demand attention in the Senate this week. The Army bill has been reported, and the Military Academy and Legislative bills will be reported from the committee to-morrow.

Well-informed representatives of the paper trade in this city say that the recent shutting down of two or three paper mills does not signify that the business situation is getting worse. On the contrary, it is asserted that where one factory has suspended at least three have started up within the past few weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- The silver Democrats in the House will oppose the amendment to Senator's Hill's Contempt of Court bill recommended by the Judiciary Committee. The amendment proposed by the House Judiciary Committee permits the impaneling of a jury in such cases, but does not allow the jury to pass upon the question of guilt or innocence, nor to fix the punishment.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Jan. 17. -- "Fred" Smith, assistant trainer of the two great pacers John R. Gentry and Robert J., was murderously assaulted at his apartments in the stables of Lewis G. Tewksbury at this place at an early hour this morning by George Castler, manager of the Alfred De Cardova Stock Farm.

ALBANY, Jan. 17. -- Thomas C. Platt will be elected United States Senator at noon Tuesday. The Legislature will meet in joint session in the Assembly Chamber at that time. Chester S. Lord will be elected as a Regent of the university at the same joint session.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 17. -- The people of Colorado think they see indications of great activity in the development of the mineral resources of the far West during the coming year. In the East men are giving more attention to this subject than they did six months ago. There is better inquiry for investments. Much of the work of this kind is being done quietly, but it is growing in volume.

A distinctive feature of the management of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railway Company is its system of what may be termed post-graduate instruction for its employes. No other railroad has it, while this line has always had its schools and appreciated their importance.

RICHARD CROKER expressed to an Atlanta reporter during his Southern journey his amazement at the criticism of Tammany by business men. He declared that Tammany was a "splendid organization," that "business required organization," and "politics was a business." He may have been misreported, but the sentiments are quite in harmony with his declarations on previous occasions.

The Rev. Charles H. Eaton, D.D., has prepared a series of addresses to young men, based on the lives of "Great New Yorkers." They are all to be delivered on Sunday evenings. He gave the first last night, taking for his theme, particularly, "John Jacob Astor and Old and New Ways of Money Making."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 17. -- Mass meetings were held in different parts of the State to-day for the purpose of creating sentiment in favor of the law which has been introduced in the State Legislature making it a high misdemeanor to sell pools on horse races run either in or out of the State.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 17. -- Lieut. Col. Andre Hernandez, commanding a detachment of Agecuria cavalry, now stationed within a few miles of Havana, states that Maceo is really dead, and that he aided in burying him. Col. Hernandez was in command of the Cuban detachment that recovered the body from Major Cirujedo's soldiers after a bloody fight and afterward buried it secretly in a spot safe from the Spaniards.

Pedestrians in West Thirty-fourth Street gazed wonderingly at the two brownstone houses at 104 and 106 yesterday. They could see only the walls of the houses above the third stories. Below that their gaze rested on an almost solid array of show bills. Doors, windows, walls, and every place were covered.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel C. Potter, pastor of the Tabernacle Baptist Congregation, preached to a small company of his followers yesterday morning at the Smyrna Welsh Congregational Church, 206 East Eleventh Street.

The subject of Prof. Felix Adler's discourse before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall yesterday morning was "The Problem of Marriage." It was the second of a series of lectures on the new-woman question.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17. -- "Unless a compromise is effected between the Havemeyer interest and Mr. Arbuckle within the next four or five days," said W.F. McLaughlin, "the fight between them will be long and bitter, and will prove expensive to both. I am beginning to hope, however, that some of my arguments with each of them are beginning to have some effect, and that the whole matter will be settled."

BERLIN, Jan. 17. -- The Berlin season is now in full swing, and the last week has been one of almost incessant festivity. The reception given to the members of Court society at the United States Embassy last Monday by Ambassador Uhl was a magnificent function. The Ambassador's saloons were resplendent with gorgeous uniforms, and the exquisite costumes of bejeweled ladies, whose diamonds presented a most dazzling effect.
One Summer morning, about three years ago, Capt. Collins of the Park police found in his mail a letter to this effect:

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 17. -- With the return of the members of the House and Senate, and the appearance on the scene of two new candidates, the Senatorial fight to-night assumed the heated phase that characterized it at the close of last week. New candidates are William J. Calhoun of Danville and Congressman Albert J. Hopkins of Aurora.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 18. -- Only two favorites won in the races to-day, much to the satisfaction of the bookmakers.

The third section of the library of the late Henry F. Sewall was placed on sale yesterday at the auction rooms of Bangs Co., 93 Fifth Avenue, and the sale will be continued to-day and to-morrow until the last lot in the collection is sold.

The court of inquiry appointed by Admiral Bunce to investigate the cause of the accident to the cruiser Montgomery, which occurred off Governors Island last week, assembled at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday. Lieut. Graves was appointed Judge-Advocate in place of Lieut. Heilner, who is sick.

The second of the junior assemblies was held at Sherry's last night and proved of equal popularity with the first ball of the series, which took place Dec. 14. At the first ball the cotillion was not begun until after supper, and the ball was late in consequence. Last night the cotillion was started at 11 o'clock, and supper was served at 12:45.

Intellectual, or supposedly intellectual, folks frequently sneer at the contemporary theatre. They declare it has no claims to their respect; that it is trivial and often vulgar, that its best work is pictorial, that it is not "literary," that it is, in short, "not worth while."

The meeting of the Tammany General Committee of the Thirty-fourth Assembly District for organization, last evening, at Loeffler's Hall, One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street and Willis Avenue, to all appearances was all harmony.

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Five Democrats -- three Senators and two Assemblymen -- bolted the Democratic caucus to-night because of their objection to the nomination of United States Senator David B. Hill as the candidate to succeed himself.

It is startling to find that the conviction of ZUKER, the incendiary, and the imposition upon him of what is virtually a sentence for life, has had so little exemplary effect. Here comes MYER and attempts a crime as detestable and atrocious as that of ZUKER, with ZUKER'S fate fairly before his eyes.

At the recent annual meeting of the American Geographical Society Lieut. PEARY described at length the plan regarded by him as the most feasible one for reaching the north pole. This plan provides for an advance by the route through Smith Sound and along the northwest coast of Greenland to the islands stretching away to the northward.
Joseph Block, a fur manufacturer of Williamsburg, died in his factory yesterday as a result of a fight he had a few minutes before with some men in front of his place.
ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- The following were among the bills introduced in the Senate tonight:

One of the most notable social events of the Winter season was the private ball given by Mrs. John Jacob Astor at her residence, 841 Fifth Avenue, last evening. There were nearly 300 guests, all prominent representatives of New York society.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The Supreme Court of the United States to-day decided that the famous dispensary law of South Carolina, at least so far as it attempted to prevent a citizen of the State from importing into the Commonwealth liquors for his own use, was in violation of the inter-State commerce clause of the Federal Constitution, and therefore, null and void.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The House began business to-day by passing a bill, reported by the Indian Affairs Committee, to prohibit the sale of intoxicating drinks to Indians.

Owing to the fact that most State Legislatures begin their sessions soon after the 1st of January, and that the Federal statute requires the vote for United States Senator to be taken on the second Tuesday after the meeting and organization of the Legislature that has one to choose, the first vote will be taken to-day in several States.

At the Hudson Street Hospital the doctors are trying to find a cigarette gift-motto button, which young Tommy Madden says he swallowed two weeks ago. Tommy lives with his parents at 54 State Street, Brooklyn.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 18. -- A resolution was adopted by the Legislature to-day fixing 10:30 o'clock to-morrow morning as the time for holding the joint session at which a United States Senator will be chosen.
