The Democrats will give their vote to Daniel Voorhees, the Populists will support Leroy Templeton, and the Republicans will support C.W. Fairbanks, who will be elected.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 18. -- Arthur Palmer shot and killed his brother, Leonard Palmer, and fatally wounded his mother and his sister, Gertrude, at the family home, on Weaver Street, early this evening. He immediately disappeared, and a large posse, headed by a Sheriff and an under Sheriff, started out to search the county for him.

The State Charities Aid Association appeals to its friends and the public for support in the important undertakings in which it is engaged, and in justification of this appeal it relies upon the substantial public benefit derived from its work in the last twenty-five years in aiding and guarding the dispensation of public charity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The President to-day sent to the house the report of the Deep Waterways Commission, made in pursuance of an act of Congress of 1895, its work being to make a preliminary examination regarding a deep waterway from the ocean to the great lakes. He accompanied it by the following message: To the Senate and the House of Representatives:

Mrs. Delia Hoffman, forty-nine years old, living at 709 Central Avenue, West Hoboken, was found in her bed at 6:30 yesterday morning murdered. The discovery was made by Richard Hoffman, her son, and John Engelbrecht, a boarder. She had been killed with a axe, which was found lying across her breast. Hoffman and Engelbrecht have been arrested on suspicion.
BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 18. -- There are seven deaths from illuminating gas in Boston's record for forty-eight hours.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- The trial of Edward J. Ivory, alias Edward Bell, of New York, who was arrested in Glasgow on Sept. 13 last charged with conspiracy to destroy life and property by the use of dynamite, was begun in the Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey, this morning, Justice Hawkins presiding.

The Greater New York Commission met in Mayor Strong's private office yesterday, and made radical changes in the proposed charter. The commission will be in session daily until the end of the month, when the completed charter must be presented to the Legislature. The first half dozen chapters were up for revision and correction yesterday.

VIENNA, Jan. 18. -- The Politische Correspondenz has a dispatch from Paris which states that France is discussing the advisability of negotiating with the United States an arbitration treaty on the model of the one signed a few days ago by the British and American Governments.

The proposition to establish a State commission to supervise the business of furnishing gas and electric light to the people and enforcing the laws relating to the obligations of the companies engaged in that business and the rights of the people who are their customers is a fine scheme for multiplying State offices, but it is a long step in the opposite direction to local home rule.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- The customary dinners on the eve of the meeting of Parliament were given to-night. Lord Salisbury's dinner was given at his residence, 20 Arlington Street, his guests including several Unionist peers and the mover and seconder of the address in reply to the Queen's speech opening the session, which will be read in Parliament to-morrow.

BOSTON, Jan. 18. -- Regarding the Chicago story that the American Bell Telephone Company has let contracts to equip a telegraph system in all the Northern States east of the Mississippi River, the Bell Telephone people here are noncommunicative, but usually well-informed stockholders say they do not believe the report is true, and they would be very much surprised if it was.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- A few Democratic Senators were surprised and annoyed to-day by the publication of a story alleging that three sound-money Democrats have made a compact to vote in the next session with the Republicans, to give the latter the organization of the Senate, and further, to assist the Republicans to pass a tariff bill.

The leading question of the day among scientific men, and in the leading papers, is the alarming increase of pneumonia, the death-rate showing an increase of over FIVE HUNDRED PER CENT, within the last few years. Doctor Gouverneur M. Smith, in an article in The Medical Record, says that while medical art has advanced of recent years in many directions, "so far as pneumonia is concerned science has shriveled."

ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Senator Ellsworth moved that the Senate at noon to-morrow ballot for United States Senator and Regent of the University, and that both Houses meet at noon on Wednesday in joint session to elect for both offices. This was adopted.

A special meeting of the Atlantic Yacht Club has been called by Commodore George J. Gould at the Waldorf to-morrow night. The report on the advisability of moving the clubhouse to Sea Gate will be the most important business considered. The majority of the members are in favor of making the move, and there is no doubt that it will be autborized.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- The report of the Waterways Commission gives a detailed account of the work of the commission, and, after considering the question in its various aspects, presents these conclusions:
ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Mr. Whritner offered a substitute for the resolutions offered by him Wednesday relating to the conflict between Cuba and Spain. The new resolutions read:

A respite has been granted sidewalk obstructors in Vesey Street for a few days by the Department of Public Works. This will afford them time enough to draft a bill for the Legislature which may legalize their present violations. The respite, Commissioner Collis said yesterday, might depend in a measure upon the courts, whether they shall compel the department to do its duty.

HAVANA, Jan. 18. -- Though the insurgents have no navy, they do not hesitate when the opportunity offers to attack the Spanish warships. The latest instance of this kind occurred yesterday morning, when a Spanish gunboat was sunk by means of a torpedo, and many of her crew were killed.
ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Assemblyman Forrester to-night introduced bills to regulate the charges for gas and telephone service and for a commission to select fenders for electric and cable cars.

-- Lord LANSDOWNE, the English Secretary of State for War, is not worrying at present about Russian designs on India, the fate of the arbitration treaty, or the new little war in Central Africa which he has on his hands. Instead, he has been devoting his powerful mind to the formulation of this circular memorandum to general officers commanding:
Somebody stole a bag containing $5,600 from a wagon standing in front of the Pacific Bank at noon yesterday and got safely away with the booty. The thief, as far as is known, was not seen by any one.
Hiram Rinaldo Brother have sold for Reutz Brose to A. Ottcnberg at about $3,000 the two five-story modern tenements 12 and 14 Cannon Street .25 by 100 each.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 18. -- The Cuban insurgents won a decided victory in the United States court this morning, as Judge Locke rendered a decision in the case of the United States vs. the steamer Three Friends for violation of the neutrality laws. He decided that no state of war existed, and no law had been violated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Pennsylvanians desiring Federal appointments from the McKinley Administration have received what is called a "quiet, but eloquent, tip" to get their applications countersigned by Senator Quay. There is no doubt of this here.

Alderman Benjamin E. Hall, Chairman of the Gas Committee of the board, announced yesterday that he had completed the bill which the committee authorized him to draft for presentation to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18. -- Secretary Olney will appear before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations on Wednesday and urge speedy action on the arbitration treaty. It was reported at the Capitol this morning that the committee would report the treaty back to the Senate Wednesday, but Senator Lodge said that he did not see how the committee could come to the point of reporting the treaty so soon.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 18. -- The German National Bank did not open its doors for business this morning, and the announcement was made that the institution was in the hands of Bank Examiner Escott. The capital stock is $251,500, with a surplus of $31,000. J.M. McKnight is President.
ALBANY, Jan. 18. -- Assemblyman Husted to-night introduced a bill regulating the height of dwelling houses in New York City. It provides as follows:
The British steamship Badsworth, Capt. Fox, from Pernambuco for New York, went ashore early yesterday morning off the Jersey coast, three miles north of Beach Haven.

The Manitoba Compromise had more than the usual infuriating effect of compromises upon extremists. It changed the political control of the Dominion, on account of the exasperation of the Catholics, and the end of it is not yet. Mr. LAURIER'S school policy has had a still more infuriating effect.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 18. -- The festivities of promenade week at Yale were at their height to-day. This afternoon was given up to official teas and receptions by all the classes. To-night was devoted to the annual Glee Club concert and the class germans. The concert was held in the Hyperian Theatre.

The seventh annual dinner of the Confederate Veteran Camp of New York, in memory of Gen. Robert E. Lee, was given last night at the St. Denis Hotel. The big banquet hall was decorated with the arms of the Southern States, grouped around the crest of the State of New York, and festoons of the American flag.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 19. -- Edward Lauterbach called on Major McKinley to-day and explained the wishes and purposes of the machine. Mr. Lauterbach said the organization desired harmony and hoped the Federal appointments would not be objectionable.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Packers and provision dealers in this city and the entire West are making ready for a concerted attack on the embargoes placed by foreign countries upon American meat products. Detroit, Kansas City, St. Louis, and Omaha are late recruits to the movement against prohibitory decrees just issued in several Switzerland Cantons and contemplated in Germany and France.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided the Fayerweather will contest, involving the distribution of $3,000,000 among educational institutions all over the country. The court's decision in the case, which was entitled Amherst College and others, respondents, versus the executors of the will, appellants, is: "Judgment affirmed, with costs to all parties appearing by separate attorneys, payable out of the estate."

HAVANA, Jan. 19. -- Capt. Gen. Weyler, accompanied by his staff, started for the field at 8 o'clock this morning. The General took a carriage from the palace to the outskirts of the city, where he mounted a horse and rode in the direction of San Jose de las Lajas, to the southeast of Havana.

NEWPORT, Ky., Jan. 19. -- Examination of the books of the failed First National Bank shows the liabilities of the bank, through loans made to ex-Cashier Youtsey direct and partly through his friends, to far exceed the amount first reported.

The twelfth annual Ihpetonga ball was held last night in the rooms of the Art Association and the assembly room of the Academy of Music, Brooklyn. Nearly 300 guests from Brooklyn, New York, Philadelphia, and Washington attended. The decorations were elaborate and profuse. Mrs. A.A. Low, Mrs. Edward H. Litchfield, and Mrs. David M. Morrison received.
CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- The steel and rail plant of the Illinois Steel Company, at South Chicago, was closed down to-day and between 2,000 and 3,000 employes thrown out of employment.

There is no occasion for any prolonged investigation to find out whether there are such things as trusts and "combines," or to ascertain whether any of them carry on their operations within this State. There has been much inquiry and accumulation of knowledge on the subject heretofore, and a new legislative investigation would have very much the appearance of a device to stave off legislation.

The Greater New York Commission shows a disposition to modify the draft of a charter submitted by its committee, but the most important change that it has yet made is one not generally favored by those who appeared at the hearings, while there seems to be no intention of making those changes most strenuously advocated by men who have made a study of municipal administration and are most urgent for reformed methods.
ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- The Assembly did little but vote for United States Senator to-day. A large number of bills were introduced, among them being the following:

The net result of the political efforts in Delaware of ADDICKS, the Massachusetts "gas man," has been such a division of his party that a free-silver Democrat is elected to the United States Senate, though the State was carried by the Republicans at the election by a plurality of nearly 4,000 in a total vote of about 37,000, which is equivalent to a plurality of 140,000 in New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Representative Fischer of New York has evolved a plan which, in his opinion, will make New York City safe from the attack of a hostile fleet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- Senator Sherman will not talk about the arbitration treaty, but Senators who have talked with him since his return from Canton are not averse to expressing opinions privately, and it is not difficult to gather that the treaty is less strong to-day than it was the day after the President sent it to the Senate.

MEDIA, Penn., Jan. 19. -- A passenger train on the Pennsylvania Railroad was derailed near here Saturday, and the engine and tender were hurled down the embankment. The cause of the wreck was a shovel handle, which had been placed on the track. No passengers were hurt, but the engineer and fireman were seriously injured.

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- Parliament reassembled to-day and the members of the House of Commons as usual proceeded to the House of Lords to hear the reading of the Queen's speech, which was read by the Lord Chancellor a follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- Thomas C. Platt to-day received a large majority of the votes cast for United States Senator, the two houses voting in separate session. A joint session will be held at noon to-morrow, when Mr. Platt will be declared elected. There was no bolt from the Republican caucus decision, but in each house Democrats refused to support David B. Hill.

We have lately put before the merchants and business men of New York statistics showing that this port is not holding its own in foreign trade. The subject is not new. In August, 1895, we had occasion to warn the people of this city that their commercial supremacy was by no means secure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The suggestion cabled from Europe that France would endeavor to negotiate a general arbitration treaty with the United States similar to the Anglo-Amercan agreement now before the Senate, is not at all new in Washington, President Cleveland having called attention in his annual message of December, 1895, to "the recent resolution of the French Chambers favoring the conclusion of a permanent treaty of arbitration between the two countries."

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- S.D. Caldwell, Vice President and General Manager of the Western Transit Company, the New York Central's lake line, has resigned on account of ill health. Mr. Caldwell has been connected with the line for the past thirteen years. His successor has not yet been named.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Action was taken to- day at a conference of the bituminous coal-carrying roads east of Chicago and the shippers and dealers of this city and coal mining centres looking to a cessation of the trouble which has been caused over soft-coal rates, alleged cutting by the Baltimore and Ohio, and other inequalities.

TOLLESTON, Ind., Jan. 19. -- In an encounter yesterday between the hired game wardens of the Tolleston Shooting Club and outsiders four men were wounded, and one of them has bet a day or two to live. The injured are:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The House spent almost the whole of to-day's session in Committee of the Whole considering private pension bills. Favorable acton was taken upon fifty-two of them, one being the Senate bill to increase to $100 a month the pension of Major Gen. Julius H. Stahel.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- A large audience was present in the Assembly Chamber to-night to witness the opening session of the annual meeting of the New York State Bar Association, which will be concluded tomorrow, when the election of officers will take place. President Edward G. Whittaker of New York City called the meeting to order, and, after prayer, he introduced Postmaster General William L. Wilson.

The newly elected Governors of the New York Athletic Club held their first meeting last night at the clubhouse and organized for the year. A communication from the Amateur Athletic Union was read asking that the club join the union again. This caused considerable discussion and was finally referred to the Athletic Committee.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- The Englewood and Chicago Electric Street Railway went into the hands of a receiver this evening. The proceedings were taken in the United States District Court, at the instigation of the New York bondholders. A confession of judgment on a note for $1,200 in favor of Stephen D. Bayer of New York City was entered by the company in court as an excuse for the appointment of a receiver.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 19. -- The planing mill of the Dixie Mill Company, about five miles above the city, on Mobile River, was burned this afternoon. The plant was valued at about $50,000, and was insured for about $25,000.

It is announced that during the inauguration ceremonies Mr. McKINLEY will wear a suit of clothing made of worsted goods manufactured at a mill in Connecticut. This is regarded as a matter of such public interest that the fact is reported in telegraphic dispatches to the American press.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 19. -- Senator Sheehan to-day introduced a drastic anti-trust bill. The measure declares that every form of agreement, combine, trust, contract, or arrangement designed to lessen competition in mercantile trade or manufacturing shall be declared unlawful and void and that Minnesota corporations entering into combinations of this kind shall forfeit their charters, and foreign corporations entering into such combinations shall be excluded from the State.

Bidding was lively at the auction sale of the Henry F. Sewall book collection yesterday, at the rooms of Bangs Co., 93 Fifth Avenue. The 271 lots sold included some rare first editions which are much sought by collectors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- The Rev. Dr. Thomas J. Conaty of Worcester, Mass., was installed as Rector of the Catholic University of America this afternoon. The exercises took place in the assembly room of the McMahon Hall of Philosophy, where a large and distinguished audience had gathered.
Mayor Strong yesterday sent a supplemental message to the Board of Aldermen, dealing with the Board of Education, the Health Board, and the Bureau of City Record.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- Assemblyman Reinhard of New York City to-day introduced a bill carrying out the suggestions contained in Attorney General Hancock's opinion allowing District Attorney Olcott of New York City to devise civil service regulations for making appointments in his office.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 19. -- Mrs. Harriet Palmer died at 10:30 o'clock this morning from the wounds inflicted by her mad son, Arthur Palmer, last evening, and Gertrude Palmer, the murderer's sister, died about 6 o'clock this evening. Their funerals, with that of Leonard Palmer, who was killed by his brother, will probably take place Thursday. Coroner Banning will hold an inquest the same day.

Acting under the advice of her physician, Mme. Melba will leave New York Saturday on La Bourgogne, and rest. She will probably return to America in time for the Chicago season and for the supplementary season here.

" Charity," in brilliant jets, beamed down last night at the Metropolitan Opera House on as large and dazzling an assemblage as ever graced the annual Purim Ball. The staging had been extended over the orchestra chairs to the first tier in the crescent, which rendered the lower floor only a promenade on the sides. The audience was massed above in the boxes, while the dancers occupied the floor.

Formal charges of neglect of duty will be prepared within a few days against Gen. C.H.T. Collis, Commissioner of Public Works, to ascertain why he refuses to clear the sidewalks of Vesey Street, and by what right he authorized the storekeepers there to violate the law which forbids any obstruction of the sidewalks.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 19. -- The two branches of the Legislature this morning voted separately for United States Senator, and Richard R. Kenney, the nominee of last night's Democratic caucus, received all the votes cast. The two branches will vote in joint session to-morrow. Kenney is a free-silver man.

-- Unfair as it doubtless is to ascribe much significance to assertions of political views by persons vile enough to break into a public school and wreck its furniture, yet one cannot help noting with the contrary of surprise the fact that those Paterson scoundrels who amused themselves in this way wrote on the blackboard before they left: "We are Bryan men."

Sonn Brothers have sold to I. Hart and Mayer the four lots on the southwest corner of One Hundred and Second Street and Central Park West. The purchasers propose to erect on this site two superior six-story apartment houses, one 60 by 100 and the other 40 by 100. The houses for which the architect, Edward L. Angell, is drawing the plans will be fireproof throughout, and supplied with elevators and other modern conveniences.

A number of Senators on the Republican side are talking to correspondents about the arbitration treaty. The most significant thing they have to say is that "there is no hurry," which means that the treaty will be put off until Mr. McKINLEY becomes President. There would be no objection to that if the time were needed to study the treaty and if it were used for that purpose.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 19. -- William E. Mason was to-night nominated by acclamation for the United States Senate to succeed John M. Palmer, at the joint Republican caucus, all other candidate withdrawing when it became apparent that Mason would have a majority. He will be elected to-morrow.

The Atlas Line steamer Alvena, bound for Haiti and West Indian ports, was run into yesterday by the Phoenix Line steamer British Queen, bound in from Antwerp. The collision occurred at the junction of the Swash and Bay Ridge Ship Channels, about two miles east of Sandy Hook shortly after 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- When the Senate convened this morning the Finance Committee reported favorably on Senator Ellsworth's bill appropriating $26,000 for the contingent expenzes of the Senate, and Senator Mullins's bill appropriating $12,000 for New York State's representation at the Tennessee Exposition. Both bills were ordered to a third reading.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- It was believed here this morning that four places had been filled in Mr. McKinley's Cabinet -- Mr. Sherman, Secretary of State; Mr. Long of Massachusetts, Secretary of the Navy; Mr. McKenna of California, Secretary of Agriculture, and Mr. Goff of West Virginia, Attorney General. To-night there is uncertainty in the minds of Republicans about all but the Secretary of State.

At the meeting of the Greater New York Commission yesterday, in Mayor Strong's office, no extremely radical changes were made in the draft of the charter. The chapter on the Building Department was amended so that each of the three Building Commissioners must be an expert builder or architect for ten years prior to his appointment.

The seventh annual banquet of the Vermont Society of Brooklyn took place at the Montauk Club last evening. About seventy persons were present. Col. Albert B. Chandler presided. With him at the speakers' table were the Rev. Theodore L. Cuyler, Col. N.T. Sprague, Herbert L. Bridgman, Justice William W. Goodrich, Robert D. Benedict, and John A. Taylor.

ALBANY, Jan. 19. -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided the Westchester County Congressional case of Fairchild against Ward in favor of the former, and so declared that the name of Benjamin L. Fairchild should have appeared on the official ballot as the regular Republican candidate in the Sixteenth Congressional District instead of the name of William L. Ward.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 19. -- During the morning hour a large number of private pension bills were reported from the Committee on Pensions and placed on the calendar.

HAVANA, Jan. 20. -- Henry Delgado, the correspondent of a New York newspaper who was arrested some time ago on the charge of being a rebel officer, and who had been lying ill in the San Ambrosia Hospital here ever since he was brought to this city, died this morning.

The firm of L.L. White Co., stock brokers, 80 Broadway, will cease to exist after Feb. 1, as Loomis L. White, the senior partner and Stock Exchange member, intends to retire from business. The partners are Mr. White and Louis K. Taylor. Mr. Taylor has no plans at present.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Speaker laid before the House a bill authorizing the Cairo and Tennessee River Railroad Company to build bridges across the Cumberland and Tennessee Rivers in Kentucky, with Senate amendments, which were concurred in.

Book buyers attended in force yesterday the sale of the Henry F. Sewall collection of rare books at the auction rooms of Bangs Co., 93 Fifth Avenue. Several of the most valuable lots of the collection, including seventy-one examples of Shakespeare and several of Edmund Spenser, were sold.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 20. -- Torpedo Boat No. 6 made a speed of 26.85 knots in the bay this afternoon, and otherwise behaved so finely that her builders were as surprised as they were delighted. The Herreshoffs guaranteed that the craft would make 27 1/2 knots under 220 pounds of steam, and as only 180 pounds were used to-day no doubt is left that she will more than meet the requirements.

Dentists of Missouri are asking for a State registration law, saying that anybody can practice there now under a diploma from any sort of a dental school of whatever standing or no standing at all, and that the State is fast becoming a dumping ground in which men may practice dentistry who are not eligible to the profession in any other State.

The snow which began to fall about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon marked a break in the cold wave in this vicinity. The tail of the cold wave passed over the New England States and Nova Scotia yesterday morning.

Distinguished anthropologists are no doubt already converging on Washington intent on studying the cranial formation of the Senators who entertain paleolithic views of the arbitration treaty. In their arguments against confirmation these Senators express social opinions that were held in the glacial period, when chipped-flint spearheads were the arguments that closed debate and the man with the thickest pate and the largest club was the boss of the neighborhood.
ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- The Lexow trust investigation resolution came up for discussion soon after the Senate convened to-day. Senator Ellsworth presided in the Lieutenant Governor's chair.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- A bill was introduced by Assemblyman Austin yesterday providing for the construction of the new Court House for the Appellate Division, in New York City. One section provides specifically that a portion of the contracts shall be awarded "without public letting." That part of the bill which contains this provision reads thus:

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Senator Grady (Dem., N.Y.,) to-day introduced a bill adding a sub-division to section 640 of the Penal Code, which is intended to prevent the desecration, mutilation, or improper use of the United States or State flag. The bill provides:

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The Senate and Assembly met in joint session in the Assembly Chamber at noon and elected Thomas C. Platt of Owego, Tioga County, United States Senator to succeed David B. Hill, and Chester S. Lord of New York City Regent of the University.

Tablets of brass should be affixed to the gate posts of the Capitol to commemorate the imposing stupidity of the five legislators -- GUY, COFFEY, McNULTY, CAIN, and ZURN -- who bolted the Democratic Senatorial caucus because they could not forget or forgive Senator HILL'S course in the Bryan canvass.

The inauguration of Dr. CONATY as rector of the University of Washington was an event of particular interest on account of the events that have preceded it. The rectorship has been the focus of a good many obscure intrigues. Nobody knows exactly why or how Dr. KEANE came to be displaced.

Instructions were given yesterday by L.J. Callanan for the drawing of a formal complaint against Gen. C.H.T. Collis, Commissioner of Public Works, charging neglect of duty and undue discrimination. Mr. Callanan furnished his lawyer, E.M. Wight, with specifications enumerating the storekeepers in Vesey Street who are violating the law against sidewalk obstructions.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 20. -- Representative Neary of Naugatuck presented in the House to-day a bill which, if it becomes a law, will revolutionize the railroad business in this State. It provides that freight shall be carried for 6 cents a hundred, milk 1/2 cent a quart, bicycles 5 cents each, passengers 1 cent a mile, open freight cars $5 for any distance within the State.
Mr. A.M. Graff has sold the four-story brownstone dwelling, 134 West Eightieth Street, 18 by 55 by 102.2.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 20. -- M.W. Dunham, the millionaire stockman of Oakland Farm, Wayne, Dupage County, Ill., who was taken suddenly sick last Friday while sitting at his desk, is still in a very critical condition.

The Police Commissioners yesterday discussed the plan of having a parade of the new policemen. The matter was brought up by Commissioner Roosevelt, who said that the Mayor had expressed a desire to see the new men, and Mr. Roosevelt wanted the Greater New York Commissioners to see them.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 20. -- M.A. Hanna, Chairman of the Republican National Committee, came here this afternoon, mainly to discuss Ohio politics. He had a good deal to say about other matters, and conferred with Major McKinley upon many men and measures of general interest.

PADUCAH, Ky., Jan. 20. -- Intense excitement exists at Dycusburg, thirty miles below here, on the Cumberland River, over a threat to burn the town to-night. There is no telegraph station at Dycusburg, and no boat until to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations this morning listened to Secretary Olney for more than one hour. The Secretary, who drew the general treaty of arbitration between this Government and Great Britain, made an elaborate argument in favor of the ratification of the treaty as sent to the Senate.

The proceedings of the Board of Education were enlivened yesterday afternoon by a spirited attack upon the educational system proposed for Greater New York. Commissioner Little led the attack, and was supported by nearly all of his colleagues. In committing the subject to a special committee, with instructions to have the sentiment of the board on disputed points brought before the Charter Commission, the vote was unanimous.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- News has been received here that Mrs. Harris, wife of the veteran Senator from Tennessee, died near Paris, Tenn., last night, and will be interred at Memphis. Senator Harris, himself an invalid, left Washington a few days ago to be at the bedside of his dying wife.

" Washington Crossing the Delaware," the famous historical painting by Emanuel Leutze, was purchased last evening by John S. Kennedy, for $16,100, at the second night's sale of the Marshall O. Roberts collection, at Checkering Hall.

The association of canal boatmen has waked up to the fact that the organization of a great corporation to engage in the business of transportation upon the Erie Canal after its enlargement threatens the destruction of the small boat-owners, but it is to be feared that the result is inevitable.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- A joint resolution for the appointment of a commission to collect statistics on mines and mining was referred.

There is something amusing in the spectacle of a Congress avowedly bent upon reconstructing the tariff on protective lines being asked at the same time to prevent the countries whose products we are endeavoring to shut out from shutting out our products. The packers and provision dealers of the West are very naturally excited over the exclusion of their wares from three Swiss cantons and the proposal to exclude them from France and Germany.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- There is an interesting story of Mrs. Charles S. Aungier, who has a cool million of dollars in her own right, her husband for whom she is searching with a warrant, and Millionaire John C. Maywell, from whom Mrs. Aungier has been divorced, but who, it is said, professes to love still.

Thomas A. Doe, Chief Clerk of the Street Cleaning Department, has sent a letter to Commissioner Waring contravening the assertion of unusual expenditures in the department. Mr. Doe says that while some critics have declared that "Waring comes high, but we must have him," the fact is that Col. Waring does not come high. The chief clerk says:

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- An item of $100,000 on the books of the Englewood and Chicago Electric Street Railway Company charged to "miscellaneous" may lead to sensational developments and cause certain Chicago Aldermen more or less uneasiness, if it does not lead to their imprisonment.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 20. -- The examining trial of Jacob Neace and Dan Farler for killing Deputy Marshal Bird was concluded to-day before United States Commissioner J.B. Marcum, at Jackson, who held them over to the United States Circuit Court without bail.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Prof. Albert S. Bickmore, of the American Museum of Natural History, was here to-day, with a bill which provides for continuance of the lectures to teachers throughout the State, which have for several years been a feature of the work at the museum. Mr. Austin introduced the bill.

After many trials and some experiences that seldom fall to the lot of a prospective bridegroom, Pastor Herman F.C.H. Schoppe of St. John's Evangelical Lutheran Church, Union, N.J., was married last night to Miss Anna. M. Heinrichs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Anglo-Venezuelan arbitration treaty has been practically concluded, as Sir Julian Pauncefote is only awaiting a cablegram from Lord Salisbury, when he and Senor Andrade will sign the duplicate drafts and forward them to their respective Governments. The formal conclusion of the treaty may take place at either the British Embassy or the Venezuelan Legation at any moment.

By far the most important topic of the Queen's speech is the treaty of arbitration. The speech is technically in the right in saying that the treaty is "concluded," although the ratifications have not yet been exchanged, and although certain Senators of the United States are concerning themselves to prevent the exchange.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- The Metropolitan West Side Elevated Railroad was placed in the hands of a receiver, appointed by the Federal court, this afternoon.

While fire was working destruction on the two upper floors of Bellevue Hospital Medical College, a little before 5 o'clock yesterday morning, the Superintendent and attendants in the adjoining hospital were obliged to exercise the utmost diligence and coolness in preventing a panic among the patients.
ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Beyond the introduction of bills no business was transacted in the Assembly to-day. The following bills were introduced:

The Senate at Albany yesterday adopted the LeNOW resolution providing for a special committee to investigate "trusts." Mr. LENOW, in advocating the adoption of his resolution and opposing the substitutes of Mr. CANTOR and Mr. GRADY, used strong language in denouncing these "unlawful combinations," but he failed to show the need of investigation to disclose their existence or their methods.

The New York Board of Trade and Transportation gave its twenty-fourth annual dinner last night at the Waldorf. The big banquet hall was decorated with smilax, palms, and pink roses, and 200 members and guests shared the hospitality of the association.

The collision between the Phoenix Line steamship British Queen and the Atlas Line steamship Alvena, which occurred off Sandy Hook on Tuesday afternoon, will probably become the subject of a lawsuit in which the Atlas Line Company will be the plaintiff.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- The meeting of the National Guard Association was full of life. The delegates put themselves on record as condemning political selections of men to wear uniforms in high positions. The members of the Governor's staff came in for a share of criticism, and a pretty severe slap was administered to the deposed Inspector General, McLewee.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 20. -- The absence of Southern iron operators at the tariff hearings of the Ways and Means Committee, at Washington, would appear to be due to indifference to a tariff on iron. This idea is borne out by Mr. Haas; President of the Sloss Iron and Steel Company, which is one of the largest iron producers and shippers of export iron in the South.

The second Wednesday cotillion took place at Sherry's last evening. The guests were received by the patronesses -- Mrs. Algernon Sydney Sullivan, Mrs. William L. Trenholm, Mrs. Samuel Spencer, Mrs. Robert Nicoll, Mrs. John Burling Lawrence, Mrs. Oliver Livingston Jones, and Mrs. William S. Livingston -- in the pink reception room.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- The trial of Edward J. Ivory, the alleged dynamite conspirator, which began on Monday, suddenly came to an end to-day by the complete collapse of the Government's case and the discharge of the prisoner.

-- Churchmen in the South, where sectarianism is almost as rampant as ever it was in New England, do not hesitate to rejoice openly over denominational "victories." Thus, a correspondent of The Southwestern Presbyterian, writing from Texas, says: "A young man who had been a Baptist and had married a daughter of one of our elders came out on the Lord's side and made a public profession of his faith and united with our church."

DENVER, Col., Jan. 20. -- Senator Henry M. Teller, who was re-elected to the United States Senate to-day, in an interview to-night on the selection of Senator John Sherman for Secretary of State in the Cabinet of President McKinley, said:

If the bill introduced in the Legislature by Mr. REINHARD of this city regulating appointments in the office of the District Attorney does not have the approval of that officer he should make that fact known promptly and emphatically. If he approves the bill, if it is, in effect, his bill, he has made two very serious mistakes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- There is good foundation for the talk that renewed pressure is being brought to bear upon Chairman Dingley of the Ways and Means Committee to induce him to reconsider his determination not to assume the Secretaryship of the Treasury.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- It is believed that Mr. C.T. Yerkes to-day controls the elevated railway situation in this city, and that he ultimately will appear at the head of a company formed by consolidating all the elevated lines in the city. This was made possible by the Metropolitan Company going into the hands of a receiver yesterday.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- State Treasurer Colvin to-day transmitted his annual report to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The action of Bank Examiner Escott, at Louisville, in swearing out a warrant for the arrest of J. McKnight, President of the German National Bank of that place, is the result of instructions from the Controller of the Currency, following a careful examination into the condition of the institution.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Further details have reached here of the recent massacre of members of a peaceable British expedition by natives of the Benin country, and the facts as now known have excited the deepest indignation even among the "Little Englandera," who declare that prompt punishment should be meted out to the murderer's.
ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- The following bills were introduced in the Senate to-day:

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- Mrs. Clara Foltz, an attorney and counselor at law of New York City, brought to Albany to-day a bill "to create the office of Public Defender, provide for his election, define his duties, and fix his compensation in the several counties and cities of New York.

ALTON, Ill., Jan. 21. -- A farmer walking along the Mississippi bank about one mile below this city this morning came upon the body of a man lying near the water's edge, and reported the fact to the police. The Coroner found the body of a young man fashionably dressed, hardly cold in death. In the forehead just above the right temple was a bullet wound.

It is evident that the opponents of the arbitration treaty intend to make as much of an obstacle of the Monroe doctrine as they can. They say that this country will not submit the Monroe doctrine to arbitration, and that if the treaty does not cover that point there is no reason why the point should not expressly be excluded.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- Mr. Reinhard's bill to permit District Attorney Olcott to make his own civil service regulations in appointing deputies, clerks and an entire office force was recommended for passage by the Assembly Cities Committee this afternoon. Assemblyman William Cary Sanger made a two-minute speech against it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The Republican members of Congress from New York decided to-day to unite in asking Major McKinley to appoint Representative Sherman of the Utica District to a Cabinet position.

After the Dock Board meeting yesterday Charles A. Pillsbury, the miller of Minneapolis; Bradford E. Church of the Duluth Imperial Mills, President of the Head of the Lake Millers' Association, and Walter Fowler, President of the Grand Republic Mills, accompanied by Erastus Wiman, President of the Consolidated Canal and lake Company, called on the Commissioners.

The third concert of the eleventh season of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, in this city, took place last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The auditorium was crowded with enthusiastic music lovers, who bravely faced the copious draughts of cold air in the house for the sake of hearing good music well played.

Justice Andrews, in the Supreme Court, has issued an order setting aside a judgment for $50,000, with costs of $389, which was obtained against Dr. C.A. Tinker, 124 West One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, by Frederick L. Colwell in an action against Dr. Tinker for alienating the affections of his wife, Genevieve R. Colwell.

The "favorable notice" by Mr. LAUTERBACH of J. SLOAT FASSETT for a Cabinet position suggests varied reflections. He would fill without discredit one of the minor positions in the Cabinet. The beneficent advance of civil service reform has stripped these offices of the patronage in the distribution of which he would be exposed to the greatest temptation.

The kite-flying experiments of Lieut. H. D. Wise, on Governors Island, have at last been successful, and the Lieutenant is the first man in America to go aloft on a kite string. He made an ascent yesterday when the wind was blowing fifteen miles an hour.
The police of Brooklyn stand in fear of a general shake-up of the force on Feb. 1. Persons who stand close to Police Commissioner Welles said last night that these fears are justified.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 21. -- Lyman J. Gage of Chicago, who was first mentioned in these dispatches as a Cabinet possibility, is being seriously considered with reference to his availability for appointment to the position of Secretary of the Treasury.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- It is believed by the police that the railroad ticket swindler who was arrested here yesterday afternoon, and who gave his name as Charles McKenna of Colorado, is Fernando Byrnes, alias Charles Martin, and a score of other names, who has been working his swindling scheme for a long time.

QUOGUE, L.I., Jan. 21. -- The three-masted schooner Nahum Chapin, Capt. S.E. Arey, coal-laden from Baltimore to Boston, came ashore here early this morning. She was heavily laden, and while the life-savers and hundreds of persons stood on the beach powerless to render aid, the schooner pounded to pieces on the bar, and her Captain and crew of eight men were drowned.

ERIE, Penn., Jan. 21. -- The Erie and Western Railroad Company was organized at Erie to-day for the purpose of bringing this city and port into closer touch with the oil and lumber sections of this State. The company organized with Edward D. Carter, President; J.V. Bolard of Waterford and J.S. Vancleve of Erie, Vice Presidents; J.J. Roemer and Frank Montgomery, Secretaries.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 21. -- Train No. 35 on the Southern Railway, an express from Washington to Greenville, Miss., was captured at Bankston, Ala., seventy miles west of Birmingham, this evening, and robbed.

Company B captured the markmanship honors at the Seventh Regiment Armory rifle range last night by breaking the record for the Kemp Trophy and making the best score for the Clark Trophy in this year's contest.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- The calendar showed but five bills, and it was suggested that until the committees should receive more bills from the printer for their consideration, the House might as well adjourn.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- Soon after the Senate convened this morning Gov. Black's private secretary was announced, and presented a message from the Governor nominating the members of the Greater New York Commission. They were confirmed. The members of the Greater New York Commission were recess appointments made by Gov. Morton.

The meeting of the Greater New York Commission in Mayor Strong's private office yesterday was not productive of important results in the way of changes. One reason for this was that only a few of the members of the commission were able to be present. The chapter on the Finance Department was adopted without important alterations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The proposition advanced by Representative Fischer of New York to reclaim two acres of Romer Shoals, in New York Harbor, and provide them with suitable means of defense, is meeting with considerable favor from members of the House who have familiarized themselves with the subject.
The reorganization or rehabilitation of the Union Pacific Railroad is far from being assured as yet.

No man ever bore more conspicuously the outward signs of valiant purposes than Senator LEXOW, who has been for some days noisily putting on his armor to do battle against the trusts. He has carried through the Senate a resolution providing that a committee of three Senators and four Assemblymen shall investigate the subject of trusts, report by March 1, and bring in a bill of remedies.

It is really satisfactory that that American picture which is probably familiar, through reproductions, to more American men, women, and children than any other American work of art whatsoever should have been secured for New York. It was secured after a competition that was remarkably keen, and that was stimulated by the natural desire of the Trustees of the Corcoran Gallery, now newly and handsomely housed, to secure the work for the National capital.

Two hundred and seventy-three lots of the Henry F. Sewall collection of rare books were sold yesterday by Bangs Co. at their salesroom, 93 Fifth Avenue. The interest stimulated among the buyers by the Shakespeare offerings of Wednesday was continued yesterday by the sale of many early and rare editions of the New Testament, Virgil, and other works much sought by the buyers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- An immigration bill has been agreed upon by all the conferrees of the Senate and House, excpt Mr. Bartholdt, (Rep., Mo.,) Chairman of the House committee in charge of the subject. He has not yet formally stated that he would not sign the report, but his associates do not expect him to do so. The full text of the measure reads:

Perhaps the most deplorable thing about the latest lynching, that of three negroes in Louisiana, was the absence of any excuse for it from the ordinary lynching point of view. Though the victims were negroes, they were not killed for "the usual crime," but for plain homicide. One of the cases was that of a wife-murderer.

James E. Lynn, who said he was nineteen years old, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Court yesterday, charged with swindling a number of persons in this city and Brooklyn by obtaining money to make crayon portraits, which were never made.
NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 21. -- As only two favorites won in the racing to-day, the bookmakers had the better of it on the day's results.

Escaping gas in the basement of the four-story brownstone house at 382 Pleasant Avenue was ignited by the fire in the furnace, and exploded with great force yesterday morning. The force of the explosion blew off the covers of the coal chute in the sidewalk, and knocked down Miss Agnes Fitzgerald, fifteen years old, who was standing near.

The twenty-eighth annual dinner of Sorosis was given at the Waldorf last night. The grand ballroom presented a brilliant scene at 7 o'clock, when about 150 members and guests were seated at the tables. The effect of the rich ornamentation of the room was heightened by floral decorations and lights of various colors.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- Charles C. Harrison, Provost of the University of Pennsylvania, Jan. 19 sent the following letter to ex-Senator Edmunds:

The Republican machine has been entirely successful so far in the State of New York. It has placed its leader in the United States Senate by the almost unanimous vote of the party caucus. It has "quieted" the claim of one of its most conspicuous opponents to a seat in the new Cabinet.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The House bill extending the time for building the bridge over the East River, at New York, was reported back favorably and placed on the calendar.

ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- Assemblyman Nixon to-day, as Chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, introduced the Annual Appropriation bill. This measure carries the regular appropriations for the year for the State departments and State institutions. Last year's bill carried appropriations aggregating about $9,700,000. This year's measure appropriates about $200,000 less than last year.

-- ELLEN TERRY and Lord SALISBURY have each had the curious experience of being refused admission to the Casino at Monte Carlo on the ground that they were not well enough dressed to meet the requirements of a mysterious but extremely strict code which has been established by the managers of that sinful establishment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- There is a chock-block in the way of the arbitration treaty in the Senate.

American shares were irregular in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- New York Central, 1/8, to 97 1/4, and Atchison, 1/8, to 14 7/8. Declined -- Canadian Pacific, 7/8, to 56 5/8; St. Paul, 1/2, to 78 3/8; Louisville and Nashville, 1/4 to 52 7/8, and Illinois Central, 1/8, to 96 3/4. Erie sold at 15 2/8, and do first preferred at 36.
We published yesterday a very interesting interview with Mr. HAAS, the President of one of the largest companies which make iron in the South, who said:

KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 21. -- Passengers by the Olivette report the circumstances of the recent capture of train near Havana by insurgents, a brief account of which has already been published in this country.

BOSTON, Jan. 21. -- The schooner Nahum Chapin, wrecked near Quogue, L.I., was built at Rockland, Me., in 1882, by Cobb, Wright Co., and registered 567 tons. She was 145 feet long and had 35 feet breadth of beam and 15 feet 6 inches depth of hold, She was valued at about $15,000, and is partially insured in the Boston Marine Insurance Company.

-- Lively opposition has been developed among both alumni and undergraduates of Harvard by a proposition to spread out the annual Class Day exercises over a period of two or three days, instead of confining them to one day, as has been the time-honored custom. The students who propose this extension of their jollification do it because "there are now so many 'spreads' that the guests do not and cannot enjoy them all."
In his recent message the Mayor, after speaking of measures taken to prevent the sale of adulterated milk in this city, referred as follows to the inspection of cows found within the city limits:
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- A son was born to-day to "Admiral Dot" and his wife, who was Miss Lottie Swartwood, also a Lilliputian. The infant weighs seven pounds and seems altogether normal.

The action of Commissioner Collis in granting permission to the storekeepers on Vesey Street, below Church Street, to violate the law against sidewalk obstructions has already borne fruit. It has emboldened those nearer Broadway to believe that they have at least equal rights. The block between Broadway and Church Street was cleared last Summer after mandamus proceedings had been taken to compel the Department of Public Works to do its duty.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Gen. Ruger in General Orders from Governors Island Headquarters his published the report of Col. Thomas Ward, Department Inspector of Small Arms with his indorsement.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 21. -- When Private Middlebrooks of Company K, Fourth Regiment, Connecticut National Guard, received his blouse, which came from Jeffersonville, Ind., along with those for the rest of the regiment, he found in the pocket a piece of paper on which was inscribed: "Miss Mary Rutherford, Jeffersonville, Ind."
The Princeton Alumni had their annual dinner last night in the banquet hall of the Hotel Savoy, under the auspices of the Princeton Club of New York.

Superintendent Knoll, at the Hudson Street Hospital, completed an X ray photograph yesterday clearly outlining the brachial artery in the right arm of Thomas Saltmann of 621 East One Hundred and Forty-ninth Street. This is said to be the first time such a feat has been accomplished.
NEWARK, Jan. 21. -- The annual dinner of the Newark Board of Trade was given to-night.

Papers read at the meeting of the New York Academy of Medicine, in West Forty-third Street, last night, on the tubercle bacillus, led to a discussion which touched upon the recent action of the Board of Health relating to the Isolation of patients suffering from tubercular consumption and the requirement that physicians report all such cases to the authorities.

Lowenfeld and Prager have sold to Abelman and Rosenbaum a plot on the south side of East One Hundred and Nineteenth Street. 140 feet west of Park Avenue, 35 by 100. The purchasers will erect on the site a five-story apartment house.

The German-American Democrats of the Eleventh Congressional District took up the subject of "Municipal Ownership of Gas, Electric Lights, and Railroads" at a meeting in the hall of the Double-Standard Club, 11 Third Avenue, last night.
LONDON, Jan. 21. -- The Government has issued a blue book containing the official correspondence in regard to the projected reforms in Turkey.
Stock market dull and heavy. One or two sensational features. Money on call, 1 1/2 to 2 per cent. Sterling exchange weak.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- It is understood that Representative Newlands of Nevada has successfully negotiated a treaty with a sufficient number of free-silver Senators from the West to insure the passage of a tariff bill at the special session.

John H. Hunter, sixteen years old, and a companion named Joseph Dolan, were prisoners in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning, charged with having robbed the home of young Hunter's father, at 161 East One Hundred and Twenty-first Street, last Tuesday morning.

Four persons who attempted to rob the bank of Henry Pinkus, at 216 Grand Street, Thursday afternoon, were indicted, arraigned in court, and, on their pleas of guilty, sentenced to prison yesterday. Three of them will be taken to Sing Sing to-day, and the other will be sent to the Elmira Reformatory.

County Clerk Purroy is really outside of the Tammany breastworks now. The leadership in the Thirty-fifth Assembly District fell last night to James McCartney. H.W. Zeltner also was chosen as a member of the Tammany Executive Committee. The selection of McCartney surprised the meeting, but it was ratified by practically a unanimous vote.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- Adjt. Gen. Tillinghast to-day issued General Order No. 2, in which he says:
A swindler managed recently to get two passes to Buffalo and return from Chauncey M. Depew, and $10 from Fred S. Gibbs. He tried, but failed, to obtain $20 from Edward Lauterbach.

PORTLAND, Ind., Jan. 22. -- A letter has been received here from the Rev. Benjamin Mitchell, who, with his wife and Miss Ida Kinsey, a Portland girl, is stationed at Bina, in the Central Province of India, right in the heart of the district which is being now devastated by famine. In his letter Mr. Mitchell says:

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 22. -- The police of Anniston, Ala., have in their custody a remarkable prisoner in the person of an armless man who is accused of forgery. His name is A.R. Fowler, and he was formerly a Presbyterian minister. He was captured at Anniston, and already an officer from Georgia is on his way to bring back the erstwhile clergyman for trial at Elberton.

The special services which have been held in Madison Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church for the past three days by the Central Council of the International Order of the King's Daughters and Sons were continued yesterday afternoon and evening, when the meetings were brought to a close.

Zola, when interviewed by a representative of The London Telegraph as to his future work, said that his "Paris," which was the last of the three volumes of that series of which "Lourdes" and "Rome" were the first and second, was almost finished. The Abbe Pierre Froment, as in the other volumes, figures in the new one.
BOSTON, Jan. 22. -- The historic "Tree Exercises" of Harvard class day seem doomed.

Permit me to congratulate THE TIMES upon its particularly full and particularly accurate reports of the Sewall library sale. Accuracy in such matters (as any bookman will testify) is of rare occurrence, and your new departure is indeed refreshing. It establishes THE TIMES as the bookman's paper par excellence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Mr. Fairchild (Rep., N.Y.,) introduced in the House to-day a bill to amend the copyright law, making it unlawful to mark as "copyright" any article, book, map, chart, , for which a copyright has not been obtained. Violation of this law is made punishable by a fine of $100, one-half of which goes to the person filing the suit.

Information was given out yesterday by an official of a Brooklyn elevated road that the board of engineering experts appointed to examine into the feasibility of running elevated and surface cars over the Brooklyn Bridge would soon report in favor of both projects.
The thirty-third annual dinner of the Dartmouth College Association was given at the Waldorf Hotel last night. A large number of the members attended.

The last of the Henry F. Sewall collection of rare books was at the auction rooms of Bangs Co., 93 Fifth Avenue. The sale has engaged the interest of book collectors since November, when the first section of the library was sold, and has been attended by representatives of many of the book publishing and selling concerns.

The library of the late Franklin B. Gowen, late President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company, was sold at auction in Birch's, 1110 Chestnut Street, yesterday afternoon, and, from a bookdealer's point of view, very good prices were obtained.

A bill has been introduced in both houses at Albany, and has been favorably reported in the Assembly, for the reorganization of the Police Department of Richmond County. Its chief purpose seems to be to legislate out the present commission of three members and create a bi-partisan board of two, to be appointed by "the County Judge, the Sheriff, and the District Attorney of said county or by any two of such county officers."
Germany cannot forgive our country for attracting every year a large number of young men who are fit for military service. She says, and with some show of justice:

ALBANY, Jan. 22. -- Visits to the Executive Chamber by Louis F. Payn, and conferences between Senators over the confirmation of Mr. Payn as Insurance Superintendent, if Gov. Black shall nominate him, are of almost daily occurrence.
URBANA, Ill., Jan. 22. -- A riot was precipitated her last night by the Sophomores of the University of Illinois, who came over from Champaign to break up the annual sociable of the Freshmen.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 22. -- United States Circuit Judge Sanborn, in Chambers, to-night issued an order authorizing the Government to begin foreclosure of its mortgage against the Union Pacific Railway. The Government representative who appeared before Judge Sanborn is Gen. J.C. Cowin of Omaha, who arrived in the city this morning.

The enlargement of the Erie Canal at the expense of the State ought to mark a new era in the development of traffic upon the waterway from the lakes to the ocean, and the most promising sign is to be found in the movement of capital on a large scale to engage in the business of transportation from the interior of the continent to this port by water.

ADAIRVILLE, Ky., Jan. 22. -- J.L. Conn, a prominent citizen of this county, was shot and instantly killed last night at Black Jack, Tenn., just over the State line, by George Dunning, one of a gang of negroes that Conn and a number of other citizens of the Price's mill neighborhood had gone to warn to cease their depredations and leave the country.
LONDON, Jan. 22. -- Sir Isaac Pitman, the inventor of the system of stenography which bears his name, is dead.

We have before this called attention to the value of he unpublished works of Edward Gibbon. By arrangement with John Murray the Messrs. Scribner will issue this important work, in three volumes, and these will include biographies, correspondence, , printed verbatim from the manuscripts in the possession of the Earl of Sheffield.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Arguments were made to-day by James A. Scrymser, the President, and Edmund L. Baylies, the Vice President, of the Pacific Cable Company of New York before the House Commerce Committee. Mr. Scrymser confined himself largely to an explanation of the cable systems of the world, showing how extensively they were dominated by British influences.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- But nine Senators were in their seats when Senator Ellsworth called the Senate to order this morning. A few members came in later, but not enough to make a quorum. A few bills were introduced, and within ten minutes after convening the Senate adjourned until Monday night. These were among the bills introduced:

A large gathering in Cooper Union last night cheered the apostles of a new civil service system, and applauded the principles of the Progressive Civil Service Association, under whose auspices the meeting was held. Music kept the audience of about 2,500 men and a few women in good humor until the Chairman, Lucas L. Van Allen, called them to order and declared the purpose of the meeting.

HAVANA, Jan. 22. -- Upon the return to Manzanillo of the gunboat Centinela after the sinking in the Cauto River of her consort, the Relampago, by the explosion of a torpedo planted by the rebels, orders were given for a force of Spanish troops to proceed to Guamo to relieve the besieged garrison there, which had been the object of the naval expedition.

James B. Duke, William H. Butler, William A. Marbury, Lewis Ginter, George Arents, George W. Gail, Benjamin N. Duke, George W. Watts, Josiah Browne, and Charles E. Emery, officers and Directors of the American Tobacco Company, accused of conspiracy, were indicted in July. They interposed a demurrer, and arguments were heard Nov. 17 by Judge Fitzgerald, who reserved decision.

When Wagner wrote a letter to the young Hans von Bulow's mother, urging her to give her son permission to adopt a musical career, the great master, appreciating the excellent education the lad had received, penned these lines: "There is nothing so repugnant to me as a musician who is that alone without any higher culture."

Hans von Bulow's life as comprised within the first twenty-five years of his career is presented in this work by Mme. von Bulow, his widow, who shows how her husband's art was developed. By means of these letters, beginning when von Bulow was eleven years old and concluding when he was twenty-five, we get in close touch with this remarkable man.

The Greater New York Commission, at its meeting in Mayor Strong's private office yesterday, made radical and important changes in Chapters 9 and 10 of the charter, which relate to the Borough Boards and the Board of Public Improvements. These changes were suggested by Corporation Counsel Scott.

In the February Magazine of Art (The Cassell Publication Company) there is an account of an artist, Mr. Bartram Hiles, with a number of designs for frieze, hammered metal, wall paper, and head and tail pieces for book illustrations, all of which are excellent. There is, too, a neat sketch of the artist, drawn by himself.

The Critic's "Lounger" writes as follows of the late Oscar M. Dunham, for many years manager of the Cassell publishing house in this city, who mysteriously disappeared a few years ago and was next heard from when he died and his body was brought here for interment last December:

Until Helen Keller was eleven years of age her only means of communication was by finger spelling. Then at her own urgent request she was given lessons in speech by Miss Fuller, Principal of the Horace Mann School. The rapidity with which she acquired the ability to speak was unprecedented. She soon abandoned finger spelling as a means of expression, and has ever since used speech alone.

COLUMBUS, Jan. 22. -- The intense interest in the selection of the successor to Senator Sherman brought nearly the whole membership of the Seventy-second General Assembly to the reunion to-day and the banquet to-night, where Gov. Bushnell presided and Chairman Mark A. Hanna, among others, responded to a toast.

The injunction recently granted by Justice Truax, in the suit brought by Catherine L. Beekman and others against the Third Avenue Railroad Company, to restrain the latter from proceeding with the construction of its proposed extension on King's Bridge Road, or Broadway, and elsewhere, has been in part upheld by a unanimous decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, Justice Rumsey giving the opinion.

Victor Hugo had a contempt for the French censorship. When he had written "Hernani," which of course belonged to the theatre where it was being performed, copies of the drama were circulated, whereupon Hugo wrote stinging letter, addressed to the Minister of the Interior.
