Then he said:
British history repeats itself in the Benin massacre. The familiar procedures by which the blessings of civilization have been conferred upon so many other barbaric communities are here repeated.

There has been a good deal of talk about Mr. McKINLEY'S choice of a Secretary of the Treasury; most of it has been discouraging, some of it disquieting. Until yesterday no one of the possible appointees discussed would at all meet the requirements imposed by the nature of Mr. McKINLEY'S victory and by the situation of the country.

The Far East, an English edition of the Kokumin-No-Tomo, is a monthly published in Tokio, Japan. For frontispiece it has a well-drawn wood engraving, entitled "Our Dreariest Remembrance," the work, as to sketch and engraving, having been made by a Japanese artist, Mr. Goda Kiyoshi.

Mr. Eugene Muntz, in a beautiful folio published by Rothschild of Paris and supplied here by Brentano's, in discussing the subject of the manufacture of the special tapestries designed by Raphael for Pope Leo X., says that up to the middle of the fifteenth century it was at Arras that all the best work was manufactured.
The Cincinnati Bar Association has passed resolutions strongly favoring the arbitration treaty recently signed by representatives of this country and Great Britain.

The second of Mr. David Bispham's song Recital was given yesterday afternoon in the Carnegie Lyceum. The popular baritone had the capable assistance of Mrs. Corinne Moore-Lawson, soprano, and the Kneisel Quartet of Boston.

-- The Fisk Library, really the New Orleans Public Library, was formally opened on Monday night last with speeches and general felicitations. It is to be a free, circulating library, and, although it now contains but 34,000 volumes, it has a good start, and is a desirable acquisition to a town where even the Tulane University has scarcely enough books to meet the needs of a schoolboys' debating society.

When the tercentenary of the foundation of Edinburgh University was celebrated, in 1882, Robert Browning was one of the invited guests. The poet was then introduced to Thomas Gilray, Professor of English Literature in University College, Dundee, and he made the remark that he was deeply interested in Dundee, as his mother had been born there.

C.R. Gregor Son have sold for Clara Bliss to Charles T. Barney several of the new three-story dwellings on the north side of One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street, between Eighth and Edgecombe Avenues, and on the east side of Edgecombe Avenue, between One Hundred and Thirty-ninth and One Hundred and Fortieth Streets.

In The Athenaeum, under the title "The Book Sales for 1896," an endeavor is made by Mr. J.H. Slater to find out how much a library brings when put up at auction, and how much for each book. By a book is meant a work of merit, distinguishable for its excellence, rarity, or binding, or because it happens to be a first edition. Only first-class collections are considered.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- Scarcely one-half the members were in their seats in the Assembly Chamber this morning when the Speaker called the House to order.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 22. -- The Coast and Harbor Defense and Improvement Convention was called to order at 1 o'clock by ex-Gov. Mitchell of Florida, First Vice President, in the absence of Gen. Schofield, who had been called away.

In the Jacob Klein firebug case in Brooklyn yesterday, Lawyer Elder said he would prove that the fire at Klein's house in Johnson Street was accidental. The principal witness of the day, Betsey Johnson, commonly called Betsey Swartz, a sister-in-law of Klein, said that the fire was caused by Mrs. Klein accidentally knocking a lamp from a bracket.
CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 22. -- Judge Nathan Goff of West Virginia, who is one of Major McKinley's most valued personal friends, left for his home this evening.

The following advertisement is taken from The Pennsylvania Gazette, No. 532, wherein the reader of Feb. 22, 1738, was informed that The Gazette contained the "Freshest advices, Foreign and Domestick. Printed by B. Franklin, Post Master, at the news printing offices near the Market.

The second of the subscription dances organized by Mrs. John S. Foster and Mrs. Alfred Melvin Snedeker was held at Sherry's last evening. The guests were received by Mrs. J.M. Varian, Mrs. George Evans, Mrs. Alfred Melvin Snedeker, Mrs. Charles Gulden, Mrs. John A. Douglass, and Mrs. W. Wall Weaver. A supper was served at midnight in the smaller ballroom, and dancing, was resumed. The Hungarian Orchestra furnished the music.

The Rev. Dr. William S. Rainsford, rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, declines to say whether he did or did not advise his parishioners who had received invitations to the Bradley-Martin costume party not to attend.

The Progressive Civil Service Reform Association, which held a meeting at Cooper Union last night, is well known to consist, intellectually, of Mr. ABRAHAM GRUBEN. The proceedings of the meeting, for all practical purposes, consisted of his speech. This is the effort for which it was given out some months ago that the orator was making strenuous and statistical preparation.

The Illustrated London News gives the key to the inner history of Mr. Barrie's "Margaret Ogilvy." Joseph Thomson was, of course, the African friend whom Barrie describes. Barrie had been sub-editor of The Nottingham Journal. Mr. Stead of The Pall Mall Gazette published Barrie's first article in London, but it was Frederick Greenwood who, with fine appreciation, first found out the true flavor of an unknown man's writings and published "An 'Auld Licht Community."

Magistrate Simms, in the Centre Street Court, yesterday committed to the Tombs a man suspected of being Arthur Palmer, who murdered his mother and brother and shot his sister at Mamaroneck Tuesday afternoon. The arrest was made by Policeman Brady of the Elizabeth Street Station, under instructions from John Cotrell, a special Deputy Sheriff of Westchester County, who was a Detective Sergeant under Inspector Byrnes in this city.

That is a strange project of law which a female attorney and counselor at law of this city has taken to Albany for introduction into the Legislature. It provides that in every county there shall be elected every three years an official to be known as the Public Defender, who may, on certain conditions, appoint assistant public defenders.

The petition and complaint on the application for a mandamus to comuel Commissioner Collis to clear the sidewalks of Vesey Street, were served yesterday on Superintendent Henkel of the Bureau of Incumbrances, on Mr. Collis, and on Corporation Counsel Scott, as representing the Mayor.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- The following statement was made by Attorney General Harmon this evening:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Mr. Turpie (Dem., Ind.,) gave notice that Monday next he would move to take up Senator Cameron's joint resolution for the recognition of the Republic of Cuba. He spoke of Secretary Olney's recent utterances on the power of Congress in the matter of recognition of Governments, and said that there was nothing at that time before the Secretary of State which would justify such intermeddling on his part.

There is, after all, nothing so very amusing in the threadbare story of the teacher who kept one day ahead of his class. The sum of the differences in the mental equipment of the instructor and that of his pupils is in many cases rather slight. If we widen the source of instruction and do not take individuals, but nations, how much may one people teach another?

CHICAGO, Jan. 22. -- The offer of the Treasury portfolio in President McKinley's Cabinet has been made to Lyman J. Gage. It now remains for Mr. Gage to decide whether he will accept. He said to-day he was considering if he could bring himself to take the office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22. -- Mr. Cox, (Dem., Tenn.,) rising to a question of personal privilege, read a newspaper paragraph crediting Mr. Walker, (Rep., Mass.,) Chairman of the Committee on Banking and Currency, with the statement that there was so little public demand for legislation on the subject of banking and the currency that he could not get his committee together to discuss the subject.

Columbia students and graduates in mass meeting yesterday afternoon protested against the action of the University Union in ordering the disbandment of the '97 crew. The gathering filled the largest lecture room in the law school, and was one of the most enthusiastic student meetings in Columbia's history.

The congress met at Berlin in July, 1878, a new balance of power or concert Was agreed upon between the seven great powers -- Great Britain, Germany, Austria, France, Italy, Russia, and Turkey. It consists of sixty-four articles. Roumania, Servia, and Montenegro were declared independent, and the new principality of Bulgaria was formed, and Ardahan, Kars, and Batoum were assigned to Russia, and the Provinces of Bosnia and Herzegovina were assigned to Austria.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 22. -- The clothing manufacturers of Chicago are almost unanimously in sympathy with the purposes of the National Clothiers' Association, whose organization has just been completed in New York.

In Boston, on the 18th inst., there were reported seven deaths caused by the inhalation of illuminating gas. Three of the victims were children, and it does not appear that any one of the remaining four committed suicide, although in the cases of these there was evidence of gross carelessness in the handling of gas burners.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- The Cadet Chapel could not hold the invited guests that assembled here to-day to witness the marriage of Lieut. J.K. Ryan of the Sixth Cavalry and Miss Katherine M. Torney, daughter of Col. Torney, Chief Surgeon at the Military Academy. The whole corps of cadets was present, and all the officers stationed here, as well as scores from other places.

The first of the two following reviews of Dr. Henry Van Dyke's recent work, "The Gospel for an Age of Doubt," has been received from a distinguished American theologian, whose initials, as appended, will doubtless be promptly recognized The second is from a writer who, remaining anonymous, approaches the subject under somewhat different traditions of mind, although writing with point and suggestiveness.

A GOOD friend said to me a few days ago: "You are inconsistent. You do not say about Wagner's music in THE NEW YORK TIMES what you say in your Story of Music.' You say in that book that this music is ruinous to the human voice, and you say in the paper that it is not.

WEST POINT, Miss., Jan. 23. -- This was another good day for the trials and some excellent running was done. The remaining three braces of the second series and one brace in the third were run before the all age setters was decided. Novelist and Lillian Russell were the first brace. Novelist was the superior in pace and range, and particularly in finding game. She was the winner of the cup.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 23. -- Winter and Spring have alternated this week, and skating and ice boating on Lake Carasaljo on Wednesday gave place to an open channel on Thursday. Golf and wheeling continue, regardless of the weather, and, while the links have been somewhat soft and muddy, the drives about the village have dried with surprising rapidity.

Thousands of men and women in all parts of the world are to-day earning their livelihood through means furnished by the labors of Sir Isaac Pitman, the originator of phonography. Sir Isaac devoted his whole life to it, and, although he worked hard he made very little money.

LENNOX, Mass., Jan. 23. -- Building operations in Lenox are active this season. New cottages are going up, and many additions and changes are being made at the country places. The new house of Giraud Foster, when completed, will be one of the most attractive of the many fine country places of Lenox.

ANNAPOLIS, Jan. 23. -- Among the unique parts that make up the commonwealth of the Naval Academy is a band of the most expert and perfectly trained waiters, on whose promptness and attention to duty largely depend the exact movements of academic autonomy. The battalion of cadets must have their fast broken in time to begin promptly their bustling day of busy work.
" This is a baby year. There are baby years; don't you think so? Just now orders for layettes are pouring in upon us."

The hand of the cyclist will be seen considerably in politics this year if he follows out his declared intention of working early and late to secure needed legislation favoring an improvement in the highways. In this State and in New Jersey the bicycle rider may be expected to use all his influence toward this end.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The British steamer Abana, Capt. Koch, which, while bound from Hamburg for Newport News, was sunk in the River Elbe, off Blankenese, by the British steamer Dartmcor, from Hamburg for Norfolk, has been raised and is now safe in Hamburg harbor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The gunboat Machias has arrived at Bangkok under orders to protect American interests, having been hurried there from Hongkong, 2,000 miles away, on receipt of official news at the State Department last week of an attack of Siamese soldiers on United States Deputy Consul General Kellett.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 23. -- Capt. Garrett and Trainer Walter Christie of the Princeton Track Association collected together about thirty of the more promising track athletes of the college this week and began indoor training in preparation for the Spring games. Under the enthusiastic leadership of the new trainer Princeton hopes to improve the poor showing made in recent years in this department of athletics.

We showed a few days ago that the work of stamping out bovine tuberculosis had been carried on with vigor in Litchfield County, Conn., by the authorities of that State, at the request of the owners of dairy herds. Of 6,304 cows inspected in the entire State last year, 4,249 were found on the farms of Litchfield County, from which considerable quantities of milk are shipped to this city and Brooklyn.

ST. JOHN'S N.F., Jan. 23. -- The brigantine Little Minnie, Capt. Jago, from Trapani for St. John's, with salt, was driven ashore at Renews Island, forty miles south of here, by incoming ice last night, and became a total wreck. The crew escaped by scrambling over the broken ice on their hands and knees.
" Looks to me like a rebuke to the undergraduates who are looking for places in the crew, so as to have an easy and pleasant vacation, such as the boys had at Poughkeepsie last Summer."

J.A. Goulden, with Senator Guy and a committee of north-side residents, called on Mayor Strong yesterday to urge the adoption by the city of the proposition of the New York Zoological Society for the establishment of a zoological garden in Bronx Park. The society has asked the Sinking Fund Commission to set aside 261 acres of land in the Bronx Park with the understanding that the society should expend $250,000 for buildings and animals.

CASTE has been the play of the week. It has held the post of honor in many capitals many weeks since the month of April in 1867. It has been called the best English comedy written since "The School for Scandal," and, with some reservation in favor of certain plays by O'Keefe, Holcroft, Bulwer, Charles Reade, Boucicault, and Pinero, that statement may be accepted.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Twelve hundred friends of ex-Gov. John P. Altgeld went through the snowstorm to the Tremont House to-night to show their esteem for him. The reception tendered to the Democratic State leader took the form of a costly testimonial, Mr. Altgeld receiving several magnificent presents.

The rector of St. George's Church is probably considerably astonished at the excitement which has been stirred up by his deprecation of any lavish display of wealth or fashion at this time. His observations have been supposed to be occasioned by the announcement of a private masquerade on a scale of expense which has not been equaled for thirteen or fourteen years.
BOSTON, Jan. 23. -- Perry Belmont, ex-Minister to Spain, chatted with a reporter to-day before he left for New York upon the financial outlook.

" Opera singers, particularly those of the first rank, are often freakish," said the old prompter, "though managers and stage hands seldom take any notice of the antics of popular singers, so long as there is no infraction of the rules. So completely absorbed are most of them in their profession that they are serenely oblivious to all else that is going on around them.

The foreclosure of the Union Pacific Railroad appears to be an assured fact. With the Government, the Reorganization Committee, and the Government Directors all in unison on the matter, and with only a few malcontents opposed to the same, it would seem that the opposition, which, however, has not yet shown its full hand, would amount to little.

The statements of Senor RODRIGUEZ, the representative of Central America, in protesting in the name of his Government against the pending Nicaragua Canal bill, make it doubtful whether the Maritime Canal Company has any rights left which the Government of Nicaragua would be bound to respect and which our Government could justly enforce if it should guarantee the company's bonds.

Frederic R. Coudert, the distinguished lawyer, President of the Manhattan Club, and a member of the Venezuelan Commission, spoke of the general arbitration treaty with England, which now awaits ratification by the Senate, as follows yesterday:

IF one were called upon to name the most interesting and inspiring example, at this day, of what the free institutions of our country may do for the citizen and of what a citizen under those institutions may do for his country, one would not go far astray in naming Carl Schurz.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23. -- Cloudy weather and 5,000 people at the track marked to-day's racing here. The feature of the day was the $1,500 Merchants' Handicap, nine furlongs, won by the top-weight, Laureate, who carried 119 pounds. Only two favorites won, the bookmakers beating the public.
The Association Will Consider Limitation of Championship Competitors.

The remarks of President SETH LOW at the dinner of the Princeton alumni the other evening indicated that his experience on the Greater New York Commission had dispelled the doubts and fears which he entertained last Spring regarding the Government of the enlarged city.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- In response to a resolution, the Secretary of the Treasury to-day sent to the Senate a detailed statement of the public revenue derived from the North American Commercial Company in its annual settlements with the department.
KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 23. -- Havana advices received in Key West are to the effect that the Spanish gunboat Cometa has been captured and burned by the insurgents.

Ask any experienced bicyclist where the best public roads can be found, and the answer will invariably be -- In New Jersey. That State has concededly led in systematic work of improving its highways during the past few years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- A tone of regret begins to be heard in all the comments upon the make-up of the Cabinet of Mr. McKinley as it has been announced in the newspapers from day to day. The most conspicuous surprise is expressed about the selection of Mr. Sherman, although it has been assumed from the first that he was to be Secretary of State.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- The new Chinese Minister to England, Lo Feng Lo, is timed to arrive in London early in June. He brings some magnificent presents to the Queen, at whose diamond jubilee fates he is to figure. The Foreign Office, which has never got on well with the present Chinese Minister, expects to find in Lo Feng Lo a better medium of communication with Pekin.

DURING the early years of this century, notably in the thirties and forties, the profession of medicine in this city was divided into cliques, each jealous of all the others and openly expressing their feelings of jealousy and unkindness.

The world is growing better and brighter, undoubtedly. Religion and learning work together to that end. They civilize and humanize. They subdue the roughness of man to man, they conquer selfishness. They tend to assimilate all mankind upon one level of joyful equality by bringing to the comprehension of each individual mind the teaching of all human experience and the blessing of divine charity.

ENGLISH, Ind., Jan. 23. -- Death last Monday claimed Indiana's oldest inhabitant. He was Nathaniel Straughan, better known to people hereabout as "Uncle Nat." He was born near Frankfort, Ky., May 8, 1792.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- According to the Illinois Republicans here there has not been a moment since the name of Lyman J. Gage was mentioned for Secretary of the Treasury that they imagined there was any probability that he would be selected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The Senate Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads this morning held another hearing on the Loud bill, which cuts off serial publications from the benefits of second-class postage rates. Those present were chiefly opposed to the bill.

-- When Gov. WOLCOTT of Massachusetts sent his message to the State Legislature a couple of weeks ago he dwelt at some length on the devastations of the army worm and bewailed the fact that there seemed to be no way of exterminating the pest. While the legislators were trying to digest his recommendation JAMES RANKIN was penning for The Poultry Monthly an article on the same subject.

GENEVA, N.Y., Jan. 22. -- An interesting anecdote of Napoleon Bonaparte has been found among the literary remains of a brave officer of his staff, Gen. H.L.V. Ducudroy Holstein, who after the downfall of Napoleon came to America and was for several years a professor in Geneva, now Hobart, College, at this place.

THE Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York has a history that is interesting because much of the prosperity of the Nation and very much of the greatness of the City of New York are due to it and its efforts for advancement and progress during the 139 years that it has existed.

The existence of man in the glacial period, in New Jersey, forms a very interesting subject in the thirtieth report, just published, of Prof. F.W. Putnam, curator of the Peabody Museum, at Cambridge. He says:
ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- Gov. Black to-day declined to discuss the report that Louis F. Payn had given him a "release" from all obligation to appoint him Superintendent of Insurance.

The first decision in this city under the law of 1895, relating to the condemnation of buildings by the Board of Health for sanitary reasons, was rendered yesterday, when Referee William G. Davis decided in favor of the Health Board, which began condemnation proceedings against the rear tenements at 308 to 316 Mott Street, inclusive.
BUTLER, Penn., Jan. 23. -- This afternoon one of the most serious accidents in the history of the Pittsburg and Western Railway occurred at Paint Creek Bridge, one mile from Shippensville Station.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Jan. 20. -- New ideas regarding the electrical development and long-distance transmission of power have turned the attention of some electricians and engineers from the wonders at Niagara Falls to operations in California, where several millions of dollars are now invested in unique electric plants among the Sierra Nevadas.

GLASGOW, Jan. 13. -- The cutter for C. D. Rose, to be built by Fay Co., Northam, Southampton, is from the design of I.M. Soper, the manager of the firm. The new cutter, unlike Soper's cutter Satanita, it is now stated will have a shorter load water line than either Britannia or Ailsa. While Satanita was 95 feet on the load water line, the new cutter is to be only 80 feet.

The official correspondence between England and Russia in regard to Turkish reform, just published, furnishes the key to the whole situation at Constantinople. It appears that in October Lord SALISBURY proposed reforms, to be enforced by the powers. Russia refused to agree to coercive measures, but, after further conference, yielded so far as to approve of coercion if the Sultan should refuse assent to the reforms.

" There is no use disguising the fact that the passage of this measure will practically reverse the purpose of the civil service reform law. This is the most astute attack yet made on the civil service reform system, and its effect will be to put the control of the offices in the hands of politicians.''

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Advices from Belgium show a serious state of affairs there arising from the conscription law, which provides that every man who has completed his nineteenth year is liable to military service for eight years, of which, however, two-thirds is allowed, as a rule, on furlough.

Mrs. G.C. Smith of West End Avenue and Ninety-second Street, this city, yesterday applied to Chancellor McGill, at Jersey City, for an order removing William Pennington, a Paterson lawyer, who had been appointed trustee for her two stepdaughters, respectively six and eight years old. Mrs. Smith was represented by Alexander Thain of this city and Otto Crouse of Jersey City, Mr. Pennington by John B. Leavitt of this city, and Eugene Stevens of Paterson.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- No conclusion was reached at yesterday's conference between the traffic managers of the Western Freight Association lines and General Manager Underwood of the Minneapolis, St. Paul and Sault Ste. Marie Railway regarding the discriminative tariff the latter intends to issue on traffic from the Atlantic seaboard to St. Paul.

The nineteenth annual convention of the National Guard Association of New York held last Wednesday was the most eventful and representative one in its history, and demonstrated that the officers of the guard have become thoroughly tired of political rule, which has been so much in evidence the past two years, and they reached a point finally where further hesitation in taking pronounced action for reform could not be tolerated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Senator Morgan is very much worked up in consequence of the serious obstacle that yesterday was thrown in the way of the Nicaragua Canal bill in the Senate by the protest received from the Minister of the Greater Republic of Central America.

The brokers' announcements at private sale indicate that fairly active conditions prevailed last week. Their sales show that the number of transactions closed and the aggregate investment involved was about the same as the totals reached for the previous six days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- James H. Eckels, Controller of the Currency, has sent a letter to the Governors of the States requesting them to recommend legislation to secure uniformity in the collection of banking statistics.

GRAMMAR SCHOOL NO. 9 has the distinction of being one of the oldest in the city, dating back to 1829 under the Public School Society, which was the immediate predecessor of the present educational system. It is on the site of the original schoolhouse at the northeast corner of West End Avenue and Eighty-second Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23. -- A letter has been sent to President-elect McKinley by the Indian Rights Association requesting the retention of Dr. W.N. Hailmann as Superintendent of Indian Schools. The persons signing the petition say that Dr. Hailmann is unquestionably the ablest educator who has ever had charge of this branch of work.

The decision of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court affirming, with some modification, the preliminary injunction granted by Justice Truax restraining the Third Avenue Railroad Company from constructing its King's Bridge Road extension above One Hundred and Sixty-second Street, in the suit of the owners of Christ's Hotel, at One Hundred and Eighty-second Street and King's Bridge Road, attracted wide attention yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 23. -- An application, supported by affidavits, was made to Judge Slough, at Lancaster, this evening for the removal of C.L. Poston as receiver of the Columbus, Shawnee and Hocking Railway. It is claimed that the application for the receivership was made for the purpose of looting the property.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 23. -- After having abandoned as hopeless the search for the missing John W. Mathews, the lawyer and manufacturer, of Monmouth, Ill., who disappeared in Chicago Nov. 11 last, the police renewed their quest last week, aided by Dr. Ringland, a mind reader, of Hamilton, Ill.

The sagging tendency which marked the stock market throughout the week developed yesterday into a weakness. Stocks closed in the majority of cases at declines, and there seemed no supporting element to give any strength to the market. The day's dealings were comparatively small.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23. -- In a recent lecture at the Academy of National Sciences, Prof. A.B. Brubaker, discussing the subject "Physical Development," said:

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Grace Jennings, who is known on the stage as Grace Vaughn, was granted a decree of divorce in Judge Tuthill's court to-day on the ground of desertion. Her husband was Andrew R. Jennings, son of A.R. Jennings, a Cleveland dentist.

ITHACA, Jan. 23. -- In response to the call of Capt. Spillman of the Cornell 'Varsity crew, about thirty-five men have registered as candidates. Four of these were members of last year's 'Varsity -- Briggs, Savage, Ludlam, and Johnston. Besides these there are in the university Tatum, Moore, and Chiswell of last year's crew, who have not come out yet.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23. -- The French collier Madeleine arrived yesterday from Callao. One of her boilers exploded soon after the steamer left Callao, killing five men and injuring several others. She put into Acapulco for repairs.

Beyond the confines of Greater New York, near the Connecticut line, at Port Chester, there is a very beautiful stone church, erected under the patronage of St. Peter, which has been undergoing a number of changes and alterations, like that of its sister churches in the County of Westchester.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, Jan. 22. -- A little over a year ago Lewis Herbert Wyckoff, Assistant Superintendent of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, and Miss Mabel Jackson, daughter of Charles P. Jackson, a well-known artist of this city, were united in marriage. Mr. Wyckoff located here about three years prior to that time, coming from Norwalk, this State, where his parents reside.

The possibilities of developing a great and lucrative trade between this country and the countries of South America are attracting more attention daily from the business men and commercial bodies of both continents.

Wall Street has had a disappointing week. Nothing serious has come to pass making or marking any change in general financial, commercial, or industrial conditions; but the security market has puzzled and disturbed the talent of the Stock Exchange.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23. -- A member of the Yale Athletic Committee said today that it was expected that the new Yale-Harvard athletic agreement would be ratified some time next week. The baseball, football, and track managers have consented to allow their plans for games the coming season to be considered along with those of the crew, and the new agreement will be one in all kinds of sport.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- As a matter of course, the people who are preparing at the Capitol for the ceremonies of inauguration are finding out that it will be impossible to fully gratify the desire to witness the ceremonies in the Senate Chamber. The reason for this is at once obvious when the attractions presented in that chamber are mentioned.
CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Mr. Gage said tonight to The United Associated Presses:

The following statement has been received from George McAneny, Secretary of the Civil Service Reform Association, in reference to Abraham Gruber's civil service speech at the Cooper Union meeting Friday night:

Chairman Lauterbach of the Republican County Committee and Thomas C. Platt had a long talk at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night. Afterward it was said by Mr. Lauterbach that the bill providing for civil service examinations in the District Attorney's office which was introduced as an amendment to the Consolidation act would be changed so as to make it a general act, applicable to all counties.

The Queen's University hockey team of Kingston, Ontario, had very little trouble in winning a game from the Yale team at the St. Nicholas Rink last night. The score at the end of the game was 3 to 0 in favor of the Canadians, but a member of the Yale team remarked after the game was over that the Queen's boys could have made it much larger if they had tried a little harder.
A bill authorizing the sale of the property at 187 Broadway and 5 and 7 Dey Street, this city, was offered in the Assembly by Mr. Austin on Friday.

The Apostolic Delegate, Sebastian Martinelli, Archbishop of Ephesus, accompanied by his secretary, the Rev. Dr. Rooker, arrived at the Pennsylvania station in Jersey City at 3 P.M. yesterday, and was met by the Rev. Dr. Brann, pastor of St. Agnes's Church, East Forty-second Street and Third Avenue.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 23. -- Ex-Gov. Charles Foster has come out as an avowed candidate for the United States Senate. He said to-day:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17. -- A tart characterization of the insurrection in Cuba, and the influences behind it, was given to-day by the Rev. Zachariah Vail-Spinoza, a Spanish-Protestant minister, temporarily residing in Washington. Mr. Spinoza is a member of the Church of England. He was born in Spain, but was educated in England, graduating from St. Augustine's College, Canterbury, twenty-four years ago.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 23. -- St. Raphael's big church was the scene yesterday of a most unusual event, the picturesque wedding, according to the rites of the Catholic Church, of two gypsies, Casto Lawogastich and Melia Georgievitch. They are members of a well-to-do band temporarily encamped on Snider's Hill, northwest of the city.

LONDON, Jan. 23. -- Distinguished by the usual number of passages in which the elementary rules of English grammar are royally set at naught, the Queen's speech at the opening of Parliament has perhaps only one flash of genius which elevates it above its prosy predecessors.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 23. -- In regard to American Strawboard stock, internal differences are said to be the reason for the attack on its securities. The recent meeting of boxmakers at Cincinnati is said to have developed considerable antagonism to the company, even to the extent of reviving the talk about an opposition company.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 23. -- In regard to American Strawboard stock, internal differences are said to be the reason for the attack on its securities. The recent meeting of boxmakers at Cincinnati is said to have developed considerable antagonism to the company, even to the extent of reviving the talk about an opposition company.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 24. -- The assassination by highbinders last evening of Fong Ching, otherwise known as "Little Pete," has created a greater sensation in Chinatown than any other happening in years.

A dispatch in THE TIMES yesterday, from Washington, gave an extended interview on Cuban affairs with the Rev. Zachariah Vall-Spinoza, who was born in Spain, educated in England, and has lived many years, as a clergyman of the Church of England, in Jamaica and Puerto Rico.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 24. -- The tenth annual convention of the Improved Order of B'Nai B'rith was opened to-day at Hazazer's Hall. One hundred and fifty delegates were presnet from several States. They represented twenty-nine lodges, with a membership of over 3,000. The report of Julius H. Wyman, Supreme President, contained some suggestions as to amendments to the Constitution.

That it is desirable and even necessary to place some restriction upon the height of commercial buildings in New York is an opinion so prevalent that it is not necessary to take account of the dissentients in discussing it.

Moody and Sankey's audience at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon filled the building to overflowing, notwithstanding the inclement weather. In the two tiers of boxes whole families occupied seats, and in other parts of the hall the devout and regularly attending women shared the space with men of all conditions.

The Central Labor Union listened yesterday to denunciations of professional labor agitators who join trades unions in order to secure political jobs through the influence of their organizations. Reports of delegates that had been sent to attend the conventions of the Knights of Labor, the Workingmen's State Trades Assembly, and the State Branch of the American Federation of Labor, that have just been held in Albany, were also heard.
CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 24. -- It is understood that Major McKinley practicaly has finished what might be called the sifting process of his Cabinet making, and is now about ready to make his Cabinet.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 24. -- Peter Jansen, one of the Delegates at Large from Nebraska to the Republican National Convention, is in the city direct from a visit to Major McKinley. He tells of an extended interview with the President-elect on Cabinet possibilities, and says:

The solemn pontifical mass was sung yesterday morning at 11 o'clock by Archbishop Martinelli, the Apostolic Delegate, who came from Washington for the purpose, at the Church of St. Agnes, Forty-third Street, near Third Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- Charles Phlag, a prisoner in the county jail here charged with horse stealing, was murderously assaulted to-day by John Williams, another prisoner, and so badly cut it is feared he will die, Williams, a colored man, is accused of highway robbery. His home is in Sing Sing, and he is known there as a dangerous man to anger.

The bill which Mr. OLCOTT has had introduced in the Assembly relating to his office differs slightly from the description of it in our previous dispatches, but only very slightly. Instead of letting Mr. OLCOTT choose from all the applicants who get a marking of 75 per cent., it allows ten names to be sent to him for each appointment.

The weather made an ambitious attempt to be wintry yesterday. Snow began to fall early, and continued fitfully or lazily throughout the day; but succeeded in lying to the depth of only nine-tenths of an inch.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 24. -- Elisha Fitch, a prominent lawyer and citizen of Fleming County, who died a few days ago at Flemingsburg, left a will somewhat out of the ordinary. There was no disposition of the estate, and the will made only the following requests as to his funeral and burial, which were carried out to the letter:...

-- Chicago ichthyologists are puzzling over the discovery of very considerable numbers of fish in the stagnant pools which exist in two abandoned quarries near Cicero. These pools, having neither inlets nor outlets, and which give out a very offensive odor, have no vegetation, and yet are alive with two unknown species of fish which sicken and die when transferred from the mudholes to pure water.

St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Park, was not large enough to contain the people who flocked there at yesterday morning's service to hear what the Rev. Dr. Rainsford had to say on the display of wealth as tending to arouse the poor. Hundreds stood in the aisles, while cushions were brought from the vestry room and placed on the stone steps of the chancel, to accommodate a part of the overflow.

Those who think that the Republican Ways and Means Committee intends to make a "moderate" tariff bill, having in mind revenue rather than high protection, must be puzzled by the reports about the plans by which the committee hopes to prevent the importation of an abnormally large quantity of dutiable goods in the weeks or months immediately preceding the enactment of the bill.

We published yesterday a statement by Judge BURKE of Ohio as to Mr. HANNA'S chances for the seat to be vacated by Mr. SHERMAN. It doubtless reflects the views of Ohio Republicans friendly to Mr. HANNA. These views are not peculiar to Ohio and differ very little from the views of New York Republicans as to the proper way of filling seats in the Senate. They do not show a high standard of public service.

Much talk is heard of what bombastic things Congress may do, or threatens to do this week. Some timid souls are apprehensive that proceedings at Washington may badly affect the financial world. It will be a tribute to the financial world's stupidity if such a thing can be.

Prof. ADLER delivered a discourse yesterday on "Woman in the Sphere of Politics," which contained much sense. He advocated the appointment of women, when fit, to administrative positions, and he favored the suffrage for women in the smaller cities. He opposed immediate and indiscriminate extension of the suffrage on the ground that it would add more ignorant and incapable than intelligent voters to the electorate.

There is great activity evident among horsemen up town, and with the return of good weather the long-expected "boom" in riding and driving circles will be fully realized. The riding schools are now taxed to the utmost in order to accommodate the increasing demands for horses, while the horse marts have begun to have an unusual number of visitors.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 24. -- Ex-Deputy United States Marshal J.B. Bruner, who made many raids with the late Deputy Marshal Bird, who recently was murdered in Breathitt Country, said to-day:

When Reuben Vager returned from synagogue Saturday to his rooms, at 152 Norfolk Street, he found his door open and a strange man packing up his belongings. He cried for the police, and the man dashed out to the hallway and down the stairs. On the floor below he encountered Mrs. Julia Vager, Vager's daughter-in-law, who had been attracted by the noise, and tried to pass her.
Mr. E. St. John, Vice President of the Seaboard Air Line, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in discussing Southern business conditions and prospects:

The decision given Saturday by Referee William G. Davis, sustaining the Board of Health in the condemnation proceedings against unsanitary rear houses and tenements, will have the effect, it is believed, of clearing away a great many rear habitations during the coming Summer.

The Rev. Dr. Leighton Williams of the Amity Baptist Church was sent yesterday by his congregation to comfort and cheer those who have remained of the Baptist Tabernacle congregation and have stood by their pastor, the Rev. Daniel C. Potter. The services were held in the little Welsh church in East Tenth Street, and there Dr. Williams, after selecting for his text the words "Finally, my brethren, be strong in the Lord," said:

During the first century of our National existence the energies of our people naturally were devoted to the development of our great and varied resources. The result is the best and most extensive systems of river and lake navigation, more miles of railroad than are possessed by all other countries, and the fact that the greatest commerce in the world, under conditions of absolute free trade, is conducted between the States of the United States.

ST. PAUL, Jan. 24. -- According to a decision yesterday here a man's homestead is a very indefinite sort of thing, valued anywhere from $50 to $500,000. A Chicago bank asked for a receiver for William Banholzer, the St. Paul brewer, on a note of $20,000 it had against the old Seven Corners Bank, which failed in 1893.
The Rev. Dr. Minot J. Savage of the Church of the Messiah preached yesterday morning on "Is Religion Dying?"

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 24. -- The people of the First Baptist Church are considerably worked up over an occurrence in the church last Tuesday night. They discussed it quietly after service to-day. The result was that it is unlikely there will be another entertainment before a committee of the church has seen the performance in dress rehearsal.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- State Controller James A. Roberts will submit a report, with important recommendations, to the Legislature to-morrow evening upon the financial condition of the State. He calls attention to a vast increase in State expenditures, and recommends a graded inheritance tax -- the largest estates to be made to pay the largest tax.
" Woman in the Sphere of Politics" formed the subject of Prof. Felix Adler's discourse yesterday morning before the Society for Ethical Culture at Carnegie Music Hall.

SALAMANCA, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- A legal battle has been begun in the courts of Cattaraugus County that will probably last several years and call for the expenditure of thousands of dollars. The point at issue is the ownership of the oil rights of the Seneca, Indian Reservation, a tract of over 60,000 acres of land lying along the Allegany River.
The following sales are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The arbitration treaty, the Nicaragua Canal, and the insurrection in Cuba will be discussed again in the Senate this week.

The marked predominance in our exports of the products of the soil, including breadstuffs, provisions of all kinds, petroleum, , shows that we are still in an early stage of industrial development. Our exports of manufactures are now increasing, however, in a ratio so noticeable as to indicate that we are entering upon the next stage.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- The visit of several detectives to this city looking for information of the whereabouts of the wife and daughter of the late John Gager, who are heirs to property in Troy valued at $60,000, recalls the romantic career of John Gager, to whose memory still stand as monuments a score of the finest houses in Poughkeepsie.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- The dispatch which was sent out from Poughkeepsie yesterday announcing the fact that the Rev. Dr. Silliman of Grace Church, this city, had been indicted by the Grand Jury of Dutchess County for violating the regulations of the Health Board of the Town of Red Hook, in which St. Stephen's College is located, has aroused much indignation in this city, where Dr. Silliman is well known and highly respected.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- The fourteenth annual report to the Legislature of the New York Bureau of Statistics of Labor is devoted mainly to the matter of wages in various industries in this State for a period of five years.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Mrs. Elijah Carson, a most remarkable woman, died Friday night at Anamosa, Iowa. Mrs. Carson had crossed the ocean 250 times, and possessed an extraordinary record of never having missed a trip on the Lucania since that splendid vessel was launched.

BERLIN, Jan. 24. -- The Emperor's allusion at a recent Court dinner to the reported existence of a Camarilla, or Court cabal, and his statement that he knew nothing of any such clique as has been alleged to exist, do not alter the fact that besides his Majesty's public Ministerial Council he has his all-potent private advisers.

Among the permanent guests at the Bellevue Lodging House, 340 Bowery, is Col. Silas C. Taylor, a former officer, he says, of the United States Army, and the owner of a mine on Snake Hill, Idaho, worth $60,000.

LYNN, Mass., Jan. 24. -- The Right Rev. William Lawrence, Episcopal Bishop of the diocese of Massachusetts, preached in St. Stephen's Memorial Church this afternoon. He made the following reference to the arbitration treaty:

It was the one hundred and thirty-eighth anniversary of the birth of Robert Burns yesterday, and Scotchmen from all parts of the city enjoyed, under the auspices of the different Scotch societies, "a nicht wi' Burns in song and story." The Burns Society celebrated the day with a dinner at Delmonico's, deserting, for the first time in its twenty-six years of existence, its original gathering place in Liberty Street.

BOSTON, Jan. 25. -- Lewis F. Geary, a young man living with his parents in Cambridge, is now laid up at his home with a pair of feet and also a pair of hands that are frightfully swollen, as a result of having been frozen.

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 25. -- One of the most interesting murder trials in Cayuga County was commenced this morning before Judge Dunwell. The accused is Frank Sheldon, a well-to-do farmer of Brutus, member of a prominent family of the county, and whose brother, Clair Sheldon, is now serving his second term in the Assembly.

-- Possibly of considerable significance, just now is the statement that the Government has for three months past had over 300 men working day and night on the fortifications at the entrance of Mobile Harbor. This news comes from a Mobile doctor, who has been talking with a Louisville reporter, and it is repeated without comment by a Mobile paper.

The cold wave which struck the city night before last continued yesterday, and all day long it was bitter cold. At 7 o'clock yesterday morning the temperature was recorded at 5 degrees above zero, which is the same temperature recorded the day before Christmas. These two days have been the coldest of the season.

State Controller ROBERTS challenges attention in his annual report by a warning to the Legislature on the subject of the increasing expenses of the State Government and a recommendation in favor of a graded tax on inheritances. The warning in regard to increasing expenses is undoubtedly needed, but to be effective it ought to be accompanied by a statement showing wherein the present public expenditures are unnecessary or extravagant, and could be reduced to advantage.

C.R. Gregor Son have sold for W. Edgar Pruden to Mrs. Mary A. McGivney the four-story brick and stone dwelling 11 West Seventy-fourth Street, taking in ex-change in part payment the new four-story brick dwelling, 162 West One Hundred and Twentieth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The House began business to-day by passing, on motion of Mr. Sayers, (Dem., Texas,) the Senate bill to provide for an examination and survey of a water route from the mouth of the jetties at the City of Galveston, Texas, through the ship canal and up Buffalo Bayou to the City of Houston.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 25. -- James L. Kernochan, the well-known New York clubman and society leader, appeared on the streets of this village this afternoon clad in an overcoat made from the skin of a grizzly bear. The skin of the head and neck were fashioned into a hood, which was worn by Mr. Kernochan to-day over his head.
Stock market irregular. Weakness in coal stocks the feature. Money on call, 1 1/2 to 2 per cent. Sterling exchange reduced.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 25. -- The public exercises in celebration of the eighty-seventh celebration of the birthday of Dr. Henry Bernard, the "Father of Education in the United States," attracted a distinguished audience in the Hall of Representatives at the Capitol this morning and afternoon. Dr. Barnard was born in the house in which he now lives, on Main Street, Jan. 24, 1811.

The committee of the New York Ministers' Association, appointed in December last to devise some means by which the pernicious influence of the so-called "New Journalism" may be counteracted, made its report yesterday morning at a largely attended meeting at the Fourth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The Greater New York Commission will not present its draft of the charter and its final report to the Legislature Feb. 1, as required in the act creating it. The Legislature will undoubtedly grant a short extension of time. It was ascertained yesterday that an extension of about two weeks will be asked for by the commission. Late this week or on Monday a preliminary report will be made to the Legislature.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Mr. Green, (Dem., New York,) moved to substitute for the Lexow resolution for an investigation of trusts by a special committee, the resolution of Senator Grady, which was defeated in the Senate, directing the Judiciary Committees of the two houses to report at once any amendments to the present law designed to frustrate the operations of trusts.
CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Ex-Gov. Altgeld's $1,500 silver set of 205 pieces, presented to him Saturday night by his admirers, has been stolen.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 25. -- Four suits for damages, aggregating $3,310,000, against D. Herbert Hostetter of Pittsburg, Penn., have been settled out of court. The suits were brought in the Superior Court April 5, 1892, and were shortly afterward removed to the United States Court. All the suits grew out of what is known as the Baltimore project, which contemplated a through railroad line from the coal fields of Pennsylvania to tidewater at Baltimore.

SHAMOKIN, Penn., Jan. 25. -- Frederick Graeber, a clerk in the First National Bank of this city, was severely injured, and Miss Maud Gothie, his affianced, was killed Sunday while driving. They drove along the mountain road until Bear Cap, a point eight miles north of this place, was reached. Here they stopped at a country inn, and, after spending a short time there, started to make the return trip.
Henry Adams, a prominent brokerage and commission merchant of this city, died at his home, 430 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon of heart failure.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 25. -- There was a free fight in a saloon here this evening, in which a number of members of the Board of Freeholders and prominent politicians participated. Fists, beer glasses, and chairs figured as weapons.

There is a fine plausibility and foxiness about Senator LEXOW'S investigation of the trusts. The resolution commands the committee to report on March 1 with a bill to cure the evils it brings to light. That looks businesslike. It promises a short, sharp, and decisive campaign, something that will keep the trust cormorants dancing like a judgment debtor in supplementary proceedings.
The performance of "Cymbeline," in which Margaret Mather was to have taken the role of Imogen, was interrupted last night by the arrest of Edward J. Henley, who was to have acted the part of Iachimo.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- The investigation of the trust's has been ordered. The Assembly to-night adopted the Senate resolution by a vote which was a party one at all stages except for the votes of Armstrong, Laimbeer, and Robbins.
Divergent opinions are held by citizens of this city on the plan proposed by State Controller James A. Roberts to increase the inheritance tax.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- In response to a resolution, the Attorney General to-day stated to the Senate that an agreement had been made with the Reorganization Committee of the Union Pacific Railway Company respecting the foreclosure of the Government lien on the property of that company. He also said he had designated the United States Trust Company of New York as the depository, and that $4,500,000 had been deposited under the agreement.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 25. -- Mr. Joseph Davis, who died yesterday in Buffalo, N.Y., was the general manager of the Davis Shoe Company of Boston, but spent most of his time in this city. This company had a contract with the Virginia State prison here, under which they employed about 600 convicts in the manufacture of shoes.

An investigation was held yesterday by the Commissioners of Accounts of charges made by foremen of fire engine companies against Louis A. La Grange, chief coal weigher for the Fire Department, and George W. Winant Son, who furnish coal to the department. The charges allege frauds in the weighing of coal.
ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- The following bills were introduced in the Senate to-day:...

TORONTO, Jan. 25. -- The coldest weather of the season prevailed throughout Ontario to-day. The lowest temperature reported to-day was 52 below, at White River, in the northwestern part of the Province.

Louis H. Lazarus, a real estate dealer, who lived at 231 East Seventy-second Street, died suddenly at his home yesterday, and, according to the doctors who attended him, he committed suicide by taking a dose of Paris green.

At the recent conference of the State and municipal Boards of Health of Ohio, at Columbus, attention was directed to an interesting decision of the Supreme Court of Minnesota relating to the exercise of the power of a city's Health Department in suburban districts beyond the city's boundaries.

There is a report from Washington that Senator SHERMAN is exhibiting his hesitation about taking charge of the State Department after all. It is a case in which a change of mind would be of advantage to the public and probably to Mr. SHERMAN'S reputation as well.

The office of The United Press Local News, whose service is taken by the principal newspapers of this city, is at 21-29 Ann Street. Information of public interest forwarded to that office will reach not only these local newspapers, but will be disseminated throughout the country by The United Press.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Senator Sherman will not discuss the report that he is to decline the position of Secretary of State in McKinley's Cabinet, contenting himself with the statement that he has no intention of withdrawing his consent to accept it.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 25. -- The chief interest in the new Cabinet still centres about the Secretary of the Treasury. The rumors pointing to Lyman J. Gage as Major McKinley's choice to succeed Secretary Carlisle are persistently renewed. Letters and telegrams commending Mr. Gage in warm terms continue to reach the President-elect in large numbers.

John C. Reid, widely known in newspaper and political circles, died at his home, 7 East Thirtieth Street, at 9:45 o'clock yesterday morning. For many years prior to 1889 Mr. Reid was the managing news editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES. More recently his time has been given almost entirely to the management of the literary bureau of the Republican State Committee.

Mr. CHARLTON, a liberal member of the Dominion Parliament, recently suggested that the removal of the Canadian duties on certain manufactured goods might serve as a basis for a reciprocity agreement with his country. With reference to these manufactured goods, Chairman DINGLEY of the Ways and Means Committee now says:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Mr. Burrows (Rep., Mich.,) presented petitions on the subject of the Senatorial election in Delaware, and Mr. Chandler (Rep., N.H.) gave notice that it was his purpose to suggest to the Senate whether some method cannot be established to "prevent the wholesale larceny of Senatorships in various States."

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Controller Roberts's report, in which he charges extravagance in the use of public money, and suggests a graded inheritance tax to increase the State's revenue, has attracted careful attention from legislators who have appropriation bills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The estimates by States and Territories of the area, product, and value of the principal cereal crops of the United States for 1896, made by the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture, are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Ex-Queen Liliuokalani paid a personal visit to President Cleveland to-day. It was entirely, and was so designated in the note sent by the deposed monarch to the President requesting the privilege of calling, and the answer of the latter granting it.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- The tabulation made in the State Banking Department of the financial operations of the trust companies in the State for the year ended Dec. 31 last presents a most remarkable showing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- That part of the shipping laws of the United States which authorizes the arrest of sailors who refuse to observe the terms of their contracts to serve on board vessels was today declared by the Supreme Court to be Constitutional and within the jurisdiction of State courts to enforce.

Oscar Hammerstein, proprietor of Olympia Music Hall, appeared before Judge Fitzgeald, in the Court of General Sessions, yesterday, to plead to the indictment found against him by the Grand Jury Saturday. The indictment charged him with a violation of the Penal Code by exhibiting a burlesque called "Silly's Dinner."

It is not the "differences" of opinion that must be cast aside, but the disrupting opinions themselves. There can never be a compromise between the Bryan Democrats and the Democrats who voted for PALMER or for MCKINLEY. There is no middle ground upon which they can come together. Their "differences" are irreconcilable.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- During the introduction of bills, Senator Cantor arose to explain his bill prohibiting the consolidation of gas companies. He was interrupted by Senator Ellsworth, who raised the point of order that there was no question before the House.

You are to be congratulated on giving to New Yorkers a daily paper fit to be read in the family circle, an achievement that, strange as it may seem, deserves particular mention in this era of "new journalism." Your editorial page, in keeping with the tone of the paper, shows careful and intelligent work, and I was therefore the more surprised to see to-day an article on "Luxury and Discontent," which abounded in economic fallacies.
F.J. Lisman of the Stock Exchange, recognized in Wall Street as an authority on investment securities, said yesterday regarding that market:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- "The most important news that we have yet received from Cuba," said Mr. Du Bosc, the first Secretary of the Spanish Legation, to-day, "reached us by cable from Madrid last night. It is a telegram from the Minister of Foreign Affairs, the Duke of Tetuan, embodying the material points of a dispatch sent to him by the Captain General at Havana. The Duke's dispatch reads as follows:

In answer to an erroneous paragraph cabled from France in the middle of December, permit me to say that there are two marquisates in the family and two branches: The eldest branch, to which belonged the Marquis de Montcalm St. Veran, (who died at Quebec,) commander of the hereditary order of St. Louis, and the cadet branch, his nephews and grand nephews, to which belonged the Marquis de Montcalm, who died lately in France.

The policy of the Rapid Transit Commission in leaving in abeyance the question of extending the underground road down lower Broadway from the City Hall Park seems likely to produce the desired effect. At the meeting to-morrow it is expected that an application for the extension will be made by the property owners on Broadway and the intersecting streets below the Post Office.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The holding up of the nomination of W.D. McHugh, appointed United States District Judge for Nebraska, develop an interesting fight in that State.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 26. -- Representative R.C. Busse of Cook County in the Legislature to-day offered the following joint resolution, and moved it be made a special order for discussion Thursday morning at 10:30 o'clock:

The gist of the whole tariff question is in the letter of C.J. HARRAH, President of the Midvale Steel Company, to the Ways and Means Committee, which will be found in our Washington dispatches. The company is, as its President states, "the largest maker of steel tires in the United States, and one of the largest in the world."

The arguments in the appeal from the recent sweeping civil service decision of Justice Keogh were heard yesterday in the Appellate Division, Brooklyn. The suit in which the decision was given was brought by S.B. Crittenden and other taxpayers against Mayor Wurster and other city officials to restrain the latter from paying salaries to various city employes who had been appointed without competitive examination.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Among the papers relating to the tariff filed with the Ways and Means Committee is the following:

The New York Yacht Club, at a special meeting held in the clubhouse last night, unanimously decided that it was not advisable for the club to take any action toward the organization of a Yacht Racing League.

Either through derangement of the check line machinery or overloading, accounts differ, an elevator accident occurred yesterday afternoon at 527 West Thirty-fourth Street, and five men narrowly escaped death. The premises are occupied by the Interior Conduit and Insulation Company. At about 4 o'clock the elevator was started from the ground floor in charge of the elevator man, and in it were Foreman Bohonan of the insulating departmen and three porters.

The report of the Controller of the State, published in your paper of to-day, is a sad commentary upon the conduct of our public affairs, and indicates clearly the consequences of reckless expenditure. The poorer we become the greater is the apparent eagerness of our rulers to spend money.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 26. -- Joe Scherrer, who recently declined an offer to ride for Marcus Daly, will sign a contract to ride for Alfred Featherstone and Joseph E. Bromley of Chicago. Scherrer is to receive a salary of $4,000 a year in addition to the regular fees for his mounts.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Senator White of Syracuse and Senator Nussbaum of the subcommittee of the Senate Cities Committee this afternoon gave a hearing in the Senate Chamber on the Uniform Charter bill for second-class cities, and several amendments were agreed upon.

The Federal Constitution was the product of compromises, and it would be strange if we could get a charter for the Greater New York which anybody could regard as ideal. Some compromise will have to be made among differing opinions as to what is best for the different districts to be united and for the whole enlarged municipality.

MONCTON, N.B., Jan. 26. -- Two persons were killed and ten were injured seriously to-day when part of an express train left the rails and plunged over a seventy-five-foot embankment into Palmer's Pond, near Dorchester.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 26. -- The freesilver Democrats in Kentucky have commenced an effort to patch up the split of last November, in order that the county and Legislative offices may not also be captured by the Republicans. Chairman P. P. Johnston of the Democratic State Central Committee has issued the following circular, which has caused more or less comment in political circles.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 26. -- From New York to-day came three Brooklyn men to urge upon Major McKinley the appointment as Secretary of the Navy of Congressman F.M. Wilson. They were Messrs. Atterbury, Willis, and Baker.

The House of Representatives is asked by its Committee on Commerce to repress what is known in railroad circles as "scalping." This picturesque name is given to the industry of selling railroad tickets at less than the rates charged by the authorized agents of the roads.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- A large delegation from New York City, representing organizations which favor the erection of a new Hall of Records, was before the Cities Committees of both branches of the Legislature to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- Immediately after the adjournment of the convention the special committee appointed to prepare a report on the tariff met at the Manufacturers' Club. There was a full and free discussion of the subject, and it was speedily shown that the committee was practically unanimous upon the kind of tariff that was wanted.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Wisconsin will have another Princeton athlete to assist in developing athletics at that institution. According to reports from Boston, "Doggy" Trenchard has been engaged by the regents of the University of Wisconsin as physical instructor. Trenchard is one of the best ends that the Tigers ever turned out, and captained his team in 1893 and 1894.

A man who spends enough of each day looking out upon Fifth Avenue to know something of its habitues takes exception to the way the women walk. "Where are all the athletic New York women of whom we hear so much?" he asks. "Look at that girl now," he continued, as a pretty young woman in a stylish street gown and handsome furs pass the window.

The New York Ministers' Association does not make the mistake of denouncing all newspapers as bad. Its censure is discriminating. Clerical and other critics have been too much given to the practice of railing at the press as an institution, judging all by the worst examples, and deploring the existence of what they appeared to consider an unmixed evil.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- The fire which started at 6:45 o'clock this morning from an overheated oven in the basement of the six-story iron building 1,309 to 1,317 Market Street, burned over the blocks bounded by Thirteenth and Juniper Streets and Market and Filbert Streets, destroyed or gutted sixty buildings and consumed property valued at $1,000,000.
ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- The following bills were passed:

The Board of Street Openings and Improvements will consider at its next meeting the petition submitted Nov. 6 relative to the widening of Ann Street. The petitioners want to transform the street into a thoroughfare 65 or 70 feet wide for the three blocks from Park Row to Gold Street. This they propose to do by taking off a slice from the building lots on the north side.

Preparations are making for an important extension of the Cataract Construction Company's plant at Niagara Falls. At a recent meeting of the Directors contracts were approved which will about double the present capacity of the plant, and will necessitate the expenditure of more than $500,000.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26. -- The principal losses by the fire are as follows:

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 26. -- A bill, which it is said, is about to be introduced in the Legislature at this place, has created much interest in those portions of the State bordering on the Hudson, and near New York. The bill provides for a marriage license law, and if it becomes a law it will put an end to secret marriages.
The New York University, through its Executive Committee, has presented the city with a fountain that will cost $10,000. The letter tendering the gift is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Republican Senators talk as if they had abandoned hope of controlling the Senate on a strict party vote even with the aid of the Vice President's decisive ballot in an emergency.

Mayor Strong sent another message to the Board of Aldermen yesterday. It chiefly concerns the Department of Charities, but the Department of Correction, the Mayor's Marshal's office, and the new East River bridge were also touched upon.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 26. -- Andrew J. Waterman failed of re-election as President of the Pittsfield National Bank at a stormy meeting held in the Directors' room in the bank to-day. Mr. Waterman's salary was cut down last year from $3,000 to $500, and it was supposed he would resign at that time, but he did not.

Final preparations nor the biggest industrial exhibition of bicycles and accessories that the world has ever seen will be completed in the Grand Central Palace by Thursday of next week. The opening of the show will not take place until the evening of Feb. 6, but the manufacturers will be privileged to move in their exhibits before that time and arrange them for the opening night.

There is a strong expectation among the cigar manufacturers of the United States that the edict, promulgated in Cuba last Spring by Captain General Weyler, prohibiting the exportation of the best grades of Cuban leaf tobacco, will soon be withdrawn, and the stock now excluded thrown open to American buyers.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 26. -- In exceedingly cold weather the firemen were called on to fight one of the most stubborn blazes in the history of the department this afternoon, in the block at the corner of Monroe Street and Fifth Avenue. This is in the heart of the wholesale district. In addition to a loss of $500,000, the fire resulted in crippling some of the best men of the department.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 26. -- The three days' session of the Second Annual Convention of the National Association of Manufacturers began here this morning in Horticultural Hall. The manufacturing interests of the country are represented at the convention by some of the leading business men of the country. All sections are represented.

A day on which the mercury persists in flirting with the zero mark is never looked upon as favorable for auction sales of real estate. The severity of the weather did not, however, prevent the assembling of a very large crowd to witness or participate in a sale in partition by Adrian H. Muller Son yesterday, in the Trinity Building Salesroom, of property formerly owned by Asa Hall, deceased.
" The inheritance tax is theoretically a desirable thing," said William B. Hornblower yesterday, "but it is a dangerous precedent to establish to make a graded tax based on the size of estates."

The finest stage production of "Cymbeline" ever seen in this country is now on view at Wallack's Theatre. As a pictorial show it is splendid; by which we do not mean to imply that it is merely expensive, sumptuous in a profusion of color and gilding and dazzling to the eye, for the genuine artistic merit of the painted scenery is uncommon.

A committee of the Philadelphia Select and Common Council came to this city yesterday to consult with the managers of the French Line, to ascertain if they could not get the company to run a branch line between their city and a French port. The committee was headed by E.C. Evans, its Chairman, and Wenzel Hartman, President of the Common Council.

Three thousand people attended the reopening of the championship races yesterday of the National Amateur Skating Association at Silver Lake, Staten Island, to which place the final events have been transferred from Stamford, Conn. Owing to the poor condition of the ice, which is covered with a crust of snow, the quarter-mile race was postponed until to-day.

Grand Commanders, with waving plumes; High Priests, with flashing jewels, and eminent Sir Knights, with gorgeous uniforms and glittering swords, entertained a host of pretty women and distinguished Free Masons at the Metropolitan Opera House last night at the nineteenth annual reception of Palestine Commandery, No. 18, Knights Templars.

Architect Lodge, No. 519, F. and A.M. -this was the legend on a shield of immortelles before a screen of palms -- gave a reception to 1,500 members and friends in Lexington Avenue Opera House last evening for the benefit of their widows and orphans' fund. An entertainment, in which Richard Lassar, boy soprano, was a chief attraction, was followed by a dance.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- The Senators who are to act on the joint committee to investigate trusts under the Lexow resolution were named to-day. They are Senators Lexow of Rockland County, Parsons of Monroe, and Gallagher of Kings.

Coroner Tuthill held an inquest yesterday in the case of Ethel Nonamaker, a little girl of Haverstraw, and a jury found that Ethel "came to her death from a rifle-shot wound at the hands of Alonzo Bedell." Ethel died at the Roosevelt Hospital, in this city, Jan. 6. She was shot while standing in a street at Haverstraw Jan. 2, by Alonzo Bedell, age fourteen.

The third concert of the fifth season in this city of the Kneisel Quartet of Boston was given in the Mendelssohn Glee Club Hall last night. The audience filled the room with its numbers and its applause. The most interesting incident of the entertainment was the first performance anywhere of George W. Chadwick's quartet in E minor, the fourth of the composer's works in this form.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Mr. Frye (Rep., Mo.,) presented a memorial from the President and Faculty of Bowdoin College, Maine, in favor of the immediate ratification of the arbitration treaty. Also a remonstrance of a labor union against the restoration of flogging in the merchant marine. Mr. Frye said there was no amendment pending in the Senate, or any bill, that restored flogging in the merchant marine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The National Board of Trade began its twenty-seventh annual meeting here to-day. Forty-one organizations were represented. The venerable President, Frederick Fraley of Philadelphia, was unable to be present, and Secretary Tucker called the meeting to order.

The County Medical Society met at the Academy of Medicine Monday evening and passed on proposed amendments to Chapter 354 of the Laws of 1883, which have for their purpose the placing of every public position in the State of New York, whether salaried or otherwise, under the civil service provisions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A very distinguished audience, representative of influential, social, and religious elements of the National Capital, filled the Grand Opera House at 4 o'clock this afternoon "to attest their approbation of the great principle of international arbitration as embodied in the treaty between this Republic and Great Britain, now pending in the Senate."
ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Senator Lexow called up the Cuban resolution and Senator Grady formally introduced his substitute, asking Congress to recognize the belligerency of the Cubans.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- The fight between Pedlar Falser and Ernle Stanton took place last last night bgfore the National Sporting Club and resulted in a victory for Palmer in the fiteenth round. The men fought at 117 Pounds for a stake of u3G0 a side and a purse of u500 given by the' club. Both are Englishmen.

The record-breaking cold wave promised for last night is lost, strayed, or stolen. It seems to have disappeared at some obscure point in the West, and the signal searchers could not find it with their most accomplished weather detective corps.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Republicans from many parts of the State, a thousand or more, all told, paid their respects to Senator-elect Thomas C. Platt at a banquet in Harmanus Bleecker Hall to-night, at which he was the guest of honor.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- Dr. William R. Alger of this city, the well-known lecturer and divine, has signified his willingness to accept the pastorate of the Unitarian church at Berkeley, Cal. Dr. Alger was seen at his home, 6 Brimmer Street, by the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES to-day, and explained the matter.

-- The Boston Traveler is waging an energetic campaign against what it calls the barbarous workings of the Massachusetts poor-debtor law. It says that creditors take advantage of the harsh and unjust provisions of this law to inflict cruel hardships upon unfortunate persons owing them money, and that the statute is especially harsh in the case of women debtors, who, under it, can be subjected to outrageous humiliations.
Mr. LEXOW is thin skinned. He is annoyed at the treatment accorded to his resolution for an investigation of trusts.

QUEENSTOWN, Jan. 26. -- The British bark Cedarbank, Capt. Moody, which sailed from San Francisco Sept. 13 for Hull, passed Prawle Point this afternoon. The Cedarbank is racing for a wager with the British ship Ditton, Capt. Stap, which sailed from San Francisco on the same day for Queenstown.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Chairman James K. Jones of the Democratic National Committee this afternoon sent a telegram to J.C. Rich, Chairman of the Idaho Democratic Legislative caucus, justifying the course of the National Committee in urging Democrats in the Idaho Legislature to vote for Dubois for United States Senator.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 26. -- It was Winter racing in earnest here this afternoon over a track covered with several inches of snow, and with the temperature at 30 racegoers had to move lively to keep warm. Three favorites won, and the 2,000 present fought a drawn battle with the bookmakers.

The Tammany Hall General Committee, in reorganizing in the Wigwam last night for this year paid no attention whatever to the recent silver issue. Not a word was said about it in its resolutions, which were mainly confined to local issues.
