DALLAS, Texas, Jan. 26. -- The spectacle of a Judge, who is also a Congressman-elect, threatening to kill another man was witnessed by a large crowd on the public streets a little after noon to-day. Judge R.E. Burke, the man referred to, has had a quarrel over money matters with J.M. O'Neall, a local politician and inventor, which never developed into open hostilities until to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 26. -- Last night was the coldest this city has experienced in two years, and there is no indication to-day that the weather will moderate during the next twenty-four hours. The suffering among the lower classes is intense, and special meetings of the various relief associations are being held to devise means for relieving the distress of the thousands of applicants for food and fuel.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- The appointment of Louis F. Payn to be Superintendent of Insurance, to succeed James F. Pierce, is considered a certainty by most Republicans. Mr. Payn has given some of his party friends who came to the city to-day to attend the complimentary dinner to Mr. Platt to understand that he expects the appointment, and is confident of enough Republican votes in the Senate to make sure of prompt confirmation.

Members of the bar are much interested in that chapter of the Greater New York charter which relates to inferior courts. The proposition to extend the terms of Judges of the City Court from six to ten years meets with general favor, and other changes in the existing City Court system are suggested.
ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- The State Prison Commission to-day submitted its second annual report to the Legislature. Under the head of "Recommendations," the report says:

The ladies' reception given by the Catholic Club last evening was one of the most numerously attended events ever held in the clubhouse. Stephen Farrelly was Chairman of the Entertainment Committee, and John D. Crimmins, William T. Ryan, Nicholas J. Barrett, and John Monks, Jr., were his associates.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- The Linden Groves of Brooklyn, said to be the champion ten-pin bowling club of the world, came to Rochester and played six games with a picked team, winning the entire series. The highest total was in the final evening game, when the Bridegrooms mowed 897 pins to Rochester's 867.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 27. -- The annual reports of the President and Trustees, of Harvard University will be ready for distribution to-morrow. President Eliot's reference to athletics is briefer than last year. He says:

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- J.A. George of Williamstown, Mass, has invented a bicycle support, which promises to increase the usefulness of the wheel for military purposes. The arrangement of the device is extremely simple. A brakelike appliance joined to the handlebar when lightly pressed drops two light steel supports to the ground.

A number of the men who attended the Platt dinner in Albany Tuesday night reached this city yesterday morning about dawn. It was a hungry-looking party, and in explanation some of the guests of the night before said the banquet was the finest starvation spread on record, but as a mental feast it beat anything within their memories.

The second sentence of Lieut. VON BRUSEWITZ is disgraceful to the German Army, to the Kaiser, and to the empire. The fellow is a murderer and a coward. He ran a citizen through the back with his sword because he had accidentally knocked against the Lieutenant's chair in entering a restaurant.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27. -- In spite of the fact that to-day was the coldest in two years, the thermometer registering only 22 above zero, 1,500 persons were at the races. Only one favorite won.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The following is the text of the bill agreed to by the House to-day:

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Jan. 27. -- A deal was closed in this city yesterday which, though surrounded with the greatest secrecy, has become known sufficiently to reveal that it is of the greatest importance to San Diego, foreshadowing the construction of a railroad from Salt Lake, presumably by the Vanderbilt interests, to afford an outlet for the Union Pacific.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The House today, after the reading of the Journal, entered upon the consideration of the Immigration bill as agreed upon by the conferrees of the House and Senate. Mr. Bartholdt, (Rep., Mo.,) Chairman of the House Committee on Immigration, refused to sign the report.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- The question of dollar gas for New York City has been so far taken out from any jurisdiction of the Committee on Trusts that a hearing on the subject has been ordered in advance of the meeting of the Lexow committee. The bill introduced in the Senate by Mr. Cantor and in the Assembly by Mr. Laimbeer will be publicly discussed next Thursday before the Senate Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations.

Among the suggestions of the Prison Commission in regard to the employment of convicts is one to the effect that their labor could be used in the construction of improved roads. This would involve the subsistence of prisoners away from the prisons and under close guard, except while the work was confined to the vicinity of the institutions.

At the meeting of the Tammany Hall General Committee on Tuesday night it was made plain why the sapient leaders of that organization have concluded to drop the subject of the late differences among Democrats upon National questions. They are not reading people out of the party any more, but are trying to revive the notion that in New York City Tammany is the party.

KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 27. -- Passengers by the steamer 0livette to-night report that Gonzalo Moreno, one of the most prominent citizens of Puerto Principe, for ten years Mayor of the city, and a rebel Colonel in the last war, has joined the insurgents. He became indignant at the outrages committed by Spaniards in arresting distinguished ladies and gentlemen, reported last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- In the Senate to-day the Military Academy Appropriation bill was taken up, the question being on Mr. Proctor's amendment to pay the trans-portion and subsistence of West Point military cadets coming to Washington to participate in the inauguration parade.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- When the report of the Cities Committee was read, Mr. Reinhard's bill providing that the District Attorney of New York shall conduct his own civil service examinations for appointments in his office was reported favorably with amendments.

Louis Mann, who was arrested Tuesday in Jersey City for causing the fire which destroyed the houses 84 and 86 Canal Street, at which Thomas Liddell, a fireman, was probably fatally injured, yesterday confessed his crime.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 27. -- The National Association of Manufacturers, in its convention to-day, adopted a series of tariff resolutions. The resolutions, as reported by Charles Heber Clarke from the Committee on Resolutions, were as follows:

The first exhibition exclusively devoted to gas products and appliances to be held in this country was opened last night at Madison Square Garden, and will continue until Feb. 6. Several thousand persons were in attendance, and the Garden presented a brilliant spectacle.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 27. -- George Dinning, who killed Joel Conn a few days ago in Simpson County while defending his little home and family of eleven children from a raid of Whitecaps, who had determined to run him out of the State, was brought to Louisville to-day for safe keeping.

Senator WHITE'S derisive view of Mr. WOLCOTT'S bimetallic mission is distinctly reassuring. Mr. WHITE is a silver Senator from California. He believes the Republican Party is unfriendly to international bimetallism. In sending an en voy to Europe it is merely trying to make the people believe that it is anxious to carry out the pledge of the St. Louis platform.

Even in the palmiest days of the County Democracy GROTE and COSTIGAN were made to understand that while THOMPSON and SQUIRE and FLYNN and the other elegant men of the organization were willing to meet them on terms of convivial intimacy in "the sty," as the New Amsterdam Club was sometimes called, they must not expect invitations to sit down with those leaders to canvasback and costly vintages at the Hoffman House.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- Owing to the failure of the North Mount Vernon Street Railroad Company to fulfill the orders of the Common Council of this city, Commissioner of Public Works F.S. Odell, in command of a large gang of men, this morning began tearing up the tracks of the company, on North Third Avenue.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 27. -- A pitiable case of destitution was discovered by the police to-day. The father and mother are dying, and three little ones were almost starved to death.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- One day not very long ago Elihu B. Washburne, a well known capitalist, and brother of former Mayor Washburne, was taken to the Harrison Street Police Station under suspicion that he was a pickpocket. Now he is suing the man who caused the trouble to recover $15,000 damages.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- The Republican machine leaders were at the Capitol to-day in force and watched the legislators at a brief session. The late hours which many members kept at the banquet to Mr. Platt prevented much business.
William C. Whitney said yesterday that he had bought a controlling interest in the stock of the Second Avenue Railroad Company. It was offered to him several days ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Col. H.A. Du Pont of Delaware, in connection with his prayer for the re-opening of his claim to a seat in the Senate, to-day submitted a supplementary petition, which was referred to the Committee on Privileges and Elections.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Jan. 27. -- A section gang of five were killed on the Consolidated Road, at East Norwalk, at 2:07 o'clock this afternoon, by a west-bound freight, in charge of Conductor McIntyre. The killed are: J.J. Powers, foreman, of South Norwalk; John Griffin, Norwalk; John Shea, West Norwalk; John Callahan, Danbury, and Salvator Spana.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27. -- The American Jewish Historical Society began its fifth annual meeting at the Hotel Rennert this afternoon, and also held an evening session. A number of representative Hebrews, having for their object an investigation into the settlement of Jews in America and the West Indies, the study of their civil and political stautus and the history of their communal role in this country, were present.

The doctrines recently put forth by the Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott of Plymouth Church, in Brooklyn, were indirectly attacked at the sixty-first meeting of the Manhattan Congregational Association, held yesterday at the South Congregational Church, at Court and President Streets, Brooklyn. The ministers plainly manifested their disapproval of Dr. Abbott's view that certain books of the Bible are fiction.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 27. -- Arthur Palmer of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was arrested at the Planters' Hotel this afternoon. He had been at the hotel for a week, registered as Paul Jones.

" My lodging is on the cold, cold ground," was the tune moodily hummed by many a sleepy guest of the Metropolitan Hotel yesterday morning, as he obeyed the Deputy Marshal's request to move out as soon as possible.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 27. -- The complex political problem surrounding the selection of Major McKinley's Cabinet is now believed to be practically solved, and Lyman J. Gage of Chicago, as Secretary of the Treasury, is regarded as the key to the situation.
This advertisement was published yesterday in a morning newspaper:

POUGHKEEPSIE, Jan. 27. -- The publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Monday of the story of John Gager's unfortunate career in Poughkeepsie and the fortune that is awaiting his widow and daughter in Troy, was read by Mrs. Gager at her home in Mount Vernon yesterday. Detectives had been trying for some time to find her, but without success.

The contests for the amateur figure skating championship of the National Amateur Skating Association were begun yesterday at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink, Sixty-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue. There were nine contestants, and they showed how well they could skate in a space roped off in the middle of the ice, leaving room for the regular skaters outside.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Reinsurance has again been effected on the British bark Lord Dufferin. Capt. Roberts, which sailed from Montevideo Oct. 7 for New York, and on the American ship T.F. Oakes, Capt. Reed, from Shanghai May 17, via Hongkong July 4, for New York. Eighty-five guineas premium and 40 guineas premium, respectively, were the rates paid.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 27. -- The Western Alabama Coal Association, a pooling aggregation of the Walker County mines, has secured contracts in the New Orleans and Mississippi River markets recently for 100,000 tons of coal as follows: From the Anchor Line of steamers on the Mississippi River, 50,000 tons; from five steamship lines with headquarters at New Orleans, 40,000 tons; from sugar plantations below Greenville, 10,000 tons.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The President has approved these acts:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- At the meeting of the National Board of Trade this morning the time was occupied by hearing and adopting the reports of the different committees. The committee report on the Consular Service was first heard and adopted, together with the following resolution, without discussion:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- An intimation was given by a member of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations to-day that the committee may report the arbitration treaty with Great Britain to the Senate on Monday. But no member of the committee would say so positively, and members of the Senate not on the committee say they do not look for it before the middle of the week.
The oldest benefit association in this city is said to be the Hebrew Mutual Benefit Society, organized July 2, 1826, although the formation, in a sense, really ante-dates this by six years.

Mrs. Cynthia McLean, the wife of an ice-wagon driver, living at 683 Eighth Avenue, was seriously burned on the back, face, and limbs yesterday morning, at her home. Afterward she lay for over half an hour in the cold hallway of the house, while the police and firemen were trying to get an ambulance from Roosevelt Hospital.

-- Spanish members of the Anarchist-Communistic groups in London are arranging for a series of meetings for the purpose of making public the barbarous treatment to which they say suspects are subjected in Spain. They declare that many of the persons arrested after the bomb outrage at Barcelona were kept for days on an exclusive diet of salt fish, and then were offered a glass of water as the reward for a confession of guilt.
ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- Three bills on the order of third reading and one general order constituted the calendar in the Senate this morning.

Wall Street is concerning itself very much just now in discussions of the business affairs of the Delaware and Hudson Canal Company. Yesterday these discussions became specially lively in view of the fact that the annual report of the company was expected. The Directors of the company met at noon.
WASHINGTON Jan. 27. -- "There must be a complete reorganization of the civil service as soon as the Republican Party comes into power," said Speaker Reed.

The Social Reform Club is quite right in condemning the violence of the strikers in the recent trouble with the cab company. It is equally right in its temperate but plain criticism of the company in refusing to deal with any union and insisting on dealing only with individual employes.

The New York committee of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad Company will meet today at the offices of the State Trust Company, 100 Broadway, to ratify an arrangement acquiesced in by the Directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company last week. By it the Santa Fe would acquire $16,000,000 6 per cent. first mortgage bonds of the Western Division of the Atlantic and Pacific.

John Bottigliso, better known as "Bottles," the Italian who led the attack on Capt. Alfred Handicott of the American Volunteers in the hall 139-141 West Thirtyfifth Street, Tuesday evening, was arrested yesterday and arraigned in Jefferson Market Court. Lieut. John Cosgrove of the Volunteers, who appeared as complainant, told Magistrate Deuel that Capt. Handicott was severely injured, and "Bottles" was held to await the result of his hurts.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- The Assembly Judiciary Committee gave a hearing to-day on Mr. Emmett's bill providing for the appointment of the Commissioner of Jurors of Westchester County by the County Judge, and legislating out of office the incumbent, John Sells of Yonkers.

An interested body of women filled the floor of the Carnegie Lyceum yesterday afternoon, and more women -- a representative gathering from all parts of the Greater New York -- the stage, the former to listen and the latter to talk on the position to be obtained, if possible, for women through the greater city charter.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 27. -- The Columbus, Sandusky and Hocking Railway Company has brought suit for $200,000 damages against the persons who were instrumental in having a receiver appointed for the road last week. The defendants are D.L. Sleeper, Speaker of the Ohio House of Representatives, who was the chief attorney; E.M. Poston, who was appointed receiver; Morris Donahue, an atorney; George W. Saul, formerly President of the Ohio Southern Railway, and Herbert R. Butler.

The amateur skating races for the championships of the United States, under the auspices of the National Amateur Skating Association, were continued yesterday at Silver Lake, S.I. Despite a slight flurry of snow the ice was in good condition, and a big throng of skaters watched the races. The management found it impracticable to construct a straightaway track, and the course on which the first day's races were held was used.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- In the House to-day a bill was passed to extend the time for the construction, by the East Nebraska and Gulf Railway Company, of its line through the Omaha and Winnebago Reservation, Nebraska.

An engine and the forward car of a train on the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad plunged from the track to the street, twenty-five feet below, last night, resulting in one death and the serious injury of seven persons. The accident occurred on Fulton Street, at the intersection of Bradford Street, and was caused by a head-on collision at the Bradford Street switch.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 28. -- Major Alexander Morgan has sworn out a warrant for the arrest of William A. Newcomb, until recently manager of the Lexington Board of Trade. He is charged with grand larceny.
The congregation of St. Paul's German Evangelical Lutheran Church proposes to erect a new structure on the site of the present building, at 145-149 West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street.

The Federation of East Side Workers met yesterday afternoon at 339 East Fourth Street and discussed the topic, "The Dependent Children of New York City." Mrs. Charles Russell Lowell read a paper dealing with the children in private institutions that are supported by the public funds.

By his unflinching determination to appoint "LOU" PAYN Superintendent of Insurance, and by his personal use of his official influence to insure the votes of Republican Senators in advance for confirmation, Gov. BLACK is showing his independence, not only of "irresponsible clamor," but of "boss dictation," and of all the powers of darkness and of light.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 28. -- A receiver was appointed to-day for the Covenant Building and Loan Association of this city, making the seventh such association to go under during the last ten days.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 28. -About twenty-five freshmen of Rutgers College last night decided to prevent the sophomores from enjoying their dinner if they could. They planned to take the sophomores by surprise, and succeeded in capturing S.M. Cuddeback of Port Jervis, A.H. Shearer of Philadelphia, W.L.R. Haines of Newark, George W. Ecker of Albany, and James MacDonald Martin of East Orange, all sophomores.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Chairman Dingley of the Ways and Means Committee, outlining to-day the programme of the Administration at the extra session of Congress, said:

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The Greater New York charter is due to reach the Legislature next Monday night. Until yesterday the legislators expected it would be here promptly, but an informal request was then made for an extension of time. This came from the Greater New York Commission through Gen. Stewart L. Woodford.

The second panel of the Sheriff's jury had its annual banquet at the Hotel Manhattan last night. More than 200 members of the jury and their guests were present. Controller Ashbel P. Fitch was to have presided, but he was ill, and his place was taken by John McAnerney, who acted as toastmaster, and introduced the speakers.

Confidence in the soundness of Mr. JOHN BOYD THACHER'S political judgment was somewhat impaired by his wild work as the temporary Gubernatorial nominee of the Bryanites last Fall. He is still thinking and talking about politics, however. To a reporter he had this to say about the present lamentable strife in Tammany Hall:

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Latimer E. Jones, who has been engaged as a stud keeper at Scolby, near Scarborough, has been arrested on a warrant charging him with forgery, alleged to have been committed in New York in 1887, whereby he is said to have obtained $100,000. He will be arraigned in proceedings for his extradition to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- There was a direct conflict of statements between representatives of the ticket brokers and the railroads, this morning, in a hearing before the Senate Inter-State Commerce Committee, on the bill to restrict the sale of railroad tickets except through authorized agents holding the certificates of the roads whose tickets they offered for sale.

The question of the arrest of citizens on warrants and the securing by them of bail has been taken up by the Police Commissioners, and hereafter the means of securing bail will be much easier for the citizen. Police Commissioner Grant, Chairman of the Committee on Rules and Discipline, issued orders yesterday requiring the Sergeants in every police station to volunteer information to prisoners as to the best means of securing bail.

Park Commissioner W.A. Stiles objects to that portion of the new charter which abolishes present form of Park Commission and provides for a single-headed administration in the boroughs. In response to the general invitation to express their views issued by the Charter Commission to the heads of the different departments, Commissioner Stiles wrote:
CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 28. -- "The appointment as Secretary of the Treasury has been tendered to me by Major McKinley, and I have accepted it," said Lyman J. Gage of Chicago to-night.

Much of the testimony laid before the Ways and Means Committee at the recent hearings was in the form of written statements and was not given to the public at the time when it was submitted. Thus, some interesting protests against suggested increases of rates and some appeals for the removal of duties were overlooked.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 28. -- The fifth annual meeting of the American Jewish Historical Society was concluded to-day. Officers were elected, some notable papers were read, and an adjournment taken. The place and time for the next annual meeting was referred to the Executive Council, with power to act.

The Immigration act finally passed by both houses of Congress contains one sound and essential provision and a number of others that are of less consequence, but some are unreasonable and some absurd.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Controller Eckels to-day addressed the House Committee on Banking and Currency on the several bills referred to him.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- Morris Jackson of this city shot Frederick McIntosh and Miss Ella M. Ausman at their boarding house, on John Street, in this city, at 6:30 o'clock this evening. He then attempted to kill himself. Jealousy was the cause.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- The third and last day's session of the second annual convention of the National Association of Manufacturers was held this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- A join resolution was introduced in the House of Representatives yesterday, and referred to the Committee on Ways and Means, admitting free of duty needlework and similar articles imported by the New York Association of Sewing Schools for exhibition purposes for the forthcoming exhibition of sewing at the American Art Galleries, in New York City.
BOSTON, Jan. 28. -- The student celebration around Harvard Square Tuesday night has had more serious results than was anticipated by the students.
William H. Weiher, builder, has bought as a site for two five-story brick flats the plot, 50 by 100, on the southeast corner of Brown Place and One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, for $10,000.

The storm effectually closed the port yesterday forenoon and the preceding night, no vessels venturing out or attempting to come in past the bar. During the afternoon, however, a number of vessels which had anchored inside the Hook, passed out, and a few of those due, which had been keeping off shore, came in. Among these were the Anchoria, from Glasgow; the Trinidad, from Bermuda, and the Yumuri, from Jamaica.

The bill reorganizing the Police Department of Richmond County was passed by the Assembly yesterday by a party vote, and that of itself reveals its political character. It establishes a bipartisan board of two members, which would have practically complete power to reorganize the force.
The "declaration to the voters," issued by the Tammany Hail General Committee, at its meeting Tuesday night, contained the following statement:

Several important matters which will have a direct effect on the coming golf season were discussed at the Executive Committee meeting of the United States Golf Association Wednesday afternoon at the office of the President, Theodore A. Havemeyer. Those present were Mr. Havemeyer, Secretary Henry O. Tallmadge, and Treasurer Samuel L. Parrish.

The Armory Board at its meeting in the Mayor's office yesterday finally selected the site of the College of the City of New York, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, and five adjoining lots, as the site for the proposed new armory to be occupied by the Sixty-ninth Regiment.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 28. -- The steamer Mohawk of the Central Vermont Propeller Line, which left New York Wednesday night for this port, went ashore at 1:30 o'clock this morning on the rocks at the end of Goose Point, between Bartlett's Reef Lightship and the mouth of this harbor.

News from Columbus, Ohio, yesterday was that the members of the Ohio Coal Traffic Association had agreed to agree on a fair basis of distribution of traffic. In this city the way was paved to a new soft coal agreement at a meeting of representatives of Eastern soft coal lines, at 143 Liberty Street.

Arguments for the extension of the proposed underground railroad south of City Hall Park to the Battery were submitted to the Rapid Transit Commissioners at their meeting yesterday. Several property owners of lower Broadway and adjacent streets, all of whom strongly favored the extension, promised to co-operate actively in securing the requisite consents when the time comes.
ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The annual report of the State Fisheries, Game, and Forest Commission for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1896, was to-day submitted to the Legislature.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 28. -- A mass meeting was held here to-night for a discussion of the question of granting a franchise to the North Jersey Traction Company. Abotu 600 citizens attended, including a number from Caldwell and Verona. The meeting was called by the Common Council, the members of which desired to obtain a free expression of public opinion before taking final action.
ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The following bills were introduced in the Senate to-day:

The National Guardsmen of the First and Second Brigades decided last night to organize an athletic association. For several years there has been talk about the young men in the various regiments managing their own athletic competitions, and the feeling has been largely in favor of such an association.

Merchants from all sections of the city have signified their readiness to unite in opposing the bills, now before the Cities Committee of the Legislature, to legalize the obstruction of the sidewalks. A petition addressed to Chairman Austin of the committee is being circulated, and many thousand signatures of men prominent in the commercial and real estate world have been affixed to it.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- Senator Lexow has been made Chairman of the Joint Committee of Seven to investigate trusts. Of his associates, Senator Parsons is most widely known. He is a strong adherent of the Platt machine and one of the lieutenants of Mr. Platt.

Funeral services over the body of John C. Reid were held at 7 East Thirtieth Street yesterday morning, in the presence of a large number of the dead journalist's old newspaper and political associates. The Rev. John Lewis Clark of the Marble Collegiate Church, in Fifth Avenue, officiated. On the casket were several floral pieces, including a large pillow of white roses and lilies, the tribute of few old personal friends.

The second Assembly ball was enjoyed last night at the Waldorf. The new ballroom was prettily decorated with Virginia ivy, smilax, La France roses, and palms, and there the guests were received by Mrs. John W. Minturn, Mrs. John C. Wilmerding, Mrs. W. Bayard Cutting, and Mrs. Edward L. Baylies.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Dr. Lyman Abbott of Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, is spending a few days at the Laurel-in-the-Pines, Lakewood, where he was seen to-day in regard to the resolutions adopted by the Manhattan Association of Congregational Ministers at their session in Brooklyn yesterday, and, in reply to questions, the Doctor said:

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- In the House to-day the bill appropriating $5,000 for the perfection of the disinfecting apparatus to be used by the Health Officer of the Port of New York in anticipation of the bubonic plague was passed, but later it was reconsidered and made a special order for Monday night. The annual appropriation bill was made a special order on second and third reading for to-morrow.
The fifth annual dinner of the Society of Colonial Wars was held at Delmonico's last evening. Covers were laid for 150.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- For more than an hour the Senate this afternoon discussed in executive session the nomination of William S. Forman of Illinois to be Commissioner of Internal Revenue, and finally confirmed it by a vote of 41 to 15.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 29. -- Louisville's midwinter housecleaning has begun with the wholesale indictment of city officials, which will be officially reported to-morrow by the Grand Jury.

In that portion of the New York Public Library which is known, and will be known for many years, as the Lenox Library, is a little room set apart for one of the most unique and valuable of libraries. It is a princely collection in itself -- the Dr. Thomas Addis Emmet Library. Every one familiar with Americana will recognize what this means.

During the reign of Elizabeth the fashion in binding underwent a considerable change, the graceful simplicity of the early work, with its rather severe and restrained ornament, giving place to a heavy, overdecorated style, in which a superabundance of gilding hid poverty of design.

It would be better and safer to abolish the Insurance Department outright than to intrust the duties of the Superintendency to such foul hands as those of "LOU" PAYN. It is the intention of the law that the Superintendent of Insurance shall safeguard the interests of policy holders.

J.S. Sargent's election as a full Academician, and the choice of J.J. Shannon and Alfred H. Parsons as Associates, is something we may be proud about. It should not be said that the English people axe not fair and honest in these matters, for, once having seen true merit, they are eager to herald and reward it.

An interesting avocation of Morris K. Jesup, the banker, is missionary work. He is devoting some time to the interesting work of the American Sunday School Union. He has recently become President of this organization, and has associated with him a number of other well-known citizens, including William E. Dodge, James Talcott, D.W. McWilliams, and Edward P. Bancroft, the latter being the Secretary of the union.

The semi-centennial celebration of the New York Academy of Medicine was held last night in Carnegie Hall. The knowledge that President Cleveland would be one of the speakers added greatly to the size of the audience, and the hall was crowded from the orchestra to the topmost gallery.

In What to Eat, a capital magazine devoted to culinary lore, and published at Minneapolis, there is an. interesting article called "A Japanese Dinner." It is the art sense of these island people which becomes conspicuous when they serve food. "Japanese dishes appeal to the eye hardly less than the brilliant gems of the Palais Royal.

Two arrests were made by the police of the Liberty Avenue Station, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, in connection with the wreck on the Brooklyn Union Elevated Railroad at Bradford and Fulton Streets, Thursday evening.

Mr. Howells's introduction to this handsome volume, entitled "English Society Sketched by George Du Maurier," is conceived in his happiest style. The volume being devoted to sketches Du Maurier made, Mr. Howells well describes the artist's manner. He says that Du Maurier "never insulted women, never betrayed the trust which reposed in the traditions of decency and generosity.

Plans are now being devised for a regular annual exhibition of works of art in Pittsburg on a grand scale. Pictures are to be contributed from all parts of the United States. How good is the idea suggested of having connoisseurs alone to select pictures we are in doubt about. While connoisseurs are disinterested, their acquaintance with art is not necessarily of the best.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- The Lexow committee expects to start after the trusts next week, and the first on the list will be the so-called Tobacco Trust. The American Tobacco Trust's officers, it is said, will be subpoenaed and cross-examined by Mr. Lexow.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- Gov. Black has a plan for hurrying the completion of the Capitol, which involves wiping out the Capitol Commission, removing the Commissioner who is in charge of the construction, and putting the entire work into the hands of the State Superintendent of Public Works, George M. Aldridge.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- After the Assembly had adopted the resolution extending the time in which the Greater New York Commission should make its report, on motion of Mr. Nixon, the annual appropriation bill, which had been set down for a special order for this morning, was advanced to a third reading, and made a special order for Monday evening, after the reading of the Journal.

Of the overdue steamships, three came into port yesterday. They were the British steamship Grenada of the Trinidad Shipping and Trading Company, from Port au Spain; the Atlantic Transport Line steamship Mobile, from London, and the North German Lloyd steamship Munchen, from Bremen. The Munchen was two days late and the Mobile three.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 29. -- Lula Jordan is the name of a mountain lass who came all the way from White County to find the woman who robbed her of her sweetheart, Tom Edgefield. Her wrath is not kindled so much against him as the woman in the case.

There is a poster quarrel in France. Whether the apparent trouble arises from the fact that the poster is to be better advertised we do not pretend to state. The last thing in posters on Paris hoardings is one with a kind of stamp on which may be read: "This poster can neither be given away nor sold; any one in whose hands it is found will be subject to prosecution."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Permanent Committee on Arbitration with Great Britain appointed by the conference held here on April 22 and 23, 1896, makes the following public statement of its views concerning the treaty between the United States and Great Britain:

Snow shovelers were at work in every much-frequented thoroughfare in this city yesterday. Fully 3,500 men and 3,200 carts were employed by Snow Contractor Furman. Broadway was practically cleared from Central Park to the Battery before sundown.

-- A recent story of society life which has had considerable vogue is materially marred by the fact that one of the characters is described as cutting her lettuce at the dinner table. It was of the doings of the particularly smart set in society that the writer was telling. A trifle like that destroyed the whole illusion.

Senator STEWART of Nevada is old enough to know and frank enough to say what he wants. With the barren ideality of international bimetallism he has little patience. The free and unlimited coinage of silver by the United States without the aid or consent of any other nation on earth is the only kind of bimetallism that would do him any good, and, accordingly, is the only kind in which he takes any interest.
CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 29. -- This was Major McKinley's birthday, and he celebrated it by tendering the portfolio of War to Gen. Russell A. Alger of Michigan, who at once accepted it.

Very wholesome and refreshing and pleasant are these stories by Mr. Rogers. The reading world has had much recounted to it of the knew England countryside, until some of us have been led to wonder whether there was anything really rural in the United States between the realm of the Hoosier Schoolmaster and the taste of the salt east wind blowing in from the Atlantic.

ALBANY, Jan. 29. -- No sooner had Speaker O'Grady called the Assembly to order to-day than a spirited discussion ensued over the communication received from the Greater New York Commission, asking that the time for the commission to report be extended from Feb. 1 to Feb. 20, in order that the commission might have time to carefully correct and revise the charter.

While water colors lend themselves to a scheme of decoration, inasmuch as they are in themselves both decorative and as a rule delicate in color, it is not often that the attention of the visitor to the annual water color display at the old Academy of Design is diverted from the pictures themselves to the effects which have been devised to make their surroundings attractive.

Criticism in the worthy days of Johnson, Burke, and Arbuthnot was seldom inclined to deal leniently toward whatever came within its province. It. took itself and its subject seriously; and its severity of temper was more easily lad into the stony paths of unsympathetic analysis than beguiled, into the exotic by-way trodden by many of our latter-day critics.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- There was a little circumstance on the curb last night -- the selling of an enormous line of puts by several big houses acting as if for one principal -- which the trade did not forget when the wheat market opened this morning. It was a hint that a big line of wheat might need the privileges.

The important London literary event in the month of January has been unquestionably the publication of Gibbon's "Autobiography" and private letters, the former in one volume, edited by John Murray, the latter in two volumes, edited by R.E. Prothero. Lord Sheffield states in the preface contributed to both works that the publication is the result of the centenary commemoration of the historian's death, in 1704.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 29. -- A circle of charitably disposed ladies of the most exclusive set in Camden were badly imposed upon this week by a couple living in one of the poorest sections of the city.

Sir Roderick Murchison, the famous naturalist, has left it on record that Gladstone was "the prettiest little boy that ever went to Eton." Most of us can testify from our own knowledge that Mr. Gladstone lately is the handsomest old man who ever went to Eton or anywhere else. Visitor to Eton are shown, of course, the name of Gladstone carved into a wall or a woodwork here and there.

The student of criminal questions comes to the terrible conclusion that both at home and abroad "the proportion of habitual criminals in the criminal population is steadily on the increase, and was never as high as now." These are Mr. W. Douglas Morrison's words, and he adds that in France, Germany, and Italy "the proportion of old offenders who come before the criminal courts is constantly growing, while in England matters are just as bad."

" I have followed the youthful developing period of your son's life with cognizance and sympathy, without exercising any other influence upon him than that of my example as an artist and of my most cautious advice. I have observed that his love of Art, and especially of music, is based upon no mere transient excitement, but upon great -- indeed uncommon powers.

In an examination of the picture sales made in England last year, some remarkable features are apparent. Thirty years ago a picture of Romney passed almost without anything more than distant appreciation. In 1896 a picture of Romney's, the. portraits of the Ladies Caroline and Elizabeth Spencer, brought 10,500 guineas, "the highest price," says The London Times, "ever paid at auction for am example of Romney."

On the Continent the term dolmen is almost universally applied to the whole construction, including the covering, mound, or cairn. Thus French and other writers speak of a chambered mound or tumulus as a dolmen. But since it is probable that some never were covered up, it seems better to make a distinction, as we do in this country.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 29. -- Train No. 15, northbound express, on the Southern Pacific, was stopped this morning at Shady Point, two miles south of Roseburg, Oregon, by two or three men. The express car was detached from the train by the robbers and the door was blown open with dynamite. Two small safes in the car were blown open and looted.

We suspect that there are very few people, not excepting active politicians of either party, who are not convinced that a complete separation of party politics from city government would result in a distinct improvement in the latter. Those who consider this separation absolutely necessary to a decently good city government are very generally convinced that it would result in an equal improvement in politics.

" On Many Seas" is full of realism, and you are satisfied that of all callings, that of the seaman's is the hardest. How many fights the present hero got into can scarcely be counted. He must have worn out innumerable belaying pins on other men's heads. Are all skippers tyrants, braggarts, liars, and screws?

Register William Sohmer was elected Chairman of the Committee on Organization of Tammany at its meeting in the Wigwam last night. He succeeds Henry D. Purroy, who was elected County Clerk on the same ticket with the Register, and who is now out of Tammany.

The choice of Mr. GAGE as Secretary of the Treasury is the strongest proof that Mr. MCKINLEY has given -- and he could hardly give one stronger -- that the sound-money men, who disagreed wholly with his views on all strictly partisan issues, made no mistake in promoting his election over the candidate produced by the Democratic miscarriage at Chicago.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Albert Cunning, a coachman, shot and instantly killed Mrs. Mary Denning at her home, 4,036 State Street, this morning. He attempted to shoot the woman's two boys, but failed. He then shot himself in the breast, inflicting a fatal wound.
William Cruikshank's Sons and Horace Co. have sold for Eugeue Smith to Mrs. William Astor, 5 Worth Street, a five-story business building, on lot 25 by 100.

The first President of the Royal Academy held that it was dangerous for a painter to be able to express himself too readily through then medium of language. But he also felt that artists should not withhold their opinions from the public, recognizing the value of their special knowledge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Attorney General Harmon has prepared a petition for a writ of certiorari to bring up for review from the United States Court for the Southern District of Florida the case of the Three Friends, the alleged filibustering steamer. This petition will be presented to the United States Supreme Court Monday.
The annual meeting of the University Settlement Society was held yesterday afternoon at the City Club, 677 Fifth Avenue.

The Greater New York Commission, through its President and Secretary, presented a request to the Legislature yesterday for an extension of time to Feb. 20 for submitting its completed charter. A joint resolution granting the request was adopted by the Assembly by a vote of 82 to 7, but the Senate failed to concur for lack of a quorum and adjourned till Monday evening.
A neat thing is credited to a landlady about the cocky Andrew Lang. It appears in a letter George Moore writes to The Saturday Review. Moore says he asked the landlady whether there was good fishing.

William Matthews, our great New York bookbinder, whose death occurred in April of last year, while he cared much for the outsides of such volumes as were confided to his care for decoration, was perfectly well acquainted with their text. There are fastidious dilettanti in bookbindings who will insist that the binder fails when the soul of the book he labors on is hidden from him.

When Mr. O'SULLIVAN of Lawrence, one of the silver men of the Massachusetts delegation, passed through this city on his way to the Chicago Convention, he purchased a Texas ranchman's hat, for which, as he put it, he "gave up" $15. This great hat, topping off the slight and weedy figure of O'SULLIVAN, attracted attention and aroused curiosity.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- The Senate bill granting a pension of $8 a month to Mrs. Martha Frank of Georgia, widow of a soldier in the Indian war of 1818, and now 102 1/2 years old, was passed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Mr. Powers (Rep., Vt.,) called up the report of the conferrees on the bill constituting a new corporation of the purchasers of the Atlantic and Pacific Railroad, and explained the provisions of the agreement.

The members of the Musical Mutual Protective Union are very much agitated over a report that Mrs. Bradley-Martin has engaged, or will engage, the Marine Band of Washington to furnish music at her great ball, and that consequently they are not to get a single dollar of the great amount that that lady is to spend.

The snowfall of each year adds a new stratum to this icecap, which is as distinguishable to the eye as is the annual accretion of a forest tree. Thus in centuries have accumulated on Antarctica these snows, which, by processes of pressure, thawing, and regelation, have formed an icecap that in places exceeds 3,000 feet in thickness.

It was generally understood yesterday that when the January Grand Jury adjourned for the term it would hand up a presentment against the Police Department on account of certain acts done by police-men in procuring certain kinds of evidence.

A plan is on foot for the extension of Riverside Drive from where it now ends, at Claremont, to a junction with the Boulevard Lafayette at or near One Hundred and Fifty-seventh Street, and a bill which has been prepared for that purpose was sent yesterday to Albany, where it will be introduced in the Legislature.

The appearance of three octavo volumes devoted to writings by Edward Gibbon, in large part unpublished heretofore, (just received there from London by the Messrs. Scribner,) may well be called the literary event of most importance during a lengthened recent period.

The report of the Long Island Railroad's condition, a result of a rigid examination by experts to verify President Baldwin's representations to .the Pratt syndicate, which purchased the Corbin holdings, at 42 1/2, was given out last night. It is satisfactory to the syndicate, and the transactions incident to a complete acquisition of the stock are at an end.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- Benzie Cox attempted to murder his wife in her mother's home here this afternoon. He did not succeed, but in the course of his attempt he sent three bullets through his mother-in-law's arm. But for the timely arrival of neighbors he undoubtedly would have killed his mother-in-law and everybody else in the house.

The fusion of Populists and Republicans in North Carolina is practically "off," and MARION BUTLER has become a Middle of the Road Populist, even like unto WATSON of Georgia, who was bound against his will to a kind of fusion with the Democrats. Elsewhere there is a tendency of Populists to "go it alone" hereafter.

A plan is on foot for the extension of Riverside Drive from where it now ends, at Claremont, to a junction with the Boulevard Lafayette at or near One Hundred and Fifty-seventh Street, and a bill which has been prepared for that purpose was sent yesterday to Albany, where it will be introduced in the Legislature.

The report of the Long Island Railroad's condition, a result of a rigid examination by experts to verify President Baldwin's representations to .the Pratt syndicate, which purchased the Corbin holdings, at 42 1/2, was given out last night. It is satisfactory to the syndicate, and the transactions incident to a complete acquisition of the stock are at an end.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- Benzie Cox attempted to murder his wife in her mother's home here this afternoon. He did not succeed, but in the course of his attempt he sent three bullets through his mother-in-law's arm. But for the timely arrival of neighbors he undoubtedly would have killed his mother-in-law and everybody else in the house.

The fusion of Populists and Republicans in North Carolina is practically "off," and MARION BUTLER has become a Middle of the Road Populist, even like unto WATSON of Georgia, who was bound against his will to a kind of fusion with the Democrats. Elsewhere there is a tendency of Populists to "go it alone" hereafter.

In the death of George B. Roberts, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad lines, which occurred at his home in Philadelphia yesterday afternoon, a man of remarkable administrative qualities is lost to the railroad world. Judged by those of his own craft, he was the foremost railroad man of the present day. His long and brilliantly, successful career has been wholly confined to railway affairs.

OAKDALE, L.I., Jan. 30. -- The large oyster planters along the Great South Bay, and especially in the vicinity of Blue Point, are jubilant over the result of an investigation made of the oyster beds by Prof. Jefferies of the Carnegie Laboratory in New York City. For some time past the shipments of Great South Bay oysters, and especially the famous Blue Points, have been below the average.
Commission brokers are trying hard to be hopeful. Letters sent to customers last night were generally confidently bullish in their prophecies.

TO-MORROW morning the doors of the old Academy of Design will be thrown open and the public will be admitted to the thirtieth annual ex hibition of the American Water Color Society. The artists and critics were admitted to the galleries on Friday afternoon, and yesterday the annual reception for specially invited guests was held.

The United Hebrew Charities of the City of New York was founded twenty-two years ago, and from a very small beginning has developed into an institution as far-reaching, comprehensive, and effective as any kindred organization in the land.

PROF. WOODROW WILSON'S volume on George Washington as illustrated by Howard Pyle, Harry Fenn, and others, and published by Harper Brothers, presents Washington to us in colors which, if not unfamiliar, are at least newly bright and uncommonly attractive.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- A hearing was given this morning by the Senate Committee on Post Offices and Post Roads to persons interested in what has come to be known as the Loud bill, recently passed by the House of Representatives, applying to the postage on second-class mail matter.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 30. -- The United States Grand Jury to-day found indictments against Gen. Carlos Roloff, Secretary of War of the Cuban Provisional Government, and his compatriot, Dr. Joseph Luis, on the charge of "beginning, setting on foot and providing, within the district of Maryland, means for a military expedition against the territory of a foreign Prince with whom the United States is at peace: to wit, against the Island of Cuba."

Senator-elect Thomas C. Platt and Mrs. Platt started for Florida at noon yesterday over the Pennsylvania Railroad. They are traveling in the private car Virginia, which belongs to President Barton of the Baltimore and Ohio Southwestern Railroad, and the car was attached to the Florida Limited.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 30. -- Every mail from Cuba brings tales of massacres of innocent women and children, and of the most unheard of torture of pacificos.

To see a village pick itself up and remove to a more favorable location would be a novelty in the East, but it is not a rare occurrence on the Western frontier. There are many people in New York with investments in North Dakota who know, to their sorrow, that towns out there have an unpleasant habit of disappearing.

The Rev. Charles Cuthbert Hall, D.D., who has been nominated for the Presidency of Union Theological Seminary and the Skinner and McAlpin Professorship of Pastoral Theology and Mission Work in the seminary, is, and for years has been, one of the most eloquent and popular preachers in Brooklyn.

Robert S. Welch of the Riverton Gun Club won the championship pigeon shooting match at Larchmont yesterday. Out of the hundred birds he shot at during the two days he killed ninety-two. He won a cup and $560. George McAlpin of the Carteret Club was second, with eighty-four killed.

DOLGEVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- The twenty-eighth annual reunion or the employes of Alfred Dolge Son was held here to-day. During the exercises, Alfred Dolge, founder of the town and originator of the labor-pension and insurance system for employes, delivered his annual address.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- The smash in the wheat market was hard medicine for the heavy holders. The bull leaders, who did all their buying above 75 and 75 cents last Fall, have seen their paper profits wiped out. Those who began around 60 cents and bought all the way up, had lines averaging about 70 cents.

The indictment of the Metropolitan Traction Company for maintaining a nuisance in the dangerous curve of the cable road at Broadway and Fourteenth Street will sharply challenge public attention and warn the company that something will have to be done about it, though it may be questioned whether a misdemeanor can be made of the exercise of a franchise on conditions to which the required legal consents have been given.

There was an immense audience at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon, when Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" was given. In the evening "Rigoletto" was performed to a very small assembly. Every time this season that a German work has been sung at the matinee at $5 a seat and an Italian work in the evening at half that price, the same state of affairs has been noticed.

According to our Washington dispatches Speaker REED recently remarked: "There must be a complete reorganization of the civil service as soon as the Republican Party comes into power." If this remark was made while discussing "the barren outlook for Republican office-seekers," it is ominous, not only for the civil service, but for the Republican Party and Mr. REED.

After a week of depressing dullness, yesterday's short session of the Stock Exchange made a showing of some activity and some strength. Throughout the list there were advances, and some enthusiasm was induced. We are on the eve of a preliminary inauguration boom, so the oracles of the Street are announcing.

Prof. Albert S. Bickmore lectured yesterday morning at the American Museum of Natural History on "Upper Egpyt -- Karnak." Karnak is the glory of the Egypt of the great Pharaohs and the temples, of Memphis, Thebes, and Philae. Dominion has descended the river, and now has its uncertain seat at Cairo.

Giuseppe Rondello, a shoemaker employed by Pietro Viafore, in Potter Place, is wanted by the police for what may turn out to be a double murder. He is suspected of killing a man Friday night and seriously wounding a woman. Three of his friends are in custody, suspected of knowing about the crime.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- William Lytle, a familiar character of the Levee for nearly a quarter of a century, died in a Clark Street lodging house yesterday. His death ended a life of misery that had its beginning in affluence. His father was a wealthy merchant in Maghetra, Ireland, where a prosperous brother, G.D. Lytle, now lives.
Vogl will sing Parsifal at the Mottl concerts of May 11 and 18 at Queen's Hall, London. Frau Mottl will sing Kundry and Wachter, Gurnemanz.
The Marine Observer at Sandy Hook reports at 1:05 A.M. that a steamer is off towards the East Channel blowing distress signals with her whistle.
BOSTON, Jan. 30. -- Five Harvard College students were in court to-day at Cambridge, and two of them were fined $15 each for discharging firearms within the city limits.

A school for teaching the theory and practice of textile manufacturing has just been opened in Lowell, Mass., the first ever established in New England, and the only one now in the country, save one in Philadelphia. This indicates that the manufacturers where this kind of industry has existed longest are just beginning to realize the necessity of improving their processes and the grade of their goods.

CANTON, Ohio, Jan. 30. -- James Wilson of Iowa, who visited Major McKinley last evening by invitation, is no doubt to be Secretary of Agriculture, but the formal offer of the portfolio will be made by letter next week.
In President CLEVELAND'S pleasant address at the Academy of Medicine celebration he touched in a vein of serious prophecy upon the vital things that make progress possible in the art of healing:

"I have found a new use for brass candlesticks," said the young housekeeper. "I have two or three pairs that belonged to my great-grandmother. I think the world of them, but in my house, as it is at present, I have no place where I can use them with proper effect -- that is, as candlesticks. But as bonnet stands they are treasures.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 30. -- A Deputy Sheriff arrived here this morning from Westchester County, New York, with a warrant for the arrest of Arthur Palmer. The indorsement of Gov. Stephens had to be obtained by mail from Jefferson City. This will arrive to-morrow morning, and the Deputy Sheriff and his prisoner will depart for New York at noon to-morrow on a special train.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The House Committee on Pacific Railroads adjourned to-day, after a session of nearly two hours, without having reached a definite conclusion respecting the Harrison bill, to provide for a commission of three Cabinet officers to settle the indebtedness of the Pacific Railways to the Government.

Some exciting games of basket ball were played last night in the Thirteenth Regiment Armory, in Brooklyn. The attendance was disappointing, but those who were there enjoyed the sport. The Eastern District Young Men's Christian Association team, in the open tourney, easily won the honors, outplaying the teams against which it was matched at every point.

The Presidential question seems to be the most talked about of any scheduled to come before the National Assembly of the League of American Wheelmen in Albany next week. The declared candidates have narrowed down to two -- Isaac B. Potter, Chief Consul of the New York Division, and Sterling Elliott of Boston, the present incumbent of the office.

J. Alexander Koones, in an article printed in The Pharmaceutical Era, has given an answer to the question, "To what extent may citizens of the United States lawfully contribute medical supplies to the Cuban patriots?"

The plan of Chief CONLIN for the repression of the more offensive sort of vagrancy is undoubtedly a good one, and it is high time that it was put into operation. The only fault we have to find with it, so far as its limited purpose goes, is that the force to be employed will probably not be large enough, but that can be remedied.

Again the incidents and events of another week in the society world, which ordinarily would have been important and interesting, if not all-engrossing, in and by themselves to the devotees of gayety, have been completely overshadowed by the excitement and anticipatory agitation caused by the near coming of the great fancy-dress ball to be given by Mrs. Bradley Martin at the Waldorf on Feb. 10.

It is said in prominent military circles that it is likely that Gov. Black will shortly appoint a board of officers to recommend a plan of reorganization for the National Guard. In connection with this reorganization, and the appointment of a Major General incident thereto, it would seem to the best interests of the service that there should be no salary attached to the new office.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Jan. 30. -- The legal tangle in which the High Point Cumberland Island Company finds itself has culminated in an injunction, issued by Judge Sweat against the foreclosure of a mortgage.

-- Ten of the sixteen States that had troops in the famous Vicksburg campaign have declared by resolution in their legislative bodies in favor of the establishment of the proposed National Military Park on the site of that famous battlefield. Pennsylvania, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Minnesota are the latest of these.

Clarence H.C. Van Deusen, Ballot Clerk of the Kings County Board of Elections, was removed yesterday for cause. Less than a month ago the Commissioners congratulated him on his work during the last election and raised his salary from $2,000 to $2,500 per annum.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- That the minds of English statesmen are beginning to be oppressed by the terrors of foreign competition was clearly shown in the House of Commons on Wednesday afternoon, when an unsuccessful attempt was made to bring in a bill to amend the Merchandise Marks act of ten years ago.

MEMBERS of New York society, of both sexes, are now taking deep thought as to "wherewithal they shall be clothed" for the coming fancy costume pageant of Mrs. Bradley Martin, at the Waldorf. They have a vast array of historic robes to choose from, the hostess having decreed that costumes must be confined to the sixteenth, seventeenth, and eighteenth centuries.

IT is not amazing, but it is worthy of note, that every one is talking about singers, singers, singers. What chance has a poor pianist or violinist against the curled darlings of the golden hall of song? Still worse, what chance have the claims of serious art against them?

THURSDAY, FEB. 4. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, James B. Butler, referee, 63 East One Hundred and Seventeenth Street, north side, 115.6 feet west of Park Avenue, 25 by 100.11, five-story brick flat. Due on judgment, $2,400; subject to first mortgage for $18,000.

A game that will go far to settle the championship in the Amateur Hockey League was played last evening between the New York Athletic Club hockey team and the team of the St. Nicholas Skating Club at the St. Nicholas Rink, Sixty-sixth Street. After a hotly contested game, the New York Athletic Club won by a score of 3 to 2.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 30. -- The shooting matches at Elkwood Park to-day attracted a crowd of sportsmen, interested in the contest for the W.A. Powder Company's trophy, a handsome silver canister filled with powder.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- On Tuesday in All Saints' Cathedral, Dr. J.D. Morrison, rector of St. John's Church, Ogdensburg, will be consecrated Bishop of the Episcopal Missionary Diocese of Duluth. This diocese has an area of 57,000 square miles, and a population of 400,000 persons. Tomorrow the cathedral the services will have a note of preparation for the consecration.

WEDNESDAY, FEB. 3. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Edward E. McCall, referee, 104 and 100 Park Row 23 Duane Street, begins Park Row, northwest side, 20 feet northeast of Duane Street, 49.7 by 102.2 by southwest 7.5 by northwest 3 by southwest 67.4 to Duane Street by southeast along same 22 by northeast 25 by southeast 81 to Park Row, six-story brick store, loft, and office building, formerly Sweeny's Hotel.

MRS. JULIAN STORY, known to the public as Mme. Emma Eames, is one of the Americans who have reached distinction in music. Her position as one of the best living sopranos is unquestioned, and what makes this fact of more importance is the undeniable promise of the woman.

The White Star freight steamship Cevic, from Liverpool, reached her dock yesterday afternoon. She was due on Monday last. Only a tale of rough weather was given to account for her five days' delay. The Cevic is a very large vessel, her gross tonnage being 8,301, and as she brought only a small cargo she presented a very large freeboard resistance to wind and wave.

CHATHAM, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- The house of Charles Betts, near Chatham Centre, Columbia County, was entered by masked burglars last night. The occupants, Mr. and Mrs. Betts and Mr. and Mrs. George Flint, were compelled at the point of revolvers to go to one room, where some of the intruders stood guard while the others ransacked the house, but secured little.

MARGARET MATHER'S Imogen pleases me more than any other portrayal of hers I have seen, and this is strange, for we all know that tradition has pronounced Imogen one of the most difficult to act of all Shakespearean female roles, second only, in its complexity of mood and variety and sweep of emotional expression, to Cleopatra, a character which none of us has yet seen properly acted.

BOSTON, Jan. 30. -- John E. Russell and President C.W. Eliot of Harvard University made quite unexpected addresses at the regular monthly meeting and dinner of the New England Free Trade League this evening.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 30. -- The cold wave included Lakewood in its sweep, and the thermometer ranged in the vicinity of zero the early part of the week. The storm of Wednesday continued until it amounted almost to a blizzard on Thursday, and the snow gave this resort sleighing again.

Washington E. Connor, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railway Company, who attended the meeting of the Ohio Coal Traffic Association at Cleveland, returned to this city yesterday. Of the bituminous coal question he said that so far as Ohio is concerned it is practically settled; the Eastern end of the operating field is the more interesting.

LOWELL, Mass., Jan. 30. -- The formal exercises connected with the opening of the Textile School took place at 4 o'clock in Hungton Hall before a large audience. A.G. Comnock, President of the Board of Trustees, presided, and in his opening address gave a brief history of the Textile School and an interesting account of the progress and extent of technical instruction in the old country in the different branches of the industry.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 30. -- This afternoon the Fayette County Circuit Cort appointed R.A. Brasfield receiver for the sale stables of the Tattersalls Company of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Many things are pointing to a season of political and social excitement with the incoming of the new Administration. Now that the Cabinet of Mr. McKinley seems to be about made up, those persons who have been hoping that it would not be without social qualities of a high order are satisfied that the Administration will not lack brilliancy of setting.

Mr. William Alexander Smith, the veteran ex-President of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in discussing the prevailing stock market conditions and prospects:
A fire that broke out at midnight last night in the large wheelwright shop of Fred Schaeffer, 410 Newark Street, Hoboken, rendered four families homeless and burned five persons to death.

February is not one of the favorite months of the year as far as weather conditions are concerned. Sun, moon, and stars pay little regard to the convenience or amusement of the dwellers of this planet, however, and carry out their programmes with equal faithfulness whether lowering clouds or howling storms hide them from view, or whether terrestrial observers enjoy the celestial picture in a serene atmosphere and under a cloudless canopy.

GLASGOW, Jan. 16. -- Yacht clubs here are considering the propriety of celebrating the sixtieth year of Queen Victoria's reign by the presentation of special prizes for yacht races in British waters. No doubt the leading clubs will at once respond to the movement.

Selleck Seely, a produce merchant at 297 Washington Street, was arrested yesterday at the instance of Frank C. Hyatt, cashier of the Clinton Bank, on the charge of grand larceny. He gave bail to appear at the Centre Street Police Court this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- After the transaction of a few matters of unimportant legislation, the House went into Committee of the Whole for consideration of the Agricultural Appropriation bill. Mr. Dockery (Dem., Mo.,) raised a point of order against several increases of salary for employes in the Bureau of Animal Industry, amounting altogether to $2,270, and they went out.

Candy and nerves are not often associated, but a New York man, Dr. W.J. Tripp, who has treated many women in all stages of nervous trouble, says that sweets and an improper diet have a great deal to do with the increase of nervousness among American women.

The housekeeping in a big hotel does not seem to be a matter of much moment to the guest, who sees only the outside and that everything goes along without friction and apparently of its own momentum, without the special oversight of any one in particular. But the work of the housekeeper is on a large scale that can hardly be comprehended by the ordinary housewife.

More property was sold at private contract in the last six days than during any of the previous weeks of the month. The sales, however, included none of magnitude, and the total investment reported was necessarily below the average maintained since Jan. 1. There was a number of purchases of business property, both new and old.

LONDON, Jab. 30. -- Since the Irish members of the House of Commons withdrew their amendment to the address in reply to the Queen's speech, which amendment referred to the financial relations between Great Britain and Ireland, it is seen that they made a serious tactical error, which was equivalent to allowing Mr. Balfour, the Government leader in the House, to spike their guns.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, Jan. 30. -- Louis C. Evans, the millionaire President and General Manager of the A.C. Evans Manufacturing Company, made a decided and sensational attempt at suicide to-day.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 30. -- The principal problem to be grappled with by the present General Assembly will be the reduction of State expenditures. The estimate of State expenses for the current two years, as made by the State Treasurer, will exceed the public receipts by $465,000. No doubt the deficit in the Treasury will exceed this sum unless the most rigid economy is adopted in the matter of appropriations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- The National Business League, an organization of business men, formed for the purpose of influencing Federal legislation, opened headquarters in the Stock Exchange Building yesterday. The league is the outcome of the last campaign, and its purpose is to supplement the work begun by the sound-money organizations which sprang into existence at that time.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The famine in India spreads in area and increases in intensity. The famine fund fails to mount up so rapidly as to warrant the sanguine estimate that a total of 1,000,000 will be reached. Thoroughly reliable and independent Indian advices concur in stating that relief will be required for about 3,500,000 people before the famine abates, the period of relief extending to September next.

BOSTON, Jan. 30. -- Isaac Lewis, who has lived a hermit-like life in a hut on Pierce Avenue, Dorchester, for many years, was found dead on the floor of the little attic room which he occupied at 2 o'clock this afternoon. He had been dead several days.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- The Emperor, desiring to be present at the christening of the new-born son of his brother, Prince Henry of Prussia, at Kiel, left to Chancellor Prince Hohenlohe the duty of receiving Count Muravieff, the new Russian Foreign Minister, who has arrived here from Paris.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- A well-informed Ohio man says that the selection of Alger for Secretary of War secures Hanna's appointment to the Senate.

SANTA MONICA, Cal., Jan. 22. -- According to the calendar this is midwinter, or thereabout, but in this favored clime, with the thermometer at 70 in the shade, with rose-laden vines looking in at one's open windows, and a rankly verdurous plain spread all around the town, how can anybody realize the midwinter fact?

RUTLAND, Vt., Jan. 30. -- Esther Damon of the hamlet of Plymouth Union, Windsor County, Vt., thirteen miles from the City of Rutland, is said to be the only pensioner of the Revolutionary War now living in New England. She was born in Plymouth Aug. 1, 1814. On Sept. 6, 1835, she was married to Noah Damon, who had been a volunteer from Massachusetts.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Judge Froman to-day appointed Ralph Metcalf receiver for the Dime Savings Bank, requiring him to give a bond for $200,000. This action was taken upon a bill filed in the Superior Court by George W. Reed, a stockholder in the concern. There was no opposition on the part of the Directors, but on the contrary, they came into court with an answer and consented to the appointment.

THE instinct of mankind for means of locomotion faster than that offered him by nature has always been a powerful one and has found expression in various ways. One of its earliest experiments was in the line of skating.

The shooting at the Seventh Regiment Armory last night was for the Covell and Gazette Trophies. The Covell Trophy is shot for by teams of six from each company, three of whom cannot be armory sharpshooters, five shots standing and five prone; competitors to be chosen as each Captain may select.

FRIDAY, FEB. 5. -- By Peter F. Meyer Co., foreclosure sale, Edward Jacobs, referee, northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Clinton Place, 28.6 by 100, four-story brownstone-front dwelling. Due on judgment, $96,777.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Charles G. Dawes of Chicago will be appointed Controller of the Currency, to succeed Mr. Eckels. At least, President-elect McKinley is reported to have said so yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- George B. Roberts, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, died at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon at his home in Bala, a suburb of this city, from heart failure, superinduced by indigestion and catarrh of the stomach.

The Tammany Executive Committee for this year, when it is completed, will number very nearly 100 members, the largest Executive Committee that the organization has ever had. The increase is mainly due to the creation of three new standing committees -- those on Municipal Affairs, Public Improvements, and the Press, and to the fact that all standing committees will have Vice Chairmen, who, like the Chairmen, will be ex officio members of the Executive Committee.

The early Englishmen were riot faddists; they had nothing especially new to exploit, writes Arthur Hoeber in The Illustrated American. They painted what they saw according to their inspiration and after a careful study of the old mas ters, but they did their work in a genuine, simple sort of away, with, as a rule, the most happy results.

COLUMBUS, Ky., Jan. 30. -- A queer character died here a few days ago. He was known as "Ground Hog" Allen, and was a cave dweller, and the most mysterious personage in Hickman County. Little is known of him, and he lived the life of a recluse.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- Charles Knox, who from 1862 to 1888 was engaged in the wholesale grocery business in this city, and who for the past few years had been of the firm of Mosby Knox, importers, New York City, shot himself in the right temple at Lowville to-day and died instantly.

"Dr. Claudius" has suddenly become Mr. Crawford's "most successful novel." When the theatrical managers have use for an article, it must be superlative or nothing. As a matter of fact, "Mr. Isaacs," "Saracinesoa," "Sant' Ilario," "The Ralstons," "Casa Braccio" and other works of this prolific writer have been more widely read than "Dr. Claudius."

The police of this city announced yesterday that Thomas H. Stout is under arrest in Cincinnati. He has been a fugitive for over five years, and, like Latimer E. Jones, has spent most of the time since leaving New York in Europe.
It is announced that the proposed exhibition of the models for the Sherman statue, to be erected in Washington, will not take place.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- The largest meeting for charitable purposes since the Chicago fire was held in Plymouth Congregational Church this afternoon. The meeting was styled a conference of South Side charities, but the list of speakers was so attractive, including such well-known philanthropic workers as Dr. Emil G. Hirsch, Miss McDowell, Dr. Henderson, and L.D. Hurley, that there were present people from all parts of the city.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- The Bolt Trust has collapsed, and prices have fallen 20 per cent. within the last three days. The market is still demoralized, with values uncertain and irregular, and there are prospects of still further declines next week.

Prof. Felix Adler closed his series of lectures on the power, attributes, and position of woman in the world, with a discourse on "Woman in the Sphere of Religion," at Carnegie Music Hall, yesterday morning, before the Society for Ethical Culture.

A report submitted from the Judiciary Committee of the Senate by Senator HILL must be taken as settling a question which has vexed many commentators: What resolutions requiring the concurrence of both houses of Congress must be submitted to the President?

Hiram Rinaldo Brother have leased for Mr. Jacob Korn to Messrs. Levy Levy, the six-story modern building 258 Grand Street, for a term of years at a total rental of $15,000. The lessees purpose to occupy the same as a wholesale jobbing house.

While George H. Vanderbilt, forty-five years old, a freight conductor on the New York and Putnam Railroad, living at One Hundred and Sixty-second Street and Amsterdam Avenue, was making up his train last night on a side track, directly opposite High Bridge Station, he was accidentally struck by express passenger train No. 183 of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Much of the time of the Senate this week will probably be spent behind closed doors.
Prof. Richard J.H. Gottheil delivered the fifth and last lecture of his course on "The Geography of Palestine" at Temple Emanu-El last evening.

" Rights and Wrongs of Rich and Poor" was the subject of the sermon preached by the Rev. Rabbi Gottheil yesterday morning at Temple Emanu-El.
