His address was plainly pointed at the adverse criticism of the coming Bradley Martin ball, and was a rebuke to those who profess to look upon every laborer as an unthinking Socialist, unable to appreciate that the lavish expenditure of wealth is an ostentatious disregard of his less fortunate condition.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -- The United States cruiser Brooklyn struck a rocky ledge yesterday afternoon while proceeding down the Delaware River to a safe anchorage from the ice behind the Government piers at Marcus Hook, sixteen miles below this city. The extent of the damage could not be learned to-day, but it is reported to be serious.

It is a striking fact that the Irish question threatens the Unionist Government more seriously than any other. It is not exactly the old Irish question. It is no longer social disorder, or boycotting, or dynamite, or any of the forms of disturbance by which the Irish leaders tried to force home rule from England.
Hoboken was visited by two disastrous fires between 11:30 Saturday night and 3 A.M. yesterday. Seven persons were burned to death and thirty families were made homeless.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 31. -- Mrs. Ballington-Booth, formerly of the Salvation Army, and now head of the American Volunteers, is a visitor at the State Prison here, with the object of securing members from among the convicts for her organization. She delivered two addresses, one this morning and the other in the afternoon, in which she explained to the prisoners the character of the work she was engaged in.
The vicissitudes of politics will give Secretary of State SHERMAN an opportunity to meet some old friends in Washington.
The annual meeting of the Mount Sinai Hospital Association took place a 11 o'clock yesterday morning in the main hall of the Dispensary Building, 149 Sixty-seventh Street.

HANFORD, Cal., Jan. 31. -- After patiently trailing him for several days, Sheriff Buckner and posse overtook George Taylor, the Missouri murderer, Friday evening, in a small cabin on the Jacob ranch near Hanford, where he was surprised and taken without a struggle. He was brought to Hanford yesterday and placed in the city jail under a strong guard.

The dignified bank President smiled quizzically as he observed his visitor glancing perplexedly about the dingy and contracted quarters in which so large an amount of business was being transacted. "All banks are not marble and rosewood," he remarked, "and there are some bank Presidents who manage to get along without cushioned chairs and velvet carpets."

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- Former Excise Commissioner Julius Harburger of New York City, as Grand Master of the Independent Order Free Sons of Israel, accompanied by William A. Gans, Chairman of the Endowment Committee, addressed the members of the order in this city to-day at Madison Hall, 87 East Madison Street.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- The Berlin newspapers, noticing the visit to the German capital of Count Muravieff, the Russian Foreign Minister, contrast the general indifference shown to his presence in the city with the interest taken in the recent sojourn of Count Goluchowski. Brief as Count Goluchowski's stay in Berlin was, it resulted in an important change in Germany's policy toward the Sultan, and probably also in the Balkans.

KEY WEST, Fla., Jan. 31. -- Advices from Havana state that, in flat contradiction of all rumors lately circulated that the rebels are demoralized and weakened and ready to surrender, especially in Pinar del Rio Province, where Weyler made the assertion that only 500 remained in straggling bands of bandits, word reached Havana Friday that the insurgents had dynamited a train, causing great damage and loss of life.

Residents and politicians of the west side who were interested in the building of a new police court building in West Fifty-fourth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, are angry because the City Magistrates do not assign a Magistrate to the court and open it for business. The building contains a district prison and accommodations for the Eleventh District Civil Court.
The matter of torpedo nets for United States warships, referred to in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Thursday, has been thus described in a recent issue of The Army and Navy Journal:

-- A thrifty Bostonian has devised what is believed to be an entirely original, if somewhat culpable, method of putting money in his purse. His plan is represented to have been to set fires in various places, putting them out before they had gained much headway or attracted outside attention, and then quietly informing the insurance company having risks upon the buildings and making settlements very satisfactory to himself.

The Central Vermont Railroad freight boat Mohawk, which went ashore at Goshen Point, near New London, during the recent snowstorm, arrived here early yesterday morning, and was put into the sectional dry dock at the foot of Pike Street, for repairs.

DENVER, Col., Jan. 31 -- There is living in Rock Spring, Wyoming, a little coal mining town on the line of the Union Pacific Railroad, a Mrs. J.F. Pierce, who claims to be the only legitimate child of the late Jay Gould and heir to all his millions. She says she has about finished the work of collecting the proof to substantiate her claims. She has a bundle of documentary evidence.

BERLIN, Jan. 31. -- Prince Egon Furstenberg, heir of the late Prince Furstenberg, the Kaiser's chief marshal, has now announced his intention to give up his residence in Germany. He says he will remain what he has been -- an Austrian, having his permanent residence in Austria, and on his Bohemian estates.

A large fleet of vessels arrived from sea yesterday, including several of the overdue craft. All had the same story of westerly gales from the Banks of Newfoundland, snow squalls, and tremendous head seas.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -- Arrangements for the funeral of the late George B. Roberts, President of the Pennsylvania Railroad, were completed to-day. The funeral will take place at 2:30 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon next. It will be held from Mr. Roberts's late country residence at Bala Station, just outside of the city limits, and where he died.

Dwight L. Moody preached at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon to a crowded house, and many heard him who are not of the regular churchgoing class. An increased attendance was decidedly noticeable in the boxes.
In their regular monthly review of current market conditions Messrs. Hollister Babcock say:

Considerable feeling has been stirred up in golfing circles in this city by the recent action of the Executive Committee of the United States Golf Association in declining to pass upon the application of the Knollwood Country Club, to be transferred from allied to associate membership. The matter was held over until a future meeting of the committee, when a larger attendance of the members could be present.
Beggars for special laws to protect their personal interest are so numerous that it appears as if a large number of people are reduced to a state of mendicancy.

Fund the legal-tender notes; permit the banks to issue currency to the par value of bonds issued for this purpose; reduce the tax on bank currency one-half. These were the simple measures which Mr. LYMAN J. GAGE proposed to the Government in 1894. There is no reason to suppose that he has changed his views regarding them since.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- A large appropriation to begin the purchase by the State of Adirondack forest lands is one of the measures which will meet the approval of Gov. Black. While he believes in pruning down the average bills of expense to be put on the State by the Legislature, he has indicated that he will make an exception in this particular.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The Senate yesterday, by its Committee on Foreign Relations, yielded apparently to public opinion in ordering a report on the general arbitration treaty with Great Britain, but the concession to a pressure that was manifestly increasing and becoming very annoying was more formal than real.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- It is expected that Gov. Black will send to the Senate to-morrow night the nomination of Louis F. Payn to be State Superintendent of Insurance, to succeed James F. Pierce, the present Superintendent, whose term of office will expire Feb. 11.

The hopeful conditions of the investment market to which we called attention two weeks ago have become still more marked. The bond market is all the time growing broader and stronger, as well as more active. The par value total of the bond transactions on the Stock Exchange on Saturday was $2,271,000, an astonishing figure for a half-day market.

Unless more snow shall fall speedily, Saturday probably saw the last of good sleighing for the present. Yesterday morning being bright encouraged a few to take a turn round Central Park, but the snow soon began to thaw under the influence of the sun, and by 1 o'clock the driveways were covered with slush.

Memorial services or deceased members of the Seventh Regiment were held in St. Thomas's Church yesterday afternoon, and a memorial sermon was preached by the Rev. Claudius M. Roome, Chaplain of the regiment's veterans.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 31. -- There is a great cry throughout the country for good roads, and nowhere is this cry more fervent than in Westchester. Besides looking for better roads, the people are looking to it that it does not lose that which it has.
The fifth annual report of the Brooklyn Free Kindergarten Society is good reading.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Senator Lodge said to-day:

Young ladies may be beautiful, but nothing is more attractive in this world than a lovely old lady, with her white hair, her rosy face, wrinkled it may be, but with eyes beaming with kindness even through her spectacles. But what can be sadder than a sickly old lady, who suffers and feels that she is a burden to those around her, and whose joy in life has departed! Is it not sorrowful?

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 26. -- A party of Cubans just arrived has brought news of the successful landing last Sunday of a big filibustering expedition on the coast of Santiago Province. The expedition disembarked without molestation from the Spanish gunboats, which were looking for it, but looked in the wrong place.

The report that the Italian Government has decided to abandon its ill-fated enterprise of African colonization has been expected for some time. It is the logical conclusion of the treaty with Abyssinia, withdrawing all claim to an Italian protectorate, and is, moreover, made necessary by the fact that the colony thus circumscribed must be a heavy tax upon the Italian Treasury without bringing any commensurate advantage to Italian influence.

Dr. LYMAN ABBOTT has succeeded in exciting the attention, and largely the animadversion, of his clerical brethren by the emission of his historic doubts concerning the tenancy of the whale by JONAH. The difficulty in reconciling the physiological processes of JONAH with those of the whale has probably occurred to nearly every reader of the Scriptural account, on what may be called the carnal side of his mind.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Secretary Morton has issued a circular regarding the annual Governmental seed distribution, in which he shows exactly what the seed for the various sections of the country has cost, the amount purchased or contracted for, and makes a comparative statement with preceding years, showing that the plan which he has adopted gets nearly twice as much seed and of a better quality.

CHESTER, Penn., Feb. 1 -- The cruiser Brooklyn is still lying at Marcus Hook, tied fore and aft to the piers, and will not be moved until there is absolutely no danger from the huge cakes of ice which fill the Delaware River from shore to shore. The damage sustained by striking Schooner Ledge on Saturday afternoon is serious, but to what extent the vessel is injured cannot be ascertained until she is dry docked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- In the House to-day Mr. Sherman (Rep., N.Y.,) called up the "anti-scalping" bill, but the question of consideration being raised, the House, by a vote of 34 to 88, refused to consider it. These bills were passed:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day rendered a decision that is considered by Constitutional lawyers as of the very highest importance, in that it materially enlarges the power of States to tax the property of corporations that have heretofore avoided taxation by claiming avoidance rights under the inter-State commerce law.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- A special session of the Senate to meet March 4 or 5, immediately on the inauguration of the new President, is now on the cards. The House, it is said, will not meet until March 15.

L.J. Callanan, who has been active in the attempts to secure the removal of the obstructions in Vesey Street, had a talk with Mayor Strong on the subject yesterday. He gives this report of the conversation:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Attorney General Harmon to-day instructed the United States District Attorney at Jacksonville to proceed against the steamer Three Friends as a pirate. The prosecution will be against the vessel, and not against her officers and crew, in accordance with Section 4,297 of the Revised Statutes, which reads as follows:

At a Good Government Club dinner the other night Mr. WHEELER H. PECKHAM said: "The time has now arrived for fully and thoroughly organizing a municipal party." By this he meant that the time has come for effecting an organization whose aim would be to divorce city government from party politics and bring about a non-partisan, businesslike administration of municipal affairs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Attorney General Harmon to-day submitted to the Supreme Court of the United States his petition for a writ of certiorari to bring up at once for review here the record of the United States court in Florida in the case of the filibustering steamer Three Friends, notwithstanding the appeal of the case to the Circuit Court of Appeals.

At a meeting of the Reformed Ministers' Association at the Reformed Church Building, Twenty-second Street, near Broadway, yesterday, the Rev. W.P. Bruce of Yonkers read a paper on "Humor in the Pulpit."
ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- Gov. Black has nominated Louis F. Payn of Chatham to be Superintendent of Insurance, to succeed James F. Pierce, whose term will expire Feb. 11.

It is not worth while to mince words about "Dr. Claudius," or to waste sympathy upon the persons who will be directly effected by the deplorable failure of the called play at the Fifth Avenue Theatre last night. Marion Crawford's brilliant reputation as a novelist will not suffer at all because an attempt to adapt one of his best-liked books to the stage has not been successful.

The movement against vagrancy and street beggary that was begun yesterday has not been set on foot until after it was obviously and urgently needed. The object, of course, is to make it certain that nobody who is able to support himself shall be supported by public and promiscuous charity because he is unwilling to work.

Another foreclosure proceeding was commenced yesterday by filing a lis pendens in the County Clerk's office against the real estate, 35 to 39 Nassau Street and 56 and 58 Liberty Street, on which the Syndicate Building stands, to foreclose a second mortgage of $250,000, made by Hugh Lamb, on June 17, 1896, the plaintiffs being the New York Realty Company, Moses Goldsmith, and Solomon Plaut.

ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- In the Assembly to-day Mr. Finn called up his resolution, introduced last week, asking for an investigation of the expenditures of money by the Police Department of New York City in certain ways not authorized by law.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the correspondence in the Sanguilly case. Mr. Olney says in his report to the President:

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- In the House of Commons to-day, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, stated that negotiations for the construction of a British West Indies cable were in progress, and that a French cable laid by a French-American company would compete with the British cable.

At the meeting of the Academy of Sciences last night Prof. Harold Jacoby showed two photographs of the stars surrounding the pole of the heavens. These photographs were made for Prof. Jacoby with the new photographic telescope at Helsingfors, Finland, the most northern observatory in the world provided with a photographic telescope.

Chinatown was a rainbow yesterday. The brilliant bow started with the ferocious dragon on a yellow ground -- a monster with red and white belly and blue scales, and a forked green tail that looked like a snake convention -- which fluttered to the Mott Street breeze from the sacred battlements of the joss house.

We discussed some days ago the bill now pending in the House of Representatives making it a penal offense for any person to engage in the business of selling railroad tickets for inter-State travel unless he is the duly authorized agent of the company issuing the tickets, constituted such by written appointment.
Stock market irregular. Money on call, 1 1/2 to 2 per cent.

Theodore Von Horn, a cabinetmaker, thirty-five years old, killed himself yesterday afternoon, after seriously wounding his wife and slightly wounding her employer, Samuel Schulhafer, at 1,242 Third Avenue. The two latter were taken to the Presbyterian Hospital, where Mr. Schulhafer was discharged in a few minutes, and Mrs. Von Horn is expected to recover.

LONDON, Feb. 1. -- A dispatch from Yokohama says that the trial of Mrs. Carew, charged with causing the death of her husband, Walter Raymond Hallowell Carew, Secretary of the Yokohama United Club, by administering arsenic, has ended in her conviction, and she was sentenced to death to-day.

N. Monsarrat, President of the Columbus, Sandusky and Hocking Railroad; Washington E. Connor, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railway, and ex-Judge Stevenson Burke, comprising a special committee of the Ohio Coal Traffic Association, have agreed on a plan for the distribution of the Ohio soft coal traffic on the following percentage basis:

Yesterday will go on record as memorable in the history of Sorosis. It was the last day's service of its present President, Mrs. William Tod Helmuth, at a social session for her present term, and a decided innovation was made in the subject for discussion.

In some of its aspects the appointment of PAYN rises above the proportions of a political scandal and becomes a public danger. If, in the first month of his term, Gov. BLACK outrages decency and affronts public opinion by putting this notorious corruptionist in the highest office of trust in his gift, what may not an alarmed people apprehend from him in the remaining twenty-three months?

The report of the Commissioners of Fisheries, Game, and Forestry shows clearly the desirability of adopting the policy of adding to the State ownership of lands within the limits of the Adirondack Forest Preserve more rapidly than can be done by the process now relied upon.

Wall Street is paying much attention to the investigation of trusts promised by the politicians up at Albany. It would be trifling with the facts, perhaps, if it were to be chronicled here that there is in Wall Street, more than elsewhere, an expectation that anything consequential will result from the promised investigation.

FORT GAINES, Ga., Feb. 1. -- The next Grand Jury will investigate the alleged ballot-box frauds in connection with the Foster-Killingsworth contest. Foster was the Populist candidate for Representative in the Legislature, his opponent being Killingsworth, Democrat. The latter took his seat, and Foster made a contest, alleging illegal voting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day, in an opinion by Commissioner Prouty, announced a decision in the matter of alleged unlawful rates and practices in the transportation of grain and grain products by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company, the Chicago Great Western Railway Company, and others, concerning a transportation practice of the Chicago Great Western Railway Company.

It was to be foreseen that a considerable number of clergymen would take for their text on Sunday the text with which Dr. RAINSFORD had already supplied the newspapers. Dr. RAINSFORD'S deprecation of ostentatious displays of wealth and fashion might have passed unnoticed if it had not been supposed to be aimed at a particular "fashionable event."

The election of officers of the Memorial Committee of posts of the Grand Army of the Republic, which was held last evening in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, resulted in a partial defeat of the party that was said to be desirous of eliminating politics from the affairs of the order. Gen. Horace Porter was placed at the head of a ticket representing this view.

TAUNTON, Mass., Feb. 1. -- Herbert A. Willis, the murderer of Frederick N. Strange in this city in June last, was taken into court this afternoon, where, by agreement of counsel and the State, a plea of guilty of murder in the second degree was accepted and a sentence of life imprisonment imposed.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 1. -- The announcement made to-day in Iowa by James S. Wilson that he had accepted the portfolio of Agriculture offered to him by Major McKinley is confirmed here. This fills the Cabinet with reasonable certainty, excepting the offices of Attorney General and Postmaster General. The McKinley Cabinet to date, therefore, may be given as follows:

There was a decided stir in Trial Term, Part XI., of the Supreme Court, yesterday, when Frank Herwig, a lawyer, announced to Justice MacLean that after court adjourned on Friday, Martin Brummerhop, Juror No. 8 in the suit of Josephine Fischer against the United States Industrial Insurance Company, had approached him and requested $25.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- If the Nicaragua Canal bill debate in the Senate be finished to-morrow or laid aside during the day, an effort will be made to take up the Bankruptcy bill, and the friends of the Torrey bill will make another effort to have that bill substituted for the Bailey bill reported by the Judiciary Committee in place of the Torrey measure passed by the House.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 1. -- Romulus Cotell, who murdered Alvin Stone and wife, and Ira Stillson, their hired man, March 29, 1896, to-day entered a plea of guilty of murder in the second degree, and was sentenced to life imprisonment at hard labor.

The recent decision of the Police Commissioners and the subsequent orders issued by Chief Conlin regarding the suppression of professional beggars in this city, will probably be put into practice to-day. The delay has been caused by a desire on the part of Chief Conlin to select good men for the work.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1. -- The Senate Committee on Railroads and Canals gave a preliminary hearing this afternoon on the Commuters' bill, which is the measure devised to allow private express messengers to carry packages and parcels on all the railroad trains in the State. James Allen, representing the Erie Railroad, spoke briefly against the bill.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- An order was issued from the War Department to-day placing Gen. Craighill, Chief of Engineers, on the retired list, in compliance with a request made by the General in a letter to the Secretary of War, dated Jan. 27. In his letter Gen. Craighill said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The exchange of views between Controller Eckels and members of the Banking and Currency Committee on financial questions was continued today. Mr. Eckels expressed the opinion that the only way to solve the present financial condition would be through a proper banking bill.

John Graham Brooks of Harvard began, yesterday morning, at the Berkeley Lyceum, a course of twelve lectures, to be given under the auspices of the League for Political Education. These will be delivered at 11 A.M. on Mondays and at 4:30 P.M. on Fridays. Mr. Brooks has taken as his general subject, "Sociology in Its Practical Aspects."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- President Cleveland has determined to veto the Immigration bill passed by Congress. He told Senator Palmer of his intentions to-day.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1. -- Charles Gates Dawes has accepted the appointment of Controller of the Currency, tendered him by President-elect McKinley. He admitted this to THE NEW YORK TIMES'S representative to-day. He said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- Major McKinley's own party may make the opening days of his Administration uncomfortable to him by refusing to approve the nomination of Gen. Alger to be Secretary of War. There is yet time in which to avert the trouble by withdrawing the offer of the War portfolio made to Alger, but the longer the time given to discuss the objections to Alger the stronger they are likely to become.
Walter Edson Andrews, one of the members of the Board of Education, has been requested by Mayor Strong to resign.

The final letter of the Secretary of the Sculpture Society in respect to the Sherman Monument leaves the sculptor of the accepted design very evidently on the defensive and without any evident defense. He may, however, take the ground that, having secured the commission, he can afford to be put in the wrong.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The debt statement issued this afternoon shows a net increase in the public debt, less cash in the Treasury, during January of $15,078,735.22. The interest-bearing debt increased $2,120,916. The non-interest-bearing debt decreased $140, and cash in the Treasury decreased $12,957,959,22.

HOLLIDAYSBURG, Penn., Feb. 1. -- At an early hour this morning this community was rocked from centre to circumference by a terrific explosion. Upon investigation the startled townspeople discovered that the destruction of the banking house of Gardner, Morrow Co., which stands on the principal business square, had been attempted by the use of dynamite.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- The details of a sensational incident which occurred at the Gridiron Club dinner Saturday night are creeping out. At this dinner more or less horseplay is indulged in at the expense of statesmen who are guests of the club. One of the features of the affair was the long-distance telephone, supposed to have a connection with Canton.
An attempt to substitute one woman for another was made in Part I., Court of General Sessions, yesterday, but was discovered.
ALBANY, Feb. 1. -- The Senate to-night adopted the concurrent resolution giving the Greater New York Commission twenty days' extension of time in which to report a charter.

Arrangements have been completed for the reception of Edward J. Ivory, recently acquitted in England of the charge of dynamite conspiracy, who is due to arrive at this port to-day on the Majestic. Collector Kilbreth has given permission to the officers of the Irish National Alliance to take Ivory and his friends from the steamer at Quarantine.
Our news columns yesterday contained the account of a case which we believe to be unique in the history of mankind. It was the case of a man who became a drunkard by advice of counsel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2. -- With the Chinese New Year, the Six Companies, the most powerful, richest, and most far-reaching Chinese organization in America, goes out of existence. For a year and a half, ever since the four provincial organizations Ning Yung, Kong Chow, Hop Wo, and Shu Hing, composing the Ze Yup federation, withdrew their active support and formed the Four Companies organization, the Six Companies has been practically in liquidation.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The Assembly Cities Committe gave a hearing this afternoon on Mr. Finn's two bills, which propose to allow the erection and use of stands and booths on the sidewalks near the markets in New York City. John Procter Clark of the Corporation Counsel's office opposed the bills in their original form and suggested amendment. A.L. Mooney, representing the Washington Market Association, spoke for the bills.

A stiff northeasterly wind laden with heavy snow, did its best yesterday to bring back the ills of the Street Cleaning Department at the very time when Col. Waring's laborers and the men of the snow contractor's force had made up their minds that the heavy work of the Winter was finished.
ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The Senate to-day confirmed the nomination of Louis F. Payn as Superintendent of Insurance.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The annual convocation of the Grand Chapter, Royal Arch Masons, of the State, is being held here. One hundred, and eighty-three chapters are represented. The annual address of the Grand High Priest, George E.W. Stivers, was delivered this morning. Grand Secretary Christopher C. Fox reported 187 chapters in the grand body.

It was the fortieth in the long list of New York Charity Balls, and the largest and most brilliant for years. Such was the verdict on the superb gathering of wealth, beauty, and fashion at the Metropolitan Opera House last night.

Seven auctioneers -- six in the Trinity Building Salesroom and one in the Real Estate Exchange -- managed to infuse a good deal of life into the business at the auction rooms yesterday. Prices ruled low in nearly every instance, and especially in the case of forty-four lots sold by Peter F. Meyer Co., in foreclosure.

-- While it is probable that the plague of which so many people are dying in India will run the course usual to such epidemics in the East, and without much effective interference from the medical authorities, yet it is receiving the earnest study of physicians skilled in all the methods of modern bacteriology.
BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- E.C. Hodges Co., stock and grain brokers, 201 Exchange Building, assigned to-day to George C. Dickson, a lawyer. Mr. Hodges said:
BLOOMSBURG, Penn., Feb. 2. -- One of the most remarkable criminal cases in Pennsylvania was brought into court here to-day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Anglo-Venezuelan arbitration treaty was signed by Sir Julian Pauncefote, the British Ambasador, and Senor Jose Andrade, the Venezuelan Minister, in the office of Secretary Olney, at the State Department, at 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, signalizing the amicable termination of a controversy that has lasted nearly a century, as well as the resumption of diplomatic negotiations between two countries which had been suspended for ten years.

The second concert of the third season of the American Symphony Orchestra, organized and conducted by Mr. Sam Franko, took place last night at Chickering Hall. The programme consisted of the familiar "Marche Militaire" in D major; the unfinished symphony and two songs, "Memnon" and "Geheimes," by Schubert; two symphonic movements, "The Saracens" and "Lovely Alda" by E.A. McDowell; Goring Thomas's songs, "Midian Village" and "Ma Voisine," and Weber's " Euryanthe" overture.

The Greater New York Commission has obtained from the Legislature twenty days additional time for completing the charter and preparing a final report. The part of that time needed for the purpose should be used to remedy a defect in the draft which will be fatal to the cause of good government if it is permitted to work out its results.

We need no further evidence of the soundness of the objections to LOUIS F. PAYN as a candidate for the office of Superintendent of Insurance than the labored efforts of Senators RAINES and KRUM to justify his appointment, followed by the adverse vote of nine strong Republican Senators, given in spite of the pressure of party influence and the coercive powers of the Governor.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2. -- The Swanhilda, from Newcastle, Australia, arrived this morning. Frank Butler, the Australian murderer, was arrested and brought ashore.

The first annual banquet of the Order of the Founders and Patriots of America was given at the Hotel Manhattan last night. The banquet hall of the hotel was filled to its utmost capacity. More than 200 persons, members of the order and their guests, sat down to one of the most elegant and elaborate dinners ever given in this city.

Gen. Daniel E. Sickles delivered an address on Cuba last night, under the auspices of the Brooklyn Democratic Club, in Historical Hall, Clinton and Pierrepont Streets, Brooklyn. Among other things he said:
Stock market dull and soft. Call money, 1 1/2 to 2 per cent.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- At a meeting to-morrow of the Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, they will elect Frank Thomson, First Vice President of the road, President, to succeed the late George B. Roberts.

HAMBURG, Feb. 2. -- The German steamer Lahn of the North German Lloyd Line ran aground on the Finkenwarder Island, in the Elbe, to-day while on her way to this port. Later the steamer got afloat, and she has arrived here. She comes to have certain improvements made in her in the yard of Blohm Voss. She is to be provided with an awning deck, and will have two of her masts removed.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 2. -- Two Maryland "booms" for Cabinet appointments met here to-day, and Senator Wellington, who did not come nearer Canton than Cleveland, is credited with having quietly assisted in causing one of them to drop quickly from public view.

It is not easy to understand the delay in passing the bankruptcy bill that has been approved by the House and is now pending in the Senate. While there is a strong feeling in the country in favor of such a law, which the Senators generally recognize, many of them seem strangely ignorant of the bill which passed the House, or of the principles by which a law on this subject should unquestionably be guided.

SPARTA, Ga., Feb. 2. -- A fortune of between $60,000 and $75,000 awaits a claimant here. Judge Joseph Babcock, one of the quaintest characters who ever lived in Georgia, died here this morning, leaving no will, no known heirs, and no knowledge about himself.

The extent of information and even the degree of intelligence which The London Times has at command in its discussion of the proposed amendments to the arbitration treaty would necessarily be rated low on the prima facie exhibition of its articles were it not for a disturbing surmise that its misconceptions may be inspired.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Secretary Lamont sent to the House to-day the report of Col. G.L. Gillespie, Corps of Engineers, on the results of a survey of New York Harbor, from the Narrows to the sea, with a view of obtaining a depth of 35 feet at mean low water.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Feb. 2. -- A fire which started in the rooms of Lieut. Gov. Lyon shortly after noon swept through the ancient Capitol of Pennsylvania, and, within and hour and a half after the breaking out of the flames, the structure was in ruins.

There is something humorous in the notion of a set address on "Humor in the Pulpit" by a minister to his professional brethren, such as was reported yesterday. The attempt to lay down the limits of jocosity in sermon is an indication that the author of the address, like the immortal Scotchman, "jokes wi' deefeculty" and not "just spontaneous."

A freight elevator used in hoisting building materials in the New York Life Insurance Company's Building, in course of construction at 346 and 348 Broadway, fell from the seventh floor to the cellar about 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon. There were six men on the car, but none was seriously injured.
ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The Senate Finance Committee this afternoon gave a hearing on the Brush bill, providing for a reduction of telephone rates.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- The funeral of George B. Roberts, late President of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, took place to-day at Bala, a suburb of this city. After services at Mr. Roberts's home, at which only relatives, intimate friends, and the honorary pall bearers were present, public services were held in the Episcopal Church of St. Asaph.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The President has approved these acts:

The movement against professional street beggars was begun yesterday, and a number of men and women who before Chief Conlin's order was put into effect had become a source of annoyance to pedestrians have already begun to serve terms in the Workhouse. None of those arraigned in the different courts attempted to deny the charge of vagrancy.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 2. -- The Senatorial fight in Kentucky, which has been going on so long, probably is ended. It certainly will be ended if the deal alleged to have been made to-day at Canton shall go through.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Before the Assembly Canals Committee this afternoon there was a hearing on the Parshall bill amending the law relating to navigation corporations engaged in inter-State commerce or commerce in the State canals, so as not to limit the capital of a company engaged or designed to engage in such.

The Alumni Association of Cheshire Academy, the Episcopal Academy of Connecticut, met last night at dinner at the Waldorf. Dinner was served in the State apartments, and covers were laid for 100. The association numbers nearly twelve times that number, settled in many sections of the country.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The full text of the Anglo-Venezuelan treaty follows:

PITTSBURG, Feb. 2. -- Yesterday a judgment for $968,253 was confessed by the Pennsylvania Lead Company in favor of George S. Griscom, trustee, for creditors. Mr. Griscom to-day asked for the appointment of receivers for the company, the Board of Directors joining in the petition. The Court appointed George S. Griscom and H.E. Anderson as receivers, directing them to operate the works until further order of court.

Decorations for the Bradley Martin ball at the Waldorf will be under the charge of Florist Small. The entire scheme has been devised to meet the ideas of the hostess, and the floral dream, when realized, will be rich in profusion and exquisite in taste.
ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- In the Senate to-day these bills were passed:

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The Assembly calendar to-day showed twenty-four bills in various stages of progression this morning, which the House proceeded to dispose of with much expedition. There were two special orders, the first of which was Mr. Nixon's measure appropriating $5,000 for the use of the Health Officer of the Port of New York in preventing the spread of the bubonic plague.

American shares were irregular in the London market. The principal changes were: Advanced -- Canadian Pacific, 1/2, to 57 1/2, and Erie, 1/8, to 15 5/8. Declined -- New York Central, 1/4, to 96 1/2; Atchison, 1/4, to 15 1/8; Louisville and Nashville, 1/8, to 52 5/8, and St. Paul, 1/8, to 78 5/8. Erie first preferred sold at 36 1/2, Illinois Central at 97, and Reading at 13 3/4.
" I wouldn't vote for him to-day for Constable!"

BOSTON, Feb. 2. -- "We can," says the Boston News Bureau, "state authoritatively that the New Haven Road does not contemplate a new issue of stock. It has yet to finance its $10,000,000 investment in New England Railroad stock and bonds, but it will not issue new stock on this account, nor is any reduction in dividends contemplated by the management.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Controller Eckels to-day further discussed banking and currency matters with the House Committee on Banking and Currency.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2. -- The cold spell was broken to-day, and bright, mild weather drew out 3,000 people. The track was very heavy, and results were affected thereby, only one favorite winning.

We must really remonstrate with his Honor the Mayor upon the strange principle of executive action which he laid down on Monday to Mr. CALLANAN, as reported by the latter. Gen. COLLIS took the ground the other day that he would give the sidewalk obstructors permission to violate the law pending their effort to have it repealed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Senate Committee on Finance to-day ordered a favorable report on the bill to permit the bottling of distilled spirits in bond. The bill sets out in detail the provisions under which spirits may be bottled and guaranteed by the Government stamp. The reduction of spirits is provided for under a clause, which reads:

A Missouri legislator is trying to devise a bill that will compel street-car companies to carry at half fare passengers for whom there are no seats. He is finding it difficult to get at a feasible measure, as may be imagined.

Although no notice was received at the Stock Exchange yesterday of the voluntary liquidation of the firm of Samuel D. Davis Co., brokers, 36 Wall Street, it was said at the office of the firm that it had been decided upon. Mr. Davis, the Exchange member, retires because of ill health. His partner was Charles B. Van Nostrand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Mr. Cornelius Vanderbilt of New York and his retinue of servants arrived here to-night, and were driven at once to the Lowery House, Vermont Avenue and K. Street, N.W., which he has leased.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Republicans continue to discuss the appointment of Lyman J. Gage to be Secretary of the Treasury, and various theories are suggested to account for this selection. The impression prevails that Mr. Gage will go into the Cabinet absolutely unfettered, and in the conduct of the Treasury Department will be permitted to formulate his own policy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Unless the Senate shall display considerable activity during the closing days of the session, a large number of Presidential appointments will fail for lack of confirmation, and the vacancies thus created will be filled with Republicans after March 4.

The bankers who were in the syndicate that underwrote, or guaranteed, the reorganization plan of the Northern Pacific Railroad were notified yesterday by J. Pierpont Morgan Co., managers of the syndicate, to turn in their pro rata share of 100,000 shares of Northern Pacific common stock and 5,000 shares of preferred.
Great interest is felt at Bellevue Hospital in the case of Henry Cohen, who has lost the hair from part of his head as the result, presumably, of X-ray experiments to locate a bullet in his brain.
ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- The House to-day passed Mr. Austin's bill for a Hall of Records in New York City.

Mr. J. HARSEN RHOADES is entitled to credit for resisting the desire of the Metropolitan Traction Company to change the motive power on the Madison Avenue surface road without giving some compensation to the city for the great benefits the change confers upon itself. It is true that the change is a benefit to the public also, but the measure of the public benefit is the enormous increase in the profits of the corporation.

The Police Commissioners decided yesterday at the board meeting that Capt. Chapman was justified in forcing his way into Sherry's on Dec. 20 last while the dinner given by Herbert Barnum Seeley in honor of his brother, Clinton Seeley, was in progress, and dismissed by unanimous vote the charges preferred against him.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- They Senate Judiciary Committee to-day appointed a sub-committee to prepare a bill to govern the holding of primary elections. It consists of Senators Lexow, (ex officio,) and Messrs. Pavey and Guy of New York, and Charles Davis of Ulster County.
" The Bradley-Martin Ball" was the subject of President George Gunton's lecture last evening at the School of Social Economics, 34 Union Square.

-- Alabama's legislators seem to be devoting most of their energies this year to the task of making people good by statute. Already a bill has been passed providing for conducting all trade in liquor through State dispensaries, and favorable reports have been made on measures putting slot machines under the ban and prohibiting the sale of pools on races run either in or out of the State.

Fire in the five-story flat house at One Hundred and Sixteenth Street and Park Avenue yesterday morning did $15,000 damage and endangered the lives of some twenty people. There are twenty-seven sets of apartments in the building, and about 150 tenants. A stray cat was noticed in the hallway by W.P. Davenport, who came home at about 5:30.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- Louis F. Payn, the new State Superintendent of Insurance, said to-day that he would take his oath of office and file his bond of $25,000 so as to be ready to assume the duties of his new position about a week from to-morrow, when the term of the present Superintendent of Insurance, James F. Pierce, will expire.

The affairs of Union Pacific were interesting to the financial -world yesterday because of news received in regard to the closing and perfecting of negotiations with the Berlin committee for the acquisition of the German holdings of Oregon Railway and Navigation Company's stock. The bid at 45 was, it is admitted, in the interest of the Northern Pacific, Union Pacific, and Great Northern in the interest of harmony and economy.

Hamilton F. Colman, a clerk in the General Land Office in Washington, was arrested at Barclay Street and Broadway yesterday by Post Office Inspectors Morris and Jacobs, and was held by Commissioner Shields in $2,000 bail for examination Wednesday on the charge of being concerned in the theft of a large amount of "periodical" stamps. He had these stamps on his person to the face value of $5,560.

WAUKEGAN, Ill., Feb. 3. -- The Bluff City Electric Railway, to be built from Waukegan to Evanston, there to connect with the Chicago line, promises to be a big thing in the way of furnishing cheap travel for the numerous North Shore towns.

Last Saturday the American Theatrical Syndicate closed its last company, the Hollands, who are at present appearing under new management at the Fifth Avenue Theatre. The syndicate was originally formed by James H. McVicker of Chicago and Henry C. Miner and Joseph Brooks of New York.
CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 3. -- It was stated here to-night on what is considered reliable authority that J. Addison Porter of Connecticut has accepted the post of private secretary to President McKinley.
Commissioner Waring of the Street Cleaning Department yesterday sent the following communication to the local Civil Service Commission:

WEST CHESTER, Penn., Feb. 3. -- The Chester County Guarantee, Trust and Safe Deposit Company is in financial straits, and unless a proposition which has been submitted to the certificate holders and depositors of the company is accepted, it will go into the hands of a receiver.

" What are you going to do about it?" "It will blow over in thirty days." These are utterances of WILLIAM M. TWEED a quarter of a century old. LOUIS F. PAYN would have done better to follow the policy defined in them instead of setting Senator RAINES and The Albany Express to defending him.

At the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday Commissioner Little's effort to delay the purchase of school sites because the objected to the method of procedure and the expense awakened a discussion and was the chief feature of the session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- If the amendments to the arbitration treaty would help to assure its ratification, it is not likely that the Administration would neglect to make the effort to have them corrected. But the prospect of approval, with or without amendment, is not considered good by either the friends or the opponents of the convention.

PHOENICIA, N.Y., Feb. 3. -- John Mulhare of this place is in bed suffering from injuries he received in a fight with a wildcat. After a fierce struggle he managed to kill the beast, but not until his clothes had been torn in shreds and he had been lacerated terribly by the sharp claws of the animal.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The Standard to-morrow will print a dispatch from its Madrid correspondent saying that at a meeting of the Cabinet held to-day the Ministers discussed for several hours the scheme of reforms for Cuba prepared by Senor Canovas del Castillo, the Spanish Premier, and Colonial Minister Castellano.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 3. -- The House Committee on Railroads and Canals gave a preliminary hearing this afternoon on the League of American Wheelmen's bill requiring all the railroads in the State to carry bicycles free as baggage. The passage of the bill was advocated by C. Frank Kireker, Chief Consul of the New Jersey Division of the League; Isaac B. Potter of New York and Herbert W. Knight of Newark.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The discussion of the contested election case of George W. Cornett (Rep.) vs. Claude A. Swanson, (Dem.,) from the Fifth District of Vir ginia, occupied nearly the whole of to-day's session of the House, and by an overwhelming vote Mr. Swanson's title to the seat was confirmed by the House.

SALT LAKE, Utah, Feb. 3. -Ex-Congressman Joseph L. Rawlins was elected United States Senator this afternoon by the Legislature, receiving thirty-two votes, the minimum number necessary to elect. Thatcher, the next leading candidate, received twenty-nine votes, and two votes were scattered.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- The hearing of the appeal of Robert T. Kneebs, the American horseman, against the judgment of the court condemning him to nine months' imprisonment for entering the trotting mare Bethel in races on the German courses under the name of Nellie Fneebs, which began here yesterday, is expected to last five days.

The text of the proposed treaty of arbitration between this country and Great Britain is given below. In brackets are printed the portions which, according to the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, it is proposed to omit. The statements in full-faced type are those inserted by the committee:

" It was intended to apply to every stage of our National life, and cannot become obsolete while our Republic endures.'' So wrote President CLEVELAND of the Monroe doctrine in his Venezuela message of Dec. 17, 1895.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The Daily Chronicle to-morrow will publish the report of an interview with Dr. Frithiof Nansen, the Norwegian explorer, who is now in London, in which the famous traveler is quoted as saying that he does not intend to make another attempt to reach the north pole.

The matrimonial ways of Europe are not as those of America, and upon the whole we may be thankful for the difference. In theory all Americans marry for love, and a very great majority of them do so in practice. In Great Britain the theory is the same, except in the "huppa' suckles."

ALBANY, N.T., Feb. 3. -- A joint committee of the Senate and Assembly Committees on Public Health gave a hearing this afternoon on the several bills for pure beer. The first to be heard in opposition to the measure was G. Thoman of the New York State Brewers and Maltsters' Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- "Do you decline to answer the questions because you are afraid of incriminating yourself?" asked Attorney McCarthy as he arose and faced President Barber of the Diamond Match Company at the annual meeting of the stockholders of that organization this morning.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 3. -- Last night the Globe Smelter shipped 1,000 tons of pig lead through the Denver Custom House in bond to Liverpool. On Jan. 18 the Pueblo Smelting and Refining Company shipped 800 tons of pig lead to Liverpool via Galveston, and these shipments have continued daily at the rate of about six carloads a day.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- The earnings and expenses of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company and the Lehigh Valley Coal Company for December, 1896, as compared with the same month in 1895, show the following results: Lehigh Valley Railroad: Gross earnings, decrease, $125,670.82; expenses, decrease, 31,875.94; net earnings, decrease, $93,794.88. Lehigh Valley Coal Company: Gross earnings, increase, $122,976.79; expenses, increase, $73,199.65; net earnings, increase, $49,177.23; decrease, $44,617.65.

Some of the provisions of the Raines law seem to have produced a good deal of dissatisfaction, by giving rise to practices which apparently were not looked for and which the friends of the law, as well as some who are not favorably inclined toward it, think call for some amendment of that much-discussed statute.

Col. WARING has asked the Civil Service Commission to put his department "under the rules," and to take charge of all applications for appointment and employment. He has faithfuly tried the plan of separate control of appointments, and he is convinced that it has more against it than for it. It wastes the time and strength of the head of the department and of his deputy. "

Some of the freak journals are making a fuss over the refusal of the doorkeepers at the Metropolitan Museum to admit into the Museum a plumber in his working clothes. It appears that the plumber was working near by, and, having some of his nooning to himself, determined to have a look at the Museum.
The large ballroom of Sherry's last evening was filled by the members of the Wednesday Cotillion at its third assembly.

The New York Life Insurance Company has bought, through JohnM. Thompson Co., from the McKenna and Binsse estates and Louisa E.A.B. Moulton, the four and five story brick tenement, 122 to 128 Leonard Street, and the three-story brick factories 57 and 59 Elm. Street, for about $225,000.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 3. -- The River and Harbor Committee of the House of Representatives spent the day in Birmingham. They arrived at 5:35 A.M. over the Alabama Great Southern. After breakfast at the Morris, they were taken around the Birmingham district in a special train, furnished by the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Attorney General Harmon appeared to-day before the House Committee on Pacific Railways, and expressed at some length his views with reference to the bill to settle the indebtedness of the Pacific Railways to the Government by a commission consisting of three Cabinet officers.

BOSTON, Feb. 3. -- The statement is made by the Boston News Bureau that "another interest besides the Union Pacific Reorganization Committee will bid for the Union Pacific property at the foreclosure sale, though who this party may be is not yet disclosed.

A gold medal was presented to Dr. John S. White, head master of Berkeley School, in West Forty-fourth Street, by a number of his friends and admirers upon his fiftieth birthday last night. Gov. Roger Wolcott of Massachusetts, Dr. White's classmate at Harvard, was expected to make the presentation speech, but was kept away by official duties, and Walter S. Logan acted in his stead.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The two resolutions offered last week by Mr. Allen (Pop., Neb.,) looking to impeding, or preventing, the sale of the Union Pacific Railroad property under a judicial decree of foreclosure, were to-day discussed at much length by Mr. Thurston (Rep., Neb.) He argued in opposition of Mr. Allen's contention that the right of the Attorney General to appear for the Government in the foreclosure proceedings was absolutely beyond question.

Meyerbeer's remarkable opera, "L'Africaine," was brought forward at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time this season. The operagoing public seemed to think that the occasion was one which called for special thanksgivings, and hence there were evidences of great joy in the auditorium.
-- The Kings County Elevated Railroad has paid to l:legistrar of Arrears Powell t further installment of $19,26U.47 on arrears for 1893.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- The Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company met at 10 o'clock this morning and elected First Vice President Frank Thomson as President of the corporation, to fill the vacancy caused by the death of George B. Roberts. During the long illness of Mr. Roberts the duties and responsibilities of the management were assumed by Mr. Thomson, and the action of the board to-day was merely the fulfillment of the general expectation.

The Rainy Day Club was entertained yesterday afternoon by Miss E. Marguerite Lindley, at the Murray Hill Hotel. The day was not sufficiently cloudy to call the members out in their club regimentals but the half dozen or more who did appear in short skirts, were gazed at with admiration by the long-skirted crowd which filled Reception Parlor 9 of the hotel.
The members of the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn engaged in a number of novel equestrian features in their arena last evening.

It is a dangerous doctrine to establish that the police power may break into private premises, whether owned or rented either permanently or temporarily, without a warrant based upon some kind of evidence of violation of law, but simply upon a casual report that the premises are being used or are in danger of being used for "immoral purposes."

Eight hundred persons who went down the bay yesterday to meet Edward J. Ivory and his counsel, former Assistant District Attorney John F. McIntyre, were greatly disappointed when they were told the steamship Majestic, on which Ivory, his counsel, and witnesses had sailed, would not arrive until late at night or early this morning.

Warden J.W. French of the first and only United States penitentiary, that which was opened at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., on the abolition of the military prison at that post June 30, 1895, has just made his first annual report to the Attorney General. During the year covered in his report the Warden had 620 prisoners in his charge, only three of whom were females.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- The Senate Judiciary Committee to-day appointed a sub-Committee on Civil Service Reform. It consists of Senators Lexow, Krum, and Cantor. That portion of the Governor's message which related to this topic was referred to the Judiciary Committee. In that message, Gov. Black expressed the opinion that "civil service would work better with less starch."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The disposition of the troublesome question of armor plate, its cost, , appears to be one upon which the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs cannot speedily reach a conclusion. An hour and a half was consumed this morning in the consideration of the Chandler report, but no decision was reached.

May Irwin and her company occupied the little stage in the lecture room of the Colored Home and Hospital, at first Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon, and for an hour an uproarious audience enjoyed the fun. There was enthusiasm enough to stock many colored camp meetings every time the actress sang one of her negro songs.

An attack on the Joint Traffic Association, President Ingalls of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago, and St. Louis Railway Company, President Thomson of the Pennsylvania Railroad, and others, was published in a Chicago paper yesterday morning. The attack was the culmination of a series of articles unfavorable to the Traffic Association.

There was a very full attendance of members of the Chamber of Commerce when the monthly meeting, yesterday, was called to order by President Alexander E. Orr. Seated by him on the dais was Brooklyn's ex-Mayor Charles A. Schieren.
ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- In the Assembly today the following bills were passed:...
MADRID, Feb. 4. -- The decree authorizing the proposed reforms in the Island of Cuba, which it was announced would be signed on Saturday, was signed by the Queen Regent to-day.

HAVANA, Feb. 4. -- Since Capt. Gen. Weyler entered the Santa Clara Province a week ago his columns have had a series of encounters with various parties of rebels, which were eventually dispersed. All the way from Las Cruces to Santa Clara the shooting on the part of the rebels increased and their movements became bolder, a party of insurgents even firing upon Gen. Weyler's camp on the River Sagua.
ALBANI', N. Y., Fel. a. -Following are abstracts of annual reports made to the State Banking Department by the savings institutions of New k'ork City.

The White Star steamship Majestic, which arrived yesterday from Liverpool and Queenstown, according to Capt. Smith had about the roughest voyage in her experience. She came over a course of 2,860 knots and took 7 days 2 hours and 45 minutes. She as expected Wednesday morning, but it was 11:30 A.M. yesterday when she arrived at Sandy Hook Bar.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 4. -- A memorial from President Ripley of the Santa Fe was presented to the Legislature to-day praying that body not to pass a maximum freight law. The memorial contains 3,000 words and discusses fully the distressed condition of Kansas railroads.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- The Senate Committee on Miscellaneous Corporations this afternoon gave a hearing on Senator Cantor's bill making the price of gas in New York City $1, and providing for a Municipal Gas Commission, to supervise the operations of the gas companies so far as they concern the public.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Prayer was offered in the House this morning by the Rev. J.J. Dolliver of Fort Dodge, Iowa, father of Representative Dolliver, (Rep., Iowa).

Mr. SETH LOW, in a letter to The Evening Post, gives his reasons for assenting to the form of Municipal Assembly provided for in the Greater New York charter, though he does not believe in it, and his standing as an authority upon city government makes it worth while to consider them.

Senators LEXOW and KRUM, with Senatorr CANTOR, are a sub-committee to take the "starch" out of the civil service, as recommended by Gov. BLACK. They do not find it so easy as they had thought it would be. One reason is that the stiffening was put into the service by the Constitution through the courts.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 4. -- The indications now are that the intentions of M. A. Hanna will occupy the Cabinet guessers the rest of this week. It is reported here by many of Mr. Hanna's Cleveland friends who have visited Canton within the last twenty-four hours that he may decide to accept the position of Postmaster General.
The Woman's Art Club of New York will give a reception to open their annual exhibition at the Klackner Galleries, 7 West Twenty-eighth Street, on Saturday evening, Feb. 13.

The nearest approach to an out-and-out quarrel that ever interrupted a meeting of the Loyal Legion occurred Wednesday night, at the dinner of the State Commandery at Delmonico's. The principals in the difference of opinion were Gen. Adelbert A. Ames of Lowell, Mass., and Gen. Newton, M. Curtis of Ogdensburg. Congressman from the Twenty-second District.

Among those who arrived on the White Star steamer Majestic yesterday was the Rev. Dr. F.B. Meyer of London. Dr. Meyer is a Congregationalist, and occupies the pulpit made famous by the distinguished English clergyman, Newman Hall. He is one of the leading spirits in what are known as the Lake conferences, which are held annually in the town of Keswick, Westmoreland, England.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- A careful canvass of the Senate affords ground for the hope that when that body reaches the Bankruptcy bill it will favor, not the voluntary bankruptcy measure before the Senate Judiciary Committee, but the Torrey bill passed by the House and rejected by the Senate committee.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 4. -- A mob hanged Robert Morton, a negro, three miles from Rockfield some time after last midnight.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- Miss Jessie Bogart, daughter of John Bogart, a wealthy farmer, residing in the outskirts of this city, is heartbroken to-night over her desertion by David Bailey, her prospective husband.

I observed in THE TIMES of this morning a Washington telegram stating that $350,000 belonging to the Cramp Company had been held up in the Navy Department since July, and that in consequence thereof I had within a day or two written to the Secretary of the Navy an "ugly letter," embodying very severe criticisms upon him and the Administration in general.

It is a queer medley of propositions that Senator CHANDLER of New Hampshire wishes to have declared as "the sense of the Senate." It would be much more logical to present them as proof of the Senate's want of sense.

E. Hartman has bought of H. Wallach, at $43,000, two five-story brownstone-front flats, 329 and 331 East Ninetieth Street, 25 by 100.8 each, and will give in trade, at $40,000, the five-story brownstone-front tenement, with stores, 1,748 First Avenue, 25 by 90, and the four-story brownstone-front flat 339 East Seventy-seventh Street, 25 by 102.2.

Senator CULLOM of Illinois shows a "truly rural" spirit as to the arbitration treaty. "Well," he says, in his artless fashion, "if Great Britain does not like the amendments they must be pretty good. I am for them." This might be a shrewd policy in war, but the treaty is intended to prevent war.

The Rev. Dr. E.S. Tipple, now pastor of Grace Methodist Episcopal Church, One Hundred and Fourth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, has signified to the Trustees of St. James's Methodist Episcopal Church of One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street and Madison Avenue, his willingness to accept their call to the pastorate if the Bishop consents to transfer him at the Spring conference.

The Rapid Transit Commission met yesterday afternoon at their rooms in the Home Life Building and took final action on the proposed underground route with its southern terminus at the City Hall. The members of the board at the meeting were Messrs. Orr, Starin, Claflin, Langdon, and Smith.

-- What is called a "hygienic house" has just been built by a Dutch physician, and illustrates rather forcibly the possibility of preventive measures being worse to undergo than several maladies. The walls of this extremely modern and scientific dwelling are made of parallel plates of ground glass several inches apart, with a concentrated solution of alum or salts of soda between them.

Men who have studied the subject of municipal reform avow their dissatisfaction with the Municipal Assembly provisions of the Greater New York charter. There is a deep-seated objection to the Assembly as proposed, on the part of those who believe in freeing the Municipal Government from the bondage of partisan politics.

NYACK, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- At the first annual banquet to-night of the Nyack Board of Trade, Senator Clarence Lexow, Chairman of the legislative committee appointed to investigate trusts, and report remedial legislation with respect to trusts, made an address on "The Tendencies of the Times Toward Combinations." He spoke as follows:

It does not clearly appear what the reforms for Cuba that were promulgated yesterday by the Queen Regent of Spain were intended to effect. It is conceivable that they were meant either to bring the war to an end by placating the insurgents or to prevent other powers from taking part in it by a proposition which should take away the support that the insurgents had in the sympathy of mankind.
ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- When the Senate met to-day the Committee on Internal Affairs reported favorably the bill to reorganize the Richmond County police force.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- Gov. Black to-day sent to the Senate the nominations for Railroad Commissioners. They were Col. Ashley W. Cole of Brooklyn, Frank M. Baker of Owego, and George W. Dunn of Binghamton. Each was for a full term of five years. The salaries are $8,000 a year each.
FORAKER and SHERMAN are the controlling factors in the Ohio situation. The President-elect and HANNA are subordinate to them.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, Feb. 4. -- A bill to authorize and encourage athletic sports was introduced in the Wyoming Legislature several days ago, passed smoothly through first and second readings, and was indorsed by all committees. A more thorough examination of the measure was given, when it came up to-day for final passage, and it was discovered that it legalized prize-fighting in Wyoming.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Following the usual custom, and repeating the action he took in 1889, when Mr. Harrison was about to succeed him as President, Mr. Cleveland will on Feb. 27 issue the following proclamation:
BOSTON, Feb. 4. -- The steamer Boston, from Yarmouth, N.S., which arrived this morning, brought thirty-three shipwrecked fishermen, who had been sent home by the United States Consul.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 4. -- People in Detroit are a good deal interested in the revival of the discussion of Gen. Alger's military record which has resulted from his acceptance of the War portfolio from Major McKinley.

Edward J. Ivory, his counsel, John F. McIntyre, and witnesses, James Wynne, Patrick Smith, and Patrick O'Rourke, arrived on the Majestic yesterday. They were met down the bay by an enthusiastic crowd of Irishmen on the Laura M. Starin. In the excursion party were a number of ladies, including Mrs. McIntyre, the mother; Mrs. McIntyre, the wife, and a number of friends.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The work of framing the new tariff law has been well advanced by the Republican members of the Ways and Means Committee.

The German Charity Ball, at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, was the most successful one, from every point of view, of the seven annual balls that have been given by the United German Societies. From the financial point of view, it realized $10,000, as against the $8,000 of last year's ball, which was about the average for the last six years. In seven years these entertainments have brought in $60,000 for charitable purposes.
Dr. W.W. Hollingsworth of Philadelphia appeared before the New York Numismatic and Archaeological Society last night, and delivered an address on "A Forgotten Treasure House."

The advance in Standard Oil stock yesterday attracted considerable attention upon the Street. The stock is selling higher than ever before in the history of the company. In the crowd of brokers who make their headquarters on the Mills Building pavement there were plenty of orders for the stock at 270. But offerings were few and far between. After 3 o'clock sales were reported at 272.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- Abraham Gruber of New York has been here to-day conferring with Republican leaders on proposed changes in the civil service laws. He had a consultation with Speaker O'Grady and later with Senator Lexow, Chairman of the sub-committee of the Judiciary Committee appointed yesterday to prepare a bill on this subject.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The impression that the Inspectors of the Post Office Department have made a mistake in arresting Hamilton F. Colman in New York yesterday on the charge of stealing uncanceled stamps used for bags and second-class mail matter is gaining ground here in the official circles concerned.

We like very much Senator HILL'S February Forum article on "The Future of the Democratic Organization." Stripped of everything that is subordinate and accessory, the whole point of its teaching is "complete separation from Populism" and the reaffirmation of the ancient faith of the party.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 5. -- Hector D. Lane, ex-Commissioner of Agriculture of Alabama and President of the American Cotton Growers' Protective Association, and Col. W.A. Broughton, President of the Association for Georgia, conferred to-day in reference to the next convention.

The voices of thoughtful citizens continue to be raised against the proposed Municipal Assembly chapter of the Greater New York charter. Men who have given largely of their time and abilities to the public service urge that the revival of a local legislative body like the old-time Board of Aldermen would be a dangerous retrograde step.

The New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which meets in Highland Avenue Church, Sing Sing; April 7, will be presided over by Bishop Stephen M. Merrill, LL.D., of Chicago. There are about 300 ministers in the conference, but 50 of the number are superannuated or occupy detached positions. Stationing the 250 itinerants will be the chief business of the session.

Again we find ourselves rather unexpectedly compelled to commend Senator HILL. He was the only Senator who had the sense and courage to denounce a bill prohibiting the sale Of intoxicating liquors in the Capitol as "silly, unwise, and unnecessary."

In the "Literary Anecdotes of the Nineteenth Century" (Dodd, Mead Co.) are many curious minor notes relative to Lord Tennyson's publishers. The "Poems by Two Brothers," the joint work of Alfred and Charles, was published by the Jacksons of Louth, who were fairly well-to-do country printers.

ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- In the Senate to-day but twenty members were present. Petitions were presented by Senators Ellsworth and Brackett asking for a reduction in the license fee under the Raines law for druggists.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Advices received here from various sources confirm the stories of the disturbances in Crete and of the killing of Christians. The various reports indicate that in the first instance the Christians were as fully to blame as the Mussulmans.

The new County Committee of the McKinley League, which is the provisional organization paving the way for a new anti-Platt Republican organization, met last night at the old State Club, in East Twenty-second Street, and installed William Brookfield as its Chairman. John E. Milholland had retired as Chairman.

SIOUX FALLS, S D., Feb. 5. -- Mme. Villard, who has been one of the especially interesting characters in this city for more than a half year, is a free woman, so far as matrimonial ties are concerned. Judge J. W. Jones to-day signed the decree which dissolved the bonds which held Julia De La Tour Du Villard to M. Brice Ernest Gabriel Raymond Odde, Marquis De La Tour Du Villard.

Gen. ALGER has given to the public a succinct and modest statement of the essential features of his war record, with documents relating thereto. These establish a reputation of which he has no reason to be ashamed. He says:
Hoffman Brother have sold for Mrs. Bellows, the Grace Church leasehold, 151 Chambers Street, with a five-story building thereon, for about $25,000.

The expert commission appointed to study the question whether continuous passenger traffic across the Brooklyn Bridge is feasible has not yet reported. Various rumors have been circulated as to what its conclusions will be. The members of the commission are able and honorable engineers, who are no doubt pursuing their investigations with all proper care and thoroughness.

For a week after to-night the bicycle will have its reign in this city. The annual show under the auspices of the National Cycle Board of Trade will open at 8 P.M. in the Grand Central Palace, at Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, and enthusiasts from far and near will welcome it. The exhibition will be bigger and more brilliant than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The State Department has received a full report of the Kellett affair at Chiengmai, Siam, from Minister Barrett, which indicates that it was only a trivial affair and that a mountain was made from an exceedingly small molehill.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- Mr. Charles Fitzpatrick, Solicitor General of Canada, who has just returned from a trip to The Continent and will sail for home on Feb. 13, has taken the opinion of Edward Blake, M.P., P.C., formerly Chancellor of Upper Canada, in regard to the appeals of the Manitoba Government from the decision of the Privy Council in the matter of the Manitoba school dispute.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 5. -- The Michigan and Ohio Transportation Company has been organized with a capital of $200,000, and a contract has been made with the Detroit Dry Dock Company to build two car ferry barges at a cost of $150,000. Each vessel is to be of wood, 340 feet long over all and 60 feet beam.

Surely there is a poet born to us, a man whose lines are singing ones, who throws in words all aglow with rich colors, who interprets human passions, who counts heart throbs, and, incomprehensible as it may seem, has a subtle humor, is keen, abounding in mother wit, and, to sum it all up, has an originality quite his own.

American hotels are so taken up with the desire to dazzle us that they sometimes make us uncomfortable. It is very fine and impressive to have one's card handled by two men and a big boy and then a little boy when calling upon friends at a great hotel, but it is fatiguing, nevertheless, to wait thirty minutes and then have the little boy come down and tell you they are not at home.

LOWELL, Mass., Feb. 5. -- According to the reports of the banquet of the Loyal Legion, held at Delmonico's Wednesday evening, a paper on the battle of Fort Fisher, read by Gen. A.A. Ames of Lowell so enraged Gen. Newton Curtis of Ogdensburg, N.Y., by its criticisms that Gen. Curtis referred to Gen. Ames in a later speech as a "a craven-hearted coward."

" From 9 till 11 I have to give two 'music' lessons, and to instill into my pupils Czerny's studies, Dohler's Tarantelle, and Willmer's 'Schwalben Etude.' That is a tiring 'robota,' (labor,) a torture analogous to the national punishment in Persia, for the wrong notes drip into my ears as constantly as the drops of water on the skull of a Persian criminal.

That excellent authority, Mr. I.H. Slater, gives in the Athenaeum the notable books disposed of last year in England. In almost all cases there has been appreciation, not depreciation, in the value of rare works. The Tudor Frere collection disposed of early in 1896 consisted of 1,074 volumes, which sold for 3,748, a fairly high average per volume.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- In combating the report of the Secretary of the Navy on the cost of making armor plate, H.C. Frick, Chairman of the Board of Managers of the Carnegie Company, has written a letter in which he speaks highly of the board of officers appointed by the Secretary of the Navy to investigate the subject.

The fourth afternoon concert, commonly called public rehearsal, of the Philharmonic Society took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. There was an audience which filled the house, and which, as usual, expended its energies in worship of the soloist. A large wreath suspended at the rear of the stage and bearing the inscription "Schubert, 1797 -- 1897," told the stranger that once more the one hundredth anniversary of that composer's birth was to be celebrated.

The Greater New York Commission yesterday approved the work of the Revision Committee as far as it has been completed. The question as to how long the Mayor's term should be was again discussed, and the period was left at four years. The section, however, was amended so as to make the Mayor ineligible as his own successor as the Sheriff of the county is ineligible as his own success under the Constitution.

A loan exhibition of 100 masterpieces is the coming Boston art event. The proceeds are to be given to the Boston Art Students' Association. Numerous committees have been formed. There is nothing so troublesome as the bringing together of pictures for a loan exhibition, but the results always are in proportion to the hard work done.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 5. -- Mark Hanna spent three hours with Major McKinley this afternoon, and then returned to Cleveland. Mr. Hanna said there was no warrant for the report that he had accepted the position of Postmaster General, yet it is believed by politicians here that in the end he will yield to the desire of the President-elect and enter the Cabinet.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- In the House of Commons today Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced that a further advance of Egyptian troops would be made toward Khartoum next season.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5. -- Mrs. Stanford, widow of ex-Senator Leland Stanford, completed arangements last night for the sale of over $500,000 worth of land.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The First National Bank of Griswold, Iowa, has failed, and George A. Stone, Bank Examiner at Mount Pleasant, Iowa, has been placed in charge.

Valentines tend to realism this season. One which may be considered a "comic" or not, as individual taste suggests, utilizes an old-fashioned brimstone match and a little blue ribbon bow to express "Your matchless beauty will bring you many a beau." Another, which has an artificial forget-me-not fastened to it, reads: "Without a (s)cent 'tis sad to see that this fair flower should be like me.
