ALBANY, Feb. 5. -- Louis F. Payn, who is to be Superintendent of Insurance on and after Feb. 11, visited the Senate Chamber this morning for the second or third time this session. During the time his name has been figuring in the daily gossip of the Senators he has kept away from what used to be called the "throne room."

BETHLEHEM, Penn., Feb. 5. -- For fifteen years, Cyrus E. Breder, cashier of the First National Bank of Bethlehem, has been regarded as an upright and honorable man, but his honesty was a cloak, and he is now a fugitive from justice, with a shortage in his accounts at the bank of $12,430.

MADRID, Feb. 5. -- A full abstract of the proposed reforms for Cuba and Puerto Rico, approved by the Queen Regent, will be promulgated to-morrow in The Official Gazette. The Ministry regards them as constituting as comprehensive a measure of home rule as can be granted in the existing conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- During the routine morning business in the Senate Mr. Gray (Dem., Del.,) presented the credentials of Richard R. Kenney (Dem.) as Senator-elect from the State of Delaware, the credentials being in due form and being signed by the Governor and Secretary of State of Delaware.

Messrs. Nicoll and Wise, in their "Literary Anecdotes," are literary specialists. Disraeli the elder followed a bent of this kind, but he generalized very much more. If the authors or the books here mentioned are not numerous, still the information given is singularly precise. The volume is a contribution toward a literary history of the nineteenth century in a limited sense.

It is announced that the Messrs. Putnam will hereafter be the publishers of the Half Moon Series, those excellent leaflets devoted to the early history of New York City. The series is published under the editorial charge of Mrs. Maude Wilder Goodwin, Mrs. Alice Carrington Royce, and Miss Ruth Putnam.

GREAT FALLS, Mon., Feb. 5. -- The Northwestern National Bank failed to open its doors this morning, and the fact caused great excitement. Rumors of a heavy defalcation were spread, and it was admitted by the officers that grave complications had arisen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- The Ways and Means Committee to-day further perfected the new Tariff bill by completing the lumber schedule. The schedule, as finally agreed upon, practically re-enacts the McKinley rates, except in respect to white pine, on which an increase is made. The advance on white pine was made at the earnest request of the lumbermen, who represented this industry to be in a very bad way.
ST. PAUL, Minn., Feb. 5. -- One little snowball is responsible for the tragic death of Peter Joseph Dreis, the oldest druggist in St. Paul and one of its leading politicians.

LONDON, Feb. 5. -- The plan formulated by the Government for increasing the strength and efficiency of the navy contemplates the construction of five battleships and three first-class cruisers, and the addition of 10,000 more men.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5. -- Officials of Eastern railroads in this city do not look for anything more serious to result from the present independent action of certain roads affecting grain rates to the seaboard than, possibly, a reorganization of the Board of Managers, which has arbitrarily dictated the policy of the Joint Traffic Association lines during the last thirteen months.

Ex-Judge DILLON follows Gen. TRACY and Mr. LOW in defending the Municipal Assembly scheme of the Greater New York charter draft, and the laboriousness of these successive defenses suggests a consciousness that the cause is weak.

Lawyers in Brooklyn are puzzling over a complication that arose in the suit for damages brought by Cornelius Hurley against the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company and the New York and Brooklyn Brewing Company. The plaintiff's daughter, Anna, was killed in a collision of a trolley car and a truck of the brewing company eighteen months ago.

The Special Committee on Trusts, of which Senator Lexow is Chairman, began yesterday its investigation of supposed monopolies in this city. It met in the Council Chamber in the City Hall at 11 A.M. Besides the Chairman, Senator Lexow, there were present Senator Parsons and Assemblymen Barry, Bedell, Mazet, and Warner.

LISBON, Feb. 5. -- Premier Hintze Robeiro to-day delivered to the King the resignation of the entire Ministry, informing his Majesty that the Cabinet members had found themselves unable to grapple with the present economic and financial situation, and had, therefore, resolved to retire from office.

One side of the shop was taken up by a long counter, and shelves and drawers extended all around the room. These were covered and filled with a great and miscellaneous, collection of strange and rare herbs and roots. Deer horns, in their velvet stage, were suspended from the ceiling. These, after being sliced as thin as wafers, are boiled, and produce what is supposed to be a valuable medicine.

The Hazlitt memoirs, which have just appeared in London from the hands of Mr. Carew Hazlitt, with the title "Four Generations of a Literary Family: The Hazlitts in England, Ireland, and America; Their Friends and Their Failures, 1726-1896," have not made a good impression. There is too much plain speech, not to say original speech, and the writer's tone is too often that of superiority.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5. -- By private dispatches, received last evening, it was positively learned that Judge McKenna had accepted a position in the Cabinet of President McKinley. The information is authentic, but the dispatch itself was not given out for publication.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- Those Republicans who are opposed to the appointment of Gen. Alger as Secretary of War are persisting in their determination to compel his withdrawal or to defeat his nomination if it shall be sent to the Senate.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Feb. 5. -- Capt. Zacharie Surratt of the schooner George S. Boutwell determined to chance getting a cargo this season at the old deserted grounds of Grand Minan. In the pursuit of this venture he was the instrument of rescuing fifty-two persons from drowning, by far the largest number ever saved by a Gloucester schooner.

Why might not expert women -- those endowed with needle skill and good taste -- try their hands at the embroidering of book covers? Mr. Cyril Davenport shows in The Portfolio the most noted of all embroidered book covers, the work of Queen Elizabeth. The volume so decorated was Matthew Parker's "De Antiquitate Britannicae Ecclesiae," and was possibly a presentation copy from the author, who in 1572 was Archbishop of Canterbury.
With regard to the bi-partisan Police Board, we regret to say that the views of ex-Judge DILLON are seriously lacking in candor. He says:

The Rapid Transit Commission has adopted its general plan for an underground road by the Elm Street route, with the terminus at the City Hall Park. It did not take in the lower Broadway extension because there still appears to be some opposition of property owners, and the commission is not willing to encounter any further resistance from that quarter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- While sanguine Republicans are talking about the rates of duty that are to be fixed by the new tariff bill, prudent Republicans are wondering when they axe to get the bill to President McKinley.

HAVANA, Feb. 5. -- Senora Eva Adan Rodriguez, wife of a rebel Colonel, who was brought here yesterday as a prisoner on the steamer Manuela, from Nuevitas and lodged in the house of refuge, was released today. She is an American citizen, and at the time of her arrest the Government promised that she would be set at liberty. Upon the representations made by Consul General Lee she was released from custody.

St. Luke's Church, the Rev. Dr. A.B. Swentzel pastor, on Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, .has been selected as the place for holding the State Convention of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew. The dates are Saturday and Sunday, May 22 and 23, and invitations are to be extended to Newark, Elizabeth, and various Connecticut local assemblies to attend.

MONTREAL, Feb. 5. -- The ninth annual race meeting of the Amateur Skating Association of Canada was inaugurated at the Montreal Amateur Association's rink to-day. The races to-day were among the most brilliant ever witnessed on the rink. Several world's records were broken. It was supposed that J.K. McCullough, the Canadian skater from Winnipeg, had established a new record of the five-thousand-metre race.

A lady who must have known Thackeray and Mrs. Brookfield gives this happy reminiscence of them in The Gentlewoman: "I was a little girl when I first saw Mrs. Brookfield; it was at a Christmas-tree party at Mr. Thackeray's house in Onslow Square. Our host looked like a Brobdingnag among the Lilliputians.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- For two or three executive sessions recently the Post Office Committee, of which Mr. Chandler is Acting Chairman, has been criticised for holding up nominations. Mr. Chandler says that in all cases where the Senators from a State have been able to agree, and where there has been no injustice done, the nomination has been reported without undue delay.

In the Kokumin-No-Tomo, a monthly published at Tokio, Japan, Mr. Negishi Yoshitaro writes interestingly about "The Ceramic Art in Japan." Vaunting the beauty of Japanese porcelain, he writes, "Without fine china, tea would taste insipid. * * * Various kinds of soup, which characterize our gochiso, (entertainments,) would lose much of their savor were they not served in proper dishes."
Frederic Taylor, banker, financier and orator, died suddenly of heart disease at his home, 47 West Seventy-third Street, Thursday evening.

GUTHRIE, Oklahoma, Feb. 5. -- The battle reported to have taken place at the Sac and Fox Agency yesterday, in which four people were killed, is ascertained to-day to have occurred at Stroude, in the eatsern part of Lincoln County.

No thoughtful patriot can fail to be interested in the conflict that is going on in Massachusetts over the Bacchante of the Boston Public Library. If the sculptor and the donor had been actuated by malice, and determined to throw into the classic shades of the library something in the nature of a Pandora's box, for the confusion of the culture of Massachusetts, they could not have succeeded better.
-- Company B of the Seventy-first Regiment, National Guard, will attend the performance of "Secret Service" at the Garrick Theatre Monday night. The company will afterward dine at the Arena.

When in 1894 Mr. Sargent was made an Associate of the Royal Academy English critics thought he was somewhat of an impressionist. In France his portrait of Carolus Durand had made a strong impression, and then Mr. Sargent was about twenty-three years old. It was the purchases made on account of the Chantry trust in 1886 which made him a reputation in England.

Better a deferred charter than one impressed with so many seen and unseen possibilities of bedevilment. A wise traveler will wait a day or a year for a safe boat rather than trust himself to an inventor's freak that may send him skyward or to the bottom the first day out.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5. -- In the House to-day Mr. Johnson (Rep., Ind.,) presented the unanimous report of Elections Committee No. 2 upon the contest of Alexis Benoit vs. Charles J. Boatner, from the Fifth District of Louisiana, in favor of Mr. Boatner. Upon a contest for the seat subsequent to the election in 1894, the seat was declared vacant by the House, and a special election was held to fill the vacancy.

What a very great contrast between this lesson and that of last week! Then, a poor lame beggar, "and him as good as dead" (Heb. 11, 12), leaped with the joy of a strong; living 'man. Now, a strong, living man, so rich that he had a "possession'' to sell, is numbered with the dead. Then, the picture was one on which angels and men love to look.
HARDLY a month passes during the riding season in which a dozen or more clubs are not organized in the metropolitan district.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Scenes and songs from history, an entertainment illustrating the story of New Jersey from the time of its purchase from the Indians to the Revolutionary period, is to be given by the Memorial Hospital Auxiliary in Music Hall, Orange, on Thursday, Feb. 11, at 8:15 P.M. The Auxiliary is well known as having given most enjoyable entertainments, and it is believed that this will surpass all previous efforts.
The Westchester Racing Association has received a large number of entries for both the Spring and Fall meetings. In the Metropolitan Handicap twenty-nine horses have been named. They are:

Judge Pryor vacated yesterday the temporary injunction he had granted Friday against a recount by the Assembly Committee on Privileges and Elections in the contest in the Twenty-sixth District. The argument on a motion to show cause why a permanent injunction should not issue is to be heard by Judge Truax to-morrow.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Feb. 6. -- At last Alabama is to enter the steel manufacturing field in a strictly business way. There already are steel plants at Birmingham and Fort Payne, but they are small, and the fixed charges for expert labor, , have been such as to prevent commercial success in spite of the fact that good basic steel was the product.

MONDAY, Feb. 8. -- By Peter F. Meyer, foreclosure sale, William A. Duer, referee, 315 Delancey Street, south side, 50 feet west of Goerck Street, 25 by 75, five-story brick tenement, with stores. Due on judgment, $15,904.

CYCLE trade forecast for 1897? How easily asked for, how difficult to fill the commission, since the cycle trade itself, whose bread and butter and bank account depend on how well it hits off the situation, is even now lame and halting and indulging, not in any prophecy or in any well-supported policy, but is adrift in speculation and unadulterated guesswork.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 6. -- There was an exciting scene in the Union County Court here to-day when Judge McCormick sentenced Samuel Bahr, a farmer, to five months in jail for assault and battery. He was indicted with his nineteen-year-old daughter Edith, last September for attacking two farmers, whose places adjoined theirs, owing to a quarrel over some cows.
The Collegiate Alumnae Association of New York City and Brooklyn had a meeting yesterday afternoon at the College Settlement, 95 Rivington Street, at which the President, Mrs. J.A. Collier, presided.
"There is an urgent demand for school teachers in New York," said City Superintendent Jasper yesterday. "There are eighty vacancies at the present time, and the eligible list is exhausted.

WEDNESDAY, FEB. 10. -- By Peter F. Meyer, foreclosure sales, Charles Donohue, referee, northeast corner of Manhattan Avenue and One Hundred and Second Street, 23 by 95, five-story brick flat, with store. Due on judgment, $46,393. Also, 54 Manhattan Avenue, east side, 49 feet north of One Hundred and Second Street, 26 by 95, five-story brick flat. Due on judgment, $30,356.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 6. -- William Black, the negro who attempted to assault Mrs. Edward Clarke in Marion County, is still in the Louisville Jail. He will be taken back next week, and will be accompanied by a portion of the State militia, by order of Gov. Bradley.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill was reported to the Senate to-day by Mr. Hale, (Rep., Me.,) who stated that he would try to call it up on Monday.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 6. -- Senator Hoar sent a long letter, brimming with enthusiasm, on the subject of the arbitration treaty, to the Massachusetts Club dinner this afternoon. He termed the treaty "Good -- glorious."
THE possibiliities as to speed and practical uses are two subjects that are pleasant to contemplate, but difficult to solve.

A most successful event, yesterday afternoon, at the Waldorf Hotel, was the Colonial tea given under the auspices of the Misses Masters School Society, for the benefit of the Baby Fold. The big ballroom was arranged like a fair, with booths for the sale of various articles, including a wheel of fortune, said to be over a hundred years old.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- The retirement of Sir Julian Pauncefote from the Washington Embassy and from the diplomatic service will not take place until the Venezuelan arbitration reaches a more definite phase, and the last possible difficulties in the way of acceptance of the general arbitration treaty between Great Britain and the United States are over.

A crowd of over two hundred men and boys, most of them shouting with all their might, dashed down through Fulton Street from Broadway, and turned south into Nassau Street, after a supposed mad dog about 11 o'clock yesterday morning. The dog, a small Scotch terrier, was frothing at the mouth and showed signs of being rabid.

When Maria Barberi, at the end of her second trial, on Thursday evening, Dec. 10, 1896, was pronounced not guilty of murder, it was the common belief that the public interest which had been awakened by her extraordinary case would quickly subside, and that she would be allowed to pass into the obscurity which was natural and agreeable to her.

The fuller details of the Spanish scheme of reform in Cuba, transmitted on the occasion of the official promulgation of the decrees, do not essentially modify the project nor affect the comments upon it we have already made. The powers of the Council of Administration are substantially increased from those of any body now pretending to represent the island.

There is still considerable doubt as to the part this State will take in the ceremonies attending the inauguration of president McKinley. While Gen. Horace Porter nor his Chief of Staff, A. Noel Blakeman, are making no complaints as to the progress of their efforts to have New York creditably represented, it is well understood in military circles and among the politicians that there is a hitch somewhere.
BOSTON, Feb. 6. -- The annual indoor meeting of the Boston Athletic Association was held at Mechanics' Hall this evening, and 5,000 persons witnessed the competitions and exciting finishes.

Interviews with representative New Yorkers clearly demonstrate that there is a deep and earnest sentiment against the Municipal Assembly chapter of the proposed charter for Greater New York. Men prominent in the higher walks of life -- educational, professional, financial, and commercial -- unreservedly declared themselves opposed to the revival of any local deliberative body similar to the old Board of Aldermen.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 6. -- The movement of the people of Louisville to force better street-car service, with longer cars and provided with conductors, inaugurated on Monday, has assumed astonishing proportions. The saying, "Do not pay your fare; force the company to collect it," has become so general that much trouble is experienced.

The peculiar vagaries of this climate were responsible for another change of cast at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The work set down for the afternoon was Wagner's "Siegfried," and the advance engagement of seats was so large that Mr. Grau would have had to disappoint a great many persons had he been forced to substitute another for it.

TRENTON, Feb. 6. -- The goings and comings of Grover Cleveland and Garret A. Hobart furnish a theme for much gossip and speculation in New Jersey these days. Mr. Cleveland will take up his residence in the State at practically the same time Mr. Hobart goes to Washington.

In a recent lecture before the Jefferson Medical College Dr. Henry C. Chapman talked of the voice in speech and singing and told some interesting fundamental facts, among which were those touching the creation of sound and how it is received.

MOST people will agree that in no other branch of sport has there ever been a year when the championship has been so undecided as in cycle racing during 1896. At least three men have a good claim on the honors which go to the American champion. They are E.C. Bald of Buffalo, the champion of 1895; Thomas Cooper of Detroit, and Thomas Butler of Boston.

Until about a month ago Louis Troga conducted a little bank at 2,351 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, that was extensively patronized by the Italian colony of the Twenty-sixth Ward. One morning he hung up a sign, "This bank is closed," and left town, leaving his wife and family behind him. More than 500 depositors mourned their loss.
STRICTLY speaking, there are two parts to the social side of the annual Cycle Show in New York.

EL PASO, Texas, Feb. 6. -- Capt. Carr of the El Paso police early this morning captured John McDonald, alias Black Jack, on this side of the Rio Grande not far from the city. Black Jack is the notorious leader of the gang of border bandits who have been committing robberies and murders in south-western New Mexico and Southern Arizona for the past year.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6. -- Despite the fact that the elements were unpropitious, some remarkable records were made to-day at the meeting of the Amateur Skating Association of Canada. A light sleet, half snow and half rain, which commenced to fall during the morning, rendered the ice extremely heavy, and a very strong wind blew during the afternoon.

A little over four years ago there was formed in Chicago, in the Republican Party, a compact and powerful organization for the control of the party. It was formed strictly on a business basis. It had no reference to the triumph of Republican principles in National politics, save in so far as the success of the party in the State would contribute thereto.

TUESDAY, FEB. 9. -- By Peter F. Meyer, foreclosure sale, William S. Andrews, referee, 332 East One Hundred and Ninth Street, south side, 407 feet east of Second Avenue, 25 by 100, five-story brick tenement. Due on judgment, $14,461.

"Uses and Abuses of the Press" was the title of a lecture delivered by Rabbi Joseph Krauskopf, D.D., before the Reform Congregation Keneseth Israel in Philadelphia Jan. 24. This lecture made a pronounced impression and excited favorable comment for its originality, incisiveness, and common sense.

If the contents of half a dozen innocent-looking glass tubes in the Hoagland Laboratory, Brooklyn, were permitted to escape, the most virulent disease known to modern science would be liberated, and, according to even the most conservative authorities, a plague of frightful character would be inaugurated.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- "If every church member in this city who is guilty of the sin of Ananias were visited with Ananias's punishment there wouldn't be preachers enough in Chicago to conduct the funeral services."

We have recently had an opportunity to examine a batch of newspaper clippings giving accounts of accidents due to the falling of electric wires. These clippings cover the months from May to September, inclusive, but it is not to be supposed that we have found in them reports of all or nearly all the accidents of that character which have taken place.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- Prof. Henry Skinner, Curator of the Entomological Department of the Academy of Natural Sciences, in a lecture delivered here, gave some valuable suggestions regarding the collection of insects. The following points are taken from the lecture:

The promotion of FRANK THOMSON to the Presidency of the Pennsylvania Road is a fresh illustration of the methods by which that corporation has secured its access. In the matter of passenger service, more especially of accommodation to the "traveling public," the Pennsylvania has been so far in advance of all other American railroad lines that there has been no comparison.

A meeting was held at the New York Presbyterian-Hebrew Church Mission, at 128 Forsyth Street, yesterday afternoon to consider what steps should be taken to relieve the poor of the east side. A good many poor Jewish men and women were present. Most of them were tailors who were out of work on account of the dullness in trade.

The past week was a quiet one in the brokers' offices, if the information regarding sales negotiated can be relied on. Their transactions were numerous enough, more numerous, in fact, than during any previous week of 1897, but as they included only three in which good-sized considerations are involved, the aggregate investment was a trifle less than it has been during the recent six-day periods.

BICYCLISTS are liable to accidents in many ways, but with the exercise of common sense there is no reason why the number of casualties should go beyond the minimum, even in the midst of the touring season. In the first place it is essential that the rider have a wheel which has been properly tested -- one on which he or she may thoroughly rely.
Col. J.C. Reiff of Woerishoffer Co., taking a rather optimistic view of future prospects, writes as follows of stock market conditions:
THAT trite question, "Do you ride?" asked in England of healthy maid or matron would have been answered scarcely two years ago by "Oh, yes! There's nothing like an early run cross country.

GLASGOW, Jan. 27. -- The new steam yacht to be built for the Queen has given rise to wonderful dimensions and fanciful details. The yacht is to be a twin screw, with an over-all length of 400 feet and a beam of 52 feet. The Belleville boilers are to be large enough to drive the steamer at 23 knots, but for ordinary steaming 20 knots are to be guaranteed.

The Bradley Martin ball in New York promises to become historical. Mr. Bradley Martin is a wealthy man of business, whose daughter is Lady Craven, and he has issued 1,800 invitations to a fancy dress ball which is to surpass all ever done before in that line in the United States. The preparations for this entertainment coincide with great distress from want of work in many American cities.

The manoeuvres of the Atlantic squadron before Charleston, S.C., this week, in an imaginary blockade of and attack on that port, recall the famous blockades of 1861 to 1863 by the United States Navy. It was clearly demonstrated by the Confederate defense that the city could not, under conditions of war then prevailing, be either captured or blockaded by hostile fleets.

The return of Mr. and Mrs. Taber will be cordially welcomed, and it is not unlikely that their engagement will be prosperous. Julia Marlowe has steadfastly held to a high standard, throughout her stage career, in the new plays she has produced, as well as in the old ones she acts in.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- The South Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church is without a regular pastor on account of the departure of the Rev. Dr. Bolton, who left under peculiar circumstances. Bishop Merrill of the diocese, who understands the details of the trouble, said to-day:

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- A United Associated Presses reporter went to Letcombe Regis, in Berkshire, to-day to see Mr. Croker's horses, which are at Martin's training stables there. There are ten horses left of the string Mr. Croker started with, and of these, Mr. Martin says, there are only three from which he expects any results.

An explosion of gas wrecked the ferryboat Columbia, as she lay in the slip at the foot of Grand Street, yesterday morning, slightly injured three men and badly frightened a large crowd of intending passengers, who were in the ferry house. Nearly, all the windows in the ferryhouse and two in stores across the street, 30 feet away, were shattered by the shock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Since the House, by a rather close vote, passed the bill to restrict immigration, some speculation has been indulged in as to whether it will be worth while to agree to the bill about which the conferrees have had so much trouble. The report has been circulated that the President will refuse to sign the bill.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 6. -- Lakewood is having its full share of Winter pastimes. Another snowstorm has brought a return of sleighing, and the air has resounded with the jingle of bells this week. There was also skating on a long strip of cleared ice on Lake Carasaljo, opposite the Laurel- in-the-Pines.

THURSDAY, Feb. 11. -- By Peter F. Meyer, foreclosure sale, Edward E. McCall, referee, 30 West Ninety-seventh-Street, south side, 275 feet west of Eighth Avenue. 18 by 100.11, four-story and basement brick dwelling. Due on judgment, $14,817.

In the years of cycling that outline the remarkable progress of the greatest of the younger industries the best barometer of the trade has been the annual exhibition of wheels in the centres of population and wealth.

With lantern photograph illustrations, Prof. George M. Whicher, who lectured on "Athletics in Education" in the Art Building of the Brooklyn Institute Friday evening, placed the manly sports and pastimes of ancient Greece vividly before his auditors. The lecture was under the auspices of the classical section of the institute's Department of Philology.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- The reports of the 127 savings banks in New York State for the year ended Dec. 31 last, filed with the State Banking Department show aggregate resources of $812,173,632; as compared with $783,078,580 the previous year, an increase of $29,095,052. The aggregate surplus of these banks has increased from $90,955,321 to $93,653,237.

GENEVA, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- The electors of the village of Geneva have declared themselves by a large majority at a recent municipal election in favor of a city charter, and now are looking to the State Legislature for an act of incorporation by which the village shall take on the airs and powers of a city government.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 6. -- Philadelphia gets the League of American Wheelmen National meet of 1897. The counting of the ballots at the office of Secretary Bassett today at precisely 12 o'clock determined this fact. It was a clear walk-over for the Quaker City, and the heavy pen and pencil marks upon the ballots showed that the delegates were anxious that the meet should go to that city.
BICYCLING was at first considered a dangerous sport which only the boys and coolheaded young men could enjoy, nor did this opinion lack an element of truth so long as the old ordinary lived.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The publication of the fact that G.W. Murray, the colored Representative from the First District of South Carolina, intended to protest against the counting of the Electoral vote of that State at the joint meeting of Congress Wednesday next, engaged the interested attention of Mr. Murray's colleagues; all Democrats, to-day, and several informal conferences were held, at which Senator Tillman was present. After one of these, Mr. Tillman said:

The New York Cycle Show opened last night in the Grand Central Palace, Forty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, in a manner to inspire its promoters and managers with the rosiest prospects for its ultimate success.

HAVANA, Feb. 6. -- When Capt. Gen. Weyler reached the outskirts of the City of Santa Clara, where he has arrived, a delegation of prominent residents of the city went out to receive him, and presented him with an address. Gen. Weyler replied to the address, and, among other things, he said:

The publication yesterday of a letter sent to Commander Booth Tucker of the Salvation Army last September by the Committee on Vagrancy of the Conference of Charities, relating to free and cheap lodging houses, was a surprise to the Commander, because, he says, he answered it some weeks ago in a speech made in the United Charities Building and afterward printed in pamphlet form.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- The cruiser Brooklyn at flood tide to-morrow morning will leave the ice piers at Marcus Hook, where she has been moored since striking Schooner Ledge last Saturday, and come up the river to League Island in charge of Pilot George Chambers.

It is very unpleasant when you are traveling in the surface cars or elevated trains to call the attention of a person who may be sitting beside you or opposite you who is spitting to the fact that it is forbidden. I have frequently done it, and sometimes have been insulted and at other times they have apologized.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- For three or four weeks farmers who reside in the vicinity of West Hurley have been annoyed by losing every few nights a sheep, and sometimes two, from their folds. The farmers began to guard their flocks nightly, armed with shotguns. For several nights their vigilance was productive of no results, and to many of them it began to look as if the visitations of the thieves had ceased.

The Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution held its fifth annual banquet at Delmonico's last night, "in commemoration of the one hundred and nineteenth anniversary of the treaty alliance with France, and in recognition of the assistance rendered by the French nation to the cause of American independence."

Few stock brokers who have attracted attention as daring, brilliant, and successful operators have retired to private life after a long career on "the Street" and left such varying impressions of their character as Addison Cammack.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- Official and newspaper opinion in Germany regards the renewed strain between France and England with complete equanimity, and the declarations concerning Egypt made by Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, in the House of Commons, in London, yesterday, are attributed to that gentleman's knowledge that England has the support of Germany, Austria, and Italy in regard to her occupation of Egypt.

Next Saturday the battle royal for the chess supremacy between Great Britain and America will have been fought and won, Lincoln's Birthday, Feb. 12, has been chosen this year as the day on which the international chess tournament is to commence, at 10 A.M., and the games will be continued until finished on the next day.

The Legislative Committee to Investigate Trusts continued its work in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. The testimony given Friday afternoon by Mr. Arbuckle and by Mr. Jarvie, his partner, in reference to the coffee enterprise of the American Sugar Refining Company, furnished the committee with hints as to the probable existence of a coffee trust, which were followed up yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- THE NEW YORK TIMES printed Monday, with credit to The Cleveland Leader, a paragraph directing attention to what The Leader says is a common error in giving the date of Major McKinley's birth. In Lanman, which has been accepted, as an authority, it is stated as having occurred Feb. 26, 1844, but The Leader says that the correct date is Jan. 29, 1843.

In looking over some papers covered with the dust of several generations, recently, the writer discovered a copy of The Boston Evening Post, dated Monday, Dec. 5, 1743.* It is a single sheet, 9 by 15 inches, "printed and sold by Thomas Fleet, at the Heart and Crown, Cornhill, where advertisements are taken in."

Child beggary in this city has been reduced to a minimum, according to the statements made in the annual report of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, just issued. Officers of that society broke up what appeared to be an organized gang of vagrant boys a few months ago.

Last evening Dr. W.H. Birchmore delivered a lecture before the Chemical Section of the Brooklyn Institute on "The Spectra of Certain Metals." The apparatus used for projection was a spectroscope illuminated by means of an electric furnace.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 6. -- The House Judiciary Committee gave a public hearing in the Assembly Chamber this afternoon on the bill of Assemblyman Wildes of Burlington County, to reduce the salaries of the State officials. The bill proposes a slash of 50 per cent. in all salaries exceeding $2,500 per year. No one was present to advocate the bill except some Burlington County politicians and farmers.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The House to-day passed two private pension bills, to which objection was made yesterday because the engrossed bills were not at hand.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- If the ambitious plans of S.M. Rice are realized the American Spirits Manufacturing Company, of which he is President, will soon lock horns with the alcohol producers of Europe in an effort to control the alcohol markets of the world.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Despite inclement weather, a large crowd attended Mrs. Cleveland's public reception this afternoon, the last of the present Administration.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 6. -- The arrival of Congressman Francis H. Wilson of Brooklyn this afternoon renewed New York Cabinet gossip and set the guessers vigorously at work again. Mr. Wilson had an hour's talk with Major McKinley this evening and was invited to go to church with the President-elect in the morning.

A general inspection of the exhibits of the leading houses at the big cycle show in Grand Central Palace reveals the fact that the show is rich in novelties relating to minor details. The tendency has been to improve on old ideas, and it is obvious that much success has attended the efforts of the thinkers.

Inasmuch as an item appeared in certain papers concerning the sudden death of Thomas E. Le Count, which was not only inconsistent with the truth, but which also reflected on the moral character of Mr. Le Count, I venture to call your attention to the facts in the case.

Lena Benjamin, fifteen years old, died at her home, in Fordham, last Wednesday afternoon under circumstances which have led to the suspicion that she was the victim, indirectly, of the faith cure, or Christian science.

The Bulletin of the New York Public Library, Astor, Lenox, and Tilden Foundations, Vol. I., No. 1, is in some interesting respects the most important publication that has recently issued from the press in this city. Its contents, to be sure, have not the freshness of news nor the charm of fiction.
A report has been made to the stockholders of the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railway Company by President A.G. Blair. He says:
With the water only a few degrees above the freezing point, a boy undertook yesterday morning to swim the East River, between Capt. Miller's boathouse and Ward's Island.

Chapter 723 of the Laws of 1895, which is called the religious corporations law, and is now causing considerable discussion in view of its possible bearing on the Dev. Dr. Lyman Abbott's utterances concerning the inspiration of the Bible, was passed by the Legislature for the purpose of codifying previously existing laws on the subject.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Feb. 7. -- Mrs. David E. Whiting, wife of a Grand Trunk fireman, claims to be heiress to half an English estate of 1,000,000.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- A dispatch from Athens to the Central News says that the Greek Government has asked the Chamber to grant a credit of 100,000 drachmas to be devoted to the support of the Cretans who are fleeing to Greece, owing to the disturbances in Crete.

As a tribute of respect to Queen Victoria and in honor of the approaching sixtieth anniversary of her accession to the throne, the members of the Anglo-American Free Church of St. George the Martyr propose to place a handsome stained-glass window in the Church of St. John the Evangelist, in whose building, at Waverley Place and West Eleventh Street, the congregation worships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The President has signed, on the recommendation of Secretary of the Interior Francis, an important order reducing the number of pension agencies in the United States from eighteen to nine. The object of the order is to effect a very large saving to the Government without inconveniencing the pensioners.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The committee appointed to prepare new playing rules for the National League and American Association of professional ball clubs has completed its work. It recommends changes in many of the existing rules, but none that alter the game in any essential respect.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Eaton delivered a lecture last night on "Horace Greeley and the Responsibilities of the Press" at the Church of the Divine Paternity, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. It was the fourth in his series of Sunday evening addresses to young men on the lives of great New Yorkers.

BELMONT, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- The finding last week in the woods of Willing Township, in Allegany County, of the blanched bones of two human skeletons furnishes the closing chapter of a county mystery dating back many years.

The coating of black, pasty, greasy mud that has covered the pavements of New York and the boots and the clothing of the people during the past week is an affliction we owe to our devotion to the paving stone, a thing that is obsolete in really civilized cities, but to which we still cling, though we know asphalt to be vastly better.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Col. Julius A. Palmer, the private secretary of ex-Queen Liliuokalani, in a communication to The Washington Times, in which he extols in the highest manner the deposed ruler, refers to the question of the annexation of Hawaii to this country.

MADRID, Feb. 7. -- There is much dissatisfaction expressed here over what are believed to be the excessive concessions made to the Cubans in the scheme of reforms, and it is thought that Cabinet changes are likely to result.

Some interesting developments may come into the stock market this week. A number of conspicuous corporations are expected to issue their annual reports. Interest will also, to some extent, fasted on what develops, or may promise to develop, in Senator Lexow's trust investigation.
I recently returned from the Monetary Conference at Indianapolis, and have presumed that some of the points relating thereto, which I note herein, would be of interest to you.

John Burke, famous for many years past as the "Mayor of the Bowery," was buried yesterday afternoon from the home of his sister, Mrs. A.L. Mead, 169 East Eighty-third Street, and his body lies in Calvary Cemetery.
ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Richard S. Emmet, Jr., Assemblyman from the Second District of Westchester, died in this city this afternoon at 228 State Street after an illness of four weeks with typhoid fever.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 7. -- Major McKinley attended church this morning. He was accompanied by Representative Wilson of Brooklyn and Assistant Secretary Pruden of the White House. The preacher was the Rev. William McAfee of Columbus, who was Major McKinley's pastor when he was Governor of Ohio.

We advise the Republican Congressmen who are devising schemes to "beat" the merit system and the reform law to consult a modest gentleman in Canton, Ohio, who in a few weeks will be President of the United States. He is curiously qualified to give them advice, and, what is very much more to the point, he can make them follow it.

Prof. Charles A. Briggs, D.D., of the Union Theological Seminary, preached yesterday morning in the Manhattan Congregational Church, corner of Eighty-third Street and the Boulevard. It was a farewell sermon, as the doctor has had no rest since his famous trial for heresy, and sails on Saturday for Europe, on a vacation until January, 1898. The church was crowded.
President H.H. Vreeland of the Metropolitan Traction Company gave out the following statement yesterday:
At the Moody meeting in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon there was an apparent falling off in the male attendance, and this was especially noticeable in the box seats.

PUTNAM, Conn., Feb. 7. -- The cable dispatches telling of the proposal of the French Government to offer premiums for large families, hoping by this inducement to restore the native population to its size of a quarter century ago, merely broach, as something novel, a system which has, for reasons not of statecraft, but merely personal, long been in operation in Eastern Connecticut.

Charles W. Brooke, the well-known criminal lawyer, died at the S.R. Smith Infirmary, Staten Island, about midnight Saturday, aged sixty, of septic perforative peritonitis induced by intestinal cancer. His son, Charles Lex Brooke of this city, was with him. His other son, Alexander, was summoned from Philadelphia, but arrived after his father's death.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- The Lexow investigation of the Sugar Trust in New York, does not seem to appeal much to the coffee and sugar merchants of Chicago. W.F. McLaughlin said:

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- The proceedings in the State Legislature this week will be purely of a routine character unless something unforeseen comes up. The committee work in each house will occupy nearly all of the time.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7. -- Burglars entered the Irvington Post Office this morning and blew open the safe. They obtained $16 in cash and $2,000 in postage stamps. After robbing the Post Office, they carried the proceeds to George Raymond's produce store, on the opposite side of the street, and there apparently divided it, as they left some papers taken from the safe on the table there.
CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Mme. Nordica is billed to sing at a concert in the Auditorium to-morrow night, but, owing to the rivalries of two piano firms, she may not open her musical mouth.

The country has learned much about finance within the last half dozen years. It was not so easy in 1891 to have views that now seem clearly right as to the operation of the mischievous elements in our currency which had then been all injected into it, but had not shown their real effect.

The third fire since last Tuesday was discovered in the five-story tenement house at 241 East Ninety-third Street yesterday morning, and the general belief is that this last fire, if not the other two, was undoubtedly of incendiary origin.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- The peculiar ailment of the Czar has been no secret at the German Courts for some years. Since he was a lad emerging from boyhood it has been known that he was subject to occasional fits. They were rare, however, and were supposed, after the closest medical diagnosis, to be likely to disappear as his physique strengthened.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Austin Lathrop, Superintendent of State Prisons, will submit his annual report to the Legislature tomorrow. Much space is given to the employment problem, the Superintendent taking the ground that the State, is bound to find employment for its convicts, and that to condemn them to idleness is a cruel and unusual punishment.

While there is a diversity of opinion among the prominent citizens of Brooklyn regarding the proposed Municipal Assembly feature of the Greater New York charter, many expressions of opinion contain some criticism of the plan as proposed by the commission.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- The 17th of this month will be the one hundredth anniversary of the establishment of the Controller's office. The bill creating it was signed on the 17th of February, 1797, by John Jay, then Governor.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- The Parschall bill, permitting canal companies engaged in inter-State commerce to have a capital of over $50,000, and limiting the same to $4,000,000, will have hearings Tuesday before the Senate and Assembly Canal Committees at 2 and 3 P.M., respectively.

Miss Lillian Russell had a novel experience yesterday, and the prisoners in the Tombs were given an unusual treat. The operatic star sang in the beginning of the usual Sunday services in the women's department, the men's department in the old prison, and the boys' department. Warden Van De Carr, acting with the approval of the Prison Guild and of Chaplain William Lindsay, extended the invitation.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 7. -- New Orleans, not content with trying to relegate New York to a secondary place as a grain-shipping port, is now reaching out for the packing-house business, with the prospect of also securing that. Yesterday there was an instance of the drift of trade in this direction.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- The recommendations of Gov. Black for economy in the State's expenditures have not impressed the legislators. Bills calling for cash are more numerous than they ever before have been, and the amounts asked are liberal.
In a letter printed in THE TIMES on Jan. 25 over the signature of "Davis," the closing paragraph says -- speaking of the so-called "restoration" of the west front of Peterborough Cathedral:

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- There is the very best authority for the statement that the draft of the reform protocol as completed by the Ambassadors at their conferences, in Constantinople, is drawn upon the assumption that the Sultan will accept the proposals, but there is no reference therein, either directly or indirectly, to any possibility of a resort to coercion on the part of the powers to enforce them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- President Cleveland's personal physician, Dr. R.M. O'Reilly of the regular army, sailed for Europe last week in response to a sudden cablegram. The dispatch was received on Wednesday morning of last week, and by nightfall Dr. O'Reilly had been given not only three months' leave of absence, but permission to go beyond the seas.

In your issue, of Jan. 30 an account is given of an assemblage of prominent physicians, well-known scientists, professional and public men, clergymen, and representatives of the highest social circles, men and women. To this assembly the President of the United States eulogized the medical profession. One of our most eminent Bishops "offered a prayer for the progress of medical science and for the increase of all aids to humanity."

Twenty-three years ago the writer, as one of the founders of the Cincinnati Zoological Garden, became impressed with the fact that such exhibitions could attain their greatest possible utility and attractiveness only by the adoption of ample exercising grounds that should, as nearly as practicable, simulate the creatures' native haunts.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- The Lake Dredgers' Association, asserted to be a gigantic pool, was organized in this city yesterday by 123 owners of dredges on the great lakes, representing a capital of $5,000,000. The meeting was held at the Builders' Exchange.

Almet F. Jenks, who was Corporation Counsel under Mayors Chapin and Boody, in Brooklyn, and who is now a member of the law firm of Grout, Jenks Mayer, caused the arrest in Brooklyn last night of Edward J. Russell, thirty-eight years old, whose address was given as 10 West Sixty-fourth Street, this city.

According to Col. WARING, Brooklyn needs no increase in her water supply. Instead of getting frightened and frantically casting about for more water from remote sources, she ought to take measures to prevent the waste of her present supply. With proper safeguards it will be ample for the needs of her people until she has double her present population.
The following sales are down for to-day at 111 Broadway:

The eighth annual entertainment of the Theatrical Treasurers' Club, at the Broadway Theatre, last evening, drew a very large audience. The programme had to be cut short, as so many had offered their services that there was not time to give all numbers. The performance was very interesting.
People who are worrying over Mr. Russell Sage's health are not keeping up to date.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- Prince Bismarck's presence at the Kaiser Wilhelm commemoration fetes is not now expected. Many old associates who desire to see him the prominent figure at the Berlin celebration, and who have urged and entreated him to be present, get the same reply, that his health is variable, and that his undertaking the journey, with its attendant excitements, depends on the advice of Drs. Schweninger and Chrysander.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The President to-day transmitted to Congress a communication from the Secretary of State and accompanying reports from United States diplomatic and Consular officers on the passports regulations for foreign countries, and, in view of their value, especially to American citizens going abroad and sojourning and traveling in foreign lands, he recommends that Congress authorize the printing of 3,000 copies for distribution by the State Department.

" We protect the interests of the consumers, not because it is philanthropy, but because it is good business," said John E. Searles, Secretary and Treasurer of the American Sugar Refining Company, in his testimony yesterday before the Legislative Committee to Investigate Trusts.

The official announcement that the underground trolley is to be used on Fourth, Madison, Sixth, Eighth, and Amsterdam Avenues and on Fifty-ninth Street points to a great amelioration of the conditions of intramural transit. The horse as a means of locomotion will be retained only provisionally and on unimportant feeders of the system.
The Rev. Dr. Parkhurst delivered last evening the closing lecture of a series of five on "Practical Religion," in the Union Theological Seminary.

The first lecture of the series to be given in this city on "The Deepening of Spiritual Life," by the Rev. F.B. Meyer of London, brought to Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon an audience in which a large number of clerical gentlemen was a noticeable feature. Evangelist D.L. Moody was on hand early.
Mr. William Rosenzweig has sold for the estate of Charles Guidst to Lowenfeld and Prager, the plot on the northwest corner of Second Avenue and Ninety-fifth Street, 100 by 100.

Almost everybody recognizes the public utility of the legislation whereby military tactics are made a branch of study in institutions of learning, and whereby a supernumerary officer of the army is detailed to give tactical instruction. It is commonly supposed that this detail is a sinecure, what is technically known as a "soft thing."
LONDON, Feb. 8. -- A dispatch from Athens to the Exchange Telegraph Company says that rumors are in circulation there that the warships of the powers are bombarding the town of Canea, Crete.
The opening game of the third annual inter-city inter-club amateur billiard tourney was played last evening at Maurice Daly's parlors, Broadway and Thirty-first Street.

The law of this State relating to corporations engaged in transportation was revised in 1890. The part relating to corporations engaged in navigation limited their capital to $4,000,000. Last year an amendment was put upon this declaring that no corporation "designed to navigate any of the canals of the State shall have a capital stock exceeding $50,000."
ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Superintendent of Prisons Lathrop is receiving requisitions for prison-made supplies from all quarters of the State.

The Spanish Minister at Washington has made public an explanation of the Spanish decrees in regard to Cuba which has at least one point worth notice. It has been assumed that the suffrage by which the elective members of the pro posed Council of Administration were to be chosen was to be the same as that by which the Cuban delegates to the Cortes were elected.
Prof. George Gunton delivered a lecture before the Republican Club, at the headquarters, 17 West Twenty-fourth Street, last evening upon "The Economic Reasons for Bryan's Great Vote in New York."

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Senator Brackett of Saratoga County has been disposed to oppose the confirmation of Frank M. Baker, who was nominated as one of the Railroad Commissioners last week. Mr. Baker is a strong Platt man and had been associated with the latter as an officer in one or more railroads. He lives in Mr. Platt's home town, Owego.

The death of Lena Benjamin, which occurred at her home, in Fordham, last Wednesday, was the subject of an investigation yesterday by Coroner Hoeber. He examined Mrs. Addie M. Stevens, who visited the girl twice during her illness; A.B. Stevens, her husband, and Undertaker George W. Howie, who attended to the funeral arrangements.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Mr. Daniel, (Dem., Va.,) from the Judiciary Committee, to-day reported back to the Senate the House bill to constitute a new division of the Eastern Judicial District of Texas, with court to be held at Beaumont, with a recommendation that it be passed, the objections of the President to the contrary notwithstanding.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Judge Grosscup this morning made a decision which puts a stopper on several million-dollar suits, and which was a great surprise to the Chicago Sugar Refining Company, controller of the Arno-Behr device for refining sugar.

HAVANA, Feb. 8. -- The evening dally papers, the Lucha and Diario de la Marina, are the first to publish comments upon the new scheme of reforms for Cuba, the publication of which was only allowed here yesterday. Both papers simply analyze the extent and scope of the reforms, without attaching undue importance to them or employing the bombastic phrases which are generally used in recording or commenting upon any unusual event.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The House Committee on Pacific Railroad to-day heard Stuyvesant Fish, President of the Illinois Central Railroad, and F.S. Bond, Vice prevalent of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, on matters regarding the Pacific Railroads.

A spirited, tasteful, and effective representation of "Romeo and Juliet" was given at Wallack's Theatre last night, and was watched with delight by a crowd of spectators. Julia Marlowe's portrayal of Juliet, last seen here on the same stage something less than a year ago, has the semblance of youth, innocence, impulsiveness, and sincerity.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Philadelphia and Erie Railroad Company was held to-day in the general offices of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. The election for managers resulted as follows: N. Parker Shortridge, John P. Green, Samuel Gustine Thompson, J. Bayard Henry, William L. Elkins, William J. Howard, Amos R. Little, W.K. Barnes, John H. Catherwood, and George Wood.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 8. -- Don M. Dickinson, chief counsel for the United States in the pending international inquiry into the extent of damages due to British sealing vessels captured by United States cutters in Bering Sea, arrived here last night from Victoria, British Columbia. He was in a train wreck yesterday in Oregon, but escaped injury, as did all the other passengers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- On one condition alone ex-Gov. Altgeld will enter the Spring campaign. That condition will be furnished by an attempt to nominate Judge Payne or some other gold Democrat. Rather than see a gold man nominated for Mayor, Altgeld says he will roll up both sleeves and wade into the fight for all there is in it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Considering the number of important judicial nominations pending before it, the Senate Committee on the Judiciary is making very little headway in clearing up its executive calendar. For more than an hour this morning Senator Hansbrough of North Dakota was heard in opposition to the confirmation of Charles F. Amidon, nominated some weeks ago to be District Judge for the District of North Dakota.

There is to be a novelty at Mrs. Bradley Martin's ball in the shape of a dance that nowadays is better known to readers of Court history and of poetry than it is to dancers. Several of the invited guests are rehearsing the "stately saraband."

CHARLESTON, Feb. 8. -- Admiral Bunce's voyage from Hampton Roads to Charleston bar, with the flagship New York, the battleship Maine, the cruiser Columbia, the monitor Amphitrite, and the cruiser Marblehead, has cost the lives of four men, injuries to several others, and damages to the ships to an amount not yet known.

The report of the expert engineers, appointed last October to decide upon the feasibility of running surface and elevated cars across the Brooklyn Bridge, was submitted to the Trustees yesterday morning at their meeting, in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- There will be no objection to the counting of the electoral vote of South Carolina at the joint convention of Congress on Wednesday. Mr. Murray, the colored representative from that State, who originated the proposition, and who prepared the memorial upon which the objection was to be based, to-day said that he would not make the proposed objection.

The Presbytery of New York maintained yesterday, with some emphasis, the position previously taken with reference to the Rev. Hermann Warszawiak. There was a heated debate on the subject, and the test vote came on the adoption of a report made by the Committee on Protests.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- It was expected that the Governor's nominations of the three Railroad Commissioners would be favorably reported to the Senate to-night, and that a debate would be precipitated because of the Democratic opposition to the confirmation of Frank M. Baker. But Senator Raines, Chairman of the Railroad Committee, announced before the session that the committee would not report to-night.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 8. -- Many rich Bostonians will attend the Bradley Martin ball in hired costumes. Invitations have been most plentifully showered on modern Athenians. Dozens of them are floating around on the upper crust of society, and not a few have found their way to people who are not especially well known from a social or any other point of view.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8. -- As a result of the conference between Manager Wheelwright of the Yale Navy and prominent New York Yale alumni, the Yale's final offer to Harvard for a reunion in athletics is ready, and will be sent to Cambridge this week. It is expected that there will be no trouble in ratifying it by the Harvard management.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- By the decisive vote of 49 to 9 the Senate this afternoon, after a discussion of almost two hours, voted not to consider the general treaty of arbitration between the United States and Great Britain with open doors. Secrecy will be maintained, and the traditions of the Senate will be perpetuated.

The sites for two small parks on the east side of the city were selected last Spring. Proceedings for the condemnation of the property, pursuant to law, are pending. In the case of the Eleventh Ward Park, at Houston and Pitt Streets, the Commissioners are taking testimony as to title of the parcels of land. On Friday last the initiatory legal steps were taken in the matter of the Tenth Ward Park.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The Senate Committee on Inter-State Commerce took the Anti-Scalping bill up this morning, and, after an informal discussion, agreed that it would be impossible to pass the bill at this session, and that any report that might be made would be useless. The House has refused to give the bill a day for consideration.

LONDON, Feb. 8. -- The Royal Geographical Society held a reception to-night in Albert Hall in honor of Dr. Fridjof Nansen, the distinguished arctic explorer. Sir Clements Markham, the President of the society, presided, with the Prince of Wales sitting at his right hand and the Duke of York at his left.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- A competitive State civil service examination for promotion of Supreme Court attendants in Kings County to the position of Court Clerk will be held in Brooklyn, Feb. 20. The competition will be limited to those whose names appear on the official roster as attendants in such court.

There is no estimating the value of the rare old jewels to be worn at the Bradley Martin ball. All the jewelers who deal in antiques say they have been cleaned out of all they had on hand, and people still keep calling for old buckles, snuff boxes, lorgnettes, diamond or pearl studded girdles, rings, and, in fact, every conceivable decoration in gems.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 8. -- The Homestead Steel Works, Edgar Thomson Blast Furnace and Steel Works, and Duquesne Steel Works resumed in full in all departments last evening. The Westinghouse Electric Works resumed in full to-day on double time. It had been operating on half time.
The losses and business depression from which the people have suffered during the past three years have cost the Democratic Party votes and victories. The "ins" are always punished for bad times.

If any one in all this big city doubts the popularity of the bicycle, he should visit the Grand Central Palace any day this week and be convinced. Between eleven and twelve thousand people braved the driving rainstorm on Saturday evening to see the opening of the bicycle show, and yesterday there was a continual stream of people passing through the gates.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Shortly after the Assembly convened Mr. Husted of Westchester, after a tribute to the late Assemblyman Emmett, offered these resolutions of respect, which were adopted by a rising vote:

" Once more in the clutches of my old enemy the grip," you say some morning when you wake up coughing and sneezing. Your eyes are watery, your head feels as if some force inside of it were bent on splitting it as a charge of gunpowder splits a rock. Every muscle is stiff and sore. Your very bones ache.

CANTON, Ohio, Feb. 8. -- It is settled that ex-Gov. John D. Long of Massachusetts will be Major McKinley's Secretary of the Navy. A letter came to Canton to-night from Mr. Long, in which he announced that he would accept the naval portfolio.

The third and last of the Junior Assemblies took place at Sherry's last night. The guests arrived about 10 o'clock, and were received by Mrs. Alexander, Mrs. Frederick Edey, and Mrs. R.H. Hoadley. The dancing was in the large white ballroom, which was decorated with palms, smilax, and American Beauty roses.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9. -- The cruiser Brooklyn, which struck on Schooner Ledge in the Delaware River, below Chester, Penn., on the 30th ult., while proceeding to Marcus Hook to secure a safe anchorage from the ice, badly damaging her bottom, was successfully docked at the League Island Navy Yard this morning.

So well disciplined and so accustomed to drill at any and all hours are the 600 House of Refuge boys on Randall's Island that they get up on call at any hour of the night and quickly obey all orders given.
" It will force the Senate to yield up its Constitutional function as a part of the treaty-making power," said Senator MORGAN in his argument against the arbitration treaty.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- A resolution was reported to the Senate to-day from the Committee on Contingent Expenses, and was agreed to, instructing the Judiciary Committee to proceed with the investigation in the matter of Charles M. Amidon, nominated to be District Judge for the District of North Dakota.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 4. -- Details of the fresh trouble between the French colonists, at Cayenne, and the Brazilians, in the trans-Amazonian Provinces of Brazil, which may lead to further diplomatic trouble before the arbitration agreement is reached have been received here.

A suit which will come up in the Supreme Court in a few days will excite considerable interest among the residents of Harlem. Efforts have been made to settle the case out of court, but without avail.

-- After admitting that Boston has been strangely derelict in the matter of honoring with statues the many literary men of more or less importance who once resided there and for a while gave the city an excuse for calling itself the Athens of America, The Boston Journal says: "We are not quite sure that Boston must take second place to New York in the list of communities which have honored their noted sons."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- For at least half of the four and a half hours the Senate was in secret session to-day the press reports of yesterday's session were the subject of discussion. Senators were indignant that after they had voted so overwhelmingly that the doors should be closed, the facts as they occurred in the chamber should be permitted to reach the public.

A correspondent whose letter we print elsewhere this morning entirely mistakes the position we have taken regarding the "too great power" to be given to the Municipal Assembly in the new charter. We have made no objection to the extent of the power to be vested in that body, but only to the manner of constituting it, which would be sure to produce a membership unfit to exercise such power.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Open competitive State civil service examinations will soon be held for the following positions in the State prisons:

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The Canal Committees of both houses gave a joint hearing this afternoon on the Parshall-Wiman bill permitting canal navigation companies to incorporate with a capital stock of $4,000,000, which was discussed at length before the Assembly Committee last week.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The majority of the leaders of the L.A.W. and also the majority of the delegates to the assembly, are here now. The latest comer was E.W. Connolly of Illinois.

In the great public debate now in progress over the new charter you take the position that too great power has been given the proposed Municipal Assembly by the Charter Commission, and advocate a continuance of the efforts which during the past thirty years have been steadily curtailing the powers of our State and city legislatures.

ROME, Feb. 9. -- It is announced that Mr. W.S. Jones, United States Consul General here, will represent the United States at the international conference which is to be held at Venice to consider means of preventing the spread to Europe and America of the bubonic plague now raging in India.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The New York State Homeopathic Medical Society is holding its forty-sixth annual session in this city, President Edwin H. Wolcott presiding.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The State Board of Land Commissioners seriously objects to that part of the Greater New York bill which proposes to take jurisdiction of the lands under water from the State and give it to the Dock Board of the greater city.

" You don't have mice here, do you?" asked a man, going into a large greenhouse the other day, and discovering mouse traps every here and there. "Yes, indeed, we do," answered the proprietor. "We were overrun with them last month. We had a great many carnations in bud, and the mice nipped off the buds and took them away with them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- In the House to-day Mr. Danford (Rep., Ohio,) called up the second agreement of the conferrees upon the Immigration bill, which was presented yesterday, and, after the reading of the statement by the conferrees, he demanded the previous question. This was seconded -- 94 to 12.

WATERTOWN, Mass., Feb. 9. -- Last night, for the first time since the close of the civil war, work in the United States Arsenal ran on at night. It was the beginning of a plan to operate all the large machines sixteen hours a day. Last night but a few men worked, but the number will be steadily increased until the complement of the night gang has been reached.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- The Assembly Cities Committee to-day gave a hearing on Mr. Austin's bill, which authorizes the repaving of streets in New York City whenever the Board of Estimate and Apportionment shall deem it necessary. John Proctor Clark of the Corporation Counsel's office submitted a letter from Commissioner of Public Works Collis on the subject.
Mr. Frederick Zittel has sold for George C. Edgar's Sons Co. the four-story modern dwelling 18 West Eighty-eighth Street, 20 by 60 by 100.8.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- In the Assembly to-day the following bills were passed:
About all of the "patronage" in the Federal civil service has been abolished, with the exception of the fourth-class Post Offices. These are still filled at the discretion of the Postmaster General.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 9. -- This morning a gig came ashore from the United States cruiser Marblehead, which is lying a few hundred feet off the Southern wharf. The gig was in charge of Passed Assistant Surgeon A.R. Wentworth of the cruiser, and it carried the six seamen who were injured on the ship during her passage down the coast as one of the vessels of Admiral Bunce's squadron.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9. -- The entire receipts at the track to-day -- $1,200 -- went to the drought sufferers in North Louisiana. Five favorites won.

Apropos of the prevailing agitation of the trust question and of the present legislative inquiry into the methods and affairs of several corporations well known to Wall Street, Mr. John H. Davis of the Stock Exchange made yesterday some observations in speaking to a representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Mr. Davis said:

JABALPUR, India, Feb. 9. -- An examination of Central India shows that the famine is prevailing in an area larger than has been affected in a century, and it is likely that the mortality resulting from the scarcity of food and attendant diseases will exceed that of any previous famine within a hundred years.
